title: Pop/Jazz; Conjuring Up The Founder, Jimi Hendrix
description: It's impossible to listen to rock-and-roll today without hearing the ghost of the guitarist Jimi Hendrix. Using the grammar of blues and rhythm-and-blues, Hendrix wrote the rules of modern rock. His improvisations, coarse and nasty or smoothly passionate, glorifed the noise and textures of the electric guitar, in the process elevating the instrument to its premier position in pop music. Working with the most basic of rock instrumentation, the trio, he took harmonic and textural liberties that have defined self-confident, risky excess to this day. On a cultural level, he translated a black performance esthetic into one for white youths. And he wrote hits, the sort that probably wouldn't have made it to the radio today; Hendrix was both a product of and definer of the 1960's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Shelly Hirsch has been named executive vice president of programming and distribution at Bohbot Communications.

title: A Move to Foil Counterfeiting
description: Canada's central bank will introduce a $50 bill Friday affixed with a color-changing film that officials say is the most sophisticated measure to foil counterfeiters.

title: Broadway Is Trying to Unite To Fight High Price of Drama
description: Producers, theater owners and unions are discussing a plan to cut costs and prices so that some serious plays would have a better chance to succeed on Broadway.

title: For the Record
description: Texas Lawyer's Creed

title: Mate Who Piloted The Exxon Valdez Won't Be Charged
description: The State of Alaska has decided not to prosecute Gregory T. Cousins, who was at the helm of the tanker Exxon Valdez when she ran aground in Prince William Sound last March, causing the nation's worst oil spill.

title: In Which Boston Brahmin Law Firms Slug it Out. Genteelly, Of Course.
description: After seven years of litigation, there is still some dispute over whether toxic solvents dumped at a tannery in Woburn, Mass., found their way into the municipal water supply and caused six deaths from leukemia. But there is no denying that bad karma from the case has seeped even further than the chemicals, crossing the Charles River and into Boston's blue-blooded bar.

title: Sale by Media General
description: Freedom Newspapers Inc. of Irvine, Calif., has agreed to buy 30 weekly newspapers in Southern California from Media General Inc., Media General said this week. No terms were disclosed. The 30 papers have a circulation of 470,000 and are published in Orange County and eastern Los Angeles County by Golden West Publishing Inc., a Media General unit.

title: Texas Meridian Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,706,000, or 15 cents a share, from a gain on debt restructuring. Dividend payments exceeded net income for the latest quarter; loss per unit was less than 1 cent a share.

title: 2 Killed and 450 Wounded During Strike in Bangladesh
description: Two people were killed and 450 wounded in violence during a nationwide general strike, the police said today.

title: South African Detective Is Held in 2 Killings
description: The South African police disclosed today that they are holding a former narcotics detective in connection with the killings this year of two whites who were prominent in the struggle against apartheid.

title: Suit Is Filed By Ferranti
description: The British military electronics company Ferranti, which has said it was victimized by fraud in its United States operations, said today that it had filed a lawsuit seeking nearly $400 million from former employees and associated companies.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Activated Tim McCormick, center, from the injured list. Placed Adrian Caldwell, center-forward, on the injured list.

title: No 3-Beatle Reunion, George Harrison Says
description: Paul McCartney's suggestion that the three surviving Beatles reunite is not for George Harrison.

title: General Mills, Nestle Plan Europe Push
description: If General Mills gets its way, the continental breakfast will soon include a bowl of Cheerios.

title: Ford Plans to Shut V-8 Engine Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company told 900 employees at its Windsor, Ontario, engine plant that it will close the factory late next year. The plant was shuttered in 1981 during the auto industry's deep recession but reopened in 1983 when demand for the larger engines grew.

title: Catholicism With a Human Face
description: It is fitting that, on the way to his shipboard summit meeting with George Bush, Mikhail Gorbachev is stopping today at Vatican City for an audience with the Pope. More than any American President or Western leader, John Paul II has played a crucial role in the historic liberalization of the Communist world.

title: ARAB NATIONS PUSH P.L.O. PEACE ROLE
description: In advance of this weekend's superpower summit meeting off the Mediterranean island of Malta, Arab foreign ministers today petitioned President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to give priority to the Middle East conflict and to acknowledge the Palestine Liberation Organization as a participant in the diplomacy of peace.

title: Giants to Open Stadium Talks
description: The San Francisco Giants will open negotiations with Santa Clara County in about two weeks on a potential new home for the National League champions 40 miles south of here, the team's owner, Bob Lurie, said today.

title: Chevron Stock Is Most Active
description: Stock of the Chevron Corporation, which has been pushed up in recent days on speculation that it is a takeover candidate, was the most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Almost 3.4 million shares changed hands, including a one-million-share block. The San Francisco-based oil company closed at $68.625, up 25 cents. ''The rumor is that it's

title: Chargers' Season Marked By Lost Close Encounters
description: When Coach Dan Henning of San Diego is asked what has been the difference between a winning and a losing record for the Chargers this season, his answer is terse: ''24 points.''

title: When Builders Must Sell Some Lots
description: LEAD: The large amount of capital needed to carry a subdivision until houses are built and sold is forcing many developers to forgo some profits by selling off lots to other builders or to individuals wishing to build their own houses.

title: Farm Prices Rose by 1.4% Last Month
description: The prices farmers received for raw products rose by 1.4 percent in November over the previous month, primarily because of higher prices for strawberries, milk, eggs and celery, the Agriculture Department said today.

Heart Risk Persists After Cocaine Use, Study Says
description: An increased risk of heart attack from taking cocaine can persist for at least two weeks after the start of a withdrawal program, a new study shows.

title: Czechs Fault Policies of Hard-line Communists as Cause of Industrial Lag
description: Frantisek Kucera, the general manager of the century-old Tos Hostivar Machinery Company, is one of those who lost out in the bargain that the hard-line Communist Government made to keep itself in power - cutting back on crucial investments to keep workers docile by providing them oranges, automobiles and homes.

title: Books of The Times; God and Man Together in the Shtetl
description: A Treasury of Yiddish Stories Edited by Irving Howe and Eliezer Greenberg With drawings by Ben Shahn. 676 pages. Viking. $29.95.

title: Japanese Developer Buys Picasso at Record Price
description: A Japanese real-estate developer paid $51.3 million yesterday for Pablo Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding'' and said he planned to hang it at an auto racing resort he is building on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu.

title: Houston Seen As Summit Site
description: President Bush has selected Houston as the site of the economic summit meeting in July for the seven leading industrial countries, White House officials said today.

description: Debt

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Some Walls, Like Mine, Don't Fall
description: LEAD: Like most of us, I sat glued to the TV this month, fixating on the people of East Berlin and West Berlin as they danced atop that famous concrete slab. My eyes focused, particularly, on the people my age - the Germans in their 20's. I watched them kiss and drink and dance. And I envied them. In fact, I'd enjoy visiting them.

description: Clarity and Sinew

title: Americans Freed After Salvador Siege
description: An American diplomat held at gunpoint in his home for more than 14 hours by leftist guerrillas was freed at dawn today when the rebels withdrew under a temporary cease-fire.

title: Rohatyn Urges Dinkins to Hold Spending Line
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has warned that Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins should plan to hold spending in next year's New York City budget to the level of this year's revenues, in a drastic no-growth approach.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 470 money market mutual funds decreased by $660.30 million, to $367.57 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 145 institutional funds decreased by $325.10 million, to $89.30 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were down by $291 million, to $119.21 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased by $44.2 million, to $159.07 billion, the institute said.

title: Shell Agrees to Pay $19.75 Million for '88 Spill Off San Francisco
description: The Shell Oil Company has agreed to pay $19.75 million for spilling more than 400,000 gallons of crude oil into San Francisco Bay last year.

title: C.I.A. Defector to Soviets Is Permanently Expelled From Hungary
description: Edward Lee Howard, the former Central Intelligence Agency agent who was said to have passed important secrets to Moscow before defecting to the Soviet Union, has been permanently expelled from Hungary, Administration officials say.

title: Penance for Felling 67 Old Maples: 100 New Trees
description: Admitting that ''we fouled up,'' New York City's Transportation Commissioner, Ross Sandler, said yesterday that his department would plant 100 new trees along Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx to replace 67 Norwegian maples that were cut down this week after department workers had inadvertently chopped off the roots.

title: Disco-Dining the Night Away
description: THE New York club scene is constantly evolving. In the 1980's, it moved from a style that had been huge and high tech to one that was diminutive and old fashioned. But with no one quite sure what sort of tastes and manners the 1990's will bring, a burst of new nightspots - fulfilling every mood and whim - has made today a clubgoers' market.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cox Landey Names 2
description: Cox Landey & Partners has named David Mandelbaum as a management partner and Jay Wolf a creative partner. Both men came from Mandelbaum, Wolf & Wiskowski, the agency where Mr. Mandelbaum was president and Mr. Wolf creative director. That agency has since dissolved. The appointments came a week after Bob Cox, the former top creative executive of Hal Riney & Partners/New York, joined Shaw & Landey, which changed its name to Cox Landey & Partners.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Athena Awards To 22 Agencies
description: Wry wit and arresting visual images distinguished 22 print ads that won Athena awards for excellence in newspaper advertising yesterday. The Newspaper Advertising Bureau, which selected the ads from more than 10,000 entries, honored the 22 winning agencies in a ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Pianist at Lehman
description: The pianist Horacio Gutierrez will play Haydn's Sonata in C, Schumann's ''Davidsbundlertanze,'' Ravel's ''Gaspard de la Nuit,'' and Liszt's ''Sonetto No. 104 del Petrarca'' and ''Mephisto Waltz'' No. 1 at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, at Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. Information: 960-8833.

title: Agnico-Eagle Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Prelude to the Summit: Who Has the Better Ship?
description: Waiting for the Soviet and American Presidents to arrive, the international audience here occupied itself by comparing the two gray warships anchored in the Marsaxlokk Bay.

title: U.N. Resolution Would Recognize P.L.O. as Palestinian Spokesman
description: A group of Arab countries today formally introduced a resolution that by calling on the General Assembly to recognize the P.L.O. as the representative of a Palestinian state sets the United Nations on a collision course with its host country.

title: A New Insider Charge At Business Week
description: In what could be an important test case of the boundaries of the Federal law banning insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused a typesetting supervisor of illegally trading on confidential information from advance copies of Business Week magazine.

title: Drug Use Is a Focus of Crane Inquiry
description: The California Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating reports of illegal drug use among workers at a construction job where a crane collapse killed five people.

title: Japan's Bumpy Financial Ride
description: For one day earlier this year, the Industrial Bank of Japan rocked Japanese regulators by slipping through a legal loophole and dealing in Japanese stocks in London - without first consulting the Finance Ministry, an almost unthinkable breach of protocol.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Christmas for Children Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed Sunday between 66th and 72d Streets from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The Popular Ferrier

title: Dow Rises 17.49 Points, To 2,706.27
description: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday on continued light volume. The broader market, while also up, gained less vigorously.

title: Gerber to Close Plant in Ontario
description: The Gerber Products Company said it will close its Niagara Falls, Ontario, plant by April, terminating about 150 jobs. The world's largest maker of baby food is consolidating production in its three United States plants: in Fremont, Mich.; Fort Smith, Ark., and Asheville, N.C.

title: Budget Office Proposes $8 Billion Medicare Cut
description: The White House budget office has proposed saving $8 billion in Medicare spending that would otherwise be required in the next fiscal year under current law.

title: This Old House
description: If the walls of 273 Water Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10004 could talk, the dainty would have to block their ears. During its more than 200 years this small brick derelict has been a brothel, a home for ''fallen women'' and a saloon called Kit Burns's Sportsman's Hall, where bad men paid good money to watch dogs fight rats. It's also seen wars, pestilence, riots and squatters.

title: Alabama Hospital Seeks $53 Million
description: The City of Montgomery, Ala., is offering through the BMC Special Care Facilities Financing Authority $53 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds for the Baptist Medical Center.

title: Protests Over Territory Continuing in Armenia
description: Tens of thousands of Armenians gathered in the streets of their southern Soviet republic for the second day in a row today to denounce legislation returning control of Nagorno-Karabakh to Azerbaijan.

title: Review/Art; Ryder and the Disciples Of His Poetic Vision
description: In the work of Alfred Pinkham Ryder (1847-1917) there are images that, once seen, form part of a collective American folk-memory. One such is ''The Race Track,'' now in the Cleveland Museum, in which a pale rider on a pale horse races round and round an empty racecourse for all eternity. Another is ''Jonah'' in the National Museum of American Art in Washington, in which the sea that surrounds Jonah's boat is so convulsive we almost think he will be more comfortable inside the belly of the whale.

title: Bronfman Stake In Israeli Concern
description: The Canadian investor Charles Bronfman has agreed to buy up to 25 percent of a leading Israeli electronics concern for $22.4 million, Mr. Bronfman's investment company Claridge Ltd. said today. Claridge said it would buy a million new shares in Electronics Company Israel Telecom Ltd., known as E.C.I., for $11 million, and another 700,000 shares from E.C.I.'s parent, Clal Electronics Industries, at $10 a share.

title: Cards Sign Cox
description: Danny Cox, who missed the 1989 season after surgery on his right elbow, has signed a one-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals for $250,000 and up to $500,000 more in bonuses. Cox, who made $600,000 last year, had surgery in March to repair an elbow ligament. He hurt the elbow pitching in an exhibition game. (AP)

title: An Underlying Factor In AIDS Is Suggested
description: Scientists have found a deficiency of a substance that is important to the normal functioning of cells in a small study of people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Hughes Aircraft Co. to Eisaman, Johns & Laws Advertising, Los Angeles, with a budget of $5 million.

title: 2 Columbia Heads Give Key Duties to Lawyer
description: Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the new co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., started putting their imprint on the studio yesterday by naming their longtime lawyer, Alan J. Levine, to run most of the company.

title: Amtrak Convicted of Putting Sewage in Florida Waterways
description: A jury in a state court today found Amtrak guilty of dumping raw sewage into Florida waterways, in the national rail passenger line's first such criminal trial.

title: Essef Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said incorporation of new employees and consolidation of two factories into into a single plant at its Statesville, N.C., facility unfavorably affected operations in the fourth quarter.

title: Alabama Hands Tar Heels Their 2d Consecutive Loss
description: Melvin Cheatum scored 19 of his 23 points in the final 9 minutes tonight as Alabama defeated North Carolina, 101-93. The loss was the second in succession for the Tar Heels.

title: Pergolesi Mass in F
description: Pergolesi's Mass in F for four choirs and two orchestras will be performed at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, on Sunday at 8 P.M., by the 53-voice Ascension Choir and the Philharmonia Virtuosi, under the direction of Dennis Keene. Soloists will be Susanne Peck, Kathy Theil, Jennifer Lane, Rodnne Brown and Robert Kuehn. Admission is $10. Information: 254-8553.

title: Shirley Wood, Editor Of Weekly Paper, 65
description: Shirley Wood, co-publisher and co-editor of The Block Island (R.I.) Times and a former editor with Time Inc., was a passenger on a commuter airplane that disappeared off Block Island on Tuesday night.

title: Unease Fills Western Allies Over Rapid Changes in East
description: The joyous revolution of freedom sweeping Eastern Europe is confronting Western Europe with some of its gravest decisions in 40 years.

title: With Salvador Flare-Up, Hope Fades
description: The tragedy of the growing violence here is that it is fortifying the extremes and seems to have all but ended any chance of a political solution to the decade-old civil war for the foreseeable future.

title: East Division Title Is on Line When Giants Tackle Eagles
description: Every week, the Giants seem to play a big game. This week, the game is bigger than most, a division championship game, according to Coach Bill Parcells.

title: Freer Technology Trade Urged
description: The United States and its allies will respond to the reforms in Eastern Europe by relaxing controls on advanced technology, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger said. Business Day, page D2.

title: Spending Drops Off; Income Up
description: Consumer spending fell in October to its lowest level in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts said continued sluggishness in personal consumption is likely to be a ''major drag'' on the economy in the fourth quarter.

title: FT Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $3,598,000, or 35 cents a share for the quarter and $2,921,000, or 29 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $24,611,000 and $25,536,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Rise of 11.5% In Taxi Fares Is Approved
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission approved an 11.5 percent rise in yellow-cab fares yesterday, the first in a series of expected fare increases on public transportation systems in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Injury Removes Carroll
description: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' backup center, will be out for two to five weeks with a sprained left ankle. Carroll hurt the ankle in the second quarter of Wednesday's 118-95 loss to Boston, when he slipped after making a turnaround jump shot. X-rays showed no fracture, but Carroll will have further X-rays on Monday as a precaution.

title: Prague Regains a Wayward Balladeer
description: One of Czechoslovakia's best-known balladeers looked out at the people packed into an auditorium here tonight, nodded his head and smiled.

title: Philadelphia Contract Plan For Minorities Is Overturned
description: A Philadelphia school district program that gave preference to minority contractors has been struck down by a Federal district judge, who says it failed to meet a new test established by the Supreme Court.

title: TV Weekend; Ambitious Movies Face Off Sunday
description: This Sunday evening at 9, there are two ambitious television movies running against each other. One, CBS's ''No Place Like Home,'' is a searing account of what it is like to be homeless in today's United States. The other, ABC's ''Shell Seekers,'' is about an independent, middle-class Englishwoman coming to terms with herself and her grown children. The more sustained dramatic clout is delivered by ''No Place Like Home,'' directed by Lee Grant.

title: PRAGUE TO SCRAP ITS FORTIFICATIONS ON AUSTRIA BORDER
description: Czechoslovakia announced today that it would begin immediately to dismantle fortifications along some sections of its 240-mile border with Austria, and remove virtually all restrictions on travel to the West.

title: The U.S. 'Wall' Around Cuba Goes Next
description: To the Editor:

title: Marvin S. Machson, Lawyer, 74
description: Marvin S. Machson, a lawyer and arbitrator, died of prostate cancer Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Economic Scene; Aid for East Bloc Expected To Be a Vital Summit Topic
description: Economic issues will be crucial in the talks between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev off Malta this weekend.

title: Orange-Co.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Panel Proposes AIDS Program To Help Inmates
description: A New York State advisory panel proposed major new programs yesterday to deal with the rising epidemic of AIDS among prison inmates, and health and prison officials endorsed the proposals as a strong plan for action.

title: FRENCH SEND SHIP TO LEBANON COAST
description: France dispatched a military ship to the Lebanese coast today, and the Christian army commander there, Gen. Michel Aoun, hailed the event as military support for his besieged forces.

title: Rangers Lose Leads and Confidence
description: For the Rangers, the shocks to their defensive system, having gained momentum over the last month, have now begun to take a toll.

title: Denver Post Picks New Editor
description: F. Gilman Spencer, former editor of The Daily News in New York, was named editor in chief of The Denver Post on Wednesday. He replaces Robert W. Ritter, who resigned. Mr. Spencer joined The Daily News in 1984 and left recently after a well-publicized disagreement with the publisher, James Hoge.

title: Bell (W.) & Co.  (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Five Missing Fishermen Put Technology to Stiffest Test
description: From a chart-lined room with a view of the Boston waterfront, a team of Coast Guard specialists is struggling to find the five-member crew of a lobster boat that has been missing for more than a week.

title: Whose Book Is It Anyway?
description: When the accounting firms of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young merged last summer, one of the most valuable assets turned out to be something the firms were quick to abandon: the Arthur Young name. For several years, Arthur

title: Florence A. Kahn, Executive, 81
description: Florence Abraham Kahn, retired owner and former chief executive of H. Abraham Inc., a Brooklyn glass-fabricating concern, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. She was 81 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Cuomo Backers Raise $2 Million For a 3d Term
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has said he is not yet a candidate for a third term next year, but his friends say they raised nearly $2 million for a third-term campaign last night.

title: Contingency Fees for Lawyers Are Plain Wrong; Uneven Representation
description: To the Editor:

title: Plea in Pentagon Fraud
description: A former executive at a military contractor pleaded guilty today to conspiring to make illegal campaign contributions and to obstructing the F.B.I.'s investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud.

title: Minimum Bid Reported Set By Campeau
description: The Campeau Corporation has set a Dec. 8 deadline for initial bids on its Bloomingdale's stores and has decided that it will not accept any offers under $1 billion, retail and merger-acquisition executives said yesterday.

title: Health Insurance of Vt.  Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dining Out Guide: Venison
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Alison on Dominick St. ** (Aug. 18, 1989), 38 Dominick Street (727-1188) - This is a simple, harmonious place to dine, with pastel-colored walls holding black-and-white photographs, royal blue banquettes and indirect lighting. Cuisine of southwestern France is the focus, and during the game season, venison surfaces on the menu. As an appetizer, there is a tartare seasoned with capers, shallots and mustard oil. As an entree, there is a roast loin served with spatzle and a fava bean puree. Appetizers range from $7 to $14, main courses $17 to $28. Lunch, noon to 2:30 P.M. Mondays to Fridays; dinner, 6:15 to 11 P.M. Mondays to Thursdays, until 11:30 P.M. Fridays and Saturdays. Aquavit ** (Feb. 5, 1988), 13 West 54th Street (307-7311) - This Scandinavian establishment is a striking modern setting, with an informal cafe on the upper level and, on the lower level, a soaring space with birch trees reaching to an eight-story glass-walled atrium. At a time of year when diners seek out lusty game dishes, Aquavit features an enticing version of venison. Sauteed, cut in thin slices and shaped in a fan, it is set on a cream-apple sauce and served with lingonberries, morels and celery root puree. Prix fixe $35 for lunch; $60 for dinner. Lunch, noon to 2:30 P.M. Mondays to Fridays (until 3 P.M. upstairs); dinner, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. Mondays to Saturdays (until 10 P.M. upstairs). Au Troquet * (Dec. 9, 1988), 328 West 12th Street (924-3413) - Au Troquet is everyone's idea of a romantic little French restaurant in Greenwich Village, with its white-framed windows and lacy curtains. Its moderately priced menu emphasizes the cuisine of Provence. Venison is given a classic treatment. Having been marinated in wine, herbs and vegetables for several days, the medallions are sauteed and served with a juniper berry sauce, pureed chestnuts and a vegetable garnish. Appetizers $4.25 to $6.75; entrees $14.50 to $21.75. Dinner, 6 to 11 P.M. Mondays to Saturdays. Felidia ** (Sept. 16, 1988), 243 East 58th Street (758-1479) - This elegant two-story restaurant, specializing in food from the northern Adriatic area, buzzes every night with a well-heeled crowd. What is listed on the menu as venison squazet is a stew with a red-wine sauce, served with one's choice of gnocchi, polenta or pasta. Another venison dish is sauteed fillet in a Barolo sauce, served with vegetables and chestnut puree. Appetizers range from $10 to $15; main courses from $17 to $27. Lunch, noon to 3 P.M. Mondays to Fridays; dinner, 5 to midnight Mondays to Saturdays. Le Perigord *** (June 16, 1989), 405 East 52d Street (755-6244) - The dining room is soft and spacious, with beige-and-pink flowered wall fabric, leather chairs and bursts of fresh flowers. The food is scintillating and the service exemplary. Noisettes of venison, complemented by a fresh cranberry and poivrade sauce, are served with both a chestnut and a celery root puree. When the chef is further inspired, he prepares a warm terrine of venison pate enclosed in puff pastry and topped with truffle sauce. Prix-fixe dinner $48. Lunch, noon to 3 P.M. Mondays to Fridays; dinner, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. Mondays to Saturdays.

title: Radiation Therapy Is Weighed for Mrs. Bush
description: One of Barbara Bush's doctors said today that the dosage of her eye medication had been altered and that radiation therapy was being considered.

title: Review/Art; From Chillida, Pillars Of Energy and Gravity
description: Eduardo Chillida is very much a European modernist. His abstract sculpture in metal and clay is intense yet measured, freest when it is most self-contained. Its edge depends upon its ability to communicate a sense that it is both aware of its limits and entirely at ease with its identity, and yet driven to push those limits and see, feel and know more. In the hands of someone with an exceptional sensibility, this push-pull between being and becoming will never be out of date.

title: Review/Film; Those Who Resisted
description: ''Dance of Hope'' opens today at the Public Theater, just 13 days before the Dec. 14 presidential and congressional elections in Chile, the first since the military coup that overthrew the Government of Salvador Allende Gossens. The timing is not accidental.

title: Bush Heads to Malta Ready For a 'Historic Opportunity'
description: President Bush left today for his first summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, saying the two leaders had a ''powerful and historic opportunity'' to transform East-West relations.

title: Benihana National reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
Westchester Airport Cleared to Begin Modernizing
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today approved an environmental plan for Westchester County Airport, opening the way for long-sought modernization and improvement.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: Today HOLIDAY FAIR, St. Bartholomew Community Preschool, 109 East 50th Street. Books, jewelry, food, entertainment. Today, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Proceeds benefit scholarship programs at the school. Information: 751-1616. Tomorrow TIBETAN-ASIAN BAZAAR, Eastside International Community Center, 330 East 45th Street. Crafts, jewelry, antiques, rugs, food, entertainment. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. Donations, $2 (children, $1). Information: 989-1829. CRAFTS FESTIVAL, Martin Luther King Jr. High School, 122 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street; sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance Inc. Clothing, jewelry, ceramics, wood and leather goods, entertainment. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Also Dec. 9 and 10 and Dec. 16 and 17. Information: 866-2239. AMERICAN INDIAN CRAFTS EXHIBIT AND FAIR, P.S. 84, 32 West 92d Street; sponsored by the Learning Alliance. Crafts, jewelry, ceramics, quilts, clothing. Tomorrow, noon to 7 P.M. Admission, $5. Information: 226-7171. ORCHID SALE, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Gift Shop, 1000 Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Information: (718) 622-4433. HOLIDAY SALE, Flatbush Development Corporation, 1114 Cortelyou Road, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn; proceeds benefit community programs. Gifts, books, food. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Information: (718) 287-2202. WINTER FESTIVAL, Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, L.I. Crafts, workshops, food. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission, $4 (free for those under 12). Information and directions: (516) 922-9207 or 922-9201. CRAFTS FAIR, Cathedral House, 50 Cathedral Avenue, Garden City, L.I. Gifts, food, raffle. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Proceeds benefit the Garden City Nursery School. Information and directions: (516) 481-7765. Sunday HOLIDAY FAIR, School of Visual Arts Annex, 214 East 21st Street; sponsored by the Society of Scribes. Demonstrations, food, raffle. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission, $1. Information: 683-0600.

title: Help Mr. Gorbachev Help the West
description: When President Bush meets President Gorbachev tomorrow, it will be with the best of intentions for improving Soviet-American relations. But it's still not clear that he has a clear and compelling strategy for doing so.

title: On Stage
description: American in London

title: Triborough Bonds' Top Yield Is 7%
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority yesterday tentatively priced $224.1 million in general-purpose revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7 percent for serial bonds due in 2004 and 2005 through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Review/Theater; Art Imitates Art in a Stoppard Play
description: You know you're at a Tom Stoppard play when even the title lends itself to at least three different meanings.

title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him
description: In his first public comments since his killing of two unarmed blacks set off three days of rioting here 10 months ago, a Hispanic police officer testified today that he fired the fatal shot because ''I feared for my life - I thought I was going to be killed.''

title: Bush Rejects Bill on China Students
description: President Bush today killed legislation that would have allowed Chinese students to stay in the United States after their visas expired. He said he was taking administrative action to give equivalent protection to the students.

title: UAL Outlays Irk Senator
description: A failed management-led buyout of the UAL Corporation that has cost shareholders about $55 million in expenses shows the conflict of interest in employee takeovers, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum said today.

title: Drop Those Hyphens And Just Be American
description: To the Editor:

title: Chang Is Crafty But So Is McEnroe
description: Not quite like clockwork, the world's top four players - Ivan Lendl, Boris Becker, Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe -emerged from the eight-man Masters field as the quartet most qualified to pursue its championship.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MARRINER AT CARNEGIE

title: Greenman Bros.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
HEI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary tax credits of $41,000, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and $194,000, or 12 cents a share for the year.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A 40's Incarnation

title: Festivities for St. Nicholas Day
description: St. Nicholas Day, the traditional Dutch children's holiday (Dec. 6) that gradually became incorporated into the English gift-giving celebration of Christmas, will be celebrated this weekend in New York. This is a sampling of events in the region. Tomorrow BRONX ARTS ENSEMBLE AND SINGERS, ''Music for St. Nicholas,'' a program of Dutch carols. Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum, Shore Road, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx; tomorrow, 2 P.M. Also at the Church of the Mediator, Kingsbridge Avenue and West 231st Street, in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx; tomorrow, 4 P.M. Admission: free. Information: 549-1899. PIETER CLAESEN WYCKOFF HOUSE MUSEUM, Clarendon Road at Ralph Avenue, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. St. Nicholas and his helper, Black Piet, will arrive on horseback and distribute gifts, candy and fruit to children at New York's oldest building, dating from about 1652. Linda Russell also will perform early American music. Tomorrow, 1 P.M. Admission: $1; 50 cents for children and the elderly. Information: (718) 629-5400. PHILLIPSBURG MANOR, Upper Mills, Route 9, North Tarrytown. Candlelight tours of the manor house, barn and gristmill, with 18th-century Dutch music and refreshments. Tomorrow and Sunday, 5 to 9 P.M. Admission is $5; $4.50 for the elderly; $3 for students, free for children under 6. Nondenominational church services will be held both evenings at 7:30 across Route 9 at the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow. Information and directions: (914) 631-8200. Sunday LEFFERTS HOMESTEAD, near Flatbush Avenue and Empire Boulevard, Prospect Park section, Brooklyn. St. Nicholas and Black Piet will arrive at the 200-year-old farmhouse on horseback. Festivities will include holiday songs, refreshments and ornament-making workshops. Sunday, 1:30 to 3:30 P.M. Admission: free. Information: (718) 788-8549.

title: Disinheritance Law Kindles Passion in Louisiana
description: Under mandate of the Legislature, legal scholars here are polishing a new state law that they detest and believe to be unconstitutional. Their task is to mesh the new law with the complex state civil code.

title: Francis McCaffrey, 72, Ex-Bronx State Senator
description: Francis J. McCaffrey, a lawyer and former Democratic State Senator from the Bronx, died of a stroke Wednesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 72 years old.

title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint
description: Vicki Sherling was teacher of the year in this small southwestern Georgia town last year, respected and honored for her winning way with gifted science students at Colquitt County Senior High School.

title: Portrait of Jackson as White Is Attacked
description: A 14-by-16-foot portrait of a white-skinned, blond and blue-eyed Jesse Jackson was knocked down on Wednesday afternoon as it was being installed in a downtown parking lot as part of a show sponsored by the Washington Project for the Arts.

title: Party Crucial to India Coalition Shifts Leaders
description: The conservative Bharatiya Janata Party, whose support is crucial to the centrist National Front as it prepares to form a government, today reorganized and strengthened its leadership.

title: Lynn Bari, 75, 'Other Woman' In 30's and 40's Movies, Is Dead
description: Lynn Bari, an actress who appeared in nearly 50 movies, most of them in the 1930's and 40's, died of a heart attack on Nov. 20 in a Santa Barbara, Calif., hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in the Santa Barbara suburb of Goleta.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Now we not only proceed from the assumption that no one should interfere in matters of the individual's conscience.

title: Ditka Plans to Stay
description: Mike Ditka says he will be back to coach the Chicago Bears next season, and he has received the backing of the team's president, Michael McCaskey. ''He doesn't need a special vote of confidence after all he's done for the Bears,'' McCaskey said on Wednesday. ''I kind of resent the question of whether or not I still have confidence in Mike Ditka.''

title: Auditor Quits a Company
description: Clean Harbors Inc., a Quincy, Mass.. environmental services concern, disclosed today that Arthur Andersen & Company had withdrawn as the company's auditors and that the accounting firm had found ''material weaknesses'' in the company's internal auditing controls.

title: Edison Brothers Stores Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: The company has changed to a Jan. 31 year from a calendar year. Last year's figures are not directly comparable because the third quarter and 9 months periods ended Oct. 1, 1988.

title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug
description: While the United States and other countries intensify their war on drugs, two European countries, Switzerland and the Netherlands, are adhering to a much more liberal approach to their drug problems.

title: Jimmy Carter's Sister Has Pancreas Cancer
description: Gloria Carter Spann, the last surviving sibling of former President Jimmy Carter, has been found to be suffering from pancreatic cancer, the same disease that killed their father, sister and brother and contributed to the death of their mother.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-24 Czechoslovakia's boarders will open to virtually all travel and fortifications along some sections of its 240-mile boarder with Austria will be dismantled, the Government announced. Page A1

title: Buffalo Park Has Growing Plans
description: Officials today unveiled plans to expand Buffalo's minor league stadium to 41,500 seats if the city lands an expansion team.

title: Entree Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 14
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter was affected by corporate expenses indirectly related to the dispositions of its Fairbank Farms Inc. unit and Ben Kozloff Inc. unit, other corporate expenses that have been eliminated, and non-recurring expenses of about $294,000.

title: Occidental Given Oilfield Go-Ahead
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation received British Government approval to redevelop the Piper oilfield in the North Sea, where an explosion on a company platform killed 167 men. The Piper Alpha platform off Scotland exploded in flames on July 6, 1988, and was destroyed.

title: French, Germans Back Copter Deal
description: The French and West German Governments have approved joint development of a combat and support helicopter called the Tiger, the French arms procurement agency said today. The contract is worth about $1.2 billion and covers development of the helicopter and construction of five prototypes over 10 years to be built by a consortium owned by Aerospatiale of France and Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. of West Germany.

title: Consoliated Talcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included the results of Vector No. 1 Acquisition Corp., acquired effective June 30. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mets Feel Little Trade Urgency
description: The Mets consider their needs to be modest, so next week's winter meetings in Nashville could produce either a trade to strengthen their bullpen or nothing at all.

title: Decom Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Adoption of FASB No. 96 resulted in net operating loss carryforward benefits of $34,000 and $143,000 for the latest fourth quarter and fiscal year, respectively.

title: Lockheed Shift To Cut 950 Jobs
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it plans to merge its two big electronics companies, the Lockheed Electronics Company and Sanders Associates, on Jan. 1 to form Lockheed Sanders Inc., based in Nashua, N.H. Lockheed said it will close the headquarters plant of Lockheed Electronics in Plainfield, N.J., and lay off about 950 of its 1,100 workers.

title: Amex Details Options Plan
description: Despite objections from some of its rivals, the American Stock Exchange is moving to put into effect a plan that allows stock options to be traded on more than one exchange.

title: INSIDE
description: Rise in New York Cab Fares An 11.5 percent increase in yellow-cab fares was approved. Fare rises for subways, buses and commuter railroads are expected to follow shortly. Page B1. Shoving Match in Japan Japan's attempt to deregulate its financial markets has taken five years and followed a bumpy path among banks, securities firms and Government bureaucrats. Page D1. New Cuomo Drug Plan The New York Governor said he wants to double the money the state spends on fighting drugs in the next few years and to emphasize treatment over enforcement. Page B1. Big Medicare Cut Urged The White House budget office has proposed saving $8 billion in Medicare spending that would otherwise be required in the next fiscal year under current law. Page A26.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Islanders Shut Out Chicago
description: Mark Fitzpatrick stopped 31 shots for his first National Hockey League shutout as the Islanders beat the Chicago Blackhawks, 2-0, in a contest between teams that both began the evening having lost five successive games. Mick Vukota of the Islanders and

title: BRIEFS
description: * China International Trust and Investment Corp., Beijing, known as Citic, said it is negotiating to buy a stake in the Hong Kong airline Dragonair, formally known as Hong Kong Dragon Airlines.

title: Colombia Jet Toll Reaches 110
description: The death toll from the crash of a Colombian jetliner rose to 110 today as outrage increased over assertions that the police joined looters in stripping the bodies of valuables.

title: Sikorsky to Lay Off About 150 Workers
description: Sikorsky Aircraft said it will lay off about 150 hourly workers Friday, in part because of shrinking United States and international military spending. The layoffs, announced Wednesday in a notice posted at four company plants in Connecticut, will be the first in Sikorsky's blue-collar work force since February 1988, when the helicopter builder laid off 19 hourly workers.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the economy misstated the third-quarter change in two price indexes.

title: Boston Digital Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Film; On Vacation Once Again
description: When Chevy Chase finds a good way to hurt himself in ''National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation,'' he generally tries it more than once. The board that whacks him in the chin is liable to strike again. Floors will collapse, ladders fall, Christmas trees come hurtling through windows. The film's penchant for breakage jokes is rivaled only by its taste for gross-out humor, and for the kinds of double-entendres best appreciated by 7-year-old boys. One extended comedy routine involves the panic caused by a runaway squirrel.

title: Two Sinkholes Force Evacuations in Jersey
description: Two sinkholes, one more than 25 feet deep, opened here today, forcing the temporary evacuation of at least six homes, the police said.

title: Drug Test Bans Tubbs
description: Tony Tubbs has been suspended indefinitely after having tested positive for cocaine last week after beating Orlin Norris in a North American Boxing Federation heavyweight championship bout.

title: Technology Code Review Urged by U.S.
description: The United States and its allies should respond to the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe by relaxing controls on advanced technology to Communist countries, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said today.

title: NATO Plans New Mix If Deep Cuts Are Made
description: The commander of NATO forces in Europe says he has begun to consider new military plans for the defense of Western Europe in the event that deep cuts are made in conventional forces.

title: Am International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Share earnings reflects preferred stock dividend requirement. The company said operating income, which included $10 million of patent licensing fees in the latest quarter, was $7.9 million compared to $8.7 million in the first quarter of last year. The decline was attributed to lower revenues, adverse product mix changes and higher manufacturing and operating costs at the company's bindery & forms press division. The company also noted higher selling and administrative expenses at its other divisions.

title: At the Movies
description: Postpartum Expression

title: Recognition Equipment reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $114,000, or 1 cent a share, due to income tax benefit from tax credits and operating losses carried forward and also included an accounting adjustment of $3,578,000 due to the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for spare parts. The company said the latest fourth quarter loss is the result of a $15.9 million provision for losses expected to be incurred in the disposition of certain non-image related businesses and accruals for severance and associated costs from downsizing operations. The remaining loss for the quarter primarily consists of $10 million for an anticipated loss associated with a long-term contract and $4.3 million in writedowns for obsolete or excess parts and equipment.

title: Head of Top West German Bank Is Killed in Bombing by Terrorists
description: The head of West Germany's largest commercial bank was killed today when terrorists detonated a remote-control bomb, demolishing the automobile in which he was being driven to work.

title: Imperial Metals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $3,725,000 on a dilution of the company's interest in Anglesey Mining Plc. Included are investment gains of $947,000 in the latest quarter and $1,997,000 in the latest 6 months. The company said a non-recurring mineral net profits interest payment of $345,000 was received during the latest quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Charges of Kickbacks Brought Against Three
description: A Federal grand jury here indicted a record promoter and a former executive of Columbia Records today, charging that radio station employees were given cocaine as kickbacks to play certain songs.

title: Alvin Ailey Company Moves Into New Home
description: A sign-painter was putting the last touches on the company logo in the lobby as guests arrived early Tuesday evening for the opening of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation's new headquarters at 211 West 61st Street, just west of Lincoln Center.

title: U S West Offer On Retirement
description: U S West Inc., the regional telephone and communications company based in Englewood, Colo., said today that it had offered early-retirement incentives to 6,000 managers in an effort to cut costs. The company said as many as 2,000 of the employees may accept the offer to leave.

title: Oracle Plans To Offer Data
description: The Oracle Corporation, the fast-growing vendor of database software used by corporations for filing and retrieving data, now wants to provide the data as well.

title: Housing Program Blossoms From Once-Deserted Shells
description: Just 11 months ago, what is now Jerome M. Douglas's living room was a staging ground for the construction crews that were bringing back to life a vacant five-story tenement on West 112th Street in Harlem. Plasterboard was piled four feet high. Rows of new windows were leaning against the wall.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Backer in Thailand
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates has added Thailand to its growing chain of agencies in the Pacific Rim. The agency, opened in Bangkok, is called BSB Thailand Ltd. and is a joint venture of Backer and two other agencies in Bangkok: Shrimp Studios, an advertising agency, and Ra-Kahng Associates, a marketing firm.

title: N.B.A. Enlarges Cable Contract
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. signed a four-year, $275 million contract with the National Basketball Association yesterday that nearly tripled the annual license fee that cable television now pays to professional basketball.

title: Drexel to Reduce Cash Portion of Bonuses
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. acknowledged yesterday that it planned to raise several million dollars of equity capital by requiring that its best-paid employees take a portion of their year-end bonuses in Drexel stock rather than in cash.

title: Troopers Union Joins Suit on Police Taping
description: The Connecticut state police union today joined defense attorneys and others in a civil lawsuit against state police officials accused of secretly recording telephone calls made from police barracks.

title: Zapata Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Included a pretax gain of $87,400,000 from the sale of leasing assets. Results for the latest year included a $16.4 million pretax writedown on the company's remaining coal-related assets.

title: Book Theft Laid to Librarian
description: The former head librarian at the University of Texas Medical Branch has been charged with stealing five rare medical books from the school. The accused, Emil Frey, 62 years old, surrendered to Galveston County sheriff's officials Wednesday and was later released on $23,000 bond. An indictment charges him with stealing five of 80 books missing from the school's Moody Medical Library. The indictment says the books are valued at between $750 and $20,000 each.

title: Prize-Winning Tenor
description: Stanford Olsen, the tenor who won the 1989 Naumburg Vocal Competition, will sing Schubert's ''Schone Mullerin'' at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening at 8. The pianist will be Phillip Farris. Tickets are $10. Information: 874-6770.

title: Addenda
description: * Young & Rubicam has acquired a majority interest in a Turkish agency, Reklamevi, based in Istanbul. The agency will change its name to Young & Rubicam Turkey.

title: Auctions
description: Rare Mushroom Lamp

title: To Auction the Mahatma's Letters Is Not the Gandhian Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Meyer Pesin Dies at 88; Ex-Jersey City Official
description: Meyer Pesin, a former corporation counsel for Jersey City and a former president of the Jewish National Fund of America, died Tuesday in Caracas, Venezuela. He was 88 years old and had lived in Teaneck, N.J., before moving to Caracas four years ago.

title: The World Of India
description: When India voted, a whole world voted.

title: Prostitution Called Link in Rochester Deaths
description: Someone is stalking and killing women in this city's red-light district. Since March 1988, 12 women have been murdered: nine who the police say were prostitutes, a homeless woman, a mildly retarded introvert who liked to walk in her solitude and a woman whose skeletal remains have gone unidentified.

title: U.S. Role Seen on Japan Jets
description: Two leading American companies have accepted an invitation from the Japanese Government to participate in a $195 million project to develop jet engines for supersonic passenger aircraft, industry sources said.

title: Yugoslav Police Check Cars To Stop Protest by Serbians
description: The police checked vehicles today to stop Serbians from reaching Ljubljana in spite of an order banning a mass protest.

title: Survey Finds Americans Favor a Reunited Germany
description: The upheaval in Eastern Europe has left Americans optimistic and ready for even greater change in the region. Two out of three say East and West Germany should be reunited, and an equal number predict that Eastern Europe will be largely out of Soviet control a year from now.

title: 5 Withdraw From List For New York Police Job
description: Five of the 11 initial candidates for New York City police commissioner have withdrawn their names, the head of the search panel said yesterday.

title: Hy & Zel's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 'Mastergate' to Close
description: ''Mastergate,'' a comedy by Larry Gelbart about Government cover-ups, will close after the matinee on Dec. 10 at the Criterion Theater, Broadway and 45th Street. The play, directed by Michael Engler, will have run for 24 previews and 68 regular performances.

title: Warning About Tests
description: In at least two decisions, the Supreme Court has indicated its willingness, despite the Fourth Amendment, to uphold the constitutionality of mandatory, random drug testing of workers in ''high risk'' or ''safety-sensitive'' jobs.

title: A Gift to Neediest Cases Fund Is Often a Holiday Tradition
description: ''I made it on opening day for the 50th year,'' Harry Harlem announced proudly in a note that arrived with a check for $50 at The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this week.

title: C.I.A. CRASH CALLED PROBLEM IN ANGOLA
description: The crash of a Central Intelligence Agency plane carrying weapons to guerrillas in Angola will set back efforts to negotiate a cease-fire and a political settlement there, American officials said today.

title: East Berlin Denounces 1968 Prague Invasion
description: The East German Government spokesman, Wolfgang Meyer, today officially denounced the Warsaw Pact's decision to invade Czechoslovakia in 1968.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme Steel Co., Riverdale, Ill. said Lawrence W. Hicks, president and chief executive of Lone Star Steel Co., Dallas, was joining Acme as executive vice president and chief operating officer. Advatex Associates, an asbestos removal company, named Richard C. Telesmanich president and chief operating officer and Daniel M. Margiotta senior vice president.

title: Chiefs' Rookie Sack Specialist Leading Drive Toward Playoffs
description: Derrick Thomas was only 4 years old in 1971, when the Miami Dolphins beat the Kansas City Chiefs by 27-24 after 22 minutes of overtime in a Christmas Day playoff battle that was the longest game in National Football League history. Thomas, however, is more concerned with making his own history and helping guide the Chiefs into the playoffs.

title: Review/Music; Rameau's 'Hippolyte' Performed in Concert
description: The French Baroque remains opera's last frontier, largely unknown to the world's major companies. That has left a vast area to be scouted out by ensembles that specialize in reconstructing the performing practices of bygone eras. One such group, James Richman's Concert Royal, explored Rameau's first extant opera, ''Hippolyte et Aricie,'' at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday and Thursday evenings. The Wednesday effort was a studious and thoroughly respectable one, though the work's Baroque grandeur could peer through only occasionally in this concert version.

title: Entertainment Chief Quits at Last-Place CBS
description: Earle H. (Kim) LeMasters, the president of CBS Entertainment, resigned yesterday after the network failed to make significant progress in its prime-time ratings performance this fall.

title: Grace Spinelli, Social Worker, 83
description: Grace Billotti Spinelli, a retired social worker who directed programs at Young Women's Christian Associations in Orange and Passaic Counties in New Jersey, died Saturday at Warren Hospital in Phillipsburg, N.J. She was 83 years old and lived in Jersey City for 53 years before moving to East Orange about 10 years ago.

title: German Red Army Faction Is Alive and Is Refining Itself
description: The killing of Alfred Herrhausen today is an ominous reminder that the Red Army Faction terrorist group - which West German police thought was severely crippled by the arrests of its leading members in recent years - is not only alive, but continues to refine its methods.

title: Fleetwood Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
U.S. Offers Compromise On Garbage Recycling
description: Under strong pressure from industry, the Environmental Protection Agency today proposed a compromise regulation aimed at reducing garbage burning 25 percent by forcing incinerator operators not to burn recyclable material.

title: At Last, Rutgers Wins Acclaim
description: Rutgers has been trying to make a national name for itself with its football and basketball teams, but national acclaim has come to the school this fall from its soccer team.

title: Philippine Coup Attempts
description: July 6, 1986 A group of military officers loyal to the deposed President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, takes over the Manila Hotel and declares Arturo Tolentino, who was Mr. Marcos's vice presidential running mate, as President. They surrender two days later. Nov. 23, 1986 The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino says Fidel V. Ramos, the armed forces Chief of Staff, has blocked a coup plot by disaffected military officers. Jan. 27, 1987 Marcos loyalists and mutinous troops try to seize military and communications installations in the capital. The mutineers hold a radio-television station for 61 hours before surrendering. July 13, 1987 Four army officers are arrested in Manila in connection with the latest coup attempt. Aug. 27, 1987 Mutinous soldiers begin attacks on the presidential palace in an effort to overthrow the Aquino Government. Dec. 1, 1989 Rebel troops bomb the presidential palace and seize the air force headquarters and two broadcast stations in an attempt to overthrow the Government. After a few hours of fighting, two rebel soldiers and a civilian are reported killed and battles are reported around the capital.

title: The Nation That Lost Its Heroes
description: Except for the politicians, of course, with their dachas and their villas, the performers and the athletes lived the best in the people's paradises.

title: Suspended Fines for 'Chlorine 5'
description: Five Wildwood Crest businessmen were each fined $200 today for dumping 50 pounds of chlorine pellets in the Atlantic Ocean last summer. The fines were suspended.

title: Cott Beverages reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net loss and included capital losses totalling $1,591,000 on the liquidation of stock-market investments for both the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CENTRISTS IN INDIA STRIVING FOR UNITY
description: As the leaders of the centrist National Front continued consultations today on the composition of the Government they hope to assemble as early as next weekend, they sought to dissuade one of their number from challenging the accession to Prime Minister of Vishwanath Pratap Singh, the man who is credited with leading the coalition to prominence.

title: Rebels in Phillipine Army Bomb Aquino Palace and Attack Bases
description: Rebel troops bombed the presidential palace this morning after attacking three military camps and three broadcast stations in an attempt to overthrow the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Hunters in Maine Overkilling Bears, Game Officials Warn
description: Hunters are killing too many bears in Maine, game officials say, and they are proposing that the state's three-month hunting season be cut by four weeks.

title: Quietly, Infiniti Creates Excitement
description: When the Nissan Motor Company introduced its Infiniti car with a series of quirky, Zen-like ads that showcased nature scenes - and not the expensive automobile - the Japanese auto maker was making a strong bet that curiosity would create a flood of customers.

title: A University for Addicts
description: In Building A, a group of addicts gathers for yet another bruising therapy session, a staple of their yearlong residential treatment. In Building B, counselors meet with addicts participating in an experimental program of intensive outpatient treatment. In Building C, meanwhile, addicts who are also convicts on probation are interviewed to find what kind of treatment would suit them best.

title: Britain Sticks to Cambodia Plan
description: Britain still intends to send a Bangkok-based diplomat on an aid-related visit to Cambodia despite an American request that it lay the plan aside, Western diplomats here said today.

title: Our Towns; When Farming Was the Soul Of Garden State
description: For more than 50 years, Lloyd Wescott ran a dairy farm in Hunterdon County about 30 miles west of here, on the Delaware River. Two years ago he sold it. At the age of 80, he was growing old for farming, and the dairy business simply was not making it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Swiss Wins Giant Slalom: Urs Kaelin of Switzerland won the giant slalom yesterday at Waterville Valley, N.H., for his first World Cup victory. Kaelin overcame Lars-Boerje Eriksson of Sweden to win in a combined time of 2 minutes 38.49 seconds through 54 gates over hard-packed snow. Eriksson, 15th after the first run, moved up with the fastest clocking of the second run, 1:20.91, for an overall time of 2:38.75. But Kaelin, third after the first run, turned in the second-fastest time of the run to win by .26 seconds. Alberto Tomba of Italy, who won the second slalom on Wednesday, missed a gate on the first run and was eliminated.(AP) GOLF Strange Ties Record: Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion, shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to tie the course record and take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the Australian Open in Melbourne.

title: KEY RATES
President of Emerson Quits for Textron Job
description: The president and chief operating officer of the Emerson Electric Company has resigned and is taking the same posts at Textron Inc., while an executive who left Emerson two years ago is back as president.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: LADISLAV ADAMEC, Prime Minister: LAH-dyih-slahv AH-dah-mets ALEXANDER DUBCEK, a former party leader: AH-lehk-sahn-dehr DOOB-check MILOS FORMAN, a filmmaker: MEE-lohsh FOR-mahn VACLAV HAVEL, playwright and opposition leader: VAHTS-lahv HAH-vell JOSEF HORA, a party spokesman: YOH-zef HOH-rah JAROSLAV HUTKA, an industrial manager: YAH-roh-slahv HOOT-kah MILOS JAKES, a former party leader: MEE-lohsh YAH-kehsh MARCEL JANSEN, a Government spokesman: MAHR-sell YAHN-sen PAVEL KAHOUT, a writer: PAH-vell KAH-hote (rhymes with note) VACLAV KLAUS, an opposition leader: VAHTS-lahv klaus (rhymes with house) VALTR KOMAREK, an economist: VAHL-truh KOH-mah-reck FRANTISEK KUCERA, an industry manager: FRAHN-tyi-sheck KUH-cheh-rah MILAN KUNDERA, a writer: MIH-lahn KUHN-deh-rah PAVEL LANDOVSKY, an actor: PAH-vell LAHN-dohv-skee ZDENEK MLYNAR, a former party official: ZDEH-nyeck MLIH-nahrzh VASIL MOHORITA, a Politburo member: VAH-sihl MOH-ho-ree-tah LUDEC URBAN, an economist: LUH-dehts OOR-bahn MILOS ZEMAN, an economist: MEE-lohsh ZEH-mahn

title: Suspect Is Cleared in Murders Of Women in the Seattle Area
description: A man who was investigated this year in the deaths and disappearances of 49 women in the Seattle area is no longer a suspect, the police said today.

title: Dr. Pearl Ma, 61, Microbiology Expert Who Studied AIDS
description: Dr. Pearl Ma, who was chief of microbiology at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan, died of cancer Wednesday in Hong Kong, according to word received at the hospital here. Dr. Ma was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan until she returned recently to her native Hong Kong.

title: Review/Rock; 'Songs for Drella,' A Tribute to Warhol
description: For rockers, Andy Warhol's greatest cultural contribution wasn't his pop art, but his early sponsorship of the Velvet Underground - the band that virtually created alternative, anti-pop rock. In the mid-1960's, Warhol discovered and managed the Velvets, who performed at his Exploding Plastic Inevitable multi-media events. Like Warhol's artworks, the songs Lou Reed and John Cale wrote for the band used simplicity and repetition, and often presented jarring images without editorializing. This year, Mr. Reed and Mr. Cale reunited to write and perform a quasi-biographical song cycle about Warhol, ''Songs for 'Drella: A Fiction,'' whose full version opened a four-performance stand on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene section). While some audience members yelled requests for Velvets songs on Wednesday, Mr. Cale and Mr. Reed are not making their collaboration a Velvets reunion.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom Sells Unit
description: The Omnicom Group said yesterday that it had sold a subsidiary, Franklin Spier Inc., to the agency's senior management and a group of investors. Omnicom did not disclose the terms of the deal. Alix Nelson, the chairman of Franklin Spier, which specializes in advertising for publishing houses, said Omnicom's emphasis on global marketing services did not suit its local focus and client list. The agency's clients include Viking Penguin and Simon & Schuster.

title: Management Is Overhauled At Cablevision Systems
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, which operates local systems in New York and 10 other states and whose programming includes the Sportschannel, Bravo and American Move Classics services, has overhauled its management, creating an office of the chairman, and naming a chief operating officer, a vice chairman for development and a programming head.

title: Bush Reluctantly Signs Bill on C.I.A. Inspector
description: President Bush today reluctantly signed into law a measure creating an independent inspector general within the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Surgery for Mother Teresa
description: Mother Teresa, who sustained a heart attack in September, will receive a pacemaker in an operation on Friday, her doctor said. The 79-year-old Roman Catholic nun was taken to Woodlands Nursing Home on Wednesday night, Sister Dorothy, a member of Mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity, said. Mother Teresa fell ill Wednesday. She rested today, and her condition was reported as being normal.

title: Why Yalta Isn't a Dirty Word
description: ''Never another Yalta,'' says the common wisdom.

title: American Medical InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After charges of $100.2 million and $128.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively, both for asset writedowns and additions to reserves. c-Net income and the year included an extraordinary charge from repurchase of debt of $33,900,000 and an accounting gain of $50,700,000, or 59 cents a share, related to adoption of FAS 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: Restaurants
description: The seven-year-old Wilkinson's Seafood Cafe needs more publicity about as much as lobsters need mittens. On weeknights this inviting little neighborhood spot has an easygoing cadence: it is busy enough to be sociable, yet calm enough to offer intimacy. If it were not my job to blow the cover on such places, I'd keep it to myself.

title: World AIDS Epidemic Draws New Warnings
description: The worldwide AIDS epidemic is gaining momentum and in some regions has shifted from a disease mostly among men to one in which half the victims are women, officials of the World Health Organization said today.

title: Owner of Huffington Plans to Sell Company
description: Roy M. Huffington of Houston said today that he intends to sell his Huffington Corporation, a holding company with oil, gas and real estate interests that he started in 1958. He did not name an asking price, but analysts said it could fetch close to $1 billion.

title: Report Finds Problems With Pentagon Computers
description: The modernization of Defense Department computer systems that are used to store information on anything from personnel records to the purchase of new weapons is a billion dollars over budget, behind schedule and beset by numerous technical problems, a Congressional report made public today says.

title: Gorbachev Lauds Religion on Eve of Meeting Pope
description: On the eve of an encounter with Pope John Paul II, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that the Soviet Union had erred in long rejecting religion and now needed its moral force to help make his plans for a restructured society work.

title: Stewart & Stevenson Servces reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed during the second quarter of 1989.

title: Awards to Kingdom And Farmer-Patrick
description: Roger Kingdom, who set the world record of 12.92 seconds in the men's 110-meter hurdles in 1989, and Sandra Farmer-Patrick, unbeaten in the women's 400 hurdles all year, continued their winning ways yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Holiday Push For Liquor Campaigns
description: WITH the holiday season under way, and people drinking less in recent years, liquor sellers are fighting harder than ever for sales. ''Colossal'' is the word Madison Avenue favors for the high-tech and novelty approaches being tried, particularly by the importers of premium vodkas.

title: Whereabouts Of Comaneci Disputed
description: Nadia Comaneci, the gymnastics champion who fled to Hungary from Rumania on Wednesday, may be at the United States Embassy in Switzerland, her former coach said today.

title: Cuomo Panel Urges More Anti-Drug Funds
description: The Cuomo administration yesterday proposed an anti-drug plan that would double the amount New York State spends to fight substance abuse within the next few years.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in moderately active trading yesterday. Market participants said they were particularly encouraged by a rise in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Nov. 18 and a drop in an index that serves as a proxy for manufacturing activity in the Chicago area, a monthly survey of purchasing managers.

title: Scots Link Palestinian's Clothing To Pan Am Bombing, U.S. Says
description: The Scottish police investigating the terrorist bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet in 1988 have found further evidence in Sweden suggesting that a Palestinian known as Abu Talb helped carry out the bomb plot, the United States authorities said today.

title: McDaniel's 37 Points Lift Sonics Past Knicks
description: Xavier McDaniel scored 37 points, including 20 in the fourth quarter, leading the Seattle Supersonics past the Knicks, 127-122, tonight.

title: Market Place; The Beneficiaries Of Liberalization
description: WHILE some analysts are warning against a euphoric heralding of investment opportunities in Eastern Europe, many of them say West Germany stands the best chance of reaping big near-term gains from the changes.

title: Review/Art; War Seen Firsthand
description: The art that recorded Britain's passage through two devastating World Wars doesn't get a lot of space in books about this century's art. It is not abstract; it tends toward works on paper rather than big, impressive paintings; some of it verges on propaganda, some on illustration. It was frequently made by artists who did not go on to bigger and better things.

title: Pilot for Top Drug Trafficker Is Extradited by Colombians
description: The personal pilot of Pablo Escobar, one of the world's biggest cocaine traffickers, was extradited from Colombia to the United States today to face prosecution in a vast drug smuggling case, the United States Marshals Service announced.

title: Fernandez Sees a Star: It's P.S. 30
description: Joseph A. Fernandez, who will become New York City's schools chancellor next month, yesterday faced an audience that, in the end, will be the measure of his success here: the schoolchildren of New York.

title: Two on Board Face Charges About Hiring
description: Two officials of a local school board in Queens have been indicted on Federal and state charges of illegally using their positions to try to force the district Superintendent to place their relatives, political cronies and friends in school jobs, law-enforcement authorities announced yesterday.

title: Review/Music; A Pianist's Russian Flair
description: For his first recital at Carnegie Hall, on Tuesday night, the pianist Yefim Bronfman seemed to be staking a claim to the sort of sober, serious Germanic repertory long championed by Rudolf Serkin and, before him, Artur Schnabel. But curiously, after a deft opening Haydn sonata, his most successful outing came at the end, with Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrushka.''

title: Destiny in Air, Leaders Arrive For the Summit
description: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived today on this Mediterranean island for a summit conference beginning on Saturday during which both hope to start the search for a new world order.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Home Health Care
description: The holidays are a time for family gatherings, and for many families with elderly relatives, it might also be a good time to discuss what can be a difficult subject: health care in the home. Planning ahead can prevent a desperate search for medical or custodial care for a person who could need such care in a hurry.

title: Your Money; How to Take Out I.R.A. Cash Early
description: Many people in their 50's and 60's - and a few even younger - would do well to begin orderly withdrawals from their I.R.A.'s and other qualified retirement plans before the end of the year. The accounts can provide needed cash for those who have taken early retirement, for example, and withdrawals can lower the long-term tax bite for those who have accumulated substantial sums.

title: U.S. Won't Retry Defendants In Bombing and Sedition Case
description: Federal prosecutors said today that they would not retry three people they called dangerous underground militants, ending the case more than three years and millions of dollars after it started.

title: Patents; A System for Avoiding Aircraft Collisions
description: Engineers at Bendix/King Air Transport Avionics, a division of Allied-Signal Inc., have obtained a patent for the heart of a new onboard aircraft collision avoidance system.

title: Arlene R. Wolberg, 82, A Psychoanalyst, Dies
description: Arlene Robbins Wolberg, a psychoanalyst and an educator and author, died of a heart attack yesterday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mae West, Wilt and The King
description: Although Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is now gone from the sports scene, having retired last season after his 20th year in the National Basketball Association, his career scoring record of 38,387 points still lives, and, many believe, may live forever.

title: Patents; An Alarm for Wallets
description: Two Taiwanese inventors have patented a wallet containing a pickpocket alarm. The wallet features electrical contacts on each side, both of which are connected to a small battery and alarm circuit. If a pickpocket gets hold of the wallet on each side, his fingers close the circuit and trigger the alarm. Wen-tsung Lin and Sheng-chuan received patent 4,884,062.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our meeting today will hardly fail to have a powerful impact on world opinion. Not only is it something new and unusual. It will also be interpreted as singularly meaningful, a sign of the times that have slowly matured, a sign that is rich in promise.'' - Pope John Paul II, after his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 10:1. ]

title: Seeking Charities That Actually Help
description: Charity giving, a year-end tradition, has become a high-pressure sweepstakes. And as the competition for donations grows, some organizations are increasingly turning to telephone marketing and even some deceptive strategies to raise funds.

title: Kellogg Outlook
description: The Kellogg Company said it expects 1989 earnings to fall short of last year's record $3.90 a share.
