The estimate excludes a gain from a change in accounting for income taxes put into effect in January that resulted in a one-time credit of $48.1 million, or 39 cents a share. Kellogg said its ready-to-eat cereal sales in the United States continue to fall below expectations. Foreign sales continue to show growth, the company said. The results for 1989 are expected to be announced in late January. Kellogg shares closed today at $71.125, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock exchange.

title: The Kremlin and the Vatican; Catholics and Communists: Trying to Bury a Bitter Past
description: Through much of the 20th century, Catholicism and Communism have appeared as titanic forces locked in combat, rival world faiths whose leaders in the Kremlin and the Vatican had no message for each other except mutual condemnation.

title: A Reversal By Brokers On Banks
description: In a move that industry experts say could lead to significant changes on Wall Street, the directors of the Securities Industry Association voted today to drop the group's longstanding opposition to allowing banks to enter the securities business.

title: I-78 Eastbound Lanes Open After Garbage Fire Damage
description: All five eastbound lanes of Interstate 78 that were severely damaged by a garbage fire in August were reopened for tonight's rush hour, officials said.

title: Workers Strike Bus Company Serving 13,000 in the Bronx
description: Drivers and mechanics for a bus company that provides 13,000 commuters with express service from the Bronx to Manhattan went on strike yesterday.

title: Pacific Telesis
description: Shares of Pacific Telesis Group, a major partner in a consortium bidding for West Germany's first private mobile telephone network, surged yesterday after press reports said the group would be awarded the multi-billion-dollar deal. Pactel shares jumped $2.25 to close at $48.125 in active New York Stock Exchange trading. Shares in Mannesmann A.G., which is heading the bidding group, posted a 10 percent gain in trading in Frankfurt. The West German press reports said the group had been chosen from among 10 bidders by a commission of experts advising the Government. A decision is due by Dec. 12.

title: R. W. McLuaghlin, 89, Architecture Professor
description: Robert William McLaughlin, emeritus professor of architecture at Princeton University's School of Architecture, died Thursday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: M. Hughes Miller, 76; A Publishing Executive
description: M. Hughes Miller, former president of Bobbs Merrill Company, the book publisher, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Joseph Medical Center. He was 76 years old.

title: About New York; Q101 Bus Carries Help for Youths On Rikers Island
description: Jim Nolan is a teacher who was assigned to Intermediate School 74 in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx 15 years ago. The landscape is one of vacant lots and shattered dreams, but Mr. Nolan saw reason to stay.

title: Councilman Williams
description: So that Reggie Williams would not have to miss a practice for tomorrow's key game with the Cleveland Browns, the Cincinnati Bengals staged a City Council swearing-in ceremony at their training site yesterday. The veteran linebacker was sworn in as an elected member of the Council in a conference room at the Bengals' field because he could not spare the time to attend the official swearing-in at City Hall with the eight other council members.

title: Reviews/Pop; Soukous Band From Zaire Shows Influences of Rock
description: A dancing midget named Emoro brought a touch of novelty to the Zairian soukous of Pepe Kalle on Thursday night at Kilimanjaro, 531 West 19th Street, where they are appearing through tonight. Mr. Emoro shared the band's dance routines, swiveled his hips and even danced while standing on his head, stepping to the beat with his legs in midair. But the show's real pleasures came from Empire Bakuba, Mr. Kalle's band, whose twining guitar lines and light but irresistible beat made every song sparkle.

title: Review/Ballet; 'Nutcracker' Recalls the Young Balanchine
description: The New York City Ballet's exquisite production of ''The Nutcracker'' helped establish the ballet as a holiday tradition in America. Why does the production, first presented in 1954, stand out so from the rest?

title: China's Chile Investment
description: The state-owned China Corporation for Agricultural Credit and Investment has bought a 25.6 percent share in a Chilean fishery for $18.6 million. The move is the largest Chinese investment in Latin America, the People's Daily newspaper reported today. It said the fishery produces 3.57 million boxes of canned fish a year.

title: No Headline
description: * American Business Journals Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a publisher of business periodicals, said it had purchased The Business Journal, a newspaper in Phoenix. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism
description: To the Editor: I am deeply grateful to Brendan Gill for detailing in public what many of us at Sarah Lawrence College privately knew all along about Joseph Campbell. Because Campbell has been proposed as a sage for our times, it is particularly important for those of us who have a different estimate of the man and his work to speak up. Mr. Gill's account of Campbell's scholarship, his politics and his views seems to me accurate. I offer a single anecdote from my experience by way of verifying his anti-Semitism.

title: For One Board Member, Limelight Is Nothing New
description: For Samuel Granirer, a 48-year-old management consultant accused of extortion and bribery, yesterday was not the first time that his activities with his local school board in Queens had thrust him into the limelight.

title: Time for You to Step Down, Mr. Ceausescu
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Cast Its Vote for a Mayor of Principle
description: To the Editors:

title: Port Authority Proposes $1 Increase in Tolls
description: The chief of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that he was recommending a $1 toll increase on all six of its bridges and tunnels and a 25-cent fare rise on PATH, the underground commuter rail system.

title: Man Found Guilty in Narcotics Officer's Death
description: A drug dealer charged with the murder last year of an undercover New York City narcotics officer on the Upper West Side was convicted of the slaying yesterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Lear Jet Again Seeking For Potential Suitors
description: The Lear Jet Corporation is scouting for potential buyers again after the Chrysler Corporation decided against acquiring the manufacturer of business jets.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Pinnacle Bid By Pacificorp
description: Pacificorp, rebuffed in its effort to acquire a utility owned by the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, offered today to buy all of Pinnacle West.

title: Dominick P. Felitti, Government Official, 83
description: Dominick P. Felitti, a retired government official who worked at the city, state and Federal levels, died Wednesday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Music; Sinopoli on the Philharmonic Podium
description: Giuseppe Sinopoli's guest-conducting engagements with the New York Philharmonic, begun in 1983, have steadily increased in interest. After taking a medical degree and practicing for a time as a surgeon and psychiatrist, the Italian polymath earned a reputation as an avant-garde composer. He turned to the serious study of conducting in the early 1970's. Now, at age 43, he ranks among the most sought-after international maestros.

title: Kabul Journal; Now on the Beaten Path: A Jail With a Bloody Past
description: If future generations of Afghans want a museum of the brutalities wrought here in the name of the Communist revolution, they need look no further than the fortress of Pul-i-Charkhi, sitting squat and menacing in the valley 10 miles east of Kabul.

title: Rep. Brooks Out of Hospital
description: Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, was released from the Bethesda Naval Medical Center today, where he had been treated there since Oct. 22 for inflammation of the pancreas, his office announced. The 66-year-old Congressman is expected to return to a full schedule, his staff said.

title: Sabres Beat the Devils With Two Late Goals
description: Dave Snuggerud broke a 4-4 tie at 15 minutes 23 seconds of the third period tonight and Pierre Turgeon had his first hat trick to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 6-4 victory over the Devils.

title: U.S. Seeking 'Honorable Exit' for Lebanese General
description: Bush Administration officials said today that they are working behind the scenes to help peacefully ease the Lebanese Christian army commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, out of the presidential palace so that Lebanon's newly elected President can finally take charge.

title: Warriors Cut Johnson
description: The Golden State Warriors have requested waivers on Marques Johnson, the forward who was attempting an N.B.A. comeback after a layoff caused by a neck injury in November 1986, while he was with the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: The New Rush Hours: All Day Saturday
description: More and more, drivers encounter the worst traffic congestion not during commuters' rush hours but on Saturdays, the day for errands and shopping.

title: Ransom H. Skeen, Executive, 88
description: Ransom Harris Skeen, a retired executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank and Chase International Corporation, died of an aneurysm Thursday at Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 88 years old and had lived in Bronxville, N.Y., for many years before moving to Winter Park in 1987.

title: Cineplex Chief Quits
description: The chairman of the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, Garth Drabinsky, resigned today from the entertainment company he built into North America's second-largest movie theater chain.

title: Patents; A Robot Said to Learn Like a Baby
description: A Massachusetts computer scientist patented his ''baby'' this week, a robot called Infant that he says is modeled on the way a human baby learns motor skills.

title: The Kremlin and the Vatican; Comments at Vatican By Pope and Gorbachev
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Pope John Paul II and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union at their meeting today at the Vatican, as translated by the Vatican: POPE'S STATEMENT

title: Leading Indicators Down by 0.4% in October
description: In another sign of a slackening economy, the Government's main forecasting index fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the fifth decline so far this year.

title: NETS END A SLUMP BY ROUTING MIAMI
description: After three agonizing weeks without winning, the Nets found nothing wrong tonight with their 101-77 victory over the Miami Heat.

title: Bridge
description: Intercollegiate competition is showing welcome signs of revival in New York City. A five-team event was played on Sept. 27 at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, and two City College teams tied for first place.

title: 'From Malta to Yalta'
description: LEAD: There is a lovely historical symmetry to President Bush's meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev off the coast of Malta. Many observers see the meeting, coming as it does in the wake of the heady events in Eastern Europe, as an opportuniy to begin the reshaping of postwar Europe, which was created, in part, at the conference at Yalta.

title: Clamor in Europe; New Chief of Czech TV Says Propaganda Role Is Ending
description: His face had not appeared on state television since 1968, and when his name was mentioned it was to denounce him.

title: Saab Said to Bar Offer by Volvo
description: Volvo said it made an informal proposal to take over its rival Swedish motor company, Saab-Scania, earlier this year, but the offer was rejected. Pehr Gyllenhammar, chairman of Volvo, said in a statement that he had made the offer to Peter Wallenberg, head of two investment firms that are major stockholders in Saab-Scania, after the company disclosed problems in its car division. Mr. Gyllenhammar said that he had made the offer in the hopes of creating a strong car industry in Sweden. Possible terms were not disclosed.

title: Hooker Corp. Plan Dropped
description: Lo Yuk-Sui, a Hong Kong real estate owner and developer, said yesterday that he had abandoned his plan to acquire the L. J. Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer with large retailing interests in the United States.

title: William P. Hoffman, A Stockbroker, 100
description: William P. Hoffman, a stockbroker who from 1917 to 1965 was a member of the New York Curb Exchange and its successor, the American Stock Exchange, died on Nov. 18, 10 days before his 101st birthday, at his home in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new insider-trading case, brought against an employee of a contractor for Business Week magazine, misstated the penalty given S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman, former Business Week broadcast editor. He was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $5,000 on two criminal counts, and agreed to pay an additional $41,000 in civil fines and restitution.

title: Hypocrisy on H.U.D.
description: Congress has been in high dudgeon all year over political favoritism and influence-peddling in the Department of Housing and Urban Development. But the H.U.D. appropriations bill suggests that lawmakers were upset less with the practice than with the practitioners. Passing out pork, it seems, is their prerogative.

title: Top Award To Kingdom
description: Roger Kingdom, the two-time Olympic hurdles champion who last summer broke Renaldo Nehemiah's eight-year-old world record for the 110-meter event, got the annual Jesse Owens Memorial Award tonight, the highest honor in American track and field.

title: Patents; A Means That May Aid In Diagnosing Cancer
description: Probing the nucleus of human cells, two scientists in Massachusetts have patented a technology they believe makes it easier to diagnose cancer.

title: Dorothy E. Rowe, Venture Capitalist, 72
description: Dorothy E. Rowe, former senior vice president of the American Research and Development Corporation, died Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 72 years old and lived in Boston.

title: East German Charter Changed
description: The Parliament amended the Constitution to eliminate the Communist Party's monopoly on power. Page 9.

title: Public Pension Funds Tempt States in Need
description: The State Treasurer, Catherine Baker Knoll, sees Pennsylvania as a state with a fragile economy and a public pension fund that is bulging with $25 billion. To help the economy, she wants the fund's managers to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in local real estate, state highways and bridges and new businesses, especially those started by women and members of minorities.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about kitchen equipment gave incorrect dimensions for Le Smoker. It is 11 inches high, 13 inches wide and 23 inches long.

title: The Malta Summit; East Berlin Amends Constitution, Loosening Communist Hold
description: East Germany's Parliament amended the country's Constitution today, eliminating the clause that assigned the leading political role to the Communist Party.

title: Christians in the Soviet Union
description: About half the Soviet Union's 286 million people profess a religious affiliation. In addition to the groups cited below, there are 40 million to 50 million Muslims, 1.8 million to 2 million Jews and 665,000 Buddhists. Figures for adherents are Western estimates. RUSSIAN ORTHODOX: 50-60 million adherents

title: Becker And Lendl Advance
description: The twin superpowers of men's tennis, Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, flicked away short-lived challenges from Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe last night to advance to the semifinals of the Masters with matching 3-0 records. They completed the week with their egos in matching form as well.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Weekender Guide column of Weekend yesterday about a benefit on Sunday for the Madison Avenue Christmas for Children Fund gave the information phone number incorrectly. It is 988-4001.

title: Security Lapses Uncovered At a Youth Detention Center
description: Security and fire-safety deficiencies at a state Division for Youth center in Columbia County threaten the juvenile offenders who live there, Comptroller Edward Regan said today.

title: Books of The Times; Defining the Western, and Two Current Examples
description: Come Winter By Douglas C. Jones 418 pages. Donald Hutter Book/Henry Holt. $19.95 Outlaw By Warren Kiefer 518 pages. Donald I. Fine Inc. $19.95.

title: INDIAN OPPOSITION CHOOSES A PREMIER
description: V. P. Singh won the unanimous backing of the victorious political opposition today and will be sworn in as the eighth Prime Minister of India at noon on Saturday, the office of the President said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: Two tables yesterday showing arms levels in Eastern and Western Europe, part of a page of charts giving background to the summit meeting in Malta, were described incompletely. The left-hand table labeled ''Conventional Arms'' gave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's estimate and the Warsaw Pact's estimate of European military strength in NATO countries. The right-hand table labeled ''Conventional Arms'' gave the two organizations' estimates for the European military strength in the Warsaw Pact countries.

title: Navajo Chairman's Son Pleads Not Guilty
description: The son of Peter MacDonald, the suspended Navajo chairman, pleaded not guilty to two counts of conspiracy today in a tribal court at which he had failed to appear for two arraignments last month.

title: Frank Cardi, Golf Official, 56
description: Frank Cardi, a former president of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association, died on Thursday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 56 years old.

title: Treasury Issues in a Modest Advance
description: Despite more reports suggesting that the economy has weakened, prices of Treasury securities rose only modestly in light trading yesterday.

title: Saying No To Good News
description: Network news people say the biggest good-news story of the modern age, which is the story of Communism's falling dominoes, is box-office poison. TV ratings depict Americans tuning out in droves despite television's wonderfully moving pictures of freedom sweeping everything before it.

title: Clamor in Europe; In August '68, It Was Tanks vs. Car Horns
description: As the invading Soviet tanks rumbled through the streets of Prague early on Aug. 21, 1968, local youths honked their car horns in raucous, unavailing protest.

title: AQUINO'S FORCES SEEM TO PREVAIL IN MANILA BATTLE
description: Forces loyal to President Corazon C. Aquino appeared to be turning back an army rebellion today after seizing rebel-held military camps and television stations with the aid of American warplanes.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Serving Game Birds
description: Game birds, extremely lean and low in fat, are becoming increasingly popular, especially for holiday meals. Those sold at retail or served in restaurants are raised on farms or ranches and do not have a strong, ''gamey'' flavor. It's illegal to sell domestically hunted game, but a small amount of shot game is coming in from Scotland, particularly grouse and pheasant. Woodcock is not available commercially, but licensed hunters with permits can shoot them. When roasted or grilled, game birds should be basted, and those with dark flesh cooked no more than medium-rare. Dark-fleshed birds have a rich, almost beefy flavor. Light-flesh birds are closer in flavor to chicken. Overcooking will make any game bird tough and dry. Braising and stewing are other cooking methods. Here's a guide to how many birds you will need for a serving. $ Bird Meat Color Birds per Serving Quail Dark Two to three Squab Dark One Grouse Dark One Woodcock Dark One Partridge Light One Guinea hen Light Half Mallard duck Dark Half Pheasant Light One-third to a half Muscovy duck Dark Up to a quarter Wild turkey Dark Up to one-sixth

title: Teen-Ager Slain Trying to Shield Brother From Bullies
description: Arnulfo Williams Jr. was the kind of big brother most children would love. He watched out for his two younger brothers, drove them to school in the morning and stood by them when they were threatened by other teen-agers on the violent streets of South Jamaica, Queens.

title: Alvin Ailey, a Leading Figure In Modern Dance, Dies at 58
description: Alvin Ailey, who rose from a childhood of extreme poverty in the segregated world of small-town Texas to become a leading figure in the establishment of modern dance as a popular art form in America, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 58 years old. Dr. Albert Knapp, Mr. Ailey's physician, attributed his death to terminal blood dyscrasia, a rare disorder that affects the bone marrow and red blood cells.

title: Alfred J. Green, Dress Manufacturer, 78
description: Alfred J. Green, a women's apparel manufacturer and an owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: Chandler Brooks, 83, a Professor Of Physiology and a Researcher
description: Dr. Chandler McCuskey Brooks, an educator and a physiologist who researched the functions of the brain and heart, died on Wednesday when an automobile struck him outside his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Abitibi Cutback
description: Abitibi Price Inc. said it will close one of the three paper-making machines at its Grand Falls newsprint mill on March 1, terminating about 250 jobs. The machine being closed was installed in 1926 and is no longer competitive in a weakening market for newsprint, the company said.

title: Chief Staff Official Is Named At Nuclear Regulatory Panel
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday named James M. Taylor its chief staff official, the executive director for operations, replacing Victor Stello Jr., who has been nominated to head the bomb program at the Energy Department.

title: The Malta Summit: Notes on Malta; Presidents, Producers and Purveyors Converge in a Siege to End All Sieges
description: The summit meeting, whose goal is lasting peace, began, naturally, with a display of war power.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-11 The Vatican and the Soviet Union will move toward full diplomatic ties under an agreement reached by the Soviet President, Mikhail Gorbachev, and Pope John Paul II. The two met for about an hour at the Vatican. Page 1 Catholics and Communists: A long but not steady enmity 10 Ukrainian Catholic Church wins legal status after 43-year ban 10 Philippine government warplanes mistakenly bombed pro-Government troops and civilians, killing at least six people. Troops loyal to President Corazon Aquino had appeared earlier to have turned back the rebellion with the aid of American warplanes. 1 The decision to use American planes against Philippine rebel forces was made by President Bush after he was told that President Aquino might be overthrown, officials said. 1 Philippine coup plot is linked to earlier plots 6 Presidents Bush and Gorbachev arrived in Malta on the eve of a summit conference. Their meeting has no formal agenda, but comes at a historic moment when nearly all aspects of relations are open for discussion. 1 Images of the Soviet Union in American advertisments have long followed the course of diplomatic ties between the countries. Now, the message is simple: The Russians are just like us. 33 The Soviet-led invasion of Prague that crushed the reform movement of 1968 was ''wrong,'' the new Politburo of the Czechoslovak Communist Party declared. 1 Czech witnesses stray and an inquiry falters 8 Hopes rise in a Czechsolovak community in New Jersey 31 The Communist Party's leading role in East German politics was abolished when Parliament amended the country's Constitution. 9 Killing of West German bank chief seen as well-planned 11 India has a new Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, who won the unanimous backing of the political opposition. He will head only the second government in 42 years of Indian independence not under the control of the Congress Party. 5 Lebanon's Maronite Catholic leaders are trying to defuse tensions between the new Syrian-backed Lebanese President, Elias Hrawi, and the defiant Christian commander of the armed forces, Gen. Michel Aoun. 3 The U.S. is urging a peaceful solution to the political standoff in Lebanon by trying to persuade Lebanon's newly elected President to allow Gen. Aoun an ''honorable exit'' without using force. 3 Leftist guerrillas in El Salvador have begun using Soviet-made anti-aircraft missiles against Government helicopters for the first time in the 10-year civil war, President Cristiani said. 7 National 12-13, 28 A Pennsylvania public pension fund could help the state's fragile economy through investments in local real estate, state highways and bridges and new businesses, the State Treasurer says. 1 The main forecasting index for the economy fell four-tenths of 1 percent in October. It was the fifth decline this year and another sign of a slackening economy. 33 Refusal to disclose classified data needed in criminal cases could create a category of high-level intelligence agents immune from prosecution, the Iran-contra prosecutor says. 12 ''A Day Without Art'' was observed across the United States by about 600 museums, galleries and other art institutions to call attention to the AIDS crisis. 12 A much-picketed abortion clinic in Pennsylvania has invited anti-abortion leaders to talk with patients in counseling sessions inside the building rather than scream slogans at them outside. 13 Plutonium that collected in ducts at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant was enough of a concern to close the plant indefinitely, the Secretary of Energy said. 12 Company safety scrutinized in crane collapse 28 Stiff fines sought for having small amounts of drugs 13 Chicago housing agency plans midnight basketball league 13 Regional 29-32 A teen-ager was shot and killed while trying to protect his younger brother from three bullies at a school bus stop in South Jamaica, Queens. 29 Two school officials were indicted on charges of illegally using their positions on the board of Community School District 27 in Queens to give friends and relatives school jobs. One pleaded guilty, officials said. 29 Queens man indicted yesterday has been in limelight before 31 New York's new Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, visited a New York City school for the first time and met with students, district administrators, civic leaders and members of the State Assembly. 31 The worst urban traffic congestion that commuters across the country face is not always during weekday rush hours but on Saturdays, the day for errands and shopping. 29 A $1 rise in bridge and tunnel tolls and a 25-cent fare increase on PATH trains was recommended by the chief of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 29 New token fare of $1.15 asked in transit plan 30 Workers strike bus company serving 13,000 in the Bronx 31 Brooklyn drug dealer gets seven consecutive life terms 30 Man guilty in officer's slaying 30 Neediest Cases 32

title: Assets Drop At Savings Institutions
description: The assets of the nation's savings and loan institutions continued to shrink significantly in September in preparation for tough financial standards that take effect next week, the Government said today.

title: CZECH PARTY CALLS '68 INVASION WRONG
description: The new Politburo of the Czechoslovak Communist Party declared today that the Soviet-led invasion that choked the Prague Spring of 1968 was wrong.

title: Ahmadou Ahidjo Of Cameroon Dies; Ex-Leader Was 65
description: Ahmadou Ahidjo, who served as President of the West African nation of Cameroon for 22 years after it won independence from France in 1960, then fled into exile in 1983, died on Thursday in Dakar, Senegal, according to a French radio report quoted by the Reuters news agency.

title: Two Flyers Sign Again
description: Mark Howe, a defenseman, and Derrick Smith, a left wing, signed new contracts with the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday. The team did not disclose the terms, but Howe said he would earn $1.925 million over the next three years.

title: When Opera Was a Lark: Six Divas Tell All
description: Singing opera 50 years ago was a friendlier experience than it is today, and the scenery didn't upstage the singers, say the six divas who are to take part in the Met Marathon on radio this afternoon.

title: Editors' Note
description: A chronology on Wednesday under the headline ''An Outline of German History'' gave pivotal dates in the growth of German nationalism and the efforts toward unification since the early 19th century. It amplified a report about the vision of reunification offered by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. Through an editing lapse by The Times, the material, provided by Reuters, skipped from 1918 to 1945 in most copies, omitting the rise of Hitler and Nazi rule. The material was added in a late edition.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Christmas for Children Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow between 66th and 72d Streets from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Search for Lobstermen Called Off
description: The Coast Guard ended its search today for the five-member crew of a lobster boat that has been missing for 11 days.

title: INSIDE
description: New Leader for India

title: Chicago Housing Agency Plans Night Basketball League for Gangs
description: The city's public housing agency is planning a midnight basketball league in the hope of attracting gang members and of easing tension in some tough neighborhoods.

title: Iran-Contra Prosecutor Says Secrecy Issue Blocks Justice
description: In his harshest criticism of the Bush Administration to date, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra cases says the Government's refusal to allow disclosure of classified information could create a category of high intelligence officials who are immune from prosecution.

title: A $1.15 Token Now Supported By Transit Staff
description: The staff of the New York City Transit Authority has revised a plan on subway and bus fares and is now proposing that the agency raise the price of a token to $1.15 from $1, but without offering discounts on bulk sales, a spokesman said last night.

title: Dow Soars 41.38, to 2,747.65; Interest Rate Hopes a Factor
description: Stock prices registered their biggest gain in weeks yesterday, buoyed by heavy foreign and institutional buying.

title: Miniscribe Layoffs
description: The Miniscribe Corporation said it will take a $40 million restructuring charge in its current quarter. The company said the first step in its restructuring included the layoff of 110 employees. It said it expects to lay off more employees at the beginning of March. Miniscribe, a maker of disk drives for microcomputer systems, also said that once the restructuring was completed its Longmont headquarters would house only administrative and sales operations and all final assembly of products would be done at a plant in Singapore.

title: Executive Weds Dr. Aisemberg, A Psychologist
description: Dr. Patricia Aisemberg and Martin Varsavsky were married last evening at their New York home by Justice Carmen Ciparick of State Supreme Court in New York. The bride, 29 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Manuel Aisemberg of Buenos Aires. Her husband, also 29, is the son of Silvia Waisman of Buenos Aires and the late Dr. Carlos M. Varsavsky.

title: Anniversary Tribute to Neediest Cases Fund
description: In December 1939, Alfred I. Jaffe paid $2 for a license to marry Mimi Muschat. ''Several years ago, I decided to make my annual contribution a tribute to my wife on our anniversary,'' Mr. Jaffe, who now lives in Somers, N.Y., wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I donated $2 for every year we were married, the $2 representing the original cost of our license.''

title: Purchasers Say Economy Worsens
description: The economy, hurt by declines in production, new orders and employment, continued to deteriorate in November for the seventh consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday as it released its monthly index of economic activity.

title: Not the First Coup, and Maybe Not the Last
description: Throughout the fighting in the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino, no group or figure stepped forward to claim leadership of the rebellion.

title: Angels and Langston Agree on $16 Million
description: In the ever-escalating world of baseball economics, Mark Langston is the latest highest-paid player in the game's history.

title: Taylor's Ankle Is Broken, but He Feels Better
description: The Giants' Lawrence Taylor has a broken right ankle, two sources with the team disclosed today. At the same time, in what seemed to be a contradiction, Coach Bill Parcells upgraded the linebacker's availability from out to doubtful for the game here Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Hassan Fathy, Architect, 89
description: Hassan Fathy, an Egyptian architect who championed the use of indigenous construction techniques to build housing for the world's poor, died Thursday in Cairo, the Associated Press reported. He was 89 years old.

title: Time for You to Step Down, Mr. Ceausescu; Troops Out of Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama's Perfect Record Is at Stake in Matchup at Auburn
description: ''My life does not begin and end with football victories, but coaching is my profession and we all dream of perfect seasons,'' said Bill Curry of Alabama.

title: Taiwan Rigs Its Election
description: LEAD: Taiwan holds elections today. True, it is the first time opposition candidates can seek office as members of political parties. Nonetheless, we can expect the elections, for the National Assembly and for city and county government posts, to contain dishonesty. While we applaud Eastern Europe's democratic changes, the U.S., which has great influence in Taiwan, has done very little to encourage democracy in Taiwan.

title: When Pets Are Put Up for Adoption, Not All Animal Shelters Are Alike
description: Winter is generally the busiest time of the year for animal shelters. People often decide to adopt pets during the holiday season, only to discover later that they cannot cope with the responsibilities of pet ownership.

title: Salvadoran President Says Rebels Are Firing Antiaircraft Missiles
description: President Alfredo Cristiani said today that leftist guerrillas had begun to use sophisticated antiaircraft missiles against Government warplanes for the first time in their 10-year civil war.

title: U.N. Postpones Vote On Palestinian State
description: Arab members of the United Nations agreed today to postpone until Monday a General Assembly vote on a resolution prepared by the Palestine Liberation Organization that would recognize the existence of a state of Palestine in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Building Outlays Up In October
description: Bolstered by the first gain in single-family home building in nine months, construction spending climbed modestly in October, and analysts said the improvement suggested lower interest rates were helping end a construction slump.

title: Church Mediating in Lebanese Strife
description: The Maronite Catholic Church continued efforts today to bridge the gap between the new Syrian-backed Lebanese President, Elias Hrawi, and the defiant commander of the armed forces, Gen. Michel Aoun. Bishop Basil Hashem of the Maronite church has been shuttling between Baabda, where General Aoun is entrenched with 1,000 troops surrounded by thousands of civilian supporters, and an army barracks in Syrian-controlled eastern Lebanon, where President Hrawi has established an office.

title: Company Safety Scrutinized in Crane Collapse
description: The company operating a crane that killed five people when it fell 16 stories in San Francisco on Tuesday had such a poor safety record that its own employees complained to state labor officials here about workplace hazards.

title: Prague's Drama Brings Tears in New Jersey City
description: The night she first saw the television newscasts showing hundreds of thousands of people demonstrating for freedom in Czechoslovakia, Vera Hudak cried.

title: The Jogger
description: The young woman who was raped, beaten and left for dead this spring in Central Park is known to most New Yorkers only as ''the jogger.'' For a rape victim to want to remain anonymous, and for the media to keep her so, is not unusual. Rape, even today, stigmatizes.

title: Beatrice Rosenberg; Prominent Attorney For the U.S. Was 81
description: Beatrice Rosenberg, a lawyer who held high positions in the Federal Government and argued more than 30 cases before the Supreme Court, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. She was 81 years old and had moved to Silver Spring from Washington two years ago.

title: Measured Mission in Manila
description: President Bush made a timely and sensible call when he sent American warplanes on ''combat air patrol'' in the Philippines yesterday. The mission served as a deterrent, helping President Corazon Aquino's democratic Government fight off a dangerous military rebellion while conforming to principled American policy.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Must You Actually Read The Books to Give the Prize?
description: Robert L. Heilbroner, the chairman of the nonfiction panel for this year's National Book Awards, evoked scattered murmurs and hisses at the awards ceremony on Wednesday when he said he had not read most of the 190 books submitted for the prize. Instead, he said, he narrowed his selections with such shortcuts as reading the first and last pages of some books, looking at blurbs and examining the index and table of contents.

title: New From the Met: Broadcasts of Old
description: Although pirated copies of Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, with wildly varying sound, have been available for many years, the company has begun a series of official releases of broadcasts of special distinction, high-priced as a fund-raising device.

title: Owens and Thompson Lift Syracuse
description: Billy Owens and Stephen Thompson scored 21 points each tonight as Syracuse used an early 21-4 run to rout Virginia Commonwealth, 100-73, and move into the final of the Carrier Classic.

title: Complaints on Phone And Mail Orders Decline
description: To the Editor: You state in ''Caveats on Ordering by Phone'' (Consumer's World page, Nov. 4) that ''Nationwide, mail and phone orders make up for the greatest number of complaints received by Better Business Bureaus.''

title: A Soft Red Glow on Madison Ave.
description: In American marketing, the Russian bear has become a pussycat.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Soldiers in Europe's House
description: By encouraging independence in Eastern Europe and withholding Soviet support for Tiananmen-style crackdowns, Mikhail Gorbachev gives preliminary shape to the political and economic arrangements he has in mind for a ''common European home.'' His ideas for the military arrangements -which he might discuss this weekend with President Bush - can only be guessed at, but there are some clear principles to keep in mind.

title: Perkin-Elmer Sale Fought
description: Two members of Congress have asked President Bush to invoke a law that they co-sponsored to block the sale of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's semiconductor division to a Japanese company on the ground that it would jeopardize national security.

title: Fidelity Lifts Minimums For Fund Investments
description: In a move to cut its administrative expenses, Fidelity Investments, one of the nation's largest mutual fund firms, is raising the minimum investment in its funds to $2,500, from $1,000. The firm will also raise the minimum amount that current investors must maintain in these accounts to $1,000, from $500.

title: 5 Believed Dead in Crash of an Army Plane
description: A twin-engine Army cargo plane with four crew members and a civilian on board crashed into a river this morning as it was approaching the Patuxent Naval Air Station near this southern Maryland community. No survivors were found.

title: Carpathians Were a Cradle of Scientists
description: To the Editor:

title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh proposed regulations today that would allow the Government to impose civil fines of up to $10,000 for possessing small amounts of marijuana and other illegal drugs for personal use.

title: Shopping For a Tree
description: Of the 35 million cut trees that will be sold this Christmas, slightly more than a third will be Scotch pines, the National Christmas Tree Association says. Next in popularity are Douglas firs, followed by two other top sellers: balsam firs and white pines.

title: Alan Bowne, Writer, 44
description: Alan Bowne, a playwright and author, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home outside Petaluma, Calif. He was 44 years old.

title: GORBACHEV VISITS POPE AT VATICAN; TIES ARE FORGED
description: With an agreement to begin official relations and a pledge of expanded religious freedom for Soviet citizens, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev joined hands today with Pope John Paul II.

title: A Drug Dealer Gets a Sentence Of 7 Life Terms
description: A 30-year-old drug dealer who ran one of the largest and most violent drug rings in Brooklyn and was responsible for 6 murders, 17 assaults, a kidnapping, a maiming and other crimes, was sentenced yesterday to seven consecutive life terms in Federal prison.

title: Soccer Top 4 Are Stingy
description: The semifinalists in the final four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament, who will play Saturday at Rutgers Stadium, have combined for 45 shutouts this season. Santa Clara (19-0-2), the only unbeaten team in the tournament, has 14 shutouts. The team's goalie, Eric Yamamoto, has 13 of those and has allowed only 7 goals in 21 games.

title: Energy Secretary Says Rocky Flats Will Be Closed Indefinitely
description: James D. Watkins, the Secretary of Energy, expressed concern today about plutonium that had escaped and collected in the ventilation ducts at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in Colorado, and said the plant would not reopen until conditions there had been proved safe.

title: The Malta Summit; Armenia Votes to Join With Disputed Area
description: The Armenian Parliament voted today to unite with Nagorno-Karabakh and denounced a decision by Moscow to hand back control of the disputed territory to the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, Armenian journalists said.

title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Hits Toll-Taker, Races 6 Miles; Chase Ends as Driver Is Shot Dead
description: A man who led authorities on a wild six-mile car chase after his van struck a police officer at the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel toll booths was shot dead as the chase ended on the Belt Parkway during the evening rush hour yesterday.

title: Beckenbauer Leaving
description: Franz Beckenbauer will quit as manager of the West German national team after the World Cup in Italy next year, the head of the West German soccer federation, Hermann Neuberger, said yesterday in Frankfurt. Neuberger said Beckenbauer, who coached the team to a runner-up finish in the 1986 World Cup, would become a marketing executive for the federation.

title: Abu Nidal Was Born In British Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: No Joint Offer for Ferranti
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. and Thomson-CSF, a French military contractor, said today that they were no longer interested in making a joint bid for Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., a British electronics company.

title: HomeFed to Lift Loan-Loss Fund
description: The HomeFed Corporation, parent company of the HomeFed Bank, said it will add $115 million to its loan-loss provisions in the fourth quarter. ''These general allowances will provide HomeFed greater flexibility to reduce its level of nonperforming assets and restructure its loan and real estate portfolios,'' said Kim Fletcher, chairman of the San Diego-based savings and loan association. ''These new provisions do not represent an addition to specific loss allowances, but instead will increase the company's level of general loss allowances.''

title: The Kremlin and the Vatican; Ukrainian Catholic Church Wins Right to Register After 43 Years
description: Officials in the Ukraine have announced that they will register congregations of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, which was forcibly dissolved 43 years ago, church members said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a mistrial in a sedition trial in Springfield, Mass., misstated the defendants' records. Two defendants - Raymond Luc

title: Chevrolet Rebate
description: The General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division said it had increased the rebate on 1989-90 full-size Blazer and Suburban light trucks to $1,000 from $750. The increase is in effect until Feb. 2. Chevrolet said it had also extended until Feb. 2 the $500 incentive on certain models of pickup trucks and its 1989 Astro van.

title: Abortion Foes Get Offer To Hear Clinic Patients
description: The owner of a much-picketed birthing center here that also does abortions has invited anti-abortion leaders to come inside to talk with his patients in counseling sessions rather than scream slogans at them outside.

title: KEY RATES
Review/Pop; A Home Away From Home For the Jazz of New Orleans
description: The New Orleans Traditional Jazz Conservation Band, a sextet that plays the music of Jelly Roll Morton, Louis Armstrong, Kid Ory and other early New Orleans jazz musicians, opened a three-week engagement this week at Michael's Pub, playing Tuesdays through Saturdays. With Woody Allen's New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Band playing every Monday night at Michael's Pub, as it has for the last 17 years, the East 55th Street restaurant will be a hotbed of New Orleans jazz for the next three weeks (through Dec. 16).

title: Serge Korff, Physicist, Dies at 83; Pioneer in Cosmic Ray Research
description: Serge A. Korff, a physicist who led worldwide observations of cosmic rays in the 1940's and 1950's, using balloons, aircraft and mountaintop observatories, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

title: A Neanderthal Law on AIDS
description: LEAD: Not long ago, one of us set off with some friends from Montreal to spend a day in Vermont. The drive should have taken an hour but ended up taking an afternoon, because the party was detained at the border for an investigation by U.S. customs and immigration officials.

title: 'Very Happy' Comaneci Arrives in New York
description: Three days after she stole across a closed border into Hungary, Nadia Comaneci, the Rumanian gymnast who captivated the world with a series of perfect performances at the 1976 Olympics, arrived in New York yesterday and explained why she had risked arrest to leave her homeland and come to the United States. ''I wanted to have a free life,'' she said. Comaneci, who was granted refugee status yesterday morning by American officials at the United States Embassy in Vienna, where she had gone from Hungary, made her remark at a brief and clamorous news conference at the Pan American World Airways Terminal in Kennedy International Airport late yesterday afternoon. She had arrived on a flight from Vienna about an hour earlier. Roses From the Crowd

title: PBS FILM ABOUT WEST BANK WAS DONE WITH ISRAELI HELP
description: A public-television documentary examining Israeli perspectives on the uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories was financed with help from the Israeli consul general in New York, an executive producer of the film said yesterday.

title: Innovative Steel Mill Is Off to a Slow Start
description: These should have been heady days for F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman of the Nucor Corporation and a man celebrated for teaching Big Steel a thing or two about operating mills more efficiently.

title: Clamor in Europe: Reporter's Notebook; Czech Witnesses Stray And an Inquiry Falters
description: The official inquiry into the beating of student demonstrators two weeks ago has run into difficulty since those who were witnesses are not eager to tell what they saw to those who are doing the investigating.

title: UAL Up $12.50 On ESOP Talk
description: The stock of the UAL Corporation rose $12.50 yesterday, to $174 a share, on reports that the company would soon begin talks with its unions and employees about putting together a new employee stock ownwership plan. In a memo to employees, Paul George, senior vice president of human resources for the company, warned that putting together a new plan involved many ''uncertainties which may affect our ability to complete a new ESOP successfully.''

title: Gorbachev Visits Pope at Vatican; Ties Are Forged
description: ROME, Dec. 1  With an agreement to begin official relations and a pledge of expanded religious freedom for Soviet citizens, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev joined hands today with Pope John Paul II.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Four Teams Share Lead: Kenny Perry and Sherri Turner shot an eight-under-par 64 to share the lead with three other teams yesterday after the second round of the J. C. Penney Golf Classic in Largo, Fla. Also tied for first at 10-under 134 were Bill Britton and Donna White, Andy Bean and Laura Davies and Mike Hulbert and Val Skinner.(AP) Zembriski Ahead: Walter Zembriski had a two-under-par 68 in the second round yesterday to take sole possession of first place in the G.T.E. West Classic in Ojai, Calif. Zembriski had a 36-hole total of eight-under-par 132 heading into the final round today. George Archer had a hole-in-one in his round of 64, which tied the course record set Thursday by Zembriski and Homero Blancas. Archer was tied for second at 133 with Al Kelley, who shot a 65.(AP) HORSE SHOW A Faultless Jumpoff Wins: Debbie Shaffner and her mount, Volan, jumped all seven fences on the jumpoff course without a fault last night to win the second phase of the American Grand Prix Association championship for jumpers at State Fair Coliseum in Tampa, Fla. Shaffner, of Ambler, Pa., the defending champion, and the Dutch-bred gelding had a time of 33.85 seconds.(AP) HORSE RACING In Front All the Way: Tomorrow's Child led from the start and won by 4 1/2-lengths yesterday at Aqueduct in the Swiss Cheese Handicap for fillies and mares. Bold Wench, who chased Tomorrow's Child throughout the seven furlongs, finished second in the field of six. Missy Slew was third. The winner, ridden by Jose Santos, won for the third time in 14 starts this year. She was timed in 1:25 2/5 and paid $9.20 for $2 to win.(AP) FIGURE SKATING Japanese Leads: Yuka Sato of Japan added the original program to her victory in the compulsories to stay ahead of Jessica Mills of the United States yesterday at the world junior championships in Colorado Springs. Sato, whose parents were Olympic skaters, earned first-place votes from five of the nine judges with a clean routine, although she was shaky on her double axel-double toe loop combination. Second place in the women's original went to Surya Bonaly of France. Mills, the defending champion, was third. (AP)

title: Artists Offer 'Day Without Art' to Focus on AIDS
description: In what organizers called ''the largest event that's ever happened to focus on the AIDS crisis,'' some 600 museums, galleries and other arts institutions across the United States observed ''A Day Without Art'' yesterday.

title: Amid the Intifada, Reserves of Humanity
description: LEAD: It is a commonplace in political and social analysis to suggest that extremism breeds extremism, violence more violence and killing even more killing. How true this is in the Middle East, where ''an eye for an eye'' doesn't seem to do justice to the widening gyre of fanaticism and hatred. It took the shooting death of my friend Zev

title: Ogrodnick's 2 Goals Rescue the Rangers
description: The minutes remaining in the third period were evaporating, and with it the Rangers' lead atop the Patrick Division was on the verge of shrinking to a single point. Enter John Ogrodnick. The left wing for the Rangers, who has salvaged his career with a stunningly productive season at age 30, rescued the Rangers tonight. In the game's last 125 seconds, Ogrodnick pumped in a pair of goals to lift the Rangers to a wild 4-3 victory over the Vancouver Canucks. Exit despair. Ogrodnick, with the Rangers having been awarded a rare two-man advantage in the waning minutes, stepped through a scramble of players to bang in the goal that evened the score at 3-3 with 2 minutes 5 seconds left. Jubilant Sendoff

title: U.S. Says Bush Used Fighter Jets To Save Aquino From Rebel Siege
description: President Bush took the unusual step of ordering American aircraft into action against Philippine rebel forces after he was advised that President Corazon C. Aquino was in danger of being overthrown, Administration officials said today.

title: Killing of German Bank Chief Seen as Long in the Planning
description: The bombing that killed Alfred Herrhausen, the head of West Germany's largest commercial bank, was a complicated attack, planned weeks in advance and executed with precision, the police said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1989
description: Markets

title: U.S. Adds Spy Satellites Despite Easing Tensions
description: The Government is planning a large expansion of its fleet of spy satellites, in part because peace is breaking out between East and West, Federal experts say.

title: Closing of Altman's in Manhasset Evokes Sadness and Fears
description: LEAD: WHEN B. Altman finally closes its doors on Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, it will mean the loss of a Long Island retailing giant that has offered an array of clothes, furniture, gifts and housewares under one roof since 1947. It also will also mean the loss of 180 jobs. To residents of the Miracle Mile area, the demise of

title: Cecelia A. Slater Weds D. H. Pikus
description: Dr. Cecelia Anne Slater, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Slater of Spring Lake, N.J., was married yesterday to David H. Pikus, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Pikus of Cedar Grove, N.J. The Rev. Ambrose Eckinger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: The Not-So-Wide Knowledge Gap
description: YOU probably saw in the news that a recent survey of college students indicated that many of them do not know much about the ''basic landmarks of history and thought.''

title: Florida Bus Searches for Drugs Are Ruled Intrusive
description: A divided Florida Supreme Court has declared Broward County's random drug searches of buses and their passengers unconstitutional, saying the practice invited comparisons with Nazi Germany and Communist countries.

title: Battle Looms on Landmarked Churches
description: NEW YORK CITY'S voters approved new procedures governing the landmarking of church properties last month, but a new political fight between church leaders and preservationists is shaping up and promises to become a contentious issue in the new mayoral administration of David N. Dinkins.

title: Foreign Soccer on Local Fields
description: ON Nov. 12 theMercy College soccer team was on its way to Winning the first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game in that school's history when Michael Gregg, a forward, heard something unusual coming from the stands.

title: INTOXICATED BY MY ILLNESS
description: I read with delight Anatole Broyard's About Men article ''Intoxicated by My Illness'' (Nov. 12). As a former cancer patient, I remember the months of mental imaging and heightened spirituality.

title: Farms as a Public Trust Debated
description: CONNECTICUT'S farmland is likely to become a battleground over the next few months as farm preservationists press their argument that it should get the same statutory protection as air and water.

title: Nina Fastenberg to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Fastenberg of New York have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Nina Fastenberg and Mitchell Auerbach, a third-year medical student at Tufts University. Miss Fastenberg, 23 years old, is an accound coordinator at the Bernard Hodes Advertising Agency in Cambridge, Mass. The future bridegroom, 25, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffery Auerbach of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Cretan Bull
description: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Greece I had an experience that I would like to share with your readers. In ancient Olympia I saw a copy of a Cretan bull in a shop window. A young man in the shop told me that he was the artist and that it was his signature painted on the underside of the bull. I told him I would buy the piece, whereupon he disappeared into a basement where, I was told by another employee, he had gone to wrap my purchase.

title: Furman Closes In On a Title Defense
description: Patrick Baynes, celebrating his 23d birthday with his first start at quarterback in nearly two years, rushed for a career-high 131 yards and two touchdowns as Furman beat Youngstown State, 42-23, today in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-AA playoffs.

title: Elizabeth Ardrey Becomes Bride Of S. J. Vaughan
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Stephenson Ardrey, the daughter of Sally D. Ardrey and Rushton L. Ardrey Jr., both of New York, to Steven Joseph Vaughan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Vaughan of Lafayette, Ind., took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; Loud and Rustic or Stately and Soft: A Choice of Ambiance to Fit the Mood
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Cowgirl Hall of Fame

title: Shearson May Sell Stake to Outsiders
description: Raising capital was on the agenda last week at two top securities firms. An outside investor became a possibility at Shearson Lehman Hutton. Under the proposal, American Express, which owns 62 percent of Shearson, would sell some of its shares. Wall Street sources said seven potential bidders have expressed interest in buying a large percentage of Shearson's stock. ''We are deeply into developing a plan that we hope will answer the questions of the rating agencies,'' Peter A. Cohen, the Shearson chief executive, said. Also, Drexel Burnham Lambert will require its best-paid employees to take a portion of their year-end bonuses in Drexel stock rather than cash. The firm's commercial paper was downgraded by Standard & Poor's. *

title: POSTINGS: Art on the Front Line; Auction To Fight Trump
description: Leading lights of the New York art and social worlds and whirls are sponsoring an auction of donated works this Wednesday, with proceeds to go toward helping fight construction of Trump City, a proposed 7,600-apartment development on the Upper West Side.

title: BIG SISSIES IN BIG EAST
description: In recording the nation's birth certificate, Thomas Jefferson, founder of the University of Virginia of the Atlantic Coast Conference, expressed ideas that, while not American in origin, have come to be regarded as distinctly American. The existence of self-evident truths was one of those ideas. The pre-eminence of the A.C.C. in college basketball is one of those self-evident truths.

title: Two Die as Charter Fishing Boat Sinks
description: A 110-foot charter-fishing boat sank in rough seas near the entrance to New York Harbor yesterday afternoon. All 19 people aboard, including some women and children, leaped into the frigid water and were picked up by rescue vessels, but two later died, the Coast Guard reported.

title: A Very Different Germany Waits to Be Reborn; More of the Same
description: To the Editor:

title: East Germany Reports On Exporting of Arms
description: The official East German press agency today made public the existence of a previously secret arms-exporting company that it said sent weapons to the Middle East, Latin America and Africa to earn currency for the Communist Party.

title: Shoppers Swell Weekend Exodus to Berlin
description: More than a million East Germans are expected to pour into the Western half of the divided former capital and across the West German border this weekend, the first of the holiday shopping season.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Chester
description: LEAD: ALONG the winding roadways of Chester Township are produce stands, open fields, apple orchards and stately homes set amid thick woods. At unexpected turns there are also such reminders of the past as the restored 1826 Cooper grist mill off Route 24, where flour ground in the traditional 19th-century manner can be bought.

title: William D. Carter, 80, Of Unesco, Is Dead
description: William Draper Carter, a former director of the Department of International Exchanges at Unesco, died of kidney failure and pneumonia Friday at Huntington Hospital on Long Island. He was 80 years old and had lived in Huntington since 1965.

title: Dog Show Draws 2,903
description: Entries for the 114th annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Feb. 12 and 13, have closed with 2,903 dogs representing 141 breeds or varieties.

title: Now on View: Trinkets From the City of David
description: After eight years of archeological digs and four years of research, the public can now view the finds from City of David excavations dating to the 10th century B.C.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A roof leak caused the latex-painted walls in my home to blister and created yellow stains on the wallpaper. Is there any way to remove the stains, and can the blisters on the dry wall be removed?

title: JUST THE MYTHS MA'AM
description: LEAD: A WILD SHEEP CHASE By Haruki Murakami. Translated by Alfred Birnbaum. 299 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $18.95.

title: Edberg Smoothly Stuns Lendl
description: When the never-irritable Stefan Edberg, bothered by a nagging cough that left him sleepless for most of the week, decided to shed his mild-mannered approach to life for the space of an afternoon yesterday, he did it at the expense of the world's top player, Ivan Lendl.

title: Testing Variable Fuel Vehicle
description: The car looks much like any other black Lumina Euro sedan. There is the red stripe along the lower body, the spoiler on the trunk, the molded alloy wheels. But there are differences. For one thing, there is that outrageous red and white legend on the front doors, the one that screams Gasoline/Methanol! GM!

title: Best Strides Are Made on Drug-Use Issue
description: Over the last six days, in nearly 150 scheduled meetings, delegates to The Athletics Congress's annual convention addressed almost every conceivable issue in contemporary track and field.

title: ...and Yonkers, Where TV Teaches
description: LEAD: A SHORT-LIVED TV series last year, ''TV 101,'' portrayed the adventures of the video-journalism class at a fictional Roosevelt High School. Coincidentally, there is a real-life television-production class thriving at a real Roosevelt High School, here in Yonkers.

title: In a Cooling Housing Markt, Real Estate Auctions Are Hot
description: AUCTIONING off property, a sales method common in foreclosures, is being used more and more to market houses and condominiums in Connecticut as the demand for real estate continues to slacken.

title: LAUGHTER, TEARS, THE PERFECTMARTINI
description: Arthur Miller should be ashamed of himself for saying that A. R. Gurney is a perfectly good playwright even though he has never written a character like Willy Loman (''Laughter, Tears and the Perfect Martini,'' by Alex Witchel, Nov. 12). Willy Loman was a great deal more than an interesting character. He was a victim of the American Dream gone sour, a casualty of greed, deceit and corruption.

title: Hard Lives of Garment Workers on Display
description: A denim dress on display shows the small rewards reaped by the garment workers of New York City's Chinatown: A seam brings 35 cents. A hem, 8 cents. A button, 2 cents.

title: Adopted and Content, but Wondering
description: TWO men walked out of the restaurant and onto the sidewalk in front of me. They were deep in conversation having something to do with adoption.

title: Regina Marshall, Lawyer, Is Wed in Connecticut
description: Regina Marshall, a lawyer, and Dr. Stuart Lustberg, a physician, were married yesterday at the home of Eileen McGann and Richard Morris in West Redding, Conn. Judge Eugene E. Spear of Connecticut Superior Court in Bridgeport performed the ceremony.

title: Some Recollections of Dutch Schultz Era
description: I read with particular interest the ''Jerseyana'' article recounting the killing of the mobster Dutch Schultz in a Newark restaurant in 1935.

title: Proposals Made by Bush At Meeting With Gorbachev
description: Following, as outlined by American officials, are the proposals made by President Bush today in his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union:

title: Sidewalk Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion: On the Street; Jackets Minus Their Mates
description: Just because your average suit comes with a jacket and skirt doesn't mean the two pieces always have to be worn at the same time, does it? Of course not, and if it's not your average suit to begin with, there is probably more reason than ever to break up the combo.

title: Philippines Reportedly Sought U.S. Aid in Mutiny
description: The Philippine Defense Minister, Fidel V. Ramos, told the American authorities in the Philippines on Friday that American air strikes on rebel ground forces might be needed, prompting high-level discussion in the Bush Administration about the wisdom of using force, American officials said today.

title: Campione d'Italia
description: To the Editor: The article by Paul Hofmann on Campione d'Italia (''Campione: Italy's Little Vegas,'' Travel, Sept. 10) brought back a treasured memory. In July 1946 I was released from the British Army after serving four and a half years. My government gave me $:100 and a navy blue suit. Two weeks later my wife and I set out for Lugano. We took the train from the north of England to Dover, crossed the Channel to Calais and then embarked on a very Spartan transcontinental train to Basel. Many hours passed, no refreshments and little sleep. France was in dreadful shape - ravaged, poor and depressed. Then we arrived in Basel at breakfast time and boarded a beautiful train with wonderful food. The sun and the Alps and the countryside transported us to paradise. We checked in at Pasion Gerber in Lugano and as far as we were concerned it was ''Grand Hotel!''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The first thing to do is to eliminate those types of ships which you cannot board in this kind of weather.'' - Mikhail S.Gorbachev. [ 28:5. ]

title: Will L. T. Try to Play on a Broken Ankle?
description: Before a Giants-Eagles game two years ago, Buddy Ryan boasted that ''the only player that can catch Randall Cunningham in the league is number 56,'' meaning Lawrence Taylor, ''and I'm not sure he can do it this year.'' But in the final seconds of that game in Philadelphia, the Eagles' coach watched No. 56 chase down his quarterback a yard short of a first down, preserving the Giants' 20-17 victory. In hurrying to the sideline for the tackle, however, L. T. pulled up lame. He had a damaged hamstring muscle in his right thigh. Stretched out on the trainer's table in the Veterans Stadium locker room a few minutes later, he looked up at Bill Parcells and smiled. ''I guess I can still do it,'' L. T. said. But now, as the Giants and the Eagles await their National Conference East showdown today at Giants Stadium, there's a new question: will L. T. try to do it despite a broken bone in his right ankle?

title: Honors in the Arts
description: The artist Helen Frankenthaler and the writers William Gaddis, Elizabeth Hardwick, Alfred Kazin and James Merrill have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, William Styron, secretary of the academy, announced Friday. Membership is limited to 50 people chosen by their peers from the 250 members of the academy's parent body, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 155th Street. The purpose of the organization is to foster an interest in literature, music and the fine arts.

title: A Resume For Leon Hess
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cornwall's Ancient Stones
description: LEAD: UNDER the bright light of the full moon, the three standing stones of Men-an-Tol cast their long shadows on the grass around. The air was still, rare on the high moors of Penwith, and the unusual silence sharpened my already intense awareness. Penzance lay just a few miles away, but its lights were hidden under the brow of heather and gorse-clad hills, and the barest orange glow broke the horizon.

title: A Majestic New 'Messiah' and Other Gifts
description: This is the season to lose oneself in a good oratorio, to inhabit a distant realm where the frescoes of Giotto and Michelangelo spring to life, where prophets, saints and seraphim lift their voices to the accompaniment of massed choirs and where the sound of the orchestra has the sheen of sustained organ harmony. The approach of Christmas allows us to wish the world could be as wonderful as the message that choral music often conveys, and this survey of seasonal music, choral and otherwise, represents the choicest fruit of a rich harvest.

title: East Germans Fear New Freedom Could Outstrip Ways to Control It
description: The position of Egon Krenz, who took over as Communist Party leader on Oct. 18, appeared to be unraveling rapidly tonight on the eve of an emergency meeting of the party's Central Committee, scheduled for Sunday.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION LRecycling as a Permanent Life Style
description: EVERY ton of recycled paper saves approximately 17 trees, according to one environmental group, and the production of paper from recycled fiber uses 64 percent less oil, 58 percent less water and produces 74 percent less air pollution than does production from raw materials. Whew! With statistics like these, I say, there's no point in throwing things away if you don't have to.

title: HOUSTON ROUTS RICE
description: Oh yes, Andre Ware also had a game today.

title: COFFEETABLE BOOKS: A PASSION FOR PICTURES
description: LEAD: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. THE COMPLETE BOOK OF COVERS FROM THE NEW YORKER, 1925-1989.

title: New Generation Marks First Mt. Everest Climb
description: LEAD: IN the spring of 1953 two mountaineers, Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa of Nepal, and Sir Edmund Hillary, a New Zealander, reached the summit of Mount Everest for the first time in the history of human assault on the peak. That event was commemmorated last year by another climb on Everest, in which Norbu Tenzing, son of Tenzing

title: Larry Davis Acquitted of Killing Drug Dealer
description: Larry Davis, who has been acquitted of murder or attempted murder charges twice in the last two years, was acquitted once again last night on charges that he fatally shot a Harlem drug dealer during a robbery.

title: Garretts of Princeton
description: The Garrett brothers' contribution to the revival of Princeton football was made complete last week when Judd Garrett, the youngest of the three, was named the Ivy League's player of the year.

title: Total Immersion in Golf's Traps
description: EVERY duffer who plods the public links of the Northeast dreams of one day playing the flat, well-groomed, straight courses of the South. We see them on TV during professional tournaments, and they look easy compared with the hilly, twisty, knobby fairways in the North.

title: GATT's Aim: Fair Trade
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is both the name of a fair-trade charter and of an organization that promotes the opening of global markets.

title: Mining the Eloquence of Ordinary People
description: ''Whattayuh feel like doin' tonight, Marty?'' ''I don't know, Ange. Whatta you feel like doin'?'' ''We oughtta do somethin'. It's Sattiday night.'' Pause. ''Whattayuh feel like doin' tonight?''

title: Compromise Eases French Dispute on Muslim Veils in Schools
description: Two Muslim girls whose insistence on wearing Islamic head scarves to school set off a national debate announced today that they would lower the scarves to their shoulders while in class.

title: Buttonholes and a Beached Whale in London
description: Remember Albert Finney as the swaggering lout in the movie ''Saturday Night and Sunday Morning''? Recall Peter O'Toole's all-electric ''Lawrence of Arabia''? They're well into middle age now, those brash boys who came in the 50's and 60's to beef up British acting in both cinema and live theater, and the passing years have left neither of them untouched. Time has transformed Peter O'Toole into a gangling cadaver, all elbows and cheekbones and floppy silver hair, and done the opposite to Albert Finney, a pretty fleshly, aldermanic figure these days. Yet you still feel something more than nostalgia when the two men respectively rattle and lumber onto the nearby stages they are occupying here this fall. That charisma, that command of the orchestra pit, remains unblighted.

title: INTOXICATED BY MY ILLNESS
description: I feel intimidated by these tales of people who find the experience of having cancer to be a source of inspiration and personal growth. I suspect that most ordinary mortals would fall short of this ideal. I suspect that this presentation of critical illness as a path to growth through adversity gives a patient unreasonable models and is likely to encourage friends and family to react unsympathetically when one fails to measure up.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in the Sports section last Sunday about the Rutgers-Vermont soccer game misidentified the Rutgers goalie. He was Dave Barrueta.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: NEWBURY, N.H.;
Town Rescinds Project Permit
description: LEAD: THE Town Planning Board has voted to rescind its approval for 79 expensive year-round second homes on 135 acres abutting Mount Sunapee State Park and ski area because the developer has not proceeded with the project. The property has 1,000 feet of shoreline on the 10-mile-long Lake Sunapee.

title: Pink Bracelets for Homosexuals in Florida Jail Are Challenged
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is opposing a county sheriff's policy that forces homosexual prisoners to wear pink bracelets.

title: Question Of the Week; Is There Bounty Hunting in The N.F.L.?
description: Yes. Buddy Ryan said he wasn't ''paid enough to dish out that kind of money'' to reward his players for vicious hits. Apparently Ryan had been paid enough in the past since his monetary bonuses of $100 or more to players after games are well documented.

title: Anne Tozier Wed To W. C. Teleisha
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Mendham, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Elizabeth Tozier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Everett Tozier Jr. of Long Valley, N.J., to William Charles Teleisha, the son of Albin Teleisha of Bethpage, L.I., and the late Marie S. Teleisha. The Rev. Martha Robson performed the ceremony.

title: Elderly Are Invited to School in Fairfield
description: LEAD: ELDERLY residents in Fairfield are serving as mentors, tutors, pen pals and class grandparents at public schools to help bridge the generational gap between them and students.

title: THE LITTLE INDUSTRY THAT COULD
description: AT THE WAREHOUSES OF HARPER & Row in Scranton, Pa., it was Christmas in September. The weather was hot and muggy, but crews were working like veritable elves, filling holiday orders from bookstores all over the country. No Grinch would steal Harper's Christmas this year. Five million books had left the warehouse in August; a similar number was rolling out in September.

title: For Egypt, Fridays Will Never Be the Same
description: Around late morning on Thursdays, things begin to slow here. Offices empty, traffic builds on homebound routes, the city's athletic clubs begin to fill and strollers take to the streets. Weekend is near.

title: FRENCH REASSERT A LEBANESE ROLE
description: Driven by internal political pressures, France has taken the lead among several nations in warning Syria against using force in an attempt to remove the Lebanese Christian military commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, from the presidential palace where he has been headquartered.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE store was moderately crowded, the tightest knot of people clustered around the display featuring calendars - next year's calendars, calendars laying out the first year in the last decade of this century. One in particular caught my eye, a credit to the marketing skills of the store manager and the calendar's popularity among buyers.

title: India Concocts A Government
description: THE new Prime Minister of India, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, who was sworn in yesterday, is embarking on an ideological balancing act that will test his substantial skills as a builder of consensus.

title: Graduating Scale
description: A lot of colleges give lip service to the notion of putting academics ahead of athletics. The 12-school Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference says it is the first basketball conference to put its money where its mouth is. Its sponsors' money, that is.

title: Correction
description: A map on Nov. 12 with an article about Baja California located Ensenada incorrectly. It is about 40 miles southeast of Tijuana; the town shown was Ensenada de los Muertos.

title: NEW RISK TAKERS IN THE REALTY GAME
description: CHARLOTTE BALLARD HAD A PROBLEM. It was the summer of 1987, and the real estate developer had paid $475,000 for a dilapidated four-story apartment building on West 116th Street. If she could successfully renovate it, she felt, she stood a good chance of turning a profit on a dozen other run-down properties that she and her partners had bought in Harlem.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Veterans Attend Rally in Protest Of Flag Burning
description: Responding to a flag-burning episode at Princeton University last month, the New Jersey Chapter of the Ex-Prisoners of War rallied around Old Glory on the campus last week.

title: COMPANIES FORM ALLIANCES TO OFFER MORE ALLURING PRIZES
