description: The frequency-marketing craze is spawning a host of partnerships. The drive by sponsors of these programs to offer their members a diverse mix of products to buy with their bonus points has pushed them to negotiate formal ventures with companies with alluring services and wares.

title: Review/Recital; Soprano In Varied Program
description: For a singer who has devoted much of her life to refining her vocal technique, it must be mildly frustrating to have attention repeatedly directed instead to her native intelligence and enterprise. Such is the lot of the American soprano Christine Schadeberg, who gave a recital of 20th-century music on Thursday evening in Florence Gould Hall. As on previous occasions, her choice of works was so imaginative and unhackneyed and her delivery so thoughtful and convincing that considerations of vocal production were largely subsumed in the evening's dramatic progression.

title:
INVESTING;
The Swings in Sneaker Stocks
description: LEAD: This year, athletic shoe companies have flown higher than basketball star Michael Jordan. Shares of L. A. Gear Inc. and Nike Inc. have more than doubled. Reebok International Ltd. has climbed 40 percent. Analysts expect slam-dunk sales and earnings to continue, with the industry reporting sales of $5 billion this year, up 20 percent from 1988.

title: The Banker Who Would Be Scrooge
description: AT 10 O'CLOCK ON THE MORNING OF OCT. 17, CARL E. REICHARDT, the chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo & Company, presided over a meeting of the board of directors in the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Los Angeles. He had nothing but good news to report for the third quarter. Net income would be strong (the final figures showed it at $153.7 million, a 17-percent rise over the 1988 figure) and costs, one of the chairman's obsessions, were well in hand.

title: Question Of the Week; Is There Bounty Hunting in The N.F.L.?
description: Pro football is one of two sports (boxing is the other) where physical destruction of your opponents pays such big dividends that bounty hunters will soon be replaced by body counters. Who orders it? We do. Every time we boo our losses. Who pays it? We do. Every time we buy from television sponsors.

title: Values Are the Means and the End
description: For at least 25 years, we Americans have failed to instill basic values in our children, in the workplace, in government and in many other parts of our society. We are simply not getting across such basic ideas as decency, fair play, courtesy, hard work, scholarship, perseverance, self-confidence, teamwork, discipline and a host of other character traits.

title: Who Is Tremendous?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudanese Agree on Food Flights, Carter Says
description: The Sudanese Government and a rebel group have agreed that international relief flights of food to the war-ravaged southern Sudan should resume immediately, former President Jimmy Carter said today.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A roof leak caused the latex-painted walls in my home to blister and created yellow stains on the wallpaper. Is there any way to remove the stains, and can the blisters on the dry wall be removed?

title: Review/Music; Baroque On Digital Pianos
description: The New York Symphonic Ensemble, a chamber orchestra founded in 1979, offered a program of popular Baroque and Classical works on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The concert was sponsored by Technics, the electronics company, which made its presence felt both in the lobby, with a large display, and on the stage, where four of the company's PCM Digital Pianos were used.

title: 'Georgia O'Keeffe: A Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA UPDATE: December 12, 1989

title: Choosing a Camcorder? The Field Can Be Narrowed
description: Thousands in this pre-Christmas season contemplate the addition of a camcorder. There is something momentous in such a purchase.

title: RANGERS GET NO ANSWERS IN SCORE SHEETS TO A BIZARRE VICTORY
description: Roger Neilson sat lost briefly in thought on the team's flight here, poring over charts and sifting through his briefcase for further data on the 4-3 victory the Rangers had magically manufactured in Vancouver barely an hour earlier.

title: A Better Way To Prepay College
description: LEAD: College tuition costs are rising much faster than the consumer price index and the rate of their increase shows no signs of abatement. Parents are increasingly worried that when their little John or Jane (or, as is more likely today, their Jennifer or Jason) reaches college age, they will be unable to come up with the price of tuition.

title: ON THE TELLY, A TALE OF SWAPS
description: A RECENT MONDAY MORNING at Shane Longman, a mid-sized merchant bank in the City of London. Phones ring, Reuters monitor screens flicker and, as a jittery bond market awaits the latest United States trade figures, Declan McConnochie, a senior bond trader, is especially jumpy. Some doggy Japanese debt he's holding as a favor to another trader is blotting his performance record.

title: An Old Story
description: To the Editor:

title: The Non-Microwave Cooking Advantage: Timing
description: THERE are several arguments for not trying to cook dinner in a microwave oven. First of all, this time-saving device cannot provide a short cut to the peeling, shopping and so forth, that is often necessary before the cooking starts.

title: St. John's Eases Into Final
description: Garbage time came extra early yesterday at Alumni Hall as St. John's easily defeated the University of San Diego, 74-59, in the opening round of the 15th annual Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament.

title: COFFEETABLE BOOKS: A PASSION FOR PICTURES
description: LEAD: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. JOCKS AND NERDS: Men's Style in the Twentieth Century.

title: MOSCOW REINED IN FORCE IN GERMANY
description: East German Communist Party officials say President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in daily telephone contact with the general commanding the 400,000 Soviet troops in East Germany during the street demonstrations in October that eventually caused the downfall of the hard-line regime of Erich Honecker.

title: Battle on Paving a Utah Trail Highlights a Clash of Cultures
description: These are lean days in this depressed southern Utah town of 652 people. The mining and lumber industries have fallen on hard times and the trickle of summer tourists has dwindled to almost nothing.

title: De Klerk Gets Full Welcome In Ivory Coast
description: South Africa's drive to win greater acceptance from its neighbors in Africa took President F. W. de Klerk to the Ivory Coast on Friday and today, on his first trip abroad as head of state.

title: Jean Barish Wed To Chad Sterrett
description: Jean Ellen Barish, the daughter of Norman N. Barish and Esther B. Barish, both of New York, was married yesterday to Chad Clarke Sterrett, a son of Capt. and Mrs. David S. Sterrett of Honolulu. The Rev. David Ver Nooy, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational service at the home of Marjorie Chorlton in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Ewing Scores 41 As Knicks Top Suns
description: Patrick Ewing scored 41 points, including 10 in the final four minutes, as the Knicks beat the Phoenix Suns, 122-112, tonight.

title: STARS JUST WANT TO HAVE FUN
description: ROLLING STONE: THE PHOTOGRAPHS Edited by Laurie Kratochvil. Preface by Tom Wolfe. Introduction by Jann S. Wenner. Designed by Fred Woodward. 118 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $50.

title: Correction
description: A report Nov. 19 on the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III football playoffs mislocated Union College. The school is in Schenectady, N.Y.

title: The Legacy of the Velvets: Rock-and-Roll as Pop Art
description: Listen to mainstream rock acts like Bon Jovi or Guns N' Roses, and you'll hear the influence of the Rolling Stones. Listen to college or alternative radio stations, and it's clear the heroes are the Velvet Underground. The Velvets were hardly a commercial success in their day, but guitar bands in the 80's - among them, Galaxie 500, 11th Dream Day and Died Pretty, all of which have recently released albums - seem to find the group a boundless source of inspiration.

title: PERILS OF THE SIMMONS WATCH
description: ''LAST YEAR, HAROLD C. SIMMONS returned to the hunt, taking positions in Lockheed and Chrysler. Since then, he has bought into Georgia Gulf and Inland Steel and signaled interest in Paccar and Phelps Dodge. His moves have not gone unnoticed. During the last few years, the 58-year-old Texas billionaire has joined the ranks of the catalysts - a select group of raiders such as T. Boone Pickens and Carl C. Icahn - whose corporate forays attract coteries of watchers. By riding the raiders' coattails, the watchers, chiefly arbitrageurs and investment fund managers, can move the market.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. SANDRA G. FLANK;
Are Computers a Good Idea for Children?
description: LEAD: Ads for computers and relatted software are everywhere, particularly these days with Christmas and Hanukkah approaching. In this computer age, is a computer a luxury item for a child or a necessity? Are computer toys - far less expensive than the real thing -worth buying?

title: INSIDE
description: Difficult Choices in Prague

title: RETAILERS TAKE A TIP FROMTHE AIRLINES
description: Retailing is frequency marketing's next frontier. The Limited is rumored to be considering such a program. And several department stores, including Sears Roebuck and Montgomery Ward, have considered or tested the concept.

title: POSTINGS: In Battery Park City; 'Blueprint' Sales
description: Sales have opened on apartments in Liberty View, a condominium tower under construction in Battery Park City at the southern tip of Manhattan, in advance of its completion, scheduled for early 1991. The building is to contain 293 apartments ranging in size from studios to two bedrooms and in price from $157,000 to $760,000. In addition, there are 7,000 square feet of professional space and a three-bedroom penthouse duplex with a terrace that is offered at $1.08 million.

title: Beautiful Waves At the Y.W.C.A. In White Plains
description: The Synchronettes have made beautiful patterns together for 25 years at the Y.W.C.A. in White Plains. The 11 synchronized swimmers, who meet weekly, say there is nothing like their sensuous routines for maintaining fitness as well as friendships.

title: British Group Clears Mines Of Kabul War
description: Two months ago, Guy Willoughby shed the natty suit that he has frequently worn in Kabul, dropped to his hands and knees off a highway north of here, and worked his way through a Soviet minefield.

title: Schools Chancellor Seeks Principals' Support
description: Speaking before the union that represents New York City school principals, the incoming schools chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, appealed yesterday to principals and supervisors to keep an open mind toward his plans for reorganizing the city's schools.

title: Review/Music; The Ecco Trio in Recital
description: The Ecco Trio found a perfect balance of the familiar and the unusual in its Weill Recital Hall program on Wednesday evening. Of the three works the ensemble played, only the Schubert Trio in B flat (Op. 99), which took up the second half of the concert, was drawn from the standard literature. Before the intermission, the group offered two tonal, melodic and traditionally structured 20th-century works, both of which would make worthy additions to any piano trio's repertory.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: TREE FESTIVAL AT MUSEUM

title: Getting In Is a Trial for Young and Old
description: FALL is the time when college-bound seniors are making their final trips to look at universities and colleges, filling out application forms, being interviewed. And so, in some instances, are their grandparents - not applying for college but for the appropriate retirement homes.

title: Must You Shout Into My Hearing Aid?
description: WHENEVER I go to my hairdresser, I remind him not to cut my side hair too short because I want to keep my hearing aid out of sight. I do this so as not to embarrass others rather than to hide my hearing impairment. When people notice I have something in my ear, they either look away or pretend that they do not see it. I feel sorry for them and I become embarrassed by their embarrassment.

title: Letters
description: CAN A NOVELIST SAVE PERU? pretends to answer the question of whether Mario Vargas Llosa can ''save'' Peru (as if the days of one-man rescue missions still existed!). He focuses on the dilemma of a novelist-turned-politician who can no longer use his imagination, because ''in politics you have no use for the imagination'' (something I hope is vigorously contested). He offers an interesting psychological look at the novelist (for those interested), but he doesn't tell us what plans Vargos Llosa has to subdue the entrenched Maoist guerrilla movement, nor does he tell us what Vargas Llosa is offering, outside of free-market medicine for an economy gone awry, or what he will do to overcome the growing problem of narcotics trafficking.

title: Building at Oceanfront Contested
description: LEAD: FOR those who live on oceanfront property on Long Island's East End, what neighbors do on their property has become as important as what one does on his own.

title: RON BROWN'S PARTY LINE
description: LEAD: IT IS THURSDAY MORNING, NOV. 9, TWO days after an election night sweeter than any in recent Democratic memory, and the party chairman, Ron Brown, is beaming out at a crowd of well-wishers and reporters assembled in the Mansfield Room of the Capitol. Gathered around the chairman and the Democratic leaders of Congress are L.

title: Amy Wall Plans January Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hally Peter Wall of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Batterson Wall to Daryl G. Nelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Nelson of Naples, Fla. A January wedding is planned.

title: Sidewalk Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: Past Glory Has Faded For Stokes
description: The wall of Carl B. Stokes's office looks like a photo essay from a history book: Carl Stokes with John F. Kennedy, Carl Stokes with Golda Meir, Carl Stokes with Lyndon B. Johnson, Harry S. Truman, Hubert H. Humphrey, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Pope Paul VI.

title: COFFEETABLE BOOKS: A PASSION FOR PICTURES
description: LEAD: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. AMERICAN CONSERVATISM: An Illustrated History.

title: THE MALTA SUMMIT: Reporter's Notebook; Superpowers Cooperating, But Not Seas
description: By having the summit conference on ships, President Bush had hoped to keep away the curious hordes. Little did he know that this would also keep away Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: New Incentives Offered For Foster Parents
description: IN what may be the first step toward making foster parenting a full-time profession in New Jersey, the Department of Human Services is offering reimbursement rates as much as four times higher than normal, along with intensive training and special support services to foster parents who agree to care for crack-addicted babies and children with AIDS or other severe medical problems.

title: Rumanian Chief Criticizes Party Over Food Supply
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania has criticized his ruling Communist Party and called for a program to modernize the food industry and improve consumer distribution, the state-run press reported today.

title: Stacey Kaplan and Gary Schreiber, C.P.A.'s, Wed
description: Stacey Robin Kaplan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kaplan of Bay Shore, L.I., was married last evening to Gary Evan Schreiber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schreiber of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbis Martin S. Rosenberg and Gershon Schwartz officiated at Temple Beth Shalom in Smithtown, L.I.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S NEXT HOT PROPERTY?
description: Before Tom Pollock, the chairman of Universal Pictures, could slide into his booth for breakfast at the posh Bel Air Hotel one morning last week, he was showered with attention from others in the dining room. The film producer Lee Rich congratulated him on the opening of ''Back To the Future, Part II,'' which had a recordbox-office gross of $43 million for the five-day Thanksgiving period and has become one of the Christmas season's major hits. Then the entertainment lawyer Bert Fields kidded Mr. Pollock about his rising value to Universal.

title: STALKING THE BLOOMS OF YESTERYEAR
description: IN SEARCH OF LOST ROSES By Thomas Christopher. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Rahway Betting on Mixed-Use Development
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS and commercial leaders in Rahway are hoping that a $20 million mixed-use project will crown nearly two decades of downtown urban renewal and lead to a revitalization of the central business district.

title: Air Force Base Is Cited For Work Conditions
description: The Government has cited the Air Force for unsafe work conditions in a fatal B-52 fire, alleging that workers were not given proper tools and cigarette butts were found near where the plane was being fueled.

title: At Last, a Place In Medicine For Interferon
description: ONCE promoted as a possible cancer cure, interferon fell into disrepute in the early 1980's when the optimistic predictions failed to pan out. But in the last year the drug has found its niche as a treatment for hepatitis and perhaps AIDS and other diseases.

title: MANY CLERICS BACK LEFTIST IN BRAZIL
description: ''Are you rich, well off?'' Antonio Mamede, a Roman Catholic priest, asks straw-hatted farm workers in the fields of Maranhao State in northeast Brazil. ''Well, if you are, then vote for Fernando Collor de Mello because he is the candidate of the rich.''

title: THERE'S GOLD IN PUMPING IRON
description: FOR THOSE WHO SEE THEMSELVES AS larger-than-life heroes, nothing seems impossible. Consider Joe Weider, the king of the body builders, head of a multimillion-dollar international empire that encompasses muscle magazines, muscle-training equipment and food supplements. A few months ago, Weider was sifting through a pile of photos in the Hollywood studio of photographer Ken Marcus, trying to put together the next cover of Muscle & Fitness, the flagship publication of Weider Health and Fitness. The covers generally feature a top male body builder shown with a female model.

title: Glittering Masquerade Helps AIDS Research
description: Serious glitter, as opposed to the purely frivolous kind, prevailed at a masquerade party Friday night in observance of the second annual World AIDS Day.

title: Hugh J. O'Rourke, Lawyer, 82
description: Hugh J. O'Rourke, an immigration and real estate lawyer, died of cancer Thursday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 82 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Westhampton, L.I.

title: Major Injuries Found Declining
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Pruning Can Yield Christmas Greens
description: LEAD: WHEN ancient tribes celebrated the winter solstice, evergreen bows were used for decoration much as they are today for the Christmas celebration. In the time of year when shorter days and cold weather made life seem desolate, plants that retained their green foliage were considered a symbol that life was still present in the forest and that spring would indeed return.

title: What Does One Say After Saying Goodbye?
description: SHIRLEY choked to death on moo shu pork, but she was in the middle of redecorating her apartment and she could not leave her husband and son to deal with a room full of new furniture, could she?

title: Out of the Closet
description: Thousands of needy New Yorkers could be warmer this winter thanks to a welcome initiative to recycle coats. Civic groups, led by a volunteer organization called New York Cares, seek donations of wearable parkas and overcoats. A similar campaign in Denver has collected and distributed more than 100,000 secondhand coats since 1981. The New York drive seeks adult and child-sized coats at special collection boxes located at 15 police stations in all five boroughs. Distribution will be handled by local agencies serving the poor.

title: Counting the Stars That Shone On City Ballet
description: Lincoln Kirstein, Jerome Robbins and Suzanne Farrell have all announced their retirement or resignation - depending on their individual choice of words - from their positions in the New York City Ballet this autumn. Patricia McBride retired from the company in July.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Garment District; Dressing Up Those Dowager Buildings
description: IN Manhattan's garment district at midday, pedestrians still jockey for sidewalk space with pushers of wheeled clothing racks, and huge delivery trucks still own the curbs on the side streets. But in the last few years the area has shed its drab industrial look for a more polished appearance.

title: Turnstile Politics: Preparing for the $1.15 Token
description: LAST Monday, it seemed all but certain that New York City's $1 subway and bus fare would jump to $1.25 on New Year's Day.

title:
ART;
When the Picture Tells the Story
description: LEAD: IN a literal sense, the purpose of illustration is to elucidate or amplify an idea, usually in written form. The illustrator's task, therefore, is to be faithful to the intent of the text, to take the cue from the given material.

title: Alice F. Collopy and Michael A. Carlucci Marry
description: The marriage of Alice Frances Collopy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Collopy of Morris Plains, N.J., to Michael Anthony Carlucci, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emilio Carlucci of Dumbarton, N.J., took place yesterday at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. A. William Sabatino, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: NATIONALISTS LEAD TAIWAN ELECTIONS
description: The first election in 40 years in which an opposition party was legally allowed to take part produced a solid majority for the ruling Nationalists as of early this morning, but the opposition won some crucial local positions on which to build a base.

title: VIVE LA DIFFERENCE
description: WE ARE CHARGING what the market will bear. London is a more popular point,'' says a British Airways spokesman sounding not the least bit apologetic about the $3,606 one-way Concorde fare between New York and London. Air France charges $952 less, flying its Concordes on a route to Paris that is 186 miles longer.

title: Noriega Linked to Steroid Smuggling, Mexico Says
description: The Mexican Government's top drug enforcement official has alleged that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, is directly involved in the manufacture and smuggling of steroids through Mexico to the United States.

title: Correction
description: A picture today on page 23 of The Business World, part 2 of The Times Magazine, showing Alan Fraser, founder of Saztec, carries an incorrect credit line. The photographer was Jay Mariano for Sygma. On page 42, a picture caption about Stephen Wolf misstates his corporate affiliation. It is UAL, not UA.

title: THE ULTIMATE DECISION
description: LEAD: THIS IS THE STORY OF MY mother's last foggy days and the deal I made to let her die in peace, I hope.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Stepping in to Make Up for the Loss of an Entire Family
description: For Rhoda S., whose entire family was killed in the Holocaust, a social-service agency has stepped in to fill many voids.

title: Vietnam Returns to the Home Screen
description: In the sudden surge of films about America's Vietnam experience, 84 CHARLIE MOPIC, newly released on cassette (1989, RCA/Columbia Home Video, $89.95), stands out for the originality of its cinematic devices. The writer-director Patrick Duncan imagines that a six-man patrol, sent into the jungle to pinpoint the location of enemy troops, is accompanied by an Army cameraman - known as 84 Charlie in Army lingo - assigned to make a training documentary. What the viewer sees is the war through the lens of 84 Charlie (Mopic stands for motion picture).

title:
ART;
EnFoco Collection Finds a Permanent Home in the Bronx
description: LEAD: ENFOCO (Spanish for ''in focus'') is a collection from the archives of Hispanic photographers that since its founding in 1974 has been without a permanent home. The photographers' group has become known by being vagabondish, by staging exhibitions in various museums and galleries. Now EnFoco has its own permanent space - 450 clean and well-lighted square feet at 32 East Kingsbridge Road in the Bronx.

title: At 75, My Mother's Irish Eyes Rediscover the New World
description: LAST summer, my mother sat down to dinner with us at our old pine kitchen table that had come, as she had, from Ireland. The table, she said, she hoped would be with us for a very long time, but this visit, she told us, would be her last.

title: Montana
description: To the Editor: We spent part of last summer in Montana's Glacier National Park and Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, Canada. As magnificent as the scenery was, we were equally impressed with the friendliness of Montana's residents, in particular, Don and Carol Young, the hosts of the bed-and-breakfast where we stayed in Kalispell, and felt that our find was too good to keep to ourselves. The Brick Farmhouse Bed and Breakfast, 1946 Whitefish Stage, Kalispell (406-756-6230) is open from June to October and is convenient to the airport and to Glacier Park. The decor is ''country,'' the breakfast lavish with fresh berries from the garden, newly gathered eggs and breads baked in the wood-burning stove. Our hosts seemed genuinely interested in all their guests and willing to assist with any special interest.

title: An Irish Baker's Path to Mount Vernon
description: WHEN John Tarrant turned 14 years old, in County Cork, Ireland, he was apprenticed to a baker. ''Did I want to be a baker? I wasn't asked and I never questioned it,'' Mr. Tarrant said the other day. ''That's how it was.'' The baker was his uncle. ''My father was a blacksmith and all his brothers were in different trades,'' Mr. Tarrant said. ''In our family of six boys and three girls, the boys were apprenticed early. My first responsibility was attending to the peat furnace when I arrived at work at 3 o'clock in the morning.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SEASONAL MUSIC

title: WARMING (AGAIN) TO MOSCOW
description: Generally, would you describe the Soviet Union as a peace-loving nation, willing to fight only if it thinks it has to defend itself, or as an agressive nation that would start a war to get something it wants? Article on page 29.

title: New Fires Burn In Korea's Kilns
description: SOUTH KOREA'S centuries-old kilns, out of operation for more than 50 years, are going full blast again. Shut down during the Japanese occupation (1910-1945) and throughout the Korean War, the pottery centers reopened one by one after the war ended in 1953, as the country undertook rebuilding and reclaiming its 5,000-year-old culture.

title: Campus Life: Middlebury; Broad Revision In Social Structure Is Recommended
description: If the Middlebury College Board of Trustees makes changes proposed by a college-appointed task force, the fraternity system here will be swept away as part of a broad revision in the college's social structure.

title: Christine Miles to Wed John Kelliher
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leland Miles of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Marie Miles, to John J. Kelliher, a son of Mrs. Francis Kelliher of Albany and the late Mr. Kelliher. A May wedding is planned. Miss Miles, formerly the director of the Fraunces Tavern Museum in New York and the museum art gallery at the South Street Seaport Museum, is the director of the Albany Institute of History and Art. She graduated from the Walnut Hill School and Boston University and received a master's degree in museum and American studies from George Washington University.

title: BATTLE OF THE BEAUTY COUNTER
description: PATRICIA FRENCH, THE founder and president of Gazelle International, a black-cosmetics company, makes no secret of her ambitions. She says she spent most of a recent flight from Paris to New York engrossed in a biography of Helena Rubinstein. As for her publicist's claim that French will be ''the next Estee Lauder,'' the 33-year-old former model and makeup consultant smiles and says, ''We all have to have a goal and a dream.''

title: New Country
description: Though she is only 21 months old, Alyssa Smith may already have received the most important gift she will ever get from her mother. Last week, in the first live liver transplant ever performed in the United States, a surgical team at the University of Chicago Medical Center took a portion of Teresa A. Smith's liver and used it to replace her daughter's diseased organ. The operation was closely watched by transplant surgeons who hope to use the technique to save more of the 700 babies who are born each year with liver disease. Until now, all liver transplants in the United States involved cadavers, which are in short supply. Since the liver regenerates itself, a portion taken from a parent or sibling will grow with the child, and the donor's liver will grow back to normal. Doctors pronounced Alyssa's transplant a success and predicted that she would be home for Christmas. Said the chief surgeon, Dr. Christoper E. Broelsch, ''The liver is going to function right away. I can tell.''

title: COFFEETABLE BOOKS: A PASSION FOR PICTURES
description: LEAD: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. SIGMUND FREUD AND ART: His Personal Collection of Antiquities.

title: J. Palanchian, 56, Musician and Mediator
description: John Palanchian, vice president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and a leading figure in classical-music labor relations, died of kidney failure yesterday afternoon at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey after a long bout with cancer. He was 56 years old and lived in Englewood.

title: Mary V. Delaney Is Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Mary Virginia Delaney, an associate at the New York architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, to David Scott Penick, an associate partner in the firm, took place yesterday at St. Andrew's Church in Sag Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Michael Perry performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Anne Garmey Marries Andrew Clutz
description: Anne Squires Garmey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Garmey of Boston and Stockbridge, Mass., and Andrew Hunter Clutz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard B. Clutz of Williamstown, Mass., were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Margaret B. Gunness performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Stephen S. Garmey, an uncle of the bride. Mrs. Clutz, 25 years old, is an assistant at the Harvard College Fund in Cambridge, Mass. She graduated from the Winsor School and St. Lawrence University and was presented at the Boston Cotillion. Her father is a partner in the law firm of Hutchins & Wheeler in Boston. Her mother, Diana O. Garmey, is the director of development at Winsor.

title: Cynthia Kanter Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kanter of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Dana Kanter, to Michael Harris Sonnabend, a son of Katherine Sonnabend of Livingston, N.J., and Henry Sonnabend of Dallas. An August wedding is planned.

title: Who Needs Fiber?
description: To the Editor:

title: W. Howard Miller, Banker, 83
description: W. Howard Miller, a former vice president of Citibank, died of pneumonia on Friday at the Twining Village Health Care Center in Holland, Pa. He was 83 and lived at Twining Village, a retirement community.

title: Hit and Run, Run and Hit
description: HOW does this sound for a tempting little weekend getaway? You and your wife board a plane on Friday evening and leave a cold, dark northeastern city for Tampa, where temperatures are in the low 80's and gentle breezes stir the palm trees ever so slightly. You are met at the airport and whisked 25 miles north to Saddlebrook, a 480-acre compound with manicured lawns, fine restaurants, a health club, meandering bike trails, an amoeba-shaped swimming pool large enough to have heated and unheated sections, perpetually smiling attendants and a circular outdoor bar where the bartenders concoct rum drinks that match the color of their dark pink Hawaiian shirts.

title: Linda Marie Schroder And Mark S. Bice Wed
description: Linda Marie Schroder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Schroder of Brookline, Mass., was married there yesterday at St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church to Mark Stephen Bice, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael O. Bice of Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Arthur O. Bice, an Episcopal priest and a grandfather of the bridegroom, officiated. He was assisted by the Rev. Robert G. Flynn, pastor of St. Mary's.

title: Wendy J. Belzberg to Wed in January
description: The engagement of Wendy J. Belzberg and Strauss Zelnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Zelnick of South Orange, N.J., and La Romana, Dominican Republic, has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Belzberg of Vancouver, British Columbia. A January wedding is planned.

title: Amy Belleau Wed To J. T. Walsh 3d
description: Amelia Claire Belleau, a daughter of Anne Bigger and Dr. Charles D. Belleau, both of Baton Rouge, La., was married there yesterday at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Cathedral to Joseph Thomas Walsh 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh Jr. of Bangor, Me. Bishop Stanley J. Ott officiated.

title: 2 Leonardo Studies Sold
description: Two drapery studies drawn on linen by Leonardo da Vinci were sold Friday by Sotheby's in Monte Carlo to Barbara Piasecka Johnson, heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune. The headless, cloth-covered figures brought $5.8 million and $5 million. They were sold by the heirs of Hubert, Marquis de Ganay.

title: A Christmas Appeal: The Neediest Cases, 1989
description: For a 73-year-old woman who has barely escaped homelessness, and for others whose stories are told today, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund offers dignity and support. Articles, page 95.

title: Russian Republic Urges Azerbaijan to End Armenia Blockade
description: The Russian republic, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, has appealed to Azerbaijan to lift a renewed railway blockade against neighboring Armenia, the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya reported today.

title:
THREE EUROPEAN VIEWS ON THE RISKS OF PEACE;
Protect Poland From 'Great Germany'
description: LEAD: THE Week in Review asked three European journalists to assess how the continent's security needs can be met as the cold war recedes.

title: Outdoors; Drawing a Bead on Gun Safety
description: Shooting accidents have been markedly reduced throughout the country in the last decade, and much of this can be attributed to the hunter-education courses now required of first-time license holders in most states.

title: Santa Clara to Play Virginia in Final
description: Virginia and Santa Clara used different means to reach the same end today as they advanced to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament for the first time.

title: Motion-Syndrome Link Is Yet to Be Proved
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle; What to Eat? Confusion Is the Main Course
description: So now decaffeinated coffee is in hot water. A study found that drinking decaffeinated coffee raises levels of the so-called bad cholesterol in the blood. People like Stanley Rubin, who weaned themselves from real coffee to decaf in the belief that it was healthier, are feeling betrayed.

title: Amy Cox to Wed David Stuart Prall
description: Bernard S. Cox of Akron, Ohio, and Mrs. Charles G. Lake of San Diego have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Caroline Cox, to David Stuart Prall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart E. Prall of Hewlett, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: Evening Hours; A Party for Chidren, Not For Theme
description: ''Tell Me a Story'' was the theme on Thursday at a fund-raising dinner for the Children's Defense Fund here. Crayons, sailboats and chocolate bunnies adorned the tables, but the writers and television personalities who regaled the 900 party-goers with after-dinner tales didn't stick to bedtime stories.

title: Negating a Trade
description: On Sept. 28, the Philadelphia Flyers traded a goalie, Pete Peeters, and a forward, Keith Acton, to the Winnipeg Jets for future considerations. Five days later, Winnipeg returned Peeters and Acton to Philadelphia for Toronto's sixth-round selection in the 1991 National Hockey League entry draft. The Flyers held that choice from an earlier transaction. On Friday, John Ziegler, president of the league, signaled offside and fined the Flyers and the Jets $10,000 each for violating the league bylaw that prohibits teams from lending players to each other.

title: Bonnie Michele Soskin to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Soskin of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Michele Soskin, to David Alan Sheer, a son of Rabbi Charles Sheer of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Gloria Sheer. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Blanchard To Wed in April
description: Lucile H. Blanchard of Middletown, Conn., has announced April wedding plans for her daughter Sandra Horsley Blanchard and Mark Anthony Vecchiarelli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Vecchiarelli of Longmeadow, Mass.

title: Gifts Bearing Touches Of Their Creator
description: A VISIT to a craft gallery or museum shop may help remove the question marks next to some of the names on a holiday shopping list. And what a variety of craft items to choose from: handmade ceramics, jewelry, glass, wood and weaving.

title: Comaneci Is Said To Go to Miami
description: The executive director of the United States Gymnastics Federation said today that he understood that Nadia Comaneci, the former Olympic champion, would leave New York before the day was out and go to Miami, where she would stay in a Rumanian immigrant neighborhood.

title: In Landlocked Days of Winter, Dreaming of Sunny Sails
description: >HE brisk northerly rattles the plastic covers stretched over yachts lying dormant in wooden cradles in the Creek Road yard at Coneys Marine in Huntington.

title: Working Out, Body and Soul
description: IT was barely noon of my first full day at Palm-Aire Spa, and I had already exercised more than I would have in a week at home: a two-mile walk at 7 A.M., a workout in the pool at 9, a toning class at 10 and aerobics at 11. This was the general pattern of my visit last month to two Florida spas: In the morning I worked, and in the afternoon I was worked on - with whirlpools, massages, loofahs, herbal wraps and facials.

title: Question Of the Week; Is There Bounty Hunting in The N.F.L.?
description: It's almost impossible to tell in a sport where the players are often sent flying farther than the ball. But whether or not the accusations are true, we can expect to see even more players than usual being banged around. Even in retaliation for plays that might not have been given a second glance before. And who knows, the next time the Eagles play the Cowboys, we might even see good old Buddy Ryan sent into orbit. For how much do you think? $200, $500, $1,000? KEITH J. EMMER Brooklyn

title: China Cracking Down on Sale of Women as Wives
description: When Miss Zhao, a junior high school student, was sold as a wife to a peasant in Shandong Province, she infuriated her husband by repeatedly trying to run away. Finally he came up with a way to keep her: he gouged out her eyes.

title: Trainer Shows Dogs the Art of Mean
description: LEAD: ELLIS TUCKER'S star pupil bared his teeth and snarled at him, ears back and straining at his leash. The 70-year-old trainer was trying his best to look fierce as well, as he snapped a short leather whip at the white German shepherd.

title: Americans Much Warmer Toward Soviets, Poll Finds
description: American attitudes toward the Soviet Union are now as favorable as they were at the end of World War II, when the two countries were allies and Churchill had not yet declared the descent of an Iron Curtain, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: The Car Won't Turn To the Ball Park
description: When work and play brought a baseball buff to Florida in November, one of the first thoughts was, ''Oooh, goody, a chance to see a game.''

title: Long Island Journal
description: Teen-Age Tangoists

title: South Carolina Tourist Lure: 100,000 Loads of Sand
description: The first of 100,000 truckloads of sand were dumped this week on a 45-mile strip of South Carolina oceanfront that had been scoured bare by Hurricane Hugo in September.

title: A Pop Virtuoso Who Can Do It All
description: Three years ago last April, Quincy Jones, pillar of the Hollywood pop-music establishment, threw an unusual birthday party for his teen-age son.

title: E.P.A. Expected to Curb Use Of Common Farm Fungicide
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to announce Monday that it will severely restrict use of a common class of farm fungicides because of health risks.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Couscous Ingredient: A Couch Potato
description: Last Sunday was one of those days when the only ingredients that looked appealing in the supermarket required little or no work to be turned into a meal.

title: Review/Music; A Pianist Makes Debut
description: Persistence pays. Krzysztof Jablonski, a pianist from Poland, won third prize in the 1985 Chopin Competition in Warsaw, second prize in the 1988 Dublin International Competition, and first prize in the 1988 Palm Beach Invitational International Competition. Part of his Palm Beach prize was a New York debut recital, which he presented on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: A RACE TO WOO THE MOST LOYAL CUSTOMERS
description: Consumers, prepare to be pampered, the frequency marketers are coming.

title: Julie Lynn Hinds Married In Miami Beach Ceremony
description: The marriage of Julie Lynn Hinds, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald B. Hinds of Miami Lakes, Fla., to Martin Ellis Franklin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland A. E. Franklin of New York and Jumby Bay, Antigua, took place last evening at Temple Beth Shmuel in Miami Beach. Rabbi Ralph Kingsley and Cantor Irving Schulkes officiated.

title: A Picasso For the Raceway
description: HOW do you make a small fortune in automobile racing? Start out with a big fortune, goes the old joke among racers who have found that money goes fast when going fast.

title: Skywalks to Link Mall's Anchors
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on Tower Place, a $60 million retail mall in the center of downtown that will make two existing department stores on adjacent blocks - Saks Fifth Avenue and McAlpins - the mall's anchors. They will be linked to the mall by skywalks.

title: Question Of the Week; Is There Bounty Hunting in The N.F.L.?
description: The charges against Buddy Ryan seem likely to be a lot of hot air. Troy Aikman himself said after the game that he doubted whether the Eagles had a bounty on him. Aikman added that he and Britt Hager, the perpetrator of the controversial late hit, are friends and that Hager apologized for the hit after the game. Aikman also said that he believed Hager's contention that he had not heard the whistle that ended the play on his late hit.

title: Correction
description: An article on the obituary page in some copies last Sunday about a memorial concert for the composer Virgil Thomson included an incorrect account provided by the Cathedral of St. John the Divine about the planning of the event. Before his death, Mr. Thomson approved the cathedral as the site, but the program was planned and the participants were invited by a group of his friends, not by him.

title: CAN A NOVELIST SAVE PERU?
description: Peru's coca problem and the rise of the Sendero Luminoso guerrilla movement are rooted in the fact that the central Government in Lima has not dealt seriously with the agricultural sector of the country. The peasants and their lands have been ignored and their production capabilities miscalculated.

title: WHEN NAIVETE MEETS WALL STREET
description: In the summer of 1987, Patricia Chegut of Englewood, N.J., received $51,751 as the settlement of a dispute involving her ex-husband's business. Mrs. Chegut, a single parent living ''from paycheck to paycheck'' on her teacher's salary, saw the money as a security blanket for herself and a ticket to college for her 9-year-old son, Derek.

title: A Very Different Germany Waits to Be Reborn
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
CONJURING UP THE 1990's
description: SOOTHSAYING HAS A long and checkered history, and the year-end predictions of economic soothsayers generally fare no better than the rest. How much more chancy is the task of the end-of-decade forecaster! Yet there is one clue to the proper approach, provided by the astounding record of the last 10 years: think boldly.

title: 3 Organizations That Help Relieve New Yorkers in Pain, Visible or Invisible; Protestant Federation Helps a Million People
description: New York City can be such a delight in the holiday season. Children can often be found lined up outside Radio City Music Hall for the Christmas show or gazing wide-eyed at the tree in Rockefeller Center. Grandmothers bake gingerbread in their kitchens. Parents hustle to grant the wishes of their children. There is a ''Happy holidays!'' on the lips of most passers-by.

title: SOME WORDS TO WORK BY
description: Presented below are definitions of words and phrases drawn from ''Managerial Literacy: What Today's Managers Must Know to Succeed,'' which is discussed on page 8. The definitions have been prepared by the authors of the book, Gary Shaw and Jack Weber.

title: Mine Cave-Ins Create Sinkholes and Fear in Jersey
description: Two long-dormant air shafts of a pre-Revolutionary War copper mine collapsed beneath two 20th-century backyards this week, leaving gaping holes, creating fears of more cave-ins and raising a mystery about what is happening far below a three-block neighborhood.

title: Where All Is Rationed But Praise for the Leader
description: With foreign delegates and journalists in town for this month's Rumanian Communist Party congress, it was standard practice for the Government to supply Bucharest's shops with goods so that reports of shortages could be exposed as enemy disinformation.

title: Challenges Await Huntington Official
description: AS the Town of Huntington's first Democrat to be elected Supervisor in six years, with only one other party ally on the Town Board, Stephen C. Ferraro has hit his first roadblock even before taking office.

title: Marijuana in Bus Driver's Bag
description: The driver of a chartered bus on which two ABC executives were killed when it was struck by a commuter train last Monday had about five grams of marijuana in his possession, the police said Friday. They said the driver, Patrick Cang, 34 years old, had a carrying case on his bus that contained the marijuana and a pipe. Kurt Sanger, 50, of New York and Adele Roffis, 61, of Los Angeles died in the crash.

title: GARDENING
description: With the garden gate closed for the season, the frenzied chores of sunny mornings have been replaced by peaceful musings on frosty evenings. This armchair gardener has found comfort in a winter book harvest that is certain to brighten the wait until spring. *

title: New League For Walk
description: Not many retired basketball professionals get a chance to return to the court to begin a new season at the age of 41, but Neal Walk, who did just that yesterday, is hardly an ordinary player.

title: Franca Brilliant Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Brilliant of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Franca Brilliant to Seth Grimes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Grimes of Glenside, Pa., and New York. A February wedding is planned.

title: Lost in America
description: IT WAS SEPTEMBER IN MARIN County. By early afternoon the restaurant was filled with people in their shirtsleeves; some wore sunglasses, straw hats and perfect tans. This was California, the land of long summers, grilled baby vegetables and bushels of salad. At the table next to mine, a man was presented with a steaming plate of Yankee pot roast with dumplings.

title: Amos 'n' Andy Are Not Villains
description: To the Editor:

title:
THREE EUROPEAN VIEWS ON THE RISKS OF PEACE;
We Need to Assert Ourselves
description: LEAD: THE Week in Review asked three European journalists to assess how the continent's security needs can be met as the cold war recedes.

title: Review/Rock; Daniel Lanois and the Sounds of Acadia
description: When Daniel Lanois performed Thursday night at the Bottom Line, he was wearing earphones - unusual accouterments for a lead singer, but not for Mr. Lanois in his better-known job as a record producer. After producing albums for U2, Peter Gabriel, Bob Dylan, the Neville Brothers and Robbie Robertson (formerly of the Band), Mr. Lanois decided to make his own. While most record producers probably shouldn't sing in public, Mr. Lanois has a warm, husky voice and picks out lean, clear guitar lines.

title: WHY POPEYE MUMBLED AND WHO MODELED FOR BAMBI
description: ENCHANTED DRAWINGS The History of Animation. By Charles Solomon. Illustrated. 322 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $75.

title: More Space, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine Hi-Fi Roams the Midprice Range
description: The Greek notion of the Golden Mean is having a rough time these days. Our immoderate age, fascinated with the pursuit of outer limits, often takes a condescending view of the middle. But at least in audio, the idea of intelligent moderation persists in the middle price range which, as a group, offers the best dollar value in stereo equipment.

title: Man in the News; V.P. SINGH: LOW-KEY INDIAN IN HIGH-ANXIETY JOB
description: Vishwanath Pratap Singh, chosen on Friday by the centrist National Front to lead its Government, brings a low-key, efficient work style honed by decades of political experience that contrasts with the aggressive, high-profile personality of his predecessor, Rajiv Gandhi.

title: FINANCIAL MARKETS GET NEW SCRUTINY
description: Two top officials in the Bush Administration today strongly urged changes to address what they said are fundamental and structural problems underlying the nation's financial markets.

title: Account of Armenian Massacre Provokes Diplomatic Storm
description: AFTER repeated instances of harassment, disturbing phone calls and a bomb threat, Susan K. Blair, a native of the South Shore of Long Island, has gone into hiding to protect her family and to await this month's release of the book she feels some people do not want to see published.

title: Lifestyle; And Now, in Living Coral . . .
description: For Dr. Jeffrey A. Scolnick, moving a 300-pound, six-foot-long fish tank into his 12th-floor studio apartment was only the first obstacle to overcome before he could have a coral reef beside his bed.

title: Just Had Lunch? Sorry. Dinner Time!
description: EARLY BIRDS are an acquired taste that you should cultivate if you're visiting your folks in Florida this winter. Though not indigenous to this locale, Early Bird Discount Dinners (a k a Sunset Specials) are so cheap and plentiful in Florida restaurants, they are a staple of your folks' diet. As an Official Guest, you'll eat Early Birds, too, so start training now, before heading south. Each night eat dinner a few minutes earlier than the night before. Your target time is 4 P.M., because Early Birds fly in Florida from 3 P.M. to sunset.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's touch and go. A lot of the discounters and big department stores have serious concerns, for good reason. The likelihood is that it's going to be a very tough Christmas.'' Gary Saunders, analyst, Josephthal & Company.

title: How Is a Mighty Instrument Fallen
description: There is no music, it sometimes seems, only musics - subdivisions of the universal art of esthetically ordered sound that appeal to narrow constituencies, most of whom actively disdain the others. But in two decades of wandering through this musical minefield as a critic, I have come across one embattled community that seems to be scorned by the rest of the musical universe. Perhaps scorned is too strong. Dismissed and disdained will do.

title: Photos and Soviet Posters
description: THE opening up of the Soviet Union and other Communist countries is an epic worthy of a less sleazy age. As it is, the show now in the library on Fairleigh Dickinson's Florham-Madison campus does more to convey the feeling of political meltdown than most of the reports by the press.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
800,000 Deer And the Myth Of the Hunter
description: LEAD: CONFRONTED with a rising tide of Lyme disease, deer-car collisions and complaints of damage by deer in northern Westchester, County Executive Andrew O'Rourke commissioned a White-Tailed Deer Study Committee. Since November last year this group has been meeting and conducting studies to resolve man-deer conflicts.

title:
DINING OUT;
Vibrant Chinese Food, Better Than Ever
description: LEAD: SINCE it opened in 1983, Chengdu 46 in Clifton has been one of the state's outstanding Chinese restaurants. Almost always distinguished by refined, authentic food - much of it the vibrant fare of Sichuan - and by courteous service, the restaurant has consistently maintained its quality. And this is in spite of an unpromising location amid car dealerships on bustling Route 46 in Passaic

title: Review/Dance; Fable of Gods and Men, To Music by Hovhaness
description: Eric Hawkins has come to seem a choreographer of primarily luminous pure dance pieces with delicate traces of symbolism woven through. But he is a storyteller, too, as a performance of ''God the Reveler'' suggested on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, where the Erick Hawkins Dance Company appears through Sunday.

title: Carla Freedman, Lawyer, Marries
description: Carla Beth Freedman, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Neil Evan Ross, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married in Syracuse last evening. Rabbis Charles Sherman and Daniel Jezer officiated at Temple Adath Yeshurun.

title: Review/Film; A Black South African's Radicalization
description: ''Mapantsula'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 24, 1988. The film opens today at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets.

title: The Shaking Off
description: A political earthquake sends East Europeans surging into the streets to shake off oppression. The impulse is like the one that, two years ago this week, first sent Palestinians into the streets to protest Israeli occupation. The intifada they call it - literally ''the shaking off.''

title: EG&G;'S RISK AT ROCK FLATS
description: LEAD: JOHN KUCHARSKI, chairman of EG&G; Inc., was winding up a week-long management conference at the Stratton Mountain ski resort in Vermont on Sept. 22 when James D. Watkins, the Secretary of Energy, called.

title: LILLE GETS READY FOR '92
description: LEAD: IN THE FRENCH CITY OF LILLE, LOCAL GOVERNMENT proceeds under the watchful eye of Lyderic, a benevolent stone giant who stands guard at the base of the city hall's belfry. According to legend, Lyderic founded the town in the seventh century, after defeating his enemy, the wicked giant Phinaert. He has long manned his post on Lille's pink-brick mairie, silent witness to the erratic fortunes of this ancient town.

title: 'Georgia O'Keeffe: A Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Officials Reinstated in a Call for Healing
description: In an effort to end turmoil in New York City's Human Rights Commission, its chairman reversed himself on Friday and reinstated the top two officials in the AIDS Discrimination Division.

title: Trains Collide in Louisiana
description: Two Southern Pacific freight trains collided today, causing eight cars to be knocked into a swamp and forcing the evacuation of more than 50 people for fear that hazardous cargo was leaking. When it was determined there was no leak, everyone was allowed to return home, said a sheriff's spokesman.

title: Expressway Board Plan Meets Local Opposition
description: A PLAN by the State Department of Transportation to build a system of roads that would connect at the Seaford-Oyster Bay interchange with the Long Island Expressway and link with the service-road system to the east and west has provoked opposition from residents and elected officials.

title: Secaucus Journal; From Farms to Shoppers' Mecca
description: YEARS ago, the town of Secaucus enjoyed two unusual claims to fame: the failed 1956 Presidential bid of Henry Krajewski, a local tavern owner, and the dubious distinction of being prime real estate for pig farmers. Indeed, Mr. Krajewski, who ran as an independent, adopted as his campaign slogan ''No Piggy Deals in Washington.'' Times have changed. Mr. Krajewski died in 1966, his Presidential aspirations unfulfilled. The pig farms have given way to warehouse outlet stores, corporate headquarters and elegant shopping malls. And a drive down Secaucus Road is now likely to lead to a stationary sea of cars filled with New York shoppers, all breathing the sweet smell of Secaucus's success.

title: A Bit Player Buys Into the Computer Age
description: IN A JANUARY NIGHT IN 1973, ALAN R. FRASER lugged a cardboard carton through customs and stepped into the crowded arrivals hall of Manila International Airport. The New Zealand entrepreneur was desperate. Fraser needed a company with the equipment and the low-cost data-entry typists to convert his box of paper into computer files. He had just come from Singapore, where a small shop had attempted the job - but had made so many errors the work was worthless. That left Fraser with only 24 hours to fulfill his company's first contract, a $500 order from an Australian accounting house.

title:
DINING OUT;
Seasonal Fare and Artworks in Tarrytown
description: LEAD: HAD we but time enough, we would visit the Gallery often. Not because it has, like some restaurants we admire, constancy, dependability and tradition locked into every venerable beam and brick but because this relatively plain dining room is a place of change. Rotating artworks, extensive and frequently updated wine lists, seasonal menus with plenty of good food in new and unusual combinations - all contribute to an exciting dinner out.

title: Retiring of Airline Pilots at 60 Is Under Fire Again
description: The chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging is renewing his attack on a Federal rule that prohibits pilots from flying jetliners after they turn 60 years old.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Newbury, N.H.;
Town Rescinds Project Permit
description: LEAD: THE Town Planning Board has voted to rescind its approval for 79 expensive year-round second homes on 135 acres abutting Mount Sunapee State Park and ski area because the developer has not proceeded with the project. The property has 1,000 feet of shoreline on the 10-mile-long Lake Sunapee.

title: 3 Organizations That Help Relieve New Yorkers in Pain, Visible or Invisible; Assisting Henry I. In His Search for a Job
description: It was a year ago that the story of Henry I., a 27-year-old deaf man who is learning-disabled and successfully employed, was told. Until he began work at the H. B. Company in the East New York section of Brooklyn, he had never held a job very long.

title: PITCHING DOCTORS
description: Every time I read another doctor-bashing article in your magazine, I wonder why you don't provide space for a rebuttal from the other side. Your readers should know that most physicians are aware that the detail men and women are full of hype. Physicians rely on their own experience, on other physicians' advice and on the literature. I don't change the medications I know work well just because some salesman walks into my office with ''goodies and trinkets.'' WILLIAM J.SOMERS, M.D. Painter, Va.

title: Quilt Celebrates State's Farmlands
description: LEAD: SITTING in a shed on her farm in Chesterfield Township recently, Jean Keisling was directing customers, who had come to pick apples, to the rows of apple trees. All the while, she was working on the embroidery on her lap. ''I never missed a stitch,'' she said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Tampa
description: Tampa is no longer the sleepy little city it was only a few years ago. Its population and that of surrounding Hillsborough County has skyrocketed from about 490,000 to about 826,000 in less than 20 years (the population of the city itself is about 287,000).

title: OFF-STACK VILLAINY
description: STRAIGHT By Dick Francis. 323 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: CAPTURING C.E.O.'s FOR POSTERITY
description: ''IT SEEMS TO BE A LAW OF NATURE,'' WROTE SIR MAX Beerbohm, the late English essayist and caricaturist, ''that no man is ever loath to sit for his portrait. A man may be old, he may be ugly, he may be burdened with grave responsibilities to the nation . . . but none of these considerations, nor all of them together, will deter him from sitting for his portrait.''

title: Craig Bray to Wed Patricia Andrews
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Andrews Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Shanley Andrews, to Craig Stewart Bray, a son of Irene Bray-Jerue of Stamford, Conn., and Eugene E. Bray of Meridian, Idaho. A January wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Connecticut Weekly last Sunday about AIDS education referred incorrectly to the role of the Connecticut Education Department in monitoring instruction in the public schools. The department indeed checks regularly to be sure school districts are offering AIDS classes, in compliance with state law.

title: New Procedure
description: Billie Sol Estes has always had his own peculiar notions about the art of the deal. Mr. Estes, the smooth-talking Texas schemer who made millions in phantom fertilizer back in the 1960's and called President Lyndon B. Johnson his good buddy, said he was all through with fast deals when he ended his most recent stint in prison in 1983. When he was released then after serving four years for parole violation (in 1971 he was paroled after serving six years for mail fraud and conspiracy in connection with his fertilizer venture) he likened his interest in creative enterprise to alcoholism. ''I'm just one drink away from being drunk and one deal away from being back in prison,'' he said. Now prosecutors think the 64-year-old entrepreneur may have done that deal. Mr. Estes and five associates were indicted last week on charges of stealing trade secrets. The authorities said that Mr. Estes and the others conspired to set up their own business using plans stolen from another company. Mr. Estes, who denied any wrongdoing in the matter, is to be arraigned this week.

title: New Champ
description: Just when it seemed that America was being consumed by despair of ever again doing anything better than the Japanese, there arrived 490 pounds of hope named Konishiki. The 25-year-old Hawaiian, who was born Salevaa Atisnoe, last week rocked the tradition-bound world of sumo wrestling by becoming the first foreigner in 17 years to win the Emperor's Cup, Japan's most coveted sports prize. With his victory in the annual tournament, Konishiki also moved a step closer to becoming the first foreigner ever to hold the exalted sumo rank of yokozuna. As a non-Japanese in a quintessentially Japanese sport, the huge wrestler has heard more than a few unkind comments during his five-year career. A few years ago, a former sumo champion said Konishiki's rise was ''a shame for Japan.'' And, in tones reminiscent of Americans who once bemoaned the fate of boxing dominated by black champions, a Japanese novelist said that if the Hawaiian were accorded the sport's top rank, ''sumo tournaments should be called off.'' None of it seemed to bother Konishiki. ''My dream has come true,'' he said.

title: Is Summitry Outmoded?
description: When President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union complete their summit conference on Sunday, they will head off to tell their friends how they have done. Mr. Bush will fly to

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 19 about a plan by two former state insurance commissioners to sell automobile insurance below current market rates misstated the effect on policyholders from potential losses. James J. Sheeran, one former commissioner, said a $750,000 surplus would be maintained to shield policyholders from losses; the losses would not be shared with policyholders.

title: IMAGE OF A CHAMPION
description: SIXTEEN MONTHS AGO, I BECAME the first American to open and run an ice cream parlor in Seoul. In some ways, it didn't make much sense. The South Korean Government was notorious for its unwillingness to open markets to foreigners. Moreover, Koreans traditionally have no taste for dairy products or sweet desserts. Yet somehow I think my father would have approved.

title: AT THE TOP: AN EXPLOSION OF PAY PACKAGES
description: LEAD: IS THE SEASON FOR GIFT GIVING. Across the land, C.E.O.'s, their vice presidents for human resources and their compensation specialists are now assembling catalogues of gifts for top management that include hefty salary increases, bonuses and stock option grants. The goodies will not be under anyone's Christmas tree by the 25th, because boards of directors do not make their final choices from the gift catalogues until January or February.

title: Review/Music; Tom Harrell on Trumpet
description: The trumpeter Tom Harrell's first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night began in earnest halfway through. With Joe Lovano on soprano saxophone and Mr. Harrell on fluegelhorn, the band picked up some speed and finally began playing as an ensemble. Using arrangements by Mr. Harrell - he makes careful use of repeating patterns for the rhythm section - the band began abstracting the basic material of the tunes, using it as fuel for improvisation.

title: Colleges Ask to Be Called Universities
description: WHAT'S in a name? A lot, say the presidents of several New Jersey colleges who are seeking to relax restrictions on the use of the term ''university'' when describing the state's institutions of higher learning.

title: Cliches Are Of the Essence
description: To the Editor:

title: Only 6 Qualify As Dynasties
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: A chapter of photography history is coming to an end. No, I don't mean that the 150th anniversary of photography's birth ends this month, although that's true enough. I'm thinking of the demise of the Kodak Colorama in New York City's Grand Central Terminal.

title: On the Same Side
description: The test of Malta will be whether George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev have taken advantage of the sudden new reality in East-West relations. That is the fact that, in profound ways, the interests of the United States and the Soviet Union now coincide.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Alan Rapoport;
'Migraine Is an Occasional Headache'
description: LEAD: PEOPLE who tend to get headaches are likely to have more of them this month and those who do not may have a few, according to Dr. Alan Rapoport, the co-director of the New England Headache Treatment Program.

title: Nancy L. Tellier Is Wed in Larchmont
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont, N.Y., Nancy Lyn Tellier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tellier of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Murphy van der Velde, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Christiaan D. van der Velde of Norwich, Conn. Msgr. James F. McCarthy, a secretary to John Cardinal O'Connor, officiated.

title: Work of This Chorus Goes Beyond Caroling
description: LEAD: EVEN before the Random Choristers II were known as the Random Choristers - back in 1940 when the fledgling group was called the Tilt Choristers - they were trying to spread a bit of holiday cheer throughout northern Westchester.

title: JUST ANOTHER NIGHT ON CRACK STREET
description: It is difficult to disagree with Philippe Bourgois's assertion that ''. . . ambitious, energetic, inner-city youths are attracted to the underground economy precisely because they believe in the rags-to-riches American Dream.'' Horatio Alger with a needle.

title: Where an Empty Seat Is Hard to Find
description: THE building on the corner of the Post Road and Dearfield Drive in downtown Greenwich is not only one of the busiest spots in town, but it is also the busiest library in Connecticut, according to State Library figures. Informal and bustling, it is as user friendly as a neighborhood pub.

title: Reality for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL
description: Like experimental novels in which the technique or approach take the place of plot or character, there are now travel books in which the vehicle is the thing and the place or people are secondary. Like modern paintings, these books suggest that we've already seen the world, and now it's best looked at from a kayak, a rubber raft or balloon, in what Willem de Kooning called ''slipping glimpses.'' Perhaps the quintessentially modern travel book would be that of the big-game hunter, who sees the sights only through his sights, who goes to a place to shoot and kill whatever ''wildlife'' it offers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-31

title: When Artistic Skills Are Applied to Toys
description: LEAD: ARTISTS, a highly individualist lot bent on creating their own forms, have conformed to a theme for a show at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Brick $164,900 527 Midwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; c/a, 2-car garage, family room, patio; taxes $2,472. Elmwood Park $184,500 144 Miller Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; pool, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,823. Howell $211,500 25 Rimwood Lane 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; deck, den, w/w carpeting, c/a; taxes $3,455. Livingston $312,500 5 Page Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen, patio; taxes $4,118. Orange $200,000 42 Clairmont Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,037. Wall $325,000 708 Allenwood Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old Dutch colonial;, family room with skylight, eat-in kitchen, dining room; taxes $3,185. OTHER AREAS Cheshire, Conn. $260,000 7 Worden Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old saltbox; cherry-stained floors, breakfast area, 1.1 acres; taxes $3,603. New Rochelle, N.Y. $445,500 71 Baraud Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 43-year-old brick colonial; 2 fireplaces, family room, deck, 2-car garage, 0.24 acre; taxes $7,200. Amityville, L.I. $182,000 22 Towne Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old brick Tudor; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,800.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Two South Africans, spearfishing on the west coast of South Africa three years ago, found the remains of a ship carrying 3,000 examples of Swedish Platmynt, the largest circulating coins ever minted.

title: A PRINCE OF HOLLYWOOD
description: ON THE PARAMOUNT STUDIO LOT EARLY IN THE fall, there is a screening party given by the producers of ''Black Rain.'' As the credits appear, the crowd bursts into applause. ''Produced by Jaffe-Lansing, in association with Michael Douglas.'' Within the industry, this partnership has magical associations. More than most private screenings, this is a ''family'' affair.

title: Dinkins Still Has Many Jobs to Fill And Many Groups To Placate
description: BY Dec. 1, 1965, New York City Mayor-elect John V. Lindsay had appointed two deputy mayors and commissioners of the fire and investigation departments. By that date eight years later, incoming Mayor Abraham D. Beame had named two deputy mayors, his budget director and corporation counsel. By Dec. 1, 1977, Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch had appointed four deputy mayors and his corporation counsel.

title: Ms. Levinbook, Professor, Wed
description: Nancy Beth Levinbook, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin S. Levinbook of York, Pa., was married there last evening at Temple Beth Israel to Dr. David Michael Widlus, the son of Martha Widlus of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Irwin Goldenberg officiated.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: Ronald Merrick, the chill Army officer at the center of ''The Raj Quartet,'' Paul Scott's compelling novels of British India, compared Subhas Chandra Bose to Hitler. Democratic India has honored Bose with three commemorative stamps. What is the truth about this man? Buried in a few catalogues is a list of 21 stamps inscribed Azad Hind or Free India. There is no indication the stamps were ever used on mail, or indeed that they ever left Europe, where an estimated 12 million were printed.

title: Pierce Awarded Grant to Friend Over Objections
description: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. gave a $350,000 development grant to a longtime friend even though other officials at the Department of Housing and Urban Development had rejected the award, H.U.D. documents and interviews show.

title: Medical School To Buy Historic Valhalla House
description: ONE of the county's oldest buildings will play a role in solving one of its newest problems. After four months of negotiation, the Westchester County Historical Society has agreed to sell the Hammond House, the 270-year-old building it owns on the edge of the Grasslands Reservation in Valhalla to New York Medical College for use as a Lyme disease research center.

title: Ms. Hoenig Wed To D. B. Maynard
description: Kathryn Lee Hoenig, an associate at the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, and Douglass Bayley Maynard, an associate at the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, were married in New York yesterday by the Rev. John B. Macnab at the First Presbyterian Church. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Hoenig of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Maynard of Westport, Conn.

title: NBC Show Deletes G.E. Mention
description: A reference to the General Electric Company, which owns NBC, was removed from a report on shoddy products that was televised Thursday by the network's ''Today'' program.

title: Jail Costs Rise as Counties Tighten Belts
description: LEAD: THE escape of three inmates, two of them convicted murderers, from the Nassau County Correctional Center in East Meadow last month has resulted in a series of investigations into procedures at the jail.

title: Dr. Murphy Departs
description: Dr. Joseph Murphy, who will step down next year as chancellor of the City University of New York, has a lot in common with many CUNY students: he's a son of working-class parents who sought to better himself through academic training.

title: Bush Proposes Steps to Help Improve the Soviet Union's Ailing Economy
description: Under pressure to speed the improvement of Soviet-American relations, President Bush today offered proposals aimed at advancing the most neglected area of the superpower relationship: economics and trade.

title: Abortion and Religion Put Focus on Election
description: Under normal circumstances, the race for the California State Senate in the 39th District here would be an obscure one with few voters turning out.

title: Not Everyone Applauds New Phone Services
description: THE recent introduction of two new telephone services has touched off a debate over whether they are an invasion of privacy. One of the new technologies allows customers to see the numbers of people who call them; the other lets them receive and retrieve messages from a telephone company computer.

title: Linda Bell Weds R. L. Blackburn
description: Linda Brantley Bell and Ronald Louis Blackburn were married yesterday by the Rev. George H. White at the Central Brick Presbyterian Church in East Orange, N.J. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John Jordan and Edward Brantley Salaam, both of Roselle, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lemuel H. Blackburn of Ewing Township, N.J.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
A Palm For Every Parlor
description: LEAD: Palm trees may be a part of the landscape in Florida or southern California, but in the colder climates particularly in the New England States, they are indoor plants. And popular ones at that.

title: Miss Weingarten Wed to S. R. Singer
description: Leslie Joy Weingarten, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Weingarten of New York and New Milford, Conn., was married last evening at the Hotel Westbury in New York to Scott Ryan Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Singer of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Stanley Davids officiated.

title: COFFEETABLE BOOKS: A PASSION FOR PICTURES
description: LEAD: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. BROADWAY BALLYHOO: The American Theater Seen in Posters, Photographs, Magazines, Caricatures, and Programs.

title:
GARDENING;
Pruning Can Yield Christmas Greens
description: LEAD: WHEN ancient tribes celebrated the winter solstice, evergreen bows were used for decoration much as they are today for the Christmas celebration. In the time of year when shorter days and cold weather made life seem desolate, plants that retained their green foliage were considered a symbol that life was still present in the forest and that spring would indeed return.

title: POSTINGS: For Hamptons Golfers; Houses on the Fairway
description: Construction is scheduled to start in February on a five-bedroom house on a one-acre plot adjoining the seventh and eighth holes of the Westhampton Country Club in Suffolk County. The 3,800-square-foot house is to be the first of six in a development to be named the Fairways on South Road between the communities of Westhampton and Westhampton Beach.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A roof leak caused the latex-painted walls in my home to blister and created yellow stains on the wallpaper. Is there any way to remove the stains, and can the blisters on the dry wall be removed?

title: It's All Unreal
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Program of Premieres To Benefit Pro Musicis
