description: Michel Roux, who runs an import firm in Teaneck, N.J., capped a recent history of contemporary arts patronage Wednesday night with a program of five orchestral premieres at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert was called ''Absolut Concerto,'' and the Swedish vodka company provided the funds for the commissions of four of the works. The fifth, a Symphony No. 1 (''Utah'') by John Duffy, was paid for by the Utah chapter of the Sierra Club. The concert was a benefit for the Pro Musicis foundation, which stages concerts in prisons and hospitals.

title: Pastimes; Aroung the Garden
description: For This Week: If old flower stalks of perennials are still standing, cut them to near ground level. Don't forget to move hoses inside and shut off outdoor faucets for winter. Also, the power tools should be cleaned and stored, especially mowers. Apply anti-desiccant sprays any time this month to conifers, rosebushes and broadleaved evergreens to cut down on drying out; the colorless material wears off in a few months and may need to be re-applied in February. Some of the New Books

title: Southern Memories Shadow the Makers Of 'Convicts'
description: Just outside a dilapidated storeroom, a balding plantation owner crouches down, staring intently at the ground. ''There's a boy out here says I owe him some money,'' he growls to a shabbily attired employee standing on the porch. The wizened figure picks up some pecans scattered amid the fallen leaves as he barks out questions: ''Where is Nancy?'' ''Where's Julia?'' ''Where's Sarah?''

title: Salvador Jesuit Is Undeterred By Killing of 6
description: On Nov. 17 in Bangkok, Thailand, the Rev. Jon Sobrino, an internationally known theologian from El Salvador, was giving a lecture about Jesus to Asians interested in Latin American liberation theology.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Sip of Irony in the Cafe

title: Campus Life: Goddard; In Vermont Hills, Students Restore Historic Campus
description: In a project designed to benefit both the body and soul of Goddard College and of its students, undergraduates are restoring the school's historic buildings and grounds. Already, three porches of the 80-year-old Martin Manor, the campus focal point, have been cleaned, repaired and, where necessary, recreated in accordance with the historical record.

title: Stephanie Moffett Is Wed
description: Stephanie Amara Moffett, a daughter of Col. Roy E. Moffett, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Moffett of Rocky Ford, Colo., was married yesterday to Stanley Lawrence Pence, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Pence of Merced, Calif. The Rev. Richard Leonard officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The bride, 27 years old, is an account supervisor at DDB Needham Worldwide Advertising in New York. Mr. Pence, 29, is a retail government securities sales liaison at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. The bride graduated from Harvard University; the bridegroom from the University of California at Berkeley.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Zembriski Wins: Walter Zembriski birdied four of the first eight holes and shot a 5-under-par 65 yesterday in the final round of the GTE West Classic in Ojai, Calif., to win his first PGA Senior Tour title of 1989. Zembriski finished the 54-hole tournament at 13-under 197 on the 6,190-yard, par-70 Ojai Valley Country Club. He won $52,500.(AP) In Front by 4: Peter Senior shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday and took a four-stroke lead after the third round of the Australian Open at Melbourne. Senior had a 54-hole total of 15-under-par 201, four shots ahead of the defending champion, Mark Calcavecchia.(AP) Two Teams Share Lead: Gene Sauers and Beth Daniel were tied for the lead in the J. C. Penney Classic with Jay Don Blake and Tracy Kerdyk yesterday after each team scored a 54-hole 17-under-par 209 in the third round at Largo, Fla.(AP) Skiing Austrian Takes Giant Slalom: Gunther Mader of Austria turned in a scintillating second run to win a men's World Cup giant slalom race yesterday at Mont-Ste-Anne, Quebec. Mader had a combined time of 2 minutes 31.04 seconds.(AP) Victory at Last: Regine Mosenlechner of West Germany got the first victory of her 15-year World Cup career yesterday in a women's supergiant slalom on Vail Mountain in Vail, Colo. She had a time of 1 minute 25.67 seconds.(AP) Horse Racing Long Shot Wins: Appealing Guy pulled away in the final furlong for a 2 1/4-length victory in the $89,850 Joe Palmer Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct. Appealing Guy, ridden by Jacinto Vasquez. returned $23 for $2 to win. The Real Virginian was second; Banquo third.(AP) Bowling Title for Venezuelan: Amleto Monacelli of Venezuela had a string of early strikes and beat Brian Voss of Boca Raton, Fla., 235-209, yesterday to win the Professional Bowlers Association touring players championship in Detroit.(AP) Bobsledding East Germans Ahead: With a combined time of 1 minute 39.38 seconds for two runs, East Germany's A team led the World Cup four-man bobsled event after the first day's competition yesterday at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. West Germany's B team was second.(AP) Dog Show Elkhound Rated Best: A Norwegian elkhound was chosen as best of 2,766 dogs at the 95th All Breed Show of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia yesterday. The winner was Ch. Vin-Melca's Calista, a 3-year-old bitch owned by Carol Andersenn of Bayport, Minn. N.H.L. Blues 2, Bruins 1: Paul MacLean and Brett Hull scored goals 13 seconds apart in the first period in Boston and St. Louis made them stand up. MacLean took a backhand pass from Adam Oates in the corner and put a 20-footer over the glove of the Boston goalie, Reggie Lemelin, at 10:10 of the first period. Hull picked up a loose puck in the Boston zone and fired his 19th goal of the season, again over Lemelin's glove, at 10:23. Cam Neely of Boston went scoreless after having made at least one goal in each of the last eight games, one short of Phil Esposito's team record of nine.(AP) Penguins 7, Nordiques 4: Mario Lemieux's third and last goal of the game and 316th of his career moved him into a tie for Pittsburgh's career record with Jean Pronovost, who retired in 1978. Playing at Quebec, Lemieux also extended his points streak to 15 games. He scored twice in the first six minutes.(AP)

title: Tasteless Dutch Tomatoes and Waiters Named Terry
description: A EUROPE WHERE THE TRAVELER'S electric shaver can be plugged in and works regardless of country, where road signs are uniform and frontiers can be crossed without tiresome formality. A Europe with a common currency and similar working conditions in each country - indeed, similar workers. A Europe no longer of disparate, strange, even feuding countries, but one happy family of nations living in harmony and sharing a common culture. How convenient. How ghastly.

title: Notable Paperbacks
description: This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the December 1988 Christmas issue. It includes novels, poetry, stories, biography, memoirs, letters, history, essays and science. ADAM, EVE, AND THE SERPENT, by Elaine Pagels. (Vintage, $8.95.) The author of ''The Gnostic Gospels'' shows how politics might have helped transform the cryptic Garden of Eden myth from a celebration of freedom to a condemnation of original sin. AMERICA INVULNERABLE: The Quest for Absolute Security From 1812 to Star Wars, by James Chace and Caleb Carr. (Summit, $12.95.) The Strategic Defense Initiative, the authors argue, is the outgrowth of an obsessive belief in unilateral defense that is rooted in the War of 1812, when the British burned the White House. AN ARTIST OF THE FLOATING WORLD, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Vintage, $8.95.) A novel about a Japanese artist who used his talents to glorify the imperialist movement. ANTHILLS OF THE SAVANNAH, by Chinua Achebe. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) A Nigerian novelist's tale of three friends who try to run a country. THE ARK SAKURA, by Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. (Vintage International, $8.95.) Inside a hollowed-out mountain, a Japanese beggar assembles a group of outcasts intent on surviving nuclear war. BAD BEHAVIOR, by Mary Gaitskill. (Vintage, $7.95.) For the unhappy characters who populate these matter-of-fact stories, there is nothing very remarkable about sadomasochism. BEING WITH CHILDREN, by Phillip Lopate. (Poseidon, $9.95.) A novelist and essayist tells about his experiences trying to teach writing to children on New York's Upper West Side. BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Signet/New American Library, $5.95.) The true story of Rob Marshall, a wealthy New Jersey suburbanite, who arranges to have his wife shot to death during a faked robbery. Also available from Signet is a new edition of FATAL VISION ($5.95), Mr. McGinniss's account of the murder by Jeffrey McDonald of his pregnant wife and two children in 1970. In a new epilogue the author rebuts a New Yorker article that accused him of tricking Mr. McDonald into confiding in him. THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD, by Iris Murdoch. (Penguin, $8.95.) A novel about lapsed revolutionaries from Oxford who decide to bankroll a friend who is writing a utopian tract. BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) In another novel about eccentrics in Baltimore, Maggie Moran, a cheerful, meddling woman, marries off her son to a 17-year-old she shanghais from an abortion clinic. A BRIGHT SHINING LIE: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam, by Neil Sheehan. (Vintage, $12.95.) This story of an officer whose deceptions came to typify the war in Vietnam won a National Book Award and a Pulitzer Prize. BY SILENCE BETRAYED: Sexual Abuse of Children in America, by John Crewdson. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A journalist shows that when it comes to sexual abuse children have more to fear from their families and friends than from violent interlopers. CAPOTE: A Biography, by Gerald Clarke. (Ballantine, $12.95.) A mesmerizing account of Truman Capote's lifelong masquerade ball. THE CAPTAIN AND THE ENEMY, by Graham Greene. (Penguin, $7.95.) A novel whose narrator, deep in the Central American jungles, seeks the true identity of a mysterious stranger who once spirited him away from a boarding school, claiming to have won him in a backgammon game. CLOAK & GOWN: Scholars in the Secret War, 1939-1961, by Robin W. Winks. (Quill/Morrow, $14.95.) How Yale University has provided the Government with very well educated spies. COMING OF AGE IN THE MILKY WAY, by Timothy Ferris. (Anchor/Doubleday, $10.95.) A chronicle of how the human spirit outgrew the earth and set its sights to the sky. DANGEROUS DOSSIERS: Exposing the Secret War Against America's Greatest Authors, by Herbert Mitgang. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The Federal Bureau of Investigation's secret files on Sinclair Lewis, William Faulkner and other literary suspects. THE CONTROL REVOLUTION: Technological and Economic Origins of the Information Society, by James R. Beniger. (Harvard University, $12.95.) How the Industrial Revolution begat the Information Revolution, by producing a society so complex that it requires computers to keep it from inevitably slipping toward entropy. A DEADLY SILENCE. The Ordeal of Cheryl Pierson: A Case of Incest and Murder, by Dena Kleiman. (Signet/ New American Library, $4.95.) A New York Times reporter tells about the sexually abused Long Island teen-ager who paid a classmate $400 to kill her father. DICTIONARY OF THE KHAZARS: A Lexicon Novel in 100,000 Words, by Milorad Pavic. Translated by Christina Pribicevic-Zoric. (Vintage, $9.95.) A novel, in the form of a do-it-yourself narrative, about a fictional tribe called the Khazars, who lived in a land where the seasons were marked by calendars that flowed in both directions and it was possible to read colors as though they were words. DISCOS AND DEMOCRACY: China in the Throes of Reform, by Orville Schell. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) In a book published a year before China's latest cataclysm, a Western journalist wonders whether the ancient society can withstand the pressures of modernization. THE DREAMS OF REASON: The Computer and the Rise of the Sciences of Complexity, by Heinz R. Pagels. (Bantam, $9.95.) A physicist tells how the computer, like the telescope and the microscope, will change the way we understand the world. DUSK: And Other Stories, by James Salter. (North Point, $7.95.) Laconic stories about exiles and drifters. EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) In one of these short stories, a high school astronomy teacher's campaign to save an old elm tree threatens to erupt into a neighborhood war. AN EMPIRE OF THEIR OWN: How the Jews Invented Hollywood, by Neal Gabler. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) Spurned by East Coast high society, entrepreneurs like Adolph Zukor, L. B. Mayer, the Warner brothers and Harry Cohn established their own fantasy land in Southern California. THE FACTS: A Novelist's Autobiography, by Philip Roth. (Penguin, $7.95.) Philip Roth comes clean with the true story of his heavily fictionalized life, including, for good measure, commentary by his character Nathan Zuckerman. FAMILY MEMORIES: An Autobiographical Journey, by Rebecca West. Edited by Faith Evans. (Penguin, $7.95.) Surprisingly absorbing recollections about the writer's relatives. FLANAGAN'S VERSION: A Spectator's Guide to Science on the Eve of the 21st Century, by Dennis Flanagan. (Vintage, $8.95.) After spending 35 years as editor of Scientific American, Dennis Flanagan learned that science is the greatest spectator sport of all. HER OWN TERMS, by Judith Grossman. (Ivy, $3.95.) A refugee from dreary south London finds that the Oxford literary world can be just as oppressive to women. HEROES OF THEIR OWN LIVES. The Politics and History of Family Violence: Boston 1880-1960, by Linda Gordon. (Penguin, $8.95.) A history of a society's attitudes toward child abuse, incest and wife beating. THE HIGH ROAD, by Edna O'Brien. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) A novel about an Irish expatriate who shatters the languid calm of a Spanish island when she has an affair with a local peasant girl. IN SEARCH OF J. D. SALINGER, by Ian Hamilton. (Vintage, $8.95.) A very unauthorized biography of the writer who chose to slip through a tear in the Veil of Maya and disappear into the silence of New Hampshire. IN THE AGE OF THE SMART MACHINE: The Future of Work and Power, by Shoshana Zuboff. (Basic Books, $11.95.) Thanks to the computer, work is becoming less a matter of manipulating things than manipulating symbols. JULIA PARADISE, by Rod Jones. (Penguin, $6.95.) The tale of a Shanghai psychoanalyst who cures a missionary's wife of tormenting fantasies by making love to her. THE KING OF THE FIELDS, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) A fairy tale of sex and violence about a tribe of cave-dwelling hunters and gatherers who fight the farmers, set in prehistoric Poland. Translated by the author from the Yiddish. LIBRA, by Don DeLillo. (Penguin, $4.95.) A novel about a C.I.A. conspiracy to kill President John F. Kennedy and blame Fidel Castro by fingering a Communist dupe named Lee Harvey Oswald. LAST DAYS OF THE SICILIANS: The FBI's War Against the Mafia, by Ralph Blumenthal. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) After Carmine Galante was murdered in a Brooklyn restaurant in 1979, Federal investigators learned of a Mafia within the Mafia, which used a network of pizzerias to launder drug money. THE LETTERS OF JOHN CHEEVER, edited by Benjamin Cheever. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) A hefty selection of letters, accompanied by editorial commentary, that presents a loving but far from idealized portrait. LIFE, A USER'S MANUAL, by Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. (Godine, $14.95.) Complex word games and characters that include a millionaire who makes jigsaw puzzles that he himself must solve. LIVES OF THE TWINS, by Rosamond Smith. (Avon, $3.95.) Joyce Carol Oates's pseudonymous novel about a woman who has a secret affair with her therapist's estranged identical twin. LONGING FOR THE HARMONIES: Themes and Variations From Modern Physics, by Frank Wilczek and Betsy Devine. (Norton, $9.95.) How physicists find order beneath the cacophony of subatomic particles, quasars, pulsars and black holes. MASCARA, by Ariel Dorfman. (Penguin, $7.95.) An ominous novel about a man without a face who steals the visages of others. THE MATHEMATICAL TOURIST: Snapshots of Modern Mathematics, by Ivars Peterson. (Freeman, $10.95.) Mathematicians seek truth and beauty with fractals, prime numbers, strange attractors, cellular automata and other abstractions. THE MIDDLEMAN AND OTHER STORIES, by Bharati Mukherjee. (Fawcett, $3.95.) From Vietnam, the Caribbean, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka to Queens, Ann Arbor and Cedar Falls, the modern immigrants in these short stories create a multiplicity of new worlds. MISSING BEAUTY, by Teresa Carpenter. (Zebra, $4.95.) In a true story of obsession and murder, a middle-aged medical school professor resorts to homicide to kick an expensive habit: Robin Benedict, a prostitute from Boston's Combat Zone. NATURAL OBSESSIONS: Striving to Unlock the Deepest Secrets of the Cancer Cell, by Natalie Angier. (Warner, $14.95.) A journalist becomes resident anthropologist in a molecular biology lab, chronicling the search for genes that cause cells to become malignant. NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS, by Richard Wilbur. Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) This collection of poems by the man named the United States' poet laureate in 1987 won a Pulitzer Prize. NORA: A Biography of Nora Joyce, by Brenda Maddox. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) A young Irish chambermaid named Nora Barnacle eloped with an aspiring writer named James Joyce for a mismatch made in heaven. NOTHING BUT THE BEST: The Struggle for Perfection at the Juilliard School, by Judith Kogan. (Limelight Editions, $10.95.) A lawyer and harpist who graduated from Juilliard tells of cutthroat competition at her alma mater. NOWHERE TO GO: The Tragic Odyssey of the Homeless Mentally Ill, by E. Fuller Torrey. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $8.95.) A psychiatrist blames his colleagues for treating the ''worried well,'' who can afford to pay their bills, at the expense of the homeless. PACO'S STORY, by Larry Heinemann. (Penguin, $7.95.) A novel about a Vietnam veteran whose nightmares follow him back to Texas and a job in a greasy spoon. The novel won a National Book Award. THE PAPER: The Life and Death of The New York Herald Tribune, by Richard Kluger with the assistance of Phyllis Kluger. (Vintage, $16.95.) The history of the newspaper that gave Tom Wolfe his start. PARIS TROUT, by Pete Dexter. (Penguin, $7.95.) After a Georgia shopkeeper named Paris Trout kills a 14-year-old black girl, the people in the town of Cotton Point try to convince themselves that they are somehow different from their racist, paranoid neighbor. The novel won a National Book Award. PARTING THE WATERS: America in the King Years 1954-63, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) A Pulitzer Prize-winning history of the Civil Rights movement. THE PIGEON, by Patrick Suskind. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $5.95.) The well-ordered life of a Parisian bank guard is transformed completely when a pigeon shows up at his door. THE POET AT THE PIANO: Portraits of Writers, Filmmakers, Playwrights, and Other Artists at Work, by Michiko Kakutani. (Peter Bedrick, $8.95.) A collection of profiles, including such subjects as Saul Bellow, Ingmar Bergman, Sam Shepard and Laurence Olivier, by a New York Times book critic. THE POWER GAME: How Washington Works, by Hedrick Smith. (Ballantine, $5.95.) In recent times, Washington has become fractured into hundreds of power centers, each fighting to garner enough influence to get things done. THE PREDATORS' BALL: The Inside Story of Drexel Burnham and the Rise of the Junk Bond Raiders, by Connie Bruck. (Penguin, $8.95.) The rise and fall of Drexel Burnham Lambert and its West Coast Wunderkind, Michael Milken. THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED: Book Three of the Vampire Chronicles, by Anne Rice. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The mother vampire of them all awakens from a 6,000-year-old sleep with a plan to bring peace on earth by killing most of the men. THE QUESTION OF HU, by Jonathan D. Spence. (Vintage, $8.95.) A history of a curious Chinese tourist who was thrown into a French insane asylum in the early 18th century. QUINN'S BOOK, by William Kennedy. (Penguin, $8.95.) A young newspaperman tries to win the heart of Maud Fallon, the beautiful enigma he saved from drowning when she was 12 years old. THE RABBI OF LUD, by Stanley Elkin. (Scribners, $8.95.) A fictional New Jersey rabbi presides over a congregation of the dead. THE RAT, by Gunter Grass. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Harvest/Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $9.95.) In a concatenation of stories within stories, Gunter Grass tells of the dawning of the posthuman age when the world is overrun by rats. THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS: Economic Change and Military Conflict From 1500 to 2000, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) When mighty empires hasten their own demise by spending too much money on the military. THE RISK POOL, by Richard Russo. (Vintage, $8.95.) Ned Hall chooses a college as far as possible from his hometown of Mohawk, where his father is a drunk and his mother is strung out on Librium. SAILING, by Susan Kenney. (Penguin, $7.95.) After a cancer patient's wife gives him a sailboat, he gets a grip on his life. SECRETS OF THE TEMPLE: How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country, by William Greider. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) A book that demystifies the Federal Reserve Board. A SOCIAL HISTORY OF MADNESS: The World Through the Eyes of the Insane, by Roy Porter. (Dutton/Obelisk, $8.95.) A collection of case studies in which the history of the asylum is told from the point of view of the inmates. SOMEONE WAS HERE: Profiles in the AIDS Epidemic, by George Whitmore. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Three true stories about victims of the AIDS virus by a man who has since died of the disease. SPENCE + LILA, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $6.95.) In a novel by the author of ''In Country,'' a farmer helps his wife in her struggle against breast cancer. THE STATUE WITHIN: An Autobiography, by Francois Jacob. Translated by Franklin Philip. (Basic Books, $10.95.) The autobiography of the renowned molecular biologist is ''not only literate but positively literary,'' our reviewer said. STORIES IN AN ALMOST CLASSICAL MODE, by Harold Brodkey. (Vintage, $12.95.) Tales from a craftsman of abundant prose about the relentlessness of suffering. THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Warner, $5.95.) A historical novel about three Irishmen who play different roles in the country's sorrows. THE THIRD GENERATION, By Chester Himes. (Thunder's Mouth, $11.95.) A searing novel, published in 1954, about a black professor whose wife tries to pass for white. THREE SCIENTISTS AND THEIR GODS: Looking for Meaning in an Age of Information, by Robert Wright. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Masterly portraits of three eccentric thinkers in search of the secrets of life. TRACKS, by Louise Erdrich. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The Chippewa ancestors of the characters in ''Love Medicine'' and ''The Beet Queen'' fight winter, smallpox and a conquering alien culture. TWO AGAINST ONE, by Frederick Barthelme. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) During a surprise birthday visit from his estranged wife, Edward is invited to join her and her lover in an enduring threesome. UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan, by Christopher Nolan. (Delta, $7.95.) A paralyzed poet tells how he learned to flex the muscles of his mind. VANISHED, by Mary McGarry Morris. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) A dull-witted middle-aged road worker and a 14-year-old runaway embark on a five-year odyssey of truck stops and cheap motels. WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The television journalist recalls how World War II transformed a sleepy city with Southern efficiency and Northern charm into a boom-town bureaucracy. WHATEVER HAPPENED TO GLOOMY GUS OF THE CHICAGO BEARS? by Robert Coover. (Collier/ Macmillan, $7.95.) A novel about an ambitious young Quaker named Richard Nixon who becomes a football star. WHEN THE MIND HEARS: A History of the Deaf, by Harlan Lane. (Vintage, $15.95.) For hundreds of years, deaf people have tried to make the hearing understand that words need not be spoken - or even written - to qualify as language. WHERE I'M CALLING FROM, by Raymond Carver. (Vintage, $8.95.) Stark, haunting tales left behind by Raymond Carver, who died last year of cancer at the age of 50. WHO KILLED CBS? The Undoing of America's Number One News Network, by Peter J. Boyer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) A horror story about the decline of Edward R. Murrow's old aerie. WHO WROTE THE BIBLE? by Richard Elliott Friedman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A scholarly hunt for Moses' ghostwriters that reads like a detective story. WRITING A WOMAN'S LIFE, by Carolyn G. Heilbrun. (Ballantine, $6.95.) A humanities professor who writes mysteries tells how literature has conspired to make women seem more like men want them to be. THE YELLOW WIND, by David Grossman. Translated by Haim Watzman. (Delta, $8.95.) A young Israeli novelist spends a season among the West Bank Palestinians.

title: Carol Rifenburg Engaged to Wed
description: January wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George A. Rifenburg of Troy, N.Y., for their daughter, Carol Elaine Rifenburg, and Richard Joseph Miller Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Rensselaer, N.Y.

title: Fashion; Hats With a Sense of History
description: Uptown or downtown, the newest hats combine warmth with whimsical historical flourishes, preferably those of old England. Men and boys are topped off as royalty or rapscallions, women and girls as Shakespearean serving girls or Dickensian dowagers. This season the two authors are muses millinery as well as literary.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Cheshire, Conn. $260,000 7 Worden Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old saltbox; cherry-stained floors, breakfast area, 1.1 acres; taxes $3,603. North Haven, Conn. $162,500 18 Temple Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; wraparound deck, cathedral ceiling in family room, wood stove; taxes $1,580. Ridgefield, Conn. $635,000 177 Nod Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; heated pool, greenhouse addition, 2 acres; taxes $5,155. New Rochelle, N.Y. $445,500 71 Baraud Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 43-year-old brick colonial; 2 fireplaces, family room, deck, 2-car garage, 0.24 acre; taxes $7,200. Peekskill, N.Y. $175,000 926 Albert Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, Florida room, family room, wet bar, 1-car garage; taxes $2,645. Rye, N.Y. $1.4 million 70 Dogwood Lane 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 79-year-old colonial; 4 fireplaces, family room, pantry, 10,446 square feet, 1.15 acres; taxes $17,684. OTHER AREAS Brick, N.J. $164,900 527 Midwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; c/a, 2-car garage, family room, patio; taxes $2,472. Elmwood Park, N.J. $184,500 144 Miller Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; pool, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,823. Amityville, L.I. $182,000 22 Towne Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old brick Tudor; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,800.

title: PSYCHOPATHIC NERD, MARRIAGE-MINDED, SEEKS....
description: THE ANASTASIA SYNDROME And Other Stories. By Mary Higgins Clark. 318 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Kids in Paris
description: To the Editor: Your section had an article about a 5-year old child who went to Paris with his parents (''Child's Play in Paris,'' Travel, Oct. 15). Is this really an amazing thing? I'm 10 years old and when I was 6 I traveled around France and England with my parents and my 9-year-old brother. I don't see what the big deal about this kid is. All he did was sit by his parents, take a nap, play a couple of games and not complain.

title:
Style Makers;
John Carruthers, Guitar Maker
description: LEAD: As a teen-ager, John Carruthers dreamed of playing the guitar professionally. But he was practical enough to become a carpenter and electrician while awaiting his big break. Though fame on the stage eluded him, Mr. Carruthers has achieved stardom of a different sort by combining his talents to become one of the country's top guitar makers.

title: BLACK UNIVERSITIES
description: Who but an avowed racist would wear a T-shirt that reads: ''It's a Black Thing - You Wouldn't Understand!'' Blacks have had masterful white role models for racism. It's easy to justify the building of pride based upon it. But let me dream of a time when at least our better-educated children know better. Please make me a T-shirt that says: ''It's a Human Thing - We All Understand!'' LOIS ATKINSON New York, N.Y

title: Lively Days for Eastern Bloc Envoys
description: Polish and Hungarian diplomats are barred from addressing each other as comrade. Embassies are increasingly used for press conferences and receptions. Ambassadors appear on television and are inundated with speaking invitations.

title: GROUPS PROPOSE PARK AT HIGHWAY
description: Seeing a chance to open more than a half-mile of prime Manhattan waterfront as public parkland, a coalition of three civic groups has advanced a proposal to rebuild the elevated West Side Highway at ground level, on the former railroad yard where Trump City is proposed.

title: A Very Different Germany Waits to Be Reborn; Unity, Justice, Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: No-Contest Plea Given By Mobil in Two Spills
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has pleaded no contest to misdemeanor charges stemming from two pipeline ruptures that poured more than 130,000 gallons of crude oil into the Los Angeles River and the city's sewers last year.

title: 'American Daguerreotypes,' at Yale
description: DAGUERREOTYPES were not the first photographs but they were the first to reach this country - from Paris, a few weeks after the process was unveiled in August 1839.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember The Neediest Cases Fund; Touching Lives of the Elderly In a Bronx Housing Project
description: Let Lillian M. of the Bronx tell the story of the last 10 years of her life:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Bankruptcy Delays Two New Megaships

title: Monasteries
description: To the Editor: I wish our facility had been included in your listing. We are a monastery founded and supported by the Sisters of St. Benedict, and we do welcome guests. Our address is Fox Bluff, Box 5070, Madison, Wis., and our phone number is 608-836-1631. KATHI CLAGGETT Communications and Marketing, St. Benedict Center Madison, Wis.

title: Youth Courts Cut Teen-Age Crime
description: LEAD: IN the six years since the village of Tarrytown instituted a Youth Court, in which youthful offenders are tried and sentenced by their peers for minor offenses, law-enforcement officials say there has been a marked decrease in juvenile crime.

title: Shopping Center Surprise in Commack
description: THE heady scent of garlic has replaced the aroma of cinnamon that perfumed Commack's Peppertree Commons. DiBenardo's restaurant recently opened in the space that once housed a sweet-roll franchise.

title: No Theft Found, So U.S. Is Resuming Sale of Radioactive Gas
description: The Energy Department says it is resuming commercial sale of a critical component of nuclear warheads after concluding that amounts listed as missing were not stolen after all.

title: PHILIPPINE REBELS INVADE ARMY BASE AND FINANCE AREA OUTCOME SEEMS UNCLEAR
description: As a rebellion from within the Philippine military entered its fourth day, rebel forces broke through loyalist troops and took up positions at the nation's army headquarters early this morning after seizing the capital's financial center. The rebel advances came despite the Government's claim that the attempted coup against President Corazon C. Aquino had been crushed.

title: Connie Circosta Marries
description: At the Middle Bay Country Club in Oceanside, L.I., Connie Ann Circosta, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Circosta of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married last evening to Gil A. Dickoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin H. Dickoff of Syosset, L.I. Rabbi Ezra M. Finkelstein officiated. Mrs. Dickoff is the senior designer at the Linda Stillman graphic-design studio in New York. Mr. Dickoff is the assistant treasurer for the Crane Company, a New York maker and distributor of mechanical parts. The bride graduated from the School of Visual Arts, the bridegroom from the State University of New York at Binghamton, where he also received an M.B.A. degree.

title: First the Wealthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Seasonal Sounds and More
description: THE barrage of holiday concerts has arrived, but music lovers with carols and cantatas have plenty of attractive alternatives.

title: Wagner Retains Title
description: Mike Taranto, the quarterback for Susan Wagner, didn't get much sleep on Friday night. In his mind, he kept going over certain plays he would use if given the opportunity when his team met DeWitt Clinton yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League championship game at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

title: COFFEETABLE BOOKS: A PASSION FOR PICTURES
description: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. BALENCIAGA. By Marie-Andree Jouve and Jacqueline Demornex. (Rizzoli, $110.) No one has gone further in proving fashion design an art than Cristobal Balenciaga, painter, sculptor and architect in cloth. Born in 1895 to a sailor and a seamstress in a Spanish Basque fishing village, the boy soon excelled at his mother's skills and could, aged 13, accost the Marquesa de Casa Torres with the offer to design for her. She launched him, and by 1919 he had his first couture house in San Sebastian, to be followed by others in Madrid and Barcelona. In 1937, he started his Paris salon, whence he pioneered the world's highest fashions for over three decades.

title: Malaysia Communists Agree To Cease-Fire After 41 Years
description: One of the world's longest insurgencies formally ended today as guerrillas of the Communist Party of Malaya pledged to lay down their arms and vowed loyalty to Malaysia.

title: Cable Television As Teacher: Its Role In Classroom Grows
description: LEAD: T/LEVISION is playing a bigger role in education in many Westchester schools as the technology becomes cheaper and easier to use, and as cable companies promote educational services and programs.

title: 'Honeymoon for One': Another View
description: Where has Sally Friedman been for the last 20 years? Her Opinion page article (''A Honeymoon for One,'' Oct. 29) left me wondering why someone as talented as she is chose to write it.

title: On the Scaffolds, a Delicate Labor in the Duomo
description: The aluminum-shafted elevator slowly makes its 196-foot climb from the floor of the Duomo to the base of the 16-level scaffolding that rings the interior of Filippo Brunelleschi's cupola. The scaffolding has been in place for nearly 10 years, its green and gray safety netting concealing the 10,500-square-foot surface of frescoes by Giorgio Vasari and Federico Zuccari. But not until last January, after a decade of research, preparation and delay, did restoration of the enormous expanse begin. The project is expected to be completed in 1992 at a cost of $25 million.

title: Risk Takers and Ground Breakers
description: ALL ACROSS THE COUNTRY, women are breaking new ground in real estate development. For 37-year-old Marsha B. Elliott, who worked in mortgage finance and sold houses before helping found Terrestris Development in 1985, development represents ''one of the last entrepreneurial barriers left for women to conquer.'' Elliott's company has built nearly 1,000 houses in the Chicago area and is now at work on a shopping center. She is in line to become the first woman president of the Home Builders Association of Greater Chicago in 1991.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: In Bizarre Free Agency, Whitey Ford Would Break the Bank
description: Perhaps it's the earthquake effect.

title: Lynn Matthews, a Copywriter, Is Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Lynn Patricia Matthews, the daughter of Moira T. Matthews of Brooklyn Heights and Richard J. Matthews of Honolulu, was married yesterday to William Angus Douglass 3d, the son of Mrs. Robert P. DeVecchi of New York and William A. Douglass of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Frances Mercer, an American Baptist minister.

title: 100 Justices Finish Crash Course in Judging
description: One hundred new town and village justices, most with no previous legal training, graduated today from a six-day cram course preparing them for the duties they will take up on Jan. 1.

title: Dr. Mei-Ling Yee Marries
description: Dr. Mei-Ling Yee, an ophthalmologist in Jersey City, and Gary William Moylen, a lawyer in Hackettstown, N.J., were married yesterday at Giralda Farms in Madison, N.J. Judge Michael J. Noonan of the Morristown (N.J.) Criminal Court officiated. The bride, 32 years old, is a daughter of Theryl Edwards of Jersey City and the late Yuen Hoy Yee. Mr. Moylen, 38, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Moylen of Morristown. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: And Now, a Few Words From Jenny Holzer
description: ONE OF THE MOST UBIQUITOUS PRESENCES ON THE current art scene is a 39-year-old maverick named Jenny Holzer, a tricky impresario of language who makes words into visual spectaculars. A writer who doesn't think the printed page is ''enough of a forum,'' Holzer hatches messages that range from deadpanned aphorisms to dark meditations about the human condition, embosses them on plaques, engraves them on marble or granite benches and sarcophagus lids and - with skilled technological choreography - sets them prancing in dazzles of colored light.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Nov. 18 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $235,000 165 Christopher Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, remodeled bath, hardwood floors; maintenance $655, 66% tax-deductible (Broker: D. J. Knight) Upper East Side $154,000 353 East 72d Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, renovated kitchen and bath, track lighting; maintenance $771, 62% tax-deductible (Broker: The Halstead Property Co.) Upper East Side $675,000 135 East 83d Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,900-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, large kitchen, 3 exposures; maintenance $1,495, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Faith Weinberg Real Estate) Upper West Side $823,750 330 West 87th Street 4-family, 4-story town house; 3 bedrooms, and dining room in duplex unit; 3 bedrooms, large kitchen in top floor unit; two 500-sq.-ft. studios on first floor; 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $7,500 (Broker: Nancy R. Sweetser Realty) West Side $269,000 155 West 68th Street (Dorchester Towers) 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, windowed dining area, c/a, roof deck; common charge $363, taxes $2,328 (Broker: B. J. Gottesman) BRONX Riverdale $335,000 5624 Sylvan Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,361 (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) Wakefield $168,000 4421 Baychester Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,150 (Broker: Cancro Realty) BROOKLYN Flatbush $325,000 259 Stratford Road 2-family, detached frame house; 4 bedrooms, 2 baths, fireplace in owner's triplex; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in other; dining room, large kitchen in each; 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,756 (Broker: Mary Kay Gallagher) Midwood $210,000 1213 East 13th Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semi-attached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage, 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $791 (Broker: Jacob Gold Realty) Park Slope $104,000 195 Garfield Place 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; oak floors, renovated kitchen and bath; maintenance $457, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: Brooklyn Properties of 7th Avenue) QUEENS Cambria Heights $176,000 117-47 229th Street 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached Cape Cod; dining area, large kitchen, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Corona $335,000 102-30 Nicolls Avenue 2-family, semi-attached brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each unit; finished basement, 2-car garage, 27- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Veterans Realty) STATEN ISLAND Great Kills $185,000 94 Glover Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, family room, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $950 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty) Richmondtown $235,000 73 Dina Court 2-family, attached frame house; 3 bedrooms, 2 baths, dining room in primary unit; 1 bedroom, 1 bath, large kitchen in other; 1-car garage, 25- by 110-ft. lot; taxes $300 (Broker: Schlott Realtors)

title: Artist's Calling Is Glass Painting
description: J. KENNETH LEAP says he still gets goose bumps when he recalls the first time he saw the stained-glass windows at the Chartres Cathedral in France. Even though he had studied details of the cathedral at the Rhode Island School of Design, from which he had just graduated, he said he was stunned by what he saw.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report from Philadelphia last Sunday in the Northeast Notebook column misidentified a principal in the Regis Group of Boston. He is Gary Reisner.

title: In Pelham, the Art of Children's Books
description: GOOD night stars, good night air. Good night noises everywhere. Those words from Margaret Wise Brown's classic book, ''Good Night Moon,'' have sent young children peacefully off to sleep since its publication in 1947. Now Clement Hurd's original painting for that book of ''the great green room,'' where a little bunny lies in bed, can be seen at the Pelham Art Center. It is part of the exhibition of ''Orignal Art From Children's Books,'' that continues at the art center through Jan. 6.

title: All That Glitters Is Not (Only) Gold In Jewelry Shows
description: Jewelry exhibitions on view and soon to open at New York's museums and galleries are rich in glitter or glorious fun. Most are also provocative or historical, and they present the widest range of such ornaments seen here at one time in many years.

title: How a Plane Crash Upended Peace Plans For Central America
description: WITH the discovery of the wreckage of a Cessna light plane loaded with Soviet-made missiles and mortars in a bean field in eastern El Salvador on Nov. 25, more than just an aircraft may have come crashing to the ground. As events throughout Central America last week made clear, the presence of the weapons cache on a plane that the Salvadorans said took off from Nicaragua also threatened to bring down much of the peace process that the presidents of five Central American countries have painstakingly constructed over the last three years.

title: Army to Decide Soon on Medal of Honor for Jewish Veteran
description: The Secretary of the Army is to decide by mid-December whether to recommend the Medal of Honor for a Jewish veteran who is said to have killed hundreds of Japanese during a single battle in World War II but who was denied the medal then, apparently because of anti-Semitism.

title: BUSH GIVES GORBACHEV ECONOMIC AND ARMS PROPOSALS
description: President Bush offered an array of more than a dozen economic and arms proposals to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today as they began their summit meeting, including an end to cold war trade restrictions.

title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar
description: In midafternoon on Aug. 3, Randal Swanson, a 29-year-old baker from West Caldwell, N.J., steered his black Toyota along West 162d Street in Manhattan, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, looking to buy cocaine.

title: Q and A
description: Travel Agencies for the Deaf

title:
FOCUS: MASSACHUSETTS;
Projects in Limbo As Market Sags
description: LEAD: The once thriving housing market in this old mill city an hour west of Boston is in the midst of a slump that has been worsened by the failure of the bank that had made the lion's share of loans for new construction.

title: A Trio Of Stories In 'Spunk'
description: WHEN a prominent contemporary playwright adapts and directs the work of a legendary figure of the Harlem Renaissance, theatergoers are going to get all set for an event.

title: Sihanouk Backs a U.N. Trusteeship for Cambodia
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk has endorsed a recent Australian proposal under which the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia would be dismantled and the nation placed under a trusteeship run by the United Nations.

title: BLACK UNIVERSITIES
description: In the 1950's, many of my contemporaries were the pioneers of school desegregation, integrating white high schools (''Black Universities: In Demand and In Trouble,'' by Eric Alterman, Nov. 5). The rush was on for blacks to enter the Ivy League or Big Ten colleges, and, later, to send their youngsters to the same. Unfortunately, what many found was isolation, non-acceptance and racism.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1988. It suggests only high points in the main fields of reader interest, and it does not include the titles chosen by the editors of The Book Review as the Best Books of 1989. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography and Biography

title: On the Way To Total Entertainment
description: One of the nation's more aggressive new video chains is betting that the mix of convenience and technology will consolidate video outlets and record stores. Next week Super Club, the offspring of a Belgian movie and video company that has grown to approximately 190 American outlets since last May, and plans to add about 300 more in 1990, will open a store in Dallas designed to offer both videos and recordings. Mixing mediums under the same roof isn't unusual, of course, but doing it from scratch and to this degree points to the future. ''The trend is to the total entertainment software store,'' says Bruce Apar, the editor of Video Business magazine. Super Club now owns the Video Towne chain in Indiana and Ohio and Record Bar stores in North Carolina and will expand and mix the merchandise in these and other chains it seeks to purchase. Darrell Baldwin, the head of Super Club, says that the technology is favorable. ''The optical disk will bring a merger of audio and video.'' Yes, New Yorker

title: JUST ANOTHER NIGHT ON CRACK STREET
description: Philippe Bourgois provides a chilling account of East Harlem's drug culture (''Just Another Night on Crack Street,'' Nov. 12). The men and women he has lived with and observed appear to be ambitious and resourceful, albeit painfully misguided. They also appear to be firmly entrenched in their deviant life style. But what of the children growing up in this environment? Are they doomed to follow in the footsteps of Mr. Bourgois's subjects? If they have to choose between the underground and the service economy, we all will be losers. JARED BERNSTEIN New York, N.Y.

title: TAX STRATEGY IN A TURBULENT YEAR
description: THE turbulence this year in the stock and bond markets has made year-end tax decisions more important than usual. There is, of course, the usual guessing game about where capital-gains tax rates are headed. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is up nearly 30 percent this year, leaving some investors wondering when to cash in their gains. Others, less lucky, bet on the troubled ''junk bond'' market and are contemplating losses. Here are some traditional year-end tax tools for investors, and a few new twists.

title: CLUBS FOR VALUED CONSUMERS ARE ONE WAY TO STRENGTHED TIES
description: Clubbing. The word intimates belonging. So it follows that some marketers, keen on building loyalty and intimacy with their customers, would fashion their frequent-buyer programs as clubs.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Taxpayers Seek Relief in an Obscure Law
description: EVERY 10 years, when property values in Connecticut's 169 towns are reassessed, some people's tax bills rise steeply. This year, after a decade of zooming land prices, shock waves from revaluations are being felt almost everywhere.

title:
The View From: Crestwood Station;
Rebuilding a Commuter Home Rockwell Painted
description: LEAD: THE Crestwood station is this kind of place: if you have got off the train and your car is stuck and you've no way to get home, Jack Quinn will drive you. Mr. Quinn is the Metro-North ticket agent, and he is the kind of guy to whom commuters give gifts at holidays. This Thanksgiving yielded a box of chocolates and package of homemade cookies.

title: Can Knots and Netting be Art?
description: SEVEN black and white tubular nets used by fishermen in Italy take on the appearance of grandiose columns as they hang from the ceiling in the ''Knots and Netting'' exhibition at the Parrish Museum in Southampton.

title: Mediators Given Time to Resolve Lebanon Standoff
description: Lebanon's warring factions backed off from a head-on military confrontation today to allow time for mediators to break a political deadlock that has threatened to plunge the country into another round of violence.

title: Who Speaks for Business?
description: IN the face of a softening economy, in response to a soft residential real estate market, in an effort to counteract the business bashing that was crippling our region's ability to compete in the marketplace, a group called the Long Island Committee for Reasonable Government was created last winter.

title: Patricia-Anne BarrettWeds Randal Martin
description: At the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church, Patricia-Anne Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian W. Barrett of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Randal Jay Martin, a son of Judith Martin of Columbus, Ohio, and William Martin of Wintersville, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Hughart officiated.

title: Capitals Defeat Devils
description: The Washington Capitals came into Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight with a dubious distinction: they led the National Hockey League in penalty time.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; In Rare Vote, Faculty To Decide on R.O.T.C.
description: The entire 2,400-member faculty of the University of Wisconsin-Madison will meet tomorrow, for the first time since 1970, to take a vote that could help decide the fate of the campus's Reserved Officers Training Corps. Professors and students alike say the vote will put the spotlight on an issue that has been debated on campus for more than two years: should the military bar homosexuals.

title: On Language; O LITTLE TOWN OF PLUGSVILLE
description: THE HOLIDAYS ADvance inexorably; trite phrases like 'tis the season and Yuletide cheer come out of the attic along with the old tinsel, and readers of this column demand specific advice on language books to prevent those on their gift lists from facing the Nifty Nineties at a loss for words.

title: New Summit Question
description: There's a noticeable feeling of edginess as superpower leaders meet here to seek a grasp on a dizzily changing world.

title: 36 in Gaza Are Reported Wounded by Israelis
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded at least 36 Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip today during protests against the army's killing of four Arab guerrillas, hospitals reported.

title: Pollution Shrouding National Parks
description: SOME of America's most cherished scenic vistas are gradually disappearing behind a curtain of air pollution. A growing number of the country's national parks, from Sequoia and Kings Canyon in California to Acadia in Maine, are at times so afflicted with air pollution that views are often obscured and health is sometimes threatened.

title:
MUSIC;
Trumpet Player Sees Threat to Brass Future
description: LEAD: SCOTT McINTOSH, a trumpeter who performs as a soloist and as a member of a brass quintet, is concerned that the rise of electronic music and cuts in music education may signal danger for professional brass players.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Rent Regulation; Extending the Right to a Renewal Lease
description: WHAT is a ''nontraditional'' family? Should people who consider themselves members of such families have a right to succeed to a rent-stabilized apartment when the tenant named on the lease dies or moves out?

title: Holiday Concerts Around the County
description: HOLIDAY concerts are proliferating around the county, starting today at 3 P.M., when the Nyack composer, writer, storyteller and singer Bobbie Wayne portrays ''A Season of Joy in Legend and Song.'' A master of the Celtic harp, Ms. Wayne also accompanies herself on dulcimer, the bodran frame drum, limberjack and sundry other folk instruments, her free family concert at the Greenburgh Town Hall devoted to songs, stories and harp solos for Hanukkah, Christmas and the New Year (993-1540).

title: A Hidden Newcomer in Stamford
description: LESS than a decade ago, the interesting places to eat in Stamford could be counted on one hand. Now, it is possible to dine out well nightly at a different place for the better part of a month.

title: Style Makers; Marisha Gavrielides, Hand-Knitting Entrepreneur
description: Four years ago, while studying in England, Marisha Gavrielides bought yarns and instructions for making stylish Anny Blatt sweaters, had them knitted by hand and took them to the United States during school holidays.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: In the early days of contract bridge, it was not unusual for a player to win a major national title at a first attempt. That feat was achieved in 1960, when Roberta Erde, now Roberta Epstein, won her debut event, the Women's Board-a-Match Teams. In 1987 in Baltimore, Jaggy Shivdasani of India made his debut in the Spingold Knockout Teams.

title: A New Breed of Volunteers Alters Ways of Helping Others
description: LEAD: NOMI MIRON is about as far from the stereotype of the traditional volunteer as one can get. A computer consultant on the fast track, Miss Miron found that her demanding workload left little time for other activities.

title: Opening the Record on Nuclear Risks
description: WHEN he became Secretary of Energy, James D. Watkins promised a new era in which the American nuclear weapons industry would no longer be allowed to invoke national security as a reason to cover up safety and management problems.

title: Direct Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Retirees Are In Demand in Eastern Europe
description: WHEN Emil Davidson retired 20 years ago, after selling the multimillion dollar plastics-molding company he founded in Elmsford, he found the quiet life in his Scarsdale neighborhood frustrating. ''Here I knew all this stuff,'' he said, ''but nobody asked me any questions.''

title: Biotechnology Poised for Breakthroughs
description: ''THIS lab is bugged,'' reads the hand-lettered sign on the door of Eugene Premuzic's laboratory at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton. The bugs in question are not transmitters for clandestine eavesdropping, but micro-organisms for cleaning up toxic geothermal energy byproducts.

title: Leader Urges Ukrainian Catholics to Act Now
description: The spiritual leader of Ukrainian Roman Catholics said today that he considers his long-banned church to be fully legal again as a result of new Soviet statements and the meeting on Friday between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Pope John Paul II.

title: PITCHING DOCTORS
description: As a second-year medical student who has already accepted his first stethoscope from one pharmaceutical company, a whole shelf-full of books from another and as the chairman of a student organization that has accepted activity money from still a third, your article ''Pitching Doctors'' (by Michael S. Wilkes and Miriam Shuchman, Nov. 5) has rekindled my interest in this issue.

title: A SATELLITE FALLS OVER INDIAN OCEAN
description: The Solar Max spacecraft, a victim of the very forces of nature it investigated for almost a decade, came crashing back to Earth yesterday, breaking into flaming pieces in the upper atmosphere but causing no known damage.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $182,000 22 Towne Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old brick Tudor; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,800. Copiague $205,000 315 West Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old waterfront Cape Cod; new kitchen, deck, 40 feet of bulkheading; taxes $3,400. Lake Ronkonkoma $175,000 31 Bayberry Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Rocky Point $172,500 72 Cherry Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old high ranch; basement, 2-car garage, additional legal 2-bedroom, 1-bath apartment; taxes $4,000. Sayville $180,000 120 Greeley Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 62-year-old colonial; parlor, basement, attic, fireplace, 3-car garage; taxes $3,800. Smithtown $230,000 79 Croft Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fireplace, basement, decks, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500. OTHER AREAS Cheshire, Conn. $260,000 7 Worden Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old saltbox; cherry-stained floors, breakfast area, 1.1 acres; taxes $3,603. New Rochelle, N.Y. $445,500 71 Baraud Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 43-year-old brick colonial; 2 fireplaces, family room, deck, 2-car garage, 0.24 acre; taxes $7,200. Livingston, N.J. $312,500 5 Page Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen, patio; taxes $4,118.

title: U.S. Urged to End Ban on In Vitro Birth Research
description: A Congressional committee said today that the Federal Government had refused to finance research on in vitro fertilization and missed a chance to improve the poor success rate because it had been trying to avoid religious controversy over the research.

title: PEARLS
description: Waste no pity on pearls, they are more popular than ever. First Lady Barbara Bush's penchant for wearing the fake variety and the renewed interest in Chanel accessories have made them best sellers. Now, even many of the fashion critics, the women who sit on the sidelines passing judgment on the styles that parade down the runways, have taken to donning them. None of these pros profess to know just why this pearl urge has overcome them. But, to a woman, they feel that pearls are right, right now. Here are snapshots of some pearl-wearers at the recent American spring showings.

title: On the Air From Classes in Ossining...
description: LEAD: IT is a bit past 7:30 A.M. at the Anne Dorner Middle School here, and the quiet of the audio-visual room is broken as the pint-sized students rush in and take their place at either side of the cameras.

title: Will Bare Be Beautiful?
description: SNIPPETS OF SKIN PEEKING OUT HERE, EXPOSED LIMBS ON VIEW there. Flashes of barely veiled bosoms and expanses of flesh everywhere. When the showings of the spring 1990 collections ended a month ago, the nude message -- though by no means the only news -- was certainly clear. Even the most pronounced color palette emulated skin tones, ranging from deep browns to rosy peaches and palest alabasters.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. BATMAN - Michael Keaton, Jack Nicholson and Kim Bassinger star in a ''shapeless, big-screen reincarnation,'' but Anton Furst has created a ''nightmare version of megalopolis.'' (Vincent Canby) 1989. Warner. $24.95. Laser disk, $24.98. 2 hours 6 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. BEDTIME STORY - Marlon Brando and David Niven star in what was the basis for last year's ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels.'' ''Good, crisp fun,'' a critic wrote. 1964. MCA. $59.95. 1:39. Not rated. COUSINS - An American remake of Jean-Charles Tacchella's romantic comedy ''Cousin, Cousine,'' with Ted Danson, Isabella Rossellini and Sean Young. ''Coarse, raucous, furiously misguided.'' (Janet Maslin) 1989. Paramount. No list price. 1:40. CC. PG-13. DREAM A LITTLE DREAM - Corey Feldman and Meredith Salenger play youngsters transformed into older lovers (Jason Robards and Piper Laurie) in this romantic comedy, ''a routine high-school flick.'' (Walter Goodman) 1989. Vestron. $89.95. LD, $39.95. 1:44. CC. PG-13. THE DRESSMAKER - Small-scale and exquisitely acted by Joan Plowright, Billie Whitelaw and others, the film is ''constructed as if it were some kind of delayed-action explosive. . . . The images and textures have the density of good prose.'' (Canby) 1989. Capitol. $79.95. 1:32. No rating. GHOSTBUSTERS II - This sequel ''has the weight and stylishness of designer toilet tissue, but it doesn't offend.'' (Canby) 1989. RCA/Columbia. $89.95. LD, $24.95. 1:42. CC. PG. GONE WITH THE WIND - A 50th-anniversary reissue of the spectacular film version of Margaret Mitchell's epic Civil War-era love story, starring Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh. 1939. MGM/UA. $89.95. LD, $49.95. 3:51. CC. G. HOTEL TERMINUS: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF KLAUS BARBIE - Max Ophuls's ''vivid, harrowing, minutely detailed'' recollection of France under the German occupation. ''Great.'' (Canby) 1988. Virgin Vision. $99.95. LD, $99.95. 4:27. Not rated. LAWRENCE OF ARABIA - ''It is David Lean's direction, adroitly weaving together music, scenery and the steely force of Lawrence's personality, that gives the film its transcendent power.'' (Maslin) 1989. RCA/Columbia. $29.95. LD, $49.95. 3:36. CC. PG.

title: Jacqueline Elliman, Banker, Affianced
description: Judith Sperry Beavers of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Lawrence Michael Elliman of St. Helena, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter Jacqueline Munroe Elliman to Robert Gerard Leonard Jr., the son of Mrs. Martin Winkler of Jericho, L.I., and the late Mr. Leonard. A June wedding is planned.

title: ONE THERE WERE FIVE BEAUTIFUL VIRGINS....
description: When The Book Review asked the British illustrator Ronald Searle to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, it stipulated that some of the drawings should be vague, suggestive, darkly mysterious. Two were sent to nine novelists. Where would their imaginations lead them? The Virgins' Ornament By John Updike

title: At a Christmas Dinner, An Act for Each Course
description: ACT I: It is Dec. 23. 10 P.M. A car is snowbound. Stranded, a married couple, Diane and Alex, take refuge in an abandoned inn. Its once grand party room, where Christmas extravaganzas were staged, now contains a ladder, some chairs, a table, a trunk - and a piano.

title: Referee's Miscount
description: The middleweight bout between Michael (the Silk) Olajide and Dennis (the Magician) Milton was held at the Empire State Convention Center in Albany Friday night. But the decision on who won is not expected until later this week, and it won't be rendered by the bout's official judges, but by the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: Scrambling to Be Counted in Census
description: For five years, an improbable collection of bureaucrats, business executives, health care professionals, members of ethnic groups and transportation planners have been trying to stake a claim to 3.5 square feet of valuable political real estate: the 1990 census questionnaire.

title: What Bush Is Making Of Civil Rights
description: AS President Bush moves to fill the Administration's top civil rights jobs, policy makers in and outside the Administration are pointing to a subtle rethinking of what ''civil rights'' means.

title: Article 009189 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Czech Opposition Leader Warns Against Efforts to Delay Change
description: Czechoslovakia's most prominent opposition leader declared today that any slowing in the momentum of renewal would mark a failure by the Government and the opposition and could lead to conflict.

title: Incinerator Tops Zwirn's List
description: LEAD: WHEN Benjamin L. Zwirn takes office as Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead on Jan. 1 as the first Democrat in that office in 73 years, he will be facing a host of problems, many of them tied to the town's plan to construct a mass-burn incinerator in the Port Washington sand pits.

title: Two Software Leaders Join Forces
description: It is hard to imagine two computer software corporations that appear more dissimilar than the Lotus Development Corporation and the Wordperfect Corporation. Lotus, of Cambridge, Mass., until recently had an image of Hawaiian shirts, irreverence and arrogance; its chief executive is a brash former journalist. The company is beginning to emerge from more than a year of turmoil in which some business customers deserted its flagship product, the 1-2-3 spreadsheet, while new versions of products fell further behind schedule. More than a dozen top executives left.

title:
FOCUS: Fitchburg, Mass.;
Bank Failure Adds to Town's Housing Woes
description: LEAD: THE once thriving housing market in this old mill city an hour west of Boston is in the midst of a slump that has been worsened by the failure of the bank that had made the lion's share of loans for new construction.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; In Smaller Museums, Warmth and Even Quiet
description: As the weather turns cold, New Yorkers head indoors, filling the city's behemoth museums - the Met, MOMA and the Natural History Museum - to the gunnels. With the holidays nearly here, it may be too much to expect a patch of quiet anywhere, but some smaller museums also offer cultural pageantry and a welcome respite from the cold.

title: JUST ANOTHER NIGHT ON CRACK STREET
description: The advertisements and television commercials with those famous slogans - ''Say No to Drugs'' and ''Crack Kills'' - what a waste of money! The answer is not catchy antidrug campaigns. It's jobs.

title: Monasteries
description: To the Editor: About the article ''A Monastery Stay'' (Travel, Oct. 1), I would like to offer the following information: The Swedish order of the sisters of St. Bridget also has a guesthouse in Rome, and many more in several countries: Sweden, England, Finland, Switzerland, India and Mexico.

title: Barry Carus Wed To Stacy Aaron
description: Stacy Ann Aaron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip I. Aaron of Roslyn Estates, L.I., and Barry Richard Carus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Carus of Merrick, L.I., were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Nathaniel Steinberg officiated.

title: Soccer Tour Set
description: An Australian select team will play a four-game exhibition tour against Major Indoor Soccer League teams in January. The Australians will play in Tacoma, Wash., on Jan. 22; in Wichita, Kan., on Jan. 23; in Dallas onJan. 25, and in Kansas City on Jan. 30.

title: Social Events
description: 'Nutcracker' and Reception

title: Alabama Tripped Up By Auburn
description: As the challenge of an undefeated Alabama football team finally arrived here - here, for the first time in 54 meetings over 97 years - the football players from Auburn University set out late this morning on their Tiger Walk.

title: Review/Dance; Virgil Thomson Tribute By Hawkins Company
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company honored Virgil Thomson on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater with two works choreographed by Mr. Hawkins to scores by the distinguished American composer, who died early this year.

title: Once Again, Cooks Is Following in the Footsteps of Taylor
description: In the National Football League's 1981 draft, the first player selected was George Rogers and the second was Lawrence Taylor. In 1982, the first was Kenneth Sims and the second was Johnie Cooks.

title: ALASKA FEARS LOSS IN PIPELINE INCOME
description: After battling the Exxon Corporation over the huge oil spill near Valdez last March, the State of Alaska is again fighting the petroleum industry, this time over repairs to a pipeline that transports a quarter of the crude oil produced in the United States.

title: Arizona Is Upset By Oregon State
description: Oregon State handed Arizona its worst defeat since Lute Olson became coach of the Wildcats in 1983 today as Gary Payton led the Beavers with 25 points in an 84-61 victory.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: This is the year of the sesquicentennial of photography's entry into the world, and to mark the occasion a number of shows were mounted. These in turn led to the publication of several books-cum-catalogues that offer quick courses in the history of photography. Foremost among them are ''On the Art of Fixing a Shadow'' (discussed below), ''The Art of Photography 1839-1989'' (Yale University), ''Decade by Decade: Twentieth-Century American Photography'' (Bulfinch/Little, Brown) and, in a vanguard vein, ''The Photography of Invention: American Pictures of the 1980s'' (MIT). There also were other anniversaries being celebrated: 100 years of the National Geographic (''Odyssey: The Art of Photography at National Geographic,'' Thomasson-Grant) and 40-odd years of Magnum photojournalism (''In Our Time: The World as Seen by Magnum Photographers,'' Norton).

title: Houston's Ware Wins Heisman Ware of Houston Wins Heisman
description: Andre Ware, the University of Houston quarterback whose passing exploits had been all but drowned out by a chorus of derision, silenced his critics yesterday when he was named the winner of the 1989 Heisman Trophy as the nation's outstanding college football player.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: How to Get Ahead In Advertising 1989. M.C.E.G./Virgin. $89.95. 1 hour 34 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.

title: THE COURTSHIP DANCE: ON GIVING AND GETTING BOOKS
description: LEAD: It was some time ago, when I was still a young student in college, that I learned that books make subtle and indeed erotic presents. One day a female friend to whom I was devoted presented me with a first edition of D. H. Lawrence's short-story collection ''The Woman Who Rode Away'' - the first direct, affectionate gift of a book I ever received.

title: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP
description: Alice Paul House

title: Deadly Virus Discovered in Laboratory Monkeys
description: Government scientists examining the carcasses of laboratory monkeys imported from the Philippines say they have discovered three with the ebola virus, which before the discovery of AIDS was considered the world's deadliest virus to humans.

title: Books in a Gilded Cage
description: TRAVELERS through southern Germany in the 18th century - in general no tourists but, rather, serious researchers in various fields - returned full of praise for the treasures they had come upon in the libraries of remote monasteries. Today's visitor is likely to find more interest in the exuberant Baroque and rococo architecture of these libraries than in whatever volumes can be found within them.

title: A Benefit to Fight Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: THE first benefit for Lyme disease research to be held in the county will take place at 6:30 Wednesday evening at the Rye Town Hilton. Proceeds from the gala, which is to feature a buffet dinner and entertainment by the ''Broadway Tonite Revue,'' will go toward several studies of the illness being conducted by physicians and scientists and the New York Medical College in Valhalla.

title: In Search Of Sea Turtles
description: CHRISTIAN LUGINBUHL tracks leatherbacks - giant, elusive sea turtles with tough, leathery backs. ''They're very difficult to track; scientists know where their nesting beaches are, but we're trying to find out where they go,'' Mr. Luginbuhl said.

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: Elaborate, large-format - which is to say expensive - architecture books this year seem to fall into two categories: monographs on the work of a particular architect, of which there are fewer than in recent years, and generic books on particular styles or types of buildings, of which there are many more. It is as if publishers had been seeking to marry the genres of textbook and coffeetable book, and like all unusual marriages, the results sometimes fall flat and are sometimes full of pleasant surprises. *

title: Medical Waste Law Survives a Challenge
description: LEAD: A COALITION of groups representing doctors, veterinarians, funeral directors, dentists, nursing homes and podiatrists tried unsuccessfully last week to stop implementation of New Jersey's new medical waste law.

title: State Seeking to Close Sag Harbor Golf Course
description: LEAD: IT is only a nine-hole course and all the greens are sand, but local golfers want to retain it because it is only one of two public links on the South Fork of Long Island.

title: Miss Tague WedIn Bryn Mawr, Pa.
description: Nancy Beausang Tague and Robert John Himmelreich were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., by the Rev. Kenneth Wolfe, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. David M. Stickley, a Lutheran minister. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Tague of Bryn Mawr. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Himmelreich of Plymouth Meeting, Pa.

title: Daria Blackham Weds in Connecticut
description: Daria Helen Blackham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Roland Blackham of Avon, Conn., and Enrique Jose Manuel Lopez-Balboa 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Enrique Lopez-Balboa of Montclair, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Lawrence Bock performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Simsbury, Conn.

title: Japanese Players Take the Grand Tour
description: The orchestra's European tour this fall was typical - late planes and buses, missing luggage, irregular meals, a customs check that held up the larger instruments, but also the pleasures of making music and friends. A typical tour for a symphony orchestra - but this was not a typical symphony orchestra, even though the principal conductor, Seiji Ozawa, is well known in Europe and helped to attract large, appreciative audiences. This was the Saito Kinen Orchestra, which, like the recently established Praemium Imperiale prizes for achievements in the arts, is part of a Japanese expansion into the marketplace of ideas as well as the business marketplace in the West.

title: STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions; Fabled Racers, a Brearley Purchase and a Church
description: This is another in a series of columns answering readers' questions about New York's changing streetscapes. The Tortoise and the Hare

title: Horse-Carriage Drivers Call New Law's Reins Too Tight
description: Horse-drawn carriages lined Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Seventh waiting for customers on a recent day, drivers and horses muffled against the biting cold.

title: SWING FEVER
description: BENNY GOODMAN AND THE SWING ERA By James Lincoln Collier. Illustrated. 404 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95. HAMP An Autobiography. By Lionel Hampton with James Haskins. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Amistad/Warner Books. $19.95.

title: Effects of Final I-287 Link Are Debated
description: FROM Montville to Mahwah, the final 19-mile link of Interstate 287 is slowly taking shape amid the crumbling rock and pristine riverbanks of some of New Jersey's most desirable real estate.

title: ART
description: The price of books on art has been rising steadily, though by no means as fast as the price of some kinds of art at auction. What $20 would have bought not so long ago may cost close to $100 today. Sometimes it's worth it (always provided that we have the money). Year after year, the catalogues of major exhibitions are the definitive studies of the works in question. Current examples are ''Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism'' by William Rubin (Museum of Modern Art/Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown, $70), the Metropolitan Museum's ''Canaletto'' by Katharine Baetjer and J. G. Links (Abrams, $60) and the National Gallery's ''Frans Hals,'' edited by Seymour Slive (Prestel Art Books/Te Neues Publishing, 15 East 76th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; $60). *

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Winter Rental Bargains in the Hamptons
description: LEAD: THE Hamptons' summer frenzy of traffic jams, packed restaurants and long lines at the movies is over and in its place is the quiet of a seaside community getting ready for winter.

title: Hostile Acts: Stopping the Violence
description: In the article ''Are Hostile Acts by Youths on the Increase?'' (Nov. 12), the point is made that ''youngsters model themselves after the most powerful people around them and if the role models change, so will the youngsters.''

title: A Cautionary Guide for Little Customers
description: Television commercials for children are not kid stuff. About $500 million a year is spent promoting toys, games, foods and other goodies to young consumers. There may be two sides to the question of whether any advertising is appropriate on programs aimed at grade-schoolers and under, but nobody is likely to take public exception to the principle that youngsters should not be fooled by adults. Some of the ways this elementary rule of decent behavior is being violated by big companies out after little customers is the subject of ''Buy Me That!,'' a cautionary holiday offering from HBO at 7:30 Wednesday evening.

title: Review/Jazz; Makowicz And Vache As a Team
description: A jazz duo formed by the pianist Adam Makowicz and the cornetist Warren Vache is having its debut engagement through Saturday at the Fortune Garden Pavilion, 209 East 49th Street. The most celebrated precedent for such a pairing is Earl Hines and Louis Armstrong (playing trumpet instead of cornet), who in 1928 recorded ''Weather Bird,'' a dazzling series of virtuosic challenges. Duos of this type were then a rarity until the pianist Dick Hyman and the cornetist Ruby Braff began performing together with some frequency several years ago.

title: Review/Music; Roger Brooks's Electrical Oddities
description: They took a bit of time to set up, but once Roger Brooks got his Maniac (Manually Activated Nonintegrated Audio Contraption), Madmass (Manually Activated Digital Multiple System) and Drastic (Dynamic Response Audio System Tandem Isometric Controls) going, a howling concatenation of bleeps and buzzes filled the room.
