Mr. Brooks, who performed at the Knitting Factory's Homemade Instrument Festival on Thursday night, has taken found electrical objects and combined them with electronic junk bought on Canal Street - children's games, for example - and turned them into big, funny machines that would fit seamlessly in a grade-D sci-fi movie, circa 1958.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FESTIVAL OF WREATHS

title: Campus Life: Chico State; Students Protest C.I.A. Recruiting In Second Sit-In
description: The second sit-in protest in less than a year at the California State University, Chico, career-placement center Thursday was the latest in a series of student demonstrations against the Central Intelligence Agency recruiting here.

title: Review/Music; Two Brothers and Others In the Shanghai Quartet
description: Sheer elegance has its point of diminishing returns. Thus for all the care, the blended sound and shared gestures, one came away from the Shanghai String Quartet's concert Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall with a feeling of music only partially dealt with.

title: COOKING
description: As many times as I have read the instruction to ''brown the meat well,'' I never understood even so simple a requirement until one day I got the chance to watch a real cook do it. Then I caught on: browning it well meant browning it well - not just giving up in relief as the poorly aged, watery meat finally turned from gray to a sort of beige.

title: CAN A NOVELIST SAVE PERU?
description: I was in charge of the United States Consulate in Cochabamba, Bolivia, in the 1960's (where Vargas Llosa spent some of his childhood). I found Gerald Marzorati's article excellent. I was particularly impressed by his mention of the informales, ''the street vendors and bus-van operators and the owners of tiny factories,'' who are pervasive in South America.

title: Teachers and Others In a Bargaining Unit
description: The article ''Broader Membership Is Giving Teachers' Union New Influence'' (Oct. 8) correctly judged that the inclusion in teacher bargaining units of such support staff members as school secretaries, instructional and noninstructional assistants, custodians and bus drivers has enhanced the bargaining power of the New Jersey Education Association and its affiliates. I am more dubious of the value to those support staff members of mixed bargaining units.

title: DEFINING SOME WORDS TO WORK BY
description: THEY PORED OVER BUSINESS periodicals, interviewed hundreds of executives, conducted a nationwide survey - all in pursuit of the words that represent ''the language of current managerial practice.'' The results are laid out in ''Managerial Literacy: What Today's Managers Must Know to Succeed,'' by Gary Shaw and Jack Weber, scheduled for publication next month by Dow Jones-Irwin.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: Tournament competitors were more wary years ago in the early rounds. It was as though each one wanted to hold back on playing sharp opening variations until the others exposed their secret innovations and prepared analysis. There were a lot of tentative Reti and English openings and you would not get a look at open games until about the fifth round. Most of the action came from players walking around the room watching the other games when it was their opponent's turn to move.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Molly Joel Coye;
Directing Innovations in Public Health
description: LEAD: IN 1985, Dr. Molly Joel Coye turned down a chance to be a television health reporter in Los Angeles to accept Gov. Thomas H. Kean's invitation to work on public health issues in New Jersey. Eighteen months later, he named her State Health Commissioner. As the Kean administration comes to a close, she says she has had far more impact as a policy maker than she would have had as a reporter, but notes that both jobs require the ability to translate complex technical issues into lay language.

title: POSTINGS: Civics Lesson; Times Sq. Documentary
description: Public school students in New York City will have an opportunity to view ways to change Times Square for the better through a 30-minute film that examines the history of the neighborhood and proposals for its redevelopment. Starting next month and continuing through the school term, the documentary ''Changing Times in Times Square'' is to be presented at 296 high schools and junior high schools in all boroughs. Later in the year it is due to be shown by local and cable television outlets.

title: U.N. CALLED ASSET TO CITY'S ECONOMY
description: New York City's role as host to the United Nations adds $830 million a year to the local economy, according to a study by Gillian Martin Sorensen, the New York City Commissioner for the United Nations and Consular Corps.

title: Edith S. Lynch Marries
description: Edith Scott Lynch of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday in New York to Philippe G. Bouriez of Paris and St.-Jean-de-Luz, Basses-Pyrenees, France. The ceremony was performed at St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. John B. G. Andrew. Mrs. Bouriez is on the board of the New York Philharmonic. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom, who is retired, was the personnel director at Shell Francaise in Paris. He was a widower.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PHOENIX;
A Bit of Mexico For Downtown
description: LEAD: AFTER 10 years of planning, the Mercado, a $5.3 million mixed-use commercial and cultural downtown project modeled after the Mexican city of Guanajuato, held its grand opening yesterday .

title: Is Eastern Europe Ready?
description: When Tadeusz Mazowiecki became Poland's first postwar non-Communist Prime Minister on Aug. 24, the euphoria at home and abroad was extraordinary. His ascent resulted from the overwhelming victory of the Solidarity-backed opposition over Communist candidates in the relatively free parliamentary elections in June -the first since 1946 - and it represented a turning point in Polish history.

title: FOR MIGRANT WORKERS, LEGALITY LOWERS WAGES
description: Thanks to the Federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, some 700,000 migrant workers in California's $16.6 billion agricultural industry have applied for legal residency in the United States. But the stamp of impending legitimacy has yielded a mixed harvest for workers.

title: 3 Organizations That Help Relieve New Yorkers in Pain, Visible or Invisible; Best Minds Must Unite To Help a City in Need
description: The men, women and children we serve are representative of a city in need. They have problems that challenge us beyond a one-time fix. They are a mosaic of human dignity.

title: A Conran's Without Price Tags? Hardly
description: Does a city really need a museum with a permanent collection featuring 15 typewriters, 13 calculators, dozens of cameras, and glass showcases filled with telephones, dishes, glassware and stereo equipment? No, it doesn't, and visitors are to be excused if they think they have mistakenly stepped into the electronics and housewares departments of Harrods. But if the Design Museum, which opened last summer on the south bank of the Thames, has a bit too much of the air of a retail establishment, this hardly matters. For this museum, temple to consumer objects though it is, has turned out to be one of the more exhilarating small cultural facilities in London.

title: Auto Insurance: If Only We'd Known...
description: NEW JERSEY today can lay claim to what may well be the most effective form of birth control.

title: Hers; My Two Uncles
description: AS A CHILD RAISED by two bachelor uncles, I lived in the world of singleness long before I began to date. From the age of 8, I enjoyed a backstage perspective on unattached men: the kind who want to marry and the kind who don't.

title: Voters and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Right to Life, and Death?
description: Nancy Cruzan, once a spirited, vital young woman, lies unconscious in a Missouri hospital. She is condemned to ''live'' in a permanent vegetative state by a tragic accident - and by a 4-to-3 vote of the state's highest court. It rejected her family's plea to let her die by removing her feeding tube. The court held that the state's right ''to promote life,'' however hideous, was virtually absolute. It also doubted the parents' claim that Nancy, when healthy, had expressed a clear preference, in such a circumstance, for death.

title: Regional Problems Spur Talk Of a New Level of Government
description: LEAD: THIRTY years after it abolished county government, Connecticut is facing a growing number of complex problems that has some planning officials stopping just short of endorsing a county approach as a solution.

title: Television Lavishes Money On Sports, but Does It Pay?
description: Late last week, in announcing a new contract with the National Basketball Association, Terence F. McGuirk of Turner Network Television made two statements that at first seemed contradictory.

title: Maria J. Sherry Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sherry of Danvers, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria J. Sherry, to Lieut. Thomas A. Murphy U.S.N., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Murphy of Paoli, Pa. A March wedding is planned. Miss Sherry, 29 years old, is an account officer for retirement plans at Fidelity Investments in Boston. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College. Lieutenant Murphy, also 29, graduated from the Haverford School and the University of Virginia and is attending the Naval Postgraduate School for National Security Affairs in Monterey, Calif.

title: Fashion; For Festive Holiday Nights, In or Out
description: All dressed up and no place to go. When is that a positive statement? Why, when you're dressed up for a party at home. And this is the prime time of year for entertaining.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE: THE BEST BOOKS OF 1989
description: BILLY BATHGATE By E. L. Doctorow. CITIZENS A Chronicle of the French Revolution. By Simon Schama. FEDERICO GARCIA LORCA A Life. By Ian Gibson. FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM By Umberto Eco. FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM By Thomas L. Friedman. HAROLD MACMILLAN Volume One: 1894-1956. Volume Two: 1957-1986. By Alistair Horne. A HISTORY OF THE WORLD IN 10 1/2 CHAPTERS By Julian Barnes. HOW WAR CAME The Immediate Origins of the Second World War, 1938-1939. By Donald Cameron Watt. IF THE RIVER WAS WHISKEY By T. Coraghessan Boyle. A PEACE TO END ALL PEACE Creating the Modern Middle East 1914-1922. By David Fromkin. THE REMAINS OF THE DAY By Kazuo Ishiguro. THE SATANIC VERSES By Salman Rushdie. THE SHAWL By Cynthia Ozick.

title: TV Program On Caring for Parents
description: I read Tamar Lewin's article [ ''Ill Parents: Women's Burden Grows'' ] the day after my television program on the same subject (''Caring for Your Parents: Mother in the Middle'') was shown on public-access television on the North Shore. I thought, when I read the article, how fortunate it was that a medium now exists allowing individuals to explore matters like these on a local basis.

title: An Appeal To Universality
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion in the Court, Case by Case by Case
description: THE more the Supreme Court considers abortion, the less urgent its deliberations seem. There is no question that the Court can slash away at the constitutional right it established 16 years ago, but for this term, at least to judge from arguments in the two abortion cases before it last week, the struggle appears to come down to some pushing and shoving.

title: EVERYONE WAS DRESSED TO KILL
description: JEAN HOWARD'S HOLLYWOOD A Photo Memoir. Photographs by Jean Howard. Text by James Watters. 248 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $39.95.

title: Stepping Up the Pace in Walking Vacations
description: A BOOM in walking vacations sounds like an oxymoron: anything that is booming must be loud and fast, and walking is quiet and closer to two miles an hour. So call it a soft boom.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Smile, Darn You, Smile
description: LEAD: YEARS ago, if you had cavities you sat in a dentist's black chair while the dentist inflicted pain normally associated with decapitations on your mouth. He cleaned your teeth with a gritty substance, you rinsed with a cherry-flavored solution and you returned in a year.

title:
GARDENING;
Pruning Can Yield Christmas Greens
description: LEAD: WHEN ancient tribes celebrated the winter solstice, evergreen bows were used for decoration much as they are today for the Christmas celebration. In the time of year when shorter days and cold weather made life seem desolate, plants that retained their green foliage were considered a symbol that life was still present in the forest and that spring would indeed return.

title:
INVESTING;
A Rebounding R.E.I.T.?
description: LEAD: In recent months, shares of First Union Real Estate Investments have slipped in response to flat earnings reports. Analysts say the declines present an unusual buying opportunity.

title: PITCHING DOCTORS
description: In the last 18 months, I have turned down two all-expenses-paid trips to drug-company symposiums in Bermuda and in Vancouver, B.C. (spouse invited, too), and countless free dinners at the finest restaurants in town. I did attend a free seminar entitled ''Performance Under Pressure,'' which included two medical talks, a buffet lunch, a talk by former Knick's great Dave DeBusschere and tickets to the 1989 N.C.A.A. basketball semifinals. Everyone has his price. KEN GROSS, M.D. Seattle

title: Evening Hours; For One Night, Tuxedos and Spurs Are Church Wear
description: Tuesday evening was a festive night at two Manhattan cathedrals - and the events weren't just church suppers. At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Gothic Romanesque Byzantine interior was illuminated by 4,000 candles for the first black-tie dinner dance in the nave. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the cathedral, presented the Spirit of the City award to Stephen C. Swid, chairman of the Municipal Arts Society.

title: Signs of Resistance At Budget Hearings
description: SIGNS of taxpayer resistance to Westchester's proposed $1 billion 1990 budget, with record increases of 18 percent to 52 percent in county property taxes, surfaced last week at two public hearings of the County Board of Legislators and in individual expressions of anger.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Bank Tower To Open in 1990
description: LEAD: AT a time of heavy building activity and projected higher office vacancy rates, the $200 million, 54-story Mellon Bank Center in this city's commercial district is well on its way.

title: Rebuilding of I-95 Bridge Seen Easing Traffic
description: BIDS are to be opened this month for the first phase of the $156 million replacement of the Raymond E. Baldwin Bridge on Interstate 95, which connects Old Lyme and Old Saybrook over the Connecticut River and on which traffic is often backed up for miles on weekends.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HURDY-GURDY MAN

title:
TELEVISION;
A Sparse Harvest Of Sugarplum Viewing
description: LEAD: ''Curiouser and curiouser,'' Alice said when she bit the biscuit that changed her size. The same might be said about holiday television programming for children. Here we are at the end of the 1980's and the baby-boomers of the thirtysomething generation are at the peak of their procreative activities.

title: John S. Pingel 3d And Miss Good To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bennett Good of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gretchen Rockwell Good, to John Spencer Pingel 3d, the son of Mrs. John M. Diefenbach of San Francisco and Mr. Pingel Jr. of Dallas. A May wedding is planned.

title: Wanted: A U.S. Insurance Plan
description: THE Week in Review asked three European journalists to assess how the continent's security needs can be met as the cold war recedes.

title: UPSCALE TALES
description: CHIC SAVAGES By John Fairchild. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: An Exotic Life Glimpsed, and Envied
description: JOLTED out of my semiconscious state, I caught a glimpse of an alternative life style today. I found a wallet.

title: Joan L. McKeown Becomes a Bride
description: Joan Leslie McKeown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. McKeown of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to David Alfred Baratta, a son of Elizabeth H. Baratta of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Alfred A. Baratta. The Rev. Charles A. Cesaretti and the Rev. Alfred M. Niese Jr. officiated.

title: Taxi Fares Rise, as If On Schedule
description: LESS than a week after New York City subway and bus fares go up, cab rides will cost more, too.

title: A Playwright Who Fashions Then Into Now
description: ''A historical play nowadays means the kiss of death,'' says the playwright Romulus Linney, who has reworked the form to critical praise in plays about the Prussian King Frederick the Great and the English poet Lord Byron. In fact, his latest work, ''Three Poets,'' which recently opened at Theater for the New City in the East Village, is based on the lives of Komachi, a ninth-century Japanese poet; Hrosvitha, a 10th-century Saxon nun and playwright; and Anna Akhmatova, the renowned 20th-century Russian poet.

title:
Prospects;
Terror Amid Change
description: LEAD: After the assassination in Frankfurt last week of Alfred Herrhausen, the chairman of the Deutsche Bank A.G., German police received a note bearing the stamp of the Red Army Faction, a known terrorist group, claiming credit for the act. With Europe undergoing large-scale political and economic changes, will terrorism increase?

title: GROUNDS FOR SELLING SHORT
description: THE WAKE-UP CALL HAS sounded. Things are really perking these days for the coffee traders on the eighth floor of 4 World Trade Center, where one of the nation's sleepier commodity markets has come to life.

title: Notes From a Prompter's Box On Making Opera Sing
description: What if opera in New York so blossomed in the 1990's that only a curmudgeon would dream of griping about the Met; that the highlights of each season would truly be the talk of the town; that opera lovers would congratulate themselves on the good luck of being around for a golden age?

title: Reclaiming the Broken Heart of Europe
description: CZECHOSLOVAKIA shakes the world.

title: Miss Niederhoffer to Wed K. B. Herz
description: The engagement of Deborah T. Niederhoffer to Kenneth B. Herz has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Niederhoffer of Tenafly, N.J. Mr. Herz is a son of Florence Herz of New York and the late Richard Herz.

title: Aga Khan in Protest
description: Calling his move a protest over methods used to test two of his horses for drugs, the Aga Khan, one of the world's leading race-horse owners, has resigned from Britain's Jockey Club. On Friday, the Jockey Club disqualified Rifada, one of the Aga Khan's horses, from victory last July in a meeting at Warwick, England, after a muscle-relaxing substance was discovered in its system. (AP)

title: Partner of Ex-House Speaker Declares Bankruptcy in Texas
description: George A. Mallick, the Fort Worth real estate developer whose business ties to House Speaker Jim Wright were instrumental in Mr. Wright's resignation from Congress last spring, has filed for bankruptcy.

title: Strung Up
description: IT MIGHT JUSTIFIABLY BE called a cable car, but it is equally fitting that the device supporting the workmen who are replacing 177,000 feet of steel cable on the Brooklyn Bridge is known as a spider. Unlike, say, the Williamsburg Bridge, just up the East River, which is supported by vertical cables, or other spans, which employ a system of diagonal stays, the Brooklyn Bridge has both. Its two independent suspension systems not only hold up the bridge but distinguish its profile, which is distinctively - and famously - weblike.

title: Some Recollections of Dutch Schultz Era
description: The fascinating article about Dutch Schultz and his demise (''Jerseyana,'' Oct. 8) reminded me of an incident during my employment as a film critic for The Newark News.

title: A Berlin Retrospective With Timely Echoes
description: As of a week or two ago, it has been possible that Berlin will one day become again what it was in the past - the de facto capital of central Europe. This notion is a nightmare to many, in that between 1933 and 1945 the name of Berlin was fouled almost beyond redemption. The very idea that it should ever again be a place of power and pre-eminence was abhorrent. And yet there are arguments - geographical, architectural, intellectual, cultural and even climatic - for its eventual reinstatement, and they deserve to be heard. Young people do not like to have their hands bound in perpetuity by their elders, and the future of Berlin will be decided by people who are now young.

title: Hooked Rugs Gain New Admirers
description: LEAD: THE ghosts of yesterday's hooked rugs are seen in today's versions, their beguiling rough-looped texture recalling a folk art form from the rural America of a century or more ago.

title: Maltese Say They Warned About Weather
description: Maltese officials warned American and Soviet summit planners several times that they should make contingency plans in case stormy weather made meeting aboard ship too difficult, an official in the Prime Minister's office said today.

title: Nouveau Heights
description: ACCORDING TO GEORGES Duboeuf, perhaps the bestknown of the Beaujolais shippers, the two greatest vintages in modern Beaujolais history were 1945 and 1976. In a business built on hyperbole, Mr. Duboeuf comes off as almost laconic. So when he says, as he has been since September, that 1989 could be better than both those years, there just may be something to it.

title: Installing Shut-Off Valves in Pipes
description: ONE annoyance frequently found in older homes, and sometimes even in homes that are not so old, is the lack of shut-off valves beneath plumbing fixtures. Shut-off valves permit turning off the water supply to individual fixtures like sinks, tubs and toilets without having to shut off the main water supply or large sections of household plumbing.

title: At Lab Centers, The Future Is Now
description: WHATEVER the eventual changes in the relationship between basic research and commercial efforts, the four Long Island biotechnology centers have many promising products in the pipeline of clinical trials and patent filings.

title: INTOXICATED BY MY ILLNESS
description: I recognized Anatole Broyard's experience. I had it, too, on learning that I had cancer. I think it comes from a sense of deliverance from the banal. One can move on to a higher plane with a free conscience. And though Mr. Broyard's friends rally 'round, they do not really understand. One feels impatient, as at a railroad station when one is about to start on a unique adventure and people come to see you off with the conversation of a cocktail party.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Providence; Condo-Rental For Downtown
description: FINISHING touches are being put on the conversion of the 104-year-old Conrad building into this city's first downtown residential development - a 24-unit project that will be half rental, half condominium.

title: How Taiwan Wins Friends and Miffs Beijing
description: Armed with a new flexibility and immense reservoirs of foreign exchange, Taiwan is struggling for a seat at the international table, and in the process new tensions are surfacing between the rival Governments in Taipei and Beijing.

title:
GARDENING;
Pruning Can Yield Christmas Greens
description: LEAD: WHEN ancient tribes celebrated the winter solstice, evergreen bows were used for decoration much as they are today for the Christmas celebration. In the time of year when shorter days and cold weather made life seem desolate, plants that retained their green foliage were considered a symbol that life was still present in the forest and that spring would indeed return.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A roof leak caused the latex-painted walls in my home to blister and created yellow stains on the wallpaper. Is there any way to remove the stains, and can the blisters on the dry wall be removed?

title: Water Main Break Disrupts Subway Service
description: A large water main ruptured in a Harlem park early yesterday, spewing millions of gallons of water into the streets and flooding a subway station at 125th Street up to the turnstiles.

title: Review/Music; Julius Hemphill Plus 3
description: The alto saxophonist Julius Hemphill's show at the Alternative Museum on Wednesday night, the first of the museum's new season, could have been broken into several nights' worth of music. Mr. Hemphill and the fluegelhornist Baikida Carroll played a duet that gently clashed pitches, rubbing dissonances for heat. Abdul Wadud, the group's cellist, performed a solo that mixed a dancing, light melody with abruptly struck, grunting chords. And Mr. Wadud and Andrew Cyrille, the group's drummer, when on their own, were an advertisement for the power of improvised interaction.

title: Willem Dafoe, Looking for Characters With Possibility
description: Gone now are the striped prison fatigues, the sunken cheeks and the shaved head; but even so, Willem Dafoe cannot banish the ghosts of Auschwitz. ''Imagine living in a house where a terrible crime had happened,'' he says. ''Now magnify that millions of times. How did it feel to be there? I expected to identify with the horror, to break down, but that would have been obscene. I'd have been weeping for myself. There was only one response - numbness, a terrific numbness.''

title: No-Show Decision
description: For more than two years, Manfred Ohrenstein, minority leader of the New York State Senate, has served under the cloud of an indictment for using the legislative payroll to hire full-time campaign workers. The fraud and grand larceny charges against the powerful Democrat should have been resolved long ago. Yet state appellate judges continue to dawdle over a key ruling.

title: The Realignments on the Home Front
description: SOMETIMES losing an enemy can be more unsettling than losing a friend. The world order that since the end of World War II has shaped American politics, its view of the world and itself has suddenly come crashing down.

title: Dr. Randi S. Fain Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Dr. Randi S. Fain and Dr. Cornelius Robert Verhoest Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Verhoest of Hawthorne, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Irving Fain of Livingston, N.J. The couple plan to marry later this month.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
An Executive Who Saw Ahead Tells How
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, at the age of 58, I retired and became a college professor. My second career is challenging and rewarding. What is more, I believe I am filling a position that might otherwise be vacant due to a shortage of qualified instructors in my field.

title: A Czech Tries to Start His Own Bandwagon
description: The man who heads the Institute for Forecasting at the Academy of Sciences, a research bureau devoted to discerning Czechoslovakia's economic and social future, has decided to take a hand in shaping it, stopping just short of publicly declaring that he wants to be Prime Minister.

title: No Headline
description: Long Islanders may well be proud of the extraordinary bequest of Wedgwood to the Sands Point Museum in Port Washington. The North Shore of Long Island is fortunate to have so many museums and cultural centers for the enrichment of its residents who find travel to New York City for the lively arts increasingly more expensive, frustrating and not a little hazardous.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: ''It drives me up the wall.'' ''It's like someone hitting me with a hammer.'' ''It grates on me; it's like hearing a fingernail run along a blackboard.''

title: Frieda Brandes, Consultant, Wed
description: At the Regency Hotel in New York, Frieda Robin Brandes and Dr. John Daniel Tydings were married last evening by Rabbi Melvin Sirner. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Brandes of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Tydings of Long Beach, L.I.

title: Driver Slain by Officers After Chase Was Unarmed
description: A Brooklyn man who was fatally shot by police officers Friday night after a six-mile chase on the Belt Parkway was unarmed, but the officers may have thought he had a weapon because of messages broadcast on the police radio, investigators said yesterday.

title: Review/Film; Stories of Manhattan By Student Directors
description: Short films are so pitilessly noncommercial that they become havens of freedom; film makers might as well give up any idea of reaching a large audience and do the most wildly inventive work they can. The exception to this rule occurs in film schools, where fledgling producers, directors, writers and cinematographers put together brief films commonly known as ''calling cards'' to the industry, meant to show agents and producers that these students have become professionals.

title: What to Do When Japan Says 'No'
description: Dear Mr. Morita and Mr. Ishihara:

title: Sentiments Shared
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana Wiesenthal to Wed J. A. Singer
description: The engagement of Diana Dale Wiesenthal and James A. Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Singer of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Melvin L. Wiesenthal of Harrison, N.Y. A January wedding is planned.

title: TOO POLITE IN A.C.C.
description: Broadcasting basketball games on television is something I have become used to doing; speaking comes easily, but the written word is another story. But the prospect of taking the Big East side in previewing the Big East-A.C.C. Challenge was too good to pass. I immediately called my buddy, Ray, who may, over the course of a season, watch more basketball games than most scouts I know. The Big East and the Atlantic Coast Conference are his specialties.

title: 'I Felt So Alone'
description: I WAS divorced on a stormy day. The radio blared flood alerts and warnings. I had tossed about the bed during a mostly sleepless night. I missed her so. I used to get up an hour earlier than she did. I would drive to the country store to pick up the newspaper and return, have it read, my cereal and banana eaten, and my huge cup of coffee drunk when she would stagger up the stairs to my study. With a crooked grin on her face she would say, ''Good morning, honey.'' She would have her tea, curl up in a corner of the couch and make faces at me while I babbled the morning news at her. It was my way of saying good morning. Perhaps I should have taken notice when she said - so many times - ''not until I've finished my tea, for God's sake!''

title: Ulysses Dove: Choreography From Life
description: LEAD: As a performer, Ulysses Dove has had an unusual career. He is the only person to have danced for Merce Cunningham and Alvin Ailey, two giants of contemporary dance whose respective esthetics could not be farther apart. As a choreographer, Mr. Dove's more recent history is distressingly familiar: He is yet another

title: J. R. Lauterbach And Vicki Baron Exchange Vows
description: Victoria V. Baron, a daughter of Pamela Stearns Baron of New York and Richard W. Baron of New York and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey R. Lauterbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Lauterbach of Pittsburgh. The Rev. William Pindar officiated at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: THE WORLD: The New Europe; Eleven Months of Peaceful Revolution
description: HARD as it is to remember today, only a year ago many countries of Eastern Europe remained the essence of gray Communist orthodoxy. But the rigid foundations of party dictatorship were already being eroded by deepening economic malaise and the reformist policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In a startling shift, the Soviet leader made it clear that Soviet tanks would not enforce the old order as they had so often in the past and that, in the satellite countries at least, an end to the Communist monopoly on political power was perfectly fine.

title: WRISTON PLAYS TO HIS LONG SUIT
description: WHAT DO DIRECTORS do?'' That was the question put to Walter B. Wriston at a meeting of the Council of Institutional Investors held in Manhattan last month.

title: TALKING: Home Papers; Saving Crucial Documents
description: WHILE most people know that it is wise to keep records connected with owning a home, it is not so clear which documents, invoices, receipts, canceled checks and other items need to be kept and which can be discarded. It also helps to know the kind of system that makes for easier record-keeping.

title: Lageman Starts to Stand Out
description: After Jeff Lageman was named the Jets' defensive player of the game following his play in the easy 27-7 victory over hapless Atlanta last Sunday, there was a lot of comment about his intensity and dedication.

title: A Teahouse Links Japan And Virginia
description: A Japanese teahouse sits in a glade of pine and beech trees in this Navy town in southeastern Virginia, a few thousand miles from its native region of Kyoto.

title: Q and A
description: M.C.I. Rent Increases

title: Ms. Segall Wed To Kevin Frank
description: Margo Ann Segall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel A. Segall of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Kevin Greg Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Frank of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Norton Shargel officiated at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: HONEYWELL RESTRUCTURES (AGAIN)
description: LEAD: EXECUTIVES at Honeywell Inc. take great pains not to use the term restructuring to refer to their current plan to sell the company's defense business, which accounts for nearly 20 percent of revenues and profits, and cut 4,000 jobs.

title:
Style Makers;
Melissa Panage, Computer-Jewelry Design
description: LEAD: Like many others who grew up near the high-technology capital of Silicon Valley, Melissa Panages loves computers. But she finds them vastly more interesting before they have been assembled or after they have been taken apart.

title: When the Meal Is Meant to Set a Mood
description: LEAD: WHEN Jeff Akerson of Weston became an assitant chef at the Homestead Inn in Greenwich last year, he thought he had reached his professional goal. But to his surprise, he found the job repetitive and uncreative. ''I was doing the same menu all the time,'' he said. ''It's the same routine.'' As more time passed, Mr.

title: Fishing for Shrimp in Flanders
description: IN the North Sea on the Flanders coast, Belgium's gray shrimp are caught beneath an almost perpetually gray sky. The bulk of them are harvested by boat, but at Oostduinkerke, shrimp fishermen on horseback still drag their nets at low tide to scoop up these tiny glistening delicacies. A basketful of gray shrimp can be a comically monstrous sight; each shrimp is less than an inch long and, before they are cleaned, all appear weirdly mustached. Just caught and heaped in a brimming basket, the slippery shrimp are rubbery-looking, like the ghoulish plastic varmints you can buy in toy stores.

title: A Very Different Germany Waits to Be Reborn; A Short History
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Bingham Wed To Thomas J. McEntee
description: Margaret Jean Bingham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bingham of Woodbury, L.I., was married in New York yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to Thomas Joseph McEntee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward McEntee of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. John Clermont performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: 1,000 Protest U.S. Support For Salvadoran Government
description: Despite bitter cold and an occasional snow flurry, more than 1,000 people turned out for two rallies and a march in Manhattan yesterday to protest United States Government support for the Government of El Salvador in its war with guerrillas.

title: Rescue Mission: Saving A Swan
description: IT was one of those dazzling late fall mornings on Mill Pond in Water Mill, when you just had to stop for a moment and marvel at the last of the foliage.

title: Who Really Deserves Marshall Plan Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Collison Weds T. A. Williams Jr.
description: The marriage of Serena Dee Collison and Thomas Allison Williams Jr. took place yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Brenda Husson performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of William Norwood Collison and Margaret Wei Collison, both of New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Rye, N.Y.

title: Iran Agrees to Allow Visit by U.N. Rights Inspector
description: For the first time since the revolution that overthrew the Shah, the Iranian Government has agreed in writing to allow a United Nations inspector to enter the country to investigate human rights abuses, diplomats say.

title: People
description: * Antone S. Ujhelyi has been promoted to senior vice president of Leo Burnett Co.

title: Doormat Diplomacy
description: George Bush's purposes in proposing an early summit were (1) to shift the disarmament focus from strategic missiles to conventional forces, thereby placing top priority on an end of the Soviet occupation of Eastern Europe, and (2) to link the end of Soviet support of Central American dictatorships to trade concessions Moscow desperately seeks.

title: Business Scene; Chrysler Loses Industry Rhythm
description: ''THERE are rhythms in the auto industry, and Chrysler is out of sync with them today,'' says Raymond Vernon, a Harvard Business School professor. The current rhythm rewards the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company because they have big operations in Europe, where profits are easier to come by than in the United States. The Chrysler Corporation's European sales are minuscule, and that shortcoming endangers the company.

title: Ames Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included loss of $5,057,000 from an accounting adjustment due to a charge from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 9 months included results of Zayre Stores, acquired in October 1988.

title: 85-Mile California Quake
description: A moderate earthquake under the San Jacinto Mountains was felt in an 85-mile stretch of southern California Saturday, but there were no reports of damage or injury. The temblor came at 3:16 P.M. and measured 4.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion, a California Institute of Technology spokesman said at Pasadena. The National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., estimated the magnitude at 4.5.

title: Clamor in Europe; Czech Students Belatedly Assail China Crackdown
description: In a belated expression of sympathy, several thousand Czechoslovak students marched here today to protest the violent suppression of China's pro-democracy movement in June.

title: Kemp Homeless Plan Offers Too Little
description: To the Editor:

title: Thanks a Million
description: George Zahringer 3d has been the most successful amateur golfer of the decade in the New York metropolitan area, thanks primarily to the teaching of Jim McLean, the head professional at Sleepy Hollow Country Club Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Port Authority Endorses Plan for Pier
description: A team of prominent Manhattan developers is poised to build housing, a hotel, shops and a marina on the East River piers at the foot of Brooklyn Heights, with the encouragement of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which controls most of the site.

title: Review/Music; Marriner and Academy
description: Neville Marriner first brought the symphonic configuration of the 30-year-old Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields on an American tour in 1987. Friday evening, he was back in Carnegie Hall with the London ensemble for the first of two concerts.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Bruins 2, Flyers 1: Bob Gould's third-period goal broke a tie as Boston, playing in Philadelphia, broke the five-game winning streak of the Flyer goalie, Ken Wregget. Philadelphia took only three shots in the first period.(AP) Sabres 4, Blues 3: Grant Ledyard scored the game-winner midway through the third period as Buffalo remained the only team in the league unbeaten at home. Ledyard took a pass from Phil Housley and beat the St. Louis goaltender, Greg Millen, with a 40-foot slap shot.(AP) Red Wings 4, Blackhawks 3: Steve Yzerman scored two power-play goals yesterday in Chicago and assisted on Gerard Gallant's tie breaker, becoming the fifth player in Detroit history to reach or exceed 600 points.(AP) RUGBY Army 9, James Madison 6: A penalty kick by Mike Kilbane as time expired in the second overtime period yesterday gave Army the Eastern intercollegiate rugby championship, in a match played in Orlando, Fla. Kilbane scored all of Army's points. SKIING First Title for Austrian: Thomas Stangassinger of Austria won his first World Cup skiing event yesterday by taking a slalom at Mont Ste-Anne, Quebec. He did his two runs in a time of 1 minute 43.51 seconds.(AP) 2 Brisk Times Win: Anita Wachter of Austria reclaimed the lead in the women's World Cup overall standing yesterday, winning a giant slalom in Vail, Colo., with the fastest times on both runs. Wachter held off a challenge by Diann Roffe of the United States, the runner-up. Wachter had a combined time of 2 minutes 18.29 seconds.(AP) GOLF Timely Playoff Eagles: Bill Glasson and Pat Bradley had an eagle at the fourth playoff hole yesterday to beat Duffy Waldorf and Patty Sheehan and win the J. C. Penney Classic in Largo, Fla. Glasson and Bradley shot the day's best round, a 66. The event matched players from the PGA and L.P.G.A. tours. (AP) SWIMMING Evans's String Ends: The Olympian Janet Evans ran her unbeaten streak to 27 races before ending it last night at the United States Open meet in Orlando, Fla. Evans was first in the 400-meter freestyle in 4 minutes 12.13 seconds, but had to settle for second in the 200-meter backstroke, which Janie Wagstaff of Mission Hills, Kan., won in 2:15.33. Evans had never swum the 200-meter backstroke in national competition before this week.(AP)

title: New Premier In India Looks To a Coalition
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh, the 58-year-old economist and politician who succeeded Rajiv Gandhi, is expected to name his cabinet in the next day or two as he seeks to form an administration that brings together parties of the left and of the right.

title: New Harvard Business Review Chief
description: Rosabeth Moss Kanter, a Harvard Business School expert in organizational behavior and a noted management consultant, took over the top editorial job at The Harvard Business Review on Friday, succeeding Theodore Levitt, who will return to teaching.

title: Cleaner New York Means More Litter Baskets, Not Moral Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Aifs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $571,000, or 17 cents a share, from the writedown of an investment for the quarter and the year included a net gain of $64,000, or 2 cents a share, from a lawsuit-settlement gain offset in part by the fourth quarter writedown.

title: Clamor in Europe; Czechs Name a New Cabinet But the Opposition Rejects It
description: Czechoslovakia named a new Cabinet today that includes non-Communists for the first time in 21 years, but it was rejected by the main opposition movement, which called for a mass demonstration on Monday to press for more change.

title: Lebanese General's Allies Confer
description: Commanders loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun, the Maronite Catholic military leader who refuses to recognize the country's new Government, met today to coordinate their forces in the face of a possible attack by Syrian troops to dislodge the defiant general from the presidential palace.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The arms race, mistrust, psychological and ideological struggle, all those should be things of the past.'' -Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:6. ]

title: New Medicare Proposal Targets Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Namsco reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter was adversely affected by the ''considerable application'' of management and sales force attention to an industry convention, new product rollout and a public offering of $5 million of 13.5 percent senior subordinated convertible debentures.

title: Filling Medicare Gaps: Debate Grows
description: A proposal to protect the elderly and disabled from unscrupulous sellers of health insurance has been gaining support in Congress since the recent repeal of the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act. But it is encountering stiff resistance from the insurance industry, which says that it would deny Medicare recipients access to health benefits they need.

title: Fur Industry Assails Critics in National Campaign
description: Responding to intensified protests by animal-rights advocates, the American fur industry has begun its first national advertising campaign in an attempt to reassure consumers that no one has the right to take away their ''freedom to buy and wear fur.''

title: For CBS, Some Advice On Programs
description: The low ratings and shortage of hit programs at CBS Inc. have posed problems for advertisers dependent on reaching mass audiences increasingly drawn to videocasette recorders, cable television and other entertainment media. On Friday, the day after the network's chief programming executive, Kim LeMasters, announced his resignation, several leading advertising agency media executives were asked what advice they would give the new program head. The executives, whose agencies represent large national advertisers like Chevrolet, Procter & Gamble, Eastman Kodak and Pepsi-Cola, offered these recommendations: John J. Sisk Jr. Senior vice president and director of negotiating, J. Walter Thompson U.S.A.

title: Larry Davis Not Guilty of Drug Dealer's Murder
description: Larry Davis, who has been acquitted of murder or attempted murder charges twice in the last two years, was acquitted again Saturday night on charges that he fatally shot a Harlem drug dealer in a robbery.

title: The Malta Summit; New Spur for a New Journey Together
description: George Bush finished one political journey today and started another. Mr. Bush began his

title: Oshman's Sporting Goods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included aftertax LIFO charges of $159,000 for the quarter and $434,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Included a loss of $827,000 for the quarter and a gain of $23,087,000 for the 9 months, both on sale of Abercrombie & Fitch, and aftertax LIFO charges of $150,000 and $432,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a gain of $1,612,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the first 9 months of 1988 have been restated to reflect a change in accounting principle for inventory accounting, including its effect on the gain on sale of Abercrombie & Fitch, as if it had occurred at the beginning of 1988.

title: Silk Greenhouse Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company indicated that as a result of delays in current year store openings, expenses during the third quarter were higher as a percentage of sales than in the prior year.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ameritrust Co., Cleveland, a financial services concern, promoted Frank I. Harding to president and chief executive of its trust and investment management group.

title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing
description: The police have charged a 24-year-old man in the slaying of Preston (Little Man) Simmons, a 14-year-old marijuana peddler, on Thanksgiving Day in the sprawling East Bronx housing project where both lived.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 3, 1989: MONDAY Albertsons Inc Harnischfeger Inds Cincinnati Bell Jamesway Corp Davis Wtr & Wst Standard Prods Co TUESDAY Alaska Air Grp Illinois Pwr Co American Stores Co Lennar Corp Angell Real Estate Premier Indl Corp Browning Ferris Inds Unocal Corp Chyron Corp Witco Corp WEDNESDAY Capital Hldg Corp Helmerich & Payne Corning Inc Louisville G&E Corroon & Black Corp Neiman-Marcus Group Deere & Co Peoples Engy Corp Desoto Inc Portland Gen Corp Fieldcrest Cannon Stanhome Inc General Dynamics Starret Co Green Moutain Pwr Times Mirror Co Handelman Co TIS Mtg Invst THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys General Host Corp Amax Inc Gen Pub Utils Corp Atlantic Energy Inc Natl Fuel Gas Co NJ Brown Group Inc RLI Corp Finevest Foods Inc Rockefeller Ctr Pptys Flight Saftey Intl SPS Technologies FRIDAY Abbott Labs Quick & Reilly Grp Lowes Cos Inc Strategic Mtg Invts

title: Tektronix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 11
description: b-Net income

title: Knicks Are Beaten By Lakers, 115-104
description: The whistle sounded and it took an instant for Stu Jackson to make his decision. Patrick Ewing, having just collected his fifth foul, would have to come out.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the Securities Industry Association misstated the business affiliation of its new chairman, Robert N. Downey. He is a partner with Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Defense Cuts: Little Pain, Modest Gain
description: LEAD: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney is preparing significant cuts in defense budgets through 1994. Although such cuts are usually feared as an economic nightmare, creating a national recession and leaving local depressions in their wake, the transition may turn out to be easier than expected and could result in economic opportunity - if properly anticipated and prepared for.

title: Browns Are Beaten By Bengals, 21-0
description: Boomer Esiason threw two touchdown passes, including a 38-yarder to Tim McGee on a trick play, as the Cincinnati Bengals revived their playoff hopes with their first shutout since 1980, beating the Browns, 21-0, today.

title: Addendum
description: * The Alfstad Blank Group, an advertising and marketing firm, has opened at 485 Fifth Avenue.

title: Sara Kaplan Marries
description: Sara H. Kaplan, the subscription marketing manager for Conde Nast Publications in New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth M. Wormser, a vice president of Citibank in New York. Rabbi Irving Spielman officiated at the Meadowlands Hilton in Secaucus, N.J. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Maury Kaplan of Fort Lee, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Wormser of Tenafly, N.J.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Dave Parker, designated hitter, to a two-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Named Hal Lanier coach. Named Jim Wright pitching coach of Scranton-Wilkes-Barre of the International League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Named Larry Hardy pitching coach and Tim Ireland assistant pitching coach of Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League. Named Jack Mull manager of Clinton of the Midwest League. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Jeff Schaefer and Brian Giles, infielders, and assigned them to Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL CHARLOTTE (NBA) - Signed Kenny Gattison, forward. Placed Dave Hoppen, center, on the injured list. FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAIDERS (AFC) -Activated Marcus Allen, running back, and Dennis Price, defensive back, from injured reserve. Waived Vince Evans, quarterback. Placed Tim Ware, wide receiver, on injured reserve. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Placed Michael Carter, nose tackle, on injured reserve. SEATTLE (AFC) - Waived Alonzo Mitz, defensive end. Activated Rod Stephens, linebacker.

title: REBEL HEAD AGREES TO ANGOLAN TRUCE
description: Jonas Savimbi, the leader of the rebel movement in Angola, said tonight that he was ready to sign an immediate cease-fire agreement with the Angolan Government.

title: Edberg Captures The Masters
description: After a bridesmaid's season in which he had twice been the runner-up in Grand Slam tournaments, a beaming Stefan Edberg was only too thrilled to get a grip on the flower-filled Tiffany trophy that pronounced him the champion of the 1989 Masters, the last event of tennis's year and the last run of the tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Onetime Abortion Foe Isn't So Sure Anymore
description: In his first three years in the Illinois General Assembly, Representative William B. Black was counted a consistent enemy of abortion. When the issue came to the floor, he voted with abortion foes nine times out of 10.

title: Clamor in Europe; All Leaders of East German Communist Party Quit
description: The East German Communist Party leadership under Egon Krenz collapsed today after a mounting wave of popular anger at its close identification with abuses under Erich Honecker, who was ousted as party leader last month.

title: Miss Miner Wed To Jesse Holland
description: Mindy Ruth Miner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott H. Miner of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Jesse Ian Holland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene N. Holland of Bronxville, N.Y. Rabbis Donald Cashman, Daniel Fogel and James Perman officiated at the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center in Queens.

title: The Malta Sumit: Reporter's Notebook; Instead of a Cold War, An Exchange of Gibes
description: President Bush tried to put his feet up, but President Gorbachev didn't join him. They never even took their coats off. Their cozy Saturday dinner and their Sunday stroll on deck were called because of rain.

title: Officials Begin Seeking Wreckage of Fishing Boat
description: Coast Guard officials began searching yesterday for the wreckage of a 110-foot charter-fishing boat that sank Saturday afternoon near the entrance to New York Harbor, killing two people. Coast Guard radio broadcasts warned mariners of the approximate location of the submerged ship, which could pose a hazard for harbor traffic.

title: Bridge
description: There is little doubt that New York City could defeat any other city in the world in a match between women's teams. Of the 16 living women who have earned the grandmaster rank of the World Bridge Federation, five live in New York City, and five other New York women are currently world titleholders.

title: Agassiz Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Miss Seidenberg Weds
description: Melissa Seidenberg, 29 years old, a special-education teacher in the Harrington Park (N.J.) public schools, was married yesterday to Jeff A. Kolodkin, 28, a director for American Trails West, a tour company in Great Neck, L.I. Cantor David Rosenzweig officiated at Bob Gilbert's Singers Caterers in Spring Valley, N.Y. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Seidenberg of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., and Susan L. Kolodkin of Wantagh, L.I., and Richard R. Kolodkin of Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Performing Artists Honored in Words and Music
description: The summit meeting in Malta between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was on everyone's minds when five performing artists were honored today in White House ceremonies and at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for lifetime achievements in the arts.

title: Clamor in Europe; For East Germany's Party, a Gamble Out of Desperation to Erase Disgrace
description: With the resignation today of the entire leadership, East Germany's Communist Party has set a precedent in this part of the world.

title: Clamor in Europe; Czech Statement on '68 Attack
description: Following is the text of the official English translation of a position paper on the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion, which the newly formed Government of Czechoslovakia made public today:

title: Swimming Minus Water
description: A new swim bench has been designed to supplement pool time and to build the same kind of strength on land in less time.

title: Spec's Music Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment of $206,000, or 4 cents a share. Figures have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split on Aug. 21, 1989.

title: Homeless Plan Called Meager For New York
description: The portion of the Bush Administration's new housing proposals aimed at the homeless will do little if anything to ease conditions for New York City's swelling homeless population, say city and state officials and advocates for the homeless.

title: Space Technology Helps Injured Knees
description: First there was the arthroscope, which reduced major knee surgery to minor incisions, enabling athletes to hop off the operating table to win gold medals in a matter of days. Now there's Hot/Ice, another promising upturn for knee and other operations.

title: 100 Chinese Defy a Ban
description: About 100 Chinese today defied a Government ban on ''English Corner,'' a glade in a Beijing park where people have gathered for years to practice English-language skills with foreigners. Cordons sealed off the glade, in the Purple Bamboo Park, which has served as a Sunday venue, and official notices nearby proclaimed that ''English Corner has been withdrawn.'' But defiant students and workers said they would continue to hold the conversation sessions until they are forcibly driven away.

title: Financial Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reviews/Music; The Jazz Generation Pays Tribute to Jimi Hendrix
description: Jimi Hendrix receives a tribute, acknowledged or not, in virtually every hard-rock guitar solo. A different kind of tribute took place on Friday night at Town Hall, where members of the jazz generation that grew up in the rock era played their own arrangements - usually radical reworkings - of Hendrix songs. ''The Hendrix Project,'' conceived and directed by Craig Dennis Street, used small and large ensembles to honor Hendrix, the composer.

title: Mortgage Rates Steady
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 9.74 percent last week, unchanged from the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders asked an average initial rate of 8.46 percent last week, down from 8.47 percent the week before.

title: Velcro Industries N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $28,000 for the quarter and $801,000 for the year.

title: Eagles Turn Giants' Mistakes Into a 24-17 Victory
description: The Giants gave it away today. They let the Philadelphia Eagles score all their points off four interceptions and fumbles, and when they fought back to tie the score, they let their chances slip away.

title: Packers Win and Stay Tied for First
description: Chris Jacke's 47-yard field goal with no time left gave Green Bay a 17-16 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers today and kept the Packers in first place in the National Football Conference Central.

title: Market Place; Foreign Events Shake Up Funds
description: AS bullets were flying around the presidential palace in Manila last week, nervous investors were selling shares of the fledgling First Philippine Fund, a closed-end mutual fund.

title: Comdr. Eric S. Purdon Dies at 76; Helped to Integrate Navy's Blacks
description: Comdr. Eric S. Purdon, retired, who commanded one of the ships that helped integrate blacks into the Navy's regular ranks, died of prostate cancer Saturday at his home in the Annapolis suburb of Harwood, Md. He was 76 years old.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 Men Found Shot Inside a Parked Car
description: Two men were shot to death in the Bronx as they were sitting in a car last evening, and investigators called the double slaying ''possibly drug-related.''

title: Cleaner New York Means More Litter Baskets, Not Moral Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Revised UAL Plan Seen
description: Three unions of United Airlines have met with officials of its parent company, the UAL Corporation, to draft a revised employee-led buyout proposal, a company spokesman said today, and the carrier's flight attendants said a new offer would come this week.

title: U.S. Inmate Count Doubled Since 1980, Congress Is Told
description: The General Accounting Office reported today that the 70 Federal prisons now hold more than 48,000 inmates, 56 percent over capacity and double the prison population in 1980, when the system was less than 1 percent over capacity.

title: The 'Auteur' Syndrome
description: LEAD: From the supercolossal ''Batman'' to the personal and innovative documentary ''The Thin Blue Line,'' from the baseball fantasy ''Field of Dreams'' to the sensitive gay tragedy ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' the selection of motion pictures here brings a cross-section of American films from big to small, from blatant commercialism to avant-garde experimentation.

title: Ex-Molloy Star Pressures Opponents, Not Himself
description: WHEN Kenny Anderson walks onto the court for the A.C.C.-Big East Challenge matchup between Georgia Tech and Pittsburgh at the Hartford Civic Center tonight, the former Archbishop Molloy High star says he will have a rooting section of at least 50 family members and friends from New York City.

title: The Malta Summit; Soviet News Reports Applaud the Summit Talks
description: Soviet news reports today hailed the meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and George Bush at Malta as another signal that the cold war is in remission.

title: Lynda Greenberg, An Editor, Is Wed
description: Lynda Jo Greenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Reuben Greenberg of New York, was married yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club to Daniel A. Hulkower, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hulkower of Port Washington, L.I. Rabbi Stephen Lerner officiated, assisted by Rabbi Neil Kurshan.

title: Malta Seeks to Fill Beirut's Shoes
description: The Republic of Malta, a crossroads between East and West long before the summit meeting of President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is promoting itself as a new international financial center, to fill the role once played by Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Coup Fails, Manila Says Amid Fighting
description: The Government said Sunday that it had quelled the military rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino after three and a half days of fighting that killed about 100 people and wounded 300 others.

title: Chairman Is Signal Apparel Chief
description: The Signal Apparel Company, a Chattanooga knitwear maker that has struggled through some money-losing quarters, has announced that its president and chief executive, Charles W. Davies Jr., has resigned and is taking a post with another textile company.

title: Salomon Sues State
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. filed a $150 million countersuit last week against West Virginia in Federal court here. The state had sued Salomon, County NatWest Government Securities Inc. and three other firms in October, blaming them for $279 million in losses suffered by the state's consolidated investment fund in 1987-89. Last Thursday, the state cleared County NatWest from further litigation when it voted to accept a $2 million settlement. Salomon said in its suit that West Virginia had made $150 million in profits in the period.

title: Question Box
description: No Heisman for Brown Q. Before Jim Brown became a great running back for the Cleveland Browns, he was a star at Syracuse, but he was never voted the Heisman Trophy as the country's outstanding college player. How close did he get? A. Not close enough to call for a measurement. In 1956, Brown's senior year at Syracuse, he barely cracked the top five among Heisman finishers, earning a little more than half the point total accumulated by the winner, Paul Hornung, quarterback at Notre Dame. Hornung received 1,066 points in the voting, and was followed by Johnny Majors, tailback from Tennessee (994); Tommy McDonald, halfback from Oklahoma (973); Jerry Tubbs, center from Oklahoma (724), and Brown, all-purpose fullback from Syracuse (561).

title: Assurance By Japan On Jet Deal
description: Japanese Government officials say the United States' two leading aircraft engine makers have been virtually assured a big role in a Government-financed project to design an extremely fast commercial aircraft.

title: Nursing Shortage, Wages and Tasks Grow
description: Shuttling between incubators in the hot, cramped neonatal intensive care ward at Kings County Hospital, Florence Cheri, a registered nurse, rarely enjoys a moment's lull.

title: Jackson Visits Portrait And Says It's Inoffensive
description: Four days after a group of enraged black men knocked down a 14-by-16-foot painting of a white-skinned, blond, blue-eyed Jesse Jackson, Mr. Jackson made a visit today to see the portrait for himself and found it inoffensive.

title: Drew Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a provision for loss of $1,750,000, or $1,155,000 net of taxes, on the disposition of a portion of the Aluminum Extrusion operation, acquired from Novo Corp. in November 1988, as well as a charge of $450,000, or $297,000 net of taxes, relating to a ladder product liability loss for both the quarter and year. The accident occurred during a period when insurance coverage was provided by an insurance company which is now bankrupt. c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $234,000, or 5 cents a share, which represents the utilization of tax capital loss carryforward.

title: Richard W. Welch, 69, A Top Boeing Executive
description: Richard W. Welch, who rose from accounting clerk to president of the Boeing Company's commercial aircraft division, died last Tuesday of a neurological disease. He was 69 years old.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Sale Decision Tough For Huffco's Founder
description: LEAD: The oil and gas explorers who built many American private oil fortunes in the 1950's and 1960's are graying, and when it comes to passing the baton not all of their offspring want to take on the task of managing their inheritance.

title: Cleaner New York Means More Litter Baskets, Not Moral Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Says U.S. Attorney Is Investigating Stock Transfer
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins said yesterday that Federal authorities are investigating a stock transaction that became a troublesome issue in the last weeks of his campaign, but said he was not worried about the inquiry.

title: Brash Eagles Label Giants Easy Victim
description: A third-quarter play with 7 minutes 7 seconds remaining this afternoon summed up the Eagles' attitude not only toward the Giants, but also toward the rest of the National Football League in a season full of tough talk by Philadelphia.

title: Richard R. Salzman, Editor, 69
description: Richard R. Salzmann, the editor in chief of the Research Institute of America, publisher of tax guides, from 1965 until he retired in 1985, died of a heart ailment on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 69 years old and had lived for many years in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Tennessee and Louisiana Tech Keep a Lock on Supremacy
description: LEAD: EVERY sport has its traditional powers and accustomed pecking order, but in women's college basketball, the competitive hierarchy is familiar and seemingly set.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: China Problems That Slow Economy Are Reflected in Lag for Port Project
description: Perhaps the boldest single project envisioned during the last decade of China's economic restructuring was a plan to copy the success of Hong Kong, 300 miles to the northeast, here on southern China's Hainan Island.

title: The Malta Summit; Tariff Offer Gives Soviets a Foothold
description: In offering to cut punitively high tariffs on Soviet exports and support observer status for Moscow in the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, President Bush has moved dramatically to encourage the Soviet Union's integration into the global economy.

title: Fire Kills Brooklyn Woman, 67; 2 Are Hurt
description: A 67-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed and her daughter and grandson were seriously burned in a fire that swept through a three-story wood building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Books of The Times; Mamet's Freaks and Psychology
description: Some Freaks By David Mamet 180 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included income of $9,235,000, or 28 cents a share, from reduction of deferred tax liability due to change in accounting principle.

title: Jet Crash Kills 2 Guardsmen
description: A fighter jet crashed today while on maneuvers over western Alabama, killing two Mississippi Air National Guardsman, the authorities said.

title: As Inner-City Areas Decay, Blacks Flee to Small Towns
description: Life in the inner city has become so bleak that a growing number of poor blacks are fleeing to smaller cities, towns and suburbs in search of opportunity or, at least, safety.

title: Congress Report Tells of Security Lapses at Nuclear Weapons Plant
description: A secret inspection of the Lawrence Livermore nuclear weapons laboratory in California turned up serious security lapses last spring, including poor protection of plutonium, a Congressional report shows.

title: No More Excuses on Gun Control
description: ''I am a southern Illinois boy who grew up hunting and at home with guns. I don't question the rights of responsible gun owners . . . The issue is whether the John Hinckleys of the world should be able to walk into gun stores and purchase handguns instantly.''

title: Review/Theater; Mamet's Tasteful Hell for a Movie Mogul
description: Women are a recent addition to the plays of David Mamet, and they really muck up the works. It's not that Mr. Mamet's writing suffers when women are on stage. In his new 45-minute comedy ''Bobby Gould in Hell'' - the second half of ''Oh, Hell,'' the double bill Mr. Mamet shares with Shel Silverstein at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater - the playwright is as funny and pungent as ever. He even gets laughs out of a ''Two Jews go into a bar'' joke that never reaches its punch line. But women drive the men in Mr. Mamet's plays crazy, even if one of the men happens to be, well, the devil incarnate.

title: Chief Judge Urges Albany to Alter Law
description: Calling drug-related crime ''the most profound crisis we have faced in 50 years,'' New York's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, called today for sweeping changes in state law to help relieve the state's overcrowded criminal and family courts.

title: An Idea Whose Time Arrived
description: NEARLY a decade ago, before the Big East conference, as the country's basketball junkies now know it, had been fully assembled, long before ESPN introduced the term ''Big Monday'' into the hoop consciousness, before Patrick Ewing graduated from high school, before most anyone knew what a Hoya was, before a 19-foot-9-inch shot meant 3 points instead of 2 and a hostile crowd could wave goodbye after the sixth foul instead of the fifth, before the month of March could be bought by a television network for $1 billion, before a former coach named Dick Vitale was any more than, in his words, a diaper dandy in the TV business - before all that, Dave Gavitt had this idea.

title: Reviews/Television; Roosevelt and Pearl Harbor: A Reprise on an Old Rumor
description: What did Franklin D. Roosevelt know about Pearl Harbor and when did he know it? ''Sacrifice at Pearl Harbor,'' tonight's British-made documentary on the Arts & Entertainment Network at 9 o'clock makes the case that the President knew a lot more about the Japanese plans to attack America's big naval base in the Pacific than he shared with its commanders, Fleet Adm. Husband E. Kimmel and Gen. Walter C. Short, who would instantly be blamed for the disaster.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about paintings by Alfred Pinkham Ryder misidentified the publishers of two books about him. The book by Elisabeth Broun is published by the Smithsonian Institution Press. The other, an extended study by Lloyd Goodrich and William I. Homer, is published by Harry N. Abrams.

title: High Stakes for Product Managers
description: Tracy Carlson has an inordinate interest in stains.

title: INSIDE
description: Hong Kong to Force Out Vietnamese Boat People Hong Kong, straining to house the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people who have arrived in the last 18 months, is making final arrangements to force them to return.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: U.S. Grants Aquino's Military Quick Sale of Anti-Tank Arms
description: Fearing that Philippine soldiers loyal to the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino were losing ground again, the Bush Administration granted a Philippine request late Saturday for the quick sale and transfer of hundreds of anti-tank weapons from American bases to Mrs. Aquino's forces, officials said today.

title: Jets Overcome Chargers, 20-17
description: The Jets did not pat themselves on the back too generously today. When they were done, they seemed to revel in their victory over the Chargers with only half-smiles, like a team that knew it had won but still wasn't quite sure how.

title: Walesa Prods British to Invest
description: Lech Walesa urged Britain today to seize business opportunities created by the wave of change in Eastern Europe. Ending a five-day visit, Mr. Walesa, a founder of the Polish union Solidarity, said at a news conference that while West Germany had 380 companies operating in Poland, Britain had only 10 or 15. The British have increased aid to Poland by $160 million, to $200 million, but have made it clear that Polish economic reforms will have to be permanent before firm commitments are made.

title: Virginia and Santa Clara Share Title
description: After fighting to a 1-1 deadlock in 150 minutes of soccer at Rutgers Stadium today, Virginia and Santa Clara were declared co-champions of the N.C.A.A. Division I soccer tournament.

title: Skagit Journal; Farmers See Park Plans As Plague in the Making
description: The farmers of the Skagit Valley have struggled through a decade of bad weather, debt and unpredictable markets. Now, just as good times are returning to this rich alluvial valley 65 miles north of Seattle, they see a new threat in a proposal to build a farm theme park amid real farms.

title: Mexican Papers Want To Keep Tie With State
description: Something odd has happened to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's effort to reduce the Government's financial influence over Mexico's newspapers.

title: Metro Datelines; Man, 74, Found Dead, Gagged With Tape
description: A 74-year-old Brooklyn man whose eyes, mouth, hands and feet had been bound with tape was found dead in his Coney Island apartment, the police said.

title: Care and Heeding of Knee Injuries
description: PROBABLY no injury is as debilitating to an athlete as one involving a knee. And this is the time of the year when athletes have already begun or are about to return to the slopes. Although other sports - indoor tennis, squash and racquetball to name three - are often associated with knee damage, skiing is perhaps the most demanding on gimpy knees. Predictably, the ski industry has come up with different methods to diagnose weakness and test rehabilitation of the knee.

title: Syracuse Wins in Rally
description: Wendal Lowery, Syracuse's third-string quarterback, hit Rob Carpenter with scoring passes of 64 and 79 yards in the fourth quarter today to lead the Orange to a 24-13 victory over Louisville in the Coca-Cola Bowl.

title: Arab Girl Dies in Clash in Gaza
description: Soldiers shot and killed a 10-year-old Palestinian girl today and reportedly wounded at least 27 other Arabs during widespread clashes set off by arrests in the occupied territories and the slaying of four Palestinians on Friday.

title: New Detroit Executive For McCann-Erickson
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has turned to a longtime automotive advertising executive to help it sell Buicks and Chevrolet trucks. It chose John Mead to be executive creative director of its Detroit office as well as executive vice president. Mr. Mead had supervised the Toyota Motor Corporation account as creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi/Southern California.

title: Arms Trade Keeps Burmese at War
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Optidiet, a diet product developed by Optibal Co., to Romann & Tannenolz Advertising, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Metro Datelines; Exhaust Fumes Kill 2 In Garage and House
description: An elderly man died in his garage yesterday after inhaling carbon monoxide fumes that also killed his wife in an upstairs room of their Bronx home, the police said.

title: Making Connections: Roseanne as Author, 'She-Devil' and Herself
description: For a barefoot prime-time goddess in jeans and a pink-and-glitter ''Wild Thing'' T-shirt, Roseanne Barr was incongruously somber as she talked about Ruth Patchett. That's the character she plays in her forthcoming feature-film debut in ''She-Devil,'' the movie that is supposed to do for the comic star of the nation's top-rated television show what ''48 Hours'' did for Eddie Murphy and ''Running Scared'' did for Billy Crystal.

title: Relief Workers Bring a Saving Grace to the War in Salvador
description: Trapped alone against a shallow doorway under intense machine-gun and rocket fire, a journalist covering the recent fighting here suddenly felt a hand touch his shoulder.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
For Amateur and Pro, 40 Rules to Live By
description: LEAD: YOU'D think the No. 1 tennis player in the world would know the rules. Well, think again. Steffi Graf was stumped by the first point of her Virginia Slims Championships final against Martina Navratilova at Madison Square Garden recently. Graf pounded a service return at Navratilova's feet. Navratilova dug out a half-volley that arched over the net, landed on Graf's side, then bounced high.

title: Clamor in Europe; Once Muffled, Czech Writers Seize a Voice
description: ''We don't exist,'' said Vera Adlova, a writer and principal official of the Czechoslovak Writers Union. ''You are talking to a corpse.''

title: Jail Guard Held After a Shooting
description: A New York City correction officer was arrested and suspended early yesterday morning in connection with a fatal shooting in Queens over the weekend, the police said.

title: Shirt Shed Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Malta Summit; U.S. Shift on Arms Talks
description: President Bush's decision to try to complete a strategic arms treaty with Moscow before the next summit meeting in June marks an important shift in his thinking on arms control.

title: Reviews/Television; Mixing Fact and Fiction In Howard Beach Case
description: Early on the morning of Dec. 20, 1986, three black men from Brooklyn were walking through Howard Beach, a nearly all-white part of Queens, after their car broke down nearby. An auto with several local teen-agers approached; racial slurs were exchanged.
