Shortly afterward, a dozen young whites, brandishing a baseball bat and screaming racial curses, set upon the men and chased them through the neighborhood.

title: Reviews/Dance; Laura Shapiro's New Suite
description: Laura Shapiro dealt with interesting themes in a program of new solo dances on Friday night at the Dia Art Foundation. The simplicity of her theatrical touches and choreography was just right for the development of those themes. But the most compelling ingredient in the work was Miss Shapiro's own presence - quiet, intelligent and nicely down to earth.

title: Vandeweghe Returning
description: Kiki Vandeweghe, his sore back said to be ''much improved,'' will return to New York on Wednesday. General Manager Al Bianchi made the announcement in Los Angeles yesterday after a telephone conversation with Dr. Norman Scott, the team's doctor, several hours before the Knicks closed out their four-game West Coast trip against the Lakers.

title: Morgan Offers A Bond Index
description: J. P. Morgan & Company will introduce a bond index today to measure changes in the world's major government bond markets.

title: Washington Talk; Bush's Approval Is High But Not Deep, Poll Finds
description: In a capital consumed with polling, the most closely watched number of all, the political equivalent of the Dow Jones industrial average, is the Presidential approval rating.

title: Penn Traffic reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said results included P&C Food Markets Inc. since Aug. 6, 1988 and Big Bear Inc. since April 1, 1989.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Film Festival With the Spirit of Margaret Mead
description: Gods, shamans, peasants and chorus girls populate the works at the Margaret Mead Film Festival, which begins today and runs through Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History. The annual festival, named for the influential anthropologist, may suggest endless accounts of Samoan initiation rites. But the 48 nonfiction films to be shown are eclectic enough to include Hindu pilgrims, rangers at Yosemite National Park and a Chinese-American bubble dancer.

title: Outside Cash For British Accountants
description: Government and professional groups in Britain are pressing ahead with reforms that could eventually allow accounting firms to incorporate to raise money by selling stakes to outside investors.

title: Familiar Redmen Result
description: In the last 15 years, St. John's has met 30 different teams in the Joe Lapchick Memorial tournament - teams from different regions, teams with a variety of philosophies and strategies - and in those years, none of those teams have beaten the Redmen.

title: The Editorial Notebook; European Marxism, 1848-1989
description: ''A specter is haunting Europe -the specter of Communism,'' wrote Karl Marx in January 1848. It took a century for that red specter to become iron gray reality in Eastern Europe. Yet just weeks after the 29-year-old German philosophy student wrote those words, Europe was swamped by a continental wave of liberal, nationalist revolutions. The upheavals of 1848 gave birth to European Marxism. Now, a strikingly similar wave of revolutions appears to signal its death.

title: The Malta Summit; ECONOMIC PLEDGES CHEER SOVIET AIDES
description: Pleased Soviet officials said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had achieved his major goal at the summit meeting: a critically needed turn away from economic cold war by President Bush.

title: The Taxi Quest: Seeking Ways to Make It Easier
description: On a cold afternoon last week, Perry Gershon stood on the Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, trying to hail a taxi. Several occupied taxis went by before an empty one finally stopped. But just as Mr. Gershon was reaching for the door, a man darted out from behind him and leaped in.

title: Hong Kong Journal; Sad Flotsam, the Boat People Must Drift Home
description: Hong Kong, straining to house the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people who have arrived in the last 18 months, is making final arrangements to force them to return to the country they risked their lives to escape.

title: A Sandinista Hero and Renegade Returns to Nicaragua From Exile
description: After eight years in exile, Eden Pastora Gomez, the renegade Sandinista hero and former contra leader, returned to Nicaragua today, vowing to forge a ''third path'' in the country's polarized political life.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Rigoletto' Cast Changes
description: ''Rigoletto'' by Verdi was the Metropolitan Opera's Saturday matinee this weekend. Simultaneously, the Met was celebrating its 50 years of Texaco-sponsored radio broadcasts by sending out to the country a tape of an earlier performance, Strauss's ''Frau Ohne Schatten.''

title: Czechs Getting a Quick Market Education
description: Czechoslovakia's moves toward political change have already had one economic effect, and the Czechoslovaks are not very happy about it: dollars are costing far more on the black market.

title: HERO OR DECEIVER?
description: Students at Wake Forest University agree that Timothy W. Bell acted heroically last June when he carried videotape of the Tiananmen Square massacre out of China.

title: U.S.-Japan Talks Falter
description: Japan and the United States have failed to resolve a longstanding dispute over foreign access to Japan's supercomputer market, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said Friday.

title: Goal of Donor To Neediest: 'Caring City'
description: President Bush's comments on voluntarism and charity have taken root in the minds of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund if several notes referring to ''a thousand points of light'' and ''a kinder, gentler nation'' are any indication.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
Boxers Help Their Own
description: LEAD: Early last month, the police found Sandy Saddler, a former world featherweight champion, wandering late at night in Brooklyn, robbed of his wallet and eyeglasses.

title: National Bank Canada reports earnings for Year to to Oct 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Trimel Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from an extraordinary credit of $30,000 for the quarter and income from an extraordinary credit of $3,081,000, or $1.06 a share for the year, from a gain on the sale of publishing assets. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Exports Rise for 3 Nations
description: The world's three largest trading nations all showed a big increase in the value of their exports in the first half of the year, compared with the first six months of 1988, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: Piedmont Natural Gas Co.  reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Debut at the Polls Delights Opposition in Taiwan
description: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party today expressed strong satisfaction with its showing in elections on Saturday, and said its performance would have been more impressive if it were not for vote buying and election fraud.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title: The Malta Summit; BUSH AND GORBACHEV PROCLAIM A NEW ERA FOR U.S.-SOVIET TIES; AGREE ON ARMS AND TRADE AIMS
description: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended their first summit meeting today with an extraordinary public affirmation of the new relationship between their countries.

title: Despite Fracture, Taylor Plays
description: Lawrence Taylor played for the Giants today on what the club said was a hairline fracture at the base of his right tibia.

title: Clamor in Europe; Czech Emigres Hail Events, but Enjoy Life in U.S.
description: Prominent Czechoslovak emigres in the United States praised the political upheaval in their homeland in interviews last week but for the most part said they would continue to live in this country.

title: Women Say They Face Obstacles as Lawyers
description: Women at the nation's largest law firms say that although they believe their pay equals that of their male counterparts, they lack the same chances for top job assignments, litigation experience and promotions.

title: Subway Service Still Disrupted On Five Lines
description: Service on four IND subway lines and the JFK Express will remain disrupted at least through the middle of the week because of a water main that ruptured and flooded a subway station in Harlem over the weekend, a spokesman for the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: Strife Over Style and Substance Tests Princeton's Leader
description: When Harold T. Shapiro left the University of Michigan two years ago to become president of Princeton University, he brought with him no small burden of expectations. An economist who, as president, had steered Michigan through a time of financial hardship, he arrived here after an unusually brief search and to a chorus of praises.

title: Reviews/Dance; Ordinary People in Everyday Doings
description: Blondell Cummings made meaningful dances out of the minutiae of human behavior in her program on Friday night at the Kitchen.

title: Outdoors: When Wind Whistles, Get the Plum Jelly Ready
description: AWAKENED by the house creaking in a half-gale out of the southwest that began before dawn, I decided to make my first duck-hunting trip of the season that afternoon.

title: For Ukrainian Catholics, Hope Mixed With Caution
description: The Rev. Patrick P. Paschak, the pastor at St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church in the East Village, came across an emotional scene in October when he visited the Ukraine, where Catholics have been forced to practice their religion underground since 1946.

title: Ailing Agency - The F.D.A. and Safety; A Guardian of U.S. Health Is Buckling Under Stress
description: The Food and Drug Administration, the Federal agency responsible for insuring the safety of food, drugs, cosmetics and medical devices, is facing rising responsibilities with a smaller staff and a budget that has remained almost constant for a decade.

title: Dahlen Is Silenced On (and Off) the Ice
description: The Rangers' 6-0 loss to the Los Angeles Kings was just minutes old, and the silence in the visiting team's locker room was split only by the angry rip of tape as the players tore it from their ankles and wrists.

title: Metro Datelines; Car Kills Pedestrian Crossing 10th Ave.
description: A 76-year-old man was struck and killed by a car yesterday morning as he was crossing a street in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-16 Their first summit meeting ended with Presidents Bush and Gorbachev affirming the new relationship between their countries. They pledged to conclude treaties on long-range nuclear weapons and conventional arms and to meet again in June. Page A1 News analysis: ''A new impetus'' behind U.S.-Soviet relations may be the most important achievement of the summit meeting, during which President Bush brushed away the appearance of skepticism toward his counterpart. A1 News analysis: The President's shift on strategic arms control became apparent after his decision to try to complete a treaty before the next summit meeting in June. A10 An offer to cut tariffs on exports from the Soviet Union will likely encourage that nation's integration into the global economy. A11 Economic pledges cheer Soviet aides A11 Instead of a cold war, an exchange of taunts A11 For networks, big stars, great scenery but ''Anchors Adrift'' A11 East Germany's Communist leaders resigned their party posts. Egon Krenz remained head of state, but his power is gone. Erich Honecker, who was ousted last month as party leader, was expelled from the party. A1 News analysis: The mass resignation by East Germany's Communist Party leadership is a ''desperate gamble'' 12 days before an extraordinary party congress elects a new Central Committee. A14 Prague named a new ruling Cabinet that includes non-Communists for the first time in 21 years, but it was rejected by opposition leaders who called for protests to press for more change. A1 Czechs getting a quick market education D6 Czech students belatedly assail Chinese crackdown A15 A Philippine revolt has been crushed after more than three days of fighting and 100 deaths, the Government declared. But 500 troops still controlled Manila's financial district. A16 U.S. grants Aquino's military quick sale of anti-tank arms A16 Rebel leader in Angola would sign cease-fire agreement. A7 A former Nicaraguan contra leader returned from eight years of exile and vowed to forge a political force in the nation free from the influence of either Washington or Moscow. A3 El Salvador's army of relief workers, once organized to guard beaches and fight fires, has been forced by a decade of war to aid and evacuate the nation's civilians. A6 India's Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, is expected to name his Cabinet soon as he tries to form a new minority Government that brings together parties of the left and right. A5 Two U.S. aircraft engine makers have been assured a big role in a Japanese Government-financed project to design a ''hypersonic'' commericial airplane capable of flying from New York to Tokyo in three to five hours. D1 Debut at the polls, 21 seats of 101, pleases Taiwan's opposition A3 National A18-21, B10 The F.D.A. is strapped for resources as its responsibilities for insuring the safety of food, drugs, cosmetics and medical devices are rising, officials and experts say. A1 Banking regulators ignored warnings in 1986 about the Columbia Savings and Loan Association's heavy investment in risky high-yield securities that may have contributed to some of the more than $500 million in losses the company reported recently, former officials say. D1 Federal limits on Medigap policies, insurance plans that fill in gaps in Medicare coverage, are the subject of a growing debate between consumer advocates and the health insurance industry. A20 Washington Talk: Bush's approval is high, but not deep A20 Report tells of security lapses at nuclear weapons plant A20 Poor blacks are fleeing inner cities for suburbs and smaller towns in search of a better life. The exodus is a result of the continuing collapse of poor neighborhoods in cities like Chicago and New York. A1 The public debate over abortion has been pulling state legislators like William Black of Illinois both ways. Once an enemy of abortion, he has found himself seized with growing doubt and ambivalence. A18 Women lawyers still face barriers to advancement in their firms, even though 87 percent say their pay equals that of their male counterparts, a new survey shows. A21 Reporter's notebook: Waiting for a verdict in Miami A18 Smuggling videotapes from China of the Tiananmen Square massacre was a heroic act for a Wake Forest University senior, but may also have been a violation of his school's honor code. A19 Regional B1-8 Housing proposals for the homeless offered by the Bush Administration will do little to ease conditions for New York City's swelling homeless population, say officials and advocates. B1 The shortage of registered nurses has sparked a feverish competition among New York metropolitan hospitals to outbid the others' salary offers. B1 Ukrainian Catholics in New York are hopeful after a landmark meeting between Pope John Paul II and the Soviet President, Mikhail Gorbachev, that Catholics in the Ukraine will again be able to pray openly. B1 Want a cab? During rush hour? It is a truism of life in New York City that it's almost impossible to catch a cab in the rush hour or the rain. But the city keeps trying. B2 Subway service disrupted after water main ruptures B2 A stock transfer by David Dinkins that became a worrisome campaign issue is being investigated by Federal authorities, the Mayor-elect confirmed. He said the inquiry would not impede the shaping of his administration. B3 Laws to relieve overcrowded courts in New York were called for by the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler. He also urged a 10 percent increase in state spending on the court system, as well as other reforms. B3 Jail guard held after a shooting B2 Larry Davis acquitted again B5 Man is held in youth's killing B5 Officials begin seeking wreckage of fishing boat B4 A project for the East River piers at the foot of Brooklyn Heights has been tentatively agreed on by a team of Manhattan developers and the Port Authority, apparently foreclosing the possibility of a riverfront park. B4 Budget hardships at Princeton have led to a rocky two-year tenure for its president, Harold Shapiro. The discontent reflects the struggle universities face as they try to pay for academic and research programs. B1

title: Two Leaders Reach A Turn in the Road
description: President Bush has moved to encourage the Soviet Union's integration into the global economy. Page A11.

title: Clamor in Europe; Egon Krenz's 46 Days as East Berlin Party Chief
description: Here is a chronology of the 46-day tenure of Egon Krenz, the East German Communist Party leader.

title: Czarist Flags Return
description: To the Editor:

title: PGI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings reflects payment of cumulative preferred dividends in arrears.

title: Toronto Dominion Bank reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Assets as of Oct. 31 were 63,100,000,000 versus 59,300,000,000.

title: Aggravating Is Kind Word
description: IN all his important games as the Giants' quarterback, Phil Simms had never made so many costly mistakes as he did yesterday. His second fumble positioned what turned out to be the Philadelphia Eagles' decisive touchdown in a 24-17 victory. His first fumble created the Eagles' first touchdown. When he was intercepted later in the first quarter, Clyde Simmons returned it 60 yards for the Eagles' second touchdown. Another interception led to the Eagles' field goal. And now, when he was asked at his locker if this had been ''the most aggravating game of his career,'' Phil Simms smiled. ''Aggravating is a kind word,'' he said. After other losses, Bill Parcells has often defended Simms, but yesterday not even the Giants' coach could defend his quarterback. And at his locker, Simms wasn't about to defend himself. When somebody asked, ''Can you explain what happpened on the. . . .'' he spoke up.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL Japanese officials have assured G.E. and Pratt & Whitney of a big role in a Government-financed project to design an extremely fast commercial aircraft. The Ministry of Trade and Industry hopes to spend $200 million in the next few years designing an engine for the ''hypersonic'' aircraft, which would travel at five times the speed of sound. The companies have indicated that they would need U.S. approval before signing any contracts. [ Page D1. ] Government and professional groups in Britain are pressing ahead with reforms that for the first time in decades could allow accounting firms there to incorporate for the purpose of raising outside equity capital. Outside capital has become more alluring since the profession's moves into nontraditional services. [ D1. ] Dollars are costing far more on Czechoslovakia's black market. The word on the street - or at least in taxicabs where the drivers run a thriving money-changing business - is that many Czechs rushed to buy hard currency as soon as the Government said it would open the Czechoslovak-Austrian border. [ D6. ] Beijing's political crackdown has stalled progress on an ambitious project to copy the success of Hong Kong on southern China's Hainan Island, where a chunk of land was to be leased to a foreign company for transformation into a duty-free port and a modern city of several hundred thousand people. [ D6. ] Congress and the business community are likely to endorse President Bush's proposals at the Malta summit encouraging the Soviet Union's integration into the global economy. The President has offered to cut punitively high tariffs on Soviet exports and to support observer status for Moscow in GATT. [ A11. ] The Republic of Malta is promoting itself as a new international financial center, to fill the role left by Beirut. [ D6. ] The three largest trading nations all showed a big increase in the value of their exports during the first half of the year. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY Federal regulators rejected warnings in 1986 about the Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., former Government officials who were involved in the decision said. They said Federal action at the time might have prevented some of the more than $500 million in losses reported by the institution. [ D1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The CBS network is in danger of taking up a long, unhappy residence in the ratings basement - at a time when that position carries unwelcome financial implications. Television. [ D11. ] CBS's low ratings and programming problems have not gone unnoticed by advertisers. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D12. ] Mexican newspaper publishers are resisting President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's effort to reduce the Government's financial influence over Mexico's newspapers. [ D11. ] The fur industry has begun its first national ad campaign in an attempt to respond to protests by animal-rights advocates. [ D11. ] City and regional magazines are becoming anxious about a possible loss of advertising because of national magazines having the ability to split their circulation into hundreds of editions. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A sharp rise in gold prices may inhibit further declines in long-term interest rates for the balance of the year, some analysts contend. There does not seem to be any clear-cut reason for gold's increase in price. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] Chrysler finds itself out of step with the current rhythm in the auto industry: profits are getting harder to make in the U.S. and easier to make in Europe, where Chrysler does not have big operations as Ford and G.M. do. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [ D2. ] Nervous investors sold shares of the First Philippine Fund last week during the attempted coup in Manila. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Applied Data Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Budget Fix Needs Fixing
description: The 1985 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law was supposed to eliminate Federal deficits by next October. It won't. Worse, the law distorts budget decisions, encourages deceit and risks turning recession into disaster.

title: The Malta Summit; Transcript of the Bush-Gorbachev News Conference in Malta
description: Following is the text of the questions and answers at a news conference today with President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. The session came at the end of their two-day summit meeting. Mr. Gorbachev spoke through an interpreter. Status of the Cold War

title: Penril Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Keller Industries Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. Results translated from Canadian dollar amounts at the rate of $1.77 equals $1.00 (U.S.) for the periods ending Sept. 30, and $1.199 equals $1.00 (U.S.) for the periods ending Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Confusion Reigns as Bowl Games Near
description: Nearly seven hours removed from the giddy climax of the football weekend of football weekends in this town, the stopped traffic at Toomer's Corner was redefining the concept of gridlock.

title: Suffolk Police Arrest Welder In Hit-Run Deaths of Couple
description: An ''overwhelming response by the public'' led detectives to a 33-year-old man who was arrested in the hit-and-run deaths of a Florida couple, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: The Malta Summit: Critic's Notebook; For TV Networks at Malta, Big Stars, Great Scenery but 'Anchors Adrift
description: For most of the way, television's treatment of the weekend summit meeting resembled one of those hoopla-heavy shows with big stars, sensational scenery and not much of a book that flop on Broadway every season.

title: Parker Leaves A's To Join Brewers
description: The spiraling search for baseball talent intensified today as the 26 major-league teams gathered for their winter meetings and Dave Parker left the Oakland Athletics to join the Milwaukee Brewers for just over $3 million for the next two years.

title: Sri Lankan Rebels Kill 17 Soldiers in Ambush
description: Ethnic Tamil rebels ambushed an army truck and killed 17 Sinhalese soldiers today in the Vavuniya district about 110 miles north of Colombo, a military official reported.

title: Petrolite reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge for reorganization of $5 million for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: More Reebok For Chiat/Day
description: Reebok International Ltd., the maker of footwear whose partnership with Chiat/Day/ Mojo has yielded some dramatic but much-criticized advertising, last week awarded the agency its advertising outside Britain and North America. A spokesman for Chiat/ Day said a budget had not been set, but the advertising trade press has reported that the account could be as large as $20 million.

title: A Ring Rivalry That Won't Die
description: THE fight defies the laws of probability. Back in 1980, when they last boxed, what soothsayer would have had the gall to prophesy that nine years later Roberto Duran and Sugar Ray Leonard would still matter enough to generate big-fight excitement one more time?

title: Pro Bono
description: * Calet, Hirsch & Spector has created a newspaper and radio campaign for the first annual New York City coat drive, which is seeking winter coats for homeless and poor people. The campaign, which began on Friday, runs through December 10.

title: U.S. Said to Have Rejected Warning on Savings Unit
description: Federal regulators rejected warnings in 1986 about a California savings and loan institution's heavy investment in risky high-yield securities, former Government officials who were involved in the decision said.

title: Bob Evans Farms Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
National Magazines Challenge Local Publications for Ads
description: The technology that has given national magazines the ability to split their circulation into hundreds of editions is also beginning to give city and regional magazines anxiety about a possible loss of advertising.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Officer's Trial Unfolds As Uneasy Miami Waits
description: Frances Pinckney brought her beat-up black-and-white television set to work last week so she could watch the testimony of Police Officer William Lozano, whose killing of two blacks set off rioting here in January.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said included are provisions for credit losses of $724,375,000 versus $155,799,000 in the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, and $895,375,000 versus $465,000,000 in the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Dairy Mart Buys Stores
description: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc. has agreed to buy 141 Stop-N-Go convenience stores in the Midwest from the Sun Company. The price was not disclosed.

title: Guilty Plea in Futures Case
description: Melanie Kosar, a trader indicted in the Federal investigation of the Chicago futures pits, pleaded guilty Friday to two counts of prearranged trading, the United States Attorney's office in Chicago said.

title: Reviews/Music; Homey Sophistication
description: For more than a decade the Roches' intermittent appearances at New York clubs and concert halls have had the emotionally charged aura of homecoming celebrations. And the Greenwich Village-based trio's concerts on Friday and Saturday at the Bottom Line were no exception.

title: Metro Matters; Subway Begging: Legal for Charity But Not for Poor
description: rrJoseph (Papa Joe) Walley, a 50-year-old former warehouse worker and recreation director, has been unemployed for the five years or so since he injured his knee. About the same time, his landlord abandoned the West Harlem building in which Mr. Walley was living.

title: Tien Lui, Play-Doh Developer
description: Tien Lui, who helped develop the synthetic molding clay Play-Doh, died Thursday in Cincinnati. He was believed to be in his 80's, but there were no records of his birth in China.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included a nonrecurring $2.5 million pretax charge reflecting the write-off of costs related to the abandonment of the company's proposed leveraged buyout plan for the quarter and 9 months included a nonrecurring pretax charge of $800,000 for corporate restructuring related to the consolidation of certain administrative functions. c-Included a nonrecurring pretax credit related to the signing of a wholesale grocery supply contract and the sale of midwest warehouse assets. The amount of the credit was not immediately available.

title: Toyota Recalls A Lexus Model
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation confirmed on Saturday that it is recalling all 8,000 of the Lexus LS 400 cars that it has sold in the United States to correct three problems.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday Factory Orders Oct. New-Home Sales Oct. Tuesday Automobile Sales Late Nov. Wednesday Productivity 3d Qtr. Thursday Consumer Credit Oct. Friday Unemployment Nov.

title: Third World Debt Never Shrinks
description: To the Editor:

title: Program Problems Continue to Deflate CBS
description: JUST after he resigned last week as the chief programmer at CBS - amid widespread rumors that the network was interviewing candidates for his job - Kim LeMasters reflexively scanned the overnight ratings for Wednesday.

title: Abraham Neuwirth, Retired Educator, 73
description: Abraham Neuwirth, the superintendent of the Bellmore, L.I., school district from 1967 to 1982, when he retired, died Saturday in a Great Neck, L.I., nursing center. He was 73 years old and had homes in Great Neck and in Alford, Mass.

title: Gold Seen as Barrier to Fall in Interest Rates
description: A sharp rise in gold prices, often viewed as a harbinger of a rising inflation rate, may inhibit further declines in long-term interest rates for the balance of the year, some analysts contend.

title: Bridport Journal; A Ghost Of Manson Reappears In the East
description: From her bedroom window, Blue Collins can look across Lake Champlain to see the white cloud rising from the International Paper Company mill in Ticonderoga, N.Y.

title: Appellate Judge Is Cleared Of Using Improper Influence
description: A state judicial panel has cleared Francis T. Murphy Jr., one of New York State's most powerful judges, of improperly interfering in disciplinary proceedings against several prominent lawyers, officials close to the case said yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference After NATO Meeting
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Bush's news conference today after his meeting here with leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Q&A
description: A response in the Q&A column of Science Times on Tuesday about time zones at the North and South Poles misstated the time difference at the international date line. East of the line, the time is a day earlier, not later.

title: Mean-Spirited on Legal Services
description: Just before leaving for Malta, President Bush took hostile action against the Legal Services Corporation, one of the nation's worthiest justice programs. He issued recess appointments to fill two vacancies on its board, thereby continuing a destructive standoff initiated by President Reagan.

title: The Neon, The Bugaloo, Touchdown!
description: When Deion Sanders, a.k.a. Neon Sanders, intercepted a pass and ran it back a long way for the Altanta Falcons on Sunday, he proceeded to engage in a whoop of exultation that, on the street, would have brought a screaming ambulance carrying men with a white coat to the scene.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the crane collapse that killed five people in San Francisco misidentified the manufacturer of the equipment. The crane was made by Peiner A.G. in West Germany, not the American Pecco Corporation. The crane was owned by American Pecco and leased to a subcontractor.

title: Alico Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,500,000, or 36 cents a share. The company said the extraordinary credit for 1988 represented the cumulative effect of accounting changes for prior years.

title: Brown Coach Resigns
description: John Rosenberg resigned yesterday as the head football coach at Brown after two consecutive losing seasons.

title: Review/Music; Queens Symphony Offers the Old and New
description: The Queens Symphony Orchestra was founded in 1953 by David Katz, who shepherded the group from amateur to professional status during his 34-year tenure. When he died in 1987, the organization faced the task of finding a conductor for the first time.

title: Higher Mortality in Scotland
description: Higher mortality in Scotland may be attributed to more adverse social and economic conditions in that region than elsewhere in Britain, researchers have concluded.

title: Police Scatter Algiers Protest
description: The police fired tear gas on Sunday to disperse hundreds of people protesting poor road conditions in the hills above the capital. No arrests or injuries were reported. The protesters, mostly Muslim fundamentalists, gathered to protest the city's failure to make repairs.

title: Plenty Of Credit
description: No doubt many Americans do not yet believe ''the cold war is over,'' just because Presidents Bush and Gorbachev say it is. But even skeptics must concede that both sides have come a long way from the depths of dangerous hostility reached in the 50's, at the time of the Cuban missile crisis or in the early years of the Reagan Administration.

title: Transplant Patients Illuminate Link Between Cancer and Immunity
description: UNUSUAL cancer patterns among transplant patients are providing startling insights into the body's natural immunity against the disease.

title: Edward W. Lang, Chemist, 65
description: Edward W. Lang, a chemist who developed the formula for Head & Shoulders shampoo for the Procter & Gamble Company, died Nov. 27 while visiting in Cincinnati. He was 65 years old and lived in retirement in Naples, Fla.

title: For Supertankers, Super Profits
description: About five years ago, with the supertanker business in the doldrums, the Loews Corporation bought seven large tankers for about $5 million each - basically, their scrap value. Now those ships are carrying crude oil between the Middle East and the Gulf Coast for up to $3 million for just one voyage, operating at considerable profit. And if the Tisch family, which controls Loews, ever decides to sell them, it could get close to $40 million apiece.

title: Goodbye, B. Altman; You'll Be Missed
description: To the Editor:

title: Prudential-Bache
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. has raised the commissions it charges individual customers by about 3 percent, a spokesman for the firm said yesterday. The move was viewed by industry analysts as a reflection of the continued pressure on retail brokerages' profits. Prudential-Bache has also informed its 6,500 retail brokers that it was reducing the amount of commission revenue it shares with its lowest-producing brokers.

title: May Swenson, a Humorous Poet Of Cerebral Verse, Is Dead at 76
description: May Swenson, a poet known for her cerebral, playful verse, and a recipient two years ago of a MacArthur Foundation Fellowship, died yesterday in Ocean View, Del. She was 76 years old and had been suffering from chronic asthma.

title: Manila Embassy Warns Americans
description: The United States Embassy today urged Americans living in the Makati area, the financial center of Manila, to leave their homes for safer areas as heavy fighting resumed between Government and rebel forces.

title: Henry Otis Dies at 83; Led Marsh & Mclennan
description: Henry W. Otis, retired chairman of Marsh & Mclennan Companies, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Computer Games To Give Adults
description: COMPUTER games make great stocking-stuffers for grown-ups, although they may be too big for most stockings.

title: Scott's Hospitality reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $107,000,000, or $1.80 a share. Year-earlier sales included $14,023,000 for the quarter and $32,953,000 for the 6 months from Abbey Hill Vehicle Services Ltd., which was sold effective May 1. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Founder of Dairy Mart Buys When Others Sell
description: For many years there was little competition in the convenience store industry. ''You could open a store almost anywhere and succeed,'' said Charles Nirenberg, who has been in the industry all his career.

title: Nynex Says Delays in Installations Are Likely to Persist Until May
description: New Yorkers be forewarned. The end of the telephone strike will reduce - but not eliminate - the maddening wait for new service.

title: Metro Datelines; 600 New York Sites Need Toxic Cleanup
description: New York's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, announcing plans to sell $40 million in bonds to clean up hazardous waste, said yesterday that at least 600 sites need work, When state voters passed the $1.2 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act in 1986, the department set a goal of cleaning up 500 sites by the year 2000. Mr. Jorling said ''it's too early to say'' whether the cleanup will be finished by that time.

title: Mattel Expects Sales to Rise 25%
description: Amid a generally restrained outlook among retailers for Christmas sales, Mattel Inc. said its fourth-quarter sales are expected to jump 25 percent from a year earlier. Shares of Mattel rose $1.625 yesterday, to $18.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, where Mattel was the second-most-active issue, with almost 3.7 million shares traded.

title: L.I. Man Indicted in Death With Fireworks Is Arraigned
description: A man from Suffolk County, charged in the first indictment relating to a fireworks death on Long Island, pleaded not guilty to the charge today.

title: Thomas Rhinelander, Real-Estate Broker, 69
description: Thomas Jackson Oakley Rhinelander, a real-estate broker and a member of a prominent family in New York, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on Saturday at the Oakwood Healthcare Center in Newport, R.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Newport.

title: To Shattered City and Its Merchants, Earthquake Proves an Opportunity
description: It has been a surprisingly cheerful month for the merchants of Santa Cruz. Selling from big tents because the Oct. 17 earthquake leveled their downtown shopping mall, many say that the day after Thanksgiving this year was their best ever and that sales have remained strong since.

title: Patterns
description: Cold Comfort

title: Jordan's Premier Is Replaced By Ally of Fundamentalists
description: Prime Minister Zeid bin Shaker resigned today and was replaced by Mudar Badran, who has held the office twice before and is sympathetic to Islamic fundamentalists.

title: Reviews/Music; Jazz in a Pianist's Loft
description: The way music interacts with its setting is an often overlooked ingredient in a performance. David Lopato, a pianist and composer who gave a public performance on Saturday night at his Greenwich Street loft, understands this and used the room to enhance his intimate, delicate compositions. He brought the small audience into the workings of the lightly amplified pieces. Each halt or start, each harmonic quickstep made itself clear.

title: Jersey Man Indicted in Killing of 2 Women
description: A Hackensack man was indicted on murder charges for the killing of two city women during an alleged sexual assault, the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office announced today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it had named D. Kenneth Richardson president and chief operating officer, succeeding Donald H. White, who retired Dec. 1. Mr. Richardson reports to

title: OPEC Study Of East Bloc
description: OPEC is studying the effect that the upheaval in Eastern European countries could have on their demand for oil, most of which is now supplied by the Soviet Union, OPEC officials said today.

title: Northeast Must Produce More Family Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Badger Co., Cambridge, Mass., an engineering and construction subsidary of Raytheon Co., appointed Lazzaro G. Modigliani president and chief executive.

title: U.S. Weighs Role Shifts For Market Regulators
description: Officials at the Treasury Department are circulating proposals to end jurisdictional squabbles between Federal regulators of the securities and futures industries, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Man and the Apes
description: Biologists from Harvard Medical School who compared a gene that is present in people, chimpanzees and gorillas have concluded that the chimpanzee and gorilla are the closest cousins. That means that neither is the clear direct ancestor of humans.

title: Ailey Program Is Changed
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has changed its opening program, tomorrow at City Center, in commemoration of Mr. Ailey, who died on Friday. The program will consist of ''Revelations'' and excerpts from six of Mr. Ailey's dances. The previously scheduled revival of ''Come and Get the Beauty of It Hot'' will be performed on Friday, and ''Sarong Paramaribo'' will be presented on Dec. 20.

title: Market Place; Behind Surge in the Utility Average
description: Laggards for much of the bull market, utility stocks have turned into top performers in the last few months, with their performance accelerating in recent weeks.

title: Average Salary Is Almost $500,000
description: On one hand, the Chicago Cubs and the Baltimore Orioles lowered their payrolls; the Cubs won their division championship, the Orioles just missed winning theirs.

title: Review/Theater; Joe Orton's 'Up Against It,' a Screenplay Staged
description: In ''Up Against It,'' his unproduced screenplay for the Beatles, Joe Orton tried to combine the irreverent spirit of ''A Hard Day's Night'' and ''Help!'' with his own far more mordant sensibility. Since the playwright's death, the screenplay has remained a tantalizing footnote to Orton's career. Although the film script is not in the same class as his plays, the published version exists for reading and imagining, raising the question of what the movie would have been like.

title: Laughter Is Still Music to Victor Borge's Ear
description: Victor Borge was at the Bosendorfer concert grand in the studio of his estate on Greenwich Harbor. He was being photographed and did not seem very happy about it. He observed his 80th birthday this year, and the celebrations, on a worldwide basis, involve being photographed.

title: Man Is Accused of Killing His Father in Hospital Room
description: A man went to a hospital room and shot his 77-year-old father to death with a pistol, then turned the weapon on himself, causing minor wounds, the authorities said.

title: Tight Limits Proposed for Popular Farm Chemical
description: The Government today proposed banning for most uses a class of chemicals widely applied to fruits and vegetables to control fungal diseases because of concerns that they may cause cancer.

title: At Least a Spy in a Library Would Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear of Death Intensifies Moral Code, Scientists Find
description: THE preacher's fire-and-brimstone warning that death will bring a dire judgment for moral wrongs is a masterful psychological ploy, judging from recent research findings. New studies show that confronting people with the fact that they will die makes them cling tenaciously to their deepest moral values.

title: The Twilight of Superpower Summits
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, said recently that Moscow ''feels immeasurably more comfortable in the international arena than ever before.'' After last weekend's meeting at Malta between George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev, Soviet leaders are entitled to relax still further: Soviet-American relations have never been so free of irritants.

title: Commissioner Offers Optimism as the Baseball Meetings Start
description: The major leagues formally opened their 88th winter meetings today with an olive branch extended to the players' union by the new commissioner, Fay Vincent; heavy trade talk, and an almost frenzied pursuit of high-priced free agents.

title: Testimony Ends in L.I. Trial Of Ex-Nurse Held in Killings
description: Both sides ended their cases today in the murder trial of a former nurse accused of killing four elderly patients at a hospital with drug injections.

title: At 25 Cents an Error, Mail Deliveries Improve
description: The postal service had such good results when suburban mail carriers began paying their customers for wrongly delivered mail that the program, intended as only a 60-day trial, will continue indefinitely.

title: Why Salvadoran Army Wants War Without End
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Sees a Surge in Syphilis And Will Start Testing All Babies
description: Every baby born in New York State will be tested for syphilis at birth, starting tomorrow, because of a sharp surge in the disease among newborns in recent years, the State Health Department said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Riney Spot Raises Questions
description: WHEN word spread in September that Helayne Spivak -the brassy, funny and very New Yorkish copywriter for Ammirati & Puris - would take charge of Hal Riney & Partners' New York creative department, the acclamation followed quickly. At last, said advertising's creative critics, Riney/ New York would have an executive creative director capable of weaning it from the emotional and mid-American style that had been identified with the gravel-voiced Mr. Riney, who often narrates his commercials.

title: Cold Breeds Wide Misery In New York
description: Bone-chilling cold, heatless apartments, subway shutdowns and a midtown gridlock alert formed a coalition of misery in New York City yesterday for thousands of homeless people, transit riders, motorists and others unwarmed by holiday cheer.

title: Arabs at U.N. Ask 2 Concessions From Washington on P.L.O. Issue
description: Arab nations asked the United States for two new political concessions today in return for dropping a campaign to win United Nations recognition of a Palestinian state.

title: Court Appoints Special Master
description: A Federal judge has appointed a special master to take control of the assets of Lifeline Healthcare Group Ltd., a company whose entire board faces charges of fraud filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. United States District Judge

title: Officer's Case Rested In Miami Slaying Trial
description: The defense rested today in the manslaughter trial of a Miami policeman after rolling a motorcycle into the courtroom to show the view the defendant had the day he shot and killed a motorcylist.

title: In Besieged Manila District, Panic and Profit
description: The normally elegant Westin Philippine Plaza Hotel had the look of a refugee camp this morning as residents of the villages around Makati, the Manila business district paralyzed by rebel forces of the Philippine military, heeded their embassies' call to evacuate their homes.

title: Jury Selection Begins California Lawmaker's Trial
description: The influential chairman of the State Senate's Business and Professions Committee went on trial today on Federal charges of bribery, extortion, racketeering and money laundering.

title: Arab and Israeli Viewpoints on PBS
description: The retaliatory spirit (you strike us, we bomb you) that has long prevailed in the Middle East seems to have infected public television. Hardly has the commotion begun to subside over the broadcast of a pro-Palestinian documentary about the uprising on the West Bank than a pro-Israeli documentary is upon us. It seems less like evenhandedness than a case of an eye for an eye -millions of viewers' eyes, that is.

title: Simms and Meggett Criticized by Parcells
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants seldom criticizes his players publicly. But today, disappointed and irritated by Sunday's 24-17 home-field loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, Parcells seemed plainly upset with the performances of Phil Simms and Dave Meggett.

title: The S & L Scandal Beyond Mr. Wall
description: There is more to the savings and loan mess than M. Danny Wall, who resigned yesterday as chairman of the Office of Thrift Supervision. But he protests that he is a scapegoat, and he ought not to become one: too many others need to answer for their roles in this scandalous episode.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer transmission error, the television program listings yesterday omitted entries for the Cinemax channel (MAX) for 7 P.M. to midnight. The entries that appeared were for the Madison Square Garden channel (MSG).

title: John Dixon, 69, Dies; Electronics Executive
description: John Wainwright Dixon, the former chief executive of E-Systems, a major electronics company and military contractor, died of cancer Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. He was 69 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Are the Jets Finally Improving?
description: It is the Monday morning question everyone on the Jets expected would be asked today - as if they have more explaining to do in winning than in losing.

title: Britain's Reserves Fall
description: Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currency fell by $931 million in November, the Government said today. In October, the reserves dropped by a record $2.9 billion. The latest decline was viewed as showing reduced intervention by the Bank of England in the foreign exchange markets to support the British pound. Economists said the latest figure indicated that the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, might be more inclined to let the pound fall than his predecessor, Nigel Lawson, who resigned in October.

title: Why Salvadoran Army Wants War Without End; Another Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretoria Sees New Arrests in Killing of 2 Opponents
description: Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said today that further arrests would be made soon in the assassinations of two prominent white opponents of apartheid this year.

title: Amtech Systems Inc reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Include extraordinary tax benefits of net operating loss carryforwards of $102,000, or 4 cents a share, in the latest year, and $193,000, or 10 cents a share, in the year-ago period.

title: New Varieties of Elm Raise Hope of Rebirth For Davastated Tree
description: AFTER decades of research, scientists are on the verge of introducing versions of the American elm and foreign hybrids that are resistant to Dutch elm disease, which has wiped out tens of millions of trees around the nation.

title: Gerald Carson, 90, A Social Historian Of Accessible Style
description: Gerald H. Carson, a social historian of the American scene, died of a heart attack early Monday at St. Mary Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. He was 90 years old and lived in nearby Newtown.

title: Czech Opposition Forum To Enter Free Elections
description: Civic Forum, the two-week-old opposition movement in Czechoslovakia, took its boldest step yet by announcing today that it would endorse candidates when the country holds its first free elections since the postwar Communist takeover.

title: Georgia Tech Defeats Pitt, 93-92
description: Dennis Scott of Georgia Tech seemed to make shots from everywhere tonight. He made shots from 3-point range. He made layups. He made shots with a hand in his face. And he kept making shots no matter what kind of defense Pittsburgh tried to contain him with.

title: Scramble To the End For No. 1 In Ranking
description: On Saturday, Alabama lost its chance for an undefeated season and sole possession of first place in the Southeastern Conference when it absorbed a 30-20 thumping from the Auburn Tigers. Yesterday, the Crimson Tide slipped from second to seventh place in both The Associated Press poll of sportswriters and broadcasters and the United Press International weekly survey of college coaches.

title: Wiener Enterprises Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: b-Net income

title: Chess
description: Dmitry Gurevich made no excuses for his 1/2-2 1/2 start in the United States Championship at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Long Beach, Calif.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., a distributor of paper, steel and glass products, said its Paper Corp. of America unit would acquire Distribix Inc., St. Louis, a distributor of paper and paper products, with annual revenue of about $200 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Fetisov May Play Soon
description: The injury to Vyacheslav Fetisov's left knee that kept him out of the last five games includes slight cartilage damage, the Devils said yesterday. Dave Freed, a team spokesman, said, however, that the damage was so limited that the Soviet defenseman might not need an arthroscopy. He said that Fetisov may return to action before the weekend. Freed also said that Coach John Cunniff experimented with the team's top two lines in practice and that Sergei Starikov, New Jersey's other Soviet defenseman, may be used against the Rangers tomorrow. He has been benched in the last four games.

title: Goran Jarvefelt, Opera Director, 42
description: Goran Jarvefelt, a Swedish opera director, died of cancer on Thursday. He was 42 years old.

title: Militia Shells a Shiite Town in South Lebanon
description: As Lebanon's political crisis continued, violence broke out in the south today between Israeli-backed Christian forces and Muslim militiamen.

title: Notebook; The Cold? The Eagles Have Warm Memories
description: The Philadelphia Eagles were in the locker room, tugging at their last layers of clothing and thawing from the bitter chill while they relished the exhilarating thrill of having toppled the Giants by 24-17 on Sunday afternoon at Giants Stadium.

title: Newspaper Agreement
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division recommended approval today of a joint operating agreement between The Las Vegas Sun and The Las Vegas Review Journal. It said they should be granted an antitrust exemption under the Newspaper Preservation Act, allowing themto combine certain operations.

title: East German Incident Involving U.S. Troops
description: Soviet military personnel in East Germany detained a team of American military officers for seven and a half hours on the eve of President Bush's meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Pentagon said today.

title: U.S. Will Scrutinize a Chinese Deal
description: The United States plans an interagency investigation of the national security aspects of China's agreement to buy an American company that manufactures metal components for commercial aircraft, Government officials said today.

title: Woman Given a New Heart, Liver and Kidney
description: In the first transplant of its kind, a 26-year-old woman has been given a new heart, liver and kidney by doctors at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Dinkins Lists $810,000 Surplus And Hopes to Use It on Transition
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins reported yesterday that he had ended his campaign with an $810,000 surplus, which he is now trying to reduce to avoid having to return substantial public financing to the city treasury.

title: Protest Rallies Resume in Prague In Effort to Oust New Government
description: About 200,000 people poured into Wenceslas Square today to shout their rejection of a new Government formed on Sunday and to applaud a call for a general strike next Monday if it is not replaced.

title: Panel Backs a 3-Month Delay in Ethics Rules
description: A three-month delay in enforcing new ethics rules for New York City employees was approved yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: ABC Seeks Court Order To Show Cuban Games
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday asked a Federal District Court in Manhattan to order the Government to allow ABC Sports to televise the 1991 Pan American Games from Havana.

title: Mothers' Group Fights Back in Los Angeles
description: Pushing baby strollers and wearing white kerchiefs, they are not exactly a formidable sight. Yet the Mothers of East Los Angeles, a small group from a community that often bemoans its inability to gain political influence, is the vanguard of a fledgling environmental movement.

title: Top Savings Regulator Resigns And Strikes Back at His Critics
description: M. Danny Wall, the Federal official who has become a symbol of the nation's failure to regulate the savings and loan industry adequately, resigned under fire today.

title: Why Salvadoran Army Wants War Without End; Anchors Aweigh
description: To the Editor:

title: Santa Claus, North Pole, 33d Street
description: Each year about 18,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus arrive in Manhattan's General Post Office, and you can read them like a script for New York itself: tales of need and greed and shining expectation, of entitlement or estrangement, of a chance to get something for nothing, or even, at times, to gain nothing at all but the chance to give to someone else.

title: Mobil Exploration Set for Zimbabwe
description: The Mobil Corporation won the right to drill for oil in one of Africa's unspoiled areas, where thousands of elephants, rhinoceroses, buffaloes and other wildlife roam. An agreement signed between the Zimbabwe Government and the Mobil Exploration unit gives it exploration rights in 7.5 million acres on the southern shore of the Zambezi River and Lake Kariba.

title: Army's Rifle of the Future: 2 Bullets at Once?
description: The Army is searching for a new, improved rifle for its 21st century soldiers.

title: In a Rebound, Whooping Cranes Are Thriving
description: THE world's population of whooping cranes, on the brink of extinction just 50 years ago, has nearly doubled this decade and now appears on the brink of a remarkable comeback.

title: Critic's Notebook; Ern Malley's Triumph: How a Hoax Became Myth
description: The very idea of fakery sets critics trembling. What if the book they are reading, the score they are hearing or the dance they are watching is not some kind of creative innovation, but a hoax? And should the thought then occur that the hoax may be a deliberate attempt by an artistic malcontent to make both new trends and their critical admirers seem foolish, the trembling may increase a thousandfold.

title: U S West In Budapest Phone Deal
description: U S West Inc., one of the nation's seven regional Bell telephone companies, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Hungary to build a mobile cellular telephone system in Budapest.

title: Article 126789 -- No Title
description: The City of Richmond yesterday tentatively priced $65.5 million in general obligation public improvement bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: On Horse Racing; Breeders' Cup Tops the List of Issues of the 80's
description: rrThe impending end of this decade has sent racing's pollsters and pundits scurrying to rank the best horses, races, trainers and jockeys of the last 10 years. But what about the issues that shape the sport? What were the most important changes in thoroughbred racing in the 1980's? And what lies ahead in these areas for the next decade? 1. The Breeders' Cup.

title: With Woes Behind, Mahorn Focuses on Image
description: All things considered, Rick Mahorn is glad to be in Philadelphia.

title: Meyer (Fred) Inc(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 4
Israeli Sees Failure to Halt Uprising as It Nears 3d Year
description: As the Palestinian uprising enters its third year, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin acknowledges that the Israeli Army has not succeeded in bringing the revolt under control.

title: Our Towns; American Faces Eviction On Morris Street
description: Evaristi Corrales, who owned and ran a bakery in Havana, fled from Cuba in 1962, three years into the regime of Fidel Castro, partly out of fear, but mainly for economic reasons. The Marxist government seized the bakery. ''I could not work after Castro took it,'' Mr. Corrales said. ''He took everything.''

title: Tips From Silicon Santa
description: IT can be frustrating to shop for holiday gifts for the kind of people who read this column. What they really need is new socks and cologne, but what they really want is 4 megs worth of 100-nanosecond, 4-megabit RAM chips or an accelerator board.

title: Press Testing Looser Bonds In Yugoslavia
description: The news magazine Mladina, whose name means youth, decided recently to do away with a Communist politician, symbolically at least, by printing spoof photographs of him, first with an assassin's pistol at his head and then in his coffin.

title: Maxwell Paper To Start in May
description: The publisher Robert Maxwell said today that his new newspaper, The European, will begin publishing next May 11, a year later than originally planned.

title: Ex-Klan Leader Says He Will Run for Senate
description: A former Ku Klux Klan leader who was elected to the Louisiana House earlier this year announced plans today to challenge United States Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat.

title: Who's in Charge? What's in Store? East Germany Gropes for Answers
description: Who is running East Germany?

title: Police Using Teddy Bears to Comfort Children
description: The New York City Police Department has been supplied with teddy bears for children traumatized by abuse, injury or a death in the family as part of a six-month program in emotional first aid that started yesterday.

title: Officials' Jets Being Recycled
description: Fifteen Soviet-built jetliners once reserved for use by top East German Communist officials will be put into passenger service, the Government press agency A.D.N. said today. Klaus Henkes, the general director of the national airline Interflug, was quoted as saying about half the planes were ready for immediate use on charter flights and the rest would be converted for regular passenger flights.

title: Jockeys Elect Leader
description: Jerry Bailey was elected yesterday to fill the unexpired term of Willie Shoemaker as president of the Jockeys' Guild. The election was held at the annual guild meeting in Las Vegas, Nev. Bailey, 32, takes over on Feb. 5 and will serve until next year's board meeting.(AP)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Second Top Editor Leaves Family Media
description: Family Media lost its second top editor since announcing a corporate reorganization last week. Annalyn Swan, the editor in chief of Savvy Woman, the company's magazine for women executives, yesterday announced her resignation. The company immediately named Martha Nelson, the magazine's executive editor, to succeed her.

title: Washington at Work; Stoic, Stubborn Admiral Is Guiding Navy in a Stormy Time of Changes
description: Adm. Carlisle Albert Herman Trost would never make it as the hero of a Tom Clancy adventure novel. ''Who would be interested in me?'' he asks. ''I'm a character that wouldn't sell books.''

title: Business and Health; Worries Abound On Medicare Shift
description: MANY employers and insurers are worried that their expenditures for employee health care will increase as a result of changes in the rules for paying doctors in the Federal Medicare program, which Congress adopted last month.

title: Hotter, Drier Amazon Seen in Forest Study
description: CONVERTING all of the Amazon's tropical forests to pastureland would reduce rainfall there by 20 percent and make the region substantially hotter, a British study has found.

title: Crescott Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $339,000 for the quarter and $769,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $209,000, or 10 cents a share, and $202,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $142,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $70,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago 9-month loss from continuing operations of $65,000 included a gain on the sale of marketable securities of $1,762,000.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 23 about a guerrilla takeover at a hotel in San Salvador referred incorrectly to 12 American Green Berets trapped there for a day.

title: Plea Defuses Battle Over Admission in Church
description: A showdown between three Pentecostal ministers and a prosecutor over the confidentiality of a burglary suspect's confession in church ended today when the man pleaded guilty to grand larceny.

title: Careers; Positive Outlook on Employment in 1990
description: CITING the results of Manpower Inc.'s latest quarterly employment survey, Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of the large international supplier of temporary help, spoke last week of a ''soft landing'' for the economy, not a recession, in 1990.

title: Michaels Stores Deal Hits Snag
description: MSI Holdings Inc. said today that it had not be able to arrange financing for its $220 million offer to acquire Michaels Stores Inc.

title: President Thinks He Struck The Right Balance at Malta
description: President Bush ended the Malta summit talks confident that he had shown global leadership while not angering a Western alliance resistant to American dominance in world affairs, Administration officials said today.

title: Reviews/Dance; New Works by Young Choreographers
description: Recent Acquisitions, an organization directed by Ray J. Guier, seeks to help young choreographers to show new works. That aim is laudable, but unfortunately Recent Acquisitions assembled no treasures on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: Metro Datelines; U.S. Opens Inquiry Into Fatal Sinking
description: The Coast Guard began a formal investigation yesterday into a boating accident in the Ambrose Channel on Saturday that killed two people. Ships were advised to avoid the area.

title: New York State Can Increase Homeownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard R. Salzmann, Editor, 69
description: Richard R. Salzmann, the retired editor in chief of the Research Institute of America, a publisher of tax guides, died of a heart ailment on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 69 years old and had lived for many years in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $4,525,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $16,825,000, or 51 cents a share, for the year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $18,111,000, which reflected retirement of debt.

title: Arnold Arnstein, 91, A Music Copyist, Dies
description: Arnold Arnstein, a music copyist who worked with Gian Carlo Menotti, Samuel Barber and other composers, died of respiratory failure on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mr. Bush, Talking Like a Leader
description: Firmly and unambiguously, President Bush said on leaving the Malta summit talks what his Administration has needed to say with one voice: ''We stand at the threshold of a brand-new era of U.S.-Soviet relations.'' And finally, he demonstrated that he understands the new era's opportunities by sending three strong messages on the Soviet economy, arms control and regional conflicts.

title: Davis Water & Waste Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago results were restated to reflect the change to weighted average from last-in first-out method of inventory evaluation.

title: Finding a Burial Place For Nuclear Wastes Grows More Difficult
description: WHEN the Department of Energy said last week that it had lost confidence in its latest effort to find a safe place to bury nuclear waste, a gnawing question resurfaced: is the task possible?

title: Stars Past and Present Meet
description: Andy McCarroll, a Vanderbilt linebacker from Memphis, was asked to stand and express his feelings about being one of the 11 scholar-athletes chosen this year by the National Football Foundation for academic and football achievements.

title: Slaught Traded to Pirates
description: The Yankees swung the first trade of baseball's winter meetings today when they sent Don Slaught to the Pittsburgh Pirates for two relief pitchers, Jeff Robinson and a minor leaguer, Willie Smith. But they said that they were still pursuing their No. 1 goal of landing a quality starting pitcher.

title: Prague 1968: Views Now In East Bloc
description: Following are the texts of statements about Czechoslovakia by the Soviet Government and the Warsaw Pact made in Moscow yesterday, as distributed in translation by Tass, the official Soviet press agency: SOVIET STATEMENT

title: Keihoku Journal; One Man's Struggle to Preserve a Bitter Memory
description: Like nearly everyone else in this history-obsessed nation, Jeong Ho Lee has a passion for remembering.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: This Time, the Crowd Is More Defiant Than Exuberant
description: Somewhere between the evening and the morning, between the announcement on Sunday night of a new Government and the mass rally today to protest its selection, a sense of impending victory gave way to grave disappointment. Where there was hope, there is now defiance.

title: Deloitte, Touche Merger Done
description: Touche Ross completed their merger in the United States on Saturday, amid signs that increasing numbers of foreign affiliates of the accounting firms had rejected the merger.

title: Prosecutors Deny Hearing Poindexter's Testimony
description: The two main prosecutors in the upcoming trial of John M. Poindexter took the witness stand today to deny defense accusations that they were tainted by exposure to Mr. Poindexter's testimony in the Iran-contra hearings in Congress.

title: Key Events in the Bidding for Lin
description: Dec. 24, 1988: A group including McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said it planned to ask for regulatory approval to increase it stake in Lin Broadcasting Corporation. June 6, 1989: McCaw said it would begin a cash tender offer of $120 a share, or $6.5 billion, for Lin. McCaw already owned 9.8 percent of Lin. June 20: Lin rejected McCaw's offer. July 10: McCaw said it had reduced its bid for Lin to $110 a share, from $120, after a court rejected Lin's contention that it had the right to buy cellular telephone interests in New York and Philadelphia. July 13: McCaw said it might raise its bid for Lin to $127.50 a share. July 21: McCaw decided to proceed with its $110-a-share offer. July 31: Lin said its deadline for a negotiated buyout agreement with McCaw had passed without an agreement and that its board would pursue other options. Sept. 3: The Federal Communications Commission refused to block McCaw's hostile takeover offer for Lin. Sept. 11: Lin said it would merge its cellular telephone operations with those of the BellSouth Corporation. Analysts estimate the value of the complex deal at up to $12.5 billion. Oct. 3:NcCaw signed an agreement to acquire Metromedia's stake in the New York cellular market to $1.9 billion. But Lin, a partner with Metromedia in the New York and Philadelphia cellular franchises, had 45 days in which to buy the stake at the same price. Oct. 10:McCaw sweetened its tender offer for Lin to $125 a share. Oct 27: Lin and BellSouth offer shareholders a special dividend of $42 a share. Lin exercised its right to buy Metromedia's stake in the New York market, barring McCaw from such a deal. Nov. 14: McCaw said two dozen institutions would provide it with $3 billion to help finance its offer for controlling interest in Lin. Nov. 20:McCaw sweetened its bid for Lin by offering $150 in cash for 22.5 million shares, or 46 percent, of Lin's stock. Dec 4:Lin accepted McCaw's offer of $154.11 a share for 21.9 million shares. Lin's merber agreement with BellSouth was still binding. however.

title: Durables Lead Factory Orders Drop
description: New orders for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in October, the Government said today, in a new sign of slack economic growth.

title: Zaire's Trade With Pretoria Isn't Slowing
description: As the Zairian diplomat poured sparkling wine for a visitor, he made no effort to hide the label, which proclaimed, ''Product of South Africa.''

title: Reviews/Dance; Wrapped in a Big Kimono While Moving, Slowly
description: ''Dances in Junihitoe: Old and New,'' which Saeko Ichinohe and Company presented Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society, was simultaneously peculiar and gorgeous. What made the program so was the remarkable garment that inspired it.

title: Ellison to Sit
description: Pervis Ellison of the Sacramento Kings, the No. 1 pick in the 1989 National Basketball Association draft, will sit out the next three weeks because of a sore right foot. Ellison has played in only four games.(AP)

title: New Test Developed for Early Ovarian Cancer
description: Researchers at the King's College School of Medicine and Dentistry have developed a promising new method of detecting ovarian cancer in its early stages.

title: Jury Bogged Down in California Molestation Case
description: The McMartin Preschool molestation case produced the longest and perhaps the most complex criminal trial in American history. Now the jury deliberations are proving just as difficult.

title: Pension Fund Strategy Shift Is Assailed
description: With politicians nationwide eyeing pension fund surpluses as a way to finance new roads, bridges and other such projects, a group representing 60 state and union pension funds has struck back. It issued a broadside yesterday against those who would like to see more pension fund money channeled into local economies.

title: Bush Wasn't Tough Enough
description: The ''no surprises'' summit meeting was surprising in its lack of ''new thinking'' about the new world unfolding. This summit smacked of summits of the 1970's, with arms control once again raising the highest expectations.

title: Edberg Completes a Final Mission
description: If men's tennis, which last week closed out the decade with the final staging of the Nabisco Masters in New York City, can be briefly considered an apple cart, then unassuming Stefan Edberg of Sweden surely upset it on Sunday with his four-set elimination of Boris Becker, the defending champion.

title: Matthews & Wright Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Slot Machine Patent Lawsuit
description: The world's largest maker of slot machines filed suit today against a Japanese company, contending that three of its patents are being infringed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 The West should help out Moscow, particularly with economic concessions, President Bush said. But he would not endorse President Gorbachev's comment that the cold war epoch was over. Page A1

title: Justification For Invasion At the Time
description: At the time of the Warsaw Pact's invasion of Czechoslovakia on Aug. 21, 1968, Tass issued a statement justifying the action. Following are excerpts from that statement, as distributed in translation by the press agency.

title: Without Rule, Colleges Are Fit to Be Tied
description: The United States has no genuine professional soccer, so the collegiate game is seen by observers outside the country as the nation's supreme product besides the national team.

title: Quakes Hint at Volcanic Activity
description: Thousands of tiny earthquakes since May indicate that molten rock is moving beneath the Mammoth Mountain volcano, but an eruption is unlikely, the United States Geological Survey said today.

title: Soviets Say Gorbachev Gave Bush a Spy Map of U.S. Navy
description: The chief Soviet spokesman said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was so emphatic in raising the issue of naval disarmament at the Malta summit talks that he handed President Bush a classified map of K.G.B. intelligence on American fleet movements and installations of particular concern.

title: Murder Trial Opens for Owner of Killer Dog
description: The owner of a pit bull dog went on trial today in the death of a toddler who was mauled after wandering close to the animal, which prosecutors contend was guarding 243 marijuana plants.

title: Stocks Extend Gain as Dow Advances 5.98
description: Stock prices extended their gains yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 5.98 points, to 2,753.63.

title: Prices Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light trading yesterday, as market participants pointed to the release of November employment data on Friday.

title: Comaneci in Florida
description: Nadia Comaneci, the former Olympic gymnastics champion who fled Rumania last week, arrived in Miami last night and said she would be settling in southern Florida.

title: Reviews/Music; Asimov Updates and Transplants 'Pinafore'
description: ''Isaac Asimov writes new lyrics for 'Pinafore'! William S. Gilbert turns in his grave!'' screamed the advance publicity for the Village Light Opera Group's production of ''U.S.S. Pinafore,'' which opened over the weekend at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Bridge
description: The American Contract Bridge League annually names an ''honorary member,'' recognizing someone who has contributed greatly to the game. The choice for 1990 is Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City, who has long been the leading player in his country. He has a world reputation as a theorist and writer.

title: Researchers Are Alarmed by Wold Shootings
description: LEAD: Wildlife researchers working in the forests of northern Minnesota have discovered that about 10 percent of a small research group of gray wolves equipped with radio transmitters were shot in a single week recently.

title: BUSH SAYS SOVIETS MERIT WEST'S HELP TO FOSTER REFORM
description: President Bush said today that the West should help out President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to show support for the changes taking place in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: Ohio Gubernatorial Aspirant Shifts His View on Abortion
description: State Attorney General Anthony Celebrezze Jr., who is considered a leading contender for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, has announced a shift in his position on abortion, angering abortion opponents.

title: International Broadcasting Corp reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
description: b-Net income The company said the share earnings reflected a reduction of earnings applicable to common stock by the accretion of discount on redeemable preferred stock. The effect is to decrease income per share and common equivalent shares applicable to continuing operations and net income by 10 cents a share in 1989 and 1988.
