The loss was partly due to the company's higher depreciation and amortization expense, which grew to $6 million from $2.2 million, and to higher interest expense.

title: Fire Kills Mother and 2 Girls
description: An overheated wood stove caused a house fire on Sunday night that killed a mother and two daughters, the authorities said. The dead were identified as Patricia A. Risley, 27 years old, and her daughters, Michelle, 5, and Danielle, 3. Mrs. Risley had sent two sons, John, 2, and Joshua, 1, out of the house and had gone back for the girls, the authorities said. The father, John A. Risely, was not home.

title: After Skirmish With Protesters, Navy Tests Missile
description: In a confrontation at sea today, the United States Navy took on an environmental group that dared it to try to launch a nuclear missile. The Navy took up the challenge, sending the protesters limping home in a damaged boat and reporting that it had successfully tested the missile.

title: Suit on Housing Bias Charges Segregation By U.S. and Buffalo
description: A group of public housing tenants sued the Federal Government, the city and a suburban town today over what they said was widespread segregation in public housing and a rental subsidy program.

title: Court Backs a San Francisco Anti-Bias Hiring Plan
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld San Francisco's agreement to hire and promote women and members of minority groups in the Fire Department.

title: Lin Backs Takeover By McCaw
description: After months of resisting takeover bids from McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the Lin Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that its board had decided to recommend that shareholders accept the latest offer of $154.11 a share, or $3.38 billion, for roughly half of Lin's stock.

title: Chase Names Director Of Securities Activity
description: Commercial banks are pushing hard to combine their recently gained powers to trade and sell corporate bonds with other financings like interest-rate swaps or interest-rate caps and floors.

title: Norman Adler, 80, Retired CBS Executive
description: Norman Abner Adler, a lawyer and former CBS executive, died of complications of emphysema Saturday at Mission Bay Hospital near his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: Precious Metal Prices Fall After the Summit Meeting
description: Precious metals prices tumbled yesterday, and dealers said the decline came in part because the weekend summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev raised promises of reduced global tensions.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: INSIDE
description: The Hidden Cost of Drugs Economists say the cost of illicit drugs to American society has risen in the last few years to far more than $60 billion annually. Page D1. Cellular Phones for Hungary U S West signed an agreement to build a mobile cellular telephone system in Budapest, the first such network in Eastern Europe. Page D1. Prenatal Help in New Jersey Seeking to reduce infant mortality, New Jersey will insure that all pregnant women in the state have access to prenatal services. Page B1. What to Do With Waste Scientists wonder if there is any safe, acceptable way to dispose of nuclear waste. Science Times, page C1.

title: Man Killed in Gunfight With 2 Police Officers
description: A man carrying a semi-automatic machine pistol was killed yesterday morning during a shootout with two police officers on a Queens street, the police said.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree To Hear Case On Water Use
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve an intensifying conflict between the Federal Government and the states over regulating the environmental impact of hydroelectric power plants.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Trail Blazers 121, Magic 95: Sparked by its defense, Portland pulled away in the second half last night to defeat Orlando in Florida. The Trail Blazers outscored Orlando, 66-44, in the second half to push their record to 13-4, second best in the league behind the Lakers. Jerome Kersey scored 22 points and Kevin Duckworth had 19 for Portland. Orlando was led by Reggie Theus with 17 points. Terry Catledge added 16 and Jerry Reynolds had 13. Portland led by 55-51 at halftime, but Kersey had 11 points as Portland outscored the Magic, 29-14, in the first eight minutes of the third quarter to take an 84-65 lead. Portland's swarming defense made the difference, cutting off the Magic's inside game in the second half. The Trail Blazers also got their running game going, scoring 26 points on fast-break opportunities after intermission. Catledge scored only 2 points in the second half, while Theus had 4. Portland also got double-figure scoring from Clyde Drexler with 18 points, Buck Williams and Terry Porter with 16 apiece and Cliff Robinson with 15.(AP) HORSE RACING My Caravann Wins: My Caravann led from start to finish and surged to a 10-length victory in the Pearl Necklace purse for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday. Medicine Woman, undefeated in four previous starts and the odds-on choice, was never in contention and finished fifth. The winner, carrying 117 pounds, was ridden by Jorge Chavez. Another Boom was second in the eight-horse field and Wise Woman finished third. The victory was the fourth in 10 starts this year for My Caravann who covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 3/5. My Caravann returned $9.80 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: Ecology & Environment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Revenue represents gross revenues.

title: Williams Sidelined
description: John Williams, the Washington Bullet forward, will be sidelined for at least three months following arthroscopic surgery to repair torn ligaments in his right knee. Williams was hurt in last Saturday's loss to Utah. Williams had played in 255 consecutive games since November 1986. (AP)

title: Metro Datelines; Conviction Is Upheld In Fire That Killed 2
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court yesterday upheld the arson and murder convictions of Melvin McPhail, who had been charged in a 1986 fire at a Bridgeport rooming house that killed two people.

title: Campaign Questions Reverberate in Inquiry on Dinkins's Stock
description: A Federal prosecutor's inquiry into ''various financial transactions'' of Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins is likely to focus on the same questions about Mr. Dinkins's transfer of stock to his son that distracted him in the campaign, lawyers and law-enforcement experts said yesterday.

title: Steven S. Schwarzchild, Professor, 65
description: Steven S. Schwarzchild, professor of philosophy and Judaic studies at Washington University, St. Louis, died of an aneurysm Friday at the Jewish Hospital in St. Louis, where he lived. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. WILL CONTINUE MEDICARE CHARGES
description: Despite the recent vote by Congress to repeal the expanded Medicare coverage, the Government will continue to collect premiums from the nation's 33 million beneficiaries after the program is expected to end on Jan. 1.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Judge for Life
description: His obituaries inevitably identified him as a Supreme Court nominee rejected by the Senate in 1969, but the most telling thing about Clement Haynsworth was that he remained on the Federal bench for the rest of his life. His death at 77 revives memories of his defeat without doing justice to his nature. He was a judge who deemed his work a high calling even if he missed a higher one.

title: 2 Optical Concerns Agree to a Merger
description: The Royal International Optical Corporation and U.S. Vision Inc. said they had reached an agreement in principle to merge. In the deal, holders of not more than 80 percent of Royal's common stock would receive $12 in cash for each share, and holders who do not elect to receive cash would receive one share of common stock of the new corporation for each share of Royal International stock.

title: Warsaw Pact Condemns '68 Prague Invasion
description: The Soviet Union and four Warsaw Pact allies made a common break with the past today by jointly condemning the Soviet-led 1968 military suppression of the Czechoslovak experiment in political liberalization called the Prague Spring.

title: General Host Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,424,000 from the agreement in principle to settle two additional lawsuits stemming from the American Salt litigation. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $12,200,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, which reflected an after-tax loss provision resulting from a November 1988 decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit upholding a 1987 judgment against the company and a subsidiary in a saltwater pollution lawsuit, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary charge of $1,650,000 which reflected a provision for the settlement of a class action litigation which resulted from the March 1987 discovery of a problem in the computerized accounts payable system at General Host's Frank's Nursery & Crafts Inc. subsidiary. The company said the latest 9-month loss from continuing operations of $4,657,000 included elimination of $2,500,000 of income tax reserves which are longer required.

title: Seahawks Stun Bills As Krieg Connects
description: Dave Krieg and John Williams combined on Seattle's longest play of the season, a 51-yard touchdown pass with 5 minutes 38 seconds left tonight, as the Seahawks edged the sputtering Buffalo Bills, 17-16.

title: Home Sales Down 0.5% In October
description: Sales of new homes fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Government reported today. Analysts said that overall purchases were driven down by a 24.7 percent decline in the West because of the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake and the effects of the slowing economy.

title: Adubato to Coach Through End of Season
description: Richie Adubato, who last week was appointed interim coach of the Dallas Mavericks, yesterday accepted the coaching job through the rest of the season.

title: Study Assails Dealers in All-Terrain Vehicles
description: More than half of the country's dealers in all-terrain vehicles continued to recommend dangerously large vehicles for children under the age of 16 despite an agreement to prevent such sales, a Federal inquiry has found.

title: KEY RATES
East German Marchers Demand Reunification and End to Party
description: Tens of thousands of marchers were back on the streets of Leipzig tonight for their weekly demonstration, but this time many of their banners demanded German reunification and the death of the foundering Communist Party.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Town Copes With Growth And Trouble It Can Bring
description: This northern Westchester town, its hills still flecked with silos and old stone walls, is starting to realize the price it has paid for financial security.

title: Fidelity Is Freeing Its Funds To Be Assertive Investors
description: In another sign of the increasing power of institutional investors in takeover battles, one of the country's largest mutual fund organizations is taking steps to give it more influence over companies in which it holds stock. Fidelity Investments, whose mutual funds own shares worth $46 billion, has removed investment limitations from 26 of its stock mutual funds in recent months and expects shareholders to approve the removal in its 37 other stock funds by the end of the year.

title: Books of The Times; Dozen Tales of the Black Experience
description: FEVER Twelve Stories By John Edgar Wideman 161 pages. Henry Holt. $16.95.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shandwick Executive For North America
description: Shandwick P.L.C., the British public relations conglomerate, yesterday took a step toward unifying its diverse agencies by appointing Dermot McNulty, formerly of Burson-Marsteller, its first executive vice president of marketing for North America.

title: Fujitsu Computers
description: The Amdahl Corporation is withdrawing Fujitsu Ltd. supercomputers from the United States market because of poor sales, a Fujitsu spokesman said. Amdahl, which is 46 percent owned by Fujitsu, decided to halt United States sales of Fujitsu's E-Series 400 and 200 supercomputers because it had sold only two in the last four years. Amdahl, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has not said whether or not it will sell Fujitsu's new VP-2000 supercomputers, the spokesman said.

title: Exxon Has Spent $1.9 Billion On Alaska Spill, Skinner Says
description: Exxon has spent $1.9 billion cleaning up last spring's Alaskan oil spill, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said today.

title: From Breeches to Bustles: French Fashion as History
description: How the clothes people wear reflect the time in which they live is demonstrated by two new museum exhibitions that, taken together, chart the course of French fashion through the 19th century and beyond.

title: By Design; Dressed-Up T-Shirts
description: Who doesn't own at least one T-shirt? Chances are, though, it is not like some that are around now. Gussied up for the holiday season, these ornamented shirts are casual, but decidedly glamorous.

title: Soviet Sway in Cuba and Nicaragua Called Slight
description: Experts on Central America said today that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, would have difficulty stopping the flow of arms through Cuba and Nicaragua to Salvadoran guerrillas even if he made assiduous efforts, as President Bush has demanded.

title: Bush Asks Aquino to Insure Safety of Americans
description: President Bush called President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines tonight to express concern for the safety of some 200 United States citizens trapped in Manila hotels occupied by rebel soldiers, a White House official said.

title: Burnup & Sims Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Prenatal Care Offered to All In New Jersey
description: All pregnant women in New Jersey, including the working poor who have no medical insurance, will be able to receive a full range of prenatal health services under an expanded program scheduled to begin in March.

title: Channel 4, Seeking Ratings, Is Shuffling Daytime Lineup
description: Channel 4 announced plans yesterday to shuffle its daytime programs in late January, scheduling soap operas earlier in the day and using game shows to lead into the late-afternoon lineup of Phil Donahue's talk show and local news.

title: IPL Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Religious Groups Exhorted to Press on AIDS
description: A statement urging church and synagogue members to work actively for greater government involvement in AIDS prevention and care was adopted here today by an interfaith group of religious leaders.

title: Understanding Down Syndrome: A Chromosome Holds the Key
description: MOVING gene by gene, researchers are beginning to understand chromosome 21, which contains the blueprint not only for Down syndrome, the most common cause of mental retardation in the United States, but also for a variety of other disorders.

title: Afghan General and Rebel Leaders Reported Slain
description: American-backed Afghan insurgents said today that an Afghan Army general and three guerrilla commanders had been killed in fighting outside Jalalabad, a heavily contested city in eastern Afghanistan.

title: Taiwan Embraces Trappings of New Wealth
description: Along with the disabled who beg for change in the business district, young American street musicians can be spotted these days performing for the spare change of Chinese executives walking from their gleaming office buildings to their Mercedes-Benzes.

title: A Firefighter's Plea to Aid Needy Fire Victims
description: Sometimes those who work in municipal services have a special insight into the plight of the deprived - and sometimes they go beyond the call of duty to act upon that insight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''That decision, in the light of all the presently known facts, was erroneous.'' -The Soviet Government on the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia. [ A15:1. ]

title: Trooper Is Sentenced In '88 Rape of Motorist
description: A state trooper convicted of raping a motorist he stopped for a traffic violation repeated his claim that the victim made up the story as he was sentenced today to 8Y to 25 years in prison.

title: Justices to Decide if Citibank Must Pay on Foreign Deposit
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether American banks, which ordinarily are not liable for deposits made in their foreign branch offices, must use their worldwide assets to repay depositors when a foreign government closes a branch or otherwise makes a normal repayment impossible.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: What Can Stop Ewing? So Far, Nothing
description: How do you play Patrick Ewing? Straight up, the way the Phoenix Suns did Saturday night? Impossible, he scored 41 points. Double team, him? Many teams have tried this season and he is averaging 29.2 points a game, second best in the National Basketball Association behind Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls. Get him into early foul trouble, which the Lakers did Sunday night in the Knicks' 115-104 loss? He still scored 29 points, including 17 in the final quarter.

title: Eugene N. Greenblatt, A Pharmacologist, 65
description: Eugene Newton Greenblatt, a pharmacologist who specialized in anti-depressant drugs, died of heart disease Saturday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Chestnut Ridge, N.Y.

title: George Mc Grath, Accountant, 99
description: George Mc Grath, a certified public accountant, died of a stroke on Friday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 99 years old.

title: Service for Alvin Ailey
description: A memorial service for Alvin Ailey, founder and director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will be held on Friday at 10:30 A.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Mr. Ailey died of a blood disorder last Friday at the age of 58.

title: Life Support for Moscow
description: Over the weekend the people of Czechoslovakia and East Germany made it vividly plain that their goal was to eliminate Communist Party rule over their nations - and that they would not rest until they reached it.

title: Criminal Inquiry Is Opened Into Ex-H.U.D. Chief's Acts
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had opened a formal criminal inquiry to determine whether a special prosecutor should investigate allegations of perjury and conspiracy against former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. The announcement came as New York State prosecutors released documents showing that a longtime friend of Mr. Pierce, Samuel P. Singletary, was under indictment on larceny charges when his consulting firm received a $350,000 development grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1985.

title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year
description: Economists say the cost of illicit drugs to American society has risen substantially in the last few years, to far more than $60 billion annually. At the same time they are discovering vast new areas of additional economic impact that they are only now beginning to understand.

title: Gasoline Price Drops
description: A gallon of gasoline cost about a half-cent less at the nation's pumps in the last two weeks because of the traditional fall-winter decline in driving, an industry analyst said. The average service-station price, including taxes, was $1.0697 a gallon as of Friday, a survey of 13,000 stations by the analyst, Trilby Lundberg, found. The previous price was $1.0751 a gallon.

title: Lord Elwyn-Jones, 80, Nuremberg Prosecutor
description: Lord Elwyn-Jones, a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials and Britain's chief legal officer under the last Labor Party Government, died of cancer on Monday at the age of 80.

title:
Books of The Times;
An Escape From the Present, Into the Past
description: LEAD: The Anastasia Syndrome And Other Stories By Mary Higgins Clark 318 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Whatever the Outcome, Aquino Stands to Lose
description: President Corazon C. Aquino may yet find a neat way to finish off the most serious coup attempt of her four years in office, but her ability to deal with widespread complaints about her administration has been severely undermined.

title: Book Notes
description: Fiction Too Risky

title: Bypassing Sensible on the Road to Status
description: Despite an entire life lived here in car country, in Southern California, I only very recently succumbed to full-blown car lust. For a month and a half I lurched, with my husband along, from showroom to showroom, sizing up the new cars and trying to decide which one to buy, which one was really me. I dreamed about cars; I drooled over them, my apparently long-repressed desire for sleek automotive flesh coming to the fore. I was embarrassed - me, a self-castigating, status symbol-seeking materialist - but unstoppable.

title: Express-Bus Lines and Commuters Can't Afford a Higher Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracing Evasion of Campaign Laws
description: In a study that traced the path of $28.5 million in 1988 campaign contributions, a nonpartisan research group today provided new evidence of how wealthy donors were able to skirt Federal laws regulating contributions to Presidential campaigns.

title: Albany's Figures Show A $500 Million Shortfall
description: Maintaining its drum roll of bad news, the Cuomo administration predicted today that tax revenues for the current fiscal year would be even worse than it had estimated just last month.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE long enjoyed beer-leavened batters for fried seafood and poultry, and shrimp is particularly good prepared this way. The batters must be well seasoned so flavors integrate with the food.

title: Standard Brands Paint reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $454,000 for both periods, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $1,145,000, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of adopting FASB 96 on accounting for income taxes.

title: Copters Save 15 on Roof in Fire
description: A smoky fire in a nine-story building used by garment makers sent panicky workers scurrying today down fire truck rescue ladders and up to the roof, where Fire Department helicopters plucked 15 people to safety.

title: Fast Food? It Just Isn't Fast Enough Anymore
description: Welcome to the Age of Zap.

title: After the Summit; Include Navies in Arms Talks, Some in NATO Urge
description: The United States is coming under pressure from some of its NATO allies to drop its rigid opposition to including naval forces in arms reduction talks with the Soviet Union, diplomats and other Government officials in several European capitals say.

title: Fettered Cyprus Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR SPECIAL SESSION ON INTERNATIONAL CO-OPERATION AGAINST NARCOTIC DRUGS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Debating Art: Censorship Or Protest?
description: An angry debate has erupted at the New School for Social Research after a caricature of a black man the school was displaying in an art show was defaced by an instructor who branded the work racist.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: EATING WELL
description: CLOTHING for fat children, in the not too distant past, was sold in the ''chubby'' department. Stores are no longer so insensitive that they call attention to obese children in this way. But the children's peers have no such qualms: fat children are still subject to cruel taunts.

title: Riser Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 21
description: b-Included a gain of $500,000 from a tax credit and a charge of $700,000 for income taxes. c-Net loss and included a one-time gain of $3.3 million from the sale of 11 stores.

title: A New Team in Place At Pergament Chain
description: Pergament Home Centers, a chain that sells home-improvement products, said yesterday that Michael H. Lurie had been named president and chief operating officer to fill one of the posts held by Murray Pergament, the longtime president, chairman and chief executive.

title: KEY RATES
McMartin Jury Chooses a Christmas Break
description: The jurors in the McMartin Preschool molestation case turned in the second of a potential total of 65 verdicts today and rejected a suggestion that they cancel their two-week Christmas vacation.

title: 13 Join a Panel for Jersey City Schools
description: The State Education Commissioner announced today the appointment of 13 Jersey City residents to a 15-member advisory Board of Education that will operate in the shadow of the state's all-powerful Superintendent in managing the public schools here.

title: Real Estate; On 3d Ave., Location Isn't Enough
description: THE old cliche that the essence of real estate is location is coming under increasing challenge in Manhattan's midtown leasing market.

title: Clamor in Europe: Reporter's Notebook; From Lowliest Janitor To National Inspiration
description: Vaclav Maly is a reluctant hero of the political upheaval that some people are calling the November Revolution.

title: High Yugoslav Inflation
description: Yugoslavia said Monday that its annual inflation rate neared 2,000 percent last month. The Federal Statistics Office reported that prices rose in November by 42.4 percent after a 45.6 percent jump in October. The annual increase in the inflation rate between November 1988 and last month was 1,975.7 percent.

title: CRANSTON INQUIRY WIDENS TO INCLUDE SIGNUPS OF VOTERS
description: The inquiries into Senator Alan Cranston's contacts with Charles H. Keating Jr., who headed a savings and loan institution that failed, have now focused attention on the activities and financing of three voter-registration groups backed by the California legislator.

title: Gigts and Loans to Nancy Reagan Stir I.R.S. Interest in High Fashion
description: The Internnal Revenue Service is examining tax returns filed by former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, to determine whether to seek additional taxes for gifts or loans of items like jewelry and designer dresses, a former official for a Los Angeles couturier said today.

title: Clamor in Europe; CZECH COMMUNISTS ACCEPT MINOR ROLE
description: In a major concession to the opposition, the Communist leadership agreed today to accept a minority role in one of the country's two principal regional governments.

title: Sensitive Topic: Fighting Ads That Hit You in the Nose
description: On the theory that many people can't stand the smell of their magazines and credit-card bills, a proposal has been advanced in New York State to bar fragrance strips from periodicals and mailings unless the samples are sealed.

title: After the Summit; COMMUNIST PARTY BEGINS TO SPLINTER UNDER GORBACHEV
description: While President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been applying his diplomatic skills to the stability of Europe, his own Communist Party is beginning to splinter along ethnic and ideological lines.

title: Review/Television; The Familiar Rumpole, In the Bailey and Beyond
description: Leo McKern first appeared 11 years ago as Horace Rumpole, the roguish, lovable barrister. Since then, the actor has regularly insisted that he is through with the role. He would rather be remembered, evidently, for his often acclaimed interpretations of Shakespeare. But Mr. McKern and the grumbling husband of She Who Must Be Obeyed are by now inseparable, and the author John Mortimer, himself a former barrister, shows no sign of running out of ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' stories. Thames Television seems to have spawned a cottage industry. Six new episodes are ready to be shown on public television's ''Mystery!'' beginning tomorrow at 10:15 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Angelo Ruggiero Is Dead at 49; Longtime Associate of John Gotti
description: Angelo Ruggiero, a longtime friend and close associate of John Gotti, died of cancer Monday at his home in Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Ruggiero, who was 49 years old, had four major cases against him pending in Federal and New York State courts and was free on $1 million bail when he died.

title: Arabs at U.N. Relax Stand on P.L.O.
description: Arab countries backed down today in a quarrel with the United States over the status of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The dispute has threatened to lead to a cutoff in American financing for the United Nations.

title: St. John's Loses to N. Carolina St.
description: LEAD: Greg (Boo) Harvey had just made a 3-pointer to give St. John's a 6-point advantage, its largest lead of the second half. When the North Carolina State guard Rodney Monroe missed a jumpshot at the other end, Harvey grappled for the rebound. Called for a foul on the play, he slammed the ball to the floor, incurring a technical foul.

title: Ad Executive Salin Leaving Party
description: A young advertising executive was stabbed to death Monday night in the East Village while walking to a subway station after attending a Christmas party, the police said yesterday.

title: Ouster Voted For R.O.T.C. In Wisconsin
description: The faculty of the University of Wisconsin at Madison has recommended that the Board of Regents sever contracts with the Reserve Officers Training Corps by May 1993 if the programs do not change their policies regarding homosexuals.

title: New York City Settles 1975 Suit On Pension Bias
description: Lawyers for New York City and 32,000 retired female city workers told a Federal judge yesterday that they had settled a 14-year-old discrimination suit against the largest of the municipal pension systems.

title: Addenda
description: * Abreu Advertising in Speonk, L.I., has changed its name to Abreu/ Mitchell Advertising, in recognition of Kim Mitchell, who has joined the agency as a partner.

title: Kodak Minilabs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would stop manufacturing photo minilab equipment at the end of the year, three years after it entered the business. It said the Noritsu America Corporation would service existing Kodak minilab equipment in the United States and distribute Kodak's Create-a-Print enlargement system, which Kodak would continue to manufacture.

title: If the Summit Were Bugged
description: LEAD: Despite intense media coverage of every summit meeting, the private sessions between the two leaders generally remain a mystery. Invariably, a staffer milling around outside the meeting room will say, ''Boy, I wish I could be a fly on the wall in there.'' Herewith a dispatch from the ''fly on the wall.

title: Arbitration Offered
description: John Tudor, a pitcher, and the outfielder John Shelby were among five free-agent players who were offered salary arbitration by the Dodgers yesterday.

title: Education; Governors and Experts Are Divided On Setting Nation's Education Goals
description: There may be only one thing that educators, business leaders, governors and President Bush agree on: America's schools are in trouble.

title: Gorbachev Seeks End Of Naval A-Weapons
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed eliminating tactical nuclear weapons from the American and Soviet Navies at his Malta summit meeting with President Bush, Administration officials disclosed.

title: A Show of Bronx Art
description: ''Bronx Views,'' an exhibition of paintings depicting landscapes in the Bronx, will open a new art gallery today at the Kingsbridge Center of the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, 100 West Kingsbridge Road, in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. The exhibition, co-sponsored by the Bronx Museum of the Arts, features 30 works by 6 artists who live in the Bronx: Rikki Asher, Garin Baker, William Behnken, Dina Bursztyn, Daniel Hauben and Leslie Lowinger. The opening of the gallery is among events commemorating the 40th anniversary of the Home and Hospital; other shows are planned for the space. Viewing hours for the exhibition are by appointment. Information: 579-0473.

title: Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: U.S. Invites Anarchy With Plan for Noriega
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideal Metal reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Liv Ullmann Appears at GAF Trial
description: Liv Ullmann had hoped that as the final witness yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation trial she could tell the jurors details about the character of the main defendant in the case, a senior GAF executive. But like her two books and many of her films, her testimony was limited mostly to her own character.

title: Alexander's Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 21
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary charge from an accounting change of $3,416,000. In the year-ago first quarter income before item of $9,045,000, or $1.82 a share, included a pretax gain of $17,094,000 ($10 million after-tax).

title: Education; Lessons
description: When business executives take up the cause of public education, they usually end up doing things like volunteer tutoring or picking up the tab to send the senior class to Washington.

title: Education; About Education
description: Early this year Wendy Kopp, then a student at Princeton, wrote her senior thesis on a plan to entice some of the best college graduates into teaching in public schools.

title: Right to Die? Yes Medical Issue? No
description: LEAD: The ''right to die'' is an inspired battle cry because almost everybody favors ''rights'' and ''freedom.'' But to call Nancy Cruzan v. Director of Missouri Department of Health, to be heard by the Supreme Court today, a ''right to die'' case seems contrived.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities again traded in a very narrow range yesterday on extremely light volume. For the second straight session, market participants chose to ignore news developments that at other times would normally have had a beneficial effect.

title: QVC Network Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dirt-Poor and Dim-Witted, Wife Is a Punching Bag
description: The battered bride at the center of Deborah Pryor's ''Briar Patch'' stands in the Virginia moonlight and dreams about floating away into outer space. Confined in the tangled brambles of Ms. Pryor's dreary play (opening the season at the Ensemble Studio Theater), theatergoers may feel similarly in need of liberation. There is no exit from this ''Briar Patch.''

title: Canadian Pacific Shifts
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., Canada's third-largest company, said that it would turn its real estate subsidiary into a public company and distribute 80 percent of the shares to Canadian Pacific shareholders.

title: Don't Blame Program Trading, Blame the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: George Selden, 60, Writer of Tales Describing a Cricket's Adventures
description: George Selden Thompson, the author of ''The Cricket in Times Square'' and other children's books, died of complications from a gastrointestinal hemorrhage yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Savings Industry's New Curbs
description: Four months after President Bush signed legislation to bail out and change the savings and loan industry, most savings institutions have taken major steps toward meeting strict new rules intended to make them safer and more conservative.

title: In Florida, Comaneci Offers Only Partial Explanations
description: The former Olympic gold medalist Nadia Comaneci repeatedly shunned questions about her personal plans, but made it clear at a news conference today that she had no immediate plans to become involved with gymnastics in the United States.

title: Presidential Air
description: Presidential Airways Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five weeks ago, discontinued all of its flights effective Monday. It had been operating 24 flights a day to and from six cities. Presidential, which began four years ago, had provided feeder service for United Airlines at Washington Dulles International Airport here since January 1988.

title: EX-BAKKER AIDES ARE NAMED BY JURY
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted two associates of Jim Bakker for lying during the PTL fraud investigation.

title: Balkan, Not Vulcan
description: Reports of the stunning ignorance being created by the American educational system make it hard to write for a mass audience.

title: Mexico Said to Be Nearing Accord to Refinance Debt
description: Mexico and its creditor banks have nearly completed negotiations for refinancing the nation's $48 billion in medium- and long-term debt, according to Jose Angel Guerria, Mexico's leading negotiator with the banks.

title: Jordan's New Prime Minister Delays Naming Government
description: The new Prime Minister, Mudar Badran, delayed naming a Government today amid pressure from a parliamentary bloc over cabinet posts.

title: Small Shop Benefits From A Big Client
description: SLATER HANFT MARTIN is a small advertising agency that is every large agency's nightmare.

title: Designatronics Inc. reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: A.M.A. EXECUTIVE LEAVING AMID RIFT
description: The American Medical Association's top executive, whose approval of two financial deals that lost money led to a dispute in the organization, has announced that he will retire when his current contract ends.

title: Miami Officer's Trial In Killing Sent to Jury
description: After testimony by 59 witnesses in 13 days, the trial of a Miami police officer for the killing of two unarmed black men went to the jury tonight. Jurors will begin formal deliberation in the morning.

title: Greenpeace Asserts Navy Was Malicious During Protest at Sea
description: The protest group Greenpeace today accused the Navy of maliciousness in ramming its flagship during a protest of the test launching of a Trident 2 missile off Florida on Monday.

title: La. Tech Rolls To Victory, 87-49
description: Venus Lacy and Sheila Ethridge each scored 18 points tonight night to lead second-ranked Louisiana Tech to an 87-49 victory over Northeast Louisiana.

title: AFGHAN CAPITAL NOW FEARS FAMINE
description: In the Pul-i-Baghmi bazaar, down by the muddy waters of the Kabul River, the old trader smiled. Although there were no customers on hand, his sacks of flour, rice and other grains were overflowing. With food prices edging up every week, the trader could see little ahead but profit.

title: Clamor in Europe; Kohl's German Unity Plan Is 'Dangerous,' Soviets Say
description: The Soviet Union today issued a sharp critique of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's plan for German reunification, describing it as ''fraught with dangerous consequences'' and ''bordering on outright diktat.''

title: Cease-Fire in Beirut Is Shattered After 10 Weeks
description: Rival Muslim and Christian factions engaged in artillery and rocket duels across Beirut's dividing line today, shattering a 10-week cease-fire.

title: Greenwich's Private Deal for Public Problem
description: When the Greenwich Board of Education went shopping for a new superintendent this year, its members knew that it would be difficult to offer a package of pay and perquisites large enough to enable an out-of-town administrator to buy a home here. After all, the average price of a four-bedroom colonial on one and a half acres is $837,000.

title: Clamor in Europe; Civic Forum: Politics on a Shoestring
description: Civic Forum, which in scarcely two weeks has assumed the mantle of Czechoslovakia's political opposition, is a mass movement whose members simply declare themselves by shouting for freedom at demonstrations and whose leaders serve by acclamation.

title: Metro Datelines; Teen-Ager Reports Subway Tunnel Rape
description: A 17-year-old high school student told the police that she was raped in an East Village subway tunnel on Sunday by a man who resembled a suspect in several other rape cases. But she was unable yesterday to identify her attacker from police sketches, transit officials said.

title: Spartans' Snow Winner Of the Butkus Award
description: Percy Snow of Michigan State, who calls himself mean on the field and a nice guy off it, was named yesterday as the winner of the Dick Butkus award as the top linebacker in college football.

title: Kustom Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After a loss of $55,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year.

title: After the Summit; Gorbachev Said to Seek End To Naval Nuclear Weapons
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed eliminating tactical nuclear weapons from the American and Soviet Navies in his Malta summit meeting with President Bush, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Federal Agent Shoots Suspect in Drug Bust
description: One of three drug suspects was shot and wounded last night during a buy and bust operation conducted in Upper Manhattan by Federal drug enforcement agents, officials said.

title: Academy of Design Dismisses Employees
description: The National Academy of Design, the school, museum and society of artists on upper Fifth Avenue, abruptly dismissed about one-fourth of its 40-member staff yesterday and said it planned to cut its educational programs and the hours for its exhibition galleries because of financial problems.

title: What Is Socialism?
description: In a speech written for his acceptance of the Frankfurt Peace Prize on Oct. 15, the Czech playwright and now opposition leader Vaclav Havel warned against the tyranny of ambitious words.

title: Axelrod Adopts Panel's Finding In a 1984 Death
description: The New York State Health Commissioner has accepted a panel's recommendation that administrative charges be dropped against two doctors who treated 18-year-old Libby Zion in the hours before her death in 1984.

title: Market Place; Index Arbitrage Seems to Falter
description: INDEX arbitrage trading - the form of program trading that has been most criticized - appears to have slumped dramatically.

title: AIDS Drug Causes Cancer in Animals
description: The AIDS drug AZT has been found to cause cancer in laboratory animals, the drug's manufacturer said today. But doctors emphasized that AIDS patients should continue to take the drug because the risk is still only theoretical.

title: Surgery for Dravecky
description: Dave Dravecky, who battled back from cancer to pitch for San Francisco this season, will have surgery in January because of a recurrence of a tumor in his left arm. Dravecky, 33, will undergo the procedure at the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Cancer Center in New York on Jan. 4.

title: Mitchell Energy & DevelopFment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and included writedowns totaling about $15 million on certain drilling rigs and real estate assets. c-After a gain of $20,594,000, or 44 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting.

title: Islanders Beat Best for 3d Straight Victory
description: The Islanders, the team with the second-poorest record in the National Hockey League, won their third straight game tonight, 3-0, beating the Buffalo Sabres, the team with the league's best record, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Ethics Rules Are Postponed
description: The City Council yesterday postponed until April putting new conflict-of-interest rules into effect for many New York City employees. The vote was 26 to 8. The postponement, from Jan. 1, is intended to encourage some officials to continue in their jobs during the transition between administrations. The new law will place restrictions on all city officials who leave office and then want to represent clients before city agencies. Some provisions will still go into effect Jan. 1.

title: DEFICIT AND TAXES TRY LEGISLATORS
description: Faced with voters who threaten them with political and even physical harm, Massachusetts legislators are trying again this week to figure out how to go about the distasteful business of raising taxes.

title: Oasis Laundries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nairobi Journal; Skyscraper's Enemy Draws a Daily Dose of Scorn
description: On recent mornings, Prof. Wangari Maathai has postponed reading the newspapers until she arrives at the office, where she braces herself over a cup of hot tea for the daily fulminations against her.

title: Fair Housing - for the Young, Too
description: Last year's Federal fair housing amendments wisely added discrimination against families with children to the list of forbidden real estate practices. That created anxiety among many senior citizens who fear that housing reserved for them may soon be overrun by children.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Every mayor-elect has a certain anxiety, a certain fear about whether or not they're up to the job. The people decided you were, and that's all that's required.'' - Mayor Edward I. Koch, to Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins. [ B1:5. ]

title: Families Learning To Redefine Home For the Holidays
description: Oh, there's no place like home for the holidays For no matter how far away you roam If you want to be happy in a million ways For the holidays, you can't beat home sweet home. -''Home for the Holidays''*

title: Cocoa Group Ousts Phibro
description: A United States commodity trading house, Philipp Brothers Inc., known as Phibro, was expelled today from the French cocoa trade association.

title: Review/Music; A Prize-Winning Tenor In Songs of Thwarted Love
description: ''Die Schone Mullerin,'' Schubert's first great song cycle, shares the thwarted-love theme of his last. But it is ''Die Winterreise'' - that final searing metaphor for the dying composer - that has preoccupied our imaginations ever since.

title: Penguins Clean House And Bring in Patrick
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins dismissed their general manager, Tony Esposito, and their coach, Gene Ubriaco, today and hired Craig Patrick, the former New York Rangers' executive, as Esposito's replacement and interim coach.

title: Woman Sues Over Her Arrest For 7 Overdue Library Book
description: A woman arrested for failing to answer a court summons on charges that she had seven overdue library books is suing the county and its solicitor.

title: U.S. and Canada in Accord On Speeding Up Tariff Cuts
description: The United States and Canada, which last Jan. 1 put into effect a free-trade agreement aimed at wiping out practically all trade barriers between the two countries within a decade, have decided to speed up tariff cuts covering $6 billion in trade.

title: INSIDE
description: New Concern on AIDS Drug AZT,the only approved anti-AIDS drug, has been found to cause cancer in mice and rats. But doctors say that AIDS patients should continue taking the drug. Page A20. New Savings Industry Rules Most savings institutions have taken steps to become more conservative and safer, but 800 of them will not meet Federal regulations that take effect tomorrow. Page D1. No Consensus on Education As a top-level panel prepares to define the nation's education goals, experts are split over the problems and the solutions. Page B14.

title: Perrier Plans Pepsico Suit
description: Source Perrier S.A., the French maker of the mineral water product, plans to sue Pepsico Inc. for breaking its franchise contract, Perrier's managing director, Frederick Zimmer said today.

title: Double Helix Films Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $19,000 from tax loss carryforward. c-After extraordinary tax benefits of $12,552 for the quarter and $200,043 for the 9 months, from tax loss carryforwards.

title: MAI Basic Four Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax non-recurring charges of $1 million for the quarter and $40,165,000 for the year. c-Net income

title: Franco Pact Extended
description: TThe Texas Rangers yesterday gave their second baseman, Julio Franco, a three-year contract extension worth $7.8 million.

title: Art Prices Are Still Astonishing, But Fever Seems to Be Cooling
description: Art is still commanding breathtaking sums in the auction houses. Pablo Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding'' was bought last week by a Japanese real-estate developer for $51.3 million, the second highest price ever paid for a painting. But indications are that the feverish buying of recent years is beginning to cool down and that buyers are becoming more selective.

title: Frederick Payne, 88, A Retired Stockbroker
description: Frederick Blake Payne, a retired senior partner of Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day, the stockbrokerage house, died on Monday at his home in Clogheen, Ireland. He was 88 years old and had been suffering from Parkinson's disease.

title: N.F.L. Bounty-Hunting Dispute
description: The National Football League is expected to announce before Friday its findings on the so-called bounty-hunting incident involving the Eagles and the Dallas Cowboys, who meet again Sunday in Philadelphia.

title: Corning Settles Suit; Accepts $25 Million
description: Corning Inc. will receive $25 million from Sumitomo Electric Industries in an out-of-court settlement of a suit that accused the Japanese company of violating two Corning patents for optical fibers, Corning said today.

title: Soviets Come to Aid of Antarctic Expedition
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to supply fuel to a group of six explorers from six nations, preventing an early end to their 4,000-mile trek across Antarctica by dog sled and ski.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: People
description: * Bryan Birch and Ed Cole have joined Foote, Cone & Belding/Southern California as senior vice presidents and co-creative directors.

title: NCH Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results were classified to conform to latest year presentation.

title: Reviews/Music; Humor by Brass Quintet in New Works
description: The repertory the Saturday Brass Quintet presented in its First Annual Contemporary Music Concert at Washington Square Church on Friday evening, consisting almost entirely of premieres and first New York performances, ranged from high pretense to low humor, and it was sometimes difficult to tell the difference.

title: Australian Lending Lags
description: Australians' demand for credit is slowing, central bank figures showed today, and economists said the trend was evidence that the economy was cooling. The Reserve Bank of Australia said private sector borrowing rose 16.6 percent in the 12 months ended in October, the smallest rise in five years. It compared with an 18.3 percent rise in the 12 months ended in September and a 25 percent rise in the 12 months to October 1988. Government policy to dampen consumer demand has pushed prime lending rates to more than 20 percent and mortgage rates to 17 percent.

title: Communism, Exposed
description: Harmonious in mood. Conciliatory on arms. Cooperative on investment and trade. President Bush brimmed with good will toward Mikhail Gorbachev at their Malta summit talks - and small wonder. He knows what terrors may await the Soviet leader. All the astonishing changes that Mr. Gorbachev has already unleashed on the Communist world are mere economic prologue.

title: Plea in Newton Killing
description: Tyrone Robinson, accused of the Aug. 22 killing of Huey P. Newton, a co-founder of the Black Panther Party, pleaded not guilty today in Alameda County Superior Court. Judge Gordon Baranco ordered the 25-year-old defendant to trial on Jan. 24 and set a bail hearing for Dec. 14. The prosecution contends that the defendant shot Mr. Newton to improve his standing with a prison gang.

title: Deere & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain for income taxes of $28,744,000, or 42 cents a share. Lastest fourth-quarter and year-ago quarter's sales reflected adoption of new accounting rules. The latest year's sales were adjusted to reflect accounting for consolidating both results of the operating company and its financial subsidiaries. The 1988 year reflected tax loss carryforwards of $69.3 million. Sales represented worldwide net sales and revenues, which now include finance income and insurance and health care premiums.

title: Colombia Says Bomb Led to Crash Last Month of Plane Carrying 107
description: Investigators have concluded that a bomb destroyed a Colombian jetliner that crashed last month and killed all 107 people aboard, and they say they believe that the bomb was hidden under a seat, an official said today.

title: Mozartean-Style Trios
description: One of Mozart's experiments with the clarinet hit upon a combination so potent that composers since the 18th century have followed it enthusiastically. The instruments in question are the clarinet, the viola and the piano - the subject of his great Trio in E flat and also of the two less familiar works played by the American Chamber Players at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon. They were Max Bruch's Four Pieces and Bruce Saylor's new Trio.

title: Sudan Peace Talks Fail Over Islamic Code
description: Peace here talks between Sudanese rebels and the Khartoum Government collapsed today in a disagreement over the country's Islamic legal code and other issues that have kept them at war for nearly seven years.

title: DRUG WAR STALLED IN 2 KEY COUNTRIES
description: Though President Bush announced in September that he was sending several hundred million dollars to fight drugs in South America, no new funds have reached Peru and Bolivia, the world's two main growers of coca.

title: Well Known and Lesser Known Aid Neediest
description: Some names attached to contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are recognizable. Most are not. But the spirit of gratification derived from giving seems to be the same, regardless of celebrity.

title: Fannie Mae Rates Set on Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday announced the interest rates for a two-part debenture offering totaling $2 billion.

title: USX Defends Stance on Icahn
description: Charles A. Corry, the chairman of the USX Corporation, said that his company's strategy would not be altered as a result of the holdings of Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who owns a substantial stake in the energy and steel company.

title: Accord Is Reached in Dispute Over Airport Bomb Detector
description: A dispute about liability insurance that kept a $1 million state-of-the-art bomb detector sitting in a crate at Miami International Airport has been resolved, with the manufacturer agreeing to absorb the cost.

title: Full Service on IND Lines May Resume by Friday
description: Full service on some IND lines in Manhattan may be restored by Friday, if repairs go smoothly, the Transit Authority said yesterday. The lines were inundated on Saturday morning when a water main broke at 135th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, spilling 18 million gallons.

title: Space Shuttle Launching Is Set for Dec. 18
description: NASA today scheduled the launching of the space shuttle Columbia for Dec. 18, but it said the 10-day flight could be delayed a day or two if a renovated launch pad is not ready.

title: Quaker Oats Sees Weakness in Toys
description: The common stock of the Quaker Oats Company plunged $3.75 a share today, to $58.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after the company disclosed weakness in its Fisher-Price toy business. Quaker said it expected earnings for its second quarter ending Dec. 31 to fall below 1988's 47 cents a share.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Concerned Collins

title: Notes Are Priced By Philip Morris
description: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday priced $450 million in notes due in 1996 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Request Is Made To Close Hialeah
description: John Brunetti, the owner of Hialeah Park, wants to close the historic race track as soon as possible because he is losing an expensive battle for bettors with nearby Calder Race Course.

title: New Volumes That Tantalize Eye and Palate
description: THE 1989 holiday season brings an exceptional bounty of books for cooks and food lovers, handsome picture books for gift-giving, thoughtful books for thinking and those rare, treasured volumes that both tantalize the eye and palate with clearly presented recipes and provoke thoughtful discourse or at least good dinner-table conversation.

title: Seymour Levine, Publisher, 66,
description: Seymour Levine, a publisher and freelance writer, died of melanoma, a skin cancer, yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: Music Theater Festival To Offer Premiere in '90
description: The 1990 spring season of the American Music Theater Festival in Philadelphia will include the first performances of a cabaret theater piece, ''Casino Paradise,'' by William Bolcom and Arnold Weinstein, as well as a reconstruction of the 1948 musical ''Love Life,'' by Kurt Weill and Alan Jay Lerner.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American City Business Journals Inc., Kansas City, Mo., acquired The San Francisco Business Times, previously managed by American City, and sold its interest as manager of The Business Press, a Fort Worth business publication. Terms of the deals were not disclosed.

title: About New York; A Tour Guide Who Sidesteps All the Schmaltz
description: Marvin Gelfand grew up in a Brooklyn family faithful to a tradition prevalent when housing was far more abundant. They moved twice a year to take advantage of the month's free rent offered to new tenants.

title: On U.S. Cultural Literacy: The Stakes and Strategy
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by E. D. Hirsch Jr., author of ''Cultural Literacy: What Every American Needs to Know,'' and Henry Louis Gates Jr., W. E. B. DuBois Professor of Literature at Cornell University. They spoke yesterday in New York at a forum on literacy in America, sponsored by The New York Times. E. D. Hirsch Jr. Most of the recent debates about the specific contents of cultural literacy have centered on the areas of contention, and that fact has cast a net of controversy over the subject. But I gain a strong sense that the question has already been decided. An expansion of our culture will be the consequence of these debates, and I personally welcome that result.

title: Sanson Family Ends Beatrice Suit
description: TLC Beatrice International, the multinational food company controlled by Reginald F. Lewis, said it had reached an agreement with the Sanson family settling a 1987 lawsuit meant to prevent Mr. Lewis from taking control of Beatrice. The Sanson family owns 30 percent of Gelati Sanson, an ice cream company based in Italy, and TLC Beatrice controls the rest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Czechoslovak emigres in the United States misidentified Dr. Charlotta Kotik. She is a great-granddaughter of the Czechoslovak statesman Thomas G. Masaryk, and not of Jan Masaryk. Jan Masaryk, who was also a Czechoslovak statesman, was Dr. Kotik's great-uncle.

title: 10,000 Jobs To Be Cut By I.B.M.
description: In a dramatic reflection of its inability to find the right combination of products to meet its goals for growth, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its domestic work force by more than 10,000 and take a $2.3 billion charge against earnings in the fourth quarter.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Heart of Gold For a House of Strays
description: Baba Goya, the title character and earth mother in the 1973 play by Steve Tesich now being revived at the Second Stage Theater, starts the morning with an Italian love song and a cup of strong Turkish coffee. As long as her household is full of warm bodies, Goya is undaunted by all of the messy problems they can pose.

title: Clamor in Europe; East Berlin Still Silent on Beatings of Protesters
description: Two months after police units began beating East Germans arrested in Dresden, Leipzig and East Berlin for demonstrating against the Government of Erich Honecker, there is still no official acknowledgment that many were severely wounded.

title: Bridge
description: The first charity bridge event in the New York metropolitan area to designate AIDS patients as its beneficiaries was played Sept. 24 at the Grand Bridge Studio, Franklin Square, L.I., and will be repeated next year. Most of the top-ranked Long Island players took part in a partly Pro-Am format, and since the playing space was donated and the directors were volunteers, virtually all the income of $3,500 went to the People with AIDS Coalition of Long Island.

title: Sir John Pritchard, Music Director, Is Dead at 68
description: Sir John Pritchard, the music director of the San Francisco Opera and, until early this year, of the BBC Symphony and the Cologne Opera, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Seton Medical Center in Daly City, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: Gambling on a New Recycling Device
description: In states with container-deposit laws, people can insert their used cans or bottles in a ''reverse vending machine'' and get back their nickel or dime deposit. But delivering an immediate reward that encourages such recycling is not as easy in states without deposit laws. Now, the Howard Marlboro Group, a sales promotion division of the giant Saatchi & Saatchi advertising agency, is trying to combine technology, merchandising and gambling to stimulate recycling and help fend off more deposit laws.

title: Economic Scene; In Takeovers, Play's the Thing
description: ARE hostile takeovers bad for children and other living things? Or are they simply nature's way of telling incompetent managers to step down?

title: News Summary
description: International A3-19 The Communist Party is unraveling in the Soviet Union as President Mikhail Gorbachev has been using his diplomatic skills to stabilize the situation in Europe. Page A1 Mikhail Gorbachev's biggest test of power is his campaign to end a shortage of consumer goods, not the threat of political opposition, he told President Bush at Malta. A1 Gorbachev said to seek end of naval nuclear weapons A16 Rifts within the Western alliance, particularly over German reunification and European integration, have appeared following the rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe. A16 Czechoslovak Communist leaders agreed to accept a minority role in one of the country's two principal regional governments. Opposition leaders said the move could set a precedent. A18 Civic Forum: Politics on a shoestring A18 Erich Honecker is under house, as are other top East German officials in his fallen leadership. A furious, impatient public has taken the hunt for corrupt former officials into its own hands. A1 Kremlin faults Kohl's plan A19 East Germany remains silent on brutality against protesters A19 Leipzig: Where indignation transforms German politics A19 Manila has become a divided city. Its financial center is paralyzed the coup attempt against President Aquino's Government, but most of the city goes about its business. A cease-fire was called to evacuate foreigners trapped in hotels. A1 News analysis: Corazon Aquino seems to have survived the most serious coup attempt of her four years in office, but some of her proudest achievements may not. A8 India's Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, named 15 people to his Cabinet, but he did not announce which positions they would hold. A7 Artillery and rocket duels in Beirut shattered a 10-week cease-fire. The fighting between rival Muslim and Christian factions did not appear to involve Syrian units or Christian forces defending the Presidential Palace. A3 Arabs at U.N. relax stand on P.L.O. A3 The prospect of famine in Kabul hangs over war-battered Afghanis as winter approaches. Efforts to blockade the capital by the Muslim rebels have squeezed up prices of essential items. A11 American is charged in El Salvador with terrorism A6 Drug War stalled in two key countries: Peru and Bolivia A13 The world faces an ecological crisis that violates human rights, said Pope John Paul II. The ''right to a safe environment'' is at root ''a moral issue,'' he said. A14 Bush proposing talks in U.S. on global warming A15 Japan's police subdue Airport protesters with cages A9 National A20-29, B10-13 The investigation of Alan Cranston has widened, focusing on the activities and financing of three voter-registration groups backed by the California legislator. A1 Most savings institutions meet new U.S. standards D1 Washington Talk: The issue haunting Congress is ethics A20 Government areas prone to abuse and mismanagement have been identified by the Office of Management and Budget. The list of 78 high-risk areas focuses especially on contracting, credit plans and financial accounting. A24 Medicare refunds due on surtax, not flat premiums A20 Gifts to Nancy Reagan stir I.R.S. interest in high fashion A20 Government can be sued for interfering in labor talks A22 Georgia's courts facing a change A22 The AIDS drug AZT causes cancer in laboratory animals, the drug's manufacturer said. But doctors say that AIDS patients should continue to take the drug. risks. A20 Big tax increases in Massachusetts are the explosive topic of this week's discussions at the State House. Last week a $1.2 billion package of tax increases self-destructed. A23 10,000 jobs to be cut by I.B.M. D1 Study challenges high-rise safety in Los Angeles basin A25 Regional B1-9 David Dinkins chose six appointees to fill important positions at the center of his new administration: four deputy mayors, a corporation counsel and a press secretary, members of his transition team said. A1 Dinkins asking donors to pay for his inaugural B8 Mayor Koch defended his tenure, advised his successor to bravely face New York City's fiscal problems and attacked the Federal Government. His remarks came in what amounted to a political valedictory. B1 Albany's figures show budget shortfall could hit $500 million B3 A small drawing branded as racist has created an angry debate at the New School for Social Research: Was an instructor's defacement of the caricature a legitimate protest or unjustified censorship? B1 A vocal critic of the school system in New York City was appointed deputy chancellor and chief operating officer by the future Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez. B1 Greenwich's School Superintendent will receive a $200,000 loan from pri-vate investors to help buy a home. The money is part of an innovative plan devised by the school board to attract out-of-town candidates for the post. B1 Advisory board for Jersey City schools is named B2 U.S. refuses private plan to take over Albany airport B2 Fighting ads that hit you right in the nose B3 Axelrod adopts panel's finding on Zion death B4 Congressional subcommittee is reviewing rail-car contract B5 Neediest Cases B5

title: NEW INDIAN LEADER SWEARS IN CABINET
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh puzzled citizens today when he named 15 people to his Cabinet but did not say which positions they would hold.

title: Education; Secrecy and Tenure: An Issue for High Court
description: A case before the United States Supreme Court that challenges the confidentiality accorded scholars who evaluate colleagues for tenure is being watched by universities around the country. Many of them agree with David Reisman, the Harvard University sociologist, who calls it ''a case of absolutely crucial importance to the academic life of the country.''

title: Car Sales Off, With Big 3 Hurt the Most
description: Sales of domestically produced cars and trucks fell in late November and were down sharply at the Big Three. Japan's auto makers, however, continued to show relative strength.

title: After the Summit; Rapid Change in East Is Taking a Toll on the Western Allies
description: After President Bush's meeting with Western European leaders in Brussels on Monday, it has become apparent that the rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe is creating political and personal strains within the European Community and the Western alliance, officials and diplomats here say.

title: Dinkins Picks 4 Deputy Mayors, Led by a Former Sanitation Chief
description: In his first broad move to put his stamp on City Hall, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins has chosen four deputy mayors, a corporation counsel and a press secretary to serve at the center of his administration, members of his transition team said yesterday.

title: Campbell Leads Wolves To 2d Straight Victory
description: Tony Campbell scored 26 points, including 9 straight late in the fourth quarter tonight, as the Minnesota Timberwolves held off the Nets, 92-90, to gain their first two-game winning streak.

title: International Broadcasting Corp. reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
description: b-Net income The company said the share earnings reflected a reduction of earnings applicable to common stock by the accretion of discount on redeemable preferred stock. The effect is to decrease income per share and common equivalent shares applicable to continuing operations and net income by 10 cents a share in 1989 and 1988. The loss was partly due to the company's higher depreciation and amortization expense, which grew to $6 million from $2.2 million, and to higher interest expense.

title: U.S. Refuses Private Proposal To Take Over Albany Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration refused yesterday to allow a private company to become the first to take control of a public commercial airport, Albany County's.

title: Japan's Police Use Steel Cages to Subdue Foes of Airport Expansion
description: About 6,500 policemen used large steel cages and an armored box suspended from cranes today in an effort to dislodge a dozen protesters armed with slingshots and bows who were opposing an addition to Japan's principal international airport.

title: Carter-Alomar Deal Agreed Upon
description: The first blockbuster trade of the winter baseball meetings appeared ready to drop when the Cleveland Indians agreed today to send their power-hitting center fielder, Joe Carter, to the San Diego Padres for Sandy Alomar Jr., widely ranked as the best young catching prospect in the game.

title: Pope Harshly Rebukes Lands That Foster Ecological Crisis
description: Pope John Paul II warned today that the world was caught in an ecological crisis that violates human rights and ''lays bare the depth of man's moral crisis.''

title: Edoardo Amaldi, Italian Physicist, 81
description: Prof. Edoardo Amaldi, one of the fathers of Italian physics and a pioneer in nuclear research, died today. He was 81 years old.

title: Conviction Is Vacated In Pikul Murder Case
description: A judge has cleared Joseph Pikul's name because the former Wall Street securities analyst died before an appeal of his conviction on charges of murdering his wife was decided, a lawyer said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Southern Progress, a division of Time Warner Inc., to Slaughter Hanson Advertising, Birmingham, Ala., for Cooking Light magazine.

title: John Hill Tyner, Antiques Dealer, 69
description: John Hill Tyner, a retired antiques dealer, took his own life Monday at his home in Chatham, Mass. He was 69 years old and had suffered from depression for 20 years, a family member said.

title: Henry A. Simons, 64, Ex-Ad Bureau Official
description: Henry A. Simons, former vice president and creative director of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau in Manhattan, died of a heart attack on Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: For a Lavish Touch, the Poor Spud Is Made Rich in Minutes
description: THIS time of year, the height of the entertaining season, calls for more lavish, richer food than usual. That does not mean there is no role for the microwave oven. It can speed preparation of dishes like potato gratin to gild the simplest meat or fish for company.

title: UAL Said to Have New Buyout Plan
description: The management of the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, met Monday with representatives of the pilots' union to outline a new buyout proposal that would give the unions a big stake in the airline, people familiar with the meeting said. They said the union was reviewing the proposal. Details of the plan could not be learned yesterday.

title: Bush Proposing Talks in U.S. on Global Warming
description: In a policy shift, President Bush has proposed that the United States sponsor an international conference in Washington next fall to begin negotiating a treaty on global warming.

title: Yankees-Mets Spring Series
description: For the second straight year in spring training, the Yankees and Mets will play a series of games against each other, culminating in two meetings in New York on the weekend before the beginning of regular-season play.

title: Don't Blame Program Trading, Blame the Market; The Governor's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Ammirati Deal Is About Set
description: After months of delay and frustration, Ammirati & Puris appears close to concluding its buyback from the Omnicom Group, which acquired the creatively renowned New York agency when it bought its parent company, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership of Britain, in May.

title: Cease-Fire in Manila Allows For Evacuation of Foreigners
description: As the military coup attempt against President Corazon C. Aquino continued for a sixth day, rebel troops in the city's business and financial district and the Philippine Government reached a cease-fire today long enough to begin evacuation of hundreds of foreigners trapped in their hotels by the fighting.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the collection of premiums under the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act included an incorrect assertion by a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services about refunds to be made because of repeal of the program last month. The spokesman said Medicare beneficiaries would receive no refunds of either monthly premiums or the surtax paid this year for the expanded health insurance. In fact, those who paid the surtax will receive a refund. Further developments are reported today on page A20.

title: Diet Additive Blamed In Additional Illnesses
description: Federal health officials said today that the number of cases of a rare blood disorder linked to the diet supplement L-tryptophan had risen to 707.

title: Testimony On Boeing
description: The Boeing Company maintained a secret library of classified documents through much of the 1970's at a marketing office in Kent, Wash., a retired employee of the aerospace giant testified today.

title: Service for Howard Rusk
description: A memorial service for Dr. Howard A. Rusk, founder of the Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine, will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. at Alumni Hall of the New York University School of Medicine, at First Avenue at 30th Street. Dr. Rusk died of a stroke on Nov. 4 at the age of 88.

title: Oil Production Report
description: Oil production in the non-Communist world is back where it was at its peak in 1979 before soaring prices pinched demand and created a glut, the International Energy Agency said today. ''In November, world oil supplies outside the centrally planned economies are estimated at 54.7 million barrels per day,'' the West's energy agency said in its Monthly Oil Report. The total is the highest since the third quarter of 1979. Oil output by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in November was estimated by the agency at 23.3 million barrels daily, compared with 30 million a day in 1979.

title: Georgia's Court System To Be Checked for Bias
description: In a ruling likely to change the racial makeup of Georgia's judicial system, a Federal Court here ordered the state to seek Federal approval for any changes it has made in the past 30 years in the way it elects its judges.

title: Clamor in Europe; Leipzig: Where Indignation Has Transformed Politics
description: At dinner the restless 13-year-old girl volunteered what was troubling her. ''I have such anger!'' she blurted out, talking loudly and very fast. ''I am so mad at my teachers, all of them ignorant party hacks; at the police, who are still training their video cameras at us when we march in demonstrations.''

title: Hadco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
FOOD NOTES
description: Takeout From Arcadia Arcadia, the two-star restaurant on East 62d Street in Manhattan, has branched out into the retail food business in time for the holidays. About a month ago, Anne Rosenzweig, the chef and owner, opened Out of Arcadia, a pocket-size shop in the Citicorp Center, 151 East 53d Street; 212-308-1320. Food to go is available for a quick lunch or a more elaborate catering job.

title: Effects Are Lavish For a Big-Time Bout
description: The sign said the white tigers would not be on display in their casino habitat this night. But at the new Mirage hotel there were other sights to see.

title: Fernandez Names Schools Critic to Be Top Deputy
description: In his first major appointment, Joseph A. Fernandez, who will become New York City's Schools Chancellor next month, yesterday named one of the school system's most vocal critics to be a new deputy chancellor and the chief operating officer.

title: George L. Nardi, 66, Pancreas Illness Expert
description: Dr. George L. Nardi, a surgeon who was an expert on diseases of the pancreas, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 66 years old. Dr. Nardi, who lived in Boston, received his medical degree from the University of Chicago in 1944, when he was 21. Except for service as a medical officer in the Navy, he spent his entire medical career at Massachusetts General. He was also an instructor in surgery at the Harvard Medical School.

title: Johnson Says He Pondered Quitting the Mets
description: Davey Johnson, manager of the Mets, ended two months of silence on the tumult that swamped the team at the end of last season and said today that he had been so troubled by his loss of authority, he thought about quitting.

title: Mattingly Waits As Salaries Soar
description: As Kirby Puckett, Rickey Henderson and Mark Langston escalated baseball salaries to record heights in the last two weeks, Don Mattingly watched with more than a passing interest. But Mattingly did not start counting the days - 321 from today - until he could become a free agent and see what barriers he could break.

title: Man, 25, Shot to Death In Queens Parking Lot
description: One man was killed and another was critically wounded in a Queens parking lot Monday night by two men whom they had arranged to meet to settle a drug deal, the police said.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Traded John Mitchell, pitcher, and Joaquin Contreras, outfielder, to Baltimore for Keith Hughes, outfielder, and Cesar Mejia, pitcher. TEXAS (AL) - Agreed to terms with Julio Franco, infielder, on a three-year contract extension through 1993.

title: Economic Worries Push Dow Down 11.95
description: Stock prices were broadly lower yesterday amid continued uncertainty over the economic outlook. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.95 points, to 2,741.68.

title: Medicare Refunds Due on '89 Surtax, but Not Flat Premium
