description: The more affluent Medicare beneficiaries who paid a surtax of up to $800 this year for coverage under the Catastrophic Coverage Act will get that money back under the measure Congress passed last month repealing the program.

title: Washington Talk; The Senate Endures A Pain Felt By House
description: Ethics is the issue that will not die on Capitol Hill. Even as the House passed an ethics bill last month, culminating a year of political agony for that chamber, a crisis was building in the Senate.

title: U.S. Panel Reviews A Contract to Build Taipei Subway Cars
description: A Congressional subcommittee is investigating the $170 million contract that a Japanese-owned rail car manufacturer in Yonkers won earlier this year to build subway cars for a new mass transit system in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: American Charged in El Salvador
description: An American religious worker who was arrested after the police found ammunition and explosives buried in her backyard was charged with terrorism by Salvadoran authorities late today.

title: Recount Set in a Race in Taiwan
description: The Government was forced to agree today to a recount in an important local race. The recount was ordered after the election victory over the weekend by the Nationalist Party, which set off accusations of fraud and led to a clash between the police and supporters of the opposition.

title: De Gustibus; Saying 'Cheese' Sometimes Makes Italians Frown
description: PARMIGIANO REGGIANO, an indispensable cheese in Italian cooking, is commonly known in English as Parmesan. But much is often lost in the translation.

title: D.& B. Clients Cautioned On Campeau
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the credit-rating company, told clients yesterday that it was no longer advising them to ship goods to the Campeau Corporation's department stores because of the delay in finding bidders for the company's Bloomingdale's stores, financial and manufacturing executives said.

title: U.S. Rebuffs Trade Critics
description: The United States hit back today at critics of the unilateral action it has taken on trade issues, saying others did the same and should not pass judgment.

title: STUDY CHALLENGES HIGH-RISE SAFETY
description: Scientists studying the effect of sonic booms on Los Angeles buildings have determined that skyscrapers may be more vulnerable to earthquakes than previously believed.

title: Corrections
description: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law Page on Friday gave an outdated name for a Boston law firm.

title: Stocks Take Taiwan on Giddy Ride
description: To investors in the Taiwan stock market, ''research'' often means talking to a fortune teller, and ''long-term investments'' tend to be measured in weeks instead of years. But what the Taiwan Stock Exchange lacks in pinstripes and gravity, it makes up for in size and performance.

title: 4 Hurt in Pakistan Bombing
description: A bomb exploded in a crowded bazaar tonight, hurling shrapnel that wounded four people, the police said. No one claimed responsibility and no arrests were made. Similar bombings in this border city have been blamed on agents of the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul, the Afghan capital.

title: Metro Datelines; Ex-Legislator Pleads Guilty in a Tax Case
description: Former State Representative Joseph Walkovich pleaded guilty yesterday to failing to file a Federal tax return for 1985.

title: Review/Art; Bonnard's Graphics Illuminate His Entire Output
description: ''Pierre Bonnard: The Graphic Art'' is a major contribution to the understanding of a French modernist revered for the lushness and luminosity of his color and light and for his discreet yet voluptuous vision. Bonnard (1867-1947) arouses such loyalty not only because of the poetry of his painting but also because of its integrity. There is a very strong sense of him as an artist beyond fashion whose men and women prefer introspection to confrontation and whose paintings are not in a hurry to tell anybody anything.

title: Review/Dance; Comic Moves and Words That Prick the Heart
description: Stephan Koplowitz is a one-note choreographer. Where will he go from here? one wonders after each new performance of his theater-dances. And then he does himself one better, mining the same vein in deeper and more poignantly funny ways.

title: Australia Tobacco Bans
description: Australia plans to ban advertising of tobacco products in newspapers and magazines, the Health Minister, Neal Blewett, said today. Mr. Blewett said legislation covering print media will be introduced next year and take effect within 12 months of being passed by Parliament. Cigarette and other tobacco advertising has been banned from Australian television since 1976.

title: Koch Urges Tough Stance On the Budget
description: In what amounted to a political valedictory, Mayor Edward I. Koch offered yesterday an ardent summation of his 12-year tenure, advised his successor to ''be not afraid'' and strongly criticized the Federal Government as being unfair to the city.

title: Dinkins Asking Donors To Pay for His Inaugural
description: Rebuffed in his effort to use campaign funds for inaugural expenses, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins will ask big contributors for up to $250,000 for an inaugural party for 6,000 to 8,000 people.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 6
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 114, Hornets 101: Larry Bird had 13 rebounds, 11 assists and 11 points last night as Boston beat the Hornets at Charlotte, N.C., and improved its record to 7-0 against the Hornets. Bird was 4 for 13 from the field. But after the Hornets closed to 66-59 with 6:09 left in the the third quarter, he made two jumpers that capped a 13-4 run. Muggsy Bogues scored a career-high 20 points for Charlotte on 10-for-15 shooting and added 11 assists.(AP) Jazz 94, Cavaliers 80: Karl Malone extended his streak of 20-point games to 15 and grabbed 19 rebounds as Utah beat Cleveland at Richfield, Ohio. Malone scored 21 points and Bob Hansen also scored 21 for Utah. The Jazz led by 51-47 at halftime and outscored the Cavaliers, 29-14, in the third quarter as Cleveland shot 4 for 23. (AP) Trail Blazers 113, Heat 107: Terry Porter and Clyde Drexler scored 26 points each and made two free throws apiece in the final 3.5 seconds as Portland held off Miami. Portland has won nine of its last 10 games. The Trail Blazers are 10 games over .500 (14-4) for the first time since the end of the 1987-88 season, when they finished at 53-29. Miami lost its eighth straight. (AP) Bulls 119, Nuggets 99: Michael Jordan scored 23 of his 35 points in the third quarter and grabbed a career-high 17 rebounds as Chicago snapped Denver's seven-game winning streak at Chicago. The loss was Denver's sixth straight in Chicago, going back to January 1984. It was Chicago's third straight victory. Jordan outscored Denver by himself in the third period, 23-18. (AP) Mavericks 107, Warriors 88: Derek Harper scored 27 points and a reserve, Brad Davis, had 10 points during a key second-half spurt as Dallas routed Golden State at Dallas. Davis led a 22-9 run late in the third quarter and early in the final period that produced a 97-79 Dallas lead that Dallas protected the rest of the way for its third victory in four starts under its interim coach, Richie Adubato. The Warriors, losing for the fifth time in six games, were led by Chris Mullin's 27 points.(AP) N.H.L. Blues 2, Red Wings 2: Sergio Momesso scored a power-play goal midway through the final period to lift St. Louis into a 2-2 tie with the Red Wings at Detroit. After Gerard Gallant gave Detroit a 2-1 lead 47 seconds into the third period, Momesso capitalized on a penalty to the Red Wing rookie, Sheldon Kennedy. Momesso converted Tony Hrkac's centering pass from the edge of the goal crease for his ninth goal to pull the Blues even.(AP) Capitals 4, Flyers 3: Alan May scored twice and Kelly Miller broke a third-period tie to lead Washington to victory over the Flyers at Philadelphia. The Flyers' Dave Poulin missed the net from the crease with 7 seconds to go as the Washington goaltender, Bob Mason, lay sprawled on the ice. It was the fourth straight road victory for the Capitals, who are 4-1 in their last five games.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Illinois 74, Florida 69: Marcus Liberty scored 21 points and Kendall Gill got 19 to lead Illinois (3-0) over Florida at Gainesville, Fla. The Illini, winning for the 26th time in the last 27 games in which Gill has played, scored the first 5 points of the second half to pull away from a 34-34 halftime tie. Florida rallied to tie the game at 63-63 on Renaldo Garcia's jumper in the lane, but a pair of free throws by Liberty put Illinois up for good with 5:18 to go. Dwayne Schintzius led Florida with 19 points. (AP) Arkansas 90, Mississippi 76: Todd Day scored 15 of his 18 points in the second half as Arkansas rallied from a 9-point halftime deficit and beat Mississippi. Ron Huery scored 14 of his 21 points in the second half for Arkansas (4-0). Lee Mayberry scored 11 of his 16 point in the second half. Mississippi (0-4) put on a spurt late in the first half and led by 44-35 at halftime. Tim Jumper and John Matthews led the Rebels with 18 each. (AP) Brooklyn College 105, Molloy 66: Moses Reiner had 19 points as Brooklyn College snapped a 10-game losing streak that extended over two seasons by routing Molloy, which has not won this season. Dexter Gordon had 13 points for the Kingsmen (1-2). Russell Smith of the Lions (0-8) had a game-high 23 points.(AP) Lafayette 81, Columbia 73: Andy Wescoe scored 24 points, including six free throws in the final 87 seconds, leading Lafayette over Columbia. Bruce Stankavage scored 16 points for Lafayette and Craig White 14. Buck Jenkins scored 14 for Columbia and Eric Speaker 10.(AP) Indiana 81, Notre Dame 72: Calbert Cheaney led Indiana's youth movement with 20 points as the 14th-ranked Hoosiers beat Notre Dame at Bloomington, Ind. Indiana (4-0) got help from a poor Notre Dame first half, in which the Irish committed 16 turnovers. Indiana had only 12 turnovers for the game. The Irish (1-2) closed to 70-63 with 1:50 left, but Indiana refused to yield a.(AP) Virginia Tech 76, Alabama 75: Rod Wheeler made a 3-pointer with 2:23 left at Blacksburg, Va., and Virginia Tech went on to upset Alabama. Robert Horry's 15-footer from the baseline gave Alabama (4-1) its last lead at 64-63 with 2:43 remaining. Then Wheeler put the Hokies ahead to stay on a jumper from the top of the key and followed 10 seconds later with a pair of free throws to give Virginia Tech (2-1) a 68-64 edge. (AP)

title: Watching The Elders Play Ball
description: Finally wrestle steering wheel into going to ball park. Can't put it off any longer. Have to see for myself how the old boys are doing in the Senior Professional Baseball Association.

title: Clabir Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $299,000.

title: Infiltrators Slain, Israelis Say
description: Israeli troops killed five heavily armed Arab guerrillas today after the gunmen crossed into Israel from Egypt through the Sinai, the army said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lawyer Takes Over At Troubled Cineplex
description: LEAD: Allen Karp, who is now responsible for running the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, the Toronto-based movie theater chain, says ''Star Wars'' is his favorite film.

title: To Cut Agency Abuses, Government Lists Its Risks
description: In the first stage of a process intended to combat mismanagement and abuse, the Office of Management and Budget has identified areas of high risk in the way the Government handles its business, especially in contracting, credit and insurance programs and financial accounting systems.

title: Bush Aides Say Gorbachev Sees Economy as Key
description: In a discussion of Soviet domestic problems with President Bush in Malta, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called his campaign to end consumer shortages in the Soviet Union ''the ultimate test'' of his leadership, senior Administration officials said today. The Soviet leader reportedly left some American officials with the impression that he was at a loss over how to solve his economic problems.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE place, Seventh Avenue in the 50's. Sammye Johnson is looking at displays of sweat shirts and T-shirts, those hanging in shop windows and those displayed on vendor stands. She overhears the following conversation between a mother and her daughter, who is about 8 years old:

title: Canadian Bid On '91 Games
description: A Canadian television network is close to signing a deal to cover the 1991 Pan American Games in Havana, which would allow the Cubans to sidestep a United States embargo, sources close to the organizers said today.

title: Healthcare International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss was due at least in part to start-up costs at two facilities.

title: Le Croissant Executive Leaves to Form Agency
description: Le Croissant Shop is losing le marketing director, but the advertising industry is gaining a new agency. Arnold E. Rivera. the former director of operations, marketing and public relations for the chain of bakeries, has formed Rivera & Robinson Advertising in New York with Marguerite E. Robinson and Mark J. Schimmel, who will continue to run Schimmel & Robinson Advertising, a general ad agency.

title: New Bulgaria Chief Hints at Giving Up Party's Dominance
description: Bulgaria's new Communist leader indicated today that his party's leading role in Government will be an open question as he initiates reforms.

title: Entwistle Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Offers to Sell China Million Tons of Subsidized Wheat
description: The United States offered today to sell one million metric tons of subsidized wheat to China in what would be the first such sale since China's army crushed a pro-democracy movement in June.

title: Paul Brown Honored
description: Paul Brown, who coached championship teams in high school, college and the pros, and the former Notre Dame athletic director Ed (Moose) Krause were honored last night by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Don't Blame Program Trading, Blame the Market; Trouble With Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES I.B.M. will reduce its domestic work force by more than 10,000 and take a $2.3 billion charge against earnings in the fourth quarter. It said it hoped to reduce its costs by $1 billion a year. But some critics said I.B.M. had not gone far enough to address its problems in a difficult and highly competitive market. [ Page D1. ] Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon's chairman, is in talks about investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Shearson Lehman Hutton in exchange for a large stake in the brokerage, people on Wall Street said. [ D1. ] Dun & Bradstreet told clients that it was no longer advising them to ship goods to Campeau's department stores because of the delay in finding bidders for Campeau's Bloomingdale's stores, financial and manufacturing executives said. [ D5. ] Mellon Bank will buy 54 Philadelphia-area branches from Meritor Savings Bank. [ D2. ] Corning will receive $25 million from Sumitomo Electric in an out-of-court settlement of a patent infringement suit. [ D5. ] USX will not alter its strategy as a result of the holdings of Carl C. Icahn, its chairman said. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY Sales of domestically produced cars and trucks fell in late November and were down sharply at the Big Three auto makers. But the Japanese continued to show relative strength. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S. and Canada have decided to speed up tariff cuts covering $6 billion in trade. The decision affects chemicals, pharmaceuticals, printed circuit boards, scientific instruments, electric motors and other items and could mean cheaper prices. [ D1. ] The U.S. offered to sell to China a million metric tons of subsidized wheat, in what would be the first such deal since China's army crushed a pro-democracy movement in June. [ D2. ] Mexico and its creditor banks have nearly completed negotiations for refinancing the nation's $48 billion in medium- and long-term debt, Mexico's leading negotiator said. [ D19. ] MARKETS Stock prices were broadly lower amid continued uncertainty over the economic outlook. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.95 points, to 2,741.68. [ D12. ] Prices of Treasury securities traded in a very narrow range on extremely light volume. [ D19. ] Yields were mixed on C.D.'s and money market accounts for the week ended yesterday. [ D6. ] The West German mark continued to dominate foreign exchange trading, with traders focusing on West Germany's potential for trade with its eastern neighbors, dealers said. [ D20. ] Copper futures fell sharply after a downturn in demand. [ D20. ] Liv Ullmann appeared as a character witness for James T. Sherwin of GAF, at his trial on charges of stock manipulation. [ D5. ] TECHNOLOGY The technology does not exist commercially to break down most multilayered plastic packaging into its individual resins and reclaim them for re-use as packaging. [ D10. ] A new machine combines technology, merchandising and gambling to encourage recycling. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS ''Other People's Money'' is a melodrama with a comic edge that deals with takeovers. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Index arbitrage trading appears to have slumped dramatically in recent weeks. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D12. ] Slater Hanft Martin has captured about half of Sony's American advertising. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D23. ]

title: Yields Are Mixed for Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Foul Mystery of North River
description: Some call it ''the Versailles of sewage treatment,'' and for good reason. The majestic North River Water Pollution Control Plant on Harlem's western waterfront is a delight to behold. Its sweeping arches, graceful lines and breathtaking vistas engage the eye and the imagination.

title: Metro Datelines; Tentative Accord Ends Bus Strike
description: New York Bus Service and its striking drivers reached tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract. It will allow service to resume this morning for 13,000 express bus riders from the north Bronx.

title: Germany's Trade Potential Helps Mark to Dominate
description: The mark continued to dominate foreign exchange trading yesterday, with traders focusing on West Germany's potential for trade with its eastern neighbors, dealers said.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Government Can Be Sued for Labor Role
description: The Supreme Court today expanded the scope of one of the most important Federal civil rights laws, ruling that state and local governments can be sued for damages if they intervene improperly in labor negotiations.

title: Gabor's Sentence Delayed
description: A judge today delayed a requirement that the actress Zsa Zsa Gabor spend 72 hours in jail and pay fines totaling $2,937 until after appeal of her misdemeanor conviction for slapping a police officer. But the judge, Charles G. Rubin of Municipal Court, refused to delay the 120 hours of community service that was also a part of the sentence. Miss Gabor has already begun that service by working at a women's shelter in Venice, Calif., said her attorney, Harrison Bull.

title: Mellon Bank to Buy 54 of Meritor's Units
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, returning to the offensive after its severe losses of 1987 and 1988, announced an agreement yesterday to buy 54 Philadelphia-area branches from the Meritor Savings Bank.

title: Ambrit Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss of discontinued operations of $299,000.

title: Niger in First Vote Since '60
description: Voters in this West African country go to the polls on Sunday in the first presidential and legislative elections since independence from France in 1960. About three million voters are expected at the polls to elect 93 deputies to Parliament. President Ali Seybou faces no opposition in the election. In 1987, voters approved a national charter that served as the basis for the new Constitution, which was approved on Sept. 24. Under the Constitution, the President serves for seven years. The previous Constitution was suspended in 1974 by Lieut. Col. Seyni Kountche, who took power in a military coup.

title: Carriage Drivers Win a Stay
description: Carriage drivers have obtained a temporary restraining order while they prepare a court challenge to a city law restricting the use of the horse-drawn taxis in midtown Manhattan. The law, which was sought by animal rights organizations and approved by the City Council over Mayor Koch's veto, bars the carriages from midtown for most of the day.

title: When He Sips, Vintners Tremble
description: IN a Bordeaux restaurant a few weeks ago, a prominent American wine importer ordered a 1982 Chateau La Grave Trigant de Boisset, from a little-known property in Pomerol. His guests, all professionally involved with wine, found it pleasant.

title: Why a Squeezable Bottle Is Under Attack
description: When the H. J. Heinz Company introduced a squeezable plastic bottle for its ketchup in 1983, the consumer-products industry hailed it as a major advance. The diner could gently squeeze out ketchup with far more accuracy than the conventional glass bottle allowed, yet the ketchup could last without spoiling almost as long as that in a glass bottle.

title: Vermont Court Blocks Homes in Deer Habitat
description: The Vermont Supreme Court has blocked the construction of a vacation-home development on the ground that it would deprive about 20 whitetail deer of a vital winter habitat.

title: Great Northern Offer Extended
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation extended its $3.6 billion offer for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation by one week until next Monday. The Atlanta-based forest-products company, whose $63-a-share offer had been rejected by Great Northern, also said that as of Monday more than 32.3 million shares, or nearly 59 percent of Great Northern's stock, had been tendered.

title: Grafton Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,950,000 for the quarter and $17,624,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after a loss of $2,141,000 from discontinued operations. d-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $5,784,000, and an extraordinary credit of $578,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said the discontinued operations included results from operations planned for disposal. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 50 Arts Organizations Receive Gift Technology
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced that the International Business Machines Corporation and Nynex Business Centers have donated computers, software and technical support to 50 arts organizations around the country. Each organization also received a one-time $1,000 grant from Nynex. The arts organizations will use the donation to improve their business operations.

title: Pro Bono
description: * The Foundation for Religious Retirement, an organization devoted to the care of retired women employees of the Archdiocese of Milwaukee, has begun a $1 million fund-raising campaign with advertising support from Cramer-Krasselt Advertising, Milwaukee.

title: Clamor in Europe; Disgraced East Germans Under House Arrest
description: Erich Honecker and top members of his fallen leadership were placed under house arrest by the authorities today as a furious and impatient public increasingly took the hunt for corrupt and repressive former officials into its own hands.

title: American Red Cross Campaign by Cabot
description: Cabot Advertising in Boston makes its national, pro-bono television advertising debut on Dec. 15 with a new and unusual campaign for the American Red Cross urging people to give blood. In an appealingly languorous style that diverges from the dire mood of much public service advertising, the all-text spot tells people, ''When you give blood, you give another birthday party, another wedding anniversary, another day at the beach, another night under the stars, another talk with a friend, another laugh, another hug, another chance.'' The words are accompanied by a pianist slowly playing ''Makin' Whoopee.''

title: Knicks Hold Off the Sixers as Ewing Scores 32
description: The Knick fans in the crowd cheered loudly last night at the pregame announcement that Charles Barkley was suffering from a viral infection and would not play for Philadelphia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International Inc., Chicago, a graphics industry supplier, promoted William A. Whitescarver to executive vice president and president of its new AM Graphics Equipment Group.

title: Revlon Head Reported in Shearson Talks
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc., is in talks about investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in exchange for a large stake in the brokerage, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Court Finds French Author Plagiarized 'Gone With Wind'
description: A French author and her publisher were ordered today to pay more than $330,000 in damages after a court ruled that she had plagiarized Margaret Mitchell's ''Gone With the Wind'' when writing her best-selling novel ''The Blue Bicycle.''

title: Campeau Faults D.& B.
description: The Campeau Corporation yesterday sharply criticized Dun & Bradstreet Inc., the credit-rating company, for advising its clients against further merchandise shipments to its stores because of a delay in the proposed sale of its Bloomingdale's department store chain.

title: California Panel Votes to Ban Sales of Offshore Oil Leases
description: California's State Lands Commission voted today to ban the sale of new oil leases in the state's offshore waters that are not already leased or declared off limits for drilling.

title: Boston Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $6,500,000 in pretax gains on the sale of 19 percent of its Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock holdings.

title: Fixing Fabric, the Older the Better
description: ''IF it's a fabric, we can fix it.'' This is the slogan at Helene Von Rosenstiel's Brooklyn studio. A textile conservator, Ms. Von Rosenstiel restores everything from wedding gowns to military uniforms, quilts and christening dresses. She even sewed new sequins on one of the ruby slippers that Judy Garland wore in ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Nicaragua Shaping a Risky New Strategy to Gain Leverage Against U.S.
description: A light plane that crashed while carrying sophisticated antiaircraft missiles from Nicaragua to Salvadoran rebels was part of a risky new Nicaraguan strategy to gain negotiating leverage against the United States, diplomats and Sandinista officials say.

title: Reviews/Television; '48 Hours' Goes 'Inside West Point'
description: Viewers of ''Inside West Point,'' tonight's report on ''48 Hours,'' may conclude that the United States Military Academy is a funny farm. Beginning at 8 P.M. on CBS, the camera concentrates on robotic plebes chugging along corridors at 120 steps a minute, making spastic 90-degree turns and hollering ''Sir!'' at any upperclassman who decides to pick on them. At lunch in the Bedlamic cafeteria, they yell for permission to pour the juice or cut the pie. ''You don't find a lot of the things we do funny?'' asks a fourth-classman named Scott Ryan, who is ordered to undertake a four-hour walking experience -marching back and forth in full gear - for failing to deliver the mail on time.

title: Monsanto Offer
description: The Monsanto Company is offering $100 million in debentures due 2009 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 8 7/8 percent debentures were priced at 99.85 to yield 9 percent, or about 11 basis points more than the Treasury's 30-year bond issue. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Noncallable for life, the issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Article 6 of Soviet Charter
description: Calls are mounting in the Soviet Union for the repeal of Article 6 of the Constitution, which insures Communist Party dominance. Here is the text of the article.

title: U.S.-Soviet Talks on Grain
description: United States and Soviet officials today ended a first round of talks on a new long-term grain pact, and both sides said the negotiations were helped by the American offers of economic cooperation advanced at the Malta summit meeting.

title: Review/Music; Trio's Ravel Is Shimmers And Mists
description: The Leonardo Trio, formed in 1985 by members of several larger New York chamber groups, made a strong impression in its New York debut concert on Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y. The players - Cameron Grant, pianist; Erica Kiesewetter, violinist, and Jonathan Spitz, cellist -bring an equal measure of polish, precision and warmth to the group endeavor, and their collective sound is impeccably balanced.

title: The Wild West Meets Victoriana
description: RALPH (LAUREN) would love it. Victoria (the Queen) would not be amused.

title: Sears Weighs Package Tours
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it might enter the package-vacation business.

title: DRUG RING SUSPECT GUILTY IN CAPITAL
description: After a three-month trial in which heavy precautions were taken to protect jurors and witnesses from possible reprisals, a 24-year-old Washington man was convicted today of operating a drug ring that prosecutors said distributed up to one-third of the cocaine in the nation's capital.

title: Reading & Bates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $89,000 and $11,951,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Sakowitz And Bonwit Sale Likely
description: Bonwit Teller, the century-old women's specialty store chain, and Sakowitz Inc., the Houston-based fashion retailer, are expected to be put up for sale soon by the L. J. Hooker Corporation, the American division of the financially distressed Hooker Corporation of Australia.

title: Fetal Research Depends on Destruction of Life; No Soliciting Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Shake-Up Pleases Penguins
description: Actions sometimes speak louder than words and the same can be said for apparel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page yesterday about national educational goals misattributed the 1983 report ''A Nation at Risk.'' The report was written by the National Commission on Excellence in Education; Diane Ravitch, a professor at Columbia University's Teachers College, was not a co-author and has never been a member of the commission.

title: Money Fund Yields Are Up
description: For the first time in four weeks, yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were all up for the week that ended yesterday.

title: ADVANCE REPORTED ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: Egypt has agreed, with some conditions, to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's plan to prepare for a dialogue between Israeli and Palestinian representatives, the State Department said today.

title: POLICE SAY WOMAN KIDNAPPED BOY TO HAVE HIM BEG FOR CRACK
description: A Staten Island woman was charged yesterday with kidnapping the 5-year-old son of a friend and using the boy to panhandle for money for crack, the police said.

title: CBS Is Said to Be Courting 'Cosby' Producer of NBC
description: CBS executives have asked Marcy Carsey, an owner of the most successful comedy production company in television, to take over the network's beleaguered entertainment division, several Hollywood production executives said yesterday.

title: Article 920289 -- No Title
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon, is negotiating the investment of about $250 million in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as part of a plan to inject new capital into the brokerage firm in exchange for a large stake in it, Wall Street executives familiar with the details of the talks said yesterday.

title: Southern Co. reports earnings for 12mo to Oct 31
It's Fade-Out for the Cheap Film As Hollywood's Budgets Soar
description: Movie studios are always trying to rein in their budgets. But once again the costs of making a movie are galloping away.

title: Many Donors Increase Gifts For Neediest
description: The desire to give more than the immediate gift is a theme that runs through letters written by donors to the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: McGraw-Hill to Cut 1,000 Jobs
description: McGraw-Hill Inc., the publishing and information services company, said yesterday that it would eliminate more than 1,000 jobs, revamp its organizational structure and take other streamlining steps that will result in a $220 million pretax charge to earnings.

title: Good for a Longbow, Great for a Cabinet
description: LEAD: As a cabinet wood, yew could never be accused of hogging the limelight; perhaps there was too much competition from more dramatic contestants. Instead, it will forever be associated in history with the English longbow.

title: 5 Colombians Arrested By Swiss in Drug Case
description: The police in this southern Swiss city said today that they arrested five Colombian drug traffickers late last month and news reports said they included Severo Escobar, a nephew of the fugitive Colombian drug trafficker Pablo Escobar.

title: Twins Lose Reardon to Red Sox But Keep Hrbek for $14 Million
description: The free-agent market continued to upstage the trade market at baseball's winter meetings today when Jeff Reardon left the Minnesota Twins and signed a three-year contract with the Boston Red Sox for a total of $6.8 million.

title: B'nai B'rith Is Threatening To Expel Its Women's Unit
description: B'nai B'rith International is ready to expel its 120,000-member women's unit for declaring itself ''a separate, autonomous organization'' that is identified with B'nai B'rith but not subject to its will.

title: Banks Lost $744 Million in Quarter
description: The nation's banks lost $744 million from July to September after earning record profits in the first half of the year, Government regulators said today.

title: Diet Pepsi Song Upsets Diet Coke Agency
description: Lintas New York, the advertising agency for Diet Coke, says Diet Pepsi is playing its song.

title: G-III Apparel Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago quarter's net income and share earnings are on a pro forma basis. The company's operating subsidiaries are G-III Leather Fashions Inc. and Siena Leather Ltd. During the quarter ended Oct. 31, 1988, G-III Leather Fashions was treated as a subchapter S corporation. For such quarter, net income on a pro forma basis is derived after a provision for income taxes which would have resulted had G-III Leather Fashions been a C Corporation for the year- ago quarter.

title: The Young Alvin Ailey's Lesson on Arts in School
description: To the Editor:

title: For Aquino, Tempered Tough Steps
description: President Corazon C. Aquino, struggling to save her Government, is facing a critical choice: whether to pursue common ground with her opponents or order a crackdown that would invite comparisons to her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: With Assist From Rangers Turn Back Devils
description: The memories were rather ingrained for the Rangers from their previous meeting with the Devils. They had a three-goal lead early in the last period and ended up losing in overtime.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FOR safety, efficiency and economy, your furnace should be professionally inspected and serviced before the heating season. Just as important for efficiency and economy is an annual inspection and tuneup of the heating system's delivery points: ducts and registers in hot-air systems; radiators and convectors in steam and hot-water systems. Usually, an amateur can do this easily.

title: Diet Additive Blamed In Additional Illnesses
description: Federal health officials said Tuesday that the number of cases of a rare blood disorder linked to the diet supplement L-tryptophan had risen to 707.

title: Infusion Set At Merabank
description: The Federal Office of Thrift Supervision has approved a $450 million capital infusion from the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation to its troubled Merabank subsidiary, the company said today.

title: Fetal Research Depends on Destruction of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Parent & Child
description: FOR the children of divorced parents, performing in the annual holiday pageant at school can be a particularly stressful experience. What should be a chance for them to show off and have fun turns instead into a painful reminder of the break in their family.

title: Mrs. Aquino Fights the Odds
description: The fighting in the Philippines has produced only losers. Military rebels have failed to shoot their way into power. President Corazon Aquino has suffered serious damage. The biggest casualty of all could be the Philippines' chances of consolidating democratic institutions and joining the East Asian economic boom.

title: IND Lines Resume Local Service on West Side
description: Partial service on the IND lines in Harlem and on the West Side resumed yesterday in time for the morning rush hour. A, B and D trains made all local stops, but C trains, which usually travel between Queens and the Bronx, were again turned around, at the northern terminus at 59th Street-Columbus Circle.

title: Metro Datelines; Worker Is Trapped As a Building Falls
description: An injured construction worker was trapped in rubble for two and a half hours today when a vacant building on the Upper East Side collapsed, the police said.

title: Advance Circuits Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: Year-ago quarter included tax benefit of $380,000 from losses realized on California operations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Ben Arno and Stephen Harty have been named senior vice presidents at Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Morgan Sells 'Junk' Issue
description: Investment bankers at Morgan Stanley & Company underwrote an $850 million ''junk bond'' offering yesterday. The proceeds from the offering will finance the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation's acquisition of the Container Corporation of America and the recapitalization of the combined companies, which will be done by a newly formed entity jointly owned by Morgan and a Jefferson Smurfit affiliate.

title: Some basic facts are good guides through a thicket of confusion toward a healthy diet.
description: Even with all the attention now being paid to the health effects of various fats and oils, Americans seem more confused than ever about what to eat to preserve their hearts and blood vessels.

title: Keeping The Young In Trim
description: JILLIAN ROLAND sat outside for nearly an hour before working up enough courage to go in. Finally, she took a deep breath, clenched her pocketbook and her father's hand and took a step into adulthood.

title: Gottschalks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $166,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting, for the 9 months.

title: Market Place; The New Lure Of 'Junk Bonds'
description: WHILE their numbers are small, a few professional money managers are beginning to edge back into the ''junk bond'' market, attracted by the flea-market philosophy that almost anything can be sold if the price is low enough.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Canon U.S.A. to Grey Advertising, its agency for the Sure Shot and Snappy cameras, for print advertising and promotional work for its 35-millimeter SLR camera lines, with a budget that could reach $5 million annually.

title: Command & Control
description: ''Two minutes to midnight'' was the symbol used by scientists worried about a world approaching nuclear war. The hands of their analogue clock have been moving counterclockwise as the threat recedes; it seems almost to be morning in the world.

title: Reports of 'Anxiety Attack' Denied by Giants' Moore
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said today that there would be no changing of the guard. He said Eric Moore, who missed most of Sunday's 24-17 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles under cloudy circumstances, would continue to play offensive right guard when the Giants (9-4) met the Broncos (10-3) on Sunday in Denver.

title: Fast 'Maglev' Trains vs. Short Air Trips
description: To the Editor:

title: Boxing's Lost-Luster Factor
description: rrWhen a popular champion loses his luster, boxing judges are sometimes the last to know. Or at least the last to acknowledge it on their scorecards. More than a decade ago, many people thought that Muhammad Ali lost to Ken Norton at Yankee Stadium and to Jimmy Young in Landover, Md. The judges in those heavyweight title bouts, apparently still blinded by Ali's flash and dash, awarded him the decision each time. But when Ali was outpunched by Leon Spinks in 1978, the judges were suddenly ready to accept his aging. Spinks was awarded a split decision that even Ali accepted.

title: The Eameses' Modernism: Democratic Yet Still Elite
description: CHARLES EAMES was the Benjamin Franklin of American design. Not that any one Eames artifact, not even his landmark plywood chair, was the lightning rod for modernism in the United States. Rather, he illuminated mid-20th-century design through invention and artistry.

title: Car Imports Up in Japan
description: Sales of imported vehicles in Japan are expected to total just under 180,000 units in 1989, up from a record 133,583 in 1988, an official of the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. The growth was helped by Japanese tax revision, increased demand for luxury cars, low interest rates and increases in disposable income, he said.

title: Advice for Prospective Volunteers at Charitable Organizations
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH: Neurology; Hopeful Findings for Premenstrual Syndrome
description: A new study suggests that depression and some other symptoms of premenstrual syndrome can be significantly reduced with an obesity drug that affects a major transmitter chemical in the brain.

title: Christmas Programs At World Trade Center
description: ''Twelve Noons of Christmas,'' a series of free afternoon performances, is to feature performers who figure into the lyrics of the song ''The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' The Turtles, a rock group, will appear in the ''Two Turtle Doves'' concert today at 12:30 P.M. on the mezzanine level of One World Trade Center, reached from the Church Street entrance.

title: Bonn Expected to Award Cellular Contract
description: West Germany is expected to announce today that it has awarded a license to build its first private cellular telephone system to a consortium that includes the Pacific Telesis Group, the regional Bell telephone company based in San Francisco.

title: Phelps Dodge Taking $375 Million Write-Off
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's leading copper producer, said today that it would take a $375 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings after writing down the value of several closed mines.

title: LDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The 1988 periods were restated for pooling of interests in January. Both year-ago periods' shares outstanding and year-ago third quarter's per share earnings were adjusted to reflect retroactive effect of 5 percent common stock dividend declared in October. The year-ago 9 months' net income and per share earnings included a non-recurring benefit of $1.4 million, or 29 cents a share, due to accounting changes.

title: Democrat Penalized by Church In Abortion Stand Wins Election
description: A Democrat who had been barred by the Roman Catholic Bishop here from receiving communion because of her support for abortion rights won election to the California Senate Tuesday night. The result tipped the balance of the Legislature in favor of abortion rights for the first time in several years.

title: France Will Stop Aid to Comoros Unless Mercenaries Leave
description: France has decided to cut off aid to the Comoro Islands until European mercenaries who seized control there 10 days ago leave the archipelago, Government officials here said today.

title: Kingfisher in Bid For Dixons Group
description: Kingfisher P.L.C., one of Britain's largest retailers, made a hostile $724 million offer for the Dixons Group P.L.C., a consumer electronics retailer. The bid values Dixons at $1.88 a share.

title: Reviews/Music; Faith Esham, From Liszt To Hindemith
description: Like so many other singers who have made their professional impact principally on the opera stage, Faith Esham appears to look longingly at recitals. Here one tests a different set of skills. Nimbleness replaces brute strength, and the voice alone creates the sense of theater.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Graphs showing the sources that cover U.S. health care; what Medicare saved by shifting to employers the bulk of the cost of medical care for workers age 65 and over (source: Federal Health Care Financing Administration) (NYT); Scramble on Health-Care Costs
description: The Government and private industry are scrambling to make each other pay billions of dollars in medical bills for the elderly and the working poor.

title: U.S. Offers Moscow a Few Ideas On How to Improve Its Economy
description: The Soviet Union received some free economic advice from American officials during the Malta summit meeting on how Moscow could put a chicken in every pot - or least some soap in every washroom.

title: Mets Give a Stunned Myers to Reds for Franco
description: The Mets resumed the sweeping overhaul of their team tonight when they traded Randy Myers to the Cincinnati Reds for John Franco in an unusual exchange of two of the star left-handed relievers in baseball.

title: Steven Gethers, 67, Writer for Television
description: Steven Gethers, a writer and director for ''Playhouse 90'' and other television drama programs, died of lung cancer on Monday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 67 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, an appliance maker, said a Federal judge had approved a $6.25 million settlement of shareholders' lawsuits that accused company officials of securities law violations.

title: Lithuanians Vote to End Communists' Monopoly
description: The Lithuanian Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to abolish the Communist Party's political monopoly in Lithuania, but fell barely short of the number of votes needed to change the constitution.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Posts A Big Loss For the Year
description: REALIZING the low expectations of advertising executives and investors who had criticized its erratic growth strategy and high operating costs, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company yesterday reported a substantial net loss for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

title: RIGHT-TO-DIE CASE GETS FIRST HEARING IN SUPREME COURT
description: Both sides of a right-to-die case received a skeptical hearing today at the Supreme Court, where the Justices spent much of an hourlong argument probing for a narrow basis on which to resolve a question as profound as ever reaches them.

title: Czech Communist Party Struggling to Stay Calm
description: In the face of widespread protest and with the threat of a new general strike, the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia is seeking to stave off disarray and panic among its members and leaders.

title: RAPE GUILTY PLEA, AFTER ACQUITTAL
description: A man who was acquitted in a Florida rape case in which the jury foreman said the victim had ''asked for it'' pleaded guilty on Tuesday to raping a woman in Decatur, Ga., and was sentenced to life in prison.

title: A Wall Running Back Into History
description: IN 1983, a small group of UCLA architects, planners and historians formed the Power of Place, a nonprofit corporation whose mission is to identify historic sites important to Los Angeles. Their idea is to establish a stronger sense of place in a city whose residents often quote Gertrude Stein's famous line about Oakland, Calif.: ''There is no there there.''

title: Gulfstream To Be Sold By Chrysler
description: Reacting to deepening difficulties in the domestic automobile industry, the Chrysler Corporation today put its military electronics and Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiaries up for sale.

title: Results Plus
description: EXHIBITION HOCKEY Oilers 6, Khimik Voskresensk 2 Esa Tikkanen set up three goals last night as Edmonton defeated the Soviet team before only 6,804 spectators in the Oilers' stadium in Alberta. Joe Murphy had a goal and an assist and Steve Smith two assists. Khimik is one of four Soviet teams touring the 21 cities of the National Hockey League.

title: Cardinals' Smith Wins 10th Gold Glove in Row
description: Ozzie Smith, the shortstop of the St. Louis Cardinals, won his 10th consecutive Gold Glove Award yesterday, becoming the only major league player to receive the honor bestowed in balloting by managers and coaches in each year of the 1980's. ''This is the highest accomplishment a defensive player can get,'' said Smith, who made only 17 errors during the season. For the first time since 1978, the National League first base award did not go to Keith Hernandez of the Mets, but to Andres Galarraga of Montreal. Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs, however, extended his streak to seven years as the National League second baseman and Don Mattingly of the Yankees won the American League award for first basemen for the fifth year in a row.

title: Swiss Vote Cheers Critics of Army
description: The outcome of a recent referendum, in which an unexpectedly large minority voted in favor of abolishing the army, has unsettled the Swiss military establishment and heartened those pushing for a reduction of the military budget and other changes.

title: Treasury Issues Dip on Fed News
description: Prices of Teasury notes and bonds slipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities after a report from regional Federal Reserve banks showed that the economy remained a bit stronger than anticipated.

title: Reviews/Music; Clarinetist Plays Berg And Francaix
description: John Craig Barker, a clarinetist from Mississippi who is a student at the Juilliard School, made his New York recital debut on Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. His program was devoted mostly to 20th century works, the one 19th-century holdover being Schumann's ''Fantasiestucke'' (Op. 73).

title: XL/Datacomp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bass Group Buys Stake in Finevest
description: An investment group led by two members of the Bass family of Fort Worth has acquired a 5.3 percent stake in Finevest Foods Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group headed by the brothers Sid R. and Lee M. Bass said it had acquired its 565,400 Finevest shares for an average price of $7.47.

title: Sammy Fain, 87, Prolific Composer of Pop Ballads
description: Sammy Fain, who wrote the music for such well-loved popular songs as ''I'll Be Seeing You,'' ''That Old Feeling,'' ''Secret Love'' and ''Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Gaming Panel Fines Caesar's, Saying Casino Catered to Bias
description: State gaming regulators fined Caesar's Hotel Casino $250,000 today for removing black and female employees from a table to satisfy a high-stakes gambler.

title: Changes in East Call for a U.S. Balancing Act
description: A senior policy maker was explaining the other day that the Bush Administration had two sets of policies for Eastern Europe - one for that night's network news and one for the year 2010. But the real challenge for Washington, he said, will be developing approaches to Europe not for tonight and not for the next century, but for next year, 1992 and 1995.

title: Islanders Come Back To Win 4th in Row
description: The Islanders, who posted a rare home victory Tuesday night, got their third consecutive road victory tonight, beating the Hartford Whalers, 4-3.

title: Metro Datelines; 4-Year-Old Boy Dies In an Apartment Fire
description: A 4-year-old boy was killed yesterday when fire swept through his family's Bronx apartment, fire officials said.

title: 5 More Arrests in Killing of Apartheid Opponents
description: The South African police confirmed today that they had detained five more men believed connected to a white conspiracy that led to the assassination of two leading white opponents of apartheid this year.

title: Boston Garden Continues To Give Knicks Trouble
description: The last time the Knicks won a regular-season game at the Boston Garden, Stu Jackson was an assistant coach at Washington State, Trent Tucker was in his second Knick season and Patrick Ewing was a junior at Georgetown. It was also a leap year and the date was Feb. 29, 1984.

title: Britain Sells Water Units Britain Sells Water Units
description: The British Government hailed its $8.2 billion sale today of Britain's water industry as eager investors lined up to beat the deadline to buy the shares.

title: Mother Talks of Transplant
description: It was more painful than she expected, but the woman who gave up part of her liver for her baby girl in the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor says she would do it again.

title: Leonard-Duran: Experts Are Split
description: Just who was the Ray Charles Leonard who climbed into the ring last June against Thomas Hearns? Was he a fighter who finally, and unexpectedly, showed his advanced boxing age of 33?

title: Swiss Bank In U.S. Link
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation of Zurich is joining forces with O'Connor & Associates of Chicago, the leading trader of financial options in the United States, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Labatt (John) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Phoenix Technologies Appoints Top Officer
description: Phoenix Technologies Ltd., a software development company, yesterday named Ronald D. Fisher as its president and chief executive.

title: Cranston Seeks Inquiry by F.B.I. On Source of Disclosures on Son
description: Senator Alan Cranston today urged William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to look for a Government source for a news article that said the bureau is investigating a voter registration group operated by the Senator's son.

title: MARYLAND ORDERS BAN ON 8 HANDGUNS
description: The state has banned the sale or manufacture of eight handguns while approving a list of 677 weapons that can legally be sold in Maryland.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allen Group Inc., Melville, L.I., a manufacturer of automotive products, named Robert G. Paul president and chief operating officer.

title: Varity Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Music; Hank Jones's Piano Game
description: Playing jazz can be a strategic exercise in which the harmonic framework of a tune, understood by all the musicians on the bandstand, becomes the field for a creative game. The set by the pianist Hank Jones and his group at Carlos 1 on Tuesday night was an example of the contest at its best, with Mr. Jones's unpredictable improvisations striking a compromise with the need for group unity.

title: Miami Police Prepare As Jury Deliberates
description: The Miami Police Department today canceled all vacations and days off and put its 1,100 officers on 12-hour shifts as it prepared for the possibility of disorder when a jury renders its verdict in the case of a Hispanic officer accused of manslaughter in the killing of two unarmed black men.

title: Metro Matters; Dinkins Stock: The Questions That Persist
description: Late on Election Day, before the polls closed, a lawyer for David N. Dinkins received an unsettling telephone call.

title: John Casey, Pleased but Humble, Savors Late-Blooming Success
description: John Casey is pleased, of course, that his ''Spartina'' won this year's National Book Award for fiction, but there is little chance, he said, that the prize will ''go to my head.'' Why? Because two months ago his brother-in-law, Dr. Harold E. Varmus, shared the 1989 Nobel Prize in Medicine. Last spring, Mr. Casey's niece, Jessica Tuck (who plays Megan Gordon in ''One Life to Live'') appeared on the cover of TV Guide. And another brother-in-law, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, formerly the Minister of Mines and Energy in Peru, is about to publish another book on economics -a subject Mr. Casey failed at Harvard.

title: Hartco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The share earnings reflected a 4-for- 3 stock split in July. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Lebanon's President Threatens to Quit if Crisis Over Aoun Persists
description: The new President of Lebanon, Elias Hrawi, threatened to resign today if the present crisis blocking his Government remains unresolved.

title: Cantel Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $961,000.

title: Rev. William D. Eddy, Tarrytown Rector, 65
description: The Rev. William David Eddy, the rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Tarrytown, N.Y., died of a brain tumor Tuesday at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Tarrytown.

title: Serving Time
description: A New York woman tells a cautionary tale of jury service:

title: Not-Guilty Plea in H.U.D. Case
description: A woman whom Federal officials have dubbed ''Robin HUD'' because of her Congressional testimony that she bought automobiles and housing for the needy with stolen Government housing money has pleaded not guilty to embezzlement.

title: Check Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Champion Sells Berkshire 300,000 Shares
description: The Champion International Corporation said yesterday that it had sold 300,000 shares of a new stock series for $300 million to Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment company headed by Warren E. Buffett.

title: St. George and the Dragon
description: The importance of human rights in American foreign policy has just been powerfully demonstrated. As change sweeps through Eastern Europe, we can feel that we played a part by pressing over many years for democratic values: free elections, the right to travel, freedom of speech and press.

title: EAST GERMAN OUT AS CHIEF OF STATE; PARTY IN DISARRAY
description: East Germany's fallen Communist chief, Egon Krenz, gave up his remaining state positions today amid the continuing political turmoil. The foundering Communist Party advanced its emergency congress to Friday and is expected to shed its Stalinist structures and even its name.

title: Israeli Army Bans an Arab Leader In Occupied Areas for 6 Months
description: The Israeli Army issued an order today forbidding the best-known nationalist leader of local Palestinians to enter the occupied West Bank or the Gaza Strip for the next six months.

title: Arnold Ordman, Ex-N. L. R. B. Counsel, 77
description: Arnold Ordman, who served two terms as general counsel to the National Labor Relations Board and later was an administrative law judge and arbitrator, died of heart failure Tuesday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 77 years old and lived in Bethesda.

title: Tiny Cocaine Doses Cut Blood Flow to the Heart
description: Very tiny amounts of cocaine, even smaller than those commonly given by doctors for anesthesia, can trigger a significant fall in the flow of blood to the heart, a new study shows.

title: Manfred Gerlach: Daring And Acting Head of State
description: Manfred Gerlach, who was named today as the acting head of state to replace Egon Krenz, is a veteran of East German politics who was among the first to sense the changing tide.

title: U.N. Puts Off Its Vote on P.L.O.
description: Under broad international pressure, Arab members of the United Nations deferred a General Assembly vote indefinitely today on a resolution to recognize the the Palestine Liberation Organization as representing a Palestinian state.

title: Edward Lender Woodyard, Admiral, 86
description: Edward Lender Woodyard, a retired rear admiral in the Navy, died of congestive heart failure on Sunday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 86 years old.

title: MBIA in Pact With French Firm
description: MBIA Inc., a financial-guarantee insurance company based in White Plains, said it had agreed to exchange professional services and jointly develop financing opportunities in Europe with Credit Local de France, a specialized French institution that provides nearly half of the financing for French municipal and regional authorities.

title: Newmark & Lewis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Nathan I. Huggins, Educator, 62; Leader in Afro-American Studies
description: Nathan Irvin Huggins, an author and educator who was a leading scholar in the field of Afro-American studies, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 62 years old.

title: Mesa Airlines reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
REAGAN ASKS COURT TO KILL SUBPOENA
description: The Justice Department and lawyers representing Ronald Reagan today asked a Federal judge to cancel his order compelling the former President to hand over private White House diaries to John M. Poindexter, a former national security adviser.

title: Insurance Rate System Modified in California
description: The California Insurance Commissioner on Tuesday put into effect a provision of the 1988 insurance referendum that prohibits auto insurers from basing rates on a driver's area of residence.

title: Telecredit Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Barneys to Open Dallas Mall Store
description: Barneys New York, the retail clothing company, said it would open a 19,000-square-foot store in Dallas's Northpark Center shopping mall next August.

title: Jail Term for a Missile Crime
description: A rocket scientist convicted of trying to ship advanced United States missile technology to Egypt has been sentenced to 46 months in prison.

title: Saga Halts Project
description: The Norwegian company Saga Petroleum A.S. said it would halt development planning for its $1 billion Midgard offshore field until buyers are found for its natural gas reserves. Plans for Midgard, which is off central Norway, depended on selling enough natural gas to justify building a $2.2 billion pipeline.

title: Philips Plans New TV Plant
description: The North American Philips Corporation announced plans to build a factory to make high definition television picture tubes by late 1992.

title: Books of The Times; Word Thieves and What Compels Them
description: Stolen Words Forays Into the Origins and Ravages of Plagiarism By Thomas Mallon 300 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

title: No Headline
description: In the world of medical training, Veronica Prego was known as an ''extern,'' a medical-school graduate working under a licensed physician in preparation for a hospital internship. In that capacity, almost seven years ago, Dr. Prego says, as she followed prescribed steps toward her goal of becoming a specialist in gastroenterology, she pricked a finger with a syringe needle.

title: Injured O'Brien May Sit When Jets Play Steelers
description: Last week, the Jets' quarterback, Ken O'Brien, was nominated for the Travelers N.F.L. man of the year award by the Pro Football Hall of Fame for his charity work. Today his good friend Tony Eason had another award in mind for him.

title: Dry Dock Lays Off 24 in Real Estate
description: The Dollar Dry Dock Bank said it laid off 24 people last week in its residential real estate lending department because of the slow pace of home sales. Robert H. Steele, Dollar Dry Dock's chairman, said originations of new mortgage loans had been running 60 percent below the bank's projections.

title: Bomb at Police Building in Bogota Kills 35 and Wounds Hundreds
description: A truck bomb containing half a ton of dynamite exploded outside the headquarters of the security and intelligence agency during the morning rush hour today, killing at least 35 people and wounding hundreds.

title: Official Sentenced
description: Luther Darville was sentenced yesterday to 18 months in prison for stealing $186,000 from the University of Minnesota when he headed its minority affairs office. A jury last month convicted Darville of three felony counts of theft by swindle despite his testimony that he gave the money to student-athletes and other students on orders from his superiors at the university.

title: Applied Materials Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Few Are Getting Rent Subsidies to Avoid Foster Care
description: A year after a rent subsidy became available to help families get their children out of foster care, the program is barely off the ground.

title: Air Canada to Cut Stake in Concern
description: Air Canada said it would sell part of its 14.6 percent stake in the Irish aircraft leasing company GPA Group P.L.C. to raise cash and reduce debt.

title: New York Fines 32 Food Stores On Overcharges
description: Customers of supermarkets with automatic checkout scanners were overcharged in 32 of the 33 stores surveyed by state inspectors this year, state officials said today.

title: Prospect Park Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said the net losses were attributed primarily to adjustments in the value of certain real estate investments made by its units, and to the increases in loan loss provisions.

title: Q&A
description: Redwood Protection Q.I have redwood patio furniture and am interested in the best way to protect it from the weather. Is applying a redwood stain enough? A.Most paint and hardware stores and many redwood furniture dealers carry sealers or protective coatings for just this purpose. A simple transparent stain would help restore the color but would not provide much protection against water penetration and soiling. These redwood furniture coatings do provide that kind of protection. They come in clear or semi-opaque versions, with pigment added to help retain or restore the original color to the wood. Insulating Pipes Q.Our water pipes run through an unheated crawl space under the house, and sometimes it takes more than 45 seconds to get hot water to the upstairs - a huge waste of water and gas. Is it feasible to insulate these pipes, and if so, what kind of insulation should I use? A.Insulating the pipes under the house is definitely a good idea. You can use flexible foam insulating sleeves, which are sold in all plumbing supply outlets and in most home centers. The sleeves are slit along one side so you can slide them over the pipes and then tape the slit closed.

title: Koch Gives Handel Medal to Danilova
description: Calling her ''one of the most extraordinary talents of this or any other century,'' Mayor Edward I. Koch bestowed New York City's Handel Medallion on Alexandra Danilova, the ballerina and teacher, yesterday in a private ceremony in the Blue Room at City Hall.

title: Two More Named Primary Dealers
description: Two New York subsidiaries of foreign companies were named as primary dealers in United States Government securities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said.

title: Syracuse Overcomes Error to Defeat Duke
description: Of all things, it came down to a pair of Syracuse free throws.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge organizers have seldom given as much attention as they should to the problems of disabled players. But in one area, some improvement is in sight: Considerable efforts are being made to solve the difficulties of those with impaired hearing, aided by a grant from the American Contract Bridge League's Education Fund.

title: Florida Rock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,507,000, or 16 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: That's Not Jack Frost Nipping at Your Nose
description: Thieves would smell something other than the sweet pine aroma of Christmas if they took a tree from the municipal park here. Once installed as the centerpiece of the seasonal decorations, the tree would go on the attack and fill the air with the odor of skunk.

title: ARKANSAS ORDERED TO ALTER DISTRICTS
description: A Federal court has ruled that the drawing of the boundary lines for legislative districts in the state's impoverished delta region in 1981 diluted black voting strength, and it ordered the state to redraw the lines in time for the 1990 elections.

title: Yo! (Ho! Ho!) Watch Your Back!
description: FORGET about Rudolph and his fellow reindeer. This season Santa will be traveling solo, racing all those macho bicycle messengers around town, dodging taxis and buses on his speedy city bike (''Coming through!''), checking destinations on his cellular phone and delivering hip gifts for the home to one and all. His shoulder bag and belt pack will be stuffed with all that is new for the 90's: stars and stripes, speckles and spots and trompe l'oeil Hereford hide. Also, gifts with high-tech impact, like an electronic appointment book that can function as an alter ego. But mostly, he has gifts with wit, like a user-friendly nutcracker shaped like an alligator. So keep an eye on the chimney. And be ready to sign for the packages.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a reduction in the work force of the International Business Machines Corporation misstated the change made by Moody's Investors Service in the company's debt rating. Moody's reaffirmed its top rating, Aaa, for I.B.M.'s senior debt. It altered its rating for only $11.5 billion of convertible subordinated debt, downgrading it from Aaa to a slightly lower rating, Aa1.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: G.M. May Expand Role in Hungary
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was negotiating to expand its business in Hungary. G.M. has had a trade agreement with Hungary for two years under which it buys auto parts from Hungarian companies for its European operations. In exchange, G.M. sells Opel cars in Hungary. Opel is a G.M. subsidiary.

title: Fernandez Appoints Another Deputy
description: Joseph A. Fernandez, who is to become New York City's schools chancellor on Jan. 2, yesterday named a woman with little academic training in education as his deputy chancellor for programs, signaling once more that his administration will be rather unconventional.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are going back to the barracks. It's finished.'' - Lieut. Col. Rafael Galvez, commander of the Philippine rebels. [ A14:1. ]

title: Incinerator Ash In a New Guise: Building Blocks
description: Long Islanders used to worry about being buried under tons of garbage. Now, as the Island tries to solve that disposal problem by building garbage-burning incinerators, residents have another worry: the tons of ash produced by burning.

title: Edwin N. Altman, 71, An Airline Executive
description: Edwin N. Altman, an executive in the airline and maritime industries for nearly 50 years, died Sunday at Overlake Hospital in Bellevue, Wash., after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Building A Better Ornament
description: IN the it-was-only-a-matter-of-time department: this Christmas, Saks Fifth Avenue is selling a glass Christmas ornament by the architect Richard Meier. The ornament, bottom, which retails for $22.50, is part of the Signature collection from American Glass Art, a division of the Crane Corporation, which annually commissions ornaments by artists. The series honors ''native-born individuals whose achievements are uniquely expressive of their American heritage,'' among them the artists Keith Haring and Sam Francis, who did the ornament above.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Circle Magazine Names a New Publisher
description: Winthrop Stevens was named yesterday as publisher of Family Circle magazine. He succeeds Charles H. Townsend, who remains president and chief operating officer.

title: In France A College For Elderly Students
description: IT was early October, and the opening of school - or as the French call it, the rentree - was in high gear.

title: Washington Talk; 'Pocket Veto' Dispute: President Calls a Truce
description: President Bush, who has made conciliation with Congress a hallmark of his Administration, seems to have called a truce in one long-running dispute with Capitol Hill.

title: Hispanic Journalists Honored by Columbia
description: Four journalists - two magazine publishers, a television reporter and a radio station director - have been awarded Columbia University's 1989 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes, given annually to journalists from the Western Hemisphere in recognition of ''distinguished contributions to the advancement of inter-American understanding and freedom of information.''

title: Isco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Stirrings of Capitalism Shake a Muslim Egypt
description: In a downtown bank the other day, a customer traded a wad of dollar bills for Government bonds -a deal that showed capitalism astir in a land that has veered through extremes of economic dogma.

title: KEY RATES
Cambodia's Hun Sen Is Himself Khmer Rouge
description: To the Editor:

title: Hardy House Plants for Winter Blooms
description: NOW that winter's weather has arrived, with high winds and icy temperatures in the Northeast, people who would sooner go without morning coffee than without bouquets of flowers are becoming reacquainted with their florists.

title: Short Selling Exonerated
description: A top enforcement official of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that recent investigations by the agency had not uncovered evidence of widespread manipulation of over-the-counter stocks by short-sellers.

title: Consilium Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Review/Music; West German Guitarist n a Narrative Suite
description: Hans Werner Henze has almost enough imagination to keep his socialist political beliefs from debilitating his musical illustrations of them. ''Memorias de el Cimarron,'' a kind of narrative suite for the guitar that Hubert Kappel brought to Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night, relates in six episodes the exploits of a runaway slave. We follow Esteban Montejo from cruel exploitation to (quoting the title of the piece's finale) ''Friendliness.''

title: FEDERAL OVERHAUL YET TO TAKE HOLD AT A-BOMB PLANTS
description: Five months after promising that a new, safety-minded team would take control of the nation's broken-down nuclear bomb factories, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins finds himself presiding over further decline and still struggling to hire the new managers.

title: Review/Music; Works Composed by New York State Women
description: New York Women Composers, an organization founded in 1984 to promote works by women who live in New York State, held a competition this year, and the winning pieces were presented at a concert by Musicians' Accord at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening.

title: Times to Raise Delivery Price
description: The price of The New York Times delivered directly by The Times in the metropolitan area will increase to $4.50 a week on Jan. 1, William L. Pollak, the vice president for circulation, announced yesterday. Most customers now pay $4.25 a week. The increase will not affect suggested newsstand prices or direct home-delivery rates outside the New York area.

title: Harbor Rescue Witness Says 3 Civilians Were a 'Godsend'
description: If not for three civilian rescuers who rushed through rough seas in a small boat, more than two people might have died aboard the charter-fishing boat that sank near the entrance to New York Harbor Saturday, a Coast Guard petty officer testified yesterday.

title: Burma Rebels' Radio Station
description: The main rebel alliance in Burma has set up a radio station at a jungle base close to the Thai border, a rebel spokesman said today. The Voice of the Democratic Alliance of Burma began news broadcasts in Burmese and English on Saturday. The rebels have fought the Government for four decades.

title: Grenades Fired at Residence Of Spanish Envoy to Hague
description: Two grenades were fired today at the home of the Spanish Ambassador here, causing some damage, the police said. No one was wounded, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility.

title: Control Data Names New Chief Executive
description: The Control Data Corporation made it official yesterday, naming Lawrence Perlman chief executive to succeed Robert M. Price. Mr. Price will remain as chairman.

title: Rockefeller Labs, Roosevelt Homes
description: Two development proposals deserve continuing strong support of the outgoing Koch administration and a welcome from the incoming Dinkins government. They are the $80 million expansion of Rockefeller University's laboratories and a scaled-down housing plan for Roosevelt Island.

title: Havel Gets a Hand From St. Agnes
description: LEAD: My wife, Zdena Salivarova, who grew up unbaptized in a social democratic family of unbelievers and had to be christened at 24 before I received my family's permission to marry her, finally has got religion - thanks to the Grand Happening in Prague.

title: Advice for Prospective Volunteers at Charitable Organizations; Groups Eager for Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Peru Says It Will Resume I.M.F. Debt Payments
description: Peru, which was nearly expelled from the International Monetary Fund three months ago for refusing to make payments on overdue I.M.F. loans, has agreed to resume some payments, Peruvian officials said today.

title: Lutheran Church Gets a Bigger Role
description: With the virtual collapse of the East German Communist Party, the leading moral authority in this part of Germany is once again what it has been for most of the time since the Reformation, the Lutheran Church.

title: Warsaw Editor Sees 'Anti-Polish Phobia' In German Upheaval
description: Adam Michnik, editor of Solidarity's daily newspaper, said today that ''explosions of anti-Polish phobia'' among Germans were threatening the democratic order in Europe.

title: Common Sense About Abortion
description: The latest round of Supreme Court abortion arguments requires the justices to apply not constitutional theory but horse sense. A realistic look at parental consent laws in Minnesota and Ohio will expose their practical effect. These are not laws that, in practice, promote family values. They are laws that make abortions harder to get.

title: France Pushes Integration of Arab Immigrants
