description: Faced with mounting resentment against the estimated 3 million Muslim Arab immigrants living in France, the Government of Prime Minister Michel Rocard today presented a 48-point plan to speed up the process of integrating them while tightening controls against illegal immigration.

title: For Lovers of Collectibles, a Show Where Play's the Thing
description: TO Bernard Barenholtz, toys were many things: 19th-century collectibles he pursued with a connoisseur's eye, learning tools he manufactured, and artifacts that revealed the history of commerce, fashion, politics and transportation.

title: NEW VERMONT LAW HINDERS CAR SALES
description: The General Motors Corporation will not be able to sell some models in Vermont in 1992 because of the state's air pollution law, a company official said today.

title: 1,500-M.P.H. WINDS FOUND ON NEPTUNE
description: Neptune is swept by 1,500 mile-an-hour winds, the fastest yet discovered in the solar system, scientists have determined from analyzing photographs taken by Voyager 2.

title: Reviews/Television; Eugene O'Neill's 'Rope,' A Precursor of Classics
description: Presented monthly on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network, ''American Playwrights Theater: The One-Acts'' is a laudable enterprise aimed at carving out a small but prestigious niche on the schedule for, in essence, pure theater. The plays are produced for Nederlander Television and Film Productions. And it is only natural that the series be eager to offer something by Eugene O'Neill (1888-1953). Some names carry considerably more weight than others. So, tonight at 9, A&E is offering ''The Rope,'' written by O'Neill in 1918. Unfortunately, the effort enhances neither O'Neill's reputation nor the series.

title: Robert Vidalin, Actor, 86
description: Robert Vidalin, an actor known to millions as the voice of Charles de Gaulle's Resistance fighters during World War II, died Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: Abortion Curb Gains in Michigan; Veto Is Vowed
description: Unmarried girls under the age of 18 would have to get parental permission before obtaining an abortion in Michigan under a bill passed today by the House despite the Governor's promise to veto it.

title: Review/Dance; Bending Ballet to the Shapes of Jazz
description: Danny Buraczeski has been choreographing jazz dance for 10 years. But his dances are as fresh and thought-provoking as ever. In part, this is due to his obvious love for the idiom and for jazz music. But the charm and originality of his dances are also due to his lack of preconception.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. GENERAL COMMITTEE - 9:30 A.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 3 P.M.

title: 5 NATIONS SEIZE COCAINE PROFITS
description: The United States and four other nations have frozen $61.8 million invested in American and European banks by an associate of the Medellin cocaine trafficking ring of Colombia, the Drug Enforcement Administration said today.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I WAS not at Woodstock, nor at Newport on the night the fans rioted, nor in Candlestick Park when the earth moved. But I was at B. Altman on the first day of its going-out-of-business sale, and should I ever be so fortunate as to have grandchildren, I can face them unashamed. I, too, have a tale to tell.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a recovery in the supertanker business referred incorrectly to an investment by the Belzberg family of Canada in Marine Transport Lines. The Belzbergs were part of a group of investors that paid $128.8 million for the company, not the sole investors; they own 25 percent.

title: Soaring Imaginations Meet a Space Traveler
description: Sweeney Henville, a 10-year-old fifth grader from Queens, and Dr. Ellen Shulman Baker, an astronaut and graduate of Public School 41 in Bayside, were having a discussion yesterday about matters scientific and emphatically nonscientific.

title: Taiwan Gold Imports Up
description: Taiwan's gold imports rose sharply in November, to the highest level since April, the Finance Ministry said today. Physical imports, including gold bars, coins and plate, totaled 13.67 tons in November, up 23.9 percent from 11.03 tons in October. The November figure brought Taiwan's total gold imports to 147.4 tons, valued at $1.81 billion, for the first 11 months of 1989.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Lin Broadcasting Corporation's acceptance of a takeover offer from McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. misstated terms for the disposition of the stock and options held by Lin's chairman, Donald A. Pels.

title: Cherkassky Replaces Bolet
description: The pianist Shura Cherkassky is to make his first appearance in Lincoln Center's Great Performers Series on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Cherkassky is replacing Jorge Bolet, who has canceled his recital because of illness. Mr. Cherkassky is to play works by Beethoven, Schumann, Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff and Liszt.

title: Seagram Co.  Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of $57,478,000 and $172,433,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and equity in unremitted Du Pont earnings of $68,844,000 for the quarter and $281,681,000 for the 9 months. c-Included dividend income from Du Pont of $52,003,000 and $150,537,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and equity in unremitted Du Pont earnings of $49,974,000 for the quarter and $225,695,000 for the 9 months. Revenue represented sales and other income.

title: 5 Hurt in Cruise Ship Fire
description: A fire broke out today on a cruise ship moored for repairs, injuring five people before it was contained, the harbormaster said. About 450 workers and crew members were on the 618-foot Bermuda Star, which was moored at Swan Island when the fire broke out shortly after 1 P.M. in an area where welders were working, said the harbormaster, Mell Pittmon. Five crew members who suffered smoke inhalation, Mr. Pittmon said.

title: Calling Client a Monster, Nurse's Lawyer Asks Lesser Charge
description: A defense lawyer summed up his case today by calling his client ''a monster in nurse's whites'' who may well have killed four hospital patients but should not be convicted of murder.

title: Bush's Next Budget Falls Within Deficit Limits Without a Tax Increase
description: To the surprise of budget experts outside the White House, the Bush Administration is proving able to prepare a budget for the next fiscal year that would meet the deficit requirements of the budget-balancing law without raising taxes or cutting fundamental domestic programs, authorities in and out of the Government say.

title: DePaul Dean Named Pace University Head
description: The dean of faculties at DePaul University in Chicago has been named president of Pace University.

title: Reviews/Music; Ellen Christi Improvisations
description: The compositions of the singer Ellen Christi are supported by the barest of material. A melody and a bass line offer suggestions to her group, and the musicians do the rest of the work, improvising whispers and turbulent shouts to fill in the blanks.

title: Ex-Canadian Official Charged
description: One of Canada's most prominent former politicians and several Indian leaders were charged with fraud and breach of trust after a long investigation into the financing of a Liberal Party leadership bid. John Munro, a former Indian Affairs Minister and a stalwart of Pierre Trudeau's Liberal governments of the 1970's and early 1980's, will appear in court on Dec. 13 to answer to 34 charges. Most of the charges relate to allegations that federal money was funneled through the National Indian Brotherhood into Mr. Munro's unsuccessful bid for the Liberal leadership in 1984.

title: Shell Plans Deep Drilling Off Texas
description: The Shell Oil Company said today that it would develop a promising oil and gas field at a record depth of 2,860 feet in the Gulf of Mexico, more than 250 miles southeast of Houston. It estimated the cost at $1.1 billion.

title: 14 Women Are Slain By Montreal Gunman
description: A young man with a rifle killed 14 women and wounded 12 other people at the University of Montreal engineering school yesterday before committing suicide, the police said.

title: Former Aide to Rep. Frank Testifies in House Sex Inquiry
description: The House ethics committee, investigating the possibility of sexual misconduct by Representative Barney Frank, heard testimony in closed session today from the man who says he ran a prostitution ring out of the Massachusetts Democrat's apartment.

title: Colonial Municipal Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After net realized and unrealized losses of $1,476,322 for the quarter and $8,390,221 for the year. c-Included net realized and unrealized gains of $1,054,863 and $1,365,797 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Honor for Elewonibi
description: Mohammed Elewonibi, a 6-foot-5-inch, 290-pound guard at Brigham Young, was named yesterday as the winner of the Outland Trophy as the nation's outstanding college football lineman. Elewonibi, a native of Nigeria who moved to Kamloops, British Columbia, when he was 11 years old, is the second Brigham Young lineman to win the Outland in the last four years.

title: Atlantic Financial Federal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter included a $39,119,000 pretax provision for credit losses.

title: Philippine Rebel Troops Surrender In Business District of the Capital
description: Philippine Army rebel troops who nearly succeeded in a rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino that began seven days ago agreed this morning to surrender and return to barracks, apparently concluding the gravest challenge yet to her deeply battered administration.

title: Hurco Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Welcoming the Eye, If Not the Body
description: THE relentless quest for the unique that was symbolic of the 1980's reached an apex of sorts in the art furniture movement, in which artists created ''functional works of art'' that were sometimes embraceable, sometimes not.

title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines
description: The ramshackle encampment of the homeless in Tompkins Square Park is drawing mounting criticism from residents of the Lower East Side, a community where rioting broke out last year when the police tried to sweep the homeless from the park.

title: Judge Punishes 'the Enemy'
description: A Federal district judge, who said he grew up in the same area as the defendant, today sentenced a 22-year-old Los Angeles drug dealer to life in prison without possibility of parole for selling five ounces of crack. ''I know the neighborhood, and I know the way it has changed,'' the judge, David Williams, said in passing sentence on Richard Van Winrow. ''This man is one of the enemy.''

title: Prague Leader Weighs Quitting Amid the Chaos
description: Prime Minister Ladislav Adamec announced tonight that he would resign if his new Government was not given ''adequate conditions for its work.''

title: Fetal Research Depends on Destruction of Life; Other Diseases Affected
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-24 Egon Krenz's remaining state jobs were yielded by the fallen East German Communist chief, and the party itself moved up to Friday its emergency congress, at which it is expected to shed its Stalinist structures. Page A1

title: The Truth Won't Out
description: Following are excerpts from an interview on Tuesday's ''Today'' television program on NBC. Jane Pauley, the co-anchor: The Navy successfully launched a Trident 2 missile Monday in a performance evaluation, but that's not the whole story. Early Monday morning off the coast of Cape Canaveral, U.S. Navy vessels reportedly rammed an unarmed ship owned by Greenpeace leaving a three-foot hole in the ship's side.

title: Lady Vols Top Maryland by 8
description: Tonya Edwards scored 8 of her game-high 22 points during a 24-13 run in the second half tonight to lead top-ranked Tennessee to a 77-69 victory over Maryland.

title: Talking Deals; Fancy Footwork In Coniston Move
description: IT had all the trappings of a deal that would never get done. It was a leveraged buyout. It required the second-largest issuance of high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' since RJR Nabisco Inc. It involved bank loans organized by Citicorp, the architect of the botched United Airlines financing. And, like United, the deal depended heavily on the good will of Japanese banks.

title: Oasis Laundries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Defaults by Bond Issuers May Be Highest of Decade
description: Defaults by bond issuers are likely to reach the highest levels of the decade this year, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.

title: Harland Bartholomew, 100, Dean of City Planners
description: Harland Bartholomew, the dean of comprehensive city planning in the United States, died Saturday at his home in Clayton, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis. He was 100 years old.

title: Accounting Rule Delayed
description: The chief rule-making body for the accounting profession decided yesterday to postpone for the fourth time the date by which companies must change the way they report their income tax expense to shareholders.

title: AIDS Panel Finds U.S. Failure in Providing Care
description: In its first report to the President, the National Commission on AIDS said today that the Federal Government had failed to take necessary steps to get health care to people with AIDS.

title: Review/Music; With Sounds of Christmas
description: There are close parallels between the Tallis Scholars and Les Arts Florissants. The English group was founded in 1978 by Peter Phillips, the French group in 1979 by William Christie. Both now count as their countries' leading vocal ensembles for Renaissance and Baroque music, enjoying notable successes on tours and recordings.

title: Bush Readies Big Cuts In '91 Pentagon Budget
description: President Bush has decided to propose a Pentagon budget of $295 billion for the 1991 budget year, substanially less than the Defense Department had hoped to receive, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Peter Max Really Can Have It All
description: AND you thought you liked shopping.

title: Output Up By 2.5% in 2d Quarter
description: American workers made modest productivity gains in the third quarter, but the lackluster manufacturing sector posted its lowest output gain in three years and continued to slow the overall economy.

title: Emirates Rejects Quota
description: The United Arab Emirates' oil minister, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, said this week that his country was ready to limit its oil output, but not to the extent demanded by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. He said the United Arab Emirates was willing to reduce its current output of 2.6 million barrels a day to less than two million in the first half of 1990. But he said it would not accept a quota of 1.094 million barrels a day assigned under last week's OPEC agreement.

title: Father-Son Banquet Sacked
description: A tradition of father-son banquets honoring the high school football team was canceled after the quarterback said he wouldn't go if his mother couldn't. ''A lot of people supporting us through hard times were mothers,'' said Owa Brandstein, quarterback for the Mohawk Trail Regional High School team. ''It's blatant discrimination. It's just wrong.'' Howard Binder, a co-founder of Friends of Mohawk, which was to sponsor the banquet this Saturday, said Monday that the banquet was canceled after the guest list became an issue.

title: Dow Retreats by 4.91 Points, to 2,736.77
description: Stock prices tracked a weak bond market to lower ground yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.91 points, to 2,736.77.

title: Metro Datelines; Yale Called Unfair In Action on Officers
description: Two Yale police officers disciplined for their handling of a confrontation at a gay studies conference were made scapegoats to appease the gay community, the Yale police union asserted Tuesday.

title: Dinkins's Celebration, for Sale
description: Denied permission to pay for an inaugural party with surplus campaign funds, Mayor-elect David Dinkins announced that he would accept new contributions of up to $10,000 from individuals and corporations and $25,000 from partnerships. The amounts would cast an unwelcome shadow over an auspicious event.

title: INSIDE
description: Report to Bush on AIDS In its first report to the President, the National Commission on AIDS said the Government had failed to take necessary steps to get health care to people with AIDS. Page A26. Reagan Fights Subpoena The former President, joined by the Government, asked a Federal judge to cancel his order compelling Mr. Reagan to turn over private diaries to an Iran-contra defendant. Page A27. Split in B'nai B'rith B'nai B'rith International is ready to expel its 120,000-member women's unit for declaring itself an organization identified with B'nai B'rith but not subject to its will. Page A26. Leaner Days for Pentagon President Bush reportedly will propose a military budget of $295 billion, much less than the Defense Department had wanted, for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1. Page B26.

title: Fed Says It Sold Dollars in Third Quarter
description: The Federal Reserve actively sold dollars from August through October in an effort to prevent further appreciation of the dollar in foreign exchange markets, the central bank reported yesterday.

title: India's New Leader Announces His Cabinet
description: After nearly a week of suspense and speculation, India's new Government took shape today as Prime Minister V. P. Singh announced Cabinet assignments.

title: El Chico reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 13
description: b-Net loss c-Included a gain of $440,000, or 10 cents a share, from cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: New Cabinet Named in Jordan
description: Prime Minister Mudar Badran announced the formation of a Cabinet today that excludes the fundamentalist Muslim Brotherhood movement, which makes up the largest bloc in Jordan's new Parliament.

title: Union Wonders if It Can Trust Owners
description: Mistrust of owners and treatment of younger players were the most widely discussed topics today at a meeting of the Major League Baseball Players Association's executive board.

title: Teachers Leader Argues for More Metal Detectors
description: The president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman, urged the New York City Board of Education yesterday to put metal detectors in each high school that requests them.

title: Xtra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,149,000 for the quarter and $1,850,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $438,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,065,000, or 16 cents a share, for the year; the year also included an accounting adjustment loss of $19,884,000 from the adoption of SFAS 96.

title: Fed Survey Calls Economy Stable to Growing Modestly
description: Economic activity in most sections of the country is ''stable to modestly expanding,'' with even generally becalmed manufacturing displaying ''pockets of strength,'' a survey by the Federal Reserve Board of its 12 district banks stated today.

title: East Germany Revamping and Taking the Politics Out of Its Army
description: The 176,000-member National People's Army, like other institutions here, is being thoroughly reshaped as a result of the upheavals in the Communist leadership that began six weeks ago.

title: Long Beach Journal; Studying American Life: Lessons Go Both Ways
description: One day, as a cultural experiment, Mary Jean Kolasa asked her students of English to stand in line.

title: The Talk of Westchester County Airport; Airport Plan: A Travelers' Oasis or a Threat to Neighbors?
description: As the morning rush hour unfolded at the Westchester County Airport this week, business commuters were greeted by the usual affronts: a packed parking lot with cars left helter-skelter on muddy hillsides, a drab, drafty Quonset-hut terminal, a waiting area little bigger than a corporate jet. ''It's a dump,'' said

title: Sun Introduces 2 Computers
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. today introduced two new server-class computers based on its Sparc design, which uses RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, to speed operation.

title: Beijing Journal; English Spoken Here (by Would-Be Expatriates)
description: A class of 40 nervous students looked blankly at the teacher who had just asked a sample question on an English test, about the purchase of shoes from a catalogue. ''Class, what is a catalogue?'' the teacher asked.

title: Grim Outlook of Early 1980's Is Back for U.S. Auto Makers
description: The prospects for the American automobile industry are more uncertain today than at any time since the early 1980's, when the Detroit producers ran to Washington to push for ''voluntary'' quotas on Japanese imports.

title: Metro Datelines; Councilwoman Seeks Father's House Seat
description: Susan Molinari, the only Republican on the 35-member City Council, announced yesterday that she would seek her father's seat in the House of Representatives in a special election early next year. Her father, Representative Guy

title: Calendar of Events: Winterthur Pieces
description: Young America: 1670 to 1840, I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street; 212-745-6100.

title: AQUINO IS PRAISED FOR REVOLT MOVES
description: The United States praised the Government of the Philippines today for arranging the release of American citizens trapped in hotels in Manila, and the Bush Administration said the Philippine President, Corazon C. Aquino, was acting within her authority when she declared a state of emergency.

title: Spurrier Interviewed
description: The Phoenix Cardinals hope to have a new head coach by Feb. 1 and Steve Spurrier of Duke has been the first person interviewed for the job. The Arizona Republic reported yesterday that the 44-year-old Spurrier confirmed he met with the Cardinals' general manager, Larry Wilson, last Thursday in Durham, N.C., where Duke (8-3) is practicing for its All-American bowl game Dec. 28 against Texas Tech.(AP)

title: The West Again? Enough!
description: FOR those who have seen one Pendleton-cosseted, turquoise-draped non-Navajo too many, from Santa Fe, N.M., there comes this poster, spawned by Lewis E. Thompson, an advertising man, and Jerome Milord, an artist.

title: U.S. Names Team
description: Michael Chang, the French Open champion, Aaron Krickstein and the doubles team of Jim Pugh and Rick Leach were named yesterday to face Mexico in the first round of next year's Davis Cup competition. The Americans, named by the United States Tennis Association, will meet Mexico in a first-round World Group match from Feb. 2-4, at Carlsbad, Calif.(AP)

title: Macmillan Case Accord
description: The former chairman of Macmillan Inc. and two senior executives settled Federal civil charges today that they failed to disclose that the company was developing a restructuring plan to ward off an expected hostile takeover attempt, almost one year before the plan was announced.

title: Broadway Actress Has Quick Start on Her Career
description: In Scene 5 of Tom Stoppard's ''Artist Descending a Staircase,'' a young woman named Sophie talks with three artists about the meaning and relevance of modern art. The time is the 1920's and, reacting to the work of the day, Sophie says that art should not be easy. One purpose of art, she says, is to celebrate the ability of the artist.

title: CUC International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said year-ago results reflected amortization of membership acquisition costs over a three- year period. During the fourth quarter of fiscal 1989, the amortization of member acquisition costs was changed to a one-year period.

title: Montreal Gunman Kills 14 Women and Himself
description: A young man with a rifle killed 14 women and wounded 12 other people today in a shooting rampage at the University of Montreal engineering school, then shot himself to death, the police said.

title: Brach's Seeks Use Of Foreign Sugar
description: The candy maker E. J. Brach & Sons said that unless it was allowed to use less expensive foreign sugar for its candies, it might lay off 3,500 workers and shut down or relocate a 65-year-old Chicago plant. Brach's, which was taken over three years ago by Jacobs Suchard A.G. of Switzerland, has petitioned the Federal Government for foreign-trade-zone status.

title: Review/Art; Julian Schnabel's Mantra: Stop Ruining the World
description: With his new paintings, Julian Schnabel should get some credit for showing up where he is least expected. The master of conspicuous pictorial consumption - famous for painting on surfaces made of broken plates or pot shards, fatigued tarpaulin or Kabuki theater backdrops - is now making paintings that criticize such consumption.

title: Plight of Homeless Prompts Gifts to Neediest
description: ''As I see so many homeless people on the street, it would give me great satisfaction if these people could be in safe shelters or, better still, homes,'' Eleanore B. Saidenberg of Manhattan wrote in the short note she enclosed this week with her $150 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Alexander Is Retiring
description: Dan Alexander, the Jets' right guard, whose 13 years of seniority is surpassed only by the 16 years of Pat Leahy, the place-kicker, and equaled only by Wesley Walker, a receiver, announced his retirement at the end of the season.

title: Bonn Cellular Pact To 4-Nation Group
description: West Germany today awarded the license to build and operate a private cellular telephone system to a four-nation consortium led by Mannesmann A.G. The group also includes the Pacific Telesis Group of the United States, Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, Lyonnaise des Eaux of France and Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank, a West German bank. It had been rumored in the last week that the Mannesmann group would be chosen.

title: Hernandez Is Signed By Indians for 2 Years
description: The free agents kept marching through the marketplace of baseball with soaring contracts today, and the march was led by Keith Hernandez, the former co-captain of the Mets, who signed a two-year contract with the Cleveland Indians for $3.5 million and said: ''I'm not ready for the bench yet.''

title: On Stage
description: 'Marjorie Morningstar'

title: Theater
description: Children at the theater are at once the most open-minded audience and the toughest critics. Or such has been my experience with the children I have taken to the theater most often - boys between the ages of 4 and 10. I have watched a 6-year-old who didn't know Dickens from Seuss eat up seven hours of ''Nicholas Nickleby'' (as well as a dinner-break pizza), held spellbound by the teeming action and the poignant figure of Smike. At 9, the same boy grew restless, though not during the rap or video sketches, at Bill Irwin's 70-minute ''Largely New York.'' (Perhaps post-modernist clowning has yet to sift down to elementary schools.) When a show loses children's attention, they don't hesitate to say so. A 5-year-old otherwise held rapt by ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' turned to me during a monotonous song (I won't name it) and asked, ''When will this part end?'' At one confusing moment in ''Les Miserables'' - when it is portentously announced that a heretofore unmentioned offstage character, General Lamarque, is dead - a 4-year-old cracked up two rows of adults by asking aloud the entire audience's unspoken question: ''Who the heck is General Lamarque?'' While the child knew nothing of France or Hugo, he must have entered the world of ''Les Miserables'' completely, for how else could he have instantly spotted a hole in its libretto?

title: Auctions
description: Verdi Letters

title: Metro Datelines; Man, 22, Is Convicted Of Killing Woman, 93
description: A 22-year-old man was convicted of murder yesterday in the beating death of a 93-year-old Bronx woman during a robbery in her home, the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Shopping Mall Videos
description: LEAD: American shopping malls will become commercial media later this month, when the Pioneer Electronic Corporation of Japan and the United Artists Entertainment Corporation in the United States formally establish Pioneer United Mallvision. The joint venture will place advertisements and other programming on giant closed-circuit video screens in shopping centers.

title: Upheaval in the East; For Hidden Slovak Dissidents, a Guide
description: When a visitor rings the doorbell at the apartment of Bishop Jan Korec, there is no sound inside, but a small light goes on in the kitchen. He would not want frequent ringing to be heard by the neighbors upstairs, who for the last eight years have been assigned to keep tabs on Bishop Korec, the leader of the underground church in Slovakia.

title: Dan Quayle: No Loose Cannon
description: Who is Dan Quayle and why is he saying all those nasty things about the Soviet Union when President Bush is saying all those nice things? Specifically, why is Mr. Quayle saying Moscow hasn't ''changed much in foreign policy'' when President Bush insists that President Gorbachev displays ''new thinking'' and that Soviet-American relations are on the ''threshold of a new era''?

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Sansui Electronics Corp. to Kirshenbaum & Bond, for its line of audio and video products, with a budget of about $2 million.

title: Gannett to End Partnership With Tinker in TV Concern
description: Grant Tinker and the Gannett Company said yesterday that they had agreed to end their partnership in the GTG television production company.

title: Books of The Times; A Sphere That Holds The Secrets of Time
description: The Gold Ball By Hanne Marie Svendsen Translated by Jorgen Schiott. 245 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Sheldon A. Vogel, 68, A Retired Lawyer, Dies
description: Sheldon A. Vogel, a former partner in the Manhattan law firm of Thacher Proffitt & Wood, died of respiratory failure on Wednesday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan and Coronado, Calif.

title: Jackson's Shooting Is Still on Vacation
description: Just before Mark Jackson went to the free-throw line for a second time in 47 seconds Wednesday night in the Knicks' 113-98 loss to the Boston Celtics, Paul Silas, an assistant coach, yelled over the din of the Boston Garden crowd, ''Confidence, Mark! Confidence, Mark!''

title: Soviets Buy More Wheat
description: The Soviet Union has bought 410,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in 1989-90, the seventh year of a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our success is unambiguous proof that a vaccine for AIDS is possible.'' - Dr. Michael Murphy-Corb of Tulane University. [ A1:1. ]

title: The Mirage Threatens Arum, King
description: In the hours before Leonard-Duran III, one of boxing's best fights was developing. But the participants were wearing tuxedos instead of trunks. And the new kid on the block was jabbing two old bullies.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Advocate for the Wrongly Convicted
description: The head of a newly formed advocacy group for people wrongfully convicted has been arrested on Federal drug and conspiracy charges after a Federal agent recognized him in newspaper photographs taken at a fund-raising event.

title: Cuba Says Americans Fired on Sentry Posts
description: Soldiers at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, fired two shots today at Cuban sentry posts, the official news agency Prensa Latina said. It said the shots broke glass but caused no injuries.

title: Robert E. Wallace, Executive, 86
description: Robert E. Wallace, a retired insurance executive, died of heart disease on Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Prices of U.S. Issues Fall Again
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped again in light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for this morning's release of November employment data.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL Western European governments are expected to create an enlarged European common market of 18 nations, not just the 12 in the European Community. [ Page A1. ] President Mitterrand of France is eager to extract a new commitment from the European Community to proceed with rapid economic integration. [ D5. ] U S West agreed to lead a corporation formed by Moscow and including seven other international telephone companies that will lay a fiber-optic cable across the Soviet Union, linking Japan and Europe. [ D1. ] Aeroflot's deficiencies have created a market for a new independent carrier, two Soviet legislators say. [ D2. ] Poland will be wired for cable television by Chase Enterprises of Hartford, which will also provide Western programming. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Government lawyers went to court to defend the Federal takeover in April of the financially troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. [ D1. ] Pinnacle West's stock climbed 90.7 percent after it said it had agreed to settle a dispute with Federal regulators by injecting capital into its insolvent savings subsidiary, Merabank. [ D1. ] Pennzoil said it had spent $2.1 billion in the last two months for an 8.8 percent stake in Chevron, the nation's largest oil refiner and marketer. It said it might increase the stake to about 10 percent but had no plans to seek control. [ D1. ] Fiat will buy half of Maserati to take advantage of some of Maserati's unused production capacity. [ D1. ] First Interstate Bancorp moved to clean up its money-losing Texas operation, adding $400 million to reserves before selling problem assets. [ D4. ] Grant Tinker and Gannett agreed to end their partnership in GTG, and each party said it was seeking a new financial backer to replace Gannett's support. [ D15. ] Victor Posner granted American International the option to buy his controlling interest in Fischbach. [ D4. ] Harold T. Miller said he would retire in April as chairman and chief executive of Houghton Mifflin. [ D15. ] THE ECONOMY Americans took out $3.34 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in October, resulting in the biggest increase in net consumer debt in five months. [ D6. ] MARKETS

title: Mexican Politicians Look North of Border
description: The migration of millions of Mexican workers into the United States in search of jobs has brought a new influx: Mexican politicians and leaders in search of their influence, money and votes.

title: Plea About Bounty On Tape, Zendejas Says
description: Luis Zendejas, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, has told The Dallas Times-Herald that a Philadelphia Eagles assistant coach pleaded with him not to tell the National Football League that he had warned Zendejas about attempts to knock him out of the Thanksgiving game between the teams.

title: Virginia Xanthos Faggi, Administrator, 60
description: Virginia Xanthos Faggi, coordinator for special projects at Columbia University, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: New Method of Creating Antibodies Hailed as a Research Aid
description: In what is considered a major advance in biotechnology, a team of California scientists have devised a new method of creating monoclonal antibodies, which are widely used in medical diagnosis, experimental cancer treatments and basic research in immunology and disease.

title: First of 5,000 Palestinians Are Reunited With Families in Gaza
description: Five Palestinians living on the Egyptian side of a refugee district divided in half by the Israeli border have crossed into the Gaza Strip, the first of more than 5,000 Arabs who are to be reunited with their families here over the next five years.

title: Market Place; Cutting 'Rebates' On O-T-C Trades
description: THE pain on Wall Street is spreading to a business whose very existence is known to few customers - the practice of over-the-counter market makers paying retail brokerage firms for orders.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Philippine military rebellion gave an incorrect date in some copies for Corazon C. Aquino's election as President. It was February 1986, not August 1986.

title: Restaurants
description: Mon Cher Ton Ton (French Room)

title: Return L.I.'s Barrier Islands to Nature, a Panel Urges
description: A Long Island planning agency recommended today that almost 5,000 houses and businesses on Fire Island and in other shore resort areas threatened by erosion be gradually eliminated and that the barrier islands they stand on be returned to nature.

title: The G.D.R. Forever
description: LEAD: Our country is stuck in a deep crises. We do not want to and cannot live anymore the way we did up to now. The leadership of one party assumed the domination of the people and its representatives, imbuing all areas of life with structures marked by Stalinism. Without violence, through mass demonstrations, the people compelled the process of revolutionary renewal, which is fulfilling itself with breathtaking speed.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Alan Bowne, a playwright and author, misstated the date of his death. It was Nov. 24.

title: Review/Film; Spoofing the Unity of Art and Agony
description: ''Dear Samuel Beckett,'' a wild-haired, whiny-voiced, starving young dramatist writes to his idol. In view of the ''uncanny kinship'' between ''Waiting for Godot'' and ''Despair,'' the young man's own play about life and death (''Life, life, life, death, death, death,'' chants a black-robed chorus), perhaps the two men might collaborate on a future project? He signs off: ''Hoping your next play is a hit. Sincerely, Ira Ellis.''

title: Frances Bavier Dead; TV Performer Was 86
description: Frances Bavier, who played Aunt Bee on ''The Andy Griffith Show'' on television in the 1960's, died at her home here on Wednesday. She was 86 years old and had been released Monday from a hospital, where she had been in the coronary-care unit.

title: October's Consumer Debt Rose at 5.7% Annual Rate
description: Americans took out $3.34 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in October, resulting in the biggest increase in net consumer debt in five months.

title: Just One More Flop
description: The Federal Government's decision to abandon its current development of the Yucca Mountain Nuclear Waste Depository in Nevada, and to start again on a new plan for the same site, repeats an old, discouraging story: a ballyhooed ''solution'' to the radioactive waste problem that turns out to be just one more flop.

title: India's Chief, at Golden Temple, Vows to Heal Punjab
description: In his first official trip out of the capital since becoming Prime Minister of India, V. P. Singh went to Amritsar today to pray at the holiest shrine of the Sikhs, promising to heal ''the heavy, bleeding heart'' of Punjab state. Thousands have died in confrontations there in the last five years.

title: Metro Datelines; Lanes to Reopen On F.D.R. Drive
description: After more than two and a half years of extensive repair work, all three northbound lanes of the F.D.R. Drive will be open again, beginning today at 3 P.M., the City Transportation Department announced yesterday.

title: Benjamin J. Lucarelli, New Jersey Builder, 82
description: Benjamin J. Lucarelli, a contractor whose company built some of New Jersey's best-known apartment and hotel complexes, died yesterday at his home in Spring Lake, N.J. He was 82 years old and had lived in Jersey City and Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Broncos Are Playing For Home Advantage
description: The Denver Broncos (10-3) have clinched the American Conference West title but have plenty to gain in a rematch of Super Bowl XXI against the Giants (9-4) Sunday in Mile High Stadium.

title: COLOMBIA CARTELS TIED TO BOMBING
description: President Virgilio Barco Vargas said on Wednesday that drug traffickers were responsible for a truck bombing that killed 52 people in the capital and pledged not to allow Colombian democracy to succumb to their ''bloody tyranny.''

title: WESTERN EUROPE MOVES TO EXPAND FREE-TRADE LINKS
description: Western European governments plan to announce an agreement later this month to establish a free-trade zone that includes the 12 nations of the European Community and 6 others, diplomats and community officials said in recent days.

title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks
description: A Hispanic police officer was found guilty of manslaughter today in the killings of two unarmed black men that set off rioting in the mostly black Overtown section of Miami. The killings, which occurred in January, have come to symbolize the ethnic tensions of this troubled city.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Two U.S. Agencies Are Expanding in Spain
description: LEAD: One of Europe's fastest-growing markets for advertising is Spain, where two American agencies bolstered their operations this week. TBWA Advertising announced the purchase of I+D, a $20 million Spanish agency that serves Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and the Robert Bosch Corporation, among other clients.

title: Poisoned Tree Stirring Fear of Copycat Killer
description: In a town 20 miles east of here there is fear that a copycat killer is on the loose. Another venerable tree has been poisoned.

title: INSIDE
description: Close Call for Aquino Philippine officials said President Corazon C. Aquino's Government was nearly toppled at the height of the military revolt a week ago. Page A8. Gain in Biotechnology A new method has been developed to produce monoclonal antibodies, substances that have become critical in diagnosis and research. Page A32. Errors Penalized Thousands A Government study found that many people were dropped from a benefits program because of Social Security Administration staff cuts. Page A20. Change on Fire Island An agency recommended gradual elimination of 5,000 houses and businesses on Fire Island and in other resorts threatened by erosion. Page B1.

title: Nigeria's 1st Vote Since '83 Is Delayed to Late Next Year
description: Nigeria's first elections since 1983 have been postponed from later this month to the end of next year, the military Government announced today.

title: 13 of 21 Board Members Quit At the Academy of Design
description: Nearly two-thirds of the advisory and fund-raising board for the National Academy of Design resigned yesterday during an emergency meeting called to discuss the academy's growing financial problems and a dispute over the institution's policies.

title: No Cause Found For the Sinking Of Fishing Boat
description: The captain of the Bronx Queen testified yesterday that he felt a thump at the stern just before the charter-fishing boat began to sink near the entrance to New York Harbor on Saturday. But neither the captain nor a diver who inspected the submerged ship could determine the cause of the accident.

title: Premiere of Flute Work
description: The flutist Paula Robison is to give the world premiere of Roy Harris's ''Lyric Study'' at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. The program also includes Aaron Copland's Duo, Robert Beaser's Variations, Samuel Barber's Canzone and ''Melodies Passageres,'' and the New York premiere of Lowell Liebermann's Sonata (Op. 23). Tickets are $15 to $20. Information: 996-1100.

title: Marietta Fills President's Job
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation today named A. Thomas Young, the company's executive vice president, to the posts of president and chief operating officer.

title: Broadcasting Bill in Britain
description: The Government published draft legislation today that would ease the way for new British radio and television stations.

title: Upheaval in the East; A Paper Daring in More Ways Than One
description: Junge Welt has still not published a photo of a bare-breasted woman, as was done in mid-November by the People's Army paper. But in the past month of political upheaval, this newspaper of the Communist Party youth organization has been transformed into East Germany's most sensationalistic publication at a time when all of the country's once uniformly conformist Communist Party papers are becoming far more aggressive and lively.

title: Portland to Seize Cars in Drive on Drinking
description: The Portland City Council has approved a law that allows the police to seize the automobiles of people who drive while their licenses are suspended because of convictions for drunken driving or those who use their autos for prostitution.

title: Constance Kaiser, 56, Phone-Book Publisher
description: Constance K. Kaiser, an executive, philanthropist and former publisher of telephone directories for Westchester and Connecticut communities, died of cancer on Wednesday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 56 years old.

title: Theaters' Landmark Status Upheld
description: The designation of 22 Broadway theaters as landmarks and a companion law that restricts their demolition were upheld yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Basketball Pact Worries Breweries
description: LEAD: By cutting back on the alcoholic-beverage commercials that can be shown, a contract granting CBS rights to televise the college basketball championship tournament is giving new impetus to those who want to ban broadcast beer and wine advertising.

title: Firefighters in Yonkers March on City Hall
description: About 300 Yonkers firefighters and their families marched on City Hall today, as their union leader accused the Fire Commissioner of neglecting them.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Beatrice Co., Chicago, said it had received almost $165 million from the Internal Revenue Service in connection with a 1980 transaction related to the disposition of Transocean Oil Inc.

title: Snow Honored Again
description: Percy Snow, a Michigan State linebacker, earned his second honor of the week last night when he was presented the Lombardi Award as the nation's top lineman. Snow, a senior who holds the school record of 164 tackles in a season, won the Butkus Award on Tuesday as the nation's top linebacker. The 6-foot-3-inch, 240-pound Snow has 163 tackles this season, one short of the school record he set last year.(AP)

title: Brokerage Firm Is Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today formally censured S. B. Lewis & Company, the brokerage firm controlled by Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, for its role in Mr. Lewis's manipulation of the stock price of the Fireman's Fund Corporation in May 1986.

title: San Francisco Journal; Grimaces Over a Dab Of Glitz In Skyline
description: In this city where glitter and glitz are dirty words, residents are trying to sort out how redevelopment has lit up their skyline with a hotel only Liberace could love.

title: Users of Steroids Risk Addiction, Two Researchers at Yale Report
description: Research suggests that people who take anabolic steroids to promote muscle growth may become addicted to the drugs, scientists at Yale University have found.

title: New Jersey Jail Riot Leaves One Man Dead and 6 Hurt
description: An inmate was shot to death and six guards were hurt Wednesday in a night-long riot at the Hudson County Jail, the authorities said today.

title: Fiber-Optic Tie Sought For Soviets U S West Plans Fiber-Optic Telephone Line for Soviets
description: U S West Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to lead a corporation formed by the Soviet Union and seven other international telephone companies that plans to lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union, linking Japan and Europe.

title: Crewmen Indicted in Grounding of Freighter
description: Two brothers who were crewmen aboard a ship that rammed a fragile coral reef in October have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of operating the vessel recklessly and while intoxicated.

title: Many Wrongly Losing U.S. Payments
description: Many beneficiaries of a Social Security program for poor people who are aged, blind or disabled have been mistakenly dropped from the rolls because a reduced staff cannot handle the workload, an agency study says.

title: Turkish Lute Music
description: Cinucen Tanrikorur, an oud (lute) player and singer, is to perform Turkish music on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Admission is $10, or $7 for students and the elderly. Information: 206-1050.

title: Mitterrand Backs Europe Integration
description: With the future of the European Community suddenly clouded by events in Eastern Europe, President Francois Mitterrand is anxious to extract a firm new commitment to rapid economic integration when leaders of the 12-nation bloc meet here on Friday.

title: Upheaval in the East; COMMUNISTS AND FOES AGREE TO A FREE EAST GERMAN VOTE AND PLAN NEW CONSTITUTION
description: East Germany's new and old political groupings held their first ''round table'' discussions today and agreed to call for the adoption of a new constitution and for free elections by May 6.

title: Wild Greenwich Tract Being Divided Into Lots
description: The last of the great private estates that helped give Greenwich, Conn., its patrician character - a 169-acre wilderness area in the town's northwest corner - has been sold and the first phase of subdividing it has been approved.

title: Review/Film; The Camps As Not Often Seen
description: Although ''Triumph of the Spirit'' is not especially graphic or brutal, it depicts aspects of the concentration-camp experience that are not ordinarily seen on film. And it serves as a reminder of why the tattoos being inflicted, the prisoners being marched to the showers, the release of the poison gas and the bodies on their way to the crematorium are not usually shown. Horror like this cannot be reduced to the level of routine fiction; the very idea of attempting as much has a profoundly trivializing effect. Events like these exist far more potently in the accounts of witnesses, in documentary footage and in our collective imagination than they ever could in melodrama.

title: AGENCIES TARGETED BY SALVADOR ARMY
description: Despite presidential promises to rein in security forces, the armed forces have intensified a crackdown on international relief groups, church workers and opposition groups.

title: Jets' Defensive Linemen Feeling More Confident
description: Although the Jets' pass rush had its most productive day of the season in last Sunday's victory over the Chargers in San Diego with five sacks, there is a feeling that things could be different Sunday against the Pittsburgh Steelers at Giants Stadium.

title: Dekalb-Pfizer Deal
description: The Dekalb Genetics Corporation said it had agreed to buy Pfizer Inc.'s 30 percent interest in Dekalb-Pfizer Genetics, a seed partnership owned by the companies. Dekalb said it would pay Pfizer $80 million. Dekalb said it would continue to conduct agricultural biotechnology research for at least five years at Pfizer's research center in Groton, Conn.

title: Realities Of the Revolution
description: What world are they living in, our elected leaders in Washington, our bureaucrats and so many of our academics and journalists?

title: 8.8% Stake in Chevron Disclosed by Pennzoil
description: The Pennzoil Company said today that it had spent $2.1 billion in the last two months to buy an 8.8 percent stake in the Chevron Corporation, the nation's third-largest oil company, and indicated that it might increase the stake by another $500 million, or to about 11 percent.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Resignation at McCann
description: LEAD: Henry Wasiak has resigned as executive vice president of McCann-Erickson North America, the agency said yesterday. Mr. Wasiak, whose nickname is Hank, was president of Geers Gross Advertising when McCann acquired it last year. McCann said that he planned to develop new business ventures and continue as an assistant professor of marketing at Pace University.

title: Agent Says He Was 'Stupid,' Not Traitorous
description: A former Federal agent, tried twice for espionage and now free on bail while awaiting a third trial, said today that he had been ''stupid'' for forming the romantic relationship with a young Soviet woman that resulted in the charges against him. But he again asserted his innocence.

title: Polish TV Joint Venture For Chase Enterprises
description: An American communications company today announced a joint venture to wire Poland for cable television and provide it with an array of Western programming.

title: Soviet Fiber-Optic Project
description: Eight telephone companies, led by U S West, agreed to form a corporation with the Soviet Government to link Europe and Japan with a fiber-optic cable. Page D1.

title: Shiite Factions Battle as Lebanon Crisis Continues
description: As predominantly Muslim areas of Lebanon observed a one-day general strike to show solidarity against Michel Aoun, the rebellious Christian general, rival Shiite militiamen fought today with rocket-propelled grenades and heavy machine guns on the streets of West Beirut.

title: Army-Navy Sends Message to Philadelphia Officials
description: The difference between Saturday's Army-Navy game and the 89 that preceded it is the location: Giants Stadium in New Jersey's Meadowlands. This is a one-time-only arrangement and also a subtle message to the city of Philadelphia, where 67 of the games have been played.

title: Dinkins Case Throws Spotlight on Maloney
description: After spending three years in the shadow of another United States Attorney, Andrew J. Maloney is now the pivotal prosecutor in New York City's most politically sensitive inquiry: an investigation of Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins.

title: Metro Datelines; Art Teacher Charged With Fondling Girls
description: A 42-year-old art teacher at Public School 59 in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with sexually abusing three students, the police said.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY JAM SESSION IN DAYLIGHT

title: Texan Is Put to Death by Injection For Killing Woman in a Robbery
description: A man who said drugs and alcohol had led him to a life of crime was put to death by injection early today for the murder of a woman in a robbery.

title: Board Drops 1876 Building As Landmark
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, joined by almost every other member of the New York City Board of Estimate, voted yesterday to overturn the landmark status of a 113-year-old building on the Avenue of the Americas that was designated in October as ''a forerunner of the skyscraper type.''

title: Israel Welcomes Egypt Move
description: Egypt's qualified acceptance of the American plan for Palestinian-Israeli peace talks received a cautious welcome today from the Israeli Government, which said its Foreign Minister was ready to attend the first meeting as early as next month.

title: Ex-Klan Leader Facing First Test in Senate Bid
description: To almost everyone in Louisiana politics, he is the most overpublicized man in American politics, a freshman state legislator without a substantive achievement who has nevertheless become a national figure.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, misidentified the period in which the company earned $:22.9 million in pretax profits. It was the first half of this year, not the second half of last year.

title: L.I. Doctor, Fined in Prostitution Case, Kills Himself, the Police Say
description: A Southampton, L.I., doctor convicted of prostitution for soliciting college students to have sex with his wife was found dead yesterday, apparently a suicide victim.

title: More Room for Finesse
description: The National Hockey League's Board of Governors decided yesterday to move the goal lines an extra foot from the goal line to the boards behind the net. Effective next season, the line will be 11 feet from the boards instead of 10.

title: Ex-Boeing Aide Guilty
description: A Federal court jury convicted a former Boeing Company marketing executive today on 39 counts arising from his possession of secret Pentagon budget documents.

title: Chinese Plant Is Bankrupt
description: A motorcycle factory in eastern China has become the first state-owned enterprise to go bankrupt in the country's 40 years of Communist rule, the official press agency reported Wednesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19 A new East German constitution will be called for, said representatives from the nation's battered Communist Party and several opposition groups. Page A1

title: Zydeco Makes a Trip To New York
description: In recent years, more and more New Yorkers have been waltzing and two-stepping to genuine Gulf Coast zydeco, the infectious Cajun-Creole dance music created by French-speaking blacks in and around Louisiana. Now the music may well be on the verge of a local breakthrough as one of its acknowledged masters, the accordionist and singer known as Rockin' Dopsie, begins an eight-night stand tonight at Tramps.

title:
WHEN NEW YORK, TO A CHILD, IS A STOCKING FULL OF GIFTS;
Museums
description: LEAD: As to the best art show for children this year, there is simply no contest. ''The Intimate World of Alexander Calder'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum (2 East 91st Street), through March 11, is in a class by itself. Calder loved to make things for children, and nobody was ever better at it. The present show includes many of the objects he made for his own children and grandchildren, and they have been installed in an imaginative and amusing way.

title: Law; For Special Cases, a 'Tax Therapist'
description: As a self-proclaimed ''tax therapist,'' Joyce Rebhun has helped thousands of late filers who have special emotional problems. Her job here is to get them penalty fee waivers from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Chicken-Lover Gets Out of Jail
description: Lynda Ashley was released from jail today after serving 10 days for illegally raising 18 pet chickens. Mrs. Ashley was jailed on Nov. 25 for violating a village ordinance prohibiting raising poultry without a permit. ''The chickens can wait,'' Mrs. Ashley said upon her release. ''I just want to be with my family and have a nice hot cup of tea.'' The family's application for a permit will be heard by the Seneca Falls Village Board on Monday.

title: Our Towns; Missing Money And the Suicide Of a Selfless One
description: Barbara Watson began working for the Department of Parks and Recreation in this Fairfield County town of 27,000 about 15 years ago.

title: Upheaval in the East; Warsaw Curbs Statue Rallies
description: The Solidarity-led Government said today that it will not tolerate more demonstrations at a monument to Lenin where anti-Soviet protesters trying to destroy the statue have twice clashed with the police. Protesters hurled paint, gasoline and explosives at the monument and fueled the fire with park benches in a demonstration that lasted until midnight Wednesday. ''The problem of the location of the monument should be decided by inhabitants of this district of Cracow in legal forums,'' the Government said.

title: Pearl Harbor Remembered
description: A thousand people gathered at two sites today to remember the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor that killed 2,403 soldiers, sailors and civilians and propelled the United States into World War II. Simultaneous ceremonies on the 48th anniversary of the attack were held by the Navy aboard the U.S.S. Arizona Memorial, which spans the hull of the sunken battleship that serves as the final resting place for 1,102 Navy officers and enlisted men, and onshore at the Arizona Memorial Visitors Center.

title: Rome Journal; Church Shares Pie With Caesar: How Big a Piece?
description: The Roman Catholic Church is warily preparing to test its hold on the hearts, the minds and, more to the point, the pocketbooks of Italian taxpayers.

title: Takeover Of Lincoln Defended
description: Government lawyers went to court today to defend the Federal takeover last April of the financially troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: Rockets Waive Lloyd
description: The Houston Rockets yesterday waived Lewis Lloyd, who was making a comeback after treatment for cocaine addiction.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 6 about accusations of anti-Semitism against the mythologist Joseph Campbell reversed two identities. He was at the center; the author Brendan Gill was at the right.

title: Upheaval in the East; Czechs Try to Sell a Stalin
description: A banner on the outskirts of this Bohemian village says, ''With Soviet Union Forever,'' but the people here want to sell their 20-foot statue of Stalin for Western currency.

title: Lawrence Milberg, 76, Partner in a Law Firm
description: Lawrence Milberg, a lawyer and senior partner in the Manhattan-based firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Specthrie & Lerach, died on Wednesday after suffering a heart attack while playing tennis near his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Aid to Poland Sets Off a Fight Over Shipping
description: American ships carrying food aid began arriving in Poland last week. But they will deliver less food than they could, critics say, with correspondingly fewer benefits to American farmers, because of a law that results in higher shipping costs.

title: Hank Jones Trio
description: Hank Jones, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow. There is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and $10 admission at the bar.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., the entertainment production company that was recently acqquired by Sony Corp., promoted Joe E. Stevens to senior vice president and controller, television.

title: Predatory Sea Lions Facing A Winter Eviction by Seattle
description: California sea lions that prey on steelhead and salmon at a fish ladder here could be caught and sent back to breeding grounds off Southern California ahead of time this winter under new government recommendations.

title: Houghton Mifflin's New Chairman
description: Harold T. Miller, who helped rally prominent authors to fight an attempted takeover of Houghton Mifflin Inc. in 1979, announced yesterday that he would retire in April as chairman and chief executive of the Boston-based publishing company.

title: England Is Seeded Sixth In 1990 World Cup in Italy
description: In a surprising decision, England has been seeded sixth for the 1990 World Cup soccer championships, ahead of Spain.

title: Upheaval in the East; Party Sees East Germans on Precipice
description: The East German Communist Party leadership moved up the opening of its critical party congress to Friday because of growing fear that the country would fall into chaos if it waited seven more days, senior officials said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Bonhomous Bistro

title: Review/Art; Andres Serrano: Provocation And Spirituality
description: ONE of the few, unintended benefits of the Congressional outrage against Andres Serrano is that it has brought widespread attention to a good artist. His photographs are indeed provocative. They are also serious art. There are 14 of them at the Stux Gallery, including the reviled and dreaded one from 1987, with its 13-inch plastic-and-wood crucifix upright in a Plexiglas tank filled with the artist's urine. This religious emblem enveloped in a dreamy golden haze (without the title, there would be little or no way of knowing what the liquid is) suggests the arty images and the mass production of religious souvenirs that have been partly responsible for the trivialization and exploitation of both religion and art.

title: Upheaval in the East; Havel Makes It Official: He'd Accept Top Billing
description: Vaclav Havel, the playwright and opposition leader, declared his readiness tonight to become President.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: The United States and the Soviet Union hope to conclude a new long-term grain agreement by mid-1990, a United States official said today after the conclusion of a first round of negotiations. The current grain agreement, now in its seventh year, expires in December 1990.

title: Iraq Announces Test of a Rocket; U.S. Fails to Confirm Launching
description: Iraq was reported to have said today that it has tested a large rocket capable of carrying satellites into space. Such a move would step up the Middle East arms race because missiles that can carry satellites could also be used to carry warheads.

title: Dance
description: Balletomanes sometimes bemoan the presence of children at performances of ''The Nutcracker.'' Aside from occasional candy-wrapper fidgeting that adults do even better, children make an ideal theater audience. But what is good children's theater? Some theater that bills itself as that is pretty awful and bores the kids as well, condescending to its audience by talking down and skimping on imagination and production elements.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
People
description: LEAD: * Dennis Berger and Art Mellor have been promoted to senior creative directors at BBDO New York.

title: Aquino and the Military: A Threat, but Protection
description: In the weeks ahead, one of President Corazon C. Aquino's gravest difficulties is that the Philippine military is not only her biggest threat, but also her sole protector.

title: Review/Theater; Everett Quinton Seeks the Foulness Within in 'Dr. Jekyll'
description: There's a psychotic killer loose in Coxsackie, N.Y., the setting for the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's new production of ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.'' The killer, a formerly mild-mannered librarian, has dismembered 16 1/2 bodies. Dr. Henry Jekyll of the Coxsackie Medical Institute believes this is no ordinary criminal. No, he declares, this librarian is suffering from quantum synaptic dualism, a theory that Dr. Jekyll's colleague Dr. Braintwain derides as balderdash. But Dr. Jekyll is determined to prove the disease's existence - even if he has to drink a potion that turns him into sleazy little Eddie Hyde, the wickedest man in Coxsackie and a really bad stand-up comic to boot.

title: Review/Film; Streep Spars With Barr In a Comedy of Revenge
description: Watching Meryl Streep at work in Susan Seidelman's ''She-Devil'' is to behold a magnificent illusionist at work. Miss Streep dives into this thimble-sized comedy and makes one believe - at least, while she is on the screen - that it is an Olympic-sized swimming pool of wit.

title: Upheaval in the East; Lithuania Legalizes Rival Parties, Removing Communists' Monopoly
description: Lithuania became the first Soviet republic to abolish the Communist Party's guaranteed monopoly on power when its parliament voted overwhelmingly today to legalize rival political parties.

title: Truck Tire Kills Motorist
description: Robert T. Schwaegerle, 66, of Westport, Conn., was killed Wednesday and his wife, Beverly, seriously injured as a tire fell off a truck and struck the roof of their car on Interstate 80 in Clearfield County. The car hurtled over an embankment and stopped in a ditch. The tire apparently came from an 18-wheel tractor-trailer, and the truckman might not have been aware what had happened, the State Police said. The truck driver kept going.

title: MGM Grand Fills Position
description: MGM Grand Inc. today named Clifford S. Perlman, a former chairman of Caesars World Inc., to head its planned casino and theme park in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Hewlett-3Com
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had completed its purchase of 5 percent of the 3Com Corporation. The move is part of an alliance between the computer companies. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had acquired its 1.45 million shares for an average of $18.89 each.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. Bolsters Savings Inquiry
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh assigned 400 additional prosecutors and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today to investigate savings and loan fraud. Money for the appointments was provided in a $48.5 million appropriation in the savings and loan rescue law enacted in August.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the United Nations debate on the Palestine Liberation Organization characterized the Finnish delegation's statement incorrectly. The Finns did not speak on behalf of the Scandinavian countries.

title: MONTREAL GUNMAN HAD SUICIDE NOTE
description: A gunman who killed 14 women and wounded 13 other people before killing himself Wednesday was described by the police tonight as a 25-year-old loner who was repeatedly frustrated in what one investigator called ''relationships of the heart.''

title: Carnegie Chairman Approached
description: A search committee of the board of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has reportedly recommended the appointment of James D. Wolfensohn, chairman of Carnegie Hall, as the new chairman of the center.

title: Pinnacle Accord Lifts Stock Price
description: The stock of the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation climbed 90.7 percent today, after the Phoenix-based financial services company said it had agreed to settle a dispute with Federal regulators by injecting capital into its insolvent savings subsidiary, Merabank.

title: Protest Ends on Indian Ocean Isle
description: Soldiers used tear gas and clubs today to disperse 1,000 high school students protesting a coup in which the island nation's president was killed, witnesses said.

title: South Brazil Cheers Break In Berlin Wall
description: Only weeks after Oktoberfest, church steeples here have cause for celebration again: the breach in the Berlin wall.

title: No End Seen to Power Struggle in Men's Game
description: The cold war between the Association of Tennis Professionals, which will administer the men's tour in 1990, and the International Tennis Federation, which will administer the four Grand Slam tournaments and the new Grand Slam Cup, failed to thaw despite frequent meetings between the two groups as the final Nabisco Masters was played out in New York last week.

title: Mexican Police Shooting Down Drug Planes, Officials Declare
description: Mexican federal police have shot down four drug-laden planes in the past three months and will continue to fire at suspicious planes that do not respond to warnings, a senior Mexican official has announced.

title: Upheaval in the East; opposition Is Unified in Bulgaria
description: Bulgaria's leading opposition groups formed a united organization today to press for democratic changes.

title: JUDGE BACKS RULE ON WORK AT HOME
description: In a defeat for organized labor, a Federal district judge today upheld a Labor Department regulation that allows people to work at home in five apparel-related industries.

title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3
description: Washington is embarking on another drug-of-the-month war, the third since 1986. Like its predecessors, our nation's latest war is destined to be another fool's errand because of its narrow focus on illegal drugs and its failure to confront society's pervasive problem of addiction. Even the bellicose political rhetoric is misleading, for drugs come to America not by invasion, but by invitation.

title: Boston U. Set Back on Tenure
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a 1987 ruling that Boston University must pay $215,000 in damages and grant tenure to a female professor who sued the university for sex discrimination.

title: TV Weekend; The Case of the Missing News Star
description: The television film ''Money, Power, Murder,'' on CBS at 9 P.M. Sunday, offers as its hero Peter Finley, an Irish-American cable-channel reporter who was obviously weaned on early James Cagney movies.

title: Upheaval in the East; Kohl's Foes Fault Plan To Cut Military Forces
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political foes asserted today that the Government's tentative plans to reduce its military forces by nearly a fifth do not go far enough.

title: NBC Adds Data Critical Of G.E.
description: NBC News said yesterday that it would broadcast on the ''Today'' show this morning a report about a Federal investigation of the aerospace industry that includes information critical of the General Electric Company, which owns NBC.

title: Eyewash Is Recalled After Contamination
description: A Florida company is recalling a nonprescription eyewash because of bacterial contamination that could cause serious infection, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

title: C. M. Dellums, 89; Led Rail Porters Union
description: C. L. Dellums, a labor and civil rights leader, died yesterday of cardiac arrest in Oakland, Calif., where he lived for the last 66 years. He was 89 years old.

title: Quake Amputee, 6, Gets Leg And Is Now in 'High Spirits'
description: The 6-year-old boy whose crushed right leg had to be amputated in the wreckage of the Nimitz Freeway after an earthquake struck on Oct. 17 has been fitted with an artificial leg and is in high spirits, a physical therapist says.

title: Soviet Lawyers in Odyssey Through U.S. Law
description: ''We,'' that pronoun of commonality and cooperation, runs wild as weeds through the conversation of Mahir Babayev, shifting its meaning as the Soviet legal expert describes his odyssey through American corporate law, the contacts made, the deals now brewing and the deals already done.

title: Who Can Predict Our Life in the Greenhouse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Terrorist Victim's European Vision
description: THE complex job of rebuilding the international economic order in the wake of the upheaval in the Communist world and the apparent end of the cold war will require dedicated and brilliant leaders like those who created the Marshall Plan after World War II. The late chief executive of West Germany's biggest bank, the Deutsche Bank, Alfred Herrhausen, who was murdered by a terrorist bomb near Frankfurt last week, was such a leader. Before his death, Mr. Herrhausen had begun to spell out his ideas on the reconstruction of Europe and its economic implications for both East and West.

title: Job Cuts Planned By Kelsey-Hayes
description: The Varity Corporation's Kelsey-Hayes Company unit said it would cut 1,000 jobs because of substantial operating losses and a soft automotive market. The company also said it would reorganize into four units. The job cuts will come through layoffs, early retirements, voluntary resignations and terminations, the company said.

title: Fiat to Buy Maserati Stake To Raise Production in Italy
description: Fiat Auto S.p.A. said today that it planned to buy nearly half of Maserati to take advantage of some of Maserati's unused production capacity in Milan, Italy.

title: CUTBACK IN DRAFT FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that military conscription of whites would be cut from two years to one year as part of a broader reduction of the South African armed forces.

title: Festivals This Weekend
description: TOMORROW BOOK SALE, Center for Book Arts, 626 Broadway, at Houston Street. Cards, crafts, jewelry and calendars. Tomorrow, noon to 6 P.M. Information: 460-9768. BAZAAR, Brooklyn Friends School, 375 Pearl Street, in the downtown section of Brooklyn. Sweaters, ceramics, jewelry, tree ornaments, food. Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: (718) 852-1029. VILLAGE SCHOOL MART, P.S. 41, Greenwich Avenue, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. Antiques, collectibles, crafts. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: 752-8475. CRAFTS FESTIVAL, Martin Luther King Jr. High School, 122 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street; sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance Inc. Clothing, jewelry, ceramics, wood and leather goods, entertainment. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Also Dec. 16 and 17. Admission, $4. Information: 866-2239. FLEA AND FARMERS' MARKET, P.S. 183, 66th Street, between York and First Avenues. Antiques, vintage clothing. Tomorrow, 6 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: 737-8888.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $431.4 million, to $367.14 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $714.9 million, to $88.58 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $319.6 million, to $119.53 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased by $36.1 million, to $159.03 billion, the institute said.

title: De Klerk Rejects Panel In Death-Squad Inquiry
description: President F. W. de Klerk tonight rejected requests that he appoint an independent judicial commission of inquiry to investigate allegations that the police operated assassination squads to eliminate opponents of apartheid.

title: Ellison Is Sidelined
description: Pervis Ellison, the No. 1 choice in this year's National Basketball Association draft, may be unable to play for the Sacramento Kings until mid-March because of tendinitis in his right big toe. Team officials believe the tendinitis developed after Ellison underwent foot and ankle surgery on Sept. 27 and changed his running gait to compensate for soreness in his foot.(AP)

title: Review/Film; 'The War of the Roses'
description: Barbara and Oliver Rose (Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas) started out as young lovebirds, ready to scrimp and save and struggle their way toward a rosy future. But by the time that future arrived, bringing with it two kids, two pets, two cars and a big house with a lighted, glassed-in shoe closet, they hated each another like poison. Why did this happen? Danny DeVito, who directed and co-stars in ''The War of the Roses,'' is hardly one to take the June-moon-spoon view of romance. It is Mr. DeVito's opinion, on the evidence of this film and his earlier ''Throw Momma From the Train,'' that love and rottenness are two sides of a single coin.

title: Upheaval in the East; Quayle Gets Free Rein To Criticize Gorbachev
description: The White House, concerned about conservative dissatisfaction with President Bush's warm praise for Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Malta summit, has given Vice President Dan Quayle free rein to criticize the Soviet President and his policies, Administration officials said today.

title: Governors and Presidential Aides Hear Advice on Education Goals
