description: In the first public follow-up to the national ''education summit'' in September, a committee of governors and White House aides heard advice today about what the United States should expect from its schools and decided to focus for now on goals, not on how to achieve them or pay for them.

title: I.R.A. Car Bomb Injures 21 In Army Town Near Belfast
description: A car bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army exploded in a suburban shopping district today, wounded 21 people and heavily damaging surrounding stores, the police said.

title: Tests of a Vaccine on Monkeys Offer New Hope in AIDS Fight
description: In the most hopeful experimental finding yet on the question of whether scientists will be able make an AIDS vaccine, researchers in Louisiana today reported that they protected eight of nine monkeys against simian AIDS with a vaccine.

title: Law; A boy's paleontologic prize is now an ancient legal dispute.
description: The fossil, along with other lizard specimens, is kept in a cabinet in the American Museum of Natural History. But to the man who found it - and has gone to court to retrieve it - the relic is scarcely more accessible now than it was for 175 million years, nestled in a hill in what was to become North Bergen, N.J.

title: Outdoors; A Winter Substitute for Monday Night Football
description: If you have a yen to improve your skills in either fly tying or fly fishing, you might wish to sign up for the classes being offered by the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited.

title: Robert J. Stephens, 51; Headed Magnet School
description: Robert J. Stephens, a principal in the New Rochelle, N.Y., school system who directed one of the nation's first elementary-school magnet programs focusing on the humanities, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51 years old.

title: New Problems for Giants: Elway, Denver Defense
description: For the Giants, it looks like a case of going from one frying pan into another and another and another.

title: Upheaval in the East; Citizenship Once Again?
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and others exiled from the Soviet Union for dissenting views may have their citizenship back on request, according to the head of a parliamentary commission.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Monday about cast changes in ''Rigoletto'' at the Metropolitan Opera referred incorrectly to a radio broadcast celebrating the company's 50th season. The program, heard on Saturday, was a mixture of live interviews and excerpts from previous years' broadcasts, not a recording of Richard Strauss's ''Frau Ohne Schatten.''

title: Dully, Leonard Defeats Duran to Retain Title
description: The war was a bore.

title: Bonwit Sale Move
description: The L. J. Hooker Corporation said it would seek approval of a Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to retain Financo Inc. to sell its Bonwit Teller and Sakowitz Inc. specialty stores. Financo is a New York investment banker specializing in mergers and acquisitions. Sanford C. Sigoloff, Hooker's chief executive, said Bonwit Teller continued to show improvement, but ''Hooker management felt that the best way to maximize returns was through a sale.'' Hooker, which is also closing its B. Altman & Company stores, is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Obscenity in Art Cannot Be Generalized
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out
description: When I was a typical wide-eyed youngster coming to New York City from rural New Jersey with my mother to see the holiday sights, fine dining was not exactly high on my shopping list. Sitting in a hushed dining room for an hour would have been as torturous as being shackled to the sofa on Christmas morning and watching my sister tear open all my presents. On these annual excursions, we usually wound up at the old Reuben's on Madison Avenue at East 58th Street, a cheerful place where mile-high sandwiches were named after celebrities.

title: Double Premiere
description: Paul Lustig Dunkel will conduct the American Composers Orchestra in the world premiere of Michelle Ekizian's ''Beyond the Reach of Wind and Fire'' and the New York premiere of Frank Ticheli's ''Images of a Storm'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The program also includes Wallingford Riegger's Variations for Piano and Orchestra, with Ruth Laredo as the soloist, and George Rochberg's Symphony No. 2. Maro Partamian, a mezzo-soprano, is to be the soloist in Ms. Ekizian's work. Tickets are $9 to $28. Information: 247-7800.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: European Jobless Rate
description: The unemployment rate in the European Community held steady at 9.1 percent in October, the same as in September, but was down from 9.7 percent a year earlier, the community's statistical office, Eurostat, said today.

title: Warning on Highway Crime
description: The New Jersey state police said today that 10 motorists on Interstate 280 in the Newark area have been robbed since September after pulling off the highway because their cars had been bumped from behind.

title: Bush Plan Misses Root Cause of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM
description: Parents who plan to take children to the movies often find themselves asking what Laurence Olivier asked in ''Marathon Man'': ''Is it safe?'' Seeking out children's films that are diverting and fun is only half the game. The other half is making sure that you aren't awake at 3 in the morning explaining that even though the tree in ''The Wizard of Oz'' got angry at Dorothy for taking an apple, the tree on your front lawn isn't mad at you. Anyone who's ever weathered one of these middle-of-the-night, movie-induced crises would probably like to avoid going through another.

title: Classical Music
description: Anyone with children has the opportunity for hands-on expertise in taking them to concerts; anyone else is a mere critic. My own experience in these matters extends to a 14-month-old, which means I have not yet really confronted the issue of which concerts my own child might enjoy. That doesn't mean she doesn't like music, if dancing in front of a loudspeaker counts (sometimes before it's even warmed up and actually emitting sound), or clambering up on the piano bench to make tone clusters. (Henry Cowell gets the credit for inventing clusters, but that's a blatant case of adultism.) For children 3 or 4 and up, actually, we all have some experience, be it with friends' or relatives' offspring or from observation of strangers (usually testy and disgruntled observations, if the subject is fussing).

title: Florio's First Appointee: A Former U.S. Attorney
description: Governor-elect James J. Florio stayed with experience today by naming for his first cabinet appointment Robert J. Del Tufo, a former United States Attorney for New Jersey, as attorney general.

title: U.S.S. Iowa Returns to Port
description: The battleship U.S.S. Iowa, its No. 2 turret still sealed after an April explosion that killed 47 sailors, arrived today to cheers from the crew's family and friends after a six-month deployment in the Mediterranean. The crew lined the rail as the Iowa docked at its home port. About 1,000 family members and friends, who greeted the sight of the ship with cheers, waited patiently for her to dock.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Official Imprisoned
description: The president of the Alabama chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People began serving a four-year jail term here Wednesday on Federal bribery charges. Thomas Reed, 61 years old, was ousted from his seat in the Alabama Legislature after he was convicted in September 1988 of accepting $10,000 as a bribe.

title: New York Recycling Program Reaches a Million Households
description: The number of New York City households that recycle trash reached one million yesterday in a program that is intended to cover all of the city's three million households by 1992.

title: Retirement Ends Reign Of Corroons at Company
description: A landmark of sorts was reached yesterday at the Corroon & Black Corporation when Robert F. Corroon stepped down as chairman and the New York-based insurance brokerage found itself for the first time without a member of the founding Corroon family in top management.

title: Metro Datelines; Repairs to the IND May Cost $20 Million
description: Cleaning up the IND subway after a water-main break on Saturday in Harlem may cost $20 million, a transit official said yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Prague's Invisible Liberator
description: An oddly revealing sight in Prague is the Museum of Czech Literature in the ancient Strahov Library. Here visitors are shown the books and authors that supposedly formed the consciousness of a nation - yet Thomas Masaryk is absent, which is like blotting Jefferson from American literature.

title: First Interstate Moves To Shore Up Reserves
description: The First Interstate Bancorp, plagued by troubles in the Southwest, moved to clean up its money-losing Texas operation today by adding $400 million to reserves before selling problem assets.

title: Profit Up 23% At Grand Met
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. reported today that its profits jumped 23 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, with higher revenue from its food, beverage and retailing operations.

title: Somerset Gets Bid
description: Somerset Bankshares Inc. said it had received an unsolicited takeover offer of $10.50 a share from Von Seldeneck, Snyder & Company, a Philadelphia-based firm, for its outstanding shares. The company said the proposal would be referred to its directors. Somerset's shares jumped $1.875 today, to $6.125, in over-the-counter trading, where its gain of 44.1 percent was the day's second best.

title: G.M. Chief to Head Panel
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday named Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, to head a panel on program trading and market volatility.

title: Cuomo at Odds With Top Judge On Budget Plea
description: Just in time to enliven Albany's dreary year-end political scene, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, today began their annual squabble over the state judiciary budget.

title: Option Granted On Fischbach
description: The Miami financier Victor Posner said today that he had granted to American International Group Inc. the option to buy his controlling interest in the Fischbach Corporation, the nation's largest electrical contractor.

title: Cream of China's Crop
description: To the Editor:

title: John Payne, 77, Actor, Is Dead; Lawyer in 'Miracle on 34th Street'
description: John Payne, an all-around actor who starred in nearly 50 films, mostly in the 1940's and 50's, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: 20th-Century Ensemble
description: Robert Craft, the conductor and critic, will lead the 20th-Century Classics Ensemble and the Gregg Smith Singers at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening at 8. The program includes Edgard Varese's ''Ionisation''; Elliott Carter's Double Concerto for Harpsichord, Piano and Two Chamber Orchestras; Arnold Schoenberg's ''Herzgewachse'' (Op. 20), and Igor Stravinsky's ''Reynard,'' ''Oche Nasch'' and ''Les Noces.'' Mark Wait, a pianist, and Thomas Schultz, a harpsichordist, will be the soloists in the Carter work, and Rebecca Sherburn, a soprano, is to be the soloist in the Schoenberg. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: KEY RATES
Russian Team to Face U.S. Collegiate Squads
description: The presence of a Russian hockey team in the United States may no longer be news, but the upcoming tour of Sokol-Kiev, an elite team, is different. The squad will play five games against college teams and then a two-game series against the USA Selects, the latter an All-Star team of current college players.

title: Review/Film; Madonna in a Runyon Reincarnation
description: ''Bloodhounds of Broadway'' attempts to rediscover the slangy, exuberant life embedded in Damon Runyon's sentimental fables of long ago. At its heart are more or less the same Broadway characters apotheosized in Frank Loesser's classic ''Guys and Dolls.''

title: Head of Air Force Says Cuts In Spending May Delay B-2
description: Donald B. Rice, the Secretary of the Air Force, said today that he was considering a slowdown in production of the B-2 Stealth bomber as military spending declines.

title: Cello Concerto
description: Daniel Gaisford will be the soloist with the Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra in Dvorak's Cello Concerto in B minor (Op. 104) tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The program, which is to be conducted by Andrew Massey, also includes Delius's ''Walk to the Paradise Garden'' and Strauss's ''Metamorphosen.'' Tickets are $5. Information: 840-2824.

title: Priest Tells of His Role In Nevada Bomb Tests
description: As an Episcopal priest, Bob Nelson prays that no one will ever use what he helps to make in his day job.

title: Lenny Pickett
description: Lenny Pickett, a saxophonist and composer, is to perform new pieces on Sunday at 9 P.M. at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street in TriBeCa (219-8242). Tickets are $6.

title: Hang the Straphanger, Subway Runs On Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Players and Owners Taking Divergent Courses in Talks
description: Not that anybody expected baseball's labor negotiations to proceed smoothly and quickly, but with the two sides talking on two different planes, the owners and the players will very likely take a long time to get nowhere.

title: When New York, to a Child, Is a Stocking Full of Gifts
description: Everyone talks about how magical New York is for children at Christmas, but coping with the city at holiday time is never easy. Here and on page C22 are suggestions from seven New York Times critics on how to give children the best of New York in every realm, from architecture to theater to restaurants. A listing of children's holiday activities appears on page C23.

title: Review/Art; Focusing the Images Of Philip Evergood
description: There is plenty to see, and plenty to think about, in the small-scale retrospective of paintings by Philip Evergood (1901-1973) at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery. In histories of 20th-century American art, Evergood has a way of falling through the cracks. He was a moralist when moralizing was not thought to be one of a serious painter's options. He had a vein of offhand bawdry that did not fit well with the stern judgments that he passed upon the public events of his day. Was he preacher or clown, historian or vaudeville act? What were we to make of a painter who was one day a horseman of the Apocalypse, the next day a student of social comedy?

title: Chairman Is Selected For British Railways
description: The British Government yesterday confirmed the appointment of Robert Paul Reid as chairman of the British Railways Board.

title: Metro Datelines; Contracts Awarded For Shoreham Study
description: The board of trustees of the Long Island Power Authority voted yesterday to hire three consulting companies to study whether the Shoreham power plant can be converted to burn non-nuclear fuel.

title: Peter Sellars Cancels Brooklyn 'Tannhauser'
description: A production by the director Peter Sellars of Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' announced for June at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has been canceled, the academy's president, Harvey Lichtenstein, said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Company Pays Tribute to Its Founder
description: The end is a new beginning, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater proclaimed eloquently on Wednesday night at the City Center. The company's members, hardly low on energy at any time, danced their hearts out as never before - in tribute to their founder and artistic director.

title: Who Can Predict Our Life in the Greenhouse?; Dueling Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban of Goalie Upheld
description: Soccer's governing body yesterday upheld its decision to ban the Chilean goalie Roberto Rojas from international play for life. Rojas was banned for feigning an injury in a World Cup qualifying match with Brazil. Rojas spoke for a half-hour before the appeals section of the Federation Internationale de Football Association in Rome but did not persuade the organization to overturn its decision.

title: Upheaval in the East; Czech Premier Quits As Dissidents Press To Control Cabinet
description: Ladislav Adamec resigned today as Czechoslovakia's Communist Prime Minister and was replaced by his relatively unknown 43-year-old deputy. Mr. Adamec reportedly felt that the new leader would find it easier to put together a cabinet acceptable to the opposition led by Civic Forum.

title: Holiday Tales for Children
description: Holiday pageants, plays, musicals and puppet shows are enchanting young audiences throughout the New York City area. Although geared to children, many ought to appeal to adults as well.

title: Officials in Philippines Tell How Leadership Nearly Lost
description: As Philippine rebel troops returned to their barracks in an uneasy truce, officials here said today that the top military and political leadership of the country was nearly toppled a week ago at the height of the military rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: New Jersey Acts to Save a Pygmy Forest of Pine and Oak
description: Sections of southern New Jersey's pygmy forest, where decades-old pitch pines and blackjack oaks reach only four to six feet in height, have been owned by the state for years, but environmentalists feared they still were not adequately protected.

title: Dow Falls By 15.99; Chevron Off
description: Stocks moved broadly lower yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.99 points, to 2,720.78.

title: Hoyas Give Big East Tie With A.C.C.
description: The intensity that John Thompson prefers to develop in his basketball laboratory on the campus of Georgetown University was revealed tonight for the sake of college basketball's latest profit-making venture.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The Zanuck Company

title: Who Can Predict Our Life in the Greenhouse; A Net Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner-Viacom Talks
description: Direct negotiations between Viacom Inc. and Time Warner Inc. to settle Viacom's $2.5 billion suit against Time Warner finally began this week. In the suit Viacom charged that Home Box Office has used anti-competitive practices in its dealings with Showtime, Viacom's pay television service.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flyers 4, Sabres 3: Ron Sutter scored 1 minute 24 seconds into overtime last night in Philadelphia, beating the goalie, Darren Puppa, with a backhander from the goal mouth after Buffalo had forced overtime by rallying from a 3-1 deficit on a goal by Mike Foligno with 11 seconds left in regulation. Philadelphia outshot Buffalo, 37-25, and limited Buffalo to only three shots on goal in the final 12 minutes of regulation time.(AP) Whalers 4, Bruins 3: Hartford won in Boston Garden as Mikael Andersson tied the score at 11:58 of the opening period and set up Ray Ferraro's go-ahead goal at 16:56. Boston rallied on goals by Lyndon Byers and Bobby Carpenter, but Peter Sidorkiewicz, the Hartford goaltender, made 29 saves for his third victory in 10 decisions this season.(AP) Maple Leafs 5, Blues 2: Mark Osborne had his second consecutive two-goal game for visiting Toronto, and a second-period goal by a rookie, John McIntyre, broke a tie, putting Toronto ahead, 3-2, at 13:52 of the second period. Brett Hull scored both goals for St. Louis and moved into the league lead with 22 this season.(AP) N.B.A. Blazers 96, Hornets 86: Buck Williams had a season-high 23 points and 17 rebounds last night to lead visiting Portland. Clyde Drexler of Portland had 25 points to lead all scorers. The Hornets (3-14) have the worst record in the league.(AP) Jazz 107, Mavericks 97: Karl Malone scored 31 points and John Stockton had 22 plus 13 assists as Utah won at home. Dallas had a 31-25 lead 9:48 into the second quarter, outscoring Utah, 10-2, in the first 2:12 of the quarter. But Utah then had a 13-2 streak in the next 2:27, going ahead to stay.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Fordham 77, Army 64: Andre McClendon scored 26 points last night to lead visiting Fordham. There were six lead changes and five ties before the Rams (4-1 over all and 1-0 in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference) went on a 16-6 run over the final six minutes of the first half to turn a 1-point deficit into a 34-25 halftime lead.(AP) Boston College 92, Brown 63: Doug Able scored 18 points and Lior Arditti, a freshman guard, made four 3-point shots in nine attempts to lead Boston College at home. Boston College (4-1) outrebounded Brown, 43-29(AP) Connecticut 79, Hartford 54: Chris Smith scored 16 points for Connecticut in Hartford, and Tate George's six assists gave him 539 for his career, pushing him past Karl Hobbs (534) as Connecticut's career assists leader.(AP) GOLF Surprise Leader: Lee Trevino, playing in his first tournament on the Senior PGA Tour, overcame bogeys on the first two holes yesterday and shot a 3-under-par 69 in the Kaanapali Classic in Hawaii. Trevino completed the first round five strokes in back of the surprise leader, Joe Jimenez, 63 years old, who has never won on the PGA or the Senior Tours. Trevino did not make a birdie until the 11th hole, but played the back nine in 5 under par and had a string of three consecutive birdies. Dale Douglass, who chipped in for an eagle in a bogey-free round, was second with a 66 in the 54-hole tournament. Doe Bies, Homero Blancas and Bob Boldt were next at 68.(AP)

title: Scholar Wins His Libel Case Over Statue
description: The Renaissance scholar at the center of a dispute about a plaster statue he has said was the model for Michelangelo's David has won $:7,500 (around $12,000) in damages in an English High Court in a libel case against The Independent newspaper.

title: U.S. Confirms Iraq Has Launched Rocket That Can Carry Satellites
description: The Bush Administration today confirmed Iraq's statement that the Baghdad Government has launched a rocket capable of putting a satellite in orbit.

title: Delays Increase At Region's Airports
description: Arrivals and departure delays over 15 minutes have grown sharply at New york area airports this year, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. LaGuardia has one of the worst records in the country. Article, page 27.

title: East Berlin's Fall: Party Seeks an Out
description: Whatever else they were saying at a party congress tonight, the East German Communists had really gathered to bury the remnants of a party that had ruled with an iron hand for 40 years, in the hope that something new could still sprout in its place.

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero: Deputy Mayor
description: As a child, she says, she was extremely shy, and to this day her mother says, ''Sally never bothered anyone.'' This may surprise those who have worked for and with Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, New York City's Commissioner of Financial Services, who was named yesterday to be deputy mayor for finance and economic development.

title: History of Another 'Apres-Midi d'un Faune'
description: Vaslav Nijinsky's strange and haunting ballet ''L'Apres-midi d'un Faune,'' created in 1912 for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, has enjoyed new popularity in recent years. But is the popular version entirely authentic? Ann Hutchinson Guest, the founder and former director of the Dance Notation Bureau in New York, says it is not. Tonight through Monday at the Juilliard Theater, the Juilliard Dance Ensemble will perform a version she says is closer to recently discovered notes by the choreographer.

title: Cynthia Hughes, Grenadian Journalist, 72
description: Cynthia Hughes, co-editor and publisher of The Grenada Newsletter, died on Wednesday after a short illness. She was 72 years old, and the cause of death was not made public.

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Barbara Joelson Fife: Deputy Mayor
description: Barbara Joelson Fife is a classic case of civic leader become political leader.

title: Plan Seen as Hurdle to Correcting Census
description: The Federal Government issued a proposal today that creates new obstacles for New York City and other urban areas that seek to correct the 1990 census to make up for undercounting minorities and the poor.

title: Upheaval in the East; Attack on Depots Discounted
description: East Germany's National People's Army said today that there were no mob attacks on its depots this week. The denial was issued after Radio D.D.R. reported that that such attacks had taken place. A spokesman said that groups showed signs of wanting to attack the depots, perhaps to obtain weapons, but that they did not carry out the attacks.

title: CZECH CHIEF LOOKS TO INDEPENDENTS FOR NEW CABINET
description: Czechoslovakia's acting Prime Minister, in his second day in office, said tonight that he wanted half his cabinet to be made up of people outside political parties. Such a cabinet would put the Communists in a minority and go a long way toward meeting opposition demands.

title: Car Mishap Idles Reekie
description: Joe Reekie, the Islander defenseman who has been an important part of the team's four-game string of victories, broke two bones in his left hand in a car accident in Huntington, L.I., early yesterday and could miss four weeks of play.

title: This $250 for Neediest Arrives With a Boop-Boop-a-Doop
description: Some letters in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund mailbag stand apart because they come from recognizable names, others because they come from unexpected places, still others because they offer a flash of humor in a sea of sympathetic thoughts.

title: Better Traps Being Built For Delinquent Parents
description: The Delaware County Domestic Relations Court here has devised a new way to find people who fail to pay child support and elude arrest: the court advertises their names on a ''Most Wanted'' list 300 times a week on cable television and once a month in full-page newspaper advertisements.

title: Proposals to Campeau For Bloomingdale's
description: As the deadline for initial proposals to purchase Bloomingdale's expired yesterday, the Campeau Corporation said it had received expressions of interest from a number of parties seeking to acquire the chain of 17 stores. A definitive announcement on the sale is expected to be made in February, Campeau added.

title: Storms Force Postponement Of Commercial Rocket Flight
description: Stormy weather today forced the postponement of the launching of a Titan 3 rocket with British and Japanese communications satellites.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our next election is not until 1992. Those who want to be president will have to wait until then.'' - President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines. [ 3:3. ]

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Economic Watch; New Soviet Blueprint Seeks a Middle Road
description: By almost everyone's reckoning, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has stumbled badly in his initial efforts to rebuild the Soviet economy from the ruins of Stalinist central planning. The 64-billion-ruble question is whether Mr. Gorbachev can succeed in his mission to find an alternative to capitalism that does not clash with the peculiarly Russian sense of order and economic justice.

title: Barbara Curran Wed in Scarsdale
description: Barbara Shay Curran and Norman Thomas MacDonald were married yesterday at the bride's home in Scarsdale, N.Y., by Justice Thomas J. Lowery Jr. of State Supreme Court in Syracuse. Mrs. MacDonald is a daughter of Helen Butler Shay of New Haven and the late Dr. Francis L. Shay. Mr. MacDonald is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. MacDonald of Thornwood, N.Y.

title: 4,500 People Attend Ailey Memorial Service at St. John the Divine
description: There were tears and laughter, public praise and personal anecdote as some 4,500 people commemorated Alvin Ailey yesterday in ''The Celebration of Alvin Ailey Jr., Going Home,'' a memorial and funeral service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The modern-dance choreographer and founder and director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater died of a blood disorder on Dec. 1 at the age of 58. He will be buried in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies yesterday on the obituary of a labor and civil rights leader misidentified him.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Nuggets 103, Celtics 102: Michael Adams scored 18 of his 20 points in the second half as Denver overcame a 16-point deficit last night at Boston Garden. Trailing by 1 point, Boston got the ball with 23 seconds left when Larry Bird won a jump ball from Adams. But Kevin McHale missed a 12-foot jumper with 5 seconds left and the ball bounced off the rim and rolled to midcourt as time ran out.(AP) 76ers 107, Pistons 101: Johnny Dawkins scored a season-high 26 points and Rick Mahorn had 22 points and 14 rebounds against his former teammates in a game in Detroit. Charles Barkley, back after missing two games with a viral infection, gave Philadelphia its biggest lead, 92-79, on a fourth-quarter layup.(AP) Heat 122, Magic 114: Sherman Douglas, a rookie, scored a season-high 31 points, including two free throws with 25 seconds left to force overtime, as Miami, playing at home, ended a losing streak at nine games.(AP) Hawks 127, Trail Blazers 120: Moses Malone scored 31 points, including 19 of 22 free throws, as Atlanta at home. Portland, which never led, trailed by 119-117 on Kevin Porter's fourth 3-point basket of the game with 52 seconds to play. But Glenn Rivers countered with a 3-pointer with 29 seconds left for Atlanta.(AP) Spurs 99, Mavericks 93: David Robinson scored 22 of his 29 points in the second half as San Antonio overcame an 11-point fourth-quarter deficit in Dallas.(AP) Suns 123, Bucks 98: Tom Chambers scored 24 of his season-high 41 points in the first half, and Mark West had a career-high 24 rebounds in a rout in Phoenix. Milwaukee's coach, Del Harris, got two technical fouls and was ejected with 30 seconds left in the third quarter. Phoenix went on to build a 117-81 with five minutes to play.(AP) Pacers 106, Bulls 104: Chuck Person's 20-footer at gave Indiana a victory at home. Just before, Scott Pippen made a 3-point shot to tie the score for Chicago. Both teams played tough, physical defense; Indiana had only four field goals in the final nine minutes. The Bulls were called for an illegal defense with 55.7 seconds to play.(AP) EXHIBITION HOCKEY Flames 6, Khimik Voskresensk 3: Sergei Makarov scored two goals against his former countrymen as Calgary won this exhibition hockey game last night. A crowd of 11,873 half-filled the Olympic Saddledome in Calgary, Alberta, to observe the top team in the Soviet Union. Calgary overcame a 2-1 deficit early in the second period, and outshot the Soviet National League's leaders, 33-18.

title: Correction
description: An editorial last Saturday mistakenly asserted that Mackinac Island was in the district of Representative Bob Traxler, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Traxler bought property on Mackinac and championed a H.U.D. project there, but the island is represented by a Republican, Robert Davis.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Shopping for a Nursing Home
description: The need to find a nursing home often comes suddenly, requiring quick decisions. Although only 5 percent of the nation's elderly are in nursing homes at any time, about 20 to 30 percent of the population can expect to enter a home during their lifetime.

title: Prefight Show a Hit; Main Event a Big Dud
description: In the darkness of the desert night, the new Mirage casino offered an elaborate fireworks display Thursday night as a prelude to its main event.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the dropping of administrative charges against two doctors at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Luise M. Weinstein and Gregg W. Stone, misstated conclusions of a grand jury that examined the death of 18-year-old Libby Zion after treatment at that hospital. The jury, which issued no indictment, said ''a definitive cause of death cannot be established.'' It did not say the death resulted from inadequacy of care.

title: Upheaval in the East; Friendly Arms Negotiators Announce Agreements
description: American and Soviet negotiators ended a 10-week round of arms talks here today with agreement on two joint verification exercises that are to begin well before a strategic arms reduction treaty is signed.

title: Unsticking Sticky Tags
description: Those stubborn price tags that stick tenaciously to holiday gifts can generally be removed with a little patience and the right remedy.

title: Girl Gets Liver From Father In 2d Live-Donor Transplant
description: Surgeons completed the nation's second liver transplant from a living donor tonight, removing part of the liver of a 20-year-old Tennessee man and implanting it in his 15-month-old daughter.

title: Ethics Courses Help Prevent Moral Nomadism; Citizens Face All Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Bill Lynch: Deputy Mayor
description: Bill Lynch may be the only politician in New York City who has gone from chief of a crew of migrant laborers on eastern Long Island to deputy mayor at City Hall.

title: Computers Speed Up Post Office Service
description: New computers have arrived at the United States Postal Service in time to speed some holiday lines. They are not everywhere yet, but the new devices handle virtually all of the manual transactions once performed by the clerk.

title: Players Still Seem Cool To Pay-for-Performance
description: Baseball's players are continuing to indicate that they will reject the owners' plan for a pay-for-performance salary scale, although the players also continue to say they do not yet have enough information to make a judgment on the issue.

title: Andrew Lorant And Miss Faraggi Have Wedding
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, Vicky-Anne Faraggi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Faraggi of Montreal, was married yesterday to Andrew Leopold Laszlo Lorant, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Laszlo Lorant of Paris. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Mary Schmidt Campbell: Commissioner of Cultural Affairs
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins surprised no one when he said yesterday that he would reappoint Mary Schmidt Campbell as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. It was Mr. Dinkins who recommended Ms. Campbell for the job to Mayor Edward I. Koch in the fall of 1987.

title: Nets' Victory Gives Fitch Sweet Revenge
description: Of the Nets' five victories this season, tonight's was the most unexpected and the most satisfying.

title: Despite Miscues, Parcells Confident in Simms
description: It has been an awful two weeks for Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback.

title: Intel Shifts Output
description: The Intel Corporation, which has been shifting production to newer factories in other states, said it would phase out its last chip plant in Silicon Valley. Intel, Silicon Valley's largest chip maker, said it would stop building microcircuits at its nine-year-old plant here in the next 18 months and switch the building to other uses. The change will affect about 400 workers, but the company was optimistic it could put most of them in other jobs. The company says the San Francisco Bay area's high housing costs are one reason it has been moving production to Arizona, New Mexico and Oregon.

title: Hungary Asks Soviets to Base Trade on Dollars
description: Seeking to expand trade with the West and bolster its economic efficiency, Hungary has moved to have its trade with the Soviet Union settled in dollars instead of rubles, State Department officials said today.

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Susan E. Shepard: Investigation Commissioner
description: Susan E. Shepard, who was named yesterday to head the Department of Investigation, may soon find herself in the awkward position of inheriting an investigation of the man who hired her, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins.

title: Unions, Docile Since '81, Show New Militancy
description: The militancy that has made workers' movements so conspicuous in the struggle for human rights in Eastern Europe, China and Latin America shows incipient signs of resurgence in the U.S. trade unions for the first time since Ronald Reagan fired 11,500 striking Federal air traffic controllers and smashed their union in 1981.

title: Man in the News; A SAVVY AND EFFICIENT MANAGER
description: When Norman Steisel became New York City's Sanitation Commissioner in 1978, he inherited a department in chaos. Half the equipment was out of service, the work force was demoralized, there were no long-range plans to cope with a looming garbage crisis, and city streets from Riverdale to Far Rockaway were filthy.

title: Chevron Acts to Bar Pennzoil
description: In what some analysts said was a surprisingly fast rush to the barricades, the Chevron Corporation said today that it had asked a Federal court to force the Pennzoil Company to sell its 8.8 percent stake in Chevron and to block Pennzoil from buying more shares.

title: 2 Investigators Are Convicted In Jersey Trial
description: Two Essex County investigators were convicted by a Federal jury today of protecting a drug dealer, who is an admitted killer, in exchange for cocaine, cash and valuables.

title: Bridge
description: The first step toward determining the 1989-90 College Champions was taken Nov. 21, when six teams in a field of 22 qualified for playoffs in Fort Worth, Tex. in March. Competing there will be, in qualifying order, Harvard, Virginia, Brown, Illinois, Caltech and Rice, who survived ''Instant Imp'' contests on their own campuses.

title: Upheaval in the East; Political Turmoil in East Germany Is Keeping Writers Too Busy to Write
description: East Germany's writers are not writing much in these turbulent days.

title: Art Fairs: A Panel Surveys Them As Los Angeles Opens Its Fourth
description: An unusual double bill took place here this week: the opening of ''L.A. Art 89,'' the fourth annual Los Angeles art fair, and ''Art Fairs: Plans and Process,'' a two-day symposium convened to discuss the increasing effect of such fairs as they spread throughout the world.

title: Gunman Kills Four and Then Himself
description: A gunman armed with a shotgun and handgun broke into the home of his former wife early today and killed her, their two daughters and her new husband before killing himself, the authorities said.

title: Sinking the Boat People
description: Nothing is more unfashionable than yesterday's victims. This is the fate of more than 50,000 Vietnamese boat people now threatened with forced repatriation from refugee camps in Hong Kong. No longer ''victims of Communist tyranny,'' they are merely ''illegal immigrants,'' in the words of Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain. According to her Foreign Office, their return is not ''forced'' but ''involuntary.'' This nice distinction will bring no comfort to those about to be repatriated.

title: Upheaval in the East; A Top Prague Communist Who Knows the Winds
description: He occupies a luxurious office as head of a major Czechoslovak Communist Party institution and is driven around in a black Tatra, a limited-production automobile assigned as a perk to the leaders of the nation.

title: Upheaval in the East; Prague's Velvet Revolutionaries Recall John Lennon
description: As dusk fell today, Vladimir Sraier, an advertising agent in a gray windbreaker, stood in a large crowd, a lighted candle in hand, at a tawny stuccoed wall in the part of Prague called the Lesser Side.

title: About New York; One Last Wish: Happy Memories Of Lisa Bilotti
description: Humans seemed tiny in the huge vaulted space that is St. Ignatius Loyola Church at Park Avenue and 84th Street. The organ droned. The flowers were beautiful. ''Tragic, tragic, tragic,'' said a woman, talking to herself and sobbing.

title: Upheaval in the East; Castro Says He'll Resist Changes Like Those Sweeping Soviet Bloc
description: In his bluntest public rejection yet of the profound political and economic changes now sweeping the rest of the Soviet bloc, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has vowed to resist all such reforms even if it means a parting of the ways with his allies.

title: Editor of The Chicago Tribune Quits His Job
description: James D. Squires, editor of The Chicago Tribune since 1981, resigned yesterday and the paper's executive editor, Jack Fuller, was selected to replace him.

title: Patents; Whooping Cough Gets New Vaccine
description: A tiny portion of the children who are vaccinated against whooping cough, a sometimes fatal childhood illness, suffer severe side effects that leave them brain-damaged or dead. Using a newly patented gene, researchers are now developing a vaccine without the dangers of the original one.

title: Brookens to Indians
description: The Cleveland Indians picked up more infield experience yesterday, signing Tom Brookens, a free agent, to a one-year contract. Brookens, 36 years old, spent nine years with the Detroit Tigers and went to the Yankees last March 23 for the pitcher Charles Hudson. He has played third base, shortstop and second, and has a career batting average of .245.

title: Reading and Writing, Knives and Guns
description: In recent weeks, 10 New York City public school students have been shot, eight fatally. On Halloween, nearly half of New York's high school students stayed home, fearing violence. Since then, store owners, pedestrians and subway riders have been terrorized by ''posses,'' disorderly gangs of youths bent on rowdiness, assault and robbery.

title: U.S. Contractor Cites 2 Officials In a Guilty Plea
description: The long-running inquiry into Pentagon fraud edged closer to former senior Defense Department officials today when a New York military contracting company admitted in court that it had illegally obtained inside purchasing information from the Navy and Air Force.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-10 Forming a Czechoslovak cabinet in which half the members do not belong to political parties is the goal of the Acting Prime Minister, he said. This would in effect mean a government in which the Communist Party would be a minority. Page 1 Portrait of top Czech Communists hit by change 9 Prague marks the anniversary of John Lennon's death 9 East Germany's Communist Party met in an emergency congress and began a debate on its own survival. A large part of the session was televised throughout the country. 1 News analysis: The Communists in East Germany seem on the verge of complete collapse, as their leaders prepare to jettison much of the Party's structure and citizens seethe with feelings of deep betrayal. 1 Turmoil is keeping East German writers too busy to write 8 Plans for a European central bank and common currency moved foward at a meeting of European Community leaders over strong objections from Prime Minister Thatcher. 1 Soviet Communist Party leaders signaled that the issue of altering the Party's guaranteed primacy in Soviet society is not off limits, but that such a move would harm the nation. 10 Bulgaria party purges more members 10 A plan for the Soviet economy that would help raise living standards without abandoning the egalitarian principles on which the Soviet Communist Party bases its legitimacy is Moscow's latest hope. Western analysts are divided over the plan's significance. 33 Soviets seek U.S. venture 33 South Korea and the Soviet Union announced an unusual form of consular relations that many analysts consider a significant step toward full diplomatic relations. 3 Castro says he will resist Soviet-style change in Cuba 9 Solzhenitsyns criticize Soviet offer of return 10 Arms negotiators announce agreements 10 President Aquino named three men - the country's Vice President, its chief opposition leader and her own cousin - as the leading suspects in instigating the abortive rebellion against her Government. 3 The campus killings in Montreal have shaken the national psyche, leaving Canadians with the feeling that they may not, as many have long supposed, be more immune to such horrors than their neighbors in the United States. 6 A nation of Indian Ocean Islands, the Comoros, is in turmoil 12 days after the assassination of its president. A mercenary who had helped the President come to power is now the focus of much concern. 1 Salvador says informer tied American to arms 6 New Indian leader looks to Sri Lanka 5 U.S. confirms Iraq has launched rocket that can carry satellites 7 National 11-13, 26 An inquiry into Pentagon fraud edged closer to former senior Defense Department officials when a New York military contractor admitted in court that it had illegally obtained inside purchasing information from the Navy and Air Force. 1 Report contradicts nuclear official on reason for probe 12 Changes for the 1990 census that would be intended to compensate for undercounting of minorities and the poor will be difficult to achieve under a plan issued by the Federal Government. 13 A deer hunter was indicted for manslaughter in the accidental killing of a 37-year-old woman in her own backyard. It is the latest chapter of a case that has inflamed debate between hunters and non-hunters in Maine. 11 The economy generated more jobs in November, but the gains were not as great as the increase in the labor force, and the unemployment rate was up one-tenth of a point to 5.3 percent, said the Labor Department. 12 Nissan U.S.A. is being sued by a California family that feels its privacy was violated by a Japanese employee of the company who stayed with them as a house guest and took copious notes about the couple's life style. 11 People who fail to pay child support are being caught through innovative techniques. A Pennsylvania county, for instance, is broadcasting the names of delinquent parents on cable TV, and Texas plans to catch evaders with computers. 11 A Presidential trip to Colombia is planned in February for a regional meeting on drug trafficking, but some aides are concerned about safety and the Administration is taking another look at security at the proposed site, officials said. 12 Four psychologists cleared in Kitty Dukakis inquiry 26 Philadelphia journal: A city still lives with the Move bombing 11 Chicago Tribune editor resigns after eight-year stint 13 Regional 27-30 The site of an old family farm in Taylor, N.Y., is being offered by its owner as a location for a low-level radioactive waste dump. The move has the town in an uproar. 1 New Jersey's largest savings bank was seized by Federal regulators after the institution recorded large lossess from real estate ventures. 33 Air-traffic delays are up at the New York region's three major airports, even as an increase in air traffic has leveled off. La Guardia has been turning in one of the worst on-time performances in the nation. 27 Dinkins appointees were named for eight important positions, including an experienced Federal prosecutor to head the Department of Investigation. 27 The eight Dinkins appointees 28 Man in the news: Norman Steisel, who was named First Deputy Mayor, has nearly 16 years of experience in the city government and a reputation for management savvy. 27 The decentralized school system of New York City needs to be overhauled if the new chancellor is to succeed, said the president of the Board of Education, Robert Wagner, who suggested plans for change. 27 Two Essex County investigators were convicted by a Federal jury of protecting a drug dealer, who is an admitted killer, in exchange for cocaine, cash and valuables. 29 A teen-age drifter was arrested and accused of the fatal stabbing of an advertising executive on the Lower East Side, the police said. 29 Neediest Cases 30

title: Lawyer Nominated as Party Chief Defended East German Opposition
description: East Germany's Communist Party met in an emergency congress this morning and debated its own survival, nominating a lawyer as its new chairman.

title: Dinkins Names Eight Appointees, Including Four Deputy Mayors
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins named eight appointees to his administration yesterday, including an experienced Federal prosecutor to head the New York City Department of Investigation, with responsibility for uncovering corruption in government.

title: Bush Aides Wary of Trip to Columbia
description: President Bush still hopes to go to Colombia in February for a regional meeting on narcotics trafficking, but some aides have expressed concern about safety and the Administration is taking another look at security at the proposed site in Cartagena, officials said today.

title: Deer Hunter Is Indicted in Accidental Killing of Woman in Maine
description: A year after a grand jury declined to indict him, a second grand jury in Bangor today charged a deer hunter with manslaughter in the accidental killing of a 37-year-old woman in her backyard.

title: Domino's Pizza
description: Domino's Pizza Inc.'s owner, Tom Monaghan, said the company had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company and J. P. Morgan & Company to study the feasibility of an employee stock ownership plan. He said he would decide whether to put an ESOP into effect on completion of the study and would remain as chairman of Domino's if one was adopted.

title: Ryan May Start for Jets
description: Because Ken O'Brien, the Jets' quarterback, suffered two concussions and a jammed shoulder and had to be relieved in the team's last three games, Coach Joe Walton has been leaning toward starting Pat Ryan against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday in Giants Stadium. The start would be Ryan's first of the season.

title: Stanley Steingut, 69, Ex-Speaker Of New York Assembly, Dies at 69
description: Former New York State Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, the Brooklyn Democrat who was a longtime power in state politics, died early yesterday at the Tisch-University Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: CBS Abandons Its Effort To Hire 'Cosby' Producer
description: CBS's effort to hire Marcy Carsey, one of the producers of ''The Cosby Show'' and two other top-rated television series, as its new president of entertainment ended yesterday when the complicated deal could not be worked out in time to meet a deadline imposed by Laurence Tisch, CBS's chief executive officer.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Troupe In Homage To the Past
description: Usually, if not always, it is the major rather than the minor artist who acknowledges the existence of mentors. Alvin Ailey, typically, never tired of crediting those who inspired him in the late 1940's to become a professional dancer. These figures were Lester Horton, the modern-dance visionary in Los Angeles who recruited him into his company, and Katherine Dunham, one of the first performer-choreographers to bring the black heritage before a wide dance public.

title: Venture Law In East Berlin
description: The East German Cabinet has proposed a law on joint ventures with foreign companies and sent it to Parliament, according to a Government spokesman.

title: EUROPEAN LEADERS GIVE THEIR BACKING TO MONETARY PLAN
description: Overriding strong objections from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, leaders of the European Community took an important step today toward creating a central bank and a common currency for the 12-nation region.

title: Israel Unterman; Professor, 68
description: Israel Unterman, a professor of management at San Diego State University, died Dec. 1 from congestive heart failure at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: Chang Out 6-12 Weeks After Workout Injury
description: In a year in which he peaked in Paris in May, Michael Chang hit a valley in Florida yesterday. Chang, the first American man to win the French Open in 34 years, learned he would be sidelined 6 to 12 weeks after fracturing a hip joint Wednesday in practice for a tournament in Palm Coast this weekend.

title: CANADA UNNERVED BY SLAYINGS OF 14
description: Although Canada has witnessed mass killings over the years, none have involved so many deaths, or so profoundly shaken the national psyche, as the rampage this week at the University of Montreal.

title: Drifter Charged in Killing on Lower East Side
description: A teen-age drifter who ran away from a Louisiana psychiatric hospital three months ago was arrested yesterday and accused of the fatal stabbing of an advertising executive on the Lower East Side, the police said.

title: U.S. Seizes New Jersey Savings Bank
description: Federal regulators seized New Jersey's largest savings association today after the institution recorded large losses from real estate ventures in New Jersey, Florida and Texas.

title: Mercenary Holding Island Nation Seeks Deal
description: Col. Bob Denard was cheered as a hero in the Comoro Islands after he pulled off a bold coup in 1978 that returned Ahmed Abdallah Abderemane to the presidency of the Indian Ocean island nation.

title: PARTY IN BULGARIA EXTENDS ITS PURGE
description: The Communist Party expelled more of the old guard from its leadership today, leaving the ruling Politburo with only three members who were there when Todor Zhivkov was dismissed as party chief on Nov. 10.

title: Upheaval in the East; Article 6 of Soviet Charter
description: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party daily, said yesterday that any article of the Soviet Constitution ''may be reassessed or updated, even to the point of elimination.'' Pravda specifically mentioned Article 6, which insures Communist Party dominanc e. Here is the tex t of Article 6.

title: Marriage Rate Study Didn't 'Abandon' Statistic
description: To the Editor:

title: Click: Up, Down and Out at Kodak
description: In an unusually blunt shoot-out at the top, the Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that Kay R. Whitmore, the company's president, will succeed Colby H. Chandler as chief executive next year and that his chief rival for Mr. Chandler's job, J. Phillip Samper, will retire as vice chairman by the end of the year at the age of 55.

title: Fan Payments Denied
description: Jamelle Holieway, former Oklahoma University quarterback, has denied charges that he and Charles Thomas, another Oklahoma quarterback, received cash payments during their collegiate careers, payments originating from a football booster who lived in Tulsa.

title: Midcontinent Airlines Closes
description: Midcontinent Airlines Inc., a regional carrier that had been scaled down since Braniff Inc.'s bankruptcy filing, has ceased operations indefinitely. About 35 Midcontinent employees in Kansas City have been laid off, the carrier's chairman, Steve Gillette, said. The carrier had nearly 50 workers in its system, he said.

title: Producer Is Accused Of Cruising Projects For Sex With Boys
description: A movie producer was arrested yesterday and accused of picking up teen-age boys in New York City housing projects and taking them to New Jersey motels for sex, the police said.

title: Bad Omen For Army?
description: Black Jack, one of three mules used as mascots at the United States Military Academy, died of stomach cancer on Thursday, just two days before the Army-Navy football game at Giants Stadium. He was 10 years old.

title: Accounts Say Reporter Gave Advice to Dinkins
description: Albert Scardino, a New York Times reporter who has been named press secretary to Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, was reported yesterday to have met with Mr. Dinkins and campaign aides in the summer to give advice about the campaign.

title: FIFA Rejects NBC's Deal to Televise '94 World Cup
description: The executive committee of FIFA, soccer's international governing body, announced today that it would not approve the television contract arranged between the United States Soccer Federation and NBC for the 1994 World Cup tournament, which will be held in the United States.

title: High-Tech Home Care Under Scrutiny
description: These days, nurses from Tri-County Home Healthcare Services Inc. in Coral Springs, Fla., sometimes find more than a sick patient when they visit a home. Just-delivered boxes of complex home medical equipment may also clutter the doorstep of the ill.

title: Communist Orthodoxy Is Affirmed by Castro
description: Rejecting the political changes sweeping through the Soviet bloc, President Fidel Castro said Cuba will embrace hard-line Communism to the end.

title: Opera, Saturday Afternoon, Live
description: This afternoon's Texaco broadcast of Richard Strauss' ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten'' is a milestone for the Metropolitan Opera, opera in America and corporate support for the arts. It begins the 50th season of Saturday matinee grand opera on radio, live from the Metropolitan stage. And it marks the longest continuous sponsorship of any program by one company.

title: New Zealand Set for Appeal
description: The Mercury Bay Boating Club, the New Zealand club that lost last year's America's Cup competition to the San Diego Yacht Club, will file its appeal next week before New York state's highest court, club representatives said today.

title: Jobs Gain but So Does Joblessness As Expansion of Economy Slows
description: Despite a surge in layoffs and the eighth straight monthly decline in factory jobs, the economy continued to generate jobs in November, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A SOVIET WARNING ON CHANGE'S LIMITS
description: Seeking to forestall internal challenges to its guaranteed leading role in Soviet society, the Communist Party leadership signaled today that the issue is not off limits for discussion but said that such a change would harm the country.

title: Soviets Seek U.S. Venture
description: A Soviet research institute is negotiating to become a part owner of a Silicon Valley high-technology company.

title: At Least 3 Inmates Are Dead In Riots at 4 Polish Prisons
description: Inmates rioted at four prisons today after lawmakers rejected a proposed amnesty for repeat offenders, the authorities said. At least three prisoners died, the Government said, but the circumstances of the deaths were not clear.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Holiday Tipping
description: The holiday season is tipping time, and often it is hard to know what is fair or wanted. There are no hard, fast rules for tipping. If someone has been serving you all year and you tip regularly, your gift should reflect that fact as well as the quality of the service. How much you tip also depends on where you live. Here are some guidelines from professional associations for minimum tipping: $ Maitre d'hotel $50 to $100 Doorman, building superintendent $20 to $30 Handyman, porter, elevator operator $10 to $20 Maid One week's salary Care giver A week's salary or a gift equal in price Paper deliverer One month's service charge Other deliverer $10 to $30 Hairdresser, barber, manicurist At least 20 percent of the cost of one visit Sources: New York State Restaurant Association, Council of New York Cooperatives, National Academy of Nannies, American Federation of Home Health Agencies, Newspaper Route Dealers Association of Greater New York, Association of Cosmetologists and Hairdressers.

title: Upheaval in the East; Solzhenitsyns Brush Off Soviet Offer for a Return
description: The wife of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel laureate who was accused of treason, stripped of his Soviet citizenship and forcibly exiled from his homeland 15 years ago, said today that it was pointless to discuss Soviet offers to restore the author's citizenship because he has no plans to return to the Soviet Union.

title: Upheaval in the East; Benin, Too, Gives Up Marxism for Reforms
description: This West African nation today followed the lead of Eastern-bloc countries and abandoned Marxism-Leninism, its ideology for the last 15 years.

title: 4 Psychologists Cleared in Kitty Dukakis Inquiry
description: A state board has decided not to take disciplinary action against four psychologists who were quoted in a newspaper article that speculated about the possible reasons for Kitty Dukakis's depression and alcohol abuse.

title: Rogers Found Guilty
description: Five hours after beginning deliberations, a Circuit Court jury in Pontiac, Mich., yesterday found Reggie Rogers, a former Detroit Lions defensive end, guilty on three reduced counts of negligent homicide in the deaths of three teen-agers on Oct. 20, 1988, in a car accident involving Rogers. Circuit Judge Gene Schnelz scheduled sentencing for Jan. 16.

title: Osaka Journal; Impatient City's Mission: Steal Tokyo's Thunder
description: As if this proud commercial city didn't have enough problems, word got out recently that Godzilla would be rampaging through town.

title: Artists Defend Banned Film On St. Theresa's Visions
description: Artists and intellectuals testified this week in behalf of the first film in Britain to be banned for blasphemy.

title: Duran's Torture Chamber
description: In all the years since Cain and Abel threw boxing's first punches, Sugar Ray Leonard will be the first to reign as a champion on the last day of a decade after having reigned as a champion on the first day of the same decade. With his agile artistry again deflating Roberto Duran, in a unanimous 12-round decision, he will enter 1990 as the World Boxing Council's supermiddleweight champion after having entered 1980 as its welterweight champion.

title: Japanese Purchase Aids Bond Rally
description: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded and yields tumbled yesterday. Dealers said one reason for the market's rally was a substantial purchase of Treasury bonds by a Japanese brokerage house that many dealers refer to as the ''Billion Dollar Buyer,'' although the house has been known at times to sell just as equally large amounts of Treasury bonds.

title: Support Softens for Shamir's Hard Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about a concert by the American Chamber Players at the Frick Collection on Sunday misidentified the ensemble's violinist. She is Elisabeth Adkins.

title: Prague Memory
description: Pictures of protesters in Prague's Wenceslas Square evoke memories of September 1948, when I last saw crowds massed in that same historic center of the Czech capital. At that time the human flood was held back by an apparently impenetrable chain of armed militiamen.

title: Bush to Name Fed Governor
description: President Bush announced today that he would nominate David W. Mullins Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, to be a Federal Reserve Board governor.

title: The Dissidents Created Perestroika
description: LEAD: In an ironic twist of the Marxist credo, the workers have risen - not to enthrone Communism, but to bury it.

title: C.L. Dellums, 89; Led Rail Porters Union
description: C. L. Dellums, a labor and civil rights leader, died of cardiac arrest Thursday in Oakland, Calif., where he had lived for the last 66 years. He was 89 years old.

title: Whose Terms to Utilize In Describing Ethnicity
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about the Social Security Administration referred incorrectly in some editions to a Government assistance program from which people were suspended. It was the Supplemental Security Income Program, covering poor people who are aged, blind or disabled; the people were not suspended from the Social Security program. (The error also occurred in the front-page ''Inside'' listing and in a picture caption.)

title: Review/Music; Sinopoli and Philharmonic In Return to Mussorgsky
description: Because Giuseppe Sinopoli is frequently mentioned as a possible successor to Zubin Mehta as music director of the New York Philharmonic, his guest appearances at the head of the orchestra excite more than routine curiosity. In some respects, the bushy-bearded Italian is a puzzle, a conductor who is fascinated by the largest and gaudiest pieces in the repertory but does not seem to have a natural affinity for such extravagance.

title: Former Chairman of Haas Guilty in Penny Stock Fraud
description: The former chairman of a brokerage firm that collapsed after the market crash in October 1987 was convicted yesterday by a Federal jury in Manhattan of participating in a conspiracy to manipulate the prices of three over-the-counter stocks.

title: Upheaval in the East; Yugoslavia Separatists Urge Break With Serbian Republic
description: Anti-Communist opposition groups in the Yugoslav republic of Slovenia have joined forces and demanded a break of ties with Serbia.

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Victor A. Kovner: Corporation Counsel
description: Victor A. Kovner met David N. Dinkins when they were both Democratic district leaders in the 1960's, establishing a lasting friendship and political alliance.

title: Devils Lose on Late Tie Breaker by Lemieux
description: The one thing the Devils need right now, Coach John Cunniff said tonight after his team absorbed its fourth consecutive loss, is patience.

title: Dr. Esther Greenbaum, Psychiatrist, Dies at 80
description: Dr. Esther Greenbaum, a psychiatrist and educator, died of cancer Wednesday at Bronx Calvary Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Like Father, Increasingly Like Son
description: When Martin Keino, a 17-year-old senior at Fork Union Military Academy in Virginia, suddenly emerged this fall as one of the country's top high school distance runners, there was a logical explanation.

title: INSIDE
description: A 64-Billion-Ruble Question

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Nov. 15 about the Roundabout Theater Company's production of Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' misinterpreted a gesture. The actors' intent was to portray 18th-century gentlemen taking snuff, not cocaine.

title: Ethics Courses Help Prevent Moral Nomadism
description: To the Editor:

title: Heard the One About the East Friesians?
description: It was a complete coincidence that I happened to be reading Freud's ''Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious'' the day I was summoned to West Germany, not long ago. It was just prior to the eruption of nationalistic feeling, the mutual embrace of the two Germanys, the breach in the wall. Before I left, people kept asking why I was going.

title: Salvador Says Rebel Now Ties American to Arms
description: Senior army and police officials say a rebel gunrunner has told them that a woman seized last month in a raid on her property knew that a cache of weapons was buried there. The woman, who is being held without bond in a Salvadoran prison, has denied knowing of the arms cache.

title: Patents; Keeping the Fizz In Soft Drink Bottles
description: Two brothers have patented a new bottle for people who buy soft drinks in economical two-liter containers and want to drink them over time without losing the fizz. Working in their kitchen in Cherry Hill, N.J., Stephen and Robert Tullman have fashioned a bottle that they say keeps 68 percent of its carbonation several hours after being drained half empty, compared with about 19 percent for a conventional bottle.

title: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees; Albert Scardino: Press Secretary
description: ''The mayor of New York City is the second most important political figure in the country when it comes to setting the tone of public discourse,'' Albert Scardino said yesterday. ''To be able to help shape that tone is a truly remarkable opportunity for someone interested in public policy, which I am.''

title: Dow Gains 10.66 but Is Down for the Week
description: Helped by early strength in the bond market, stock prices rose modestly yesterday.

title: Vandeweghe Mending
description: Kiki Vandeweghe, the Knick forward who has been bothered by back problems and by tendinitis in his left foot, returned to New York from California on Thursday and worked out yesterday at the Knicks' practice center in Purchase, N.Y.

title: U.S. Argument In Lincoln Case
description: Government lawyers, trying to justify a Federal takeover last April of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, argued in court today that the company had attempted a number of times to portray itself as profitable when it was not.

title: May McClintock, 84, An Author and Editor
description: May Garelick McClintock, an author and editor of children's books, died of cancer Wednesday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: Air Traffic Being Delayed At Rising Rate
description: Air traffic delays are up dramatically at the New York region's three major airports, even as an increase in air traffic has leveled off.

title: Report Contradicts Reason Given By Nuclear Official for an Inquiry
description: An outside investigator has concluded that conflicts within the Nuclear Regulatory Commission led the agency to pursue a highly unusual investigation of a staff member last year. The conclusion contradicts an assertion by Victor Stello Jr., formerly the commission's chief of staff, that the reason for the inquiry was suspicion of wrongdoing that could affect safety.

title: Stuart Novins Is Dead; TV Reporter Was 75
description: Stuart Novins, a CBS news correspondent for 35 years, died of respiratory failure Thursday at Porter Medical Center in Middlebury, Vt. He was 75 years old and lived in Middlebury.

title: KEY RATES
AQUINO ACCUSES 3 OF LEADING REBELS
description: In her first public appearance since the Philippine Government was nearly toppled, an angry President Corazon C. Aquino today named three men - the country's Vice President, its chief opposition leader and her own cousin - as the leading suspects in the abortive rebellion.

title: Family Farmer Wants to Sell, But for a Radioactive Dump?
description: There have been Allens in this Cortland County town since 1817, and Allens on Allen Hill for more than 130 years. For nine generations their sweat and blood have mingled with the town's history, as doctors, carpenters and, for the last six generations, farmers.

title: Your Money; Caution, Patience: Advice for the 90's
description: For investors considering what year-end moves to make in their portfolios, the watchword from Wall Street experts is prudence. ''Nineteen-ninety may well be a year to sow rather than to reap,'' said Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. ''Rates of return on stocks could well be below average, in general, after 10 years of far above-average returns in the 1980's.''

title: Seoul and Moscow Set Up Partial Ties
description: South Korea and the Soviet Union today announced an unusual form of consular relations that many analysts consider a significant step toward establishing full diplomatic relations.

title: Upheaval in the East; U.S.-Soviet Exchange Planned
description: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to exchange agricultural experts in the next two years. The agreement calls for the exchange of teams in forestry, agricultural economics, agricultural science and food processing, the United States Undersecretary of Agriculture, Richard T. Crowder, said. He said the summit meeting between President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had helped in concluding the agricultural agreement.

title: Books of The Times; Of the Holocaust, German Scholars and a Survivor
description: In Hitler's Shadow West German Historians and the Attempt to Escape From the Nazi Past By Richard J. Evans 196 pages. Pantheon Books. Hard cover, $18.95; paperback, $8.95. Double Indemnity A Memoir By Zofia S. Kubar 208 pages. Hill & Wang. $17.95.

title: Boeing to Offer A New-Size Jet
description: The Boeing Company said today that its commercial aircraft division would begin offering airlines a new twin-engine jet of a size between the existing 767-300 and 747-400.

title: Corrections
description: A response in the Q&A column of Science Times on Tuesday about time zones at the North and South Poles misstated the time difference at the international date line. East of the line, the time is a day earlier, not later.

title: Philadelphia Journal; City Steeped in History: Bell in '76, Bomb in '85
description: Fodor's 1989 guide to this city says it is a place of ''audacious uniqueness'' where the Declaration of Independence was signed, where people shout ''Yo!'' in greetings and where ''the city's first black Mayor, W. Wilson Goode, made a perverse kind of history by approving the bombing of a neighborhood.''

title: Irresponsible Publicity on the Fur Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics Courses Help Prevent Moral Nomadism; Reward Good Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Bears on Injury List
description: The Chicago Bears have placed William (the Refrigerator) Perry, a defensive lineman, and Lemuel Stinson, a cornerback, on the National Football League's injured reserve list for the rest of the season. (AP)

title: Nissan Sued by U.S. Couple; Was Boarder Really a Spy?
description: To Stephen and Maritza French, the Japanese businessman boarding in their home for six weeks seemed a polite guest who worked at improving his English and even volunteered to help wash the family car.

title: Upheaval in the East; Trial Shows Strain on One of Yugoslavia's Ethnic Fault Lines
description: At her husband's trial in Yugoslavia's most troubled region recently, Nadira Vlasi compared the hearings to a political style that much of Eastern Europe has given up with bewildering speed in recent months.

title: Patents; New Way to Investigate Genetically Based Illness
description: Researchers at Applied Biosystems of Foster City, Calif., a manufacturer of biotechnology laboratory equipment, have patented what officials call a more accurate method for investigating genetically based illness.

title: Gold Medal for Architect
description: The architect Fay Jones has been chosen as the 48th recipient of architecture's highest award, the American Institute of Architects Gold Medal, the A.I.A. announced yesterday. The 58-year-old Mr. Jones, who was Frank Lloyd Wright's apprentice in the 1950's, is to receive the medal on Feb. 22 as part of the Accent on Architecture awards gala at the National Building Museum in Washington.

title: Robert Schleck, 64, A Research Analyst
description: Robert W. Schleck, a former foreign service officer, teacher and research analyst who conducted studies on economic issues in New York City, died of cardiac arrest on Nov. 29 at Leland Memorial Hospital in Riverdale, Md. He was 64 years old and lived in Mount Rainier, Md.. After graduating from Princeton

title: School Government Needs Overhaul, Board President Says
description: The president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., called yesterday for a radical overhaul of New York City's decentralized school government, saying the new Schools Chancellor would need ''some basic structural reforms'' to succeed.

title: Blues forFading Reds
description: Republicans can't believe their luck. Gorbachev happened on their watch, yet it makes them nervous. They should be joyous, because in politics you get the credit for good things that happen on your watch and the blame for disasters.

title: NEW INDIAN LEADER LOOKS TO SRI LANKA
description: India's new Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, turned his attention today to New Delhi's most pressing foreign-policy problem: the restoration of good relations with Sri Lanka, where 25,000 Indian troops are stationed against the wishes of the Sri Lankan Government.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1989
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Ethics Courses Help Prevent Moral Nomadism; Signal to Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Nordstrom Growth
description: Nordstrom Inc., the Seattle-based fashion retailer, will take over the B. Altman store site in White Plains and open its first Westchester County store in 1993, the company said yesterday. Nordstrom, which has been held up as a paragon in emphasizing customer service, will build a new 250,000-square-foot store on the site of the present Altman store of 220,000 square feet in the so-called Million Dollar Mile shopping complex in White Plains. Nordstrom already operates one store in New Jersey and plans to open three more. B. Altman, owned by the L.J. Hooker Corporation, is conducting going-out-of-business sales in six of its seven stores.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed some insulation under the floor over my crawl space. This insulation has a vapor barrier on one side, and so I removed the plastic vapor barrier sheets that originally covered the earth floor in the crawl space. I would now like to cover the earth floor with something else so that I can store things there. What kind of earth cover can I use that will not be a vapor barrier and that will still be comfortable to crawl around on when I go down there to remove or replace stored items?
