title: 'There Is No Other Way'
description: The dazzling events in Eastern Europe have aroused another long-frustrated hope. If freedom can beat the odds in Poland and East Germany, is there not a chance for peace between Israel and the Palestinians?

title: Group Identifies 39 False Rembrandts
description: The Rembrandt Research Project, a group of art experts, said today that 39 paintings attributed to Rembrandt are not genuine, including one at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Old Fighters
description: After nine years the rematch between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran was just what a fight fan should have expected: two middleweights who were nine years older, a little slower and a little richer than they were at their last encounter. But the 16,000 fans who turned up last week in Las Vegas were booing at the lack of action as Mr. Leonard (left) cautiously sparred with a lethargic Mr. Duran to win a lopsided 12-round unanimous decision to retain his World Boxing Council title.

title: Outlaw Rock: More Skirmishes on the Censorship Front POP VIEW; More Skirmishes on The Censorship Front
description: An outlaw image clings to popular music regardless of how many benefits it puts on, how often it parades high-minded sentiments, no matter how much it accommodates itself to movies, television and advertising.

title: HEY DUDE, LIKE NEH - OH WAY!
description: I enjoyed Patrick Cooke's article on changing American dialects (''Are Accents Out? Hey Dude, Like NEH-oh Way!'' Nov. 19). It brought back fond memories of my childhood summers on a beach in southern Maine. The perfect icebreaker for renewing old friendships and making new ones was to acknowledge - and often poke fun at - one another's regional accents. CHRISTINE M. HORIGAN Cambridge, Mass.

title: 'The Least of These,' About Personality Disorder
description: NOW that ''The Least of These'' has been unveiled by the American Stage Company, it's best not to dwell on it, but hope that the worst of the season is behind us, and that we can get on with our lives.

title: Victoria Falk to Wed Peter Michaelis
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. McDonough of Chicago have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. McDonough's daughter Victoria Stafford Falk and O. Peter Tead Michaelis, a son of Michael Michaelis of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Diana Tead Michaelis. Miss Falk is also a daughter of Ralph Falk 2d of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: THE HIDDEN FILES
description: Mr. Honicker incorrectly implies that D. Louis H. Hempelmann was associated with a cover-up. The first scientific/medical descriptions of these radiation exposures and their sequelae were written and published by Dr. Hempelmann (first, in classified form, as then required by the classification of all nuclear-related information emanating from Los Alamos, and then as the first monograph on the subject, in Annals of Internal Medicine, 1952, after classification made that possible). It is the political policy makers and administrators who were responsible for classification/security policies, not the medical staff who ethically may not breach patient confidentiality. Dr. Hempelmann was correct in his statement that he was not responsible for those policies.

title: WEEDS ARE US
description: In the last few years I haven't had a client who hasn't asked me to design a wildflower meadow for him, thinking it would be maintenance-free, effortlessly and constantly beautiful - and somehow morally superior because it's natural. I've had a difficult time persuading them that without considerable maintenance they'd end up with the ''weed-filled-empty-lot'' look and that a wildflower meadow isn't at all natural in a 20-by-50-foot city backyard.

title: Another Day, Another $4? Toll Plan Irks Drivers
description: Stopped in lines in another morning rush hour at the George Washington Bridge, motorists used terms like ''crazy'' and ''rip-off'' to describe a proposed dollar increase, to $4, in tolls on interstate bridges and tunnels.

title: Q and A
description: Sources on Freighter Travel

title: Bellport Seeks to Preserve Its Historic Charm
description: LEAD: THE Suffolk village of Bellport is getting ready to legislate a plan to protect more than 80 houses listed with the National Register of Historic Places.

title: POSTINGS: Douglas Elliman Sold; Milsteins Buy Firm
description: Douglas Elliman & Company, one of Manhattan's largest and most prominent residential brokerage and management companies, has been sold, a victim of internal dissension and the sour real estate market. Founded in 1911, the firm was bought by a partnership involving five members of the Milstein family, which is active in New York real estate. Howard P. Milstein has become the president. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Lillian E. Clarke Becomes a Bride
description: Lillian Elizabeth Clarke, a daughter of Mrs. Manuel Rafael Giberga of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Alan T. Clarke of Clarkesville, Md., was married yesterday to Theodore P. Donahue Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donahue of New York, Litchfield, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Richard Peard officiated at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, Va.

title: Salvador President Offers Rebels New Talks
description: In a what appeared to be a major effort to improve the image of his Government, President Alfredo Cristiani today offered to renew peace talks with guerrillas this month and posted a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the killers of six Jesuit priests.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Quechee,Vt.;
Slump Buffets Luxury Project
description: LEAD: A WOODED ridge overlooking ski slopes, golf courses and a man-made lake is the site for a troubled plan to create 300 expensive houses and condominiums. If the plan succeeds, it will significantly enlarge what already is one of Vermont's largest second-home developments.

title: Carved and Woven in Ghana
description: A MARKETPLACE in Accra, the capital of Ghana in West Africa, holds a colorful fusion of fabrics and handcrafted objects. Here, masks, Ashanti stools, fertility dolls, textiles and other wares from different regions of the country are sold.

title: Couple Add a Twist To the Jigsaw Puzzle
description: LEAD: MARY ANN LOMBARD and her husband, Robert, have been puzzle people for as long as they can remember.

title: Hofstra Makes St. John's Work for 58-47 Victory
description: Along the sidelines at Alumni Hall last night in the first half of the St. John's-Hofstra game, Lou Carnesecca winced repeatedly, paced nervously and, watching his players falter on defense, shouted, ''Don't lose him, don't lose him.''

title: Landfill Odors Presage More Problems
description: LEAD: FOUL odors rising from the Huntington town landfill in East Northport have given Long Island a whiff of what is to come, as towns strive to seal garbage dumps that rise like pyramids from the Island's flat terrain.

title: Boy Meets Girl, '89, Can Be a Detective Story
description: Eager to trust but determined to verify, many single women in this age of risky romance are hiring private detectives to check the backgrounds of their suitors.

title: Miss Turner Marries Bruce M. White
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I., Barbara Helen Turner and Bruce Murray White were married yesterday by Canon John W. Davis.

title: Featherweight Title Retained by Paez
description: Jorge Paez, the International Boxing Federation featherweight champion, retained his title today when he stopped Lupe Gutierrez, a game challenger, at 2 minutes 1 second of the sixth round of a scheduled 12-round fight.

title: Review/Jazz; A History of the Blues, By Jimmy Witherspoon
description: Jack Kleinsinger's Highlights in Jazz concerts are the last vestige of jazz as a variety show. The format, broken up into small and large features for everybody on stage, makes them entertaining, but it rarely allows the best parts of the performance to build up speed. Thursday night's show, featuring the singer Jimmy Witherspoon, was no different.

title: FICTION
description: THE BLUE VALLEYS. By Robert Morgan. (Peachtree, $15.95.) The strong, pungent stories in ''The Blue Valleys,'' a first collection by the poet Robert Morgan, are set in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina, whose hills and valleys are a sturdy home for his characters, mostly working people at the mercy of circumstance. As these intricate tales progress chronologically from Civil War times to the present, the dignity of simple farm life is complicated by the advent of computers, working wives and disrespectful children, and the land becomes less a source of livelihood than a vital touchstone. In perhaps the best story in the book, ''Tailgunner,'' a former prisoner of war named Jones realizes that he has spent his life doing things he never wanted to do, married a woman he never intended to marry. Wondering why he alone was spared in the World War II crash of a B-24, he encounters his real self only in the pine woods. ''It was as though he had forgotten something about himself for almost forty years,'' Jones muses. ''He could not explain why the peacefulness of the trees reminded him of instants of great danger and sickness, why he felt close to some bedrock definition, some value.'' Similarly, in the story called ''A Brightness New and Welcoming,'' a soldier dying in the sordidness of a Yankee prison camp during the Civil War thinks about the pristine water of a spring that he had cleared on his home place, and the way the spring ''seemed the dial of some instrument.'' The resilience of childhood, the misery of life in a trailer and the humor of December romance are also among the diverse subjects of the stories in this beautifully crafted collection, a procession of tales rich with native detail and character, told in language as plain and deep as the hills, the whole weighted with an awareness of death that looms over the struggle for a meaningful life.

title: Gelbart Hard-Boiled: The Case of the Alter Ego
description: This is the City of Angels. It's not my regular beat. My name is Friedman. I'm a country singer who writes mystery novels. A perfectly logical choice to investigate Larry Gelbart and Cy Coleman's new Broadway musical. So I took the case. The story of ''City of Angels'' - which opens tomorrow at the Virginia Theater - is the story of Stine, a Chandleresque mystery novelist, and his fictional detective, Stone. Stine (played by Gregg Edelman) is a participant-observer of life; Stone (James Naughton) is what Stine might like to be if he didn't smugly believe he was smarter than his own creation, and if he didn't have to sit around writing screenplays all day to make a living. Though Stone is the creation of Stine, they are, in essence, fated foils, and their lives compete, overlap and finally embrace each other like the Pacific Ocean and the nighttime California shoreline.

title: Dayton Tops Union For Division 3 Title
description: The quarterback, Dan Sharley, scored on two short runs today, leading Dayton to a 17-7 victory over Union in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl and the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III football championship.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service is completing a month-long market test of a 25-cent self-stick stamp that does not have to be licked. Avoiding this nuisance costs a little under 3 cents a stamp. The test sites are Atlanta; Chicago; Cleveland; Columbus, Ohio; Dallas; Denver; Houston; Indianapolis; Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles; Miami; Milwaukee; Minneapolis; Phoenix and St. Louis. The test ends tomorrow.

title: Corporate Advertising of Our Heritage Is a Unique Public Service
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKRUPTCY WAS A DISAPPOINTMENT
description: LEAD: A FEAST FOR LAWYERS Inside Chapter 11: An Expose. By Sol Stein. 341 pp. New York: M. Evans & Company. $18.95.

title: Miss Denne Plans To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Alison Joan Denne and Brooks Lewis Foehl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Foehl of Needham, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Denne of Riverside, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: SHAKESPEARE MEETS CERVANTES
description: LEAD: THE DEVIL'S MODE By Anthony Burgess. 290 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Virginia Spahr to Wed M. M. Keator
description: May wedding plans for Virginia Randell Spahr and Matthew Medbury Keator, both 1988 graduates of Trinity College in Hartford, have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nelson Spahr of Malvern, Pa. Mr. Keator is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrit Medbury Keator of Stamford, Conn.

description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Athans Weds Leonidas Demas
description: Stacey Elaine Athans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Athans of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday in Hempstead, L.I., to Leonidas George Demas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Demas of Holiday, Fla. The Rev. Nicholas J. Magoulias officiated at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul.

title:
ART VIEW;
IMAGINE VENICE AS A FLOATING DISNEYLAND
description: LEAD: What happens to Venice affects all of us. The great city does not belong only to Italy, or to the Italians. It is held in trust as part of the inheritance of all humankind.

title: Laurie Salitan Marries Marc Kushner
description: Dr. Laurie P. Salitan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark A. Salitan of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening at the Regency in New York to Marc Alan Kushner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour W. Kushner of Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Melissa F. Crespy officiated.

title: Problems at Nuclear Arms Plant
description: The nation's only plant for the final assembly of nuclear bombs would not be able to respond effectively to emergency releases of radioactive material, according to a draft report by experts who inspected it in October at the behest of Energy Secretary James D. Watkins.

title: Just the Basics
description: Dear Editor:

title: Review/Cabaret; A Songwriter Reminisces
description: Philip Springer, a veteran New York songwriter who wrote the music for 1950's hits like ''How Little We Know,'' ''Moonlight Gambler'' and ''Santa Baby,'' did not reach his creative peak until a decade ago, when he collaborated with E. Y. (Yip) Harburg on the lyricist's final songs.

title:
GARDENING;
A Tree for All Seasons, or Just One
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS trees made their appearance as early as the week before Thanksgiving at some nursery lots this year. These are the trees meant to be planted outside after a brief period of decorative glory indoors.

title: LONE STAR FAKES
description: TOM TAYLOR DID NOT ENJOY HIS LUNCH that afternoon back in 1987. He was dining with a friend, Bill Holman, in a Chinese restaurant in Austin and discussing one of their favorite subjects - the old, rare documents of Texas history that Holman, a former librarian and printer, studies, and that Taylor, a printer and book merchant, dabbles in selling.

title: NONFICTION
description: FEAR IN CHILE: Lives Under Pinochet. By Patricia Politzer. (Pantheon, $18.95.) The stories of the 14 Chileans interviewed in ''Fear in Chile'' - among them a Communist student, an army colonel, a grandmother who is a diehard supporter of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, a yuppie banker - make up a volume of must-reading for would-be dictators. General Pinochet came to power in 1973 - he is to step down after elections on Dec. 14 - and in a country that had never known dictatorship or torture, he buried a 150-year history of democracy and civic culture. Chileans had always thought ''it can't happen here''; Ms. Politzer, one of Chile's best opposition journalists, shows how it did. (The book is superbly translated from the Spanish by Diane Wachtell.) A colonel's tale illustrates how fear of chaos led many to support the coup and blind themselves to the violence that came later. A priest talks about the consumer goods General Pinochet brought to the middle class, and how fear of losing their televisions turned Chileans into the Israelites rebelling against Moses: ''they missed the food they'd had as slaves, and they had no appreciation for freedom and the right of self-government.'' A copper miner speaks of how fear crippled the unions. And there is the hallucinatory terror of the state: a village mayor survives her own execution, a boy is beaten unconscious for wearing long hair, prisoners in the National Stadium fall from the bleachers and ''split open like watermelons'' on the soccer field. Ms. Politzer's sympathies are evident, but all her interviewees get a fair hearing. What emerges is a different Chile from the country of heroic protests seen on the news. These Chileans do heroic deeds, but they also become secret police informers. They cheat on their imprisoned husbands. They let their children go hungry to meet car payments. They are, in short, people.

title: TIGHTER CONTROLS SEEN IN ZIMBABWE
description: As Zimbabwe approaches its celebration of a decade of independence, people here are increasingly apprehensive that their country, which in the view of some has been relatively democratic, is following the political pattern of many other African nations.

title: Supporters Rally to Defense Of Convicted Miami
description: Waving banners and chanting ''Inocente!'' supporters today rallied to the defense of William Lozano, the Colombian-born policeman who was convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two black men.

title: Caribbean Choices, Grand and Budget
description: For some travelers heading for the Caribbean islands and the Bahamas, the goal is a grand resort that in one way or another offers what is perceived to be the best: comfort, elegance, service and, for some guests at least, sports facilities that are either a few steps away or easily arranged. For others, just being where the sea water is 75 degrees when it's snowing up north may matter more than luxury.

title: A Texas Troubadour Whose Songs Rang True
description: If the backbone of traditional country and western music was the tight, almost familial, relationship between performers and fans, it's distressing how few live records manage to detail those homey bonds. A particularly melancholy absence has been that of ErnestTubb and his Texas Troubadours, arguably country's most beloved stage act, who released only two pseudoconcert LP's with dubbed-in audience noise.

title: Two School Superintendents Needed
description: LEAD: THE Greenburgh Central 7 and the White Plains School Districts are entering the final stages of nationwide searches for new superintendents, with their school boards expected to announce their choices in January and February, respectively.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-34

title: A MEXICAN RELIC IS BURIED AT LAST
description: After nearly 75 years, one of the most grisly relics of the Mexican Revolution has finally been laid to rest. But the interment of what remained of the right arm of General Alvaro Obregon is not likely to erase the talismanic qualities Mexicans have long associated with both the limb and the man.

title: Seaside Sparrows on 'Concern' List
description: LEAD: SEASIDE sparrows on Long Island have been placed on the list of ''management concern'' species by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which created the new category to draw attention to troubled species before they became eligible for listing as threatened or endangered.

title: Moscow Also Reconstructs Its Defense Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incorrect information supplied by Lenz Riecker Publishers, the Q & A column on Nov. 5 misstated the number to use when ordering a copy of the New York State Rent Stabilization Code.

title: Peace Without The Khmer Rouge?
description: For years, policy makers have faced an excruciating dilemma in Cambodia: How to forestall both the return of the Khmer Rouge and the acceptance of Vietnamese aggression. Now that Vietnam has largely withdrawn from Cambodia, the decibel level of the debate has risen sharply, reflecting legitimate fears that the murderous Khmer Rouge might re-enact the killing fields.

title: Reviews/Music; Opera Students in Stravinsky's 'Rake's Progress'
description: Igor Stravinsky's opera ''The Rake's Progress'' (1951) is a monument to artifice. Determinedly awash in what the composer called ''the early cliches I have tried to re-establish,'' the libretto of W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman echoes almost every device of 18th-century opera, and the score revels in the results of Stravinsky's three-year immersion in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte.''

title: TV Tidbits Starve Democracy
description: LEAD: Modern-day political campaigns may be made for television but democracy is not. TV's tolerance for the languid pace of political discourse, never great, has all but vanished.

title: If You Can't Improve on the Original . . .
description: Film goers and VCR buffs, both young and old, will undoubtedly remember ''Dinner at Eight,'' the M-G-M movie adapted by Frances Marion and Herman J. Mankiewicz (''Citizen Kane'') from a play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber. Produced by David O. Selznick and directed by George Cukor, the 1933 movie had a cast that included Jean Harlow, Wallace Beery, Lionel Barrymore, Marie Dressler and Billie Burke. Who can forget John Barrymore playing a has-been, alcoholic thespian bearing an uneasy resemblance to his off-screen self?

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WHAT ABOUT SPIES?

title: Corporate Advertising of Our Heritage Is a Unique Public Service; An Unholy Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Wiener to Marry Richard Biegen
description: The engagement of Deborah Ruth Wiener to Richard Scott Biegen, a son of Dr. Elaine Biegen of Whitestone, Queens, and Arnold Biegen of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been made known by her parents, Prof. and Mrs. Joel H. Wiener of Teaneck, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: SOME TEMPERANCE MOVEMENT!
description: In the mid-1860's, officers at the United States Naval Academy were disturbed by reports of drinking and carousing by midshipmen. The brass concluded that healthier diversions were needed for the future officers and gentlemen, and football was introduced in 1869. The sport's popularity grew, and in the fall of 1890 Annapolis challenged the United States Military Academy to a game. The West Pointers obliged, and a grand rivalry was born. This rivalry is celebrated in 100 YEARS OF ARMY-NAVY FOOTBALL (Donald Hutter/Holt, $24.95), illustrated with more than 100 black-and-white photographs. Gene Schoor, a sports journalist, chronicles each game of the series, its key plays and such players as Felix (Doc) Blanchard and Glenn Davis, Army's famed ''Mr. Inside, Mr. Outside'' tandem of the 1940's; Pete Dawkins, West Point's All-American halfback in the late 50's; Navy's Joe Bellino, who scored three touchdowns in the 1959 Army-Navy game; and Roger Staubach, the midshipmen's legendary quarterback of the 60's. (Mr. Staubach went on to an outstanding professional career with the Dallas Cowboys.) Reminiscences from notable alumni enhance Mr. Schoor's narrative. The author also recounts the heroism and leadership of former players from the Spanish-American War to Vietnam. The book thus honors not only this national sporting classic but also those whose duty and sacrifices far outweigh any feats on the gridiron.

title: From Ashes of German Communism, a Man With Roots in the Left
description: Whether Gregor Gysi will succeed in restoring the credibility of East German Communism is an open question. What is not in doubt are his credentials for the task. At 41, he is among East

title: Two for Tea, or Rum, or Tennis
description: COMPARED with some of the orgiastic, rum-drenched singles resorts that have flourished in the Caribbean in recent years, Sandals, a couples-only club in Ocho Rios, seems like a religious seaside retreat. That's not to say that there aren't a lot of bibulous fraternity-bash shenanigans at night, but the difference is that at Sandals the mirthmakers return to the dorm under their own power, and with their wives or steady girl friends. And on toga night, the togas stay on.

title: WEEDS ARE US
description: Michael Pollan asks great questions: why mow lawns? And, recently, why weed? (''Weeds Are Us,'' Nov. 5). Though the questions are fine, his reductive answers are disappointing.

title: Officials at U.N. Quietly Meet Baltic Leaders
description: On Friday, the day after Lithuania defied President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and became the first Soviet republic to end the Communist Party's monopoly of power, a tall Latvian slipped into the United Nations on an unannounced assignment.

title: The Great Swamp: Some Other Aspects
description: The recent article on the Great Swamp struck a special chord of memory from my youth. I visited the Great Swamp several times as a teen-ager in the late 20's. Although I lived in New York, I had an aunt and uncle who belonged to a semirural community called Chatham Colony, about a mile south of the Lackawanna Railroad, which brought us to Chatham on holiday visits.

title: Moscow Also Reconstructs Its Defense Thinking; Cold-War Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: LOW TALES OF THE HIGHBORN
description: Michael Pye misses the real point, which is that the entire content of a newspaper is virtually gossip (''Low Tales of the Highborn,'' Nov. 12). Take, as an example, the articles about the youths accused in the attack on the Central Park jogger. Anything beyond the fact that an attack took place and that one should attend to one's safety is gossip. What is important about the occupation of the victim? It is really irrelevant. Or what is the difference between someone gossiping about a neighbor's illness and a newspaper publishing details of a President's illness? J.S. BOHAN Newport, R.I.

title: Cheryl M. Granat Wed To Dr. E. W. Segall
description: The marriage of Cheryl Marlene Granat, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Granat of Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. Eugene Walter Segall, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Segall of Hollywood, Fla., took place last evening at the Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony.

title: Olympic Politics
description: He's been critical of his hometown's preparations for the 1992 Summer Games, but now Juan Antonio Samaranch, the head of the International Olympic Committee, says things are going just fine. Even so, Samaranch, a native of Barcelona, Spain, said he would personally supervise a scheduled meeting between the Barcelona organizers and the I.O.C.'s coordination commission in April.

title: China Trip Seeks to Alter Americans' Perceptions
description: Behind the decision to send President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, on a mission to Beijing was a desire by the Administration to get Congress and the public used to the idea of restoring normal diplomatic contacts with China.

title: Yale Rep Revives Williams
description: THROUGHOUT the pinnacle and the decline of Tennessee Williams's career, ''Summer and Smoke'' wafted in the distance, a rarefied example of the playwright's incomparable style, but only occasionally revived.

title: Review/Music; Armenian Orchestra in Mini-Tour
description: The Armenian Philharmonic's appearance at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was as much an expression of need as of accomplishment. The stated purpose of the orchestra's three-city visit to this country is to raise money for rebuilding after the vicious earthquake of exactly a year ago. Usually the visits of such Eastern-bloc ensembles have been carefully orchestrated expressions of national pride. Here, pride seemed mixed with want.

title: LOW TALES OF THE HIGHBORN
description: I am amazed at the low level of your reporting. Tom Driberg - Lord Bradwell, that is - was elevated to the peerage for his services to Britain, and was a distinguished member of his country's Government from the end of World War II until his death in 1976. JOAN LITTLEWOOD London

title: Who's Afraid Of Superstars?
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning Is Old Hat
description: He had an off year, missed two games entirely and had the lowest rushing totals of his four-year career. But old habits die hard, so they made Johnny Bailey do what he's had to do most autumns since he started playing college footall in 1986. The Texas A. & I. running back had to go over to Sheffield, Ala., Friday night to pick up the Harlon Hill Trophy as the best player in Division II.

title: Money Can't Buy It All
description: Money has apparently reached such stratospheric heights in baseball that players can afford to leave a million or three on the table.

title: Broadway and the Bottom Line
description: The core market of consumers is aging. . . . Costs are out of control. . . . Five out of six new products lose money. . . . The most talented workers increasingly look to competing industries for most of their livelihood. . . .

title: Whose Women Are They?
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislators Struggling To Find Budget Cuts
description: WESTCHESTER County's commissioners appeared one at a time before the Board of Legislator's Budget and Appropriations Committee last week, seeking to resist the cuts in expenditures that the legislators have vowed to make in County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed record spending plan.

title: Style Makers; Simon Bocanegra, Photographer
description: His intent as a photographer is clear. ''I like to take something that everybody sees in a pejorative way and make a diamond out of it,'' said Simon Bocanegra, a 40-year-old French photographer who is having his first show in the United States.

title: El Salvador's Army: A Force Unto Itself
description: IT WAS A SCENE SALVADORANS HAD HOPED THEY WOULD NEVER SEE again. On Nov. 16, while a full-scale battle raged between the Salvadoran Army and leftist rebels in the streets of the capital, the bodies of six Jesuit priests murdered in the night lay strewn across a university campus. A witness said the killers had been soldiers in uniform.

title: Gretchen A. MaierWeds T. A. Teran
description: Gretchen Anne Maier and Timothy Alba Teran were married in New York yesterday in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral by Kenneth Clancy, a Roman Catholic deacon. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Maier of Norristown, Pa. Mr. Teran is a son of Eric Alba Teran D'Antin of New York and the late Patricia Wheel.

title: HEY DUDE, LIKE NEH - OH WAY!
description: High school and college-age people who communicate in bisyllabic extensions do so for a number of reasons. For one thing, people don't listen to one another as closely as they once did. Hence, young people add syllables and redundant words and phrases to get the message across. They pad their sentences with such expressions as ''It was, like, a great sound, ya know?'' The excess baggage of ''like'' and ''ya know?'' is intended to be an attention-grabber. Indeed, much older adults also pepper their sentences with ''ya knows?'' because they don't believe their wives or children are listening to them - because the television is on or because the listener has ''heard it all before.''

title:
DANCE;
Villella Imparts Tricks of the Trade
description: LEAD: IN Edward Villella's movement lexicon, the spirit of plie is up, not down, and raised arms originate in the back. Such ''inside understandings,'' as this former Balanchine dancer described them, are a priceless legacy of years spent dancing with the New York City Ballet.

title: A Shop Where Youths Learn to Work for More Than Money
description: IN September a submarine-sandwich shop opened here on Sussex Street. Every day since, the small restaurant and takeout business has attracted lunch crowds of St. Michael's Hospital employees and students from the New Jersey Institute of Technology and Rutgers University across the street.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: Whomever Stu Jackson decides to start should depend upon whom the Knicks are playing. Jackson is unstoppable against Philadelphia, Washington, Indiana, Milwaukee, and Chicago. Strickland's speed and defense are invaluable against Atlanta, Boston, and Cleveland. Against Detroit and most of the Western teams, they should play together. PATRICK COLMENAR Teaneck, N.J.

title: A TAKEOVER BATTLE LEFT CARBIDE THE MOST VULNERABLE
description: Perhaps the only major chemical company that remains very vulnerable to the commodity-chemical cycle is the Union Carbide Corporation. As part of a restructuring aimed at warding off a 1984 takeover attempt by the GAF Corporation, Carbide sold its consumer products businesses, its agricultural businesses and most of its European operations. The company now depends on chemicals and plastics for more than 65 percent of its sales.

title: More Sooner Charges
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association plans to look into comments made by a former University of Oklahoma quarterback, who told a newspaper that he used to receive favors from team boosters and his coach, Barry Switzer, and that he knew of far more serious violations he would not describe.

title: Jets' Futures Unclear
description: When Dan Alexander announced last Thursday that he would retire at the end of the season, his decision raised a question or two: is this the beginning of a series of retirement announcements by older Jets (especially if it becomes clear they no longer fit into the team's plans)? And is Dave Cadigan, the heir apparent to Alexander's right-guard spot, ready to step in?

title: CRUMBS IN THE COVERS
description: Your article about eating in bed evoked the most pleasant of childhood memories.

title: U.S. Must Face Italy In Cup
description: When the United States returns to World Cup soccer action in June after an absence of 40 years, it will play in the same group as Italy, which is the host team and one of the world's soccer powers.

title: Households Still Shrinking, but Rate Is Slower
description: American households have shrunk to their smallest ever, but they are not shrinking as fast as they were a few years ago, Census Bureau officials say.

title: Jury Awards $1 Million in Buddhist Suit
description: A State Supreme Court jury has awarded a Westchester County man $1 million after determining that a neighboring Zen Buddhist religious community created a nuisance when it put 200 fluorescent stakes around his property and used chainsaws and power equipment at odd hours.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed some insulation under the floor over my crawl space. This insulation has a vapor barrier on one side, and so I removed the plastic vapor barrier sheets that originally covered the earth floor in the crawl space. I would now like to cover the earth floor with something else so that I can store things there. What kind of earth cover can I use that will not be a vapor barrier and that will still be comfortable to crawl around on when I go down there to remove or replace stored items?

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: Choosing a site for a National Championship, now officially described as a North American Bridge Championship is no easy matter. The site must have a large hotelwith plenty of convention spaceor a convention center with plenty of adjoining hotels.

title: Nixon's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Seat Strategy
description: To the Editor: K. C. Cole's ''Confessions of a Seat Strategist'' was the greatest, and yes, I do identify. Perhaps she is a good second to S. J. Perelman in the humor department. I chuckled and roared all week thinking of the contretemps. STEVEN S. FEINBERG Providence, R.I.

title: Architect Leads Way for Women
description: WORKING out of a converted barn in Saddle River, Eleanore Pettersen has created buildings as diverse as a luxury town house, a church, a convent school, offices and a nursing home.

title: Hard-Line Czech President to Quit And Dissident Is Seen as Successor
description: Gustav Husak, one of the Eastern bloc's last old-guard leaders, said tonight that he would resign as President after the formation of a new Czechoslovak government on Sunday.

title: POSTINGS: Going Up in Newark; New U.S. Courthouse
description: Construction has started on the $47 million Martin Luther King Jr. Federal Office Building and Courthouse, the largest Federal Government development to be undertaken in years in Newark. The 350,000-square-foot project, which is to contain 13 courtrooms, has been in the planning stages for five years and is to be finished in 1991.

title: Fund-Raisers Face Keener Competition
description: LEAD: AS the end of the year approaches and charitable organizations step up requests for money, they are finding competition keener and donors fewer and harder pressed.

title: ISLANDERS AND RANGERS TIE
description: The Islanders and the Rangers got what they earned and deserved tonight, battling to a 0-0 tie in a tense, clean, fierce and often delightful game played before a roaring capacity crowd at Nassau Coliseum.

title: MR. DIRTY
description: MOBBED UP Jackie Presser's High-Wire Life in the Teamsters, the Mafia, and the F.B.I. By James Neff. Illustrated. 498 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.95.

title: Helen Hai Ryun Kahng Is Married
description: Helen Hai Ryun Kahng, a convertible bond sales specialist at Oppenheimer & Company in New York, was married there yesterday to David Royce Jaffe, a partner in the Chemical Venture Partners investment concern in New York. Rabbi Stephen Pierce and the Rev. Soon Man Rhim, a Presbyterian minister, performed the interfaith ceremony at the United Nations Chapel. Mrs. Jaffe is a daughter of Ray A. Kahng and the late Choon Hi Choi Kahng of Armonk, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot S. Jaffe of Stamford, Conn.

title: Unfailingly
description: Today's lecture on cliches, drawn from recent news reports, takes the form of a quiz.

title: New Turmoil Over Police in Houston
description: In the last six weeks, two Houston police officers have shot and killed motorists after traffic stops. Two other officers were found guilty in rape cases. One more was arrested for heroin possession, one was charged with coercing sex from a prostitute, one was reassigned amid charges of police harassment and two officers' houses were searched as part of a drug investigation.

title: GANDHI DISMISSING OFFICIALS IN PARTY
description: Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, analyzing the reasons leading to the defeat of his Congress Party in general elections last month, has begun wide-ranging changes in the organization by dismissing top party officials.

title: ACTIVE P.L.O. ROLE SOUGHT FOR TALKS
description: As the newest effort to resolve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict slides into familiar patterns of ambiguity, the Palestine Liberation Organization is balking at the role of invisible player assigned to it by Egypt, a principal Arab backer.

title: Outdoors; Put Down That Ax and Maul
description: While attacking a pile of two-foot-long white oak logs with splitting ax and maul a few days ago, I yearned for a pellet stove. That lack of fortitude abated in less than half an hour as I warmed to my task and encountered a series of straight-grained logs that readily sundered with a single blow. I also knew that I wasn't in pellet country.

title: CRIME
description: After years of writing bizarre criminal tales set in modern-day Hong Kong and Manila, William Marshall has discovered another teeming city and another tumultuous era to suit his flamboyant style - New York in the late 19th century. THE NEW YORK DETECTIVE (Mysterious Press, $17.95) introduces Detective Virgil J. Tillman, known as ''the Thinking Detective,'' and his patrolman partner, Ned Muldoon of the Strong Arm Squad, along with a rowdy cast of crooks and scoundrels, in a boisterous historical melodrama.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Smack for Autobiography

title: CRUMBS IN THE COVERS
description: I am not so curmudgeonly as to disdain a ''cuppa'' in bed first thing in the morning or a breakfast tray with The New York Times on Sundays. However, after your Food article ''Crumbs in the Covers,'' are we to be treated to ''Profiteroles on the Parquet'' or ''Dejeuner on the John''? Great Escoffier! JACQUES BURDICK New York, N.Y.

title: Variety Spices Christmas Music
description: LEAD: THE next two weeks will be filled once again with the sound of Christmas music, ranging from full-length versions of Handel's ''Messiah'' in Roslyn today and Brookville next Sunday to ''Hallelujah Choruses'' by community chorales and church choirs and the customary sprinkling of sing-alongs.

title: A Year-Round Caribbean Resort
description: BY 10 o'clock on a Sunday morning, the disco music was drifting up from the hotel patio and a splashy game of volleyball was going in the mango-shaped swimming pool. A towel attendant was dancing behind his counter. A couple of people in bathing suits were playing table tennis. Most of the lounge chairs were filled with pink bodies yearning for a tan, and the bar was busily turning out pina coladas and rum punches.

title: BEFORE THE FALL
description: PETE ROSE My Story. By Pete Rose and Roger Kahn. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: When the Place Names All Sound Alike
description: IN Connecticut, it can sometimes be a challenge not only to get from here to there, but also even to know where there is, or when you've actually arrived there. When I first came to live in central Connecticut in 1977, the number of localities with similar sounding names complicated my becoming familiar with the lay of the land.

title: Kristen Page Marries
description: Kristen Anne Page and Thomas Joseph Forrest Jr. were married yesterday at the First Lutheran Church in Albany by the Rev. William H. Rittberger. Mrs. Forrest, 24 years old, is a daughter of Marilyn Van Wormer Page of Delmar, N.Y., and the late Robert Wentworth Page. She is the office coordinator at Jenks & Partners, producers of television commercials in New York. The bridegroom, 23, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest of Albany, is a stage manager at Peter Corbett Associates, also producers of television commercials in New York.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: AT holiday time, it is easy to revise a line by Ford Madox Ford, proclaiming that ''only two classes of books are of universal appeal: the very best and the very worst.'' On the contrary, many a New Jersey reader will rejoice at the gift of a book from a third category: works, like those listed here, that compliment the intellect and that feature, by virtue of author or subject, a recognizable New Jersey connection.

title: A Bookseller and Her Customers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rev. Julie BrooksPlans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Brooks Jr. of St. Paul have announced the engagement of their daughter the Rev. Julie Markell Brooks and Charles Andruss Zelle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis N. Zelle of Minneapolis. A January wedding is planned.

title: STYLISH TO THE END
description: A FIRST DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY What Our Children Need to Know. Edited by E. D. Hirsch Jr. with William G. Rowland Jr. and Michael Stanford. Illustrated. 271 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: ONE hundred years ago this month, Jefferson Davis, the first, last and only president of the Confederate States of America, died peacefully at the age of 81. Had it not been for one independent-minded New Jersey man, Davis's life might have ended a lot sooner, and a lot more unpleasantly, at the end of a rope.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold $215,000 318 East Buckalew Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; 2-car garage, c/a, family room, den; taxes $3,732. Howell $154,000 27 Cannonball Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, family room, patio; taxes $2,296. Jackson $105,000 8 Heritage Terrace 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1-year-old town house; c/a, w/w carpeting; monthly maintenance $90, taxes $2,102. Maplewood $239,000 18 Garthwaite Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, screened porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,115. Morristown $289,000 36 Edgehill Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; h/w floors, full basement, 1 acre; taxes $2,734. Short Hills $181,500 292 Glen Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; 2 fireplaces, enclosed porch, 1-car garage; taxes $4,175. OTHER AREAS Katonah, N.Y. $605,000 40 Glenwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, library, wet bar, eat-in kitchen, guest cottage, pool, 4.4 acres; taxes $9,932. Middletown, Conn. $175,000 44 Cimarron Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old raised ranch; fireplace, expansion possibilities, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,434. West Islip, L.I. $450,000 19 Viking Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old waterfront colonial; c/a, 2-car garage; 75- by 150-foot lot on the waterfront; taxes $7,600.

title: From 1836, the Labor of a Popular Historian
description: LEAD: THE image of a top-hatted man, sketchbook in hand, a rapt expression on his face, greets the visitor to the current exhibit at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford. It is a self portrait, many times enlarged, of the 19th-century engraver, historian and writer whose long career is celebrated in ''When Images Were Magic: Connecticut's First Popular Historian, John Warner Barber.

title: WEEDS ARE US
description: As I explained to Michael Pollan, ''Time Landscape'' is not a 19th-century greenhouse encased in glass, but a landscape history interweaving with the 20th century, which illustrates the concept of co-existence rather than domination. It is a narrative and environmental sculpture, recording the history of Greenwich Vilage, from the time prior to human intervention and continuing to the present. It is a part of the sculpture that birds and other animals transport seeds to the site, including nightshade and any other non-indigenous flora that may float this way. ALAN SONFIST New York, N.Y.

title: Boston's Black Areas Mount New Secession Drive
description: The Roxbury section of Boston is a mix of red brick town houses, high-rise public housing projects and weed-covered lots. To the north stand the glittering skyscrapers of the downtown financial district; to the west, comparatively well-to-do suburbs like Brookline and Newton.

title: Seat Strategy
description: To the Editor: It is unrealistic of Ms. Cole to expect to meet the same sort of charming, tactful, polite and silent people she is undoubtedly used to admitting to her circle of friends, when she is traveling on public transport.

title: Water Scarcity Is Found to Be Mounting Problem
description: After nearly a century of broad strides in irrigation, the world is now facing mounting problems of water scarcity accompanied by rising costs for new projects and widespread environmental damage that irrigation can cause, a new study concludes.

title: Some Hot Tips for Holiday Gifts
description: The search for the perfect gift quickens as the holiday shopping season moves into full swing. For the Wall Street types and junior financiers on your list, here is a grab bag of gifts with a financial twist.

title: Stamford Makes Art A Common Endeavor
description: When a disparate group of merchants, business people and professionals who work on Bedford Street in downtown Stamford was invited to select a sculpture for the public library as part of the city's Public Art Program, few of them knew much about sculpture and none of them knew any of the others.

title: NONFICTION
description: DRIVE: The Story of My Life. By Larry Bird with Bob Ryan. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Biographies and autobiographies of sports superstars rarely achieve (or are expected to achieve) literary distinction, but even so Larry Bird's ''Drive: The Story of My Life'' is a disappointment. On the basketball court, the Boston Celtic forward is renowned for his flair for the unexpected, but in print, Mr. Bird serves up cliches on the order of ''Every season is a learning experience'' and ''There is no feeling like that championship feeling'' on nearly every page. His predilection for blandness becomes downright bizarre when he is discussing his personal life, especially when he glosses over what must surely have been the most traumatic event of his life - his alcoholic father's suicide when Mr. Bird was 18 years old. Minimizing the event (and its effect on him), Mr. Bird writes ''I know in [ my father's ] mind he thought he was doing something to help the family financially.'' He gives even shorter shrift to his brief, failed, early first marriage and his relationship to a daughter born out of wedlock. From the very beginning of his autobiography, written with Bob Ryan, who covers the Celtics for The Boston Globe, Mr. Bird makes it clear he sees his life in terms of basketball, but offers few insights on the complexities of the professional game. Occasionally, Mr. Bird offers some unexpected nuggets, such as the grudge he's nurtured against Kent Benson ever since the brawny center snubbed him when Bird was an insecure freshman at Indiana University. About the closest Mr. Bird comes to going out on a limb in this book is when he lists reasons why he doesn't like certain professional stadiums. But he still sounds like a summer camper who was forced to write a letter home to his mother.

title: Social Studies: The Christmas Lunch and the Office Party
description: The office Christmas party isn't what it used to be, but it's getting livelier.

title:
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Boston's 'Linkage' Fee;
Developers of Big Downtown Projects Assessed by the City
description: LEAD: DURING the commercial building boom of the last five years, the largest downtown projects here have helped create low-cost housing in outlying neighborhoods through ''linkage,'' a program of fees paid in stages that started in 1984 and has helped make this city a national leader in low-cost housing production.

title: What's That I Hear? Far Too Much
description: SOMETIME between its headline-snaring decisions about flag burning and about abortion limits, the United States Supreme Court handed down a decision affirming the right of New York City to limit the volume of rock concerts in Central Park's open-air bandshell. With luck, the precedent will ripple out to communities everywhere, eventually reducing some of the torment imposed on captive audiences by mega-decibel noise.

title: Argentine Leader Reaffirms Economic Plan
description: President Carlos Saul Menem reaffirmed his inflation program today after his Government rationed gasoline sales and fired hundreds of train engineers who went on strike this week.

title: Small Investors Buy Harness Horses
description: LEAD: UNTIL last year, Tony Matturri used to spend most evenings at the Meadowlands Race Track, betting $50 on at least three races. Mr. Matturri, who works as a toll taker on the New Jersey Turnpike and lives in Harrison, hung around, ''down and dirty, looking like a ragpicker,'' he said, right at the finish line, trying to handicap the horses.

title: THREE BY A NOBEL LAUREATE
description: LEAD: WEDDING SONG By Naguib Mahfouz. Translated by Olive E. Kenny. Edited and revised by Mursi Saad El Din and John Rodenbeck. 174 pp. New York: Doubleday. Cloth, $16.95. Anchor Books/Doubleday. Paper, $7.95. THE BEGINNING AND THE END By Naguib Mahfouz. Translated by Ramses Awad. Edited by Mason Rossiter Smith.

title: The Baby Bells Scramble for Europe
description: The Baby Bells, long seen simply as providers of local phone service, have ambitions to go global. Last week, U. S. West Inc. reached agreements to lay the world's longest fiber-optic cable across the Soviet Union and build a cellular phone system in Hungary, a first for Eastern Europe. A consortium including the Pacific Telesis Group won a multibillion dollar contract for the first private cellular system in West Germany, beating out bids from five other regional Bell companies.

title: Perestroika Ole
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Faction Says It Foiled Attack on Leader
description: The pro-Iranian Party of God in Lebanon discovered and dismantled a car bomb today that was aimed at its spiritual leader, a spokesman for the group said.

title: CUNY Tries for Revival While It Faces Austerity
description: The City University of New York is entering a period of transition as it searches for a new chancellor, tries to replace many of its aging college presidents and prepares for a turnover of almost 2,000 faculty members in the next few years.

title: Campus Life: Trinity College; Black Talks Prompt Protest and Complaint
description: Speeches by leaders of two black groups have prompted a march on the president's office at Trinity College and the first complaint filed under the college's new racial-harassment policy.

title: DATA BANK: Dec. 10, 1989
POSTINGS: On This Spot . . .; 15 Markers For Times Sq.
description: New Yorkers who revel in the historic details of the neighborhoods they know and love will soon have 15 new plaques to read that mark famous places in the Times Square area. The Municipal Art Society, which is placing the markers in a continuing project entitled ''The Sidewalks of New York,'' is to unveil two on Thursday at 3:30 P.M. They will be affixed to lampposts on the traffic island bounded by Broadway, Seventh Avenue and 43d Street.

title: G.O.P. Official Quits In Housing Controversy
description: A Republican national committeeman has resigned months after party leaders asked him to step down amid controvery over his lobbying to get Federal housing grants for his clients.

title: Corrections
description: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on Nov. 26 included an erroneous entry under the heading ''Unrestricted Fare.'' The $298 round-trip fare offered by T.W.A. between New York and Chicago is available on Saturdays only; it is not unrestricted.

title: TALKING TO HIMSELF, BUT VERY LOUD
description: THE SECRET SPEECHES OF CHAIRMAN MAO From the Hundred Flowers to the Great Leap Forward. Edited by Roderick MacFarquhar, Timothy Cheek and Eugene Wu. 561 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Council on East Asian Studies/ Harvard University Press. Paper, $15.

title: Seedlings For Sale At Bargain Prices
description: LEAD: ALMOST two million tree seedlings will be distributed this spring to Connecticut residents through two programs. For landowners with at least one acre, not including their house lot, and who agree not to sell trees with roots attached, the state offers seedlings at bargain prices. Conifers, including pine, spruce, fir and larch can be ordered in groups of 250 for $22.

title: As Usual, Germans Can't Agree on What Is German
description: IN the middle of Europe is a nation whose frontiers were never static or fully accepted either by its own members or by neighboring nations.

title: Three Agencies With a Mission and a Focus: Home Family, and Children; Children Deserve Help For Productive Lives
description: As the new millennium approaches we reflect on the enormous strides that mankind has achieved - organ transplants, space travel, computers and global communication.

title: TOUGH WOMAN IN THE MACHO STATE
description: STRAIGHT FROM THE HEART My Life in Politics and Other Places. By Ann Richards with Peter Knobler. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Borland Returns Home
description: It must have seemed like a good idea at the time - when Borland International Inc. went public on the London Stock Exchange in 1986. Listing in the United Kingdom was far less costly than in the United States. But the move has proved a liability because it has made it hard for American investors to buy into the Scotts Valley, Calif.-based software company. Through good times and bad, its shares have languished.

title: Sidewalk Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Evening Hours; Swirling Couture Amid the Costumes
description: Close to 2,000 guests climbed the Fifth Avenue steps of the Metropolitan Museum Monday night to pay homage to ''The Age of Napoleon,'' the new Costume Institute exhibit. About 700 guests, the women in couture dresses, dined and were joined later by 1,200 others in eclectic dress for dancing and drinks. Earlier Monday night, the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation benefited from a party at Alan Flusser's new men's wear shop at 50 Trinity Place. Tuesday evening, to benefit the New York Public Library, 49 separate parties were held; 700 guests paid $300 each to attend. That night, friends of Mary Lasker gathered at the Carlyle for a dinner given by Derek Bok, the president of Harvard University, to announce the establishment of the Mary Woodward Lasker professorship and research program at Harvard's public-health school. Wednesday evening, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals parked its adoption van outside the club Au Bar, where a cocktail party celebrated the society's new book, ''Four-Footed, Finned or Feathered Four Hundred.'' The book is $55 from the A.S.P.C.A., 44l East 92d Street, New York, N.Y.10128. That night at the Sheraton Centre, guests from the entertainment, art, fashion, decorating and business worlds auctioned gifts and 100 decorated trees to benefit the Community Research Initiative's AIDS program.

title: Ex-Salvador Officer Is Refused Residency
description: The Government has refused to grant residency to a former Salvadoran policeman who has been living in the United States for eight years and is currently on a hunger strike to protest American military aid to his native country.

title: 2 Titles in Cross-Country
description: Bryan Dameworth, a senior from Calabasas, Calif., and Melody Fairchild, a junior from Boulder, Colo., won national titles today in the Kinney High School cross-country championships. Dameworth completed an unbeaten season by outkicking Andrew Maris of Buckley, Wash., with 250 yards left to triumph by 11 seconds in 14 minutes 49.9 seconds for 5,000 meters. Fairchild, also undefeated, opened a 100-yard lead midway on the Balboa Park course and finished in 17:05.5 for a 7-second victory over Megan Thompson of Florissant, Mo., in the women's division.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: By giving Strickland more minutes off the bench, the Knicks increase his crunch time experience, raise his value and perhaps prod Jackson into playing within the team framework that leads to success and championships. PETER MCINTYRE Matawan, N.J.

title: PORTS IN A STORM
description: DO YOU KNOW THE BISHOP OF Norwich? No reason why you should, actually, but his eminence was a 19th-century man of the cloth much given, we are told, to garrulity, especially at table. His name comes down to us not so much for what he did, which was talk too much, but for what he didn't, which was pass the Port.

title: Miss Borthwick To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Pamela Chapman Borthwick to Shannon Melvin Bass, a son of Patricia Bass of Whidbey Island, Wash., and Stanley Bass of Del Mar, Calif., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Borthwick of Pinehurst, N.C. An April wedding is planned.

title: FICTION
description: REBEL WITHOUT A CLUE. By Holly Uyemoto. (Crown, $17.95.) In this deceptive novel, adult concerns like power, fame, intimacy and mortality are tackled expertly, as is realistic dialogue laced with the macho accents of two male adolescents. But the writer is neither an experienced author nor a man. Holly Uyemoto, a 19-year-old who lives in northern California, delves into the flashy, sometimes fatal world of easy money, sex and drugs, and emerges with a terrific book. ''Rebel Without a Clue'' is a straightforward tale of the twisted lives of Christian Delon, a thoughtful teen-ager loafing away the summer after his high school graduation and mired in the sludge of the idle rich of Marin County, Calif., and Thomas Bainbridge, his best friend, who at 18 is the ''highest-paid male model in our economically disturbed world,'' a lanky youth with ''wide eyes the color of 7-Up bottles,'' chiseled cheekbones - and AIDS. ''I found myself scrutinizing him closely,'' says Christian, ''afraid he'd disappear right before my eyes. The enormity of the situation hadn't begun to set in but I knew that it meant sooner or later I would only see him in photographs and behind my eyelids. Suddenly I couldn't stop looking at him.'' Christian follows Thomas from brightly lit movie sets to Hollywood soirees attended by characters like a ''balding columnist'' wearing eyeliner and various ''acclaimed talents'' who ''lick mirrors and razors and each other's noses.'' Breaking this destructive cycle, Christian is left with hope for himself but only ambivalence for his dying best friend - a sophisticated ending for an admirable first novel.

title: Nixon's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner; Places For Weary Shoppers to Relax
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Manhattan Ocean Club

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; To Use Basil or Chives?
description: When novice cooks look at a recipe and see an ingredient they cannot easily obtain or do not like, they go on to another recipe. Experienced cooks look at the same recipe and think about what they can substitute.

title: To Rescue the Thrift Rescue Plan
description: FOUR months ago, Congress swallowed hard and approved the largest Federal bailout on record, the rescue plan for the savings and loan industry that will spend $159 billion over the next decade. But already financial experts are warning that lawmakers are not finished with the problems of the industry.

title: Robinson Leads Spurs Over Nets
description: The Nets were in the wrong place at the wrong time tonight.

title: Fran Farber, Bank Aide, Becomes a Bride on L.I.
description: The marriage of Fran Melanie Farber, the daughter of Rosalind Farber of North Woodmere, L.I., and the late Sydney Farber, to Dr. Paul Mitchell Glat, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jay Glat of New York and White Plains, took place last evening at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere. Rabbi Paul Siegel officiated. Mrs. Glat, 26 years old and a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York, is an administrative assistant in corporate banking in the New York office of the Algemene Bank in Amsterdam. The bridegroom, 27, is a resident in surgery at the New York University Medical Center. He is a graduate of Princeton University and the N.Y.U. School of Medicine.

title:
DINING OUT;
Haunting Thai Flavors in Port Chester
description: LEAD: JUST when Chinese cuisine seems to be mired in the cliches of Hunan-Sichuanese cooking (a small handful of restaurants providing happy exceptions), Thai cuisine comes to our gustatory rescue, reviving our taste buds with the haunting flavors of lemon grass, coriander, ginger, basil, chilies, coconut and curries, to name a few.

title: California Resumes Air War Against Invading Fruit Fly, Stirring Debate
description: For the second time in this decade, California has undertaken vast aerial spraying of a pesticide over residential areas here in an effort to eradicate the Mediterranean fruit fly, fueling a renewed debate that pits protection of agriculture against environmental concerns.

title: TALKING: Equity Loans; Shopping For the Best Deal
description: SINCE the Tax Reform Act of 1986, equity loans on homes have become one of the few remaining ways to borrow a large sum of money on which interest charges are tax deductible. Thus it has become an increasingly desirable way to finance anything from a new car to college tuition.

title: Old Story
description: Against the backdrop of war, a Southern belle in a plantation setting is alternately involved with a milquetoast and a rogue. ''Gone With the Wind'' or the French bestseller, ''The Blue Bicycle''? Both of the above, said a French court last week in ruling that the 1983 novel by Regine Deforges was an ''illicit reproduction'' of the Margaret Mitchell epic published a half-century ago. In a plagiarism suit brought by the American Trust Company Bank, which owns the world rights to the Mitchell work, the court awarded the Mitchell estate $330,000 in damages. The judge said that ''The Blue Bicycle,'' whose heroine pouts through life and love on a vineyard in southern France circa World War II, ''relates to the most important elements of Miss Mitchell's work.'' Joe Mitchell, a nephew of the author, accepted the judgment casually. ''We seem to have won,'' he said. But, as Scarlett O'Hara might have said, the appellate bench is another court. And lawyers for Miss Deforges said they would appeal.

title: Trying to Build Heaven on Earth
description: NESTLED in the rocky Texas hill country 10 miles southwest of here, amid oak, cypress and juniper trees, is a plot of land that will soon be promoted as a bit of heaven on earth.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: WENDY KRAMER KATT;
Love, Guilt and Holiday Gift-Giving
description: LEAD: IT may be better to give than to receive, but giving at holiday times can be a stressful experience. Did you buy the right present? Are you spending too much? And, oh, those crowds at the mall!

title: Books From a Pro-Nazi Publisher Cause an Uproar in Brazil
description: In the heartland of Brazil's German descendants, an uproar has erupted in recent weeks over a new publishing house that specializes in Portuguese-language books denying the Nazi genocide of World War II.

title: Where Shopping is Charity
description: WHEN holiday shoppers want the money they spend to support their favorite charities, they head for shops run by museums and nonprofit organizations.

title: Barbara Miller, Lawyer, to Wed
description: The engagement of Barbara Miller and Gregg Jordan Berman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Berman of Richmond, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon A. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y. The couple plans to marry in March. Miss Miller, 27 years old, is an associate in the New York office of the Philadelphia law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. A cum laude graduate of Wellesley College, she received a J.D. degree from American University.

title: New Restaurant Is Planned for Central Park
description: The Harlem end of Central Park would get a new restaurant, cafeteria and catering hall - with room for nearly 400 people - under a proposal that has been approved by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: On Being Little But Not Belittled
description: To the Editor:

title: Cushioning for a Recession?
description: All things considered, chemical industry executives should be pretty scared.

title: Gorbachev Says the Party Should Wait Before Sharing Power
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today rebuffed growing demands from inside and outside the Communist Party for early action to end the party's monopoly on the nation's political power.

title: A LESSON LEARNED FROM THE LAST DOWNTURN
description: Most chemical companies are in fighting shape to enter a down cycle. Throughout the 1980's they have been shutting inefficient plants, trimming back personnel, investing in modern equipment and divesting money-losing operations. Today, most have their fixed costs under control.

title: Santa as Athlete
description: On Dec. 19, around noon, New York City's Union Square Business Improvement District plans the First Santa Claus Ulympics (that's yule-lympics), in which about 50 contestants, in red suits and beards, will compete. Events include sprinting, broad jumping, yule log rolling, wreath tossing and a toy sack relay. It's mainly a holiday celebration - toys from the sacks will be distributed to homeless kids. But the games also convey another message. According to Clement C. Moore, author of ''A

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The study means that narcotics is one of America's major industries, right up there with consumer electronics, automobiles and steelmaking.'' Robert B. Reich, Harvard professor, on a Federal study putting the cost of drug abuse at $60 billion a year.

title: The Taxi Industry Wins Again
description: In one respect, New York City's latest cab fare increase may be a blessing in disguise. It doesn't do riders any good, but it might remind Mayor-elect David Dinkins that if he means to serve the public, he has to fight the taxi cartel.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BLACK BABY. By Clare Boylan. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Alice, 67 years old and never married, lives in the underheated Dublin home that was left to her by her parents, alone except for a cat that gives her nothing in the way of affection. She is attended only by her nephews and their loathsome wives who, as the novel opens, have presented her with an old gramophone that she mistakes for a coffin.

title: 4 Towns Planning Festivals for New Year's Eve
description: FOUR communities will ring in the new year with town-wide festivities that are heavy on the performing arts and music but light on alcohol. The New Year's Eve festivities, which are modeled after the First Night celebration in Boston, will be held in Danbury, Hartford, New Haven and Stamford.

title: Golf Attire
description: To the Editor: Since 1982, my husband and I have operated a golf tour operation catering to upscale country club members whom we escort to golf clubs throughout Europe, Asia and the South Pacific. Your Q&A answer (Travel, Aug. 6) about how women should dress for a golfing trip to Scotland and Ireland in October was partially correct in saying that slacks or skirts (pleated or not) would be quite appropriate. We always advise people to dress in layers, and we think knickers or Bermudas and knee socks are a better choice than slacks or skirts in this area - slacks can get wet bottoms and wearers of skirts can get cold ones. A knitted hat is almost a must at that time of year, too. JUNE BRETON FISHER Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Switzerland Is Seeking to Curb Money Laundering
description: Stung by the country's reputation as a place of preference for money laundering by international drug traders, the Swiss Government is showing signs of changing its policy after decades of defending banking laws that made it easy for depositors to hide the origins of money.

title: When Modernism Kissed The Land of Golden Dreams
description: In 1960 THE ARCHITECTURAL PHO-tographer Julius Shulman took a picture of a glass house perched high in the Hollywood Hills that will always be, for me, one of those singular images that sums up an entire city at a moment in time. The house is sleek and white, and its glass walls are cantilevered out over the hills; two elegantly dressed women lounge inside as the lights of the vast sprawl of the Los Angeles basin twinkle below. Modernity and elegance, privacy and openness - things that so rarely went together in the older cities of the East Coast - here become one, bound together in a way that epitomizes the seductive power of Los Angeles in the first years of its heady postwar growth. Here was the modern world, fresher and newer than in the East, possessed of a visual drama that the cities of the East Coast could only dream of, and yet with all of their luxury and style.

title: America's Cup Battle in Japan
description: While lawyers tend to the legal battle over who should be awarded the America's Cup, a political brushfire in Japan is drawing the attention of potential contenders.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: No Caddies Need Apply

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE FLAXFIELD. By Stijn Streuvels. Translated by Peter Glassgold and Andre Lefevere. (Sun and Moon Press, Paper, $11.95.) During his long career, the Flemish writer Stijn Streuvels (the pen name of Frank Latour, who was born in 1871 and died in 1969) published over 40 books. The author of novels, essays and story collections, he was a major figure in the Flemish cultural revival that began toward the end of the 19th century, with his reputation peaking during the period between the two world wars.

title: Mansion Inventory Irks Minnesota Governor
description: When a newspaper published a purported inventory of the governor's mansion - including 156 chairs, six television sets and 26 sofas - an annoyed Gov. Rudy Perpich and his wife, Lola, responded by proposing that the state sell off the place. Besides, his office said, there are a mere 113 chairs and 15 sofas.

title: The Last Romantic Demurs, But on the Other Hand . . .
description: Less than two weeks have passed since Vladimir Horowitz's death, and Shura Cherkassky - the 78-year-old Russian-born, London-based pianist who is playing a recital at Avery Fisher Hall today at 3 - finds himself described with increasing frequency by concert reviewers as the last representative of the Romantic school of pianism. Mr. Cherkassky says he doesn't look at it that way. But in describing his own style, he makes it clear that his demurral is only a formality.

title: Morton Frank, 77, Ex-Publisher And Chairman of Family Weekly
description: Morton Frank, a retired publisher, died of complications Thursday following heart surgery at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Easton, Conn.

title: LEARNING TO SEE BY MINIMALISM'S SLOW FIRE
description: The finely tuned art of minimalism moves in incremental ways, more like the tortoise than the hare. Changes come in terms of minor adjustments and subtle physical shifts that foment dramatic visual differences - if you know where to look. These points were inadvertently brought home last month when Ellsworth Kelly and Peter Halley, purist artists from widely different generations, both had outstanding gallery shows, perhaps the best of their careers.

title: LIFE AND DEATH IN HIGH LATITUDES
description: THE STARS, THE SNOW, THE FIRE Twenty-five Years in the Northern Wilderness. By John Haines. 182 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. $16.

title: East Germany: From Both Sides Now
description: It would be inaccurate to say that when I made a fateful decision to defect on Jan. 10, 1985, the circumstances mirrored those of my countrymen now leaving East Germany for the West.

title: Katherine Brokaw to Wed Steven Russ
description: Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Brokaw of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Anne Brokaw, to Steven Russ, a son of Lieut. Col. Lawrence G. Russ, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Russ of Melvin Village, N.H., and Fremont, Neb. An April wedding is planned.

title: Maura A. Cronin To Wed in June
description: Neil Reynolds Cronin of East Dennis, Mass., has made known the engagement of his daughter Maura Ann Cronin to Matthew Powers Connolly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Connolly of Weston, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Free Agency Sets Record for Number of Signings in One Day
description: The trade mart never had a chance. Its cousin, the free-agent market, overwhelmed everything and everyone in its relentless path.

title: 'Nutcracker' Role Fulfills a Dream
description: LEAD: AS different as life may have been while growing up in San Juan, Tokyo, Leningrad and Hicksville, Ana Sylvia, Yuko Kawamata, Elena Kunikova and Jennifer Kropac, respectively, had at least one dream in common: dance the Sugar Plum Fairy in ''The Nutcracker.''

title: NONFICTION
description: ON THE EDGE: The Life and Times of Francis Coppola. By Michael Goodwin and Naomi Wise. (Morrow, $22.95.) The film director Francis Ford Coppola has grappled with the conflict between art and commerce throughout his career, according to Michael Goodwin, a film journalist, and Naomi Wise, the film critic for San Francisco Focus, in ''On the Edge.'' They present a compelling case, taking the reader through the creation of more than a dozen movies, ranging in commercial appeal from ''The Godfather'' to ''One From The Heart,'' a cold, technological experiment that most filmgoers ignored. The authors' research reveals the director's contrasts: the innovator who demands complete creative control while hoping to find a ''family'' with whom to collaborate; the entrepreneur who negotiates a directing fee of $3 million plus 10 percent of the adjusted gross but later loses his studio, American Zoetrope, to bankruptcy; the emotional wreck who lies on top of a roof during the filming of ''Apocalypse Now,'' letting rain spill over him as he moans, ''Let me out of here.'' The authors' conversational (if occasionally flippant) writing style suits the subject, their anecdotes are engrossing, their observations sound. But since neither Mr. Coppola nor most of his current associates would aid Mr. Goodwin and Ms. Wise, they depend on extensive written material and talks with Mr. Coppola's colleagues from years ago. ''All too often,'' the authors admit, ''we've been forced to rely on accounts we don't entirely trust.''

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Troupe At End Of an Emotional Day
description: At last there is a production of ''Come and Get the Beauty of It Hot'' to do justice to the gifts of Talley Beatty, one of the first popular black modern-dance choreographers of our time. The revival by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, presented for the first time this season Friday night at City Center, was minus one section and looked miscued in its final moment. But this was otherwise a performance that set Mr. Beatty's cool, hot jazz dance spinning elegantly and exactly across the stage.

title: Those Unique Students, The 'Average' Ones
description: DO you sometimes wonder why television and print media remind us again and again about the needs of gifted or handicapped children with scarcely a mention about the needs of most children: our average children?

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Old Houses Decked Out For Christmas Visitors
description: New York City offers a treasure of Christmases past, quiet old houses that have been dressed in their holiday best and that offer a welcome change from the rush, crush and glitter of the shopping season.

title: Now the Recyclable Trash Is Overwhelming New York
description: NEW YORK CITY recycles 800 to 900 tons of trash every day: newspapers, magazines and cardboard that the Sanitation Department picks up in Manhattan and Queens and glass that Staten Island residents are required to separate from the rest of their trash. Last week, the number of households taking part in the city recycling programs under a five-month-old law passed the one-million mark.

title: An Actor Tries to Keep Radio Theater Alive
description: ''WHAT is radio theater, and isn't it supposed to be dead anyway?'' David Ossman, whose resume lists his talents as ''radio producer, director and trainer; narrations, voice-overs and characters,'' was asked just that question during a recent performing and teaching gig, as he called it.

title: U.S. Ties With West Germany Begin To Eclipse Relationship With Britain
description: While no one in the Administration will say so, it has become clear in recent months that the longtime ''special relationship'' between the United States and Britain is being overshadowed by an increasingly demanding relationship between Washington and Bonn.

title: WE ARE NEIGHBORS, WE ARE STRANGERS
