description: FEVER Twelve Stories. By John Edgar Wideman. 161 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; School Officials Take a Dim View Of Condom Sales
description: Two brothers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison are feeling the wrath of the administration over a product bearing a likeness of the school's mascot.

title: SAVINGS REGULATOR PLANS ASSET SALES
description: L. William Seidman, who manages the special regulatory agency created to liquidate and find buyers for the troubled properties held by failed savings institutions, said today that about 40,000 properties were being prepared for sale in 1990. About half, he said, are in Texas and Oklahoma.

title: CRUMBS IN THE COVERS
description: I was surprised to read that Wolfgang Puck said he does not like to eat in bed (Food: ''Crumbs in the Covers,'' by Linda Wells, Nov. 12). When Wolf and his wife, Barbara, visited us for a few days, I took a picture of them eating a breakfast in bed of hot chocolate souffle with whipped cream and raspberries. They didn't leave a crumb. MAIDA HEATTER Miami Beach

title: Fresno State Wins Bowl
description: Ron Cox, a linebacker, led a ferocious defense and returned an interception 58 yards for a touchdown today as Fresno State defeated Ball State, 27-6, in the California Raisin Bowl.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: HOLIDAY CONCERTS

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY FANTASIES

title: A Woman Blessed With the Gift of Compassion
description: BISHOP Rosetta Wheeler, head of the 80-member Mount Hebron Church of God in New Haven, ran her hand along her living room wall and gave thanks. She gave thanks for the chairs and the tables and the soft drink she held in her hands. She then told the story of North Carolina where, as a sharecropper's daughter, she picked cotton from dawn until dusk and went home to sleep in one bed with five of her sisters and brothers. One day, she said, she knelt in a ditch and prayed that she be given a better life.

title: A LITERARY HIGH-WIRE ACT
description: THERE IS UMBERTO AND THERE IS Eco. Umberto is the author of ''The Name of the Rose,'' an experimental whodunit that overnight became an international best seller; Eco is professor of semiotics at the medieval University of Bologna. Umberto has now written ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' a novel that is seducing the American literary establishment but was at the center of a heated, yearlong critical debate in Italy. Some Italian critics believed it was a plotless distortion of history written by a buffoon who used his knowledge of publishing ways to manipulate the market. Others considered it the first novel of a new, global, collage culture. The American critics have deepened the ambiguity: Some have refused to consider ''Foucault's Pendulum'' a novel, but have praised it as a dazzling philosophical entertainment.

title: At the Malta Meeting, West Met West, Too
description: FOR President Bush, the summit meeting last weekend in Malta was not only a time to begin forging a new relationship with the East. It was also an opportunity for more clearly establishing Washington's role within the Western alliance.

title:
ART;
Geometry, Sometimes Almost Garish
description: LEAD: AT the very least, ''Restructure/Subverting the Grid'' at the New Jersey Center for the Visual Arts proves that plane geometry does not have to be plain geometry.

title: Campus Life: Marquette; Rugby Club Faces Punitive Action For Harassment
description: Marquette University's government Senate has voted to recommend that the university disband its rugby club for one year because of its harassment of a female student.

title: A Christmas Appeal: The Neediest Cases, 1989
description: For a young mother desperately seeking education, and for others in need whose stories are told today, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund offers dignity and hope. Articles, page 103.

title: Guard's Allotments in Drug War Approved
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has approved the state-by-state spending allotments that the National Guard will use for its expanded role in the national war against drugs.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
State Raises Project Subsidy
description: LEAD: A 600-ACRE mixed-use project 15 miles south of Pittsburgh has received $1.95 million, which the state awarded to Washington County for infrastructure improvements.

title: Short, Nasal, Unhandsome - and a Star
description: It's been said many times that Dustin Hoffman, who will open here Dec. 19 in ''The Merchant of Venice,'' is a wholly unlikely star, an actor with multiple handicaps: he's too short, his nose is too big, his voice has been described, charitably in the opinion of his detractors, as nasal, lacking in resonance and range. I remember taking note of these things when I saw him in his first stage appearance in 1964 or '65. He was 27 or 28 at the time, a somewhat late bloomer, and he played a crippled German homosexual in a play by Ronald Ribman called ''Harry, Noon and Night.'' The role foreshadowed his brilliant performances as the lame Ratso Rizzo and the autistic Raymond Babbitt in the films ''Midnight Cowboy'' and ''Rain Man.''

title: Jersey Mine Cave-Ins Raise Questions of Financial Risk
description: The collapse of two old copper mine shafts in backyards here on Nov. 30 has left a 75-house neighborhood nervous about possible cave-ins of 40 other shafts and raised questions about paying for future property damage and for plugging of the 279-year-old mine.

title: 'Field to Factory' Explores Migration at Hudson Museum
description: A PHOTOGRAPH of a tree is included in the Hudson River Museum of Westchester's current exhibition here: ''Field to Factory: Afro-American Migration 1915-1940.'' The picture seems quite ordinary until one reads the caption: ''Hanging Tree, New Madrid, Missouri.''

title: Different King, Different Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Hamilton and Harry Usher, Engineers, Wed
description: Lisa A. Hamilton, the daughter of Lester Y. Hamilton of Westbury, L.I., and Jeanne E. Cross of Columbia, Md., was married in New York yesterday to Harry M. Usher, a son of Hubert G. Usher of Sacramento, Calif., and Addie M. Usher of Los Angeles. Pastor Carl C. Alexander and Assistant Pastor Michael Joyce, both of the Tabernacle of Praise in the Bronx, performed the nondenominational ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: LOW TALES OF THE HIGHBORN
description: I find it appalling that you saw fit to print a major story on the British gossips. To record anything beyond their demise is wasteful of paper and time.

title: School Appointments Questioned
description: Thomas Sobol, the New York State Commissioner of Education, said on Friday that he had ''some questions'' about Joseph A. Fernandez's appointment of two deputy schools chancellors for New York City.

title: Stormy Exchanges Over Fate of City Manager in New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, the self-appointed ''Queen of the Sound,'' was delighted last summer when a publication crowned it the city with the best prospects in the state for economic success in the l990's.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 103, Lakers 101: Mark Alarie hit a driving layup for Washington with 22 seconds left for Washington last night in a game played in Landover, Md. With Washington down by 101-100, Alarie was unable to get off a 10-foot shot, but drove into the lane and scored with a layup over two Los Angeles defenders.(AP) Nuggets 106, Hornets 93: Alex English scored 25 points as visiting Denver limited Charlotte to three field goals in the fourth quarter. Charlotte led, 58-56, at the half, the first time all season that the team has been ahead at halftime.(AP) Hawks 104, Timberwolves 91: Dominique Wilkins scored 33 points, including 7 in a tie-breaking 13-0 run at the start of the third quarter, for Atlanta in a home game. Minnesota led, 55-49, at 1:22 before halftime, but lost this edge by intermission. During a 19-0 Atlanta run over two quarters, Spud Webb was banged into the backboard support following a steal. Minnesota's Tony Campbell was ejected from the game for a flagrant foul.(AP) Pistons 121, Pacers 93: Isiah Thomas scored 20 of his 30 points in the first half for Detroit in Auburn Hills. Detroit shot 72 percent in the first half on their way to a 59-38 lead at the intermission.(AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 6, Flyers 6: Joe Sakic scored on a penalty shot with 23 seconds left in regulation yesterday in Quebec and Lucien DeBlois tied the game 16 seconds later as Quebec rallied for the tie.(AP) Capitals 7, Bruins 3: Dino Ciccarelli scored two goals and Don Beaupre stopped 33 shots as Washington matched its best offensive showing of the season by routing the Bruins, the National Hockey League's best defensive team, in Boston.(AP) Golf Rain Helps Bies: Heavy rain washed away Lee Trevino's chance of improving his position and canceled the third round yesterday, making Don Bies the winner of the storm-shortened two-round Kaanapali Classic in Hawaii, the final tournament of the 1989 Seniors PGA Tour.(AP) 2-Stroke Lead: Mike Hulbert and Bob Tway combined for an eight-under-par 64 yesterday to take a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the Chrysler PGA team championships in Wellington, Fla. They were at 28-under-par 188 after 54 holes.(AP) Tennis Patrick McEnroe Advances: Patrick McEnroe teamed with Jim Grabb yesterday to reach the final of the Masters doubles championship in London. The two Americans beat Pieter Aldrich and Danie Visser of South Africa, 6-4, 6-1, 6-3.(AP) Skiing 13th for Walliser: Maria Walliser posted her 13th career World Cup downhill triumph yesterday, edging her Swiss teammate Michela Figini by 15-hundredths of a second in Steamboat Springs, Colo. Walliser ran the race in 1 minute 32.69 seconds.(AP) Speed Skating East Germans Dominate: East Germany dominated the ice yesterday as Uwe-Jens Mey won both men's races and Angela Hauck took both women's events in World Cup competition in Karuizawa, Japan. Mey won the men's 500 in 37.10, and the 1,000 in 1:14.57. Hauck won the 500 in 40.80 and the 1,000 in 1:24.10.(AP) Ski Jumping Austrian Wins: Ernst Vettori of Austria made the best jump of the second round yesterday to edge Matti Nykaenen of Finland, the Olympic champion, and win the World Cup 90-meter competition in Lake Placid, N.Y.(AP) Horse Racing Favorite Takes Nashua Stakes: Undefeated Champagneforashley, the odds-on favorite, led all the way in romping to a nine-length victory in the $110,800 Nashua Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner, ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, covered a mile and a sixteenth in 1:45 1/5 and earned $66,480 for Lions Head Farm. He returned $2.40 for $2 to win. Armed for Peace was second in the four-horse field of 2-year-olds, 10 1/2 lengths ahead of Flathorn.(AP)

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday by a Polish journalist on European security needs misspelled the author's name.

title: Tracy A. Walter Is to Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald G. Walter of Shrewsbury, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracy Ann Walter, to William C. Ferry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Ferry Jr. of Meriden, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: I.B.M.'s Low-Radiation Monitors
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has quietly begun selling computer monitors that contain special technology intended to reduce the user's exposure to electromagnetic radiation. The low-radiation monitors are currently available in the United States only for mainframe and midrange computer systems. But I.B.M. officials said the technology could be incorporated into personal computer monitors if it becomes clear that customers demand it.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WORCESTER, MASS.;
A New Focus For an Old Area
description: LEAD: THE ISLAND, an aging neighborhood here, has an attractive new centerpiece, a $4.8 million apartment building for the elderly called Lafayette Place that is to be a residential anchor for the renewal of Millbury Street.

title: Sunday Best
description: Simply mention Sunday dinner in the presence of a bona fide French gastronome and his wide-eyed, sentimental expression will tell all. With his descriptions, you can almost taste the glistening poulet doti, hear the quiet simmering of the pot-au-feu, smell the faint sweetness of a quatre-quarts aux poires warm from the oven.

title: Campus Life: Dayton; At One School, Christmas Comes 17 Days Early
description: More than a thousand people filled the John F. Kennedy Plaza at the University of Dayton on Friday shouting, ''Five, four, three, two, one'' as they waited for President Raymond L. Fitz to light the 40-foot Christmas tree and officially begin Christmas on Campus.

title: Finally, a Hot High-Tech Offering
description: In a slack market for initial public offerings in technology, many analysts are toasting this month's coming debut of MIPS Computer Systems Inc. Investors might find that it is best to join the party now, buying during the offering but maybe selling before others take a sober look at MIPS's long-term prospects.

title: A Heritage of Selflessness: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Six Reasons, Ages 2 to 10, To Strive On
description: For want of $15, Shelly T. almost didn't go to college.

title: Zerlina Stall Weds Edward J. Kaplan
description: Temple Beth El in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Zerlina Stall, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour R. Stall of Poughkeepsie, to Dr. Edward J. Kaplan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold L. Kaplan of Beacon, N.Y. Rabbis Erwin Zimet and Charles M. Feinberg performed the ceremony.

title: A Glimpse Into Albania
description: FOR years I had wanted to visit Shqiperia - the land of the eagle - whose people reputedly descend from the ancient Illyrians and have spent their entire history fighting foreign domination.

title: Edward J. Bloustein, 64, Is Dead; President of Rutgers Since 1971
description: Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University since 1971, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he was attending a business meeting. Dr. Bloustein lived in the president's house on the school's New Brunswick-Piscataway campus. He was 64 years old.

title: FOCUS: Log Homes; Kit-Built Units Gain as Prime Residences
description: WHEN Tom and Julia Berry decided to build a house two years ago, they didn't think too long or hard before deciding to have to it built of logs. After all, they had been married in a log cabin in Maine's northern woods.

title: NOT YOUR AVERAGE FAMILY
description: A THIN, IMPROBABLY LOOSELY PUT TOGETHER man is standing on the stage of the Continental Divide, in New York's East Village. He looks out at the club's dinosaur decor and its audience of second-generation bohemian children and laughs, for who knows what reason. Then he begins to chant. For emphasis, he picks out chords on an electric keyboard and blows short clusters of notes from a tiny pocket trumpet that once belonged to Josephine Baker's Parisian revue.

title: Eagles' Aide Dies
description: Doug Scovil, the quarterbacks coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, died of a heart attack yesterday. An obituary appears on page 60 of Section 1.

title: Suit Seeks Drug Treatment for Pregnant Women
description: Three hospitals and a drug-treatment center in New York City have been sued for refusing to provide drug and alcohol treatment to pregnant women. The case, brought by the Women's Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union in a class-action suit, is thought to be the first in the nation to challenge exclusion of pregnant women from drug programs, a widespread practice.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Reviews/Music; Mozart and Schubert, By Austrian Pianist
description: Thomas Larcher's evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall Wednesday night included not a single virtuoso piece, yet one could hardly imagine a more challenging collection of pieces to present at a New York debut. C-minor profundities began and ended the program - Mozart's Fantasy and Sonata, and then the Schubert sonata from the last year of his life. In between were Schoenberg's Three pieces (Op. 11) and an episodic fantasy by Mr. Larcher himself called ''Naunz.''

title: Knicks Win in a Runaway Against Celtics
description: Johnny Newman drives the middle for a two-handed dunk. He hits a 3-point field goal from the top of the key. He makes another 3-pointer from the left baseline.

title: New Directory for County Students
description: YOUNG people in the county in need of help with a wide variety of problems ranging from drug and alcohol abuse to how to get a driver's license and prepare for college entrance examinations can now turn to an 82-page countywide directory.

title: Europe Backs Idea of One Germany
description: European Community leaders endorsed the idea of a single German state today, but they attached a series of conditions aimed at insuring that moves toward German unity do not bring instability to Europe.

title: Sheree Fabrikant Weds W. D. Bloch
description: Sheree Ilese Fabrikant and Wayne David Bloch, both associates at New York law firms, were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbis William Greenburg and Eugene Wernick officiated.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Office Complexes Pushing Farther East
description: LEAD: THE development of a major office hub where Veterans Memorial Highway and the Long Island Expressway converge will move closer to fruition next month. That is when a partnership of the Related Properties Corporation of Manhattan and Computer Associates International of Garden City breaks ground for the first phase of a 1.48 million-square-foot headquarters complex for the software manufacturer.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Be sure to use approved outdoor wiring if decorating small trees and shrubs for the holidays. Fasten the light strings carefully to strong limbs to avoid any snapping or tearing. Transplanting of shrubs and trees continues this month as long as the ground can be worked deeply enough to accommodate the root balls. Draft Problem

title: Jackie Robinson? Who's That?
description: Who was Jackie Robinson, and why is it that so many know so little about him?

title: Even in California, Finally, Real Estate Is Not Hot
description: CALIFORNIANS are begining to learn what Texans did five years ago and New Yorkers more recently: that what goes up in real estate may also come down.

title: Dinkins Has to Answer Questions on Stock Again
description: REPORTS of a Federal inquiry into a stock transaction by Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins passed like a dark cloud through City Hall last week, breaking the rhythm of the transition, provoking surly confrontations with reporters and stirring fears of disorganization and drift.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 19 about shopping in London misstated the source of cashmere. It comes from goats, not sheep.

title: A Slovak Goes From Prison to Power
description: More than anyone else, Jan Carnogursky, a slight, diffident Slovak lawyer and civil-rights campaigner, personifies the rapid dismantling of one-party Communist rule in Czechoslovakia.

title: In an Afghan Border Town, the Fighting Wins Just One Thing: More Death
description: After staying up all night to direct a firefight with the American-backed guerrillas besieging this shattered town, Brig. Gen. Abdul Sattar made a picture of bullish confidence as he relaxed in the late-autumn sunshine and stroked his moustache.

title: Pain, Laughter, Love and Life After the Holocaust
description: The Jewish refugee couples who settled in the United States after World War II shared a wry expression with one another. ''Hitler married us,'' they would say, trying to explain what seemingly mismatched people were doing together as husband and wife.

title: Fossils Lead Way Into a Living Past
description: LEAD: YOUNG voices rang out on the Westchester Community College campus here one recent Friday morning. ''I found a trilobite,'' called out one and then another.

title: CORRECTON
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday about things to do with children in New York at Christmas misidentified the statue overlooking the skating rink at Rockefeller Center. It is Prometheus.

title: A Reluctant Education
description: IT APPEARS THAT I WILL NOT HAVE A CHILD. I AM 41 years old, and even I have to admit that the possibility, now, is remote. Still, I cannot quite bring myself to say, ''I will not have a child.'' And so I hedge: It appears that. . . .

title: Holding Out
description: Socialism may be fraying at the seams, and glasnost, perestroika and compromise may be the words of the hour elsewhere, but Fidel Castro remains a purist. In a speech last week in Havana, Mr. Castro, who has been in power in Cuba for more than 30 years, expressed both a fierce support of socialism and an unease at being one of the few who do. ''If destiny assigns us the role of one day being among the last defenders of socialism in a world in which the Yankee empire has succeeded in embodying Hitler's dream of world domination, we will know how to defend this bulwark to the last drop of blood,'' he said. Mr Castro complained of the difficulty of building Communist states when others are tearing them down, and noted the possible consequences of a warming between the United States and the Soviet Union, which sends him so much support. ''From the crisis that has emerged in the socialist camp, we can only expect negative economic consequences for our country,'' he said.

title: PRODUCTIVITY IS UP COMMODITIES RELIANCE, DOWN
description: In the late 1970's, chemical companies operated as though demand would never decline and prices would never stop rising. ''Everyone looked at the same tea leaves, predicted shortages and built at once,'' recalled William C. Kuhlke, vice president for polymers at Dewitt & Company, a Houston-based chemical industry consulting firm.

title: Jill M. Sanders To Wed in May
description: Plans for a May wedding have been announced for Jill Marissa Sanders and Alan David Holtz by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morton Sanders of New City, N.Y. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Holtz of St. James, L.I.

title: Fashion; In a Roomful of Penguins, You Can Be a Breed Apart
description: The room is buzzing, the evening young. There you are, feeling suave and Cary Grantish in your classic black dinner jacket, black tie, satin-stripe pants and black pumps. You head to the bar for a cocktail, and, lo, the waiters are dressed exactly like you - and better looking to boot.

title: Local Waters Yield Few Treasures
description: LEAD: WARSHIPS, schooners, freighters, tugs and passenger ships, including paddle wheelers, lie at the bottom of local waters, where scuba divers prowl about their murky hulls.

title: Troubles Erupting in Converted Co-ops
description: IT promises to be a tough winter for the residents of the Prince Albert, a 40-unit apartment building in Kew Gardens, Queens, that was converted into a cooperative four years ago.

title: INSIDE
description: Life in the Uprising: Arabs and Jews Speak

title: Ms. Rose to Wed Craig W. Hupper
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Rose of Annapolis, Md., have made known June wedding plans for their daughter Susan Kent Rose and Craig W. Hupper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hupper of New York and Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Three Agencies With a Mission and a Focus: Home Family, and Children; The Family, Whatever Its Form, Must Survive
description: As the oldest nonsectarian agency on Staten Island (in service since 1919), Staten Island Family Service Inc. has been committed to the needs of the community during the Depression, developing the War Chest during World War II, changing as the needs of the family have changed. The preservation of the family unit has been the core element of our mandate but the structure of the family is changing. Today this means divorced families, families with adult children of alcoholics and single-parent families.

title: French, Fearing New Bombings, Hunt Terror Cells
description: France and Spain are tracking down a pro-Iranian Lebanese terrorist network that had planned a series of attacks in this country over the holidays, French security officials say.

title: Ms. GrunewaldPlans to Marry
description: The engagement of Catherine Ann Grunewald and Brian John Collins has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John D. Grunewald of Chatham Township and Spring Lake, N.J. Mr. Collins is a son of Prof. John Collins and Titia Collins, both of Cazenovia, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: Lydia Gray Weds Stephen Bartholow
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Lydia Beatriz Gray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gray Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Stephen Bartholow Jr., the son of Mr. Bartholow of Dallas and Frederick, Okla., and Ann Ford of Dallas. The Rev. Dr. R. Maurice Boyd, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth M. Johnson, a Methodist minister and an uncle of the bride.

title: ANGST IS A KILLER
description: DUCKS By Helen Hodgman. 121 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $16.95.

title: Labrador Love: Once Again, The Circle Is Unbroken
description: ON a bitter February night, my husband, Bill, and I came home from our veterinarian's office, wet-eyed, holding an empty red dog collar and lead. Dickens, our big male Labrador, met us at the door and nuzzled us inquiringly. There was no way to tell him that his beloved companion, Bonnie, would never come home again.

title: THE HIDDEN FILES
description: On March 7, 1936, my great-great-uncle, Dr. Herman Fried, died at the age of 55. He was a well-known specialist in X-ray therapy. His life was cut short because, in those days, people were not as aware of the dangers of radiation as they are today.

title: Campus Life: Clark; Enlivening History Through Veterans Of World War II
description: Timothy Donohue realized that many of his classmates think of World War II as something in ancient history, not something that began for the United States only 48 years ago.

title: The End of History, Explained for the Second Time
description: THE debate about the ''end of history'' has not come to an end. Francis Fukuyama, the State Department official who declared the end of the ideological struggle between East and West in an article last summer in The National Interest, has responded to his critics, and taken the argument a step further.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the chairman of Universal Pictures, Tom Pollock, misidentified the movie studio recently acquired by the Sony Corporation. It is Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about seasonal TV programming for younger viewers omitted the date for the initial WNET broadcast of ''The Adventures of Alice in Wonderland.'' The program will be shown at 6 P.M. on Sunday, Dec. 24.

title: Good-Natured Corrections
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Coalition Assisting Hispanic Parents
description: LEAD: FOR Spanish-speaking parents who have little or no facility with English, dealing with their children's school often brings frustration and confusion. Asking and answering questions, getting information from the school or participating in teacher conferences involve significant obstacles.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q.&A. column on Nov. 26 misstated the registration fee for the Global Home Exchange and Travel Service. It is $35.

title:
THEATER;
In Search of the Untouched Moments of Life
description: LEAD: Paddy Chayefsky's play ''The Tenth Man'' opens tonight at the Vivian Beaumont Theater 30 years after its premiere on Broadway. The production is directed by Ulu Grosbard and the 13-member ensemble includes Joseph Wiseman, Bob Dishy, Jack Weston, Peter Friedman and Phoebe Cates. The original production, directed by Tyrone Guthrie with a cast led by Lou Jacobi, Jack Gilford and George Voskovec, ran for more than 600 performances.

title: Paris or Versailles?
description: To the Editor:

title: Turks Fear Changes Undercut Ties to Europe
description: Eastern Europe's shifting political map has left Turkey wondering from the sidelines whether it will end up a diplomatic loser when the dust settles.

title: Lose Your Bag, Sir? And Other Stories
description: TALES of what the Government calls ''mishandled'' luggage are legion: Try any dinner table. To give you an idea of the pool you are dipping into, in September, 226,303 travelers complained to United States airlines about their luggage: misdelivered, rifled, crushed, burned, emptied or never seen again.

title: Seton Hall Adds to Winning Streak
description: The past, present and future of Seton Hall basketball assembled at the Walsh Hall Gymnasium today and an impressive winning tradition remained intact as the Pirates defeated Iona, 85-67.

title: A Prescription for Troubled I.B.M.
description: By all accounts, the International Business Machines Corporation is in trouble. Drastic measures are now in order if it is to keep its dominance in computers. Some would even argue that the time has finally arrived for it to drop its stubborn preoccupation with the mainframe, maybe even spin off its minicomputers.

title: Miss Briggs Weds Harold Berry 3d
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., Marion Shepley Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Briggs Jr. of Rye and Manset, Me., was married yesterday to Harold James Berry 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Berry of Darien, Conn. Dean Perry R. Williams, who retired as the Dean of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Cleveland, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Edward Johnston.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: JOHN JAY;
Junior High Is Becoming a Middle School
description: LEAD: THE John Jay Junior High School here is becoming John Jay Middle School next fall, and the students are already talking about the change.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: Under Stu Jackson, Strickland is dishing for easy baskets, taking better shots, committing fewer turnovers and playing tighter defense.

title: Seat Strategy
description: To the Editor: ''Confessions of a Seat Strategist'' by K. C. Cole (Travel, Oct. 22) was more whimpering than strategy.

title: Ellen L. Kennelly To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Ellen Lee Kennelly to John Nicholas Brown 3d has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Eve Williams Puloka of Nukualofa, Tonga, and Richard Bayard Kennelly of Claremont, Calif. Mr. Brown is a son of Capt. and Mrs. Nicholas Brown of Baltimore and Middleburg, Va. A May wedding is planned.

title: Game Day on the Sidelines: Frenetic World Come to Life
description: Who was climbing onto Jim Mora's back? The Saints' coach was rapt in the football game, peering from the sidelines, as his team was routing the Tampa Bay Buccaneers with two minutes remaining. Suddenly, someone leaped onto Mora and gave him a bear hug.

title:
TEANECK JOURNAL;
Effort to Display Menorah on Town Green Finally Succeeds
description: LEAD: PERSISTENCE on the part of the Teaneck Menorah Committee has finally paid off with the Town Council. Last month, after several previous rejections, the Council approved the committee's request to erect an eight-foot-high menorah on the municipal green during the holiday season.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Singapore's Tough Stance On Smoking

title: Hans Hartung, European Pioneer Of Abstract Painting, Dies at 85
description: Hans Hartung, a pioneer of European abstract painting, a prominent figure in the Parisian art world from 1945 onward and the winner in 1960 of the Grand Prize at the Venice Biennale, died on Thursday at his home in Antibes, France. He was 85.

title: Sale of Assault Weapons Banned in Boston
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a law today banning the sale of assault weapons in Boston and said he would like to see more gun control across Massachusetts and the nation.

title: Soviet Party's Role Defended
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev rebuffed growing demands for early action to end the Communist Party's monopoly on political power, warning against an ''emotional'' rush to alter the Soviet Constitution. Page 30.

title: EAST GERMANS PICK NEW PARTY LEADER
description: After a turbulent all-night meeting marked by bitterness over abuses of power and privilege by its former leaders, the East German Communist Party this morning elected Gregor Gysi, a 41-year-old lawyer, to the new post of chairman.

title: 2 More Palestinians Killed in West Bank as Revolt Enters 3d Year
description: Two Palestinians were shot and killed today on the second anniversary of the start of the uprising in the occupied territories, as Israeli and Arab figures made it clear that neither side was willing to make concessions to bring the violence to an end.

title: Where Boomerangs Are Not Exotic
description: RUTH MORRISSEY keeps Down Under close by. She runs the Australia House in Mystic, where she sells Australian opals and aboriginal paintings, sculpture and didgeridoos. She also tells of the mining of opals and the making of didgeridoos, the traditional musical instrument of the aborigines.

title: Michigan Tops Duke By 113-108
description: Sean Higgins scored 7 of his 32 points in overtime, leading Michigan to a 113-108 victory today over Duke.

title: Review/Music; Electronic Components In Work by 3 Composers
description: Three composers who combine electronics and performance got together Thursday night at Roulette, and the program they assembled offered a sharp disjunction in mood between the first piece and all that followed.

title: Two Bronx Galleries Produce Lively Displays
description: ONCE more into the Bronx - for group shows at the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery and at the Longwood Arts Gallery. They are not related, these alternative spaces, but both are diamonds in the rough and both can be counted on for lively displays graced by a prominent name or two.

title: Ballot Questions Provide A Lesson For All
description: RARELY receiving the intense attention focused on the vote for candidates, the outcome on ballot questions can be an equally telling test of the mood of the electorate.

title: A Rebirth in Country French in Norwalk
description: TALENT and perseverance will out, as the chef Patrick Benrezkellan and the co-owner and maitre d'hotel Patrick Ravanello, both formerly with Guy Savoy in Greenwich, have demonstrated so ably in transforming a good South Norwalk storefront delicatessen and bistro called Cafe Parfait into La Provence, an excellent French country restaurant.

title: For Many, Donating to Charity Is the Perfect Gift
description: Some of Santa's surrogates are sending holiday contributions to charitable and nonprofit organizations in the names of their friends and family members, instead of scouring shopping malls and stores for just the right presents.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: Even though Jackson seems to be playing like he's in a funk, he has the capability and will be showing it again soon enough. Strickland is playing great, but that may be because he doesn't have the pressure of starting or, at this time, the pressure of not getting enough minutes. Together, they complement and supplement each other's strengths and weaknesses. GENE WOLFF Roslyn, L.I.

title: OPTIONS EXPAND IN DELUXE EQUIPMENT
description: We're still in the sybaritic 1980's, but not for long. So indulge yourself while there is time; and if top-rank sound equipment figures in your notion of self-indulgence, the following may add to your temptations.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed some insulation under the floor over my crawl space. This insulation has a vapor barrier on one side, and so I removed the plastic vapor barrier sheets that originally covered the earth floor in the crawl space. I would now like to cover the earth floor with something else so that I can store things there. What kind of earth cover can I use that will not be a vapor barrier and that will still be comfortable to crawl around on when I go down there to remove or replace stored items?

title: Super Failures Haunt Broncos
description: The Louisiana Superdome in November of last year was the site of a deep soul-searching session by the Denver Broncos. They had just been destroyed by the New Orleans Saints, 42-0, and had fallen to 6-6. And what the Broncos would not say about the debacle, the Saints' quarterback, Bobby Hebert, would.

title: Nancy J. Adams To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Adams of Centerport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Adams, to Craig Philip Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Taylor of Coventry, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: 'Boesman,' Prophetic and Brilliant
description: THE time for ''Boesman and Lena'' is now.

title: Sun, Surf and Singles
description: THE streetcar named Desire may be retired, but there is still a bus called Hedonism. I found myself heading for this bus one recent afternoon at the Montego Bay Airport.

title: BACK FOR THE BRINK ONCE MORE
description: In frontier days, if you believe western folklore, a man condemned to hang was set free if the rope broke. In those days, the New York City Opera would have been a legend.

title: The Verdict In Miami
description: IN a city with ethnic tensions, violence can ignite quickly. Last January, rioting erupted in the primarily black Overtown section of Miami after two unarmed black men were killed when a Hispanic police officer fired at their motorcycle, which was being pursued by a patrol car for traffic violations. In the three days of disturbances that followed, one person was killed and 11 were shot.

title: Allergy Complaints Rise in Rainiest Year
description: RICHARD, a 41-year-old resident of Glen Cove, said that he has had a stuffy nose and burning, itchy eyes during the spring, summer and fall seasons for about the last 15 years. But this year, he said, he also has suffered severe headaches.

title: Dubuffet and Bultman in Storrs
description: JEAN DUBUFFET (1901-1985) and Fritz Bultman (1919-1985) are not exactly peas in a pod, one being a Frenchman who valued nature - unspoiled human nature, that is - above culture, the other an American ''committed to conquering nature.'' Nevertheless, shows by the artists are running side by side at the Benton Museum of the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Worcester, Mass.;
A New Focus For an Old Area
description: LEAD: THE ISLAND, an aging neighborhood here, has an attractive new centerpiece, a $4.8 million apartment building for the elderly called Lafayette Place that is to be a residential anchor for the renewal of Millbury Street.

title: After Music Videos, All the World Has Become a Screen
description: MTV probably didn't know its own strength when the cable channel started broadcasting music video clips day and night on Aug. 1, 1981. But as the end of the decade draws near, the fast pace and kaleidoscopic style of music video has ricocheted across popular culture, changing the way people listen to music and leaving its frenetic mark on movies, television, fashion, advertising and even television news.

title: Hospital Economy: Change the Diapers Policy
description: Dr. Stanley Hellerstein's garbage doubled last spring after his infant granddaughter was brought to visit him, along with her disposable diapers.

title: PERSPECTIVE: Housing Rehabilitation; The 'Turnkey' Approach Tried in Harlem
description: IT is only one small building, but the transformation in progress at a vacant and rundown five-story walk-up at 460 Convent Avenue, at the corner of 150th Street in central Harlem, has something to say about the way gut-rehabilitated housing can be produced for low-income working people and the homeless in New York City.

title: Riverhead May Lose $300,000 Grant
description: LEAD: A $300,000 state preservation grant to the 1881 Vail-Leavitt Music Hall in Riverhead may be revoked as a result of dissension among those who would save the structure, Long Island's only remaining two-story opera house.

title: Social Events
description: Saving a Colorful Past

title: Filling the Need for Moms and Dads
description: LEAD: BY the end of January, 26 new foster homes will be added in the Stamford area, more than double the number currently available. And for the last few months, 35 people have been devoting their Wednesday evenings to training sessions that will qualify them as licensed foster parents.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe it is important that we not exhaust ourselves in placing blame for problems that exist,'' - Brent Scowcroft, at a dinner with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in Beijing. [ 1:6. ]

title: New Phase in Scarsdale Police Rating
description: LEAD: SCARSDALE residents will have a chance this week to participate in their Police Department's bid for accreditation by the Commission on Accreditation for Law Enforcement Agencies, a nonprofit corporation based in Fairfax, Va., that promotes professional standards for law-enforcement agencies.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Winter Chore: Repairing Doors
description: WINTER months, when humidity levels generally are at their lowest of the year, are the best for curing problems affecting wooden interior doors.

title: Nixon's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: New Laws of Subway Life Are Met With Lawsuits
description: A SUBWAY musician's folk tunes were echoing off the walls at the 72d Street IRT subway station the other day. Was the music entertaining or distracting? That burly fellow with the extended hand at the Brooklyn Bridge stop was just asking for help. Or was he hinting that if he did not get a few coins there might be trouble?

title: Portuguese Voyagers Reach New Shores
description: SINCE the 15th century, when their navigators discovered how to steer ships by the stars, the Portuguese have been world travelers. Their voyages have left a legacy of Portuguese language and culture in romantic places like Macao, Goa, Mozambique and Farmingville.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $787,500 9 Hobby Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, new Victorian colonial; study, master suite w/spa bath and deck, 1.06 acres; taxes not yet assessed. Chappaqua, N.Y. $782,500 50 Overlook Drive 5-bedroom, 5-bath, 60-year-old Norman Tudor; fireplace, family room, screened porch, den, butler's pantry, playroom, 1.2 acres; taxes $11,969. Katonah, N.Y. $605,000 40 Glenwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, library, wet bar, guest cottage, pool, 4.4 acres; taxes $9,932. Farmington, Conn. $810,000 101 Pembroke Hill 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath new French country manor; butler's pantry, whirpool bath, central vacuum, 3-car garage, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Middletown, Conn. $175,000 44 Cimarron Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old raised ranch; fireplace, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,434. New Haven, Conn. $118,000 133 Oakley Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; newly remodeled, skylight in master bedroom, dining room; taxes $993. OTHER AREAS Nesconset, L.I. $132,000 37 Roosevelt Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 24-year-old ranch; finished basement, porch, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. West Islip, L.I. $450,000 19 Viking Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old waterfront colonial; c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $7,600. Morristown, N.J. $289,000 36 Edgehill Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; h/w floors, full basement, 1 acre; taxes $2,734.

title: Selling Out
description: The farming community of Taylor, N.Y., is sharply divided over the prospect of a nuclear waste dump being located in the area: it's Arthur Allen versus everybody else. Mr. Allen, who says he can no longer make a living from his 730-acre dairy farm in upstate New York, is the only person in New York State who has said he is willing to sell his land for use as a low-level nuclear waste dump. His neighbors are not at all pleased, and with inspectors due to visit this week to check the Allen farm's suitability for dumping, hostility is growing. ''The hysteria is out of sight,'' said Sondra Allen, his wife. Local groups have vowed to block the inspection and Mr. Allen's life has been threatened. But the Allens say that despite back-breaking work, they can no longer make a decent living. Mr. Allen said it made no sense that he should continue to grub for survival simply because some of his more prosperous neighbors are worried about land values. ''It's their affluence that caused the nuclear problem to begin with,'' he said.

title: The Wall of Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: More Aid Sought For Runaways
description: LEAD: WITH thousands of runaways reported each year in New Jersey, social workers and law-enforcement officials say that more public attention should be focused on the problem.

title: 2 Killed in Fire on Soviet Ship
description: Two seamen were killed and 80 crew members rescued on Friday when a Soviet fish-factory ship caught fire in the Bay of Biscay, the British Coast Guard said. A Belgian freighter spotted the ship, the Vitautus Putna, ablaze 550 miles off Land's End at the southwestern tip of England. The freighter launched lifeboats while members of the coast guard summoned other nearby ships to help in the operation. A crewman was found dead on the Soviet ship and the body of another was recovered from the water, the coast guard said.

title: Fond Thoughts Of a Brief Meeting Before the Wall Fell
description: YOU may not remember me, Fritz von Witzleben, but in the fall of 1979, I visited East Berlin. It was a sobering day, except for my visit with you at the Metropole Theater. You were the only one who spoke English when I asked to photograph the beautiful costumes in the window. You said: ''No, Madame, we do not permit photography. But I will give you the photos of the actors and actresses.''

title: New Liver Transplant Recipient in 'Outstanding' Recovery
description: A 15-month-old girl was showing an ''outstanding'' response today after undergoing the nation's second living-donor liver transplant, but she faces a tough battle in the next few weeks, hospital officials said.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Wallingford
description: INCORPORATED in 1670 on the same 39.6 square miles of the Quinnipiac River Valley that it occupies today, Wallingford is one of Connecticut's oldest towns and one of the most stable. The scent of its early agricultural economy still drifts downwind from the handful of remaining dairy farms where cows graze, withered cornstalks rustle in the wind and pumpkins dot the wintry fields.

title: Another Host Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE WITHOUT FATHER
description: NEAR THE MAGICIAN A Memoir of My Father, Edmund Wilson. By Rosalind Baker Wilson. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $18.95.

title: Tide of Luxuries Sweep German Leaders Away
description: In the end it was the saunas, hunting lodges and imported fixtures that brought the Communists down.

title: A Season of Gloom for Some
description: LEAD: WHILE most people are getting into the holiday spirit with a flurry of gift shopping and party planning, others approach the season with gloom and anxiety. Dr. Douglas Berv, a New Haven psychiatrist who is an assistant clinical professor at the Yale School of Medicine, calls it holiday depression.

title: Events for Children Highlight Week's Fare
description: PERHAPS in the belief that holiday shoppers will be too busy to attend concerts, the secular music season will come to an almost complete halt in about a week, so drink deeply while the opportunity is offered. Today, in fact, offers an impressive array.

title: A May Wedding For Miss Gibson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. Gibson of Manhattan Beach and Palm Springs, Calif., have made known May wedding plans for their daughter, Bridgette Susan Gibson, and William Ernest Goodman 5th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodman 4th of New York, Bay Head, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Rainbow's End: Receding Dream Of Owning a Home
description: MIDWAY through our 30's, my husband and I have managed to acquire an advantage that's rare in our generation: we have a low overhead. Each month, the mortgage we pay is a relatively small portion of our total income.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Honolulu
description: Honolulu is an easy place to know and love if you give it half a chance. Some promoters call it a paradise, but it isn't. It is a city - commercial, expensive, noisy and tacky. It has traffic, drugs and street people. It also has abundant natural and manmade beauty, exceptional weather, exotic foods, friendly people, low unemployment, virtually no heavy industry.

title: Animal Emotions
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: 1992 MEETS PERESTROIKA;
West Germany Needs Western Europe
description: LEAD: Most of the speculation about the reforms in East Germany, and the potential for reunification, misses the point. Talk of an emerging German superpower is not only premature, but it does not take into account what we Germans, both East and West, really want. Obviously, we do not see - nor do we wish to see - a single Germany ''on the rise again.

title: The Arab Uprising After Two Years: Voices From Both Sides
description: Twenty-four months into their revolt, many Palestinians are beginning to lose their buoyant mood and near-universal conviction that the uprising will gain them a state, or anything else, now or anytime soon.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: THE REV. ROBERT WILLIAMS;
Answering the Call for a Gay Ministry
description: LEAD: HOMOSEXUALITY and the Episcopal faith are inextricably woven into the psyche of the Rev. Robert Williams.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DADDY. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) In Danielle Steel's 25th novel, when bad things happen to good people everything still turns out great. Ms. Steel's hero is a handsome and successful advertising man named Oliver Watson, 44 and the father of three, who discovers that his wife is serious about all that self-actualization stuff she's been talking.

title: About Men; Where Have You Gone, Bily Boy?
description: Long before I knew what ''camp'' was, Billy cracked me up with his Carmen Miranda photo collection and his swivel-hipped impersonations of our ancient sixth-grade teacher doing the watusi, a la Annette Funicello. I have not seen Billy in 10 years, and sometimes I miss him. He was a very funny boy. And sad. I guess I didn't really understand that part then. We met in elementary school, it was 1959. I was overweight. ''Husky,'' my Pop said. ''You'll grow out of it,'' my Mom said. At the rate I consumed pancakes and spaghetti, the grow-out date was still pretty distant. We had just moved into town the summer before. I had been tested and moved up a grade and was terrifically shy around the sophisticated third-graders.

title: A Bank by Any Other Name
description: Five senators and other Washingtonians wish they'd never heard of Charles Keating or his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. So does John Keating of Encino, Calif.

title: 3 People Are Dead in 2 Hit-and-Run Accidents
description: Two men, both immigrant workers from El Salvador, and a woman in her 60's died yesterday in two hit-and-run auto accidents, one on Long Island and the other in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: That brilliant though eccentric theoretician Aron Nimzovich more than a half-century ago advised that the player should take a stand, espouse a cause, set himself to prove a thesis rather than look at strategy dispassionately. There is a lot to be said for that partisan approach because it mobilizes energy and enthusiasm.

title: CZECH WRITERS: POLITICIANS IN SPITE OF THEMSELVES
description: LEAD: Sitting in a dirty bar in Prague, Nathan Zuckerman contemplates an incredible scene conjured up in his mind: ''Styron washing glasses in a Penn Station barroom, Susan Sontag wrapping buns in a Broadway bakery, Gore Vidal bicycling salamis to school lunchrooms in Queens.'' Then he looks at the filthy floor and sees himself sweeping it.

title: Let's Hear It For the Men
description: To the Editor:

title: The Far North Shows a Compass Of Styles
description: Eskimo masks - boldly spotted, bespectacled, framed with feathers, conceived as grinning doll-like figures or masks within masks - are among the most arresting artifacts on view in ''Crossroads of Continents: Cultures of Siberia and Alaska,'' an exhibition opening Friday at the American Museum of Natural History. The traveling show of 450 items, which remains through March 25, is the first to explore the relationships and differences between the peoples native to the regions bordering the Bering Strait.

title: A FOREVER AMAZING WRITER
description: LEAD: ABRAHAM LINCOLN Speeches and Writings 1832-1858. Speeches, Letters, and Miscellaneous Writings; The Lincoln-Douglas Debates. 898 pp. New York: The Library of America. $35. ABRAHAM LINCOLN Speeches and Writings 1859-1865. Speeches, Letters, and Miscellaneous Writings; Presidential Messages and Proclamations.

title: Playing Games With Labor Laws: When Work Fills a Child's Hours
description: Right here, under the nose of the Federal Government, children not yet in their teens are working 20, 30 and 40 hours a week in flagrant violation of the child labor laws.

title: A Chance to Meet Some American Composers
description: A bitter irony colors many projects of new American orchestral music, casting a pall that is rarely discussed but is nonetheless palpable. That irony centers around the disparity between musical style and public response. For just at a time when American orchestral music has never been more accessible - when it speaks in a riotous welter of languages ranging from Minimalism to neo-Romanticism - the audience seems as elusive as ever.

title: Nassau Update: Affordable Housing
description: LEAD: Lottery in Inwood

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Government mints around the world are making a nice profit honoring everything from the panda to sporting events. Buried within this marketing morass are several small groups that are marketing medals as e art first and commemorative pieces second.

title: THE HIDDEN FILES
description: I was appalled by the facts disclosed in your article, not only for what had been hidden so long by the Atomic Energy Commission - though some of us have long known about similar cover-ups by the A.E.C. - but for what was revealed by your author about a man who clearly made every effort to have his story and identity protected. Nothing justifies such detailed and public violation of a person's right to privacy, no matter how important the ''story.'' Even the photograph of this man seems to have been taken furtively - the man appears to have been dodging the camera.

title: Miss Rogers Wed On Long Island
description: Judith Ann Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Hayden Rogers of Dix Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruce Willie Driscoll Jr., a son of Lieut. Col. Driscoll, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Driscoll of Virginia Beach, Va. Msgr. Saverio Mattei officiated at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Dix Hills.

title: NONFICTION
description: WITNESS TO HISTORY: A Refugee from the Third Reich Remembers. By Joachim von Elbe. (Max Kade Institute for German-American Studies/University of Wisconsin, $18.95.) Through the eyes of Joachim von Elbe one sees the agonizing history of various Germanies: the Imperial Germany of the Kaisers, the turbulent Weimar Republic, the despotic Third Reich, then the Federal Republic, whose fundamental laws the author helped codify. His is an unusual perspective. Born in Westphalia in 1902, bred to assume his place in the administrative ruling elite, he fled Hitler's Reich in 1934 after being classified a ''Mongrel of the Second Degree'' (his grandmother was a niece of the ''non-Aryan'' composer Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy). What makes ''Witness to History'' valuable is its matter-of-fact decency and its picture-album recall of such episodes as Einstein speaking to students in Hamburg in 1920, Goring ranting in Danzig in 1930, Furtwangler's defiant conducting of Mendelssohn in Berlin in 1934. As a refugee in the United States, Mr. von Elbe studied law at Yale University, became a naturalized citizen, then returned as a G.I. to a devastated Germany. He stayed on as legal adviser to the military government and successive United States ambassadors, finding time to write an authoritative study of Roman Germany. In a lawless century, his story has redemptive value, and his book readably adds to the literature about a divided nation groping to understand where it is heading, what it has been.

title: Texas State Senator Elected to Congress To Fill Leland Seat
description: A Texas State Senator, Craig Washington, defeated a City Councilman today in a runoff election to choose a successor to Representative Mickey Leland, who died in a plane crash in Africa four months ago.

title: THE HIDDEN FILES
description: I would like to express profound thanks for Clifford Honicker's article. I am one of the survivors of Operation Crossroads. I was on a rescue tug assigned to the salvage unit at Bikini Atoll, in the Marshall Islands. We were back in the lagoon within hours after each of the detonations, performing a variety of damage-control operations. I have experienced many of the problems cited in Mr. Honicker's article and, for almost 35 years, I felt isolated and puzzled by the Government's failure to do any follow-up studies.

title: The German Die Is Cast
description: Now there's no point talking about whether the two Germanys will be reunited. The questions are when, how, in what context and with what results.

title: New Law a Worry to Scuba Divers
description: LEAD: HOW New York State will interpret the new Federal Abandoned Shipwrecks Act is worrying two local organizations representing more than 200,000 scuba divers in the metropolitan area.

title: Giants Lacking a High Gear
description: They created the most memorable moments of the Giants' victory in Super Bowl XXI: Phil McConkey waving a towel to stir up the crowd, Jim Burt celebrating with his son on his shoulders, Harry Carson dumping Gatorade on Coach Bill Parcells.

title: NEW PIZAZZ FOR THE SENSIBLE COVERUP
description: Men have always understood the mystique of the raincoat. Whether a trenchcoat, balmacaan or windbreaker, it is a coverup that makes sense, at once protective and also light enough to be comfortable over a suit. More important, though, is that such coats are considered ''proper,'' yet at the same time offer some swashbuckling dash. Now women are on to this good idea. Of course, their versions are being interpreted with more color and, in most cases, with a lot more flair. And even the most classic woman's balmacaan can be dressed up with accessories.

title:
GARDENING;
A Tree for All Seasons, or Just One
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS trees made their appearance as early as the week before Thanksgiving at some nursery lots this year. These are the trees meant to be planted outside after a brief period of decorative glory indoors.

title: Whalers Defeat Devils
description: Sean Burke, the towering goaltender, is the man the Devils expect to win more games for them than any other member of the team. The Devils are successful when Burke plays well and suffer when he is ineffective.

title: Review/Cabaret; Jim Morris and Mr. Bush
description: ''I know what it's like to be homeless,'' declares Jim Morris, impersonating George Bush. ''I don't have a home in Minneapolis or in Denver.''

title: Fashion: On the Street; To Brave The Cold, Hefty Furs
description: They really don't need the weather as an excuse, but when the temperatures drop into the teens and 20's, as they did last week, those who have fur coats wear them.

title: A Retrospective Puts Rod Stewart In Context
description: ''Rod Stewart: Storyteller/The Complete Anthology: 1964-1990'' (Warner Bros. 25987, four CD's only) is an attempt to do for Mr. Stewart what ''Decade'' did for Neil Young and, not that he really needed it, ''Biograph'' did for Bob Dylan. In other words, it aims to tie a diverse career together and make a serious case for its subject.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CHRISTMAS VILLAGE;
Where the Spirit of Christmas is Not Profit
description: LEAD: PRANCER, Vixen, Comet, Dasher and the rest of Santa Claus's reindeer arrived at Christmas Village in Torrington last week and were assigned to pens bearing their names. The reindeer, majestic with their full-grown antlers, are a Christmas tradition in Torrington, where they are the highlight of Christmas Village, a city-owned park that since 1947 has opened its gates to the public for the two weeks before

title: PAPERBACK BESTSELLERS: December 10, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction Q 1 4 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $5.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. Q 2 2 SAVAGE THUNDER, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) A young English widow finds romance with a Cheyenne in 19th-century Arizona. Q 3 7 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once-idyllic California town. Q 4 2 STOLEN BLESSINGS, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The scandalous life of the Hollywood superstar Marilyn Taylor. Q 5 5 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $5.50.) The exploits of Billy the Kid. Q 6 11 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a funeral. Q 7 * 6 KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Three Vietnam veterans on the trail of a friend who may be responsible for a series of murders. Q 8 * 2 THORNYHOLD, by Mary Stewart. (Fawcett, $5.95.) Mysteries, witchcraft and romance await a woman who inherits an English cottage. Q 9 1 A SEASON IN HELL, by Jack Higgins. (Pocket, $5.50.) A young widow's quest for her stepson's killers results in horrendous adventures across Europe. Q 10 2 CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Bantam, $5.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. Q 12 5 MITLA PASS, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $5.95.) The abduction of a woman leads to romance in Elizabethan England. Q 14 20 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $5.95.) Q 3 31 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A police-procedural account of a case involving murder and incest in an Oregon town. Q 4 11 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. Q 6 320 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. Q 7 * 16 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $6.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. Q 8 35 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) A ''new science'' that makes it possible to see order and patterns in what appears to be erratic. Q 9 81 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. Q 10 2 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton.
