The cartoonist's sketches and notes from the past 10 years. Q 2 10 THE CALVIN AND HOBBES LAZY SUNDAY BOOK, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $9.95.) A new collection of cartoons. Q 3 72 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. Q 4 2 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1990 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. Q 5 * 1 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1990. (World Almanac, $6.95.) The latest edition of a reference work. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A Sudden 2-Token Limit Is as Quickly Taken Back
description: The Transit Authority in New York City unexpectedly imposed a two-token sales limit yesterday to curtail hoarding, but riders' anger and long lines at token booths - unusual for a Saturday - prompted officials to lift the restriction hours after it was imposed.

title: Holiday Concerts, Secular Recitals
description: A FEW concerts this week are still bucking the holiday trend, and Real Art Ways, a Hartford-based artists cooperative that has never been one to stay on the beaten path, has scheduled a three-day New England Composers Festival that has nothing whatever to do with Christmas.

title: For Aquino, Rescue Comes With Price Tags
description: AS they marched out of Manila's high-rise business district Thursday morning, recoilless rifles on their shoulders and bandoleers still strapped across their chests, the troops who had nearly toppled the Philippine Government were smiling and singing. Seeing the cameras, a few held their hands in the shape of a ''T,'' imitating referees calling a brief time-out in a closely contested game.

title: Wooed By Developers, Stables Resist
description: HORSE racing may be the sport of kings, but in Westchester horseback riding is the sport of commoners, say the co-founders of the Westchester Horse Council, the equine industry's voice in the county.

title: Style Makers; Sally Safir and Richard Heimann, Bookplate Designers
description: It could be that he's in the forefront of what he calls, only slightly tongue in cheek, ''a literary affectation.'' Richard Heimann certainly hopes so because he and his wife, Sally Safir, are fledgling entrepreneurs in a new business called Ex Libris (the name is from Latin words used to mean ''from the library of''), which offers a choice of 148 bookplate designs in styles as varied as Victorian and architectural, romantic and amusing.

title: Nancy Hoguet Plans to Marry
description: Geoffrey R. Hoguet of Katonah, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his sister, Nancy Clarice Hoguet, to George Hammond Tilghman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Tilghman of Locust Valley, L.I. Miss Hoguet is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Roland Hoguet of Princeton, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
A Tree for All Seasons, or Just One
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS trees made their appearance as early as the week before Thanksgiving at some nursery lots this year. These are the trees meant to be planted outside after a brief period of decorative glory indoors.

title: Transactions
description: Hockey

title: Ms. Stanger Weds Dr. Michael Kraus
description: Allison Katherine Stanger, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Richard Stanger of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Kraus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ota Kraus of Prague. The bride's father, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Mead Chapel at Middlebury (Vt.) College.

title: E.P.A. OFFICE FACES INQUIRY IN HOUSE
description: A House subcommittee has opened an inquiry into the office of the Environmental Protection Agency's inspector general, to determine among other things whether it engaged in ''questionable investigative practices'' when it looked into charges of misconduct by the agency's Administrator, William K. Reilly.

title: A Precious Moment
description: Mikhail Gorbachev is remaking history in the Soviet Union and Europe. With the end of the cold war, George Bush has the same opportunity in the United States - the first chance in 40 years to think seriously about diverting resources from old and rapidly receding threats to a new agenda of urgent needs.

title: Gen. Aoun Exercises The Power of Not Moving
description: LEBANON'S Christian enclave, which remains bitter toward the prospect of Muslims increasing their share of power under Syria's protection, was swept last week by euphoria. The inspiration was the defiant stand of Gen. Michel Aoun, who has adamantly refused to relinquish his seat of power at the presidential palace in the Beirut suburb of Baabda.

title:
DINING OUT;
Colonial Flavor in a Charming Old Inn
description: LEAD: LOOKING at the menu at Braddock's Tavern in Medford is a little like taking a tour of South Jersey. There is a dish called veal Burlington, another called Coryell's Crossing roast loin of pork (named after the point on the Delaware River where the Coryell family ran a ferry) and yet another named the Medford

title: THE HIDDEN FILES
description: Clifford T. Honicker's chilling account of Louis Slotin's, S. Allan Kline's et al encounter with the Nuclear Age is as horrific as it is emblematic of the lengths to which many will go to protect the nuclear industry (in which many of the Fortune 500 are involved) and the ideology of maintaining a strong and nuclear-based national defense at any cost. (''The Hidden Files,'' Nov. 19). That even today Allan Kline refuses to go public speaks volumes.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;
When the Moon is Full, the Bridge Anglers Are Out
description: LEAD: IT'S 9 o'clock at night. It's pouring rain and cold. You are driving as fast as you can over the Meadowbrook Parkway drawbridge to get to your warm, comfortable home.

title: PETER SELLARS LOOKS AT MOZART THROUGH A TV LENS
description: ''Why not? My mother lives in Vienna,'' is how Peter Sellars answered Ernst Neuspiel, production chief of Austrian Television, during an intermission last year at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N. Y., when Mr. Neuspiel invited the prolific 31-year-old stage director to Vienna to videotape his iconoclastic productions of three Mozart operas. ''Don Giovanni,'' set in Harlem, ''Le Nozze di Figaro,'' set in Trump Tower, and ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' set in a diner, had been suggested to Austrian Television by its German partners in the venture, Rainer Mockert of Plaza Media and Eberhard Scheele of Mediascope, as provocative supplements to the network's extensive programming plans for the bicentennial of Mozart's death in 1991.

title: Prospects; Chrysler's Big Problem
description: In an effort to concentrate its resources on the North American automotive market, the Chrysler Corporation announced last week that it would sell Chrysler Technologies, which owns Gulfstream Aerospace and two military electronics companies. Chrysler's November car sales were down 17 percent from November 1988. Four experts offer their views on the auto maker's future. Malcolm S. Salter Professor of business administration and chairman of the advanced management program, Harvard Business School.

title: TIANANMEN SQUARE REMEMBERED
description: BEIJING SPRING Photographs by David and Peter Turnley. Text by Melinda Liu. 176 pp. New York: Stewart, Tabori & Chang. Paper, $19.95. JUNE FOUR A Chronicle of the Chinese Democratic Uprising. By the Photographers and Reporters of Ming Pao News. Translated by Zi Jin and Qin Zhou. 171 pp. Fayetteville: The University of Arkansas Press. Paper, $14.95.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
Cuts and Trims Help Plants Grow
description: LEAD: Any woody plant is an investment. To be sure it lives for a few decades rather than a few years, proper care is essential. And one of the least understood is pruning. Now, while these plants are dormant, is the time to begin. With the foliage gone, the branching structure of deciduous plants can be evaluated before choosing where to meddle.

title: Legislators Pursue Inquiry On Mosca
description: ANTHONY M. MOSCA, the County Police Commissioner who was recently rebuked by a state commission for his intervention in a drug arrest involving a family friend, was acting in a police undercover operation that the District Attorney's office said last week had serious weaknesses.

title: Cunningham Still Hears About That Sweet Moment
description: This has been a particularly swinish season, even by the bullyragging standards of the National Football League. So many coaches and players have indulged in charges of cowardice, foul play and even bounty hunting that one amateur bacteriologist fears an outbreak of the dreaded ''Ditka virus.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. LOUIS;
City Studying Warehouse Use
description: LEAD: THE fate of 10 warehouses here is under review by the city after a subsidiary of the Anheuser-Busch Company canceled plans to build a $70 million arena because the city refused to allow the warehouses to be torn down.

title: What Mr. Wall Should Have Known
description: ''If I knew then what I know now,'' M. Danny Wall, the chief savings and loan regulator, lamented shortly before his resignation last week as director of the Office of Thrift Supervision.

title: Fashion; A Fine Shirt for Bowling (Also Dancing)
description: There are some sports that Ralph Lauren doesn't have a lock on yet. In bowling it's Ralph Kramden who sets a style that is newly popular with many young people.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $650,000 38 Cedar Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, patio, terrace, 1.1 acres on the waterfront, 7 boat slips; taxes $10,300. Commack $220,000 11 Candy Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; foyer, den, attic, partly finished basement, patio; taxes $5,000. Great River $650,000 391 Great River Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old ranch; finished basement, 2 fireplaces, 2.5 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $12,400. Kings Park $160,000 49 Rumford Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; den, dining room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Nesconset $132,000 37 Roosevelt Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 24-year-old ranch; finished basement, porch, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. West Islip $450,000 19 Viking Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old waterfront colonial; c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $7,600. OTHER AREAS Katonah, N.Y. $605,000 40 Glenwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, library, wet bar, eat-in kitchen, guest cottage, pool, 4.4 acres; taxes $9,932. Middletown, Conn. $175,000 44 Cimarron Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old raised ranch; fireplace, expansion possibilities, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,434. Howell, N.J. $154,000 27 Cannonball Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, family room, patio; taxes $2,296.

title: Three Agencies With a Mission and a Focus: Home Family, and Children; Restoring the Balance In Distressed Families
description: There's no place like home.

title: Nancy Bari Baker and David M. Milberg Marry
description: Nancy Bari Baker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard N. Baker of Oceanside, L.I., was married last evening at Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., to David Michael Milberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry H. Milberg of Coatesville, Pa. Rabbi Philmore Berger performed the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE TURBAN FOR THE CROWN: The Islamic Revolution in Iran, by Said Amir Arjomand. (Oxford University, $9.95.) A sociologist specializing in Islam tries to explain the mystifying Iranian revolution, in which people rose up to demand less freedom and fewer material things. Last year our reviewer, Robin Wright, called this ''a thought-provoking work and a major contribution to serious scholarship on Iran, modern revolutions and the role of religion in contemporary politics.'' MEMORIES OF AMNESIA, by Lawrence Shainberg. (Ivy, $3.95.) A surgeon suffering from creeping neurological damage becomes convinced that his mind is sabotaging his brain. Last year our reviewer, Diane Johnson, called this novel ''an exercise in paradox, with interesting ruminations on the nature of thought itself. . . . The surrealism of the operating theater reminds one of Kafka's schematized world, pared to its elements of torture and terror - electroencephalographs, optic lobes, oscilloscopes. . . . One also learns a lot about the brain.'' A THIEF OF TIME, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $4.95.) A search for a missing anthropologist leads Lieut. Joe Leaphorn and Officer Jim Chee of the Navajo Tribal Police to a ring of archeological thieves. The novel ''transcends the conventions of the simple whodunit and plunges the reader into a fully realized world, populated by complex, fascinating characters,'' Michael Dorris said here last year. BALM IN GILEAD: Journey of a Healer, by Sara Lawrence Lightfoot. (Merloyd Lawrence/Addison-Wesley, $9.95.) A Harvard professor tells how her mother, Dr. Margaret Morgan Lawrence, endured years of racism to become a child psychiatrist in New York. ''The wound within is the real subject of 'Balm in Gilead,' although that may not be Sara Lawrence Lightfoot's primary intent,'' H. Jack Geiger said here in January. ''It is a daughter's loving biography.'' THE CARETAKERS, by Bernard Mathias. Translated by Freeman G. Henry. (Penguin, $7.95.) The son of a family of Holocaust survivors is torn between the dark world of the synagogue and the Parisian intellectual life. This novel ''movingly depicts the dilemmas and complexities faced by postwar Jews haunted by the unimaginable,'' Joyce Howe said here last year. GREY IS THE COLOR OF HOPE, by Irina Ratushinskaya. Translated by Alyona Kojevnikov. (Vintage International, $8.95.) A pre-glasnost poet sentenced to prison for ''anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda'' tells how she and her fellow prisoners carved out a psychological space where at least their minds could be free. This memoir has ''an idyllic, exultant tone unprecedented in camp literature,'' Francine du Plessix Gray said here in 1988. SPIRIT OF THE HILLS, by Dan O'Brien. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) In the Black Hills of South Dakota, a Vietnam vet out to revenge his brother's death meets up with the last of the great wolf hunters and a beautiful Sioux political activist. Dan O'Brien ''writes with great confidence, and his story, no matter how twisty or lurid it becomes, is always credible,'' Richard Goodman said in The Book Review last year. THE CLUSTERING OF AMERICA, by Michael J. Weiss. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) More important perhaps than New York, California, Minnesota or Maine are Blue Blood Estates, Money & Brains, Furs & Station Wagons, Bohemian Mix and the other demographic clusters that make up the socioeconomic map of the United States. Earlier this year our reviewer, Roy Blount Jr., said he enjoyed ''lingering over various bits of information [ like ] the clearly demarcated 'mayonnaise line' across the national map, which supposedly 'separates the creamy Hellman's mayonnaise buyers to the South from the tart Kraft Miracle Whip salad dressing lovers to the North.' '' THE MOTHER OF DREAMS. And Other Short Stories: Portrayals of Women in Modern Japanese Fiction. Edited by Makoto Ueda. (Kodansha, $6.95.) To transcend the roles expected of them in Japanese society some of the women in these stories take lovers, others commit suicide. ''Throughout the placid prose there is strong emotion,'' Susan Minot said here in 1986. ''The women themselves are quite powerful, whether they are waitresses, secretaries, art dealers, ballerinas or housewives.'' WOMEN OF THE WORLD: The Great Foreign Correspondents, by Julia Edwards. (Ivy, $3.95.) An erstwhile foreign correspondent tells the stories of colleagues like Marguerite Higgins, Martha Gellhorn, Gloria Emerson, Margaret Bourke-White and Mary Roberts Rinehart. Last year our reviewer, Marvine Howe, called this book ''engaging and spirited.'' THE AUTOMOTIVE HISTORY OF LUCKY KELLERMAN, by Steve Heller. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) A master mechanic hopes to raise the spirits of his disenchanted son by leaving him a 1932 Model 18 Ford Deluxe Roadster. In 1987 our reviewer, Garrett Epps, called this a ''quiet and often beautiful book, [ with ] unspoken moments between father and son [ that ] create an unforgettable image.'' FORBIDDEN JOURNEY: The Life of Alexandra David-Neel, by Barbara M. Foster and Michael Foster. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $12.95.) After leaving Paris to study with a tantric wizard in a Himalayan cave, Alexandra David-Neel devoted herself to importing the ideas of Tibetan Buddhism to the West. ''Hers was a great human life, very well written up in 'Forbidden Journey,' '' Janwillem van de Wetering said here last year.

title: How a Camera Divides the Photographer and the Experience
description: AS the mushroom came into focus, a pale umbrella above the green spikes of moss, it was clear to me again, as it had been when I was a child, that an elf could shelter there from the rain.

title: At the Slater Center 10 Years of Service
description: LEAD: THE Thomas H. Slater Center in White Plains is marking its 10th anniversary this year, and Charles Booth, the executive director of the community center, is both optimistic and pessimistic about the future.

title: Tempting Treats for the Holidays
description: LEAD: WITH just two weeks to go for holiday shopping, coupled with the perennial search for a gift that will please even that finicky colleague or relative, the solution might be right under one's nose. A selection of appealing foods and condiments produced in New Jersey and nearby by a handful of individuals and small companies could come to the rescue of the shopper.

title: Grenada's Pungent, Versatile Nutmeg
description: ONE of the oddest commodities in my mother's kitchen was an institutional-size tin of grated nutmeg that always gave me a funny feeling. Other mothers bought their spices by the ounce. Mine invested by the pound. Going to Grenada finally put that tin in perspective. As I walked through the nutmeg processing station in the coastal town of Gouyave, peering into spice-filled bins nearly the size of my bedroom and listening to literally tons of whole nutmegs rattling down chutes to be sorted, my mother's tin shrank in my memory to less than the size of a single grated speck of the spice.

title: Strangers Help Ease the Pain of Tragedy
description: THE small blue Chevy stopped at the side of the road. The occupants, a couple who had recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary, were engaged in a typical and somewhat heated discussion about lodging for the night.

title: Tara! Tara! Tara!
description: GONE WITH THE WIND The Definitive Illustrated History of the Book, the Movie, and the Legend. By Herb Bridges and Terryl C. Boodman. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Fireside/Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95. GONE WITH THE WIND The Screenplay. By Sidney Howard. Based on the novel by Margaret Mitchell. Edited by Herb Bridges and Terryl C. Boodman. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Delta. Paper, $12.95. THE ART OF GONE WITH THE WIND The Making of a Legend. By Judy Cameron and Paul J. Christman. Introduction by Daniel Mayer Selznick. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Prentice Hall. $29.95. THE COMPLETE GONE WITH THE WIND TRIVIA BOOK By Pauline Bartel. Illustrated. 200 pp. Dallas: Taylor Publishing Company. Paper, $9.95. SCARLETT'S WOMEN Gone With the Wind and Its Female Fans. By Helen Taylor. 275 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. Cloth, $35; Paper, $12.95. HOLLYWOOD'S GOLDEN YEAR, 1939 A Fiftieth-Anniversary Celebration. By Ted Sennett. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press.

title: How Cash Is Given to Politicians' Interests
description: POLITICIANS and wealthy donors know that the legal limits on contributions to candidates for Federal office are all but meaningless. But no one has dramatized that fact as well as Charles H. Keating Jr. The unfolding case of how he encouraged five Senators to use their influence on behalf of his failing California thrift, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, shows Mr. Keating was a master at finding the loopholes through which money could be moved in the lawmakers' direction. Unwittingly, he has become a symbol for groups like Common Cause, which for years have urged Congress to tighten campaign finance laws.

description: *4*BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Oct. 89 Sept. 89 Oct. 88 New York 4,530 3,872 4,492 New Jersey 2,683 3,374 3,810 Connecticut 1,270 903 1,512 *4*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.05 10.05 10.78 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.65 8.65 8.39 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 9.85 9.86 10.58 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.40 8.43 8.22 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 9.92 9.92 10.71 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.56 8.58 8.60 Co-ops (N.Y.)
