title:
FILM;
For Morgan Freeman, Stardom Wasn't Sudden
description: LEAD: ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' starring Morgan Freeman as an aging Southern chauffeur, opens here Wednesday, followed the day after by ''Glory,'' featuring Morgan Freeman in the uniform of the first black regiment in the Civil War. Last October, a fast-moving devotee of the works of Morgan Freeman could have caught him playing a tough cop in ''Johnny Handsome.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed some insulation under the floor over my crawl space. This insulation has a vapor barrier on one side, and so I removed the plastic vapor barrier sheets that originally covered the earth floor in the crawl space. I would now like to cover the earth floor with something else so that I can store things there. What kind of earth cover can I use that will not be a vapor barrier and that will still be comfortable to crawl around on when I go down there to remove or replace stored items?

title: Central American Leaders to Try to Rescue Peace
description: Faced with deeping conflicts in El Salvador and Nicaragua, delegations from five Central American states began preparations here today for a presidential summit meeting aimed at rescuing their imperiled regional peace process.

title: Finding a Christmas Tree As Grandfather Used to
description: LEAD: IN December, a steady stream of station wagons and sedans leaves the Garden State Parkway at exit 114 and heads for the North Woods area of the Hazienda Evergreen Plantation here in search of the perfect Christmas tree.

title:
MUSIC;
Many Approaches to Performing 'Messiah'
description: LEAD: HANDEL'S ''Messiah,'' a work associated with both the Christmas and Easter seasons, is an oratorio that has received more performances than any other choral work. This season alone, several organizations in New Jersey will provide more than a dozen ''Messiah'' performances.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: The Knicks are squandering the considerable talents of Mark Jackson. First, Stu Jackson started yanking him in the crucial last minutes of close games. Then the news media hopped on the Jackson-bashing bandwagon, and his confidence has suffered. Jackson has earned his role as playmaker.The Knicks should play Jackson and Strickland together regularly. HENRY DREHER New York

title: Alvin Ailey: Believer in the Power of Dance
description: Alvin Ailey was at the peak of his creative power when he died, on Dec. 1, at the age of 58. Yet he, more than most of his generation in dance, had accomplished what he set out to do. And those accomplishments had a resounding impact on modern dance.

title: On Language; Chappy Chanukah
description: According to the New York Times stylebook, the eight-day Jewish Feast of Lights that celebrates the victory of the Maccabees and begins at nightfall of Dec. 22 this year, is spelled Hanukkah. Two k's.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: The Knicks should play Jackson and Strickland together. When they play together, there is increased player and ball movement with an open man often in position to make an easy basket. RICHARD J. KITTRELL New York

title: Truman Capote Answers Robert Morse's Prayers
description: Robert Morse's last Broadway appearance was in ''So Long, 174th Street,'' the 1976 musical version of ''Enter Laughing.'' The show's exit was another matter. Not only did it close almost immediately, but the theater, the Harkness, was torn down as well. For months afterward, as he rode the bus up and down Broadway, the actor was assaulted with the sight of his name on a ghostly marquee above the gutted theater. Embarrassed, he called his agent to see if someone could take it down. But no one would claim responsibility. ''It was Kafkaesque,'' he recalls. ''It was the end of the theater. It was the end of me. You get a little insecure.''

title: Kashmir Muslims Kidnap Indian Aide's Daughter
description: Islamic militants in Kashmir say they have kidnapped the 21-year-old daughter of the Indian Cabinet minister responsible for internal security.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Vista Condo Units Going on the Block
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER COUNTY'S first major real estate auction will take place at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown next Sunday, with the remaining 45 condominiums of a 261-unit development in Vista, a northeastern hamlet in the Town of Lewisboro, on the block.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: COME WINTER. By Douglas C. Jones. (Donald Hutter/ Holt, $19.95.) The fictional town of Gourdville in northwestern Arkansas is Douglas C. Jones's bailiwick, a hilly place wedged between Indian territory and the White River, within spitting distance of the Missouri line. In 1870, when ''Come Winter'' begins, this remote corner of the West is being civilized, largely due to the efforts of Roman Hasford, one of the Hasford-Pay clan, whose history Mr.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Mozart: Piano Sonatas (K. 309, 457), Fantasies (K. 396, 397, 475) Cyprien Katsaris, piano. Teldec CD 244 191; CD only. This is not your usual Mozart. Mr. Katsaris makes no attempt to imitate a fortepiano or play a ''Classic'' Mozart. He feels the music Romantically and uses plenty of pedal (without any blurring) and large washes of color. His sound is beautiful, and he can produce a legato that, in Mozart's own words, ''flows like oil.'' The great C minor Fantasy (K. 475) and the last movement of its accompanying C minor Sonata (K. 457) emerge with a great deal of drama. There are some individual ideas about ornamentation. In the C major Sonata (K. 309) the pianist plays the opening appoggiaturas as grace notes, and on the repeat plays them as the appoggiaturas they are, thus straddling both worlds. But Mr. Katsaris has always been an individualist. This French-born Greek pianist is one of the best and most interesting of his generation (between 35 and 45). - Harold C. Schonberg Riley: 'Salome Dances for Peace' Kronos Quartet. Nonesuch 79217; two CD's, LP's and cassettes. The Kronos Quartet can take credit for helping resurrect the compositional career of the founding Minimalist Terry Riley, after his years of immersion in the study of Indian singing. An eight-minute segment of this two-hour score (in a different performance) was included on an earlier Kronos Nonesuch anthology, ''Winter Was Hard.'' The complete work has a curious appeal, though that appeal may not extend to dogged opponents of the California new-music esthetic. The music is simple, innocent, yet, within in its own terms, intelligent and compelling, reaching beyond European modernism to embrace the Orient and universal mystic rituals. - John Rockwell Elgar: 'Enigma Variations,' 'Cockaigne,' Serenade for Strings, 'Salut d'Amour' Baltimore Symphony conducted by David Zinman. Telarc CD-80192; CD only. Compare this release with Leonard Slatkin's recent RCA accounts of the ''Enigma Variations,'' ''Cockaigne'' and the serenade, and Zinman easily emerges as the more sympathetic Elgarian. He understands that ''nobilmente'' doesn't necessarily mean slowly, that Elgar's is the art of the impulsive, the nudge as well as the hesitation. Here's a ''Cockaigne'' by turns jaunty and affectionate, an ''Enigma'' that brings its portraits to life without parodying them, a Serenade and ''Salut d'Amour'' that charm without ever cloying. Apart from an ill-tuned flute in the ''W. N.'' variation of the ''Enigma,'' the Baltimore orchestra plays splendidly, and Telarc supports it with sonics both forward and spacious. - Scott Cantrell Schoenberg: Five Pieces for Orchestra, Op. 16; Webern: Six Pieces for Orchestra, Op. 6; Berg: 'Lulu' Suite Arleen Auger, soprano; City of Birmingham Symphony conducted by Simon Rattle. EMI/Angel CDC 7 49857 2; CD only. Following on the heels of his recent blockbuster recordings of ''Porgy and Bess'' and ''The Rite of Spring,'' Simon Rattle now shows, with his big-boned approach, that he can make Schoenberg just as rhythmically exciting, colorful and thunderous as Stravinsky; that he can jell Webern miniatures into music as expressive as a Mahler movement, and that Berg's final opera contains music as bittersweet as Gershwin's best. Mr. Rattle also, of course, shows off, milking every phrase for the last drop of emotion. But it works. His versions of Schoenberg and Webern may not quite match James Levine's Berlin accounts for beauty and grace. They may lack Pierre Boulez's elegance and point. But they are without equal for pure drama. The Birmingham players know their way around the music, and Arleen Auger sings the ''Lulu'' excerpts with smooth confidence. The sonics are epic. - Mark Swed Debussy, Janacek, R. Strauss: Sonatas for Violin and Piano Dmitry Sitkovetsky, violin; Pavel Gililov, piano. Virgin Classics VC 7 90760; CD and cassette. To hear this glorious account of the Strauss Sonata (1887) is to wonder that the piece is so rarely heard in the concert hall. It's a young man's grandiloquence and ardor, dreaminess and playfulness, but a rich musical culture shines through it. Mr. Sitkovetsky plays radiantly, and his subtly shaded vibrato is welcome relief in these throb-besotted times; Mr. Gililov is a marvelously responsive, characterful collaborator. They're no less responsive to the mercurial twists and turns of the Janacek, a piece that while written (and twice revised) in the composer's 60's, burns with hardly less fire. Only the Debussy disappoints: The slinky, sultry first movement proves all too straight, and what follows falls just short of ''fantasque et leger.'' Sonics are lively, but some will find the piano sound a little too cavernous. - S. C. POP/JAZZ Phil Collins: '. . . But Seriously' Atlantic 82050; all three formats. Among pop music's top stars, Mr. Collins comes the closest to embodying the ideal of the solid citizen. His solo albums blend pop straightforwardness with echoes of English art rock and post-Motown pop-soul into a comfortably accessible mainstream sound that is distinctive, if at times a bit plodding. As its title suggests, ''. . . But Seriously'' is a soberer album than usual. Its four socially conscious songs reflect on homelessness, South African injustice, urban racial unrest and the troubles in Northern Ireland. Mr. Collins's sympathetic reflections are bluntly phrased but also so broad in their perspective that they sound more official than personal in tone. ''Colors,'' the most ambitious song, is a two-movement suite that ends with a denunciation of the South African Government. - Stephen Holden The Tragically Hip: 'Up to Here' MCA 6310; all three formats. Straightforward, bluesy rock - the Rolling Stones via John Cougar Mellencamp - isn't obsolete. The Tragically Hip, from Toronto, charge up the old forms with deep-seated, homey eccentricity. Wiry, catchy, down-to-earth guitar lines and a decisive beat hold the songs together, as the lyrics sidle from oddball stories to free associations on the edge of coherence; the taut drama of ''When the Weight Comes Down,'' for instance, might or might not be about a custody battle. And Gordon Downie sings in a haggard, quavery, tenacious voice that bends melodies downward and around, then growls with defiance. The Tragically Hip are tragically misnamed; they sound sweaty, not trendy. - Jon Pareles Roxanne Shante: 'Bad Sister' Cold Chillin'/Reprise 925809; all three formats. In the title track of her debut album, Roxanne Shante hears that a group of female rappers are in town to challenge her status as the Queen of Rap. The story masks a history lesson: Ms. Shante's 1984 single, ''Roxanne's Revenge,'' predated M. C. Lyte, Queen Latifah and other Jenny-come-latelys. In a curt, almost cynical voice, over spare, rugged beats by Marley Marl, the producer, Ms. Shante's 10 new raps - from the slinky put-down, ''Knockin' Hiney'' to the how-to advice of ''Independent Woman'' - combine humor and raw rhythmic power with Ms. Shante's sturdy sense of identity. The long-awaited ''Bad Sister'' proves she's tougher and wittier than the competition. - Karen Schoemer Gipsy Kings: 'Mosaique' Elektra Musician 9 60892; all three formats. ''Mosaique'' demonstrates how fine the line is between enhancement and sterilization when a producer attempts to contemporize a traditional musical style. In producing last year's ''Gipsy Kings,'' Claude Martinez sparingly added modern touches to flamenco-descended music by the southern French gypsy ensemble and came up with something fresh and exciting. On ''Mosaique,'' the thicker, often kitschy arrangements, which bring in strings, piano, trumpet, oboe, electric guitar and more elaborate synthesizer and percussion, subvert the passion that is the Gipsy Kings' greatest strength. One of the high points of last year's album was a fiery remake of ''My Way.'' One of the low points on ''Mosaique'' is a stiff, mechanical ''Volare.'' - S. H. The Grateful Dead: 'Built to Last' Arista 8575; all three formats. In the wake of their first Top 10 hit, the Grateful Dead have faltered. As on the 1987 album ''In the Dark,'' songs proffer reassurance and apocalypse; although ''Built to Last'' is more elaborately produced than many Dead albums, most of the music sounds labored yet thin. Brent Mydland, on keyboards, has emerged as a songwriter and husky-voiced singer, with the attempted ecology anthem ''We Can Run'' and conventional, pop-oriented love songs; ''I Will Take You Home'' is accompanied only by keyboards. And songs by the Dead's two longtime guitarists and singers, Bob Weir and Jerry Garcia, are plodding and scattered. But if anyone can resuscitate them in concert, the Dead will. - J. P.

title: GHOSTBUSTERS, TOO
description: JULIAN'S HOUSE By Judith Hawkes. 354 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

title: Taping Suit Perplexed By Who Was Wronged
description: HALF a dozen lawyers from around the state gathered at the Attorney General's Office in Hartford last month to open the book on a series of narrow legal questions that will reverberate in Connecticut through 1990 and perhaps beyond: How many people might have had their telephone conversations improperly recorded by the state police over the last 15 years? And how are they to be notified that they might have been wronged?

title: Civilization Owes Debt to an African Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Was the Athelete of the Decade?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: The Authentic Flavors of Portugal
description: FEEL like ethnic food? If you live on Long Island, you will probably end up at an Italian or Chinese restaurant. Although rarer, there are other Nassau-Suffolk ethnic outposts that add culinary richness to the local food scene.

title: Elizabeth M. Bartram to Wed in March
description: Mrs. Walter Stiles Hoyt of Hobe Sound, Fla., has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Elizabeth Meagher Bartram of Palm Beach, Fla., to Kirk Henckels, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ross Henckels of Fort Worth. The prospective bride is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Rensselaer Wardwell Bartram 3d of Palm Beach and Greenwich, Conn. A March wedding is planned. Miss Bartram, 28 years old, graduated from the Palm Beach Day School and the Masters School. She is a realtor associate with Transfield Real Estate in Palm Beach. Her father was an investment banker in Palm Beach and a board member of the Mystic (Conn.) Seaport Museum.

title: Man Watching Subway Robbery Kills Mugger and Flees, Police Say
description: A man watching a subway robbery early yesterday stabbed one of the muggers dead after telling him, ''We're not going to have any more of this,'' the police said.

title: The Attitude Is Not Cavalier
description: To the Editor:

title: H.U.D. Revokes Ban on Religious Displays
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has revoked its ban on religious decorations in federally financed emergency shelters, and will allow a Salvation Army shelter to display a picture of Jesus, a H.U.D. official said.

title: Light Is Trendy for China's Beer
description: At the Qingdao Brewery, the vice director, Zhang Jianhua, held up a glass of Tsingtao beer and downed it with a smile.

title: TOP AIDES TO BUSH ARE VISITING CHINA TO MEND RELATIONS
description: The White House national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, made a surprise visit to Beijing today and said he had come as an emissary of President Bush ''to bring new impetus and vigor'' into United States-Chinese relations.

title: Eastern Airlines Investigated
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is weighing whether to file criminal charges against Eastern Airlines on the basis of allegations that the company failed to insure that planes were being properly maintained at Kennedy International Airport, company officials said yesterday.

title: Historic Quaker Meetinghouse Is Moving
description: LEAD: SET behind a low stone wall and veil of branches on an old estate in Armonk, the weathered 30-foot-high barn is a paradox of frail shingles and indomitable frame. Built in 1798 by North Castle Quakers, it served for a century as their austere meetinghouse before it was turned into a shelter for livestock.

title: Amy Cherry Wed To Pierre Abitbol
description: Amy Elizabeth Cherry and Pierre N. Abitbol, associates at the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher in New York, were married there last evening at Temple Emanu-El by Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich. The bride is a daughter of Jay Leonard Cherry of Hartford and the late Carm Cherry. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Abitbol of Paris. Mrs. Cherry-Abitbol, 31 years old, graduated from the Loomis-Chaffee School and summa cum laude from Barnard College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received a J.D. degree from the University of Chicago. Her father is the legislative director at the Travelers Companies in Hartford.

title: Czechs' New Prime Minister: Quiet Communist Bureaucrat
description: By any standard, Marian Calfa, the newly designated Czechoslovak Prime Minister, is one of the least-known national leaders.

title: At 7 Years of Age, an Actor's Career Is Born
description: ''THE KING AND I'' has left Connecticut, but in our home the memories and the music linger on. Peter, age 7, is consumed with the theater. He is totally stage-struck.

title: A Dog Shepherds Its New Masters to Its Will
description: DOG people, cat people: the great divide of the human species. My husband and I have always fallen on the cat side. It's their independence and languor we admire, their cool assumption of equality. Yet there it was: early one Friday evening in May, Jack and I took up with a dog.

title: Football: Lucky to Play, Lucky to Walk Away
description: Last month, as I lay on the turf in Husky Stadium at the University of Washington, I knew that an important part of my life had just come to a close. You see, as a linebacker on the Arizona State University football team, I'd just been involved in a tackle that left me temporarily paralyzed.

title: POSTINGS: In the Adirondacks; Inn Out, Condos In
description: The Rocky Point Inn, a well-known resort that had operated in the central Adirondacks for almost a century, has been torn down and its 26-acre site is being redeveloped into a vacation condominium complex called Rocky Point. Forty of 76 units planned for the development are now rising and are scheduled to be finished by early next summer.

title: Review/Jazz; Hopkins and Murray Plus 2
description: The bassist Fred Hopkins and the cellist Deidre Murray love music's lower depths. The quartet they assembled for a concert Wednesday at the Alternative Museum included the baritone Andy Bey and Brandon Ross on electric guitar, and their music rippled and churned in a register most groups use primarily for accompaniment.

title: N.H.L. To Add 7 Clubs
description: The National Hockey League announced yesterday that it planned to expand from 21 teams to 28 teams in the next decade. The expansion would be the biggest since the N.H.L. doubled in size in 1967, from 6 to 12 teams.

title: Japan's Loud Voice in Washington
description: The Toshiba Corporation of Japan was roundly condemned by Congress two years ago for illegally selling high-technology milling equipment to the Soviet Union for use in building quieter submarine propellers. Some lawmakers were so incensed that they even invited the news media to watch the sledgehammering of the Japanese company's products on the Capitol's steps. There was widespread talk of tough sanctions against Toshiba, aimed at the $2.5 billion a year in computers, cellular phones and other products it sells in the United States.

title: Polish Inmates Riot Over Amnesty, but Then Yield
description: Rebellious inmates surrendered to the authorities today at two of four prisons where riots broke out after Parliament refused to extend a nationwide amnesty to hard-core criminals.

title: Unwanted Excitement In 'A Christmas Carol'
description: IF technical problems arise during the making of a movie, the scene is reshot and the bloopers never make it to the screen. In live theater, however, there is no way to hide backstage problems from the audience.

title: The Great Swamp: Some Other Aspects
description: There is more to the story of the environmental problems of the Great Swamp than reported in the excellent article ''In the Natural State'' on Oct. 15. It is not only Commissioner Christopher Daggett of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection who is thoughtful, although we look upon him as a savior.

title: Easing the Effects Of Divorce Upon Children
description: Re: ''Children Can Survive a Divorce,'' the recent Opinion page article by Janice Cohn and Gary Skoloff:

title: THE CHALLENGE OF KEEPING U.S. TECHNOLOGY AT HOME
description: Despite mounting concern about the nation's dependence on Japan and other foreign nations for important technology, keeping crucial components or machinery in American hands is proving exceedingly difficult.

title:
ART;
Flouting Tradition at 2 Shows
description: LEAD: THE East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art has a reputation for periodically mounting exhibitions that introduce artists who seem to warrant a wider audience. The nearby Vered Gallery, on the other hand, is best known for regularly presenting the latest work by its permanent roster of familiar names.

title: No Money in the Microwave, Please
description: ONE STORY THEY LIKE TO TELL at the Office of Currency Standards is about the farmer whose cow ate his wallet. The O.C.S., part of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Engraving and Printing, will replace damaged currency for individuals or institutions, provided the claimant meets certain criteria. ''We explained we needed physical evidence to make restitution,'' says Gracie Scruggs. ''So the man had the cow slaughtered, and sent the stomach in for examination.''

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: Strickland.

title: 'Summer and Smoke' At the Yale Rep
description: THROUGHOUT the pinnacle and the decline of Tennessee Williams's career, ''Summer and Smoke'' wafted in the distance, a rarefied example of the playwright's incomparable style, but only occasionally revived.

title: Excerpts From Statement By European Community
description: Following are excerpts from the statement today by the leaders of the European Community:

title: Wrong Kind of Ball
description: With a $2.75 million contract, he is the highest-paid player on the Pittsburgh Steelers, but after doing a little neighborhood comparison shopping, Bubby Brister, the Steeler quarterback, has decided he may be throwing the wrong kind of ball.

title: Into the Void, and Back
description: NO ONE had a camera, but the picture is etched in my mind. I am preparing for my first open-water dive, hung about with hoses, mask and snorkel, bent double from the weight of the cylinder of compressed air on my back. I have somehow twisted my instrument console and extra regulator together and buckled my buoyancy compensator and weight belt over them both, which necessitates taking off everything except my bathing suit and beginning the whole clumsy and confusing process of gearing up all over again.

title: Linda Longo Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Linda Mary Longo to Richard Bryan Hirsch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto J. Hirsch of Florissant, Mo., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James A. Longo of Franklin Lakes, N.J. An October wedding is planned. Miss Longo, 23 years old, is an editor at McCall's magazine in New York. Mr. Hirsch, 30, is the managing editor of Cabinet Manufacturing and Fabricating magazine in Hackensack, N.J. She graduated from Montclair State College, he from Drake University.

title: Marla J. Kroser To Marry in May
description: Dr. Albert S. Kroser and Dr. Lila Stein Kroser of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marla Jill Kroser, to Evan David Lerner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Lerner of Hollywood, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Changing Face Of Dentistry
description: In response to Dr. Avram Goldstein's essay, ''How Government Is Changing Dentistry'' (Opinion page, Nov. 12), I was disappointed to see the attitude expressed by this practicing periodontist. I think Dr. Goldstein's difficulties in accepting modernization of the practice of dentistry is not to be construed as the professional perception of all practitioners.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RMULTIMEDIA NUTCRACKER

title: Debra A. Pollack, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lowell D. Pollack of Hartsdale, N.Y., have made known July wedding plans for their daughter, Debra Ann Pollack, and Daniel Eric Wollman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell A. Wollman of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Tempting the Taste for Chocolate
description: THE progression is predictable. Someone strolls down Greenwich Avenue in Greenwich and notices activity in the window of the Complete Kitchen. He stops to observe a man presiding over a machine, making chocolate truffles. Another man, wielding a silver tray of the delectables, smiles and waves from inside. The stroller walks in, tastes, swoons and buys.

title: LESS LIKELY TO GET LIKKERED UP
description: THE HARVEY GIRLS Women Who Opened the West. By Lesley Poling-Kempes. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Paragon House. $19.95.

title:
GARDENING;
A Tree for All Seasons, or Just One
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS trees made their appearance as early as the week before Thanksgiving at some nursery lots this year. These are the trees meant to be planted outside after a brief period of decorative glory indoors.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID HOLD UNITY TALKS
description: More than 4,000 representatives of South Africa's anti-apartheid movement gathered here today to search for a consensus on how to bring down the white minority Government.

title: Bill Page, Art Director, 60
description: Bill Page, an art director and designer, died of coronary arrest at his home in Manhattan on Thursday after suffering from neurological problems. He was 60 years old.

title: THE YEAR OF THE DOUGHNUT
description: THE QUEST FOR THE PRESIDENCY 1988 By Peter Goldman, Tom Mathews and the Newsweek Special Election Team. 430 pp. New York: Touchstone Books/Simon & Schuster. Paper, $9.95.

title: EXILED GREEK KING WANTS TO RETURN
description: Constantine XII, King of the Hellenes until the military junta he tried to overthrow abolished the monarchy in June 1973, said in a rare interview in exile here that he would like to go back to Greece. He said he would return the way the people wanted him to, in ''whatever capacity that happened to be.''

title: Navy 3-Pointer Stuns Army
description: Elliot Uzelac, the football coach who had watched his teams at the Naval Academy lose 25 of 32 contests the last three seasons, displayed a lot of nerve before the game against Army today.

title: Employees Seek to Transfer Skills
description: LEAD: ''THERE are very few jobs that require crawling down smoky halls,'' Robert H. Buxton said recently to a group of people hoping to change careers. It was a realization, made 15 years ago, that changed his life.

title: Dental School's Closing Upsets Patients
description: LEAD: FOR 15 years, Lavon Bassette says, she and her family have used the clinic at the Fairleigh Dickinson University dental school for all their cleanings, fillings and bridgework. But when the clinic closes in June, Mrs. Bassette and 5,000 other patients will be forced to look elsewhere for low-cost dental treatment.

title: March Wedding For Miss Kavetas
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Kavetas of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Louise Kavetas, to Adam Rothschild, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Rothschild of Scarsdale, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: CARTER REDUX
description: When Jimmy Carter returned to his home in Plains, Ga., in 1981, after losing the Presidency, he was an all-but-shattered man. He was pilloried as the author of America's malaise and the architect of its economic stagnation, and humiliated as the remaining 52 American hostages in Iran were released the day Ronald Reagan was sworn into office - after Carter's own rescue effort had died ignominiously in a remote desert in Iran. His personal finances were devastated: The thriving peanut warehouse he left in a blind trust when he went to the White House was $1 million in debt; he stood to lose his farms and perhaps even his house. What he had to look forward to after the Presidency, Jimmy Carter himself conceded, was a ''potentially empty life.''

title: Detroit's Slump Grows Worse
description: Auto sales were weak in November, with the Big Three American makers showing steep declines. General Motors decline for the month was 22.6 percent, while Ford was down 15 percent and Chrysler off 17 percent. There were sales gains for cars made at Japanese auto plants in the United States. Honda, for example, now has 9.6 percent of the American market and is approaching Chrysler' 10.3 percent share.

title: Philippine Rebel Holdouts Finally Yield
description: Eight days after a widespread revolt broke out within its military, the Philippine Government regained control today over a strategic southern air base and finally put an end to the rebellion that nearly brought down President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Phillies Sign Howell
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have signed the right-hander Ken Howell to a one-year contract worth $615,000 after he posted a 12-12 record last season, tying Jeff Parrett for the team's leadership in victories. Howell was not a free agent, but could have taken the club to salary arbitration. Last season, his first with the Phillies after being acquired in the off season from Baltimore, the 29-year-old Howell made $225,000. (AP)

title: Defining an Issue, Then and Now
description: My eye caught the headline ''Many Issues Neglected in Race for Governor'' (Oct. 22), and the thought occurred to me that the word ''issue'' has undergone change in current usage.

title: Jennifer Kuhn to Wed C. P. Irwin 4th
description: The engagement of Jennifer Sherburne Kuhn to Charles Parson Irwin 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin 3d of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. John F. Raynolds 3d of Stamford, Conn., and Ascutney, Vt., and Jay C. Kuhn of Belvedere, Calif. A May wedding is planned. Miss Kuhn graduated from the Emma Willard School and Denison University. She is a producer with Image Devices International, a film company in Miami. Her father is president of Kuhn & Associates, an insurance brokerage company in San Francisco. Her stepfather is the president of Outward Bound, USA, a nonprofit outdoor-education organization in Greenwich, Conn. Her mother, Eleanor H. Raynolds, is a partner in Ward Howell International, an executive search firm in New York.

title: Beyond Fast Food: Dining With Children
description: MOST parents expect their eating habits to change with the arrival of offspring, but few are prepared for exactly how dramatic that change will be.

title: Davin Schoenberger, Rabbi, 92
description: Rabbi Davin Schoenberger, who performed the marriage of Anne Frank's parents and later fled Nazi Germany, died Tuesday at University Hospital. He was 92 years old.

title: Chicken Delight
description: THIS is a good recipe to make when your wife is out of town or consulting a nationally prominent divorce attorney. I call it ''Boiled Chicken Thighs Jimmy.''

title: BEST SELLERS: December 10, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 2 2 6 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Viking, $21.95.) After a writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, the deceased goes on a murderous rampage. 3 3 4 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.95.) The history of the sea islands told in fictional form. 4 4 15 CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $21.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords. 5 5 8 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 6 6 3 STRAIGHT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) A steeplechase jockey inherits property and a mysterious enemy. 7 13 2 THE ELEVENTH HOUR, by Graeme Base. (Abrams, $14.95.) An illustrated mystery story about a birthday party attended by 11 animals. 8 7 2 SORCERESS OF DARSHIVA, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) The fourth volume in the ''Malloreon'' fantasy saga. 9 11 12 JIMMY STEWART AND HIS POEMS, by Jimmy Stewart. (Crown, $9.95.) Verses by the venerable motion picture star. 10 10 8 TALES FROM MARGARITAVILLE, by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) Short stories set on a mythical Caribbean island. 11 8 2 SWAN LAKE, by Mark Helprin. (Ariel/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A new retelling of the fable upon which the ballet is based, with illustrations by Chris Van Allsburg. 12 14 13 CALIFORNIA GOLD, by John Jakes. (Random House, $19.95.) A young man from Pennsylvania makes his fortune in 19th-century Los Angeles. 13 * 9 13 THE PILLARS OF THE EARTH, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $22.95.) The lives of men and women whose fortunes are linked by the construction of a cathedral in 12th-century England. Q 14 12 3 THE RENEGADES OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) Three clans struggle to survive outside the huge stone fortresses in the fantasy world of Pern. Q 15 12 OLDEST LIVING CONFEDERATE WIDOW TELLS ALL, by Allan Gurganus. (Knopf, $21.95.) A 99-year-old woman reflects on her past. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction Q 1 1 6 MY TURN, by Nancy Reagan with William Novak. (Random House, $21.95.) The former First Lady's memoir of her White House years. Q 2 9 9 ROSEANNE, by Roseanne Barr. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The autobiography of the television comedian. Q 3 3 58 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. Q 4 2 12 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays. Q 5 6 5 DRIVE, by Larry Bird with Bob Ryan. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The autobiography of the Boston Celtics basketball star. Q 6 5 3 ALL MY BEST FRIENDS, by George Burns with David Fisher. (Putnam, $17.95.) Reminiscences about show business acquaintances. Q 7 4 6 EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) The author recalls the places he visited and the books he read in his youth. Q 8 10 86 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. Q 9 7 5 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $18.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. Q 10 8 15 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade teacher in Holyoke, Mass. Q 11 8 I WANT TO GROW HAIR, I WANT TO GROW UP, I WANT TO GO TO BOISE, by Erma Bombeck. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Fifteen stories of children surviving cancer. Q 12 14 5 CHILI DAWGS ALWAYS BARK AT NIGHT, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $17.95.) Essays on politics, religion, sex, golf, etc., by the syndicated columnist. Q 13 3 THE LONG GRAY LINE, by Rick Atkinson. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) The lives of members of West Point's class of 1966, from cadet years through Vietnam to the present. Q 14 13 3 HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the brain affects the body's endocrine and immune systems. Q 15 12 3 WONDERFUL LIFE, by Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $19.95.) What the contents of a small quarry in the Canadian Rockies have revealed about the past and about scientific methods. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous Q 1 2 22 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. Q 2 1 6 MARTHA STEWART'S CHRISTMAS, by Martha Stewart. (Potter, $18.95.) Advice about cooking, decorating and entertaining during the holiday season. Q 3 4 46 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. Q 4 5 7 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS THREE ANCIENT CUISINES, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $18.95.) Recipes from China, Greece and Rome. Q 5 3 3 THE WAY TO COOK, by Julia Child. (Knopf, $50.) More than 800 recipes from ''the French chef.'' These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ENCHANTED DRAWINGS: The History of Animation, by Charles Solomon. (Knopf, $75.) An ambitious, sprawling illustrated account of the evolution of animated movies, packed with tales of warring studios, greedy producers and great artists. JEAN HOWARD'S HOLLYWOOD: A Photo Memoir, with photographs by Jean Howard and text by James Watters. (Abrams, $39.95.) Herself one of Hollywood's most beautiful and privileged people, Jean Howard snapped her shutter with a social historian's eye, capturing the great at play in the 1940's and 50's. IN SEARCH OF LOST ROSES, by Thomas Christopher. (Summit, $18.95.) A delightful book-length essay on antique roses, from ancient Rome to Tombstone, Ariz., and on the obsessional characters who hunt and love them, by one of their number. AMELIA EARHART: A Biography, by Doris L. Rich. (Smithsonian Institution, $19.95.) THE SOUND OF WINGS: The Life of Amelia Earhart, by Mary S. Lovell. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Two biographies of the famous American pilot (and feminist) who vanished in the South Pacific in 1937. The authors agree on the important facts; Ms. Lovell is more skeptical about her flying skills than Ms. Rich, and thinks better of her husband and publicist, G. P. Putnam. THE JEWS IN AMERICA. Four Centuries of an Uneasy Encounter:

title: Brooke Hummer Weds in Chicago
description: Brooke Hummer and Grove Newhard Mower were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Chicago by the Rev. Edward Duncan, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Wayne Hummer of Chicago. Mr. Mower is a son of Mrs. Robert T. Hensley Jr. and Edward B. Mower Jr., both of St. Louis.

title: Built With Kits, Homes Can Be Huts or Mansions
description: When Tom and Julia Berry decided to build a house two years ago, they didn't think too long or hard before deciding to have to it built of logs. After all, they had been married in a log cabin in Maine's northern woods.

title: A Heritage of Selflessness: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Aid to Family Blessed Only With Love
description: Three cribs, a twin bed, a specially constructed wheelchair, a bassinet and a small, brightly decorated Christmas tree all compete for a space in the living room of Rosa and Anthony C.'s fifth-floor walk-up.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: The Knicks are fortunate to have two young guards who can pass the ball, and it is much too early in the season to make a rash judgment and trade either player. CHRISTOPHER GEORGE MAROS New York

title: Teachers Gain by Peer Coaching
description: LEAD: A STAFF development program in the West Orange School District that has helped teachers increase their classroom effectiveness and has had a large impact on student performance will be recognized during a visit on Tuesday by the State Commissioner of Education, Dr. Saul Cooperman.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Butterflied Leg of Lamb With International Flair
description: A butterflied leg of lamb is a perfect choice for the savory dish East-West Lamb because it is tender without being fatty, and it's flavorful.

title: Doug Scovil, 62, Dies; A Pro Football Coach
description: Doug Scovil, the coach credited with developing Randall Cunningham into the starting quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles, died of a heart attack today at Veterans Stadium. He was 62 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Elinor Coleman Troupe Tackles Large Issues
description: Communications theories, mythology, mysticism, eschatology - Elinor Coleman certainly dealt with ambitious subject matter in the program that the Elinor Coleman Dance Ensemble presented Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation. But her works were nothing but vague thoughts about momentous issues.

title:
ART;
Self-Expression Turns To an Ancient Medium
description: LEAD: THE technique of enameling, which involves the fusion of melted glass to metal, has many functional and decorative applications. The term calls to mind Faberge's precious, intricately decorated Easter eggs and the brilliant sunbursts of Art Deco jewelry, but enameling also can produce the durable surfaces of bathtubs and the weatherproof finishes of street signs.

title: A New Europe Needs a New Currency
description: The spectacular movement for democratization in Eastern Europe, with the highly symbolic collapse of the Berlin wall, will compel us as Europeans to seek a new order. German unification, a taboo subject until a few months ago, is becoming a realistic prospect. After Austria - a neutral country - it will soon be Hungary's turn to request associate status in the European Community.

title: LIVING WITH AIDS
description: Implicit in Eugene W. Feldman's letter concerning the ''safeness'' of safe sex is the belief that people with AIDS shouldn't have sex at all (Letters, Nov. 12, in response to ''Fighting AIDS All the Way,'' by Larry Josephs, Oct. 8).

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Howell Trying to Balance Growth With Open Space
description: LEAD: THE southward flow of New Jersey residential development over the last five years has reached deep into Howell Township, blanketing once open fields with row upon row of new houses.

title: Review/Dance; Zenon in Work by 4 Choreographers
description: The Minneapolis dance group with two names offered a new program on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. On this occasion, it called itself Zenon Dance. On Tuesday, its opening night, it was Jazzdance by Danny Buraczeski.

title: Michigan Plane Crash Kills 4
description: A private plane crashed shortly after taking off today, killing the pilot, his son and two other passengers, the police said. The pilot, Mark A. O'Donnell, 40 years old, died at a hospital about two hours after his single-engine Cessna 172 crashed in a cornfield, the police said. His son, Mark E. O'Donnell, 10, and the passengers, Richard Maser, 42, and Charles Lawrence, 54, were killed instantly.

title: Fewer Army Recruits for Bell-and-Kettle Duty
description: The Salvation Army, following a 91-year tradition in New York City, has placed its red kettles on sidewalks, hoping to coax $1 million in donations to help the hungry and homeless during the holiday season.

title: Miss Coleman, Art Specialist, Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Suzanne Gertrude Coleman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Coleman of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Frederic Moore Bancroft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward Bancroft of Old Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Damien Myett officiated.

title: Czechs Stream Into Vienna, to Look, Not Buy
description: On the first weekend day since the Prague authorities eased travel restrictions, more than 100,000 Czechoslovaks streamed into Austria today, mostly on one-day shopping sprees here in the capital, in Linz and in Salzburg.

title: Q and A
description: IRA Penalty

title: Style Makers; Tomasz Starzewski, Fashion Designer
description: For the last four and a half years, Tomasz Starzewski, a 28-year-old Londoner, has designed evening wear that has been sold in stores like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's. But until this fall, almost no one outside a coterie of affluent clients had heard of him.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: BEYOND THE RIDGEWritten and illustrated by Paul Goble. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $13.95. (All ages) DANCING TEEPEES Poems of American Indian Youth. Selected by Virginia Driving Hawk Sneve. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. 32 pp. New York: Holiday House. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Comaneci Hailed and Jeered in Florida
description: Never mind that Nadia Comaneci's Rumanian accent makes it difficult for many people here to understand her. Miami's rock-music radio station WXDJ, which calls itself The Breeze FM, wants her to be co-host of its morning talk show.

title: Tasty Options to Costly Gifts
description: SOME friends of mine have never allowed their children to buy them Christmas gifts. All presents must be homemade. So over the years they have received the most touching presents, many of which required hours of careful planning and hard work. Of course, there were the inevitable misshapen pieces of pottery and the peculiar bits of knitting that came unraveled almost at once. But even those meant so much more than an impersonal overpriced gift bought in haste at the last minute - and often returned in haste after the holidays.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's true that we should be grateful for everything given us. It's true, to a certain degree at least, that it's the thought that counts. But once these truisms are out of the way, it's time to get down to the nitty-gritty. And that is when it comes to gift-giving, there are people, lots of them, who give something they themselves would like to own.

title: The Meaning of Devotion
description: A man on the city police's list of 10 most wanted suspects was arrested Friday after he walked into a station house to bail out a friend. A picture of the 20-year-old man, Kevin L. Jones, charged in an October shooting, was posted on the wall of the police station when he walked in. One police officer said: ''He looked up at the picture. His girlfriend looked up at the picture. Everyone else looked up at the picture. He got arrested.''

title: Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
description: Strickland over Jackson. Jackson unsuccessfully shoots and turns the ball over much more than Strickland. DAN QUITTMAN Harrison, N.Y.

title: IT SEEMED LIKE A GOOD IDEA AT THE TIME
description: FROM WHISTLE STOP TO SOUND BITE Four Decades of Politics and Television. By Sig Mickelson. 186 pp. New York: Praeger. Cloth, $37.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Although this column is devoted to still image-making as opposed to pictures that move, I receive many videotapes. It's not so strange, though, the tapes are about photography.

title: 'You Lose Your License 90 Days'
description: AS the Commissioner of the Department of Motor Vehicles, Lawrence F. DelPonte is charged with implementing Connecticut's new drunken driving law, which will take effect on Jan. 1. It will allow the suspension of a license for as long as two years if a driver refuses to submit to a blood alcohol test or if test results show the driver is intoxicated.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SEX IN THE FORBIDDEN ZONE: When Men in Power - Therapists, Doctors, Clergy, Teachers, and Others - Betray Women's Trust. By Peter Rutter. (Jeremy P. Tarcher, $17.95.) In his provocative book, ''Sex in the Forbidden Zone,'' Peter Rutter, a San Francisco psychiatrist, says all the right things. Male doctors, therapists, attorneys and clergy should not have sexual relations with their female patients, clients or parishioners.

title: In East Europe, Reform Isn't Good Enough
description: IF the Communists thought at the outset that they could survive in power by chucking a few corrupt old officials out the palace window to placate the baying mob, this past week showed how wrong they were.

title: STREETSCAPES: The B. & O. Freight Warehouse; Wrapping a West Side Landmark in a Truck Shop
description: MAYBE it was more interesting as a view than as a building - a plain, white neo-Classical rectangle silhouetted against its much larger sibling to the north, the streamlined Starrett-Lehigh Building.

title: Two Baltic Republics Vote In Test of Communist Rule
description: Communists faced strong challenges from opposition candidates today as Latvians and Estonians voted in local elections widely viewed as a referendum on the party's future in the two republics.

title: Joy and Apprehension Among East Berlin's Jews
description: The handful of citizens who are observant Jews or of Jewish ancestry in this country are viewing the current political upheaval here with a peculiar combination of elation and fear.

title: Amrep Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Jets Are Said to Seek Patriots' Steinberg
description: The Jets, who lost to Pittsburgh, 13-0, have reportedly asked permission to talk to Dick Steinberg of New England about becoming their general manager. Steinberg is the Patriots' director of player development. Articles, page C4.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Klemtner Promotions
description: Klemtner Advertising Inc. has promoted six people in its upper management: Michael J. Trepicchio to executive vice president and management director; Martha Crane and Kim Langley to senior vice presidents; Robert Erwin and Paul Nani to senior vice presidents and account group supervisors, and Theresa L. Mulvihill to director of accounting.

title: Supreme Equipment & Sysems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Metro Matters; Cost of Probity In Mayoral Race: 50 Cents a Voter
description: For about 50 cents apiece this year, New Yorkers contributed a measure of probity to political campaigning.

title: Post of Tyco President Added by Grinnell Chief
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc., a leading maker of fire protection systems, has named L. Dennis Kozlowski president and chief operating officer, succeeding John F. Fort, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: Krieg's Pass Lifts Seattle Over Bengals
description: Dave Krieg lobbed a 1-yard touchdown pass to Curt Warner with 3:51 to play today, giving the Seattle Seahawks a 24-17 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Film Society to Honor James Stewart in April
description: The actor James Stewart is to be honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center in its annual tribute on April 23 at Avery Fisher Hall. Excerpts from his films are to be shown, and members of the film industry are expected to attend.

title: Niagara Mohawk Power Corp reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
Military Budget Waste Linked to Congress
description: Congress wastes millions of dollars by loading down the Defense Department budget with special tidbits for constituents and by imposing excessive restraints on spending programs, according to a Pentagon draft report made public today.

title: An Upheaval in Sports, Too
description: The powerful East German sports system has been shaken by revelations of corruption and of greater privileges for elite athletes than were known. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: PE Ben Oilfield Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Touchdown On '3d and Arkansas'
description: IN the fifth round of this year's National Football League draft, the Giants were waiting their turn.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Eagles Top Cowboys in an Emotional Contest
description: The Eagles didn't have to play dirty against the Cowboys today. In fact, they didn't even have to play hard as they won by 20-10, under the watchful eye of the new commissioner, Paul Tagliabue.

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months' revenues included $3,250,000 of net insurance proceeds arising from May 1989 storm damage to the company's Dallas distribution center.

title: DENG CITES A NEED TO REPAIR U.S. TIES
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, meeting the first high-level American officials to visit here since the June killings in Tiananmen Square, said today that the two countries must restore and improve their strained relations in the interest of world stability.

title: Yale's Black Studies Said to Founder
description: Yale University's black studies program, one of the oldest in the nation and long considered one of the best, is in disarray, professors in the program say.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Kings 8, Nordiques 4: Luc Robitaille scored twice and had three assists and Wayne Gretzky and Bernie Nicholls each contributed 4 points as Los Angeles won in Quebec. Gretzky's 4 assists extended his point-scoring streak to 15 games.(AP) Sabres 4, Capitals 3: Buffalo got its 12th consecutive victory at home, equaling the franchise record set in 1972-73. Buffalo is the only team in the league without a loss on home ice this season. The Sabre goals were by Rick Vaive, Dave Andreychuk, Scott Arniel and Alexander Mogilny.(AP) Jets 4, Flames 1: Two Winnipeg power-play goals, by Pat Elynuik and Dale Hawerchuk, early in the second period sealed the victory. Bob Essensa then held off a third-period change by visiting Calgary.(AP) Blackhawks 7, Canucks 1: Al Secord had two goals and Jacques Cloutier extended his home winning streak to eight as Chicago defeated Vancouver. (AP) Track and Field Metropolitan Meet: Matt Materazo, a former Syracuse runner, looked impressive in winning his first race of the indoor season yesterday in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress all-comers meet at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck, N.J. Materazo, representing the Westchester Puma club, won the 800-meter run in 1 minute 53.1 seconds. Glenda Truesdale of the Gazelle Striders won the 55-meter dash in 8.2 seconds and the 200 meters in 26. Speed Skating American Tied for First: Bonnie Blair of the United States tied Angela Hauck of East Germany for first place in the women's 1,000-meter race yesterday at a World Cup event in Karuizawa, Japan. Blair, of Champaign, Ill., and Hauck were timed in 1 minute 23.32 seconds.(AP) Speeding Dutchman: Bart Velkamp of the Netherlands had the second-fastest 5,000-meter time ever, 6 minutes 59.96 seconds, to win a World Cup race in Skien, Norway, yesterday. Eric Heiden of the United States was clocked in 6:59.15 in Oslo 10 years ago.(AP) SKIING Swede Wins; Tomba Injured: Alberto Tomba, a two-time Olympic gold medalist, broke his left collarbone in a fall yesterday, as Niklas Henning of Sweden won the first super giant slalom of the men's World Cup ski season. The event was staged at Val d'Isere, France. Henning was timed in 1 minute 17.07 seconds.(AP) Boxing Breland Keeps Title: Mark Breland successfully defended his World Boxing Association welterweight championship in Tokyo yesterday. The referee, Julio Cesar Alvarado of Panama, stopped the scheduled 12-round bout in the fourth round as blood poured from a cut over Fujio Ozaki's right eye. College Basketball Oregon State 96, Tennessee 90: Oregon State held Tennessee to 4 points in overtime yesterday in a game played in Knoxville, Tenn. Tennessee forced the overtime by scoring the final 5 points of regulation, tying the score at 86.(AP)

title: Topps Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months' share earnings were restated to give effect to the 3-for-2 stock split distributed on Nov. 15.

title: Academy of Design Is Deciding If Its Past Should Be Its Future
description: The 164-year-old National Academy of Design has been shaken by a factional conflict between those who want to continue its transformation into a museum presenting eye-catching exhibitions and those who wish to maintain its traditions as an institution that primarily serves its 450 artist members.

title: 1 Is Killed in Nicaraguan Campaign Unrest
description: A campaign march by hundreds of opposition supporters turned violent today. The police said at least one person was killed and witnesses said 20 people were injured.

title: Trail in 49 Deaths Is Cold But the Police Press On
description: In its long hunt for the killer of 49 young women, the Green River Task Force has used botanists and anthropologists, seers and psychologists, a laser that can lift fingerprints and a computer that can match a face to slivers of jawbone.

title: Lackluster Season for Retailers
description: The 1989 Christmas shopping season is not exciting either retailers or consumers, as sales run even with or slightly ahead of last year, despite a wave of price-cutting.

title: Michigan Plane Crash Kills 4
description: A private plane crashed shortly after taking off on Saturday morning, killing the pilot, his son and two other passengers, the police said. The pilot, Mark A. O'Donnell, 40 years old, of Fenton, died two hours after the crash at a hospital in Flint. The three other victims were found dead at the scene where the single-engine Cessna 172 crashed in a cornfield, said Sgt. Pat Darrow of the Michigan State Police. The plane crashed at about 6:30 A.M. about one-half mile west of the runway of the Linden airport, he said.

title: Uncertainty Keeping Anxiety High
description: In sharp contrast to the languorous close of most years, anxiety levels among credit market participants are likely to remain high as 1989 nears an end, and the source of their uncertainty is the Federal Reserve.

title: Vintage Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fireman's Fund Name
description: The Fireman's Fund Corporation has changed its name to the Fund American Companies to erase confusion between the holding company and its insurance subsidiary and to return to a name it used 21 years ago. The corporation's board decided to retain the name Fireman's Fund Insurance Company for the subsidiary, while creating a separate identity for the holding company.

title: Black Industries reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
Johnson Matthey Shift
description: Eugene Anderson, chief executive of Johnson Matthey P.L.C., resigned last week to pursue other business interests. He will be succeeded as head of the precious metals and engineering group by Joseph Stevenson, previously an executive director who has been with the company since 1958 and has been on its board since 1982, the group said.

title: Cantel Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $961,000.

title: Anti-Apartheid Groups Say They're Ready for Serious Negotiations
description: A conference held to unite groups opposed to apartheid concluded today with a declaration that its members were ready to negotiate South Africa's future with President F. W. de Klerk if he proved that he was serious about dismantling white minority rule.

title: The Fossil Marxist
description: Compared with the change sweeping through Eastern Europe, Fidel Castro seems a Marxist museum piece - staging show trials, jailing dissenters, resisting any dilution of dogma. Now he edges closer to an open break with his Soviet benefactors. In a tirade Thursday, he complained that Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms were ''slandering socialism, destroying its values, discrediting the party and liquidating its leading role.''

title: Review/Theater; Middle-Class Male Looks in a Mirror
description: In ''Progress,'' the British playwright Doug Lucie argues that peaceful co-existence between the sexes is impossible because almost all men are pigs. But the play, which opened yesterday at the Hudson Guild Theater, takes a sardonic view of its characters' basest motives. Until the final harrowing moments, you don't realize just how depressing a message it contains.

title: National HMO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rocket Teammates Find Special Bond In Addiction Battle
description: CONCERN was evident on John Lucas's face last week.

title: 32 Americans Awarded Rhodes Scholarships
description: Two women who are cadets at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., are among 32 Americans named today as Rhodes Scholars.

title: Mortgage Rates Climb
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.76 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was up from a rate of 9.74 percent in the previous week. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.39 percent last week, down from 8.46 percent the week before.

title: Peters (J.M.) Co(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Miss Richter Wed To Jeffrey Hagler
description: Lisa Audrey Richter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Richter of Dix Hills, L.I., was married yesterday at the Dix Hills Jewish Center to Jeffrey Asher Hagler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Hagler of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Rabbi David Chanofsky officiated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The voice of the people is the voice of Heaven. It is the only righteous voice.'' -Yanko Yankov, a Bulgarian lawyer. [ A8:3. ]

title: Campus Slur Alters a Code Against Bias
description: To Nina Wu, a junior at the University of Connecticut, the handmade poster she hung on her dormitory room door a year ago was just a joke. It listed the types of people who were ''welcome,'' ''tolerated,'' ''unwelcome'' and ''shot on sight.'' The last category included ''bimbos,'' ''preppies,'' ''racists'' and, some students say, ''homos.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Leo Burnett Billings Rise Above $3 Billion
description: The Leo Burnett Company said that its combined total billings broke the $3 billion barrier this year. The advertising agency estimates that when the counting is done, its billings will total $3.245 billion in 1989, up 13 percent from 1988.

title: Magna International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: One Dies in Jersey Motel Fire
description: One person died and another was injured when a fire broke out today in a room at the Eatontown Motor Lodge, officials said. Units from at least three towns helped battle the blaze, which broke out about 6:20 P.M. in the single-story, wood-framed motel on Route 35, said Officer Charles Blanchard, a police spokesman. Theodore Lewis, the Eatontown Fire Commissioner, said he did not know whether the fatality was a guest or a visitor. He said investigators from the Monmouth County Prosecutors office and the borough's fire department were trying to determine the cause of the blaze.

Michael Rickey, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Hotel Westin Canal Place.

After the Lean Years, a Triumph

description: BEWILDERED by the variety and extent of the veteran outdoorsman's equipage, most people searching for a Christmas gift buy their outdoorsman a wool shirt. Wool shirts are fine, but two of them will last from middle age to senility.

description: Last June, Geneal Fengier, a mother living in a weathered block on the South Side of Milwaukee, expected to get the usual welfare check of $700 for her disabled husband and three teen-age children. Instead, she got a notice that her family would get no check at all.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; For Chicago Tribune Editor, The Power Struggle Ends
description: ALTHOUGH James D. Squires resigned as editor of The Chicago Tribune on Friday, the event that made the resignation all but inevitable was a bruising corporate power struggle that took place a year ago for the leadership of the Tribune Company, which owns The Tribune and The Daily News in New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mexico Tourist Job to Bozell
description: Bozell is planning a party this afternoon replete with mariachi band and tamales to celebrate its acquisition of the tourism account for Mexico.

title: Datapoint Cuts Payout
description: The Datapoint Corporation, a struggling computer company based in San Antonio, said on Friday that it had cut dividends on its preferred shares and had hired Kidder, Peabody & Company to determine alternatives for getting the most value for shareholders, including a possible sale of the company. The company also reported a loss of $13.1 million for the first quarter of its current fiscal year, which ended Oct. 28, in contrast to net income of $2.8 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: More Republican Lobbying of H.U.D. Is Disclosed

Pierce Jr. and his aides on behalf of development projects, some of which received Federal assistance.

title: Market Place; Renewed Interest In Penn Central
description: SOME analysts are beginning to look at the Penn Central Corporation with renewed interest. Amid concerns that the equities market might decline as takeovers fade and the economy continues to slow, the telecommunications and military technology company is being viewed by some as a wonderful hedge.

title: New Jersey Bank Takeover May Imperil Other Realty Lending
description: The Government takeover of New Jersey's largest savings institution last Friday could cramp the state's already ailing real-estate market by making other lenders more cautious about backing large housing developments and office projects, experts said today.

title: We Must Help Besieged Salvador
description: For more than a month, Americans have watched El Salvador turn ugly. Staring at the blood and chaos, Americans are now asking, once again, whether U.S. policy there is working. It is. Ten years ago, El Salvador was ruled by a military junta. Today, it is a working democracy that has held four fair elections.

title: Jets Seeking
description: Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, has asked the New England Patriots for permission to talk to Dick Steinberg, the Patriots' director of player development, about taking command of the Jets' front office, a pro football source said today.

The high value of the Canadian dollar against the U.S. dollar was another adverse factor. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Talks Go On in India Over Woman's Kidnapping
description: Negotiations between the Government and militant Muslims holding a Cabinet minister's daughter hostage appeared deadlocked today after the abductors demanded the release of seven jailed confederates, officials said.

title: Through Glasnost, Darkly
description: LEAD: It has been more than 100 years since Marx and Engels wrote ''A specter is haunting Europe, the specter of Communism.'' That specter has returned - not portending the onset of Communism but the end of it.

title: Chile Will Vote Freely This Week, Thanks in Part to Allende's Followers
description: Jorge Arrate has about him the air of an aging, if well-trimmed, hippie. It comes partly from his graying beard and choice of a home in a slightly Bohemian art district, but mostly from his words.

title: Rocket Launching Is Put Off
description: Trouble with a fuel tank pressurization system today forced the Air Force to postpone for one day the launching of a military navigation satellite. Lieut. Col. Ron Rand, an Air Force spokesman, said the trouble was a faulty pressure regulator for helium for the Delta 2 rocket's fuel tanks. The Delta 2 is to take aloft a satellite that will join four others that tell United States and allied military forces where they are within 50 feet anywhere in the world.

title: Chile Is Getting Independent Central Bank
description: In the first attempt in Latin America to free a central bank from Government control, Chile's central bank will begin functioning autonomously on Monday under a five-member board. The governing panel was named last week in a surprisingly harmonious agreement between the departing Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and a coalition of the expected winner of this week's presidential elections.

title: Walker Hitting Stride
description: The Knicks had to lose one player in the expansion draft. Choosing between Kenny Walker and Sidney Green was not easy. Both were capable of playing two positions, Walker at small and big forward, Green at center and power forward. The decision came down to whether Green's size was more beneficial than Walker's athletic and shot-blocking abilities.

title: Reasons Leads Giants With 11 Tackles
description: Two consecutive losses had provided a jolt that Gary Reasons said no Giant could ignore. Reasons, a sixth-year linebacker, readily conceded his part in those losses, to the San Francisco 49ers and the Philadelphia Eagles. Reasons said he had missed too many reads on defense. He said he had missed too many tackles.

title: Surgery Stops Bleeding By Recipient of Liver
description: The recipient of the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor underwent surgery today for the second time in two days to stop bleeding on the surface of the new organ, hospital officials said.

title: Edward J. Bloustein, 64, Is Dead; President of Rutgers Since 1971
description: Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University since 1971, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he was attending a business meeting. Dr. Bloustein lived in the president's house on the school's New Brunswick-Piscataway campus. He was 64 years old.

Review/Dance; A 'Faune' Derived From Nijinsky's 1915 Notations
description: The Juilliard Dance Ensemble's production of ''L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune'' (''Afternoon of a Faun'') on Saturday night at the Juilliard Theater was a reminder of how comparatively few choreographic works have been notated over the centuries. Instead, dances are usually taught by one generation of performers to the next. Because memories play tricks, such a method of preservation can blur or distort a piece's nuances.

title: Dalai Lama, Accepting Prize, Urges Peaceful Tibet Solution
description: The Dalai Lama accepted the Nobel Peace Prize today and said he remained committed to nonviolence in seeking an end to China's 40-year occupation of Tibet, his Himalayan homeland.

title: Review/Television; The Crime of the Century Is Reviewed Once Again
description: The execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann more than 50 years ago for the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., the 20-month-old son of America's national hero, continues to stir up interest. Was the German-born Hauptmann a victim of circumstances, of anti-German sentiment, of unscrupulous police officers and prosecutors? For those aroused by such questions, ''Reliving the Lindbergh Case,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, provides two answers to each of them, yes and no.

title: The Airline Lorenzo Dreamed Of
description: Nine months into a strike by the vast majority of its work force, Eastern Airlines is close to emerging from bankruptcy protection as the low-cost carrier Frank A. Lorenzo has been trying for three years to create. But the airline's survival remains uncertain, depending largely on whether it can successfully reach beyond the bargain-hunting passenger on which it has relied since spring, before the cash from its asset sales runs out.

description: b-Included income of $1,108 from discontinued operations. c-Included income of $45,474, or 1 cent a share, and $53,880, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations. The Telecommunications division, sold in July 1989, and the Transact Services division, sold in October 1989, are treated as discontinued operations.

title: Computer Gain By Japan Seen
description: The top Japanese computer makers are overtaking their United States competitors and this trend is likely to continue into the next decade, according to a report by the consulting firm of Arthur D. Little.

title: Jan C. Grossman, Consultant, Weds
description: Jan Carol Grossman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Grossman of New York, was married yesterday to Joshua Morton Rubins, a son of Eve Rubins of Baldwin, L.I., and the late Dr. Irving Rubins. Rabbi Lester Bronstein officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Murdoch Looking for Ventures in Moscow
description: Rupert Murdoch may be an ardent capitalist, but apparently that has not tempered his eagerness to use perestroika to extend the reach of his media properties.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Many Faces of Rayful Edmond
description: In Ralph Ellison's classic novel ''Invisible Man,'' the protagonist dons a pair of dark glasses to disguise himself and escape a gang bent on destroying him. The ruse works better than he could have imagined. More than disguised, he is transformed - into Rinehart, a figure widely known in Harlem, but in wildly different ways.

title: The Blot on Turkey's Name
description: Over the years, Turkey has offered two replies to charges that its police routinely engage in torture - that the charges are exaggerated, and in any case things are getting better. The sad inadequacy of those answers is documented anew in a devastating report by the human rights committee of the New York City Bar Association. The report says that inhuman practices are widespread, and that Turkey's existing remedies are ''almost a complete failure.''

title: LELAND SUCCESSOR IS CHOSEN IN TEXAS
description: A Texas State Senator, Craig Washington, defeated a City Councilman on Saturday in a runoff election to choose a successor to Representative Mickey Leland, who died in a plane crash in Africa four months ago.

description: The first Czechoslovak Cabinet in 41 years without a Communist majority was sworn in today by President Gustav Husak, the Communist hard-liner, who resigned immediately afterward.

title: Susan A. Wright Is Married
description: Susan Ann Wright and Richard Harold Kail were married yesterday at St. Mark Lutheran Church in Morris Township, N.J., by the Rev. Eddie A. Nilsen. Mrs. Wright-Kail, 31 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wright of Convent Station, N.J. A graduate of Ithaca College, she is a vice president of the United Jersey Bank in Hackensack. Mr. Kail, 32, is a son of Adrienne Stoner Kail of New York and Morton Kail of Eastchester, N.Y. He graduated from Pace University and is the production manager of Wintry Press, a publishing company in New York.

title: Bush Renews Vow on Tax
description: President Bush said Friday that reducing the tax rate on capital gains would be a leading priority for his Administration next year, setting the stage for another intense battle over the tax cut for investors.

title: Latin Chiefs Open Talks, With Salvador Truce a Possible Outcome
description: The five Central American presidents opened a two-day summit meeting here today amid growing signs that the talks will produce at least a temporary cease-fire in the 10-year Salvadoran civil war.

title: INSIDE
description: Deng Wants Warmer Ties China's leader, Deng Xiaoping, told Americans in Beijing that the two countries must improve ties in the interest of world stability. Page A9. Chile's Central Bank Chile became the first Latin American country to free its central bank from Government control, in a step intended to stabilize its monetary policy and deter inflation. Page D1. description: The mild capitalism emerging in Eastern Europe, though unthinkable in these Communist nations just a few years ago, is a far cry from the free-market economics practiced in the West - and will probably remain so for a long time.

title: Program to Find Marrow Donors Is Falling Short
description: An ambitious Federal program to register volunteers who can donate bone marrow needed by dying patients is falling far short of the need, forcing the vast majority of patients to raise huge sums of money to conduct their own, generally fruitless, searches.

Poindexter nears, it is clear that the former national security adviser is adopting a defense strategy that portrays Ronald Reagan as a knowing and active participant in the Iran-contra affair, not the disengaged President depicted by Mr. Poindexter in his testimony before Congress.
