title: Ms. Miller Wed To Walter Gidaly
description: Barbara Miller and Walter Gidaly were married in New York yesterday at the Prunelle Restaurant by Judge Benjamin W. Mehlman, the village justice of Ocean Beach, L.I. The bride is the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Joerling of Cincinnati. Her husband is a son of Sari Joel of the Bronx and the late Harry Gidaly.

title: Lvov Journal; At Newly Freed Parish, Priestly Skirmish Rages
description: Two bearded Christian priests are butting faiths, struggling for the shepherd's staff here at the Church of the Transfiguration, acting out the zealous, liberating aftermath of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's historic visit to Pope John Paul II.

title: Abbott Chief to Retire
description: Abbott Laboratories, the drug company based in Abbott Park, Ill., said today that its chairman and chief executive, Robert A. Schoellhorn, would retire in August at age 62. Mr. Schoellhorn will be replaced by Abbott Labs' vice chairman, Duane L. Burnham, 47, who will become chief executive on Jan. 1. Mr. Schoellhorn will remain chairman until his retirement. Mr. Burnham, who joined Abbott in 1982 as chief financial officer, was formerly president and chief executive of the Bunker Ramo Corporation.

title: Recent Shuffles in the Soviet Bloc
description: East Germany Head of Government: Prime Minister Hans Modrow Took Office: Nov 20 Predecessors: Egon Krenz (took office on Oct. 18: resigned on Dec. 3) Erich Honecker (took office as Communist Party Leader in May 1971, became head of state in Oct. 1976; forced to resign both posts on Oct. 18.) Communist Party Chairman: Gregor Gysi Took Office: Dec. 9 Election: Scheduled for May 8. On Dec. 3, the Communist party leadership under Krenz collapses because of popular anger at abuses under Honecker. Politburo and Central Committee resign. A 'round-table' of 12 delegations, including the Communists and opposition groups led by the New Forum, meets on Dec. 7 and calls for a new constitution and free elections. Czechoslovakia Head of Government: Prime Minister Marian Calfa Took Office: Dec. 7; sworn in on Dec. 10. Predecessor: Ladislav Adamec (took office Oct. 12, 1988; resigned: Dec. 7.) Head of state: Open, Gustav Husak, Communist leader from 1968 to December 1987 and President since May 1975, resigned on Dec. 10. No successor yet chosen. Head of Communist Party: Karel Urbanek Took Power: Nov. 24 Predecessor: Milos Jakes (took office Dec. 1987; resigned Nov. 24.) On Nov. 28, Adamec, the caretaker Communist Prime Minister, pledges to give up the party's 41-year monopoly on power. On Dec. 3, a new Cabinet, to be headed by Adamec and to include non-Communists for the first time in 21 years, is rejected by the Civic Forum, the main opposition group. On Dec. 7, Adamec is replaced by Calfa. On Dec. 10, a new Government is named, with Communists holding a minority of Cabinet positions. Poland Head of Government: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki Took Office: Aug. 19. The Communists, under Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, beaten in national elections, accept a Governemtn with themselves in a minority position. Mazowiecki, a senior Solidarity official and Roman Catholic layman, is the first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early postwar years. Head of Communist Party: Mieczyslaw Rakkowski Took Office: July 29 Predecessor: Gen. Wojciech Haruzelski (took office Oct. 1981 Hungary Head of Government: Three-member body formally headed by Rezso Nyers. Took Office: October The Communist Party, which has ruled since 1956 and has been led since 1988 by Karoly Grosz, formally disbands on Oct. 7 and renames itself the Socialist Party. In a referendum on Nov. 26, voters reject the election timetable of the Socialists, forcing them to abandon plan to elect the first President of the republic while the party retained full control of the Government. Bulgaria Government and Communist Party Leader: Petar T. Malaoenov Took Office: Oct. 29 Predecessor: Todor I. Zhivkov, who resigned. Zhivkov was head of the Communist Party since 1954 and President since 1971.

description: For the two and a half years since he mauled a toddler to death, a pit bull named Willy has lived in cage No. 214 at the Humane Society animal shelter here, pacing his narrow enclosure, gnawing his rawhide bone or romping in the exercise yard with kennel attendants who have come to love him.

title: Pennies From Heaven and Bills From a Bag
description: Christmas came early at a motel bar near Midway Airport here when a well-dressed woman walked in, wished everyone a happy holiday and started passing out $100, $50 and $20 bills from a brown paper bag.

title: Vietnam Rice Crop Up
description: Vietnam has produced 18.02 million tons of unmilled rice this year, 4 percent more than expected and 8.5 percent more than last year's crop, the official Vietnam News Agency said in a report made available Friday. The high output was attributed to three good harvests and to policy changes made in 1988 after riots forced the Government to abandon an unpopular drive toward group cooperation.

description: To counteract the bureaucracy and inefficiency that have accompanied publishing mergers and acquisitions, a number of houses are creating more imprints - semi-independent fiefdoms of two to a dozen or more people who have considerable flexibility to acquire and publish books.

description: New Jersey's promise of prenatal care to all pregnant women, including those with no medical insurance, merits close examination and emulation. No state, or nation, could make a sounder investment in its future.

description: India's new Finance Minister has said the country's external debt is about $60.6 billion, or nearly twice the figure given by the previous Government.

title: Some Ideas for the Holiday Shopper Biking in the winter has its own special needs. Performance Inc., of Chapel Hill, N.C., uses three layers of fabric to make its Performance Winter Century Cycling Glove. The inside layer is Thermolite, a DuPont insulation material. The next layer is an insert made of Gore-Tex, a wind- and water-resistant fabric that allows perspiration to escape. The outside is made of Lycra, a nylon stretch material, and terry cloth, for wiping the brow. The leather palm contains a foamlike material to absorb shock. Available in red, silver or green; sizes XS to XL. Price: $29.95. Telephone (800) 727-2453.  SKIING  The opportunity to go skiing often depends on the children. Casby Inc., of Conneaut, Ohio, has developed a device to allow parents to take their children onto the slopes with them. The Ski Starter, for youngsters 3 years old or more, is designed with a waist belt of nylon webbing, and an eight-foot harness for holding the child in check on a ski slope. The harness clips off the waist belt for the child's ride on a chair lift. Adhesive squares applied to the tips of the skis and a tether between them keep the child's skis in a snowplow position. Price: $24.95. Telephone (216)224-0060.  GOLF  The Tee-Off platform trainer allows a player to practice anywhere there is enough room to raise a club. The Tee-Off comes with a high-impact plastic ball suspended by a nylon cord from a steel arm. It is attached to a two-foot-by-one-foot base of fiberboard covered in artificial turf. The Tee-Off Company, of Madison, Wis., includes a diagram to show the golfer how to gauge a hit by the way the ball rotates around the arm of the device. Available in right- or left-handed models. Price: $34.95. Telephone (800) 533-9791.  RUNNING  Shoes that are laced too tight can cause aching feet. Shoestring Inc. of Ketchum, Idaho, has come up with an idea for elastic laces that are secured with a plastic locking device the size of a nickel called Willy's. Once the right tension is found, the laces are threaded through the lock and snapped shut. Release the lock, and they are adjustable. Available in 31 colors, including neons and metallics. Price: $4.65 per pair for 20-inch and 30-inch laces, and $5.65 per pair for 60-inch. Available in New York at Super Runners Shop (six locations), or telephone Shoestring at (800) 999-2342.  FISHING    A video, ''Encyclopedia of Saltwater Sport Fish,'' takes the angler one step further than most books in teaching how to catch a fish and identify a species. The viewer can see his prey as it is being caught. Bennett Marine Video of Marina del Rey, Calif., produced the 60-minute film. James Marsh, the commentator, shows footage of catching the 36 species (from the amberjack to the wahoo) he discusses. Price: $29.95. Telephone (800) 262-8862; in California, (213) 821-3329.  TENNIS  A new version of the pitch-back, the portable rebound net for practicing tennis, has been designed in Australia. Known as the Roobound, th Price: $79 to $89. For local dealer, telephone (415) 777-4004.  YACHTING  The current court battle over who keeps the America's Cup, San Diego or New Zealand, is only one part of the event's controversial past, which dates to 1851. In his new book, ''A Picture History of the America's Cup,'' John Rousmaniere has delved into the archives of the Mystic Seaport Museum of Mystic, Conn., for a century's worth of black-and-white photos, mostly from the Rosenfeld Collection of Stanley Rosenfeld and his father, the late Morris Rosenfeld. The 128-page book, published by Mystic Seaport Museum Stores Inc., places the event in perspective for the armchair sailor. Price: $39.95. Telephone (800) 331-2665; in Connecticut, (203) 572-8551.
description: Sports gear of every kind is flooding the market this season. A kaleidoscope of neon and metallic colors enlivens products from shoes to tennis racquets. From this wellspring of sports paraphernalia, the avid holiday shopper should be able to find the right gift. Here are a few ideas. CYCLING

title: Quayle Sees No Difference With Bush on Gorbachev Reforms
description: Vice President Dan Quayle yesterday tempered some of the skepticism he voiced last week about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, saying that most of his dissatisfaction concerns the Soviet Union's influence in Latin America.

title: Argentine Inflation Up
description: Argentina's cost of living rose 6.5 percent in November, indicating that inflation is heating when the Government had promised it would be stamped out. The monthly increase was the second lowest this year, but it was higher than the 5.6 percent October figure, reversing a trend that had been downward since July.

title: 50,000 in Bulgaria Demand Faster Movement Toward Democracy
description: Tens of thousands of Bulgarians rallied here in the capital today to demand swifter democratic change, including an end to the Communist Party's constitutionally assured leading role and the resignation of its entire Central Committee.

title: 4 POWERS TO MEET ON GERMAN ISSUES
description: The Ambassadors of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France will meet here on Monday to discuss the rapidly evolving relationship between East and West Germany, an Allied statement said today.

title: Cornell Seeks Coach
description: For the second time in less than a year, Cornell University is searching for a new head football coach.

title: BUS SAFETY RAISED IN CRASH DEFENSE
description: Bus safety and drinking were the focus of testimony today as the defense began its case in the trial of Larry Mahoney on charges of drunken driving and murder.

title: Reviews/Music; A Pianist's Final Evening of Beethoven
description: A complete Beethoven sonata cycle, offered chronologically, is a steep climb for a pianist, even at the comparatively leisurely pace that the Irish pianist John O'Conor has taken. Mr. O'Conor began making his way through the 32 sonatas in February, when he gave the first of eight concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art devoted to the works. And on Friday evening, he finished the series with the cycle's summit.

title: Bush Says Savings Bailout May Not Be Enough
description: President Bush said for the first time today that the bailout of the savings and loan industry, which he signed into law in August, might not be enough to cover the actual cost of the industry's problems.

title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime
description: Sgt. Norman Horowitz waved through the window of the blue police van at the elderly neighborhood beautician. ''Hi, pretty lady,'' he boomed. She flashed a gap-toothed grin and waved back.

title: British Group Has 5.1% of MDT
description: A British investment group reported that it had acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the MDT Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the British group said it had purchased the MDT shares for investment purposes. The investment group is led by Britannia Arrow Holdings P.L.C., a publicly traded London-based holding company.

title: Upheaval in the East; Soviet Congress Reconvenes Today, the Joy of Spring Nipped in the Bud
description: The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, inaugurated in the spring in a burst of outspokenness and optimism, is reconvening on Tuesday for a second, far more wintry session of complaint and doubt about the torpid pace of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promised renewal of the nation.

title: Parcells Has Praise for Carthon
description: Once the game at Denver on Sunday had begun, Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, knew his players were ready. All it took, he said yesterday, was ''about the first three handoffs to Maurice Carthon.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Business section on Sunday about the International Business Machines Corporation offered an assessment of I.B.M.'s current financial problems and presented a ''blueprint'' to remedy them.

title: S.E.C. in Pact With Dutch
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its Dutch counterpart announced an agreement today to cooperate in trying to stem a broad range of cross-border violations of securities laws.

title: New Treasurer Is Sworn In
description: Catalina Vasquez Villalpando took the oath of office today as the United States Treasurer, the official whose signature goes on every bill. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady administered the oath, and Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, held the Bible. President Bush attended the ceremony at the Old Executive Office Building. Ms. Villalpando, a Texan, is a past chairwoman of the Republican National Hispanic Assembly.

title: Electronic Toys for Girls and Boys
description: ADULTS still struggling with computer anxiety may be surprised to find that children as young as 3 years old can, with a little help, handle the machines quite successfully and learn something in the process.

title: Review/Ballet; 2 Debuts in 'Nutcracker'
description: George Balanchine's production of ''The Nutcracker'' took on extra luster with two role debuts in a performance by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Gold Prices Continue Climb; Demand Is Strong in Europe
description: Gold prices continued to climb yesterday, largely on strong European demand. Dealers said much of the demand, which later spilled over into the New York market, was started by rumors that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had offered to resign. The rumors were dismissed by Pravda and other Soviet press agencies.

title: 'Brain Drain' in Hong Kong
description: The exodus of professional people from Hong Kong is so great that economic growth may be only half of projections, a business group warned today. Many emigrants are seeking foreign passports before China takes over the British colony in 1997.

title: Mays (J.W.) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $49,714 from discontinued operations, which reflected expenses related to the retail operations, which were discontinued on Jan. 3.

title: Crown Books Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Topics of The Times; Sequin Sequel
description: A recent public opinion poll found no discernible increase in voluntarism in response to President Bush's call for a new national spirit of service, what he calls ''a thousand points of light.'' But if voluntarism hasn't benefited from the President's call, commerce may.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: By Design; The Swept-Back Look
description: Judging from the way a good many women have been turned out at the big galas this season, the neatly swept-back hairdo that leaves the face, ears and neck in graceful relief is the coif of the moment. The aim is to appear cool and elegant. No matter how hotsy-totsy the outfit, the smooth, controlled hairdo tones it down. Last week at the Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum, the socialite C. Z. Guest had her well-known chin-length bob pulled back and anchored with a discreet braid of fake hair. It looked superb with her Adolfo evening jacket, heavily encrusted with gold embroidery.

title: The Rising Dominance of OPEC
description: Reflecting its expansion into refining and distribution, Saudi Arabia's oil company has emerged as the largest oil company in the world, the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said in its issue that was published today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Stanley Steingut, the former New York State Assembly Speaker, referred incorrectly to service by his father, Irwin Steingut, as Assembly minority leader. It began in 1930, not 1928.

title: Left and Right in Greece Denounce the King's Offer to Return
description: Political parties on both the left and the right today criticized Greece's deposed King over a published interview in which he said he would like to return to restore unity to his country.

title: Q&A
description: Chewing Gum Q. Is it bad for you to swallow chewing gum? Does it get digested? A. The nonsoluble gum base of chewing gum is not digested, but neither are parts of many foods, like popcorn or lettuce, scientists in the food industry say.

title: Honduran Leader Walks Out on Talks
description: A summit meeting among the five Central American Presidents was suspended late Monday night when President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras stormed out of the session after the dispute with President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.

title: ARMY, FACING CUTS, REPORTED SEEKING TO RESHAPE ITSELF
description: The United States Army, facing major cuts in its forces stationed in Europe and a declining budget, has proposed reshaping itself largely into a fast-reaction force based in the continental United States, senior Army officials say.

title: Joseph L. Ferraro, Lawyer, 67
description: Joseph L. Ferraro, a retired lawyer and former president of the Board of Education in Paterson, N.J., died of complications of heart surgery on Sunday at the St. Joseph's Medical Center in Paterson. He was 67 years old and lived in Oakhurst, N.J.

title: Official in Kansas Quits as Heat Rises Over His Race Slur
description: The director of the Kansas Bureau of Investigation has resigned after news reports that he told a racist joke led 22 state legislators to protest.

title: Xplor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Issues Slip in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched lower in very sluggish trading yesterday, and market participants said that activity was likely to remain spotty for the rest of the month.

title: Cray Research Expands Products
description: Cray Research Inc.'s chairman, John A. Rollwagen, said the company would expand its product line, introducing a lower-price version of its Y-MP supercomputer sometime in the first half of 1990. The new computer will be priced close to $2 million. The least expensive Cray now begins at about $5 million. Mr. Rollwagen also said the Minneapolis-based company would keep its focus on designing fast supercomputers.

title: Rangers Face Uncertain Future
description: His team was done for the night; he just wasn't sure if he ought to be, as well. Neil Smith, the eager and anxious general manager of the Rangers, hesitated before ducking into an elevator late Sunday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: DEALS
description: Baseball KANSAS CITY (AL) - Agreed to terms with Mark Davis, pitcher, on a four-year contract. MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Joaquin Andujar, pitcher, on a one-year contract with Indianapolis of the American Association. BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Activated Jim Petersen, forward-center, from the injured list. Waived Leonard Taylor, forward. Colleges NAVY - Dismissed Elliot Uzelac, head football coach. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Recalled Jamie Huscroft, defenseman-right wing, from Utica of the American Hockey League. LOS ANGELES (NHL) - Recalled Todd Elik, center, from New Haven of the A.H.L.

title: Environmental Ed 101
description: To the Editor:

title: Pall Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said latest quarter's share earnings was reduced by about 5 cents and latest quarter's revenues were decreased by about $3 million because of Hurricane Hugo's effects on its Puerto Rico-based facilities.

title: Six Officials Who Made a Difference Will Receive Public Service Awards
description: One matches inmates and bunks in a prison system bursting at the seams. Another winnows census data for facts useful to New York City. And one calmed the nervousness of a whole medical staff to add a medical center for AIDS patients to a hospital and nursing home.

title: Ben Barton, Music Publisher, 89
description: Ben Barton, a music publisher who supplied songs to Frank Sinatra and others, died in his sleep Friday at the Actors' Fund Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: Wyse Says It Will Take Taiwan Bid
description: Wyse Technology Inc., a one-time Silicon Valley superstar that went into a tailspin, will be sold to an investor group from Taiwan for $10 a share in cash, the company announced today.

title: America West Debt Is Purchased
description: An affiliate of an Australian airline that is partly owned by the publisher Rupert Murdoch has purchased $15.6 million worth of debentures in America West Airlines, maintaining its 19.1 percent stake in the regional carrier based in Tempe, Ariz. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing,the Australian group said it had bought the debentures, which are convertible into 1.2 million America West shares.

title: The Joys Of Inflicting A Sore Head
description: Football players are dripping in armor for good reason. Without a helmet, without a steel mask, without shoulder pads, elbow pads, knee braces and taped wrists and fists and the occasional neck brace, football players might get hurt - or suffer even greater bumps than they already do.

title: Sharper Images
description: Engineers at the University of Rochester have developed a new process for sharpening blurred images in photographs.

title: Jets Will Interview Steinberg of Patriots
description: On the verge of closing out another lackluster decade, the Jets have decided to hire a single person to run their football operation. The first executive they will interview is Dick Steinberg, the New England Patriots' director of player development.

title: Central Sprinkler Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Hospital Defends Limiting of Drug Program
description: A spokesman for a hospital accused of discriminating against pregnant women seeking drug and alcoholism treatment said the hospital denied the women access to its inpatient detoxification program because of financial and medical concerns.

title: PATTERNS
description: Japanese Style

title: Upheaval in the East; Excerpts From Speech By Gorbachev on Bloc
description: Following are excerpts from the speech by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to the Communist Party Central Committee last Saturday, as translated by the Soviet press agency Tass: Comrades, implementation of the long-term course of perestroika exerts not only a revolutionary influence on all the spheres of life of Soviet society, but also influences other socialist coutries and developments in the world. At the same time, perestroika itself comes under the influence of the world, and needs favorable international conditions.

title: Licenses Awarded by Britain For 3 New Phone Networks
description: The British Government yesterday awarded licenses to build three wireless networks for telephone and information services to international consortiums that include the Pacific Telesis Group, U S West Inc. and Cable and Wireless P.L.C.

title: Bar Group Ready to Name First Black President
description: New York's most prestigious lawyers' organization, the City Bar Association, is preparing to name its first black president.

title: Taking Over Repairs For Bridges Is Urged
description: New York City should prepare itself to assume responsibility next year for a 10-year, $1 billion reconstruction program for its four East River bridges, the State Transportation Commissioner, Franklin E. White, told city officials yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music; Whitney Director Said to Be Under Fire
description: Trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art are debating whether Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the museum's director since 1974, should stay on in that post, according to board members who would not speak for attribution.

title: Intelogic Trace Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain due to retirement of debt of $1,249,000, or 8 cents a share. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter's results reflected losses in the company's securities portfolio.

title: Bush Rebuffed Plea for Meeting, Iran-Contra Prosecutor
description: Lawrence E. Walsh, the Iran-contra prosecutor, today disclosed a sometimes bitter exchange of private letters in which the White House rebuffed his request for a meeting with President Bush to discuss the imperiled prosecution of a former intelligence official.

title: New Programs Ease Burden Of Caring for Aged Relatives
description: Twice a week, a health worker comes to Susan Glantz's home in Alexandria Township, N.J., and gives her a two-hour break from the strain of caring for her 85-year-old mother-in-law, who has Alzheimer's disease.

title: Topics of the Times; Back to the Past
description: While most of Eastern Europe is coming apart, Albania thrives - according to an upbeat advertisement in The Times the other day. The ad, signed ''American Friends of Albania,'' celebrated the 45th anniversary of the Albanian people's ''Liberation from Nazi-Fascist occupation'' in 1944. It described a land where: ''There are no taxes on the people . . . No inflation . . . No unemployment . . . No cases of AIDS . . . No problem of drug addiction, no beggars or homeless [ and ] no crime in the streets, which are clean and free of garbage.''

title: GATT Chief Sees U.S. Export Lead
description: The United States seems certain to overtake West Germany and become the world's biggest exporter this year, the head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, said today.

title: Upheaval in the East; Baker Says Unification Isn't Just a German Issue
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in remarks aimed at Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, said today that German reunification was not just a German issue but one to be decided in consultation with Bonn's NATO allies, its neighbors and the Soviet Union.

title: High Court Upholds Reagan Aide In Appeal of Wedtech Conviction
description: Lyn Nofziger, one of Ronald Reagan's closest political advisers, won a legal victory today when the Supreme Court refused to review an appellate court ruling in June that overturned his conviction on charges of illegal lobbying.

title: South Pole Emerging As Center of Astronomy
description: Fighting chronic fatigue caused by thin air and deadly cold, scientists here are assembling a new type of telescope that may reveal the mysterious origin of cosmic rays.

title: Arafat's Crucial Audience: Israelis
description: LEAD: While the Palestine Liberation Organization has made significant steps in the last year in laying the groundwork for a negotiated peace, it has failed to impress its most crucial audience: the Israeli people.

title: Donald F. Poulson, 79, A Professor of Biology
description: Donald Frederick Poulson, a senior research biologist and a professor emeritus of biology at Yale University, died on Thursday at Yale-New Haven Hospital from injuries suffered on Nov. 29 in an automobile accident in New Haven. He was 79 years old.

title: Devaluation In Argentina
description: The Argentine Government announced a series of economic measures late Sunday night, including a devaluation of its currency, and banks and foreign exchange houses were closed today to give them time to digest the actions.

title: Anemia Drug Rights Go to 2 Makers
description: In a decision that leaves patent rights to a valuable new genetically engineered drug still in hot dispute, a Federal magistrate in Boston ruled yesterday that two competing biotechnology companies have valid patents.

title: Bramalea Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Homeless Shelter in Church Is Upheld
description: Quoting Scripture as well as the law, a Civil Court judge yesterday dismissed a suit by an East Side condominium that sought to prevent a church next door from sheltering 10 homeless men in its basement three nights a week in the summer.

title: Market Place; Are Small Stocks Set to Rebound?
description: IS now the time for small stocks to start outperforming their larger brethren? Some money managers think so, betting both on the much-heralded ''January effect'' - the phenomenon of small stocks rising rapidly around the beginning of a new year - and on the relative cheapness of small stocks.

title: Police Seeking Man Who Killed Mugger
description: Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they were preparing a composite sketch of the unidentified man who fatally stabbed a subway mugger early last Saturday. They hope the sketch will help in their search for him if he does not turn himself in.

title: Deadline Passes in India With No Word on Captive
description: A deadline for the release of prisoners set by Kashmiri militants holding the daughter of India's Home Minister passed tonight with no indication of the young woman's fate.

title: EGYPT AND SYRIA REOPEN AIR LINKS
description: Syria and Egypt, longstanding Arab adversaries, agreed today to re-establish air links severed a decade ago. The move could foreshadow a renewal of diplomatic ties, which were broken after Egypt made peace with Israel, officials here said.

title: Topics of The Times; The Classic Diaper
description: Last year, in a decision widely criticized as hardhearted, the town leaders of Lisbon, Me., decided that recipients of welfare from the town would be required to buy cloth diapers for their babies. The town's motive was economy: it costs less to use a cloth diaper over and over than to keep buying new disposables. Now it turns out, however, that there are powerful environmental reasons for cloth as well.

title: H.J. Heinz Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of distribution of shares, effective Sept. 27.

title: Review/Concert; Hearing Virgil Thomson in His Music
description: What are we to make of the painfully small audience at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night for a Continuum retrospective of Virgil Thomson's music that, given the recentness of his death, took on the look of a memorial?

title: At Annapolis, Football Victory Is Joy to Behold
description: To the roster of Navy heroes that starts with John Paul Jones and runs through Bull Halsey and Jimmy Carter and Roger Staubach, the Naval Academy added a new name today: Frank Schenk.

title: Hong Kong Forcibly Returns 51 Boat People
description: In a secret operation that began just before dawn, 100 Hong Kong prison officers, many dressed in riot gear, today herded 51 Vietnamese refugees aboard a plane bound for Hanoi in the first forced repatriation of boat people to the country that they risked their lives fleeing.

title: Wife of Kidnapped Colonel Criticizes U.N. Over Safety
description: Robin Higgins, the wife of Col. William Higgins, accused the United Nations today of making its forces ''sitting ducks'' by failing to insure their safety. Colonel Higgins, a member of a United Nations observer force, was kidnapped and reported to have been executed in Lebanon.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday and a chronology on Nov. 25 about political changes in Eastern Europe gave an incorrect date for the start of Communist rule in Hungary. The Communists took control in stages in the late 1940's, culminating in the establishment of the Hungarian People's Republic in 1949.

title: Should a Hospital Tell Patients if a Surgeon Has AIDS?
description: A lawsuit filed by a physician before he died of AIDS in June is forcing a court review of the rights of ill doctors to continue to treat patients and perform surgery without informing patients of their condition.

title: Dress Barn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
'Verdi's Nice, but Can You Type?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Killing of Human Rights Workers on the Rise
description: Sixty-eight men and women who monitored human rights abuses in their countries were killed this year and 10 others disappeared after being seized by security forces, Human Rights Watch says in its annual report.

title: Congress, a School for Scandal
description: Tempers ran short as the House rushed to wind up its business for the year. During one of several late nights, those present on the floor began baying ''Gephardt! Gephardt!'' to encourage the majority leader to excuse them. Representative Marty Russo, who was trying to talk about Lithuania at the time, was not amused. Descending the podium, he grabbed Representative Dennis Eckart by the collar, began to swear at his smaller colleague and was hauling off to slug him when Representative Barney Frank intervened.

title: Acquisition by Unilever
description: Unilever, the diversified British-Dutch consumer products company, said today that it had acquired Compania Productora Nacional de Aceitas S.A. of Chile for an undisclosed sum. The company, which employs 350 people, manufactures margarine and edible fats and oils, and had 1988 sales of $28 million.

title: Oregon Plans to Go Ahead With Lottery on N.B.A.
description: In spite of objections by the National Basketball Association, the Oregon Lottery Commission decided unanimously today to add professional basketball to its Sports Action betting game.

title: Catching Up With a Comfortable Joan Baez
description: Midway in her concert at the Bottom Line on Friday evening, Joan Baez joked to the audience about where they might have been when they first heard her recording of ''The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down.''

title: Link to Death Plot Is Denied
description: The brother-in-law of a former President of Mexico pleaded not guilty today to conspiracy in the killing of an American drug agent and other charges in an indictment accusing him of being a member of an international drug ring.

title: Chock Full O' Nuts Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago quarter results included a pretax gain on marketable equity securities of $178,000, or 1 cent a share. Latest quarter results included results of Jimbo's Jumbos Inc. which was acquired in November 1988.

title: Betrayal in Beijing
description: These have been days of joy and light for all who now march in the streets for freedom and all who live in its grace.

title: People
description: * Linda Clasen has been appointed creative director of Gregory & Clyburne.

title: Amerifirst Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $12,200,000 and $17,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $8,400,000. c-Net income d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,392,000 for the quarter and $2,804,000 for the year, and year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $7,901,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Peary was not a fake or a fraud and he did reach the North Pole. He was where he said he was when he said he was.'' -Thomas D. Davies, on a new study of Admiral Peary's Arctic exploration. [ A1:2. ]

title: Datapoint Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $4,433,000, or 44 cents a share, which included $4,361,000 gain from extinguishment of debt and $72,000 gain from tax-loss carryforwards. c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $1,610,000, or 16 cents share, from tax-loss carryforwards. The company attributed the loss to a $5.7 million loss in the company's investment portfolio, a $2.7 million charge to fight a shareholder's consent solicitation and $2.2 million to streamline the U.S. sales organization.

title: More Holiday Gifts From Silicon Valley
description: SILICON Santa is back with some last-minute software gift suggestions for your favorite computer whiz. Some of Santa's suggestions are practical, while others are just for fun. After all, many computer users need an injection of fun whether they know it or not.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Guardsman Chief Hopes to Expand in East
description: LEAD: Guardsman Products Inc. said yesterday that Charles E. Bennett will become president and chief operating officer in January, replacing William P. Radcliff, who has held the job since 1983.

title: Centers Abundant in Class of '90
description: Help may be near for the many National Basketball Association teams that need centers. Although there is not another Patrick Ewing or a David Robinson around, centers appear to be plentiful among this season's college seniors.

title: KEY RATES
A Protest By Nestle
description: In response to a consumer group, the Nestle Foods Corporation, maker of a top-selling instant coffee, said yesterday that it was suspending for 30 days the purchase of coffee beans from El Salvador.

title: New X-Ray Technique Helps Dinosaur Hunters
description: A method developed to find buried toxic waste is helping scientists dig up what may be the longest fossilized dinosaur ever found, a 120-foot seismosaurus who died in a river 145 million years ago.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bonn Leader Softens His Plan for German Unity
description: Taking account of foreign concerns, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany softened a vital element of his vision of German unity today as representatives of the four wartime occupying powers met here and insisted on ''the importance of stability'' in Eastern Europe.

title: Shareholder Group Is Suing Chevron
description: A group of shareholders of the Chevron Corporation sued the company in Delaware chancery court to block part of a new ''poison pill'' plan aimed at thwarting a hostile takeover. The stockholder suit, court documents said, seeks to block an amendment to Chevron's shareholder rights plan that lowers to 10 percent, from 20 percent, the amount of stock held by a third party needed to begin anti-takeover provisions.

title: KEY RATES
49ers' Montana and Taylor Go Long and Rams Come Up Short
description: Joe Montana and John Taylor combined for touchdown passes of 92 and 95 yards as the San Francisco 49ers twice came back from 17-point deficits to beat the Los Angeles Rams, 30-27, tonight and clinch the National Football Conference West championship.

title: Aquino Should Get Tough, Say People Back Home
description: For three decades the lush rice farms, gracious old Spanish towns and horse-drawn carriages of central Luzon have been Aquino territory, the place where Benigno S. Aquino Jr. launched his political career and where his widow, Corazon, mustered the support to oust the repressive Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos nearly four years ago.

title: ETZ Lavud Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in U.S. dollars and reflected the rate of exchange of the Israeli shekel to the dollar on Sept. 30.

title: U.S. Needs a Formal Safe-Haven Policy Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Publishing Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Expos Sign Andujar
description: Joaquin Andujar, who is pitching for Gold Coast of the Senior Professional Baseball Association, agreed yesterday to a minor league contract with the Montreal Expos.

title: McKinney Fails Test
description: The winner of the bantamweight gold medal in the Seoul Olympics, Kennedy McKinney, faces a hearing in Las Vegas, Nev., Friday after testing positive for cocaine following his last fight, a four-round split decision victory on Oct. 31 over Jose Luis Martinez. McKinney, 5-0-1 as a pro, could be fined or face possible revocation of his boxing license when the matter goes before the Nevada State Athletic Commission.(AP)

title: Bright Ideas For Selling The Ordinary
description: WHEN the fountain pens are put away and the sketch pads stored, when copywriters kick off their shoes and talk honestly, there is one question they mull: Can a deodorant commercial be creative?

title: Japan Curbing Foreign Workers
description: Over the objections of groups representing foreign workers, Parliament has approved amendments to the immigration laws that would for the first time impose fines on Japanese companies that employ illegal foreign workers.

title: With New Boldness, Surgeons Create Patchwork Patients
description: WITH hearts, kidneys, livers and pancreases being transplanted almost routinely, surgeons are now forging ahead to give combinations of organs - as many as five at a time - to treat a wide variety of conditions ranging from birth defects to diabetes and cancer.

title: Pet Sets Off Moves Affecting 3 Agencies
description: Pet Inc. yesterday sent $45 million worth of familiar supermarket names, including its Progresso brands, tumbling into the laps of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/St. Louis and Waring & LaRosa. And in a related move, the $20 million-plus Ragu Foods account is leaving Waring, where it has been for 19 years, for J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. That agency was hired earlier in the year to do new product assignments for the Chesebrough-Pond's subsidiary.

title: Upheaval in the East; Yugoslav Rift Grows as Croatia Seeks Vote
description: The nation's political divisions seemed to widen today when the Communist Party in the republic of Croatia called for free multi-party elections next month and the leadership in the republic of Slovenia accused Serbia of seeking to break up the country.

title: Careers; Saving Jobs Through Use Of ESOP's
description: WITH so many jobs in jeopardy these days, Lee Smith, executive director of New York State's Industrial Cooperation Council, believes one approach to saving jobs and companies is through employee stock ownership plans, known as ESOP's.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE OF THE 16TH SPECIAL SESSION 3 P.M.

title: Intercontinental Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net loss The company said the increase in revenues and earnings in the latest quarter is primarily attributable to the inclusion of revenues of consolidated subsidiaries which it did not own in the year-ago period, and a gain on the sale of marketable securities.

title: Brother May Be Dropped From Suit
description: Federal officials are expected to drop William J. Keating as a defendant in a $1.1 billion civil lawsuit stemming from the failure of a savings and loan association run by his brother, Charles, The Detroit News reported today.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bulgaria's Communist Chief Plans To Relax Grip and Hold Elections
description: Yielding to popular demands for more democracy, Bulgaria's new leader said today that the Communist Party's monopoly on power should be abandoned and that free parliamentary elections should be held by next spring.

title: Stake in Lockheed COMPANY NEWSock Exchange trading.
description: Harold C. Simmons, a Dallas financier, has raised his stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 16.9 percent from 10.8 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons did not amend his previous statement that he has no immediate plans to take over the Calabasas, Calif., military contractor. Mr. Simmons has been buying Lockheed shares since the spring. The company's stock was unchanged today at $39.625 in New York St

title: Uncle Sugar, Uncle Milk
description: Christmas brings candy canes, chocolate bonbons - and a woeful tangle of Federal meddling. Candy makers' grief over sugar import quotas peaks during this big selling time. Milk chocolate makers suffer added grief this year, over milk quotas. What's happening is regulation gone haywire.

title: Upheaval in the East; I.M.F. Backs Poland's Effort for Western Aid
description: The International Monetary Fund signaled today that it would endorse Poland's efforts to convert to a market-oriented economy, unlocking billions of dollars of Western assistance for the country.

title: For Mild Depression, Caring Approach May Be as Effective as Therapy
description: MANY people who are mildly depressed can improve with minimal treatment in which they get regular support from a professional but receive no drugs or formal psychotherapy, researchers have found.

title: Dr. Aaron Gissen, 72, Anesthesiologist, Dies
description: Dr. Aaron J. Gissen, a former professor of anesthesiology at Harvard Medical School, died of rheumatic heart disease Sunday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 72 years old.

title: Special Sums Increase Gifts To Neediest
description: Most of the checks sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are made out for predictable amounts: $25, $100, $1,000, But some donors personalize their gifts with sums that have symbolic significance.

title: Dinkins Gets Candidate List For Top Police and Fire Posts
description: A screening panel considering candidates for New York City police commissioner proposed three yesterday for consideration by David N. Dinkins.

title: Max Grundig Is Dead at Age 81; Founded an Electronics Company
description: Max Grundig, a radio and television pioneer who founded a major producer of top-quality high fidelity systems and radios, died in a hospital on Friday. He was 81 years old.

title: Drunken Driving Is Still Big Killer, Bush Says
description: President Bush said today that despite a decline in deaths caused by drunken driving the problem remains ''as crippling as crack'' and is one of the most serious facing the nation.

title: British Retail Sales Off
description: British retail sales fell sharply last month as the Christmas shopping season began, the Government reported today, indicating gains in the battle against inflation. Official figures showed sales dropped eight-tenths of a percent in November from the previous month. Analysts had predicted an increase of one-tenth of a percent.

title: Student Is Acquitted Of Anti-Semitic Acts
description: The former president of the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York at Binghamton was acquitted today of painting anti-Semitic slurs on the walls of the group's campus office in 1988.

title: Hailing the Butchers of Beijing
description: Three bitter questions reverberate over the Bush Administration's startling overture to China:

title: William C. Woodward, Executive, 76
description: William Carl Woodward, a former executive with the Aluminum Company of America, died of respiratory arrest following surgery yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 76 years old and lived in Pittsburgh and Washington.

title: Hawkins Chemical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Chip Maker Posts Profit
description: As anticipated, the National Semiconductor Corporation returned to profitability in its second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 26.

title: Man-Copter's Flight: 7 Inches
description: One month after they first got off the ground, the California college students who built the only successful human-powered helicopter have made their achievement official.

title: Decaffeinated Coffee Caused Only Small Rise in 'Bad' Cholesterol
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East; In Face of Protests, East German Sports Leaders Agree to Resign, Papers Report
description: The political reforms sweeping across East Germany at breath-taking speed have apparently caught up to the nation's vaunted sports system.

title: Court Stops Work At Stewart Airport
description: Construction at Stewart International Airport near Newburgh must be stopped until the State Department of Transportation assesses the impact of the airport expansion on the environment, a State Supreme Court justice has ruled.

title: Review/Television; In Clips and Quotes, MTV Bids the 80's Farewell
description: Ronald Reagan on the Soviets: ''They are the focus of evil in the modern world.'' Beep. Ivan Boesky on capitalism: ''I'm proud of this nation. We can seek profit, and if we gain profit, that's even better.'' Beep. David Byrne on drug dealing: ''It's a bigger business than GM, and they don't even advertise.'' Beep. The Rev. Jesse Jackson on the Reagan era: ''A dream for relatively few, a nightmare for millions.'' Beep.

title: Chess
description: Bobby Fischer advised a junior colleague who was pondering the purchase of a new book on openings a number of years ago: ''Get it. If it wins one game for you, it more than pays for itself.''

title: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $640,000, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of Thriftway Inns property.

title: Upheaval in the East; Opponents of Communist Candidates Post Big Gains in Voting in 2 Baltic Republics
description: A political group challenging the Communist Party's monopoly on power seemed to have won a resounding victory in elections for Latvian city and regional councils on Sunday, according to preliminary results today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asea Brown Boveri, an engineering technology company, said it would acquire W+E Umwelttechnik A.G., a Swiss developer of waste technology, from Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala. Terms were not disclosed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Douglas Elliman & Co., a residential brokerage and management company, named Alan Rogers managing director and Robert Rand Lewis general counsel and managing director.

title: Soviets Trying to Become Team Player in Mideast
description: Asserting that it wants to be a force for moderation in the Middle East, the Soviet Union has moved away from a policy of confrontation with the United States and now indicates that it prefers partnership with Washington in the diplomacy of the region.

title: Michaels Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Neutrogena Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $345,000, or 1 cent a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting for income taxes. Prior year share earnings have been restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed March 31, 1989.

title: A Thorny East Bloc Issue: Replacing Hated Managers
description: As Poland, Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European nations move away from communism, they are confronting a thorny problem: what to do with the thousands of managers hand-picked by the Communist Party to run their nations' enterprises.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Shift on Middle East Moscow has moved away from a policy of confrontation in the Middle East, signaling it prefers to work with Washington in the region. Page A10. Iowa's Captain Testifies The captain of the battleship said he was not certain who caused the fatal explosion last April. Page A20. Verdict in Officer's Death A drug dealer was convicted of ordering the murder of Officer Edward Byrne in Queens last year. Page B1. Welfare Goal Endangered Teen-age mothers may refuse to sign up for job programs because of a lack of child care. Page A20.

title: South Africa Acquits Police in Killing
description: Twelve policemen and an army officer were acquitted of murder today in the first such private prosecution brought in South Africa.

title: City Tries Sterilization for an Animal Problem
description: The patient having her Fallopian tubes tied on the operating table had been pulled from a trap near the South Platte River that morning. Poking out from under the surgical cloth was her flat paddle of a tail.

title: Our Towns; Housing Distress: When Mortgages Are Out of Reach
description: Patrolman Michael Zaicek is 27 years old and has been a member of the Yorktown police force for three years. He is getting married soon, and until three months ago had been sharing a house with several others and commuting 15 miles to work. Since he was a police officer and didn't own a house, he was eligible for one of the first seven units up for sale under the affordable housing program in this northern Westchester County town of 32,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES The head of Columbia Savings and Loan is resigning as part of a sweeping effort to disentangle the institution's huge ''junk bond'' portfolio from its savings and loan business. Thomas Spiegel, the primary architect of Columbia's strategy, said he would devote his time to setting up and managing an operation that would own the junk bond portfolio. [ Page D1. ] President Bush said for the first time that the bailout of the savings industry might not be enough to cover the actual cost of the industry's problems. [ D13. ] Two competing biotechnology companies have valid patents to a valuable new drug produced with recombinant DNA technology and used to combat anemia in patients suffering from kidney failure, a Federal magistrate ruled. The decision left neither Amgen nor Genetics Institute able to claim a clear victory. [ D1. ] BellSouth agreed to terminate its merger agreement with Lin, whose board recommended that Lin merge instead with McCaw Cellular. In return for ending its agreement with Lin, BellSouth will receive $66.5 million, and McCaw will contribute $26.5 million to a Los Angeles cellular phone company of which BellSouth owns 85 percent. [ D1. ] The British Government awarded licenses to build three wireless networks for telephone and information services to international consortiums that include Pacific Telesis, U S West and Cable and Wireless. [ D5. ] Wyse Technology will be sold to a group from Taiwan for $10 a share in cash, the company announced. The deal is believed to be the first tender offer for a publicly traded American company by a company from Taiwan. [ D5. ] The push by Pennsylvania banks to combine continued, as Pittsburgh's largest bank and its largest savings institution agreed to merge. [ D2. ] Ciba-Geigy will sell two electronic systems subsidiaries, including Spectra-Physics, to focus on its core pharmaceuticals, chemicals and vision care businesses. [ D5. ] A.T.& T. will cut about 8,500 positions in 1990, in addition to the 25,000 it eliminated this year. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Saudi Arabia's oil company is the largest in the world and three other national oil companies owned by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries now rank among the world's 10 largest, the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said. Their rankings reflect the expansion of the companies into refining and distribution in recent years. [ D1. ] The I.M.F. signaled it would give its approval to Poland's efforts to convert to a market-oriented economy, unlocking billions of dollars of Western assistance for the beleaguered country. [ A17. ] The U.S. seems certain to overtake West Germany as the world's biggest exporter this year, the head of GATT said. [ D9. ] MARKETS

title: The Storming of St. Pat's
description: The demonstrators who stormed St. Patrick's Cathedral Sunday may have hoped to inspire sympathy for the problems of homosexuals in New York City and resistance to the Catholic Church's positions on abortion. They mostly brought discredit on themselves for demonstrating in a way that obstructs consideration of their arguments.

title: Osmund A. Leahy, 74, Retired Army General
description: Osmund A. Leahy, a retired Army major general, died of cancer Saturday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Travel Agents Agree to Merge
description: Thomas Cook Travel Inc. has agreed to merge with Crimson Travel Service and Heritage Travel in a deal that will create the third-largest travel agency in the United States, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Dow Off 3.20 as Technology Stocks Decline
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday, with the downturn sharpest in the technology sector. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.20 points, to 2,728.24.

title: Employer Group Calls Westchester's $1 Billion Budget 'Appalling'
description: An organization representing Westchester's major employers today described County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed billion-dollar budget for 1990 as ''appalling'' and recommended that the county legislature reject it.

title: Upheaval in the East; In a School, Revolution's Workshop
description: For the students of the Higher School of Applied Arts, the nationwide student strike that began on Nov. 20 has meant nothing but work, and they love it.

title: Official in Illinois Is Accused In Fire Deaths of 4 Children
description: A man whose three children died in a fire has been charged with murder and aggravated arson in connection with their deaths and the death of a fourth child, the authorities said today.

title: Surgery Not Required For Injured Tomba
description: Alberto Tomba, the two-time Olympic gold medalist from Italy who on Sunday broke his left collarbone in a fall at Val d'Isere, France, will be sidelined for at least a month. But Dr. Giorgio Fontanesi, a physician at the clinic where Tomba was taken after the accident, said the 22-year-old skier would not need surgery as was feared after his tumble during a World Cup super-giant slalom.

title: Child Falls From Helicopter
description: A 9-year-old girl being airlifted for a sprained ankle fell from a helicopter's air-rescue litter, suffering serious head and internal injuries. Debbie Baisa was in critical but stable condition today at William Beaumont Army Medical Center after the accident on Saturday. Manny Baisa, the girl's grandfather, said the girl, who fell about 30 feet, underwent surgery for a broken hip Sunday, after having surgery earlier for her head and internal bleeding.

title: Village Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Village Bank is a wholly owned subsidiary of Village Financial Services Ltd., which is traded on the Nasdaq list. Village Financial announced on Dec. 4 that it had completed the acquisition of Village Bank upon the bank's conversion from a New York chartered mutual savings to a New York chartered stock savings bank.

title: Peary Made It to the Pole After All, Study Concludes
description: Robert E. Peary's polar expedition reached the North Pole in 1909 just as the explorer said, according to a study made public today that used new scientific methods to re-examine the evidence.

title: 23 Promoted At Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had appointed two vice chairmen and 21 managing directors.

title: American Medical
description: American Medical International Inc. said it intends to sell 12 acute-care and psychiatric hospitals in the United States as part of its plan to sell assets in the wake of a change of ownership. The hospitals to be sold have nearly 1,800 beds. ''The proposed divestitures are integral to our plan to concentrate management and financial resources on the devlopment of a small group of acure-care hospitals,'' said Harry J. Gray, American Medical's chairman. He said the company intends to retain about 40 acute-care hospitals. American Medical, which was sold to an investor group in October, has already sold or signed agreements to sell $200 million worth of properties.

title: Upheaval in the East; Rumania Ejects Journalists
description: Three Hungarian journalists who went to Rumania last week to meet a dissident clergyman were detained by the police, expelled from the country and banned from re-entering for five years, it was reported today. The Rumanian police also confiscated their film and video cassettes. Szilvia Izso, a reporter for Nepszabadsag, the official newspaper of the ruling Socialist Party, and two other reporters of a regional newspaper went to Rumania on Thursday to interview the Rev. Laszlo Toekes, a Protestant clergyman who has been harassed for his criticism of human rights violations in Rumania.

title: A Savings Resignation Over 'Junk'
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Thomas Spiegel, said today that he would resign at the end of the year as part of a sweeping effort to disentangle the huge ''junk bond'' portfolio of the institution from its savings and loan business.

title: BellSouth Terminates Pact With Lin
description: The BellSouth Corporation agreed today to terminate its merger agreement with the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, whose board recommended last week that Lin merge instead with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.

title: Labor Board Member Faulted
description: A member of the State Labor Relations Board used state workers to help organize a union leader's golf tournament and cast the critical vote in a decision favoring her brother's union, the state Inspector General said today.

title: Bush Versus Quayle?
description: When he surprised the world by choosing Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana as his running mate, George Bush said he wanted a Vice President just like he himself had been in the Reagan Administration - loyal, quiet and on the team.

title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven
description: BIOLOGISTS from the United States and Guam are ready to release six Guam rails, an endangered bird that has been preserved only in zoos, into the wild.

title: Japan Has No Monopoly on Superconductivity
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 113, Jazz 110: Craig Ehlo made two 3-point shots for Cleveland in the final 4.3 seconds of overtime, including the game-winner as time expired last night. Bobby Hansen's fifth 3-point basket of the game put Utah ahead by 110-107 with 1 minute 9 seconds remaining. Both teams failed to score on possessions before Ehlo's 3-pointer tied the score. After Utah took a timeout, Cleveland's Reggie Williams blocked Darrell Griffith's jump shot and the Cavaliers controlled the ball and called time out with 1.5 seconds left. Ehlo inbounded to Larry Nance, who passed back to Ehlo beyond the top of the key for the final shot. Mark Price led Cleveland with 27 points. Karl Malone scored 32 points for the Jazz. (AP) N.H.L. Maple Leafs 3, Blues 1: Mark Laforest made 35 saves in the first two periods to keep Toronto in the game and the Maple Leafs got two third-period goals from Gary Leeman to beat visiting St. Louis last night. The Maple Leafs' third consecutive victory left them 1 point behind the third-place Blues in the Norris Division.(AP) Kings 2, Canadiens 2: Mikko Makela's third-period goal enabled Los Angeles to tie the Canadiens, and break a losing streak in Montreal at five games.(AP) Flames 3, Oilers 3: Martin Gelinas, a rookie forward, scored with 28 seconds left in the third period as Edmonton tied visiting Calgary.(AP) EXHIBITION HOCKEY Khimik 4, Red Wings 2: Vladimir Fedosov scored two goals to lead Khimik in the second of four games on the Soviet team's six-game N.H.L. tour. Khimik outshot the Red Wings, 37-24.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Michigan 84, Chicago State 57: Demetrius Calip, starting for the injured All-American Rumeal Robinson, scored all 11 of his points in the first half as sixth-ranked Michigan routed Chicago State last night. Sean Higgins led Michigan (6-1) with 16 points. Chicago State (1-6) was paced by Gerald Collins, who scored 15 points.(AP) Georgia Tech 101, North Carolina A. & T. 87: Brian Oliver scored 33 points and Dennis Scott added 29 as 15th-ranked Georgia Tech beat North Carolina A. & T. Scott opened the second half by hitting five 3-point shots in the first 10 minutes. Kenny Anderson, a freshman, scored 20 points. Glenn Taggart scored 29 points for the Aggies (1-5). (AP) WOMEN'S BASKETBALL Texas 85, Rutgers 63: Vicki Hall, a sophomore, netted 21 points and 11 rebound to lead the 11th-ranked Texas Lady Longhorns last night at Rutgers. Cheryl Cop, a freshman point guard, scored 21 points for Rutgers.(AP) HORSE RACING Lady Professional Leads All the Way: Roger Laurin's Lady Professional, coupled in the wagering with Samra, led from start to finish yesterday to carry 112 pounds and Francisco Medero to a 3 1/2-length victory at Aqueduct in the $34,000 Long Legend purse for fillies and mares, 3 years old and up. Private Theatrics, the favorite, was runner-up in the five-horse field, half a length ahead of Samra. Lady Professional covered the mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:48 2/5 to earn $20,400 with her fourth victory in 17 starts this year. The winning entry returned $10.80 and $3.20.(AP)

title: Talking Business with Cooper of Trimedyne; Laser Technology To Treat Disease
description: Lasers now constitute a $700 million market that analysts expect to grow into the billions. Howard K. Cooper, president and chief executive of Trimedyne Inc., a Tustin, Calif., company that was a pioneer in the development of laser technology in the treatment of cardiovascular disease, recently discussed the outlook for medical uses of the laser, an acronym for light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation. By diagnostic category, cardiovascular disease is the single most costly ailment in the United States, accounting for $85 billion a year, or 15 percent of the total amount spent by Americans on health care. Q. What is spurring the growing use of lasers? A. First, it is important to understand that a laser produces a high-intensity beam of light that can perform a host of functions, including bar-code scanning in supermarkets, etching of surface-mount semiconductors in electronics manufacturing and lighting for multimedia entertainment. The sheer diversity of the market is contributing to the rapid growth. As an alternative to surgery, laser procedures typically offer safer and less invasive treatments, which translate into shorter hospital stays and, in many cases, the avoidance of surgery. Q. How are lasers used to treat disease? A. Let's use a specific example to illustrate the technique. Without lasers, a patient with atherosclerosis, a degenerative vascular disease that narrows arteries in the heart, brain, legs and other parts of the body, might be treated by bypass surgery. In more severe cases, amputation might be the only alternative. In laser treatment, a fiber-optic probe is inserted into an artery through a small puncture in the arm or leg. The probe is steered through the cardiovascular system to the blockage formed by thickened fatty deposits, commonly referred to as plaque, which blocks the blood flow. To vaporize the plaque, the probe is heated by a steady flow of energy from the laser system. Q. How does the cost of laser treatment compare with standard surgery? A. Typically, laser treatment is substantially less expensive. The average cost of treating a blocked leg artery with a laser is $7,000, while major surgery would cost an average of $27,000. Q. How successful is the laser treatment? A. Lately, this has become a major point of debate within the medical community. In my opinion, the decision on whether or not to use a laser should be made on a case-by-case basis. Since 1987, about 30,000 cardiovascular disease cases have been successfully treated with laser technology, and many patients were spared major surgery. Each month, another 1,000 to 1,500 new cases are treated. In general, success depends upon several factors, including the severity of the patient's blockage. Q. What is the risk in laser treatment compared with invasive procedures? A. There is nothing to indicate that the complications experienced in laser treatment are any worse than those that might be encountered through the use of balloon angioplasty. Q. Are there different types of lasers? A. Yes. In treating cardiovascular disease, the most widely used is the hot-tip laser - a vaporizer of plaque through a steady flow of energy - which was first approved for marketing by the Food and Drug Adminstration in 1987. There are other laser systems in varying developmental stages, including the cold- and cool-tip lasers that release energy impulses to achieve the same objective. Q. Can any of these lasers be used to unclog plaque in the heart arteries? A. Separate clinical trials using either the hot- or cold-tip laser in coronary cases are currently under way. Given the unique structure of the heart arteries, smaller laser probes are used in coronary arteries. The first F.D.A. approval of lasers for coronary cases could occur in 1990. Q. Looking out to 1995, how big will the total market for lasers be and what share will medical applications have? A. Five years can be an eternity for any technology, so it is really impossible to say. As laser technology continues to be refined, however, I think many more applications will be discovered. In the health and medical area, you will see a greater embracement of laser-based procedures, particularly among physicians and hospital adminstrators. As with any new approach, there is a tendency to resist change, and yet change is inevitable.

title: Upheaval in the East; From All Czechoslovakia, a Joyful Noise
description: Millions of Czechs and Slovaks celebrated their country's dramatic political changes with five minutes of pandemonium at midday today.

title: Japan Has No Monopoly on Superconductivity; U.S. Semiconductors
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh Look in Dressing: The Dress
description: Is the dress bounding back into fashion's foreground after a couple of decades on the back burner? Donna Karan is one of many influential designers who think it is, citing the easy, nonrestrictive shapes that fit comfortably into women's active lives.

title: Dealer Guilty Of Ordering Officer Killed
description: Howard (Pappy) Mason was convicted in a Federal court yesterday of directing a racketeering enterprise - a violent crack operation in Jamaica, Queens - and of ordering the 1988 murder of a young New York City police officer to maintain and enhance his criminal position.

title: Ex-Hoechst Executive To Head Unit of Akzo
description: Richard M. Clarke, a former vice chairman of the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, has been named president and chief executive of Akzo America Inc., the North American unit of the Dutch chemical company Akzo N.V.

title: More Obesity Found Among Hispanic Americans
description: A new survey has found that Hispanic Americans, on the average, tend to be more overweight than other Americans.

title: For Lyme Disease, a Promising Test
description: GOVERNMENT scientists have developed a sensitive new test for the bacterium that causes Lyme disease that one day might help in diagnosing the mysterious condition and in charting its spread to new areas.

title: Reviews/Music; 7 Soloists in Aggregate Play An Evening of Brahms
description: Much of the memorable chamber music literature was written before permanent and professional ensembles ever existed. Beethoven had no Juilliard Quartet at his service nor Haydn a Beaux Arts Trio. Individuals gathered to perform their music, often with a minimum of rehearsal. A spirit of adventure (or misadventure) was always in the air.

title: Upheaval in the East; Czechoslovakia's New Cabinet
description: Communist Party Prime Minister - Marian Calfa First Deputy Prime Minister - Walter Kamarek (Proposed by the opposition) Deputy Prime Minister - Frantisek Pitra (head of Czech regional government) Deputy Prime Minister for State Planning Commission - Vladimir Dlouhy (supported by the opposition) Defense Minister - Miroslav Vacek Foreign Trade Minister - Andrej Barcak Transportation and Communications Minister - Frantisek Podlena Engineering Minister - Ladislav Vodrazka Energy Minister - Frantisek Pinc In addition, the Communist head of the Slovak regional government will be named a Deputy Prime Minister Wednesday. People's Party Deputy Prime Minister for Scientific and Technological Development - Frantisek Reichel (supported by the opposition) Minister Without Portfolio - Richard Sacher (supported by the opposition) Socialist Party Deputy Prime Minister for Agriculture - Oldrich Bursky Minister of Price Controls - Ladislav Dvorak Unaffiliated First Deputy Prime Minister - Jan Carnogursky (proposed by the opposition) Deputy Prime Minister - Josef Hromadka Foreign Minister - Jiri Dienstbier (proposed by the opposition) Finance Minister - Vaclav Klaus, (proposed by the opposition) Labor and Social Affairs Minister - Petr Miller (proposed by the opposition) Minister of People's Control (Treasury) - Kvetoslava Korinkova Minister Without Portfolio - Robert Martinko The Interior Ministry, which runs the nation's secret and uniformed police, will be run by Calfa, Kamarek and Carnogursky

title: Frank A. Gulotta, 82, Ex-New York Justice
description: Frank A. Gulotta, a former presiding justice of the appellate division of the New York State Supreme Court and the father of the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, died of complications of diabetes on Sunday at the Franklin Hospital Medical Center in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Lynbrook, L.I.

title: LTX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform to current year operations.

title: News Summary
description: West German leader Helmut Kohl softened a vital element of his vision of German reunification. Taking account of foreign concerns, he eased away from his notion of an early ''confederation'' of the two German states. Page A1 Bonn's Social Democrats try to upstage Kohl on reunification A16 German reunification is not an issue solely for Germans, but must be decided in consultation with NATO, the Soviet Union and other European nations, Secretary of State Baker said. A16 Facing protests, East German sports officials agree to resign A16 The new Soviet Congress reconvenes today for a second session. Coming at a critical juncture amid the upheaval in Eastern Europe, the session will probably show more pessimism and doubt than the inaugural session last spring. A18 Communists' opponents appear victorious in two Baltic states A18 Bulgarian Communists' monopoly on political power should be abandoned and free elections should be held by next spring, said the nation's new President and Communist Party chief. A1 Millions of Czechs and Slovaks celebrated their country's dramatic political changes with five minutes of pandemonium that welcomed the installation of a Cabinet without a Communist majority. A17 In a Prague school, revolution's workshop A17 I.M.F. backs Poland's effort for Western aid A17 Forced repatriation of Vietnamese from Hong Kong began just before dawn yesterday. Prison officers herded 51 refugees aboard an airplane bound for the nation they risked their lives fleeing. A1 Japan curbing foreign workers A6 The decision to send aides to China was defended by President Bush. He rejected criticism that he has forgiven Chinese leaders for the June massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators. A9 Aquino should get tough, say people back home A8 In the Middle East, the Soviet Union has moved toward diplomatic partnership, instead of political confrontation with the United States. While Israel is gaining improved relations with Moscow, nations like Syria and Libya are losing a mighty ally. A10 Quayle says U.S. seeks repeal of U.N. condemnation of Zionism A5 Egypt and Syria reopen air links A11 The rising dominance of OPEC in oil market D1 Deadline passes in India with no word on captive A13 Pre-election violence in Nicaragua overshadowed the second day of a regional summit meeting in Costa Rica. A clash between Sandinista youths and Government opponents left one person dead and at least 11 others wounded. A3 South Africa acquits police in killing A3 Killing of human rights workers on the rise A14 Left and right in Greece denounce a king's offer to return A7 National A20-23, B11-12 A plan to restructure the U.S. Army

title: Justices Expand Power To Shield Federal Data
description: The Supreme Court today gave Federal agencies new discretion under the Freedom of Information Act to shield from disclosure some records bearing on criminal investigations.

title: Gathers Out of Hospital
description: The Loyola Marymount center Hank Gathers, who collapsed on the court during the Lions' 104-101 victory over the University of California at Santa Barbara on Saturday night, was released yesterday from Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, Calif. Gathers, who led the nation in scoring and rebounding as a junior last season, is awaiting a diagnosis from Dr. Michael Mellman, the school announced.

title: Accounts
description: * Catskill Association of Tourism Services to Lipman, Richmond, Greene.

title: Rebound Is Predicted In Advertiser Spending
description: Advertiser spending in the United States in 1989 has not kept pace with the increase in the gross national product, although it should rebound in 1990, said Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson. Mr. Coen, speaking yesterday at the annual Paine Webber media conference in New York, attributed the decline this year primarily to the normal post-Olympic-year drop in advertising and to sluggish newspaper advertising sales.

title: Merger of First Federal And Pittsburgh National
description: The push by Pennsylvania banks to combine and increase their share of local markets continued yesterday, as Pittsburgh's largest bank and largest savings and loan agreed to merge.

title: Review/Theater; 40's Hollywood Doubly Mocked In Gelbart's 'City of Angels'
description: There's nothing novel about show-stopping songs and performances in Broadway musicals, but how long has it been since a musical was brought to a halt by riotous jokes? If you ask me, one would have to travel back to the 1960's - to ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and ''Little Me'' - to find a musical as flat-out funny as ''City of Angels,'' the new show about old Hollywood that arrived last night at the Virginia Theater.

title: Home Shopping Network Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $5 million, or 5 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $4.7 million, or 5 cents a share, for year-ago period, both reflected repurchase of long- term obligations.

title: Japan Growth Forecast
description: Japan's gross national product is expected to grow 5 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1, according to a research report released today.
