The Research Institute on the National Economy, a leading independent research center, said growth would be helped by consumer demand and by corporations' capital spending on technological innovation. The report predicts that consumer prices in Japan will rise 2 percent in the year and that the nation's trade surplus will decline to $79.6 billion.

title: From Cold War to Nuclear Nostalgia
description: CHUCK Hansen lives in Sunnyvale, Calif., with 20 doves, 60 pigeons and about 5,000 (at last count) once-secret documents that detail the era when the United States exploded hundreds of nuclear weapons that filled the sky with blinding fire and radioactive clouds.

title: Ford-Jaguar
description: The Ford Motor Company has acquired a controlling interest in Jaguar P.L.C. as part of its $2.5 billion takeover of the British luxury car maker. Ford, the No. 2 United States auto maker, said that by the close of business Friday, it had acquired 77.4 percent of the outstanding shares of Jaguar stock, including the 13 percent it owned before Nov. 2.

title: Reform in East German Sports
description: The leadership of East Germany's national sports authority has agreed to resign, three newspapers reported. Page A16.

title: Laurentian Bank of Canada reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The bank said results for both periods included a number of unusual items that make year-to-year comparisons difficult. The bank said the unusual items resulted in a combined gain of $7.1 million in fiscal 1989 and $4.5 million in fiscal 1988.

title: Joseph R. Cloutier, 81, President Of Indianapolis Motor Speedway
description: Joseph R. Cloutier, who presided over extensive renovations and instigated a sharp increase in prize money during his 10 years as president of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, died today at his home. He was 81 years old.

title: Argentine Charged in Money Scheme Is Sent to U.S.
description: An Argentine man charged with laundering $250 million in cocaine proceeds through storefronts in Los Angeles and New York pleaded not guilty today in Federal court here, Judge William Keller ordered the man, Raul Silvio Vivas, held without bail on the argument by prosecutors that he is the mastermind of an international network. ''It is alleged that he devised the scheme and set it into motion,'' said Assistant United States Attorney Russell Hayman.

title: New Jersey Acts to Close Loophole Blamed in Dump Fire Under I-78
description: Both houses of the Legislature today unanimously passed bills intended to close a loophole that contributed to a trash fire that buckled Interstate 78 in Newark in August.

title: Sunbelt Nursery Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Upheaval in the East; Bonn's Social Democrats Trying To Upstage Kohl on Reunification
description: West Germany's Social Democratic Party intensified the national political debate today by taking credit for the ideas advanced by Chancellor Helmut Kohl in his vision of German unification just as he was softening aspects of the proposal.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS AIDES' CHINA VISIT
description: President Bush today strongly defended his decision to send two senior aides to Beijing last weekend, rejecting criticism that he has forgiven Chinese leaders for the killing of democracy demonstrators there in June.

title: Reviews/Music; Rockin' Dopsie and Sons Crank Up the Zydeco Beat
description: Good zydeco music moves like a trusty old tractor: once it wheezes and clatters up to speed, it's just about unstoppable. Rockin' Dopsie and the Zydeco Twisters (formerly the Cajun Twisters), one of south Louisiana's top zydeco bands, cranked up the beat until listeners could hardly help dancing on Friday night at Tramps (45 West 21st Street), where the band is in residence through this Saturday night.

title: Vast Yellowstone Fire Now Seen as Unstoppable Natural Cataclysm
description: THE forest fires that swept vast areas of Yellowstone National Park in 1988 constituted a largely uncontrollable natural event that occurs once every 200 to 300 years, say two biologists who have spent more than a decade studying the ecology of the park.

title: Back-to-Nature Plan Pits Islanders vs. 'Mainlanders'
description: Seven miles of Great South Bay separate the ''mainland'' here from a handful of other communities in Islip Township - those on Fire Island. A conflicting vision of the future is threatening to widen that watery gulf, pitting summer residents on the island against year-round residents on the mainland.

title: Military Navigation Satellite Launched by Delta 2 Rocket
description: An Air Force Delta 2 rocket today launched a military navigation satellite that will join a network of spacecraft that tell American and allied military forces where they are within 50 feet anywhere in the world.

title: Empire Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $260,000 and $896,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After extraordinary charges of $466,000 for the quarter and $302,000 for the 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Books of The Times; Primo Levi and the Ghosts of Auschwitz
description: The Mirror Maker Stories and Essays By Primo Levi Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 176 pages. Schocken Books. $16.95.

title: Santa Cruz Journal; In Quake-Shaken Hills, A New Peril: Landslides
description: The roads are mostly open and the National Guard disaster units moved on weeks ago, but for several hundred families near the summit of the Santa Cruz Mountains, the phrase ''returned to normal'' still rings hollow.

title: Iowa Captain Doubts Sailor Named by Inquiry Set Blast
description: The captain of the battleship Iowa disagreed today with a Navy conclusion that Petty Officer Clayton M. Hartwig was the most likely culprit for the explosion that killed 47 men in a gun turret on the ship.

title: Corsicans Blow Up Houses
description: Corsican separatist guerrillas blew up about 40 vacation homes under construction today and pledged to continue fighting foreign investment on the French Mediterranean island. Armed and hooded members of the Corsican National Liberation Front staged the attack on the Oasis resort, a complex of 120 homes being built near the northwest port of Calvi. No one was hurt but a third of the houses were destroyed.

title: School Union Rebuffs Request by Fernandez
description: In an incident that suggests the battles awaiting Joseph A. Fernandez as he tries to streamline the New York City Board of Education, a union has advised 60 of the top 300 board officials not to sign letters of resignation that the incoming Chancellor had sought.

title: Review/Art; 20-th Century Works Collected By a Couple With a Shared Vision
description: It is not often that the middle of December brings us an exhibition as remarkable as ''20th-Century Modern Masters: The Jacques and Natasha Gelman Collection,'' which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum. It is a show to which every informed student of modern art has long looked forward.

title: Bridge
description: Attempts to arrest the gentle American trend toward a higher average age of bridge players, and an impending decline in numbers, hinge on one question: How can more people be induced to take the initial step, and exchange the role of non-player for that of player?

title: Foreigners As Owners
description: Foreign ownership of United States factories, banks and other businesses has increased in recent years, but most fears about adverse economic consequences from foreign control are unwarranted, according to a study released today by a Washington research group.

title: Mark Davis Signs With Royals for $13 Million
description: The great chase for Mark Davis ended yesterday when the Kansas City Royals signed the left-handed relief pitcher for four years for a total of $13 million, at an annual average of $3.25 million, more than five times his 1989 salary. With the signing, the Royals brought two reigning winners of the Cy Young Award together on the same pitching staff for the first time in baseball history.

title: Cardinal Says He Won't Yield to Protests
description: Responding to the arrests Sunday of more than 100 people protesting his statements on homosexuality, AIDS and abortion, John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that his approach could be changed only ''over my dead body.''

title: National Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net loss and after income of $11.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from discontinued operations of the information sytems group. c-After a loss of $32.9 million from discontinued operations of the information systems group. Share earnings reflected preferred stock dividend requirements.

title: Gunman Is Slain by Officers At Brooklyn Housing Project
description: A man armed with a gun was shot and killed by anti-crime housing police officers last night in the Van Dyke Housing in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: A Woman's Risk of Diabetes Rises With Each Pregnancy
description: THE more times a woman is pregnant, the higher her risks of developing diabetes and impaired glucose tolerance, a precursor to diabetes, researchers at the University of California in San Diego, have concluded.

title: Cairo Journal; Will the Bureaucrats Beach the Nile's Gondoliers?
description: What gondolas are to Venice, feluccas are to the Nile. But while Venice fights pollution and erosion, it is a wave of bureaucracy that threatens the lateen-sailed phantoms of Africa's longest river.

title: Ciba-Geigy to Sell 2 Electronics Divisions
description: Ciba-Geigy Ltd. said today that it plans to sell two of its electronic systems subsidiaries, including Spectra-Physics of San Jose Calif., to focus on its core pharmaceuticals, chemicals and vision care businesses.

title: Grumman Girds for Arms Cuts
description: The Pentagon budget cuts proposed by the Bush Administration are rattling the entire weapons industry, but nowhere are the tremors being felt more strongly than at the headquarters of the Grumman Corporation here.

title: Reports of Congenital Syphilis Rise
description: An increasing number of women trading sex for cocaine and its crack derivative are passing on syphilis to their newborn babies, Federal health researchers say.

title: Denver Offense Is Its Weak Link
description: In three of the Denver Broncos' four losses the defense allowed 16, 16 and 14 points. And for the first time since John Elway arrived here in 1983, the offense is being called the team's weak link after it sputtered in the whipping wind and thick snow Sunday in a 14-7 loss to the Giants.

title: Bay Meadows-Calif Jockey reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Sunday about ''The Phil Springer Songbook - Second Edition,'' a revue that plays weekly at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street, misstated the performance day. It is Tuesday, not Wednesday.

title: Child Care Lack Dims Welfare Program's Future
description: Many teen-age mothers on welfare who lack adequate child care may refuse to sign up for new job and education programs mandated by the landmark 1988 welfare law, state welfare and education officials say.

title: Quayle Says U.S. Seeks Repeal Of U.N. Condemnation of Zionism
description: Vice President Dan Quayle formally committed the Bush Administration today to repealing a much criticized resolution of the United Nations General Assembly that defines Zionism as ''a form of racism.''

title: Reviews/Music; Making Connections of Sight and Sound
description: Friday night's concert at Florence Gould Hall invited the audience to hear pictures and see sounds. Here the New York Chamber Ensemble offered a series of pieces inspired by paintings, or at least the idea of painting.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising is celebrating the 10th anniversary of its public service campaign for the National Crime Prevention Council with a campaign entitled ''the McGruff Files,'' in which the anti-crime mascot relates tales of how the police and citizens work together to reduce crime.

title: WNEW-AM Sale Planned
description: WNEW-AM, the venerable New York station that carries big band music and New York Giants football, is being offered for sale.

title: More Pessimistic Dinkins Warns Of Fewer New Programs for City
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, adopting the fiscal pessimism that a faltering economy has forced upon him, warned New Yorkers yesterday not to expect major increases in city services next year and said, ''Government simply cannot afford to do all that needs to be done.''

title: Jewelmasters Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: b-After a gain of $106,000, or 5 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.

title: Official Concedes an Error With Asbestos From Blast
description: A top New York City environmental official acknowledged yesterday that a four-day delay in notifying Gramercy Park residents that a steam-pipe explosion had contaminated their neighborhood with asbestos was partly the result of ''a very unfortunate misdiagnosis'' by the city's own experts.

title: Review/Art; Holzer Makes the Guggenheim a Museum of Many Messages
description: With the exhibition of Jenny Holzer's work that opened yesterday at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the museum continues to kick up its heels, tossing off a severe case of the dulls that plagued it for the last several years as far as contemporary art was concerned. This is a fresh, eye-opening exhibition that brings to a broader public the work of the artist who has been selected to represent the United States at next summer's Venice Biennale.

title: New Contract Accepted By City Ballet Dancers
description: The dancers of the New York City Ballet have voted to accept a new, four-year contract. Previous contracts were for three years.

title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent
description: Two of Mexico's most powerful drug traffickers were found guilty today of the 1985 murder of a Federal drug agent from the United States. Each was sentenced to a prison term of more than 100 years, and millions of dollars in personal property was ordered seized.

title: Correction
description: A recipe for shrimp in beer batter in the 60-Minute Gourmet column last Wednesday misstated the amount of beer needed. It is 1 cup.

title: Louise Dahl-Wolfe, A Photographer, 94
description: Louise Dahl-Wolfe, one of the nation's best-known fashion and portrait photographers, died of pneumonia on Monday at the Allendale (N.J.) Nursing Home. She was 94 years old.

title: How to Handle Hate on Campus
description: How do America's colleges and universities -devoted to free inquiry and expression - cope with racist, sexist or homophobic speech? A recent Connecticut case illustrates the special complexities of the issue for public institutions.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Edisto Island, S.C.
description: LEAD: ON this quiet barrier island 40 miles south of Charleston - and 20 miles removed from Hurricane Hugo's swath of destruction - Philip Bardin is giving new meaning to grits.

title: This Wine Gift Travels Well
description: WORRIED about the appropriate wine gift? How about Bordeaux? Or Burgundy? No, not the wine, the places.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Ayer Executive Retires
description: LEAD: F. Bradley Lynch, vice president and director of corporate communications at Ayer, announced his retirement, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Lynch, who has been with Ayer for 14 years, will be replaced by M. Victoria Horstmann, a vice president of Ayer, who has been assistant director of corporate communications and manager of international communications.

title: Review/Film; 'Blaze,' a Story of a Rogue and a Stripper
description: The way ''Blaze'' remembers it, its heroine was just a simple country girl when she first got into stripteasing for a living. She was working as a waitress in a doughnut shop when a stranger asked if she wouldn't like to sing and play her guitar at his nightclub, and she thought that would be fine. But when she got there, complete with a new stage name (''Your eyes are like stars and your hair is like fire. . . .,'' said this poetic stranger), some of the fellas in the audience thought she ought to take off her clothes. So she did, but only to be polite. She was so polite she even folded up her clothes.

title: Woman, 23, Killed by Train
description: A Wallingford woman was killed this evening after signals at a railroad crossing apparently failed to work and an Amtrak train traveling 60 miles an hour slammed into the side of her car, the police said.

title: U.S. Savings Bond Sales
description: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $541 million in November, bringing to $116.96 billion the value of such bonds held by Americans, the Treasury Department reported Monday. Sales for the first two months of the 1990 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, totaled $1.13 billion, the same as in October and November 1988. Savings bonds now earn interest at a rate of 6.98 percent when held five years or longer.

title: I.B.M. System to Help the Deaf Use Telephones
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a computer system intended to make it much easier for deaf people to communicate by telephone.

title: Publisher's Stake In Gradco Systems
description: The Plenum Publishing Corporation, a New York-based publisher of scientific and technical journals, and its chairman, Martin E. Tash, have acquired 6.3 percent of Gradco Systems Inc. and said they might seek control of the office-automation company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Plenum said it began buying Gradco shares in September, after Keith B. Stewart, Gradco's chairman and chief executive, said he was pursuing a buyout of the company. Earlier this month, Mr. Stewart said he could not obtain financing.

title: Hanover Chooses New President
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation raided the senior management of its archrival, the Chemical Bank, yesterday, naming Thomas S. Johnson as president of Manufacturers Hanover. The bank's chairman, John F. McGillicuddy, said, ''We look to Tom as my successor.''

title: A Press Aide And Deputies To Arts Chief Are Named
description: The National Endowment for the Arts received White House approval yesterday for the appointment of Alvin S. Felzenberg as deputy chairman and Selina Ottum as deputy chairwoman for public partnership, said Joseph Slye, a press officer for the endowment.

title: SYRIANS CHALLENGE MUSLIM MILITANTS
description: With its troops in Lebanon reinforced for a possible confrontation with the Christian military commander, Syria is using its extra strength to move against another rival for influence in the country, the pro-Iranian Party of God.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Angotti in Buyback
description: LEAD: Angotti, Thomas, Hedge said yesterday that it had repurchased a minority share of the company's stock held by the Omnicom Group. No figures were released. Omnicom aqcuired the stake in June, when it bought the agency's parent company, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership of Britain. Barrie Hedge, president of Angotti, whose clients include KLM and Kirin beer, said his agency was concerned that prospective clients would be wary of conflicts with accounts held by other Omnicon agencies.

title: Review/Dance; Fancies of Rachael Milder
description: Successful fantastic or eccentric dances involve more than an assortment of strange steps or crazy notions. The steps and notions must be connected and developed in such a persuasive way that the choreographic fancies take flight and invite the viewer along for the ride. Rachael Milder's fancies remained resolutely earthbound in Wilder Milder Dances, the program this Chicago-based choreographer presented on Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Tracking The Hispanic TV Audience
description: LEAD: THE A. C. Nielsen Company has begun a pilot program here to test its new national television ratings system for Hispanic audiences. A nationwide system is scheduled for next year.

title: Building a 'Flying Train': U.S. Interest Grows, but Others Are Ahead
description: Visions of trains riding fast-moving magnetic fields instead of scraping along rails have fascinated scientists for decades. Now the Federal Government, which killed its first research programs for such ''flying trains'' in 1975, is reconsidering its approach. Manufacturers looking for new markets have formed a coalition to press for research money in the field. In addition, Government officials, bankers and investors are showing up in growing numbers at seminars discussing the technology, known as magnetic levitation, or maglev for short.

title: Fishing Boat Dodges Gunfire and Canadian Navy
description: It is not unusual for Canadians and Americans to feud over fishing rights. Nor is it unusual for Canadian patrol boats to chase American vessels back to their own territorial waters.

title: Coping With Stress Over Exams and the Holiday
description: ''It's not that I necessarily have a problem,'' Marie-Christine David was saying. ''It's just that I have to stop leaving it all to the last minute.''

title: U.S. May Get Help
description: Help for the United States national team in an area of severe need -creating and scoring goals - could be on the way in the form of a million-dollar player. Roy Wegerle, the 25-year-old younger brother of the former Cosmos and Tampa Bay Rowdies player Steve Wegerle, was transferred from one English First Division club to another on Monday for $:1 million (about $1.6 million) and afterward said he wants to play for the United States in the 1990 World Cup.

title: Turks Act Humanely To Kurdish Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; At the Met, A Chilling And Chill 'Dutchman'
description: The late Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production of ''Der Fliegende Hollander,'' imported by the Metropolitan Opera from San Francisco 10 years ago, was generally reviled. In his version of Wagner's opera, the action all took place in the head of the Steersman, who dreamed the whole thing. That was an extremely clever concept whose only flaw was that it did not work: attention focused on the psychology of a minor character rather than on the fateful liaison between the ghostly Dutchman and his fanatical lover, Senta.

title: 18 Nations Ban Steel Subsidies
description: The Bush Administration announced today that countries that provide two-thirds of the steel imported into America had signed agreements to end Government subsidies like low-cost loans and export incentive payments that help their steelmakers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Robert A. Johnson senior vice president.

title: Metro Datelines; Wiretaps on Gotti Allowed for Trial
description: In a ruling clearing the way for a trial, a judge said yesterday that prosecutors could use secretly recorded conversations as evidence against John Gotti, the organized-crime figure.

title: Talks on Prague Vote Stall On How to Pick a President
description: Negotiations between the Communist Party and the opposition stalled today over the election of a President to replace Gustav Husak, the hard-liner who resigned under pressure on Sunday.

title: Henry H. Reichhold Dies at 88; Founder of a Chemical Company
description: Henry Helmuth Reichhold, the founder of Reichhold Chemicals Inc. of White Plains, died Monday at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: Losses Widen for Campeau and 2 Retail Divisions
description: The Campeau Corporation, which owns Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and seven other department store chains around the country, yesterday reported greater losses for itself and its two retail subsidiaries in the third quarter.

title: Behind Bars, Helmsley Faces Austere 7 1/2-Hour Workday
description: Unlike her 28-room residence in Greenwich, Conn., and her penthouse atop the Park Lane Hotel, there will be no swimming pool at any of the prisons where Leona Helmsely is likely to serve her sentence.

title: Border Patrol Reorganized
description: Rumania's hard-line Communist leadership has put its border guards under police supervision, the state press agency said today. It gave few details, but the move appears to have been meant to stop the growing number of illegal crossings by citizens fleeing political repression and economic hardship. The gymnast Nadia Comaneci defected on Nov. 30 and now is in the United States.

title: Review/Film; 'Miss Daisy,' Chamber Piece From the Stage
description: ''That car,'' says Miss Daisy, ''misbehaved.''

title: Mencken - Getting A Bum Rap?
description: In 1948, H. L. Mencken suffered a stroke that blocked his ability to read. For his last seven years, a man whose intellectual energy had been fueled by books could not comprehend a word on a printed page.

title: Pioneer Savings Bank F.S.B.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $1,880,000 from use of prior years' operating losses.

title: Continental Orders
description: Continental Airlines has ordered jet engines worth nearly $1.4 billion from CFM International to power up to 40 Airbus Industrie planes, the engine maker said. CFM International, a venture of the General Electric Company and Snecma of France, said Continental had ordered 20 planes powered by CF6-80E1 engines and 20 powered by CFM56-5C2 engines, with options to buy 20 more of each. The CF6-80E1 is set to go into service in late 1992, and the CFM56-5C2 is scheduled to go into service in 1991, the engine maker said.

title: Deutsche Bank Names New Leader
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest commercial bank, today named Hilmar Kopper as the successor to Alfred Herrhausen, who was murdered by terrorists on Nov. 30. In his new job, Mr. Kopper will head the biggest bank and one of the most powerful industrial empires in West Germany.

title: U.N. Plans Summit Talks on Saving Children
description: A ''world summit for children'' is being planned here next September to mobilize money and resources to save the lives of 50 million children, who the authorities predict would otherwise die in the next decade.

title: 30-Year Bonds For Central Power
description: The Central Power and Light Company has offered $150 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs
description: In a rare statement by a member of the judiciary, a Federal judge in Manhattan called last night for the legalization of all drugs that are now illegal, including marijuana, heroin and crack.

title: Core Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Full Slow Ahead in Germany
description: ''Wir sind ein Volk,'' proclaim the Christian Democratic party posters suddenly evident in Bonn: ''We are one people.'' That sentiment is so powerful that few West German politicians can resist it. But one people is not the same as one economy or one state. Once the rush of sentiment subsides, it will take time to work out the economic and political differences between the two Germanys. And the architects of a new international structure that can accommodate one Germany will need at least as much time.

title: Defense Works For Nets
description: Once again, a professional basketball team left Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight feeling frustrated and flustered. No, it was not the Nets. By holding the Philadelphia 76ers to 47 points in the last three quarters, New Jersey (6-13) cruised to a 97-82 victory, the Nets' third victory in their last five games. And the Nets did it with defense. They blocked 12 shots; they scored 27 points off of the 76ers' 19 turnovers, and they held Philadelphia to 39.3 percent shooting from the field.

title: Reviews/Jazz; Connick's Charismatic Piano Style
description: No other jazz performer in recent memory has enjoyed the meteoric success of Harry Connick Jr., the 22-year-old New Orleans-born pianist and singer who performed a sold-out concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening.

title: Schools and 'Clean' Asbestos: What Price Safety?
description: The Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph in northwestern Missouri will spend about $1.25 million this year, nearly 10 percent of its annual budget, to clean up asbestos in its 47 schools.

title: WINE TALK
description: THIS is the crucial time in the holiday season, the time when it becomes appallingly clear that the whole thing is going to cost far more than you anticipated, that you are over the limit on all your credit cards and, worst of all, that you really haven't even started to shop.

title: Sorting 4,000 Coats to Help the Needy Beat the Cold
description: As Marcia Williams sorted the down jackets, wool and leather coats and an occasional fur, and put them in large plastic bags, she thought about all the coatless New Yorkers she had seen this fall.

title: Yankees Add Leary To Starting Rotation
description: On the day after they lost any chance of signing Mark Davis, the hottest pitcher in the free-agent market, the Yankees moved into the trading market yesterday and sent two of their prime prospects to the Cincinnati Reds for Tim Leary, the onetime prodigy of the Mets who has pitched for four teams in an unfulfilled career in the big leagues.

title: Boggs Settlement
description: Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox, a five-time American League batting champion, has reportedly settled an 18-month palimony battle with Margo Adams, his former companion on road trips, according to an article in The Boston Globe. The newspaper said that it was told by an unidentified source that a sum of money was agreed on but that the judge ordered the parties not to discuss the outcome of a settlement hearing last Friday in Orange County Superior Court in California.(AP)

title: French Honor an Abbot the Church Dislikes
description: After an exhausting calendar of events, France's bicentennial celebrations ended appropriately today in an argument over history, with the Roman Catholic Church having the last word that the French Revolution was perhaps not such a good thing after all.

title: Leonard Burness, Internist, 80
description: Dr. Leonard Burness, a retired New York internist, died on Nov. 29 at the British Clinic in Mallorca, Spain, as a result of a fall six months ago. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan and on Mallorca.

title: Straphangers Shouldn't Pay to Build a Vast Transit Bureaucracy; Lower the Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Ideas Are All Divac Needs to Be a True Laker
description: It was only in the days after the Lakers had selected Vlade Divac in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft last June that Mitch Kupchak at last got through by phone to the 21-year-old center in Yugoslavia.

title: 5 Latin Leaders Urge Disbanding of Contras and Salvador Rebels
description: Five Central American presidents signed a broad new peace agreement today calling for international control of all aid to the United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels and immediate steps toward the demobilization of leftist guerrilla forces in El Salvador.

title: Roasts: A User's Guide to Techniques and Oven Times
description: THE precise technique for roasting meat varies slightly from cut to cut. The recommendations listed here are based on interviews with three dozen chefs and butchers and nearly 100 hours of testing.

title: Rogue Computer Disks Distributed in Europe
description: A computer disk containing a destructive program known as a Trojan horse has been mailed to computer users in at least four European countries.

title: Bush to Attend Talks in Colombia
description: A summit meeting on drugs to be attended by President Bush and the leaders of the three major Latin American drug-producing countries will take place in February in Cartagena, Colombia, a United States official said today.

title:
Metro Datelines;
False Data Charged In School Board Case
description: LEAD: A Democratic district leader was charged yesterday with giving the city's Board of Education false information about her personal finances while she was on a local school board.

title: Reviews/Jazz; A Pair Of Opposites In a Reunion
description: On Dec. 15, 1979, the pianist Cecil Taylor and the drummer Max Roach played two concerts together; they reunited Friday night at Town Hall, and the sparks flew again.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Unlike many defendants who come before the court, you were not driven to this crime by financial need. Rather, your conduct was the product of naked greed. Throughout its course, you persisted in the arrogant belief that you were above the law.'' - Judge John M. Walker Jr., sentencing Leona Helmsley to prison. [ B1:5. ]

title: Review/Theater; On a Feather-Strewn Stage, Multiple Flights of Fancy
description: In a program note to ''Lava,'' Richard Foreman suggests that his new play ''may at first seem even a bit more perplexing than the 'unbalancing acts' that are performed'' in his other works. Theatergoers are forewarned and forearmed. For 20 years, this author and director has been offering ideographic emanations of his inner life. In a sense, he posts road maps without destinations. As with ''Lava,'' the journey is intriguing, although the extent of the interest depends on one's willingness to indulge the playwright's fancifulness.

title: No One Can Control Runaway Medical Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: For Celebrations, Nothing Beats A Roast
description: ROASTS remain. A grand ode, an enduring symbol.

title: Accompaniments From A (Acorn Squash) to P (Popovers)
description: Hashed Brussels Sprouts Preparation time: 10 minutes Cooking time: 30 minutes 2 pounds brussels sprouts 3 tablespoons olive oil 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice 1 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper.

title: The Year Fall Fell
description: Another season is missing. The evidence is in this graph, which charts New York City's recent weather. October shows peak after peak of summer days. Winter isn't even supposed to start till next week, yet November plunged us prematurely into midwinter. Fall has been squeezed out.

title: Off-Duty Prison Guard Slain on Bronx Street
description: An off-duty state corrections officer was shot and killed near his home in the Bronx late yesterday, the police said.

title: Excerpts From Baker's Speech on Berlin and U.S. Role in Europe's Future
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at the Berlin Press Club, as provided by the Federal News Service:

title: N.C. State Is Placed on Probation for 2 Years
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association put North Carolina State's basketball team on two years' probation today and barred it from the 1990 N.C.A.A. tournament for violations that included the misuse of complimentary tickets and sneakers provided to the players.

title: 4 Miller & Rhoads Stores Sold to May
description: Four of the stores of Miller & Rhoads Inc. will be sold to the May Department Stores Company of St. Louis for about $22.7 million. The stores, two each in Richmond and Hampton Roads, will be added to the May-owned Hecht Company chain next month, said John E. Stokely, the president of Miller & Rhoads.

title: Polls Show Brazilian Leftist Candidate Closing Gap as Election Day Nears
description: Five days before Brazilians vote for President, polls indicate that the leftist candidate has suddenly risen within striking range of winning the race.

title: In Disorderly Contest, Devils Down Islanders
description: Two local teams reversed their recent streaks tonight when the Devils defeated the Islanders, 7-2, in a ragged and rugged affair at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Herring: Only A Pickled Fish, But One Wrapped in Tradition
description: TO the herring dealers in the heavily Hasidic neighborhood of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the weeks before Hanukkah are like a trip back to the turn of the century, when herring was a staple among Jews on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 9:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE OF THE 16TH SPECIAL SESSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Campbell Promotions
description: LEAD: Campbell-Mithun-Esty announced four senior management promotions: Harold J. Greer to executive vice president; John Neal to executive vice president and director of account services; Patricia Stewart to executive vice president and new business chairwoman, and Thomas H. Winner to executive vice president and director of marketing services.

title: Accord Backed in Little Rock Desegregation Suit
description: A Federal district judge approved a $129 million settlement of a desegregation suit involving the Little Rock schools Monday, but he assailed the school districts for suggesting that the money be used to retire debts.

title: San Francisco
description: CHESTNUT STREET between Pierce and Steiner Streets is a cozy, aromatic stretch of 50-year-old Italian delis and 100-year-old bakeries. Although the Oct. 17 earthquake caused extensive damage as close as a block away, business on this Marina District street recovered quickly, as soon as power was restored.

title: Baker, in Berlin, Outlines a Plan To Make NATO a Political Group
description: Seeking to give some American direction to the rapidly changing events in Europe, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today outlined proposals for transforming NATO from a primarily military organization to a political alliance.

title: Report Faults Khartoum Militias
description: Militias armed by successive Sudanese governments have killed tens of thousands of civilians in the Sudanese civil war over the last six years, Amnesty International said today.

title: Straphangers Shouldn't Pay to Build a Vast Transit Bureaucracy; Season Tickets
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Bars Proposed 15% Increase in Connecticut Rail Fare
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today blocked a 15 percent fare increase for Connecticut rail commuters that had been proposed to take effect on Jan. 1.

title: No More Aid For Bailout
description: The White House said today that President Bush had no plans to ask Congress for more money to close failed savings and loan institutions, despite his remark a day earlier that recent legislation may not provide enough.

title: Skeptics Are Challenging Dire 'Greenhouse' Views
description: As governments try to come to grips with what is widely depicted as a potentially catastrophic warming of the Earth's surface, dissenting scientists are challenging what they see as unnecessarily gloomy predictions.

title: No One Can Control Runaway Medical Costs; Diagnosing Ulcers
description: To the Editor:

title: Slump in 'Junk Bonds' Adding to Drexel's Woes
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house that came to define the fast-money world of Wall Street in the 1980's, has seen its financial position deteriorate in recent months, and some employees, clients and competitors are privately questioning whether Drexel can survive as an independent firm.

title: Beijing View Of the Furor
description: President Bush is taking something of a chance in the surprise visit to Beijing over the weekend by a special emissary: that the Chinese leadership will quickly reduce the repression that has followed the crushing of democracy protests in June.

title: Economic Scene; Buyout Fever: The Patient Lives
description: WITH Michael Milken under indictment and the market for ''junk bonds'' under water, ''leverage'' has become a four-letter word. Corporate buyouts constructed on pyramids of debt, goes the conventional wisdom, have weakened once mighty industries and deprived Washington of billions in corporate income taxes.

title: INSIDE
description: Focus on a Housing Grant A company run by a friend of Samuel R. Pierce Jr. has long refused to account for a grant Mr. Pierce awarded as Housing Secretary. Page A25. A Curb on Steel Subsidies The European Community and six other nations signed accords with the United States to end government subsidies to their steel industry. Page D1. AIDS Policy Challenged The National Commission on AIDS and other groups asked the Government to drop its policy limiting people infected with the AIDS virus from entering the country. Page B14. Central America Accord Five Central American Presidents signed a broad accord calling of international control of all aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. Page A14. Marrying for Success Many companies still expect men to wed by the age of 30, perceiving marriage as a sign of stability and dedication. The Living Section, page C1.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Valhi Withdrawal
description: Valhi Inc., a company controlled by Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, said it had withdrawn its offer to acquire its NL Industries subsidiary in a stock swap. The Dallas-based Valhi said investment bankers for the Houston-based oil and chemicals unit had decided that the company could not support the exchange ratio offer in the Valhi proposal. NL shares rose 12.5 cents each today, to $23.875, on the New York Stock Exchange while Valhi's also gained 12.5 cents each, to $16.375. Valhi, which owns 66 percent of NL Industries, had offered NL shareholders 1.5 shares of Valhi common stock for each NL share.

title: Disarmament Includes East German Politburo
description: It now turns out that the entire Politburo of the ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker had permits to carry pistols at all times and that most of them did.

title: Police Fire Hurts 50 South African Strikers
description: The police fired on striking black transport workers today, wounding 50, officials said, and a bomb exploded on a railway line near Cape Town, forcing the cancellation of rush-hour trains.

title: Metro Datelines; Contractor Killed In His Backyard
description: A 41-year-old decorating contractor was shot four times in the chest and killed by a lone gunman in his backyard in Queens late yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: East and West Germans Talk About Border Transportation
description: Officials from East and West Germany, hit by an explosion in cross-border traffic after an effective dismantling of their border, today discussed the problem of improving transport links.

title: Reviews/Music; More Nostalgia Than Rock In Paul McCartney's Return
description: Paul McCartney knows that his years with the Beatles made him a historic figure. On his current tour, which arrived at Madison Square Garden on Monday for the first of four nights, he wants to make sure everyone else knows, too. The concert starts with an 11-minute film of performances by the Beatles and by Mr. McCartney's 1970's band, Wings, alongside contemporary news footage. Yet the effect of, for instance, juxtaposing ''The Long and Winding Road'' with Vietnam War scenes, is to show Mr. McCartney crooning obliviously as people suffer and die.

title: Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. projected a decline in earnings in the first quarter of its 1990 fiscal year and said its sales would grow more slowly than had been predicted. The announcement came two weeks after a top executive said the company expected worldwide sales growth of more than 20 percent. Apple's stock dropped $3.25 a share today, to $36, in over-the-counter trading on volume of more than 9.1 million shares. Apple said its sales for the quarter ending on Dec. 29 would exceed the $1.40 billion for the corresponding quarter of the previous year, but the increase would be less than it had expected earlier. The revised sales figures, the company said, are likely to drive earnings below the $1.10-a-share of a year ago.

title: Marcella Cisney Dies; Stage Director Was 76
description: Marcella Cisney, a theater director and administrator, died of cancer on Friday at Yale-New Haven Hospital in Connecticut. She was 76 years old.

title: Couple Indicted in Child's Death in Queens
description: A 24-year-old woman and her male companion have been indicted on charges that they beat her 3-year-old son to death in April in the hotel room where they were living near La Guardia Airport, authorities said yesterday.

title: College Graduates Facing More Money and Fewer Jobs
description: College graduates next spring will earn more money but find fewer job opportunities, a survey of United States employers indicates.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about recruiting by Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins referred incorrectly in some editions to the background of Anthony E. Shorris, a candidate for budget director. He is a former deputy budget director.

title: Reviews/Television; Murky Questions on 'The Right to Die?'
description: Can television intelligently treat the sort of subject that lends itself to emotion-squeezing by the tabloid talk shows? Evidence that it can is available tonight at 9 on Channels 13 and 49.

title: Volkov Finds a Varied Niche
description: The Hawks' rookie shooting guard speaks English with a heavy accent. So does their rookie small forward, their rookie power forward and their rookie center.

title: 2 New Parties Formed in Serbia
description: Two independent opposition parties announced their formation in Serbia today, defying hard-line Communist policies in the largest Yugoslav republic.

title: ICO Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,259,000, or 9 cents a share, recognized on the completion of the refinancing of secured bank indebtedness in January 1989. c-Net income and included an extraordinary gain on bond debt restructuring of $11,795,000, or $1.54 a share.

title: Police Arrest a Newark Man In I-280 Bump-and-Rob Case
description: A man suspected of robbing motorists on Interstate 280 by bumping them with his car and holding them up after they had pulled over was arrested on Monday, the police said.

title: Book Notes
description: The Gift of Words

title: Review/Music; Marianne Faithfull Sings Weill's 'Seven Deadly Sins'
description: Periodically, in the world of popular music, some aspirant gets saddled with the title ''the new Bob Dylan.'' In the semi-classical, semi-popular world of Kurt Weill, there has been a parallel succession of ''new Lotte Lenyas.'' From Gisela May to Ute Lemper, from Julia Migenes to Teresa Stratas, they keep on coming. Now we've another claimant, perhaps the best one yet, in Marianne Faithfull.

title: Note and Bond Prices Unchanged
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds traded in a very narrow range again yesterday, with prices essentially unchanged on the day. Dealers, who are awaiting fresh economic data, largely ignored developments in foreign exchange markets, where the dollar was battered.

title: Report Finds Fault With E.M.S. Computers
description: New York City's ambulance service is ''totally unprepared'' to cope with a breakdown of its computerized dispatching system, an internal study by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation said.

title: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Mixed
description: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed again in the week ended yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Emerson Electric Company, the big St. Louis-based manufacturer of electrical and electronic products, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two industrial companies for a total of nearly $600 million.

title: Dinkins, at Senate Hearing, Says Drugs Are Overrunning New York
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins of New York told a Senate panel today that drugs are overrunning his city and that some neighborhoods have become ''free fire zones'' where small children carry beepers linking them with drug dealers.

title: American Savings Head Steps Down Under Fire
description: Bowing to stockholder pressure, the American Savings Bank announced yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, John T. Morgan, was retiring and that William G. Lillis, the bank's president, would take on the added duties of chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about Czechoslovaks visiting Austria carried an incorrect byline. It was written by Brenda Fowler, not Elizabeth M. Fowler.

title: What D'Amato Has Done for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Behind the Jitters At 3-D Systems
description: MOST technology stocks are out of favor on Wall Street, but 3-D Systems had been a dramatic exception for the last several months. Then, this week, the company's largest shareholder said it wanted to sell, and 3-D's stock price plunged. 3-D Systems stock rose to $16.50 at the end of November from $5 a share in July. But on Monday alone it was down as much as $5 before ending at $11.875 in over-ther-counter trading. Yesterday, the stock fell 12.5 cents, to $11.75.

title: Notebook; Unheralded Skaters Revitalize Princeton Team
description: Hobey Baker of Princeton, who played in pre-World War I years, is acclaimed as the best American-born college hockey player in history. The sport's most valuable player award is named after him, as is the university's rink.

title: No One Can Control Runaway Medical Costs; How Insurance Works
description: To the Editor:

title: A Times Appointment
description: John C. Brewer has been named executive vice president of The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation, which markets The New York Times News Service and other news services, columns and feature packages to newspapers and magazines. The appointment is effective Jan. 1. Mr. Brewer, who is 42 years old, will retain the executive editorship of the news service, to which he was appointed in March 1988.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misidentified a mutual fund managed by Greg Melvin. It is the Federated Growth Trust, owned by the Federated Research Corporation.

title: French Rightist Loses Immunity in Slur Case
description: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the extreme rightist National Front, was stripped of his immunity as a member of the European Parliament on Monday night so that he could be prosecuted for an anti-Semitic slur.

title: Tennessee Secretary of State Survives Attempt at Suicide
description: The Tennessee Secretary of State, whose office is at the center of a scandal involving charity bingo, shot himself in the mouth today in a suicide attempt, the authorities said.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Berenter Departure
description: LEAD: Helene M. Kalmanson, one of the better-known rain makers in the agency business, will be leaving Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster at the end of the month for unspecified activities. Ms. Kalmanson, who in 14 months of hunting new business at Berenter helped the agency land the Hartmarx Corporation, Deer Park water and the New York area Chevrolet dealers' association, said offers from other agencies, as well as the possibility of starting a business and strategic consulting company, had persuaded her to leave the agency.

title: NEW CHURCH ROLE IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: The brief item, eluding all but the most meticulous newspaper readers, served notice of the end of an organization that Czechoslovkia's Communist leaders always liked to regard as their fifth column within the Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Pop Life
description: Poetry and Folk Art

title: Real Estate; A 'Jukebox' Hotel for Times Square
description: A $300 MILLION hotel designed to look and light up like a giant jukebox has just opened in Times Square, where the idea for the building first took root in the mind of its architect almost 50 years ago.

title: The Tools That Fed a Growing Nation
description: IMAGINE walking into a museum and seeing your eggbeater on display, your apron framed on the wall, your sauce-stained recipe book in a glass case.

title: Plea Bargain Offered
description: The plea bargain offered to the suspended Dallas Mavericks star, Roy Tarpley, in his drunken-driving case is the standard deal offered to any first-time offender, a prosecutor in Dallas said yesterday. Tarpley was arrested Nov. 15 after the police stopped him and said he tailgated another car on a Dallas freeway. The police filed resisting-arrest charges after the 7-foot, 250-pound player allegedly became belligerent. The charges on Tarpley carry maximum six-month jail sentences and $1,000 fines. Jason January, the chief misdemeanor prosecutor for Dallas County, said he met with Tarpley's attorneys to outline the plea-bargain offer. But Tarpley's attorneys have requested a postponement of a preliminary hearing in the case until Jan. 31.(AP)

title: Redmen Defeat Rams For 21st Time in a Row
description: Fordham lost for the 21st consecutive time to St. John's last night.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a potential Soviet investment in a biotechnology company referred incorrectly in some editions to a Harvard Medical School instructor.

title: Valletta Journal; Hardly the Knights of Old, but Still on Crusades
description: The American and Soviet Presidents were thinking of the future as they swept through in imperial style, but it was the magnet of the past that brought the Knights back to Malta recently to wander among the bastions, ramparts and palaces their soldier-monk predecessors had built.

title: France to End Controls On Foreign Exchange
description: France announced today that it would abolish its remaining foreign exchange controls beginning Jan. 1. The controls have been in place for 44 years.

title: C.P.A. Group Repeals Rule
description: The board of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has rescinded a rule that prevented the largest accounting firms, collectively, from having more than five seats on any of its rule-making committees.

title: Commtron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Financial Weekly Sold
description: Southam Inc. said Monday that it had sold The Financial Times of Canada weekly newspaper and certain related operations to the Thomson Newspapers Corporation, a unit of the Thomson Corporation. The properties will be managed by The Globe and Mail, one of Toronto's daily newspapers. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Lindsay Crosby, 51, A Son of Bing, Dead
description: Lindsay Crosby, a son of the entertainer Bing Crosby, was found dead in his home in Calabasas, a Los Angeles suburb, apparently a suicide. He was 51 years old.

title: Reviews/Television; Andrews and Burnett Prove The Durability of a Formula
description: They don't make shows like that anymore, you say? Nonsense. Julie Andrews and Carol Burnett got their big breaks in late-1950's stage musicals: Ms. Andrews in the British import ''The Boy Friend,'' Ms. Burnett in Off Broadway's ''Once Upon a Mattress.'' In 1962, they teamed up for a television special called ''Julie and Carol at Carnegie Hall.'' Nine years later, they appeared in ''Julie and Carol at Lincoln Center.'' And, by golly, they're having another reunion, tonight at 10 on ABC, in ''Julie and Carol: Together Again.'' Taped at the Pantages Theater in Hollywood, the show celebrates good solid first-rank professionalism.

title: Campeau Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $81,000,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included after-tax gains on the sale of assets of $101 million for the latest 9 months and $318 million for the year-earlier period. The company said the discontinued operations are comprised of some of the company's real-estate assets. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Proler International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were restated for 3-for-1 stock split of common shares effective July 17.

title: Young Men Pressed To Wed for Success
description: WHEN Michael McCartney, 26, was looking for a management job last year he had no interest in finding a wife too. But interviewers' interest in his personal life prompted him to tell them he was engaged to be married.

title: 3-Part Pricing By USAir
description: USAir Inc. has offered $245.145 million of pass-through certificates in a three-part pricing.

title: Thatcher Defends Refugee Policy
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong would continue, to deter other Vietnamese from fleeing to the colony in the hope of making their way to the West.

title: Helmsley Gets 4-Year Term For Tax Fraud
description: Saying that Leona Helmsley had been motivated by ''naked greed,'' a Federal judge in Manhattan sentenced her yesterday to a four-year prison term and fined her $7.1 million for tax fraud. Mrs. Helmsley, who described herself in advertisements as the queen of the Helmsley hotel chain, would be eligible for parole after 16 months in prison.

title: TVX Stock To Paramount
description: The TVX Broadcast Group Inc. said on Monday that Paramount Communications Inc. had acquired the preferred and common stock of the Virginia Beach-based independent television station owner for $110 million.

title: Lomas to End Insurance Link
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation, which entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September, said today that it would sell its life insurance group, which has asssets of $962 million and a book value of $212.9 million.

title: Washington Talk; But, Soviets Ask, How Do You Shut Them Up?
description: It is easy to mock Congress after a year in which it careened from one scandal to the next.

title: U.S. AIDES CRITICAL OF BRITAIN'S MOVE
description: The Administration and Congressional leaders today criticized as unacceptable Britain's forced repatriation of Vietnamese refugees from Hong Kong.

title: Daily News Buys Plant Site
description: The Daily News announced yesterday that it had purchased a 22-acre site in New Jersey on which it hopes eventually to build a modern plant, capable of printing in color.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Russ Togs Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,550,000, or 21 cents a share. c-Included a loss of $1,103,000 from discontinued operations and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,290,000.

title: Walesa Backs Plan to Create a Market Economy
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, said today that the Government should be given special powers to speed the conversion of Poland's planned economy to a market-based system.

title: Mencken Center May Be Renamed
description: Directors of the National Press Club have put off a decision on renaming the club's H. L. Mencken Library and Reference Center while they look into disclosures about racial and religious bias in Mencken's diaries, the club's president, Peter Holmes, said today.

title: U.N. Monitor in Nicaragua Sees Threat to Vote in Rising Violence
description: Prospects for a free and fair election in Nicaragua could be threatened by rising political violence and inflammatory coverage by Nicaraguan news organizations, Elliot L. Richardson, the United Nations special representative monitoring the electoral process, said in a report issued today.

title: Seaching Out Chilies and Such North of the Border
description: TWO years after Casa Moneo closed for renovation, never to open again, New Yorkers are still scrambling for the fixings to produce Mexican dishes like burritos, salsa verde and mole poblano. The 59-year-old store on West 14th Street was the single most important source on the East Coast for ingredients and equipment used in Mexican cooking.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Trademark for Wine Blends Is Resisted
description: EIGHT months after an organization of 30 California wineries registered Meritage as the trademarked name for an expanding class of $12 to $35 Bordeaux-style blended wines, its campaign to standardize the name nationwide is running into resistance.

title: Review/Film; Tale of Hope and Fatalism By Isaac Bashevis Singer
description: From a window in one of his apartments, the one in Coney Island, Herman Broder (Ron Silver) has an unobstructed view of the Wonder Wheel. It's a sight to which the camera often returns in ''Enemies, a Love Story,'' Paul Mazursky's deeply felt, fiercely evocative adaptation of Isaac Bashevis Singer's brilliantly enigmatic novel. Mr. Mazursky doesn't belabor the image, and he doesn't have to. The story itself has a sense of life's cyclical possibilities, of a bustling new world rising from the ashes, of hope and fatalism inseparably intermingled. Somehow, the giddy spectacle of this neon-lined amusement park artifact captures those paradoxes perfectly.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Scandinavian Holiday

title: Stuarts Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Monday about a planned talk by Beverly Sills misstated the date. She is to speak at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, at 8 P.M. on Tuesday, not on Monday.

title: Bridge
description: No match could have been closer than the final of the Mexican Grand National Teams played on Thursday in Mexico City. After 64 deals, the score was exactly tied, with each team having 165 imps, and the title was shared. One winning team consisted of Gonzalo Herrera, Miriam Rosenberg, Nancy Gersen and Magy Rosenfeld; the other had George Rosenkranz, Miguel Reygadas, Laura Mariscal, Alicia Duran and Elias Konstantinovsky.

title: CHILE'S CANDIDATES REST THEIR CASES
description: Three men who hope to succeed Gen. Augusto Pinochet as President of Chile, ending more than 16 years of military rule, rested their cases with the people after huge rallies in recent days.

title: Harley-Davidson
description: An investment group led by Malcolm I. Glazer, a Rochester business executive, has raised his stake in Harley-Davidson Inc. to 7.29 percent, from 6.2 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Glazer said he bought 87,300 shares between Nov. 24 and last Friday for $38.175 to $41.25 each. He has requested Federal clearance to raise his stake in the Milwaukee-based motorcycle maker to 15 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21 The Soviet Communists' monopoly on politics and power is not an issue open for debate, President Mikhail Gorbachev said, quickly settling the question during the oecond session of the National Congress. Page A1

title: Prejudices Without The Mask
description: I am profoundly unshocked to learn that the night thoughts H. L. Mencken confided to his diary were sometimes tainted with racism and anti-Semitism. To have been utterly free of such stuff in Mencken's time and place would have been astonishing. I speak with authority here, for I was growing up just a block away from Mencken while he was keeping his diary.

title: Last Laps for East Germany's Olympic System
description: Inside the Gymnastics and Sports Club of Berlin, life seemed as normal as ever today. A men's volleyball team practiced under the watchful eyes of its coach. A group of pre-teen-age boys played soccer, four-on-four. Five little girls pranced through the moves of a gymnastics routine they will perform Saturday as part of the club's Christmas show.

title: Rutgers Dismisses Anderson as Coach
description: Rutgers University dismissed its coach, Dick Anderson, yesterday, citing the Scarlet Knights' poor record for the last two seasons.

title: Lessons
description: In Dylan Thomas's ''Child's Christmas in Wales,'' the poet recalls the ''useless presents'' that he and other youngsters used to receive, like books that ''told me everything about the wasp except why.''

title: 3 Youths Shot As Gangs Clash At Courthouse
description: A shootout at noon between two gangs of teen-agers on the steps of the New Haven Superior Courthouse ended yesterday with three youths wounded and four others under arrest, the police said.

title: Vari-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: GORBACHEV BLOCKS DEBATE ON ENDING PARTY SUPREMACY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, appearing wary and temperamental, today beat back attempts by the national Congress to question the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power and politics in the Soviet Union.

title: Pardon Decision Is Expected Tomorrow in Slaying
description: Fourteen years ago a black teen-ager was sentenced to death in the shooting of a white student during racial fighting in a Mississippi River town. Now the Louisiana Pardon Board is about to recommend whether Gov. Buddy Roemer should set him free.

title: 10 Killed and 100 Are Hurt In Police Clash in Bangladesh
description: At least 10 people were killed and about 100 wounded in northeastern Bangladesh today when the police opened fire in battles with an angry crowd protecting suspected thieves, officials and witnesses said.

title: Times Co. Takes Earnings Charge
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would take a charge of about 57 cents a share against fourth-quarter earnings.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Avenue Editor Leaving To Develop Magazine
description: LEAD: Avenue, the glossy fashion and culture magazine, is losing the editor who gave it a respectability that often eludes controlled-circulation publications.

title: Teen-Ager Shot After a Dispute at School
description: A 17-year-old Bronx student was shot twice in the head yesterday after a dispute outside his high school, the police said.

title: Team of Men and Dogs Reaches South Pole
description: A six-man international team of explorers reached the South Pole on Monday, marking a major milestone in its 4,000-mile trek across Antarctica with skis and sled dogs.

title: Helicopter Venture
description: A French-Asian project has been formed to make light helicopters for military and civilian use. The French state-owned Aerospatiale group will have a 55 percent stake in the venture, while the China Aero Technology Import-Export Corporation and Singapore Aerospace will own 30 and 15 percent, respectively. Andre Bloch, an Aerospatiale spokesman, said a prototype for the new two-ton helicopter will be ready in 1993. The venture will be based in China and France. No financial details were disclosed.

title: G.O.P. Counsel Ordered Before Integrity Panel
description: Risking a contempt-of-court citation, the counsel to the Republican State Committee yesterday failed to turn over subpoenaed documents to the State Commission on Government Integrity.

title: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Moscow Speech
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to the Congress of People's Deputies, as recorded and translated by The New York Times:

title: Pharmacy-Food Effort With Volvo
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, announced today that it would join the Government as equal partner in a giant pharmaceutical and food group created by combining the Pharmacia, Procordia and Provendor companies.

title: Klansman Loses Police Job
description: An outspoken member of the Ku Klux Klan who recruits for the racist organization has been dismissed from his job as a police officer. Thomas Herman ''was terminated because the Board of Selectmen no longer had the confidence in his ability and integrity to perform his duties as a police officer,'' the chairwoman, Betsy Coes, said Monday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cafes One L.P., Dallas, which had agreed to sell its Bonanza family restaurant franchise to Metromedia Co., will begin to liquidate this month.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. yesterday priced a $250 million offering of three-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Because of strong demand, the size of the issue was increased from $200 million.

title: Excerpts From Latin Leaders' Agreement
description: Following are excerpts from the declaration adopted by five Central American presidents here today, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Immigrants Give Thanks in Gifts to Neediest
description: Gratitude for the bounties they found here has led many people who immigrated to the United States to make donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: NHD Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Prices Up at Disneyland
description: Disneyland has increased one-day admission prices by $2, to $25.50 for adults and $20.50 for children. Parking prices have risen too, by a dollar, to $4. A Disneyland spokesman, Bob Roth, said the company had raised prices to offset the costs of its Splash Mountain ride, which opened last summer. Ticket prices were also increased by $2 a year ago.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Decatur, Ga.
description: LEAD: WHEN Robert Blazer started a modest open-air market here in 1977, his dream was to bring fresh produce to this Atlanta suburb at low cost. In 12 years, that dream has grown to include prepared foods, fresh seafood, flowers and staff members from all over the world catering to immigrants from all over the world.

title: Bush Is Right on China
description: LEAD: As a centrist Democrat who advocates policies that advance our national values and our national interest, I am troubled by the eagerness of many fellow Democrats to score debating points off President Bush's China policy.

title: Bergen Brunswig reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for the 25 percent stock dividend in July 1989.

title: Making the Holiday Palatable for Dieters
description: AT holiday time, the advice offered to dieters and the health-conscious is relentless and often useless. It can be divided into three categories of exhortation: get a grip on yourself and stick to your diet; throw caution to the wind and diet on Jan. 1; do the best you can, but do not worry.

title: Marcus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 9

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
People
description: LEAD: * Steve Blacker has been appointed group publisher for Business Month and Inc. magazines, and Jay MacDonald has been promoted to publisher of Business Month.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: Few dishes are steeped in as much snobbery as bouillabaisse. There are those who deem that it cannot be authentically prepared more than a seashell's toss from the port of Marseille. To be sure, the classic bouillabaisse is made with seafood, as many as a dozen varieties, from the Mediterranean. I have prepared the real thing often, and it can be astoundingly good. But the abundance of excellent seafood found in American waters makes a version that all but the most ethnocentric Frenchman would agree is sublime.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Farm Magazine Thrives In Fertile Asphalt Soil
description: One would expect the Social Register to be published in the Society Hill section here, but not Hogs Today. And that reality can be a shock to Philadelphians who accidentally wander into the Farm Journal building on Washington Square.

title: Parliament Urges Allowing Trial Of Nazi War Criminals in Britain
description: The House of Commons voted overwhelmingly tonight to recommend changing British law so Nazi war criminals living in Britain can be prosecuted.

title: Spending Can Be Cut in Half, Former Defense Officials Say
description: Laying the foundation for a fundamental political debate, military experts from previous administrations told Congress today that the $300 billion annual Pentagon budget could be safely cut in half over the next decade because of the reduced threat from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Charges Against Captain in Valdez Spill
description: A judge refused today to dismiss criminal charges against the captain of the Exxon Valdez, the tanker that caused the nation's worst oil spill, rejecting arguments that the skipper had gained immunity from prosecution by reporting the accident.

title: Dow, Helped by Energy Sector, Rises 23.89
description: Helped by a strong performance in the energy sector, stock prices rose broadly yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 23.89 points, to 2,752.13.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: QUERIES ON GRANT TO PIERCE FRIEND
description: A consulting company run by a longtime friend of Samuel R. Pierce Jr. has for two years refused Federal requests that it account for a $300,000 grant awarded by Mr. Pierce while he was Housing Secretary, newly released Government documents and interviews show.

title: Bush Gamble With Beijing
description: Hunkering down against growing criticism of President Bush's diplomatic overture to Beijing, Administration officials said today that the surprise weekend mission was a ''calculated gamble'' taken by a President who considers himself his own China expert.

title: 40 Wounded and 300 Held in Egypt as Police and Muslims Clash
description: In Egypt's latest outburst of Muslim fundamentalist unrest, Islamic militants fought the police with guns, chains, knives and gasoline bombs on the streets of Assyut in a battle that left 40 wounded and more than 300 in jail, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. Chip Plan Short Of Its Goals
description: U.S. Memories, the proposed cooperative venture to manufacture computer memory chips, is scaling back its fund-raising goals to keep the project alive, the venture's president said today.

title: Notebook; Paez Is More Than Just Eccentric
description: Last Friday, a day before he stopped Lupe Gutierrez in six rounds, Jorge Paez did a handstand on a moving escalator at Bally's casino in Reno, Nev.

title: Super Valu Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
Rykoff-Sexton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted for stock split effected in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 16, 1989.

title: Dissident Group to File Charges Against Krenz
description: East Germany's largest opposition group is filing charges against the former Communist leader, Egon Krenz, over destruction of sensitive security police papers, the official press agency, A.D.N., said today.

title: President Dropped
description: The car owners who make up the Championship Auto Racing Teams Indy-car series yesterday refused to renew the contract of the organization's president, John P. Caponigro. Caponigro, 33 years old, who had been CART's president since last February, apparently was seeking a longterm contract extension, but the car owners would offer him a renewal only through the end of next year.

title: Scorn Gives Comaneci A Lesson In Image
description: Nadia Comaneci sat in the deserted, dim bar of a Great Western hotel here, sipping strawberry daiquiris and watching a ''Batman'' rerun on television. She perked up when her image flashed on the evening news, but it was only more of what she has been hearing for a week: Nadia the home-wrecker, Nadia the spoiled princess.

title: Voting Machines Baffle The Soviet Lawmakers
description: Democracy may be a delicate tool in the hands of beginners, but members of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies discovered today that technology can be similarly fragile.

title: 20,000 Demonstrate in Benin
description: The police fired gunshots and tear gas on Monday to disperse about 20,000 protesters demanding the resignation of President Mathieu Kerekou. Witnesses said violence flared in the city, the economic center of this West African nation, where the demonstrators, mostly students, set police vehicles on fire and blocked roads with burning tires, apparently unimpressed by Benin's official rejection last week of Marxism-Leninism and announcements of planned economic liberalization.

title: Bear, Stearns Will Resume Index Arbitrage for Itself
description: Bear, Stearns & Company yesterday became the first major Wall Street firm to resume index arbitrage for its own account.

title: KASHMIR MILITANTS MAKE NEW THREAT
description: Negotiations for the release of an Indian Cabinet minister's daughter held by Kashmiri Muslim separatists reached an impasse Tuesday night as the militants renewed their threat to kill her.

title: Results Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Villanova 64, Connecticut 57: Greg Woodard and Arron Bain each made two free throws in the last 10 seconds last night to lead Villanova to a Big East victory in Hartford. The Wildcats (5-3) survived a UConn rally that cut a 13-point lead to just 3 points, 60-57, with 10 seconds left on 3-point baskets by Nadav Henefeld and Dan Cyrulik. Woodard made two foul shots with nine seconds to go.(AP) Temple 74, St. Joseph's 54: Mik Kilgore scored 15 points to lead Temple (3-2, 1-1) against St. Joseph's (1-5, 0-3) in an Atlantic 10 Conference game, giving John Chaney, the coach of the Owls, his 400th victory. Chaney, who also coached at Cheyney State, is 175-52 in his seventh season at Temple. Mark Macon had 12 points for Temple, which won its 26th straight home game.(AP) Coppin State 70, Maryland 63: Reggie Isaac had 24 points and Larry Stewart scored 6 of his 18 points in the final 90 seconds to lead the visitors to an upset victory in College Park, Md. Coppin State improved to 5-2. Maryland fell to 4-3. The loss was the first by Maryland to another Maryland school since the 1968-69 season, when the Terps were defeated by Navy.(AP) Illinois-Chicago 65, Michigan St. 57: After Brian Hill's 3-point basket snapped a 52-52 tie, unheralded Illinois-Chicago went on to upset Michigan State last night at Chicago. It was the Spartans' first loss in seven games. Corwin Hunt scored 19 points to lead Illinois-Chicago (4-2) as the Flames played an aggressive defense that forced 24 Michigan State turnovers.(AP) SKIING Perfect Run for Zurbriggen: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, reviving his hopes of winning a fourth World Cup in his farewell year, captured a supergiant slalom race yesterday with a perfect run down a fast and treacherous course at Sestriere, Italy. Zurbriggen, trying to equal a record of four overall titles held by Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, raced to victory in 1 minute 37.39 seconds.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 7, Bruins 5: Rob Brown scored three goals last night to lead Pittsburgh at home. The Penguins have won four of their last five games and are 3-1 since Craig Patrick succeeded Gene Ubriaco as coach. (AP) Canucks 4, North Stars 2: Barry Pederson had a goal and two assists as Vancouver handing Minnesota its seventh straight defeat. The victory ended an eight-game road losing streak for the Canucks and marked the third straight home loss for the North Stars, who are tied for the league lead with 13 home victories.(AP) N.B.A. Lakers 103, Hornets 89: James Worthy scored 27 points and grabbed eight rebounds last night as the visiting Lakers handed Charlotte its eighth straight loss. Michael Cooper of the Lakers and Stuart Gray of Charlotte were ejected after a second-quarter brawl that also involved Worthy. Four technical fouls were called.
