The brawl began 10 minutes 53 seconds before halftime when Gray and a teammate, Kenny Gattison, went to block Worthy's shot. Worthy and Gray began pushing and, after they were separated, Gray tried to punch Scott. Cooper intervened and shoved Gray into a row of photographers on the baseline. Gray got up, tackled Cooper and they wrestled until order was restored. The referees conferred and decided to eject Gray and Worthy, but then instead ejected Gray and Cooper.(AP) Rockets 103, Suns 83: Akeem Olajuwon scored 25 points, grabbed 20 rebounds and blocked 9 shots as Houston ended a four-game losing streak with the victory at home. Otis Thorpe added 24 points and 14 rebounds and Buck Johnson scored 22 points for Houston. It was Olajuwon's third 20-rebound game of the season.(AP) Bucks 106, Magic 103: Jay Humphries made two free throws with six seconds left as Milwaukee, playing at home, held off a late Orlando rally. Paul Pressey led the Bucks with 20 points, including 4 points in the final 39 seconds. Orlando had a chance to tie but Jerry Reynolds's 3-point shot at the buzzer went off the rim.(AP) Hawks 102, Spurs 94: In Atlanta, Moses Malone scored 24 points and Glenn Rivers added 21 as the Hawks posted their seventh consecutive victory.(AP) Pacers 113, Timberwolves 112: Chuck Person scored 31 points and set up a wild finish in overtime as surging Indiana held off Minnesota at home.(AP) Bulls 105, Mavericks 97: Michael Jordan scored 41 points to lead Chicago at home. Dallas, now 3-4 under the interim head coach Richie Adubato, lost its third straight game, its longest losing streak of the season.(AP) Pistons 121, Nuggets 108: Joe Dumars led a Detroit rally that erased a 16-point second-quarter deficit and Isiah Thomas keyed a third-period spurt as Detroit handed Denver its first home loss of the season.(AP)

title: Port Authority Puts Off Final Vote on Toll Rises
description: Under a barrage of public criticism and a threatened veto by Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has put off final action on a sweeping increase in bridge and tunnel tolls and the PATH train fare.

title: Development Solves Towns' Border Battle
description: Over the last few decades, this Fairfield County town has tried the souls of its neighbors: Ignoring their objections, it built up its borders with shopping malls, office buildings, and a hotel-convention center.

title: Fine-Tuning for Campaign Finance
description: Public hearings today and tomorrow will examine New York City's new public campaign financing system. For the most part it succeeded admirably, reducing reliance on big contributions and creating at least a perception of cleaner government. But there's much room for improvement.

title: Florio Names 3 More to His Cabinet
description: Governor-elect James J. Florio announced three more members of his cabinet today, the new heads of the Environmental Protection Department, the Community Affairs Department and the Board of Public Utilities.

title: Navy Account of Iowa Explosion Is Criticized
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee looking into the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa asserted today that the Navy had failed to make its case that the blast was set off deliberately and that Petty Officer Clayton M. Hartwig was the most likely culprit.

title: Purchasers See Slower Growth
description: The association of the nation's purchasing managers has predicted that the United States will avert a recession in 1990, but that growth will be only moderate.

title: Bring Back Collusion
description: rrIt was less than a year ago that Peter Ueberroth made his last fireside chat to Mr. and Mrs. America and all the ships at sea. Through the crackling over the wireless, one seemed to have heard Peter repeating the prophecy by Louis XV, ''Apres moi, le deluge.'' (While serving as baseball commissioner, Peter seemed to be giving his fireside chats in French, under the impression that New York was a foreign country, and he may have been right. But that's another story.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a ''Notebook'' article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Denver Broncos' offense misidentified Andy Heck's team. It is the Seattle Seahawks, not the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Reviews/Music; Re-enacting the Conflict Of Brahms vs. Wagner
description: The very existence of the American Composers Orchestra testifies to the ambivalence of contemporary composition. Once again on Sunday afternoon, this intrepid collection of musicians formed what is essentially a 19th-century Romantic orchestra and acted out the familiar struggle of current composers alternately embracing the past and wrestling to free themselves from it.

title: Webster Clothes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
For U S West Official, A World Full of Deals
description: Dining with Hungary's commercial attache at the Four Seasons in New York, Andres Bande showed him a portable cellular phone and told him to call home. The attache did, and was impressed.

title: U.S. URGED TO END SCREENING ON AIDS
description: The National Commission on AIDS, the American Bar Association, the international societies of the Red Cross and other groups asked the Government today to drop its policy of barring people infected with the AIDS virus from entering the country unless they get a special waiver.

title: Straphangers Shouldn't Pay to Build a Vast Transit Bureaucracy
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 'Angels' Shows Canceled
description: Today's matinee and evening performances have been canceled for ''City of Angels,'' a musical comedy by Larry Gelbart and Cy Coleman. A spokesman for the show said Gregg Edelman, one of its stars, has laryngitis. Those with tickets for the performances may exchange them or get a refund at the Virginia Theater box office, 245 West 52d Street.

title: Measuring the Interest in
description: It's been mostly a long downhill slide for mathematics and the physical sciences, as university undergraduates increasingly shy away from majoring in these subjects. The trend has been documented since 1966 by the Higher Education Research Institute of the University of California at Los Angeles, which annually selects about 15 percent of American colleges and universities to participate in a freshman questionnaire program.

title: Amcast Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: The company said the latest results included the effect of a 13-week strike at its Stanley G. Flagg unit, which resulted in a sales decline of $7.9 million and a loss equaled to 26 cents a share. Year-ago results ended Nov. 27, 1988.

title: Metro Datelines; Two Police Officers Acquitted in Melee
description: Two New York City police officers were acquitted Monday of assault charges stemming from the police melee with hundreds of demonstrators in Tompkins Square Park last year.

title: Spelling Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest first quarter included results of Worldvision Enterprises Inc. and Laurel Entertainment Inc., which were acquired in March.

title: North Says He Has Forgotten Key Events
description: Oliver L. North, a likely prosecution witness in the trial of John M. Poindexter, said at a hearing today that his ability to recall crucial events in the Iran-contra affair had dulled over time and was heavily influenced by Mr. Poindexter's Congressional testimony.

title: Katherine Rosen Weds Daniel Walz
description: Katherine Falk Rosen and Daniel James Walz were married yesterday by Justice Stephen G. Crane of State Supreme Court in his chambers in New York. The bride is a daughter of Doris Falk Rosen and Victor D. Rosen, both of Oakland, Calif. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Walz of New London, Conn.

title: Bulgarian Dissidents Asking for More
description: Although pleased that Bulgaria's Communist leaders have pledged to end their party's automatic grip on power and hold free elections, people in the opposition warned today that they would press for further democratic reforms.

title: Former Bolivian Interior Minister Held in U.S. on Cocaine Charges
description: A Bolivian colonel who as Interior Minister was dubbed his nation's ''minister of cocaine'' in the early 1980's was ordered held without bond today on drug trafficking charges that could send him to prison for 30 years.

title: Idiots' Delight
description: Scores of almost identical letters are pouring in from all over the U.S. attacking the Council on Foreign Relations and urging me to resign from it.

title: 2-Month Layoff Announced for Graham Troupe
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has announced a two-month layoff of its dancers in January and February, immediately after a two-week tour in Italy.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Wine Talk column in The Living Section last Wednesday described the rising influence of Robert M. Parker Jr., publisher of The Wine Advocate. The column reported that many merchants refused to buy wines that had not scored well in his ratings.

title: Lionel E. Rubinstein, Publisher, 81
description: Lionel E. Rubinstein, a founder of The Rome Daily American, an English-language newspaper published in Italy for 31 years, died Friday at Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Books of The Times; A Novel Illuminates a Shocking Soviet Reality
description: Goodnight! By Abram Tertz (Andrei Sinyavsky) Translated by Richard Lourie. 364 pages. Viking. $22.95.

title: Bowne & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack
description: Donald Glenn was unemployed, deep in debt and stealing money from Karen, the woman who loved him. His life had become crack. Starting Karen on the drug made him feel better, but then he felt terrible about that, too.

title: Du Pont Plant
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company and Waste Management of North America Inc. have chosen Philadelphia for a plastic recycling plant to serve the Northeastern United States and eventually anchor a national network. Du Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., and Waste Management, based in Oak Brook, Ill., plan to announce a Midwestern site next year. The Philadelphia plant, which at first will have an annual capacity of up to 40 million pounds, will begin operating in the spring of next year and will have 70 employees.

title: Great Lakes Campaign
description: Eight Great Lakes states and the province of Ontario began a $6 million campaign today to lure visitors from abroad to the region with a promotion touting the area as ''North America's Fresh Coast.'' The initial focus of the campaign will be Britain, followed by West Germany, Scandinavian and other Western European countries. The lakes are bounded by Ontario, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, Illinois, Indiana. Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York, all of which will contribute to the travel promotion.

title: Mary Rogers Brooks, Actress, 76
description: Mary Rogers Brooks, the daughter of the humorist Will Rogers, died Wednesday after a brief illness. She was 76 years old. Mrs. Brooks died at St. John's Hospital and Health Center from complications associated with cancer, a hospital spokeswoman, Paulette Weir, said.

title: Inter-City in Deal To Sell Divisions
description: Westcoast Energy Inc. of Vancouver, British Columbia, agreed to acquire the gas utility and propane businesses of the Inter-City Gas Corporation of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for $727 million (Canadian), or about $626 million in United States currency. The transaction, which is still subject to regulatory approval and a vote of Inter-City's shareholders, is not expected to close until March.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 9:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE OF THE 16TH SPECIAL SESSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10A.M.

title: Disincentive to Study
description: To the Editor:

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of computer problems at The Associated Press, tables reflecting trading in stocks options that appear on Page D18 are incomplete. The news service said that because of the problems it was ''unable to process a final summary of trading.''

title: Louis Breglio, 74, Dies; A Retired College Dean
description: Louis A. Breglio, a former dean of students at Brooklyn College, died yesterday at his home in Wantagh, L.I., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Plans for Dinkins Inaugural Grow With the Guest List
description: Planning a celebration that would more than double the size of past ceremonies, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins's inaugural committee yesterday sent out the first of 13,000 invitations to his swearing-in on the City Hall steps on New Year's Day and a reception afterward.

title: St. Moritz Sold for $175 Million
description: Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. announced today that it had agreed to sell the St. Moritz Hotel at 50 Central Park South in New York City to FAI Insurances Ltd., for $175 million.

title: Atom Tests' Legacy of Grief: Workers See Betrayal on Peril
description: Workers at the Nevada Test Site, the desert proving ground for American nuclear weapons, were repeatedly exposed to dangerous levels of radiation from underground and atmospheric atomic blasts over three decades, according to Government records made public in a court case here.

title: Kulicke & Soffa Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stocks Higher as Dow Rises by 8.96 Points
description: The stock market moved higher yesterday in more active trading, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.96 points, to 2,761.09.

title: I.C.H. to Sell Unit
description: The I.C.H. Corporation said it would sell its Great Southern Life Insurance Company for $105 million in cash and a $40 million 15 1/2 percent subordinated note to the Financial Holding Corporation of Missouri. The deal is subject to several conditions, including bank and regulatory approvals.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about air traffic delays at airports in the New York region misstated the percentage of flights at La Guardia delayed by air traffic controllers. From January to September of 1989, according to Federal Aviation Administration figures, 11.3 percent of all flights, whether arriving or departing, were delayed.

title: Whitney To Consider Its Direction
description: In the wake of reports that it would ask for the resignation of its director, Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday appointed a committee to ''review the current status and consider future directions of the museum.''

title: Wenner Sets US Sights On Quality
description: JANN S. WENNER hopped around his dark, memento-filled office sputtering a word not often associated with the world of Def Leppard: ''quality.''

title: Cloud Over the Charter, Dispelled
description: The U.S. Justice Department's welcome embrace of New York's revised City Charter dispels the last cloud hanging over the plan for a new government. Now officials from Mayor-elect David Dinkins on down can move ahead, confident that the Federal Government won't swoop in to declare illegal their efforts to govern.

title: Craftmatic-Contour Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NCR Employee Is Held in U.S.
description: A Canadian employee of the NCR Corporation was held without bail Tuesday after he was charged with attempting to sell proprietary information about NCR products to the Unisys Corporation.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Slips
description: Japan's trade surplus shrank last month for the seventh straight month, squeezed by domestic demand, surging oil imports and a strong dollar.

title: Chrysler to Halt Subcompact Work
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would not build any subcompact cars until the mid-1990's after it stops production of its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon.

title: Acquisition Fever Seen Taking Hold in Japan
description: One of British advertising's grand acquisitors of the 1980's said yesterday that Japan was likely to assume that role in the 1990's. Addressing the annual media conference sponsored by Paine Webber Inc. in New York, Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of the WPP Group, predicted that the slowdown of advertising growth in Japan would lead companies there to ''increasingly look outside for development, and Japanese ad agencies will follow them.''

title: Upheaval in the East; Communists in Bulgaria Expel Zhivkov
description: Todor I. Zhivkov, who had been Eastern Europe's longest-ruling leader until a month ago, was expelled today from the Bulgarian Communist Party, a humiliation that may increase his chances of facing formal corruption charges.

title: Ennis Business Forms reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock distribution in July 1989.

title: Instrument Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $1,277,000, or 5 cents a share, from discontinued operations for the quarter, which included a gain on disposal of operations of $642,000, and a loss of $19,699,000 for the year from discontinued operations, which included a loss on disposal of operations of $18,258,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,616,000, which included a loss of $961,000 on disposal of operations, and $2,864,000, which included a loss of $961,000 on disposal of operations, for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $30,000 from the reversal of net operating loss carryovers for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $3,720,000, or 12 cents a share, from utilization of net operating loss carryovers, for the year.

title: DISCIPLINE IMPOSED ON A SCHOOL CHIEF
description: The man who came here 15 months ago with the reputation of an aggressive educator and with promises to prod the school system out of its malaise has been censured by the city's school board following attacks for what some board members labeled irascibility and arrogance.

title: Arts Tabloid Prospers By Helping Others Out
description: Paper, the hip black-and-white tabloid that chronicles New York's downtown arts and culture scene, is building a thriving side business filling other publications' pages. The latest to call was Murdoch Magazines' Mirabella, an erstwhile competitor in covering fashion trends, which retained Paper to write, design and paste up its eight-page ''News'' section for the March issue.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Tuesday about the MTV program ''Decade'' misattributed a remark about the Reagan Adminstration. The comment, that it became ''fashionable to be racist'' during those years, was made by the film maker Spike Lee, not by Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman.

title: TV Networks Want Nielsen To Change Rating Methods
description: Hoping to find television viewers who are not counted by current rating methods, the three major broadcast networks yesterday recommended some changes in the way the A. C. Nielsen Company measures the national audience.

title: Adding Injury to Insult
description: Ron Hextall, who has only two appearances in goal for the Flyers this season, was sent down to Philadelphia's farm team in Hershey for a one-game rehabilitation assignment. Midway through the last period of last night's game, he was carried from the ice after injuring his right groin while trying to stop a shot by New Haven's Scott Bjugstad.

title: Jets' Quarterback Situation Is a Mystery
description: As the Jets began preparations for their game against the Rams, the question of who would play at quarterback -Tony Eason, Kenny O'Brien, Pat Ryan, all three, or any combination thereof - hovered around the team.

title: It's Time to Rethink U.S. Policy on El Salvador; An American Arrested
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Test Aircraft Carrier, Western Naval Officials Say
description: The Soviet Union is believed to be conducting flight tests on its first full-scale aircraft carrier, Western naval officials said today. The vessel's commissioning raises questions about Moscow's future naval strategy, they said.

title: New-Home Completions
description: Completions of new homes fell by 3.5 percent in October, to an annual rate of 1.31 million units, in the second consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department said Tuesday.

title: Books of The Times; The Short Stories From Which a Novel Grew
description: The Neumiller Stories By Larry Woiwode 289 pages. Michael di Capua Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Three D Departments reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

Currents;
Tape Measuring, Le Corbusier's Way
description: LEAD: IF you plan to measure your waistline after the holiday festivities, try the Modulor Rule from Princeton Architectural Press in Manhattan. This measuring tape is based on Le Corbusier's Modulor proportional system, which the architect devised in the 1940's as a way of relating human measurements to architecture.

title: Manual on Treatment Under Professional Fire
description: A new psychiatric treatment manual has come under increasing attack from critics in the mental health profession, who fear that disgruntled patients may use it as a basis for lawsuits, or that it may inappropriately promote certain therapies.

title: Yankees Are Still Seeking Help
description: On the day after they added Tim Leary and his losing record to their pitching rotation and its losing record, the Yankees paused in their pursuit of redemption yesterday and said they were now looking at other areas to upgrade a team that ran fifth and finished 13 games below the .500 mark.

title: D'Amato Cited In Another Brief Filed by Green
description: The man whose allegations of improprieties by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato prompted the Senate Ethics Committee to name a special counsel on the matter submitted a further complaint today citing additional instances of what he called ''possible D'Amato misconduct.''

title: Police Describe Slayer of Mugger
description: The police released a composite sketch yesterday of the unidentified man who, they said, stabbed and killed a subway mugger early last Saturday and who has since become something of a cause for civil liberties and anti-crime groups.

title: Valspar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
World's Fair to Grey
description: Expo Vienna A.G. has selected Grey Advertising to promote the 1995 World's Fair in Vienna and Budapest, billed as the first world's fair to be held simultaneously in two countries. Grey's advertising, public relations, direct marketing and audio-visual operations will service the account. Billings are expected to exceed $50 million over five years. Grey will set up an office in Vienna and will also rely on its new affiliate in Budapest.

title: Stanley Olson, A Biographer, Is Dead at 42
description: Stanley Olson, a biographer of the painter John Singer Sargent and the writer Elinor Wylie, died of a stroke on Saturday in his apartment in London, his sister said yesterday. He was 42 years old and had suffered another stroke in 1986.

title: Burke Helps Devils Sweep Islanders
description: The Devils posted their second victory within 24 hours over the Islanders tonight and moved from fifth to third place in the Patrick Division.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Luby's Cafeterias Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
P.T.A. and Scouts Clash on Liability
description: The Boy Scouts and the National Congress of Parents and Teachers have been unable to agree on who is responsible for scout leaders whose behavior sometimes leads to lawsuits.

title: RIVALS IN LEBANON LIVE UNDER WRAPS
description: Lebanon's rival leaders live under constant fear of assassination and in strict confinement, rarely venturing out of their security-tight bunkers or army barracks.

title: GAF Guilty In Carbide Stock Case
description: The GAF Corporation and a senior executive were found guilty yesterday afternoon of illegally trying to manipulate the stock of the Union Carbide Corporation in 1986 after an unsuccessful attempt to take over the company.

title: Easing Business Cycles: The Wichita Experience
description: This plains city of 300,000, which once boomed as a railhead for Texas cattle, runs these days on airplane production. But unlike the time of the Chisholm Trail, Wichita is far from a one-industry town, and its albeit bumpy ride in the 1980's illustrates a mix of forces that operate in today's diversified economy to blunt both boom and bust.

title: Kigeme Journal; Why Worry About Crops When Fishing's Better!
description: Pelagie Nyirahabimana watched hundreds of fish gather for feeding underneath the chicken hutch suspended over her commercial fish pond. The fish get bigger and fatter faster from chicken manure than any other nutrient, the 30-year-old fish-farming expert explained.

title: 1,000 a Month Reported Slain in Sri Lanka Strife
description: Amnesty International said today that well over 1,000 people were being killed each month in a tide of political violence sweeping across Sri Lanka.

title: Car Sales Continue To Slump
description: Sales of cars made in the United States plunged in early December, as the auto industry's slump showed no signs of abating.

title: I.B.M. Sees An Advance
description: Researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that they had for the first time succeeded in storing more than a billion bits of information on a single square inch of disk surface.

title: Cooper Development reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $15.3 million and $13.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, of settlement and valuation adjustments related to the company's investment in Cooper Cos. senior exchangeable redeemable preferred stock. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $465,000 for both the quarter and year, and the quarter and year also included a $16.6 million valuation adjustment relating to the company investment in the preferred stock of Cooper Cos.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: For millions of Americans, winter is a particularly difficult time because they have a circulatory disorder called Raynaud's syndrome, which makes it difficult for them to keep their fingers and toes warm.

title: Aerial Tram, the Symbol of Roosevelt Island, Must Be Preserved
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; A Crucial Vote At Cypress Fund
description: ONE of the longest-running disputes in the world of closed-end funds comes to a conclusion today as Cypress Fund shareholders vote on whether to throw out management.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., the pharmaceuticals company, named Timothy W. Ellis president of its Genetic Systems Corp. and Guilio Vita senior vice president and scientific adviser of its Bristol-Myers Pharmaceutical Research unit and Bristol-Myers Squibb Licensing Group.

title: Warriors in the Battle Against Grime
description: ''WE'RE the little elves,'' said Vance Baxter Vogel, president of the Little Elves professional housecleaning service in Manhattan. They do not wear green caps and pointed shoes, but Mr. Vogel or one of his 12 employees will whisk into a house and vacuum, dust and scrub.

title: Upheaval in the East; Europeans Praising Baker Blueprint
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's blueprint for a new European order won generally favorable reviews today from European statesmen and commentators, but privately many officials predicted that Washington will have a difficult time putting its vision into practice.

title: Parent & Child
description: JEROME L. SINGER remembers talking to an imaginary companion as he traveled to junior high school in the morning. His friend was an ancient Roman.

title: Upheaval in the East; Expert From Cold War Analyzes East Germany
description: It was unusual and surprising for the Secretary of State to quote word for word and at some length from a cablegram by the United States Ambassador to East Germany, since such messages are customarily treated as secret by the State Department.

title:
Currents;
New Campus Complex Designed by a Master
description: LEAD: TO see the work of internationally prominent architects these days, you just need to go to college. Many are turning to design luminaries to distinguish their campuses, as new buildings at Harvard, Cornell and Rice Universities by England's James Stirling dramatically demonstrate.

title: Giants' Nelson Retires
description: Karl Nelson, whose career as a starting offensive tackle for the Giants has been interrupted twice by Hodgkin's disease, retired today as a professional football player.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief of Consolidated To Retire Next Month
description: LEAD: The Consolidated Stores Corporation, the nation's largest retailer of close-out merchandise, said yesterday that James M. Guinan, its chairman and chief executive for the last 16 months, will retire by the end of January.

title: Indian Tribal Colleges Reverse History of Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET JEWS LEAVE AT A RECORD PACE, MANY FOR ISRAEL
description: The number of Jews streaming out of the Soviet Union has reached a record. Not counting people departing this month, more than 62,500 Jews have left this year, surpassing by more than 20 percent the high of 51,320 set in 1979.

title: Dixon Ticonderoga reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. to Give Some Plutonium Production Data
description: The Department of Energy has decided to disclose for the first time the amount of plutonium produced by a nuclear weapons plant.

title: Canada Approves Connaught Offers
description: Canada cleared two bids for the biotechnology company Connaught Biosciences Inc., letting the market choose between Institut Merieux's International S.A.'s offer of $942 million (Canadian), or about $813 million in United States currency, and a lower offer by a Swiss-American coalition. Analysts said Merieux's $37-a-share offer was certain to beat the bid of $30 a share from the Swiss pharmaceutical company Ciba-Geigy A.G. and its California associate, the Chiron Corporation, which values Connaught at $764 million.

title: A.T.&T.-Soviet Satellite Link
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company proposed increasing telecommunications circuits between the United States and the Soviet Union by using the Soviet Intersputnik satellite system for the first time.

title: Generic Drug Fee Proposal
description: The Bush Administration plans to propose that generic drug companies pay fees that would be used to strengthen Government regulation of the industry, people in the executive and Congressional branches said.

title: New York City Charter Revision Approved by Justice Department
description: The United States Justice Department approved the revised New York City Charter yesterday, removing the last obstacle to a new municipal government, which will begin to take shape Jan. 1.

title: Soviet Thaw Brings Down A Vodka Ban
description: Perhaps it was not as dramatic as the opening of the Berlin Wall, but it was another sign of the thaw in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. This town of 10,000 has lifted its six-year-old ban on sales of Russian vodka.

title: Article 792989 -- No Title
description: The Soviet Union has paid Belgium $685,000 in damages caused by the crash of a Soviet MiG-23 fighter plane, the Government said today.

title: Bridge
description: For players on the East Coast, the last major tournament of the 1980's begins in Manhattan tomorrow at the Penta Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. It is the Winter Regional of the Greater New York Bridge Association, and this is the schedule:

title: Mitsubishi Plans European Factory
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation will invest between $278 million and $347 million to build a wafer fabrication and chip assembly plant near Aachen, West Germany, a company spokesman said. The plant, to start operations in 1991, will make four-megabit dynamic random access microchips.

title: Old-Time Sailors' Handmade Boxes
description: LEAD: The range of skill that used to go into the construction of small boxes for storing items of every conceivable kind varied as much as the woods employed.

title: 60 Percent Back Testing for Drugs at Work
description: Sixty percent of American workers favor employers' testing their employees for drug use, according to a Gallup poll released today.

title: Accounts
description: * United Airlines to Wahlstrom & Company for its Yellow Pages advertising.

title: William P. Ennis, 85; Headed War College
description: Lieut. Gen. William Pierce Ennis Jr., who retired from the Army in 1962 after 36 years of service that included command of the Army War College, died Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old and lived in Newport, R.I.

title: A Hotel Where Magic and Humor Reside
description: IN the last few weeks, guests checking into Room 1418 at the Century Paramount Hotel on West 46th Street in Manhattan have been getting not only a room key and a red rose in a bud vase on the bedside table, but also a bit of a shock.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Premiere of Sexually Charged 'Episodes'
description: ''Episodes,'' a tough-minded new dance piece by Ulysses Dove full of energy, sexual connotations and technical polish from dancers who seem shot out of a cannon, is the kind of choreography that propels young audiences to their feet and sets them screaming.

title: Studies Give New Clues on Action of AIDS Virus
description: The AIDS virus is more prevalent in the blood of infected people than scientists believed, and there is no period of infection when the virus is dormant, new research shows.

title: Suns Acquire Rambis
description: The Phoenix Suns acquired the veteran forward Kurt Rambis and two second-round draft choices from the Charlotte Hornets yesterday in exchange for the forward Armon Gilliam, the Suns announced in Phoenix.(AP)

title: Expanded Medicare Repealed
description: President Bush signed the bill tonight repealing the expanded Medicare benefits that were designed to prevent financial catastrophy for victims of major illnesses. Mr. Bush, who had stayed out of the fractious debate in Congress, signed the measure without comment. The program ran afoul of objections by beneficiaries who were required to pay for its coverage.

title: Aerospace Decline Seen
description: The Aerospace Industries Association today predicted a moderate decline in sales in the 1990's because of cuts in United States military spending as East-West tensions ease.

title: Candidates Ask for More Public Campaign Money
description: As they assessed the first test of New York City's campaign finance law, candidates and politicians agreed yesterday that they would like fewer restrictions and more public money for their campaigns.

title: Retail Sales Increased By 0.8% in November
description: In a report providing some reassurance that economic expansion will continue into 1990, the Commerce Department said today that retail sales climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the biggest gain since August.

title: Delta to Expand Atlanta Operation
description: Delta Air Lines said it plans a big expansion of its operations at Atlanta's Hartsfield International Airport with financing from $347.9 million in tax-exempt bonds issued by the city.

title: Upheaval in the East; Croatian Communists Endorse Free Election
description: The Communist Party in Croatia, Yugoslavia's second-largest republic, endorsed multi-party rule today, paving the way for free elections in April.

title: Reitman's (Canada) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
BP America Names Head For Its New Operation
description: LEAD: BP America, the United States subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., has incorporated its American exploration and production group as an independent subsidiary, the Tex/Con Oil and Gas Company.

title: Agreement Is Reached at the U.N. To End Use of Drift Fishing Nets
description: After difficult negotiations that have pitted the United States against Japan for the first time at the United Nations, an agreement has been reached on steps to end the use of huge fishing nets 30 or more miles in length, that can sweep whole ocean areas free of marine life.

title: Integrated Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $617,674,000 for the quarter and $609,395,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $8,784,000, or $1.17 a share, for the quarter and $19,864,000, or $2.20 a share, for the 6 months. Both year-ago periods' operating results of the company's life insurance segment were restated to conform with FASB No. 97 and to reflect the discontinuance of the company's life insurance segment, securities clearing operations and non-financial services operations. Integrated said the losses from discontinued operations consisted primarily of writedowns of the value of the company's life insurance subsidiaries, writedowns in the value of the principal distributor of the company's tax-sheltered annuities, which the company has agreed in principle to sell, and writedowns of the values of Integrated's life insurance agencies which the company has sold or disposed of subsequent to the commencement of its liquidity problems or currently plans to sell or dispose of.

title: People
description: * James C. Crimmins has been named executive vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide.

title: Covenant House Under Scrutiny
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhatttan said yesterday that he was investigating allegations of financial ''improprieties'' involving the Rev. Bruce Ritter, the head of Covenant House, a home for runaway youths.

title: KEY RATES
Secret Fund of Detroit Police Is Investigated by Grand Jury
description: A Federal grand jury here is investigating reports that public money has been improperly diverted from a secret account administered by the Detroit Police Department, the United States Attorney said today.

title: Study Supports Global Warming Prediction
description: Direct measurements of atmospheric heat and water vapor have confirmed for the first time a fundamental feature of the theory that is central to predictions of future global warming, scientists at the University of Chicago report in today's issue of the British journal Nature.

title: Birds Like It; Cats and Squirrels Don't
description: When the last maple leaf has fallen, and there's virtually nothing flowering in the garden except stalwart winter heaths, and when the first snow blankets the ground, sensible gardeners come inside for the fallow season. But still, through the windows, they can take joy in color and movement outdoors, if they have been provident and affixed bird feeders on suction cups to the panes of glass.

title: Chairman Leaving
description: Thomas M. Bancroft Jr., chairman of the New York Racing Association, said yesterday that he would step down next Jan. 10.

title: It's Time to Rethink U.S. Policy on El Salvador; The Lesser Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: Nofziger Will Not Be Retried
description: The independent counsel who prosecuted Lyn C. Nofziger, the former White House aide, on charges of illegal lobbying said today that he would not seek to try the case again.

title: Charge Is Set By Tambrands
description: Tambrands Inc., maker of Tampax tampons, said yesterday that it will take a one-time charge in its fourth quarter of $65 million, equivalent to half of its 1988 fourth-quarter revenue. The company, based in Lake

title: Drugs in Atlanta: A Lost Generation
description: It was a decade ago that 29 young blacks, most of them children, died here in a series of murders that shook Atlanta to its core and transfixed the nation.

title: Reasons Is Emerging As a Valuable Giant
description: When the Giants drafted Gary Reasons in 1984, they had two Pro Bowl linebackers in Lawrence Taylor and Harry Carson. They had just drafted a future Pro Bowl linebacker in Carl Banks, and they had just cut loose an aging Pro Bowl linebacker in Brad Van Pelt.

title: The Woman Behind the Movie About the Scandal
description: Blaze Starr was on stage. ''Hi, hon,'' she was saying in her medium-heavy West Virginia drawl. ''You get right over here, and I'll tell you all about it.'' A half-dozen regular customers were pressing close to the legendary stripteaser, asking eager questions. This was not, however, a heavy-breathing pack of male aficionados of bump and grind, but a group of female shoppers browsing at Blaze Starr's Handmade Jewelry in the Carrolltowne Mall.

title: U.S. War Game in West Germany to Be Cut Back
description: In an effort to save money and to take account of political changes in Eastern Europe, the Pentagon has sharply scaled back the major American military exercise in Europe, by, among other things, eliminating the use of tanks, Pentagon officials said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers 102, Heat 75: Magic Johnson and Vlade Divac each scored 6 points during an 18-2 second-half run last night to lead the Lakers in Miami. The Heat trailed, 65-54, with four minutes left in the third quarter before Los Angeles scored 7 consecutive points. After Sherman Douglas scored for Miami, Los Angeles scored 11 points in a row; Divac made three baskets during the run. Los Angeles, which has beaten Miami by an average of 32 points in five meetings, built the lead to 94-61. (AP) Celtics 109, SuperSonics 97: Larry Bird scored 40 points and passed Julius Erving for 21st place among the N.B.A.'s point leaders as Boston, playing at home, ended Seattle's four-game winning streak. Bird, playing in his 11th season after sitting out most of the 1988-89 campaign with injuries, raised his career total to 18,391 points. He needed 13 to pass Erving. Bird also had 11 rebounds and 10 assists. (AP) 76ers 112, Hawks 103: In Philadelphia, Hersey Hawkins scored 27 points as Philadelphia snapped Atlanta's seven-game winning streak. Johnny Dawkins and Charles Barkley each added 23 points for Philadelphia, which led by 60-46 at halftime and never trailed. Dominique Wilkins led all scorers with 38 points. (AP) Mavericks 90, Timberwolves 87: The visiting Mavericks snapped a three-game losing streak as Rolando Blackman scored 20 points.(AP) Cavaliers 99, Bucks 93: Larry Nance scored 31 points, including 4 in the final minute to lead Cleveland. The Cavaliers, who outrebounded the Bucks, 54-33, are 3-0 since Nance returned from off-season ankle surgery. They were 6-11 when he returned. The Bucks lost their fifth straight road game.(AP) Jazz 102, Suns 95: John Stockton had 22 points and 15 assists as Utah rode an 11-0 run late in the game for the victory at Salt Lake City. Karl Malone had 24 points and 12 rebounds for the Jazz, who got 18 points from Thurl Bailey off the bench. The Jazz made eight free throws without a miss in the final 29 seconds.(AP) Warriors 134, Nuggets 114: Chris Mullin scored 33 points and grabbed a career-high 18 rebounds, including 12 in the decisive second period, as Golden State won at home. Mullin, averaging just 4.6 rebounds this season and 3.3 over his five-season career, had 15 by halftime.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Missouri 89, Arkansas 88: Doug Smith scored the last of his 24 points on a layup with 12 seconds left last night to give Missouri the victory in Fayetteville, Ark. Mario Credit gave Arkansas an 88-87 lead with a jump hook with 51 seconds remaining. After Smith scored, Lee Mayberry missed a long jumper for the Razorbacks in the final seconds. Missouri is 8-0. Arkansas is 5-1. The 6-foot-10-inch Smith and 6-9 Nathan Buntin, who also scored 24 points, consistently got inside the Arkansas defense. Todd Day scored 26 points for Arkansas. (AP) Georgetown 92, St. Leo 51: Dikembe Mutombo scored 15 points, grabbed 17 rebounds and blocked 8 shots last night as Georgetown (6-0) won its 23d straight home game. The Hoyas never trailed, using a decided height advantage to easily dispose of the Division II Monarchs (4-3).(AP) HORSE RACING Kid Russell Is Winner: Kid Russell shook Creativity off nearing the stretch, opened a clear lead and held on to carry Jerry Bailey to a one-length victory in the $45,000 Dr. Patches purse yesterday at Aqueduct. The Real Virginian rallied to finish second in the field of eight 3-year-olds and up, one length ahead of Leading Appeal. Kid Russell covered six furlongs on the fast but dull track in 1:11 2/5 to earn $27,000 with his fourth victory in 10 starts this year. He returned $4.80 for $2 to win.(AP) N.H.L. Maple Leafs 4, Red Wings 2: Ed Olczyk and Gary Leeman each had a goal and an assist last night in Detroit as the Maple Leafs won their fourth straight game. The Maple Leafs, who last won four in a row in 1987, improved to 16-17-0 and ended the Red Wings' five-game unbeaten streak. With the score tied, 2-2, after one period, Tom Fergus put Toronto ahead to stay with a power-play goal 6 minutes 54 seconds into the second period.(AP) Kings 5, Whalers 2: Bernie Nicholls scored his 23d and 24th goals and Wayne Gretzky tied an N.H.L. record by earning an assist for the 17th straight game to lead the visiting Kings.(AP) Blackhawks 3, Canadiens 1: Denis Savard scored the tie-breaking goal late in the second period to lead the visiting Blackhawks to their fourth straight victory. Savard took a pass from Steve Larmer at the side of the Canadiens' net and beat the goaltender Brian Hayward with a fake at 19:37 of the second period. It put Chicago ahead, 2-1. Adam Creighton scored into an empty net with seven seconds left. Jimmy Waite, the Chicago goaltender, won in his first N.H.L. start.(AP) Bruins 4, Sabres 2: Ray Bourque atoned for a rare error with the go-ahead goal and Dave Christian, who was acquired earlier in the day from Washington, scored a goal as Boston ended ended Buffalo's 12-game home winning streak. Buffalo, which could have set a franchise record with its 13th straight home victory, is 13-1-1 at Memorial Auditorium. Bourque, an All-Star defenseman, made a rare error to allow the Sabres to tie the game, 2-2, early in the second period. But Bourque got credit for the game-winning goal when Daren Puppa, the Buffalo goaltender, misplayed his long slap shot. (AP) Jets 3, Canucks 3: Paul Reinhart's goal at 8:24 of the third period gave Vancouver the tie in Winnipeg, Manitoba. Reinhart scored with a slap shot after Dave Ellett gave Winnipeg a 3-2 lead at 2:52 when he beat Kirk McLean after an excellent setup by Dave McLlwain. The Canucks appeared to break the tie with 2:34 remaining in regulation time, but Referee Denis Morel ruled that Igor Larionov had directed the puck into the net with his skate. Kirk McLean robbed Randy Carlyle with a spectacular glove save with 59 seconds left to preserve the tie. (AP) Oilers 5, Nordiques 1: Craig MacTavish scored his league-leading fourth shorthanded goal and picked up his 300th N.H.L. point to lead Edmonton, playing at home. MacTavish's goal, his 12th of the season, came with the Oilers two men short in the second period and broke the backs of the last-place Nordiques.(AP)

title: '90 Soccer Calendar Busy
description: The Marlboro Cup, a series of four-team international soccer tournaments held in four United States cities, will be facing some unaccustomed competition from abroad next year: the 1990 World Cup.

title:
Currents;
Humble Materials And a Polished Result
description: LEAD: WITH cheap, ''unassuming'' materials ranging from paper products to wood pulp to wood chips, the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien of New York have built a house for the exhibit ''Domestic Arrangements,'' at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis through Feb. 11.

title: Bankruptcy Looms As Option to Owner Of Bloomingdale's
description: The Campeau Corporation's rocky 18-month adventure in American retailing has run into its biggest cash squeeze yet, forcing its American subsidiaries, which own Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and other national chains, to say they might have to file for bankruptcy protection.

title: Battle of New Jersey Goes to Seton Hall
description: Seton Hall traveled down the highway tonight to play Rutgers in a hostile environment before a raucous crowd of 8,722 at the Louis Brown Athletic Center. The Pirates were opposing a team that was primed for the challenge. Selected by many publications to be the class of the Atlantic 10 Conference this season, Rutgers hoped to topple a team that became the darlings of New Jersey last season by making it to the National Collegiate Athletic Association final.

title: 4 Fined for Fight In Laker-Hornet Game
description: Stuart Gray, a Charlotte Hornets forward; Byron Scott and Michael Cooper, Los Angeles Laker guards, and James Worthy, a Laker forward, drew fines from the National Basketball Association yesterday for fighting in the second period in the Lakers' 103-89 victory over the Hornets Tuesday night at Charlotte, N.C..

title: Best Products Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Best Products attributed the increasing losses to additional interest expense of $26.4 million and $76 million for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Coffee Group Sets Meeting
description: The new Coffee Consumers Caucus will meet with Government officials next month for discussions on American policies affecting the international coffee cartel and its effect on the United States, the caucus's founder, Godfrey Harris, said today.

title: De Klerk and Mandela Discuss Future
description: President F. W. de Klerk discussed South Africa's future with Nelson R. Mandela today, raising the expectation that the imprisoned anti-apartheid leader may be released early next year.

title: Sullivan Naming Panel on F.D.A. Problems
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, says he will appoint a panel to study the troubled Food and Drug Administration and make recommendations within a year.

title: Carlos Barral, Author, 61
description: Carlos Barral, an editor and author, died of internal bleeding in a hospital on Tuesday. He was 61 years old.

title: Bush Plans a Brief Stay at Colombia Drug Talks
description: The White House announced today that President Bush would attend a four-nation conference on narcotics in the Colombian city of Cartagena, but Administration officials said Mr. Bush would spend only a few hours there because of security concerns.

title: Calendar: Wreath Workshop
description: Presents Past, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; 212-861-3358.

title: Court Backs Landmarks Law
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday rejected a broad challenge to New York City's landmarks preservation law by St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: It's Time to Rethink U.S. Policy on El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Amzi Berla, 59, Advertising Executive
description: Peter Amzi Berla, an advertising and marketing executive, died of cancer yesterday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Miami Officer Reprimanded For Sign Viewed as Unfitting
description: A rookie officer has been reprimanded by the Police Department for covering his badge with black tape - a gesture usually reserved for honoring slain officers - as a show of support for William Lozano, a Hispanic colleague convicted of manslaughter last week in the death of two black men.

title: Harvesting a Tree in the Woods or on a City Sidewalk
description: ABOUT 35 million Americans are expected to bring Christmas trees home this month. No one knows how many of them buy their trees at garden centers or tree lots in cities, but a growing number are going to Christmas tree farms to choose and cut their own trees in an effort to re-create one aspect of an old-fashioned holiday season.

title: Celebrating Jimmie Lunceford, a Big-Band Master
description: Any list of the greatest bands of the swing era usually starts with those of Count Basie, Benny Goodman and Duke Ellington. Except in select circles, Jimmie Lunceford's orchestra is apt to be farther down the list. Yet the Lunceford band, for a few brief years in the 1930's, was one of the most exciting big jazz bands that ever played.

title: Conrail Layoffs
description: In a significant cost-cutting move, the Consolidated Rail Corporation said it would cut its nonunion work force by 12 percent, or about 450 administrative and management positions, and would take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $70 million to $80 million for the cuts and other related restructuring expenses. Conrail, the giant freight railroad created in 1976 from the bankrupt remains of six Northeast railroads, was spun off to the public in 1987. It has been hurt by an overall decline in rail traffic.

title: Israel Bank Head Quits
description: The head of Israel's fourth-largest bank, the United Mizrahi Bank, has resigned today in the wake of charges that the institution was mismanaged. ''My resignation is in no way an agreement with criticism voiced recently in regard to management of the bank under my leadership,'' the managing director, Michael Zvineri, said. The Bank of Israel, the country's central bank, recommended on Sunday that Mr. Zvineri resign because the bank had granted too many unsecured loans. United Mizrahi is linked to Israel's National Religious Party.

title: Anti-Government Protesters Confront Benin's Riot Police
description: Thousands of demonstrators calling for the resignation of President Mathieu Kerekou confronted riot policemen here today.

title: What Makes Plane Boarding Like Hockey
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentine Leader Seeking Labor-Business Pact to Rescue Economy
description: Argentina's Government said today that it is trying to enlist the leaders of business, labor and the political parties in forming a social pact that will help the country weather its latest economic crisis.

title: Neighbor Sighted 160,000 Light-Years Away
description: Astronomers have detected what they believe is the most distant star in the Milky Way galaxy, and they expect the discovery to lead to the first precise measurement of the galaxy's total mass.

title: ABDUCTED WOMAN FREED IN KASHMIR
description: Rubiya Sayeed, the 23-year-old daughter of India's Minister of Home Affairs, was freed here this evening by her kidnappers shortly after the release of five Kashmiri Muslim militants.

title: John Slawson, 93, Retired Leader Of American Jewish Committee
description: Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president emeritus of the American Jewish Committee, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Dr. Slawson retired in 1967 after 24 years as leader of the organization, which was founded in 1906 to combat bigotry and to protect the civil and religious rights of Jews here and abroad. Earlier he had been executive director of the Jewish Board of Guardians of New York, executive director of the Jewish Welfare Federation of Detroit and assistant director of the Jewish Welfare Federation of Cleveland.

title: PHILIPPINE REBELS REMAIN AT LARGE
description: Two weeks after a military uprising against President Corazon C. Aquino, most of the army rebels have not been identified or captured, and many are in hiding. Some have returned to their units to resume regular military duties.

title: CRUMBLING SPHINX: WAS IT SABOTAGE?
description: The Egyptian authorities have reopened an investigation into what really happened last year when a 700-pound chunk of the Sphinx's shoulder plummeted to the ground. In a nutshell, the question is: Did it fall or was it pushed?

title: Quanex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2,345,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-After an extraordinary loss of $4,464,000 from the early extinguishment of debt and tax loss carryforwards.

title: Low-Priced Packages Await College Skiers
description: Over the next few weeks, colleges throughout the East will be closed for winter breaks. Coincidentally, a number of Eastern ski areas have scheduled special programs and low-priced packages for college students. The timing is particularly fortuitous this year: skiers are reporting the best skiing in recent memory in the East.

title: Dragonair Stake Sold
description: Beijing's primary overseas investment arm agreed Tuesday to buy 26.6 percent of Hong Kong's Dragonair carrier. The airline's founder, the Hongkong and Macau International Investment Company, sold the stake for more than 100 million Hong Kong dollars (about $12.8 million).

title: Q&A
description: Concrete Atop Concrete

title: Inspectors Jeered at Possible Nuclear-Waste Site
description: State inspectors trying to examine a Cortland County site being considered for a low-level radioactive-waste dump were jeered by protesters today and forced to abandon their inspection.

title: News Events Inspire Gifts To Neediest
description: Events that made news in 1989 -both good and bad - inspired some people to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as the 78th annual campaign moves into high gear.

title: British Say Deportations Will Resume in 1990
description: A senior British Government official said today that there would probably be no more deportations of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong to Vietnam this year.

title: Time Warner Reports Fees
description: Investment bankers were paid a total of about $125 million in fees related to the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc., according to the prospectus for newly issued securities of Time Warner Inc.

title: Squatter Camps on Federal Preserve to Be Razed
description: Armed with a Federal court ruling, the National Park Service plans to demolish 156 squatter camps in the Big Cypress National Preserve. But the squatters are disputing the ruling and have written to 79 United States senators in a last-ditch attempt to save their holdings.

title: Topics of The Times; Health Data, Hidden
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop left office recently, in a well-deserved blaze of glory. But now there's reason to wonder about the way he handled a Reagan Administration request to investigate whether abortion is harmful to a woman's health. Dr. Koop reported there were not enough data to support such a conclusion. According to a study by the House Government Operations Committee, Dr. Koop was fudging his findings.

title: Zaire's Battered Economy Inspires Optimism
description: Western economists here say this country's long-moribund economy is showing promising signs of recovery.

title: Review/Film; Black Combat Bravery in the Civil War
description: Before the Battle of Antietam on Sept. 17, 1862, Robert Gould Shaw, a young white Bostonian with strong abolitionist sentiments, wrote to his mother, ''We fight for men and women whose poetry is not yet written.''

title: 2 Survivors of Iowa Blast Deny Shipmate Set It Off
description: Two survivors of the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa asserted today that the sailor who has been accused by the Navy of deliberately setting off the blast in which he and 46 shipmates died did not cause the explosion.

title: U.S. Actions In Bond Loss By Columbia
description: Federal regulators had placed tight restrictions on the Columbia Savings and Loan Association last month after new accounting rules forced the institution to recognize large losses in the value of its ''junk bond'' portfolio, company executives and Government officials said today.

title: Hialeah Cuts Racing Days
description: The owner of Hialeah Park, who had wanted to close the race track, agreed today to keep it open Saturdays, Sundays, and Mondays.

title: Dinkins Supports Removal of Tents In Tompkins Park
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he supports plans by the New York City Parks Department this week to remove tents and other structures that homeless people have erected in Tompkins Square Park on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

title: U.S. Corn Sale to Soviets
description: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 103,632 metric tons of United States corn to the Soviet Union for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department. No selling prices or further details were released.

title: Number of Poor in Boston Is Found to Decline
description: The number of people living in poverty here declined in the economic boom of the 1980's, a study by a nonprofit organization has found.

title: Pedro Toledo Ugarte, Financier, 54
description: Pedro Toledo Ugarte, co-president of Spain's largest commercial bank, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya, died of a liver ailment on Tuesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 54 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about overweight among Hispanic Americans referred incorrectly to the body mass index used by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: INSIDE
description: Guilty Verdict in Stock Case The GAF Corporation and a senior executive were found guilty of stock manipulation. Page D1. Mandela Meets de Klerk The imprisoned black leader was welcomed into the South African President's office. Page A3. At the Galaxy's Edge Astronomers have found what they believe is the most distant known star in the Milky Way. Page B16.

title: Entertainment Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $640,000, or 5 cents a share, and $2,146,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after extraordinary credits of $402,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,159,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said the extraordinary credits are gains on the extinguishment of debt.

title: Macy, R. H.  & Co.  reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: Sales represented net retail sales, which included licensed departments. The sales from licensed departments totaled $24,396,000 for the latest first quarter and $25,403,000 for the year- ago perid.

title: Talking Deals; At Avis Europe, Solving a Puzzle
description: WITH a palpable slowdown of debt-financed takeovers in the United States, Wall Street merger experts view the prospect of an integrated European market in 1992 and closer ties with a newly emerging Eastern Europe as providing their next frontier. Yet, as the recent experience of Avis Europe P.L.C. shows, acquisitions in Europe can present a dizzying array of problems and challenges that can have large effects on a deal's ultimate cost.

title: Influence in Nassau; H.U.D. Housing on Long Island: Tales of Favoritsm
description: Certain applicants for scarce apartments in several buildings for the elderly subsidized by the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Nassau County have been able to bypass long waiting lists, according to a former employee of the company that runs the buildings, as well as current and former elected officials.

title: Huffman Koos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included a tax benefit of $338,000.

title:
Currents;
Architects' Show Focuses on Lighting
description: LEAD: ''FURNITURE and tableware design get all the attention,'' Susan Bower said. ''Lighting tends to be overlooked.''

title: Topeka Has Failed to Do Enough To Integrate Schools, Court Rules
description: A Federal appeals panel has issued a revised opinion saying that the city of Topeka has not done enough to desegregate its schools since the Brown v. Board of Education case. But in a dissenting opinion one judge argued that ''substantial integration'' had been achieved.

title: U.S. Judge Rules Drug Tests Violated Rights
description: The United States Postal Service has violated the constitutional rights of job applicants by requiring them to undergo drug tests without good reason, a Federal district judge here has ruled.

title: GTE Receives $4.5 Million
description: The GTE Corporation has accepted $4.5 million from Home Shopping Network Inc. as the cash settlement on a $100 million damage award against the retailer, which sells its products on cable television. The two sides announced in

title: Mother Held In Killing Says She's a Victim
description: A woman who has been charged with her companion in the beating death of her 3-year-old son at a Queens hotel has had a deeply troubled and violence-scarred life in which she, her relatives and lawyer picture her as no less a victim than her son.

title: St. Louis Sails Past Rangers
description: The Ranger injury report before the game was bad. The developments during the game itself - further damage to personnel and pride -were bad, too. So it was little surprise that the mood afterward was grim.

title: Witt Fears Change May Hurt East Germany's Sports Elite
description: Back home on a break from shooting a film in Spain, wearing fashionably faded jeans and a matching jacket, Katarina Witt warned today that too many changes could damage East Germany's elite sports system and drive top athletes out of the country.

title: Upheaval in the East; Unification: Caution Flag
description: While jostling furiously for a visible place on the reunification bandwagon, West German politicians have begun urging more caution and less haste in plotting German unity.

title: Texas Court, 6-3, Overturns Murder Conviction of Black
description: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals today set aside the rape and murder conviction of a man who twice came within days of execution and whose case caused outrage among blacks here.

title: Upheaval in the East; Aid to Poland and Hungary Pledged by Western Nations
description: Western governments announced plans today to step up their economic assistance to Poland and Hungary as part of a 24-nation effort to help the two countries make the difficult transition from centrally planned to market economies.

title: How the Brazilian Leftist Surged: With TV
description: Television, which electronically binds this sprawling nation together, is a major factor behind the sudden surge of a leftist candidate in Brazil's presidential race, analysts here say.

title: Cambodia Agrees to U.N.-Controlled Election
description: The Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia is ready to disband its Council of Ministers before a United Nations-controlled election in an effort to end the 11-year civil war, a leading editor with close ties to the Government said.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in very light trading again yesterday, as dealers shrugged off a report that suggested that consumers, who account for two-thirds of the economy, remained active last month.

title: 10-Week 'Boheme' Tour Planned by City Opera
description: The New York City Opera National Company, the touring division of City Opera, is to begin a 10-week tour of Puccini's ''Boheme'' on Jan. 19 in State College, Pa. The tour, which is to include 57 performances and will travel to 26 states and Canada, is to end in Columbia, S.C., on March 28.

title: Ultimap International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Topics of The Times; Underground Voices
description: A New Yorker returning to the city after a long absence finds himself confused by the subway system but comforted by the conductors. He is grateful to them for telling him at every stop where he is, where he is going next and what his travel options are. The simple announcement ''14th Street - change for the L'' leaves him wondering if he will ever go to Canarsie, which is where the L train goes. The complex ''42d Street - change for the A, C, E, R, 1, 2, 3'' makes him feel rich with choice, as if he were at an international crossroads.

title: Japan Gallery Director
description: Dr. Gunhild Avitabile, the Far East curator at the Museum of Applied Arts in Frankfurt, has been named director of the Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street. Dr. Avitabile is to assume her job next month.

title: British Air and KLM Acquire 40% of Sabena
description: In a deal that gives them an opportunity to develop Brussels as a major airline center, British Airways P.L.C. and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reached an agreement today in which each will acquire a 20 percent stake in the airline operation of Sabena S.A. of Belgium.

title: Metro Matters; For Mayor-Elect, Belt-Tightening Ahead of Time
description: ''My campaign,'' David N. Dinkins declared repeatedly as a candidate, ''is about change.''

title: A Feud Between The Nation and The New Republic
description: The New Republic and The Nation, once almost indistinguishable as the country's principal journals of liberal opinion, have for several years now intensely disliked each other as only former members of the same political family who have taken diverging paths can. Lately, there have been more than the usual number of sniping incidents as the ideological battle of the magazines goes on.

LEAD: ABSENT from this holiday season are the decorous white lights, balls and tinsel of the last few years. In their place are ornaments that appeal to virtually any special interest, from golf to food to fine French furniture. Even the decorations are being decorated: there are some romantic glass covers for past years' pristine white lights.

title: Despite Worries, Mall's Registers Jingle
description: There was young Kyle Beneziano, waiting in line for his chance to go through the artificial snow and talk to Santa Claus. He was yelling and kicking. ''His mother took him to meet Santa already at the Willowbrook Mall,'' said his grandmother, Linda Beneziano.

title: Ormand Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary loss representing a charge from reversal of tax-loss carryforward of $174,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months included an extraordinary tax credit of $2,000 as well as income from discontinued operations of $341,000, or 17 cents a share, which included $759,000 loss from discontinued operations and $1,100,000 gain from disposal of discontinued operations. Year-ago quarter's results included $384,000 loss from discontinued operations and $384,000 gain from disposal of discontinued operations. Results for 1988 have been restated.

title: Matsushita-Philips Deal
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and Philips N.V. of the Netherlands will jointly set up a British company to develop devices enabling one remote controller to control different entertainment systems, a Matsushita spokesman said. The device is called a domestic digital bus, or D2B. Philips plans to sell televisions and videotape recorders with D2B in Europe, and Matsushita is considering it in Japan.

title: Home Improvement
description: FOR making home repairs, happiness is often having the right tool for the job. Many tasks can be accomplished with only a basic kit: tape measure, claw hammer, crosscut saw, hacksaw, regular and cross-slot screwdrivers, adjustable wrench, pliers and electric drill. But adding some specialized tools broadens the range of projects possible and makes some jobs easier.

title: Schembechler Will Retire as Michigan Coach
description: After more than two decades as one of America's most successful college football coaches, Glenn Edward (Bo) Schembechler of Michigan announced today that he would leave his job following the Jan. 1 Rose Bowl game against Southern Cal.

title: 2 British Soldiers Killed in Raid
description: A gang armed with guns and bombs attacked a security post on the Irish border today, killing two British soldiers and seriously wounding a third, the police said.

title: 63 Arrested in U.S. Protest
description: Sixty-three people were arrested today in a demonstration outside the Federal Building here to protest United States military aid to El Salvador. One hundred people, including priests, trade union members and the actors Martin Sheen and Edward Asner, took part in the demonstration and carried posters reading ''Death Squads Out of El Salvador'' and ''Stop Aid to Death Squads.'' Mr. Asner was among those arrested.

title: For Prague's Institutes, It's Goodbye to Marxism
description: If the students at the Higher School of Economics weren't already in a state of elation over the present political upheaval and their prominent role in bringing it about, today's press announcement would have been even more happily received. But it did come as another increment of joy.

title: UAL Board Plans Talks With Group
description: The board of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it would hold talks with representatives of the Coniston Group, which owns 11.8 percent of the company and has threatened to oust the board unless it finds a way to raise the price of UAL shares.

title: Pulaski Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Telco Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
The Czar's New Clothes
description: All over this country there are officials who try to deal with the drug menace - policemen, Federal agents, prosecutors, judges - and know that our policy does not work. They see that the criminal law does not reduce drug supplies or stop the rot in our society. But fearful of being called ''soft,'' few say anything in public.

title: Dinkins Margin Smallest in 80 Years, Tally Shows
description: The New York City Board of Elections released the official mayoral election returns yesterday, showing that Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins defeated Rudolph W. Giuliani by 47,080 votes, the smallest majority for a mayoral candidate in more than 80 years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This planning system reminds me of egg production.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in The Living Section on Wednesday about yule log cakes misstated the telephone number for Park Avenue Gourmandises in Manhattan. It is 212-331-4289.

title: Alien Workers Bring Factory a $580,000 Fine
description: In separate actions over the last two days, the Government has won an indictment and imposed a record fine of $580,000 against a South Carolina pillow factory accused of hiring more than 100 illegal aliens, including a 12-year-old boy.

title: Why Rush to Surrender on Drugs?
description: Federal District Judge Robert Sweet adds his voice to those who call for legalization of drugs, along with George Shultz, the former Secretary of State; William F. Buckley, the columnist; Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore, and Milton Friedman, the economist. But the judge offers no persuasive new insights. Instead he demonstrates how frustration with the drug problem clouds common sense.

title: Kabul's Edge In Civil War: Its Air Force
description: The night was black, so much so that the ammunition truck unloading behind the Soviet-built Antonov-32 transport plane, and the plane itself, could only just be made out against a sable sky.

title: Upheaval in the East; SOVIET DEPUTIES FAULT GORBACHEV
description: Defending its economic stewardship, the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev shifted the emphasis of economic planning from heavy industry to consumer goods today. But skeptics in the country's legislature questioned whether a workable recovery plan was even in place yet.

title: Macy's Quarterly Loss Rises to $33.1 Million
description: Contributing more glum news to the retail industry, R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that its losses had worsened in the quarter ending Oct. 28 and that it would cut back its new-store openings sharply over the next two years.

title: Changes On Benefits In Texas
description: Texas lawmakers approved changes on Tuesday in the way benefits would be assigned to workers for job-related injuries and deaths, with business groups and insurers triumphing in a long feud with trial lawyers and union officials.

title: Trac Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $48,243, or 1 cent a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Edward D. Mysak, 59, Speech Disorder Expert
description: Edward D. Mysak, a professor of speech pathology at Teachers College in Manhattan and an expert in the treatment of stutterers and communication disorders in victims of cerebral palsy, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: From Guns to Butter; With Cutbacks Likely in Military Spending, Debate Will Center on Where Cash Will Go
description: No one knows how much money will become available or when. But a consensus has emerged here that improving relations with the Soviet Union will permit the United States to spend tens, perhaps hundreds, of billions of dollars less on the military in the 1990's than was believed possible only weeks ago.

title: Novell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Fleet Aerospace Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $70,000. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $99,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Hill & Knowlton Move
description: David Wynne-Morgan, the chairman and chief executive of Hill & Knowlton in London, has been elected to the board of Hill & Knowlton Inc., the public relations and public affairs counseling firm owned by the WPP Group. Mr. Wynne-Morgan, who was also named executive vice president of Hill & Knowlton Europe, will organize a European financial relations division that will have a mergers and acquisitions capability.

title: M.T.A. Hinting At Retaliation In Connecticut
description: The chairman of the New York State Metropolitan Transportation Authority is considering ''onerous'' sanctions against Connecticut unless Gov. William A. O'Neill backs down on his threat to veto a 15 percent fare increase proposed for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, an M.T.A. spokesman said yesterday.

title: Bruins Trade Joyce
description: In a move designed to increase scoring, the Boston Bruins yesterday traded Bobby Joyce, a second-year left wing who in 115 National Hockey League games had scored 26 goals, to the Washington Capitals for Dave Christian, a center-right wing with 272 goals and 354 assists in 734 N.H.L. games over 10 seasons. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about the departure of Joan Kron as editor of Avenue magazine cited the authorship of the book ''High Tech'' incompletely. It was written by Ms. Kron and Suzanne Slesin.

title: Degradable Plastics Criticized
description: The label ''degradable'' is surfacing on plastic products from trash bags to diapers, but environmentalists say it is a marketing ploy that should be rejected.

title: Penwest Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
New Coach Is No Stranger
description: Gary Moeller, the 48-year-old offensive coordinator who was named today to succeed Bo Schembechler as Michigan coach, is no stranger to the Wolverine program.

title: HEAD OF BOSTON U. WEIGHS CANDIDACY
description: John R. Silber, the president of Boston University, said today that he was ''exploring very seriously'' a bid to become governor of Massachusetts.
