title: When Child's Play Is Collecting, It's Serious Stuff
description: ''IT'S not easy to find good erasers anymore,'' said Sammy Globus, who ought to know. The 10-year-old connoisseur was sitting on his bedroom floor in New York surrounded by the Sammy Globus Collection of Pencil Erasers, an assemblage that may one day do for bits of rubber what Andy Warhol did for cookie jars.

title: Sun City Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Aides See No Victory in American's Release
description: United States officials, reflecting the uncertainty about Jennifer Jean Casolo within the Administration, said privately today that the Connecticut woman's release from prison in El Salvador was not seen as ''a victory'' for the Administration.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Devtek Corp., a maker of aerospace and military products, said it had raised its stake in Tridon Ltd., a Hamilton, Ontario, auto products manufacturer, to 51 percent.

title: Recipients Selected For '89 Mayor's Awards
description: Six performers and a theater organization are the recipients of this year's Mayor's Awards of Honor for their contributions to cultural life in New York city.

title: The Latin Peace Pact Lives
description: Give five Central American presidents credit for breathing fresh life into the ailing regional peace plan. They have agreed on a declaration that calls for demobilizing guerrillas in El Salvador and disbanding U.S.-aided contras in Nicaragua.

title: Frederick J. Ludwig, 71, Professor And a Former Queens Prosecutor
description: Frederick J. Ludwig, a law professor who had been a police officer and an acting district attorney in Queens, died Monday at his home in the Bronx. He was 71 years old.

title: Florida Courts Spurrier
description: Steve Spurrier, the football coach at Duke, has been offered the head coaching job at Florida, but has not given the university an answer, the school said yesterday. The university confirmed a report in The Tampa Tribune that said the 1966 Heisman Trophy winner, who played quarterback at Florida.

title: Decline Seen In Home Prices In New Jersey
description: The days of steeply climbing house prices are over, and the 1990's could begin with prices dropping by as much as 12 percent, according to a report released today by Rutgers University based on three million house sales in New Jersey.

title: Dithering in Moscow
description: Do we want perestroika to succeed? Let's see when it took root.

title: A Forgetful North Vividly Recalls Poindexter as Only Nonantagonist
description: Oliver L. North told a Federal district judge today that John M. Poindexter's testimony before the Iran-contra investigating committees deeply affected him because Mr. Poindexter ''was the only one of all the witnesses who testified who didn't hang Oliver North out to dry.''

title: Review/Music; New Ensemble Explores the 20th Century
description: Robert Craft, the conductor and author who was Igor Stravinsky's assistant from 1948 until the composer's death in 1971, has convened an ensemble of freelance players who are experienced in contemporary music, and with whom he hopes to explore the modern repertory.

title: Danilo Kis Memorial
description: A memorial program for Danilo Kis, the Yugoslav writer and essayist, will be held at 7 P.M. tonight at the Yugoslav Press and Culture Center, 767 Third Avenue, near 48th Street. Speakers will include Susan Sontag, Joseph Brodsky and Roger Straus. Mr. Kis died of cancer in Paris on Oct. 15 at the age of 54.

title: Avery Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $500,000 and $10,484,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $2,757,000, or 23 cents a share. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $5,572,000 and $57,690,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $14,000 for the quarter, which represented additional expenses related to debt extinguished during the fiscal 1988 third quarter, and an extraordinary credit of $2,038,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year. The company said the extraordinary credits represented the net gain attributable to the early extinguishment of debt which is net of expenses principallly representing the writeoff of original issue discount and previously incurred financing fees associated with the debt. Such debt was acquired at market prices which in the aggregate were less than the principal amount of the debt. The company also said it did not report sales and revenues because all of its operating businesses have been discontinued.

title: Great Northern Takeover Fight
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said it would use the courts to fight an unsolicited offer from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation and would not seek a friendly merger or defensive restructuring. Georgia-Pacific, based in Atlanta, has offered $63 a share, or $3.8 billion, for the Norwalk, Conn., paper company.

title: Tokyo Executive Pleads Not Guilty in Recruit Bribery Case
description: The former chairman of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone pleaded not guilty today to taking bribes in the Recruit shares-for-favors scandal, one of the biggest to rock Japan.

title: 9 Podiatrists Indicted for Fraud
description: Nine podiatrists in the New York metropolitan region, including four college instructors and two former deans, have been indicted in a Medicaid fraud case, officials said today.

title: Jackson Says His Knicks Pass the 'Chemistry' Test
description: Stu Jackson, the rookie Knick coach who had no previous head coaching experience, presented his quarterly report yesterday. And the presentation had the trimmings of a ''How am I doing?'' news conference.

title: Brooklyn Academy And Philharmonic To Be Led by Davies
description: They have shared a house in Brooklyn since 1954, and now they are marrying - sort of. The Brooklyn Academy of Music, perhaps New York's prime source of musical adventure, has announced a partnership with the quieter and community-minded Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, also a resident of the 82-year-old Brooklyn Academy theater on Lafayette Avenue, in the Fort Greene section.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Re-signed Mike Smithson, pitcher, to a one-year contract. Re-signed Dana Kiecker, pitcher, and purchased his contract from Pawtucket of the International League. Signed Jeff Stone, outfielder, to a contract with Pawtucket. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Lance Parrish, catcher, to a three-year contract. CHICAGO (NL) - Announced they will not offer a contract to Pat Perry, pitcher. METS (NL) - Signed Orlando Mercado, catcher, to a free-agent contract with Tidewater of the International League. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Dave Schmidt, pitcher, to a one-year contract. OAKLAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Jamie Quirk, catcher, and Scott Sanderson, pitcher, on one-year contracts. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Agreed to terms with Frank DiPino, pitcher, on a two-year contract. TEXAS (AL) - Signed Tom Grieve, vice president and general manager, to a three-year contract extension.

title: 22% Fall in Cotton Crop
description: The 1989 cotton crop is expected to be slightly less than 12.1 million bales, down 22 percent from last year's harvest but almost the same as estimated in November, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday. In its new estimate based on field conditions as of Dec. 1, the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service said a 20 percent drop in the acreage for harvest and slightly lower yields accounted for the decline.

title: Upheaval in the East; CZECHS NEAR PACT TO PICK PRESIDENT
description: The Communist Party and the opposition appeared to be moving toward agreement today on a plan to purge Parliament of hard-line Communists to pave the way for the election of a successor to Gustav Husak, the Communist President who stepped down under pressure on Sunday.

title: Salvador Judge Impugns Evidence And Frees American in Arms Case
description: An American woman arrested here after an arms cache was uncovered on her rented property was deported today after a military judge ordered her released for lack of evidence. The announcement of her freedom was made by President Alfredo Cristiani.

title: 11 Nations in Drug Test Accord
description: The United States, the Soviet Union and nine other countries today signed an agreement that calls on the countries to test one another's athletes for the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title:
Currents;
Japanese Crafts: No Junk
description: LEAD: ''YOU rarely find high-quality Japanese crafts in American stores,'' says Noriko Fujikawa. ''Too often you see only junk or antiques.''

title: Is Rumania Next to Go?
description: LEAD: Astonishing changes have swept every Eastern European country except Rumania, which might have been expected to change as drastically as its neighbors but has not. Why?

title: GATT Talks With China
description: Chinese delegates were asked numerous questions about their economic policies as GATT member states reopened talks on Beijing's bid to rejoin the world trade forum, officials said today.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
An Insidious Test for AIDS
description: LEAD: One morning not long ago, a young woman came to my apartment to take blood and urine samples, as required by the company to which I had applied for an individual health insurance policy. She opened her briefcase and began arranging needles, vials and bandages on the kitchen table.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Campeau has run into its biggest cash squeeze yet, forcing its two American retail subsidiaries to say for the first time that they had to consider the possibility of filing for bankruptcy protection. The cash problem stems from payments and interest on $5.04 billion in debt and an inability to obtain additional loans. [ Page A1. ] R. H. Macy's losses worsened in the quarter ended Oct. 28. It said it would cut back its new-store openings sharply in the next two years. [ D8. ] GAF and a senior executive were found guilty of illegally trying to manipulate the stock of Union Carbide in 1986 after an unsuccessful attempt to take over the company. [ D1. ] Federal regulators placed tight restrictions on Columbia Savings and Loan last month after new accounting rules forced it to recognize large losses in its ''junk bond'' portfolio. [ D1. ] Hoping to find television viewers who are not counted by current rating methods, the three major television networks recommended some changes in the way Nielsen measures the national audience. [ D1. ] Integrated Resources announced a loss of more than $1 billion for the April-June quarter as a result of failing businesses and cheap asset sales in a bid to avoid bankruptcy. [ D2. ] UAL's board said it would hold talks with representatives of the Coniston Group, which holds an 11.8 percent stake and has threatened to oust the board. [ D5. ] British Airways and KLM will each acquire 20 percent of Sabena, giving them an opportunity to expand in Brussels. [ D5. ] A.T.& T. proposed increasing telecommunications circuits between the U.S. and the Soviet Union, using Soviet satellites. [ D5. ] Investment bankers received about $125 million in fees related to the merger of Time and Warner Communications [ D5. ] MARKETS The stock market moved higher in stepped-up trading, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.96 points, to 2,761.09. [ D12. ] Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in very light trading, as dealers shrugged off a report that suggested stronger-than-expected retail sales in November. [ D22. ] Yields of money market mutual funds were unchanged to slightly down for the week ended yesterday. [ D10. ] Gold futures prices fell sharply as the Soviet Union rejected changes that many investors had hoped would lead to a gold-backed Soviet currency. [ D23. ] The dollar finished mixed against other major currencies. [ D23. ] THE ECONOMY Sales of U.S.-built cars plunged in early December, as the industry's slump showed no signs of abating. As dealers' inventories rose to their highest levels in a decade, the industry's annualized selling rate fell to its lowest level in more than two years. [ D1. ] Retail sales climbed 0.8 percent in November, the biggest gain since August, the Commerce Department said, in a report that provided some reassurance economic expansion would continue. [ D8. ] INTERNATIONAL The nation's trade deficit shrank 29 percent in the third quarter, to $22.69 billion, the smallest trade gap in six years. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS An integrated European market and closer ties with Eastern Europe are expected to be the next frontier for buyouts. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] A long-running dispute comes to a conclusion today as Cypress Fund shareholders vote on whether to throw out management. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D12. ] ''Our generation just demands quality,'' says Jann S. Wenner, publisher of Rolling Stone and editor in chief of US. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D25. ]

title: Yields Flat Or Off a Bit
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were unchanged to slightly down for the week ended yesterday.

title: Current Account Trade Gap Shrank 29%
description: The deficit in the broadest measure of the nation's trade shrank 29 percent in the third quarter, to $22.69 billion, the smallest trade gap in almost six years.

title: Winterthur Treasures in a New Light
description: ADMIRERS of American antiques have an opportunity to sample treasures of the Winterthur Museum in an entirely new way at an exhibition that opened Tuesday at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art in Manhattan.

title: Talks on Indian Ocean Isle Stall
description: A French naval task force cruised off the Comoro Islands today as negotiations to persuade mercenaries to leave the archipelago remained deadlocked for a third day.

title: Harris Tweed Weavers Idled by Fashion's Mood
description: Here on Lewis and Harris, a remote island of peat bogs and rocky pastures and black-faced sheep, the talk is about the fashions and the weather in America.

title: Washington Talk; Odd Couple Is Doing 'Clean Air' Fandango
description: The scene: a recent Washington reception.

title: School Says No to Mistletoe
description: Mistletoe has been banned at Moorhead State University after a psychology instructor, Margaret Potter, filed a grievance saying she believed it encouraged sexual harassment.

title: Takeover Bill In Pennsylvania
description: The Pennsylvania Senate voted, 45 to 4, yesterday in favor of one of the strongest anti-takeover statutes in the nation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3026 Soviet Jews are emigrating in record numbers, and Israel is bracing for its greatest explosion of immigration since its early days of independence. Page A1

title: Landscaper Charged In Killing of Girl, 14
description: A 20-year-old landscaper was arrested today and charged with the murder of 14-year-old Jessica Manners, whose body was found last March on a rocky embankment of Setauket Harbor near her home in Stony Brook.

title: Close to Home
description: MY brother-in-law is impossible. My sister is not so bad. My niece is easy. My aunt is as impossible as my brother-in-law. My mother can be tricky. My older daughter lives so far away that sending a check is the only sane stratagem. My younger daughter provides a long list that always ends with ''lots of surprises.'' It is time for the Christmas shopping.

title: Utility Backs Merger Deal
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire agreed today to be bought by Northeast Utilities for about $2.3 billion, ending a long battle for the cash-short company.

title: The Catcher Was Highly Mysterious
description: In the baseball press boxes at Shea Stadium and Yankee Stadium in the 1960's and early 1970's, a man wearing a black suit, a black tie, black shoes - the ensemble never varied - with black hair and a touch of gray at the temples, black eyebrows rather closely knit, and a warm smile, an elegant demeanor, a high intelligence and an air of mystery was often seen.

title: Blue Arrow Moves To Change Name
description: The board of Blue Arrow P.L.C. voted unanimously to recommend to stockholders that the company change its name to Manpower P.L.C., the name of the big agency it acquired in 1987.

title: A-PLANT OPERATOR TOLD TO POST BOND
description: A Federal district judge has taken the unusual step of ordering a company whose legal costs are paid by the Energy Department to post an $85.4 million bond to cover the settlement of a suit brought by neighbors of a nuclear weapons plant in Ohio.

title: Nurse Convicted In Four Killings At L.I. Hospital
description: A former nurse at a Long Island hospital was convicted today of murder, manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide for killing four patients as part of a scheme in which he hoped to be seen as a hero.

title: Cutting Classes, and Welfare
description: A teen-ager from a welfare family is repeatedly absent from school. Is it fair to penalize the family by reducing its welfare payments? Wisconsin thinks the answer is yes. That might make sense if the state also provided adequate social services to help students stay in school. Without them, the policy is unfair.

title: Economic Scene; No Consensus About Recession
description: IS the economy on the verge of a recession?

title: Review/Theater; Truman Capote, When the Best Years Were Over
description: When the curtain rises on the bloated, jowly bubble of flesh that is the title character of ''Tru,'' Jay Presson Allen's monodrama about Truman Capote, a sentimental theatergoer is not so much startled by the resurrection of Capote, who died in 1984, as shocked by the obliteration of Robert Morse, last seen on Broadway in the mid-1970's. Buried somewhere in that skin-colored tub of Jell-O - the work of makeup man Kevin Haney, whose credits include the movies ''Altered States'' and ''Wolfen'' - is the sprite whose grin of impetuous youth charmed a nation in ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' a good quarter-century ago.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q&A column of Science Times on Tuesday about a possible 10th planet referred incorrectly to the orbit of Chiron, a rocky object in the outer solar system. It lies between Saturn and Uranus, not beyond Pluto.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Traffic May Become A Phenomenal Mess
description: Forget gridlock. New York City transportation officials say they are braced for what they're calling a ''traffic syzygy'' today.

title: Dinkins Appointee Sees No New Tax Incentives
description: Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, who is to be deputy mayor for finance and economic development in the administration of David N. Dinkins, said yesterday that she did not foresee New York City providing any new tax incentives to help retain businesses in the near future.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''ALADDIN,'' a play performed by the Royal Buckingham Theater Company, 8 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays, and 3 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, through Jan. 15, at the Nat Horne Theater, 440 West 42d Street. Tickets: children, under 12, $10; others, $15. Information: 279-4200. ''THE DANGEROUS CHRISTMAS OF RED RIDING HOOD,'' with music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Bob Merrill and book by Robert Emmett, with previews at 7:30 tonight, 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow and 1 P.M. on Sunday; regular performance at 3:30 P.M. on Sunday. Tada Theater, 120 West 28th Street. Admission: children, $5; adults, $7. Information: 627-1732. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE WIZARD,'' a play about a shy dragon who lives in Central Park and a sly wizard, written by Miranda McDermott, with child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. on Saturdays, at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations required: 734-5195. ''THE CHRISTMAS SPIRIT,'' a play about the importance of giving simple gifts in the holiday season, presented by a new group, Any Theater Company, 2:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Heckscher Oval, Children's Library, Lincoln Center. Free. Visitors may donate toys or clothing, particularly mittens, hats or scarfs, to be given to the Partnership for the Homeless. Informaton: 870-1630.

title: Birch Society Disclosed Waldheim Secret in '76
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Bars Reduction in Social Security Staff
description: President Bush has barred a planned reduction in the Social Security Administration's staff in the face of mounting complaints of curtailed services to beneficiaries, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Washington at Work; Kirkland Wins Acclaim for Success Abroad, but Faces Criticism at Home
description: Television viewers could hardly have expected to see Lech Walesa when they tuned in the sitcom ''Roseanne'' and the Miami-Notre Dame football game Thanksgiving week. But there was Poland's Solidarity leader, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. button in the lapel of his conservative brown suit, promoting the labor federation in a 30-second spot that appeared in tens of millions of American living rooms.

title: Critic's Notebook; Vincente Minnelli's Films as Hollywood's Mirror
description: In early adolescence, when I was too ignorant to know that a roguish Fred Astaire could be more seductive than an overwrought Richard Burton, Vincente Minnelli's ''Sandpiper'' seemed the ultimate screen romance. Years later, I was amazed to realize that this crass 1965 Burton-Taylor melodrama about adultery in scenic Big Sur was one of the last gasps from the director of such graceful, classic musicals as ''Meet Me in St. Louis,'' ''Gigi'' and ''An American in Paris.'' Now, ''Directed by Vincente Minnelli,'' the ambitious, important and hugely entertaining retrospective that opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, makes me think ''The Sandpiper'' is the ultimate screen romance, at least on Hollywood's terms.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., a holding company with interests in food and distribution, appointed Everett L. Grant 3d senior vice president and special assistant to the chairman for finance.

title: Reviews/Film In Raul Ruiz Retrospective, The Director's First Work
description: Is Raul Ruiz a genius or the overrated remnant of a faded avant-garde? Like his enigmatic films, this Chilean director's controversial reputation admits no easy answer. But one thing is certain. Anyone who approaches his imagistic, disjunctive tales as puzzles to be solved is bound to be thwarted. Mr. Ruiz's films are collages to be interpreted, their rewards roughly equivalent to the viewer's imagination and energetic involvement.

title: Tokyo Journal; For Women and for Socialists, It's Always Uphill
description: ''Doh-eee! Doh-eee! Doh-eee!'' a crowd of young people chanted the other day as Takako Doi, leader of the Japan Socialist Party, headed toward a microphone in a sleek automobile showroom. At the side of the stage was a poster declaring, ''Doi for Prime Minister.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed John Tudor, pitcher, to a one-year contract. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Signed Michael Williams, guard, to a one-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Waived Jay Vincent, forward. SAN JOSE (CBA) - Traded Monroe Douglass, guard, to the Tulsa Fast Breakers for a sixth-round choice in next year's college draft. FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Placed Jake McCullough, defensive end, on injured reserve. Activated Brad Henke, nose tackle, from the developmental squad. LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Signed Sean Smith, defensive lineman. Waived Richard Brown, inside linebacker. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Signed Rick Tuten, punter. PHOENIX (NFC) - Waived Bob Buczkowski, defensive tackle. Signed Mike Barber, wide receiver. HOCKEY EDMONTON (NHL) - Signed Vladimir Ruzicka, center, to a four-year contract. LOS ANGELES (NHL) - Recalled Paul Kelly, right wing, from Phoenix of the International Hockey League and assigned him to New Haven of the American Hockey League. RANGERS (NHL) - Recalled Jeff Bloemberg, defenseman, from Flint of the International Hockey League. PHOENIX (IHL) - Signed Vern Smith, defenseman. SENIOR PRO BASEBALL GOLD COAST - Released Paul Blair, outfielder, and Grant Jackson, pitcher. COLLEGES AKRON - Extended the contract of Gerry Faust, head football coach, through the 1993 season. CLARION - Announced the retirement of Don Leas, men's and women's diving coach, effective at the end of the 1989-90 season. NORTHERN ARIZONA - Named Charlie Dickey offensive line coach.

title: Rangers Lack Almost Everything
description: The offense is lifeless, the power play clueless, the lineup once again helpless in the face of nonstop injuries. For the Rangers, it's a long, ugly list of liabilities.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Zydeco Shows

title: NATO to Let Shevardnadze Visit Its Headquarters
description: In yet another indication that the cold war is drawing to a close, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union will make a visit to NATO headquarters next week, NATO announced today.

title: Judith R. Tishman, 54, Photographers' Agent
description: Judith Rothenberg Tishman, a photographers' representative in Manhattan for many years, died of complications from a brain tumor yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Theory of Evolution Has Never Been Proved; The Fittest Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Betting on What in China?
description: Two big bets: President Bush gambles that China's embattled hard-liners will reward his sudden support with a big diplomatic payoff that will prove he's a savvy realist. Deng Xiaoping, who has his own brand of realism, bets that the visit of senior U.S. envoys to China reinforces his domestic and international position at minimal cost.

title: Afternoon Surge Cuts Dow's Loss to 7.46
description: The stock market closed moderately lower yesterday after recouping more than half of its earlier decline.

title: France Goes on Alert Against Terror
description: Parisians woke up this morning to find all major stores, airports, subways and train stations heavily guarded by paramilitary police forces as France went on a nationwide alert to guard against what Minister of Interior Pierre Joxe described as a distinct possibility of terrorist attacks and bombings over the holiday season.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Starring Jimmy Webb

title: Dow Jones Profit Outlook
description: Dow Jones & Company expects earnings for all of 1989 to increase by about 40 percent above 1988 levels, Warren H. Phillips, the publishing company's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Review/Jazz; A Duo on Bass and Piano
description: When the veteran saxophonist Spike Robinson was prevented by illness from joining the Dutch pianist Jack Van Poll as a duo on Tuesday night at J's, on Broadway at 97th Street, he was replaced by the bassist Brian Torff, a change that created a different kind of duo.

title: Debt Securities Of Lakeland, Fla.
description: A $167.5 million bond issue by Lakeland, Fla., is offering a maximum yield of 7.10 percent for an issue due 2008 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Ritter Denies Sex Allegations on Covenant House
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, the founding head of Covenant House, yesterday emphatically denied allegations by a 20-year-old former male prostitute that the priest had misused Covenent House funds and offered the youth special financial benefits in return for sex.

title: Czech Inquiry Into the Fateful Beating of Students in November Accuses Party Chiefs
description: A commission has concluded that beatings of peaceful demonstrators in November resulted from a decision by the political leadership of the country to suppress dissent.

title: Xerox Sues Apple Computer Over Macintosh Copyright
description: The Xerox Corporation filed suit here today against Apple Computer Inc., accusing it of unlawfully using Xerox copyrights in its Macintosh and Lisa computers.

title: Salvador Judge Frees 6 Held With American
description: A judge today ordered the immediate release of six Salvadorans detained with Jennifer Jean Casolo on suspicion of storing arms for leftist guerrillas.

title: Chrysler Planning New Incentives
description: In the grip of a domestic automotive sales slump, the Chrysler Corporation said it will announce a ''new and innovative'' incentive program Friday morning. A spokesman declined to elaborate. Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler chairman, is expected to discuss the incentives in a scheduled speech by satellite to the 5,287 dealers of the company's Chrysler, Dodge, Plymouth, Jeep and Eagle models.

title: New Toyota Target: The Midwest
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation thought particularly long and hard before opening a dealership last year in this isolated and economically depressed southeastern Kansas town of 9,000 people. For one thing, communities like this and indeed the Midwest as a whole are the last bastion of the Big Three domestic auto makers, far less penetrated than other regions by Toyota and other Japanese manufacturers.

title: Grand Jury Asks Curb On Police Neck Holds
description: A grand jury report on the choking death of a black man at the hands of a white, off-duty Middletown policeman recommended today that police agencies implement stricter policy standards regarding neck-restraint holds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Radio Revenue Up 7.5%
description: The Radio Advertising Bureau has said that when 1989 is finished, radio advertising revenues will total $8.49 billion, up 7.5 percent from 1988. Network radio advertising rose 12 percent, national spot advertising 9.5 percent and local advertising 6.8 percent. Smaller increases are projected for 1990, when the bureau forecasts an increase of 5 to 7 percent.

title: Market Place; Making 'Junk Bonds' Respectable
description: With more potential sellers in the ''junk bond'' market than buyers, some institutions with large junk portfolios are using a version of financial magic to turn their holdings into marketable securities with investment-grade ratings.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Restaurants
description: If you experience deja vu upon entering Michael's, the ebullient new California-style restaurant on West 55th Street, chances are you dined several years ago in Jams or Batons, two East Coast representatives of that sunny genre that have since closed. California cuisine - characterized by charcoal grilling, minimal saucing and mini-rain forests of greenery on plates - has been annexed into mainstream American cooking, so the term isn't often heard these days. In that context, the ultra-cool, try-this-dish-it-will-blow-your-mind Michael's is a throwback.

title: Poindexter Lawyers Accuse Bush And Reagan of Deceptive Strategy
description: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter charged today that President Bush and former President Ronald Reagan had adopted a strategy calculated to avoid the perception that they ''are still attempting to hide the true facts regarding their involvement in the so-called Iran-contra affair.''

title: Skeptical Bulgarians Defy Communists
description: Defying calls to disperse from both Communist officials and their own opposition leaders, about 20,000 jeering Bulgarians ringed the Parliament building today to demand an immediate end to the Communist Party's monopoly on power.

title: U.S. Plans to Ground Air Fleet That Can Direct Nuclear War
description: The Pentagon plans to halt the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that for three decades has been a grim symbol of America's preparation to wage nuclear war even if the President and other political leaders were killed in a surprise attack, Pentagon officials said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada, Toronto, said that over the next year it would add another two to three percentage points to its share of the Canadian air passenger market, currently just over 50 percent.

title: Where to Hear Sounds Of the Holiday Season
description: THERE must be someone, somewhere, who still thinks of Christmas as a holiday that lasts a single day - or, counting Christmas Eve, a day and a half. But as early as the seventh century, a day was added to Christmas celebrations in several countries to commemorate the Feast of St. Stephen, the first Christian martyr, on Dec. 26.

title: We Now Pronounce You a Family
description: In New York, and around the country, new living arrangements provoke new rules. Some recently proposed by the New York State Housing Division would grant officials a strange new power - to turn pairs of unrelated adults into families.

title: Rutgers and Navy Must Choose Direction
description: The athletic directors, Jack Lengyel at Navy and Fred Gruninger of Rutgers, will find no dearth of candidates for the head football coaching vacancies brought about this week with the dismissals of Elliot Uzelac and Dick Anderson.

title: Inventories Up by 0.4%; Sales Off 0.7%
description: Business inventories climbed to their highest level in two months in October. Some analysts said that while the backlog had not reached a dangerous level, it was a growing concern.

title: World's Fair For 2 Cities
description: The Bureau of International Expositions in Paris announced yesterday that the 1995 World's Fair would be held jointly in Vienna and Budapest, with the Governments of Austria and Hungary acting as sponsors.

title: Bush and the New Moralism About China
description: At the Geneva conference on Indochina in 1954, John Foster Dulles, the U.S. Secretary of State, publicly refused to shake hands with Zhou Enlai, the Chinese Foreign Minister - both a diplomatic affront to China and a personal insult to a man highly sensitive to the appearance of things.

title: Airlines Sign Pact
description: Swissair and Singapore Airlines signed a cooperation agreement and said they plan to work out details to exchange 5 percent of each other's shares by the end of 1990. The agreement established the third link in a global alliance of airlines. Swissair, Switzerland's national flag carrier, and Singapore Airlines signed bilateral agreements with Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines earlier in the year.

title: Judge Orders the Arrest Of Republican Counsel
description: The counsel to the New York State Republican Committee resigned yesterday, minutes after a judge ordered him arrested for ignoring subpoenas to testify before the State Commission on Governmental Integrity.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased $336.3 million, to $366.81 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of 144 institutional funds decreased $387.4 million, to $88.20 billion. The assets of 228 general-purpose funds were up $148.8 million, to $119.68 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased $97.7 million, to $158.93 billion, the institute said.

title: Review/Film; The Boy May Not Talk Much, but He's a Video Genius
description: ''The Wizard'' is a blatant kiddie knockoff of ''Rain Man,'' with 13-year-old Fred Savage, the winsome and very natural star of television's ''Wonder Years,'' as a boy who spirits his strangely uncommunicative younger half-brother away from a hospital and travels across the country with him, discovering along the way that little Jimmy (Luke Edwards) is a real prodigy when it comes to video games. They even stop at a casino in Nevada and win some money.

title: Letterhead Litigation and the Endless Effort to Define Permissible Lawyer Advertising
description: Former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger once declared that when it came to courtroom skills, all lawyers were not created equal. What was needed, he said, was a way to certify the best of them, something that would be to advocates what the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval is to cake mixes and Underwriters Laboratories is to toasters.

title: In Albany and Trenton, Worries Over Economic Outlook; Advisers to Cuomo Expected to Suggest Delay in Next Tax Cut
description: Offering Gov. Mario M. Cuomo the kind of advice that he seems to be hoping for, the Governor's committee of economic advisers will recommend that the next phase of the state's income tax cut be delayed, committee members said today.

title: I Did Drugs Until They Wore Me Out. Then I Stopped.
description: LEAD: I have to laugh at the debate over what to do about the drug problem. Everyone is running around offering solutions -from making drug use a more serious criminal offense to legalizing it. But there isn't a real solution. I know that. I used and abused drugs, and people, and society, for two decades.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Marketing Risk: Mechanical Failure
description: To the many other problems that marketers face, add this new risk: advertising that does not compute.

title: Injured Ismail May Miss Bowl
description: Raghib Ismail, the Notre Dame sophomore flanker, running back and kick returner, suffered a separated left shoulder in the loss to Miami on Nov. 25, and may have only a limited role in the Orange Bowl game against Colorado on Jan. 1.

title: When Film Directors Get the Credit for What Screenwriters Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Leader Sets Demands For New Pact in Early Talks
description: Amid warnings of impending New York City deficits, a senior city union leader yesterday staked out an unusually early position in upcoming labor negotiations and called for moderate wage increases equal to the rate of inflation at the least.

title: Guinness to Share In Stroh Juice Unit
description: Guinness P.L.C. will increase its presence in the non-alcoholic beverage business by buying a 44.5 percent share of the Stroh Brewery Company's Sundance Natural Juice Sparklers for $58 million, the companies said. Guinness, the British brewing and liquor giant, and Stroh, the nation's third-largest beer brewer, said they expect to complete the transaction by the end of the year, creating the New Era Beverage Company.

title: Majerus Mends
description: Coach Rick Majerus of Utah, 41 years old, underwent coronary bypass surgery for more than five hours yesterday in Salt Lake City and afterward was listed in critical but stable condition, with a prognosis for normal recovery. Majerus felt chest pains after a game against Purdue two weeks ago. Before the surgery, Majerus said an assistant coach, Joe Cravens, would lead the Utes for the rest of the season.(AP)

title: Postema Loses
description: Pam Postema spent 13 years as an umpire, climbing the minor league ladder from the rookie leagues to the Class AAA level, which is one step short of the major leagues. For the last two springs, she worked major league spring-training games under the scrutiny of Ed Vargo, a former major league umpire who is director of umpire supervision for the National League.

title: Salvador Signals Its Sensitivity to Image Abroad
description: The decision to release an American woman arrested when a rebel arms cache was found on her rented property underscores the growing sensitivity of the Government to its international image.

title: Holtzman Is Cleaning House, Asking Goldin Aides to Quit
description: In the first big housecleaning in a New York City municipal department since the elections, aides to Comptroller-elect Elizabeth Holtzman said yesterday that she had asked for the resignations of 13 senior policy and personal appointees of the outgoing Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Field Executive Goes To Disney Publications
description: The Walt Disney Company, which is stepping up its publishing activities, has hired Charles P. Wickham from Field Publications, known for its Weekly Reader. He will supervise all Disney publishing operations in the United States and Canada.

title: Treasuries Gain on 'Junk' Sales
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, pushed by renewed selling in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market and a larger-than-expected increase in weekly unemployment claims.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the release of an American woman in El Salvador carried an incomplete version of a comment she made before leaving for the United States. The woman, Jennifer Jean Casolo, said, ''I don't think I have suffered as terribly as thousands of Salvadorans have suffered here.''

title: POLES DRAFT BILLS TO SLOW INFLATION
description: Poland's Solidarity-led Government adopted a package of austerity measures today that is intended to reduce the country's inflation rate and create a market economy.

title: Louisiana Panel Votes to Ease Prisoner's Term
description: Louisiana's Pardon Board today recommended to Gov. Buddy Roemer a reduced sentence that could mean freedom in five years for Gary Tyler, a black whose contention that he was framed in a murder case 15 years ago has won international support.

title: Leader Seeks Slower Route to Pluralism By Allowing Party to Raise Monopoly Issue
description: As he has struggled in the last week with the predicament of a Communist monopoly holding power over a nation of discontent, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has also managed to emit very clear signals that he is thinking the unthinkable: of yielding the party primacy guaranteed by the Constitution.

title: On Stage
description: Here Comes 'Mrs. Klein'

title: Theory of Evolution Has Never Been Proved
description: To the Editor:

title: No From Yanks
description: If Fernando Valenzuela leaves the Dodgers, it will not be to join the Yankees, who said yesterday that they were not interested in the free-agent left-hander and never had been.

title: Andrei Sakharov, 68, Soviet 'Conscience,' Dies
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the indomitable human-rights campaigner who prevailed in official exile to become a relentless prod to the Soviet Union's new congress, died apparently of a heart attack late Thursday after a long and wearying legislative day. He was 68 years old and lived in Moscow.

title: Pitt Coach Reported Out
description: Mike Gottfried, who had four winning seasons as the University of Pittsburgh's football coach, was dismissed today, according to athletic department sources.

title: Libya Cuts Some Links to France
description: Libya has suspended air, sea and communications links with France over the last week in a dispute over the French Government's decision to withhold the delivery of three Mirage fighter planes and other weapons already purchased by Libya, French officials said today.

title: Fannie Mae Prices Debt
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $900 million in debentures due 1996 through a nationwide selling group of various securities dealers led by the corporation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; President Is Named At McCaffrey
description: CONTINUING to build the management that will run the agency after its pending buyback from Saatchi & Saatchi, McCaffrey & McCall yesterday named William J. Vieser its president.

title: Andrei Sakharov, 68, Nuclear Inventor and Mainspring of the Soviet Conscience
description: Andrei Dmitriyevich Sakharov was one of those rare figures who appear at turning points in history, a man whose courage in fighting for intellectual and political freedom impressed much of the world but put him in long and dangerous conflict with his own country.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a New York City towing operation referred incorrectly to a store that was hit by an unregistered car. The store, Daffy's, sells clothing; it is not a restaurant. A picture caption with the article misidentified the man in the foreground. He was Franklin Sepulveda, a Transportation Department officer.

title: New Look for Devils Comes From Coach
description: Although the Devils will play the 32d game of their season Friday night, they feel as if training camp had just ended this week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about sanctions imposed on the basketball program at North Carolina State University misidentified the National Collegiate Athletic Association's director of infractions. He is Charles Smrt.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Upscale Brasserie New York could surely use some authentic French brasseries, those bright, bustling, drop-in restaurants that serve traditional fare at economical prices. La Cite, the dazzling new rococo extravaganza on West 51st Street, is a bit highfalutin to be called a brasserie. A better term might be brassaurant, Manhattan style, where prices can escalate fast.

title: Helen Robinson, Champion Angler, 89
description: Helen Robinson, a world-class angler who held several competitive fishing titles and was on a television show, ''The Old Lady and the Sea,'' died Monday in Miami from complications from a fall. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Robinson set women's world records, among them the 1961 capture of a 796-pound black marlin and a 584-pound black marlin in 1962, both from Pinas Bay, Panama.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * HKH&F Inc., to Gray Kirk & Evans, for its Hamburgers, Kennedys and Harris & Frank retail groups, with a budget of $2.5 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have never been in America in my life, but I think it is a country that should not give up its responsibility for Europe.'' - Gregor Gysi, leader of the East German Communist Party. [ A1:4. ]

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: When Film Directors Get the Credit for What Screenwriters Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Byrne Joins Sports Authority
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean today nominated his predecessor, former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne of Princeton, to a four-year term as a member of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Mr. Byrne will replace William Taggart, whose term expires on Jan. 11.

title: TV Weekend; Not Going Gentle Into That Good Night
description: A small piece, ''Age-Old Friends'' turns out to be first-rate television. It is based on the Bob Larbey play ''A Month of Sundays,'' which had a brief Broadway run, starring Jason Robards, in the spring of 1987. Mr. Larbey's television adaptation makes its debut tomorrow at 8 P.M. on pay-cable's Home Box Office. Hume Cronyn is the star this time, and he turns in a wonderfully intelligent and energetic performance as Cooper, a crusty resident of an upscale retirement home in New Jersey.

title: U.N. Backs Guidelines for a Pretoria Democracy
description: The United Nations General Assembly gave unanimous backing today to a declaration setting political guidelines for the peaceful dismantling of apartheid and the creation of a democratic South Africa.

title: Justice Dept. Examining U.S. Airlines
description: The Justice Department is investigating several of the nation's leading carriers, including American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines, to see whether they illegally fixed prices in a round of fare increases in September.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Issue of Bride's Is Claiming a Record
description: Weighing in at 3.9 pounds and rising more than one and a quarter inches off the coffee table, the February/ March 1990 issue of Bride's magazine is claiming the record as the largest consumer magazine ever published. Totaling 1,040 pages, including the cover, the Conde Nast publication will include 798 pages of ads. Newsstands will begin sagging with the issue at the end of December.

title: Tent City in Tompkins Square Park Is Dismantled by Police
description: The ramshackle tent city of the homeless in Tompkins Square Park was torn down yesterday as scores of city and park police officers mounted a long planned, long announced operation of nearly military complexity.

title: Bavarians Seize Heroin Cache
description: The police seized heroin with a street value of $20 million from a truck bound for Amsterdam from Turkey, Bavarian state officials said today. Seventy-two bags, each with 2.2 pounds of the drug, were found Monday in a hidden compartment.

title: Ex-Senator Defeats 2 Opponents In Election to Succeed Pinochet
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, bowing to the people's will that he give up power, today joined more than seven million voters in choosing his successor, and with 93 percent of the votes counted, a former Senator claimed victory.

title: When Film Directors Get the Credit for What Screenwriters Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Visual Installations Derived From Sound and Poetry
description: Whether by chance or design, the two main exhibitions at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo play off each other in unexpected ways, forming a whole greater than the sum of its parts. These shows say a lot about the present moment in art, especially the quest for new meanings in old materials and images.

title: 'Late Night' Makes Santa of Dan Rather
description: The card has the look and the greeting of a Christmastime corporate freebie. ''Charge Yourself a Lovely Holiday Gift . . . It's on Us!'' declares the cheery red script on thick, glossy white paper. Below is a facsimile of an American Express card, embossed with an account number, an expiration date and Dan Rather's name. Beneath that are the instructions: ''Detach carefully along perforations.''

title: Guilty Verdict In Bribe Case
description: The consultant Thomas E. Muldoon was convicted today of charges that he helped a military contractor funnel bribes to a Marine Corps contracting official for help in getting Pentagon contracts.

title: GUNMEN IN MANILA HIT U.S. COMPOUND
description: Armed men riding in a van fired two rifle grenades into a United States Government compound here today, the local police and the American Ambassador reported.

title: Firm's Foreign Ties Could Cost It a Big Client
description: Washington law firms know that representing foreign Governments can be risky. When the Minneapolis City Council meets Friday, one law firm will find out just how risky it can be.

title: WNET Trustees Elect New Chairman
description: The trustees of WNET, the major public television station in New York, yesterday elected Henry R. Kravis as the chairman. Mr. Kravis, a founding partner in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, a merchant banking firm, will replace William M. Ellinghaus on May 1.

title: Our Towns; Minus the Jargon: Sisters of Mercy Update Image
description: Sister Carol Ann Henry grew up in a religious town, South Amboy, and she said she thought it was natural she would be a nun.

title: From Dropout To Drug Baron To Prison Term
description: A 26-year-old high school dropout who became a millionaire by running a Queens cocaine ring was sentenced yesterday to 35 years in prison and fined $1 million.

title: Video With Music
description: The Nowhere Men, a performance-art ensemble, and Reek of Success, a rock band, will perform Kevin Carter's ''Ipsodefacto,'' a music and video piece, at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, tonight and tomorrow at 8:30. Tickets are $10. Information: 255-5793.

title: When Film Directors Get the Credit for What Screenwriters Do
description: To the Editor:

title: New Mexico Paper Sold
description: The Gannett Company, the Weashington-based media company, said yesterday that it had sold The New Mexican, its Santa Fe, N.M., newspaper, to Robert McKinney, the paper's publisher and editor in chief, and his daughter, Robin McKinney Martin. Mr. McKinney resumed his jobs with the paper in 1987 after a nine-year legal battle with Gannett over his employment contract. The media company purchased the newspaper from Mr. McKinney in 1976 for 300,000 shares of Gannett stock. To repurchase the newspaper, Gannett said, Mr. McKinney and his daughter are transferring 800,000 shares of Gannett stock to Gannett in a tax-free exchange.

title: Home From Salvador, Freed American Is Bitter
description: The American woman deported from El Salvador after being freed from charges of hiding arms and ammunition for leftist rebels arrived in New York yesterday and harshly criticized the Bush Administration for not presuming her innocence.

title: Ruiz's Surrealistic 'Pirates'
description: Raul Ruiz's ''City of Pirates'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6, 1985. The film (in French with English subtitles) opens today with Mr. Ruiz's ''Three Sad Tigers'' at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Pop/Jazz; Saxophonists Who Show A Reverence For the Past
description: Though they might not like being compared, Branford Marsalis and Scott Hamilton, two young and talented tenor saxophonists playing in town this weekend, are similar in their reverence for the past. Still, they are rarely mentioned in the same breath.

title: Cowboys Rely on Youth, But Get Same Old Results
description: In past years, a December game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys often meant much to the playoff hopes of both teams.

title: KEY RATES
Review/Opera; A New 'Hoffmann' Cast
description: An almost entirely new cast has taken over from the original singers in Offenbach's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' at the Metropolitan Opera. Of the principals, only Jose van Dam remains, and his palpably evil portrayals of Lindorf, Coppelius, Dappertutto and Dr. Miracle - the four villainous manifestations of Hoffmann's psyche - remain among the unquestionable joys of this year's staging.

title: BRAZIL WILL VOTE WITH EYE ON ARMY
description: As campaigning in Brazil's presidential race ended today with the two candidates tied in opinion polls, attention swiveled to the traditional arbiter of Brazilian politics, the military.

title: Kashmir Officials Under Attack For Yielding to Muslim Abductors
description: A day after Indian officials obtained the release of a Cabinet minister's abducted daughter in return for the freeing of five imprisoned Kashmiri Muslim militants, the onus of having cut a deal with terrorists seems to be falling almost entirely on the state government of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Reynolds Metals Project
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, based in Richmond, said today that it would spend $30 million at its sheet and plate plant here to expand and upgrade aluminum plate production for the aircraft and aerospace industry. Scheduled for completion in 1991, the project will increase Reynolds's plate production capacity by 16 percent, to 80 million pounds a year, and plate machining capacity for wing skins by 50 percent.

title: NORTHEAST BANKS FACE HEAVY LOSSES ON PROBLEM LOANS
description: Troubled real estate loans are causing heavy losses for bankers in the Northeast.

title: West Germany Postpones an Agreement on Open Borders With 4 Neighbors
description: In one of the first signs that events in Eastern Europe may complicate the European Community's integration process, West Germany postponed signing an agreement today to create a border-free region with four of its Western European neighbors.

title: Review/Art; Show at Studio Museum Of Its Artists in Residence
description: The artists in residence program at the Studio Museum in Harlem has been in existence since 1969, and it remains, according to the curator Grace Stanislaus, the ''key program, the one that really defines who we are as an institution.'' Each year, work by the previous year's three resident artists is shown at the museum. This year's exhibition is a clear sign of the program's strength.

title: Racing Pacers Get Jump On Nets
description: It is hard for a professional basketball team to score only 9 points in a quarter. It takes terrible shooting. It takes poor ball-handling. It takes a lack of hustle. Even then, it is still hard to imagine.

title: Lamar University Drops Football
description: The Lamar University board of regents today voted to discontinue the school's football program, citing projected losses of half a million dollars over the next three seasons.

title: Calendar of Music Events for the Holidays
description: This is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Christmas season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted.

title: Rules Control Contingency-Fee Practice; Why Not for Doctors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Win Rose Bowl for Bo? Schembechler Says No
description: On a cold and snowy Midwestern day, the Michigan football players completed final exams, prepared to open practice Friday for the Rose Bowl and contemplated life without Bo Schembechler after 21 seasons.

title: Books of The Times; He Founded a State Before It Was a Land
description: The Labyrinth of Exile A Life of Theodor Herzl By Ernst Pawel 554 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Home Section yesterday with an article about the Winterthur Museum show at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art misidentified a piece of furniture. It was a Philadelphia high chest, not a Rhode Island chest-on-chest.

title: Tutu and Belafonte At Dinkins Ceremony
description: Harry Belafonte will be master of ceremonies, Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa will speak and the diva Marilyn Horne will sing ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' at David N. Dinkins's inauguration as Mayor on New Year's Day, the head of the inaugural team said yesterday.

title: Scientists Puzzled by Unusual Neptune Rings
description: The four distinctive rings that Voyager 2 discovered around Neptune, especially the lumpy outer one, have scientists shaking their heads and confessing that all their previous theories to explain planetary rings must be scrapped or drastically revised.

title: Auctions
description: Props From Hollywood

title: Move Backed On Utility
description: In its first special session since 1966, the New Hampshire House of Representatives voted today to authorize Northeast Utilities' takeover of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first public utility to go bankrupt since the Depression.

title: Iran Rejects Iraqi Demand to Redraw Border in a Peace Pact
description: Iran today rejected Iraqi demands that the border between the two countries be redrawn under a peace agreement.

title: Getting Along Famously in Kansas
description: When Roy Williams walks through an airport, few people recognize him. He is rarely asked for autographs and there is nothing about Williams's unassuming demeanor that suggests he is the head basketball coach at Kansas, which has one of the top programs in college basketball.

title: Like Garden, Jets Might Think Young
description: The Jets are looking for a general manager. About time. For well over a decade, this football team has been a floundering example of a franchise without a single vision, without a plan.

title: M.T.A. Warning Connecticut Of Cuts Without Higher Fares
description: Robert R. Kiley, chairman of New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, warned Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut yesterday that he would press for sharp cuts in commuter rail service on the New Haven Line unless Mr. O'Neill drops his opposition to $7.7 million in higher fares -or its equivalent in subsidies.

title: Dozens Get Subpoenas In Durenberger Inquiry
description: A Senate Ethics Committee inquiry into Senator Dave Durenberger has issued subpoenas to dozens of organizations that paid a Minneapolis publisher in lieu of direct speaking fees to Mr. Durenberger, the Senator's spokeswoman confirmed today.

title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results
description: The television drama was hardly sophisticated, but the point was clear: A young man writhes on his bed, howling from drug withdrawal, while his family agonizes and finally decides to go to the authorities.

title: PAKISTAN WEARIES OF AFGHAN BURDEN
description: The Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is growing increasingly impatient with the burden of supporting the Muslim guerrillas who use Pakistan as a base for their operations against the Soviet-backed Afghan Government.

title: Offering by Chicago Priced
description: Chicago is offering a total of about $161.5 million in water and waste-water transmission revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: The Soviet View: Two Germanys, in Confederation
description: LEAD: The future of the two German states has been widely discussed in the last few months, especially during the past few weeks, largely because the winds of perestroika have moved westward to East Germany.

title: P.L.O. Attack Kills 6 Syrians in Beirut
description: Guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization mounted an attack today against a Syrian Army garrison in southern Lebanon. The police said 6 people were killed and 20 wounded. The attack was believed to be the first Palestinian frontal attack on a Syrian position in 13 years.

title: Image-Conscious East Germany Ran Drug Tests Before Trips
description: For more than a decade, in an effort to prevent international embarrassment, East German athletes were tested for drug use before they were allowed to compete outside the country, Dr. Claus Clausnitzer, the chief of East Germany's only drug-testing laboratory, said today that from 1978 until last month, his staff tested all athletes selected by officials to compete outside the country, where they might be tested again. Only athletes who tested negative in Clausnitzer's lab were allowed to go, and over the years just three had positive results at a foreign event.

title: F.D.A. Is Studying Effects of a Generic Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was investigating a report that the generic version of a cancer treatment drug had been linked to a higher-than-normal incidence of toxic effects on the nervous system.

title: Volcano Erupts in South Alaska
description: The Redoubt Volcano erupted today, shooting volcanic ash seven miles into the air at its site in Cook Inet and prompting the evacuation of seven oil workers.

title: Tudor to Cards
description: The ranks of free agents were reduced by one yesterday when John Tudor agreed to a one-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals, one of his former teams. The left-hander will be guaranteed $350,000. Based on the number of games he pitches, he could earn an additional $1 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 105, Hornets 101: Mark Alarie sank an 18-foot jumper with 15 seconds left to snap a 101-101 tie for Washington. After Rex Chapman brought visiting Charlotte even at 101-101 with a steal and a layup with 28 seconds to play, Alarie hit a jumper from the top of the key. Washington's Jeff Malone added two free throws in the final second.(AP) Spurs 104, Rockets 100: Willie Anderson sparked a fourth-quarter burst with 10 of his 19 points and San Antonio outscored visiting Houston, 19-9, in the final 7:24 to win. The game matched Akeem Olajuwon against a Spurs rookie, David Robinson. Robinson won the points battle, 19-15, and Olajuwom dominated the boards, 16-9. The difference in the game was fouls. Robinson committed his only foul with 47 seconds left in the game. Olajuwon was called for five fouls.(AP) Bulls 124, Magic 113: Michael Jordan scored 26 of his 38 points in the first half as Chicago, playing at home, jumped to an early lead and cruised to victory. Jordan scored his 38 points in only 25 minutes, the fewest he has played this season. He came out with 3 minutes 57 seconds left in the third quarter and the Bulls ahead by 88-63. He also sat out seven minutes in the first half.(AP) N.H.L. Whalers 3, Flyers 2: Mike Tomlak, a rookie, broke a 2-2 tie in the third period with a five-foot power-play goal to the stick side to give Hartford the victory last night in Philadelphia. The goal came with 7 minutes 56 seconds left in the game.(AP) North Stars 4, Penguins 4: Larry Murphy went around visiting Pittsburgh's defense and beat Tom Barrasso with 7:47 left in regulation. Mario Lemieux extended his scoring streak to a league high 20 games this season by assisting on Chris Dahlquist's third-period goal.(AP) Flames 8, Nordiques 2: Joe Nieuwendyk registered the first three-goal game of the season by a Calgary player as the Flames beat Quebec.(AP) EXHIBITION HOCKEY Khimik Voskresensk 6, Blues 3: Khimik Voskresensk, the leader in the Soviet National League, earned a split of its six-game tour against National Hockey League teams by scoring five consecutive goals to beat St. Louis last night. Dmitri Kvartalnov and Valery Zelepukhin each had a goal and an assist for Khimik.(AP) WOMEN'S BASKETBALL Louisiana Tech 89, DePaul 75: Venus Lacy and Sheila Ethridge combined for 44 points and 23 rebounds last night to lead top-ranked Louisiana Tech in Ruston, La. Lacy, Tech's 6-foot-3-inch center, had 24 points, 13 rebounds and 2 of the Lady Techsters' 7 blocked shots. Ethridge scored 20 points, had 10 rebounds and 1 block as Tech improved to 6-0. DePaul fell to 4-2 despite Melanee Ehrhardt's 23 points and 22 more by Veronica Ross. Tech led by 46-35 at halftime. All 12 of the team's players saw action after that and all but one of them scored.(AP) HORSE RACING King's Swan Wins Handicap: King's Swan, a 9-year-old gelding, raced to a 4 1/2-length victory yesterday in the Tri Jet Handicap at Aqueduct. The winner, ridden by Jose Santos and carrying 114 pounds, scored his third victory in 13 starts this year. Congeleur, ridden by Herb McCauley, was second in the six-horse field. King's Swan raced the mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:44 3/5. He paid $8 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: How Much Is a Baby Worth?
description: This was going to be a column devoted to criticizing the drug legalizers. Then I read a new study about crack babies.

title: Hextall Injured
description: While on a one-game conditioning assignment with the Hershey Bears of the American Hockey League, Ron Hextall of the Philadelphia Flyers had to be carried from the ice midway through the third period after injuring his right groin in a game Wednesday against the Nighthawks in New Haven. The goaltender will be out six to eight weeks. (AP)

title: Jersey Warehouse Fire Forces Evacuations
description: A warehouse fire in Piscataway, N.J., burned for several hours last night, spread to several nearby small workshops and a house and forced the evacuation of about 100 people, the police said.

title: Delay in Albany Tax Cut Urged
description: Offering Gov. Mario M. Cuomo the advice he seems to want, the Governor's economic advisers will recommend a delay in the next phase of New York's income tax cut. Page B1.

title: Review/Film; 'Family Business,' a 3-Generation Caper
description: If you can believe that Sean Connery and a Sicilian wife could be parents to Dustin Hoffman, and that this same Dustin Hoffman and a Jewish wife could be parents to Matthew Broderick, then you should read no further than the next paragraph.

title: New Job for Ex-Leader Of Academy of Design
description: Historic Hudson Valley, an organization that administers a half-dozen historic properties in upstate New York, yesterday named John H. Dobkin as its president. Mr. Dobkin, the director of the National Academy of Design since 1978, will become president on Jan. 1.

title: Pinnacle Rejects Pacificorp Offer
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation rejected an acquisition proposal by Pacificorp, the Portland, Ore., utility company. Pacificorp, which had made an earlier cash bid for Pinnacle's Arizona Public Services unit, had offered to exchange 0.18 share of its common stock for each share of Pinnacle.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HANDS ACROSS THE STRAIT

title: The Students Of Generosity Aid Neediest
description: For many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the generosity or selflessness of a relative, friend or colleague prompts the gift.

title: East German Asks Help of U.S. In Keeping His Country Separate
description: The new leader of the East German Communist Party asked for help today from the United States to keep his country from being absorbed by its powerful West German neighbor.

title: France and S.E.C. in Inquiries Pact
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its French counterpart signed a cooperative agreement on securities investigations today.

title: New York City Will Test for AIDS In Autopsies to Trace Its Spread
description: In an innovative move to help measure and confine the AIDS epidemic, New York City will begin testing for the virus in all 8,000 autopsies that the Chief Medical Examiner's office performs each year, and then use the results to find out who else might be infected.

title: Karate Teacher Accused of Rape
description: A karate instructor who taught rape defense in this Westchester suburb has been charged with raping and sexually abusing three teen-age girls who were his students, the police said today.

title: CALIFORNIA LIMITS SOUGHT FOR SMOG
description: Sweeping anti-smog proposals introduced today call for drastic reductions in automobile emissions in California by the year 2000, a goal some manufacturers call impossible.

title: Albany Panel Says $2 Million in Anti-Drug Funds Is Wasted
description: Treatment programs run by friends of the director of New York State's drug-abuse agency received more than $2 million in state contracts although they failed to treat a single addict, a state commission asserted today.

title: 2 Groups Raise Stakes in Vons
description: Two separate groups, one led by Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier, and the other by Safeway Stores Inc., have raised their stakes in the Vons Companies, the El Monte, Calif., supermarket chain.

title: Dining Out Guide: Steak
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Amsterdam's Bar and Rotisserie * (March 3, 1989), 428 Amsterdam Avenue, at 80th Street (874-1377) -Amsterdam's strategy for success combines a menu of simple rotisserie dishes, down-to-earth prices and an informal setting. The restaurant is frenzied at times, and the most agreeable place is the elevated back dining room. One of the best dinner entrees is roasted shell steak, which comes out of the rotisserie nicely seared and is served with a red-wine-peppercorn sauce. French fries are clean and crisp, as are the roasted new potatoes. The wine list has 20 well-chosen selections. At dinner, appetizers are $3.50 to $6.95, entrees $9.95 to $15.95. Open noon to midnight Sunday to Thursday, until 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday. De l'Alsace a Brandywine Diner's Journal (June 2, 1989), 274 Third Avenue, near 21st Street (353- 8190) - Serious beef-lovers can find hefty porterhouse and T-bone steaks here. A steakhouse with a French accent, this cozy Gramercy Park restaurant has hired the Alsace-born chef of the four-star Lafayette as consultant. A recommended dish is steak a la stone, a sliced sirloin with sauteed peppers, onions and mushrooms. Home fries or mashed potatoes make a good side dish. Appetizers are $7 to $10, entrees $16 to $22. Lunch is 11:30 A.M. to 2 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday. Le Steak Diner's Journal (Dec. 23, 1988), 1089 Second Avenue, near 58th Street (421-9072) - Le Steak, a Second Avenue fixture for 25 years and still going strong, is popular for its reasonable three-course dinners. The dark Tudor-style bistro serves a full-flavored sirloin with thin, light french fries for $21.95; the price includes cheesy onion soup or romaine and escarole salad in a well-balanced vinaigrette, dessert (the fine creme caramel is the best option) and coffee. Open 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. daily. The Post House ** (Aug. 26, 1988), 28 East 63d Street (935-2888) - The Post House, with its urbane ambiance and clientele, is expensive, but the quality of the steaks is excellent. Among recommended offerings is the aged rib steak with a well-seasoned crust; the same huge cut is available Cajun style with a moderately peppery coating. Most seafood is equally compelling. Recommended appetizers includeplump crab cakes, sauteed shrimp and cedar-planked salmon. The Post House has a broad and provocative wine list that includes some vintages from small producers in New York State. At lunch, appetizers are $8 to $12.50, entrees $16 to $29; at dinner, appetizers are $9.50 to $13.50, entrees $20.50 to $29.75. Open noon to 11 P.M. Monday to Friday, 5:30 P.M. to midnight Saturday, until 11 P.M. Sunday. Sparks Steakhouse ** (Oct 27, 1989), 210 East 46th Street (687-4855) - Sparks is a bustling, diet-be-damned kind of restaurant that serves the best steaks in town. It also features a superior wine list strong in California cabernet sauvignons and red Bordeaux. Among beef entrees, the choices include a tender and unadorned prime sirloin with a salt-edged crust, and an excellent filet mignon. The menu also carries an adequate selection of fish. Split and broiled lobsters are a delight here. Crusty hash browns make the best side dish. Appetizers are $4.95 to $13.50, entrees $19.95 to $29.95. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5 to 11 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. What the stars mean, page C32.

title: In Albany and Trenton, Worries Over Economic Outlook; New Jersey Economy Grew Much Slower Than Nation's in '89
description: After six years of sustained growth, New Jersey's economy slowed so sharply this year that the state stands a greater risk than the nation of sliding into a recession next year, a panel of economic advisers to the Governor warned today.

title: South Florida Restricts Water Use in Dry Spell
description: South Florida's water managers responded to the worst dry spell in 27 years today with restrictions on washing cars and watering lawns and golf courses in this region of more than four million people.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 An East German call for U.S. help was made by the country's new Communist Party leader. He asked for help in keeping his country from being absorbed by its powerful West German neighbor. Page A1

title: For the Once Privileged, Bias and Assault
description: In the absence of any official guidelines from the new leadership of East Germany, a wave of intolerance has washed across this country in recent days, expressing itself in instances of bigotry, social discrimination and outright assaults.

title: Degrees of Error
description: Robert E. Peary was an intrepid explorer who lost eight toes and almost his life in various attempts to reach the North Pole. But ever since April 6, 1909, the day he said he attained this goal, his claim has been repeatedly affirmed and disputed. The latest inquiry holds that he got within five miles of the Pole, close enough for vindication.

title: Hog and Cattle Prices Up As Cold Spell Hits Midwest
description: Prices for near-term deliveries of hogs surged more than a penny a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as frigid weather in the Midwest slowed marketing and reduced slaughter rates.

title: INSIDE
description: New Turn in Ethics Inquiry A Senate panel investigating Senator Dave Durenberger has subpoenaed dozens of organizations that paid a publisher in lieu of direct speaking fees to the lawmaker. Page D17. Report Assails Drug Agency Friends of the director of New York State's drug-abuse agency have received more than $2 million in state contracts, although they have failed to treat a single addict. Page B1. Setback for Jewish Veteran An Army review board has found that a Jewish veteran should not receive a Medal of Honor that was denied him in 1945 because of what his advocates say was anti-Semitism. Page A20. Hong Kong and Boat People Amid the international condemnation of the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people, Hong Kong residents are expressing their approval of the radical measure. Page A11.

title: In Bad Timing, Jets Meet Rams on the Rebound
description: Joe Walton, the coach of the Jets, this week described the game Sunday against the Los Angeles Rams as ''a good test for all our young guys.''

title: No Relief on Sunday For Struggling Bills
description: The Buffalo Bills were riding high not long ago with American Conference yardage leaders at quarterback (Jim Kelly), running back (Thurman Thomas) and receiver (Andre Reed) and with a defense that had slipped but remained one of pro football's best.

title: CBS Explains Delay on Naming Executive
description: A CBS executive said yesterday that the network's plan to name Jeff Sagansky president of the entertainment division had been delayed only by minor complications related to Mr. Sagansky's departure as president of Tri-Star Pictures.

title: GATT Critiques U.S. Policy
description: In its first examination of overall United States trade policy, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, said today that its 96 member nations saw the United States as one of the countries most open to imports. But it added that they were troubled by persistent protection for certain parts of the American economy and a trend toward unilateral retaliation in trade disputes.

title: Medal of Honor Elude Jewish Veteran
description: An Army board of review has concluded that a Jewish veteran of World War II should not receive a Medal of Honor that was denied him in 1945 because of what his advocates say was anti-Semitism by a senior officer.

title: Cahners Magazine Head In Shift to Trade Shows
description: Neil Perlman is switching from publishing magazines to running trade shows, and he sees similarities between the endeavors. Mr. Perlman, now with Cahners Publishing, has been named the president of Cahners Exposition Group, which produces large trade shows.

title: Rehearing Is Sought in Texas Murder Case
description: A prosecutor said today that he would ask a state appeals court to change its decision of Wednesday overturning the conviction of a death row prisoner.

title: Lender Halts Funds for Campeau Suppliers
description: A major lender to the suppliers of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Jordan Marsh and other regional retail chains owned by the Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it had stopped advancing funds to those suppliers.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Troupe in 'Rainbow'
description: Like Alvin Ailey, Donald McKayle choreographed a superb work early in his career that became a signature piece.

title: At the Movies
description: Director of 'Glory'

title: 2 Yonkers Condominium Projects Offer River Views
description: LEAD: Westchester County's image as a suburb for the well-to-do has not been shared by Yonkers, the fourth-largest city in New York State. And in Yonkers, residential neighborhoods east of the Saw Mill River Parkway have traditionally been considered more desirable than those in the city's older northwest section.

title: Magical Moments: Actors Sparking Flashes of Insight
