description: SOME people lament a theater that chases after lavish visual effects, but not I. Would ''The Phantom of the Opera'' retain half its mystery without dry ice and the sensuous, slow progress of thick curtains sweeping across the stage, promising to reveal something magnificent?

title: Japanese Join Film Venture
description: In another instance of the growing Japanese interest in the film business, Nomura Babcock & Brown, a Japanese investment firm, said yesterday that it would put $100 million into Morgan Creek Productions.

title: Review/Dance; The Cooler Flamenco Style of the Maria Benitez Company
description: There has been a new look to flamenco dancing in New York in recent years. It was exemplified by the glowing, quietly compelling performance of the Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company on Tuesday that opened the company's two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street).

title: Philip Morris to End Support For Important Research Prize
description: Philip Morris Inc., the tobacco and food company, said today that it was withdrawing financial support for the World Food Prize, a $200,000 prize for farm research that was considered the most prestigious award in the field.

title: HONG KONG OPINION AGAINST REFUGEES
description: As foreign governments and international relief agencies condemn Hong Kong's forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people, Hong Kong residents are expressing their approval of the radical measure, and even at times suggesting that harsher measures are needed.

title: Review/Film; Hoodlums Disguised As Men Of the Cloth
description: ''We're No Angels'' opens with a funny sequence involving an electric chair and a jailbreak, and goes down the mountain from there.

title: Pleasant Ridge Journal; The Freeway It Took A Generation to Build
description: James J. Blanchard was a high school sophomore in 1957, when highway engineers began talking about the new superhighway that might someday slice across this small suburb.

title: Armed Force Deployed To Stop Benin Protests
description: Hundreds of police officers and soldiers were deployed in the streets of Benin's two main cities today to prevent protests against President Mathieu Kerekou.

title: Inmate Sentenced in Escape
description: A Somers State Prison inmate who called himself ''an animal'' and said he would have committed violent crimes if his escape attempt had been successful was sentenced Wednesday to an additional 10 years in prison. Judge Michael A. Mack sentenced Donald L. Williamson, who is already serving a 20- to 40-year sentence for kidnapping and rape, to an additional 10 years because he has shown no remorse.

title: Payouts Suspended On Some Mesa Units
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who transformed his company into a limited partnership four years ago to ''maximize values to shareholders,'' said today that he would eliminate distribution payments to holders of common units in his Mesa Limited Partnership.

title: Jersey to Ship Out Chromium
description: The state will spend $30 million to ship 65,000 tons of chromium-contaminated dirt from residential sites in the city, under a plan made public by environmental officials.

title: Rules Control Contingency-Fee Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: CZECH AIDE DENIES VALIDITY OF PACT ON SOVIET TROOPS
description: The new Foreign Minister said today that the agreement under which Soviet troops are stationed in Czechoslovakia was invalid because it was concluded under duress.

title: U.S. Acting to Limit Food Health Claims
description: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed limiting the health claims that appear on food packages, saying they are too broad and in some cases fraudulent.

title: Legal Scholar to Take Helm at Third Circuit
description: If Judge A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. has his way, there will be no big fuss next month when he becomes Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit here.

title: Shearson Announces Cash Plan
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and the American Express Company announced a plan yesterday to raise badly needed cash for the brokerage firm by selling assets and issuing new stock and debt.

title: Output Rose A Slim 0.1% Last Month
description: Industrial production rose by a lackluster one-tenth of 1 percent in November despite rebounding from a major strike and the devastating California earthquake, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Trade Gap Widest in 10 Months
description: The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in October to the highest level in 10 months and imports soared to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Carnations and Candles At Sakharov Doorstep
description: Some stood silently, in tears. Some talked quietly with friends, while others gazed into the candle flames flickering beneath the portrait of the man they had come to mourn.

title: U.S. Issues Unchanged After Early Gains
description: Prices of Treasury securities were largely unchanged yesterday after strong opening gains were erased later in the session.

title: Jet Lands Safely After Engines Stop in Flight Through Volcanic Ash
description: All four engines of a KLM Boeing 747 temporarily shut down yesterday when the jumbo jet flew through a cloud of ash from the erupting Redoubt Volcano in Alaska, Government officials reported.

title: Man in the News: Patricio Aylwin; A Moderate Leads Chile
description: In July and August 1973, Patricio Aylwin moved with urgency and secrecy around Chile's troubled political scene - among church and military leaders, ministers of the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens and leaders of his own Christian Democratic Party.

title: Peter M. Horn, 91, Judge for 30 Years In New York Courts
description: Peter M. Horn, a retired judge who served in the courts of New York City for 30 years, died on Tuesday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass., after a long illness. He was 91 years old and lived in Pittsfield.

title: Bomb Plant Reopening Is Put Off After Mishap
description: A nuclear bomb plant in Washington State that was shut last December because of safety problems has had an unexplained chemical reaction in a pipe that ruptured a gasket and sprayed acid into an area sometimes occupied by workers.

title: Bridge
description: Players come from many parts of the world to take part in American National Championships. At the Fall Nationals in Lancaster, Pa., last month there was at least one Australian. Richard Kahn of Cheltenham, Victoria, namesake of an American star of yesteryear, successfully completed his requirements to be an American life master, a rarity Down Under.

title: Corrections
description: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Nov. 30 and its headline, about an investment fund created by the leveraged buyout firm of Forstmann, Little & Company, referred incorrectly to deals in which the firm has previously invested. They have been only friendly transactions to buy companies - deals in which management of the acquired company has cooperated.

title: Over Angry Shouts, M.T.A. Votes to Raise Fares by 15%
description: Straining to hear each other over the shouts of protesters, members of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved fare increases yesterday averaging 15 percent for its buses, subways and commuter railroads in the region.

title: MERCENARIES QUIT INDIAN OCEAN ISLES
description: Col. Bob Denard, the French soldier of fortune who ruled the Comoro Islands for the last three weeks, flew to South Africa today with 21 other mercenaries after handing his fief over to the French military authorities.

title: Review/Dance; On Confronting Adversity
description: Seven choreographers presented works on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater as part of Dance Theater Workshop's Fresh Tracks series of programs by new talent. The offerings varied greatly in style. Yet all concerned people in crises, and one of the things that made the evening stimulating was seeing how the characters in these pieces managed to cope with their problems.

title: Olive Booth, Humanitarian, 98
description: Olive Booth, the last of the surviving granddaughters of Gen. William Booth, founder of the Salvation Army, died on Wednesday. She was 98 years old.

title: Soviets Say Cutback In Military Spending Will Be 8.2% in '90
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would slash military spending by more than 8 percent next year. It also gave the most detailed breakdown to date of its armed forces.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bulgarians, at Rallies, Revel in a New Voice
description: Bulgarians are discovering that if democracy ever does arrive, as their Communist leaders pledge, it can be a boisterous, unpredictable, exhilarating and at times tedious process.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He is plunging a dagger into the city's heart.'' - Mayor Edward I. Koch on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's approval of a measure that could allow Staten Island to secede from New York City. [ 1:3. ]

title: Ban on Film for Blasphemy Is Upheld in Britain
description: The Video Appeals Committee of the British Board of Film Classification has upheld a ban on ''Visions of Ecstasy,'' the first film ever to be banned for blasphemy in Britain.

title: Bookmaking Case Nets Law Official
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the New Orleans District Attorney, Harry Connick, on charges that he illegally helped a well-known Louisiana bookmaker and his gambling business.

title: Witt Takes to Airwaves
description: Katarina Witt, East Germany's most famous athlete, said yesterday that she planned to appear on East German television tomorrow to discuss recent events regarding possible changes in the country's elite sports system. In an interview that appeared on NBC's ''Today'' show yesterday, Witt defended the system.

title: Devaluation By China
description: In a long expected move, China said tonight that it would devalue its currency by 21.2 percent against the dollar, effective Saturday. It is China's first devaluation since 1986.

title: Drug Official For New York Resigns Post
description: New York State's top drug-treatment official resigned today, one day after the release of a blistering state report that said he had directed more than $2 million to drug-abuse programs that were run by his friends and that failed to treat anybody.

title: Blame Lack of Toilets, Not Moral Decay, for Public Urination
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Oppose Repeal Effort
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would oppose an American effort to repeal a General Assembly resolution that equates Zionism with racism.

title: SoHo Gift to Wall St.: A 3 1/2-Ton Bronze Bull
description: Wall Street awoke to a gigantic bull on its doorstep yesterday - a 3 1/2-ton 16-foot-long bronze sculpture by an artist from SoHo who deposited it outside the New York Stock Exchange and declared it a Yuletide symbol of the ''strength and power of the American people.''

title: Grant Sanger, 81, Dies; Surgeon and Professor
description: Dr. Grant Sanger, a surgeon who was an associate professor of clinical surgery at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center for 27 years, died of a heart attack on Thursday while dining at the Harvard Club in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Beijing Plan for Hong Kong Dims Hopes for a Democracy
description: Hong Kong's hopes to establish a democratic government after it reverts to Beijing's authority were diminished today when China declared that only one-third of the post-1997 legislature would be directly elected.

title: Former New Orleans Mayor Says He Won't Enter Race
description: Ernest N. (Dutch) Morial has announced that contrary to widespread expectations here, he will not seek to regain the mayoralty, an office he held for eight years.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-12 The East German exodus to the West has continued unabated. While 10 million East Germans have visited West Germany and returned home, each day about 2,000 have chosen to settle. 1 Warsaw's relations with East Berlin and Bonn have come under economic and political strain from the side effects of the revolution that has swept East Germany since October. 8 Andrei Sakharov's death was grieved by the Government that once exiled him for speaking out on human rights. The Kremlin moved quickly to seek a state funeral, but his family reportedly has other burial plans. 1 Carnations and candles at Sakharov's doorstep 10 A possibile settlement in Afghanistan hinges on whether Moscow would exclude President Najibullah. But White House officials are divided over how to interpret the signals given by President Gorbachev. 3 Moscow's five-year economic plan fails to include fundamental structural changes that would reorient the the Soviet Union to a free market system, the Secretary of State said. 10 East's turn to West puts Comecon in peril 35 The European Community has a role in reshaping Europe, French officials say. President Francois Mitterrand is expected to voice concerns about NATO's presumed predominance when he meets President Bush. 9 The Czech-West German border should be open, said Prague's Defense Minister. He also vowed to shorten compulsory military service and reduce the active military reserves by 90,000. 9 In Bulgaria, what price democracy? As boisterous crowds rally in Sofia, the rattled Communist Party is trying to keep pace with demands, and both sides are testing the limits of dissent. 9 A Colombian drug baron was killed along with his son and 15 bodyguards in a shootout with Colombian security forces in the north coast city of Cartegena. 1 Man in the News: Patricio Aylwin, President-elect of Chile, has closed the breach with his old adversaries on the left while extending a reassuring hand to those on the right. 5 A Chinese dissident may flee China with his wife soon. The fate of Fang Lizhi, who is hiding in the American Embassy in Beijing, was brought up with the Chinese Government by the national security advisor, Brent Scowcroft. 7 Beijing's plan for Hong Kong dims hopes for a democracy 6 Sectarian killings in India's Punjab have scarred the prosperous Sikh state. Last week, Prime Minister V.RP. Singh promised to heal the ''heavy, bleeding hearts.'' 6 Soviets oppose repeal of U.N.

title: Gillette Job Cuts Set As Part of Overhaul
description: The Gillette Company said today that it would cut 750 workers, sell some of its European toiletry units and reorganize its United States operations.

title: Upheaval in the East; New Measures Strain Poland's Ties to 2 Germanys
description: Relations between Poland and the two Germanys are being strained by the side effects of the peaceful revolution that has swept East Germany since October, diplomats and Government officials in several European capitals say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: The Latest in Luggage: Lightweight and Mobile
description: The holiday and vacation traveler, as well as the business traveler, has a wider choice of luggage this season than ever before.

title: Sakharov, Russia's Prickly Conscience
description: On an October day in 1975, Andrei D. Sakharov opened the door of his apartment on Chkalova Street in Moscow, greeted the small group of correspondents warmly and invited us in. Somehow, his greatness seemed accentuated by the simplicity of his surroundings. He wore a tattered sweater and old slippers; his flat was filled with worn furniture. He obviously cared about more important things than material possessions.

title: Jewish Audience Thrilled by Campbell
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Chief Weighs Limits on Asylum
description: The head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering whether to ban some people seeking political asylum in the United States from working in cities that already have large immigrant populations.

title: BET P.L.C. Set To Add Hestair
description: BET P.L.C., an industrial services company, said it would acquire Hestair P.L.C. for $:192 million in cash, or about $307.2 million.

title: 2d High-Water Mark; Phoebe Mills Has New Success Diving
description: Phoebe Mills is ready to compete. She takes a deep breath and begins her approach. The slender but strong 17-year-old builds speed, hits her takeoff mark and is suddenly airborne.

title: Review/Jazz; From South Africa, a Sunny Musical Mix
description: The jazz that developed in South Africa in the 1950's and 60's blended church music, South African ethnic influences and American jazz into a distinct style that overflows with optimism. It is sunny music that has kept a sense of dance, both in its group rhythms and in its solos. On Thursday night, Hugh Masekela, an expatriate South African who is one of the best known of all musicians to come out of South Africa, brought a fine band of African and American musicians to S.O.B.'s, where they gave a potent example of how distinct and refined the blend can get.

title: On the Sidewalks, the Color Of Money, in Firs and Pines
description: By his own admission, Radek Halden, a cross-country ski instructor from Norway, was not much of an expert on Christmas trees when he arrived in New York City two weeks ago.

title: At the Pump, Pollution Curb Yields Bonus
description: Clouds, even the ones formed by pollution, can have a silver lining. Regulators who have been trying to keep the chemicals that form harmful ozone from getting into the air have found that the same equipment that controls those chemicals can help control benzene, a toxic component of gasoline.

title: Ms. Joselow, Reporter, Weds in Rhode Island
description: Froma Joselow, a reporter for The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin, and David C. Harrop, a writer in New York, were married yesterday at the White Horse Tavern in Newport, R.I., by John H. McGann, a justice of the peace.

title: Composer at Premieres
description: The composer Andrzej Panufnik will conduct the New York Chamber Symphony in the world premiere of his ''Harmony'' and the New York premiere of his Violin Concerto at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, at 8 o'clock tonight. Elmar Oliveira will be the soloist in the concerto.

title: Convictions of 5 Apartheid Foes Voided
description: In a stunning psychological victory for the anti-apartheid movement, South Africa's highest court today reversed the convictions of five blacks who were found guilty of treason or terrorism last year after the longest political trial here in recent memory.

title: Killings by Police Stir Punjab's Fury
description: Kulwinder Singh's descent into brutality and terror began in May 1985, when he was a 15-year-old 10th grader.

title: Your Money; Retirement Plan To Beat Inflation
description: WITH life expectancies increasing, many people who stop working at age 65 can expect a 20- or 25-year retirement. That makes it vital to accumulate an investment portfolio that will provide returns that outpace inflation. And those who accept a lump-sum pension distribution and roll it over into an individual retirement account will need to manage it with long-term needs in mind.

title: Helen Robinson, Champion Angler, 89
description: Helen Robinson, a world-class angler who held several competitive fishing titles, died here Monday of complications from a fall. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Robinson set women's world records, among them the 1961 capture of a 796-pound black marlin and a 584-pound black marlin in 1962, both at Pinas Bay, Panama.

title: Chinese Jumbo Jet Flying to New York Is Hijacked
description: A Chinese jumbo jet bound for New York was hijacked today and forced to land in western Japan, Japanese authorities said.

title: Rivers Behind Hydropower Dams Aren't Dead; What Was a Waterfall?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Gerry Mulligan in Philharmonic Crossover
description: Zubin Mehta has always had a soft spot for crossover experimentation. This fall a New York Philharmonic subscription program included a world premiere of a piece for tuba and orchestra by Roger Kellaway. Now it's the turn of Gerry Mulligan, the mellow master of the cool-jazz baritone saxophone, who is the featured performer (along with his accompanying trio) at the current Philharmonic subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall. The series began Thursday night and continues tonight and Tuesday night.

title: 'Bikini' by Busby
description: Gerald Busby, a pianist and composer, will direct a program of his works at Weill Recital Hall at 8:30 tonight. Among the works to be performed are ''Bullet-Proof Bikini,'' for piano; ''Get it Out!,'' for two sopranos, mezzo-soprano, contralto, piano and electric pencil sharpener, and ''Trip to the Valley,'' for piano, tape and spare tire.

title: Prague Would Cut Defenses Along West German Border
description: Czechoslovakia's Defense Minister proposed today that the nation begin dismantling fortifications along all of its 150-mile border with West Germany.

title: George M. Fanelli, 92, A Retired Court Justice
description: George Marion Fanelli, a retired New York State Supreme Court Justice and a former District Attorney of Westchester County, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at a nursing home in Lansdale, Pa. He was 92 years old and had lived in Lansdale for the last year after growing up and living in New Rochelle.

title: Legal Services Panel Keeps Its Chief
description: The Legal Services Corporation, an ideological battleground for eight years, voted today to keep its conservative president, who has worked to narrow programs designed to provide legal aid to poor people.

title: Sense of Urgency Moves Donors to Neediest
description: There is a sense of urgency about many of the letters addressed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a sense that people everywhere, no matter what their personal circumstances, must pitch in to stem the tide of poverty or despair.

title: Commuter Plane Fuselage Found by Divers
description: Divers found the fuselage of a commuter plane in the 100-foot-deep waters of Block Island Sound today, but there was no sign of the eight people who were on board.

title: Ex-Senator Sentenced to Prison in Tax Case
description: Former State Senator Richard Schermerhorn was sentenced to 18 months in prison and two years' probation for income tax evasion, obstruction of justice and filing a false statement today.

title: New Emigres Putting Strain on Services
description: Two-year-old Israel Mastov, with a pacifier tied around his neck, runs about his parents' apartment in Rego Park, Queens, chattering: ''Zdrast! Hi! Shalom!''

title: Brief Closing for Pisa's Tower
description: The Mayor of Pisa signed an order today that will close the Tower of Pisa to the public from Jan. 7 to April 7 for safety reasons. Mayor Giacomino Granchi said officials would at least consider adopting safety measures that would allow a limited reopening of the tower. Shifting ground under the 180-foot tower left it tilting almost from the time that Bonnano Pisano started building it in 1173.

title: Steinbrenner, Mark Davis And Pretzels
description: ''No way Mark Davis would have fit in in New York,'' George Steinbrenner said. ''Some guys don't want the challenge of New York.''

title: For Music Lovers, a Lincoln Center Gift
description: People give a book of the month and even cakes and cookies of the month, so why not music of the month, or at least every other month? Now there is the Lincoln Center Video-of-the-Month, featuring videocassette tapes of six of the most popular programs from the Emmy Award-winning series ''Live From Lincoln Center.''

title: California Steps Up Anti-Pollution Drive
description: In its quest to clean up polluted air over Los Angeles and other major cities, California is putting unparalleled pressure on automobile makers and fuel companies to cooperate in designing the low-polluting vehicles of the future.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Steel and Wire Corp., Cuyahoga Heights, Ohio, a maker of shelving and other storage products, said its board had rejected as inadequate the increased acquisition offer of $9.50 a share by Chicago West Pullman Corp., Cincinnati, a railroad and steel company.

title: G.M. to Buy Half of Saab Car Unit
description: The General Motors Corporation surprised the auto industry today by announcing it would buy half of Saab-Scania A.B.'s troubled car-making operations. The move enlarges G.M.'s European presence and plugs a hole in the company's product line, which needs models that can compete with imports like BMW and Mercedes-Benz.

title: Law Firm Tied to Salvador Is Dropped by Minneapolis
description: The City Council voted today to dismiss a law firm because it lobbies for President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, a day after four partners and an associate lawyer resigned from the firm for the same reason.

title: Leda Anchutina Eglevsky, 73, Dancer and Founder of Troupe
description: Leda Anchutina Eglevsky, who danced in George Balanchine's first American ballet companies and founded the Eglevsky Ballet with her husband, Andre Eglevsky, was found dead yesterday morning in bed at her home in Massapequa, L.I. The cause of death was not immediately determined. Always reluctant to give her age, Miss Anchutina was thought to be 73.

title: Pardo DelliQuadri, 74, Social Work Educator
description: Pardo Frederick DelliQuadri, who was the dean of several schools of social work, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 74 years old.

title: Landry to See Dallas Game
description: Tom Landry, the coach at Dallas for 29 years until he was dismissed in February, will attend the Giants-Cowboys game today as a guest of Wellington Mara, the Giants' co-owner and a longtime friend.

title: The Czech' History: A Waiting Game
description: The Czechoslovakiadid it in their own style -peacefully, led by intellectuals and students in Prague's streets, after a long wait. It was the quickest flip to democracy in the region. It was also the neatest, and perhaps the one with the most promise.

title: Alcan Aluminium
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said its directors had adopted a shareholder rights plan to discourage hostile takeover bids. The giant aluminum company said the plan, effective immediately, would allow holders of the rights to acquire common shares at a 50 percent discount of market value in certain cases. The rights would be triggered if someone acquired between 10 and 20 percent of the company's voting shares. Saying it does not know of any intended takeover, Alcan said the plan was aimed at encouraging any direct approaches to its board,

title: HIGHER FARES IN THE NEW YEAR
description: Increases were approved yesterday for subway, bus and commuter train fares effective Jan. 1 NEW YORK CITY TRANSIT AUTHORITY Subways and buses . . . $1.15 Elderly and handicapped Buses . . . $.55 Subways . . . $1.15 round trip LON ISLAND RAIL ROAD AND METRO NORTH Average fare . . . up 15% New off-peak 10-trip discount ticket . . . 10% off New off-peak family fare (one or two children between ages 5 and 11 with parent or guardian) . . . $.50 each child New annual subscription discount . . . 4% off (by check); 2% off (by credit card) Penalty fee for purchase on train . . . $2 Metro-North peak period . . . extended until 8 P.M. METROPOLITAN SUBURBAN BUS AUTHORITY Base fare (Nassau and western Suffolk) . . . $1.15 Base fare (between Nassau and Queens) . . . $1.30 Transfer charge . . . $.10 (Article, page 29)

title: More Sway for Noriega IS Expected in Panama
description: The National Assembly convened for a second day today with members saying they planned to vote Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega head of Government.

title: 2 States Join Vermont Suit on Age Discrimination
description: Connecticut and Massachusetts have joined Vermont's fight to force the retirement of a 70-year-old Vermont Supreme Court Justice.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about the Bulgarian leader, Petar T. Mladenov, and a chart on Monday about political changes in Eastern Europe gave an incorrect date for his appointment.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: East's Turn to West Puts Comecon in Peril
description: As the countries of Eastern Europe rush to strengthen their economic ties with the West, Comecon, the trade organization that has been a pillar of the Soviet bloc, is rapidly disintegrating, many Eastern European officials and economists say.

title: Review/Dance; Seamy Side of the Street
description: There is nothing in ''Chelsea's Bells,'' a new duet by Barry Martin for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, that you won't see on MTV. But even music videos usually give you more than an image of a young man consistently expressing a stirring in his loins for a woman in prostitute's gear who kicks him around.

title: Brooklyn Concert
description: Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat,'' the Brahms Clarinet Trio in A minor (Op. 114) and Schubert's Piano Trio in B flat (Op. 99) will be performed at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Letter: On Medicare; Catastrophic Care Is a Community Task
description: To the Editor:

title: Valenzuela Stays With Dodgers
description: Fernando Valenzuela, who had been on the verge of signing with another team, decided yesterday to return to the Los Angeles Dodgers for one year at a guaranteed $2 million. The left-hander could earn an additional $500,000 in bonuses if he pitches 240 innings.

title: Upheaval in the East; YUGOSLAVIA PLANS TO EASE PARTY GRIP
description: The Communist Party will give up its monopoly on power and allow independent parties to compete in free elections next year, according to a draft declaration published today.

title: A Badger Returns
description: Pat Richter, a former Wisconsin wide receiver whose 11 catches and 163 receiving yards in the 1963 Rose Bowl game against Southern California are still records for the New Year's Day game, was named the athletic director at his alma mater yesterday. He replaces Ade Sponberg, who resigned under pressure last month.

title: About New York; Of Metaphysics And the Making Of Useful Things
description: In India, that ancient land of cults, a new belief system has sprouted in recent years. Adherents, called Redmondians, follow the teachings of the one they call the Cosmic Puppeteer.

title: Congress Stops the Spinning Door
description: To great fanfare, the Ethics Reform Act of 1989 increased Federal pay and reduced honorariums. It also attacked the revolving door phenomenon that has long plagued government. The act clarifies and strengthens existing law requiring former high executive branch officials, all members of Congress and top staff members to wait one year before returning to lobby their old haunts. President Reagan pocket-vetoed a similar measure at the end of an Administration riddled by just the sort of behavior the new law makes criminal.

title: Becker Defeats Edberg in Davis Cup Final
description: Boris Becker overpowered Stefan Edberg, 6-2, 6-2, 6-4, tonight as West Germany, the defending champion, and Sweden split the opening two singles matches in the Davis Cup final.

title: Dow Drops 14.08 on 'Witching' Day
description: Stocks closed moderately lower yesterday, after recovering from earlier sharp losses, as investors reacted to the ''triple witching hour,'' the quarterly time when stock options, stock-index futures and stock-index options all expire.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on Thursday about a proposed takeover statute in Pennsylvania referred incorrectly to the handling of profits made by investors who seek control of a Pennsylvania company - either though a proxy fight or by purchasing more than 20 percent of the stock -and sell shares within two years of seeking control. The profits would have to be returned to any company whose stock was involved.

title: The Copernicus of Communism
description: Andrei Sakharov was a good and great man who dared to say the world was round when his masters insisted it was flat.

title: President Named For Arby's Chain
description: Frank Belatti was named president and chief operating officer of Arby's Inc. in a move hailed by a group of dissident franchisees as a step toward ending their feud with the fast-food chain's parent. Mr. Belatti was the chain's executive vice president for marketing and has in the past been critical of Victor Posner, who controls the DWG Corporation, the Miami Beach, Fla., parent of Arby's.

title: Patents; 'Roto Rooter' For Clogged Arteries
description: A CARDIOLOGIST at the Stanford University School of Medicine and his father obtained a patent this week on what amounts to a Roto Rooter system for clearing clogged arteries.

title: Metro Datelines; Bronx Man Arrested In East Side Killing
description: A man was arrested yesterday and charged in the killing of a New Jersey man who was stabbed to death in August as he stood at the entrance to his daughter's apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Bank of New England Says It Will Post Large 1989 Loss
description: The Bank of New England Corportion announced yesterday that its problems in real estate lending were far more severe than previously estimated and would result in a substantial loss for the year.

title: N.F.L. Fines Wyche
description: For his failure to allow reporters into his team's locker room after a 24-17 loss to the Seattle Seahawks on Sunday, Coach Sam Wyche of the Cincinnati Bengals was hit with what the National Football League termed a substantial fine yesterday. The size of the fine was not disclosed.

title: Army Cites Strong Evidence in Barring Medal
description: The Army said today that there was ''incontestable evidence'' that a Jewish World War II veteran did not perform the heroic actions that he had claimed in seeking the Medal of Honor.

title: Top Newspaper Executives Predict Tough Year for Ads
description: Top executives of some of the nation's largest newspaper companies predicted this week that 1990 would be another tough year for advertising sales, but most said they thought a recession was unlikely.

title: Savings Incentive Studied
description: The Bush Administration is studying a plan that would create a new type of long-term savings account in which interest would be wholly exempted from taxes and depositors would be allowed access to their money before retirement, Administration officials said today.

title: Kodak Charge Cuts Earnings
description: In a development that came as little surprise to the financial community, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by $273 million, or 85 cents a share, because of write-offs of assets in discontinued businesses and payments to employees who are losing their jobs.

title: Metro Datelines; Officer Resuscitates A Dog; Yes, a Dog
description: In a case of mouth-to-muzzle resuscitation, Officer Michael Fusco of the Shelton, Conn., police revived a 14-month-old dalmatian Thursday after a squash ball became lodged in its throat.

title: Frederick Nolting Jr., U.S. Envoy To Saigon in 60's, Is Dead at 78
description: Frederick E. Nolting Jr., who was United States Ambassador to South Vietnam from 1961 to 1963, died on Thursday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, Va., a spokesman for the center said.

title: The Usual Panic
description: For real excitement you can't beat a snow forecast in what the television people infesting my parlor call ''the Washington viewing area.''

title: Farm Income Report
description: Farmers are expected to receive income next year of between $52 billion and $57 billion, compared with an estimated $53 billion this year, the Agriculture Department said this week.

title: School Districts' Battle On Tuition Goes to Court
description: A neighboring borough that sends its students to this Bergen County community's high school has refused to pay its tuition bill since the beginning of the school year. As a result, the Ridgefield Park Board of Education contends it may have to borrow money to meet its payroll next week.

title: Coors's Bid to Buy Stroh Expires
description: A letter of intent for the Adolph Coors Company to buy the Stroh Brewery Company's domestic beer-making operations for $425 million expired today with no sale, freeing Stroh to seek other buyers, the companies said. Chris Sortwell, Stroh vice president for corporate planning and development, said the companies had agreed not to discuss details.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Bucks 103, Pacers 98: Visiting Milwaukee overcame a 16-point halftime deficit to win. Fred Roberts's free throw with about a minute to play tied the score at 95-95. A 6-point run by Milwaukee, with Jack Sikma scoring the go-ahead layup, gave the Bucks a 101-95 lead with eight seconds to go.(AP) Heat 95, Timberwolves 84: Visiting Miami built a double-digit lead in the first half and made it last. The victory was only the second in 12 games for Miami. Both victories were against expansion teams. Miami used its fast break and Rony Seikaly's inside scoring, including four slam-dunks, to put together two 8-1 runs in the second quarter, in which Minnesota shot just 30 percent. Bench strength helped Miami in the third quarter. Minnesota made a belated and unsuccessful fourth-quarter charge behind Tony Campbell, who had 23 points total.(AP) Jazz 94, Pistons 91: Karl Malone scored 27 points and John Stockton 26 as Utah, playing at home, held the opposition under 100 points for the sixth consecutive regulation game. Malone, Stockton and Darrell Griffith combined for 20 of Utah's 23 fourth-quarter points to help the Jazz overcome a 75-71 third-quarter deficit.(AP) Suns 121, Rockets 96: Mark West grabbed 15 rebounds, scored 11 points and blocked 5 shots as Phoenix won this home game. The team, which shot only 36 percent from the field in its last two losses, shot 54 percent last night while holding Houston to 39 percent.(AP) Nuggets 121, Kings 112: Walter Davis, Denver's instant offense off the bench, scored a season-high 35 points as Denver collected its 10th victory in 11 home games this season. Davis connected on a jumper with 2:28 left in the first period, putting Denver ahead to stay at 26-24. Sacramento made several mild threats in the second half, led by the shooting of Rodney McCray and Danny Ainge, but the team got no closer than 8 points.(AP) Lakers 119, Celtics 110: James Worthy led a long-range shooting attack with 28 points and visiting Los Angeles broke open a close game with a 12-0 run at the start of the fourth period. Los Angeles won with free throws, outscoring Boston by 28-8 at the line. The Lakers led, 60-55, at halftime, fell behind briefly in the third quarter, then went ahead to stay on three free throws and an 18-foot shot by A. C. Green.(AP) Mavericks 95, 76ers 88: Rolando Blackman scored a season-high 28 points and Dallas scored the last 10 points of the game to win in Philadelphia. Dallas trailed by 88-85 with 2:38 remaining, but Blackman and Derek Harper closed out the scoring with 5 points each. Philadelphia played the final 18:23 without Charles Barkley, who scored 14 points before being ejected by Referee Steve Javie.(AP) Cavaliers 120, SuperSonics 101: John Williams scored 5 of his career-high 32 points in an 11-0 fourth-quarter run that broke open this home game for Cleveland. Williams scored 21 points in the first half. Seattle gained a 68-61 edge with an 11-2 spurt midway through the third quarter, getting baskets from five players in the run. But Cleveland answered with a 13-2 run. Cleveland was without Coach Lenny Wilkens, who has a sinus infection. Dick Helm, an assistant coach, handled the team.(AP) Warriors 116, Trail Blazers 111: Chris Mullin scored 30 points, including 10 in a fourth-quarter comeback, as Golden State snapped Portland's home winning streak at nine games.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 8, Blackhawks 4: Steve Yzerman scored three goals and Gerard Gallant two last night as Detroit ended visiting Chicago's winning streak at four games. The Red Wings scored five times on nine second-period shots. Yzerman scored twice during the period and Gallant capped the outburst with a power-play goal. After Al Secord tied the score at 2-2 with an unassisted goal at 1:57, Yzerman took a bouncing puck in the slot and beat Jim Waite, the Blackhawks' starting goalie, at 2:30. Waite, a rookie, was then replaced by Alain Chevrier, who allowed four goals on the six shots he faced in the period.(AP) GOLF Green and Bies Lead: The team of Tammie Green and Don Bies shot a best-ball score of 11-under-par 61 yesterday and took a two-shot lead after the first round of the Mazda Champions tournament in San Juan, P.R. The field pairs the top 12 qualifiers on both the men's Senior Tour and the L.P.G.A. Tour. Green and Bies combined for 11 birdies, 7 by Bies and 4 by Green, over the par-72 Hyatt Dorado Beach East course.(AP) SKIING Race Postponed: Strong winds at the top and melting snow at the bottom of the course yesterday wiped out the first men's downhill race of the World Cup season in Val Gardena, Italy. The race was moved to this Dolomite resort from Val d'Isere because of lack of snow in the French resort. The downhill race was rescheduled for today here.(AP) VOLLEYBALL Title on the Line Today: Nebraska will play Long Beach State today in Honolulu for the title in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I women's tournament. Cris Hall had 19 kills to lead Nebraska over U.C.L.A., 15-13, 15-11, 15-6, in the semifinals Thursday night. Long Beach State beat Texas-Arlington.(AP) HORSE RACING Slew the Knight Wins: Slew the Knight slipped through along the rail and went on to win the $36,000 Hail to Reason purse for 3-year-olds and up yesterday at Aqueduct. Slew the Knight, ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, beat Joker's Farce with Jose Santos riding, by 5 1/4 lengths in the eight-horse field. Joker's Farce finished 1 3/4 lengths ahead of Wee Stark. The victory was the fourth in eight starts this year for Slew the Knight, who covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:45 4/5 and earned $21,600 for Philip Dileo. Slew the Knight returned $10 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: Knicks' Wilkins Wins Battle of the Brothers
description: Normally, Gerald and Dominique Wilkins are not matched against each other when the Knicks face the Hawks. But tonight, circumstances dictated otherwise.

title: Baker Says Gorbachev's Economic Plan Lacks Basic Changes
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d expressed some disappointment today with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new five-year plan for the Soviet economy, saying it failed to include the kind of structural changes that would begin to re-orient the Soviet Union to a more productive free-market system.

title: Snappy Legal Journal To Lose Weekly Forum
description: Manhattan Lawyer magazine, the snappy, irreverent journal on the New York legal scene, will cease publication as a weekly next week, and reappear as a monthly next spring, its president announced yesterday.

title: Risky Limits on Interns' Hours
description: LEAD: For the last few months, I have faced each day of work with fear. As a second year medical resident at a major New York hospital, I am responsible for a number of patients, many of whom I know little about. Yet I make the critical medical decisions for these people - decisions I know could mean the difference between life and death.

title: Illness and Snow's Threat Cancel Bush Visit
description: President Bush's planned visit to New York yesterday, which was to have begun with his helicopter landing on Central Park's Great Lawn, was canceled because snow was predicted and Mr. Bush had laryngitis.

title: V.E. Hernandez Weds Kai Bloom
description: Kai Astir Bloom and Valentin Eduardo Hernandez were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York by the Rev. Salvatore B. Matarazzo. The bride is the daughter of Susan Frisch Sagor of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Roger F. Bloom of new York. Her husband is the son of Mrs. Valentin Hernanded of Caracas, Venezuela, and New York, and the late Mr. Hernandez.

title: U.S. Divided on Soviet Afghan Stand
description: Bush Administration officials are divided over whether the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and his aides signaled at the Malta summit talks that they were ready for a political settlement in Afghanistan that could exclude President Najibullah.

title: Doesn't the Taxi Meter Ever Stop?
description: LEAD: The $140 million fare increase approved by the Taxi and Limousine Commission demonstrates - once again -that on the commission's agenda the public takes a back seat to the interests of medallion owners. Raising the fare will have only one effect - to enrich medallion owners. It will not improve service and will not, for the vast majority of drivers, increase earnings.

title: FREE TRAVEL FAILS TO CURB EXODUS OF EAST GERMANS
description: East Germany's hope that the exodus of its people would drop drastically once travel restrictions were removed has not been fulfilled in the month since the travel curbs were lifted, and West Germany continues to receive a steady stream of immigrants.

title: Scarlett and Rhett Take Atlanta Again
description: Just as it did 50 years ago, this city gave a brazen and bosomy hug this week to the 50th anniversary of the premiere of ''Gone With the Wind,'' a weeklong promotional frenzy that included a costume ball, a parade, tours of antebellum homes, star-gazing and memorabilia-hawking.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about an attack by Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas on a Syrian Army garrison misstated the site. It was in southern Lebanon, not Beirut.

title: CUOMO APPROVES A SECESSION VOTE FOR STATEN ISLAND
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo tonight signed a bill that would allow Staten Island to secede from New York City, but only after steps that would take at least three and a half years.

title: KEY RATES
Rivers Behind Hydropower Dams Aren't Dead; Repeal Utilities Act
description: To the Editor:

title: James Beard, 70, Dies; Professor and Author
description: James Franklin Beard, a professor of English and a leading authority on the American author James Fenimore Cooper, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester, Mass. He was 70 years old and lived in Worcester.

title: Baker Hughes, Norton in Deal
description: The Norton Company, a diversified industrial company whose businesses include abrasives, ceramics, plastics and chemical process products, signed a definitive agreement to sell its Eastman Christensen Company unit to Baker Hughes Inc. for $550 million in cash and other considerations.

title: Arjune Enters Plea of Guilty In Arrest Case
description: A man under Federal protection whose testimony against a major crack ring made him a hero to some people in New York City returned to Spokane today and pleaded guilty to a charge of resisting arrest. He also apologized.

title: Blame Lack of Toilets, Not Moral Decay, for Public Urination
description: To the Editor:

title: Quantum in Move To Pull Back Drugs
description: A subsidiary of one of the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies said it was removing all but one of its drug products from the market after misrepresentations were made to Government regulators during the approval process. Quantum Pharmics of Amityville, L.I., a unit of New York-based American Home Products Corporation, has agreed to voluntarily give up the marketing approvals granted to 25 of its generic drug products by the Food and Drug Administration, an American Home spokeswoman, Carol Emerling, said.

title: Blame Lack of Toilets, Not Moral Decay, for Public Urination
description: To the Editor:

title: Scots Narrow Suspects in Pan Am Blast
description: Nearly a year after a bomb destroyed a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people, Scottish investigators said today that ''hard evidence'' implicates several people in the attack.

title: Leland H. Watson, Lighting Designer, 63
description: Leland H. Watson, a lighting designer for many years, died of leukemia on Dec. 8 at his home in Lafayette, Ind. He was 63 years old.

title: Review/Theater; Timeless Parable of Epidemics Of Evil
description: ''The Crucible'' is Arthur Miller's most produced play, for reasons that are chillingly apparent in Arvin Brown's revival at the Long Wharf Theater. The play combines a clear dramatic line with a pronounced moral fervor that has not lessened in the 36 years since it was first presented.

title: Michael Mann, 86, Ex-Regional Chief Of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Michael Mann, retired regional director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O for New York and New Jersey, died of heart disease on Dec. 9 at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 86 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Upheaval in the East; Poland Outlines Goals On Delaying Payments
description: The Polish Government, nearing a loan accord with the International Monetary Fund, said today that it would like to postpone capital repayments on its foreign debt until after the year 2000.

title: CML Group Gets New Jacobs Bid
description: CML Group Inc. received a revised unsolicited bid from Irwin L. Jacobs, the corporate raider, to acquire CML for $25 a share in cash, or a total of about $167.5 million. CML previously received an unsolicited bid from Mr. Jacobs of $23 a share.

title: Sammy Lerner, 86; Hollywood Songwriter
description: Sammy Lerner, a Hollywood songwriter who wrote the theme song for the cartoon character Popeye in 1932, died of cancer on Wednesday in a Los Angeles nursing home. He was 86 years old.

title: If Carthon Gets Call, He'll Be Ready to Run
description: The Giants will play the Dallas Cowboys at Giants Stadium at 12:30 P.M. Saturday in what could be a runaway. Against a defense that ranks fourth from the bottom in the National Football League, the Giants seem capable of rushing for 150 to 175 yards, even in the cold and wind.

title: Upheaval in the East; Calm Island Amid Turmoil: East German Farmers
description: One of the few groups in this society that has remained calm and quiet in the last 10 weeks of political uproar has been the country's farmers.

title: Review/Theater; Illegal Immigrants on the Irish Mile
description: Almost all the characters in Janet Noble's likable comedy-drama ''Away Alone'' are illegal Irish immigrants in their 20's who have settled in an area of the Bronx that has been nicknamed the Irish mile.

title: Producer Prices Down By 0.1% in November
description: A sharp drop in the cost of gasoline helped to push producer prices lower in November, the Government said today.

title: Administration Supports Family Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivers Behind Hydropower Dams Aren't Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Call Him Mr. Dinkins, Not 'Dave' or 'David'
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, whose adherence to the forms of public courtesy is as steady as the New York City press corps's is uneven, hopes his future contests with reporters will be played out with decorum, his new press secretary allowed yesterday.

title: Devils Rally Past Kings
description: A sustained, deafening noise from the sellout crowd filled Byrne Meadowlands Arena for several minutes late in the game tonight as the Devils rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 7-5 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Books of the Times; Slaves' Historian Changes His Mind
description: Without Consent or Contract The Rise and Fall of American Slavery By Robert William Fogel 539 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.50.

title: Indiana Running Back Wins Maxwell Award
description: The field was reversed yesterday for Anthony Thompson of Indiana, the record-breaking running back who was second to Andre Ware of Houston in the Heisman Trophy balloting. This time Thompson was voted the 53d Maxwell Award by the Maxwell Club in Philadelphia as the outstanding college player and Ware was second.

title: President Rejects Plan to Ground Nuclear Airborne Command Post
description: President Bush today rejected a recommendation by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to halt the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that could be used to wage a nuclear war, Administration officials said.

title: Coping: With Imperfect FM Reception
description: You don't have to mount an antenna on the roof to get decent FM radio reception. Many indoor antennas cost much less than a directional roof antenna with a rotator, and provide much better reception than the antennas that come with most FM sets.

title: Review/Dance; A U.S. Journey, From Slavery On
description: In the midst of the hectic preholiday season, there is an oasis of civilized and joyous song and dance uptown at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where the Charles Moore Dance Theater is performing through tomorrow. The company of dancers and musicians, founded in 1974 by Charles Moore and Ella Thompson Moore, his wife, specializes in dance from Africa, the Caribbean and South America, with an emphasis on revealing the African influence on dance of the last two areas.

title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots
description: A United States Marine Corps reconnaissance team, which has been quietly patrolling the Southwest border since Thanksgiving, exchanged fire with drug smugglers for the first time late Wednesday night along the Arizona border, Administration officials said today.

title: Ad Executive Killed in the East Village Was Attacked Twice
description: A young advertising executive who was killed earlier this month leaving a Christmas party in the East Village was set upon by different robbers in two attacks within a few minutes, the police said yesterday.

title: European Bloc Levies Bayer Fine
description: The European Community fined the West German chemical producer Bayer A.G. $590,000 for violating competition rules in the marketing of an additive for animal feed. The fine stems from Bayer's insistence that West German customers buy the additive, which promotes growth in animals, only for themselves.

title: Rio Journal; Kiss the Frog and He May Turn Into a President
description: As beachgoers cheered and whistled, the beautiful princess leaned over and planted a big kiss on the bearded frog.

title: Government That Exiled Him Hurries to Mourn Sakharov
description: The Soviet Government, which once exiled Andrei D. Sakharov for being a human rights champion, today embraced him in death. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev mourned the national loss of ''a man of conviction and sincerity.''

title: Harriet Reade, Environmentalist, 68
description: Harriet Reade, a founder of the Children's Psychiatric Center who also helped environmental causes in New Jersey, died of cancer Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 68 years old and lived in Middletown, N.J.

title: Blame Lack of Toilets, Not Moral Decay, for Public Urination
description: To the Editor:

title: A Top Medellin Drug Trafficker Dies in a Shootout in Colombia
description: One of the most violent figures in the world of cocaine smuggling was killed in a shootout this afternoon with Colombian security forces.

title: Review/Theater; Reason Battles Instinct In Calderon's 'Dream'
description: The early 17th century was a time of great soul-searching in Europe. Aftershocks from the Reformation and Counter-Reformation still shuddered through cathedrals and palaces, calling into question political alliances, religious convictions and personal beliefs. This introspection inspired a library of dramatic literature that is all too infrequently performed.

title: Metro Datelines; Jury Acquits Wife In Spouse's Killing
description: The wife of a senior partner in a large accounting firm was acquitted yesterday of murder and manslaughter in the stabbing death of her estranged husband.

title: 3d West Virginian In Corruption Inquiry Is Punished by Court
description: A Federal district judge has sentenced a former president of the West Virginia State Senate to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine for extorting $5,000 from a company that sought to promote the legalization of casino gambling in this state.

title: Past-Due Mortgages Up
description: The delinquency rate for home mortgages jumped sharply in the July-September quarter to the highest level in more than two years, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said Thursday. In the quarter, 5 percent of mortgage payments for one-family to four-family residences were 30 or more days late, up from a second-quarter rate of 4.52 percent, a 10-year low. It was the highest delinquency rate since the second quarter of 1987, when 5.02 percent of mortgages were past due.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bush and Mitterrand Meet Today on Europe's Role
description: Reflecting France's traditional distrust of NATO, President Francois Mitterrand is expected to emphasize the European Community's claim to a predominant role in reshaping Europe when he meets President Bush on the Caribbean island of St. Martin on Saturday.

title: Penn State To Join Big Ten Conference
description: After a coy decadelong flirtation that blossomed into a full-scale romance over the last few months, the Big Ten has finally popped the question and Penn State has said yes. The school has agreed to give up its independence and join the venerable athletic conference.

title: Chrysler Broadening Its Rebates
description: In an effort to attract more customers to its dealerships, the Chrysler Corporation has significantly broadened the scope of its rebates and its low-interest financing programs.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Is a Magnum Enough?
description: The holidays mean toasts, and toasts mean champagne. Champagnes are bottled in a greater variety of sizes than are other wines and that means you can generally buy what you need and no more. Most French Champagne is sold in half-bottles, bottles and magnums. Splits and jeroboams are also fairly common, and a few producers bottle nonvintage champagnes in sizes even bigger than the jeroboam. If you plan to serve an extra-large bottle, have a tub of ice, with some water added, on hand to chill it. Here are the sizes of champagne bottles, and the approximate servings they provide: Bottle Size Glasses Split 1/4 bottle 1 1/2 Half-bottle 375 mililiters 3 Bottle 750 mililiters 7 Magnum 2 bottles 15 Jeroboam 4 bottles 30 Rehoboam 6 bottles 45 Methuselah 8 bottles 60 Salmanazar 12 bottles 90 Balthazar 16 bottles 120 Nebuchadnezzar 20 bottles 150

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Treatment Chief Out

title: Mr. Baker's First Draft for Europe
description: If the Bush Administration doesn't think hard and convincingly now about America's place in the Europe emerging from the current earthquakes, Washington will lose the constructive role it has played for two generations.

title: Hess and Steinberg to Meet And Discuss Jets' Future
description: The Jets' final days of the 1980's have taken on strange overtones. Neither coaches, players nor front-office officials know what 1990 will bring.

title: Rockwell Contract
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had awarded it a supplementary contract valued at $375 million to build a set of spare orbiter structural components for the space shuttle. The cost-plus-incentive fee agreement is a supplement to its existing contract to build the new space shuttle scheduled for delivery in 1992.

title: Script for Bush's Drug Deal Yields a Comedy
description: First there was the ''Doonesbury'' comic strip. Then the skit on ''Saturday Night Live.'' But the most damning comments about a purchase of crack in front of the White House orchestrated by Federal officials came this week from the bench.s is like a Keystone Kops thing,'' said a bemused Judge Stanley Sporkin of the United States District Court as he heard the case of 18-year-old Keith Jackson, a local high school student charged with selling the bag of crack that President Bush used Sept. 5 as the prop to announce his war on drugs in his first nationally televised speech. Sept. 5 to announce his war on drugs.

title: To Greener Pastures
description: Tony Meola, the starting goaltender on the United States national team and the college player of the year, said yesterday that he would give up his last two years of eligibility at the University of Virginia and turn pro.

title: Koch Nominates 5 To Bench in 3 Courts
description: In his last opportunity to shape the city's judiciary, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday named five people to the bench and announced that public hearings on the nominations would be held on Dec. 27.

title: Judge Allows Tests of Police For Drug Use
description: A new policy by the New York City Police Department requiring all members of its 27,000 uniformed force to be randomly tested for drugs was upheld yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Backwater Norwalk Office Park Thrives
description: MAINTAINING a remarkable immunity to slumps in the real estate market, the Merritt 7 Office Park in Norwalk has been fully rented since the first of four buildings opened 11 years ago.

title: The Kissinger Syndrome
description: In sending a high-level mission to the unrepentant rulers of China, President Bush acted on the premises of a particular world view. That is the one that Henry Kissinger brought to Washington as foreign-policy impresario for Presidents Nixon and Ford.

title:
GARDENING;
Poinsett's Amazing Namesake
description: LEAD: WHEN one considers the diversity among the poinsettias available today, one cannot help but wonder were Joel Poinsett's ghost to return, whether he would recognize the plant named after him.

title: Review/Music; Clarinetist in Recital
description: Daniel McKelway, the clarinetist who gave a recital in the Young Concert Artists series at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening, is a technically assured player and a fearless interpreter. From the first bars of the program's opening work - the Brahms Sonata No. 1 in F minor (Op. 120) -one gathered that Mr. McKelway was not about to settle into an evening of comfortably standard readings.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: IN A DARK WOOD WANDERING. By Hella S. Haasse. Revised and edited by Anita Miller from a translation by Lewis C. Kaplan. (Academy Chicago, $22.95.) A best seller in the Netherlands, where it has never been out of print since its publication in 1949, Hella S. Haasse's epic historical novel, ''In a Dark Wood Wandering,'' has taken 40 years to arrive in American bookstores.

title: Like the Toy? See the Movie.
description: You ordered the burger, the fries and the Coke, but you certainly didn't order the Flounder. There he is anyway: a three-inch blue-and-yellow rubber replica of a character from ''The Little Mermaid'' right there in your McDonald's Happy Meal, in a box adorned with jokes and puzzles that test your knowledge of Little Mermaid lore. Come back next week and Ursula the sea-witch will be waiting. Another $5 will buy you a McGift Certificate and a little stuffed Flounder for the Christmas tree.

title: Lorena CrisfieldEngaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Lorena Hathaway Crisfield to Richard Parker Callanan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Callanan of Auburndale and Plymouth, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Lucile Stafford Proctor of Princeton, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass., and James Pearce Crisfield of Youngstown, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: Steinberg and Jets Plan More Talks
description: The Jets and Dick Steinberg were impressed enough with each other at their first meeting on Friday to schedule further talks tomorrow.

title: A BROTHER'S DEATH
description: It seems almost obscene to infringe on the emotional display of Ms. Ascher, but, of course, she has published her thoughts. She writes that, ''we knew that my brother was gay, and his openness had enabled my parents to share the happiness he and George were finding together. . . .'' She goes on to to say that, ''. . . in a careless world, love is precious whatever the pairing.'' Apparently, she means that even if it kills her brother. Perhaps the devastating sadness expressed in her article is, in part, caused by the knowledge that her brother's death was really unnecessary. RICHARD A. YOUNG New York, N.Y.

title: Nursing Enrollments End 5 Years of Declines
description: The number of new students enrolling in college and university nursing programs increased for the first time in five years, but the increase is too small to overcome an acute nursing shortage, a new survey shows.

title: MEXICAN CAPITAL RESTRICTS DRIVING
description: Responding to public fears that the arrival of winter will push pollution to intolerable levels, the government of the Mexican capital has for the first time imposed restrictions on automobile use and begun putting in place a plan to improve air quality by reducing toxic emissions.

title: Hanoi Protests Over Boat People
description: Vietnam opposes the forced return of boat people who sought refuge in Hong Kong and reserves the right to send them back to the British colony, the official Hanoi press agency said.

title: Fashion; Blown by the Wind From Points East
description: Colorful layered garments from the gusty deserts of India and Africa and the foothills of the Himalayas can protect wearers in city canyons, too. Urban nomads can find this warm and newly chic attire at some outposts in lower Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Dance; Two Pearson-Widrig Collaborations
description: To see the two collaboratively choreographed works that Sara Pearson and Patrik Widrig presented Friday night at Performance Space 122 was to watch two talented artists dance their way into a rut. Both pieces, to taped collages, concerned lovers' difficulties in getting along. But these choreographic variations on a theme lacked variety.

title: Wendy L. Willis To Marry in May
description: Mrs. Charles E. Willis of Locust Valley, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Wendy Lee Willis, to David W. Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Smith of Manhasset, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Poland's Injustices to Germans Also Need to Be Acknowledged
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Tropez
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Nocturne in St.-Tropez'' (Travel, Aug. 20), which recently came to my attention, I realize that the focus was on the beautiful people in what has become one of their special enclaves, but I would like to point out that between Colette's arriving there in 1926 and Brigitte Bardot's putting St.-Tropez on the world's movie screens in 1955, an event occurred that merits mention.

title: Arnold Moss, 80, Popular Actor Famous for Shakespearean Roles
description: Arnold Moss, the popular classical actor, died of lung cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Coping With a Loved One's Death and the Holidays
description: LEAD: IT is at this time of year that Peter Lynch, a New Haven psychotherapist, finds his calendar crowded with lecture dates. What he talks about is how to cope with the death of a loved one, and such grief, he says, is more pronounced between Thanksgiving and New Year's.

title: Emigre Settles Down to Play the Court Star
description: LEAD: STEFANIE GOETTSCHE laughed as she recalled her first experience on a basketball court, in her freshman year at Staples High School in Westport. ''It was weird at the beginning because I didn't know how to shoot at all,'' she said. ''I would get the ball under the basket and it wouldn't go in.''

title: On the Mark
description: To the Editor:

title: Stephanie Adler Plans to Wed in May
description: James L. Adler Jr. of Phoenix and Audrey R. Wolf of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie L. Adler to William S. Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harrison of Haddonfield, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Bittersweet Pilgrimage
description: THE cobblestone streets of the medieval German city of Freiburg, near the French border in a valley protected by the lush slopes of the Black Forest, are lined by narrow canals filled with fresh, running water. They were built, some say, in an effort to help keep the streets cool in hot weather.

title: AMERICA'S RADIATION VICTIMS
description: To the Editor In May 1968, I (age 12) watched my father collapse on a tennis court in Southampton, L.I. (''America's Radiation Victims: The Hidden Files,'' by Clifford T. Honicker, Nov. 19). That December, he was dead of acute leukemia at the age of 40.

title: Celebrating Hanukkah in the Glare of Christmas
description: LEAD: LAST December, Susan and Steven Goldstein of Mystic and their daughter, Rebecca, then 3 years old, celebrated the first night of Hanukkah with a dinner party for friends, most of whom were not Jewish.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: A three-way tie: Dutch Reagan, who spent eight years ducking media beanballs, Wayne Gretzky, and Martina Navratilova. JEROME AGEL New York

title: HE LEFT HER FOR A WOMAN CALLED PINKY
description: THE CHINCHILLA FARM By Judith Freeman. 308 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: From Carols to Handbells, for Younger Listeners
description: THE cultural needs of children are not being forgotten this holiday season, with more than a dozen attractions designed for younger listeners - and in some cases featuring them.

title: Maurice Stans's Offer Rejected by His Town
description: An offer by Maurice Stans to donate his family home and a new museum to his hometown has been rejected because officials do not want to be responsible for the upkeep.

title: Sex, Art and Censorship on the Drawing Board
description: The first reaction is shock. The rather comfortable, familiar proscenium space at Manhattan Theater Club's Stage One has been temporarily transformed into a theater in the round. To get to its seats, the audience must tiptoe through clumps of straw while instinctively trying to avoid fake pieces of manure. The set in the middle of the stage area - designed by David Ultz - is a raised platform that more than anything else resembles an enormous sketch pad. Wrapped around it is what seems to be a similarly sized piece of drawing paper. High on the walls in the basement at City Center and surrounding all four sections of seats is a long and narrow strip of drawings, caricatures of many varieties of very 18th-century-looking faces.

title: A Winner, Maybe
description: IN what must be one of the longest long counts on record, Dennis Milton has defeated Michael Olajide in a middleweight bout that began Dec. 1 at the Empire State Plaza Convention Center in Albany and ended two weeks later in the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: Beyond Expectations
description: MY CULINARY CHAUVINISM DISAPPEARED WHEN I got my first chance to eat in England. Along with a whole bag of heavy sweaters for that mid-June jaunt, I had secretly packed a jar of pickled jalapeno peppers for my trip. If British food was truly going to be as dismal as I had always heard, I wanted to be able to give it a little heat, if not life.

title: Denver Cools Cardinals, 37-0
description: Bobby Humphrey rushed for 128 yards today to become the first Denver rookie to reach the 1,000-yard mark as the Broncos limited Phoenix to 101 yards in a 37-0 victory, the first shutout of the Cardinals in four years.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Generous on the Tang, Stingier on the Calories
description: Burritos and tacos have become almost as all-American as apple pie and hamburgers. Throw a little chili in the pot; add a little salsa, and what was formerly a simple stew or snack takes on an air of the Southwest.

title: More Housing For a Railyard
description: AFTER a 12-year hiatus, residential construction has resumed at a 52-acre former railroad yard on this city's near South Side.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; A Trip in Time to T. R.'s Summer White House
description: Theodore Roosevelt's home on Long Island, like the hyperactive President, is neither pretentious nor subtle.

title: COMFORTABLE WITH HITLER
description: HEIDEGGER AND NAZISM By Victor Farias. Edited by Joseph Margolis and Tom Rockmore. Translated by Paul Burrell (French) and Gabriel R. Ricci (German). 349 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $29.95.

title: WHO SHOULD PAINT THE WHITE HOUSE?
description: LEAD: THE PRIVATIZATION DECISION Public Ends, Private Means. By John D. Donahue. 264 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: Silvana Mangano Is Dead at 59; Starred as Peasant in 'Bitter Rice'
description: Silvana Mangano, the Italian film actress who created a sensation as a passionately earthy peasant in ''Bitter Rice'' in 1948 and shaped increasingly compelling characterizations in later movies, died yesterday in Madrid. She was 59 years old and had been hospitalized in a coma for several days.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about jigsaw puzzles with mystery themes misidentified a Bloomfield company marketing them. It is Be Puzzled, not DePuzzled.

title: MUSIC Lessons and Carols, Anthems and Motets
description: A festival of lessons and carols is being presented this afternoon at 4 in the South Congregational-First Baptist Church of New Britain. This fusing of Christmas music and Bible readings, born in medieval England, is now celebrated in many American towns.

title: Hyphens Add Spice to the American Stew
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Reduce Hazardous Waste
description: SOMEWHERE along Interstate 195 in western Monmouth County, on the stretch of highway between Trenton and Freehold, two huge wooden structures display graphic messages to passing motorists. Residents of this rural, undeveloped, horse-breeding region are, to say the least, unhappy with a proposal to site a hazardous-waste incinerator on one of the state's few remaining pieces of virgin land.

title: Alexis M. Egan Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Egan of Malvern, Pa., and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexis Marie Egan, to Paul Francis McCarthy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William McCarthy of Hingham, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Marina Ivashenko and Gregory Slayton Are Wed
description: At the Harvard University Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass., Marina Jolanta Ivashenko, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Ivashenko of Rutherford, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Winston Slayton, a son of Walter Slayton of Virginia Beach, Va., and Susan North Childs Slayton of Norfolk, Va. The Rev. Eric Schenkel of the Boston Covenant Church performed the nondenominational service.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE HIDDEN ORDER: Tokyo Through the Twentieth Century. By Yoshinobu Ashihara. Translated by Lynne E. Riggs. (Kodansha International, $17.95). Japanese interiors may be the picture of stark and perfect order, but step out into a Japanese city and chaos takes over. Streets zigzag; buildings of all shapes and sizes are jumbled together like someone's closet full of toys. Neither center nor grid anchor Tokyo or check its growth; the city has over the centuries sprouted like a patch of weeds, overcoming fires and other setbacks to adapt easily to industrialization and the information era. In ''The Hidden Order,'' the architect Yoshinobu Ashihara educes the logic behind the apparent confusion. Architects in Japan think from the inside out, he writes; they start inside the traditional house, and they start with the floor. People move through their homes shoeless and crouching; their line of vision is about a foot lower than in Western houses. With a perspective angled so insistently downwards and lengthwise, walls seem an afterthought, rice-paper interruptions that slide open to the touch. The line between private and public is blurry: the intimacy of the Japanese home, and its lack of space, force people out of the house for social contact and turn public places into living rooms, kitchens and studies. The Japanese city sprawls outward with the same centrifugal force, defying blueprints but quick to respond to changing human and technological needs. Mr. Ashihara draws upon an impressive knowledge of philosophy, mathematics, esthetics and religion to illustrate his points. Unfortunately, the translation from the Japanese by Lynne E. Riggs is awkward, so much so that in some places it is hard to tell whether Mr. Ashihara means to praise or criticize, when he is describing the way things are and when he is prescribing change.

title: Elizabeth Vogel Wed To John M. Schmidt
description: Elizabeth Vogel and John M. Schmidt were married yesterday at St. Vincent the Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Madison, N.J., by the Rev. James Reedy.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Much has been written about the proper storage and care of pictures. Generally, photographs - whether prints or slides - should be kept cool, dry and in the dark. But what about cameras, lenses and other equipment?

title: Review/Music; A Critic Makes Music
description: Composers have often taken up criticism, and the best composer-critics, from Berlioz and Schumann to Wagner to Thomson, count among history's most insightful commentators about music.

title: Poland's Injustices to Germans Also Need to Be Acknowledged
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Events
description: Concert for Amnesty

title: Heroes of 'Glory' Fought Bigotry Before All Else
description: The history books show a certain Col. James Montgomery, who commanded a black Civil War regiment in the vicinity of Charleston, talking about his soldiers in a particularly instructive way.

title: The U.S. Stake in the Philippines
description: THE rebel members of the Philippine armed forces who tried to overthrow President Corazon C. Aquino earlier this month made many political and tactical mistakes. But perhaps their biggest error was in thinking that the United States might remain neutral during a rebellion and support them if they prevailed.

title: STOCKING STUFFERS? TRY ACCISSORIES
description: If you're racing to complete your holiday shopping, it helps to have a few audio fans on your Christmas list. They are easy to shop for - even at the last minute. To find something in a hurry in a hi-fi shop to please music-minded friends, just check out all those little gadgets known collectively as audio accessories.

title: Raw Presumption
description: To the Editor:

title: Michele Ocken Engaged To Wed Michael Wolfson
description: February wedding plans have been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Paul Ocken of Watchung, N.J., for their daughter Michele Ocken and Michael A. Wolfson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Wolfson of Princeton, N.J.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The United States enjoyed an unprecedented building boom during the 1980's, with overbuilding and an oversupply of office space, shopping centers, hotels - just about everything, all over the country. Texas was not an anomaly, it was a precursor.'' - David Shulman, director of real estate research, Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Bush Defends China Visit; Is Open to East Berlin Aid
