description: President Bush said today that he had ''no second thoughts at all'' about sending envoys to China last week. But he added that he did not believe that it was time for the United States or other countries to remove sanctions against China, imposed after the killings of students protesting for democracy in Beijing.

title: Hospital Care for Poor Included in Budget Bill
description: A SPECIAL provision written into the Federal budget bill will permit New Jersey to continue using a $465 million trust fund to pay for hospital care for the poor.

title: Heart Patients Win Retroactive Disability Benefits
description: A Federal judge has ordered that retroactive disability benefits be paid to heart patients in New York State who were erroneously cut off the Social Security rolls by the Federal Government.

title: Greek Communists Face Revolts in the Ranks
description: Like many Communist parties that have relied heavily on the support of Eastern European governments, Greece's Communist Party is battling for survival.

title: Fighting in Salvador Prompts a New Exodus
description: Stepped-up fighting in El Salvador's decade-long civil war appears to have created a new wave of Salvadoran refugees intent on fleeing northward through Mexico toward the United States, alarming officials here and in Central America and leading to greater Government vigilance.

title: Chatter, Chirps, Cackles - On With the Dance
description: Dancegoers never know what they'll hear next at a performance. Usually it's music, but choreography can also be accompanied by the spoken word or even by sheer babbling. Often on such occasions movement can either intensify or contradict the import of the words, and in the process the text makes perfect sense. At other times a text may be deliberately incomprehensible. Nevertheless, when cryptic words are married to expressive movements, the union can be rich in significance.

title: Travel Myths
description: To the Editor: For 35 years I have been hustling around the globe and been the director of summer schools abroad. I am thus accustomed to the risks and thrills both of solo and group wandering. The following strike me as the four dominant myths about travel:

title: Review/Music; LadyGourd SanGoma
description: In ''Sorceress,'' one of the more intense pieces in LadyGourd SanGoma's ''Look Above the Clouds,'' the quartet of African-American female singers, dancers and instrumentalists dons silver masks to act out a ritual of transformation. Twirling tubular instruments that make an eerie cry, the women dance and sing a chant that a program note describes as ''dedicated to all women of color, who against all odds managed to turn glass into diamonds.''

title: PITCHING DOCTORS
description: The materials that detail men disseminate are not bad or wrong or poorly presented (''Pitching Doctors,'' by Michael S. Wilkes and Miriam Shuchman, Nov. 5). Rather, they are so professional, so slickly done, that it is hard to remember they are not necessarily the broad scholarly surveys that ought to form the basis for wise prescribing. In other words, the materials become accepted on the basis of what they are not: they aren't egregiously wrong or flaming charlatanism. Likewise, the products may be prescribed because of what they aren't: they aren't inconvenient and they aren't total unknowns anymore, and they aren't so unsafe that they shouldn't be marketed at all. From there, it's easy to continue down that primrose path to overuse of a familiar product. ELLEN WILLIAMS Branford, Conn.

title: New Yorkers of All Ages Receive Aid From Neediest Case Fund Agencies; Helping 'Total Child' Takes a United Effort
description: Now that the excitement of New York City's election is over and a new mayor is in office, a critical task lies ahead. A new beginning is at hand with the awesome responsibility of bringing this city out of a myriad of complex economic and social problems that affect the poor and needy. But the responsibility for these changes does not lie with the mayor alone. Guided by his leadership, we all share this responsibility and need to play a part to get the city back on track - and in particular, to help the thousands of poor children and their families who are in such desperate need.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Greg LeMond. His growth as an athlete during the 80's was capped by the most astonishing comeback on the final day of the 1989 Tour de France. RICHARD FERTELL New York

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MELUSINE By Lynne Reid Banks. 248 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Treed
description: WITH ITS UNCATALOGUED FLORA and fauna - literally millions of species and genera - the tropical rain forest canopy is the natural world's richest frontier, a world unto itself, really. And the latest best hope for scientists eager to explore it is, fittingly, a little on the otherworldly side.

title: 10 Men Steal 5 Cars in Garage
description: A gang of 10 armed robbers invaded an apartment-house garage on the Upper West Side early yesterday, held up the attendant and made off with five late-model cars, the police said. The last car was cut off by police officers arriving at the garage and one of the occupants was seized.

title: SHATTERED CHILDREN
description: LEAD: SOUL MURDER The Effects of Childhood Abuse and Deprivation. By Leonard Shengold. 342 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: English Asks Trade
description: AFTER a decade of service, Alex English has asked the Denver Nuggets to trade him, but the Nuggets are not inclined to do so. ''I want out; I want to be traded,'' English told The Denver Post. ''I hope it's done soon.''

title: A BROTHER'S DEATH
description: My brother's name was Doug, the partner he left behind is Skip (Hers: ''A Brother's Death,'' by Barbara Lazear Ascher, Nov. 19). Doug's ashes rest in the sea off the coast of Maine, and he has been gone two years. In every other respect (that he was 31 when he died of AIDS, that he was the brother of two sisters and that his parents were unashamed of the cause of his death) the circumstances of Doug and Bobby are the same. Ms. Ascher's description of grief is eloquent. She captures the feeling as if she had stepped into my skin.

title: FICTION
description: FAULTY GROUND. By Gabrielle Donnelly. (Victor Gollancz/David & Charles, $19.95.) When a University of London professor named Susan Barnes decides to visit her cousin Joanna in Los Angeles, she brings along the notes for her half-finished introduction to a new edition of ''Emma'' and a complete set of prejudices regarding the vapidity of the Hollywood film industry, the California beach culture and the United States in general. Upon her arrival, she finds herself surrounded by a ''circle of impregnably smiling faces,'' which are attached to people who say insipid things like, ''God, I would kill for a British accent!'' As these clues might indicate, Gabrielle Donnelly's second book, ''Faulty Ground,'' is a modern-day novel of manners in the tradition of Jane Austen. However, instead of a Regency drawing room, the action revolves around a California kitchen, equipped with a stream of walk-in visitors and a constantly ringing telephone. The refrigerator is stocked with an abundant supply of white wine, and the plot is laden with an intricate series of friendly alliances and romantic dalliances, as characters pair off and re-pair off in something of a West Coast square dance. With a fine ear for the rhythms of colloquial speech, Ms. Donnelly neatly sketches the contrasts between the deft, rapier wit of the British and the blunt, straight-ahead style of their American counterparts. Warming to the local demeanor, Susan gradually revises her stereotypically European view of the New World as a land without history or social graces. Illusion, she finds, is the metier not only of Hollywood but also of those who live in the shadow of the movie industry. As Susan contemplates her new emotional and geographical terrain, she begins to sense the violent forces that churn beneath its pleasant exteriors. By the novel's end, she is faced with a moral choice of classical proportions, proof that the dark stuff of tragedy flows just below the surface in even the sunniest of climes. SARAH FERGUSON

title: Lee Van Cleef, Actor, Dies at 64; Played Villains in Many Westerns
description: Lee Van Cleef, the film actor whose steely eyes and rugged features led to a long career portraying Western arch-villains, died, apparently of a heart attack, early today at St. John's Regional Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Oxnard.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: THEODORE J. BERGERON JR.;
'All Children Should Be Educated'
description: LEAD: NOT so long ago, people with disabilities faced a future of dependence on their parents or on institutions. But that has changed, and one group that has been helping such people prepare for independent living is the Shoreline Association for Retarded and Handicapped in Guilford.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Weak Links in the Food Chain
description: LEAD: THE Iroquois marked life's rites of passage with fertility dances, tribal initiations and getting the reins to Dad's stallion on Saturday nights. Other societies prefer confirmations, birthdays and graduations. But the true test of advancing maturity, sophistication and status is food. Meaning, you are what you think you should eat.

title: Usual Suspects
description: A former Bolivian Government official was taken prisoner last week in Washington's war on drugs. Col. Luis Arce Gomez, who was called the ''minister of cocaine'' when he served as Bolivia's Interior Minister in the early 1980's, was captured last weekend when Bolivian authorities raided his ranch. The Bolivians promptly turned Colonel Arce Gomez over to American authorities, who then whisked him off to Miami, where he was held without bond on drug-trafficking charges that could get him 30 years in prison. The colonel, who was part of the military government that came to power in Bolivia in a 1980 coup backed by cocaine traffickers, is also under indictment back home. Authorities there say that as Interior Minister, Colonel Arce Gomez set up a sort of licensing arrangement for drug kingpins, charging them huge sums to stay in business.

title: A LUXURY FIGHT TO THE FINISH
description: BERNARD ARNAULT, THE 40-YEAR-OLD CHAIRMAN of LVMH, which combines some of France's oldest, most pretigious names, no longer has to apologize for the way his new Paris office looks. Arnault, a short, trim, somewhat awkward man, spent his first 10 months here with mud brown walls and a simple wooden desk - a far cry from the crystal chandeliers he left behind at the Christian Dior fashion house. Only recently has he lent his perfectionist touch to his new surroundings: it's out with earth colors and in with pastel-gray carpets, pastel-gray leather sofas and swivel chairs, abstract murals flecked with blue and gray.

title: The Trade Deficit Takes Off Again
description: The U.S. merchandise trade deficit widened sharply to $10.2 billion in October, the biggest imbalance in 10 months, as imports reached a record level. The Government also reported that inventories climbed four-tenths of a percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted $793.9 billion. In November, wholesale prices edged down a tenth of a percent and capacity utilization also was down a tenth of a point, to 82.7 percent. But industrial production inched up a tenth of a percent that month and retail sales rose eight tenths of a percent. Sales of U.S.-built cars plunged 28 percent in early December, however.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'COOKIES AND CAROLS'

title: Zacatecas: Workhorse Of the Spanish Empire
description: EVERY summer during the festival of the Morisma, the Christians and the Moors fight it out one more time on the hills outside Zacatecas. Charlemagne, John the Baptist and Mohammed come to life again in a medieval pageant in which roles are passed down from generation to generation. The outcome, of course, is always the same. The Spaniards always win. At the end of the battle, the littlest Moors, dressed in oversize trousers, troop down to the city, tugging their mothers' hands. The glory that was Spain lives on for another day in the Mexican sierra.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: INDIANAPOLIS;
Competition For Suburbia
description: LEAD: AN insurance company moving into a former tire factory will anchor Quadrant Four, a 50-acre downtown business campus meant to compete with suburban office parks.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: The wealth of the Americas flowed to Spain in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries. Each year, if wars permitted, two fleets would cruise the Caribbean, depositing Spanish trade goods and picking up gold doubloons, silver pesos, emeralds and pearls. Goods from the Orient, brought by the Manila fleet to Acapulco and by mule across Mexico to Vera Cruz, were loaded aboard. When the ships were filled, both Caribbean fleets would rendezvous at Havana and sail home.

title: PITCHING DOCTORS
description: The recent New York State public-health law has indeed reduced the number of prescriptions written for the benzodiazepines by virtue of the triplicate prescription requirement. However, in addition to the triplicate form, the law requires that a prescription for benzodiazepine may supply a patient for not more than 30 days, and that a patient be examined by his doctor each time a renewal is needed.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE BIG FIX. Inside the S&L Scandal: How an Unholy Alliance of Politics and Money Destroyed America's Banking System. By James Ring Adams. (John Wiley & Sons, $19.95.) Finance - and financial fraud - can be dry and arcane. But in ''The Big Fix,'' James Ring Adams offers a front-row seat at a three-ring circus. Mr. Adams presents the downfall of some high-flying financial empires, including the Butcher brothers' Tennessee banking system and Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. He also chronicles the bumbling efforts of financial regulators, who seemed unable to rein in banks and savings and loan associations when their examiners found problems. And Mr. Adams shows members of Congress - from former House Speaker Jim Wright to Senators Donald Riegle and Alan Cranston - juggling political contributions with one hand while using the other to interrupt the regulatory process. But Mr. Adams, a financial journalist, means to do more than tell tales. He argues persuasively that the system of Government insurance for bank and thrift deposits - instituted after the banking crises of the 1930's - was ''a deeply flawed notion,'' bound to go haywire. Such guarantees, he explains, allow financial institutions to keep attracting funds even as they make risky investments and lose money; depositors do not care because they know that the Government will reimburse them even if a bank or a savings and loan institution closes. Now that Americans are faced with a bill estimated at more than $150 billion to make good on the deposits of failed savings and loan associations, Mr. Adams should find a ready audience.

title: Patricia A. Mahoney Plans To Marry R. P. Dempsey
description: James Jeremiah Mahoney of Norwich, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter Patricia Anne Mahoney to Richard Patrick Dempsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Dempsey of Kennebunk, Me. A February wedding is planned.

title: Too Much Resonance
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth A. Stevens To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Beth Anne Stevens and Steven Charles Rattner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rattner of Pittsburgh, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Stevens of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Seoul Factions Break Two-Year Political Deadlock
description: President Roh Tae Woo and the three main opposition leaders have broken a deadlock over a range of issues lingering from the term of Mr. Roh's predecessor, politicians and diplomats said today. The dispute has bogged down Korean politics for two years.

title: Legislators Nearing Deadline on Budget
description: COUNTY legislators grappling with a proposed $1 billion budget for 1990, Westchester's largest, face what may be a large and hostile crowd tomorrow night at the Board of Legislator's last public hearing. Final action on the spending plan is expected a few days later. Those likely to fill the lawmaker's eighth-floor chamber at 7:30 P.M. - individual taxpayers, representatives of community organizations and elected officials - are expected to relay the frustration and indignation they have expressed indirectly in recent weeks over the 18 percent to 52 percent county tax increases contained in the proposed budget. Talk of Hiring an Analyst

title: Updating Needed In 'Oil vs. Fish' Debate
description: Factual errors and flawed arguments pervade Thomas Belton's call for ''constructive debate'' on offshore oil and gas exploration off New Jersey's coast (''Oil vs. Fish? No, a Way to Have Both,'' Opinion page, Oct. 29).

title: A Calendar of Holiday Music Events
description: THE musical presentations planned at churches and concert halls in Connecticut for this Christmas season are noteworthy for their variety. There will be traditional carols sung by congregation and choir in simple church services and gala productions of seasonal works performed in concert. Esoteric anthems and obscure works by the great composers will be offered for the serious music lover, and elaborate productions with large casts will present an opportunity for celebration.

title: Two Decades as 'Honest Brokers' for Medicine's Moral Issues
description: THE philosopher met the psychiatrist by chance during a Christmas party in l968. Over a punch bowl, they discussed matters many people would have regarded as the stuff of dreams or science fiction. A biological revolution was almost at hand, they agreed, and the day was fast approaching when hearts would be produced artifically, organs could be transplanted and death itself would have to be redefined.

title: EXHAUSTED BY SUCCESS
description: LEAD: RAZZLE DAZZLE The Life and Work of Bob Fosse. By Kevin Boyd Grubb. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press.

title: Fair Play
description: To the Editor:

title:
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office Parks;
Foreign Concerns Look to Suburbs for Investment
description: LEAD: A SMALL but growing number of foreign concerns are aggressively acquiring, building and leasing office park projects in New York City's suburbs. Their success runs counter to the current slowdown in the commercial real estate market in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Spending It
description: As Marie Antoinette made a mistake in mentioning cake, Leona Helmsley might have done well to talk less about taxes. No tumbrels rolled outside Federal Court in Manhattan as Mrs. Helmsley was sentenced for tax evasion last week, but her punishment was surprisingly stern: four years in prison and $7.1 million in fines. Mrs. Helmsley, who called herself the queen of the Helmsley hotel chain, was on trial for diverting more than a million dollars in company money to pay for personal expenditures including renovations on the mansion she shared with her husband, Harry, who had also been charged but was found mentally incompetent to stand trial. During the trial, the 69-year-old Mrs. Helmsley was portrayed as a high-handed autocrat who summarily dismissed employees who displeased her and who was widely quoted as once having bragged to a maid that ''only the little people pay taxes.''

title: ESCAPE FROM REHAB
description: LEAD: RUMMIES By Peter Benchley. 257 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title:
INVESTING;
A Champion of Chocolate
description: LEAD: COCOA prices have collapsed in recent months, reaching the lowest level in a decade. With producers facing huge surpluses, analysts expect no recovery soon. As Ronald L. Strauss, an analyst for William Blair & Company, puts it, ''There are an awful lot of cocoa beans around.''

title: Walesa Leads Gdansk Memorial
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, led about 1,000 people today in marking the anniversary of the killing of scores of Baltic coast workers by security forces during food riots in December 1970.

title: Inquiry Urged on Sex Bias in Health Studies
description: Three members of Congress have called for an investigation of whether federally supported medical researchers exclude women from clinical tests.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Politburocrats denounced the uprising of the people as a counterrevolution and wanted to repress it with violence, but in reality, they were the counterrevolutionaries.'' - Prof. Michael Schumann, a member of the East German Academy of Sciences, addressing a congress of the country's Communist Party. [ 30:1. ]

title: Still Dreaming of Chestnuts And a White Christmas
description: In the mid-50's, when I was experiencing my first twinges of critical taste, I instituted our family's annual Christmas card contest. On Christmas afternoon, once all the presents had been opened, I would scoop the season's hundred-or-so cards off the mantelpiece and sort through them for nominees. A majority - cartoon Santa Clauses, wreathes and glitzy noels, were consigned to the junk pile. The winners, picked by an informal committee in two rounds of voting, were usually either homemade woodcuts, good reproductions of religious works of art, or unusually inviting and detailed seasonal illustrations.

title: Hockey in Dixie? It's About Time
description: AWAKENING from a creative coma, the National Hockey League plans to be born again in the South. Praise the Lord, y'all, and pass the tardy puck.

title: Six Congressmen Hold Meetings in Colombia
description: Six Congressmen back from a secret trip to Colombia say they are more convinced than ever that President Virgilio Barco Vargas deserves unwavering support in his country's battle with drug traffickers.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Having read that it is always best to stain cedar shingles, rather than paint them, we contracted to have all the peeling paint sandblasted off our shingles. But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately. Also, some tell us to apply one coat of primer, then one coat of stain. Which is best: latex or oil?

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: A trend that can intimidate stamp collectors is the flood of gummed paper that some countries and non-countries put out to commemorate just about any topic you can think of.

title: Judicious or Crabbed?
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Expanded Views Of Figure as Form
description: LEAD: THROUGHOUT history, artists have treated the human body as form, often making the familiar contours an integral part of a composition.

title:
WINE;
Gift Ideas for Novice and Connoisseur
description: LEAD: FROM the generous array of gifts in Westchester stores that would be appreciated by wine buffs, here are several suggestions for the novice as well as the connoisseur, at prices from $4.95 to $1,200.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Canada's New Cross-Country Express Train

title: Giving Voice to Christmas Spirit
description: CHURCHES in the county are offering a rich and varied supply of Christmas music throughout the week, when resident choirs and organists will be joined by soloists and instrumental ensembles. And devotees of ''Messiah'' sing-alongs have several chances to raise their voices.

title: New Yorkers of All Ages Receive Aid From the Neediest Case Fund Agencies; Offering Help to Those Who Try to Survive
description: A homeless woman, pregnant and without resources, a father out of work and unable to pay the rent and buy food, an AIDS mother's infant who needs care, a grandmother who needs help with day-to-day household chores. These are some of the people who have turned to the agencies and programs of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York in increasing numbers during 1989.

title: Catherine A. Chesebrough Is Married
description: Catherine Ann Chesebrough and Hynek Pesta Kalkus were married yesterday at the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour in Manhasset, L.I., by the Rev. Thomas E. Hammond. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Chesebrough of Manhasset and Naples, Fla. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kalkus of Arlington, Va., and Newport, R.I.

title: Correction
description: A photograph last Sunday with an article about Japanese lobbyists in Washington was published in error. It showed William G. Walker, the American Ambassador to El Salvador, instead of William N. Walker, former deputy United States trade representative.

title: As Lockout Threat Looms, Players Lock Up Big Bonuses
description: FOR more than a year, clubs and agents have wrangled over lockout language in players' contracts. The clubs, at the urging of the Player Relations Committee, insisted that the players agree to provisions that said they would not be paid if the owners locked them out. No season was specified, but 1990 was the target because the two sides have to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement for a period beginning next year.

title: Nearing the End Of a Bad Year For Traveling
description: OVER the next two weeks or so, 23 million Americans will board airplanes, 1.25 million will crowd onto trains and an additional 1.4 million will take a bus. It is the time of year when everyone in the country seems to be going somewhere else.

title: A Second Chance for Vision
description: America had a fair idea of what it was getting in George Bush: a competent, cautious steward with a slim agenda and no taste for what he called ''the vision thing.'' He would make changes at the margins of the Reagan Revolution without disturbing its core. The nation would be kinder and gentler. Taxes would stay low, defenses strong. He would be a prudent leader in placid times. Uncharismatic, for sure, but the voters found that preferable to the uncertain candidacy of Michael Dukakis.

title: Review/Music; 4 Helping Hands at Piano
description: Cristina Perotti from Italy and an American, Laurence Lynn Dutt, form a piano duo specializing in music for four hands at one piano. Their program at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night had none of the expected music - no Schubert or Mozart, no Ravel.

title: Pace Entices Students To Try Nonprofit Field
description: THE day Patrick Lyden, a Pace University senior, opts for a job in the corporate sector may not be far off. For starters, the money will be better than he is earning now, not to mention the health-care benefits he will be entitled to, and perhaps a chance to have his graduate-school tuition reimbursed.

title: Alison F. Brecher to Marry in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Brecher of Hartsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Alison Fay Brecher to Eric Scott Savitch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin R. Savitch of White Plains. A March wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Elephant Esthetics
description: LEAD: Since his creation in 1931 by the French artist Jean de Brunhoff, the little elephant Babar has reigned not only as king of the pachyderms but also as France's most enduring contribution to 20th-century children's literature. His adventures, including the 30 that Jean's son Laurent has added to the family oeuvre since 1946, have been translated into 18 languages.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: No other athlete is as synonymous with his sport as Mike Tyson. To talk boxing is to talk Tyson. ADAM BERLIN New York

title: Volcanic Ash in Anchorage
description: A slight wind shift brought a haze of ash from Redoubt Volcano drifting down on Alaska's largest city today, prompting the authorities to issue a warning to people with lung ailments. The volcano, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage, began erupting Thursday and was belching ash skyward for the third day in a row, though in a somewhat reduced amount, said the United States Geological Survey. Until the wind shift, the fallout had been bypassing the city of about 250,000 residents.

title: Joyce R. Ellman to Marry
description: Joyce Rachel Ellman, an assistant general counsel for the New York City Transit Authority, and Marc Howard Fryburg, a lawyer in New York, plan to marry in April. Ms. Ellman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Ellman of New York, graduated cum laude from Barnard College and received a J.D. degree from Yeshiva University. Mr. Fryburg, a son of Dr. Estelle Fryburg and Carl Fryburg of Riverdale, the Bronx, graduated from Johns Hopkins University and the Columbia University School of Law.

title: Opposition Leader in Panama Rejects a Peace Offer From Noriega
description: A leader of Panama's opposition today rejected a peace offering by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was declared head of Government on Friday.

title: If a 'Zine' Is Weird, This New Yorker Has It
description: Thousands of magazines are stacked throughout Michael Gunderloy's home, but he cannot pull out a copy of Time, Newsweek or Reader's Digest.

title: Church Seeks to Raise the Human to the Divine; One-Sided Truce
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
At Blue Hill Cultural Center, Competition Is a Shopping Mall
description: LEAD: THE Blue Hill Cultural Center does not offer the easiest situation for exhibiting or viewing art. The center is the atrium and lobby of the Blue Hill Plaza, an office complex in this Rockland County community. The art must compete with a small but bustling shopping mall and with abundant green foliage in the atrium.

title: For Business, Liquor is Out And Gifts of Glass Are In
description: Crystal has always been a favorite gift for brides. But in the past two years, corporations have realized the value of giving a valuable gift like crystal to top clients and high-performing employees.

title: A Deceptive Exterior in North Bellmore
description: CONTRAST and contradiction characterize North Bellmore's Smithville Cafe. Its rundown roadhouse exterior does not do justice to its warm, woody interior. This 19th-century landmark, which has served as a stagecoach stop, hotel, bordello, speak-easy and cowboy bar, became the Smithville Cafe in 1976.

title: 'PERMIT ME TO BE TERRIFIED'
description: LEAD: THE DISCOVERY OF THE ART OF THE INSANE By John M. MacGregor. Illustrated. 390 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $49.50.

title: Miss Lawrence,Student, to Wed
description: The engagement of Cynthia Terry Lawrence to Alan Read Ziegler Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ziegler of Rochester, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Thomas A. Farr of Beaufort, S.C., and Alfred N. Lawrence Jr. of Lawrence, L.I. A February wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
Poinsett's Amazing Namesake
description: LEAD: WHEN one considers the diversity among the poinsettias available today, one cannot help but wonder were Joel Poinsett's ghost to return, whether he would recognize the plant named after him.

title: U.N. Asks Hong Kong to Delay Deportations
description: United Nations refugee officials are asking Hong Kong not to forcibly return any more boat people to Vietnam until an international meeting next month tries to come up with a new approach to the problem.

title: Studying the 'Critical Languages'
description: LEAD: AS secondary school educators focus their attention on preparing students to live and work in the next century, global literacy ranks high on their priority list. And the study of foreign languages, in particular the less commonly taught ones like Russian, Chinese and Japanese, is receiving serious attention in New

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: NEW AND SELECTED STORIES, 1959-1989. By Charles Edward Eaton. (Cornwall Books, $18.95.) A golden-boy diplomat adopts a loser of a rookie, and the men gradually shift roles; a cherished kidney-shaped swimming pool becomes a fount of marital discord; an academic embroiders a glorious curriculum vitae.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Magic Johnson. He has led the Lakers to the National Basketball Association final round eight out of 10 years and has managed to win five times. He is also a class act on and off the court. JEFFREY SCHER Forest Hills, Queens

title: With Sakharov Gone, His Colleagues Balk at Challenging Party Monopoly
description: For all their grief and insurgency, the congressional colleagues of Andrei D. Sakharov met today and decided that they were unable immediately to provide the political legacy he desired: the creation of a formal political opposition to challenge the Communist Party monopoly nationwide.

title: Marcos's Estate and His Widow Are Held Liable in 2 U.S. Killings
description: Imelda Marcos and the estate she shared with her late husband, former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, were found liable by a Federal jury on Friday in the murders of two Marcos opponents here eight years ago.

title: Cold War's Thaw Might Reach Clear to South Pole
description: For the first time in the two centuries since human beings set foot on the continent, Antarctica is poised to become a world center for scientific research, scientists say.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 112, Mavericks 108: Bernard King equaled his season high with 31 points and made two jump shots and two free throws in the final 1:36 for Washington in a home game. Rolando Blackman scored 21 points, including Dallas's last 13. Dallas ran off 12 consecutive points for a 57-51 lead with 2:57 left in the first half, led by as much as 11 and was ahead by 65-57 at halftime. But the team went cold in the third quarter.(AP) Skiing Victory for Zurbriggen: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland battled rapidly changing weather yesterday to win the downhill event at Val Gardena, Italy. The victory gave him a lead of 126 points in the overall World Cup standing. He was timed in 2 minutes 1.88 seconds.(AP) Track and Field Upset in the 800: Mike Gaughran upset Matt Materazo, one of his Westchester Puma Track Club teammates, in the 800-meter run yesterday at the Manufacturers Hanover Open at West Point, N.Y. Gaughran won in 1 minute 52.38 seconds. Maryellen McGowan, a former Villanova star, took the women's 1,500-meter run in 4:25.11. Hockey Canada Edges Sweden: Steve Graves scored to cap a three-goal third period yesterday, giving Team Canada a 3-2 victory over Sweden on the opening day of the Izvestia tournament in Moscow. Czechoslovakia beat Finland, 5-3. The Soviet Union beat West Germany, 6-1. (AP) Speed Skating Sweep for Mey: Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany swept the sprint events at the World Cup meet in Seoul, South Korea, yesterday, with a time of 37.18 seconds. Mey won the 1,000 meters in 1:15.81. Angela Hauck of East Germany swept the women's events. She won the 500 in 40.80 and the 1,000 meters in 1:23.68. (AP) Boxing Chavez Retains Title: Julio Cesar Chavez knocked out Alberto Cortes of Argentina with a right-left-right combination in the third round last night in Mexico City to retain his World Boxing Council superlightweight title. Chavez knocked Cortes down and into the ropes 1:56 into the round. Cortes took a seven-count before standing up, but Referee Arthur Mercante stopped the fight.(AP) Bowling World Cup Title for American: Patty Ann of the United States, a bowling instructor from Bloomington, Ill., defeated Martina Beckel of West Germany, 202-191, yesterday in Dublin to capture the women's title in the 25th Bowling World Cup.(AP) Horse Racing Victory for Passing Ships: Passing Ships wore down French Fighter in the final yards yesterday to win the $121,000 Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct by a head. Hierarchy was third. Passing Ships, with Edgar Prado up, won for the fourth consecutive time. The 5-year-old gelded son of Fifth Marine ran the mile and five-eighths on a fast track in 2:50 1/5 to earn $72,600 for Gold 'n' Oats Stable, returning $6.80 for $2 to win.(AP) Golf One-Shot Lead for Hill and Rizzo: Mike Hill and Patti Rizzo shot a 12-under-par 60 yesterday for a 125 total and a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Mazda Champions Tournament in San Juan, P.R. Hill and Rizzo each had six birdies.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 5, Kings 2: Gord Murphy and Mike Bullard scored 16 seconds apart as Philadelphia got four goals in five minutes in the second period to beat road-weary Los Angeles last night and move into first place in the Patrick Division. Philadelphia, playing at home, also held Wayne Gretzky scoreless, ending his point-scoring streak at 18 games.(AP) Capitals 5, Whalers 2: Steve Leach and Dino Ciccarelli scored within a 2:20 span in in the second period for visiting Washington. Randy Cunneyworth, in his first game with Hartford since being acquired on Wednesday from Winnipeg for Paul MacDermid, scored at 5:31 of the second period. (AP) Sabres 3, Bruins 1: Phil Housley's goal midway through the third period yesterday helped Buffalo hand Boston its fourth straight home loss. Clint Malarchuk, making his first start since a 5-1 loss in Boston on Nov. 30, lost his shutout bid when Andy Brickley scored at 8:21 of the third period.(AP) Canadiens 3, Red Wings 1: Chris Chelios carried the puck the length of the ice and fed Mats Naslund, who one-timed the pass and beat the goaltender, Sam St. Laurent, with 5:15 remaining in regulation time. The goal was Chelios's 300th career point. (AP)

title: Debating Secession in the Shadow of Manhattan
description: As dawn broke over Staten Island yesterday, the bleary-eyed breakfast crowd at Uncle Nick's Coffee Shop in Tompkinsville was already deep in debate over a suddenly real issue that only hours before seemed little more than a perennial political pipe dream: secession from New York City. ''I like being part of

title: Anya C. Hurlbert Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Anya Christine Hurlbert, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Boston Hurlbert of Houston, was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Dr. Matthew White Ridley, the son of Viscount and Viscountess Matthew White Ridley of Blagdon, Northumberland, England. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: Japanese Debate How to Enthrone Emperor
description: With the formal enthronement of Emperor Akihito nearly a year away, Japan has become entangled in a debate among scholars and political leaders about what sort of ceremony would be appropriate.

title: What to Do With the Cold War Money
description: THE idea of a ''peace dividend'' first surfaced in 1969. A Cabinet Coordination Committee was set up to report to President Lyndon B. Johnson on what the Federal Government should do with its savings when the War in Vietnam finally ended. The committee proposed that the Federal Government dedicate $39.7 billion a year from its savings - in 1969 dollars - for the upkeep of the infrastructure.

title: Linking 421a to Low-Income Housing
description: MOST of the people in the Spring Creek Gardens complex in the East New York section of Brooklyn earn considerably less than $20,000 a year, while those in the Belaire condo minium tower, on Manhattan's Upper East Side, make whatever is needed to buy half-million dollar condominium apartments and million-dollar penthouses.

title: Comings and Goings
description: WHETHER the father did a victory dance was not disclosed, but a spokesman said Mark Gastineau, the former Jets defensive end, got a son, Marcus, early Friday morning when the actress Brigitte Nielsen gave birth to a 7-pound boy in Scottsdale, Ariz. Gastineau, who is in the process of being divorced from his wife, Lisa, has a 7-year-old daughter. . . . Rick Majerus, the 41-year-old University of Utah basketball coach who underwent a seven-bypass heart operation in Salt Lake City on Thursday, has been recovering from the surgery normally, his doctors said yesterday. . . . The amount of the fine assessed Coach Sam Wyche of the Cincinnati Bengals for barring reporters from the dressing room after last week's loss to the Seattle Seahawks was $3,000, Wyche said yesterday. The National Football League did not specify the amount in its announcement Friday. . . . Wyche's boss, Paul Brown, who founded the Cleveland Browns as well as the Bengals, was honored as the 1989 Walter Camp man of the year last night in New Haven. As an N.F.L. coach, Brown won 223 games, lost 127 and had 9 ties in 25 years.(AP)

title: Campus Life: Maryland; A Housing Bill Angers Students And Landlords
description: When Councilman James T. Herl of Prince George's County attended the University of Maryland, he fought for students' rights against landlords who he said were more concerned about profit margins than respectable and affordable housing.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Ben Johnson's enormous individual talent was only exceeded by his talent for self-delusion. In that respect, his story transcended the boundaries of sport and helped define an era. MATT FARRAND Brooklyn

title: Corrections Called For In Election Process
description: Now that elections are over for the 1989 season, it would make some sense for the State Legislature to take a closer look at how local boards of election operate. And to take corrective actions that will eliminate problems that have occurred in parts of the state.

title: Town's Tradition Brings Out Its Artists
description: AT the Bethlehem Post Office a sound of Christmas is the steady thump of rubber stamps hitting ink pads.

title: Susanna M. Bellis Plans a Wedding
description: Susanna Marie Bellis and Michael Paul Gibbons, a son of Pamela Gibbons of Morristown, N.J., and William J. Gibbons of Orange, N.J., plan to marry in February, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Bellis of St. Paul, have announced.

title: Small in Size But Not in Scope
description: SMALLNESS is currently the thing at City Without Walls. Not one of the 46 works in the gallery's ''Eighth Annual Metro Show'' is more than 12 inches in any dimension. It makes for easier transportation and distribution: Metro shows customarily go forth unto the people where they work, and the pit stops are not necessarily art galleries.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Wyndham Complex Upsets Garden City
description: LEAD: IN the summer of 1987, the Lefcon Partnership of Lake Success announced that preconstruction sales would begin at the Wyndham West, the first of two buildings in a 316-unit condominium project called the Wyndham at Garden City. The apartments were priced from $325,000 to $1.25 million.

title: East German Communists Confront Party's Collapse
description: Confusion and insecurity reigned in East German politics today as the Communist Party struggled to redefine its role and new parties tried to take form.

title: Two Musicals We Needed Have Checked In
description: I think we can tell ourselves that it's going to be all right now.

title: Is the Run On the Hits An Error?
description: Are renters finding what they want when they go to the video store? In this the year of big-movie cassettes for sale (''Batman'' et al.), some in the trade are concerned that rentals, still the real right arm of video with about 70 percent of the revenue, aren't getting enough attention. ''What renters really want in a video store is breadth and scope of selection,'' says Nicholas Santrizos, the chairman of Trylon Video, a New York-based distributor. And, he adds, renters aren't getting it - especially in smaller stores. With the stress on sales, fewer titles are being offered for rental, he says. ''People aren't getting the variety they're used to.''

title: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN POWER: The Rise and Decline of U.S. Globalism, 1918-1968. By John Taft. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The ascension of the United States as a world power, according to John Taft, was largely due to the efforts of a Northeastern, Ivy League-educated, internationalist elite. This group, including George Kennan, Averell Harriman and Dean Acheson, believed that world order could be created through the Wilsonian ideals of free trade, democracy, anti-imperialism and world organizations. After World War II, Mr. Taft writes in ''American Power,'' they supported the containment of Communism, the Korean War and the cold war in general. They served in the foreign-policy establishment for 50 years and shaped the political, economic and military underpinnings of United States diplomacy. Mr. Taft maintains that this policy was dealt a severe blow when the United States tried to extend its power and influence into the third world in the 1950's and 60's. The frustrations and failures that culminated in the Vietnam debacle caused the internationalist liberals to question former policies and led to what Mr. Taft terms ''isolationist liberalism.'' This loss of resolve resulted in a major loss of United States power in the world. Mr. Taft has done a fine job, but tells only part of the story. He glosses over the role certain business interests played in United States involvement in different parts of the world. He also gives little credit to the McCarthyite red scare that led, in the name of anti-Communism, to the support of corrupt regimes such as Ngo Dinh Diem's in South Vietnam. To Mr. Taft, the author of ''Mayday at Yale,'' post-Vietnam foreign policy is liberal isolationism. To others, it is a reasonable reaction to a world that can no longer be ordered by American and European elites.

title: Lifestyle; Experts on the Toy Market Provid A Briefing to Santa's Elderly Helpers
description: Vanessa Teixeira said what she really wanted for Christmas was a tea set and chair cushions.

title: Learning Values in a Group Setting
description: THE eighth-grade pupils in Shirley Singer's advisory group were paired by a draw of cards and directed to interview their partners, asking each other questions about their favorite activities, favorite music group and favorite pet at home. They then reassembled to share with their fellow pupils what they had learned about one another.

title: Left or Right? Brazilians Will Decide Today
description: Brazilian voters will choose on Sunday between two presidential candidates offering radically different paths for Latin America's most populous nation: socialist or free market.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: UTZ, by Bruce Chatwin. (Penguin, $7.95.) A petty aristocrat named Kaspar Joachim Utz becomes trapped in Czechoslovakia by the priceless collection of porcelain that he refuses to leave behind. The last novel of Bruce Chatwin, who died earlier this year, shows him ''at his most erudite and evocative,'' Robert Stone said here in January. '' 'Utz' provides its readers with a rich and rewarding meditation.'' THE MASTER OF THE GAME: Paul Nitze and the Nuclear Peace, by Strobe Talbott. (Vintage, $10.95.) In the third installment of his chronicles of arms control, Strobe Talbott tells how the ever-practical negotiator Paul Nitze turned Ronald Reagan's utopian Star Wars plan into a bargaining chip. Mr. Talbott ''demonstrates his own mastery of bureaucratic drama, combining a gift for characterization and an eye for the revealing anecdote with a firm grasp of his subject,'' Lawrence Freedman said in The Book Review in 1988. ''His sources are enviable, allowing him to offer an instant history that rings true throughout.'' CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Bantam, $5.95.) An artist goes home to Toronto for a retrospective of her paintings and finds herself haunted by memories of a disturbed childhood friend. ''All this is vintage Atwood,'' our reviewer, Alice McDermott, said in February: ''the precise and devastating detail, the sense of the ordinary transformed into nightmare, the quiet desperation of characters trapped, silenced, utterly alone.'' DESPERADOS: Latin Drug Lords, U.S. Lawmen, and the War America Can't Win, by Elaine Shannon. (Penguin, $4.95.) A reporter for Time magazine tells why she thinks economic and diplomatic relations between Mexico and the United States interfered with the investigation into the death of Enrique Camarena, the Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was murdered in Guadalajara. This ''well-reported reconstruction of the investigation'' raises ''disturbing questions,'' Jeff Gerth said here last year. THE FIFTH STATION, by Kevin McIlvoy. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) When their brother is killed in a mill accident, two steelworkers move to New Mexico and try to forget. Last year our reviewer, Patricia Dobler, said this first novel is ''rich with details of both mill life and life in a rural New Mexican community.'' TOCQUEVILLE: A Biography, by Andre Jardin. Translated by Lydia Davis with Robert Hemenway. (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) This biography of the visitor who explained the American mind to both the French and the Americans is ''written with admirable thoroughness,'' Joan Wallach Scott said here in February. THE VEILED ONE, by Ruth Rendell. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Like a patient with his psychiatrist, the suspect in a parking-garage murder develops a fixation on his interrogator. Last year our reviewer, Josh Rubins, said Ruth Rendell's ''uncompromising psychological suspense novels . . . offer harrowing, coolly ironic excursions into the minds of genteel psychopaths and secret sex offenders, the lonely and obsessed and deluded. . . . [ Her ] prose - lean, sly, almost clinical - reinforces the bleakness.'' THE SIGNIFYING MONKEY: A Theory of African-American Literary Criticism, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Oxford University, $10.95.) Looking to both ancient African myths and contemporary literary theory, a scholar develops a new theory of black literature. ''This somewhat intimidating, quite serious essay in literary criticism can be enjoyed by a variety of readers,'' John Wideman said in The Book Review last year. Oxford has also reissued Mr. Gates's 1987 book, FIGURES IN BLACK: WORDS, SIGNS, AND THE ''RACIAL'' SELF ($10.95), in which he applies the ideas of modern critics like Michel Foucault and Jacques Derrida to the works of Ishmael Reed, Alice Walker and other black writers. Howard University Press has republished BLACK IS THE COLOR OF THE COSMOS: Essays on Afro-American Literature and Culture, 1942-1981 ($15.95). The pieces, written by Charles T. Davis and edited by Mr. Gates, analyze such authors as Jean Toomer, Richard Wright and Ralph Ellison. WAVERLY PLACE, by Susan Brownmiller. (Signet/New American Library, $4.95.) In a fictionalized account of the Joel Steinberg-Hedda Nussbaum case, Susan Brownmiller tries to fathom how a couple in her Greenwich Village neighborhood dug themselves into a sadomasochistic life that led to the killing of a 6-year-old girl. Last year The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said that, while the book is not satisfying as a novel, it ''serves a potentially constructive purpose. It tries to fill the emotional void created by any incomprehensible human act. It proposes how such a thing could have happened and allows us to participate in the drama of its answer.'' ALICIA: My Story, by Alicia Appleman-Jurman. (Bantam, $4.95.) After losing her family, a teen-age girl helps her fellow Poles escape the Nazis. This autobiography is ''so profoundly observed, and the life it records so remarkably lived, that no amount of prior immersion in the sad community of witnesses to the Holocaust can dull the reader to its heroine,'' Sonia Taitz said in The Book Review last year. KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Signet/New American Library, $5.95.) Three Vietnam veterans suspect that a member of their old platoon is the infamous Koko, a serial killer in Southeast Asia who leaves a playing card with a picture of an elephant in his victims' mouths. ''In this fable of men undone by the ultimate horror, evil is anything but banal,'' Richard Fuller said here last year.

title: Review/Dance; Three Suites and a Solo In the Ailey Tradition
description: Alvin Ailey was a master of the choreographic suite. That was made clear when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented two of his finest works in the suite form last Sunday night at the City Center Theater as part of the company's series of programs called In the Black Tradition.

title:
DINING OUT;
Generous Spanish Cuisine in Newark
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES as an antidote to the high-rolling holidays, one simply wants to eat out at a relaxed, friendly spot that serves honest food without putting too much strain on the depleted pocketbook. The Ironbound section of Newark is dotted with Portuguese and Spanish eating places that offer oversized portions from menus that are fairly interchangeable - from their garlic shrimp to their flans to their generally reasonable prices.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Having read that it is always best to stain cedar shingles, rather than paint them, we contracted to have all the peeling paint sandblasted off our shingles. But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately. Also, some tell us to apply one coat of primer, then one coat of stain. Which is best: latex or oil?

title: Q and A
description: Nuns' Tours of Rome

title: Magic Johnson Turns Back the Nets
description: Whenever the Los Angeles Lakers visit, there is excitement in the air, a large crowd is in the stands, and the opposing team's level of play usually rises.

title: There Are Benefits In Homeschooling
description: Not long ago, the Long Island Weekly published an article I wrote about homeschooling my 8-year-old son. I had expected some reader criticism, but I was completely unprepared for the ferocity of the negative responses. Since people tend to be uncomfortable with that which they do not understand, those who responded might feel less averse towards our choice of education if they knew more about it.

title:
GARDENING;
Poinsett's Amazing Namesake
description: LEAD: WHEN one considers the diversity among the poinsettias available today, one cannot help but wonder were Joel Poinsett's ghost to return, whether he would recognize the plant named after him.

title: PERSPECTIVES: East Side Zoning; Adjusting the Rules for Avenue Buildings
description: IN New York City, zoning change is always in the air. Ever since the basic change of 1961 there have been refinements and additions to the law, sometimes tending to encourage, sometimes to discourage, redevelopment. And at times the goal is to alter the style of new residential construction.

title: Robyn A. Loring To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Loring of St. George, S.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Robyn Ann Loring and Leon Kotler Specthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jared Specthrie of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Witness to Murder in El Salvador
description: LEAD: The brutal murders of six Jesuits and their housekeeping staff in El Salvador last month provoked feelings of profound disbelief and shock within and without the Society of Jesus.

title: DATA BANK: Dec. 17, 1989
Louise Bell Gilliam Is to Wed in April
description: Louise Bell Gilliam and Arthur Lee McGrady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lee McGrady of Charlottesville, Va., plan to be married in April. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Sara Brown Gilliam and George Harrison Gilliam, both of Charlottesville.

title: THE DAY BEFORE THE THAW
description: GOODNIGHT! By Abram Tertz (Andrei Sinyavsky). Translated and with an introduction by Richard Lourie. 364 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: Lights That Dazzle in the Front Yard
description: LEAD: THE magic of Christmas takes many forms. It may be found in the spirit of helping the needy, in a present under a tree or in a sumptuous repast with family and friends.

title: Why Gold Is So Bright
description: Gold prices have risen sharply since September, from about $360 an ounce to $425 an ounce in early December before falling back to $408.25 at the close on Friday. Are we poised for another bull market in gold? Four precious metals analysts offer their views. Vahid Fathi Vice president, Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., Cleveland.

title: San Francisco Crane Collapse Was No Fluke
description: When a construction crane fell more than 16 stories into the heart of San Francisco's financial district last month, killing five people, it was one of the worst such accidents on record. But it was no fluke.

title: Style Makers; Konstantine Kakanias, Illustrator
description: If Konstantine Kakanias had his way, most of the things that surround him in the world would be painted - and he would quickly volunteer for the job. The 28-year-old artist, who was born in Athens, lives in New York and is well on his way to putting his imprimatur on scenic backdrops for shop windows, glossy magazine pages and table tops.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold $66,000 52 Manchester Court 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old condominium apartment; h/w floors, dining room; monthly maintenance $153, taxes $1,090. Howell $172,000 114 Pine Needle Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,900. Holtsville, L.I. $137,000 100 10th Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old modular ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,400.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Rickey Henderson. His major league-leading totals on offense were: stolen bases, 838; walks, 962; runs, 1,122. Ty Cobb's comparable totals in his best decade (1910-1919) were: stolen bases, 577; walks, 602; runs, 1,050. THOMAS ASSICURATO The Bronx

title: The Taxpayers' Campaign Chest
description: THE New York City Campaign Finance Board is the rare government agency that didn't spend its budget. Taxpayers may exult at the budgetary success the brand-new office had in substituting taxpayers' money for big special-interest contributions in this year's city political campaigns - the first large municipal experiment of its kind in the country.

title: Among Historians, The Old Frontier Is Turning Nastier With Each Revision
description: ONE of the standard college textbooks still in use puts it this way: ''The history of the American West is, almost by definition, a triumphal narrative, for it traces a virtually unbroken chain of successes in national expansion.''

title: The Mellowing Of the Post-Modernists
description: At the beginning of the decade, photography served the art world as a sign of cultural hyperabundance. It was held responsible for filling the world with images, for replacing primary experience, for substituting reproductions for unique art objects. It also helped usher in an era in which high culture seemed less vital and interesting a subject than the realm of television, magazines and movies.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Tottenville
description: ONCE the forgotten village in the forgotten borough, Tottenville, on the southwestern tip of Staten Island, is being pulled rapidly, if somewhat grudgingly, into the modern era. Stately homes and upscale condominiums are being built on every available lot in the 1,600-acre community, including what older residents remember as their ice skating ponds, ballfields and ski slopes.

title: An Actor Relives the Sorrows of His Homeland
description: John Kani wears a chip on his shoulder like a badge of honor. He has earned it, for his talents as South Africa's most prominent black actor have been forged against the anvil of apartheid.

title: Theater Workshop Gets a Reprieve
description: LEAD: PHIL and Barbara Schaap, directors of the Theater Workshop Production and Fantasy Playhouse in Lynbrook, have got a reprieve.

title: City's Once-Hoped Boon to Revitalization Becomes Its Burden
description: NORWALK officials and residents are bracing for more bad news this week about the city's major tourist attraction, the Norwalk Maritime Center. The center is to present a financial report to the City Council on Wednesday and it is expected to show that the Maritime Center will need more money to survive.

title: Miss Charles Wed to Francis Maguire
description: The Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Wendy Anne Charles, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simpson Charles 3d of Short Hills, to Francis Patrick Maguire, a son of Mrs. Michael J. Fives of Hauppauge, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Kenyon J. Wildrick performed the ceremony.

title: FICTION
description: RUNNING WILD. By J. G. Ballard. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) Over the last 25 years, the British writer J. G. Ballard has touched a great many stylistic bases, ranging from straight science fiction (''The Drowned World'') to abrasive experimentalism (''Crash'') to autobiographical realism (''Empire of the Sun''). But regardless of genre, Mr. Ballard's books have tended to share certain qualities, including a fascination with electronic media, a taste for black-comic paradox and, most of all, an ability to immerse the reader in different fictional worlds. ''Running Wild,'' which is presented as the forensic diaries of Dr. Richard Greville, a psychiatric adviser to the London police, certainly bears the first two of these trademarks. Greville has been asked to investigate the Pangbourne Massacre, a mysterious tragedy in which the 32 adult residents of an exclusive community 30 miles west of London have been murdered, and their 13 children apparently abducted. Who could have carried out such an atrocity? And why? Greville lists the various theories put forth by the authorities, in order of escalating absurdity. He watches hours of videotaped evidence and ponders the community's way of life, one in which ''scarcely a minute of the children's lives had not been intelligently planned.'' Slowly - more slowly, in any case, than most readers - he comes to the conclusion that the assassins were the children themselves. The Pangbourne offspring, he concludes, ''were rebelling against . . . a despotism of kindness. They killed to free themselves from a tyranny of love and care.'' Really? The assumptions ''Running Wild'' is supposed to challenge, such as the fairy-tale version of family happiness, haven't been widely accepted for decades. Nor has Mr. Ballard given himself ample space to compensate for his warmed-over concept: the novel's 104 pages immerse us no deeper than the ankles. ''Running Wild'' has its pleasures, but it's J. G. Ballard at his scantiest, his most reduced. What he gives us here is a dream communicated in Morse code.

title: Robert D. Blue Dies; Former Iowa Governor
description: Robert D. Blue, a champion of the elderly who served two terms as Iowa's Governor in the 1940's, has died of complications from a stroke. He was 91 years old.

title:
GARDENING;
Poinsett's Amazing Namesake
description: LEAD: WHEN one considers the diversity among the poinsettias available today, one cannot help but wonder were Joel Poinsett's ghost to return, whether he would recognize the plant named after him.

title: 'Be My Friend, I'll Give You My Life'
description: THE Elmsford Animal shelter is a very special place. It offers sanctuary, rather like a medieval alms house, for abandoned and mistreated animals.

title: 'LISTEN TO THIS,' I SAY
description: LOVE AND WILL Twenty Stories. By Stephen Dixon. 193 pp. New York: Paris Review Editions/ British American Publishing. $17.95.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: EAST BERLIN DIARY
description: Christoph Hein, a writer and intellectual prominent in East Berlin, has long been an outspoken critic of his nation's Government. A recent play of Hein's, ''The Knights of the Round Table,'' has been widely read as an allegory of the leadership crisis in East Germany; in recent months it played to packed houses in Dresden and has become a rallying point for the opposition. Hein's novel ''The Distant Lover'' was published last spring in this country by Pantheon Books; two others are forthcoming. The day the wall came down, The New York Times Magazine invited Hein to keep this journal of the fast-moving events in East Berlin.

title:
ART;
Works on Paper: Detailed Realism
description: LEAD: FOR the second year, the works-on-paper competition sponsored by the Firehouse Gallery of Nassau Community College in Garden City is national in scope. The 82 pieces selected by two jurors - the artist George Tooker and Susan Brundage, director of the Leo Castelli Gallery in New York City - were culled from more than 550 entries from around the country.

title: Holiday Gift Baskets That Promote Peace
description: WITH English plum puddings, Jamaican rum cakes and Mexican ornaments, Laine Dyer and Nicole Shirley are hoping to promote peace.

title: Platinum Prints, Canvases of Color
description: THE Yale Center for British Art has never seemed more British than it does now, with ''The Desired Haven,'' a group of 89 photographs by Frederick H. Evans (1853-1943).

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. KIMBERLY E. CHRISTENSEN;
Economics and the Condition of Women
description: LEAD: IT has been about 20 years since the women's movement began. There have been some victories and some losses for the movement, and a lot of publicity. Despite this attention, Dr. Kimberly E. Christensen, an assistant professor of economics at the State University of New York in Purchase, finds that college students of both sexes are not well-informed about the issues involved, particularly economic ones.

title: Judicious or Crabbed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Gadgets Put in Focus
description: Kingdoms have reportedly been lost for want of a nail; and even in video, seeming trifles can make a big difference. Accessories of various kinds can be a great help to videophiles, particularly those who shoot their own videotapes. Besides, such gadgets offer frequently overlooked opportunities for Santa Claus.

title: Suspect in Sex Attacks on 3 Boys Is Sought
description: The police said on Friday that they were looking for a man who sexually assaulted three boys in separate incidents in the last month in two Brooklyn parks.

title: Hawaii to Screen for Potential Child Abusers
description: In an ambitious effort to combat child abuse, Hawaii has begun the nation's first effort to screen all parents for danger signs.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Having read that it is always best to stain cedar shingles, rather than paint them, we contracted to have all the peeling paint sandblasted off our shingles. But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately. Also, some tell us to apply one coat of primer, then one coat of stain. Which is best: latex or oil?

title: The Czechs Start Over
description: Its a pity Eva Stychova didn't live to see it, though I can imagine the cracks she would make, accompanied by her knowing smile.

title: English Christmas
description: To the Editor: We found ourselves in the same situation as the person who wrote (Q & A, Travel, Oct. 8) about what to do in London during the Christmas holiday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of resorts in the Caribbean on Dec. 10 misidentified a hotel on St. Barthelemy. It is Castelets.

title: Lifestyle; Little Pigs On Move From Sty To Parlor
description: Llamas and boas, ferrets and parrots have led the exotic pet parade in years past. The latest status symbol is a miniature pig that stands 14 to 18 inches high and weighs about 40 pounds.

title: Pop Operetta Set in a Diner on Christmas
description: BY now, theatergoers who favor traditional holiday fare may have had their seasonal share of the Scrooge saga. As ever, it seems that a slew of ''Christmas Carols,'' or variations thereof, were already under way just after Thanksgiving weekend, in community and college theaters. Most have passed, although there is still time, through next Sunday, to attend the McCarter Theater's annual Dickens extravaganza in Princeton.

title: Rangers Click Early, Then Crumble Again
description: The burst late in the third period began at his own blue line. Pat LaFontaine, a few quick, quirky strides later, was at the other blue line. There, he met the puck, and an instant later he had a step on James Patrick, the defenseman for the Rangers.

title: Distracted Pirates Fall to Fordham
description: All it took was one look at the puffy eyes of P. J. Carlesimo to realize that this had not been an ordinary day for the Seton Hall coach.

title: Misery Replaces Hope in a Battered Afghanistan
description: As a volley of guerrilla rockets pounded the airport in the Afghan capital on a bitterly cold December day, a conscript in the Government army standing sentry near the runway laid down his Kalashnikov rifle, spread a blanket on the ground, and prostrated himself in prayer.

title: Princeton '55 Mounts Drive on Social Issues
description: Ralph Nader and four other members of Princeton University's class of 1955 have announced a campaign to recruit ''the silent 50's generation'' to social causes.

title: Church Seeks to Raise the Human to the Divine
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Lawrence Taylor. He redefined linebacker, forced offenses to redesign blocking patters, turned sacks into an art form and carried a team on his back all the way to the championship. GREG KIERNAN Stamford, Conn.

title: THE MEKONS TAKE AIM AT ROCK-AND-ROLL
description: ''Hey - rock-and-roll!'' Sally Timms shouted as she and her fellow Mekons crammed themselves back onstage for encores at the Knitting Factory a few weeks ago. For most bands, the phrase is simply a sure-fire way to draw a yell from an audience. But for the Mekons, it is anything but unexamined; when they say rock-and-roll, they're simultaneously loving, wistful, suspicious, defiant and gleeful. They're not kidding when, with abundant good humor and dark irony, they call their new album ''The Mekons Rock 'n' Roll'' (Twin/Tone/A&M 5277, all three formats).

title: Sports Alliance Overlooked
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Museums Without Tears
description: DURING the last two years, a fortuitous combination of personal and professional circumstances has enabled me to spend considerable time in three of the world's great museums - the Louvre, the Hermitage and the Uffizi. Upon returning from these journeys to Paris, Leningrad and Florence, I sensed a certain loss of interest on the part of my hometown audience when I began talking about daily, near-idyllic forays into the halls of art. ''But what else did you do?'' asked one friend. ''I mean, after you'd paid your respects to Venus on the half-shell.'' Implicit in these comments is the assumption that museum-going on trips is at best a culturally rewarding duty and at worst an ordeal. Fun, presumably, is to be found elsewhere - far from the hordes foolishly aiming their cameras at masterpieces instead of buying infinitely superior reproductions on 50-cent postcards.

title: Bobcat and Terrapin Are Said to Be Imperiled
description: THE populations of two wildlife species - the bobcat in the northern part of New Jersey and the diamondback terrapin in the south -are plummeting, and each is being considered as a candidate for the state's list of threatened and endangered species, environmental officials and an independent researcher said.

title: Style Makers; Babette Pinsky, Coat Designer
description: Babette Pinsky says a woman's coat should make as much of a fashion statement as her dress, skirt or blouse do. It is, after all, the garment the outside world usually sees first.

title: Fashion: On the Street; Stepping Out In Wild Spots Of Fake Fur
description: Fake furs. They're hot fashion. And why not? Made of synthetic pile cloth, they provide affordable, lightweight warmth, and look wild, too.

title: RIGHTISTS DEPLORE PRETORIA CHANGES
description: By the waters of Boksburg Lake, members of the self-anointed guardian of white supremacy, the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, sat down today to decry the betrayal of their tribe by President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Can't See Teams Without Cable
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Season of Giving, the Neediest Cases Fund Helps the Giftless; A Mother of 2 Gets Lessons in Parenthood
description: Betty R. is a diabetic and a mentally retarded 42-year-old mother of two who lives in the East New York section of Brooklyn. The first time an official of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service saw her apartment, ''It looked like a cave.''

title: Angling Trips? Start Planning
description: ALTHOUGH it is possible to put together a trip on the spur of the moment, most traveling anglers plan months ahead. This is particularly true if they wish to fish in a remote area where accommodations and guides are limited.
