title: Places for AIDS Patients Are Still Scarce
description: WITH New York City's hospitals in a crisis of overcrowding, the idea of freeing beds by shifting those AIDS patients who are ready for other types of care makes perfect sense, health experts agree. Yet efforts to turn that concept into reality are encountering many obstacles and delays.

title: Evening Hours; The Faces May Be Familiar, but Not the Places
description: There was a time when one could take a census of the rich and social in New York by poking a head into certain hotel ballrooms during the charity season and counting the hundreds of notable noses. If they weren't at the Waldorf, they were at the Plaza or the Pierre. Some nights they were at all three.

title: THE WELL-STOCKED BRAIN ....
description: A FIRST DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY What Our Children Need to Know. Edited by E.D. Hirsch Jr. and Michael Stanford. Ilustrated. 271 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95.

title: Egyptian Aide Is Unharmed As Bomb Explodes Near Him
description: The Government minister who has led Egypt's crackdown on Muslim militants escaped injury today when a truck bomb exploded just before he arrived at his sports club, security officials said.

title: China Draws Fire for Effort to Curb U.N. on Rights
description: Human rights campaigners who think that the United Nations can discourage abuses are concerned by China's support for a proposal before the General Assembly to restrict the organization's right to criticize individual governments for violations.

title: New York G.O.P. Is Better Organized But Still Seeks Challenger to Cuomo
description: As it prepares for a critical gubernatorial election, the New York State Republican Party is better financed and better staffed than it has been since the Rockefeller era. But it still lacks an experienced and well-known candidate to challenge Gov. Mario M. Cuomo if he seeks a third term and to end a 16-year Republican absence from the Governor's mansion.

title: Pleas for Bulgaria's Muslim Minority
description: A little-noted issue in the last few days, but a highly delicate one as Bulgaria talks of dismantling old systems, is the fate of the country's large and long-victimized Muslim minority.

title: Q and A
description: Looking at a Co-op's Books

title: Rockville Centre Acts To Ease Truck Traffic
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of Rockville Centre are so upset about heavy truck traffic along a half-dozen local thoroughfares that the Village Board has established weight limits for those trucks that use the streets mostly to haul garbage to the Town of Hempstead incinerator in Westbury.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Within the next two weeks, there will be be millions of ''I'm going to be a better person'' resolutions made. Thousands of them will be either ''this year I am going to start a diary'' or ''this year I'm going to keep up the diary I did start.''

title: OPENLY GAY PRIEST ORDAINED IN JERSEY
description: Bishop John S. Spong, head of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, ordained an openly gay man as a priest yesterday, over the strong protests of traditionalist Episcopal Church bishops and members who argued that the ordination would disregard Christian moral standards.

title: Campus Life: Wabash; A New President, An Old Debate: Admit Women?
description: The inauguration of a new president at Wabash College this month has given rise to renewed speculation that this all-men's liberal arts college - one of two of its kind in the nation - might some day join the ranks of coeducation.

title: Fashion; Chic for the Last-Minute Shopper
description: The holiday gift bought this week in a panic needn't be banal. ''At the last moment, people buy a plain tie, plain gloves,'' said Louise Maniscalco, director of the personal shopping service at Barneys New York. ''But that's not what anybody really wants. People want something a little offbeat, a little whimsical.''

title: Knicks Win 9th in a Row at Home
description: The Knicks last night won their ninth successive home-court game since the beginning of the season, a franchise record for the fastest start. The 118-97 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics came so easily that it was enough to lull the Madison Square Garden capacity crowd of 18,212 to sleep.

title: Loyalty in Albany: Official's Downfall?
description: Twenty-five years ago Julio A. Martinez was battling to overcome heroin addiction. He won. Within three years he was helping establish Phoenix House, which grew into the largest private drug-treatment agency in the country. He set up a drug-free program for adolescents in jail on Rikers Island. And in 1979 he became the director of New York State's drug-treatment efforts, eventually overseeing a budget of $350 million.

title: Baseball League Sues On Broadcast 'Piracy'
description: A LAWSUIT filed by major league baseball against a tavern here seeks to have it stop the unauthorized showing of satellite broadcasts of games to patrons, but the tavern's owner says he is only doing what other bars in the area have done for years.

title: NONFICTION
description: LILY POND: Four Years With a Family of Beavers. By Hope Ryden. (Morrow, $17.95.) It is likely that ''Lily Pond'' will appeal to nature lovers. The startling thing, though, is how well Hope Ryden's study of a beaver family succeeds on other levels. Her observations of a pair of wild beavers in New York's Harriman State Park is eloquent and suspenseful, educational without being didactic, and includes a reasoned analysis of whether humans should further disrupt nature's balance. ''I don't believe in feeding wildlife,'' writes Ms. Ryden, ''but like most people I don't always abide by my own principles.'' She abandons those principles when certain that the family she possessively calls ''my beavers'' will starve to death and feels vindicated later when the pair becomes self-sufficient. The author, however, is usually a silent observer of her beavers. Ms. Ryden, whose previous books include ''Bobcat Year'' and ''God's Dog,'' both observes and explains the extremely sophisticated behavior of the animals, noting that the beaver is not truly a nocturnal animal but developed its nighttime habits in reaction to humans. Beavers are probably best known for their engineering, and here too she observes and argues that much of the animals' behavior seems ''too complex to be casually dismissed with the simplistic word 'instinct.' '' The animals are fascinating and likable, as is the story of their life.

title: In Pizza, Something for Everyone
description: SINCE the late 40's, the popularity of pizza has spread so far that for some families it is now as American as apple pie. And just about everyone has a preference in pizza: Neapolitan. Sicilian. Chicago. Thick crust or thin. Recent years added a new dimension, the California-style pizza with toppings that can include anything from artichokes to zucchini. These innovative pies, the domain of the trendy restaurants, have now invaded the traditional pizza parlor.

title: As Iron Curtain Wavers, Export Opportunities Arise
description: LEAD: AS small to mid-size European nations emerge from behind what was the Iron Curtain, opportunities for trade and joint ventures will abound for Long Island's small to mid-size high-technology companies, according to an official of the Federal Department of Commerce.

title: Bias Suit Builds Bridge to Friendship
description: WHEN David Harrington lists his friends, he is quick to include Milo Sheff. And Milo puts David on his list. The 10-year-olds share an interest in drawing. And they have another bond. They are suing Connecticut.

title: Part-Time Council, Full-Time Power
description: New York's City Council is a little like a lottery winner who has lived from hand to mouth for years and suddenly must learn to manage money, or make a profligate mess of things. What the Council must manage is power. The new City Charter gives it central authority over the city's most pressing duties. Unless the Council changes the way it does business, it will fail.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Lack of Affordables Slows Job Growth
description: LEAD: SINCE 1982 the most visible signs of New Jersey's economic prosperity have been new commercial and residential construction. Among the unwanted side effects of this growth have been shortages of labor and of affordable housing.

title: Geriatric-Care Managers Face Growing Demand
description: The graying of New Jersey described in John Paul Marosy's article, ''When the Aged Need Care, Their Families Need a Hand'' (Opinion page, Oct. 15), coupled with the anticipated growth of the state's economy resulting in an increasing need for qualified workers, causes a new concern in the workplace.

title: Helen Matheson to Wed David Hilliard
description: The engagement of Helen Dow Matheson to David Shelburne Hilliard, a son of Mary Eichert Hilliard of New York and Landon Hilliard of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tompkins Matheson of The Plains, Va. A January wedding is planned.

title: FICTION
description: BEAUTIFUL MUTANTS. By Deborah Levy. (Viking, $17.95.) Although billed as a novel, Deborah Levy's rather thin little book, ''Beautiful Mutants,'' reads more like a short story. Episodic, concise and poetic, this unconventional tale about social misfits and secret desires feels dreamlike in its quick passage and sometimes indelible imagery. Dispensing with plot, Ms. Levy has organized an exploration of the mind's dark regions that employs as her dreamer an odd, mystically inclined woman known only as Lapinski. Lapinski's voice, with its sleepwalker's rhythms, is the center around which a handful of characters - the beautiful mutants - orbit. Indeed, she is hardly more than a voice. We learn little about her except that she's a Russian exile in London who works in a meat-packing factory. Her lovers and acquaintances, who come to us filtered through her dreamscape, are a ragged, if not disturbed, bunch. There's a weary poet whose oracular pronouncements (''It is difficult to make a map in splintered times when whole worlds and histories collide'') seem trite; an anarchist who raids the zoo and communes with a llama; a jaded, masochistic banker; and a prostitute. Each character flutters briefly for several pages, long enough to skim the lower depths and retrieve the sort of sexually overripe and violent images that were the French poet and dramatist Antonin Artaud's stock in trade and are now the novelist Kathy Acker's. These scenes are either luridly visceral or earnestly poetic, but in the end they fail to cohere. The concoction of a successful dream narrative requires the inclusion of just enough of the mundane so that macabre visions can register against it. While ''Beautiful Mutants'' provides some choice moments, too often they are submerged by Ms. Levy's penchant for excess.

title: Amy Weber Engaged To Marry David Stern
description: A January wedding is planned by Amy Sue Weber and David Lawrence Stern, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Weber of Westbury, L.I., have announced.

title: Fast-and-Loose Oilers Leave Fear Far Behind Oilers Leave Their Fear Far Behind
description: INSIDE the locker room, a stuffed Bugs Bunny has so many obscene messages about this week's foe sketched on it that one wonders if a wrong turn was made into a bawdy saloon. Out on the practice field on this warm, bright day, a touchdown toss clicks, and whoops and hollers reach a fever pitch as one player lovingly locks another in a headlock.

title: THE RIGHT TO PREGNANCY BY CONTRACT
description: BIRTH POWER The Case for Surrogacy. By Carmel Shalev. 201 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: INSIDE
description: A Spy Inquiry Is Curtailed The F.B.I. has found no solid evidence in its intensive espionage investigation of a veteran diplomat, Felix S. Bloch, and it has significantly scaled back its inquiry, Federal officials say.

title: Review/Music; The Selah Vocal Ensemble
description: The Selah Vocal Ensemble, a choir that specializes in Jewish sacred and secular music of all eras, turned its sights on sacred works by the late-Renaissance composer Salamone Rossi in a concert last Sunday afternoon at the Jewish Museum.

title: Diana Sousa to Wed George C. Jepsen in May
description: Mrs. George Sousa of West Hartford, Conn., has announced May wedding plans for her daughter Diana Sousa and George Christian Jepsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jepsen of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Center Set Up to Help In Small Claims Process
description: LEAD: ''PEOPLE don't know very much about small claims court, or they are afraid of it,'' said Lauren Adler, project coordinator for the New York Public Interest Research Group chapter at the State University of New York at Purchase, where a Small Claims Court Action Center recently opened.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL MIAMI DOLPHINS (AFC) - Placed William Judson, cornerback, on injured reserve. Signed Earnest Gibson, cornerback. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Signed Orlando Lowry, linebacker. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Placed Sam Seale, cornerback, on injured reserve. Released Johnny Thomas, cornerback. Activated Elliot Smith and Michael Brooks, cornerbacks, from the developmental squad. COLLEGE NORTHERN ARIZONA - Appointed John Kaiser defensive and special teams assistant coach. FRIDAY BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Agreed to terms with Gerald Perry, first baseman, on a one-year contract and traded him and Jim Lemasters, pitcher, to the Kansas City Royals for Charlie Leibrandt and Rick Luecken, pitchers. SEATTLE (AL) - Agreed to terms with Matt Young, pitcher, on a one-year contract. FOOTBALL NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Fined Sam Wyche, Cincinnati Bengals coach, an undisclosed amount for his failure to allow reporters into the team's locker room after a loss to Seattle. CHICAGO (NFC) - Activated Mark Green, punt returner, from injured reserve. Placed Mo Douglass, defensive back, on injured reserve.

title: Historical Society Settles Into New Home
description: LEAD: THE Westchester County Historical Society has moved to the renovated Westchester County Records and Archives Center on Saw Mill River Road in Elmsford. As with any move, there were things to sort, pack or discard.

title: Men, Women And the Revolution
description: I HAVE always told friends I would know the revolution had come when they put diaper-changing tables in men's rooms. This year I moved to New Jersey and found that it had happened without me. The tables are already in place at the Princeton MarketFair - and it was built two whole years ago.

title: Christmas For the Thrifty: Yes, in Paris
description: PARIS is one of the cheapest places I know to have a glorious Christmas - or rather have a glorious time escaping from Christmas. Not a total escape; for that you'd have to go to Lhasa or Teheran. But if this year you can't face another magazine-ad-type American family Christmas with the father in Santa Claus costume and everybody sitting happily around the tree amid mountains of gaily wrapped laptop computers, Cabbage Patch dolls and electric trains, while through the snowy window can be seen the front end of the new car ''we gave to each other,'' Paris makes a blissful change. Hurry over, however, while it lasts! Every year Christmas in Paris becomes a tiny bit more Americanized.

title: Franklin P. Darmory, Chemical Executive, 46
description: Franklin P. Darmory, president of the Alcide Corporation of Norwalk, Conn., died of a heart attack on Dec. 7 while in London on a business trip. He was 46 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. MICHIKO KOSAKA;
On the Trail of Automatic Translation
description: LEAD: TECHNOLOGICAL advances and an increasingly global economy have heightened interest in developing a computer that can translate from one language to another without human intervention. As part of a joint project with researchers at New York University and Hunter College, Dr. Michiko Kosaka, an assistant professor of computer science at Monmouth College in West Long Branch, is conducting research on automatic machine translation of Japanese to

title: Earning It
description: Some have always been more equal than others in Marxist Europe. But with the new freedom in the East has come a tide of old resentments of the privileges accorded party officials and top athletes, among others. Katarina Witt, the Olympic figure-skating champion, thinks some of her complaining East German countrymen are being a bit ungrateful. In an interview a day after some senior officials resigned amid protests over payments to athletes, Miss Witt said that she and other Olympic stars got no more than they deserved. ''I don't think it's fair that a lot of people who were fans before are now changing,'' she said. ''I got thousands of letters after the Olympics from people telling me they watched the skating and it helped them forget their problems. Why do those people forget this now?'' Miss Witt suggested that if athletes lost their perks, East Germany might lose some athletes.

title: No Such Thing As History
description: To the Editor:

title: Lotus Takes a Gamble on 'Notes'
description: THE Lotus Development Corporation recently introduced a product called Notes, which was five years in development. Notes is a new type of network corporate communications software sometimes referred to as ''super E-mail,'' a shorthand way of saying that it is a high-powered electronic message system. It is also part of an emerging, nebulous category of software known as groupware.

title: To Repair Our Nation
description: The need for large-scale investment in public works is obvious to anyone who travels about the United States. And there is a way to make it possible despite the Federal Government's budget deficit: the creation of state infrastructure banks.

title: Boston's Retail Doyennes Diverge
description: VETERAN shoppers here say that except for the bargain basement at Filene's and the blueberry muffins at Jordan Marsh, New England's two stylish department stores - neighborly rivals for 136 years - seem indistinguishable.

title: America's Ex-Coach Assesses the Cowboys
description: IN his time as their coach, the Dallas Cowboys appeared in five Super Bowl games and won two. In seven other seasons, they advanced to the National Conference championship game before being eliminated. Over a span of 20 seasons from 1966 through 1985, only twice did the Cowboys fail to qualify for the playoffs.

title: Review/Music; Dennis Russell Davies in Brooklyn
description: On Wednesday, Dennis Russell Davies was named music director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and principal conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, both effective in 1991. On Friday evening, he conducted the first in a three-concert series with the Philharmonic at the academy - the final installment is this afternoon at 2 - and a better advertisement for himself could hardly be imagined.

title: Ms. Engelbourg Planning to Wed
description: January wedding plans for Karen Ann Engelbourg and Donald Bruce Stewart have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Saul Engelbourg of Newton Centre, Mass.

title: A Limit On Doctors' Hours Is Studied
description: LEAD: DOCTORS at Yale-New Haven Hospital, the University of Connecticut Health Center and Hartford Hospital have begun a review of the number of hours physicians in their residency programs are required to work.

title: Women and the Respect They Deserve
description: I felt an all too familiar rumbling in the pit of my working-mommy belly as I read Janet Gibbs-Albanesius's article, ''That Old Question for a Candidate'' (Opinion page, Oct. 29). To respond to it, I must make a statement that they just don't ask men the same questions they ask women in any given situation.

title: GARBO IS ONLY PART OF THE STORY
description: THE MAN WHO SHOT GARBO The Hollywood Photographs of Clarence Sinclair Bull. Text by Terence Pepper and John Kobal. Foreword by Katharine Hepburn. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $40.

title: E .C. Dothard, State Trooper, 58
description: E. C. Dothard, the state trooper wounded in the 1972 assassination attempt on Gov. George C. Wallace, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound Friday night in a hospital where he was being treated for terminal cancer. He was 58 years old.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: Some of the most dangerous illusions on the chessboard stem from one of the greatest geniuses of the game, Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894. This man, who was so adept at analyzing the structure of the game - embodied by the pawn formation - was cavalier about the factor of time and of rapidity of development and what it could do. It was to be 100 years before another world champion, Bobby Fischer, was to elevate time as the prime factor of the game.

title: Raising Money Tops Colleges' Agenda for 90's
description: Colleges and universities, facing many of the same competitive pressures as big corporations, are trying to raise huge amounts of money to prepare for the 1990's, a decade that many educators think will bring expensive and potentially disruptive changes to their institutions.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: HELEN M. COOPER;
Women and War: A Scholar With a Feminist Perspective
description: LEAD: THROUGH history, writers have chronicled the effects of war on both sexes. Recently scholars have tried to study literature in terms of women's issues, with some surprising results.

title: Review/Theater; Reflections of Despair In a Sardonic 'Krapp'
description: In its journey across New York in search of site-specific locations, the nomadic En Garde Arts troupe sets new challenges for theatergoers. In the case of ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' the first question is how to find the temporary theater. The address is 1 Main Street, Brooklyn, a byway by the waterfront in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge. Inside an unused space in an office building, one can find a table set for ''Krapp's Last Tape.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Salt Lake City
description: Salt Lake City, home of the artificial heart, the Mormon Church and a persevering pioneer spirit, has in the last two decades, become a contemporary, cosmopolitan city.

title: The New Takeovers
description: SINCE the early 1980's, corporate America has been wracked by endless takeover battles. Prices for companies soared, propelled by investors' seemingly insatiable appetite for debt. Those heady days are gone, however. And for the next year or so, takeover specialists predict that deals will be fewer, fetch lower prices and involve far less debt.

title: FINALLY, A SPECIALIST IN REALLY EARLY EARLY MUSIC
description: Man-bites-dog it is not, but these days it qualifies as news when an early-music specialist of international standing comes to New York to perform anything earlier than Haydn or Mozart. Most early-musicians are tripping over each other on their self-appointed march through music history, some already feverishly polishing off Beethoven so they can move on to Schumann, Brahms and even Wagner.

title: Aides Study on the Job to Be Nurses
description: LEAD: UNSKILLED hospital workers are taking courses at their work sites that could lead to certificates in licensed practical nursing, in a program offered by the Seton School of Iona College.

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Starting with ''The Ipcress File'' in 1962 and proceeding to such virtuoso pieces as ''Funeral in Berlin,'' Len Deighton has demonstrated again and again that he is a master of the British (is there any other?) espionage novel. His latest book, SPY LINE (Knopf, $18.95), will not disappoint his admirers.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Gretzky.

title: Where Communist Economics Fell Short
description: IT'S not over 'til it's over, Yogi admonished. But with Muscovites salivating over the arrival of McDonald's and Hungary celebrating the embrace of General Electric, it is hard to deny that the long ideological war between capitalism and socialism has ended in a decisive win for the home team.

title: Off The Mark
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms Makers Gird for Peace
description: WAR is a dirty business. But for makers of guns, tanks and planes, it is a profitable one.

title: REFINED MODERNISM MAKES A SPLASH IN THE LAND OF GLITZ
description: It is difficult to know whether the newly finished headquarters of Creative Artists Agency at the intersection of Wilshire and Santa Monica Boulevards here is a throwback or an odd stroke of the avant-garde for this city of the forever new. For this building, the first Los Angeles-area work of I. M. Pei, marks a determined break with the raw, intense and wild architecture that has characterized Los Angeles in the last decade. It is reserved, almost discreet: a classic modernist palazzo. What could be more daring in the city that is known for the work of Frank Gehry on the one hand, and for roadside stands shaped like hot dogs on the other?

title: Motorcyclists Lose in Battle With the Tortoise
description: Three desert motorcycle races have been denied Federal operating permits. The denials marked a victory for environmentalists trying to save the desert tortoise.

title: Foundation Is a Friend To Children With Cancer
description: LEAD: LAST summer Julie Smythe was given a diagnosis that is a parent's worst nightmare: she was told that her 7-year-old daughter, Tishna, had cancer. The girl, who had been complaining of back pains, needed an immediate operation to remove a kidney tumor the size of a grapefruit.

title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale
description: A recent spurt in corruption cases at the Drug Enforcement Administration has undermined morale and crippled many investigations at a time when the agency is all but overwhelmed by the illicit drug trade, agents say.

title: THE DAZZLE OF GLASS, SEEN OVER TIME
description: Every technique used to make glass over 3,500 years is represented in ''The Art of Glass: Masterpieces From the Corning Museum,'' an exhibition on view at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street. The 116 molded, blown, cut, engraved or painted works in these dazzling displays were made during the peak periods of this craft, from ancient Egypt onward, and include some of the finest examples extant. The show remains through Feb. 3. ''There has rarely been an exhibition that covers the whole history of glass from its beginnings right down to today,'' said David B. Whitehouse, Corning's deputy director and the curator of the exhibition. ''This is a distillation of our collection.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Having read that it is always best to stain cedar shingles, rather than paint them, we contracted to have all the peeling paint sandblasted off our shingles. But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately. Also, some tell us to apply one coat of primer, then one coat of stain. Which is best: latex or oil?

title: Help for the Big Holiday Spenders
description: YOU have probably been spending your way into a corner this gift-buying season. So, how about a gift for yourself at no cost - something, say, in the $50-and-up category. Here's a shopping list of ways to save or earn some money - many of them obvious but often overlooked and all of them free for the asking. To be eligible, however, you may have to make a phone call, dash off a short letter or maybe just change your way of thinking. Happy shopping!

title: Central America's Reversal on Rebels
description: WHEN the presidents of five Central American countries met in Honduras last August, they quickly gave up the idea that they could stretch a single broad framework of peace across their contrasting political conflicts. In two days of often bitter meetings, they settled for a narrower, less idealistic accord: ratification of an agreement to disband the American-supported Nicaraguan rebels.

title: A VICTORY HALF WON
description: FREEDOM BOUND A History of America's Civil Rights Movement. By Robert Weisbrot. Illustrated. 350 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95.

title: Carrie M. Minot Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. George R. Minot of Santa Barbara, Calif., and North Haven, Me., have made known the engagement of Mr. Minot's daughter Caroline Mary Minot to Julian Edward Metcalfe, a son of David P. Metcalfe of London and the late Alexa Metcalfe. A March wedding is planned.

title: From a Sheet of Paper, an Ark or an Alphabet
description: LEAD: MARTHA LINK WALSH of Branford was once a math teacher. Then at age 22, she became ill with hepatitis and mononucleosis. To help pass the time in bed, her mother gave her a pair of scissors and some paper.

title: Manila Moves on a Rebel Area
description: Troops backed by tanks were rushed to Davao today after reports that rebel soldiers planned to stage a new attempt to topple President Corazon C. Aquino, this time in the southern Philippines.

title: Special Oscar for Kurosawa
description: Akira Kurosawa, the Japanese director of ''Rashomon,'' ''The Seven Samurai'' and other films, will receive an honorary Academy Award at the presentations on March 26. Mr. Kurosawa's ''Rashomon'' (1951) and ''Dersu Uzala'' (1975) won Oscars as best foreign-language films.

title: Fixing the Schools Is Not Enough
description: PLANS to reform our schools tend to overlook the fact that about half of our youngsters grow up in families that are not viable from an educational viewpoint. Frequent divorces, a bewildering rotation of boyfriends and parents who come home from work exhausted both physically and mentally, have left many homes with a tremendous parenting deficit. Instead of providing a stable home environment and the kind of close, loving supervision good character formation requires, many child care facilities, grannies, and baby sitters simply insure that children will stay out of harm's way.

title: Give Families a Choice of Schools
description: SIX years after studies first warned that mediocre schools make America a nation at risk, the need to improve schools is so dire that it drew some of the country's top leaders to a nationwide summit just a few weeks ago.

title: A Debate Over Access To U.S. University Research
description: THANKS largely to American university research, Toshiba Inc. is developing a new technology for recording images on disks, the Toyota Motor Company is devising new engineering stress sensors, and the Asahi Chemical Company is computerizing its manufacturing processes.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Orchestra to Get A New Home
description: LEAD: THE Philadelphia Orchestra Association has announced plans for a $95 million hall one block south of the Academy of Music, the orchestra's home since it was founded in 1900. The 2,800-seat hall, designed by the Philadelphia architectural concern Venturi Scott Brown & Associates, will be at Broad and Spruce Streets, a primarily commercial area about five blocks south of City

title: Church Seeks to Raise the Human to the Divine; Who Is the Church?
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Clawson, a Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Clawson of Rochester have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Martha L. Clawson and Bradford B. Bjorklund, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Bjorklund of Mill Neck, L.I.

title: Birding in Mexico's South
description: AS soon as the plane lifts off from Mexico City and heads south toward the state of Chiapas, you can see plumes of smoke rising over the mountains. A lot of the forest is already gone. Some of it is burned off by peasant families who hope to raise one or two meager harvests of beans or plantains before the soil is exhausted. Then they abandon that plot to unproductive scrub, and move on to slash and burn another plot. Larger tracts are cleared by cattle-grazing corporations that supply cheap hamburger meat to the United States.

title: Four Old Dutch Desserts Revived
description: LEAD: HISTORY lessons can be sweetened now with cookies and pastry created by Peter G. Rose, a food historian who lives in South Salem, and by Peter and John De Jong, brothers who own the Village Bake Shop in Mount Kisco.

title: Fran Tolins Engaged To Joshua Weingast
description: February wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roger Tolins of Roslyn, L.I., for their daughter, Fran Susan Tolins, and Joshua Alan Weingast, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weingast of Pomona, N.Y.

title: BEFORE THE BEDROOM WALL
description: LEAD: THE NEUMILLER STORIES By Larry Woiwode. 289 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title:
FILM;
Camille Claudel: Passion Reborn
description: LEAD: One morning in 1898, Auguste Rodin came to lunch at the home of his friend Eugene Morand, director of the Ecole des Beaux Arts. ''He comes all this way to escape the one he adores,'' Morand told his son afterward. ''It's a very sad story. That girl is the best pupil he ever had; she is a genius; she is very beautiful, and she loves him; but she is mad.

title: Nina Reetz Wed To G. P. Richter
description: Nina Katherine Reetz and Gregory Peter Richter were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. P. C. Enniss, a Presbyterian minister, at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Gay Edwards Reetz of Bronxville and John Henry Reetz of Bradford, Pa. Her husband is a son of Elisabeth Richter of Ridgewood, N.J., and Kurt G. Richter of Little Silver, N.J.

title: Betsy Kirkland Engaged to John Cahill
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Hayes Kirkland to John Tobin Cahill, a son of Mrs. Joseph F. Cahill of Charleston, S.C., and the late Mr. Cahill, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Kirkland Jr., also of Charleston. A February wedding is planned.

title: Sixteen - The Third Time Around
description: Well, either it was menopause at long last, or else I was pregnant. Terrific. No one's going to believe this. From a college professor? Try.

title: Lifestyle: Christmas Dinner; The Coziest Substitutes For Hearth and Home
description: Christmas may be the holiday most closely associated with home and hearth, but if you find youself in need of a cozy substitute, an enchanting restaurant may be the answer. Many of the top luxury establishments, like La Cote Basque and Le Bernardin are closed Christmas Eve and Christmas Day; others, like the River Cafe (open Christmas Eve only) have been booked for weeks. Here is is a selective roundup of dining spots where a holiday mood is combined with quality food:

title: Battles Won, Memories Lost
description: DID an American Army sergeant kill more than 500 Japanese soldiers singlehandedly in one battle during World War II? Was he denied the Medal of Honor because he is Jewish?

title: Gifts, From Wipers to a Rolls
description: IF that Christmas stocking feels a bit thin and spindly this year, it may be because the world's largest supplier of windshield wipers has had its way with Santa.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Drug Trafficker's Death Cheers Many Colombians
description: A wave of euphoria swept across Colombia today in the aftermath of the killing by security forces of a powerful drug trafficker accused of directing a four-month terror campaign.

title: Beirut Decree Cuts Funds to Renegade Commander
description: The Government of President Elias Hrawi, still reluctant to use force to oust Gen. Michel Aoun, the renegade Christian commander, is instead resorting to economic and political pressure to remove him.

title: Persuading Americans To Save
description: POLITICIANS here finally appear to be waking up to what economists have been telling them: The long binge of overspending and undersaving by government, business and consumers threatens to depress living standards and reduce the nation to a second-rate economic force during the next decade. Already, there are symptoms, among them lagging productivity, slow wage growth, the sale of major assets to foreign investors, stubbornly high interest rates and the huge trade and budget deficits.

title: How Chile Is Devising a Democracy
description: THE easy triumph of a coalition candidate in the presidential elections in Chile last Thursday reflects, on the surface anyway, the end of the longstanding animosity between the leftists who supported the late Salvador Allende Gossens and the centrists who opposed him 16 years ago.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: Sneaky and improper dumping is a source of controversy and outrage for bridge players as well as for environmentalists and urban planners. Can it ever be proper to play badly by intention, dumping points to opponents who have not earned them and damaging other players in the process? It is easy to answer this question with a flat negative, and many, but not all, authorities do so.

title: HOW THE HARDLINERS WON
description: In an article that purports to reveal the power struggle that unfolded behind closed doors in the Chinese capital, Nicholas D. Kristof, in fact, delivers a slanted and, at times, morally repugnant revision of the tragic end of the Beijing Spring (''China Update: How the Hardliners Won,'' Nov. 12). The implication is that the students brought on themselves the brutal suppression that followed the demise of the moderate factions.

title: Boiler Explosion Kills Worker
description: An autopsy today determined that a worker died of extreme heat when a boiler exploded at a tannery Friday night, the police said. Joseph Insogna, 62 years old, of Gloversville, was working alone in the Pan American Tannery when the boiler blew up about 7:30 P.M. or unknown reasons, said Patrolman Stan Stoller of the Gloversville police.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL'

title: U.N. Racing Winter in Drive to Feed Afghans
description: Hoping to stave off the malnutrition afflicting thousands of children in Afghanistan, the United Nations is struggling to bring food and medicine to the country before the worst of the winter snow sets in.

title: TALKING: Curb Appeal; Low-Cost, High-Yield Cosmetics
description: AT a time when co-op and condominium owners are struggling to maintain the market value of their homes, curb appeal - the first impression a buyer gets of a complex or building - is assuming new importance.

title: Holly Hackett and John Kania Marry
description: Holly Hackett and John Vinson Kania were married yesterday in Locust Valley, L.I., by the Rev. Charles G. Newberry at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church. The bride, 29 years old, is the daughter of Lela Ottley Leslie of Locust Valley and Randall Winslow Hackett of New York. Her husband, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Kania of Cheshire, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about elections in Uruguay gave an incorrect party affiliation for the vice-presidential candidate of the Broad Front, a leftist coalition. The candidate, Danilo Astori, has since informed The Times that he is an independent, not a Communist Party member.

title: Girls Should Quit Smoking - It's a Breeze
description: FANS! They're the solution. Not screaming, frenzied rock-star fans, not electric fans, but hand-held semicircles of ribbed paper, lace and silk. Fans held delicately in front of one's face, calling attention to flirtatious eyes. Fans snapping shut for emphasis. Fans gracefully fluttered to advertise allure. Fans are the solution.

title: Title to Georgia Southern
description: Mike Dowis kicked a 20-yard field goal with 1:41 left today to lift top-ranked Georgia Southern to a 37-34 victory over Stephen F. Austin for the N.C.A.A. Division I-AA championship.

title: Chinese Jet Is Hijacked to Japan; Tokyo Will Deport Suspect
description: A man identified as a dissident in China was arrested and hospitalized in Japan on Saturday after a Chinese jetliner bound for New York with 223 people aboard was hijacked and forced to land in the southern Japanese city of Fukuoka.

title: 'Wozzeck' Speaks To Us by Mixing Two Musical Modes
description: Alban Berg's ''Wozzeck'' was the first atonal opera to get anywhere near standard repertory status, and it is still the only one. (Berg's second opera, ''Lulu,'' is the only other remote contender.) It was first heard in 1925 and had almost 30 productions by the early 30's. After a hiatus while Nazi disapproval halted its progress before German-speaking audiences, it resumed its place at home and spread to all the world's operatic capitals. At a time when atonality is increasingly seen as a failed project, the work shows no sign of loosening its hold - though the rows of empty seats traditional at its Metropolitan Opera revivals testify to a continuing failure of communication between this score and some part of the mainstream opera audience. This is understandable, but probably remediable: there are aspects of the score that may still be drowned out by its reputation. ''Wozzeck'' returns to the Met Thursday evening, with a cast including Hildegard Behrens and Gottfried Hornik. It is always worth rehearing, and especially by anyone who thinks of it as a nihilistic, hopeless work: that it is not.

title: Incentive Exists In N.F.L.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Lawyers, Crime May Not Pay
description: IN its wars on drugs, organized crime and white-collar racketeering, the Government means to seize ill-gotten gains wherever they are. Although prosecutors insist that they are using restraint, criminal defense lawyers say they have much to lose because of the Government's authority to freeze assets before trial and even to pursue legal fees that have already been paid.

title: Marjorie R. Miller To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Roni Miller, to Andrew Lawrence Porter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Porter. Both families live in Jericho, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Hastings Delays Development Vote
description: LEAD: AFTER months of public hearings and debate, village officials here are facing a crucial decision on a proposed residential-commercial development along the banks of the Hudson River.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title:
INVESTING;
Unearthing Profits From Cleaner Coal
description: LEAD: IT is no surprise that investors have shunned the coal industry. On top of strikes in Appalachia and a continuing coal glut comes Washington's determination to curb acid rain by requiring the use of cleaner coal. Congress is likely to pass some legislation next year. But two types of coal companies might prosper: those that mine low-polluting low-sulfur coal, and those that are diversifying.

title: Michelle ArtilesTo Wed in April
description: Michelle Patricia Artiles and Jeffrey Howard Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Cohen of Livingston, N.J., plan to be married in April. Their engagement was announced by Lucy Artiles of Miami, the prospective bride's mother.

title: 'Mistress of the Inn;' 1751 Farce, in Fairfield
description: DO not dismiss the Boston Post Road Stage Company on the evidence of the current cheerless production of ''The Mistress of the Inn.'' The dauntless little professional theater in Fairfield has considerable virtues but playing classic comedy is just not one of them.

title: The Fate of a Waterfront Minus Ships
description: THE last remains of New York harbor's century as a bustling port are being swept away, affording a clearer view of what the waterfront will be like in the next century.

title: Nursing Homes Pressed on AIDS Policy
description: LEAD: AFTER years of turning away AIDS patients, nursing homes on Long Island are coming under increasing pressure to accept sufferers of the fatal illness.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on page 15 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Roger and Me'' misidentifies the film maker. He is Michael Moore.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MARCEL PROUST. Selected Letters: Volume Two, 1904-1909. Edited by Philip Kolb. Translated by Terrence Kilmartin. (Oxford University, $29.95.) When Marcel Proust wrote these letters he had not yet fully embarked on his life's work, the seven-part novel ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' although one can observe him here beginning to arrange his withdrawal from salon society.

title: Dennis Quaid: Sometimes He's So Easy to Love
description: One of those sticky questions that cling to Hollywood actors is why the undeniably popular Dennis Quaid - whose screen presence seems an unbeatable mix of boyish grin, effortless sex appeal and sudden bursts of passion - has never starred in a blockbuster movie. GREAT BALLS OF FIRE (1989, Orion, $89.98), appearing on video little more than five months after it bombed in theaters, won't do much to clear up the box-office mystery. Mr. Quaid's hyperkinetic performance as Jerry Lee Lewis didn't doom the movie; it suffered from skewed expectations.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: One athlete showed that he was the greatest at his position in the history of the sport. His name: Michael Jack Schmidt. ROBERT LIGANSKY Brooklyn

title: Balloons Not a Threat To the Environment
description: Re: ''In the Natural State,'' Oct. 29:

title: Under the Microscope At County's New Lab
description: WHEN a suspect is arrested in a drug case in Westchester, the police have five days to analyze the drugs seized or the suspect must be released and the charges dropped. Last year, drugs from 3,530 cases were sent to the crime lab and 88,705 tests were performed on the drugs. This year's cases are expected to total 3,800.

title: Milk Prices Rise to Record Level for Fourth Month
description: Milk prices in the New York metropolitan area rose to a record level for the fourth straight month in early December, state marketing officials said this week.

title: Neighbor Wins Suit Against Zen Monastery
description: A TWO-YEAR dispute between a religious organization and a neighboring Pound Ridge homeowner was settled last week when a State Supreme Court judge upheld most of the neighbor's claims and awarded him a $45,000 settlement.

title: HOMESPUN HISTORY
description: CLOTH AND HUMAN EXPERIENCE Edited by Annette B. Weiner and Jane Schneider. Illustrated. 431 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. $39.95.

description: To the Editor:
