description: To the Editor:

title: Plantation Owners Sell History to Preserve It
description: Along the back roads of Louisiana's plantation country, among white-columned mansions and gardens perfumed with sweet olive trees, marketers are busily trying to sell history.

title:
MUSIC;
A Tamer 'Mecanique' in Wayne
description: LEAD: ''BALLET MECANIQUE,'' a revolutionary work by the New Jersey-born composer George Antheil (1900-1959), caused riots at its premieres in both Paris and New York in 1927 and 1928. Raymond Des Roches, a professor of music at William Paterson College who will conduct the New Jersey Percussion Ensemble in the rarely played work tomorrow night, says he does not anticipate any riots during the performance in

title: Lapchick Event Is Embarrassing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Remarks to Reporters By Bush and Mitterrand
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France today in St. Martin, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: Q. . . . I understand that one area of disagreement between the both of you was on the subject of export controls on highly sensitive goods shipped into Eastern Europe, the so-called Cocom regulations. President Bush, I wonder if at this point, since you're making overtures in other areas, you feel it's time to relax these regulations? And also if President Mitterrand would respond, too, if you and the United States are in more agreement today on this than you were before the meeting? BUSH: One, I did not have a discussion with the President of France on that subject. Two, we should and will review our Cocom - our participation in Cocom, our discussions in Cocom. There are certainly still legitimate national security interests that must be preserved, and I don't think we have one iota of difference with France on that. But I think it is timely that we take a new look at some of the commercial constraints. Q: On East Germany, do you have any specific prescriptions to keep the situation from running wild? Apparently it's quite different from what was going on in Poland and Hungary. Mr. President, perhaps some instant food aid as winter approaches? Is there some special way to treat the East German chaotic situation? BUSH: I don't know there's a special way, but we spelled out at NATO the four points that relate to German reunification - the Strasbourg declaration under the meeting headed by President Mitterrand addressed themselves to that question. Obviously, if there's emergency food aid required there - we have no request for that - but if it's required, we would be very responsive, as I expect others in the alliance would be. Q. President Mitterrand, I'd like to ask you if you discussed in any way China, and what you think of President Bush's decision to send his envoys to China recently? And if I could follow on that, Mr. Bush, if perhaps you've had second thoughts about the nature in which this was done, in the secretive fashion, and in the toasting of the Chinese while your envoys were there? MITTERRAND: Thank you for this question. Well, I should have said in my presentation, indeed we did talk about China, and this was at the initiative of President Bush, who himself expressed the wish of being able to give us his views on this subject and the reason for what was done. So, I think now you might hear this. BUSH: I have no second thoughts at all. And being somewhat familiar with China, I've learned that you listen to everything that's said in a toast. We've looked at every word and analyzed it, and I'm strongly supportive of this mission by General Scowcroft and Larry Eagleburger. I've said that I initiated it and I'm not going to go further, except to say that I hope that it will have positive results. Q.Is there any agreement between France and the U.S. to slow down Mr. Kohl in his drive toward reunification? MITTERRAND: I have your answer. Is there an agreement or conformity of view to slow down? Yes, there's a great conformity of views -particularly to slow down the - as to - considering slowing down Mr. Kohl, that's a specific matter. But we think that everything as was said in Strasbourg is to be done in the respect of treaties and the principles of Helsinki. Q. Mr. President, my question is addressed to you on Lebanon. If General Aoun refuses to leave, do you approve of a military operation against him, and did you discuss this situation with President Mitterrand? BUSH: We did discuss the Lebanese situation. Both of us want to see a bloodbath avoided there. It is the position of the United States that Mr. Hrawi is the head of government there and recognized as such and that, in our view, things would be much benefited if Mr. Aoun left. . . .

title: Earth Day Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Semaphore Theater Performs Janice Margolis Fantasies
description: Semaphore Dance Theater of Boston offered two imagistic productions by its director, Janice Margolis, on Thursday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace. Both had texts by Thomas Frick and taped collages that blended original scores with sound effects and solemn and frivolous music by various composers. Ms. Margolis's fantasies were often surprising, but not always persuasive.

title: The Remaining Marble Twin
description: To the Editor:

title: The Private War of Tom Cruise
description: Like so many American kids of his generation, Tom Cruise came of age after America's fall in the war in Vietnam. Tet, My Lai, Cambodia, Kent State: To him these were just names, vague and confusing, void of any historical or emotional charge. The war was simply not part of his concerns or his consciousness. What the Vietnam War was all about, what the war did to America, what it did to thousands of Vietnam veterans who came home crippled and in wheelchairs; all these young Tom Cruise knew little or nothing about. By his own admission, when it came to Vietnam he was a total innocent.

title: AMERICA'S RADIATION VICTIMS
description: Los Alamos, N.M., is 25 miles from the Pueblo Indian Reservation communities of Santa Clara and San Ildefonso. I was raised at Santa Clara during the 1950's, and my grandfather, grandmother, father and mother all worked at Los Alamos. Scores of Indians were employed there during (and after) the time it was a ''closed atomic city,'' although Mr. Honicker probably would not have found many references to this in the hidden files.

title: India Premier Praised for His Cabinet
description: When India's ninth democratically elected Parliament is called into session on Monday, Prime Minister V. P. Singh will bring with him a Cabinet that by most accounts has been constructed with imagination and skill.

title: Food Bank Settles Into New Home
description: LEAD: AFTER wandering from place to place, the Connecticut Food Bank, the largest in the state, has found a new home. Now, its director says, all it has to do is to fill it.

title: Campus Life: Bard; Parietal Rules Under Attack At Special School
description: A group of students at Simon's Rock, part of Bard College, is fighting the parietal rules against nonresident students' staying overnight in single-sex freshmen dormitories. The administration is showing signs of retreat.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Baseball: Nolan Ryan. Hockey: Wayne Gretzky. Football: Joe Montana. Tennis: Martina Navratilova. Basketball: Magic Johnson. Track and Field: Edwin Moses. My choice: Montana. THAYER SWALLEN Fairfield, Conn.

title: Birthday Gala for N.A.A.C.P. Draws Stars and Sables
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, remembers a time when the only blacks at major hotels were those serving ''white folks.''

title: Julie Simone Brill Weds Mark Miller
description: Julie Simone Brill, an assistant attorney general of Vermont, and Mark Edward Miller, an industrial designer, were married yesterday at the Mountain Top Inn in Chittenden, Vt. Tom Voity, a justice of the peace in Chittenden, officiated.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Martina Navratilova. Her phenomenal ability elevated interest in women's tennis so it now has as much visibility as the men's game. And recently, she has made the transition from unbeatable dynamo to aging underdog with wit and grace. SARA DZIKIEWICZ Long Island City

title: Miss Perlstein to Wed Dr. L. B. Lusk
description: The engagement of Marcia Harriet Perlstein to Dr. Lawrence Bradley Lusk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Lusk of White Plains, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Perlstein of Oakland, Calif. A March wedding is planned.

title: Eastern Europe Awaits the Storm
description: THE future of capitalism in Eastern Europe could be in Andzrej Bialous's chicken coop. Mr. Bialous, an energetic, raw-boned mechanical engineer, has moved several cutting and stitching machines into the former chicken house where four of his employees piece together flimsy plastic pocketbooks that are best sellers in the Ukraine.

title: CONSUMER RATES
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: When Harry Met Sally . . . 1989. Nelson/Orion. $89.98. Laser disk. $24.95. 1 hour 36 minutes. Closed captioned. R. On and off for 11 years - beginning in college in the late 60's -Harry (Billy Crystal) and Sally (Meg Ryan) ostensibly debate whether men and women can be nonsexual friends. But that issue instantly evaporates and the question becomes: When will they realize they were made for each other? ''What Harry and Sally do in the meantime - the true focus of this often funny but amazingly hollow film - is saunter through the romanticized lives of intelligent, successful, neurotic New Yorkers.'' Rob Reiner has made ''the sitcom version of a Woody Allen film, full of amusing lines and scenes, all infused with an uncomfortable sense of deja vu.'' (Caryn James) Star Trek V: The Final Frontier 1989. Paramount. No listed price. LD. $29.95. 1:47. CC. PG. An aberrant, emotional Vulcan with a holy man's long white robe and a crazed zealot's gleam in his eyes (Laurence Luckinbill) is determined to take over the Starship Enterprise and lead it through a new frontier to enter an Edenic place where God awaits. Because the actors (William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, DeForest Kelley) ''are tireless and sincere in their roles,'' the film ''has its appealing moments'' and the director, Mr. Shatner, keeps it ''just this side of camp. . . . But true fans may be disappointed that the film's profuse plot waters down its familiar texture.'' (James) Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown 1988. Orion. $79.98. LD. $39.95. 1:38. R. Pepa's longtime lover, a male chauvinist rat, walks out on her, leaving only a bland message on her answering machine. Planning suicide, Pepa (Carmen Maura) spikes a blenderful of garden-fresh gazpacho with sleeping pills, but forgets to drink it. Her best friend, who has been having a blissful affair with a man she didn't realize was a Shiite terrorist, comes by looking for refuge from the police. ''These are only some of the delirious ingredients in this most entertaining, deliberately benign Spanish farce.'' Pedro Almodovar's film ''has much of the cheeringly mad intensity of animated shorts produced in Hollywood before the television era.'' (Vincent Canby) Renegades 1989. MCA. $89.95. LD. $34.98. 1:45. CC. R. Kiefer Sutherland plays a Philadelphia cop who infiltrates a high-powered gang of criminals to expose the dishonest policeman they've bought off. During the gang's escape from a jewel robbery, they kill Lou Diamond Phillips's brother and tear off with a lance that is sacred to the Lakota Sioux tribe. Mr. Sutherland and Mr. Phillips team up to find the killer and retrieve the lance. ''It is a fast, violent, implausible film about mismatched partners, and though it doesn't exactly break the bounds of its trashy genre, it's not at all bad for what it is.'' (James) Lock Up 1989. I.V.E. $89.95. 1:55. R. Frank Leone (Sylvester Stallone), a lug with a trusting hangdog loy

title: Veteran Denied a Medal Sadly Vows to Fight On
description: David Rubitsky, his hands trembling slightly as he read from a handwritten statement on lined notebook paper, today rebutted the Army's finding that he was simply an honorable old soldier with a foggy memory.

title: Plan for AIDS Testing In Prison Raises Questions
description: A RECENT proposal by the State Department of Corrections to make AIDS testing available to all state prisoners on a voluntary basis raises vexing medical, ethical and financial issues for prison and health care officials, experts say.

title: Review/Music; Richard Goode's Pianism
description: What makes Richard Goode such a splendid chamber-music pianist, I think, is not an anonymous personality, but - to the contrary - the restrictions on his own personal passions imposed by those around him.

title: Sasha L. Iglehart, Editor, Will Marry Michael Richardson, Student, in June
description: June wedding plans for Sasha Lonsdale Iglehart and Michael Elliot Richardson have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Corning Iglehart of Glyndon, Md. Mr. Richardson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot L. Richardson of McLean, Va.

title: Pastimes: Gardening; A Few Questions on Their Minds
description: Gardeners ask questions. As they plant and grow different kinds of plants, they learn. Some are answered; others are not. Gathered here are the most frequently asked questions. But one answer is never final; what works for one may not work for another. The fun is in the learning.

title: F. J. Gillis Affianced To Lisa Guglielmone
description: A March wedding is planned by Lisa Kathleen Guglielmone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tito Walter Guglielmone of Oakdale, L.I., and Frederick Joseph Gillis, a son of Miriam R. Gillis of Detroit and the late Judge Joseph Augustus Gillis Jr. Ms. Guglielmone, 28 years old, graduated from Cornell University and received an M.B.A. degree from New York University. She is a data-base marketing manager for Philip Morris USA in New York. Her father is the director of curriculum for the five public schools in the Herricks School District in New Hyde Park, L.I. Her mother, Virginia Guglielmone, teaches mathematics at Sayville (L.I.) High School.

title: THE WAY IT SHOULD BE REMEMBERED
description: I recently spent two weeks in Charleston, S.C., where I was a volunteer with the American Red Cross Hurricane Hugo relief effort (''The Way It Should Be Remembered,'' by Blanche McCrary Boyd, Nov. 19). Never having visited Charleston before, I had no memory of how things had been before the storm. I knew surely that the shattered ancient oaks, shorn veranda and acres of mangled countryside were not the norm, but I pushed my reaction to these things aside in the urgency of attending to the needs of the population. These became my images of Hurricane Hugo: new mattresses and box springs, new shoes and clothing, dentures, eyeglasses, a stove, a refrigerator. When I returned to New York and people asked me what it was like - how bad it was - I told them about the mattresses and dentures.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 19 about donating unwanted books gave the hours of the Bryn Mawr Book Shop in New York City incorrectly. The shop is open Thursday through Saturday from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., and on Sunday from 12:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M.

title: March Wedding For Ms. Poorvu
description: Alison Poorvu, an assistant director of admissions at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, and Daniel G. Jaffe, a geologist, plan to marry in March. Their engagement was announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Poorvu of Cambridge, Mass.

title: New Museum's Focus Is Agriculture
description: LEAD: THE seed was planted in 1929, when a Flemington farmer, Hiram Deats, donated his grandfather's plow to the New Jersey College of Agriculture. He hoped to encourage the collection of historic agricultural implements that one day might be housed in a permanent museum.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: Never has an individual dominated his sport the way Wayne Gretzky has done over the past 10 years. To break the career scoring record in such a short time, when it took Gordie Howe over 25 years to score the same number of points, is simply unbelievable. GREGG WILLINGER New York

title: With More Machines, That Phone Conversation May Be on Tape
description: A growing number of Americans, accustomed to taping everything from college lectures to television shows, now own answering machines or other devices that allow them to record conversations with their families, friends and business associates.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Not Too Sweet or Sour
description: Remember sweet-and-sour pork? It is one of the first dishes most people over 40 ate at a Chinese restaurant. It was always a Cantonese restaurant; 40 years ago, Szechuan had yet to reach the United States. Actually, the dish was mainly sweet; the vast quantities of sugar and the canned pineapple in heavy syrup disguised whatever sour ingredients had been added. There were always pieces of bell pepper, and sometimes carrots, in the sauce.

title: Sudan Hardens Crackdown on Internal Opponents
description: The junta that squashed a democratically elected government in the Sudan nearly six months ago is toughening its stand against its opponents by imposing death sentences, bombing southern towns in an intensified civil war and saying that it plans to carry out a strict Islamic code.

title: WHERE DID HER LOVE GO?
description: LEAD: CALL HER MISS ROSS The Unauthorized Biography of Diana Ross. By J. Randy Taraborrelli. Illustrated. 585 pp. New York: Birch Lane Press. $21.95.

title: Scientists Out of Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Davis, a Lawyer, Wed to Dr. Ira Wolmer
description: Beth Renee Davis, an associate in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, and Dr. Ira Elliot Wolmer, a cardiology fellow at St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond in West Brighton, S.I., were married last evening. Rabbi Mark Friedman performed the ceremony at Beth Jacob Synagogue in Norwich, Conn.

title: The Winning Ways to Desegregate The Schools
description: THIS fall, Seattle voters narrowly approved, in a nonbinding referendum, a measure asking the school board to stop busing students for racial balance. The vote, which was not as clear as it might look, may symbolize the state of school desgregation these days.

title: THREE WHO HAD MUCHTO SAY TO ONE ANOTHER
description: One of the works of art now on the market that this critic would most like to find in his Christmas stocking is the painting after Veronese by Eugene Delacroix that is now on view at the Salander-O'Reilly Gallery, 20 East 79th Street. The subject is a detail - two bearded heads - from the great ''Marriage at Cana'' by Veronese in the Louvre.

title: Miss Zuckerman To Wed in March
description: March wedding plans for Roberta F. Zuckerman and Peter Hirsch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Hirsch of Harrison, N.Y., and Wayne, Me., have been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zuckerman of New York and Margate, N.J.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Providence;
'Y' Rehabilitating 183 S.R.O.'s
description: LEAD: WITH local, state and Federal funds, the Greater Providence Y.M.C.A., will rehabilitate the single-room-occupancy units in its nine-story building on Broad Street. Work on the $2.9 million project is expected to begin in February or March and take eight months, said Edward R. Di Persio, the Y.M.C.A.

title: Local Hero
description: ALL-AMERICA football players do not develop often on the Brookville, L.I., campus of C. W. Post. But there was one this season. John Lavelis, a senior defensive end, was named to the all-America first team for Division III chosen for Kodak by the American Football Coaches Association. Lavelis and Paul Cioffi, a defensive end from Montclair State, were the only selections from the metropolitan region.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Carry on with the holiday projects such as shopping, decorating, wrapping, mailing, baking, etc, but do not neglect house plants that will need watering, debugging and leaf cleaning with a damp paper towel. Hold back on the use of fertilizer at this time of year as most indoor plants are in a dormant-rest period. Club Moss Wreaths

title: Review/Music; Chamber Quintet's Particular Program
description: Most of the musicians who take part in the summer Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival were trained in New York, live in New York or appear often in New York. So it's not surprising that the city has not seen a group under the Santa Fe banner since 1981. On Wednesday, as part of a national tour, a quintet of musicians presented a program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It was an eccentric program, but there were pieces and performances to enjoy.

title: Review/Music; A Soprano In Debut
description: Darynn Zimmer, a soprano, was presented in her New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening by Joy in Singing, an organization that offers vocal master classes and holds an annual competition. Ms. Zimmer has a lovely voice - compact but amply powered; generally sweet in tone, but dark and sensuous when the music and text require those qualities. She sings with a quick vibrato that is focused and expressively used. And when she is at her best, she conveys a song's essential spirit, both vocally and through her physical demeanor.

title: POSTINGS: Mount Kisco House; Stolen, Seized And Now for Sale
description: The phrase ''hot house'' may come to take on a new and radically different meaning as a result of a series of legal actions in Westchester County involving a large one-family home that was built from stolen materials. The property, at 10 Seth Canyon Drive in Mount Kisco, was seized two months ago by Westchester County after its owner, Wally Dworaczyk, pleaded guilty to stealing the materials used to build the two-story house and was put on probation for five years.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Babylon $535,000 68 Thompson Avenue 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 90-year-old waterfront colonial; sun porch, pool, 1 acre, boathouse; taxes $9,000. Bayport $237,500 6 Marina Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; fireplace, partial basement, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $5,300. Great River $268,000 16 Riviera Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old waterfront ranch; dining room, finished basement; taxes $6,700. Holtsville $137,000 100 10th Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old modular ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,400. Rocky Point $100,000 8 Surf Road 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, den, basement, beach rights; taxes $1,400. Smithtown $217,000 19 Hurtin Boulevard 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $4,700. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. $390,000 3 Torrance Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 21-year-old colonial; c/a, patio, 2-car garage, dining room; taxes $4,707. Stamford, Conn. $437,500 53 Heritage Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; c/a, marble countertops, 1 acre; taxes $4,904. White Plains, N.Y. $339,000 27 Chesley Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split-level; eat-in kitchen, family room, wet bar, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $4,431.

title: Disney Memorabilia Burns
description: Treasured memorabilia from the career of Walt Disney, including early original drawings by the cartoonist and animator, were destroyed in a house fire here Friday. The house, in the Toluca Lake area, about 20 miles northwest of downtown, is owned by William Cottrell, an 83-year-old relative of Mr. Disney by marriage.

title: History's Echoes in a Town Changed by Storms and Wealth
description: RESIDENTS of this seaside town have weighed equity against history - and history has come up light.

title: Nancy Schwartz and Robert Fechtner Are Wed
description: At Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., Nancy Jill Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin P. Schwartz of South Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Robert David Fechtner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Fechtner of Watchung, N.J. Rabbi Barry Greene performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Norman Summers.

title: John M. Alden, Engineer, 66
description: John M. Alden, an engineer and the founder of Alden Electronics, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 66 years old.

title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS
description: DRIVING THE SIDEWINDING ROADS OF THE Kentucky knobs, even the casual observer notices islands of prosperity among the jagged limestone cliffs and river valleys. Many of the peeling clapboard farmhouses of my childhood have been torn down and replaced with brick ranch-style homes. A new truck or car sits in the driveway - at times of day you'd expect the owner to be away at work. A few of the old farmhouses have been lavishly restored, their orgy of Victoriana (beveled glass, wicker porch furniture, gingerbread trim in contrasting colors) standing in jarring contrast to the stark, frugal lines of the houses themselves. Accompanying me along these roads, an elderly friend points. ''Pot houses,'' she sniffs.

title: Campus Life: Cornell; Two Fraternities Are Disciplined After Fatal Fight
description: Cornell University has punished two fraternities after a drunken fistfight on Oct. 5 that resulted in a student's death.

title: Notre Dame Won 8 Titles
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Anjelica Huston's Oscar
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulgaria Is Eager But New to Freedom
description: ACROSS centuries of Turkish domination, decades of iron-fisted Communist rule and a few odd years of Nazi collaboration, Bulgaria's familiarity with democracy has been nodding at best.

title: F.B.I. Said to Lack Proof in Spy Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found no solid evidence in its intensive espionage investigation of Felix S. Bloch, a veteran diplomat, and the agency has significantly scaled back its inquiry in recent days, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Out of the Way! It's 200,000 Miles or Bust
description: ARE you wondering, ''Should I trade in the old clunker or should I endure it a while longer and save on those nagging monthly payments?'' If you have ever wondered what lies beyond 100,000 miles on a car, you can learn from my experience. I chose not to buy up and instead I am helping our trade imbalance by continuing to drive fine American hardware.

title: Review/Music; Choir and Brass Quintet Evoke the Renaissance
description: Vox, a 19-voice choir from Philadelphia, and the Saturday Brass Quintet, a New York ensemble, pooled their resources for a Christmas program at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: Medieval Islam Was a Preserver, Not a Destroyer, of Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: No Aid to Mozambique Rebels, de Klerk Says
description: President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa says his Government has cut off aid to the insurgents in Mozambique, but he acknowledges the possibility that private citizens in South Africa might be helping the rebels.

title: For Weather Volunteer, The Sky's the Limit
description: LEAD: WHEN Bruce Rosenberg awoke on Nov. 28, he knew he was destined to make a mark on history.

title: Taking the Squeak Out of Stairs
description: SQUEAKY stairs are a comfort to some homeowners. Familiar noises on the stairs signal the return of family members, while unfamiliar noises may warn of an intruder.

title: Dinkins and Jackie Mason Meet at Party
description: Rusty Staub, the sports broadcaster, restaurant owner and former baseball star, was going to be there. So was Jackie Mason, the comedian and former star of the television show ''Chicken Soup.'' And so was Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, whom Mr. Mason had disparaged while campaigning for Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor of New York City.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RIDING HIGH. By Emily Brooks. (Poseidon, $19.95.) The horsy set in privileged Edgeville, N.Y., certainly lives soap-opera style. It takes a little while to figure out who everyone is and how they all interrelate. And then it takes a little longer to determine why people who are supposed to be so well off and well educated are living such purposeless, pedestrian lives.

title: CAPITALIST SPIRIT LINGERS IN HAINAN
description: As China's leaders try to tug the nation toward greater central planning and more orthodox Communism, people here on the country's sun-drenched southern frontier are enthusiastically pulling in the other direction.

title: THE PLAYWRIGHT ON HIS HIND LEGS
description: SOME FREAKS By David Mamet. 180 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BARBERSHOP PLUS

title: Farewell Notes to Koch Offer Jobs and Hugs
description: ''You will never be out of the sandhogs' thoughts.''

title: New Shotgun Season Is Termed Unwarranted
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation is jumping the gun, so to speak, when it proposes a new shotgun season for deer in Westchester County [ ''A Shotgun Season for Deer Is Proposed,'' Oct. 29 ] .

title: Vallone Approves Big Raises For Five Top Council Aides
description: Five top staff aides of the New York City Council have received substantial pay increases to the $100,000-a-year level as the legislative body prepares to exercise expanded powers in the new year.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Ellsworth, Me.; 3 Outlets In the Works
description: THREE factory outlet malls proposed for this coastal city of 10,000 represent a new direction for an area that features strip-shopping centers along busy Route 1.

title: N.F.L. Injuries? Fans Know Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. Train, Champagne Class
description: FOR many Americans notions about long-distance train travel have more to do with mythology than memory. While few of us really knew the Santa Fe Super Chief or ever rode the 20th Century Limited, the mere whisper of such names evokes excitement and romance, in the same way we are still stirred by the sound of a faraway locomotive whistle. In our fantasies, trains are travel, not merely transportation. So when the American-European Express began operating last month between Chicago and Washington - four vintage rail coaches rebuilt by hand and coupled to the rear of Amtrak's regularly scheduled Capitol Limited - it generated not only curiosity but also high expectations. With fares at $1,042 for two people sharing a compartment, more than twice the cost of Amtrak's most expensive berth, travelers are not merely buying passage; they are buying a ticket aboard a rolling stage set, a kind of living fantasy of first-class railroad travel, surrounded by leather and Honduran mahogany, china and Belgian damask and attended by a cast of waiters, trainmen and porters in full costume, right down to their epaulets and royal blue shoulder capes.

title: Reviews/Music; New World Symphony, A Youthful Conduit
description: The New World Symphony calls itself America's National Training Orchestra. But the ensemble, of which Michael Tilson Thomas is ''founding conductor and artistic adviser,'' now also counts as Miami's principal orchestra, with the demise several years back of the Florida Philharmonic.

title: West Germany Takes 2-1 Cup Lead
description: Boris Becker and Eric Jelen teamed today to lead West Germany, the defending champion, to a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup final against Sweden.

title: Lysa Flanz Plans A May Wedding
description: The engagement of Lysa Carla Flanz to Robert Daniel Ginsberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ginsberg of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Brenda Flanz Levine of Montreal and Kenneth Flanz of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Why Shopping in Department Stores Is No Fun
description: LEAD: DEAR Retailer:

title: Endowment Embattled Over Academic Freedom
description: New rules intended to force stricter supervision of grants by the National Endowment for the Humanities have led to protests about infringement of academic freedom.

title:
In Season of Giving, the Neediest Case Fund Helps the Giftless;
A Teen-Ager Is Rescued From Suicide
description: LEAD: Gina D.'s mother first knew something was wrong with her daughter when Mrs. D. came home after running errands and Gina said she had something to tell her.

title: Jacqueline Sue Balley Plans a May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Balley of North Hills, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Jacqueline Sue Balley, and Lawrence Marc Glassheim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Glassheim of Merrick, L.I.

title: Will East German Athletes Continue to Dominate?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Redmen Roll Past Manhattan
description: Boo Harvey's new haircut, Malik Sealy's career-high scoring performance and some signs of life from the St. John's bench in the team's last four games were among the highlights last night at Alumni Hall as the Redmen easily defeated Manhattan College, 68-52.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-35 Vaclav Havel may become President of Czechoslovakia until elections are held. The playwright appeared close to an agreement with former Prime Minister Alexander Dubcek to lead the opposition's fight for the vacant post. 1

title: Campus Life: University of Connecticut; Converting Excess Dining Credits to Help Charities
description: It was a combination of charity and protest as 150 University of Connecticut students waited in line last weekend at Jonathan's, one of three fast-food restaurants here on the campus. The students were using the balance on their Vali-Dine cards to help feed the needy and homeless in nearby Willimantic.

title: Cable TV Vs. Consumers: Battleground Emerges
description: THE head of the New York State Consumer Protection Board knows firsthand the escalating costs of cable television service on Long Island. ''I'm a Cablevision subscriber and I now pay $80.20 a month for my cable,'' said Richard Kessel, who has cable hooked up to several television sets in his Bellmore home so he can catch sports and ''News 12, Long Island.''

title: A Bill of Rights for the Disabled Nears Passage
description: LEGISLATION designed to provide equal treatment and broad changes for disabled people in the United States, estimated to number at least 43 million, is expected to be enacted early next year.

title: Escape From the Doomsters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mona L. Kennedy Becomes a Bride
description: Mona Lynn Kennedy was married yesterday to Brian Pfohl Kirby at the Doylestown (Pa.) United Methodist Church by the Rev. Brian Cloud, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. John Davids, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Kennedy Jr. of Holicong, Pa. Mr. Kirby is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kirby of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: THE WELL STOCKED BRAIN ... AND THE OPEN MIND
description: THE GRAYWOLF ANNUAL FIVE: MULTI-CULTURAL LITERACY Edited by Rick Simonson and Scott Walker. 188 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. Paper, $8.50.

title: Collecting Crystal for Pleasure and for Profit
description: In a bid for a share of the upper tier of the crystal market, more and more manufacturers are forming collectors' clubs. Membership buys certain privileges - for instance, the ability to purchase exclusive pieces. But the real intention of these marketing ploys is to lock in collectors to a given brand, thereby increasing the sales of both retailers and manufacturers, which market the clubs together.

title: Miss Hoyt Plans To Wed in March
description: A March wedding is planned by Colleen Marie Hoyt and Charles Richmond Dailey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Dailey of Newtown, Conn., the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Hoyt of Pennington, N.J., have announced.

title: A Craving for the Choicest Glass
description: FEW people keep them under their pillows or massage them like good-luck charms. But the craving for high-priced objects and goblets of cut glass certainly rivals the craze for the fashionable ''new-age'' crystal rocks, especially during this gift-giving season, when 40 percent of all crystal is sold.

title: AND FIRST IN PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: LEAD: THE MAKING OF THE PREFIDENT 1789 The Unauthorized Campaign Biography. By Marvin Kitman. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50

title:
FOCUS: Reno;
A City Betting on a Diversified Downtown
description: LEAD: A HOTEL that once played a significant role in thousands of divorce proceedings now seems destined to have an equally significant role in an effort to marry the two parts of this city's downtown, which lie on opposite sides of the Truckee River.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; Turkish With Flair And Zesty Cuban
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Anatolia

title: Hunts' Assets Will Pay Creditors, Court Rules
description: Long and arduous bankruptcy proceedings for Nelson Bunker Hunt have wound to a close in a crowded Dallas courtroom, ending one of the largest personal bankruptcy cases in American history and leaving Mr. Hunt with a fraction of his former worth.

title: Sydney Solomon To Become a Bride
description: The engagement of Sydney Ann Solomon to Harry N. Neuhaus has been announced by their parents, Dr. and Mrs. Henry A. Solomon of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Peter Neuhaus of West Palm Beach, Fla. A February wedding is planned.

title: Pricier Products for a More Extravagant Buyer
description: To cash in on the consumer craze for high-priced crystal as gifts and collectibles, several manufacturers have moved into the upscale market or broadened their line of prestige products that sell for $500 and up. And to appeal to collectors, they are offering many of these products, from clocks to figurines, on an exclusive basis either by limiting the quantity or the time in which they are available for sale.

title: Line of Greeting Cards For Black Expressions
description: THOUGH Christmas is in just a week, Carole Joy Creations is still receiving last-minute orders for greeting cards. Last year a retailer who had just heard of the company called as late as Dec. 22 to order cards, said Victor M. Gellineau Jr., who handles marketing.

title: Evening Hours; Festivities In the Spirit of the Season
description: Carolers, bell ringers and dancers waving giant paper snowflakes paraded through the marble halls of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue in a burst of holiday joy on Thursday night. An enormous Christmas tree glittering with simulated snow stood tall in Astor Hall.

title: A Search for Volunteers to Transcribe Braille
description: LIKE many organizations that depend on volunteers, the Connecticut Braille Association is finding fewer people who are willing to work as volunteers, to transcribe books into Braille.

title: THE WAY IT SHOULD BE REMEMBERED
description: I cried when I saw the first pictures of Hugo's devastation, and cried again when I read Blanche McCrary Boyd's essay about her visit to Charleston after the hurricane. To those of us who were born and reared there, Charleston will always be home.

title: Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
description: The American diver Greg Louganis. Since 1976, he has won four Olympic gold medals, 47 American titles, and 120 of 153 major events. Beyond that, in this decade of million-dollar earnings and cocaine and steroid abuse scandals, Louganis exemplifies the true spirit of competition and the beauty of sport. ELIZABETH GREENSTEIN New York

title: Hoyas Win By 73 Points
description: Georgetown scored the final 21 points of the first half today and went on to beat the University of the District of Columbia by 112-39, the third-largest margin of victory in school history.

title: A Holiday of Lace for All Year-Round
description: WHITE lace, with its snowy patterns, evokes a winter holiday spirit. For Michelle Anderson, who owns La Dentelliere in Scarsdale, however, lace has no season. ''There is always a holiday for something,'' she said, as she showed customers items like doilies and napkins that are popular yearlong.

title: Card Anxiety: Seasonal Malaise
description: AS the holiday season begins, I always become a victim of Christmas Card Anxiety, a tension that begins the day after Thanksgiving and continues right through Twelfth Night, when I figure the formal holiday season is over.

title:
FOCUS: RENO;
Reno Is Seeking Less Dependence On Its Gambling
description: LEAD: A hotel that once played a significant role in thousands of divorce proceedings now seems destined to have an equally significant role in an effort to marry the two parts of this city's downtown, which lie on opposite sides of the Truckee River.

title: WHEN PRACTICE REFUSES TO MAKE PERFECT
description: The news arrived by fax, as news so often does these days, but it echoed nostalgically from a past seemingly long gone. The Philadelphia Orchestra regretfully announced that ''Transfigured Notes'' by Milton Babbitt had been dropped from a subscription program beginning Dec. 7 and would be replaced by another Babbitt score, ''Composition for 12 Instruments.''

title: The BBC Faces Up to Technology - and the Till
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation knows it is going to be in business at least thorugh 1996.

title: Cockney Cuisine: Eel, Pie and Mash
description: SUSAN HALL sits on a wooden bench in S. R. Kelly and Sons, an eel and pie shop in London's East End and, with shining blue eyes, surveys the plate before her. An oblong meat pie with a flaky and ''ever-so-luverly'' brown crust dominates one half of the plate. Next to it lies a huge dollop of mashed potatoes, swimming in a green-flecked sea of parsley sauce, or ''liquor.''

title: Mexico's Colonial Heart
description: IN many ways, the geographic heart of Mexico is also its spiritual and cultural heart. Dotted with elegant colonial cities and villages that still hew to traditional folkways and crafts, the area extending in an arc west and north of the capital is rich both in character and history. And unlike the Yucatan or the resorts of the Pacific Coast, the states of Michoacan, Guanajuato and Queretaro are readily accessible from Mexico City, equally appealing whether visited in a series of small excursions or in a single leisurely swing with pauses along the road to savor the colonial highlands.

title: New York's Christmas House
description: In this holiday season the best-decorated house in New York has only a few simple wreaths in its windows, no Christmas tree and no garlands. What is on its walls is glorious beyond reckoning. True, the walls of the Frick Collection, at Fifth Avenue and 70th Street, are glorious all year round. But they're even more so right now, with 17 paintings on loan from Fort Worth's Kimbell Art Museum hanging in the glass-vaulted courtyard.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; A Year to Make The Selection For Housing
description: To insure what it calls a more diverse experience in the freshman year, a committee named by Provost John Deutsch has recommended a plan to delay the selection of housing choices at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Realizing the Rights of the Disabled
description: WITH the passage of a powerful new disability rights law virtually certain, attention has shifted from its political prospects to its worldly consequences. A Senate supporter has vowed that it will emancipate millions of disabled people who spend their lives ''overcoming not what God wrought but what man imposed by custom and law.'' But it's what legislators have wrought and what courts may impose that concerns skeptics in the business community. While they endorse the bill's aim, many say they're worried about vague and potentially costly obligations.

title: Israelis Say a Missing Airman Is Held by Iran
description: The wife of an Israeli airman taken prisoner in 1986 by Shiite militiamen in southern Lebanon said today that her husband is now in the custody of the Iranian authorities. Asked about the woman's assertion, a senior Israeli military official in Jerusalem said tonight: ''It's true. I can confirm it, and we are calling on Iran to release him.''

title: THE CASE AGAINST GREED
description: LEAD: DANGEROUS PURSUITS Mergers & Acquisitions in the Age of Wall Street. By Walter Adams and James W. Brock. 208 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: Susan H. Diker To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram J. Diker of Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Helen Diker, to William Mark Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervyn M. Levine of Winnipeg, Canada. An April wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
Uncommon Italian Dishes in Armonk
description: LEAD: MADDALENA, in the trim roadside house last occupied by Le Gueridon, brings to the area a distinctive menu listing a number of dishes out of the common run of Italian restaurant food. The Ligurian chef and co-owner Gino Izetta comes from San Remo, a bustling port city on the Italian Riviera. And the kitchen reflects not only the subtler dishes associated with the north of Italy but also heartier renditions demanded by seafarers docked in this

title:
THE VIEW FROM: B. ALTMAN;
Employees and the Faithful Will Remember
description: LEAD: AT first glance the banners seemed to be part of the Christmas decor: red with white lettering, hanging next to greenery dotted with tiny white lights. Then you look more closely and see the words: ''Going out of business sale - Closing our doors forever''; Everything must go, regardless of cost''; ''All sales final, no refunds or exchanges.

title: A New Center Heals Chronic Wounds
description: FOR nearly 100 years, Mount Vernon Hospital has been an integral part of the small city for which it is named. A bit run-down by the most modern standards, the hospital is nevertheless viewed with pride -even affection - by many old-timers. It is, after all, the place where local children are born and where the sick and elderly have traditionally sought remedies for what ails them.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ICE SCULPTURE

title: Keeping Pace as Family Problems Change
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago, with just one counselor on a budget of $26,000, Family Service of Westchester began helping families cope.

title: Texas Justice
description: Texas has put 33 people to death since it resumed executions in December 1982. Clarence Lee Brandley twice came within days of being a 34th - even though the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals now says that his 1981 conviction for rape and murder was a ''subversion of justice.''

title: Dickens's 'Carol,' Staged a Capella
description: CHARLES DICKENS'S ''Christmas Carol'' is perfect holiday fare. The problem for most theaters is finding ways to present this venerable classic so that audiences will continue to come back season after season.

title: 37 Arts Groups to Share $14 Million
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced this week that it was awarding $14 million in challenge grants to 37 cultural organizations, including 9 in New York City, to support long-range projects of special artistic merit.

title: Teamster Denies Fighting U.S. Through His Union
description: A high-ranking Ohio teamster official denied Friday that he took part in his own union's attempt to thwart the Government's disciplinary action against him.

title: Journeying Into a World Of Arab Music
description: Any listener whose interest in Western classical music extends beyond superficial ''music appreciation'' to a concern with origins, formal principles and stylistic evolution must sooner or later come to grips with the rich musical heritage of the Arab world.

title: No Leading Role
description: THE MOST IMPORTANT weapon in my arsenal,'' Joseph Stalin was quoted as saying, ''is the dictionary.''

title: POSTINGS: TriBeCa Condos; 2-for-1 Renovation
description: In an unusual renovation, a block-through building in TriBeCa that has a cast-iron facade on one side has been divided in two to carve eight apartments and three stores out of the structure. The $5.5 million condominium project involves a five-story building with the address 129 Duane Street on its south side - the one with the cast-iron front - and 54 Thomas Street on the north. It is in the midblock west of Church Street and had previously been used for offices.

title: Review/Dance; Painterly Evocations in Dunn Pieces
description: Set, costumes and lighting blended with motion to magical effect in an evening of dance by Douglas Dunn, seen on Dec. 9 at Mr. Dunn's SoHo loft. Mimi Gross's vivid set and Carol Mullins's painterly lighting were so right that the dance often looked designed to animate that imaginative landscape. Given Mr. Dunn's abiding sense of irony, that might even have been his aim.

title: When The Patient Is a Parent
description: THE phone call was a surprise. I had spoken with my mother earlier in the day. Her doctor had indicated the chest pain was caused by pneumonia but the prescribed antibiotics were working, her fever was down and she felt better. Then my brother called to report she had increasing chest pain and was fearful of being alone. The tone of his voice suggested an effort not to alarm me but his message was an unmistakeable cry for help. ''I'm not sure what to do,'' he said.

title: UNLOCKING THE RABBIS' SECRETS
description: THE TALMUD The Steinsaltz Edition. Volume One: Tractate Bava Metzia, Part One. Commentary by Adin Steinsaltz. Translated and edited by Israel V. Berman. 252 pp. New York: Random House. $40. THE TALMUD The Steinsaltz Edition. A Reference Guide. By Adin Steinsaltz. 323 pp. New York: Random House. $40.

title: MENCKEN'S DIARIES: SUSTAINED BY SCORN AND BEER
description: H.L. MENCKEN made the first entry in his diary on Nov. 5, 1930. The great journalist, critic and editor was 50 years old, just married for the first time and, as Charles A. Fecher, the editor of the diary, tells us, deeply, romantically in love with his wife, Sara. It's ironic that Mencken began his diary in the first year of a new decade. The one that had just ended had been his in a very real sense. During the 1920's, he had established himself as the most powerful and original force in American literary criticism, a force that might be admired or detested but could not possibly be ignored. In the 30's, his popularity would decline sharply, his influence diminish, his career founder. His beloved Sara would die, leaving a terrible void. But the initial entries in his diary display him at the top of his form - gleefully heaping scorn on some of his favorite targets. Nov. 6, 1930

title: DIPLOMATS STEP UP DRIVE IN CAMBODIA
description: With warfare continuing inside Cambodia after the announced departure of Vietnamese troops, diplomatic activity to resolve the war is increasing again, with a senior Australian Foreign Ministry official arriving here on Sunday and a Soviet delegation expected next week.

title: New Delay for Shuttle Flight
description: A lag in preparations has caused the next launching of the space shuttle Columbia to be delayed one more day, until next Thursday, the space agency announced Friday. The latest change came two days after shuttle managers had decided on a two-day postponement.

title: Anticipated Life: How Long, O Lord?
description: ''Why no, I don't mind waiting. It seems to me I've been here no time at all. Is Carter still President?''

title: DUBCEK EXPECTED TO SUPPORT HAVEL IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: Vaclav Havel, the playwright and opposition leader, and Alexander Dubcek appeared close to an agreement tonight that would lead to Mr. Havel's becoming temporary President of Czechoslovakia until national elections could be held.

title: Two Cultures Clash In a Film on Iranians
description: LEAD: IN an opening scene of ''The Suitors,'' a wry tragicomedy that will be screened Tuesday through Saturday at the New Community Cinema in Huntington, the New York City skyline looms incongruously before a sheep being transported from the bucolic countryside in the back seat of a spotless station wagon.

title: Susan Edler to Wed
description: Susan Edler and Leonard Jarvis Wyeth are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Klaus W. Edler of Cornwall, Conn., have announced. Miss Edler, an architect at Centerbrook (Conn.) Architects, graduated from St. Margaret's School in Bushey, Hertford, England, and the Rhode Island School of Design. Mr. Wyeth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Wyeth of Lakeville, Conn., graduated from the Brooks School and Syracuse University. He received a master's degree in architecture from the University of Virginia and is an associate at Centerbrook.

title: Surprise In Big 11
description: THE Big Ten may be an athletic conference, but as its athletic directors may be discovering, it is not they but the university presidents who call the signals.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Kidnapped Words According to Thomas Mallon, plagiarism shocks us because it is the only case in which we can know where a writer's words actually came from. This is from ''Stolen Words'' (Ticknor & Fields).

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about a visit by American officials to Beijing misstated Qian Qichen's title. He is China's Foreign Minister, not Prime Minister.

title: Postema Blazed Trail For Somebody Else
description: IT didn't work out for Pam Postema. She came as close as any woman has ever come to being an umpire in the major leagues, but last week they let her go. There is no next step for her.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Dec. 3 with an article about Tampa misstated the basis for calculating taxi fares. After the initial 95 cents, the fare is $1.50 for each mile, not kilometer.

title: Competitiveness Begins at School
description: AMERICAN businessmen must be smarting from the Japanese critique of our industrial and educational systems made as part of Japanese-American trade negotiations. I know that I am. If ever a challenge was issued to American educators and business people, this was it. Without subtlety, the Japanese told us that we are not likely to be competitive in the world economy of the future because we are failing to educate our youth.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
Orchestra to Get A New Home
description: LEAD: THE Philadelphia Orchestra Association has announced plans for a $95 million hall one block south of the Academy of Music, the orchestra's home since it was founded in 1900. The 2,800-seat hall, designed by the Philadelphia architectural concern Venturi Scott Brown & Associates, will be at Broad and Spruce Streets, a primarily commercial area about five blocks south of City Hall.

title: Record Rainfall a Mixed Blessing
description: LEAD: IT should come as little surprise to those Long Islanders still trying to dry out their waterlogged basements that this year's torrential rainfall, amounting to more than 71 inches, washed away a 120-year-old record.

title: Some New England Finales to Holiday Dinners
description: ''JASPER WHITE'S Cooking From New England'' (Harper & Row, $27.95) is a timely new addition to the cookbook shelf. The owner of Jasper's in Boston has assembled a collection of traditional and contemporary New England recipes, many of which make for mouth-watering holiday fare.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: From Ashes, Stained Glass

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Enfield, Conn. $133,000 515 George Washington Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, remodeled 28-year-old ranch; new kitchen, in-ground pool; taxes $1,353. Hamden, Conn. $125,000 99 Valley Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; finished attic and basement, gas heat; taxes $1,440. Stamford, Conn. $437,500 53 Heritage Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; c/a, marble countertops, 1 acre; taxes $4,904. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $438,000 248 Pine Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 33-year-old ranch; family room, finished basement w/playroom and workshop, 1.6 acres; taxes $7,861. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $950,000 Old Stone Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old rebuilt contemporary; 3 fireplaces, den, family room, stone terrace, porch, pond, 3.2 acres; taxes not yet assessed. White Plains, N.Y. $339,000 27 Chesley Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split-level; eat-in kitchen, family room, wet bar, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $4,431. OTHER AREAS Short Hills, N.J. $420,000 55 Athens Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 39-year-old split level; den, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $6,754. South Orange, N.J. $415,000 491 Mayhew Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old Tudor; fireplace, porch, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $6,804. Smithtown, L.I. $217,000 19 Hurtin Boulevard 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $4,700.

title: Lisa Piscitello Weds Whitney Talcott
description: Lisa Marie Piscitello and Whitney Agnew Talcott were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn., by the Rev. David W. Good. The bride is a daughter of Mary L. Piscitello of New London, Conn., and the late Robert A. Piscitello. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Agnew Allen Talcott of Old Lyme and the late Mr. Talcott.

title: The Military Math of Peace in Our Time
description: FOR four decades, the Pentagon has based its budgets, its strategy and its public relations largely on one premise: the Russians are coming. But now the Russians are going, and the Pentagon is experiencing the painful process of adjusting to the new military reality.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE wind had fallen during the night and with it the temperature - through the 30's, the 20's, into the teens by morning. Two areas of open water remained on the frozen reservoir, one large, one small. The larger one was host to an assortment of gulls and waterfowl. The smaller one held a single small diving bird.

title: Boston Post Road Offers ''Mistress of the Inn''
description: DO not dismiss the Boston Post Road Stage Company on the evidence of the current cheerless production of ''The Mistress of the Inn.'' The dauntless little professional theater in Fairfield has considerable virtues, but playing classic comedy just is not one of them.

title: Goldin to Open a Financial Consulting Firm
description: Harrison J. Goldin, who failed dismally in his attempt to spring from the City Comptroller's office to the mayoralty, plans to open a financial consulting firm specializing in advising troubled businesses and municipalities.

title: AMERICA'S RADIATION VICTIMS
description: The following is from a letter my father wrote to me in 1981: ''In 1956, I went to Nevada to a field test of an atomic shot. It was a 28-kiloton shot and we were in the trenches at three miles from ground zero. . . . The ground rolled like the waves in the ocean, and the flash was so bright that, with my eyes closed and with my head cradled in my arm and my arm resting on my leg, I could see every bone in my arm and legs like you see in an X-ray picture. This lasted for a minute or so. The shock waves were unbelievable - so powerful.''

title: Laura M. MestelWeds F.E. Rubin
description: The marriage of Laura M. Mestel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Mestel of Bayside, Queens, to Frederick E. Rubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton R. Rubin of Woodmere, L.I., took place last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: Poster of a Nude Stirs East Hampton
description: LEAD: A DIET poster featuring a photograph of an enormously fat naked woman has prompted a First Amendment dispute in quiet wintertime East Hampton.

title: A BROTHER'S DEATH
description: I felt a grief similar to that of Ms. Ascher when I read her article. I am a 21-year-old man, attending college in New York, and I am also gay. With these circumstances in my life, the horror and despair caused by AIDS is a reality that I must face every day.

title: East Germans to Sell Secrets To Maintain Sports Program
description: The sports secrets that have given East Germany hundreds of Olympic medals are on the block.

title: Style Makers; Leslie Hope Derene, Photographer
description: Leslie Hope Derene studied historic preservation at Boston University and spent eight years working in the fashion industry before finding her true calling. She now takes photographs and mounts them on gift and note cards, holiday ornaments and portfolios.

title: BENIN GOVERNMENT IS GROWING FRAGILE
description: This was to have been a week of celebration in this sliver of West Africa as workers removed the cover protecting a new bronze statue of Lenin.

title: POSTINGS: The Metropolitan Club; Facade Mudpack
description: The Metropolitan Club, which moved into its building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and East 60th Street 95 years ago, is cleaning the exterior of the landmarked property, which was designed by Stanford White. More than $1 million is being spent to dissolve as many as five layers of paint on the marble exterior, and then slather it with a chemical poultice to remove stains caused by the reaction between air pollutants and impurities in the stone.

title: The Single Solitary Only Child
description: ''THE only child gets whatever he or she wants.'' Of all the stereotypical statements attached to the label only child, this one is probably the furthest from the truth.

title: Ramos Hurt Critically
description: Ramon Ramos, a Portland Trail Blazer forward and former star at Seton Hall, was listed in extremely critical condition late today with brain damage suffered early this morning in a car accident. Ramos, a 22-year-old forward who was activated by the Trail Blazers 10 days ago after a knee injury, had not appeared in a National Basketball Association game. Dr. Kim Burchiel, chairman of University Hospital's neurosurgery department, said there was evidence of damage to areas of the brain involving movement. ''It is not clear that he's going to survive,'' the doctor said. The Oregon state police said Ramos was alone and driving north on Interstate 5 about 3:15 A.M. when he apparently struck a patch of ice.

title: STREETSCAPES: The View Down Fifth Avenue; Tower Now Blocks the Prospect
description: IT was the most evanescent of unofficial landmarks, a haphazard alignment of buildings spanning half a century along a mile-long stretch of Fifth Avenue. The view south toward the Empire State Building - actually a gradually rising succession of buildings - was long familiar to tourists and New Yorkers walking down the avenue along Central Park from as far north as the Cooper-Hewitt Museum at 91st Street.

title: Beatrice Minkus Hessen, Editor, 52
description: Beatrice Hessen, an editor of her father's well-known philatelic journal, died of cancer on Thursday at her home in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 52 years old.

title: RITES OF DEFIANCE
description: LIVES OF COURAGE Women for a New South Africa. By Diana E. H. Russell. Illustrated. 375 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH NEW EXPORT RULES FOR EASTERN BLOC
description: Reflecting the dramatic improvement in East-West relations, the international agency that controls technological exports to the Eastern bloc is close to the most significant relaxation of rules in its 40-year history, Bush Administration officials said this week.

title: Greeting Cards Fashioned For Black Expressions
description: THOUGH Christmas is in just a week, Carole Joy Creations in Danbury is still receiving last-minute orders for greeting cards. Last year a retailer who had just heard of the company called as late as Dec. 22 to order cards, said Victor M. Gellineau Jr., who handles marketing.

title: Who Done It?
description: The body of a lion, the head of a man and now the center of controversy. A panel of antiquities experts in Egypt recently concluded that a 700-pound chunk that fell from the shoulder of the Sphinx last year was dislodged by natural forces - wind, rain and salt. But then along came Larry Hunter, an otherwise unidentified American. Mr. Hunter recently presented authorities in Cairo with a videotape of the confession of a guard who said he saw two antiquities officials hammering at the Sphinx's shoulder before the chunk was dislodged. Ridiculous, said one expert after another, including the two who were accused. Some suggested that the whole incident had more to do with old enmities between experts. It seems that Ahmed Khari, who was in charge of restoring the Sphinx until he was fired after the shoulder separation, has had profound personal differences with Farouk Hosni, the Minister of Culture, whose portfolio includes Egypt's antiquities. The unspoken implication seemed to be that if the guard's confession was true, Mr. Khari was fired unjustly. In any case, Mr. Hosni ordered the investigation into the matter reopened.

title: Giants Gain Playoffs With Easy Victory
description: The last time the Giants made the playoffs was three seasons ago, and they won Super Bowl XXI. Today, they made the playoffs again.

title:
TRACK AND FIELD;
LaGuardia Junior Wins 2 in Loughlin
description: LEAD: Nasville Peart, a 16-year-old junior at La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts, won the boys' 55-meter dash in 6.3 seconds, a tenth of a second off the meet record, for his second victory in the 36th annual Bishop Loughlin indoor track and field games yesterday at Draddy Gym at Manhattan College.

title: Zarin Mehta to Head Ravinia Music Festival
description: Zarin Mehta, the managing director of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, has been named executive director and chief operating officer of the Ravinia Music Festival, the summer home of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, in Highland Park, Ill.

title: Class Learns to Cope With Conflict
description: ON a recent morning, Naomi Drew gathered her kindergarten and first-grade class at the Cambridge School around her on the floor to talk about how learning to solve problems with the children's peers could make the world a better place.

title: Campus Life: Wellesley; Condom Jewelry Makes a Point For AIDS Alert
description: Students at Wellesley College have a new gift-giving option this holiday season. Condom jewelry was sold for $1 at the Student Center for two days last week by AIDS Alert, a student group dedicated to raising AIDS awareness. Each condom packet is decorated with glitter and paint and has hardware attached to make it either a pin or an earring.

title: A Small Flotilla of Unanchored Anchors
description: Some months ago, NBC ran a full-page advertisement that asked if it mattered whether the anchor of a nightly news program was this fellow or that. The ad's unastonishing answer was that it mattered a lot and that NBC's own man Tom Brokaw was the anchor of choice. Unfortunately for NBC, that does not seem to be the opinion of most viewers. For the last three months, ABC's ''World News Tonight,'' with Peter Jennings, has either led the three-man pack in ratings or, at worst, tied with the ''CBS Evening News,'' anchored by Dan Rather. ''NBC Nightly News'' is third and last. The figures are close: Last month, ABC's ''World News Tonight'' was watched in 10.9 percent of the nation's 92.1 million homes with television sets; CBS's ''Evening News'' was watched in 10.3 percent and NBC's ''Nightly News'' in 9.9 percent. But every decimal represents a lot of consumers and a lot of advertising revenue.

title: THE DACHSHUND THAT KILLED STALIN
description: ASTROPHOBIA By Sasha Sokolov. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 385 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $21.50.

title: Margot L. Fuchs,Student, Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Fuchs of Tenafly, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Margot Lynn Fuchs, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Yeshiva University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Marc Alan Schwartz, a third-year student at Columbia University Law School. Mr. Schwartz is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Schwartz of Holmdel, N.J.

title: Ron Kovic Today: Warrior at Peace
description: ''It was an incredible experience,'' Ron Kovic said of watching Tom Cruise portray him on the set of ''Born on the Fourth of July'' in Dallas last year. ''I was looking at myself live through the most difficult periods of my life. I was forced to deal with the reality of the hell that I had lived through in a way that I never dealt with it before.''

title: POSTINGS: L.I. Shopping Center; Out of the Ashes . . .

Construction is expected to start on the $20 million, 147,000-square-foot retail project next spring, with completion scheduled for late next year.

title: Playoffs Keep Parcells Awake
description: Two weeks ago, after the Giants lost to the Philadelphia Eagles, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said he slept well. After Saturday's convincing 15-0 victory over the Dallas Cowboys, Parcells said he could not sleep well and was in his office today at 6:30 A.M.

The Case of an Actor Who Loves His Craft
description: It was about noon, mid-December, with the sun rudely shining and the Manhattan sidewalks as cold and hard as Bogart with Mary Astor. I was wearing my navy blue sports jacket, with gray slacks, light blue shirt, red tie, black loafers, black wool socks without dark blue clocks on them. I was neat, clean, shaved and sober, and I didn't care who knew it. I was everything the well-dressed journalist ought to be. I was calling on James Naughton, the guy who's received huzzahs for his acting and singing as Stone, the Raymond Chandleresque detective in the new hit musical ''City of Angels.''

description: EXPERTS try furiously to explain why the United States is in decline as a manufacturing center while Japan and West Germany flourish. The blame has fallen heavily on the work force (inadequately educated), consumers (wasteful spenders) and the Government (lacks a trade policy). Now a new explanation is becoming popular - the high cost of capital - and like the others, it provides some useful insights.

title: Skyline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bronx the Newly Chic Is Celebrated in Word, On Film and on Stage
description: Suddenly, it is more than just a place: it is a fictional domain, as exotic as it is mysterious. The pull of its ethnic gravity is so powerful that it is inspiring a new generation of writers, playwrights and film makers to portray the life of its neighborhoods. So compelling is its geography that a cluster of recent book, film and theater reviews has actually used the word ''romantic'' in describing it. What is this magical terrain? The Bronx.

title: North Point Seeks Buyer
description: Beset by rumors that North Point Press has been sold or is closing, its officers acknowledged on Friday that they are seeking a buyer. But in a statement, the officers of the Berkeley, Calif., publishing house denied that it was in financial difficulty.

title: India's Homespun Chic (Nothing Imported)
description: It was probably inevitable that in the high-tech era that has now gone down in history as ''Rajiv's India,'' someone would find a way to put a gloss on ethnicity.

title: Deep in December, It's Time to Go After the Ruffed Grouse
description: Although it is legal to hunt ruffed grouse deep into winter in much of the Northeast, few do so. As summer wanes and the first frosts arrive in late September or early October, the grouse hunter begins to chafe at the bit. He is waiting for a gale and rain to rip the leaves from their moorings, making it possible for him to see a grouse, or a woodcock, when it goes aloft through the ''bare, ruined choirs where late the sweet birds sang.''

title: Montreal Shuts Out Stumbling Rangers
description: From the season's start, the Rangers had complained about the ice at Madision Square Garden. It stole their speed, they argued nightly, and played with their passes.

description: ''Gorbachev is a kind of mysterious personality to me,'' Andrei D. Sakharov said on Thursday, a few hours before he died.

description: IN grainy, tactile black-and-white, the Mick crunches one of his 536 home runs. For those of a certain age, as comfortable now in front of their television sets as they once were in the bleachers, it is yesterday again.

description: The principal newspaper publishers in New York State have pledged to increase their use of recycled paper from the current level of 7 percent of all paper to 40 percent by the year 2000, state officials announced last week.

title: Bethel Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sports of The Times; To 49ers' Jeff Fuller, 'It's a Miracle'
description: ON a Sunday afternoon a few weeks ago, Jeff Fuller was at his mother's home in Dallas with several friends when somebody asked if he minded watching a pro football game on television. ''Who's playing?'' he asked. ''The Patriots,'' he was told. ''Not them,'' he said. Not the Patriots, thank you. On Oct. 22, only moments after the San Francisco 49ers kicked off, Johnny Stephens, the New England Patriots running back, had turned the corner on a sweep when Fuller tackled him near the sideline. One of hundreds of hard tackles every Sunday in pro football. After the collision, Stephens hopped to his feet, but Fuller didn't. Stretched out on his back on the Stanford Stadium grass, the 49er safety appeared unconscious.

They say the volume provides a new kind of definitive scholarly documentation of the murder of millions of Jews and others during World War II.

description: Jewel Stradford Lafontant, the United States Coordinator for Refugee Affairs and an Ambassador at Large, was married yesterday in Washington to Naguib Soby Mankarious, a business consultant in Washington. The ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square was performed by the Rev. Dr. John C. Harper, the rector of St. John's, and the Rev. Dr. Ruth Williams, an Episcopal priest.

title: Gladys Burr, Held as Retarded In Error for 42 Years, Dies at 82
description: Gladys Burr, who spent 42 years in state institutions after being mistakenly labeled mentally retarded, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport, Conn. She was 82 years old.

description: A car containing blood samples that was reported missing Saturday by a Brooklyn medical laboratory was found last night with all of the samples intact, the police said.

description: The Soviet Government's brand new economic plan leaves unanswered whether perestroika - economic restructuring - is moving backward or is just on hold. At first glance, the plan looks disappointing indeed. It preserves strangulating central control and postpones perestroika's critical ingredient, decontrol of prices.

title: Del Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Alone at the Top By a Wide Margin
description: For a fellow who has almost everything he desires, Herve Filion is an uncommonly hard-working man. At the top of his profession, with over 5,000 more harness racing victories than his nearest rival driver, the 49-year-old native of Angers, Quebec, is still steering pacers and trotters around oval racetracks. He usually appears six days a week at two of them: Freehold (N.J.) in the afternoon and Yonkers Raceway at night. Such devotion to his field of work has amassed for Filion a total of 796 victories this year and 11,989 for his career, which began in 1953 when Filion was 13 years old.

Lethal European Weather
description: As many as 14 people were believed to have died in storms across Western Europe over the weekend, sinking fishing boats, sweeping cars into the sea and cutting telephone and electrical lines. Off Scotland, the wreck of a fishing boat missing with six people on board was found by police divers on the bottom of the Firth of Clyde a quarter-mile from shore. There was no immediate sign of survivors in the 100-mile-an-hour gales.

title: 'Midlife Crisis' Is Investigated by One Who Doubts It's There
description: Mention ''midlife'' and the word ''crisis'' pops into mind automatically - the all-purpose explanation offered these days for infidelity, divorce, embezzlement, bankruptcy, espionage or just plain orneriness.

title: Review/Television; Old-Fashioned Christmas With Lucy and Her Gang
description: Tonight's Christmas special at 8:30 on CBS, the network's holiday centerpiece, is an ''I Love Lucy'' episode that has not been seen in its entirety since the original broadcast on Dec. 24, 1956. Cynics may well conclude that budget worries have really got out of hand when CBS reaches back 33 years for material to flesh out its prime-time schedule. More generous folk can maintain that the ploy is inspired, returning today's viewers to a more carefree and innocent time, a time before today's myriad and daunting crises.

title: Upheaval in the East; Rumanian Police, Trying to Oust Dissident Cleric, Battle Thousands
description: Rumanian security forces, using tanks and water cannon, battled thousands of anti-Government demonstrators after the police tried to deport a dissident clergyman, the Hungarian press agency and people familiar with the unrest said today, It was believed to be one of the largest outbreaks of anti-Government protest in at least two years in Rumania, where the hard-line Communist leadership of President Nicolae Ceausescu has crushed dissent and rejected the efforts for reform under way in much of Eastern Europe.

description: While bankers and business executives in London and Paris fret about schedules and cost overruns, hundreds of British and French workers in hard hats and coveralls dig steadily toward each other through the gray chalk-clay earth beneath the English Channel. Their assignment is to realize Napoleon's dream - and what has become one of the most visible symbols of the economic and political integration of Europe: a tunnel connecting England and France.

title: The Army vs. the Marines
description: During the years of the Reagan military build-up, Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger let each service buy every weapon on its wish list, unhindered by any overall strategic concept. Richard Cheney, the present Secretary, seems to be conducting the build-down with the same disdain for forethought. For lack of an overall strategy, the services are fighting one another for roles and dollars.

title: Knicks Await Post-Fight Oakley Ruling
description: ''What fight? Was there a fight? Who fought?'' Patrick Ewing and several other Knicks, whether to be evasive or just funny, posed questions of their own in responding to reporters' questions about the fight Saturday night between Charles Oakley and Xavier McDaniel during the Knicks' 118-97 rout of the Seattle SuperSonics at the Garden.
