title: Review/Dance; Benitez Troupe Turning Dreams Into Realities
description: The Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company turned dreams into realities on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. The program included both pieces that have already been reviewed and works that the troupe was performing for the first time this season. In most of the compositions, the performers suggested that they were archetypal Spanish images achieving a flesh-and-blood actuality on the stage.

description: With a quarter of their season behind them and a record of 6-15, the Nets appear well on their way to another dismal campaign.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 An overhaul of Poland's economy was proposed by the Solidarity-led Government. The far-reaching legislative program would break monopolies, cut subsidies and turn industries over to the private sector. Page A1 Andrei Sakharov was mourned by thousands in Moscow. His wife, Yelena Bonner, presided over the ceremony, directing the ordinary citizens who saw him as a symbol of human rights and the policemen who once hounded him. A1 News analysis: Sakharov's legacy in Soviet politics remains uncertain. President Mikhail Gorbachev's muted response to his death raises the question of whether the nation will follow in the direction Sakharov envisioned. A15 Moscow raced America to the moon. After years of denial and silence, Soviet officials disclosed to visiting American engineers details of their unsuccessful effort to be the first to land men on the lunar surface. A1 East Germany's Communist Party announced it would forfeit its monopoly on political power and compete in the May 6 elections with emerging democratic forces. A1 News analysis: A confessional congress breaks with Stalin A14 Thousands marched in Prague to commemorate the beatings of protesters last month, but the rally soon evolved into a demonstration of support for Vaclav Havel's bid for the presidency. A15 Eastern Europe market: Big lure and many hurdles D1 Rumanian security forces battle thousands A14 A witness to the killing of six priests in El Salvador last month said she was repeatedly accused of lying by U.S. and Salvadoran investigators and threatened with deportation. U.S. officials denied the charges. A1 A U.S. soldier was shot in Panama by Government troops. The White House said the killing was part of a pattern of aggression by Gen. Manuel Noriega and would not rule out a military response A7 U.N. asks for role in Latin talks for U.S., Soviets and Cuba A6 Brazilians voted for a new president in a runoff election that was too close to call. Fernando Collor de Mello, a free-market advocate, held a small lead over Luis Inacio da Silva, a Socialist, with 40 percent of the vote counted. A3 Killing a Colombian drug trafficker was only possible with the help of a mid-level trafficker extradicted earlier this year and tips from Colombians seeking a reward, an offical said. A3 Reporter's Notebook: Why is all of Chile laughing? A12 A curfew in India's Kashmir valley was imposed for the third day, as Government troops moved onto the streets of the Muslim region to quell pro-independence protests. A5 India's homespun chic (nothing imported) A11 West Bank Arabs keep a court system intact A10 Khmer Rouge transfers refugees from camps in Thailand A9 Pope criticizes Hong Kong on deportations of Vietnamese A13 National A16-17, A20, B7-14 A Federal judge was killed when a package mailed to his suburban home in Alabama exploded. F.B.I. officials said they had unearthed and were following a number of leads. A1 Judge praised as a man of moderation and wisdom B11 The underworld of hate and racism lived by America's white supremacists is being vividly portrayed by a former neo-Nazi in Phoenix. Having renounced his membership in the White Aryan Resistance, he now lectures against racism. A1 Drug tests for transport workers in the private sector will begin today. The first round of random testing for millions of railroad workers, mariners and bus and truck drivers is expected to refuel the debate over invasion of privacy. B9 A giant balloon will circle Antarctica on a trail-blazing, 15-day flight. The balloon, the largest ever launched on the continent, will carry four scientific experiments. B9 Archeological trove of fossils found in Virginia B12 Pennsylvania county judge is found guilty of corruption A20 Is the ''midlife crisis'' just a myth? A psychologist who heads a new study on the issue says there is a lack of evidence for the all-purpose explanation for divorce, bankruptcy and other midlife woes. A16 The long-enduring Salvation Army, the unusual Christian denomination organized along military lines and devoted to relieving suffering, is no less dedicated to saving souls. A16 Study finds housing crisis in rural America A17 Arizona Governor under fire for action on killers A16 Rescuers reach family trapped below Alaskan volcano B14 Spying or consumer research? Observing the habits of consumers, sometime without their knowledge, has become a standard practice for many large corporations and advertising agencies. Because it serves some of the city's poorest patients, many of whom have no insurance, its resources have been badly sapped. B1 The sale of Rockefeller Center to a Japanese company, one in a series of well-publicized deals for pieces of the American landscape, has been a source of many jokes, but has also made some Americans anxious and angry. Results Plus
description: College Basketball Notre Dame 86, U.C.L.A. 84: Jamere Jackson hit two free throws with 10 seconds remaining as Notre Dame pulled ahead by scoring its last 13 points from the foul line to upset U.C.L.A. at South Bend, Ind. Trevor Wilson, who scored 21 of his 29 points in the second half, had 6 of the Bruins' final 8. His basket on a drive inside tied the score at 84-84 with 22 seconds left. But Wilson fouled out on the infraction against Jackson 12 seconds later.(AP) Horse Racing Winner Sets Mile Record: Grand Canyon ran the fastest mile ever by a 2-year-old in the United States and won the $1 million Hollywood Futurity by 6 1/2 lengths yesterday at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif. Ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. and sent off as the 4-5 favorite, the big colt raced the one-turn mile out of the chute in 1:33, shattering the stakes record of 1:34 1/5 set by Snow Chief in 1985. The time was just two-fifths of a second off the track record set by Greinton the same year. Farma Way was second, 2 1/2 lengths ahead of Silver Ending in the field of nine. Grand Canyon, a 2-year-old son of Fappiano and Champagne Ginny, is owned by D. Wayne Lukas, the trainer, and Overbrook Farm of Lexington, Ky. He returned $3.60 for $2 to win. (AP) Stretch Run Does It: Never Forgotten came from last in a five-horse field for a 2 1/4-length victory in the $68,300 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner, with Art Madrid up, ran the six furlongs in 1:22 3/5. Never Forgotten earned $40,980 for Sharon L. Hild and returned $15.20 for $2 to win.

title: Question Box
description: N.F.L. Overachievers Q. Since the advent of the 16-game regular-season schedule in the National Football League, what is the worst record in each conference for a team that made the playoffs? What is the best record in each conference over the same span for a team that failed to make the playoffs? A. Excluding this season and the strike-curtailed seasons of 1982 and 1987, there have been 9 full years of the 16-game schedule. In the National Football Conference, no team has ever made the playoffs in that time with a winning percentage of .500 or less. The poorest mark to qualify was the 8-7-1 record stitched together by the Minnesota Vikings in 1978, the first year of the expanded schedule. That record not only proved good enough to reach the post-season, it also earned the Vikings the Central Division championship. The Green Bay Packers also finished at 8-7-1, but Minnesota won the top spot because it had the better record in the two meetings of the teams. In the playoffs, though, sanity prevailed, and the Vikings lasted only one game, a 34-10 loss to the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Drug Tests: Who Is Covered
description: Four million workers with safety-related jobs will be subject to drug test beginning Monday under Transportation Department rules. Federal Aviation Administration Effective Dec. 18/538,000 Domestic air carriers, commercial operators of large aircraft, commuter airline and air taxi operators and other commercial operators, like crop dusters, must test employees who are pilots, flight engineers, flight navigators, aircraft dispatchers, mechanics, repairmen, flight attendants, aviation security screeners, ground security coordinators, non-F.A.A. controllers and ground instructors. Exempt: Private and corporate pilots. Federal Highway Administration Effective Dec. 21/3 million drivers Interstate motor carriers must test drivers of trucks weighing more than 26,000 pounds, trucks of any size carrying hazardous materials, and that carry more than 15 passengers; a Federal court, however, has enjoined random and some post-accident tests. Coast Guard Effective Dec. 21/120,000 workers Mariners on commercial vessels and any licensed or documented seamen, including harbor pilots operating temporarily on board vessels, will be subject to testing by their employer. Exempt: Service and entertainment workers on cruise ships, scientific personnel. Federal Railroad Administration Effective Jan. 16/90,000 workers Engineers, brakemen, dispatchers, signalmen, conductors and others directly involved in the movements of trains will be subject to random testing by their employer. (Since 1985 there has been pre-employment and post-accident testing.) Research and Special Programs Administration Effective April 20/116,500 Workers Workers for companies operating pipelines used to transport natural gas and hazardous liquids, and operators who produce and store liquefied natural gas will be subject to testing by their employer. Urban Mass Transit Administration Effective Dec. 21/195,500 workers Transit systems that receive Federal money must test vehicle operators, controllers and maintenance workers.

title: Review/Theater; Attraction Breeds Suspicion in 'Sunshine'
description: She may not be Gypsy Rose Lee or Blaze Starr, but Sunshine takes pride in her work. From inside her glass booth in a New Jersey porno house, she says whatever is necessary, via a telephone linkup, to make her customers feel close to her. ''I know how to love you and how to take care of you,'' she tells a transfixed college student while opening and closing her flimsy robe. Young and attractive beneath her smeared makeup and tousled hair, Sunshine puts something a little personal in every peep show, to encourage repeat business. ''I'm dyin' for love,'' she whispers with Marilyn Monroe-ish ardor, and you know that she means it.

description: Morris Furman, a real-estate developer and philanthropist, died yesterday of complications of a stroke in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

description: b-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $134,319, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $504,494, or 12 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said the extraordinary credits represented tax benefits from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Treasury Selling Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and two- and four-year note auctions tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.

title: Robert D. Blue Dies; Former Iowa Governor
description: Robert D. Blue, a champion of the elderly who served two terms as Iowa's Governor in the 1940's, has died of complications from a stroke. He was 91 years old.

title: Ski Bindings Show Advances in Safety
description: IN the past 10 years, enormous strides have been made in the engineering of ski bindings to help reduce injuries to skiers. The basic mechanical function of bindings has been fairly unchanged in recent years, but there are always a few improvements that can be added. This season is no exception. Binding mechanisms are highly sophisticated, the materials used in their manufacture are high-tech. Even in appearance, bindings are streamlined and decorated with neon colors.

title: Nicole Belson Weds Erik T. Goluboff
description: Nicole Belson and Erik T. Goluboff were married yesterday at Temple Rodeph Sholom in New York by Rabbi Harold Saperstein and Cantors Louis Teichman and Ephraim Biran. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel Jay Belson of Jamaica, Queens. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hal Goluboff of Brooklyn Heights.

title: Browns' Fake Kick Surprises Vikings
description: Mike Pagel threw a 14-yard touchdown pass to the linebacker Van Waiters on a fake field-goal attempt with 5 minutes 30 seconds left in overtime today as the Cleveland Browns kept their division title hopes alive with a 23-17 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Pope Criticizes Hong Kong on Vietnamese
description: Pope John Paul II today criticized Hong Kong's repatriation of Vietnamese refugees and called for a policy that was ''more respectful of the dignity of man.''

title: U.N. Is Urging Broader Talks on Latin Peace
description: In an attempt to speed the search for peace in Central America, the United Nations has for the first time asked the United States, the Soviet Union and Cuba to become directly involved in talks between the region's governments and rebel groups.

title: Salvation Army Is More Than Christmas Kettles
description: Even in New York, successful young bankers are not usually found playing music for coins on the sidewalk. Yet no one batted an eye when Kenneth Burton, assistant treasurer and manager of the mortgage administration department for the Bank of New York, recently stood outside Macy's on a freezing cold evening playing Christmas carols on his euphonium.

title: Blazers' Ramos Remains in Coma
description: Doctors said Ramon Ramos, the former Seton Hall player now a Portland Trail Blazers rookie, remained in a coma today after being critically injured in a car accident, and they have given him a 50-50 chance for survival.

title: PANAMA SHOOTING CONDEMNED BY U.S.
description: The Bush Administration said today that the shooting of an unarmed American army officer by Panamanian soldiers Saturday night was part of a pattern of ''aggression'' by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and that Washington would not rule out a military response.

title: Cascade Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Body Found on Jersey Beach
description: The body of a 26-year-old woman from neighboring Wildwood was found on a dune here this morning, the police said. Detective Sgt. Tom Stocker identified the woman as Tamara Davis. Authorities had not determined the cause of death or where Ms. Davis was killed, but it appeared she had been dragged to the spot, he said. The body was found in the snow about 300 yards from the ocean.

title: INSIDE
description: Killing of U.S. Officer Raises Panama Tensions Washington said the fatal shooting of an unarmed American army officer by Panamanian soldiers Saturday was part of a pattern of ''aggression'' by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Officials would not rule out a military response. Page A7. Death of a Drug Baron Colombia told how it finally tracked down Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a major drug trafficker, and said it expected reprisals for the killing of the cocaine kingpin. Page A3. Millions Face Drug Tests Many private transportation workers are about to join the ranks of those routinely tested for illegal drug use.

title: Blue Jays Trade Whitt to Braves
description: The Toronto Blue Jays traded their last original player, Ernie Whitt, to the Atlanta Braves today in a deal involving two minor leaguers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Executives Honored
description: The Advertising Hall of Fame announced the election of three new members, who will be inducted on March 28. They are James E. Burke, former chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Johnson; Raymond O. Mithun, co-founder of what is now the Campbell-Mithun-Esty agency, and Jean Wade Rindlaub, former director and group copy head of BBDO, who wrote the ''Back home for keeps . . .'' ads for Community Silverplate during World War II. Mrs. Rindlaub is also the mother of John Rindlaub, the head of communications for Young & Rubicam.

title: American Museum of Historial Documents reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $90,294, or 2 cents a share, from tax- loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

title: Opera Stars to Sing At Richard Tucker Gala
description: Ghena Dimitrova, Susan Dunn, Nicola Martinucci, Robert Merrill, James Morris, J. Patrick Raftery, Stefania Toczyska, Margaret Jane Wray and the Collegiate Chorale are to sing arias, duets and choruses from grand opera at the annual Richard Tucker Music Foundation gala on Jan. 7 in Avery Fisher Hall. Anton Guadagno will conduct, and Beverly Sills will be guest host.

title: Lakeland Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Study Finds Housing Crisis in Rural America
description: Nearly three out of four poor households in rural America pay more for housing than the Government says they can afford, according to a report by two nonprofit research organizations.

title: CPI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 11
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,246,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $495,000 and $1,203,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: b-Net income

title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use
description: Millions of privately employed transportation workers are about to join the swelling roster of people who are routinely tested for illegal drug use, fueling debate about whether random drug tests are an unwarranted invasion of privacy.

title: Allan P. Bradley, 77, Ex-Officer For New York Education Officials
description: Allan P. Bradley, who served as a legislative liaison officer for two New York state education commissioners, died of a heart attack Friday at Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 77 years old and lived in Wilmington, N.C.

title: Chicago Dock & Canal Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Giant Balloon to Ply Antarctic Skies
description: Scientists are preparing to launch the biggest balloon ever to be chosen for a trail-blazing flight around this vast continent.

title: Upheaval in the East; PRAGUE MARCHERS RALLY FOR HAVEL
description: Tens of thousands of Czechoslovaks poured into the streets of the capital today to commemorate protesters beaten by the authorities a month ago, but the march quickly turned into a powerful demonstration of support for the election of Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright, to the presidency.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Aerobats Explore Wild Blue Yonder
description: LEAD: THE Red Baron lives - in competition aerobatics flying, an amateur sport that has more than doubled in number of contests and contestants in the 13 or 14 years it has existed in the United States.

title: Amy Hiraga Wed To Peter Wyrick
description: Amy Hiraga, a daughter of Shyoko Hiraga of Seattle and the late Noburu Hiraga, was married yesterday to Peter Alexander Wyrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wyrick of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Mayor Robert Bleakley of Poughkeepsie at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Extradition Key to Bogota Drug Raid
description: The tracking and slaying by the police of a major drug trafficker was helped by the extradition of a midlevel drug trafficker earlier this year and by information from Colombians seeking to collect a $625,000 reward, a senior Government official said today.

title: Mony Real Estate Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Lowrance Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mayflower Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Penny Rolfe Marries Timothy Sullivan
description: The wedding of Penny Rolfe, a daughter of N. Anthony Rolfe and Susan Sulzberger Rolfe, both of New York, to Timothy Paul Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Sullivan of Shrewsbury, Mass., took place yesterday at Le Club in New York. Judge Stanley S. Ostrau of State Supreme Court in New York officiated.

title: Possis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Staodynamics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Net loss

title: As a Hospital Grows, Debts Threaten It
description: Even as it nears completion of a $500 million rebuilding project that will make it one of the country's largest and best-equipped health-care institutions, the Presbyterian Hospital finds itself in a financial crisis that threatens its survival as a teaching center.

title: The Cup That Isn't
description: Soccer skeptics, noting how much trouble the United States had in qualifying for the World Cup finals for the first time in four decades, have been saying that the young team will be lucky to make it past the first round next year.

title: Commercial Intertech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,570,000 and $17,389,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After loss from discontinued operations of $200,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Harvey Group Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: b-Net income c-Included extraordinary credits arising from tax benefits of loss carryforward of $79,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 13 weeks and $375,000, or 14 cents a share, for the 39 weeks. The company said the latest 9 months' net income included a gain of $599,000 ($413,000 net of taxes, or 16 cents a share) relating to the settlement of certain pension obligations.

title: Limited Reopening Of Plutonium Plant In Washington State
description: A plutonium production plant at the Hanford nuclear reservation reopened today to process spent nuclear fuel that has been stuck in the plant since it was shut down a year ago. But the Energy Department said that after the processing is completed, in four to six weeks, the plant would be shut for another year.

title: Pennsylvania County Judge Guilty of Corruption
description: A suspended county judge who prosecutors said used favors and fear to reign over a courthouse has been convicted of bribery and corruption.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Health page on Thursday about a new psychiatric treatment manual referred incorrectly to Dr. T. Byram Karasu of the psychiatry department at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He is deputy chairman, not chairman.

title: West Bank Arabs Keep a Court System Intact
description: Chief Justice Khalil Silwani drives to Ramallah every morning, into ''the center of the intifada,'' as he likes to put it, and prepares to preside over cases brought before the Supreme Court for the West Bank - if ever a case is presented.

title: T Cell Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Third World Borrowing Still Growing
description: The total debt of third world countries is still rising, and an increasing number of countries are accumulating arrears, the World Bank said today.

title: Alfin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Constitution vs. Chemical Arms
description: LEAD: President Bush's proposal at the Malta summit meeting to halt the production of chemical weapons was another important step toward a global treaty banning poison gas. But before such a treaty can be completed, negotiators will have to cope with a problem we don't usually associate with arms control: the U.S.

title: Becker's Victory Clinches Title
description: Boris Becker, hitting winners from all over the court, routed Mats Wilander, 6-2, 6-0, 6-2, today to clinch West Germany's Davis Cup victory over Sweden.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; CBS and ABC to Use Ad That Names Drug
description: CBS and ABC have extended the boundary of prescription drug advertising on television by agreeing to broadcast a commercial for Nicorette, Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals USA's nicotine-based chewing gum, which is used to help people stop smoking.

title: Develcon Electronics reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $142,000, or 4 cents a share for the latest year and an extraordinary charge of $459,000 for the year-ago period. The company said the latest period included writeoffs totaling $1,248,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hometown Mourns Colombian Drug Dealer
description: Thousands of mourners thronged the streets of an Andean town for the funeral of Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the drug trafficker who was shot to death by the police last week.

title: Rochester Phone Yield at 9.14%
description: The Rochester Telephone Corporation yesterday priced $100 million in 30-year debentures, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Reports Say Sudanese Junta Executed 2 Civilians
description: The Sudanese military junta executed two civilians on Sunday and announced that five more would be put to death, including two doctors, reports from Khartoum say.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cineplex Odeon Corp., Toronto, the movie theater chain, appointed the following executive vice presidents: David M. Allen, Canada; Neil A. Blatt, film; Ellis Jacob, chief financial officer; Howard I. Lichtman, marketing and communications; Barry H. Silver, operations, and Robert J. Tokio, real estate.

title: Europeans Tell Turkey to Wait
description: The European Community today rebuffed Turkey's application to join, saying it wanted to wait until 1993 before beginning negotiations about membership for the nation.

title: Topics of The Times; Seasonal Sympathy
description: A Connecticut resident rashly drove to New York Sunday to attend a holiday party in Greenwich Village. He counted himself lucky to find a legal parking spot on 10th Street, not far from Fifth Avenue. There were just-wrapped Christmas presents stowed in the trunk but he took care to lock the car.

title: Rightist Is Victor in Regional Vote in Spain
description: The veteran rightist politician Manuel Fraga scored the most important victory of his political career in his home region of Galicia in elections on Sunday.

title: What the U.S. Said About China in June
description: The Bush Administration secretly renewed high-level contacts with China in early July, shortly after imposing sanctions over Beijing's crackdown on dissent in June. Here is the text of the statement on the sanctions issued by the White House on June 20.

title: Descendants of the Etombed Revive Decaying Graveyard
description: Amy Anderson, a legal secretary from Jamaica, Queens, was looking for some stray puppies one night last year in what she thought was a garbage-filled lot. As she and two companions picked their way through splintered furniture, old tires and other trash, the beam from her flashlight fell on a tire hanging on a small upright stone.

title: Business and Health; Studying Hospital Costs and Quality
description: AS industrial executives have learned, high quality does not necessarily mean higher costs. Indeed, the opposite is often true. An improved production line and a motivated work force can usually cut costs by reducing the parts that have to be scrapped or repaired before shipment. The same seems to be true of hospitals.

title: Krelitz Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $92,000 and $148,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $44,000 for the quarter and $69,000 for the 6 months.

title: FUROR IS REIGNITED
description: A prisoner with a violent criminal background walked away from a state work-release center here Sunday and raped a woman, the authorities said.

title: Absent Watchdogs - A Reagan Legacy; Regulators Say 80's Budget Cuts May Cost U.S. Billions in 1990's
description: In their zeal to cut the fat out of Government, Reagan Administration officials also cut the managerial muscle that was responsible for watching over the Government's financial liabilities and obligations, reports by Congressional and Government investigators show.

title: McRae Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Toyota, Nissan Exports
description: Japan's two largest auto makers, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, said today that their exports fell more than 15 percent in November compared with last year. Toyota said its exports fell 17 percent, to 123,834 vehicles, while its overseas production rose by 90.3 percent, to 52,108 vehicles. Nissan, the country's second-largest car maker, said its exports in November fell 19.4 percent, to 76,822 vehicles, while its overseas production rose 5.1 percent, to 56,653 vehicles.

title: Patterns
description: Dark Humor

title: PRESIDENT CALLS PANAMA SLAYING A GREAT OUTRAGE
description: President Bush today called the weekend slaying of an American Marine officer by Panamanian soldiers ''an enormous outrage.'' With tensions high, a United States military officer in Panama City wounded a uniformed Panamanian a few hours after the President spoke.

title: Delia W. Kuhn, Writer, 86
description: Delia W. Kuhn, a writer, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 86 years old. .

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Put Bomb Production Over Safety, Report Says Although the Government was warned before 1950 that nuclear weapons workers were being exposed to dangerous radiation, it decided not to tell them, a Congressional report says. Officials ''swept the problem under the carpet,'' Senator John Glenn said. Page A20. A Plan for Aiding Children New York's troubled child-welfare system should be rebuilt as a network of small neighborhood centers where parents could get help near their homes, many experts say. Page B1. Trade Boon for Kremlin The Soviet Union and the European Community signed a 10-year commercial accord that ends European quotas on Soviet products. Page D1. Brazil Conservative Ahead Fernando Collor de Mello led in returns from Brazil's presidential elections, and two television networks said he had won. Page A12. Sihanouk's Balancing Act Prince Norodom Sihanouk admits he is unpredictable, but says the West seeks an impossible clarity when little is clear in Cambodia. Page A3. A User-Friendly Court A Supreme Court computer will make decisions available moments after they're handed down. Page A24.

title: Reply Ready For Big Ten
description: Bryce Jordan, the president of Penn State University, is expected to announce Tuesday that the school has agreed to join the Big Ten Conference. A Penn State spokesman, Bill Mahon, would say only that Jordan would hold a news conference about Penn State and the Big Ten, but declined to disclose what Jordan planned to say.

title: Upheaval in the East; Soviets Softening on Limits For Missiles at Sea, U.S. Says
description: Soviet negotiators have discussed a possible compromise approach in the Geneva arms talks on sea-launched cruise missiles, one of the major remaining issues holding up a new strategic arms treaty, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Study on Trade Fails To Reach a Consensus
description: So divisive have trade issues become that a group of eminences assembled by the Twentieth Century Fund was unable to develop a consensus about how the United States should proceed.

title: Informer and His Guards: Did They Get Too Close?
description: A protected witness in five murder and drug conspiracy cases and his police guards developed such a close relationship in three and a half years that they took vacations in Florida together and sold vehicles to one another, the lawyer for the witness's widow has said.

title: Memorial for Arnold Moss
description: A memorial service for the actor Arnold Moss is to be held at noon tomorrow at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street. Mr. Moss died of lung cancer on Saturday at the age of 80.

title: Lottery Sifts Deep Mounds Of Dreams For Housing
description: The envelopes were piled more than two feet high on the floor of Jonathan Poole's office. There were thousands of them - perhaps 4,500 in all - and they filled the small room in a sprawl at least seven feet long and five feet wide.

title: When Life Is a Medical and Not a Legal Issues; Call It Starvation
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford and VW Weigh Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen A.G. are discussing a European joint venture to produce multipurpose vehicles, but Ford is releasing few details about it. A spokeswoman for Ford, Lin Cummins, said today that the two companies were involved in talks about ''a possible European cooperation in a specific product segment.'' She did not elaborate.

title: Sharing the Blame for Boat People
description: A chorus of angry, righteous protests have been stirred by Britain's hard-boiled decision to forcibly bundle 51 Vietnamese boat people onto planes bound from Hong Kong to Hanoi. Governments, relief agencies, the European Parliament and now Pope John Paul II have joined in denouncing what is plainly an inhumane act.

title: Metro Datelines; Youth, 18, Is Killed In Subway Stabbing
description: An 18-year-old high school student was stabbed to death yesterday in a fight with another youth on a northbound F train in Carroll Gardens following a dispute the pair had a few days ago, the transit police said.

title: Informatrix 2000 reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: A White House Ghost
description: Were President Reagan and Vice President Bush, as he was then, more culpably involved in the Iran-contra scandal than either has admitted? We may never know for sure, but the possibility, like some vengeful ghost, keeps coming back to haunt them.

title: Arthur Goldman, 83, A Housing Consultant
description: Arthur S. Goldman, a construction economist who served as director of marketing and research for House & Home magazine from 1940 to 1963, died of the effects of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 83 years old and had been a longtime resident of Westport, Conn.

title: Cellcom Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After gain from sale of discontinued operations of $327,401 and net operating loss carryforward benefit of $168,661. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $371,086. Share earnings are ajdusted to reflect 1-for-3 reverse stock split which became effective June 7, 1989.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Lee Brown is an outstanding police chief who's been successful in three communities, and he's also a very impressive human being. When he walked into the room for his interview, he looked about six feet tall.

title: Unusual Cold Spell Sends Energy Prices Up Sharply
description: Energy prices exploded yesterday, as unseasonably cold weather upset refinery and distribution programs for heating oil. The unusually cold weather so early in the heating season has found some refiners and fuel oil distributors in the Northeast with relatively low stocks of heating oil.

title: 11-Part Offering From Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest investor in home mortgages, is offering $300 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Upheaval in the East; Sakharov Is Buried; Burden Is Passed
description: The body of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Nobel laureate who labored to his last against his Government's abuse of democratic rights, was buried this evening after a long day of farewell in which tens of thousands of sorrowing partisans were exhorted to press his struggle forward.

title: Child Sex-Abuse Case Rocks Small Town in North Carolina
description: When five people were indicted on charges of sexually abusing children at a day-care center, the news reverberated through this town of 5,800 people, seemingly touching everyone.

title: Reviews/Music; Chamber Choir's Devotions
description: If the Roman Catholic Church has lost much of its political power over the last centuries, it has at least translated this mighty influence into esthetic terms. If Popes and bishops no longer command our lives, Christian art is as much a part of our lives as ever.

title: Settlements By Imperial
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, a savings and loan company based in San Diego, said today that it would pay $13 million and issue stock warrants to settle lawsuits filed earlier this year by disgruntled shareholders.

title: Granite Co-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $1,859,974 writedown of marketable securities; $437,500 loan loss provision and $69,000 in costs related to formation of a holding company for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: BRIEFS
description: * Datapoint Corp., San Antonio, a maker of business computers and office automation systems, reduced its headquarters staff by 144 employees.

title: Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the principal reason for the lower net in the latest quarter is that its refining operations experienced lower margins because of increased crude oil costs.

title: Review/Dance; Proverbs as Entertainment, by Tom Evert
description: Tom Evert promised the audience a ''short and sweet'' program on Sunday afternoon at Eden's Expressway, when the Tom Evert Dance Company presented an informal showing of his dances. He lived up to that promise, for his work had a gentle, amiable edge, even in a high-energy gymnastic ritual for three men, an excerpt from ''Mantl.'' Mr. Evert also has the rare - and underappreciated - gift of wholehearted goofiness, and he glows with an infectious delight. Those qualities turned the major pieces on the program into one of the happiest and most nuttily inspired dance events of the season.

title: Compassion For Neediest After Sadness
description: Some letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund stand out for the poignancy of their messages and others for their harsh descriptions of suffering witnessed in New York City.

title: Corporate Boards Are Shrinking
description: Corporate boards of directors are becoming smaller, and at the same time are adding increasing numbers of outsiders, according to a study by SpencerStuart Executive Search Consultants.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; ABC Luring Readers For Its New Magazine
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. appears to be succeeding with an unusual experiment in ''circulation synergy.'' The communications company has announced that Episodes, its forthcoming subscription-only soap opera magazine that will cover only the ABC network's daytime dramas, has built its circulation to more than 500,000, in three weeks, using direct-response commercials on its soap operas to lure subscribers.

title: 'Collars for Dollars'
description: LEAD: Every year in early December, a sign appears in the complaint room of the Manhattan District Attorney's office: ''Only 21 more shoplifting days until Christmas.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's increase in subway, bus and commuter rail fares gave an incorrect figure for the Transit Authority's 1990 capital budget. It is $1.4 billion.

title: Ingles Markets reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns; Jimmy the Greek Had Job Trouble. Now, She Does.
description: It has been nearly two years since Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder gave his opinion of the origin of black athletic prowess. The furor has mostly blown over, but for Janet Morgan, a social studies teacher here, the remarks still reverberate.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18 The slaying of an American officer in Panama was ''an enormous outrage'' said President Bush, who would not rule out a military response. Hours later, an American officer wounded a uniformed Panamanian. Page A1

title: Review/Theater; Generation Gap in Fugard's 'My Children!'
description: In August Wilson's ''Fences,'' Courtney B. Vance had a job to traumatize any young actor. In the role of a rebellious teen-age son, he had to challenge James Earl Jones for supremacy in a household and, by implication, on the stage. Mr. Vance, though not long out of the Yale School of Drama, wasn't fazed. Armed with a baseball bat and a raging desire for justice, he faced down the majestic Mr. Jones in a volatile confrontation of such balanced power that it became the detonation point of one of the decade's most explosive plays.

title: Contribution Limits In New Jersey Races Suggested by Panel
description: The State Law Enforcement Commission said today that candidates in the recent New Jersey State Assembly election raised more than $9.7 million and spent more than $7.6 million, making it the most expensive Assembly campaign in state history.

title: Fernandez Has Surgery
description: Tony Fernandez, the Toronto Blue Jays' shortstop, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair mild cartilage damage in his left shoulder. Dr. James Andrews, of Birmingham, Ala., performed the surgery Friday. Fernandez was scheduled to begin physiotherapy immediately and should be ready in time for spring training, the club said.(AP)

title: RIGHTIST IS AHEAD IN BRAZILIAN VOTE
description: Fernando Collor de Mello, a 40-year-old conservative, led in returns from Brazil's presidential election, and two television networks said he had won.

title: Upheaval in the East; Casualties Reported In Rumania Protest Spawned by a Clash
description: A confrontation between the police and a prominent church leader in Rumania over the weekend led to a large-scale anti-Government protest that reportedly resulted in many casualties as security forces responded with water cannon, tear gas and some gunfire.

title: General Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7,700,000, or 9 cents a share. c-After a loss of $3,800,000 for the quarter and income of $194,500,000, or $2.37 a share, for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 6 months also included a charge of $70,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Flights of Fancy, Bursts of English, in Beijing
description: ''Now, after the June events, we lack all - faith?'' the young man asked. ''Is that the right word?''

title: Dataphaz Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in thin trading yesterday, aided by a sharp selloff in the stock market.

title: The Supreme Court, on Line
description: Dramatic changes are afoot in the way the public learns the official doings of the U.S. Supreme Court. The justices speak through written words that set forth their legal reasoning. Since the beginning they have communicated with the public through the written word on paper, even as society has in recent years mastered instant, electronic dissemination.

title: Rise in Index Arbitrage
description: The pace of index arbitrage trading accelerated in the final week of November, but remained well below the levels that existed before many Wall Street firms agreed to abandon the practice for the own accounts, figures released yesterday showed.

title: TWO MORE BOMBS STIR FEARS OF LINK TO JUDGE'S SLAYING
description: Two days after a Federal appeals judge was slain with a letter bomb in Birmingham, a similar device was found in a Federal court building here today and a lawyer in Savannah, Ga., was killed when a bomb exploded in his office.

title: North Hills Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Metro Datelines; Ban on Panhandling Limited in Subways
description: A Federal judge yesterday limited a Transit Authority ban on panhandling in the subway system.

title: New York City Public Employees Pay for Their Own Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine and Probation for Lewis In Stock Manipulation Case
description: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, an influential Wall Street executive who once served as an adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission, was sentenced yesterday to three years of probation and fined $250,000 for helping to manipulate a stock price in 1986 - an action that benefited the American Express Company.

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING My Caravann in Front: My Caravann, owned by Basil J. Plasteras, led from the start and cruised to a 5 1/4-length victory yesterday over Lake Valley in the $45,000 Dotted Swiss feature at Aqueduct. The winner, with Jorge Chavez up, covered the six-furlong test for fillies and mares in 1:12 1/5. Lake Valley, the favorite, was a nose ahead of Box Office Gold in the six-horse field. My Caravann, who has won 5 times in 11 starts, earned $27,000 and returned $4.80 for $2 to win.(AP) Milestone for Harness Driver: Herve Filion last night became the first driver to win 800 harness races in one year. Filion, 49 years old, of Quebec, set the record of 798 in 1988. He reached 799 yesterday afternoon with two victories at Freehold Raceway, and reached 800 in the evening at Yonkers when he guided Winter D J to a two-length victory in the second race, a one-mile pace, in 2:03 2/5. Filion has 11,993 victories in all. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Louisville 93, Austin Peay 59: Denny Crum became the top-winning basketball coach in Louisville history last night as the Cardinals won behind LaBradford Smith's 18 points. Crum is 444-149 in his 19th season.Peck Hickman was 443-183 in 23 seasons with the Cardinals (1944-67). Louisville's seventh consecutive victory also enabled the Cardinals to equal their best start since the 1982-83 Final Four squad also opened with an 8-1 mark. Louisville led by as many as 44 points in the second half, using 7 of their 10 dunks.(AP) Iowa 59, Drexel 50: James Moses scored 17 points and Ray Thompson 16 as unbeaten Iowa came from behind in a home game. Iowa (7-0) trailed by 32-26 at halftime, but started the second half with a 13-5 burst to lead, 39-37. A basket by Acie Earl gave Iowa a 43-38 lead with 10:11 left, but Drexel (2-5) closed to 47-46 on Todd Lehmann's 3-point shot with 5:04 remaining.(AP) Bowling Green 81, Michigan State 79: Clinton Venable made a 3-point shot with 14 seconds as the visiting Falcons upset Michigan State. Venable's basket came after Michigan State (7-2) had rallied from a 7-point deficit to take a 79-78 lead on Parish Hickman's rebound of a missed free throw with 1:02 remaining. With 10 seconds left, the Spartans called a timeout. But Steve Smith missed a running 10-footer with 5 seconds left and Venable ran down the ball near midcourt as time expired. Steve Watson led Bowling Green (7-1) with 20 points in a game that included 8 ties and 17 lead changes.(AP) Arkansas 91, Bethune-Cookman 61: Arkansas, led by hot-shooting Mario Credit, forced 31 turnovers and scored the first 21 points of the second half o turn a close game into an easy homecourt victory in Fayetteville. Credit made nine of 11 shots from the floor to lead the Razorbacks (6-1), who led just 30-27 at halftime. Arkansas outscored Bethune-Cookman (1-5) by 61-34 in the second half.(AP) Alabama 63, Baptist 32: David Benoit scored 8 points and Marcus Webb 7 as Alabama (7-1) reeled off the last 29 points of a 32-6 first half while holding Baptist College (2-7) scoreless for 16 1/2 minutes en route to victory at home in Tuscaloosa. Baptist's 6 first-half points were the fewest allowed in a half by Alabama since Dec. 6, 1947.(AP) N.H.L. Maple Leafs 6, Blues 3: The goaltender Alan Bester made a triumphant return from the minors to stop 45 shots for Toronto in a home game. Bester was making his first start for Toronto since being recalled from Newmarket after a self-imposed two-week conditioning stint. Toronto blew the game open with four goals in the second period. In the first period, the team's center, Dave Hannan, reinjured his left knee and left the game.(AP)

title: New York City Public Employees Pay for Their Own Pensions; Like a Paycheck
description: To the Editor:

title: In Poland, a Small Capitalist Miracle
description: This sooty industrial town, surrounded by potato patches and hog farms, might be the last place in the world one would expect to find a venture capitalist. But Jan Bednarek, a 51-year-old engineer who heads a state-owned synthetic fiber company here, has given life to 18 start-up companies by forcing his way through the narrow openings the Communist system has traditionally left for entrepreneurs.

title: 3 Deaths on the Subway Attributed to Cold Wave
description: The current wave of unusually cold weather claimed its first victims over the weekend among the homeless seeking shelter in New York City's subway system, the Transit Authority said late yesterday.

title: Thomas M. Quinn, Lawyer, 49
description: Thomas Michael Quinn, founder and former senior partner of Quinn, Coti & Flicker, a law firm in Manhattan, died of a brain tumor yesterday at the home of his parents, Gerald C. and Florence M. Quinn, in Hyannis, Mass. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working United States oil rigs climbed by 25 last week, to total a 1,079, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count was 930. The rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Family Management Ends at Dexter Corp.
description: The Dexter Corporation, one of the country's oldest industrial companies, has elected a new leader, ending a family management that dates to before the American Revolution.

title: Albany Issues List of Schools In Trouble
description: The State Education Commissioner, rejecting a request from the incoming New York City Schools Chancellor, today released a list of what his staff termed the 43 most academically troubled public schools in the state. All but four are in New York City.

title: Republic In Savings Bank Deal
description: The Republic New York Corporation, a banking company best known for its strong financial position and business with the rich, announced plans yesterday to enlarge its foothold in the New York market by acquiring the Manhattan Savings Bank by issuing about $200 million of Republic stock.

title: Dinkins Names Houston's Chief To Be His Police Commissioner
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins yesterday named Lee P. Brown, the Police Chief of Houston, as his Police Commissioner, making him the first non-New Yorker to head the nation's largest police force in a quarter century.

title: 2 U.S. Officials Went to Beijing Secretly in July
description: The White House said today that the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, made a secret trip to China in July, shortly after President Bush suspended high-level meetings with the Chinese Government over the June crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger also went on the trip.

title: Par Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' nets were after reduction for minority interest in earnings of subsidiary.

title: Bali Jewelry Ltd reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Jayark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mattel Sets Deal
description: Mattel Inc., the toy maker, agreed to acquire Corgi Toys Ltd., a British maker of miniature model cars. Terms were not disclosed. It said the transaction is expected to be completed before the end of the year. Mattel said the acquisition fitted with its primary strategy of adding to its strong brands, which include Barbie dolls, Hot Wheels and Disney infant and preschool toys.

title: In New Retail Shop, Beene Envisions a Laboratory of Fashion
description: By Geoffrey Beene, who as a designer has collected every known accolade in fashion, has embarked on a new career, as a retailer. Today, his first retail shop opens at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street in the Sherry Netherland Hotel. It is a tiny Art Deco jewel box that he hopes to use the way Paris designers traditionally viewed their couture collections: as laboratories of fashion and as sounding boards for changing tastes.

title: Esterline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $347,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $723,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $291,000, or 4 cents a share, and $1,242,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest results included one month of operating results from six former Criton Technologies' companies acquired Sept. 27, reduced by interest on the transaction financing and a pro rate portion of annual amortization of the acquisition costs.

title: Mohawk Pleads Guilty In Illegal Casino Case
description: The Mohawk owner of the largest illegal casino on the St. Regis Indian Reservation pleaded guilty to gambling charges today in Federal District Court, saying he did so in order to appeal his case to a higher court.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Saturday referred incorrectly to the American Steel and Wire Corporation of Cuyahoga Heights, Ohio. It manufactures steel rod and wire from semi-finished steel.

title: Upheaval in the East; German Momentum
description: While politicians in Washington, Moscow, London and Paris debate whether the two Germanys can unite, and when, Germans are rushing ahead with practical steps that could soon make unification either inevitable or superfluous.

title: Ford Joins In Rebates On Mini-vans
description: Responding to a continued slump in the auto market, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would match the Chrysler Corporation's mini-van rebates. Ford also said it would extend holiday shutdowns at most car and truck assembly plants in early January.

title: Upheaval in the East; Austerity Program Is Proposed in Yugoslavia
description: The Communist Government proposed a new currency and a six-month wage freeze today to fight inflation, which rose last month to an annual rate of almost 2,000 percent.

title: Sports News Briefs; Car Crash Kills Falcon Tight End
description: Brad Beckman, a tight end for the Atlanta Falcons who played briefly for the Giants in 1988, died early today in a car crash on Interstate 85. He would have turned 25 on New Year's Eve.

title: Review/Music The Paul Winter Consort Hails Solstice in Cathedral
description: Few musicians are more ideally suited to making creative use of the booming acoustics of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine than the soprano saxophonist Paul Winter. In his explorations of natural sound over the years Mr. Winter, a dedicated environmentalist, has woven recorded wolf and whale cries into his pieces and even played a concert in the Grand Canyon.

title: DWG Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary charge of $20,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $350,000, or 2 cents a share for the 6 months.

title: Review/Dance; After Leaving The Garden
description: ''After Eden,'' a signature 1966 pas de deux choreographed by John Butler to music by Lee Hoiby, takes another look at Adam and Eve after they've left the Garden. As performed by Sarita Allen and Stephen Smith in a program presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday night at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, the duet was a gripping contest of wills and weaknesses.

title: When Life Is a Medical and Not a Legal Issue; Who Will Be Safe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Sentencing Policy, Disabled
description: When Congress created the U.S. Sentencing Commission in 1984, the idea was to get sentencing policy for Federal crimes out of politics. The commission deserves credit for producing a new sentencing code but its deliberations have been marked by false starts and tormented by internal bickering. And now its work is inhibited by three vacancies on the seven-member board.

title: Montclair Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $109,000 charge for costs associated with the bank's subsequently terminated agreement to affiliate with First Fidelity Bancorp of New Jersey. c-Included $358,000 charge for First Fidelity costs.

title: F.A.A. Admits Delay in Enforcing Security Rules
description: Tighter aviation security rules ordered after the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 a year ago have been slow to take hold, a special commission investigating the bombing was told today.

title: Marriott Plans Retreat From Fast-Food Wars
description: Complaining of ''hamburger wars,'' carryout pizza places and McDonald's, in particular, the Marriott Corporation said yesterday that it was getting out of the highly competitive fast-food business in downtown areas and along the nation's byways.

title: Shannon Airport Plan
description: A $122 million aircraft maintenance center will be built at Shannon Airport in Ireland, the three companies that will jointly own and operate the project said today. GPA Group, the Irish leasing company that owns Guiness Peat Aviation, will own 30 percent, while Lufthansa and Swissair will own 35 percent each of Shannon Aerospace Ltd., the company formed to construct, operate and own the maintenance center. Construction of the 300,000-square-foot aircraft overhaul and maintenance center will begin this spring, at the airport on Ireland's west coast, the companies said.

title: New York's Sinking Child-Care System Awaits Help
description: With evidence mounting that New York City's child welfare system is overwhelmed, experts are increasingly suggesting radical changes, including the virtual dismantling of the system.

title: Concern for Freshman
description: The missing Indiana University player, Lawrence Funderburke, has been in touch with the University of Missouri to inquire about transferring there, an Indianapolis television station reported yesterday.

title: Retread a Tire to Keep It Out of the Dump
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Sailor's Dream, Sailor's Nightmare
description: If not for the nightmare that preceded it, Kendall Truitt, Gunner's Mate 3d Class, U.S.N., might have thought a dream had come true. What sailor wouldn't like to tell off the whole Navy, in a televised Congressional hearing? A House subcommittee listened as Mr. Truitt testified that the Navy's conclusion that another gunner, Clayton Hartwig, caused an explosion on the battleship Iowa was ''a big cover-up'' of the ship's safety lapses.

title: International Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rules Halt Some Suffolk Aid for Heat
description: Hundred of Suffolk County families on welfare or fixed incomes are being denied emergency aid to pay for heating oil and utility bills because of new state regulations that bar assistance to people who live in multifamily houses with common utility meters or oil tanks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Review/Television; Profile of an Early Traveler On the Road to Civil Rights
description: Viewers who don't know as much as they might about black history have the opportunity this evening to meet one of its heroines. ''Ida B. Wells: A Passion for Justice'' tells of the brave life and works of the 19th-century journalist, known among black reporters as ''princess of the press,'' who led the nation's first anti-lynching campaign. The hourlong program, on Channel 13 at 10 and Channel 49 at 9, is a strong start to a second season of ''The American Experience.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday misstated H. Fisk Johnson's new position at S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. (Johnson Wax). He was named general manager for Canada, not a vice president of the company.

title: U.S. Will Hold Up Restarting Of Savannah River Reactors
description: In a concession to environmentalists, the Energy Department has decided not to restart its Savannah River nuclear reactors until an environmental impact study is completed, a department letter says.

title: Poland's Inflation Slows
description: Retail prices soared 22.4 percent last month in Poland as industrial output fell. For the 12 months that ended in November, retail prices were up 557 percent. But a sharp slowdown in the monthly rise in prices - from 54.8 percent in October - offered some hope that the Solidarity-led Government's free-market policies were beginning to have a positive effect. The central statistical office said the slowdown was largely caused by an easing in the increase in food prices, from 65 percent in October to 17.4 percent in November.

title: Manila Journal; Reliving the Longest Day, Envoy Speaks Softly
description: By the time American warplanes buzzed the Philippines' presidential palace and a rebel-controlled military airfield here, cutting short a coup attempt this month, Nicholas Platt was already 14 hours into ''what has to have been the longest day of my life.''

title: A Block of Stores Burns in Bronx
description: A stubborn four-alarm fire burned for six hours yesterday in the Bronx in a block-long strip of stores that was heavily damaged by a blaze set by arsonists a week ago, fire officials said.

title: Art's Way Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Critics Circle Selects 'Left Foot' for Best Film and Actor
description: ''My Left Foot,'' the film biography of Christy Brown, a disabled Irish writer, was voted best film of 1989 by the New York Film Critics Circle, a group whose 27 members represent various New York-based daily and weekly publications. Daniel Day-Lewis, who portrays Mr. Brown, was voted best actor.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bulgarian Turks in Sweden Protest Immigration Curbs
description: Thousands of ethnic Turks who fled Bulgaria went on a hunger strike today to protest a tighter immigration policy, the national radio reported.

title: Nike Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The 'Peace Dividend': A Rubber Check
description: In what is being billed by the Administration as a victory for ''deficit reduction,'' the Pentagon is settling for a fiscal 1991 budget of $292 billion.

title: F-16s Collide Over Germany
description: Two American F-16 fighter-bombers collided over a southern part of West Germany today, dropping an engine and ammunition through the roof of a vegetable market. One of the pilots was killed but no civilians were hurt in the accident, the police said. The other pilot escaped without serious injury. The F-16s, each carrying ammunition, were on a training flight when they collided near Maxdorf.

title: The Limits of Transplantation: How Far Should Surgeons Go?
description: AS organ transplantation becomes increasingly successful, surgeons are facing a new series of thorny practical and ethical issues.

title: More Retail Shifts at Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it had dropped its 10-year association with the model Cheryl Tiegs and loosened its marketing ties to the Walt Disney Company as it struggles to reshape its retailing image.

title: F.B.I. Discounts Salvador Inquiry Role
description: The Justice Department said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation played only a minor role in the questioning of a woman who linked the Salvadoran Army to the killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador last month.

title: General Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Included a gain on disposal of discontinued operations, net of income taxes, of $10,288,000, or 33 cents a share. The company said the reduction in revenue in the latest quarter is principally due to the sale of the Clare Relay division in January.

title: JG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net loss The company said latest quarter figures included a net gain of $2,529,000 from the sale of its Barker Bros. furniture division in August. Prior third quarter results included Barker Bros. sales of $13,574,000, while the latest quarter excludes this division. The results included sales from the Barker Bros. division of $27,101,000 for the first two quarters of the latest year and $37,181,000 for the three quarters in the prior year.

title: Daedalus Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The company said the reduction in net earnings is attributable primarily to increases in research and development and the exhaustion of all tax loss and credit carryforwards which contributed approximately $150,000 to the net earnings of the period ended Oct. 31, 1988.

title: Georgia-Pacific Makes a Move
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that it had started soliciting shareholders of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to call a special meeting to consider replacing Great Northern's board with nominees who support its multibillion-dollar takeover offer.

title: 6-Week Strike Over At Rolls-Royce
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., a maker of aviation engines, cut its workweek from 39 to 37 hours to end a six-week strike by 2,000 engineering workers at its Glasgow plant. The workers voted by a 3-to-1 ratio Saturday in favor of a management offer to reduce the basic work week to 37 hours by November 1991, Rolls-Royce and union leaders said. They returned to work today. In return, local unions agreed to greater flexibility on working practices and job training to prevent a falloff in productivity at the plant. Agreement on a 37-hour workweek by 1992 has already been negotiated at two other engineering companies: Smiths Industries P.L.C. of Cheltenham and NEI-Parsons of Newcastle-upon-Tyne.

title: Discrimination Appeal To Be Heard in Court
description: The Minnesota Supreme Court has agreed to hear the appeal of a landlord convicted of discrimination by denying housing to an unmarried couple.

title: Annual Bird Counts Are Starting to Yield Scientific Insights
description: WHAT began in the last century as a Christmas hunting contest has become an annual count of North American birds that provides scientists and conservationists with incomparable data about hundreds of species.

title: Slaying Leads Florida Leader To Consider Bulletproof Vest
description: Gov. Bob Martinez, whose life has been threatened by Colombian drug traffickers, said today that he would consider wearing a bulletproof vest after the assassination of a Federal judge in Alabama.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi, Again, For British Air
description: Six years after Saatchi & Saatchi introduced its award-winning ''Manhattan Landing'' commercial for British Airways, in which the island of Manhattan appeared to land at Heathrow Airport, the London agency has once again produced a major image-building ad for the airline.

title: Eagles Stumble and Fall Behind Giants in East
description: The New Orleans Saints interrupted Philadelphia's quest for a second straight National Football Conference East title tonight, beating the Eagles, 30-20, behind three touchdown passes from John Fourcade and a defense that forced four turnovers.

title: American Ship Building Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leading Hard-Line Politician Is Elected to Iran's Parliament
description: Former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi of Iran won a seat over the weekend in the country's Parliament, giving him a public platform to advocate the hard-line views held by a wide group of Iranian politicians.

title: Single Europe Banking License Set for '93
description: The European Community today approved the last step for creating a single banking license that would allow a bank licensed in one community nation to open as many branches as it would like anywhere in the community.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. UNICEF EXECUTIVE BOARD - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Duplex Products reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Assembly, Facing a Veto by Kean, Increases Pensions for Lawmakers
description: The New Jersey Assembly approved bills today that would raise the salaries of the governor, members of the cabinet and judges in 1991 and improve the pensions of legislators in 1992.

title: Dow Falls 42.02; Real Estate Woes Cited
description: Stock prices were broadly lower yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost 42.02 points, or 1.53 percent, to end at 2,697.53.

title: Q&A
description: Dust of Ages Q. Why do the structures of ancient civilizations sink so far below the surface? A. Although archeologists ''tend to uncover things,'' that is not because ruins have sunk beneath the surface, said David Webster, professor of anthropology at Pennsylvania State University. Instead, he said, they are usually covered over with newer buildings or natural deposits of sand and debris. There are exceptions, said Dr. Webster, who specializes in Maya archeology in Mexico, Honduras and Guatemala. ''For example, in Mexico City, the Aztecs built temples on a lake bed, where they did sink,'' he said. ''Modern buildings sink there for the same reason. But in the Maya area, the buildings on bed rock are right there where they always were.''

title: What's Under the Tree? Clues to a Relationship
description: WHAT'S in a gift? Telling clues to the relationship of the giver and receiver, social scientists say.

title: Mallard Coach Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Tokyo Arbitrage for 2 U.S. Firms
description: At least two top Wall Street firms that halted much of their program trading activity on Wall Street in October, when criticism of that practice reached fever pitch, are engaged in that business for their own account in Tokyo.

title: Careers; Job Help For Laid-Off Employees
description: THANKS to downsizings and mergers, the outplacement industry is growing fast.

title: Metro Datelines; Churches Plan Week For 'Good Neighbors'
description: A broad spectrum of religious leaders announced plans yesterday for a Good Neighbor Week next month to help ease the city's racial and religious tensions by encouraging people to get to know one another.

title: U.S. Lessons: Drafting And Diving
description: rrWith an assist from the elegant forearm of Sophia Loren, the United States soccer team is now firmly ensconced in the attractive Florence-Rome portion of the World Cup tournament next June.

title: Mounting Problems Delay Shuttle Launching
description: Continuing problems with launching pad equipment, combined with the approach of the holidays, have forced a postponement of the next space shuttle mission until at least Jan. 8, the space agency announced today.

title: Risks Seen In Using Certain Sleep Aids
description: Elderly people who use certain long-lasting sleeping pills or tranquilizers, including Vali um, are 70 percent more likely to fall and fracture their hips than those who take no such drugs, a new study has found.

title: Soo Line Accepts $21.50-a-Share Bid
description: The Soo Line Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to accept a revised takeover offer of $21.50 a share from Canadian Pacific Ltd. On Oct. 18 Canadian Pacific offered $19.50 a share. Canadian Pacific already owns 56 percent of Soo Line's 9.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Somber Pageant Focuses on AIDS Sufferers
description: Francisco and Gloria, who played the roles of Joseph and Mary in a Christmas procession here Friday, brought a modern message to a centuries-old story of rejection.

title: Stock Sold By Inland To Nippon
description: Inland Steel Industries said today that it had sold 185,000 shares of newly issued preferred stock to Japan's Nippon Steel Corporation for $185 million.

title: Eastern Air Said to Be Near Deal
description: In an agreement that is close to being signed, American Airlines would buy the Latin American routes of Eastern Airlines for almost $350 million and pay Continental Airlines about $100 million to settle a lawsuit over American's computerized airline reservations system, a person close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: New Spin on Hard Disk
description: NOTHING improves the performance of a computer more than switching from a system based on floppy disks to one with a hard disk drive. But hard drives are not immortal. They fail from age and accident, carelessness and the hostile nature of the universe.

title: Community Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings for the comparable year is not available since no stock was issued prior to November 1988.

title: Books of The Times; The Self-Told Tale of a Dying Man
description: In the Face of Death By Peter Noll Translated by Hans Noll. 254 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Oak Hires New Chief To Revitalize Company
description: William S. Antle 3d, who six months ago started a concern that helps companies improve their performance, has become president and chief executive of Oak Industries. His mission is to return the San Diego company to profitability.

title: Chileans Divided Over Left's Poor Showing
description: The poor showing in elections last week by Congressional candidates from parties of the far left, particularly the Communist Party, is a matter of relief for many Chileans but of concern to others.

title: Kasler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Collins Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $192,000, or 6 cents a share, and $699,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $196,000 for the quarter and $1,768,000 for the year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in SportsMonday this week about the Loews Cup squash tournament gave an outdated name for the site. It was the New York Sports Club, formerly called the Uptown Racquet Club.

title: Congressman Calls for Legalizing Drugs
description: Representative George W. Crockett Jr. has called for the decriminalization of drugs, becoming the first member of Congress to do so publicly and drawing sharp criticism from the director of Federal drug policy.

title: Comtech Telecommunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Metro-Richelieu Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $16,841,000. c-Net income and after an extraordinary loss of $905,000. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: By Design; Wearing Men's Hats
description: Women have always got a kick out of purloining some piece of men's clothing. Last week, it was their hats. When icy winds and weather descended on the city, women who ordinarily walk around bare-headed went shopping for warm coverings. A good many ended their search in the men's department.

title: Canadian Western Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Music; Scandinavians Tell of Love and Nature
description: The New York Festival of Song presented the third installment of an eight-concert overview of the art-song literature on Sunday afternoon at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street. The repertory offered by the festival is broad and international, and it balances familiar works with songs drawn from neglected corners of the literature.

title: Corrections#YES#
description: An article yesterday about a former neo-Nazi who now speaks against anti-Semitism misidentified a Californian who quit the White Student Union and also now works with Jewish organizations. He is Gregory Withrow.

title: Sihanouk Explains His High-Wire Role in Awkward Cambodian Coalition
description: Now 67 years old, Prince Norodom Sihanouk still sits in a gilded exile in the old French legation here, pampered by the Chinese, monitored by the Khmer Rouge and haunted by the past and by the fear of making one final, disastrous error to the detriment of the independent Cambodia he has devoted his soul to achieving.

title: Couple Back in U.S. With 28 Haitian Children
description: An Indiana missionary couple re-entered the United States today with 28 Haitian children they intend to adopt.

title: Jock Mahoney Is Dead; Film Stuntman Was 70
description: Jock Mahoney, a former stuntman who acted in such television shows as ''Yancy Derringer'' and ''The Range Rider,'' died Thursday, apparently of a stroke, at Harrison Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old and had been hospitalized after an automobile accident two days earlier.

title: Review/Concert; Panufnik Argues Case for His Own Music
description: Andrzej Panufnik is one of those composers not made for great celebrity. His music represents neither a daring thrust beyond the gravitational pull of 19th-century Romanticism nor a luxurious retreat back into it.

title: Righetti Starts Over As Yankee Reliever
description: One night last September, in the final days of a season that had already slipped into the past, Dave Righetti sat in a corner of the Yankee clubhouse and faced the realization that he would become a starting pitcher again.

title: Doctors Said to Miss Depression Half of Times
description: Doctors fail to recognize severe depression in half the patients who suffer it, and the problem is even worse in prepaid health plans, researchers say.

title: Fastcomm Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $8,397 from tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: Social Security Chief Scolds Staff Over Handling of Disability Cases
description: Gwendolyn S. King, the new Commissioner of Social Security, has strongly criticized the agency's staff over the handling of disability cases, providing the strongest evidence yet that the Bush Administration intends to break with stringent policies of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: Jetronic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $10,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $38,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months, from utilization of operating-loss carryforwards. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $222,000 for the quarter and $30,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary credit of $197,000, or 8 cents a share, for the both periods.

title: Morris Furman, Realty Developer, 80
description: Morris Furman, a real-estate developer and philanthropist, died Sunday of complications of a stroke in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Upheaval in the East; Transylvania Casts Off Rumania's Tall Shadow
description: Ethnic Hungarians in Rumania, who trace their proud history back to the Middle Ages and today comprise 2 million of the nation's 23 million people, have long struggled to sustain their linguistic, religious and cultural identity against Rumanian nationalism and Soviet Communism.

title: Jets Begin Overhaul by Hiring Steinberg as General Manager
description: The Jets began overhauling their football team today by hiring Dick Steinberg, the New England Patriots' player-development director, as vice president and general manager.

title: Quicker Rabies Test Is Developed
