description: A NEW test that can detect the rabies virus in animals in just four days, rather than the 30 days needed for the current method, has been developed by researchers at the New York State Department of Health.

title: More Support for India Leader
description: As a new Parliament assembled here, Prime Minister V. P. Singh today picked up the backing of several more legislators from small regional parties, strengthening his position.

title: Chess
description: The story is told about the time Anatoly Karpov's analysis team showed him their new idea for an opening in which he was looking for something better than what had been played up to that point. They dug up a speculative gambit that had what they thought was a solid positional basis, a powerful initiative and great attacking chances. After observing all this, the Soviet former world champion said, ''Yes, yes, I see my pawn is gone, but where is the mate?''

title: 120 Sentenced for Rebellion In a South African Homeland
description: A judge sentenced 120 rebel soldiers today to prison terms ranging from 3 to 10 years for their role in a failed attempt to topple the government of one of South Africa's black homelands.

title: Bass Group Lifts Its Stake in Vons
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass, the Fort Worth financier, has raised its stake in the Vons Companies 14 percent from 12.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that it had bought 575,700 Vons shares last Thursday for $19.54 a share.

title: Hershey-Ronzoni
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation confirmed that it had tentatively agreed to acquire the Ronzoni Foods Corporation, an important expansion of Hershey's pasta business, which is No. 2 in the industry. Hershey, which had previously said it was negotiating the purchase, would not disclose the tentative purchase price of Ronzoni, a part of Kraft General Foods, a unit of Philip Morris Companies. But it said that the deal must still be approved by the Department of Justice. Ronzoni's dry pasta, pasta sauces and cheese businesses had revenues of about $80 million in 1988. With a 9 percent market share, Ronzoni would increase Hershey's share to about 27 percent. The market leader, Borden Inc., has about 32 percent.

title: In Once-Pristine Antarctica, a Complicated Cleanup Begins
description: PRESSED by environmental groups, the United States has taken a long step toward cleaning up its aging, untidy stations in Antarctica.

title: Plan Urges Speed in Bailout
description: The Bush Administration will tell regulators to start immediately selling more than $300 billion in assets of failed savings and loan associations as part of its rescue of the industry, according to a plan scheduled for release by the end of the year.

title: Fernandez Appoints 3 And Renames 6 to Posts
description: Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday named additional top aides to his new administration, including Nilda Soto-Ruiz, a longtime insider in the Board of Education who is highly regarded by her colleagues.

title: Physicians Rid a Man's Body Of AIDS Virus in Experiment
description: For the first time, researchers have apparently eradicated the AIDS virus from a patient's body, but experts caution that many more patients must be treated before the effectiveness of the technique can be fully determined.

title: Lower Expenditures Balance a Decrease In Corporate Taxes
description: Corporate tax receipts for the last two months indicate that New York City will receive $110 million less than expected in the fiscal year ending June 30, but this should not throw the budget out of balance because some expenses are also lower, the city's budget director said yesterday.

title: Arsenio Hall Denies Plagiarizing Buchwald Script in Making Film
description: Arsenio Hall testified today that he and his best friend, Eddie Murphy, conceived the idea for the movie ''Coming to America'' with no help from an earlier script idea by the columnist Art Buchwald.

title: Science Watch; Threatening Mistletoe
description: Dwarf mistletoe, a close relative of the leafy mistletoe of Christmas lore and a major cause of tree loss, is more pervasive in older stands of spruce trees in the Northeast than once commonly thought, forestry experts say.

title: Man in the News; A Chief Known for Turning Strife Into Calm; Lee Patrick Brown
description: Lee P. Brown has made a career of taking over strife-torn police departments in racially troubled cities and bringing a relative sense of calm.

title: New System Warns of Volcano Dust, but a Plane Still Flies Into Trouble
description: A NEW satellite system to warn aircraft of dangerous plumes of volcanic dust got its first test last week, with dismal results.

title: Homeless Project Is Rejected
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators, in a surprise vote, narrowly defeated a proposal today to build housing for 108 homeless families on 33 wooded acres in the town of Greenburgh.

title: For 90 Students, Contest Was Lost in the Mail
description: Bad luck apparently prevailed over brilliance yesterday. At least 90 seniors at Stuyvesant High School lost their chance for thousands of dollars worth of college scholarships after their entries in a national science competition were received after the contest deadline, even though school officials insist they were sent on time.

title: Answering Questions About Fonts
description: THE so-called Font Wars rage on in the personal computer industry, but in the spirit of the holidays let us pause in a lull in the fighting to celebrate a major victory for Apple Macintosh users. Adobe Type Manager, a utility from Adobe Systems Inc., (415) 961-4400, is a true gift to Mac owners, even though it costs $99.

title: S.E.C. Post on Foreign Ties
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was creating a post to coordinate enforcement cooperation with foreign stock regulators.

title: Alpine Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,291,000 and $2,598,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains on extinguishment of debt of $13,470,000, or $2.98 a share for the quarter and $13,876,000, or $3.06 a share for the 6 months. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $1,301,000 and $1,762,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Old Canada Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Walton Defends Using Injured O'Brien Against Rams
description: Coach Joe Walton insisted today that he did nothing unusual by bringing Ken O'Brien, who is slated for possible surgery this week, into Sunday's game in an attempt to rally the Jets from a 28-7 deficit against the Rams.

title: Community And Soviets In First Pact
description: The Soviet Union and the European Community today signed a commercial accord that calls for ending most European Community quotas on Soviet products.

title: Pittsburgh Announces Gottfried's Dismissal
description: The University of Pittsburgh yesterday officially dismissed Mike Gottfried, the head football coach, four days after his ouster had been leaked to reporters. Paul Hackett, the offensive coordinator, was appointed acting head coach.

title: Forecast for the Flu Season: Not Bad, and an Early Peak
description: This year's flu season may peak earlier than it did last year, but there is no sign that it will be abnormally bad, an influenza specialist at the Federal Centers for Disease Control says.

title: How Power Passed to Communists in Postwar Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor:

title: Education Units Support Turner's Program
description: Four national education groups said today that they support the Turner Broadcasting Company's commercial-free news program for classroom use.

title: Imagine Films reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $260,000, or 5 cents a share, for both periods, from utilization of tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: More Ramos Surgeryu
description: Ramon Ramos, the Portland Trail Blazer rookie who has been in a coma since suffering a severe brain injury in an automobile accident early Saturday, underwent emergency surgery yesterday after taking a sudden turn for the worse.

title: Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KEY RATES
Upheaval in the East; Once the Leading Edge, Hungary Loses Its Place
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, ending a two-day visit here, applauded Hungary today for its role in bringing about the ''unforgettable days'' of the last few months.

title: How the Deficit Adds Up
description: The buzzword among surveyors of Government management problems comes from accounting.

title: Capote's Face as A Work Of Art
description: It was 6:31 P.M., hardly the customary hour for theatrical miracles on Broadway. Robert Morse, a 30-year veteran of the stage, was sitting in his dressing room at the Booth Theater and saying, ''I have never before been in a role where I had to be so elaborately made up.''

title: Biomet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bridge
description: The last major knockout team championship of the eighties was won Sunday night by a foursome headed by Sue Snow. She is an Australian who has represented her country on many international occasions, and will soon return there, spurred by impending maternity, after a three-year residence in Manhattan.

title: Mony Real Estate Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Supreme Court to Transmit Decisions by Computer
description: Taking a giant step into the computer age, the Supreme Court announced today that it would soon start making its decisions available to the public electronically within moments after they are handed down from the bench.

title: Simon Stein, Doctor, 93
description: Simon Stein, a doctor who specialized in the treatment of ear, nose and throat ailments, died of a stroke on Saturday at the Ridge Terrace Health Care Center in Lantana, Fla. He was 93 years old and until recently lived in Boca Raton.

title: Stewart Klonis Is Dead at 86; Directed the Art Students League
description: Stewart Klonis, executive director of the Art Students League for 34 years until his retirement in 1980, died in his sleep on Saturday. He was 86 years old, and lived at the Palm Beach Home for Adults in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.

title: EAC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $341,000 and $772,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $140,000, or 7 cents a share for the quarter and $1,402,000, or 72 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: Friction and Flare-Ups as the Playoffs Near
description: Brian Bosworth said in a Sunday night ESPN interview that friendships and decorum among National Football League players and teams were exaggerated and relatively nonexistent.

title: CBS Names New Chief of Programming
description: CBS, as expected, named Jeff Sagansky as its new president of entertainment yesterday, reaching outside the company for a chief programmer for the first time in the network's history.

title: ISRAEL AUTHORIZES APPROACH TO P.L.O.
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that his ministry authorized and paid for meetings between relatives of Israeli soldiers captured during the invasion of Lebanon and representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Ashland Journal; Going Home as a Doctor To a Debt and His Roots
description: For as long as he can remember, Roger Pelli has wanted to be a doctor. But when he finally gained admission to medical school on his third try, the 32-year-old father of two had one big problem: no money.

title: Campbell Soup Family Disbands Voting Trust
description: Nine descendants of a founder of the Campbell Soup Company, have agreed to disband a family voting trust that controls 26.5 percent of the company's shares.

title: Diodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $30,590,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Dr. Brown, Police Commissioner
description: Some may say that Lee Brown's race - he is black - played a big role in his appointment as New York City's next police commissioner. But race ought to be irrelevant: he is, by all accounts, one of the finest police executives in the country.

title: Risks to A-Plant Workers Were Ignored, Study Says
description: The Federal Government was warned before 1950 that thousands of workers at nuclear weapons plants were being exposed to dangerous levels of radiation, but decided against telling them of the risks, according to a Congressional staff report made public yesterday.

title: McDaniel And Oakley Suspended And Fined
description: Charles Oakley of the Knicks and Xavier McDaniel of the Seattle SuperSonics were fined $7,500 apiece and suspended for one game yesterday by the National Basketball Association for their Saturday night fight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Upheaval in the East; Czech Army Denies a Coup Plan; Opposition Leader Offers Support
description: On the eve of a pivotal session of the Czechoslovak Parliament, a spokesman for the army went on national radio to deny reports of preparations for a military coup, and the leader of the opposition group Civic Forum, Vaclav Havel, voiced support for the recently appointed Minister of Defense, Col. Gen. Miroslav Vacek, and urged soldiers to follow his orders.

title: Paul B. Richards, Contractor, 68
description: Paul B. Richards, managing director of the General Building Contractors of New York State for 30 years until his retirement in 1987, died of a heart attack Saturday at Albany Medical Center Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in New Salem, N.Y.

title: CSP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Upheaval in the East; Farmers, Fearing a Drop in Prices, Criticize Poland's Economic Plan
description: The far-reaching economic program of the Solidarity-led Government came under attack today from farmers' representatives, who said they preferred guaranteed minimum prices to the risks of a free market.

title: Cooper Cos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $4,446,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $16,726,000 for the year, both from sale of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $3,519,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $3,786,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from sale of discontinued operations of $113,934,000 and $123,947,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $11,272,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the losses from sale of discontinued operations included income from operations of $12,150,000, or 52 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter and $2,137,000, or 9 cents a share, in the 1988 year. The company also said 1988 results were restated to reflect Cooper Technicon, which was sold, as a discontinued operation. The company said its results from continuing operations are not directly comparable because of the disposition of certain of its assets.

title: 'This Infamous Act'
description: On Nov. 10, 1975, the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted an Arab-inspired resolution defining Zionism as a ''form of racism and racial discrimination.''

title: Arizona Governor Has Surgery
description: Gov. Rose Mofford underwent surgery today for an infected gallbladder and to clear blockages believed caused by gallstones. The Governor, who is 67 years old, was admitted on Sunday to St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center complaining of chest pains, but no heart trouble was found, doctors said.

title: Goodmark Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Proposal Made On Centralizing For Purchasing
description: Saying millions of dollars are being wasted at a time of serious budget deficits, the State Government Integrity Commission called on New York City's incoming administration yesterday to centralize its purchasing system.

title: Sports News Briefs; Dravecky Wins Hutch Award
description: Dave Dravecky has been voted the 1989 winner of the Hutch Award.

title: Blount Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $119,411,000, or $9.94 a share and $129,601,000, or $10.78 a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which included $127,500,000 aftertax gain on the sale of the company's specialty steel business offset by a $10,500,000 aftertax charge for the sale or discontinuance of certain other operations, and the 9 months also included a loss from an accounting adjustment of $10,834,000 based on a change in accounting for claim revenue on construction contracts. The year-ago losses from continuing operations of $63,189,000 and $73,933,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both included $61,700,000 aftertax charge against continuing operations.

title: Volcano Keeps Flights Grounded in Anchorage
description: Redoubt Volcano continued to spew clouds of steam and gritty volcanic ash high into the sky today, forcing airlines to ground flights or route them around the abrasive powder for fear of engine damage.

title: Manatron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
General Cinema reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $865,935,000, or $11.73 a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,203,000, or 19 cents a share for the quarter and $61,593,000, or 83 cents a share for the year.

title: Nichols, S E Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $806,000, or 17 cents a share, for both periods, on the early retirement of subordinated debt; the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $5,171,000, or $1.09 a share, which included a $4 million pre- tax gain from the sale of the F.R. Schreiber division. c-After income from discontinued operations of $677,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,448,000, or 31 cents a share, for the 9 months. The latest 9 months' income from continuing operations included $770,000 pre-tax operating losses prior to closure and a $3.8 million provision for costs and expenses relating to the previously announced 11-store closure program. Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations included $1.2 million pre-tax gain on the sale of realty.

title: Market Place; Liquidation Vote At Realty Trusts
description: INVESTORS in two troubled real estate investment trusts in Dallas, both the offspring of the ill-fated Southmark Corporation, are being asked by current management to reverse a liquidation process begun more than four years ago.

title: Morrison Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Included an income from discontinued operations of $432,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Charter Power Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from cumulative effect of change in accounting principle of $2,700,000. Year-ago results were restated to reflect the cumulative effect of the adoption of SFAS No. 96 (accounting for income taxes).

title: Upheaval in the East; Leipzig Marchers Tiptoe Around Reunification
description: The marchers at the regular Monday demonstration in Leipzig today exchanged most of their banners for candles and their chants for silence - to commemorate ''victims of Stalinism,'' and to cool passions that have begun to flare in recent weeks over the issue of German reunification.

title: Review/Music; A Mixed Bag for Christmas From the Chamber Society
description: Like a slightly perverse Santa Claus, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center took the Alice Tully Hall stage over the weekend with a lumpy bag of unexpected and delightful oddities in tow. The holiday program ranged historically from Heinrich Biber's ''Battalia'' (1673) to Arthur Maddox's ''Little Tricker the Squirrel Meets Big Double the Bear'' (1988) and sylistically from the raucous humor of Mozart's ''Musical Joke'' (1787) to the sophisticated eccentricity of Stravinsky's Three Pieces for String Quartet (1914).

title: Corcoran Gallery's Director Resigns Under Fire
description: Dr. Christina Orr-Cahall, the director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, resigned today after six months of debate and controversy over her decision to cancel an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: Smith Labs Agrees To Merger Plan
description: Smith Laboratories of San Diego, a medical equipment manufacturing company, agreed to merge with the privately held Columbia Hospital Corporation of Fort Worth in a stock swap. Under the agreement, Smith will become a subsidiary of Columbia, which was founded two years ago by the investors Richard Rainwater and Richard Scott.

title: Campbell Shares Up on Speculation
description: The Campbell Soup Company's stock soared on renewed takeover speculation a day after the family-run company disclosed that a trust holding 26.5 percent of its voting shares had been dissolved. Campbell rose $4.75 a share today, to $54.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 9.6 percent gain was the fourth best of the day.

title: Review/Music; A Bit of Humor and Nudity
description: It could be argued that contemporary music might have a larger audience if composers endowed their works with a touch of humor. Humor and, perhaps, a bit of nudity. Gerald Busby, a composer and pianist with a decidedly impish streak, included both those elements in a concert of his works at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday evening.

title: OEA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $266,000, or 8 cents a share, from cumulative effect of acounting change.

title: Jordan Plans to Lift Martial Law
description: Prime Minister Mudar Badran told the new Parliament today that his Government would lift martial law, which for 22 years has banned large public meetings and allowed the authorities to restrict freedom of speech.

title: Herbert Blaize, 71, Grenada Chief Who Won Vote After the Invasion
description: Prime Minister Herbert A. Blaize of Grenada, a longtime political figure in that Caribbean island nation who regained power after United States armed forces invaded to oust a leftist Government there in 1983, died yesterday morning at his official residence. He was 71 years old.

title: Bush to Name Kitty Dukakis
description: President Bush will nominate Kitty Dukakis, the wife of his former Democratic Presidential rival, for a post on the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, the White House said today. Mrs. Dukakis, who is Jewish, has previously served on the President's Commission on the Holocaust, which is being replaced by the council. The commission was set up to raise money and build a museum in memory of the Jews exterminated by the Nazis.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BSN Corp., Dallas, a sporting goods and women's sportswear retailer, said it wants to reacquire Cheerleader Supply Co. for $40 million from Prospect Group Inc., a railroad operator and specialized consumer products company.

title: Upheaval in the East; I.M.F. Loan Pact With Warsaw Is Delayed
description: Poland, seeking large amounts of Western aid to switch to a free-market economy, today unexpectedly delayed signing a crucial loan deal with the International Monetary Fund and the fund's negotiators returned to Washington.

title: GEAC Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $600,000, or 3 cents a share and $6,200,000, or 29 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $1,000,000, or 5 cents a share for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mayflower Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Higher Cancer Risk Found in Radiation
description: The risk of getting cancer from low levels of radiation appears to be four times as high as previously estimated, the National Research Council said today.

title: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, 92, Noted Military Planner for U.S.
description: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, a noted American military planner and commander in World War II, died Sunday at Fort Belvoir, Va. He was 92 years old and had been in declining health.

title: New Materials Altering the Aircraft Industry
description: The race to develop stronger, lighter materials that will make aircraft sturdier and more fuel-efficient is intensifying. After a sluggish start a few years ago, a lighter version of aluminum, called aluminum lithium, appears to be gaining a foothold in the aerospace industry. But the use of advanced-polymer composite materials - plastic resins reinforced by materials like glass or steel - is also growing quickly.

title: Upheaval in the East; Serbia Turns Down Call by Yugoslavia For Austerity Steps
description: Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, rejected an overhaul of the economy today, saying the drastic measures would create civil unrest.

title: Doctor Gets 3 Years' Probation for Infanticide
description: An obstetrician convicted of infanticide in the death of a fetus aborted in the eighth month of pregnancy was placed on three years' probation today and ordered to perform 300 hours of community service.

title: Florio Picks 2 Commissioners
description: Governor-elect James J. Florio today named the people he wants to head the Labor and Commerce Departments when his administration begins on Jan. 16.

title: Beirut, Unsure of Future, Embraces Holidays
description: Lebanese are preparing to celebrate Christmas and the New Year with fanfare rarely seen in 15 years of civil war.

title: Cambodians Like Hun Sen Government; Best in Centuries
description: To the Editor:

title: Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New York Court Voids Law on Abusive Language
description: New York State's highest court struck down a major provision of the state's harassment statute today, ruling that abusive and obscene language represented a constitutionally protected form of free speech.

title: Chief Auditor at Citicorp Finds Nosiness Pays Off
description: Dennis O. Green, named yesterday as head of Citicorp's worldwide auditing group, did not plan to become an auditor.

title: Tuscarora Plastics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Private Universities Hitting Tax Law Limit
description: One after another, private universities are reaching the Federal limit on tax-exempt bonds they may issue and are revising or delaying the construction projects for which the bonds were primarily used.

title: Upheaval in the East; Leaders of the 2 Germanys Meet; Symbolic Reconciliation Cheered
description: The leaders of the two Germanys met today for the first time since the East fell into the throes of protest and change, and in a symbolic reconciliation agreed to reopen the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin and introduce free movement across their border for all Germans by Christmas.

title: History and Memories of the Fight for Civil Rights
description: Freedom Bound A History of America's Civil Rights Movement By Robert Weisbrot 350 pages. Illustrated. W. W. Norton. $21.95. Voices of Freedom By Henry Hampton and Steve Fayer with Sarah Flynn 692 pages. Illustrated. Bantam Books. $25.95.

title: Du Pont Case Conviction
description: Three Argentine nationals were convicted today of trying to extort $10 million from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in exchange for documents the chemicals company contended were technological road maps to the manufacture of Lycra, a form of the popular stretch fiber spandex.

title: Neediest Gifts Come With Eloquence of Youth
description: Some of the most eloquent thoughts about giving to the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund come from some of the youngest donors and their parents.

title: Savannah Victim Is Called Quiet but Effective
description: Robert Edward Robinson, the lawyer who was killed Monday by a mail bomb, was a Savannah success story, according to friends and associates here.

title: Bomb at Envoy's Hom
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today it was pursuing several leads in last week's apparent attempt to firebomb the home of the Danish Ambassador to the United Nations. ''There are several leads we are following,'' an F.B.I. spokesman, Joseph Valiquette said. The authorities have not determined a motive for the incident.

title: Ketchum & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Western Europe Seeks Arab Economic Ties
description: A meeting of 22 Arab and 12 European Community foreign ministers is scheduled in Paris this week to revive a stumbling political and economic discussion between Western Europe and the Arab world.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Unit Faces Chapter 11
description: Lawyers for Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company told a group of bondholders yesterday that it was prepared to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation, the company it formed to acquire the Jim Walter Corporation last year for $2.4 billion. A Hillsborough representative confirmed the report.

title: Phoenix Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title:
Designs for Europe;
Regionalize, and Centralize, Europe
description: LEAD: A specter is haunting Europe, the specter of a united Germany. The best way of exorcising it -satisfying Germans without frightening everyone else - would be to bind the Germans into a stronger and more integrated European Community. That, in turn, will require some radical adjustments on the part of E.C.

title: H.U.D. Is Called Weak In Its Policing of Ethics
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has a weak system of policing for possible ethics violations by its officials and consultants, a Congressional study issued today says.

title: Maloney's Overtime Goal Ends Devils' Domination
description: The Islanders, on the verge of being used by the Devils as a divisional doormat for the third time in a week, erupted with a 5-4 overtime victory tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Washington Talk; Congress, Not Bush, Ponders Peace Issue
description: Congress is out of session, but Representative Lee H. Hamilton, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, would not wait until the lawmakers reconvene in January. Today he held his second hearing in two weeks on ''Economic Adjustment After the Cold War.''

title: Review/Theater; 'Merchant' Restored as a Comedy
description: Contrary to Broadway gospel, Dustin Hoffman does not have star billing in the new ''Merchant of Venice'' at the 46th Street Theater. That honor is reserved instead for the Peter Hall Company - or, to put a finer point on it, for Peter Hall. Once you've seen the production, in many ways an unexpected one, you'll understand that Mr. Hall isn't being pretentious and that Mr. Hoffman hasn't suddenly been struck by false modesty. This really is the director's ''Merchant'' - at times Shakespeare's, too - and Mr. Hoffman plays a supporting role.

title: Manor Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
9-Month Loss At Koor Unit
description: Tadiran, the electronics subsidiary of Israel's ailing Koor Industries, reported today that it had a record loss of $96 million for the first nine months of 1989. The unit, which said it would lay off up to 1,000 workers, lost $32 million in the period a year earlier.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TBWA Advertising Is Chosen by Steuben
description: Steuben, whose advertising account has been up for grabs since Doyle Graf Raj dissolved earlier this year, has chosen TBWA Advertising after a six-month search.

title: V for Victory Sweeps Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: The Crepes of Yore: Simplicity, Elegance and High Ceremony
description: I WAS a college student living in France when I discovered crepes.

title: Review/Film; Surveying What's Left When G.M. Leaves Town
description: ''Roger and Me'' was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27, 1989. The film opens today at Cinema Third Avenue, at 60th Street.

title: Residents in Vermont Decline to Bail Out an Idled Incinerator
description: Fearing for their health and their pocketbooks, residents of 25 Vermont communities have voted not to spend $19.5 million to buy a trash incinerator that was orphaned by the bankruptcy of its parent company.

title: Youths Who Look for a '10' in the Mirror
description: Wondering what to get your adolescent offspring for Christmas? How about something truly lavish, admittedly hard to wrap and put under the tree but absolutely irreplaceable? A nose job, for example.

title: Upheaval in the East; Rumania's Suppression of Protest Condemned by the U.S. as 'Brutal'
description: The White House today condemned Rumania's continuing crackdown on political demonstrators as ''brutal'' and said the United States was considering teaming up with its Western allies and Moscow to develop some kind of coordinated response.

title: Hong Kong's Move Worries Refugees Elsewhere
description: Britain's decision to send boat people back to Vietnam from Hong Kong is causing alarm among Vietnamese refugees and refugee workers throughout Southeast Asia.

title: A.T.&T. to Reduce Long-Distance Rates
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it would reduce rates by 1.3 to 2 percent on interstate and international long-distance services used primarily by residential and small-business customers.

title: Part of Dinkins Surplus Destined for Inaugural
description: The Campaign Finance Board yesterday authorized Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins to use $97,000 of surplus campaign money for his inaugural expenses. The money had originally been set aside for a runoff primary and would normally be carried forward for future elections.

title: Zimbabwe's Rulers and Foes Merge Parties at a Congress
description: The ruling party and main opposition merged today at their first national congress, charged with framing a new constitution.

title: Buchwald Takes On Studio, Lightly
description: The humorist Art Buchwald was in full form today as he took the stand in his $5 million lawsuit against Paramount Pictures, often provoking laughter in the crowded Los Angeles courtroom and even causing a usually stern-faced judge to smile more than once.

title: Lincoln Center Sampler
description: In a program intended to introduce young people to the performing arts, Lincoln Center is offering a family sampler of tickets to several performances from now until spring. The sampler, which will be on sale through the end of the month, includes ''The Nutcracker'' by the New York City Ballet, the Big Apple Circus, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, ''The Sound of Music'' by the New York City Opera and a guided tour of Lincoln Center. The combination ticket, at $140, is available by mail from Family Sampler, Public Affairs, Lincoln Center, 140 West 65th Street, New York, N.Y. 10023, or through Center Charge: 874-6770. Information: 877-1800, extension 433.

title: Merrill Sets Asset Sale
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it would sell off a large part of one of its divisions and lay off about 300 employees in the division within the next few months.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. signed a letter of intent with the Toppan Printing Company of Japan to establish a jointly owned United States company that would acquire and manage Texas Instruments' photomask operation in Dallas. The company said it would receive a cash payment of $19 million and would have a minority interest in the new company. A photomask is a photographic negative used to transfer chip circuitry patterns optically to a chip's surface from the computer where they were designed.

title: McDonnell Jet Factory Switch
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it would move the production of its T-45 Navy jet to St. Louis from its Douglas Aircraft division in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Upheaval in the East; GORBACHEV WINS VOTE ON ECONOMY
description: The Gorbachev leadership won legislative approval of its revamped economic program today, easily rebuffing a no-confidence vote from a thin weak line of opponents who warned that it amounted to a retreat from the promised reforms of perestroika.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., a discount retailer, promoted Dave Muensterman to president of its Crafts and More division.

title: BOOK NOTES
description: The Reclusive Pynchon Two days ago Little, Brown sent copies of Thomas Pynchon's forthcoming novel, ''Vineland,'' to some 200 critics and reviewers, few of whom have been neutral about the author's past work.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, a dance review in some copies on Saturday about ''Chelsea Bells'' by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater had an extraneous sentence fragment in place of the critic's name. The critic was Anna Kisselgoff.

title: Rogue Program Failed Its Own Test
description: The unusual design of a destructive computer program mailed to more than 10,000 computer users around the world may have undermined an elaborate extortion attempt, computer security experts said yesterday.

title: American Greetings reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $20.9 million ($11.9 million, or 37 cents a share, after taxes) for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Tab Products reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Review/Film; How an All-American Boy Went to War and Lost His Faith
description: As a teen-ager in Massapequa, L.I., in the 1960's, Ron Kovic believed in all of the right things, including God, country and the domino theory. He was Jack Armstrong, the all-American boy, good-looking, shy around girls and a surreptitious reader of Playboy. He was the archetypal son in a large archetypal lower-middle-class Roman Catholic family.

title: Nancy Green, 72, Theater Producer And Casting Head
description: Nancy W. Green, a theater producer and television casting director, died of a heart attack on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72 years old.

title: Testimony Ends in Drunken-Driving Case
description: Testimony ended today in the trial of the bus driver charged with killing 27 people, and lawyers said the nation's worst drunken-driving case might go to the jury Wednesday.

title: Paul W. Bradford, Executive, 89
description: Paul W. Bradford, a retired executive of American Express, died on Friday at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Youth Agency Accused In a Lawsuit of Neglect
description: The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union sued the state's child-welfare administration today, charging that the agency inadequately investigates child-abuse and neglect cases and fails to care for children who are removed from abusive homes.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Hanukkah, Apple Wine

title: AMR Deal On Eastern Routes Set
description: American Airlines confirmed last night that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Central and South American routes and other assets of Eastern Airlines in a deal valued at $471 million.

title: Poindexter Trial Judge Limits the Prosecution
description: A Federal judge ruled that testimony that Oliver L. North gave at his trial could not be used to convict a former superior, John M. Poindexter, who also faces charges related to the Iran-contra affair. The ruling was a setback to the Government's prosecution of Mr. Poindexter, since Mr. North had said at his trial that he acted at the behest of his superiors. But the extent to which it will hurt the Government's case is unclear, since the prosecution will be able to use the exhaustive testimony Mr. North gave to Congressional committees.

title: High Cost of Becoming Yellow-Cab Driver Discourages Recruits
description: To the Editor:

title: Worthington Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Clinical Trials of AIDS Drug Remain Crucial
description: To the Editor:

title: Mallard Coach Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Bankers Trust's Profit Lower After Bad Loans
description: The Bankers Trust Company, which had escaped the trend among other banks of higher lending losses this year, announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be cut by $90 million after taxes, because of losses on two large loans.

title: Premier Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
INSIDE
description: Conference of Soviet Jews The first Congress of Jewish Committees and Organizations of the Soviet Union pondered the conflicting goals of emigration and rebuilding Jewish life in the country. Page A18. New Estimate on Radiation The risk of getting cancer from low levels of radiation appears to be four times as high as previously estimated, a new report by the National Research Council said. Page A22. Cutting Firefighting's Cost In a decision that could save New York City $25 million a year, a collective-bargaining board says the number of firefighters on pumper trucks may be cut from five to four. Page B1. Train-Truck Collision Three people were killed and dozens were injured, some of them seriously, when an Amtrak train collided with a truck in the foggy San Joaquin Valley of California. Page A20. General Wedemeyer Dies Albert Wedemeyer, who played a leading role in the evolution of American policy toward China after World War II, was 92 years old. Page D23.

title: Construction of Housing Fell 4.7% in November
description: Housing starts dropped by 4.7 percent in November, pulled down by a big drop in multifamily construction.

title: About New York; Asian Refugees Discover Gold In Two Hearts
description: Robert and Beatrice Donofrio personify this season's best dream, the dream that anything is possible for those of good heart. He is a tattooed, plain-spoken civilian employee of the Police Department who has always lived on Staten Island. She grew up poor in the Philippines, found her way to America and earned a doctorate from Columbia University.

title: 6 Arrested at Times Building
description: Six people were arrested last night after blocking the entrance to the New York Times building in Manhattan as a part of a protest against the newspaper's reporting from El Salvador. About 80 people marched and chanted behind police barricades across the street from the paper's offices at 229 West 43d Street. The protest was organized by the New York Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador. The protesters said the reporting by The Times was sympathetic to the Government there. Six people wrapped in copies of The New York Times stained with red ink lay down in front of the entrance to the building and were arrested on trespassing charges. They were released and given court dates.

title: HRE Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included capital gains of $3,779,000, or 63 cents a share, and $5,341,000, or 89 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included capital gains of $120,000, or 2 cents a share, and $521,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest quarter and year results included $296,000 and $700,000 in costs, respectively, related to Kimco Group's takeover attempt.

title: Upheaval in the East; VISITORS HORRIFIED AT PROTEST SCENE
description: Two brothers, visiting from Hungary, were at a friend's apartment in the Rumanian city of Timisoara last Saturday night when someone rushed in to say the revolution had begun.

title: Morgan's Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $364,000 and $926,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Veal That Is Rich But Not Expensive
description: VEAL is one of the most delicate of meats and is the best to prepare in sauces. The prime cuts like the rack and fillet are expensive, but in the shoulder, flank, breast and shank, you can find delicious veal for very little money.

title: USE OF TESTIMONY BY NORTH LIMITED
description: In a setback to the Government's prosecution of John M. Poindexter, a Federal district judge ruled today that prosecutors could make only limited use of Oliver L. North as a witness in Mr. Poindexter's Iran-contra trial.

title: Review/Theater; Rumanian Directors' Views Of Shakespeare and Ionesco
description: The influence of transplanted Rumanian artists is being celebrated at the American Repertory Theater, with a pairing of productions - Andrei Belgrader's double-header of Ionesco one-acts and Andrei Serban's radicalization of ''Twelfth Night.'' The two directors have repeatedly enriched the stage with their approaches to classics, although this time with Mr. Serban the result is less edifying than intended. On the other hand, Mr. Belgrader's versions of ''The Bald Soprano'' and ''The Chairs'' are invigorating revisits to two seminal works of absurdism.

title: Rexene to Sell Plant For $88 Million
description: The Rexene Corporation, a plastics manufacturer, agreed to sell its Bayport, Tex., polyethylene and polypropylene plant for $88 million to the Lyondell Petrochemical Company, the concern created by the spinoff of ARCO's Texas-based petrochemical operations.

title: Real Estate; Old Buildings Altered for New Times
description: THE strategy has been called ''adaptive re-use'' of old buildings, and one Manhattan real estate executive says it can be very successful as well as profitable.

title: Economic Scene; Foreign Investors: Fifth Column?
description: THE Japanese are coming! The Japanese are coming! warn assorted Congressional Democrats, union leaders and business interests who watch in horror as foreigners - specifically the Japanese - swallow up everything from computer chip makers to the best beaches in Hawaii.

title: Base Ten Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $50,000 for the quarter and income of $1,313,000, or 37 cents a share for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $2,493,000 and $2,948,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,584,000, or 15 cents a share from an accounting adjustment.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHERE is no better place to find last-minute gifts than a good wine shop. There is always a chance of a final-hour run on the 1961 Petrus, but if you can settle for anything less there will be plenty to choose from.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ALICE ARTZT is seated in the front of an increasingly crowded bus. As the passengers climb aboard, they appear to be somewhat puzzled. ''Is this the 104?'' one woman asks. ''Yes,'' says the driver. At the next stop a man enters asking ''Is this the 104?'' ''Yes,'' the driver says again.

title: Par Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' nets were after reduction for minority interest in earnings of subsidiary.

title: Lessons
description: Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, has an irreverent question that he asks whenever some college president starts extolling the glories of American higher education: ''Would you ever hire an instructor who has never taught, never had a course in teaching and can't speak English?''

title: Iago Galdston, 94, Medical Spokesman And a Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Iago Galdston, a psychiatrist, an educator and the secretary of the Medical Information Bureau of the New York Academy of Medicine for 34 years, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 94 years old and lived in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn and in Newtown, Conn.

title: Greenhouse Effect: Shell Anticipates A Sea Change
description: Whether global warming will raise the level of the world's oceans is still being debated, but engineers who build natural-gas production platforms at Shell Oil do not want to take chances. In what is considered the first major project that takes account of the changes the greenhouse effect is expected to bring, the engineers are designing a huge platform that anticipates rising water in the North Sea.

title: Icahn's USX Stake
description: Federal antitrust regulators have cleared the investor Carl C. Icahn to acquire a bigger stake in the USX Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based steel company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last month, Mr. Icahn disclosed that he owned nearly 34 million, or 13.26 percent, of USX's outstanding common shares and that he might acquire as much as 25 percent.

title: Mets Sign Fernandez To a Three-Year Pact
description: Sid Fernandez, who could have become a free agent after next season, agreed yesterday to a three-year, $6.05 million deal with the Mets, making him the fourth-highest-paid player on the team in terms of the total value of the contract.

title: EATING WELL
description: MOST Americans had likely never heard of the diet supplement L-tryptophan until last month. Since Nov. 11, when the Food and Drug Administration issued an alert to the public to stop taking L-tryptophan supplements, it has been in the news almost every week. On Dec. 5, the agency recalled the product from stores and detained all imports of the supplement.

title: Ruling Allows Cuts in Crews Of Fire Trucks
description: New York City can reduce the number of firefighters assigned to many of its pumper trucks from five to four, which is expected to save at least $25 million a year, under a ruling issued yesterday by the city's Board of Collective Bargaining.

title: A Cooking Class To Call Your Own
description: AT their first cooking lesson, Judy and Harold McMillan experimented with various oils, vinegars and spices, and made brown rice, vegetable salad and a quiche Lorraine. At their second class, they made chicken breasts stuffed with pate, deboned a duck and stuffed a pheasant. Their next lesson calls for preparing sesame noodles and stir-fried vegetables. At each session they have the undivided attention of Mary Beth Clark, a Manhattan cooking teacher who gives lessons at their home or hers.

title: Standard Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 11 Are Indicted in Atlantic City Influence Peddling
description: A state grand jury today indicted 11 of 14 people who were arrested in Atlantic City in July on a variety of charges including influence peddling, bribery, racketeering, conspiracy and official misconduct.

title: Sabres Unwrap Their Many Gifts
description: The breaks this past summer would usually come in the evening. Rick Dudley, his ambition still keen but his vision slightly blurred from hours spent watching old tapes of the Buffalo Sabres, would drop down from the converted attic that passes for an office at the team's practice facility and make his way over to the rink.

title: Review/Dance; Proverbs And Mimes Are Merrily Embodied
description: Choreographers from Albany, Atlanta and London were represented Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y in a ''Sundays at 3'' program sponsored by the Y's Dance Center.

title: Nichols, S E Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $806,000, or 17 cents a share, for both periods, on the early retirement of subordinated debt; the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $5,171,000, or $1.09 a share, which included a $4 million pre- tax gain from the sale of the F.R. Schreiber division. c-After income from discontinued operations of $677,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,448,000, or 31 cents a share, for the 9 months. The latest 9 months' income from continuing operations included $770,000 pre-tax operating losses prior to closure and a $3.8 million provision for costs and expenses relating to the previously announced 11-store closure program. Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations included $1.2 million pre-tax gain on the sale of realty.

title: Doubleheader for Democracy; A Daunting Challenge in Brazil
description: Victory didn't come easily for Fernando Collor de Mello, the winner of Brazil's first popular presidential election in 29 years. Six months ago, polls showed that he, the center-right candidate, held an overwhelming lead. But by Sunday, when the final round of voting began, the contest against Luis Inacio da Silva, a radical left-wing labor leader, had suddenly turned tight.

title: Review/Dance; A Brendel And Baker Program
description: The program of solos and duets presented by Peggy Baker and Janis Brendel on Saturday night at St. Mark's Church was a memorable one, not just for the skills of the two dancers but for the intelligence and taste with which the dances were chosen.

title: In Manila Coup Effort, Economy Is Big Victim
description: In the weeks before the coup attempt against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino earlier this month, the beleaguered Philippine economy had never looked so promising.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Tennis; Capriati Turns Pro
description: At 13 years of age, Jennifer Capriati of Tampa, Fla., won the Junior French and Junior United States Open championships this year. Yesterday, she joined the pro ranks and signed a multiyear agreement with International Management Group Inc. of Cleveland, the group announced.(AP)

title: Marietta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Dinkins Pledges Partnership To New York's New Finest
description: Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon gave a gentle valedictory, Mayor Edward I. Koch made a sentimental farewell and Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins brought a hopeful hello to 1,224 New York City police recruits who graduated from the Police Academy yesterday.

title: Disclosing Financial Data, Reader's Digest to Go Public
description: In moves that will give its shareholders greater liquidity and help it avoid potential tax problems, the Reader's Digest Association is going public.

title: Deficit-Reduction Bill Signed To Cancel Cuts in Spending
description: President Bush today signed a $14.7 billion deficit-reduction bill for the current fiscal year, ending automatic cuts that were imposed across the board in October.

title: Emile de Antonio Is Dead at 70; Maker of Political Documentaries
description: Emile de Antonio, a producer and director of anti-establishment documentary films, died after a heart attack Friday in front of his home on the Lower East Side. He was 70 years old.

title: Long Beach State Signs George Allen as Coach
description: George Allen, who quickly transformed the Los Angeles Rams and the Washington Redskins from losers to winners after he became head coach, agreed yesterday to tackle perhaps his biggest coaching challenge. And he will attempt it at 71 years old.

title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City
description: Just after midnight, exhausted after another day of tramping the streets, Kevin Williams was killing time aboard a Brooklyn-bound No. 4 subway train. There were a handful of other passengers, including three young women talking together in the seats opposite him. Mr. Williams, who is 28 years old and homeless, fought back the urge to stretch out.

title: Market Place; Big Slide in Housing Prices Is Latest Worry on Wall St.
description: Once again, the ''wealth effect'' is bothering Wall Street. This time, the worriers may be on to something.

title: Mony Real Estate Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Cut Campaign Costs, Not Spending
description: LEAD: Heraclitus declared that ''everything flows and nothing stays,'' but some facets of the political scene are remarkably enduring. Even before disclosures of campaign contributions by savings and loan executives tarnished the reputations of conscientious and responsible members of Congress, there was a broad consensus that a new approach to raising money for politics is needed.

title: Stocks Decline Broadley; Dow Loses 1.92
description: Stock prices declined broadly yesterday, as investors' worrries about the economy and the real estate market contributed to violent swings in the market.

title: New Plan Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Area Yields Are Mixed For Funds and C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at New York area commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: It's Official: Penn State Will Become Big Ten's No. 11
description: Officials of the Big Ten Conference and Penn State University confirmed today that the Nittany Lions would become the conference's 11th member.

title: Coast Guard Faulted in '88 Sinking of Boat
description: The Coast Guard's failure to require life rafts and signal beacons on small commercial passenger boats contributed to the loss of life in the sinking of a vessel off the Oregon coast, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded today.

title: The Challenge of Teaching History As the Cold War Recedes in Europe
description: Many times this fall, Baiba Schletty was ready to throw away the lesson plan and make her high school history students look far beyond the orchards and fields that are the economic foundation of rural Berryville, Va.

title: Dresdner Bank Plan
description: Dresdner Bank, West Germany's second-largest commercial bank, announced plans today to open an office in Dresden, the East German city where the bank was founded more than a century ago. The bank was founded in Dresden in 1872. Although its management was shifted to Berlin in 1884, Dresden remained the bank's legal headquarters until 1950. The official headquarters have been in Frankfurt since 1957.

title: Corcoran Head Talks About Her Quitting
description: Dr. Christina Orr-Cahall says she hopes that her resignation on Monday as director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art might finally end the political firestorm that has engulfed the museum, the arts world and her own career for six months.

title: Cybermedic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $93,795 for both the quarter and year.

title: Review/Art; A Show in Minneapolis Offers History Behind Designs
description: One of the most ambitious exhibitions in recent months is ''The American Craftsman and the European Tradition'' at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts.

title: Navy Chief Says Lapses in Safety Led to Series of Deadly Accidents
description: The Chief of Naval Operations has concluded that inadequate supervision, lax safety procedures and complacency contributed to recent accidents in which Navy personnel were killed and injured, Pentagon officials disclosed today.

title: Bridge
description: There is little doubt that the world's greatest concentration of bridge players is in Norway, where one-fifth of the adults know the game. In a population of 4 million, 16,000 belong to the national organization.

title: Multimedia Taps Subsidiary For Its Second in Command
description: Multimedia Inc., which owns newspapers and broadcast stations and produces the Phil Donahue television show, has named James T. Lynagh president and chief operating officer.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in November, as food and shelter grew more costly while energy prices edged down, the Labor Department said today.

title: Manville Trust Payment Plan
description: The trust set up to handle the injury claims of asbestos victims against the Manville Corporation said Monday that the Denver-based construction and building material company had agreed to speed payments to the trust.

title: Oppenheimer Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the large increase in operating revenues were principally due to the expansion of the company's construction services subsidiary, Oppenheimer Design-Build.

title: Doubleheader for Democracy; A Promising Renewal in Chile
description: After 16 years of cruel tyranny, Chile now stands poised for a remarkable political transformation. Patricio Aylwin's triumph in last week's presidential election means a return to democratic life under particularly promising circumstances. Washington has a clear interest in giving strong support to what could become the region's model democracy.

title: European Trade Accord Advances
description: The 12 nations of the European Community and a group of six other Western European nations agreed today, as expected, to intensify negotiations about setting up a common economic space with minimal trade barriers.

title: Lawsuit Accuses Housing Aides of Racketeering
description: Two New Haven developers charged in a lawsuit yesterday that a group of local and Federal officials monopolized the subsidized housing market in Hartford by operating a racketeering enterprise that used extortion and harassment to freeze out small, independent and minority developers.

title: Florida Orders Suspension Of Hialeah Park's License
description: The Florida Department of Business Regulation said it would suspend Hialeah Park's parimutuel license because the race track had altered its racing schedule without approval.

title: U.S. Delegate Calls U.N.'s Session 'Constructive'
description: As the 44th United Nations General Assembly moves toward a close, the American representative, Thomas R. Pickering, described the session today as ''one of the most constructive and realistic within memory'' and said it had promoted a ''nondogmatic approach'' to world problems.

title: Review/Film; The Fears of a Bullfighter, In French 'Sand and Blood'
description: By JANET MASLIN

title: Wausau Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Upheaval in the East; Shevardnadze Calls for Links in East-West Pacts, but Warns on Germany
description: As the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, became the first Warsaw Pact minister ever to visit NATO headquarters, he called today for cooperation between the two military alliances, but he also warned that rapid reunification of Germany could destabilize Europe.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls 93, Lakers 83: Michael Jordan scored 37 points last night to lead Chicago to its fifth victory in a row. The defeat snapped a Laker winning streak at four games, while the Bulls won their ninth in a row at Chicago Stadium. Chicago led, 70-60, after three quarters, but the Lakers went on an 8-2 run in the first 2:06 of the final quarter, cutting the deficit to 72-68 when Orlando Woolridge dunked. That was the closest the Lakers came. James Worthy led Los Angeles with 19. (AP) Hornets 102, Mavericks 97: Dell Curry's jumper with 37 seconds left ended a 95-95 tie and Charlotte, playing at home, went on to break a losing streak at 10 games. After Curry gave Charlotte a 97-95 lead, Dallas's Ron Harper had a chance to tie it from the free-throw line with 27 seconds left, but he missed both shots. Armon Gilliam led the Hornets with 23.(AP) Celtics 95, Bucks 86: Larry Bird scored 21 points and Boston held Milwaukee to 36 points in the second half. The victory ended a nine-game regular-season losing streak in Milwaukee for the Celtics.(AP) Pistons 94, SuperSonics 77: Mark Aguirre scored 12 of his 21 points in the first quarter as Detroit, playing at home in Auburn Hills, Mich., ended a losing streak at three. Bill Laimbeer had 20 points and 11 rebounds and John Salley added 16 points for Detroit. Seattle's Sedale Threatt scored a season-high 18 points in his first start of the year.(AP) Hawks 115, Kings 112: Dominique Wilkins scored 11 of his 30 points in the final 4:41, rallying Atlanta at home. Sacramento lost its fifth straight game. Wayman Tisdale's basket put the Kings ahead, 102-94, with 5:34 left before Atlanta came back with 10 straight points. Kenny Smith's basket on a goal-tending call got the Kings even at 106-106 with 1:25 to go, but Wilkins scored with 1:10 left to give Atlanta the lead for good.(AP) Bullets 112, Timberwolves 99: Jeff Malone scored 12 points in the third quarter and Mel Turpin added 6 in the first 3:14 of the fourth quarter to enable Washington, playing at home in Landover, Md., to post its fourth straight victory. Malone finished with 20 points, while Turpin had 17 points and 12 rebounds, both season highs. Minnesota, losing its sixth straight game, led by as many as 8 points in the first period and trailed by only 53-52 at halftime.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL E. Tennessee St. 92, N.C. State 82: Calvin Talford and Alvin West scored 18 points each and sparked an early 11-0 run as East Tennessee (6-1) upset North Carolina State (6-2) in Raleigh, N.C. It was the Wolfpack's first game since being put on N.C.A.A. probation for two years. Rodney Monroe missed three straight 3-point shots with less than two minutes remaining for N.C. State. (AP) Syracuse 129, C. W. Post 72: Stephen Thompson scored 20 points and Billy Owens 18 as the Orangemen tied a Carrier Dome record with a 70-point first half against Division II C. W. Post. The 129 points were the third most in school history. The Orangemen improved to 8-0 with their 14th straight homecourt victory. Willard Mack scored 20 points for the Pioneers (5-2).(AP) Ga. Tech 109, Coastal Carolina 82: Dennis Scott scored 33 points and Brian Oliver added 27 as Georgia Tech built a 29-point halftime lead and coasted to the victory at home in Atlanta. The Yellow Jackets (6-0) are off to their best start since 1977-78. Scott reached the 30-point mark for the fourth time this season. Kenny Anderson finished with 17 points and 8 assists for the Yellow Jackets. Tony Dunkin led Coastal Carolina (4-2) with 22 points.(AP) Arizona 83, Miami (Fla.) 53: Wayne Womack scored 20 points and had 12 rebounds as Arizona used its inside strength to rout Miami at Tucson. Arizona (3-2) dominated from the start in handing the Hurricanes (3-2) their second straight loss. Womack, a 6-8 sophomore, registered his career bests before leaving the game with about four minutes remaining after jamming his right ankle.(AP) Oklahoma St. 79, Texas Southern 77: Corey Williams made both shots of a one-and-one foul situation with six seconds left to give Oklahoma State the victory at home in Stillwater. Charles Price, who scored a career-high 34 points including 15 from 3-point range, missed a long jumper on Texas Southern's final chance and a tip-in try also missed at the buzzer. The Cowboys (5-2) rallied from a 7-point deficit in the final 7 1/2 minutes to overcome the shooting of Price and Fred West. West scored 24 points, 19 in the second half, but the Tigers fell to 3-4.(AP) N.H.L. Whalers 8, Penguins 4: Todd Krygier and Ron Francis each scored twice and a four-goal first period carried Hartford to the victory over slumping Pittsburgh at Pittsburgh. The Penguins are 1-3-1 in their last five games, while the Whalers are 6-3 in their last nine. (AP) Oilers 5, North Stars 0: Bill Ranford made 22 saves for his first shutout of the season, leading streaking Edmonton over flickering Minnesota at Bloomington, Minn. Craig MacTavish scored twice and Craig Muni and Esa Tikkanen had shorthanded goals for Edmonton, which has used a 12-2-3 surge to go from last to first place in the Smythe Division.(AP) Capitals 2, Flyers 1: Kelly Miller scored with 3:30 left in regulation time to give Washington the victory in a penalty-marred contest in Philadelphia. Referee Denis Morel handed out 100 minutes in penalties in the second period, 66 of them after a brawl between Washington's Alan May and Philadelphia's Terry Carkner. Both received game misconducts and five other players were penalized.(AP)

title: Speaking of Soviets . . .
description: School textbooks can remain in print for decades, but they are frequently revised to take account of new evidence or shifting attitudes. The excerpts below, from the 1968 and 1988 editions of a history book, reflect changed American views about the Soviet Union. 1968

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18 In a military operation in Panama, U.S. troops were ordered into the streets in an effort to topple the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga, the White house announced. Page A1

title: Manatron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Loans, Credits for India
description: The World Bank said Monday that it and its sister agency, the International Development Association, had approved loans and credits of $165 million for India to modernize its irrigation system in the state of Punjab. Punjab is one of the country's most productive agricultural areas. The $15 million loan is for 20 years, including five years of grace, with a variable interest rate that is currently at 7.74 percent. The $150 million I.D.A. credit is for 35 years and is essentially interest-free.

title: Upheaval in the East; With Reform, Tough Times for the Warsaw Pact
description: In a few months, political turmoil in Eastern Europe has transformed the Warsaw Pact military alliance from a force feared in the West to an increasingly hollow organization without a clear purpose.

title: Changes for Reynolds
description: It has been almost 18 months since Butch Reynolds smashed Lee Evans's 20-year-old record in the 400 meters, with a time of 43.29 seconds in Zurich. Six weeks later in the Seoul Summer Olympics, he won a silver medal in the 400-meters and a gold for anchoring the winning 1,600-meter relay team. But since then, Reynolds has remained on the outskirts of the fame and fortune that other successful Olympians find, with just two endorsement contracts.

title: TLC Beatrice Cancels Plan To Sell 35% Stake to Public
description: TLC Beatrice International Inc., the food company controlled by the Wall Street investor Reginald F. Lewis, said yesterday that it was abandoning a plan to sell a 35 percent stake to the public. The company cited what it called unfavorable market conditions.

title: POP LIFE
description: Music for Mermaids

title: As Salmon Abound, More Are Smoked
description: AT one time, all it took to enjoy smoked salmon was a bagel. Now you need a Baedeker.

title: Centers Is?
description: We've been compiling an end-of-the-decade wish list of terms that deserve being revised because they are awkward, anomalous or misleading. Consider, for instance, the National Institutes of Health, including such estimable organizations as the National Cancer Institute and the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development.

title: Upheaval in the East; Jews Meet in Moscow First Time Since 1918
description: The first nationwide gathering of Jewish representatives since the first year of Bolshevik rule was convened today, and it underlined the participants' quandary over the future: how to see to the great tide of those who want to emigrate yet still protect the interests of those who stay in hopes of a Jewish renaissance.

title: CANADA TO LOWER PLANNED NEW TAX
description: Bowing to months of public pressure, the Canadian Government said today that it would lower the rate on its proposed value-added tax to 7 percent, from the original 9 percent.

title: Joseph Nathanson, Obstetrician, 94
description: Dr. Joseph Nathanson, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist, died of renal failure Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: Killearn Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Farewell, Merry Agony
description: What I like about this time of year is the chance to go Christmas shopping. It used to be, I couldn't stand Christmas shopping.

title: LITHUANIAN PARTY NEARS THE BRINK
description: In the face of warnings and threats from the Kremlin, the Communist Party leader of Lithuania called today for independent Lithuanian statehood. He said the republic's party organization wanted to create conditions ''in the immediate future'' that would allow the republic to secede from the Soviet Union if it so chooses.

title: Christmas Party Helps Forgotten Recall Joy
description: They came to raise a ruckus here this afternoon, to hoot and holler and cut the rug. And they cheered the loudest when the band played ''Older Women Make Better Lovers.''

title: From Women's League to Chains
description: A former president of the Indianapolis League of Women Voters and her two sons were led to court in chains today, two years after they were charged with running a large marijuana-smuggling ring.

title: Apple Is Said To Settle Suit
description: Apple Computer Inc. agreed to settle a patent-infringement lawsuit filed against it by Quickview Systems Inc., people close to the industry said.

title: North Hills Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Xerox vs. Apple: Standard 'Dashboard' Is at Issue
description: The Xerox Corporation's $150 million copyright suit against Apple Computer Inc. is one of the most important skirmishes in a battle to determine whether desktop computers, like automobiles, should have a standard ''dashboard,'' and if so, who should control the rights to use it.

title: Cambodians Like Hun Sen Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan for Monthly Refund to Offset Medicare Overcharge Gains Favor
description: The Social Security Commissioner said today that she supported a plan to send monthly refund checks to nearly 27 million elderly people early next year to offset Medicare premium overcharges.

title: Circle K Stores
description: The Circle K Corporation signed a nonbinding letter of intent for the sale of 350 stores to PC Ventures. It said the stores would continue to be operated under the Circle K name. The transaction, to be completed before April, involves stores in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana, Utah and Colorado. Circle K provided no information about the buyer or the terms of the sale.

title: 301 Chinese Expelled by Japan
description: In the first of what is expected to be a series of transfers, the Japanese Government said today that it would return 301 Chinese who sailed here over the summer falsely claiming to be Vietnamese refugees and seeking to resettle in Japan.

title: Oakley Isn't Missed As Ewing Dominates
description: Surprisingly, Karl Malone did not score with ease against the Knicks last night, as was expected with Charles Oakley not on hand to guard him. Malone had 29 points, just a bit over his 28.1 season average.

title: Techmire Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,700 and $3,330 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Andal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the decline in revenue in the latest quarter resulted from the July divestiture of 75 percent of its ownership in its business of trading and distributing flat rolled steel and tin mill products.

title: 3 Die and Dozens Are Hurt As Train Hits Truck in Fog
description: In the dense, cold fog that hangs low over the San Joaquin Valley at this time of year, a truck collided with a passenger train here this morning, leaving three people dead and dozens injured.

title: Upheaval in the East; Czechs Introduce Program for Free Elections and Free Markets
description: Czechoslovakia's Communist-dominated Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to support an ambitious Government program that sets the country on the course toward Western-style parliamentary democracy and a free-market economic system.

title: McDonald's President Promoted to Chairman
description: The board of the McDonald's Corporation yesterday promoted its president and chief executive, Michael R. Quinlan, 45 years old, to chairman and chief executive, effective March 31.

title: Upheaval in the East; At a Plant in East Berlin, Men Are of Two Minds
description: There are no more members of the Communist Party working in the turbine balancing unit of the Bergmann-Borsig electrical machinery company on the northern edge of this city.

title: About Education
description: For education, the decade about to end has been one of calling attention to the need for fundamental changes. Optimists say the 1980's have the country tooled up for action in the 90's. Pessimists scoff at a ''Waiting for Godot'' approach to changes in education. They contend that, even though some schools have improved, reforms have largely bypassed the troubled urban schools. They see the dismal lives of poor children as the decade's worst failure.

title: I.B.M. to Base a Computer On Powerful i486 Intel Chip
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was introducing a personal computer based on the Intel Corporation's powerful i486 microprocessor.

title: A Rule Is Bent For Students At Stuyvesant
description: Curse-the-fates gloom gave way to joyful pandemonium in the halls of Stuyvesant High School yesterday as the nation's most prestigious high-school science contest broke a near- half-century tradition and bent its rules - for the sake of unscientific justice.

title: Jets Need O'Brien's Successor
description: During his coronation yesterday at the Jets' complex as their new vice president and general manager, Dick Steinberg twisted a green-and-white Jets key ring with two keys on it. ''They gave me a key to the front door and a key to the front gate,'' he said with a smile. ''I guess it's official.''

title: Alternate Certification Helps to Ease Teacher Gap
description: In 1983 Ridgefield Memorial High School in New Jersey abolished its music program because the courses were so dull that no one was signing up for them.

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $2,066,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,116,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from tax- loss carryforwards. c-After extraordinary credits of $297,000, or 1 cent a share, and $1,625,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the extraordinary credit in the year-ago quarter included a charge of $1,042,000 from the early retirement of debt and a gain of $1,339,000 from a tax benefit. The extraordinary credit in the year-ago 9 months included a tax benefit of $2,667,000 and the charge from early retirement of debt.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. UNICEF EXECUTIVE BOARD - 10 A.M.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday. Dealers sold some securities when it became apparent that the Federal Reserve Board was not prepared to ease credit conditions immediately.

title: Make Room for West Side Students
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts may be one of America's most successful urban renewal projects. Over the years it has weathered scary economics and disputes among temperamental artists. Yet its esthetic whole continues to exceed the sum of its constituent institutions.

title: Oates and Ford to Read In Series at the 92d St. Y
