description: The authors Joyce Carol Oates and Richard Ford are to read from their works at 8 P.M. on Jan. 8 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The reading is part of a series sponsored by the Poetry Center at the Y. Admission is $10.

title: 'Worlds of Max Roach'
description: A performance by the Uptown String Quartet at 8 P.M. on Jan. 22 is to open ''The Worlds of Max Roach,'' a three-night jazz series at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Mr. Roach, a composer and percussionist, is to be the host and a featured performer at the concerts.

title: Paychex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Europeans Are Seeking a Way to Stop Illegal Entry
description: Having pledged to eliminate internal border controls after 1992, the 12 nations of the European Community have now set about trying to insure that illegal migrants, drug traffickers, terrorists and other people deemed undesirable cannot enter the newly integrated region.

title: Omni Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Northeast India State Challenged By Student Agitators and Rivals
description: A new confrontation between student agitators and the state Government has begun in the northeastern state of Assam, where general elections were not held last month because of concern over possible violence.

title: Cuomo Picks State Official For Top Drug-Abuse Post
description: Moving quickly to quiet criticism of his administration, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday chose a state official with a reputation as a trouble-shooter to become the new head of New York State's drug abuse agency.

title: Mass Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: January Crude Oil Contract Expires in Volatile Trading
description: The contract for January delivery of crude oil expired yesterday in volatile trading. Prices set contract highs before closing with a sharp decline.

title: Sotheby's Sales at Peak
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the world's largest art auctioneer, said today that its worldwide sales reached a record $2.93 billion this year.

title: Indonesia Palm Oil Plan
description: Indonesia, a leading palm oil producer, plans to expand its export of the commodity as its output surges, the Trade Minister, Arifin Siregar, said Monday. He said Indonesia's production could reach four million tons of crude palm oil before the target date of 1994. Exports now account for about half of production but will soon take a larger share, he said. Indonesian palm oil output is estimated at 1.9 million tons in 1989, up from 1.69 million in 1988.

title: Nets Top Heat at Finish
description: Roy Hinson's layup with 3.6 seconds to play tonight broke a tie and gave the Nets a 100-98 victory over the Miami Heat.

title: GUNFIRE IS HEARD IN CAPITAL
description: The United States launched a military operation in Panama early this morning designed to topple the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Texas Utilities Co reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents operating revenue.

title: Metro-Richelieu Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $16,841,000. c-Net income and after an extraordinary loss of $905,000. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Honda Starts Up New Ohio Plant
description: Honda of America began mass production Monday of Civics at its new plant, a 1.4-million-square-foot operation in west-central Ohio about five miles from the auto maker's first assembly plant at Marysville. The Japanese-owned company, now the fourth-largest auto maker in the United States, said it will make 65,000 cars at the new plant next year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: The Unequal Alliances
description: The cold war bred an assumption that the two sides of the East-West equation should be considered equals. That has been the basis of arms control negotiations up to now. But it is breaking down.

title: Mosbacher Backs Soviet Fiber-Optic Cable
description: Demonstrating a new American flexibility regarding high-technology exports to the Eastern bloc, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today that a deal in which an American company would help lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union could go ahead if certain conditions were met.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sears Agrees to Pay $100,000 Civil Penalty
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to resolve Federal Trade Commission charges that it failed to make required disclosures in its home insulation advertising.

title: Bordeaux Producer Seeks L.I. Land for Winery
description: A LARGE Bordeaux producer is seeking land to grow grapes and build a winery on Long Island. If the project materializes, possibly early next year, it will represent the first significant foreign investment in the New York wine industry, said James Trezise, president of the New York Wine and Grape Foundation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Partner at Canter Leaves to Join Bozell
description: Richard S. Lessler has left Canter, Achenbaum & Associates, where he was a partner, for Bozell, where he joins the strategic planning group. He will concentrate on the agency's Dallas clients.

title: Excerpts From the Opinion On Harassment in New York
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion of Judge Stewart F. Hancock Jr. as the New York State Court of Appeals today struck down a provision of the state's harassment statute that barred the use of abusive and obscene language.

title: Giants Receive Help In Division-Title Bid
description: When the Monday night game between the New Orleans Saints and the Philadelphia Eagles ended early this morning, the drinks were on the house at the Down Under bar in Hoboken.

title: U.S. FINDS EVIDENCE LINKING BOMBINGS
description: Federal investigators said today that they had found ''hard forensic evidence'' linking package bombs, including one that killed a Federal appellate judge in Alabama and a second that killed a lawyer in Georgia.

title: Israel-Iran Oil Deal Disclosed and Tied to Captives
description: Israel informed the United States a month ago that it had concluded a deal with Iran for the purchase of Iranian oil, the State Department said today.

title: BEFORE THE CLASH, AN OUTWARD CALM
description: While tensions between the Government here and the United States were rising today, throngs braved steamy heat in search of Christmas bargains.

title: Sportscene Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: KEY RATES
Pier 1 Imports Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: The company said the 1989 quarter and 9 months included results from one more week than the quarter and 9 months of 1988. The company has opened 26 new stores during the quarter and plans to open another 19 before the end of its fiscal year on March 3, 1990.

title: Nominee for Energy Post Is Accused of Lying
description: Two former Government investigators testified today that Victor Stello Jr., President Bush's choice to head the nation's nuclear weapons industry, lied to them in an investigation of the Three Mile Island nuclear accident.

title: Upheaval in the East; Europeans Plan an East German Trade Pact
description: The European Commission disclosed proposals today for a wide-ranging trade and economic pact with East Germany, one day after it signed a similar deal with the Soviet Union.

title: Review/Television; Beast Tries to Survive Loss Of the Other Half of the Title
description: Catherine is dead. The inconsolable Vincent can't stop weeping. And the new villains, a truly nasty lot, have something to do with what's referred to vaguely as South American drug interests. The question: Can television's ''Beauty and the Beast'' survive the departure of one of its stars, Linda Hamilton, who used her real-life pregnancy as an excuse for dropping Catherine from her repertory? For the time being, and well into January, the Beast in this contemporary fable will be without a Beauty as a new contender warms up on the sidelines. Television, evidently, will try anything.

title: Montclair Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $109,000 charge for costs associated with the bank's subsequently terminated agreement to affiliate with First Fidelity Bancorp of New Jersey. c-Included $358,000 charge for First Fidelity costs.

title: Baseball; Brewers Sign Yount To $9.6 Million Pact
description: Robin Yount's long-standing loyalty to the Milwaukee Brewers was a major reason the free-agent outfielder agreed to return to the team yesterday, but so was the contract: a three-year deal estimated to be worth $9.6 million that will make Yount the sixth player to average at least $3 million a year in salary starting next season.

title: Micron Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said that the revenues and earnings were affected by decreasing prices and Micron's transition from the 256K to the 1 meg dram.

title: Hagler Camp Insists He's Retired
description: Is Marvelous Marvin Hagler coming out of retirement?

title: Compensation Dispute As Steinberg Joins Jets
description: Victor Kiam, the owner of the New England Patriots, said today that he never intended to let Dick Steinberg out of his contract to join the Jets as their new general manager.

title: Clinical Trials of AIDS Drug Remain Crucial; Parallel Track
description: To the Editor:

title: Comptroller Asserts Banks Face Growing Realty Woes
description: Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, said yesterday that bank problems with bad real estate loans were growing but were not yet serious enough to cause losses of the magnitude that led to the collapse of most large Texas banks a few years ago.

title: PRESIDENT WAIVES SOME CHINA CURBS
description: President Bush waived a Congressional ban today on loans to companies that do business with China and also approved the export of three communications satellites that will be launched by the Chinese.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE been thinking about something different to serve my family for Christmas Eve dinner. It should be a relatively light prelude to the multicourse feast we will set out Christmas Day. I have always found Cornish hens to be festive for some reason, perhaps because they can be served individually and garnished in so many ways.

title: NDL Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted.

title: Man in the News; The Choice Of Brazilians; Fernando Collor
description: When Fernando Collor de Mello sought to sell Brazilians on his free-market vision of less government and more growth, he conjured up the image of the maharajah.

title: Echlin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said approximately half of the sales increase was due to the inclusion of Hobourn Group Ltd., acquired by Echlin in September.

title: Invention, Design, Engineerng Associate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Softech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
Kings Dismiss Russell
description: The Sacramento Kings, whose 6-14 record is the fifth worst in the National Basketball Association, dismissed Bill Russell as vice president yesterday and named Coach Jerry Reynolds director of player personnel. The Kings said a search would begin to find a coaching replacement for Reynolds, who took over as coach for Russell in March, 1988.

title: Thomas Murphy, 79; Headed Bricklayers
description: Thomas F. Murphy, former president of the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftsmen, died of pneumonia Thursday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 79 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: TOO MANY COOKS? THE MORE THE MERRIER
description: FIVE cookbook authors were recently asked to consider themselves a family and to imagine the following scene:

title: Stella Gibbons Is Dead; British Author Was 87
description: Stella Gibbons, who won fame with her first novel, ''Cold Comfort Farm,'' died Tuesday at her home in north London. She was 87 years old. Miss Gibbons, who was a journalist before she turned to books, wrote more than 30 novels and volumes of short stories and poems, but none rivaled her most celebrated story, which parodied an earthy, regional school of writing popular at the turn of the century.

title: Teen-Agers Die Sitting in a Car To Stay Warm
description: Three teen-agers trying to keep warm in sub-freezing temperatures by running the engine of a car in a closed garage in Irvington, N.J., yesterday morning died of carbon-monoxide poisoning and smoke inhalation, according to the authorities.

title: Youth Pushed to Death in Subway
description: An 18-year-old youth fleeing three other youths on a fast-moving subway train was pushed to his death in the Fordham section of the Bronx last night, the police said.

title: Clinical Trials of AIDS Drug Remain Crucial; Discrimination Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The New Yorker: Staid No More
description: As executives at The New Yorker tell it, the closest the magazine ever got to lending merchandising support to advertisers and their agencies was presenting them copies of the ubiquitous Saul Steinberg poster, ''A New Yorker's View of the World.''

title: McRae Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Bernard P. McSherry, Lawyer, 68
description: Bernard P. McSherry, a lawyer active in the affairs of Huntington, L.I., died of an aneurysm on Monday at Huntington Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Centerport, L.I.

title: Low State Ranking Is Called Unfair by Outraged School
description: The hallways are quiet and free of litter and graffiti. Math and reading test scores have been steadily improving in every grade except the third. In orderly but overcrowded classrooms, students are attentive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Sluggers Inc., to Gearon Hoffman Conlon & Nye Advertising, for MVP Children's Vitamins, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''God bless our German fatherland.'' - Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, addressing a cheering audience in East Germany. [ A1:6. ]

title: Kinshasa Journal; Getting Rich in Zaire: An American, 33, Tells How
description: He is young, brash, wealthy and seems to be buying up everything in sight.

title: Deserted Synagogue of 1919 Sets Off Boston Tug-of-War
description: The Vilna Shul is tucked on a side street along the north slope of Beacon Hill, where generations of immigrants clung to life in a cold new world.

title: Fur-tive Behavior
description: LEAD: Last week, I retreated to the country to wear my fur coat. Here in New York City, you just don't dare to do it, unless you have a limousine and can move fast from car to building. Even so, if you appear in public in a fur coat, you can be subjected to jeers, spray paint, ketchup and worse. I was on the bus when a fierce woman wearing leather shoes whipped out a scissors and cut off a big piece of the hair of another woman wearing a mink coat.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CABINET drawers that stick or bind are high on the list of life's little irritations. But the trouble is generally curable, once it has been identified.

title: CURRENTS
description: IN 1939, Argentina introduced the butterfly chair: two triangular iron frames covered with a leather sling. It was designed in 1938 by three architects - Jorge Ferrari Hardoy and Juan Kurchan, who were Argentinian, and Antonio Bonet, a Spaniard who practiced in Buenos Aires - and imitated worldwide in different versions: some collapsible, others with brightly colored canvas slipcovers.

title: Mechanical Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $82,000, or 3 cents a share, and $667,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also included after-tax income of $286,000 of which $203,000 was from continuing operations and $83,000 from discontinued operations from the implementation of FASB No. 96. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $49,000, or 1 cent a share, and $367,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Market Place; Single Arbitration Agency Is Sought
description: THE Securities Industry Association has called on Wall Street to set up a single industrywide agency to handle the arbitration of customer disputes, rather than continuing to maintain separate programs at various exchanges and at the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Fighting in Panama; 250 in Times Square Protest Invasion of Panama by U.S.
description: Chanting angrily and waving placards, about 250 people demonstrated at an Armed Forces recruiting station in Times Square yesterday to protest United States military action in Panama.

title: Overcrowding Doesn't Affect Schools Evenly
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Decision On Golf Clubs
description: A United States District Court judge issued a preliminary injunction today preventing the PGA Tour from enforcing its rule against square-grooved golf clubs.

title: Scientists Urge Delay of New Nuclear Arms Plants
description: The National Academy of Sciences advised the Department of Energy yesterday to postpone and possibly cancel $1 billion in new plants to process plutonium for bombs, including one that is a key part of its modernization plan.

title: Mets Trade Samuel for Pena and Marshall
description: The Mets finally traded away their unhappy center fielder yesterday when they sent Juan Samuel to the Los Angeles Dodgers for one relief pitcher, Alejandro Pena, and one power hitter, Mike Marshall, whose career has been plagued by back problems.

title: D'Amato Still Excels at Fund Raising
description: Buffeted politically, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is nevertheless maintaining the fund-raising pace that has made him one of the champion money raisers in the Senate.

title: 5 Departures Called Sign Software Link Is Near
description: The Open Software Foundation, an ambitious multi-company attempt to create an industrywide computing standard, has lost five high-ranking managers recently, lending support to reports that the organization is nearing an agreement to merge with an American Telephone and Telegraph software development group.

title: 225,000 IN COLONY TO BECOME BRITISH
description: In an attempt to ease the worries of Hong Kong residents about China's scheduled takeover of the British colony in 1997, the British Government said today that it would grant full British citizenship to a maximum of 50,000 households. The decision will give as many as 225,000 people in Hong Kong the right to settle in Britain.

title: Pact to End Soybean Subsidies
description: The United States has won a 20-year fight with the European Community over European soybean subsidies, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today. American farmers have complained that the subsidies cost them hundreds of millions of dollars a year in lost exports.

title: Fighting in Panama: Critic's Notebook; From the Late Show to the Early Show, It Was All Panama
description: Television insomniacs were probably the only ones who caught the earliest news of the United States invasion of Panama. CBS and ABC broadcast their first bulletins at 12:37 A.M. - a few minutes after Pat Sajak and Arsenio Hall had retired.

title: Priest's Accuser Is Called a Liar By His Father
description: The father of a purported male prostitute who accused the Rev. Bruce Ritter, the head of Covenant House, of giving him special financial aid in return for sex, said yesterday that his son was a chronic liar and thief with a ''personality disorder'' and a history of ''hurting those who try to help him.''

title: Trump Says He May Seek Retail Chain
description: Donald J. Trump, the developer, said yesterday that he was talking to the Campeau Corporation about a possible bid for Bloomingdale's, ''but it looks like nothing will materialize because of the short lease on Bloomingdale's flagship store with no options to renew.''

title: Morning-Show War
description: When you declare that a ''state of war exists'' between the country you control and the United States, and when you then pass the word that it's O.K. to rough up or kill local U.S. soldiers and their dependents, you would be well advised to expect a massive military response.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about politics and the New York City schools referred incorrectly to Sandra Ramos-Alamo, who is on the District 10 school board in the Bronx. She is not a member of the Benjamin Franklin Democratic Club.

title: End of East German Party Leaves Bitter Taste; Not Lutheran
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year, 1959. The City, Paris. The House, Windsor.
description: Her perfumes line a bathroom shelf, his pipes wait by his desk, and their clothes, a reminder of just how small they both were, still hang in wardrobes, awaiting the call of a garden party or a game of golf or just another of the ''who-was-there?'' dinner parties for which the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were famous.

title: RADICALS HEARTEN MANY IN KASHMIR
description: Young militants calling themselves Allah's Tigers have been roaming across this city on Kashmir's Dal Lake for several months, ordering hotels to stop serving drinks and liquor shops to shut their doors. They also have some suggestions about how women should dress and what videotapes should be sold in the bazaars.

title: In Depressed Farm Belt, Cultivating Self-Reliance
description: Three years after the agricultural economy began slowly and unevenly to struggle out of its deepest recession in half a century, rural America is still freckled with small towns and small farms that the recovery left behind, places like the Green Hills region of northern Missouri.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I took this action only after reaching the conclusion that every other avenue was closed and the lives of American citizens were in grave danger.'' - President Bush. [ A19:1. ]

title: Putting It All on the Line
description: Three weeks ago, the Philadelphia Eagles had second down on the Giants' 1-foot line. Three times Anthony Toney smashed into the middle of the line, and three times he was stopped for no gain.

title: New York Expands Plan to Rid Hudson of PCB's
description: A $280 million plan to dredge PCB-laden sediments from the Hudson River was announced here today by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Andrei Sinyavsky Lives in France, But His Soul Remains in Russia
description: When he walked from the bed that serves as his writing place, limping and stooped as if weighed down by the burden of exile, his hair and beard as white as a page, Andrei Sinyavsky looked a great deal older than his 64 years.

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article on Tuesday about Lee P. Brown, the newly designated Police Commissioner of New York City, misidentified his wife and misstated the size of his family. His wife's name is Yvonne, not

title: Systematics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
3 Youths Shot in Middletown
description: A 19-year-old Waterbury youth was killed and two of his relatives were injured in a shooting tonight that authorites believe was drug-related, the police said. Officers found the Waterbury youth, Thomas Parker, and his relatives, James Sessons, 21, and Bruce Parker, 22, both of Philadelphia, lying in the snow with gunshot wounds at 8:10 P.M., Lieut. Louis Aresco said. The three were taken to Middlesex Memorial Hospital, where Mr. Parker was pronounced dead. A suspect was taken into custody.

title: Rumania: Remarkable Common Ground
description: First of all, the very idea is astonishing: the Soviet Foreign Minister goes to Brussels to visit NATO and speak to the European Parliament. What he has to say is more astonishing still, even in these days of Soviet marvels. He expresses ''profound regret'' over repression in Rumania, one of Moscow's allies.

title: In Upward Revision, G.N.P. Growth Rate for the Third Quarter Is Put at 3%
description: The nation's economy grew at a faster rate in the third quarter than previously estimated, but economists and analysts continue to say it is slowing dramatically.

title: Fighting in Panama: The President; A Transcript of Bush's Address on the Decision to Use Force in Panama
description: Following is a transcript of the address by President Bush from the White House at 7 A.M. today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: U.S. Lists Death Rates for Medicare Hospital Patients
description: In an effort to help patients and their families make informed choices on where to be hospitalized, the Government today published its fourth annual report on death rates for Medicare patients at nearly 6,000 hospitals, including 196 where deaths exceeded Federal predictions.

title: Fighting in Europe: Europe; Soviet Union Condemns Strike but Says East-West Issues Aren't Involved
description: The Soviet Union called for world condemnation of the United States military strike in Panama today while stressing that it was not necessarily an East-West issue.

title: KEY RATES
Fighting in Panama: Prelude to Invasion; What Bush and His Spokesmen Said in the Days Before the U.S. Action
description: Following are excerpts from statements by President Bush and White House spokesmen as the Panamanian crisis developed over the last week. The excerpts of statements by Mr. Bush and Roman Popadiuk, Deputy White House spokesman, were provided by The Associated Press. The excerpts of briefings by Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, were provided by The Federal News Service, a transcription company. SATURDAY

title: Fighting in Europe; Reaction in Europe
description: European reaction to United States attack in Panama was largely muted today. But the governments that did speak out were divided over President Bush's decision to use force.

title: Securities Job for Koch Aide
description: Kevin B. Frawley, the Commissioner of New York City's Department of Investigation under Mayor Edward I. Koch, will join Prudential-Bache Securities as vice president and general counsel, the investment concern has announced. Mr. Frawley has held several positions in city government, including criminal justice coordinator, special counsel to the first deputy mayor and assistant director of operations for enforcement services. Mr. Frawley, a graduate of the Fordham University School of Law and the College of Holy Cross, will start on Jan. 11.

title: Ford Planning Wider Rebates
description: The Ford Motor Company today announced a broadened sales incentive plan on many 1989 and 1990 vehicles in the hopes of increasing sales during the industrywide slump.

title: Gillette to Buy Stake In Wilkinson Sword
description: The Gillette Company, which has about 50 percent of the United States blade and razor market, said yesterday that it planned to buy the American operations of Wilkinson Sword Inc., which has about 3 percent. It will also buy an ownership but nonvoting interest in much of Wilkinson's larger European operations.

title: Seoul Legislator Is Convicted As Spy but Draws Light Term
description: A legislator was convicted today of spying for North Korea and was sentenced to 15 years in prison, a relatively light term that the judge said was prompted in part by the thawing of relations between Communist and non-Communist nations.

title: Fighting in Panama; Panama's Troubled Past
description: JANUARY 1964. Riots break out in the Canal zone, which the United States has controlled since 1903. Panama temporarily breaks dipolmatic relations with Washington to express discontent over American control of the canal. Relations resume in April, when the two coutries agree to renegotiate their treaty relationship. OCT. 11, 1968. President Arnulfo Arias Madrid is overthrown by officers of the National Guard, who establish a junta. Power is held by Col. Omar Torrijos Herrera. OCT. 1, 1979. The United States flag is lowered within the Canal Zone and adminsitrative authority for canal is transferred to a binational commission. JULY 31, 1981. General Torrijos dies in airplane crash. August 1983. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega takes over as commander of the armed forces. The next year, General Noreiga obtains the resignation of President Nicolas Ardito-Barletta and replaces him with the Vice President, Eric Arturo Del Valle. JUNE 6, 1987. Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, second in command of the army accuses General Noriega of electoral fraud and a political killing. The accusations set off the first anti-Noriega protests. FEB. 4, 1988. Federal grand juries in Miami and in Tampa hand up drug and racketeering indictiments against General Noriega. FEB. 25, 1988. President Delvalle dismised General Noriega, but is instead ousted himself by the National Assembly. Manuel Solis Palma, a Noriega ally, is appointed acting President. United States continues to recognize President Delvalle. MARCH 3, 1988. United States courts block withdrawal of Panama funds from American banks. Eight days later, President Reagan imposes economic sanctions. MARCH 16, 1988. General Noriega puts down a coup attempt led by the police chief. Continuing street protests bring the capital to a halt. APRIL 8, 1988. President Reagan freezes over $56 million in Panamian assets in American banks and prohibits American companies and the the Government from making payments to Panama. MAY 7, 1988. National elections are held. Exit polls give the opposition a large lead, but offical results give General Noriega's candidate a 2-to-1 lead. Violence breaks out. General Noriega anulls election. President Bush declares it fraudulent. MAY 11. President Bush orders 2,000 additional American troops to Panama, bringing the total United States military presence to 12,000. OCT. 3. Coup effort against General Noriega fails. DEC. 15. Panama's National Assembly declares ''state of war'' between United States and Panama. DEC. 16. Panamanian soldiers kill a United States marine lieutenant. DEC. 18. A United States Army officer wounds a Panamanian police corporal, who he thought was about to draw a weapon. DEC. 20. President Bush orders United States troops into combat in Panama in an attempt to seize General Noriega.

title: Japanese Discount Rate Expected to Be Raised
description: Despite a series of denials by Government officials and reports of disputes within the Government, speculation is mounting here that a rise in Japan's key discount rate is imminent.

title: Upheaval in the East; INDUSTRY SAGGING IN EAST GERMANY
description: East German industrial output dropped last month and the number of unmet production goals has more than doubled, worsening consumer shortages and hurting export commitments, official figures published today showed.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: TEN or so years ago I found under the tree a small picture book called ''An Edwardian Christmas,'' by one John S. Goodall. I don't know who gave it to me, but I am eternally grateful. I drown in books - the characters and settings tend to rise up and close above my head - and never do I drown more happily than in Mr. Goodall's never-never land. If I had seen ''An Edwardian Christmas'' at a more impressionable age, I might have spent my life yearning for a butler and a covey of maids in ribbon-streamered white caps. And I might have yearned even more than I do now for a holiday unscarred by losses and loneliness and that terrible trickster that is memory.

description: Debt

Rumanian Leader Speaks Nicolae Ceausescu addressed Rumanians, justifying a crackdown on protests and blaming 'fascist, reactionary groups' for the unrest. Page A14. title:

People
description: LEAD: * Alison Danzberger has been named senior vice president and director of the National Broadcast Unit of Foote, Cone & Belding in New York, succeeding Robert D. Daubenspeck, who is retiring.

title: Namibia Reaches Agreement On a Western-Style Charter
description: This territory's constituent assembly agreed in principle today on a democratic, Western-style constitution that should clear the way for independence within months and end 74 years of South African rule.

title: Taylor Is in Pro Bowl and Into History
description: Lawrence Taylor and Anthony Munoz became part of football history today as they were elected to the Pro Bowl for the ninth consecutive season.

title: Cuomo Is Urged To Suspend Sale Of State Lands
description: New York is selling off excess state property to raise money without first allowing the public to examine the historic or environmental impact of the land sale, environmentalists asserted today.

title: East Germans Allow Balloons To Fly at Brandenburg Gate
description: Two hot-air balloons bearing peace slogans were anchored today in front of the Brandenburg Gate as a sign of friendship.

title: Donald Sullivan, Professor, 47
description: Donald Sullivan, director of the Graduate Program in Urban Planning at Hunter College, died of a gastric hemorrhage on Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Some Flu Drugs Fail to Halt Spread, Study Finds
description: Some drugs used to combat influenza may actually increase the likelihood of spreading drug-resistant strains of flu, a new report indicates.

title: Groups Oppose Blue Cross Raise In New Jersey
description: A plan by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey to raise premiums an average of 33.7 percent for 605,000 individual subscribers was attacked today as ''excessive and discriminatory'' by a coalition of public interest groups.

title: Tokyo Project Adds Bechtel
description: The Bechtel Group said today that it had won what it believed to be the first significant role for an American company in a large Japanese construction project.

description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $36,000, or 1 cent a share for the 13 weeks and $294,000, or 12 cents a share for the 39 weeks. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $137,000, or 6 cents a share and $200,000, or 11 cents a share for the 13 weeks and 39 weeks, respectively.

title: Stranger to New York, Brown Says First Act Will Be to 'Reach Out'
description: Police Chief Lee P. Brown, who will take over as New York City's Police Commissioner next month, describes himself as a stranger to New York and says he will not make any major changes in the current system until he learns his way around.

title: Review/Theater; Patients Sacrificed in the Name of Research
description: When The Associated Press broke the news, it seemed almost incomprehensible. In order to chart the degenerative progress of venereal disease in the human body, the United States Public Health Service withheld treatment from hundreds of poor, black men in rural Alabama. The study lasted from 1932 until it was exposed in 1972. How could something so reminiscent of Nazi medical practices have happened in America?

title: Beauticontrol Cosmetics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Jet Staff Can Only Sit and Wait
description: Joe Walton may know his fate as Jets coach next Tuesday when he meets with the club's new general manager, Dick Steinberg.

title: My Only Child, Dead a Year
description: LEAD: Today is the first anniversary of the worst day of my life. While America celebrates the season with holiday brightness, I am in black despair. On Dec. 21, 1988, my daughter and only child, Theodora (we called her Theo), was on her way home from London, where she had spent a semester studying drama.

title: Fighting in Panama; 6 Days Leading to the Attack
description: FRIDAY, DEC. 15 Panama's National Assembly declares Panama 'to be in a state of war while the aggression lasts' and names Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega 'maximum leader of the struggle for national liberation.' SATURDAY, DEC. 16 Four unarmed, off-duty United States Army officers in a private car are fired upon at a roadblock by Panamanian troops; one is killed and one wounded. A Navy lieutenant and his wife who witness the shooting are taken into custody by Panamanian troops; the officer is beaten, his wife is threatened. U.S. troops in Panama are put on maximum alert. Late in the evening, President Bush is briefed by the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. SUNDAY, DEC. 17 President Bush consults with Vice President Dan Quayle at a brunch, meets with security advisers in the afternoon and decides to order U.S. forces to Panama. U.S. troops in Panama are moblized. MONDAY, DEC. 18 An American lieutenant shoots and wounds a Panamanian traffic officer who thinks he is pulling a weapon. President Bush says he does not rule out military action. TUESDAY, DEC. 19 President Bush meets advisers on final plans for the assault. The President attends another Christmas party that night, then informs Congressional leaders by phone of the plan. WEDNESDAY, DEC. 20 Just before ''Operation Just Cause'' begins at 1 A.M., Guillermo Endara is sworn in as President by a Panamanian justice at an American base in Panama. President Bush calls the Congressional leadership. The operation begins; other governments are notified by the President, the Vice President and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. President Bush remains in the Oval Office until 4 A.M., then gets a few hours sleep before his address to the nation shortly after 7.A.M.

description: In a finding that could ultimately open up an entirely new approach to prenatal testing, researchers have determined the sex of a group of fetuses by testing pregnant women's blood.

title: A Needless Cloud Over New York City
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo's approval of flawed legislation that would allow Staten Island to secede from New York City will subject all New Yorkers to years of needless uncertainty. In his rush to recognize Staten Island's rights, Mr. Cuomo has ignored the rest of the city's, giving life to a frivolous law that statesmanship would have stopped.

title: Why the Invasion Was Justified
description: How does President Bush justify sending 10,000 troops into combat in tiny Panama? He offers four reasons, two of them so inflated that they evaporate on inspection. ''To defend democracy in Panama,'' he said. Yes? Well, who appointed America the world's political policeman? ''To combat drug trafficking,'' he said. Yes? Well, when did it become the mission of America's armed forces to chase after Manuel Noriega like an operetta Foreign Legion pursuing the Red Shadow?

title: Fighting in Panama; Panama Task Forces: Who They Were, What They Did
description: American military strategy as described by Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staffe, in a briefing yesterday Task Force Atlantic Battalion from the 7th Infantry Division; battalion from the 82nd Airborne Division. Secured prison at Gamboa, electrical distribution center at Sierra Tigre, and Madden Dam. Protected installations in the Colin area. Neutralized 8th Infantry Company of the Panama Defense forces. Blocked a Panamanian infantry unity in the north. Task Force Semper Fidelis Marine rifle company; Marine light armored infantry company; MP's Secured the Bridge of the Americas; Secured Howard Air Force Base. Task Force Red Ranger battalion parachute unit; special forces of Southern Command. Neutralized Rio Hato; blocked the Pacora River Bridge. Task Force Bayonet 6th Mechanized battalion; light tank platoon; 5th battalion of 87th Infantry. Mechanized battalion seized the Comandancia, Noriega's headquarters. Blocked Panamanian military units at Fort Amador. Task Force Pacific 82d Airborne Brigade Attacked cavalry squadron at Viejo, engaged the infantry company at Finajitas and Battalion 2000. HOW THE CAPITAL WAS SEIZED United States troops of the 193th Infantry Brigade, 5th Mechannized Brigade, Marines and light infantry isolated the Panamanian Defense Headquarters at the outset of the fighting, then mechanized forces and infantry systematically attacked and destroyed it. The area is on a peninsula surrounded by the Bay of Panama and the Pacific approaches to the Panama Canal. To the north is Quarry Heights, the American military headquarters, from which U.S. operations were directed. The Avenue of the Martyrs, between the Panamanian headquarters and Quarry Heights is the route Noreiga loyatists used to reinforce the Panamanian strongpoint from outside the city during a failed coup attempt in October. United States forces sealed this route by engaging Panamanian forces west of the city and closing the Bridge of the Americas connecting Panama City with the eastern side of the Canal. The Americans also cut the route from nearby Fort Amador, another Panamanian strongpont. American paratroopers and Rangers seized Torrijos international airport east of the city in an airborne operation. Together with special operations forces secretly parachuted in earlier, they blocked the Pacora River Brider north of the airport to prevent the 2000 Battalion from moving. Rangers also parachuted into the coastal region of Rio Hato to disperse two companies of Panamanians stationed there. American units were used to neutralize Panamanian forces in Colon on the Atlantic side and to secure the canal.

title: Fighting in Panama; Canal Treaty: Step by Step
description: SEPT. 7, 1977. President Jimmy Carter and the Panamian leader, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, sign two treaties dealing with the Panama Canel. The first covers the operation and defense of the canal during a phased transfer of control from the United States to Panama. The transfer is to be complete by Dec. 31, 1999. The second treaty guarntees the permanent neutrality of the canal, and has no fixed termination date. OCT. 1, 1979. The treaties are entered into force. The United States remains respnsible for the operation of the canal until the end of the transition period. A United States Government agency, the Panama Canal Commssion, manages, operates and maintains the canal under the supervision of a board composed of five Americans and four Panamanians. Until 1990, the Administrator is an American and the deputy administrator a Panamanian. APRIL 1, 1982. Panama formally assumes responsiblity for policing the Canal Zone. The transfer of powers means that the United States special police force in the Canal zone will be disbanded and Panamianian police and courts will now arrest and try United States and Panamanian residents of the zone with the exception of certain civil cases still covered by United States law under the terms of the 1977 treaty. JAN. 1, 1984. The deadline by which the number of American employees of the Commission is to be at least 20 percent lower than the number working for the Panama Canal Company in 1977. OCT. 1, 1984. Pursuant to the treaty, the United States closes the School of the Americas, an institution in the Canal Zone where over four decades some 44,000 Latin American military officers received advanced training. Military commisary and postal privileges end for some 1,00 of the 1,700 American employees of the Canal Commission. The only American canal workers who can keep these privileges are those with family members in the United States armed forces, retired military personnel and certain employees of the Defense Department. JAN. 1, 1990. Under the treaty the Panama Canal Commission top job is supposed to pass from an American to a Panamanian. The Panamanian is to be recommended by the Government of Panama and appointed by the President of the United States with the advice and consent of the United States Senate. The nine-member board continues to have authority over the administrator. DEC. 31, 1989. At noon the Republic of Panama assumes full control over the canal.

title: For a Panamanian, Hope and Tragedy
description: LEAD: As a Panamanian, I feel like a person who just woke up from radical cancer surgery and was told he had lost a major organ. Life will not be the same again, but he has a new lease on life. He can't feel good about it, but he can't feel totally bad about it either.

description: Cerebral palsy was long believed to result mainly from interference with the baby's oxygen supply during labor and delivery. But researchers are now finding that this assumption is rarely correct.

title: NCR Authorizes Stock Repurchase
description: The board of the NCR Corporation authorized the repurchase of up to 15 million shares, or about 21 percent, of NCR's common stock in the next two years as part of the company's continuing stock repurchase program. NCR's shares were unchanged today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $58.875.

title: Natural Gas Sales Set At Denver Amoco Sites
description: Amoco Inc., the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said today that it would begin selling compressed natural gas at four gasoline service stations in the Denver area early next year.

title: Brazil Confirms Collor Won And His Opponent Concedes
description: The Government confirmed today that Fernando Collor de Mello, an advocate of a free-market economy, won the first free presidential election in Brazil in 29 years.

title: Hong Kong to Push for Rights as Britons
description: Hong Kong politicians and citizen groups vowed today to press their fight to force Britain to open its doors to all its colonial subjects here and grant them full British passports before the colony is handed back to China in 1997.

description: Guillermo Endara

title: Lavalin Industries reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,700,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mandela Lives Without Regrets, His Son Reports
description: In this dusty farm town lost among the rolling green hills of the Transkei homeland, a shopkeeper awaits the release of a father who has passed 10,000 days in captivity.

title: MEESE IS DISPUTED ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter asserted today in a legal paper that former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d approved of Oliver L. North's covert efforts to arm the Nicaraguan rebels in the summer of 1986. The assertion directly contradicts Mr. Meese's accounts about the matter.

title: Schneider Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said fourth quarter results are distorted by the significant effecvt of a strike at its main plant in Kitchener, Ont. in 1988. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Combat Operation; Military, After Achieving Initial Success, May Face Difficult Urban Warfare
description: American military forces in Panama face a new phase of combat operations in the next few days in which they must wrest control of Panama City from lightly armed but potentially dangerous paramilitary units that have been loyal to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Golden Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Death Rates and Type of Hospital Correlated
description: Mortality rates at osteopathic, public or profit-seeking hospitals are higher for comparable illnesses than are rates at private hospitals affiliated with medical schools, a study concludes.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Magic 110, Bulls 109: Otis Smith scored 28 points, including a layup with two seconds left, to lead Orlando at home last night despite Michael Jordan's 52 points. Jordan had 20 points in the fourth quarter, but Orlando rallied from five deficits in the final 4 minutes 49 seconds to win its sixth game over a 1989 playoff team and fourth over a division leader this season. Orlando's 9-15 record is the best start after 24 games in National Basketball Association expansion history. Other Orlando victories over division leaders include the Knicks, the Los Angeles Lakers and Utah. With Chicago leading, 109-108, Smith got the ball at the top of the key with four seconds left, drove between Jordan and Scottie Pippen and layed the ball in. Jordan, who was 20 for 37 from the field and converted his 10 free-throw attempts, tried a desperation shot from 30 feet, but Smith and Nick Anderson both got a hand on the ball. The bench, led by Smith, gave the Magic a big boost in the first half, scoring 31 points. Jordan, who scored 54 points in overtime earlier this year against Cleveland, has 19 50-point games in his career.(AP) San Antonio 103, Sacramento 100: David Robinson scored 26 points and made three free throws in the final 27 seconds as San Antonio won its 10th consecutive home game. The Spurs, 11-1 in San Antonio this season, also guaranteed having their second consecutive winning month, a feat the team had not accomplished in four years. San Antonio, 8-5 in November, is 7-1 in December with five games remaining. The score was tied at 98-98 with 27 seconds to play when Robinson hit two foul shots. After Harold Pressley missed a 20-footer, Vernon Maxwell added two more free throws, giving the Spurs a 102-98 lead with 3.4 seconds left. Waymon Tisdale's short jumper got the Kings within 2, but Robinson hit a foul shot with 1.1 seconds left, giving the Spurs their margin of victory. (AP) Nuggets 104, Cavaliers 89: Walter Davis scored 8 points during an 11-0 run in the first quarter, then hit an 18-footer to cap a 16-4 spurt in the second quarter for the visiting Nuggets. Cleveland had its four-game winning streak snapped as the Cavaliers suffered their first loss since Larry Nance returned from ankle surgery. They were 6-11 before Nance came back. Denver took control early, going ahead by 12-2 as Cleveland made one field goal in the first 5:30. Blair Rasmussen of Denver grabbed 11 of his 16 rebounds in the first quarter, and the Nuggets outrebounded Cleveland, 57-38, for the game.(AP) 76ers 118, Bullets 111: Charles Barkley scored 34 points, and Ron Anderson added 14 of his 22 in the fourth quarter as Philadelphia, playing at home, ended the Bullets' four-game winning streak. Philadelphia held a 110-102 lead with 3:27 left, but Washington closed to 112-108 on a jumper by Jeff Malone with 2:01 remaining. Barkley then made a free throw and passed to Mike Gminski for a layup with 1:21 left to secure the victory.(AP) Celtics 113, Jazz 109: Larry Bird scored 40 points and Kevin McHale had 13 of his 19 points in the third quarter as Boston beat Utah for the 19th consecutive time in Boston Garden. The Celtics outscored Utah by 13-3 at the end of the third period for a 90-77 lead, then had to ward off challenges down the stretch by the Jazz, who have not won in Boston since joining the N.B.A. as a New Orleans franchise in 1974. Utah, which was led by Karl Malone with 39 points, ran off 9 consecutive points at the start of the fourth period to close to 90-86. But the Celtics responded with an 8-2 run. Blue Edwards had 19 points, Thurl Bailey had 18 and John Stockton added 15 for the Jazz.(AP) Lakers 106, Timberwolves 97: Orlando Woolridge scored a season-high 20 points, including the first 4 by his team in overtime, to lead the visiting Lakers. The Timberwolves, who never trailed in regulation and scored only 38 points in the last 29 minutes, have lost seven straight games. Magic Johnson's layup with seven seconds left in regulation gave the Lakers their first tie at 91-91. In overtime, Woolridge made two free throws for a 93-91 lead, the Lakers' first free throws of the game. Tony Campbell, who scored 26 points, made a jumper to tie the game, but Woolridge's layup put the Lakers up for good with 3:22 remaining.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Maple Leafs 2: Glen Hanlon, the Detroit goaltender, turned aside 26 shots last night and Joe Kocur snapped a 1-1 tie with a second-period goal to lead Detroit at home. Detroit, 5-2-2 in its last nine games, stopped the Maple Leafs, who had won five of their last six. Hanlon, 4-1-2 in his seven starts since returning from a groin injury, surrendered Gary Leeman's first-period goal and another to John Kordic in the third. The veteran goaltender's biggest save came early in the second period when he stopped Daniel Marois on a breakaway to keep the score tied, 1-1. After Leeman and Shawn Burr traded first-period goals, Kocur scored his sixth of the season to put Detroit ahead to stay.(AP) Whalers 4, Bruins 3: Ron Francis of Hartford scored his 17th goal of the season on a deflection with 25 seconds left to lead the Whalers at home. Dave Babych intercepted Ray Bourque's clearing pass at the left point and his blast was redirected by Francis past the goaltender Andy Moog. Todd Krygier, Ed Kastelic and Dean Evason also scored for Hartford (18-17-1), which went over .500 for the first time since Nov. 14. The Whalers are 7-3 since Nov. 30. Andy Brickley, Craig Janney and Randy Burridge scored for Boston (17-14-3).(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Illinois 101, Missouri 93: Kendall Gill scored 27 points last night and keyed a 12-4 run midway through the second half for Illinois (7-0). Illinois used the spurt to open a 72-62 lead and Missouri (9-1) never got closer than 7 points the rest of the way despite a closing flurry by Anthony Peeler. Illinois claimed its seventh straight triumph in the series and the Fighting Illini raised their record to 8-1 over all against Missouri at the St. Louis Arena, a neutral site. Marcus Liberty added 26 points for Illinois. Missouri led five times in the first half, enjoying a 22-17 edge before Gill and Liberty sparked a 23-8 surge that put Illinois ahead 40-30. Nathan Buntin hit a 3-pointer to bring Missouri to within 45-40 at halftime. Missouri challenged at 58-56 when Buntin scored inside with 13:49 to go, and at 60-58 less than a minute later. Small started the Illini's decisive surge with an inside basket and, after Coward countered for Missouri, Gill then scored two baskets to spark the run.(AP) Georgetown 97, Virginia Tech 64: Mark Tillmon scored 29 points and Alonzo Mourning added 27 last night as Georgetown won its 25th straight home game. Georgetown (8-0) has outscored its opponents by 777-475 this season, a 37-point average margin of victory. Mourning also had 11 rebounds and Dikeme Mutombo had 10 points and 12 rebounds for Georgetown, which has not lost at the Capital Centre since the 1987-88 season when St. John's beat the Hoyas, 65-58. Virginia Tech's Bimbo Coles, who is trying to become the first player in Metro Conference history to lead the league in scoring three years, finished with 22 points. He is the only member of the Hokies (4-3) averaging in double figures.(AP) HORSE RACING Bold Wench Is Winner: Bold Wench took the lead on the backstretch and held it the rest of the way for a one and one-half length victory in the Kittiwake Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday. Bold Wench, carrying 118 pounds, was ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. to her second victory in a row and seventh in 18 starts this year. Naskra's Return finished second in the eight-horse field, two and one-half lengths ahead of Rose Park. Bold Wench covered the 1 1/8 miles on the fast track in 1:51 2/5 and earned $30,000 for Jack R. Maro. Bold Wench returned $6.20 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: Fighting in Panama: Legal Case; Administration Says International Agreements Support Its Action
description: The Bush Administration today cited the United Nations Charter, the Organization of American States Charter and the Panama Canal Treaties as the legal bases for its military offensive in Panama.

title: If a Faithful Side Chair Should Waver
description: LEAD: Upholstered side chairs should have agreeable proportions and be light enough for easy handling, yet they are expected to cope with heavier loads and more stress than sturdier furniture. Even so, they generally stand up remarkably well. The most frequent problem tends to be a loose seat joint, a common structural weakness.

title: Disney Stock Falls $11.375; Volume High
description: The Walt Disney Company's stock price, which has soared ever upward this year, returned to earth today.

title: Upjohn Will Take 4th Quarter Charge
description: The Upjohn Company said today that it would take an after-tax restructuring charge of about $200 million in the fourth quarter to pay for closing a chemical plant in North Haven, Conn., as well as for a previously announced early retirement plan for United States employees and other costs. The pharmaceuticals maker said it planned to sell its industrial chemicals lines in 1990.

title: AIDS-Infected Man Sentenced in Attack
description: A drug addict who tested positive for the AIDS virus was sentenced to five years in prison on Tuesday for assaulting a police officer with a hypodermic needle.

title: Pre-Crash Race Alleged
description: A trucker has told the police that he saw what appeared to be a race between Ramon Ramos's sports car and another vehicle shortly before the crash that left the Portland Trail Blazer rookie in a coma.

title: Fighting in Panama: Reaction; Congress Generally Supports Attack, but Many Fear Consequences
description: President Bush's decision to attack in Panama won support from both parties in Congress today, but received a more reserved response from some Latin American experts who said the long-term costs and the danger of American troops getting bogged down make this a riskier operation than is immediately apparent.

title: Calendar: Classic Designs and Holiday Festivities
description: Ancient Is Fresh, New York School of Interior Design, 155 East 56th Street; 212-753-5365.

title: Countrywide Credit reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on repurchase of 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures of $2,314,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: A Woman Is Raped Aboard an F Train
description: A 23-year-old Brooklyn woman was raped yesterday aboard a subway train as it traveled through Brooklyn, the transit police said.

title: Rampant Drug Abuse and Record Murder Toll Compete With 911 Calls and Budget Freezes
description: In Houston, he battled police violence and racism. In Atlanta, a serial killer. When Lee P. Brown takes over as New York City's Police Commissioner next month, he will face challenges every bit as stubborn.

title: Leaving on a High Note
description: Saying ''I'm tired,'' Erk Russell, who led the revival of football at Georgia Southern College, stepped down yesterday, four days after his third Division I-AA national championship in five years. Erk's Eagles, as the team became known, also captured titles in 1985 and 1986 and reached the championship game last year.

title: Durenberger Regretful For Financial Mistakes
description: United States Senator Dave Durenberger said today his financial dealings did not violate Senate rules, but he apologized for mistakes he made and said he would work to restore public confidence.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday headed ''Baseball's Bull Market,'' about the contracts given to players after the 1987 and 1989 seasons, described the 1987 season incorrectly. It was the last in which the players' union accuses the owners of having acted in collusion against free agents, an assertion that is still before an arbitrator.

title: The Neediest As Reminders Of Good Luck
description: With the holiday weekend rapidly approaching, Isabella Montgomery of Washington wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund: ''If only money could buy that most important ingredient: a loving family. As we await the holiday arrival of our children and grandchildren, I realize how blessed we are. I wish I could package this treasure and share it with others.''

title: Most Liver Diseases Can Be Prevented
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Sox Too Late
description: If the Boston Red Sox are to re-sign Mike Smithson, they will have to wait until next May 1, when they regain the right to negotiate with him.

title: U.S. Airline Policy Remains Too Protectionist
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSAD WILL TRAVAL TO SOVIET UNION
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria is to visit the Soviet Union and is planning a meeting with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in what political analysts close to Damascus described as a reappraisal of his policy in light of changing international and regional conditions.

title: 2 Held in Killing of Youth on Bronx D Train
description: Two teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with killing an 18-year-old youth on Tuesday by pushing him from a fast-moving subway train in the Bronx, the police said.

title: BRIDGE
description: A 23-year-old record was decisively erased 11 days ago in Madison, Wis., when Sabine Zenkel won three sectional events. This gave her the Life Master title eight weeks after joining the American Contract Bridge League, breaking by three weeks the record established by the late Jeremy Flint of England in 1966. And in one of those eight weeks she did not play.

title: Harcourt Brace Names Jovanovich as Chief
description: Peter Jovanovich was elected president and chief executive of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. yesterday. He will succeed Ralph D. Caulo, who, the company said, would resign at the end of the year to pursue business interests in Florida and Texas.

title: Admirers of 1989 Knicks See Hint of Golden 1970's
description: Joe Lapchick, the former St. John's coach, while watching the artistry of the 1970 Knicks championship team, once said: ''I just sit at the games and want to rip out the mooring of my seat at some of the plays they make. You really have to know and understand basketball to enjoy some of the things they are doing our there.

title: Washington Talk; The Right-to-Die Issue, Personified
description: While many Supreme Court cases have roots in individual encounters with the power of government, they often acquire an abstract quality that obscures the personal dimension.

title: Reviews/Music; Galway Deploys the Trappings of Celebrity
description: Since 1975, when he began his solo career, James Galway has counted among the superstars of classical music, with all the potentially invidious connotations of that term. In other words, he has sold himself as much on his pixie Irish personality as on his musical gifts, making crossover albums, appearing on talk shows and reveling in all the trappings of celebrity.

title: 2 Hunts Fined And Banned From Trades
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, the former billionaires whose fortunes collapsed after a failed effort to corner the world silver market a decade ago, will pay fines of $10 million each and be banned from trading in the American commodity markets in a partial settlement of charges stemming from the episode, Government officials and lawyers said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Curtice Burns Foods, Rochester, which processes and markets food products, named Darryl L. Canfield corporate controller.

title: Midwest Cold Wave Keeps Setting Records
description: A cold wave continued breaking records in the nation's midsection today as forecasters warned of even more bitter weather to come.

description: Following are excerpts from briefings on the Panama invasion given by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at the Pentagon this morning, and by Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. title: Israeli Agency for Migrants Says Funds Are Now Critical
description: In the midst of urgent appeals to American Jews for money to pay for Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel, the treasurer of the Jewish Agency has said the organization will have to turn its immigrant-absorption services over to the Government if American donors do not give more.

title: Aquino Approves a Measure Granting Emergency Powers
description: President Corazon C. Aquino signed a bill today granting her emergency powers and said she would use them to protect the country and revive the economy after this month's military revolt.

title: Max & Erma's Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a tax credit of $26,000, or 1 cent a share, and $353,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a tax credit of $86,000, or 3 cents, and $251,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Scene; Fires and U.S. Helicopters Transforming Panama City
description: Thick plumes of gray and white smoke rose over Panama City today, more than 12 hours after United States forces began a night attack to capture Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Upheaval in the East; Czechoslovak Communists Replace Chairman of Party
description: Czechoslovakia's Communists ousted the party leader today and elected as party chairman a former Prime Minister who has emerged as one of the more conciliatory leaders in the recent weeks of dramatic upheaval.

title: Huey Long's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: In a SoHo Show, the Wit and Whimsy of Piero Fornasetti
description: RICK GALLAGHER cannot remember exactly when he first became interested in the work of Piero Fornasetti. ''All I know,'' Mr. Gallagher said, ''is that the first things I saw were plates with whimsical recipes, like how to cook a dragon or a dodo, but all completely deadpan.''

title: Sale by Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. sold a 7.5 percent stake in its Toyko-based venture, Yamatake-Honeywell, for $126 million to a group of Japanese financial and industrial institutions. On Oct. 24, Honeywell sold a 16 percent stake in the venture and now holds 26.5 percent. It said proceeds from the sales would be used to repurchase up to 10 million of its shares, which rose $2.25 today, to $82.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Federal Express reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $18,100,000, or 35 cents a share.

title: Two Elite New Yorkers, as Edited by a Third
description: It was almost preordained that Louis Auchincloss - novelist, lawyer, president of the Museum of the City of New York and member of a prominent old New York family - would undertake the culling and commentary for the excerpted diaries of two distinguished 19th-century New Yorkers: Philip Hone, a businessman and Mayor of the city, and George Templeton Strong, a lawyer, Columbia College trustee, civic leader and a pillar of the Philharmonic Society.

title: Funds Post Rise in Yields
description: Yields of tax-free and taxable money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report rose for the week that ended yesterday.

title: For Table Tops, Items That Aspire to Be Art
description: AT Archetype Gallery on the Lower East Side, a candlestick is not just a candlestick. It aspires to be art, at least in the show ''Tabletop Objects,'' which runs through Dec. 24 at 411 East Ninth Street (529-5880).

title: Taiwan Monetary Policy
description: Taiwan will temporarily relax its tight monetary policy to help local companies pay out billions of local dollars in salaries and bonuses before the Lunar New Year on Jan. 27. Bankers said the measure would also keep interest rates and the United States-Taiwan dollar exchange rate stable. They said the easing will start in mid-January, lasting about a month. Taiwanese companies traditionally give a New Year's bonus worth three to six months' salary.

title: 2 Approved As Deputies To Chancellor
description: Joseph A. Fernandez, the incoming New York City Schools Chancellor, succeeded yesterday in securing the appointments of two deputies whose credentials had been challenged by the state, and he promptly claimed a crucial triumph in his effort to push through his program to improve the school system.

title: PARENTS & CHILD
description: IT has been almost two years since the 30-year-old brother of Kay O. died of a bone-marrow disease. Kay, a writer from Minneapolis who asked that her full name not be used, said she found herself thinking about him more often during the holiday season. She is approaching 30 herself and is still trying to sort through her feelings about what happened, not only to her brother but also to herself and to members of her family. It is a wound that, although not apparent to outsiders, still hurts during family gatherings.

title: Upheaval in the East; Ceausescu Blames 'Fascists' For Uproar in Rumania City
description: The Rumanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu, speaking to his nation for the first time since security forces cracked down on tens of thousands of protesters in a western Rumanian city Sunday, said tonight that the demonstrations had been the work of ''fascist reactionary groups.''

title: Coniston Urging UAL Buyout Plan
description: Coniston Partners, the investment group that owns 11.8 percent of the UAL Corporation's stock, said it would work with the company's board to overhaul UAL if management and the unions did not come up with a buyout plan by Jan. 8. Coniston said it still thought the best course was to sell the company, which owns United Airlines, to management and the unions.

title: The Outrage At Players' Millions
description: A story yesterday in a another newspaper about Sid Fernandez, the portly pitcher, signing a three-year contract with the Mets for $6 million began, ''During a winter of outrageous contracts. . . .''

title: Fighting in Panama: The Drug War; Washington Hopes to Close a Trafficking Haven
description: A major goal of the strike in Panama was not just to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega but to eliminate the nation as a haven for illicit narcotics traffickers, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Tie Moves Rangers Into First Again
description: For the Rangers, the two goals amounted to a glut. That one of them had come on the power play amounted to a minor miracle. So the fact that the entire night's work amounted to just a single point was no reason to complain.

title: Judith Jamison Is Named Ailey Company Director
description: Judith Jamison, whose career as a dancer, choreographer and director of her own company has been bound up with the life and ideals of Alvin Ailey, was chosen yesterday to succeed her mentor as director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Mr. Ailey died on Dec. 1. Ms. Jamison, who is 45 years old, was discovered by Mr. Ailey in 1964 at a humiliatingly unsuccessful audition for a television special to be directed by the choreographer Donald McKayle. She fled from that first New York tryout, almost stumbling over a man seated at the side of the stage. It was Mr. Ailey, and three days later he called to invite her to join his modern-dance company.

title: New Jersey Gives Up Park Land in Swap With Developer
description: A deal in which state officials pushed through the sale of state park land to a developer to keep a large corporation from leaving New Jersey has raised questions about the state's guardianship of public property.

title: Fighting in Panama: United Nations; 2 PANAMA VOICES ASK TO BE HEARD
description: The Security Council refused today to choose between rival claimants to be the legitimate government of Panama, but it agreed to meet to hear a formal complaint by Nicaragua about the American action.

title: Synercom Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $152,000, or 2 cents a share, and $772,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Review/Music; Quartet Experiments, Without Amplifiers
description: The Soldier String Quartet usually plays with amplification and a drummer, but on Sunday evening the group's percussionist took the evening off, and its violinists (David Soldier and Laura Seaton), its violist (Ron Lawrence) and its cellist (Mary Wooten) left their amplifiers home and played a concert at Roulette.

title: Probation for Bobby Seale
description: A local court on Tuesday placed the Black Panther co-founder Bobby Seale on probation for a year, fined him $1,000 and ordered him to perform 100 hours of community service for writing bad checks in a financially disastrous venture to sell ribs at a barbecue festival. The 52-year-old Mr. Seale pleaded guilty Nov. 20 to four misdemeanor counts of passing bad checks for more than $10,700 in ribs, lodging and other expenses for his booth at Cleveland's National Rib Cook-Off last year.

title: Fighting in Panama: Strategy; Gaps in Vital Intelligence Hampered U.S. Troops
description: Unlike the invasion of Grenada, which was ordered by President Reagan on short notice and with no forces in place, the Panama operation was developed and refined over a period of several years by the Pentagon and started with a base of 12,000 American troops already in Panama. Nevertheless, like the

title: HUNGRY CHILDREN INCREASE IN SURVEY
description: Hunger and homelessness in the nation's cities rose most rapidly this year among families with children, the United States Conference of Mayors said today.

title: CURRENTS
description: RED SQUARE, a new rental apartment house at 250 East Houston Street in Manhattan (near Avenue A) that opened in July, is just another plain red brick building. ''Standard,'' said Michael Rosen, who developed the 130-unit building with Brian Vail and Michael Gruss and the architectural firm Schulman Lichtenstein Claman Ephron of Manhattan.

title: Serbian Workers Hold Brief Warning Strike
description: About 650,000 workers in Serbia staged a brief strike today against changes proposed by the national Government headed by Prime Minister Ante Markovic.

title: Fumes From Garage Kill 2 in House Above
description: Two cousins died and a third was hospitalized yesterday after fumes from an unattended car idling in a Brooklyn garage seeped into a house above.

title: Stencil Designs to Suit Every Taste
description: FOR do-it-yourselfers who want to try their hand at stenciling, Stencil World carries tools and about 200 kits.

title: Computers, for Youngsters Who Can Barely Say the Word
description: DIANE BISHOP looked tense. And confused.

title: Stephen Hartdegen; Priest, 82, Compiled New American Bible
description: The Rev. Stephen J. Hartdegen, an internationally renowned biblical scholar, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Holy Name Friary in Ringwood, N.J. He was 82 years old. Father Hartdegen, a member of the Franciscan Order, served from 1944 to 1970 as editor in chief of a team of 51 scholars who issued the New American Bible, a translation from ancient Hebrew, Greek and Aramaic scriptures. It replaced the Douay version of the Bible and was declared the official translation for use in Roman Catholic liturgy in the United States. He was also general editor of the Complete Verbal Concordance of the New American Bible, published in 1977.

title: Basketball; Mavericks Less Bad Than Nets
description: Neither the Dallas Mavericks nor the Nets could take much pride in the way they played tonight. But at least the Mavericks came away with a victory.

title: Review/Theater; 'Art of Success' Makes Hogarth The Warhol of the 18th Century
description: ''The Art of Success,'' the play by Nick Dear at the Manhattan Theater Club, had its premiere at the Royal Shakespeare Company in England in 1986, but an American theatergoer might well assume it had been written in New York this fall. In our year of Mapplethorpe and Serrano, here is a scabrous comedy about the creation, purpose, promotion, merchandising, censorship and government patronage of art - all set forth in a theatrical palette that encompasses rough sex, scatological language, ribald political satire, urine and excrement. The production is, of course, made possible in part by funds from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: 18 Dead in Brazilian Flooding
description: At least 18 people have died in floods which swept northeast and central Brazil, national newspapers reported today. They said 17 people had died in the eastern state of Bahia, where about 12,000 people are now homeless. Heavy rains have been falling in the town of Goias, an 18th-century gold rush town in central Brazil. Newspapers said flood waters had killed one gold miner and threatened old buildings.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hospital Corp. Drops Psychiatric Unit Sale
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said its plan to retire debt with the $1.13 billion sale of 53 psychiatric hospitals had fallen through, but company executives said yesterday that they still expected to get the money by selling assets.

title: Volcano's Eruption Subsides; A Few Flights Are Resumed
description: The eruption of Redoubt Volcano subsided Tuesday, allowing some holiday travelers to catch flights as fears eased that volcanic ash would clog jet engines.

title: Chopping Down Washington's Cherry Tree
description: The Making of the Prefident 1789 The Unauthorized Campaign Biography By Marvin Kitman Illustrated. 358 pages. Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Acquittal in a Case Deemed Not Racial
description: A white man who beat a black teen-ager with a golf club has been acquitted of assault and harassment by a Nassau County jury that decided the attack was not racially motivated.

title: Oil Sale Disclosure Upsets Israeli-Iranian Contacts
description: The disclosure of an Iranian oil sale to Israel has disrupted secret contacts that were under way between the countries for some time and were conducted through a variety of intermediaries at different European and international locations, a senior Israeli official says.

title: Talking Deals; Inland's Links To Nippon Steel
description: THE last two years have seen an intensifying of the ties between American steelmakers and their Japanese counterparts in the forms of joint ventures and research and technology agreements. Still, this week's sale by Inland Steel Industries of 185,000 shares of its newly issued preferred stock to the Nippon Steel Corporation for $185 million, is perhaps the boldest link yet.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Alexander Julian, to McCaffery & Ratner, for the Couture Collection and Colours clothing lines, with billings of more than $2 million.

title: Troop Talks Pending, Soviets and Czechs Say
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the new Prime Minister of Czechoslovakia, Marian Calfa, agreed today that the issue of Soviet troops stationed in the Soviet ally will be discussed in special negotiations in a few weeks.

title: More on Panama
description: THE OPERATION: A18 After initial successes, Americans may face urban warfare. THE STATEMENTS: A19-20 Remarks by President Bush and other American officials. THE DECISION: A21 The operation, developed and refined over several years, won bipartisan support in Congress. THE PANAMANIANS: A22 The two-and-a-half-year struggle between Manuel Antonio Noriega and Washington. Profiles of the new leaders. THE SCENE: A23 Houses in the capital were hit, and many burned. THE REACTION: A24 Moscow and Latin America condemned the invasion. The United Nations refused to choose between rivals. THE DRUG WAR: A25 Washington hopes to shut down Panama as a trafficking haven.

title: The Games Played For Nintendo's Sales
description: Meet the man behind Nintendo, the video game maker that is the talk of America three Christmases running.

title: Fighting in Panama: Latin America; U.S. Denounced by Nations Touchy About Intervention
description: From Mexico to Argentina, Latin American governments today roundly condemned the use of force by the United States against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama.

title: Lois Darling, 72, Dies; An Artist and a Writer
