description: Lois MacIntyre Darling, an artist, author and conservationist, died of leukemia on Tuesday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Esther M. F. Cloward, Women's Rights Advocate, 91
description: Esther Marie Fleming Cloward, a longtime advocate of women's rights, died Tuesday at the White Plains Hospital after a brief illness. She was 91 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: 16-Year-Old Killed by 3 Men in Brooklyn
description: A 16-year-old youth was fatally shot in the back last night after being chased down a street in Brooklyn by three men firing guns, the police said.

title: Dow Drops 7.68 Points, To 2,687.93
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, amid worries about the economic outlook and the events in Panama. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.68 points to end at 2,687.93.

title: Ben Barzman Dead; Scriptwriter Was 79
description: Ben Barzman, a scriptwriter who was blacklisted during the McCarthy era and whose movie credits include ''Back to Bataan'' (1945), ''El Cid'' (1961) and ''The Blue Max'' (1966), died on Friday after a stroke. He was 79 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 13 about Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. misstated the dollar value of the firm's public underwritings of high-yield ''junk bonds,'' as well as its market share, for the fourth quarter through Dec. 11. A related chart misstated the figures in the same categories for the year through Dec. 11. For the quarter, Drexel underwrote $807.3 million in such bonds and ranked third among competitors, with a 14.8 percent share, according to IDD Information Services. In 1989, through Dec. 11, the firm underwrote $9.5 billion in high-yield junk bonds and had a 34.9 percent share, IDD said. IDD, which supplied the numbers for the article, says the incorrect figures resulted from a computer error.

title: Farm Credit Banks In $2.4 Billion Issue
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks yesterday priced $2.4 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds with three-month, six-month and one-year maturities.

title: Vanishing Act for Tax Cut
description: Like one of those snowstorms that fill the news for a few days and then drift quietly out to sea, the 1990 income-tax cut, featured prominently in New York State tax forms for the last two years, has silently disappeared from the charts.

title: McDonnell To Supply Jets to Seoul
description: South Korea said today that it had chosen the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to supply its air force with 120 new fighter jets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Wisconsin Gains In Coach Search
description: The University of Wisconsin has been given permission to talk to West Virginia's head football coach, Don Nehlen, about its vacant coaching position, the West Virginia athletic director, Ed Pastilong said today.

title: Margaret G. Bachner, Lawyer, 88
description: Margaret G. Bachner, a retired lawyer who represented the Jewish Board of Guardians in children's cases in the 1950's and 1960's in Manhattan, died on Monday in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. She was 88 years old.

title: Holy See Aims for Role as U.N.'s Conscience
description: About three times every week, John Paul Reiner, a corporate lawyer, leaves his bright office in the Chrysler Building to sit in a windowless meeting hall at the United Nations.

title: Georg von Lilienfeld, German Diplomat, 77
description: Georg von Lilienfeld, a German foreign service officer and diplomat in the years before and after World War II, died on Dec. 11 in Munich, where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Dec. 6 about holiday celebrations credited the copyright owners of the song ''Home for the Holidays'' incorrectly. They are Robert Allen, who wrote the music, and Al Stillman, who wrote the lyrics. The extracts with the article were printed by permission.

title: Trans Canada Glass reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $18,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $2,872,000, or 13 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,407,000, or 7 cents a share, and $4,639,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hurt by Single-Home Loans, Dime Savings Sees a Loss
description: The Dime Savings Bank, an active lender on home mortgages in the New York area in recent years, announced yesterday that it expected a $110 million loss in the fourth quarter, mostly from problems with single-family homes bought as investment properties.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Ex-Aide to Dukakis Leaving Hill, Holliday
description: LEAD: John R. Sasso, who joined Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos last year after leaving Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign, is leaving the Boston advertising agency to open his own public-policy consulting company.

title: New Wang Plan
description: Troubled Wang Laboratories Inc., which has been criticized for having too limited a product line, said it would integrate industrywide standards into its product lines by developing new sets of hardware and software based on popular operating standards like Unix and DOS. Many computer companies have been making equipment compatible with that of other manufacturers. Wang said the announcement was part of a general strategy outlined last month by its president, Richard Miller. Wang, which posted a loss of $62.1 million in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, cut 2,000 jobs last month, in addition to about 5,000 jobs eliminated earlier this year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ashland Coal Inc., Ashland, Ky., a mining company, said it would buy Mingo Logan Coal Co. for $137 million from BP America Inc.

title: Kraft General Chief Selected
description: The Philip Morris Companies announced yesterday that Michael A. Miles had been named chairman and chief executive of its Kraft General Foods unit, a vice chairman of Philip Morris and a Philip Morris director. Philip Morris had already announced that it planned to make the appointments.

title: C.P.A. Rallying Cry: Dull No More!
description: In one of the season's surprise screen hits, ''Look Who's Talking,'' the profile of the heroine is no surprise: Mollie Krane, career woman, is indispensable to her clients and pretty to boot.

title: Kirill T. Mazurov, Soviet Official
description: Kirill T. Mazurov, a former Deputy Prime Minister and Politburo member, has died at the age of 75, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Daniel J. Silver, 61, Rabbi and an Author
description: Rabbi Daniel Jeremy Silver, an author who was spiritual leader of The Temple, a Reform congregation in Cleveland, died yesterday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He was 61 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East; Kohl Strives to Address Hope and Fear on Unity
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl concluded his emotional first visit to East Germany today, saying that the yearning for German unity was entirely normal and that peace in Europe could not be secured ''until the right to self-determination in Central Europe is realized.''

title: Fighting in Panama: The Attack; U.S. TROOPS GAIN WIDE CONTROL IN PANAMA; NEW LEADERS PUT IN, BUT NORIEGA GETS AWAY
description: About 10,000 American troops backed by helicopter gunships and overwhelming firepower took control of much of Panama today. But after installing a new Government sympathetic to Washington they had not achieved a major objective: capturing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. American officials said that in the broad assault, the largest American military operation since the Vietnam War, at least 15 American servicemen and an American civilian woman were killed and 59 other Americans were wounded. There was no exact count of Panamanian casualties, but news reports said scores were killed and hundreds wounded. Four of the helicopters were downed.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Ohio Office for Martin
description: LEAD: The Martin Agency, the ad shop whose award-winning creativity made Richmond an advertising town, is heading to the Midwest, opening an office in Columbus, Ohio, to service the Banc One Corporation, a bank holding company that yesterday awarded its account to the agency. Billings will be about $12 million annually.

title: Barkley Withdraws
description: Iran Barkley is suffering from a torn retina in his left eye and has withdrawn from a World Boxing Organization middleweight title bout that had been scheduled for Jan. 15 against Doug DeWitt. Bob Arum, the promoter, made the announcement.

title: Suicide to Donate Heart to Brother Is in Vain
description: A man who said in a note that he wanted to donate his heart in an effort to save a brother with heart disease committed suicide outside a hospital Monday night. But the body was found too late, and his heart could not be used for a transplant.

title: New Nuclear Plant Operator Got Bonuses Despite Lapses
description: The Energy Department says it has given the new operator of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant $3.9 million in contract bonuses despite serious safety lapses, including workers found sleeping on duty.

title: Ms. Magazine Names Editor
description: Robin Morgan has been named editor in chief of Ms. magazine, which is to be transformed in the spring into a bimonthly publication without advertising.

title: Yanks Send Sanders To Columbus
description: In a move the club did not announce, the Yankees sent the outfielder Deion Sanders outright to Columbus of the International League on Tuesday.

title: Norman Mailer Complains About Mention in 'Tru'
description: Truman Capote, who sparked more than a few literary contretemps during his lifetime, has now been drawn into a controversy five years after his death. The novelist Norman Mailer is having a theatrical tiff with Jay Presson Allen, the author of ''Tru,'' a one-man Broadway show about Capote starring Robert Morse.

title: End of East German Party Leaves Bitter Taste; Spymaster's Brother
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubt Voiced on Marrow Use Against AIDS
description: A top Government AIDS researcher expressed reservations yesterday about a report that a bone marrow transplant coupled with an antiviral drug may have rid a patient's body of the AIDS virus.

title: Islanders Get 3 Leafs
description: The Islanders and the Toronto Maple Leafs made a multiplayer trade yesterday involving players who have spent much or all of the season in the American Hockey League.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column on Nov. 5 about the publication of Pete Rose's book misidentified some evidence included in major league baseball's report about his gambling. A letter from the book's co-author dated Dec. 14 points out that the evidence consisted of records of phone calls made by Mr. Rose, not tape recordings of the calls.

title: Hockey: Notebook; Short List for New Union Chief
description: The replacement for Alan Eagleson as executive director of the National Hockey League Players Association could be nominated as soon as the weekend of the All-Star Game, Jan. 21-22, in Pittsburgh.

title: Even the Nuns Have to Carry Mugger Money
description: ''The sisters, who wear their habits, they've been broken into 14 times since Aug. 1,'' Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan was saying.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Implications; War: Bush's Presidential Rite of Passage
description: For George Bush, the United States invasion of Panama early this morning constituted a Presidential initiation rite as well as an attempt to achieve specific goals.

title: Upheaval in the East; U.S. Ambassador No Longer Keeps His Poles Apart
description: It was George Bush's first visit to Poland, and when talk over dinner turned to Solidarity, the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, picked at his food and said the banned union no longer existed. It was just a bunch of people that John Davis was always having to dinner.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Holder Raises Saatchi Stake
description: LEAD: Southeastern Asset Management, the Memphis investment company that is the Saatchi & Saatchi Company's largest shareholder, has increased its stake to 11.2 percent by buying 1.7 million additional shares.

title: Bayou Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company changed its method of accounting for inventory from the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, under which the company operated since its inception, to the last-in, first- out method (LIFO). This change resulted in a $2.4 million reduction in 1989 earnings, or 19 cents a share.

title: Fighting in Panama: The State Dept.; Excerpts From Statement by Baker on U.S. Policy
description: Following are excerpts from a special State Department briefing given by Secretary of State James A Baker 3d, as provided by The Federal News Service, a transcription company: THE STATEMENT

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Renegade Style Helps Shop Thrive
description: LEAD: ABOUT two years ago, Jack Roth - renegade, iconoclast and prominent advertising executive - decided it was time to apply his ideas about retail advertising and marketing to consumer goods products. Characteristically, he did not bother waiting for a client to come along. He started his own soup company.

title: Polish Miners, Grimy Kings of Coal, Face Dethroning in Economic Overhaul
description: Coal miners have long been the nobility of Poland's working class, and mine managers have been kings among those nobles, but king though he may be, Erwin Koziol, head of the mine here, has fear writ large on his face nowadays.

title: Continental Homes Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the current quarter included about $1,141,000 in net profit from its California joint ventures and a pretax loss of about $1,100,000 relating to the final disposition of property in Tucson, Ariz.

title: A Diary for the Home
description: FIRST there was the agenda for jotting down addresses and appointments. Now there is ''Home Facts'' (Times Books, $19.95), an agenda for the house in which you keep track of furnishings, insurance policies and the exact measurements and materials used in its construction.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
CMS Chief to Weigh Conversion of Shoreham
description: LEAD: If James W. Cook has his way, he could be calling the shots on the conversion of the Shoreham nuclear power plant to one that uses natural gas.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Dec. 15 about a method for turning ''junk bonds'' into investment-grade securities misstated the status of a regulatory review of the First Executive Corporation's attempt to repackage some bonds. The California Department of Insurance is conducting an examination of the transaction and has not yet reached a decision on it. A related article appears on page D6.

title: Aztec Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TV Weekend; 'Bill Cosby Salutes Alvin Ailey,' an NBC Special
description: Yes, this being Christmas, you will be able to savor once again over this long holiday weekend such traditional chestnuts as ''The Sound of Music'' and ''The Homecoming: A Christmas Story,'' which back in 1971 served as a pilot for the long-running series ''The Waltons.'' This is the time of year when television viewing plummets as families find other activities for diversion, so the budget-conscious networks fall back heavily on reruns and news specials.

title: Imperialism, Bush-Style
description: LEAD: ''God told me to take the Philippines,'' President William McKinley explained to news reporters in 1898, describing his decision-making process during a sleepless night of dialogue with the Almighty. Lyndon Johnson informed television audiences in the mid-1960's that he had prayed for foreign policy guidance, and presumably God told him to send troops into

title: Bach's Magnificat in D
description: Kenneth Dake will conduct the St. George's Choral Society in Bach's Magnificat in D at St. George's Episcopal Church, 209 East 16th Street, on Christmas Eve at 10:30 P.M. The performance is offered as a prelude to a Service of Lessons and Carols, which begins at 11. Admission is free. Information: 475-0830.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Pentagon; Excerpts From Briefings on the Military Action in Panama
description: Following are excerpts from briefings on the Panama invasion given this afternoon at the Pentagon by the Defense Department spokesman, Pete Williams, and by Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Kelly and Adm. Ted Sheafer of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: THE STATEMENTS Hunt for Noriega

title: THIRD AREA CODE FOR LOS ANGELES
description: Telephone customers in Los Angeles will have a third area code in 1992 because the system is overloaded caused by cellular phones, fax machines, computers - and by ordinary phones.

title: Forman in His Own and Others' Words
description: Milos Forman gets only good reviews in tonight's profile on ''American Masters,'' at 11:30 on Channel 13. The movie director's agent, producer, screenwriter, cinematographer, sound man and several actors speak admiringly of him, but none can match the impression of amiability and imagination conveyed by the man himself.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; U.S. vs. British Ads: The Most Effective?
description: Are British advertisements, which often entice consumers with entertainment and subtle humor, more effective than hard-sell American ones? Not to Americans, suggests a study of two Hellmann's mayonnaise print ads - one American, the other British.

title: U.S. Is Giving High Priority to Building a New Embassy in Moscow
description: The State Department, citing ''changing conditions'' in the Soviet Union, is giving high priority to constructing a new United States Embassy in Moscow to replace the one to be razed after years of indecision.

title: 5th Amendment Right to Silence Is Debated in Aliens' Cases
description: The right to keep silent under the Fifth Amendment is being tested here in deportation hearings for a group of Latin American immigrants who were seized in a raid on a racetrack.

title: Killing of 200 Reported In Sri Lanka Violence
description: At least 200 young men were shot or hacked to death in the worst day of violence in Sri Lanka, residents said today.

title: INDIA'S NEW CHIEF GIVEN A GO-AHEAD
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh won a resounding vote of confidence in the Indian Parliament today, clearing the way for the new Government's first package of bills intended to open the administration to public scrutiny.

title: Anne T. Board Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Anne Taylor Board, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Board of Wilmington, Del., to William Burpee Richards, the son of Mrs. LeRoy Richards Jr. of Ardmore, Pa., and the late Mr. Richards, took place yesterday. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Fighting in Panama: Casualties; First American Dead Arrive From Panama
description: The first four coffins holding bodies of Americans killed in Panama arrived at the United States Air Force base here on a bleak Thursday afternoon. Another 14 arrived in brutal sub-zero temperatures shortly after midnight today.

title: Lincoln Center Gets No More Subsidy Than Kennedy Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Readers Buy This 'Hot Book'?
description: Dubbed a ''hot book'' not long after it was started nearly two years ago, 7 Days, the weekly magazine, now faces the difficult task of proving that Manhattan's trend-setters actually read it and are willing to pay for it.

title: 32 Dead in Brazil Floods
description: Two weeks of pounding rains in northern Brazil have killed 32 people and left thousands homeless, civil defense officials said today. Worst hit was the state of Bahia, where 24 people died and 25,000 were left homeless, according to Jornal do Brasil, a daily newspaper here.

title: DURENBERGER SAYS HE BROKE NO RULES
description: Apologizing to his Minnesota constituents, Senator Dave Durenberger said Wednesday that his personal financial dealings revealed poor judgment on his part but that they did not violate Senate rules.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Daryl Elliott has been promoted to senior vice president of Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Ex-Police Aide Held On Charge of Fraud In a Detroit Scheme
description: A former police official suspected in the disappearance of money from a secret $1.4 million Police Department fund was arrested on fraud charges today.

title: Braniff Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the latest quarter figures included charges of $64 million from the the writeoff of goodwill and $22.4 million related to its Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition.

title: Slower Growth Seen In Industrialized World
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today projected that growth in the industrial world would slow next year while inflation would inch up slightly.

title: Better Reporting Seen in Zaire's AIDS Case Count
description: Health officials here reported in October that 335 people were either sick or had died of AIDS, a figure that had remained virtually unchanged for nearly two years.

title: Restaurants
description: Do you want to have a little fun with a Manhattan foodie? Just mention casually: ''I'm going to the Quilted Giraffe tonight for the first time. Is it good?''

title: Engineered Support Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and the year included a gain of $500,000, or 15 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: U.S. Alters Plan for Offsetting Excess Charges for Medicare
description: The Government announced today that it would send two checks early next year to each of 27 million older Americans to offset continued deductions from their Social Security checks for a $5.30 monthly premium for extended Medicare coverage that was repealed last month.

title: Upheaval in the East; Hungary's Parliament Paves Way for Election
description: Parliament voted today to dissolve itself in March, paving the way for the first free elections in the country in more than four decades.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a diversified services company, named Kathleen M. Burns treasurer.

title: Star's Transfer Blocked
description: East German sports authorities yesterday blocked the move of Rainer Ernst to a West German club, saying the soccer star was not playing well enough to deserve a transfer.

title: Appointment at West Point
description: Brig. Gen. David Bramlett has become the United States Military Academy's 62d commandant of cadets, West Point officials said today. General Bramlett, 48 years old, will assume responsibility for the military training in the classroom and field for the academy's 4,400 cadets. A native of Galesburg, Ill., General Bramlett is a 1964 graduate of West Point.

title: Israel to Seize Property of Young Stone-Throwers' Parents
description: The Israeli Army announced today that it would begin impounding property or sealing homes belonging to the parents of Palestinian children who throw rocks at soldiers in the occupied territories.

title: A Christmas Compendium: What to See, Hear, Do
description: AS the season to be jolly moves into its frenetically jolliest of weekends today, New York City will be singing, shopping, sparkling, touring, dancing and otherwise celebrating. The long Christmas weekend, which coincides with the beginning of Hanukkah this year (related article, page C34), may chiefly be a time for indoor family festivities. But for those with a desire to venture out into a world awash in smiling Santas, joyous carolers, spectacular pageants and twinkling lights, the city will be filled with holiday activities in the next four days.

title: Party Is Little Changed, But Not the Partygoers
description: The days have passed, to the extent they ever really existed, when inherited wealth and family connections could propel a bright prep school and Ivy League graduate into a position of influence over international affairs. But the unofficial club of America's foreign-policy elite, the Council on Foreign Relations, continues to hold its annual sons and daughters meeting in its white limestone town house on Park Avenue.

title: Fighting in Panama; Panama Canal Opens After One-Day Closing
description: The Panama Canal reopened today after a one-day closing caused by the United States military strike, the only time anything other than natural disaster has halted operation of the 75-year-old waterway.

title: Dr. William Greenough, 75, Dies; Devised Variable-Annuity Fund
description: Dr. William C. Greenough, an economist and lecturer whose work transformed pension-fund management, died on Wednesday night at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after suffering complications from a heart attack. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 199 Counts On Ohrenstein Are Upheld
description: An appeals court yesterday upheld the indictment of the New York State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein. But the ruling dismissed many counts that were at the heart of the prosecution's case.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's bloody cold out here. I can't stand it. I'd rather not be out in this weather, but we all get that Christmas spirit, so here we all are, freezing in Rockefeller Center.'' - Simon Jones, a visitor from London. [ B4:1. ]

title: Marcos Lawyer Says the U.S. Offers Plea-Bargaining Deal
description: Imelda Marcos, the widow of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, has been offered a deal by the United States Government in which she would plead guilty to some charges in a racketeering case in return for a suspended jail sentence, one of her lawyers said yesterday.

title: New League Names Michaels as a Coach
description: Walt Michaels, who coached the Jets in 1977-82, yesterday was named a head coach in the International League of American Football for an unspecified team. He had also been head coach of the New Jersey Generals for two seasons in the United States Football League.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'GONDOLIERS'

title: Fighting in Panama: Nicaragua; Army Told to Surround U.S. Embassy as Reply to Move in Panama
description: Nicaragua ordered its army to surround the United States Embassy in Managua today in retaliation for surrounding the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama with American troops, Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann said.

title: Review/Film; Stallone And Russell As Buddies
description: Sylvester Stallone, a man in desperate need of career advice, had the good sense to subordinate his larger-than-life screen presence to the demands of a buddy film, and the bad judgment to pick this one. ''Tango and Cash,'' which finds Mr. Stallone wearing three-piece suits and glasses in an excessively ambitious attempt to make the break with Rambo, pairs him with Kurt Russell as a fellow Los Angeles narcotics officer. While the film hints at an easygoing rapport between these two, it buries any glimmer of fun beneath stupid jokes, schoolyard sarcasm and brutish, musclebound direction.

title: Fighting in Panama: The United States; Legislators Express Concern On the Operation's Future
description: Capitol Hill took a sober second look today at the United States attack on Panama.

title: Company News; Air Canada Sells Some GPA Shares
description: Air Canada said it had sold 37 percent of its shares in GPA Group P.L.C. for $650 a share, or a total of $212 million (United States), resulting in an after-tax gain of $110.3 million. Ireland-based GPA Group, the world's leading aircraft leasing company, completed the share placement on behalf of Air Canada by placing 5.4 percent of its share capital with financial institutions in Canada, Ireland, Japan and the United States The sale will reduce Air Canada's holding in GPA to 9.3 percent from 14.7 percent on a fully diluted basis, making Air Canada the third-largest shareholder in GPA.

title: Rome Journal; They Came, They Saw, Then They Sandblasted
description: This capital remains, of course, one of the world's great beauties, but it is hiding many of its charms these days behind veils.

title: Soedjatmoko, 67, Indonesia Diplomat And Social Scientist
description: Soedjatmoko, a prominent Indonesian intellectual and former diplomat, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at Muhammadiyeh Islamic University in Jogjakarta, in Central Java, where he was lecturing. He was 67 years old and lived in Jakarta, the nation's capital.

title: Brooklyn Drug Officer Wounded and Robbed
description: An undercover police officer was shot and robbed of $11,000 by two gunmen yesterday in Brooklyn in a ''buy and bust'' narcotics operation, the police said.

title: 'Messe de Minuit'
description: David Shuler will conduct the Choirs of the Church of St. Luke and the Fairfield Period Instrument Academy in Charpentier's ''Messe de Minuit Pour Noel'' and Poulenc's Motets for the Christmas Season at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson Street, on Christmas Eve at 10 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 924-0562.

title: Review/Theater; 'Kingfish,' An Exercise In Absurdism
description: The title character in Marlane Meyer's ''Kingfish'' is a Doberman pinscher portrayed by a black box with a green grin and a rope tail. The dog's bark is supplied by an actor sitting at a microphone. In this play, Ms. Meyer, a playwright with a previously demonstrated talent for gritty realism, has taken a sidestep into self-conscious absurdism.

title: Review/Dance; Updating 'Nutcracker' With Break-Dancing
description: David Storey describes his production of ''The Nutcracker'' as a contemporary version. And little Clara's fantasy, in the first few moments, about meeting the man who owns the Hard Rock Cafe, prepares us for the best and worst. But the production at the Marymount Manhattan Theater remains steadfastly somewhere in the middle of that spectrum.

title: Fighting in Panama: Beijing; China Calls U.S. Strike in Panama A Violation of International Law
description: Saying it is ''shocked,'' China today condemned the American military strike in Panama as a violation of international law and demanded the immediate withdrawal of American forces.

title: Disputes at 2 Realty Trusts
description: A Federal judge has sealed the votes collected yesterday at the shareholder meetings of two real estate investment trusts in Dallas pending a hearing on the adequacy of the disclosures made to investors by the two former executives of the troubled Southmark Corporation who run the trusts.

title: Neighborhoods Santa Has No Trouble Finding
description: UNADORNED homes are rare commodities around Christmastime in Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst and Canarsie. With thousands of plastic Santas and snowmen, armies of toy soldiers and multicolored megawatts of lights decorating block upon block of houses and apartment buildings, no one could accuse these Brooklyn neighborhoods of a lack of holiday cheer.

title: Spending Rises 0.7%; Income Up
description: Consumer spending rebounded in November from a sharp fall in the previous month, while personal incomes increased eight-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Times Co. Sets Stock Buyback
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its board had authorized spending up to $50 million to purchase shares of the company's class A common stock.

title: H.U.D. to Review Plan For a Housing Project
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday that it will review its decision to finance a disputed housing project on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Post 9.7% Rise on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 49.4 milion shares, or 9.7 percent, in the four-week period ended Dec. 15. Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

title: Stiffer Rules Proposed for Mutual Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed new rules intended to give investors in mutual funds more and clearer information about the funds and their managers.

title: Boston Five Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Music; Glen Velez Synthesizes East and West
description: Since the 1960's, some Western musicians have picked up non-Western instruments in attempts to create music that gets back to natural sounds and shakes off corrupt Western modernity. Most of that music is quaint, good-natured and naive, rarely worthy of its ethnic sources. But Glen Velez, the composer and percussionist who performed Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory, has come up with East-West hybrids that combine a Western sense of proportion with non-Western improvisations and meditative depths - music that earns a place between two worlds.

title: David Schwartz, 73, Ex-U.S. Claims Judge
description: David Schwartz, a former judge in the United States Court of Claims and a former Justice Department lawyer, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at the Washington Hospice. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Precision Aerotech reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $5,801,000 and $6,172,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $485,000 for the quarter and $219,000 for the 6 months.

title: Market Place; Home Shopping Finds a Bargain
description: THE Home Shopping Network, having lost one huge lawsuit to the GTE Corporation, is acting like its second big suit, against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is also likely to fail.

title: Review/Theater; The Death of an Idol in 'Parting Gestures'
description: Rafael Lima's one-act drama ''Parting Gestures'' goes over some very well-worn dramatic territory with mixed success: a death in a family inspires the airing of dirty emotional laundry and leads to a painful catharis.

title: Fighting in Panama: Image; Selling of a Military Strike: Coffins Arriving as Bush Speaks
description: It was a political image-maker's nightmare.

title: Review/Film; 'Camille Claudel,' a Soul's Disintegration
description: Gerard Depardieu is not only the greatest, most enthusiastic film actor in France, he is also the most generous. Since 1971, he has made 64 movies, good, bad, great and indifferent.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cablevision Systems Corp., Woodbury, L.I., said it would buy Gateway Cable from Gilbert Media Associates L.P. for $102.5 million. Gateway serves Newark and South Orange, N.J., and is close to other Cablevision operations in New Jersey.

title: Economic Scene; Getting Prepared For One Germany
description: MANY people's anxieties these days focus on the political and military dangers of German unification. Memories of the Third Reich do not fade.

title: Oakland Battles U.S. to Be Nuclear-Free
description: The Federal Government is making a test case of this city's effort to turn itself into a nuclear-free zone.

title: Upheaval in the East; Medical Aid for Poland
description: The European Community said today that it would send medical aid to Poland as part of a medical aid program in place since 1982. The 1989 package worth $2.9 million will buy medication and small medical supplies. The aid brings total European Community medical aid to Poland since 1982 to $60.8 million. The supplies will be distributed by the Red Cross and a West German medical charity.

title: As Labor Pool Ebbs, Factories Fish Harder
description: Ronald P. Sandmeyer, a man who patrols the shop floor in a three-piece suit and provides holiday turkeys to all hands, exudes old-school attitudes about how to run a business. But that does not extend to having unusually high employee recruitment standards.

title: William M. Benkert, Coast Guard Admiral, 66
description: William M. Benkert, a retired Coast Guard rear admiral who was a specialist in marine environment and maritime safety, died of lung and liver cancer on Dec. 14 in McLean, Va., where he lived. He was 66 years old.

title: First Executive's 'Junk Bond' Transfer Examined
description: The California Department of Insurance is examining the transfer of ''junk bonds'' by the First Executive Corporation to a series of affiliated companies. The transaction involving bonds worth more than $700 million took place in late 1988, but officials at the state regulator did not learn of it until mid-1989, they said.

title: Israel Must Also Win Trust of the Palestinians; PBS Documentary
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Alters Phone Policy
description: Many local telephone companies will no longer be able to earn a guaranteed profit beginning Jan. 1, 1991, the Federal Communications Commission said today.

title: Upheaval in the East; At Least 13 Are Reported Killed At Protest in Rumania's Capital
description: Rumanian Government forces clashed with protesters in the streets of Bucharest today as anti-Communist demonstrations spread to the country's capital, Western diplomats there said. The United States Embassy in Bucharest reported that at least 13 protesters had been killed, but diplomats said the demonstrators had not been dispersed.

title: Stock-Volume Spurt in Taiwan
description: The volume of stock trading in Taiwan in 1989 rose today to about 26 trillion Taiwanese dollars ($56 billion), or more than three times the amount for 1988.

title: Burlington Industries Capital Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included nonrecurring charges of $30.5 million, principally costs associated with the formation of Burlington Industries Capital, the Burlington Industries Inc. employee stock ownership plan and incentive compensation payments. The company said the results for the year-ago fourth quarter aren't available. During the period, earnings from operations (defined as earnings before interest, taxes and other expenses) were $52.1 million.

title: Saynor Varah reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest 6-month period included an after-tax gain of $676,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Joseph Bachelder, 78, Opinion Researcher
description: Dr. Joseph D. Bachelder, a public-opinion researcher, died yesterday at his home in Jamesburg, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: SOVIET JEWS SEEING FRUIT OF EFFORTS
description: When Jewish families in half a dozen Soviet cities gather during the next few days to view a videotape of a popular animated film about Hanukkah, officials of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture will have won a 20-year gamble.

title: More on Panama
description: STATEMENTS: A16 Remarks by President Bush and Pentagon officials. THE SECOND DAY: A17 One American and possibly several others were reported to be hostages. THE AMERICAN FORCE: A18 Pentagon officials discussed strategy. Bodies of the American dead were flown home. ASSESSMENTS: A19 Prosecution of General Noriega would face obstacles.

title: Reviews/Art; Sculpture Shows at 2 Branches of the Whitney
description: ''Out of Wood: Recent Sculpture,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, underlines the continuing vitality of American wood sculpture. Raoul Hague, Jene Highstein, Mel Kendrick, Michael Lekakis and Ursula von Rydingsvard have different roots and different approaches, and they represent several generations. Yet all five sculptors work in a direct and highly physical manner, and they all want to offer an experience of fullness and enchantment.

title: Cuomo's Ex-Drug Chief Is Rehired, or Is He?
description: Julio A. Martinez said in an interview today that he had accepted the new job offered to him by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last week after he resigned under fire as the state's drug-treatment chief. But Cuomo administration officials contended that Mr. Martinez was still undecided about the job; they maintained that no agreement had been reached on his future.

title: President Adds a Title At Northern Trust
description: The board of the Northern Trust Corporation, a bank holding company based in Chicago, yesterday gave its president, David W. Fox, 58, the additional title of chief executive. As chief, he succeeds the chairman, Weston R. Christopherson, 64, who plans to retire in April.

title: Poindexter Trial Is Delayed Over Reagan Papers
description: The judge in the Iran-contra case of John M. Poindexter today delayed the start of the trial and ordered former President Ronald Reagan to provide the court with excerpts of White House diaries and notebooks to see if they contain evidence relevant to Mr. Poindexter's defense.

title: Playoff Confusion Is Coming to an End
description: National Football League computers, statisticians and prophets will finally get a rest as the regular season ends this weekend. The games will mean sudden death, or sudden life, for the 17 teams that entered the final weekend with Super Bowl XXIV hopes dancing in their thoughts.

title: Fighting in Panama: The President; Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on Central America
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference at the White House this afternoon, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Ms. Kingsbury-Smith Becomes a Bride
description: Eileen Kingsbury-Smith and Thomas Leffingwell Pulling were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony. The bride, 48 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kingsbury-Smith of Washington. A graduate of the Hewitt School, she is a former vice president of Tiffany's. Her father, who was a publisher of The New York Journal-American, is the national editor of the Hearst Newspapers.

title: Stocks Gain; Dow Rises 3.20 Points
description: Stock prices were slightly higher yesterday, as advances of blue chips helped to pull up smaller stocks.

title: Upheaval in the East; Mitterrand, in East Germany, Calls for Caution on Unification
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France today urged closer links between East Germany and Western Europe, but emphasized the need to avoid quick moves toward German unity.

title: Books of The Times; When Wit Was All And Kindness Was Nil
description: The Brideshead Generation Evelyn Waugh and His Friends By Humphrey Carpenter 523 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $27.95.

title: Clean Harbors reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Plane Downing Kills 4 in Sudan
description: A plane carrying four humanitarian workers from a southern Sudan town surrounded by rebels was shot down today shortly after takeoff, and all aboard were killed, a United Nations official said.

title: Upheaval in the East; Rumania Since the 1940's
description: 1944: Soviet forces enter the country with the overthrow of the regime allied with Nazi Germany during World War II. March 1945: Under Soviet pressure, King Michael accepts the appointment of a Communist-led coalition Government. 1946: Elections usher in a Communist-dominated bloc with 89 percent of the vote, although opposition parties charge fraud. Dec. 30, 1947: The King is forced to abdicate and the Rumanian People's Republic is proclaimed. 1948: The republic's first Constitution is adopted and nationalization of the country's industries and banks begins. Thousands of political arrests are made, and the Communists gain full control. 1952: After a purge in the Communist Party, the Government adopts a new Constitution closer to the Soviet model. 1965: Nicolae Ceausescu becomes Communist Party chief. 1968: The Government denounces the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia - the most striking example of Bucharest's independence of Moscow in foreign policy. It also has maintained diplomatic relations with Israel after the Middle East war of 1967, and it became the first Eastern bloc country to recognize West Germany. 1981: Rumania begins to introduce policies to eliminate a foreign debt of more than $11 billion by the end of the decade. Over the years the measures include widespread, severe cuts in residential and industrial energy use and a basic disregard for consumer needs. May 1987: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union visits, but President Ceausescu indicates that the reforms taking place in other Eastern bloc countries will not be introduced in Rumania. November 1987: After months of energy rationing made worse by severe weather, thousands of people, led by workers at a tractor factory, march through the city of Brasov to protest a decline in living standards. Authorities make hundreds of arrests. Similar disturbances break out later in other cities, including the western city of Timisoara. March 1988: The President announces a program calling for the demolition of up to 8,000 villages and the resettlement of their residents, including about 50,000 Hungarians, in housing complexes. The program draws internal and international criticism and severely strains relations between Rumania and Hungary. Dec. 16, 1989: Rumanian security forces begin a crackdown on tens of thousands of protesters in Timisoara. There are reports that as many as 2,000 people were killed. President Ceausescu blames ''fascist reactionary groups.'' Dec. 21: Demonstrations spread to Bucharest.

title: Sears Scraps a Gift Idea Gone Awry
description: A Christmas gift idea from Sears, Roebuck & Company - a $22.25 rocket and launching pad to build and blow up, ''simulating a countdown gone awry'' - was pulled off the market this week after four Idaho children complained to the White House that it sounded not much like holiday fun but a lot like the 1986 Challenger shuttle disaster.

title: Southmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $74,634,000 and $183,787,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $792,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $29,636,000, or 65 cents a share for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6,299,000, or 14 cents a share for the quarter and $17,627,000, or 38 cents a share for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $19,564,000, or 43 cents a share for both the quarter and year. The company said the results for its latest full-year period were adversely affected by additions to provisions for losses of $962 million, most of which was recognized in the third quarter. The latest fourth quarter results were attributable to losses from businesses accounted for as discontinued operations and an adversed tax accural adjustment.

title: Man Awaiting Florida Execution Is Ordered Acquitted in '79 Killing
description: In a rare ruling, the Florida Supreme Court today ordered a verdict of not guilty for a former Army ''Soldier of the Year'' who was under a death sentence in the 1978 murder of a young woman.

title: Upheaval in the East; Gorbachev Voices 'Alarm' On Lithuanian Party Split
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that a decision by the Lithuanian Communist Party to sever its links with the national party raised ''concern and alarm,'' and that the Central Committee would hold an emergency meeting in the next few days to discuss the issue.

title: Interim Project for Homeless Opens Doors in Westchester
description: The first of three transitional housing complexes intended to ease Westchester's problem of the homeless was dedicated here today by New York State and local officials, while in New Jersey families began moving into that state's first such project.

title: Upheaval in the East; PARTY IN PRAGUE IS SUSPENDING 32
description: Ending a turbulent two-day meeting marked by bitterness over abuse of power by former leaders, the Czechoslovak Communist Party voted today to suspend the party memberships of 32 former leaders and expel a former party ideologist whom it accused of instigating the Soviet-led invasion of the country in 1968.

title: Company News; Walkout Disrupts Hyundai Motor Co.
description: The production lines at South Korea's largest car maker, the Hyundai Motor Company, came to a halt after workers put down their tools to press for higher pay. The company said about 15,000 union members held a rally and then walked out, idling assembly plants in the southeastern city of Ulsan.

title: Vallen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split to be paid Jan. 17.

title: Company News; Beacon to Acquire Coleman Division
description: Beacon International Ltd. of Toronto has agreed to buy the heating and air-conditioning division of the Coleman Company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The transaction is scheduled to be completed in early 1990. Beacon International is a subsidiary of the Beacon Capital Corporation.

title: Israel Must Also Win Trust of the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified a shop that has introduced a line of frozen hors d'oeuvres. It is Dufour Pastry Kitchens, at 808

title: Company News; Deal With I.B.M. By U.S. Memories
description: U.S. Memories Inc., the cooperative venture to manufacture computer memory chips, has agreed to license the technology it needs for its first product from the International Business Machines Corporation, the two companies said yesterday. The agreement, which was expected, will give U.S. Memories the manufacturing process and design for a dynamic random access memory chip capable of storing four million bits of information, or four megabits.

title: Utah Hires McBride
description: Ron McBride, a 50-year-old coaching veteran, was appointed head coach at the University of Utah yesterday, replacing Jim Fassel, who was dismissed last month after a 4-8 season. McBride joined Utah from Arizona, where he was an offensive-line coach the last two years. McBride has been an assistant coach 26 years, including stints at Utah in 1977-82 and 1985-86.(AP)

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Rebirth Brass Band

title: Poland's Brave New Economics
description: The muscular economic package announced this week by Poland's Finance Minister is designed to stamp out rampant inflation. It may, instead, stamp out the Solidarity-led Government. The plan boldly seeks to create a market economy nearly overnight. But along the way, prices will temporarily soar and hundreds of thousands of Polish workers may lose their current jobs.

title: Fines for 10 Cowboys
description: The Cowboys announced today that 10 Dallas players and 7 from the Philadelphia Eagles had been fined by the National Football League for fighting in a Thanksgiving Day game. The fight sparked accusations that Coach Buddy Ryan of the Eagles had put bounties on some Cowboy players.

title: Intelligent Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Shifts at Corning Paper
description: The Corning Leader will become a morning newspaper and begin publication of a Sunday issue in March 1990, its publisher, Neil C. Hopp, said this week. The first morning issue is scheduled for March 5, followed by publication of the first Sunday paper on March 11. The Leader, owned by the California-based Howard Publications Group, has a circulation of 17,000.

title: Company News; Caterpillar's Stock Declines
description: Caterpillar Inc.'s stock fell sharply today after the heavy-equipment maker lowered its outlook for the fourth quarter, blaming sluggish economic growth for depressing its sales, especially in the construction industry.

title: Woman on Death Row: Case of Pretoria Justice
description: Evelina de Bruin sits in her solitary cell waiting for the executioner and weeping for her children.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Press; Editors Say Journalists Were Kept From Action
description: Some news executives criticized the Pentagon yesterday for keeping a 16-person pool of journalists away from the fighting during the first 24 hours of the invasion of Panama.

title: KCS Group reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,472,000, or $4.71 a share. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,374,000. Share earnings reflects retroactive effect of stock splits on Nov. 3, 1989. The company said the sale of KCS Group's propane business for $27.1 million in September resulted in an $8 million gain.

title: Fighting in Panama: Hostages; At Least One American Is Being Held
description: At least one American, and possibly several more, are being held hostage in Panama by gunmen loyal to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but no demands for ransom have been put forward yet by the Panamanian captors, Administration officials said today.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Love and Death in a Wilderness
description: There is a wonderful Steven Spielberg film about love and hope and sacrifice, a film in which the miraculous and the ordinary go hand in hand. It's the story of a flier who dies, the woman he loves, and the magical way in which fate gives them a second chance. It's ''A Guy Named Joe,'' and its spirit - feisty and adventurous, frankly sentimental, filled with wonder - shows up often in Mr. Spielberg's work. But Mr. Spielberg didn't direct this film; he only watched it. What he did direct is a remake, titled ''Always.''

title: Defense Lawyers Take Aim at Police Taping
description: Six weeks ago the Connecticut state police were sued for tape-recording telephone conversations between defendants and their lawyers. Now lawyers across the country are raising questions about confidentiality in their backyards.

title: Look Who's Talking
description: Atlanta Hawks Kevin Loughery, Mike Glenn. Boston Celtics: Bob Cousy, Tommy Heinsohn. Chicago Bulls: Johnny Kerr, Junior Bridgeman. Cleveland Cavaliers Jim Chones. Denver Nuggets: Dan Issel. Detroit Pistons: Dick Motta. Golden State Warriors: Jim Barnett. Houston Rockets Mike Newlin, Tom Nissalke. Indiana Pacers: Bob Leonard, Clark Kellogg. Los Angeles Clippers Kevin Loughery. Los Angeles Lakers Stu Lantz. Milwaukee Bucks Jon McGlocklin. Minnesota Timberwolves Len Elmore. New Jersey Nets Michael O'Koren, Jim Spanarkel. New York Knicks Walt Frazier. Orlando Magic: Jack Givens. Philadelphia 76ers: Steve Mix, Jack Ramsay. Phoenix Suns Dick Van Arsdale. Portland Trail Blazers Steve Jones, Geoff Petrie. Sacramento Kings Rich Kelley. Seattle SuperSonics Rick Barry. Utah Jazz: Hot Rod Hundley, Ron Boone. Washington Bullets Kevin Grevey, Phil Chenier.

title: Fighting in Panama: Panama City; PANAMA'S CAPITAL STILL NOT SECURED
description: Few areas in Panama City appeared totally secured by United States forces today as scattered fighting with paramilitary groups continued.

title: A vinyl sculpture by Betty Collings at the Bertha Urdang Gallery.Reviews/Art; Could It Be the 70's Again? An Artist Looks Back.
description: Betty Collings's new work is a kind of contradiction. Her colorful vinyl sculptures may convey a sense of deja vu - they hark back to Process Art of the early 1970's - and yet many of them hold their own in the present, as a further development of early 70's concerns and ideals.

title: Dvorak's Mass in D
description: Kyler Brown will conduct Dvorak's Mass in D, Poulenc's ''Hodie Christus Natus Est'' and Harold Darke's ''In the Bleak Midwinter'' at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street, on Christmas Eve at 10 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 869-5830.

title: Horizon Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $55,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $101,000, or 2 cents a share for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Company News; A.T.&T.'s Computer Contract
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had been awarded a Department of Transportation computer contract for the purchase of as many as 40,000 work stations, powerful computers that will be used for office automation.

title: Dean Foods Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Ronald Pacchiana, 56, Construction Executive
description: Ronald D. Pacchiana, a construction executive in Westchester County, died last Friday in the crash of a twin-engine Piper Navajo near Cairo, N.Y. He was 56 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Testing for Lyme Disease Found to Vary Greatly
description: Results of blood tests for Lyme disease vary greatly among different laboratories and even within the same laboratory, a new study shows.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Topps Makes A Move Into Magazines
description: YOU can't flip it. Nor is it packaged with a brittle stick of stale bubble gum. But the Topps Company is betting that American children will flock to it the way they have to the baseball cards the company has printed since 1951.

title: KEY RATES
Former Arby's Head Is Made Shoney's Chief
description: Shoney's Inc., a restaurant chain based in Nashville, yesterday named as its chairman and chief executive Leonard H. Roberts, who left this fall as head of Arby's Inc. restaurants after a dispute.

title: Pan Am Bombing Suspect Convicted in Other Attacks
description: A Palestinian suspected in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 was convicted today along with three co-defendants in a series of attacks in northern Europe four years ago.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''PINOCCHIO,'' a show by Bil Baird's Marionettes, 1 and 3:15 P.M. daily (no show Christmas Day), at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section. Tickets: $12. Information: 307-7171 or (718) 636-4100. ''ALADDIN,'' a play performed by the Royal Buckingham Theater Company, 8 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays, and 3 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, through Jan. 15, at the Nat Horne Theater, 440 West 42d Street. Tickets: children, under 12, $10; others, $15. Information: 279-4200. ''THE MOSCOW PUPPET THEATER,'' a program with 16 puppeteers, 7 P.M. today, 2 and 6 P.M. tomorrow, and noon and 4 P.M. on Sunday, at the Rapp Arts Center, 220 East Fourth Street. Tickets: $10. Information: 947-5850 or 529-6160. ''SILLY DANCING,'' a Seasame Street Muppets show, with Big Bird and Oscar the Grouch and their friends, with singing, dancing and audience participation, through Jan. 7, at the Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street. Tickets: $10, $11.50; group rates available. For hours and dates: 496-7070; for group rates: 563-8080. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE WIZARD,'' a play about a shy dragon who lives in Central Park and a sly wizard, written by Miranda McDermott, with child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. on Saturdays, at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations required: 734-5195. ''WILBUR, THE CHRISTMAS MOUSE,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, directed by Robert Stark, 1:30 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, and ''Santa Claus and the Magic Bell,'' 3 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: 765-9540.

title: Benching by Laryngitis
description: A severe case of laryngitis will force Texas-El Paso's head coach, Don Haskins, to stay away from his team for as long as two weeks.

title: Cavco Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Verdict of Manslaughter, Not Murder, in Bus Case
description: A 36-year-old chemical plant worker today was acquitted of the most serious charges against him but was convicted of manslaughter and virtually all the other counts he faced as a result of the nation's deadliest alcohol-related traffic accident.

title: Most Teen-Age Abortion Is Outside Consent Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Washington Talk; To Senator McCain, the Savings and Loan Affair Is Now a Personal Demon
description: John McCain's Senate colleagues have just begun to notice how troubled he seems. But his friends back home have been noticing the telltale signs for months.

title: LETTERS ARE FOCUS OF BOMBING INQUIRY
description: Federal investigators here said today that a flurry of threatening letters in recent days included two that were sent to the same addresses where bombs were received.

title: Fighting in Panama: Overview; U.S. TROOPS PRESS THEIR HUNT FOR NORIEGA; LOOTING IS WIDESPREAD IN PANAMA'S CAPITAL
description: United States forces moved into central Panama City today to hunt Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and try to restore order as looters and bands of armed civilians defied a nighttime curfew.

title: Fighting in Panama: Implications; Noriega Must Be Captured, a New Leader Established in Power and Hostages Freed
description: More than 36 hours after the start of the United States thrust into Panama, at least three major problems remained unresolved today, none of them easy to deal with. Each problem has the potential to diminish the success, if not turn it into failure.

title: Upheaval in the East; The Rumanian Turmoil Through Soviet Eyes: Chants and Sudden Violence
description: For the last six days Western journalists have not been allowed in Rumania, where anti-Government demonstrations have reportedly been met with force. Here are dispatches on the situation in Rumania yesterday from Bucharest correspondents for the Soviet press agency, Tass, which translated the reports. Crowd Chants 'Freedom'

title: Invention, Design, Engineerng Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Armitage Watkins, 83; Was a Literary Agent
description: Armitage Watkins, a literary agent who represented such authors as Pamela L. Travers, Roald Dahl, Peter DeVries, Glendon Swarthout, Alan Moorehead and Bill Mauldin, died of cancer on Sunday at a nursing home in Kings Park, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Company News; Head of Chase Retiring in 1991
description: Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, plans to retire during 1991, according to a memorandum distrubuted to officers of the bank earlier this week.

title: Company News; Kodak Completing Camera Payments
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is making its last payments to customers who bought its instant cameras but were unable to buy film for them because of a patent dispute between Kodak and the Polaroid Corporation. Kodak was forced to stop making and selling instant cameras and film in 1986 after a Federal judge ruled that it had infringed seven Polaroid patents.

title: Review/Film; 'Always,' Love and Death in a Wilderness
description: There is a wonderful Steven Spielberg film about love and hope and sacrifice, a film in which the miraculous and the ordinary go hand in hand. It's the story of a flier who dies, the woman he loves, and the magical way in which fate gives them a second chance. It's ''A Guy Named Joe,'' and its spirit - feisty and adventurous, frankly sentimental, filled with wonder - shows up often in Mr. Spielberg's work. But Mr. Spielberg didn't direct this film; he only watched it. What he did direct is a remake, titled ''Always.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: New Team at Aurora

title: New Orleans Official Denies Aiding Gambler
description: District Attorney Harry Connick, indicted Friday on charges that he conspired to help an arrested bookmaker continue a gambling operation, pleaded not guilty in a Federal court today.

title: U.S. Issues Mixed in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were very narrowly mixed in dull trading yesterday, as dealers effectively closed their books on 1989.

title: Finger-Pointing Won't Help Schools
description: By publishing a list of the 43 most academically troubled schools in New York State - 39 of them in New York City - the state Education Department incurred the wrath of Joseph Fernandez, the incoming New York City schools chancellor. He rightly asserts that official identification of failing schools only serves to demoralize them unless the state is prepared to offer substantive help.

title: Review/Film; Women Who Share A House And Secrets
description: Only viewers in a leisurely, playful frame of mind are invited into Jacques Rivette's films, in which theater rehearsal halls and fantasy worlds weave in and out of his characters' ''real'' lives. This quality has made Mr. Rivette the most determinedly noncommercial of the critics-turned-film makers who began the French New Wave 30 years ago. He is also the most long-winded. ''Celine and Julie Go Boating'' runs more than three hours, ''L'Amour Fou'' over four.

title: O'Brien Out For Surgery
description: Ken O'Brien has decided to undergo exploratory surgery on his right shoulder on Friday, and will miss the Jets' final game Saturday against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Savings Bailout Cost Seen Rising
description: Almost 500 more savings and loan associations than initially projected by the Bush Administration are likely to be taken over by the Government under the bailout legislation, according to numbers released today by the Office of Thrift Supervision. That is sure to mean that the ultimate cost of the rescue, which has been estimated at $159 billion over the next 10 years, will be considerably higher.

title: New England Electric reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and included an after-tax writedown of $179 million from rate settlement agreement.

title: INSIDE
description: More Savings Units Face Takeover by U.S. Almost 500 more savings institutions than initially projected will have to be taken over by the Government, a Federal report showed. The industry's losses were $3.8 billion in the third quarter, a near-record level. Page D1. Lyme Disease Tests Faulted Results of Lyme disease tests vary among laboratories, which could mean wrong diagnoses. Page A28. Poindexter Trial Delayed A judge said he would review Ronald Reagan's private papers before convening an Iran-contra trial. Page A23. Critical Genetic Finding Scientists have discovered a gene that they believe is crucial to the development of the human immune system, which protects the body against disease. Page A28.

title: Panama for the Panamanians
description: The second-guessing began immediately, inevitably. Why did President Bush decide to strike now against the Panamanian dictator, Manuel Noriega? Why so massively? Did he recognize the costs in terms of casualties, hostages and U.S. standing in Latin America and elsewhere?

title: Auctions
description: A Rocker's Images

title: Former N.B.A. Names On, Not In, the Air
description: Ever wonder what became of such former National Basketball Association players and coaches as Jim Chones, Jack Givens, Rich Kelley, Junior Bridgeman, Jan McGlocklin, Mike Glenn, Ron Boone, Hot Rod Hundley, Jim Barnett, Jim Spanarkel, Clark Kellogg, Johnny Kerr and Tom Nissalke?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Fighting in Panama; Pentagon List Of U.S. Dead
description: The Pentagon has been releasing the names of servicemen killed in the Panamanian invasion as their next of kin are notified. Here are the names released so far: BROWN, Pfc. Roy Dennis Jr., an infantryman, of Buena Park, Calif. CONNORS, Lieut. (j.g.) John Patrick, a member of the Navy's special operations unit known as the SEALS, and a native of Arlington, Mass. DAVES, Pfc. Jerry Scott, a member of the 1st Battalion, 504th Parachute Infantry Regiment and a native of Hope Mills, N.C. ISAAK, Cpl. Garreth C., a Marine, and a native of Greenville, S.C. LEAR, Specialist Phillip S. an infantryman, of Westminster, S.C. MANRIQUELOZANO, Specialist Alejandro I., of Lauderhill, Fla. MARKWELL, Pfc. James William, a medic, of Cincinnati, Ohio. McFAUL, Chief Engineman Donald Lewis, a SEAL, of San Diego, Calif. PEREZ, Cpl. Ivan D., an infantryman, of Pawtucket, R.I. PRICE, Pfc. John Mark, an infantryman, of Conover, Wis. RODRIGUEZ, Torpedoman's mate Second Class Issac George, a SEAL, of Missouri City, Texas. ROTH, Pfc. Scott Lee, a military policeman, of Killeen, Texas. SCOTT, Pvt. Kenneth Douglas, an infantryman of Princeton, W. Va. TILGHMAN, Boatswain's Mate 1st Class Christopher, a SEAL, of Kailua, Hawaii.

title: One Kansas City Paper
description: The merger of The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times will take place on March 1, the editor of the newspapers said today. Plans to merge the morning Times and the afternoon Star were announced on Oct. 5. Joe McGuff, editor and vice president, said the decision came about because of sagging demand for afternoon papers and changing life styles. The newspaper, to be called The Kansas City Star, will publish in the morning.

title: Allegheny International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included charges for restructuring and product write off costs of $21.1 million and $23.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included charges for restructuring and product write off costs of $9.3 million for the quarter and $11.3 million for the year.

title: Islands of Calm Amid the Urban Bustle
description: With the frigid professionalism of a dip picking pockets on a 42d Street bus, Jack Frost has been neatly working the midtown holiday throngs, stinging ears, freezing feet, snatching breaths and causing weary shoppers and tourists to look inward - not to the higher thoughts prompted by the season, but to places of refuge from the rigors of the street.

title: If Giants Top Raiders, Benefits Will Mount
description: The rewards for the Giants are big: if they beat the Los Angeles Raiders here Sunday they will achieve these things:

title: ACDS Graphic Systems reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $217,904, or 3 cents a share. c-Net loss Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Fighting in Panama: Noriega; Attempt at Prosecution Would Face Obstacles
description: The Government's case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is fraught with legal obstacles stemming from his past associations with United States intelligence operatives and President Bush.

title: Gamecocks Coach Signs
description: Ten months after being hired, South Carolina's football coach, Sparky Woods, signed a five-year contract yesterday that will pay him $95,000 a year and includes provisions regarding graduation rates and drug testing.

title: A Neglected Name on the Hall Ballot
description: rrThe 1990 Baseball Hall of Fame ballot is before me and must be mailed soon. Forty-four players are on it - a voter can mark up to 10 choices -and two, both new on the ballot, will almost certainly and properly be elected. They are Jim Palmer, the tall, elegantly effective pitcher, and Joe Morgan, built, as Russell Baker once wrote about someone else, like an ambulatory fireplug, but he played like a dream.

title: Business Seen Raising Outlays at Slower Rate
description: The nation's businesses plan to increase capital spending 4.9 percent in 1990, compared with an 8.5 percent increase this year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Mistrial Is Declared in Capital Crack Case
description: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today after jurors failed to reach a verdict in the case of a teen-ager accused of selling the crack that President Bush used as a prop in a nationally televised address in September.

title: 5 People Die in a New Jersey Fire
description: Five people died in a house fire early today, and firefighters searched through debris for at least one more person, an East Orange fire official said.

title: Compositions by Marlo
description: Marlo, a composer who goes by only one name, will give a concert of her recent piano works and chamber pieces at Up Front Muse, 190-A Duane Street, tomorrow evening at 8:30. The performers include members of two ensembles, Hot Kitty and Evolution. Tickets are $5. Information: 334-9847.

title: Sears to Borrow $800 Million For an Employee Stock Plan
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would borrow $800 million to finance an employee stock ownership plan that would raise its workers' stake in the company to 21 percent from 15 percent.

title: A New Challenge for an Old Hand; Jack Krumpe Tries to Help the Islanders Win Back Fans
description: His office is a living room on Long Island, tucked deep inside the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, with the emblem of the New York Islanders imprinted on the carpet and a lack of bustle in the air. No hard hats are needed. No empire is being constructed.

title: N.B.A. Sues Over Lottery
description: The National Basketball Association filed a lawsuit today attempting to stop the Oregon Lottery from including professional basketball in its Sports Action betting game.

title: William Hunt's Bankruptcy Plan Cleared
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge here today formally approved a reorganization plan for William Herbert Hunt, whose fortune collapsed after a failed attempt to corner the silver market 10 years ago.

title: Gentry Crowell, 57; Top Tennessee Aide
description: Gentry Crowell, Tennessee's Secretary of State, whose office has been at the center of a bingo and political corruption scandal, died at the Vanderbilt University Medical Center on Wednesday, eight days after shooting himself in the head in a suicide attempt at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: U.S. Deficit Up in November
description: The Federal budget deficit increased $28.96 billion in November, raising the imbalance in the first two months of the fiscal year to more than half the legislative ceiling for the entire year, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Roy Bennett, 77, Dies; Adviser to 3 Presidents
description: Roy Bennett, an adviser to three Presidents on economics and foreign policy, died of a heart attack Wednesday at New York Hospital, where he was recovering from surgery. He was 77 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: School Board Drops R.O.T.C. At King High in Manhattan
description: Plans to begin an R.O.T.C. program at the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Manhattan have been withdrawn in response to pressure from students, teachers, politicians and Dr. King's widow, who said a military program had no place in a school named in honor of the civil rights leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner.

title: Review/Art; Otherworldly Sculptures Of the Unsung Turku Trajan
description: To see the 11 sculptures by Turku Trajan that are now at the Zabriskie Gallery is to be entranced and perplexed, for Trajan's legacy remains one of the genuine curiosities of 20th-century American art.

title: Key Gene in Immune Defenses Is Believed Found
description: Scientists have discovered a gene that they believe is crucial in the development of the human immune defenses, possibly a central genetic switch for the process by which the body generates a wide array of protective antibodies.

title: Dresdner Bank Plan
description: Dresdner Bank, West Germany's second-largest commercial bank, announced plans Tuesday to open an office in Dresden, the East German city where the bank was founded in 1872. Although its management was shifted to Berlin in 1884, Dresden remained the bank's legal headquarters until 1950. The headquarters have been in Frankfurt since 1957.

title: On Stage
description: 'Oh, Kay!' Hits the Road

title: Family Leave Bill Is Approved and Sent to Kean
description: The New Jersey Senate gave final passage today to a bill that would require employers to give their employees up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to deal with family crises.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-20 U.S. forces in central Panama City hunted for General Noriega and tried to restore order as looters and bands of armed civilians defied a nighttime curfew. Few areas in the city appeared totally secured. Page A1 News analysis: The Panama affair still has at least three major problems unresolved: capturing General Noriega, getting the new Government up and running, and rescuing the hostages. A1 At least one American hostage and possibly more are being held by Panamanian gunmen loyal to General Noriega, but no demands for ransom have been put forward yet, Administration officials said. A17 Old military foe of Noriega is being flown to Panama A18 Prosecution of Noriega would face obstacles A19 Legislators express concern on the operation's future A20 U.S. finds little support at the U.N. for action in Panama A20 Other articles about the Panama crisis A16-20 Rumanian forces battled protesters in the streets of Bucharest as anti-Communist demonstrations spread to the country's capital, Western diplomats there said. A1 The Czechoslovak Communist Party voted to suspend the memberships of 32 former leaders and expel a former party ideologist whom it accused of instigating the Soviet-led invasion of the country in 1968. A12 The Lithuanian Communists' break with the Moscow leadership raised ''concern and alarm,'' President Gorbachev said. He also indicated that an emergency meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee would be held to discuss the issue. A12 Reporter's notebook: Little cheer left in Soviet Congress A12 Group keeps religion alive to Soviet Jews A11 U.S. is giving priority to building new Moscow embassy A10 Mitterrand warns against a rush to German unity A12 Workers are few in Poland's Communist Party A14 A plan to review corporate mergers was adopted by the European Community. The move ended 16 years of debate in which member nations had balked at ceding their antitrust authority. D1 Japan's trade surpluses are being whittled down by an unlikely source: 10 million Japanese tourists with a passion for overseas travel. A1 A suspect in the jetliner bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 last year was convicted in Sweden for a series of attacks in northern Europe four years ago, along with three co-defendants. A3 Israel to seize property of young stone-throwers' parents A3 India's new chief given go-ahead A5 Woman on death row: case of Pretoria justice A8 More Zaire AIDS cases show less underreporting A9 National A22-28, B6 Winter arrived with an arctic force that shut hundreds of schools in the North, threatened citrus crops in the South, and exposed armies of the homeless to danger. A1 The cost of the savings bailout is likely to be considerably higher than expected as Government figures show that many more savings associations will need to be taken over than was initially projected. D1 Washington at Work: John McCain, a Republican Senator from Arizona, is struggling against a personal demon - his role in the savings and loan affair and ties to Charles Keating, chairman of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. A24 Durenberger says he broke no rules A25 U.S. alters plan for offsetting excess Medicare charges A23 Oakland battles U.S. to be a nuclear-free zone B6 A Kentuckian was acquitted of the most serious charges against him but was convicted of manslaughter and most of the other counts he faced as a result of the nation's deadliest alcohol-related traffic accident. A22 Scientists have discovered a gene that they believe is crucial in the development of the human immune defenses, possibly a central genetic switch by which the body generates an array of antibodies.
