A28 Blood test results for Lyme disease vary greatly, a new study shows. Experts said the the variation in testing could lead to wrong diagnoses and subject patients to expensive, unnecessary and potentially hazardous treatment. A28 Ex-police aide held on fraud charges in Detroit A25 Man awaiting execution is ordered acquitted in '79 killing A26 Links to two bombs found in letters A28 Regional B1-5 New York City's budget deficit could grow to $1.8 billion, and Mayor-elect Dinkins will have to propose a solution on Feb. 1. Plans to expand services are expected to be scaled back. B1 An indictment of a State Senator, Manfred Ohrenstein, was upheld by a State Appeals Court. But the ruling dismissed many counts at the heart of the prosecution's case. B1 The new Police Commissioner of New York City, Lee Brown, paid homage to what he called a ''premier'' department and repeatedly declined to discuss plans for change during his first official visit to the city. B3 A transitional housing complex for the homeless opened in Westchester, while New Jersey families began moving into that state's first such project. B5 Westchester County passes $1 billion budget with cuts B5 Cuomo's ex-drug chief is rehired, or is he? B1 New Jersey family leave bill is approved and sent to Kean B1 A party for children of America's foreign-policy elite B4 Five people die in house fire in East Orange, N.J. B3 Helmsley rejects plea in state court B3 R.O.T.C. dropped from King High in Manhattan B3 Neediest Cases B5

title: Ouster Set At Centrust
description: Florida state officials took action Wednesday to oust the head of Florida's largest savings and loan association, contending he used $45 million in depositors' money to bankroll an art collection and extravagant standard of living.

title: Review/Jazz; Caught Between 2 Worlds
description: The much touted trumpeter Byron Stripling, who played at Birdland on Wednesday night, is stuck between two worlds. Until recently the lead trumpeter for the Count Basie Orchestra, Mr. Stripling is also a Louis Armstrong impersonator.

title: Humana Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included income of $9,598,000 from a favorable court ruling and a loss of $8,557,000 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Frigid First Day of Winter Spreads Deaths and Records Across U.S.
description: Winter arrived yesterday with an arctic onslaught that shut hundreds of schools in the North, threatened citrus crops in the South and exposed armies of the homeless to danger.

title: At the Movies
description: Broderick on 'Glory'

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds increased by $208.20 million, to $367.11 billion, in the week ended last Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $378.50 million, to $87.82 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were up by $831.10 million, to $120.51 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds decreased by $244.40 million, to $158.78 billion, the institute said.

title: Buyers Sought for Historic Houses
description: Two vacant, deteriorating houses of historic significance in Collis P. Huntington State Park in Redding, Conn., are facing demolition because the state sees no reason to preserve them, but they may yet get a reprieve.

title: Dinkins Faces Tall Budget Deficit and Short Deadline
description: A little more than four weeks after he takes office, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins is required to present a plan to resolve what seems likely to be the biggest problem of his first year and one that might help shape an entire term: a New York City budget deficit that has been estimated at $395 million and that could grow to as much as $1.8 billion.

title: Deposits Increase At Unit Trusts
description: The Investment Company Institute, a national association of investment companies, reported yesterday that unit investment trusts increased their deposits by $569.2 million in November to $8.96 billion in 1989.

title: Felled Player Mending
description: Hank Gathers of Loyola Marymount, who collapsed during a game Dec. 9, will miss the Lions' game tomorrow against Oklahoma, even though tests have shown him to be in good physical condition. The school said yesterday that doctors had urged a waiting period of five to seven days. Gathers was the country's leader in scoring and rebounding last season.(AP)

title: Scanning the City From a Kitchen: Pedestrian View
description: When Judy Wadia and her husband, Pheroze, bought a home in Weehawken six years ago and built a soaring studio for her in back, a major reason was the stunning view of the Hudson River and the New York skyline stretching from the George Washington Bridge in the north to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in the south.

title: H E R O Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $26,639. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Toshiko Akiyoshi

title: Democracy in Taiwan
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East: Reporter's Notebook; Little Cheer Left in Soviet Congress
description: There may be no better forum for studying Mikhail S. Gorbachev than amid a few hours ennui in the hope-burdened, promise-ridden Congress of People's Deputies, where the legislators have just been ordered into weekend overtime to labor like makework elves under the oratorical lash of the ultimate red Santa.

title: Richardson Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $1.5 million pretax charge associated with restructuring of manufacturing lines for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Cold Comfort
description: Here, for the first full day of winter, is a list of cold-comfort thoughts.

title: The U.N.Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M.

title: Cold Comfort, Indeed
description: ''The life of the journalist is poor, nasty, brutish and short. So is his style. You, who are so adept at the lovely polishing of every grave and lucent phrase, will realise the magnitude of the task which confronted me when I found, after spending ten years as a journalist, learning to say exactly what I meant in short sentences, that I must learn, if I was to achieve literature and favourable reviews, to write as though I were not quite sure about what I meant but was jolly well going to say something all the same in sentences as long as possible.''

title: Skippers and Clubs Back Effort To Strip San Diego Club of Cup
description: Eight former America's Cup skippers and several yacht clubs have asked the New York State Court of Appeals to disqualify the San Diego Yacht Club from the 1988 America's Cup series, which it won, and return the cup trophy to New Zealand.

title: Company News; G.M. Sets Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would place 1,600 workers on indefinite layoff in February at its plant in Linden, N.J., where it makes Chevrolet Corsicas and Berettas. G.M. said the second shift at the plant would be eliminated on Feb. 26. Corsica and Beretta cars also are made in Wilmington, Del. A United Auto Workers shop chairman, Guy Messina, said rumors of layoffs had been circulating at the plant all week.

title: Commercial Metals reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. Donor Provides Israeli Immigrant Fund
description: Natan Sharansky, the former Soviet Jewish dissident now living in Israel, announced today that a private $20 million fund to provide housing for Soviet Jewish immigrants has been created with a single donation from an American businessman.

title: Catalina Lighting reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Upheaval in the East; WORKERS ARE FEW IN POLAND PARTY
description: Poland's Communist Party is losing touch with the workers, its leaders said today.

title: From Paul Newman's Own Company, $250,000 for Neediest
description: Paul Newman this week donated one of the largest gifts ever received by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund - $200,000 - then promptly decided it was not enough, and so pledged another $50,000.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Jews on the Supreme Court: Were they different and why are there none now?
description: No Jew has sat on the United States Supreme Court since 1969, when Abe Fortas resigned. It is an odd phenomenon, given the prominence of Jewish lawyers in the United States. In that period, Jews have led the American Bar Association, dozens of major law firms and virtually every major American law school.

title: The End Of a Fool
description: In the end the man turned out to be a fool, just a fool like so many of his kind.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Brother Nicholas Evokes Astaire
description: Harold Nicholas's tribute to Fred Astaire, which opened on Tuesday at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, is not, as such tributes often are, an attempt to emulate a bygone performer. Mr. Nicholas, who starred with his brother, Fayard, as the Nicholas Brothers in nightclubs and movies in the 1930's, 40's and 50's, is an established singer and dancer in his own right.

title: Israel Must Also Win Trust of the Palestinians; One-Sided Criticism
description: To the Editor:

title: Misanthropartyites
description: LEAD: Why all this angst during the holiday season?

title: Dodgers Sign Brooks for $6 Million
description: Following up their three-player trade with the Mets, the Los Angeles Dodgers signed Hubie Brooks, a free agent, to a three-year, $6 million contract yesterday. The question is will the Mets follow up the deal by making another one for a center fielder?

title: 'No Deal Neil' Steering Rangers Toward Trading for Some Help
description: Earlier this month, Neil Smith, the Rangers' general manager, turned to a friend and colleague and confessed to being confounded by his job. ''It changes every week, every day, from what I thought it would be,'' Smith said.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bulgarian Communist Youth Choose 26-Year-Old Leader
description: The Communist youth movement dismissed its leadership today and chose a new chief. Those ousted included the granddaughter of the disgraced former party leader Todor Zhivkov.

title: Review/Dance; 'Sarong Paramaribo,' a Trip Through Time and Cultures
description: ''Sarong Paramaribo,'' the latest novelty for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is very much that -an unusual pastiche of Balinese dancing and show business by Lester Horton that had its company premiere at the City Center (131 West 55th Street) Wednesday night.

title: Penn State Asked to Quit
description: Penn State has been sent a letter by Atlantic 10 officials suggesting the school leave the conference by June 30, The Pittsburgh Press reported today.

title: Univar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected as a 100 percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 4.

title: Fighting in Panama: The United Nations; U.S. Finding Scant Support for Action in Panama
description: The United States appeared in serious difficulty today as it struggled to win international backing for its assault of Panama and for the newly installed Government of President Guillermo Endara against mounting third world and Soviet criticism of President Bush's action.

title: Company News; Drug Is Priced By SmithKline
description: The SmithKline Beecham Corporation said today that it would sell Eminase, a new drug for heart attack victims, at a price of $1,700 a treatment. The drug will be shipped shortly after the first of the year.

title: Article 978689 -- No Title
description: The Westchester County Legislature approved a 1990 budget of more than $1 billion tonight, after a bipartisan coalition forced cuts which reduced projected tax increases but which some county officials said would eliminate services and hundreds of jobs.

title: Upheaval in the East; Yugoslav Loan Plan Is Seen
description: Western creditors may lend Yugoslavia up to $4 billion in the next two years if it adopts Premier Ante Markovic's new market-oriented economic program, Yugoslav banking officials and news reports said today. The officials said the International Monetary Fund agreed to grant Yugoslavia an 18-month standby credit worth $600 million. The loan, once fully approved by the I.M.F. authorities, would be available from Jan. 1, 1990.

title: Jets Wrap Up With Little to Gain (Except a Loss)
description: LEAD: Willpower as much as talent could decide power as much as talent could decide the regular-season finale Saturday for the Jets against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Helmsley Rejects Plea Agreement in State Tax Case
description: Already sentenced to a four-year Federal prison term for income tax fraud, Leona Helmsley yesterday rejected an offer to serve a concurrent state prison sentence in exchange for pleading guilty to charges of evading about $750,000 in New York State income taxes.

title: In Defense of (Listen to This) Joke Tellers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Agency Warns of Danger To Children in a Toy Rabbit
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that a stuffed animal toy sold to nearly two million people might present a hidden danger of suffocation to small children.

title: Fighting in Panama: Strategy; Old Military Foe of Noriega Is Being Flown to Panama
description: Pentagon officials said today that Eduardo Herrera Hassan, a former colonel in the Panamanian army, was being flown to Panama by the United States at the request of Panama's new President, Guillermo Endara.

title: No Jubilation, Please
description: Those of us who fundamentally oppose U.S. interventions in other nations, particularly in this hemisphere, do not have a clear case against the invasion of Panama. But neither are President Bush's arguments conclusive; and numerous doubts remain to be resolved.

title: Australia Seabed Project
description: The Government announced Wednesday that it would open up Australia's continental shelf to mineral exploration. The exploration area will be extended to 200 nautical miles from the Australian coast, from the current three-mile limit, the Resources Minister, Peter Cook, said in a statement. ''The Australian seabed is largely unexplored but it is believed to contain many minerals, including diamonds and heavy mineral sands,'' he said.

title: Hilton in for Barkley
description: Matthew Hilton will replace Iran Barkley as the challenger in the Jan. 15 bout in Atlantic City with Doug DeWitt for the World Boxing Organization middleweight title. Barkley, the No. 3 contender, had laser surgery for a detached retina earlier this week.

title: Texas Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,407,000 for the quarter and $2,807,000 for the 6 months. The company said year-ago results are restated to consolidate all subsidiaries.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks 117, Heat 115: Doc Rivers stole the ball from Grant Long and hit two free throws with seven-tenths of a second left last night in Miami as Atlanta withstood a fourth-quarter rally by the Heat. After a free throw by Dominique Wilkins put Atlanta ahead, 115-113, with 8.7 seconds left, Long took an inbound pass and drove to the basket. Rivers slapped the ball away and dribbled into the frontcourt, where he was fouled by Sherman Douglas. Rivers hit both free throws, giving the Hawks enough of a lead to survive Glenn Rice's basket at the buzzer. (AP) SuperSonics 123, Trail Blazers 102: Derrick McKey scored 13 of his 22 points in the third quarter and keyed a 14-0 run when Seattle took command and beat visiting Portland. McKey scored 9 points in the burst as Seattle stretched a 9-point lead into an 89-66 cushion. Dale Ellis got 11 of his 23 points as the Sonics outscored Portland, 35-21, and opened a 93-72 lead after three quarters. Clyde Drexler led the Trail Blazers with 25 points.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 4, North Stars 2: Dave Christian and Bobby Carpenter scored third-period goals last night as Boston ended its longest home losing streak in three years. Reggie Lemelin made 30 saves as the Bruins won for the first time in the last five games at Boston Garden. (AP) Penguins 5, Capitals 2: In Pittsburgh, Mario Lemieux extended his league-leading scoring streak to 23 games with a goal and two assists in a game interrupted by an injury to Dave Newell, the National Hockey League's senior refereee. Newell left the game with a separated right shoulder suffered with 3:21 left in the first period and John Ashley, N.H.L. officials supervisor, suspended the game at that point. After an early intermission, the game was resumed with Dan Schachte, the linesman, taking over Newell's duties.(AP) Oilers 3, Jets 2: Glenn Anderson scored two goals as Edmonton beat visiting Winnipeg. Peter Klima also scored for Edmonton, which has lost only once in its last 13 games. Brent Ashton and Thomas Steen scored for the Jets.(AP) Kings 6, Nordiques 1: Mario Gosselin stopped 30 shots by his former Quebec teammates and John Tonelli had a goal and two assists as Los Angeles, playing in Inglewood, Calif., extended Quebec's streak withouth a victory to 12 games.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Duke 89, Davidson 44: Phil Henderson led a balanced attack with 14 points as Duke took command early and raced to the victory in Davidson, N.C. Duke (4-2) dominated defensively, forcing 28 turnovers and limiting the Wildcats (1-5) to 18-for-61 shooting.(AP) North Carolina State 110, North Carolina-Asheville 70: Rodney Monroe made 9 of 14 shots from 3-point range and scored 31 points to lead North Carolina State (7-2) in Raleigh, N.C. North Carolina-Asheville fell to 5-3.(AP) Wake Forest 67, Alabama 65: Anthony Tucker made two free throws with 29 seconds to play to secure the victory for Wake Forest (6-1) in Winston-Salem, N.C. Tucker and Chris King combined for 26 second-half points and the Deamon Deacons held off a late charge by Alabama (7-2).(AP) Providence 85, Boston College 66: Quinton Burton had 14 points to lead six Providence teammates in double figures as the Friars won the Big East opener for both teams in Providence. The Friars, 5-2 over all, never trailed in the game and were helped in the first half by 16 Eagle turnovers. Boston College dropped to 5-3. (AP) Hofstra 57, Florida Southern 54: Derrick Flowers scored a basket and two free throws in the final 31 seconds, finishing with 21 points, as Hofstra overtook previously unbeaten Florida Southern, 57-54, in Hempstead, L.I. Flowers connected on a jump shot with 31 seconds to go, giving the Flying Dutchmen (3-5) a 55-54 lead. He then added two free throws with two seconds left after Derek Flowers of the Moccasins (7-1) missed the front end of a one-and-one two seconds earlier. Matt Tucker and Frank Walker each added 13.(AP) La Salle 71, Villanova 70: In Philadelphia, Doug Overton scored 19 points and Randy Woods scored 5 points in the last 53 seconds as unbeaten La Salle defeated Villanova (6-4). Lionel Simmons added 15 points and nine rebounds for La Salle (5-0), which leads the 55-year-old series, 22-21.(AP) HORSE RACING Aqueduct Closed Today: Today's racing card at Aqueduct was called off yesterday because of a forecast for extremely cold weather. ''We are optimistic that there will be racing Saturday and Sunday,'' Gerard J. McKeon, president of the New York Racing Association, said. In the feature race yesterday, Lost in Flight put on a strong finish and scored a 1 1/2-length victory. Lost in Flight, ridden by Mike Smith, posted her second victory in 12 starts this year and returned $12.20, $6.20 and $4.60 for $2 across the board.(AP)

title: Heir of a Hit Song Named
description: ''Why Do Fools Fall in Love?''

title: Pop/Jazz; Two Groups Recapture The Sounds Of the 50's
description: One of the lessons that 1980's pop culture has taught is that nothing really disappears. So enormous is the nostalgic appetite for the moods and attitudes of the past that sooner or later even the most despised pop kitsch becomes ripe for resurrection As recently as a decade ago, a revue devoted to the insipid American pop of the Mitch Miller era would probably not have found an audience. Rock-and-roll, though heading into middle age at that time, still reigned supreme. But to a younger pop audience that has grown up in the more conservative, conformist 80's, the wholesome pop iconography of the 50's doesn't seem so remote. That may explain why youthful crowds are flocking to two amusing cabaret revues, both of which celebrate music that rock-and-roll was supposed to have eradicated forever.

title: Topeka Journal; Historic Battleground, Old Battle: School Bias
description: As Linda Brown recalls it, her father, the Rev. Oliver Brown, was troubled that his 5-year-old daughter had to attend a distant, all-black school, passing a good, all-white school in her neighborhood.

title: Police Dept. Is Praised By Next Commissioner
description: Stepping nimbly through a mine field of questions, New York City's new Police Commissioner paid homage yesterday to what he called a ''premier'' department and in his first official visit to the city repeatedly declined to be drawn into his plans for change.

title: Campbell Heirs Take a Stand
description: The three children of John Dorrance Jr., the late patriarch of the Campbell Soup Company, said today that they were committed to keeping the company independent. The company's stock heated up on more buyout rumors.

title: Dining Out Guide: Near Downtown Theaters
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Indochine ** (Nov. 25, 1988), 430 Lafayette Street (505-5111) - This still-trendy, somewhat noisy restaurant across from the Public Theater serves a vivid mix of Vietnamese and Cambodian cuisines. One of the best starters here is sweet and sour shrimp soup, generous with perfectly cooked shrimp and flavored with pineapple and tamarind. Vegetable spring rolls with crab are another bright appetizer. The gray sole fillet steamed in banana leaves with lemon grass and coconut milk is worth seeking out for a main course, as are deep-fried chicken wings stuffed with vermicelli, vegetables and diced chicken. Appetizers are $5.50 to $11.50; entrees, $10.50 to $16.50. Dinner from 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. daily. John Clancy's ** (March 11, 1988), 181 West 10th Street (242-7350) - Among reasons to recommend this handsome all-seafood restaurant are the chef's talent at mesquite grilling and the congenial, very professional staff. Always included in the eight or so daily entree specials is a fish served whole on the bone, a preparation that enhances flavor and texture. The entrees might be grilled whole red snapper or whole sea bass with cilantro. Another winner is the halibut steak in sesame sauce. Portions are large here, so diners may want to opt for a light appetizer, like oysters on the half shell. John Clancy's is one of the few restaurants in New York that serves authentic English trifle, a rich composition of sherry-soaked genoise, raspberry puree, creme anglaise and whipped cream. Appetizers are $4.50 to $11, entrees $16 to $30.50. Open from 5:30 to 11 P.M. Monday to Saturday, 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. K-Paul's New York * (Nov. 17, 1989), 622 Broadway, south of Bleecker Street (460-9633) -The Cajun cooking virtuoso Paul Prudhomme serves his Louisiana specialties in a spacious downtown location five nights a week. The room is dominated by a glassed-in kitchen as long as a bowling alley. When Mr. Prudhomme is not in attendance there, the food can lose something. Dinners begin with a basket of irresistible breads like cheddar-jalapeno rolls. The signature appetizer is Cajun popcorn (fried puffs of battered crayfish); another good choice is the seafood gumbo. Main courses to recommend include swordfish with hot fanny sauce, blackened prime rib of beef, and blackened tuna steak. Appetizers are $6 to $10, main courses $18 to $28. Dinner served 5:30 to 11 P.M., Monday to Friday only. La Metairie * (Nov. 23, 1984), 189 West 10th Street (989-0343) - The downtown branch of La Metairie is one of the city's most diminutive restaurants, having just 16 seats. With its lace-curtained windows, candlelight and caged doves, it is also one of the more romantic places to dine near West Village theaters. Two appetizers on the current menu are fresh cured salmon with anise served over cucumber and frisee, and mushroom ravioli made with chanterelles and morels. For main courses, there are roasted monkfish sliced over melted leeks and ginger, and breast of duck with green-apple demiglace. For dessert there is a nicely glazed tarte Tatin. Appetizers are $7 to $18, entrees $18 to $26. Open 6 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday. What the stars mean, page C30.

title: Company News; Nynex to Take $45 Million Charge
description: The Nynex Corporation said it expected to take an estimated $45 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings because of changes in its management pension plan that take effect on Jan. 1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Avenue Names Editor
description: Susan Mulcahy has been named the editor in chief of Avenue magazine, replacing Joan Kron, who said she would resign last week. Ms. Mulcahy, a former columnist for The New York Post and for New York Newsday, will continue as editor in chief of On The Avenue, Avenue's sister publication. Ms. Mulcahy was featured in the recent advertisements for the Gap clothing stores.

title: European Antitrust Agreement
description: After a 16-year struggle, European Community ministers adopted a far-reaching plan today to give the community powers to review corporate mergers. They unanimously adopted a compromise plan after a bitter tug-of-war in which Britain's and West Germany's powerful antitrust bodies fought against ceding any of their powers to the bureaucracy in Brussels.

title: Donnelley to Buy Meredith/Burda
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, the world's largest commercial printer, said it had agreed to buy the Meredith/Burda Company, the big printing company, for $570 million. Donnelley, which prints many national publications - Time, Newsweek, Business Week and TV Guide, among others - said the deal is expected to close early next year.

title: Oiler Aide to Toledo
description: Nick Saban, an assistant coach with the Houston Oilers, is taking over as head football coach at Toledo, the university announced yesterday. Saban, 38 years old, was previously an assistant with six college teams, including Ohio State, Michigan State and Syracuse. ''A lot of people want to know why I want to come back to college football,'' Saban said. ''I think college football is a lot more fun.''

title: New York Loses Case on Protests Over A-Wastes
description: The state today lost its request for a court order against protesters who kept officials from two potential sites for radioactive waste in Allegany County.

title: Coach Hunt Must Wait
description: The University of Pittsburgh, which plays Texas A&M in the John Hancock Bowl next Saturday, has put on hold its search for a new coach to replace Mike Gottfried.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Overview; CEAUSESCU FLEES A REVOLT IN RUMANIA BUT DIVIDED SECURITY FORCES FIGHT ON
description: After ruling Rumania as a dictator for a quarter of a century, President Nicolae Ceausescu was forced to flee Bucharest Friday when angry crowds of anti-Government demonstrators, backed by army units, took over large sections of the capital.

title: Brooklyn Man Faces Charge In Killing of Abused Baby
description: Housing Authority detectives yesterday charged a 20-year-old Brooklyn man in the death of a 13-month-old girl who they said was stomped to death because she would not stop crying. She had been the victim of repeated sexual abuse, they said.

title: In Panama, the Worst Is Yet to Come
description: LEAD: The atmosphere in Washington following the invasion of Panama has been one of self-congratulation and relief at being rid of a major embarrassment and danger to U.S. personnel. After the euphoria subsides, though, the Administration will face a set of tough problems that are now only dimly perceived.

title: Letter: On the Pilgrims; The Indians at Plimoth Plantation
description: To the Editor:

title: Pronouncing The Names
description: SILVIU BRUCAN, an opposition leader: SEEL-vyoo broo-KAHN

title: Atlanta in Contrast: Civil Rights and Racial Hate
description: Atlanta likes to call itself the home of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the civil rights movement, but the area surrounding it is home to some of the most prominent white supremacists in the nation.

title: INSIDE
description: 6 Senators Face an Inquiry For H.U.D. and Thrift Roles

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Citibank notified Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores that they could be in default on $2.34 billion in loans unless they comply with a reporting requirement within 10 days, the two Campeau Corporation subsidiaries said. [ Page 37. ] Merv Griffin sought bankruptcy protection for Resorts International, his troubled hotel and casino company. With some of Resorts' largest bondholders backing its debt-reduction plan, the company is seeking a short-term ''prepackaged'' bankruptcy. [ 37. ] Whitbread P.L.C., the British brewer, said it would sell its liquor division to Allied-Lyons P.L.C., a leading British liquor company, for the equivalent of $877 million. [ 39. ] Boeing plans to lay off about 1,200 workers in the first half of next year, mostly in Everett, Wash. [ 39. ] Eastern Airlines is cutting back some domestic flights, including some nonstop service from Miami to the Northeast. [ 39. ] India's Supreme Court upheld Union Carbide's $470 million claims settlement for the 1984 Bhopal disaster. [ 41. ] THE ECONOMY Heating oil prices have surged and spot shortages have occurred in recent days. Experts fear continued cold weather could bring more widespread shortages. Several companies are rationing sales to dealers, and governors have sought delivery curbs. [ 37. ] Striking coal miners may soon have a contract after a bitter nine-month strike against Pittston Coal, officials said. [ 17. ] The Senate Ethics Committee said it would investigate charges of improper conduct and influence peddling by six Senators - the five who met with regulatory authorities on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., the former California savings and loan executive, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, whose role in Federal housing projects has been questioned. [ 16. ] Orders for durable goods rose 5.1 percent in November. The Commerce Department attributed the surprisingly strong showing to a surge in demand for aircraft and parts. [ 37. ] Federal Reserve policy makers decided not to change monetary policy at their late fall meeting but left open the possibility of lower interest rates if economic events dictated, minutes of the session show. [ 38. ] The lagging Christmas shopping season picked up new life in its final week, with a potential bonus due on Sunday, an extra shopping day this year. But retailers see only limited sales gains for the season, which has been plagued by bitterly cold weather. [ 39. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrials rose 20.26 points, to 2,711.39, giving Wall Street visions of its traditional holiday rally - covering the last five trading days of the old year and the first two of the new. But volume dropped 30 percent, to 120.9 million shares. [ 40. ] Prices of Treasury securities fell in a shortened session. Dealers said the 5.1 percent rise for durable goods orders in November unsettled the market, although some saw it as an aberration and predicted the Federal Reserve would ease credit next year. [ 40. ] The dollar tumbled below the 1.7250-mark level, as strong demand continued for the West German currency. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $1.30 an ounce, to $413.20. [ 46. ] Orange juice futures prices fell sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange [ 46. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Most people can pare their 1989 tax bills, but they must act in the coming week. Charitable contributions and state and local tax payments are two areas of opportunity. Your Money. [ 38. ] American inventors obtained a larger share of the patents issued in the United States this year than they did in 1988, reversing a 26-year decline. Patents. [ 38. ]

title: More Trips Start at a Home Computer
description: Prospective travelers with questing minds and a good deal of patience appear increasingly comfortable using their home computers to browse through an often bewildering array of travel offerings. But travel agents have little to worry about.

title: Bethlehem Journal; O Little Town, Where Are Your Tourists Now?
description: Their heads down, their cameras held close to their bodies, a small group of tourists hurried past the shuttered Arab stores and watchful Israeli soldiers that give this biblical city its feel of siege and arrived this morning at the Church of the Nativity.

title: Elizabeth Miller, 67, U.S. Baptist Executive
description: The Rev. Elizabeth Miller, an executive of the American Baptist Churches for more than 36 years, died Saturday at her home in King of Prussia, Pa., after a long illness. She was 67 years old.

title: Right to Bear Arms Underlies All Our Liberties; Enforcement Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Sales Rise in Final Week
description: The lagging Christmas shopping season picked up new life in its final week, with a potential bonus due on Sunday, an extra shopping day this year. But retailers across the country estimated yesterday that sales for the season, which has been plagued by bitterly cold weather in many areas, have shown gains of only 3 to 5 percent over last year, down from a 7 percent increase in 1988.

title: Stray Bullet Kills Tenant on Watch
description: A tenant volunteer on watch in a Bronx apartment-house lobby was shot to death Thursday night with a stray bullet from a street dispute outside the building, the police said yesterday.

title: Upheaval in the East: Germany; Cheers as Brandenburg Gate Reopens
description: Leaders of the two Germanys reopened the Brandenburg Gate today, breaching a barrier that more than any other had come to symbolize the division of the nation.

title: Maryland Judge Seriously Hurt by Bomb
description: A Maryland criminal court judge known for strong advocacy of gun control and harsh prison sentences was injured today when a package bomb exploded in his apartment in Hagerstown, Md.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about immigration to Israel referred incorrectly to the distribution of money collected by the United Jewish Appeal, an American fund-raising campaign. None of the money goes to the Israeli Government.

title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull
description: The owner of a pit bull that mauled a 2-year-old boy to death was acquitted of second-degree murder today but found guilty of involuntary manslaughter and other lesser charges.

title: Review/Music; Beethoven and the Thrill of Hushed Intensity
description: One of the great glories of the modern symphony orchestra, more stunning in its way than the full-throated climaxes, is the effect of massed powerful instrumentalists playing with hushed yet full-bodied intensity. This is not something that comes naturally to 100 musicians trained in a highly competitive environment that offers few rewards for reticence. It takes doing, and its mastery is one of the hallmarks of a fine conductor.

title: Finally, Rumania
description: What a year. What a week. What a Friday. The Brandenburg Gate was reopened in Berlin by Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Hans Modrow of East Germany. And stunningly, in the face of horrifying violence, Rumanians drove the despotic Nicolae Ceausescu from power. Except for tiny, Stalinist Albania, one-party tyranny appears near an end in Central and Eastern Europe.

title: Upheaval in the East; Poet Ousted by Party Joins Rumanian on TV
description: The poet Mircea Dinescu, who stood with former Foreign Minister Corneliu Manescu after the takeover of the Rumanian television studios in Bucharest yesterday, had been thrown out of the Communist Party in March for having contacts with foreigners.

title: FIGHTING IN PANAMA: The Survivors; For Military Families, Worry, Grief and Pride
description: The apprehension for many families began with phone calls, soldiers saying they would be out of reach for a time. They were about to embark on a dangerous secret mission, they said, to a destination they did not know. Some cried. Everyone hung up uneasily.

title: Manhattan Vents Wrath In Survey About Cable TV
description: Maybe they love their MTV, their CNN, their HBO or their Cinemax. Maybe they hate it. But 110,000 cable television subscribers have something to say about cable service in Manhattan.

title: 16-Year Sentence Proposed for Driver in Crash That Killed 27
description: A jury recommended a 16-year prison sentence today for the man convicted of manslaughter Thursday in the crash that killed 27 people on a church bus.

title: Companies Sharing Good Fortune With the Neediest Cases
description: The office party, be it a cup of cheer hoisted at the boss's desk or a lavish spread in a hotel, is as much a component of the holiday season as are Santa Claus and jingle bells. So too, for some companies, is the practice of sharing good fortune with the less prosperous, and contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have come from a variety of businesses.

title: Overtime Victory Puts Devils 1 Point From the Top
description: The Devils kept taking the lead and the Flyers kept coming back, forcing the game into overtime tonight at the Spectrum. But the Devils stuck to the pattern and Kirk Muller gave New Jersey a 5-4 victory with a goal 78 seconds into the sudden-death period.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: EXHIBITION HOCKEY Soviet Union 8, Canada 0: Playing in Moscow, the Soviet Union won the Izvestia tournament last night, and Canada, which could have finished first, had it won, ended up in fourth place, with a 2-1-2 record. The Czechoslovaks, who ended up second, beat West Germany, 5-0. Finland, which ended up third, beat Sweden, 5-1. After the sixth Soviet goal, someone in the crowd of about 14,000 threw a bottle of blue paint onto the ice. The police searched the stands behind the Canadian net, but could not find the offender. They then ejected everyone in the area.(AP) N.B.A. Bulls 125, Hawks 113: Michael Jordan scored 29 points as visiting Chicago won a battle for first place in the Central Division last night. Dominique Wilkins had 34 points and 11 rebounds, but could not keep Atlanta from losing, although the loss was only the team's third in 12 games. (AP) Spurs 119, Suns 115: Terry Cummings scored 29 points and David Robinson 28 for visiting San Antonio. Phoenix led, 84-83, after the third period on Eddie Johnson's 3-point goal with two seconds left. But layups by David Wingate and Vernon Maxwell at the start of the fourth quarter put San Antonio ahead to stay.(AP) Jazz 114, Hornets 100: Karl Malone scored a career-high 52 points for visiting Utah, hitting 22 of 28 attempts from the field. Malone, who also had 17 rebounds, hit his last 8 field goals. Charlotte trailed by only 100-94 with 4 minutes 14 seconds left in the game. But Malone's 3-point play and breakaway dunk, sandwiched around a jumper by Bobby Hansen, keyed a 10-0 run that sealed the victory.(AP) 76ers 89, Celtics 88: Ron Anderson made two long jump shots in the final minute as Philadelphia, playing in Boston, rallied from a 17-point deficit to win. Boston was ahead, 65-48, midway through the third period and still led by 82-70 with seven minutes left before Derek Smith sparked Philadelphia's comeback. Smith scored 9 of his 13 points in the rally. Anderson's long jumper put Philadelphia ahead by 87-86 with 55 seconds left, but Dennis Johnson drove down the baseline to regain the lead for Boston. Larry Bird, who managed just 11 points, missed two long shots in the final seconds.(AP) Nuggets 137, Magic 125: Alex English scored 25 points as Denver, the league's highest-scoring team, shot 58.6 percent from the field and won in Orlando. Denver took a 70-53 lead at halftime after making 30 of 47 shots the first two periods. The team led by as many as 21 points and did not let Orlando, ranked last in scoring defense, get any closer than 10 points in the second half. English hit 12 of 14 shots as Denver hit 58 of 99 for the game.(AP) Mavericks 101, Clippers 92: Rolando Blackman scored 9 of his 31 points in a decisive 13-4 fourth-quarter spurt for Dallas in a home game. Blackman scored the most points by a Maverick this season. Los Angeles led, 85-84, before Blackman made two free throws with 6:23 left, giving Dallas the lead for good.(AP) Rockets 103, Kings 92: Akeem Olajuwon's 29 points and 21 rebounds sparked Houston to a 103-92 comeback victory in Houston. The Rockets' Derrick Chievous scored a season-high 17 points. Olajuwon's performance marked the fifth time this season and 27th in his career that he has had 20 or more rebounds in a game.(AP) Bucks 112, Cavaliers 100: Jay Humphries scored 27 points and sparked a 12-0 third-quarter run as Milwaukee, playing at home, turned a 61-58 lead into a 73-58 advantage and won. Cleveland got back to within 7 points at the quarter's end with a 12-4 rally, but Milwaukee expanded the lead to 13 in the opening minutes of the final period behind 7 points from Paul Pressey.(AP) Warriors 150, Pacers 124: Mitch Richmond scored 31 points and Chris Mullin 28, leading seven Warriors who scored in double figures as Golden State won at home. Indiana's Chuck Person scored 32 points, extending his streak of games with 30 or more points to five. Vern Fleming of Indiana matched his career high with 30. Sarunas Marciulionis, Golden State's rookie from Lithuania, equaled his season high with 21 points.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 2, Canadiens 2: Shayne Corson scored with two seconds left in regulation time to lift Montreal to a tie in Buffalo last night in a meeting between the league's top two teams. Buffalo was called for icing with five seconds remaining in the third period. With the goaltender, Brian Hayward, off in favor of an extra attacker, Brian Skrudland won the ensuing faceoff in Buffalo's end and pulled the puck back to Chris Chelios at the point. Chelios fed Corson in the right circle, and Corson hit the open side of the net for his 14th goal of the season. Rick Vaive became the 29th player in league history to score 400 or more goals. Daren Puppa made 25 saves for Buffalo. Hayward stopped 22 shots for Montreal.(AP) Maple Leafs 5, Blackhawks 3: Tom Fergus and Ed Olczyk scored 18 seconds apart early in the third period to lift Toronto to victory in Chicago. After Toronto killed off a four-minute Chicago power play, Fergus took a pass from Daniel Marois, went around Dave Manson and beat Jacques Cloutier with a 20-foot wrist shot at 5:34. Allan Bester, playing his second game since returning from the minor leagues, made 39 saves. Toronto killed all eight Chicago power plays.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Kansas 90, Arizona State 67: Kevin Pritchard helped trigger a quick getaway last night as Kansas opened this home game with a 15-0 run, closed the first half with a 14-1 burst and coasted to victory. After trailing by 50-23 at halftime, Arizona State never got closer than 23 points.(AP) Manhattan College 88, Wagner 72: A senior forward, Peter Runge, scored a career-high 31 points as Manhattan College pulled away and won. Manhattan led by 41-37 at halftime and began the second half with a 10-3 burst. Kelly Monroe, who scored 23 points, had the final 7 points in the run on a 3-pointer, two free throws and a layup off a fast break. The Seahawks' only lead was 26-25 on Monty Davis's 3-point play in the first half.(AP)

title: Braniff in Pact to Return Jets
description: Braniff Inc. and the Irish aviation company GPA Group P.L.C. have announced an agreement for the return to GPA of five jetliners leased earlier this year to the troubled airline.

title: U.S. Says Noriega Seems to Direct Attacks in Panama
description: Panama's deposed leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is believed to be personally directing a hit-and-run counteroffensive by armed civilians as he struggles to avoid capture by American troops, a senior United States military officer said this afternoon.

title: Fighting in Panama: Missing; CBS Producer Barely Given Time to Rest
description: On Monday, when CBS News called Jon Meyersohn to tell him to go to Panama, the 33-year-old producer was enjoying a brief spell at home in New York City after an extraordinary and arduous series of assignments. He had been at the opening of the Berlin wall, the meeting of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and Pope John Paul II in Rome, the demonstrations in Prague and the Gorbachev-Bush summit meeting at Malta.

title: COPING WITH HOLIDAY SNAPSHOTS
description: More photographs are taken during the Christmas holidays than at any time outside the summer vacation season. The holidays are occasions for recording and preserving festive gatherings of family and friends. But if summer was the last time you used your camera, a bit of preparation is in order before you try to capture your holiday memories.

title: Ethiopia to Let Food Aid Into Rebel Area
description: In a move to ease a looming famine in Ethiopia, the Government there said today that it would allow relief food provided by foreign governments and aid agencies to be distributed in the rebel-held province of Tigre.

title: Fighting in Panama: United Nations; Council Deadlocked on Panama Rivals
description: The Security Council remained deadlocked today as it tried to decide the legitimate government of Panama in the aftermath of the United States military strike.

title: Those Holiday Markdown's: Real Bargains or Illusion?
description: Consumers who have been rushing through the winter wonderland of department store markdowns have been happy shoppers for the most part this holiday season. Walk into any big store and there are customers amazed or pleased - or both - by the extent of on-sale items.

title: Bicycle-Riding Thief Sought by the Police
description: The police said yesterday that they are searching for a bicycle-riding thief who preys on elderly women on the Upper East Side, snatching their purses and throwing the women to the ground if they resist.

title: Fighting in Panama: Trying to Cope; Back Home, Army and Families Forge a Chain of Concern
description: At times like this, the military resembles an extended family - drawn together in grief and pride and fear, imperfectly but deliberately coping with the emptiness felt when soldiers go off to war.

title: Texas Gives $10,000 Fines to Two Agents
description: Johnny Rodgers, a former Heisman Trophy winner from Nebraska, and a Nebraska sports marketing company were fined $10,000 each today by the Texas Secretary of State, who charged that both had illegally contacted the 1989 Heisman winner, Andre Ware of Houston.

title: New England Bank Cancels Dividend
description: The Bank of New England Corporation said it would cancel an announced common stock dividend of 34 cents a share. A week earlier, the banking company, based in Boston, said that because losses in its real estate lending would result in a large loss for the year, it would consider rescinding the dividend.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Decline
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday session. Dealers said the Government's report of an unexpectedly large rise of 5.1 percent in durable goods orders in November unsettled the market at the opening.

title: Fighting in Panama: Panama's Military; Changing an Army Poses a Challenge
description: By ''decapitating'' Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's control of Panama's military, the United States has created a challenge that may prove to be as formidable as the capture of the general himself: the purging and restructuring of the 15,000-man army, police and customs force he commanded and bent to his own will.

title: How Rumania Came to Be
description: May 1877: Rumania gains full independence from Turkey at the Congress of Berlin, which concluded the Russo-Turkish War. 1916: Rumania enters World War I in the side of the allies. 1920: Under the treaty of Trianon, between Hungary and the victorious Allied Powers of World I, Rumania is awarded substantial territory from Hungary, including Transylvania. 1933: Prime Minister Ion Duca is assassinated by the Iron Guard, an extreme nationalist group dedicated to preserving Rumania and the Rumanain Orthodox Chruch against Western influences and ideologies. 1938: The leader of the Iron Guard, Cornellu Codreanu, is killed, ostensibly while trying to excape from jail. He had been imprisoned on treason charges by King Carol II, who ruled with a handpicked coalition called the Front of National Renascence. 1940: Rumania, neutral at the outbreak of World Ear II, adopts a pro-German orientation. Nevertheless, when Hungary demands the return of territories annexed by Rumania after World War I, Nazi Germany favors Humgary. Rumania is compelled to cede northern Transylvania to Hungary. The Soviet Union demands and receives Bessarable, which becomes the Moldavian Soviet Republic. June 1941: Rumania joins the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union. August 1944: Soviet forces enter the country, and the Government, led by Marshall Ion Antonescu, is overthrown. March 1945: Under Soviet pressure, King Michael accepts a Communist-led coalition Government. 1946: Elections usher in a Communist-dominated bloc with 89 percent of the vote. Opposition parties charge fraud. Dec. 30, 1947: The King abdicates and the Rumanian People's Republic is proclaimed. Nationalization of the country's industries and banks begins as the Communists gain control. 1952: The party comes under the control of Gheorghiu-Dej, a longtime revolutionary who begins loosening ties with the Soviets and cultivating Yugoslavia, China and the West. 1965: Nicolae Ceausescu becomes Communist Party chief on the death of Gheorghiu-Dej. 1968: The Government denounces the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia, the most striking example of Bucharest's independence of Moscow in foreign policy. May 1987: President Mikhail Gorbachev of the Soviet Union visits, but President Ceausescu indicates that the liberalization taking place in other Eastern bloc countries will not be introduced in Rumania. November 1987: After months of energy rationing made worse by severe weather, thousands of workers march through Brasov to protest a decline in living standards. The authroities make hundreds of arrests. March 1988: The President announces a program to demolish 8,000 villages and resettle residents, including about 50,000 ethnic Hungarians, in urban housing complexes. The action frays relations between Rumania and Hungary. Dec. 16, 1989: Rumanian security forces begin a crackdown on protesters in Timisoara. There are reports that as many as 2,000 are killed. President Ceausescu blames ''facist reactionary groups.'' Dec. 21: Demonstrations spread to Bucharest. Dec. 22: President Ceausescu is overthrown. Forces loyal to him counterattack later in the day.

title: Henry L. Ughetta, 63; Former Lawyer Is Dead
description: Henry L. Ughetta 2d, a former partner in the law firm of Wilkie Farr & Gallagher, died Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 63 years old and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for 11 years.

title: Books of The Times; Black Military History in the U.S.: No Longer the Untold Story
description: Forged in Battle The Civil War Alliance of Black Soldiers and White Officers By Joseph T. Glatthaar Illustrated. 370 pages. The Free Press. $24.95. Thomas Morris Chester, Black Civil War Correspondent His Dispatches From the Virginia Front Edited by R. J. M. Blackett Illustrated. 375 pages. Louisiana State University Press. $35. America's First Black General Benjamin O. Davis Sr., 1880-1970 By Marvin E. Fletcher Illustrated. 226 pages. University Press of Kansas. $22.50.

title: LEBANON MILITIAS ARE SPLINTERING
description: Lebanon's long political crisis has caused sharp divisions within Christian and Muslim sectors, generating fear about factional violence breaking out on each side of the dividing Green Line.

title: Review/Music; Setting of Havel Letters
description: Petr Kotik led his S.E.M. Ensemble in a program that suggested some unusual connections and contrasts on Tuesday evening at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo. The contrasts were between the philosophical and the functional. The connections were between forms of functional music from different eras, mostly filtered through modern sensibilities.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Pentagon; Bush Raises Force in Panama by 2,000
description: Concerned about the slow pace of efforts to establish control in the Panamanian capital, President Bush dispatched 2,000 more soldiers today to reinforce the 24,000-member American force in Panama, Pentagon officials said.

title: Bush Expected to Name Conservationalist to a Top Environmental Post
description: President Bush will soon name a professional conservationist to the State Department's top environmental post, Administration officials said today. They said the move portended a higher profile for environmental issues in foreign policy.

title: Upheaval in the East; Hungary to Hold Free Vote On March 25, Leader Says
description: The Acting President of Hungary, Matyas Szuros, announced today that the country's first competitive elections in 41 years will be held on March 25, the state news agency reported.

title: Rumania's Sudden Thrust to Democracy
description: LEAD: After 24 years of increasingly despotic rule by its deposed President, Nicolae Ceausescu, Rumania appears better prepared for the transition to democracy than is commonly supposed in the West.

title: William Bailey, 68, Chemistry Professor And Polymer Expert
description: William John Bailey, chemist, educator and former chairman of the board of the American Chemical Society, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Straub Hospital in Honolulu, where he was attending a professional meeting on polymers. He was 68 years old and lived in University Park, Md.

title: Foreign-Route Spree At American Airlines
description: Robert L. Crandall, chairman and president of American Airlines, is a man in a hurry. He is snapping up international routes so quickly that at least for the near future he will not have enough planes to add the number of flights he would like.

title: Delivery Industry's Happy Marriage
description: For holiday shoppers, it has come down to that time when the gift they ordered absolutely, positively has to be there overnight. Not to worry, Federal Express told customers this week. The nation's largest overnight delivery company has teamed up with about 200 catalogue retailers, from L. L. Bean to the Sharper Image, to try to deliver their packages quickly, and holiday-season business has been brisk.

title: Orders Up Strong 5.1% For Durables
description: Bolstered by a surge in demand for aircraft and parts, orders for durable goods rose by a surprisingly strong 5.1 percent in November.

title: Sheller-Globe Countersuit
description: Two top executives of Knoll International Holdings Inc. have denied allegations that they fabricated important financial data in connection with Knoll's sale of the Sheller-Globe Corporation, an auto parts maker.

title: Ernest L. Sisto, 85, Photographer For The Times for Nearly 50 Years
description: Ernest Ludwig Sisto, an award-winning photographer who worked for The New York Times for nearly 50 years, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital in Grass Valley, Calif. He was 85 years old and had been living with a son Daniel in Rough and Ready, Calif., for 18 months.

title: A Leader for Rebels
description: The Notre Dame offensive coordinator, Jim Strong, was named head coach at Nevada-Las Vegas yesterday.

title: Knicks Extend Streak Behind Newman's 25
description: The Knicks proved tonight that they could win without Patrick Ewing if they had to. They defeated the Washington Bullets, 122-112, here at the Capital Centre to run their winning streak to five games and their season mark to 16-7.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Not even Hitler killed his own children, and here they used automatic machine gun bursts to strafe them down.'' - Slavomir Gvozdenovic, editor of a literary review in Timisoara, Rumania. [ 1:5. ]

title: Upheaval in the East: In the Spotlight; An Old Party Stalwart At Rumania Barricades
description: Only a few days ago, Corneliu Manescu was under house arrest in a primitive dwelling on the outskirts of Bucharest. Today, the 73-year-old former senior Communist Party official appeared on Rumanian television, announcing to the nation that he is heading a ''national salvation front'' that would stay in power until free elections could be held.

title: Glasnost Smiles on U.S. Bookshop
description: Although the glasnost policies of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have taken much of the suspense out of the Victor Kamkin bookshop here, they have brought the largest Russian bookstore in the West a boom in business.

title: Dwane L. Wallace, 78, Is Dead; Pioneer Leader at Cessna Aircraft
description: Dwane L. Wallace, who guided the Cessna Aircraft Company for more than 40 years, died Thursday of complications after heart surgery at the Wesley Medical Center in Wichita, Kan. He was 78 years old and lived in Wichita.

title: Boston Mayor's Ulster Project
description: A nonprofit group founded by the Mayor of Boston and a Northern Ireland political leader will build a $100 million shopping center in the economically depressed city of Londonderry in Northern Ireland.

title: Dow Up 20.26; Year-End Rally Envisioned
description: Wall Street had visions of its traditional holiday rally - covering the last five trading days of the old year and the first two of the new - as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 20.26 points yesterday, to 2,711.39, but activity was thin, as is usual before a holiday.

title: They Meet Again
description: The last time P. J. Carlesimo's Seton Hall team met Michigan, the national championship was at stake and it took one overtime and a 1-point margin to deprive the Pirates of the title. When the teams meet again today, Carlesimo just wants to see how good his young team is.

title: Early Music for Today
description: ''I may be fooling myself,'' said the harpsichordist and early-music specialist Frederick Renz, ''but I believe it's possible to perform early music in a way that represents what was done at the time the music was written, but also speaks to a 20th-century audience.''

title: Fed Voted for No Change In Policy at Nov. 14 Meeting
description: Federal Reserve policy makers decided not to change monetary policy at their late fall meeting but left open the possibility of lower interest rates if economic events dictated, according to minutes of the session released today.

title: Higher Auschwitz Count Doesn't Aid Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Giorgio Cavallon, 85, a Pioneer in Abstract Art
description: Giorgio Cavallon, a pioneer Abstract Expressionist who brought to American painting a Mediterranean feeling for color and light, died last night at New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Opera; A 'Wozzeck' With Staying Power
description: ''Wozzeck'' is not exactly ''Hansel and Gretel.'' In other words, the opera that Alban Berg fashioned from Georg Buchner's harrowing play of proletarian military degradation is hardly cheery holiday fare. But the Metropolitan Opera's production, which dates back 30 years and which returned Thursday night, remains one of the company's finest achievements, and a healthy audience welcomed it warmly.

title: Boeing Plans 1,200 Layoffs
description: The Boeing Company plans to lay off about 1,200 employees in the first half of next year, with most of the cuts to be made among production workers at its plant in Everett, Wash., its chairman, Frank A. Shrontz, said today.

title: Big Talk From Promoters of Big-Money Lewis-Johnson Rematch
description: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter under suspension for his steroid-tainted past, may have a brighter future if promoters can parlay pay television and whatever curiosity the public may have in seeing him in a rematch against his rival Carl Lewis.

title: Paint Is Flung on Mural; Bottles Bear Swastikas
description: The Pathfinder Mural, a 70-foot-high Greenwich Village wall painting including portraits of Marx, Lenin, Fidel Castro, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and others, was splattered with paint on Wednesday night.

title: Musingly On the Bounty
description: The Government looked distinctly cheap when it offered $1 million for General Noriega. For that kind of money you can't even get a halfway decent baseball player anymore.

title: Peru Suspends Anti-Drug Effort
description: Protesting American military action in Panama, Peru has requested that the United States suspend its anti-drug operations in Peru's coca-growing areas, an American narcotics official said. The suspension came after Peru withdrew its Ambassador from Washington. Page 15.

title: Operation High Hokum
description: From the President's most trivial actions to the most serious, like risking American lives in battle, the White House stage managers work hard to create the most favorable atmosphere for the chief executive's decisions. But sometimes the margin between necessity and excess can be thin indeed, as reflected by the code names for military operations.

title: Right to Bear Arms Underlies All Our Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Paul C. Agnew, Psychiatrist, Dies at 66
description: Dr. Paul C. Agnew, a psychiatrist who headed the Dannemora and Matteawan correctional centers in upstate New York in the 1970's, died of pneumonia yesterday at the University of Vermont Hospital in Burlington. He was 66 years old and lived in Plattsburg, N.Y.

title: Stay of New York Law On Smoking Is Denied
description: New York's tough statewide anti-smoking law, scheduled to take effect on Jan. 1, will not be shelved during a new court challenge, a state judge said today.

title: Upheaval in the East: East-Bloc Reports; Excerpts From Coverage by the Rumanians and Hungarians
description: Following are excerpts from dispatches by the Rumanian press agency Agerpres and Rumanian and Hungarian radio and television broadcasts, as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service: Censor No Longer Needed

title: Roger Hallowell, 79, Headed Silver Concern
description: Roger H. Hallowell, former president and chairman of Reed & Barton, the silver company, and a decorated Navy commander, died of a stroke Wednesday at a nursing home in Peabody. He was 79 years old and lived in Manchester, Mass.

title: Europe and Arabs to Resume Talks
description: The European Community and 22 members of the Arab League decided today to resume a formal dialogue on political and economic issues, six years after talks between the two groups broke down.

title: Life and Longing on the 732d Rung
description: Even the most tennis-ignorant can recognize a Chris Evert or a John McEnroe. But ask someone as knowledgeable as the editor of Tennis magazine to identify the 732d-ranked player in the world, and unless there's a ranking list handy, the response will be a shrug and a blank expression.

title: Upheaval in the East: Moscow; Soviets Welcome the Uprising Against Ceausescu
description: The Government today hailed the routing of the Ceausescu regime as ''the will of the Rumanian people'' and expressed its support of Rumanians' demands for democracy.

title: Westchester's Horse Country Image Rides Into the Sunset
description: Here in northern Westchester County, someone sporting riding breeches on the street is more likely to be off to the stables than making a fashion statement. But the horsey life is in retreat.

title: 7 States Reach Accord On Teacher Credentials
description: The six New England states and New York have agreed to offer a regional credential for teachers and loosen the certification restrictions that keep many teachers from simply moving across state lines for new jobs.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Wrath in East Europe; 'The Year of Democracy' Will Still Leave Many Problems and Unanswered Questions
description: The armed rebellion against Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania demonstrates that no hard-line Communist regime in Eastern Europe can evade the popular wrath sweeping the region.

title: Fighting in Panama: U.S. Statements; Excerpts From Briefing On Panama Operation
description: Following are excerpts from today's Defense Department news briefing on events in Panama by Pete Williams, the department spokesman, and Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Kelly and Rear Adm. Ted Sheafer of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by The Federal News Service, a transcription company.

title: U.S. Drops Appeal in Suit Over Nuclear Arms Plant
description: The Energy Department is dropping its appeal of a $78 million judgment in a suit filed by neighbors of a nuclear weapons plant in Ohio, but does not know where it will get the money to pay the 14,000 plaintiffs, the department's top lawyer said today.

title: Patents; American Inventors Gained in '89
description: IN a reversal of a 26-year decline, American inventors this year obtained a larger share of the patents issued in the United States than they did in 1988.

title: Jetliner, in Flight to Tokyo, Lands In Alaska After a 600-Mile Error
description: A Thai Airways jumbo jet flying from Seattle to Tokyo mistakenly reversed course over the northern Pacific on Thursday evening and wandered 600 miles off its flight path before it was alerted by air traffic controllers, Federal aviation officials said yesterday.

title: KHMER ROUGE SAY THEY HOLD A CITY
description: Khmer Rouge guerrillas said today that they had captured the third district capital since Vietnamese troops withdrew from Cambodia three months ago, the guerrilla radio reported.

title: Colorado Arrives
description: The undefeated University of Colorado football team made its first trip here in 13 years today, landing amid 65-degree temperatures after taking off in readings of 15 below in Denver. The Buffaloes are preparing for a night game New Year's Day against Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl that could determine the national championship.

title: Yankees Sign Garcia and Announce Cerone Contract
description: In November 1979, the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays swapped six players, the most noted of whom was Chris Chambliss. The Blue Jays, however, also got a promising young second baseman, Damaso Garcia, and the Yankees received a young starting catcher, Rick Cerone.

title: Veteran Firefighter Moves Up to Become Commissioner
description: Taking charge of the nation's largest Fire Department will be a veteran of 31 years as a firefighter, Carlos M. Rivera, who is moving up from the post of Chief of Operations.

title: Bushes Visit Children With AIDS in Wards
description: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, toured the children's AIDS wards of the National Institutes of Health today and urged Americans to overcome ''a misplaced fear'' of the disease in order to ''wage all-out war against this terrible killer.''

title: About New York; Even the Ghost Of a Critic Likes The Army Band
description: The lights dim, a black-and-white image fills the big screen, the popcorn is hot and fresh. Suddenly, you're watching ''All About Eve,'' winner of six Oscars for 1950, including best picture. The scene is the ''21'' Club. Addison DeWitt, the all-powerful columnist, is lunching with the up-and-coming Broadway actress, Eve Harrington.

title: Upheaval in the East; Another Hard-Liner Totters In the East
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu was the virtually the last old-style Communist leader to resist the wave of liberalization that swept across Eastern Europe at the end of the 1980's.

title: Searching For a Moral Imperative
description: Perhaps the mood will pass by New Year's Day, but for now it is increasingly difficult to watch Division I basketball and football contests with a straight face.

title: Right to Bear Arms Underlies All Our Liberties; Costs of Verification
description: To the Editor:

title: Twin Brothers Held in Jersey In Slayings of 2 Cabdrivers
description: Twin brothers were arrested today in connection with the killings of two Trenton cabdrivers in November, the police said.

title: Eleanor Shaler Dickson Actress, 89
description: Eleanor Shaler Dickson, a socially prominent actress and singer of the 1920's and 30's, died of pulmonary problems yesterday at her home in Gladwyne, Pa. She was 89 years old.

title: Patents; A New Respirator To Administer CPR
description: Using the motor from a large vacuum cleaner as a power source, a family doctor in Canton, Mich., has developed a new respirator to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Search; Hundreds of Tips but Still no Noriega
description: Early Wednesday morning, American special-operation forces equipped with night-vision devices, stun grenades and customized submachine guns struck seven sites around Panama where intelligence information indicated that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega might be staying, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Resorts International Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: Merv Griffin, the show business personality and businessman, sought bankruptcy court protection yesterday for Resorts International Inc., his troubled hotel and casino operator.

title: Upheaval in the East: Washington; Bush Promises to Help If Rumanians Change
description: The Bush Administration said today that it was prepared to extend to Rumania the kind of assistance granted to Poland and Hungary if the government that emerges in Bucharest adopts similar political and economic reforms.

title: India Supreme Court Backs Carbide's Bhopal Settlement
description: India's Supreme Court today upheld the legality of the agreement under which the Union Carbide Corporation paid $470 million in final settlement of claims for the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: Maradona Is Facing Ban From Cup Finals
description: Diego Maradona, the 29-year-old Argentine forward whose knack for scoring goals is nearly matched by his penchant for controversy, is skirting possible disqualification from the 1990 World Cup finals.

title: The Martinez Mess
description: By choosing a well-respected state bureaucrat, Arthur Webb, to direct New York State's drug-abuse agency, Gov. Mario Cuomo limits the political damage caused by disclosures of the previous director's abuses. But Mr. Cuomo's handling of the whole mess still warrants criticism.

title: Some Careers to End As Jets' Season Does
description: The season that the Jets couldn't wait to begin became the season they couldn't wait to end, and it will sputter to a halt Saturday at Giants Stadium against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Bridge
description: Going down in a slam that need not have been attempted is always irritating. But the irritation is compounded when the post-mortem reveals that an esoteric line of play would have succeeded. This was South's fate on Sunday on the diagramed deal from the Regional Knockout Team final at the Penta Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Eastern to Cut Some Flights in U.S.
description: Eastern Airlines, which just sold its Latin American routes, is also cutting back some domestic flights, including nonstop service from Miami to Boston, Philadelphia, Orlando and Tampa, Fla., and several Caribbean cities, the company said today.

title: Fire Director, Budget Chief Are Selected
description: Filling the post that he has called his top priority, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins yesterday named the executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, Philip R. Michael, as his Budget Director. Mr. Dinkins also named a career firefighter, Carlos M. Rivera, to be Fire Commissioner.

title: Upheaval in the East: Hungary; High Prices Dampen Hungary's Holiday
description: As Hungarians make their Christmas shopping rounds this year, in and out of stores trimmed with silver wreaths and bright ornaments, they are discovering a shortage of good cheer.

title: Cities Are Looters' Jungles As Chaos Consumes Panama
description: Two days after United States forces invaded the country, Panama appeared close to anarchy as bands of looters and roving gunmen took over and ravaged one neighborhood after another.

title: Surprise By Nets Fades
description: The first 6,500 fans who walked into Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight received free Nets T-shirts. And at halftime of the game with the Detroit Pistons, it appeared they might receive a surprise from the Nets, who were tied at 46-46. But the Nets went on to lose another game in frustrating fashion, 96-90.

title: Your Money; Strategies to Pare Tax Bill for 1989
description: MOST people who take an evening to go over their finances will find they can pare their 1989 tax bills, but they must act in the coming week.

title: Giants Know This: They Must Stop Bo
description: The same Bo Jackson who played left field this summer for the Kansas City Royals will be at Giants Stadium on Sunday running the football for the Los Angeles Raiders against the Giants. And Bo knows how to run.

title: Heating Oil Stockpiles Grow Tight
description: An unusually sustained cold stretch, combined with fundamental changes in the energy market in the Northeast, has shoved heating oil prices sharply higher in the last few days and created spot shortages.

title: Ethics Panel Plans Inquiries Into Conduct of 6 Senators
description: The Senate Ethics Committee announced today that it would begin a formal investigation of charges of improper conduct and influence peddling by six Senators, including Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, whose role in Federal housing projects has been questioned.

title: Hors d'Oeuvres of Kings
description: More caviar is sold in December than at any other time of the year. And it's also when prices generally drop. There is less expensive caviar than sturgeon roe, but none has the same delicacy. Lumpfish is gritty and salty and its black color comes from dye. Whitefish is better, especially when left its natural golden color. Good salmon roe is rich and briny. The best caviar is always fresh, not pasteurized, and a pound is usually measured at 14 ounces. As for fine sturgeon caviar, these are the choices: TYPE: Beluga CHARACTERISTICS: From giant Caspian Sea sturgeon. The rarest, largest and most costly eggs, usually black; most delicate flavor. PRICE: $400 to $700 TYPE: Osetra CHARACTERISTICS: Smaller than beluga, and often a lighter color; has a rich, nutty flavor. PRICE: $160 to $400 TYPE: Sevruga CHARACTERISTICS: Smallest, least expensive Caspian Sea caviar. Not so distinctive as osetra PRICE: $120 to $250 TYPE: Pressed CHARACTERISTICS: Very rich, fairly salty jamlike paste of broken caviar. PRICE: About $100 TYPE: American CHARACTERISTICS: From native sturgeon; similar to sevruga. PRICE: $75 to $150 TYPE: Chinese CHARACTERISTICS: From large Amur River sturgeon; like beluga or osetra, but usually grayish green. PRICE: $200 to $350

title: A Default Threat for Campeau
description: The Campeau Corporation's two American retail units said yesterday that they had been notified by their leading bank lender that they could be in default on $2.34 billion in loans unless they comply with a reporting requirement within 10 days.

title: Patents; Advances Reported In Use of Liposomes
description: Researchers at the Liposome Company in Princeton, N.J., have obtained two patents covering the use of liposomes, which are microscopic bubbles that could prove helpful in delivering drugs to the right places in the body.

title: Japan Economic Growth
description: The Japanese Government today forecast that the country's economic expansion would slow next year but would still be one of the fastest growing of the major industrial nations. The economy is expected to grow 4 percent in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins next April 1, down from the 4.6 percent estimated for the current year. The projected rate would outpace the estimated growth for the United States and West Germany. Japan has also projected a $78 billion trade surplus for 1990-91, down from an estimated $81 billion this year.

title: Fighting in Panama: Peru; Protest by Lima Asks U.S. to Halt Anti-Drug Drive
description: Protesting American military action in Panama, Peru has requested that the United States suspend its anti-drug operations in Peru's coca-growing areas, an American narcotics official in Lima said today.

title: Corrections
description: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday referred incorrectly to the first Jews to have served on the United States Supreme Court. Benjamin N. Cardozo followed Louis

title: Essex County Fined For Conditions in Jail
description: A Federal judge yesterday angrily ordered Essex County to pay $3.4 million in fines by Jan. 4 for failing to correct dangerous conditions at the county jail.

title: T. A. Hack Weds Jan Wurtzburger
description: The marriage of Jan Wurtzburger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon A. Wurtzburger of New York and Bedford, N.Y., and Talbot A. Hack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard officiated. Mrs. Hack, 28 years old, graduated from the Spence School and Princeton University. She is the registrar at Franklin College in Lugano, Switzerland. Her father is a governor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Dec. 12 about the acquittal of a student accused of painting anti-Semitic slurs in the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York at Binghamton gave an incorrect account of testimony about a can of spray paint found in a desk in the group's office.

title: In El Salvador, a Widening Campaign of Repression
description: LEAD: Jennifer Casolo, the American church worker the Salvadoran Government charged with hiding weapons for leftist guerrillas, was deported to the U.S. earlier this month after spending three weeks in a Salvadoran jail. But the religious communities in El Salvador and here at home warn that the U.S.-backed Salvadoran

title: As Deficit Threatens, City Hall Budget Watchdog Becomes Master
description: No one can say Philip R. Michael, who was named yesterday as New York City's next budget director, does not know what he is getting himself into.

title: George Harold Dennis Executive, 91
description: George Harold Dennis, retired president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company in Madrid and former representative of Radio Liberty to the Spanish Government, died on Thursday at the White Plains Medical Center after a long illness. He was 91 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about perceptions of the American invasion of Panama referred incorrectly to NBC's coverage of President Bush's news conference and the simultaneous unloading of coffins of American servicemen killed in Panama.
