NBC recorded the scene at Dover Air Force Base and showed it immediately after Mr. Bush's news conference, not during it.

title: Search Ends at Site Where 5 Died in Fire
description: Firefighters yesterday finished searching the charred remnant of a house where five people died in a fire on Thursday, and said no more victims were found.

title: Higher N.Y. Transit Fares Aren't the Answer . . .
description: New York City is the financial services capital of the world. But it is way behind Milwaukee, Wis., in the way that its transit system collects fares. It would be nice if, in 1990, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority would take its fare collection of one-size-fits-all into the 20th century. Nice, but unlikely.

title: Let Freedom Shine In Squares of America
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Graduate Students at Princeton Refuse to Remain Invisible
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East: Tass; Reports From the Rumanian Capital by Correspondents for Tass
description: Until today, Western journalists were not allowed into Rumania. Here are dispatches on the situation in Rumania yesterday from Bucharest correspondents for the Soviet press agency, Tass, which translated the reports. 'The Army Is With Us!'

title: News Summary
description: International 3-15 President Ceausescu of Rumania fled Bucharest, routed by crowds of pro-democracy demonstrators backed by army units. The state security police reportedly remained loyal to the President. Fierce fighting was reported. 1 News analysis: The armed rebellion in Rumania proves that no hard-line Communist government in Eastern Europe can evade the popular wrath sweeping the region. 1 Mass graves were found in Rumania. In Timisoara, townspeople said 4,500 corpses of those massacred by the security forces in last weekend's crackdown were buried in three graves. 1 An old Communist Party stalwart at Rumania's barricades 9 The U.S. will offer aid to Rumania as it did to Poland and Hungary if the new government that emerges in Bucharest adopts similar political and economic reforms, the Bush Administration said. 10 Soviets welcome the uprising against Ceausescu 10 The Brandenburg Gate was opened by the leaders of the two Germanys, breaching a barrier that has long symbolized the division of East and West. 7 High prices dampen Hungary's holiday 7 Gen. Noriega is leading an offensive against American troops by organizing hit-and-run attacks by armed civilians, a U.S. official said. The Pentagon said it would take 5 to 10 days to gain control of Panama City. 1 Panama appeared close to anarchy. The newly installed Junior Vice President narrowly escaped assassination when he was attacked as he left the National Assembly. Bands of armed looters roamed Panama City's streets. 1 President Bush ordered more troops into Panama to reinforce the 24,000-member American force amid concerns about the slow pace of efforts to gain control of the capital. 13 Gen. Noriega still eludes capture despite hundreds of tips 13 Changing an army poses a challenge 12 Peru halted U.S. anti-drug operations in the nation's coca-growing area as a protest against the U.S. invasion of Panama, an American narcotics official said. 15 The United Nations Security Council remained deadlocked as it tried to decide which is the legitimate government of Panama in the wake of the American invasion. 15 Criticism of U.S. action is supported in O.A.S. vote 15 For military families, worry, grief and pride 14 CBS producer barely given time to rest 14 Aid to a famine-hit region in Ethiopia held by rebels will be allowed by the Government to cross rebel lines to help ease a looming famine. 3 Arab and European chiefs will meet annually to discuss political and economic issues, the Arab League and the European Community decided, ending a six-year suspension of formal talks. 3 Lebanon militias are splintering 5 Khmer Rouge say they hold a city in Cambodia 6 National 16-17, 32 An investigation of six Senators by the Ethics Committee will examine the role of Alfonse D'Amato of New York in housing grants and the possible influence of five others on the regulation of a California savings and loan. 16 White supremacist groups in Atlanta have become the focus of attention in the investigation of four bombing incidents in the South. Investigators say a racial motive may link the bombs, which were all mailed from north Georgia. 16 A bomb injured a Maryland judge. It was hidden in a package mailed to his apartment. The F.B.I. said that so far there is no evidence linking the bombing to the mail bombs that killed a Federal judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Georgia. 16 The Pittston miners' strike may end soon. But as negotiators seek to work out an agreement, ripples of the bitter coal dispute are still widely felt. 17 A conservationist will be appointed by President Bush to the State Department's top environmental job, officials said. They predicted a higher profile for environmental issues in foreign policy. 16 Rising prices for heating fuels and spot shortages have been the results of an unusually sustained cold stretch, combined with fundamental changes in the energy market in the Northeast. 37 Delivery industry's happy marriage 37 A foreign-route spree at American Airlines 37 Jetliner, in flight to Tokyo, lands in Alaska after 600-mile error 17 Holiday sales rise in final week before Christmas 39 Regional 33-36 Harsh cold gripped New York City and surrounding areas. Just over the threshold of winter, New Yorkers endured temperatures that remained in single digits or low teens. 33 Mayor-elect David Dinkins appointed the director of the state Financial Control Board, Philip Michael, as the city's new Budget Director. He picked a career firefighter, Carlos Rivera, as Fire Commissioner. 33 New York's new Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, must keep in balance a budget that exceeds $26 billion at a time when new resources are scarce and ills like homelessness, drug abuse and AIDS abound. 35 New York's new Fire Commissioner, Carlos Rivera, is a 31-year veteran of the department. He will be the first Hispanic head of the Fire Department in its 124-year history. 35 Manhattan cable-television service was the subject of a questionnaire mailed by the Bureau of Franchises to 375,000 subscribers. Unsuspecting officials were overwhelmed by the response. 33 An 70-foot-high mural was damaged at the Pathfinder Press building in Greenwich Village. Vandals hurled bottles of white paint labled with swastikas at the painting, which includs portraits of Karl Marx, Fidel Castro, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Harriet Tubman. 35 Westchester's horse-riding image has been diminished as horse stables have been squeezed out by rising real estate prices. Riders can still be spotted in riding breeches, but the horsey life is in retreat in New York's suburban counties. 33 State loses request on anti-nuclear-waste protest 34 Brooklyn man charged in the death of a 13-month old girl 35 Neediest Cases 34

title: Suspect in Burglary on S.I. Wounded by Police Sergeant
description: An off-duty New York City police sergeant shot and wounded one of two burglary suspects yesterday evening when he found them breaking into a cousin's house on Staten Island, the police said.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is Christmas. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collection, recycling or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on Sunday schedules. Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: Bitter Coal Strike May Be at End, but Ripples From Dispute Are Widely Felt
description: Children of striking coal miners might not get the Barbie dolls and Nintendo games they asked for this Christmas, but officials on both sides said yesterday that after nine months of a bitter labor dispute, the miners might soon have a contract.

title: Review/Dance; Revival Is a Tribute to a Longtime Ailey Associate
description: Joyce Trisler's ''Journey'' remains a strange, baffling excursion. This solo, choreographed in 1958 to a recording of Charles Ives's ''Unanswered Question,'' depicts a woman who briefly emerges from shadows only to vanish again.

title: A Cold That Commands the Day's Attention
description: It stung the face and touched bare fingertips like a flame. It shattered plans and turned the most ordinary tasks to hardship. It meant danger and misery for some, poetry and adventure for others. But no one, it seemed, could ignore the cold.

title: Cranston Calls Off Sunday Wedding Plans
description: Apparently in part because of his ethics troubles, Senator Alan Cranston has announced that his plans to marry this Sunday have been called off. In a statement issued by his office here Thursday, the 75-year-old Senator suggested that local news organizations' attention to his wedding plans and the pressure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair were responsible for his decision. ''When the press pounced upon us before we filled out the marriage license forms,'' the statement said, ''it became clear to me that this is not an appropriate time to start a marriage and it would not be fair to Cathy to bring her into the middle of a stressful situation, so we will not be married on Dec. 24.'' Mr. Cranston was to have married Cathy Lee Pattiz, 49, at his sister's home in Los Altos Hills. The marriage would have been the third for Mr. Cranston, whose last marriage ended in divorce in May, and the first for Miss Pattiz, an Illinois native who has known the Senator since 1968.

title: Filling Without Spilling
description: Make room on that Things-We-Didn't-Know-We-Needed-But-Probably-Do list for the Trash Bag Support.

title: Three Men Charged In Gambling Scheme
description: The fire chief of New Hyde Park and two other men have been arrested and charged with running a $10-million-a-year sports-betting business, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: Allied-Lyons Is Buying Whitbread Liquor Unit
description: Whitbread P.L.C., the British brewer, said today that it would sell its liquor division to Allied-Lyons P.L.C., a leading British liquor company, for the equivalent of $877 million.

title: Bolivian Plane Crash Kills 23 but 5 Survive
description: A Bolivian Air Force transport plane crashed on Thursday in the jungle, killing 23 of 28 people on board, including 2 Americans, the air force said today.

title: Upheaval in the East; King Michael Ready to Return to Rumania
description: King Michael, the exiled Rumanian monarch, said today that he was ready to return to his country as head of a constitutional monarchy ''if the people want me to come back.''

title: POSTINGS: 200 Acres, $400 Million; Planning for a New Campus on S.I.
description: The College of Staten Island has unveiled its master plan for a $400 million campus designed by Edward Durell Stone Associates on the site of the old Willowbrook State School. The plan involves the construction of six new buildings and the renovation of 14 others at a 200-acre site near the center of the island off Victory Boulevard.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: There is a long tradition of giving money, called Hanukkah gelt, to children during Hanukkah. Some believe the custom dates back to the original Hanukkah celebration when Judas Maccabaeus rededicated the Temple in Jerusalem. But most scholars feel these gifts of pocket change to children originated in Eastern Europe during the Middle Ages.

title: Female Artists Offer Students Advice on Art and Creativity
description: THE artist Judy Chicago sent advice to a White Plains High School student, Susie Korn, and made drawings on the letter. Another artist, Jenny Holzer, sent a list of her ''Truisms'' - ''Lack of charisma can be fatal''; ''Loving animals is a substitute activity'' - to Amy Whittle, while the sculptor Mary Frank drew figures on the envelope of her letter to Esmeralda Cruz.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PITTSFIELD, MASS.;
Revitalizing Old England's
description: LEAD: ONE of this city's most prominent structures, the vacant England's department store building, has been bought by a developer who plans to renovate it for retailing and other uses.

title: Pot Luck
description: FOR A REFUGEE FROM A small town, Manhattan always feels like the luckiest place to be on New Year's Eve. It's the one night when my consort and I can walk out our front door and into the park at midnight to toast city life in an effervescence of fireworks and Champagne.

title: Q and A
description: Tax on an Apartment Sale

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SATELLITES;
A New Breed of Dishes Fuels Sales
description: LEAD: THE satellite communications industry is going through the same type of revolution that hit the computer field in the early 80's. Just as advances in the microprocessor let computer makers pack more power in smaller machines, gains in transmission technology and microelectronics are fueling a similar miniaturization wave in satellite equipment.

title: Beatrice ZenzieAnd G. B. GregoryTo Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Zenzie of Princeton, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Beatrice Wistar Zenzie and George Bradford Gregory, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Gregory of Los Angeles.

title: Age Not Stalling Giants' Anderson
description: In 1979, as a rookie, Ottis Anderson replaced Terry Metcalf as the St. Louis Cardinals' tailback. Today, Metcalf's son, Eric, is a rookie running back for the Cleveland Browns, and Anderson, now with the Giants, is at 32 the oldest starting running back in the National Football League.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Brains of the Mutants

title: Sidewalk Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE/On Music
description: For the daily reviewer, special events are like oases in a desert of routine. Here is where this writer drank last year.

title: Islanders Gain Edge With Sutter's 2 Goals
description: Heading into the final period, it had been anybody's game, anybody but a goaltender.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow is Christmas. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collection, recycling, or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways running on Sunday schedules; Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title:
MUSIC;
Horne Concert to Benefit Young Singers
description: LEAD: IT is a fitting tribute that the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne will be spending New Year's Eve at Symphony Hall in Newark, celebrating in performance and afterward with members of Opera/Music Theater International, which was formed three years ago. When the basso Jerome Hines founded the organization, which was established to bridge the gap between advanced vocal training and professional operatic careers, Ms.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Jake Barnes and Brett Ashley in ''The Sun Also Rises'' by Ernest Hemingway did not meet at the Deux Magots cafe in Paris, as Warren Obr said in his report on Paris hotels and restaurants. In Hemingway's novel, Barnes had been wounded in Italy in World War I and was invalided to a hospital in England. The book places his first encounter with Lady Brett during the war, which ended in 1918, and the action in Hemingway's story takes place in the 1920's.

title: Parental Attitudes And Education
description: Barry Edelson (''Parents Don't Really Care About Education,'' Opinion, Nov. 19) is right in his concern about the attitudes parents have regarding their children's education. Much research has shown that parental attitude is a major determinant of children's success in school.

title: Yes, Father, There Is a Santa
description: HOW do I begin to tell the story of the moment that changed my life forever? Although some of the details remain foggy, the major points are as clear as if they had happened yesterday.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Malaysia
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: Checklist: The Year's Outstanding Cassettes
description: Here are some of the most notable movies released (or reissued in special editions) on video in 1989. This year the studios concentrated on selling new releases as well as renting them, often dropping initial prices from the traditional $90 level to $25 and lower (''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' offered in October at $22.99, for example). Since by now prices vary widely from store to store, they are not listed. All films were released in theaters in 1988 unless otherwise noted. The Accused Paramount. 1 hour 50 minutes. Laser disk, Image Entertainment. Closed captioned. R.

title: .050 Hitter In Spotlight
description: IN baseball record books his first name is listed as Bill, a nickname, he said, he acquired as a student at Williams College. His legacy is one line in the record book: 20 times at bat, 1 hit, 3 walks, 2 runs batted in, and a lifetime batting average of .050.

title: Bethlehem Without Christmas
description: There are no decorations, no festivities in Bethlehem this Christmas. There will be church services for visitors, and six foreign choirs have come to sing in Nativity Square on Christmas Eve. But the people are staying silently in their homes. The holidays have been proclaimed a time of mourning and of protest.

title: Review/Dance; Dunham's 'Magic,' by Ailey Troupe (Jack Mitchell); April Berry in Shango, part of The Magic of Katherine Dunham. (Jack Mitchell)
description: One of Alvin Ailey's most inspired ideas was ''The Magic of Katherine Dunham,'' a program devoted to the black heritage in dance as popularized and introduced to a wide public by the foremost pioneer in the field.

title: Congress Wasn't Meant to Be a Lifetime Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Melvin E. Dawley Is Dead at 84; Retired Lord & Taylor Executive
description: Melvin Emerson Dawley, who spent 36 years with Lord & Taylor, the last 13 of them as the retail chain's chief executive officer, died Thursday at his home in Mountain Lake, a residential community in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 84 years old and, until a few months ago, also had a home in Bronxville, N.Y., where he was a longtime resident.

title: Always, There Was a Right Moment
description: LEAD: A HOUSE WITH FOUR ROOMS By Rumer Godden. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: MORE/On Dance
description: Downtown - or experimentalist - dance had a varied and vibrant year, with inspired work not only from performers and choreographers but from designers of lighting, sets and costumes as well as composers.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Some Lines On the Rest of The Millennium
description: Where is the world headed? The Week in Review asked a number of people to hazard some predictions about life in the 1990's. Some stuck their necks out farther than others, but, if experience is any guide, all of us are in for surprises. Economic Warfare

title: Fashion; Faking It: Jewels Down to Here Make a Real Splash
description: A simple little black dress and stupendous jewelry: that's the fashionable way to ring in the new year.

title: Q & A
description: Baby Sitters in London

title: Question of the Week; Will East German Athletes Continue to Dominate?
description: East German athletes will continue to dominate in the world of sports because of their spirit of competition and their pride. They, along with the Soviets, will still rule the world of gymnastics, swimming and ice skating in the Olympics. Politics has no influence on sports. CLEMENTE LISI New York

title: A Hobby Becomes an Obsession With Junk Mail
description: DENISON HATCH is a junk mail connoisseur. Stacks of cheese log catalogues, record club offers and vacuum cleaner deals fill a basement office in his Stamford home from floor to ceiling. File cabinets spill over with solicitations for such collectibles as Princess Diana porcelain dolls, Lady Liberty wristwatches and Dr. Seuss books by mail.

title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows
description: THE day is still not over, but shadows and the temperature have begun to fall quickly as Dave Stewart drives slowly down Center Street, turns left onto 15th and then finally pulls to a stop at Cypress Avenue. There are old, tired houses to his right and to his left, a barricade of yellow police tape in front of him and then a strange wide expanse of leveled earth beyond that, as if a bulldozer had suddenly pushed everything aside.

title:
GARDENING;
Holly, a Symbol of the Winter Solstice
description: LEAD: HOLLY has played an important role in midwinter festivals at least as far back as the Druids' celebration of the winter solstice. Once the shortest day of the year had passed, they knew that spring would bring forth rebirth. Plants that retained their green leaves throughout the winter were considered to be sacred; they were thought to be the repositories of the life that would return to plants that had lost their leaves and were considered to be dead.

title: Lisa Marvin to Wed Stephen Laico
description: The engagement of Melissa Elizabeth Marvin to Stephen Andrew Laico, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Laico Jr. of New City, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Nancy T. Marvin and John T. Marvin, both of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Lendl at Skydome
description: Top-ranked Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe head a field of 56 scheduled to play in the $1.5 million Skydome World Tennis event to be held Feb. 12-18. The tournament will mark the first time professional tennis is played at the Skydome and it is the first major event on the new Association of Tennis Professionals tour.

title:
IN SHORT: Nonfiction;
A Glimpse Into the Abyss
description: LEAD: The chaos and horror of the Oct. 17 earthquake in San Francisco is captured in FIFTEEN SECONDS: The Great California Earthquake of 1989 (The Tides Foundation/Island Press, Paper, $19.95), a collection of photographs and reportage chronicling the devastation wreaked in that fateful quarter-minute. ''A few days after the main shudder, they told us the quake had lasted only 15 seconds,'' wrote Stephanie Salter, a columnist at The San Francisco Examiner.

title: Little Roast Pigs in the Streets
description: BEAUTIES, BEASTS AND ENCHANTMENT Classic French Fairy Tales. Translated by Jack Zipes. Illustrated. 598 pp. New York: NAL Books/New American Library. $21.95. FRENCH FOLKTALES From the collection of Henri Pourrat. Selected by C. G. Bjurstrom. Translated by Royall Tyler. Illustrated. 484 pp. New York: Pantheon Fairy Tale and Folklore Library/ Pantheon Books. $21.95.

title: Review/Rock; D'Arby's Tribute To Soul Music
description: To be Marvin Gaye, Prince, Otis Redding, Sam Cooke, Stevie Wonder, James Brown and Bob Dylan rolled into one is a tall order - and it comes as no surprise that Terence Trent D'Arby, who has taken the job upon himself, falls short.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SATELLITES;
A More Reliable Link For Computer Networks
description: LEAD: For generations, truckers have known truck stops as a place to grab some coffee, chat with a waitress and telephone a company dispatcher to report their whereabouts. But advances in mobile satellite communications may eliminate the need to phone in.

title: IN SHORT: Fiction
description: LEAD: A VILLAGE AFFAIR. By Joanna Trollope. (Cornelia & Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $17.95.) Alice Jordan, the heroine of the British writer Joanna Trollope's most recent novel, is a welcome newcomer to the rural English village of Pitcombe, where almost everyone admires her unconventional beauty, three enchanting children, respectable if colorless husband and 18th-century manor house, the one possession Alice had been certain would make her happy.

title: High-Tech Fortunetelling
description: STRUNG ALONG THE 46 CHROMOSOMES of every human cell are some 100,000 genes. Among them, in each one of us, are a few that can be deadly. Every person has a unique set of these seven or eight lethal genes. They are usually hidden, but in the wrong environment or in combination with certain other genes they can express themselves in dangerous ways.

title: Miss Bartsch to Marry D. S. Osborn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Bartsch Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have made known the May wedding plans of their daughter Nancy Ellen Bartsch and David Shove Osborn, a son of James E. Osborn 2d of Greenwich, Conn., and Little Compton, R.I., and the late Nancy Brayton Osborn.

title: Winners, From Opera to Rags By Joplin
description: DOOMSAYERS, CULTURE AND capitalism seem to conspire these days, both in Europe and America, despite all evidence to the contrary. With classical recordings, beyond larger complaints about a decline in artistry among our composers and performers, one hears laments about the foreign ownership of formerly American record firms, about a pervasive middlebrowism in the choice of repertory, about the conglomeration of record corporations at the expense of the little label, and about compact disks driving small labels and marginal repertory from the marketplace.

title: When a Woman Hires A Detective or Lawyer
description: To the Editor:

title: Adverbially Yours
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Time off. Merry Christmas. Too Cold

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: One profession that has continually looked at eradicating a need for itself is dentistry. This is not being done by a group of second-rate, money-hungry clods, as described by Barbara Klaus in her article ''Smile, Darn You, Smile'' [ ''Long Island Sound,'' Dec. 3 ] . The work is being carried on by some of the brightest research and clinical people in the world who have created a 70 percent reduction in decay over the past 20 years, reduced the incidence of periodontal disease in adults, consistently improved the comfort of care, and contributed greatly to the overall good health of people the world over.

title: MacLean Sparks Devils
description: The Devils rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 3-2 triumph over the St. Louis Blues tonight, and the victory moved them into second place in the Patrick Division.

title: The King of Beers Raises the Ante
description: IT is obvious that it is the king around here. Drive past its mammoth corporate headquarters a few miles south of downtown, and you spy the people filing in, day after day, to board the bus tour, thread through the brewery and meander around the stable to gawk at the famous Clydesdales. Many of the faithful then pay further obeisance by snapping up souvenir shirts and mugs at the tour center and then - why not? - by quaffing samples of the brews.

title: MORE/On Film
description: It was a poor year for foreign films, a fine one for talented American newcomers and a year that found a number of cinematic mainstays going strong. It was also a year that brought a bumper crop of sorry spinoffs. None of my top 10 films is a sequel. ''BORN ON THE FOURTH OF JULY.'' Like all of Oliver Stone's films, this one aims directly for the solar plexus. It delivers a knockout punch. Mr. Stone's directorial bravado is hugely effective, even at its most reckless. Tom Cruise's devastating performance sets one man's nightmare against a brilliantly evoked backdrop of national tragedy.

title: SHOWDOWN AT WINDOW ROCK
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: THE TREE THAT CAME TO STAY
description: The day the tree came to stay the snow fell down with a hissing sound. The children saw each flake, for just a minute, sticking to the car windows, and then they melted and were gone. When the car climbed the big hill to the farm where they always found their Christmas tree, the wind whistled around them, and they felt warm behind the glass.

title: A Gift Wrapped in Anticipation
description: THE magic of Christmas is a fleeting gift of childhood. Once gone, it can almost never be recaptured. As the season approaches, a brief glimmer of a long ago Christmas will be recalled by a carol overheard, the sparkle of a decoration or the familiar scent of fresh pine. It comes and goes so quickly that sometimes we can scarcely identify what it is that brings on that feeling of excitement and anticipation we associate with a more innocent time in our lives.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Christmas Books: Beyond Santa Claus
description: LEAD: IN children's books, as everywhere around us, celebration has become not only an end in itself but also a subject in itself. Despite their charm, most of the cunning creatures that inhabit seasonal books - little mice, little men - are completely absorbed by the gingerbread, by the tree, and above all by the presents.

title: Trees Don't Vote
description: THE FATE OF THE FOREST Developers, Destroyers and Defenders of the Amazon. By Susanna Hecht and Alexander Cockburn. Illustrated. 266 pp. New York: Verso. $24.95.

title: MORE/On Theater
description: A diverse theatrical year was especially enhanced by revivals. These are the 10 most noteworthy plays, productions and events. ''SWEENEY TODD.'' A razor-sharp production of the Stephen Sondheim revenger's musical. In this intimate, environmental version, directed by Susan Schulman, Bob Gunton makes Sweeney's barbarous obsession tangible.

title: Social Life of Single Professionals
description: LEAD: DR. SUSAN GUNDUZ, a Northport pediatrician who is single and in her early 30's, was invited to the home of married friends for a party.

title: DES Victims: Search Must Go On
description: BY the end of this year, critical research into the effects of DES (diethylstilbestrol) will come to an end, despite the fact that millions of men and women born between 1941 and 1971 still suffer the effects of this ''wonder drug,'' and most of them still don't realize that the future may hold problems for them.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Civic Center Synagogue; Constrasting Styles Are Startling on White Street
description: THE Civic Center Synagogue at 47 White Street is just the kind of building planners warn against. Built in 1965, it replaced an unusual 1866 neo-Grec loft building, startlingly interrupting an otherwise intact 19th-century streetscape, one of the finest in the four proposed TriBeCa historic districts, or even in the city.

title:
ART;
'Connecticut Now' in New Britain
description: LEAD: THE ''Connecticut Now'' exhibition at the New Britain Museum of American Art is not the massive survey of recent art the title may portend, but rather the work of four artists who are inter-related in stimulating ways. At a time when the art world in general has no overriding direction, the personal but strong styles of these four fit right in with the current mood.

title: Familiarity And Isolation
description: Since Sunny Trefman [ ''Familiarity: Worth the Risk,'' Nov. 12 ] has bothered to comment on my essay, I would like to reply, partly because a correction is required.

title: An Anniversary Celebration and Cause Celebre
description: IT WAS THE YEAR OF PHOTOGRA-phy's sesquicentennial. A year that most museums spent celebrating the medium's past, while a courageous few tried to sort out its present. A year when the International Center of Photography launched a new, ambitious presence in midtown Manhattan and the Friends of Photography, in San Francisco, opened its long-awaited Ansel Adams Center. But overshadowing all the positive energy of the last 12 months was the controversial figure of Robert Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March at the age of 42.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Back in 1979, The Word Was Malaise
description: THE 1970's were not all bad by any means. But by the time 1979 was entering its final weeks, feelings of gloom were so heavy that even some of President Carter's detractors had to admit he had a point: the country was suffering from a bad case of malaise. Sometimes it seemed that the decade would never end.

title: Fighting in Panama: Overview; G.I.'s in Panama Report Gains in Restoring Order
description: The American military commander here said today that his forces had begun to make significant progress in restoring order in Panama City and the countryside. But there was no indication that the American forces had made any progress toward one of their main goals, the capture of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the dictator who went into hiding when the Americans invaded this country four days ago.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold $96,500 41 Tulip Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old condominium apartment; porch, w/w carpeting, c/a; monthly maintenance $123, taxes $2,367. Jackson $112,900 387 Route 528 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,401. Lakewood $147,500 136 Adelaide Place 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; c/a, front porch, 2-car garage, den; taxes $2,637. Livingston $510,000 66 Shrewsbury Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, c/a, den w/fireplace, deck; taxes $7,390. Maplewood $237,500 56 Salter Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, sun room; taxes $3,809. Spring Lake Heights $160,000 555 Monmouth Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 5-year-old condominium town house; c/a, patio, dining room; monthly maintenance $85, taxes $1,691. OTHER AREAS Stony Brook, L.I. $160,000 2 Mystic Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, fireplace, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,000. Scarsdale, N.Y. $350,500 174 Ferndale Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 69-year-old Norman Tudor; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, deck, playroom; taxes $5,016. Branford, Conn. $161,000 30 Pine Orchard Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; h/w floors, attic, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,261.

title: A CHURCH WITHOUT PRIESTS
description: IN ITS FORMER LIFE, SAN PATRICIO'S WAS A HIGH-SCHOOL band hall. Even now, a placard announcing Sunday Mass at noon and a white wooden cross over the front door are the only outward and visible signs that this mustard-colored square structure with its gray tar-paper roof is a church. A landscape of bare fields, punctuated by cattle, oil rigs, low, crawling cactus and mesquite stretches out from the church and the town of Throckmorton, Tex. - Pop. 1,174. On the way up from Abilene, there have been few landmarks of note, other than an occasional nose-diving coyote, lashed to a fence post, tail in the air.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Zimbabwe
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History
description: What happened? Morning in America, hole in the ozone, Oliver North, AIDS, terrorists, contras like Founding Fathers, $640 toilet seats, triumph of democracy, just say no. 1980 It's America vs. the Soviet Union, Khomeini, Castro, inflation and Jimmy Carter.

title: QUESTIONS FOR THE COSMOS
description: TO THE EDITOR: Has anyone replicated Robert Jahn's experiments in the area of psychokinesis? If they are as carefully designed as he claims, anyone should be able to set them up and get similar results. Has Professor Jahn allowed an outsider who is knowledgeable about computers, statistics and laboratory loopholes to observe his experiments?

title: Officials See No Quick End To Hard Times for Neediest
description: In some ways, the face of need has changed little since Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, encountered a homeless beggar on Christmas Day 1911 and decided to start the Neediest Cases Fund drive. But to long-time experts in the social services it is markedly different.

title: Fashion: On the Street; There Arose Such a Clatter!
description: As the shopping days till Christmas dwindled down to a precious few, New Yorkers did what comes naturally to New Yorkers. They scurried about midtown in every direction, creating a sort of free-form street theater, with every stroller an actor, every block a stage.

title: Who Cares What the Neighbors Think?
description: PORTRAIT OF DAVID HOCKNEY By Peter Webb. Illustrated. 289 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $35.

title: The Books He Left Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East: Overview; RUMANIAN INSURGENTS CAPTURE CEAUSESCU; HIS POLICE BATTLE WITH ARMY FOR SURVIVAL
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, the deposed Communist President of Rumania, was reported captured today as the army continued to do battle with the dictator's powerful security police in Bucharest and in at least half a dozen other Rumanian cities.

title: Irish Harps
description: To the Editor: We were disappointed with a couple of points in the article ''Finding an Authentic Irish Harp'' (Travel, Oct. 8). My harps are played by classical and traditional players, and I make both gut- and nylon-strung harps. My lever system is not operated by rotating an off-center screw, it's adjusted by doing so. All gut-strung harps are sensitive to humidity changes; this does not mean that mine are any more sensitive than anyone else's.

title: Cause for Alarm
description: FINAL WARNING Averting Disaster in the New Age of Terrorism. By Robert Kupperman and Jeff Kamen. 249 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Fighting for Their Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown. On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass. Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: Years ago, if you watched Bill Cosby, Danny Kaye or Tim Conway, you could see humorous sketches about dentists. Today, things are totally different. Barbara Klaus, a person who wants to inflict pain on dentists to compensate for the fact that she is not funny, couldn't get into comedy school and obviously failed whatever writing courses she might have taken.

title: Fighting in Panama; Secret U.S. Fighter Jet Is Tried Out in Panama
description: The United States used its radar-evading F-117 'Stealth fighter-bomber for the first time in the Panama invasion this week, the Defense Department said tonight.

title: Gina Valenti to Wed Robert Sansone
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark Valenti of Smithtown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gina Marie Valenti, to Robert Blake Sansone, the son of Robert Sansone of Marina Del Rey, Calif., and New York, and Marietta Sansone of Watchung, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: Robinson Legacy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ruth C. Wysor Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Geoffrey Wysor Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ruth Clifton Wysor to Robert Leonard Straus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Straus of Jersey City. An April wedding is planned.

title: 'Valentine & Orson'
description: To the Editor:

title: A DRAPERY MAKER IS SLAIN IN BRONX
description: A 61-year-old drapery manufacturer was stabbed to death at his factory in the Bronx yesterday while his wife waited for him in the office upstairs, the police said.

title: Moonless Meditations
description: DYAD By Michael Brodsky. 299 pp. New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. Cloth, $23.95. Paper, $11.95.

title: Knicks' Odd Cast Overtakes Nets
description: Would you believe that the Knicks could win a game with the improbable team of Patrick Ewing, Trent Tucker, Kenny Walker, Pete Myers and Rod Strickland on the floor?

title: Crack Smoking Seen as a Peril to Lungs
description: Doctors report that heavy crack smoking appears to be causing a growing number of addicts to become critically ill with symptoms similar to those of pneumonia. They say the condition is not easily detected unless the patients reveal their crack habits, but if it is not treated properly it can lead to death.

title: Deborah J. Kroll To Wed in March
description: A March wedding is planned by Deborah Jayne Kroll and George Henry Weltman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Weltman of Stamford, Conn., the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome I. Kroll of Manhasset, L.I., have announced.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: South River
description: A WALK through South River is a stroll through New Jersey's past. The center of the 2.8-square-mile borough, which was once the commercial hub of western Middlesex County, has changed little since the turn of the century, when most of its houses and stores were built. Main Street still has a 5 & 10, a Chinese laundry and a barber shop with a barber pole out front. And the borough's two hardware stores carry many items that would only be needed by owners of 19th and early 20th century houses. ''The traditional small town values we see here are quickly disappearing all over the United States,'' said Ann J. Rafano, chairwoman of the newly formed South River Historical Society. ''People look out for each other. That's why I wouldn't like to live anywhere else.''

title: Happy Soft Landings
description: HOW SOFT A LANDING?'' headlines the latest newsletter of economic commentary from the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.

title: How Handicapped Students Enrich Campus Life
description: AT two of the commencement exercises at Rutgers University I attended, there were a small number of handicapped students who received diplomas.

title: Tracy Margel Engaged To Adam K. Bernstein
description: Tracy Jill Margel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Margel of Villanova, Pa., and Adam K. Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Bernstein of Washington, are planning an April wedding.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SATELLITES;
Tracking the Movement of Planes and Trucks
description: LEAD: Increasingly, corporations are flocking to a new satellite technology to relay information from computers at one site to those at another. While it has been available since the early 1980's, this new genre of satellite dish, called very-small-aperture terminals, or V.S.A.T.'s, are only now becoming popular because many of their kinks have been worked out and their cost has dropped, to around $10,000 per location, from about $70,000.

title: QUESTIONS FOR THE COSMOS
description: TO THE EDITOR: Congratulations to Prof. Robert Jahn of Princeton for having the courage to pursue his investigation of psychic phenomena (''Questions for the Cosmos,'' by Steve Fishman, Nov. 26). That is exciting. But as one who has participated in informal experiments testing such things as telepathy and psychometry (with startling results) and as someone who has read widely in the literature, I would ask: How many times do we have to prove that ESP exists? And when are we going to spend more of our resources investigating how and why it happens? Those surely are the questions we should be asking. GRACE E. HINRICHS Canandaigua, N.Y

title: POSTINGS: Luxury on West 86th; A Russian Deal
description: In an unusual real estate deal, two Manhattan developers have gone into partnership with a Russian philanthropy to tack nine stories onto the philanthropy's Upper West Side town- house headquarters. The expanded building will contain ll luxury apartments and 3,200 square feet of doctors' offices, as well as new headquarters space for the philanthropy, the Russian Aid Society, which will share in revenues from the medical space.

title: Ellen Healy and William Cross Wed
description: Ellen Patricia Healy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Healy Jr. of Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York to William Redmond Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Cross Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass. The Rev. Brian Lathrop, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Richard Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Fighting in Panama: Statements; Key Sections From Briefing By the General
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference by Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman in Panama as transmitted by CNN:

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Nov. 12 about writers and their sources of inspiration misattributed an account of the poet Hart Crane's boisterous behavior at parties. A reader has written to point out that the author of the account was Malcolm Cowley, not Malcolm Lowry.

title: The Ritual of Season's Greetings
description: FOR weeks I've been hearing friends complain that they are sick of Christmas, or, at least, its more secular aspects. They have been especially fed up, they say, with that longstanding ritual of season's greetings.

title:
INVESTING;
Toy Companies' Tidings of Joy
description: LEAD: ONCE again this holiday season, Nintendo is playing the grinch who steals Christmas from the United States toy industry. Sales of the Japanese company's video games could gobble up almost 20 percent of the toy market this year.

title: Swig Sweetly
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE without Champagne? Better the Fourth of July without hot dogs. Or Thanksgiving without turkey. But wait: there is another wine for great occasions, one many wine drinkers would say outclasses Champagne any day. We're talking about Sauternes, the favorite of the tsars, the most famous sweet wine in the world.

title: Tina Sue Rosenbaum To Wed Neal Kurzner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Erich Rosenbaum of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter Tina Sue Rosenbaum to Neal Steven Kurzner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Raymond Kurzner of New York. A March wedding is planned.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY MANORS;
Christmas the Way It (Really) Used to Be
description: LEAD: Now Christmas has come,

title: Karen Helle to Wed David Nemiah
description: May wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Helle of New Canaan, Conn., for their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Helle, and David Stewart Nemiah, a son of Dr. John C. Nemiah of Hanover, N.H., and Mrs. William Geist of Rehoboth Beach, Del.

title: Elizabeth McDaniel Wed at Villanova
description: Elizabeth Chase McDaniel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Chase McDaniel 2d of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to Malcolm John Sutherland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Olin Raymond Jackson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Villanova (Pa.) University Chapel.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Mexico
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Poland; Opening Way for Aid, Poland Agrees to Economic Change
description: Poland agreed to far-reaching economic changes in return for as much as $4 billion in Western aid in a letter of intent signed today with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Style Makers; Stephan Van Dam, Map Publisher
description: Stephan Van Dam's career as a map publisher and design entrepreneur began with origami. Such was his fascination with the Japanese art of paper folding that the Swiss-born designer, 30 years old, came up with ''The World Unfolds,'' an award-winning series of maps that presented the lay of the land in major cities in the United States in tidy, fold-up booklets small enough to put in a purse.

title: Getting Breaks On Hotel Rates
description: THIS is how a $150-a-night hotel room became an $85-a-night room: Last October, planning a trip to San Diego, I called the Sheraton Harbour Island Hotel for rate information. The reservations clerk said the standard room rate was $150. I plunged ahead:

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: Of all of the labels known generically as cinderellas, Christmas seals have proved the most consistently attractive to collectors.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown. On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass. Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?

title: A Nation Divided by a Common Passion
description: ITALY, you might say, is a country where everyone likes football, but doesn't like one another. In terms of soccer towns (which means almost all of them) and soccer teams, it remains essentially a collection of city states, which have only in name been welded into a single nation. The longstanding notion in the north is that from Rome on down, it's no longer Italy, it's Africa. Still more bigoted northerners insist that Africa begins just north of Rome. SPQR, insist such detractors, does not stand for the Latin words, Senate and people of Rome but for sono porici questi Romani: these Romans are pigs.

title: In Riverdale, Glasnost Goes to School
description: In the Bronx, glasnost translates into Michael Kirsanov biting into his first hamburger and Nadya Barabanov watching soap operas like ''Days of Our Lives'' and ''Santa Barbara.''

title: Philharmonic Ensemble Striving for a Rebound
description: THE gift of music is precious, but it cannot always be taken for granted. A case in point is an orchestra that music lovers in the county almost lost.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Having spent a pleasant few days at La Residence du Bois in Paris at the end of May, I agree wholeheartedly with Warren Obr's description of the facilities (''Paris: Comfort and Good Coffee,'' Travel, Oct. 8). However, I do not agree with his description of the prices. I paid 1,350 francs, which made the price of a double room approximately $212. Mr. Obr's article quoted the price as $154.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PORT ST. LUCIE, FLA.;
New Community On 4,600 Acres
description: LEAD: SALES of home sites to builders and individuals are on the rise at St. Lucie West, a master-planned community of individual neighborhoods near the $11.2 million sports complex where the New York Mets hold spring training.

title: Helena Malone Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Malone of Cuffs Grange, County Kilkenny, Ireland, have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Helena K. Malone and Mitchell B. Vidur, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Vidur of Woodbury, L.I. Mr. Vidur owns U.S. Rides, a limousine service in Port Washington, L.I., and New York. His father is a lawyer in Brooklyn. His mother, Dolores Vidur, is in the accounting department of the Melville, L.I., advertising agency of Greenstone Rabasca Roberts.

title: Stephanie S. Scherer To Wed Eric Young
description: The engagement of Stephanie Susan Scherer to Eric David Young, a son of Paula Young of Oceanside, L.I., and Carl Young of White Plains, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Scherer of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: Long Island Guide
description: WINTER GARDENS

title:
ART;
Still Lifes, Delicately Perceived by a Camera
description: LEAD: IN Dency Kane's fruit and vegetable still lifes, on view through Jan. 10 in the Media Port Gallery at the Port Washington Public Library, the camera functions as an instrument of both intensification and transformation. It pushes perception to a higher level of awareness, while at the same time injecting an element of doubt about photography's fabled veracity.

title: An Explosion Of Exceptional Dancing
description: VIRTUE, AS THE CHINESE SAYING goes, is not hereditary - and neither, to offer a paraphrase, is talent. Dynasties of the gifted might argue otherwise. But the explosion of exceptional dancing that marked 1989 had less to do with genes than with plain hard work - dedication and commitment from the performers.

title: China's Lonely Press Tries to Look the Other Way
description: Fearful of reviving its own domestic opposition, the Chinese leadership has kept much of the extraordinary change in Eastern Europe out of the press.

title: Others Fought In Noble Battle
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: UNDER GOD'S SPELL: Frontier Evangelists, 1722-1915. By Cathy Luchetti. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $27.95.) One of the most fascinating things about revivalism is how it reproduces itself, re-creating even in the contemporary world a mood of apostolical preaching established millenniums before. Evangelical Christianity on the American frontier is the focus of ''Under God's Spell,'' a collection of diary entries by 19th-century missionaries; the book also contains an 18-page introductory essay about general aspects of this phenomenon by Cathy Luchetti, the co-author of ''Women of the West.

title: INSIDE
description: Natural-Gas Demand Soars The recent bitter cold across much of the nation has left dozens of utilities and large industrial customers scrambling to secure enough energy to avoid shortages. Page 20. Gorbachev Warns Baltics The Soviet President criticized those seeking secession from the Soviet Union, saying any such move would ''sow discord, bloodshed and death.'' Page 17. Tutu Backs Palestinians As troops and protesters clashed in Bethlehem, Archbishop Desmond Tutu began a pilgrimage to the Holy Land, offering support for the creation of a Palestinian state. Page 3. Egyptian-Syrian Relations Syria and Egypt appear ready to end a 12-year break in diplomatic relations within the next few weeks, officials said. Page 3. News summary, page 2 Obituaries, page 22

title: Fixing the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNY Adopts Race-Bias Plan
description: Concerned about a growing number of racial incidents on campuses, the State University of New York is planning several steps to defuse trouble before it gets out of hand, officials said last week.

title: That's Shoe Biz
description: THE RUBY SLIPPERS OF OZ By Rhys Thomas. Illustrated. 232 pp. Los Angeles: Tale Weaver Publishing. Paper, $14.95.

title: A Treetop Only Wings And Hopes Can Touch
description: The nation's official Christmas tree is not the 70-foot Norway spruce at Rockefeller Center in New York City, the 38-foot blue spruce on the Ellipse in Washington or the 18-foot Fraser fir at the White House, all of them strung with ornaments and lit with great ceremony at this time of year.

title: 'Teutonically Inspired' Fare in Stamford
description: DEVOTEES of the Atlantic Market in the Springdale section of Stamford, the meat market and delicatessen that sells freshly made bratwurst, weisswurst and other German-style standbys, have cause for celebration.

title: Fourth New Year's Eve for Safe Ride Home
description: LEAD: FOR the fourth year, the White Plains Hospital Medical Center is offering Safe Ride Home for those who feel they have had too much to drink to drive home on New Year's Eve.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: On behalf of the members of the Suffolk County Dental Society, I am writing to object to the scurrilous article on dentistry.

title: Ms. Rassias Wed To David Smith
description: Veronika Aphrodite Rassias, a daughter of John A. Rassias and Mary Anne Evanstock Rassias of Norwich, Vt., was married yesterday to David Markwood Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kent D. Smith of Monterey, Mass. The bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Gould Farm in Monterey.

title: Muslim Head Covering Far Different From Veil
description: To the Editor:

title: New Lives for Some Vintage Firehouses
description: THEY were built around the turn of the century, to house the horse-drawn equipment that firefighters used to keep Connecticut's towns safe. Now, many vintage firehouses are gone, but a few scattered throughout Connecticut have been transformed into museums, restaurants and, in at least one case, a home. Gradually departments have vacated the older buildings because the fire equipment was too large or fire companies within departments were consolidated.

title: Campus Life: Stanford; Ban on Alcohol At Sports Events Being Considered
description: After beer brawls and 30 arrests at Stanford University's last football game of the season, the university is considering banning alcohol at all its sport events.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Planning; U.S. Invasion: Many Weeks of Rehearsals
description: The Bush Administration laid the foundation for the attack against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega weeks ago by drafting new military plans, rehearsing them and secretly moving tanks and helicopters to Panama in case President Bush decided to order United States forces into action, senior Administration officials said.

title:
GARDENING;
Holly, a Symbol of the Winter Solstice
description: LEAD: HOLLY has played an important role in midwinter festivals at least as far back as the Druids' celebration of the winter solstice. Once the shortest day of the year had passed, they knew that spring would bring forth rebirth. Plants that retained their green leaves throughout the winter were considered to be sacred; they were thought to be the repositories of the life that would return to plants that had lost their leaves and were considered to be dead.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Singapore
description: In a remarkable combination of will, foresight and happenstance, what began as a swampy island only 85 miles from the Equator has been transformed into the most modern, efficient and simply the cleanest city of Southeast Asia. The last is not a bad attribute in a part of the world where sanitation is more talked about than practiced.

title: Caution: Model Trains Can Cause Derailment From Reality
description: THE toy train is making a comeback this season as one of the most popular holiday gift items. Good, old-fashioned fun, parents might think as they consider the purchase. Nostalgic, romantic, quaint. But hold on. Take it from a train widow. These contraptions can be dangerous.

title: Anne Lewin, Lingerie Designer, Weds
description: Anne Maree Lewin and Scott Alexander Frances were married yesterday at the Union League Club in New York by the Rev. Richard Davis Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The bride is the daughter of John Charles Lewin of Townsville, North Queensland, Australia, and Wendy Maree Lewin of Brisbane, Queensland, Australia. Mr. Frances is a son of Evan Frances Agnew of New York and the late Alexander Frances of New York.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Uruguay
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watchthe people, or be watched by tigers.

title: Crystalline Ice Fantasies In Frozen Manchuria
description: FAR north of China's Great Wall, a city of crystalline sculptured ice emitting colored light transforms long frozen winters into a fantasyland. The annual Ice Lantern Festival in Harbin, capital of the northeastern border province of Heilungkiang and once a city of many Russians, celebrates the lunar new year like no other place in China.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Japan
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: Upheaval in the East: Emigres; From Abroad, Uncertainty And Grieving
description: Mujur Stancu held a candle and wept yesterday as he sang and prayed in St. Dimitru's Church for the thousands of his countrymen who have been killed in Rumania this week.

title: Chief Democrat Urges Higher Ethics
description: DEMOCRATIC leaders in the county said last week that they were confident that their party's newly elected chief, Dennis Mehiel, could help them gain control of both the executive and legislative branches of the county - a goal that has eluded them for the 51 years of modern Westchester government.

title: White Plains Is Moving to Fill Its Few Empty Sites
description: White Plains took major steps last week toward completing the postwar transformation of its once languid commercial and residential center into a business and retail hub that already attracts 250,000 office workers and shoppers a day.

title: Joanna L. Fowler, Student, to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Howland Auchincloss Fowler of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanna Louise Fowler, to Eric Carl Jonsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Rey Jonsson of Honolulu. An August wedding is planned. Miss Fowler graduated from the National Cathedral School for Girls and Princeton University and expects to receive an M.B.A. degree from Stanford University in June. Her father is a physicist at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Gaithersburg, Md.

title: Double Standard
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PRESSURING PERDUE
description: TO THE EDITOR: Short of becoming a vegetarian, consumers with concern for other species can:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everywhere people were falling around me. I do not know how many there were. I was too afraid to even begin to count.'' - Gyorgy Kondra of Timisoara, Rumania. [ 14:2. ]

title: Talks Are Recessed in Coal Strike
description: Negotiators for the United Mine Workers union and the Pittston Company failed in an effort today to reach a settlement before Christmas in a bitter strike by 1,700 miners in three states.

title: Lovers and Other Pedants
description: SHIRA By S. Y. Agnon. Translated by Zeva Shapiro. Afterword by Robert Alter. 585 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $24.95.

title: French Name, Italian Heart and Soul
description: HOLIDAY party chitchat often centers on food and restaurants. The most animated conversations target the new, the innovative, the unusual. Far less attention is given to venerable doyens that dot the island.

title: C. S. Lewis, Sins and All
description: LEAD: A CHILD pushed open the door of the wardrobe so as to hide in it. It was, however, no ordinary wardrobe. It was hung with fur coats. The child pressed on further through the dark recesses of the cupboard, pushing aside the soft folds of fur and discovering beyond them a new world. What crunched beneath the feet was not mothballs but snow.

title: Question Of the Week: Next Week; How Will Sports Change in The 1990's?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Humbug: When Gifts Become Problems
description: THE Swatch watch doesn't tick; the picture on the Sony television is fuzzy; the mittens you sent your daughter from the mail-order house don't match. As the long-awaited unveiling of gifts gets under way this holiday season, a lot can - and often does - go wrong. What recourse do gift givers and recipients have?

title: John Parker, 89, Dies; Electronics Executive
description: John E. Parker, an investment banker and business executive who was chairman of the Bunker-Ramo Corporation and other companies in the electronic and computer data programming fields, died of colon cancer yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Barbara Linsenmeyer to Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Linsenmeyer of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Linsenmeyer, to Thomas Patrick Malone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Thomas Malone of Street, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Thailand
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: Winter Wedding For Miss Green And R. P. Rule
description: The engagement of Regina Steuart Green, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick John Green Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mr. Green, to Richard Paul Rule, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Roderick Rule of Sarasota, Fla., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother. A February wedding is planned.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: In the Kindergarten of the Heart Small boys sometimes have a finer perception of femininity than grown men. Here's an infant voluptuary from ''The Snows of Yesteryear: Portraits for an Autobiography'' by Gregor von Rezzori (Knopf).

title: U.P.I.: Look Back in Sorrow
description: DOWN TO THE WIRE UPI's Fight for Survival. By Gregory Gordon and Ronald E. Cohen. Illustrated. 429 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: THE VIOLENT DECADE. By Frank Gervasi. (Norton, $25.) Frank Gervasi, a journalist who was based in Europe in the late 1930's and during World War II, re-creates in ''The Violent Decade'' the chaos of life during those eventful times. The writing is precise - detailed, accurate and colorful - and the first-person account allows the reader to know not only the characters responsible for earth-shattering events but the people whose shattered lives Mr.

title: Karen Perlmutter Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Perlmutter of Greensboro, N.C., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Karen Wendy Perlmutter and Neil Harrison Koffler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Koffler of Newport Beach, Calif. Ms. Perlmutter, 23 years old and a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, is a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at St. John's University in New York. Mr. Koffler, 23, also graduated from Penn. He is an associate at Siegler, Collery & Company, an investment concern in New York.

title: O'Brien Has Surgery
description: The surgery on Ken O'Brien's right shoulder went as planned on Friday and the Jets' quarterback is expected to be ready for training camp next summer. In any event, he is not going to be permitted to throw in minicamp next April.

title: Sports People; All-Stars and Stripes
description: WHEN the Blue-Gray All-Star football game is played in Montgomery, Ala., tomorrow, Charlie Finley will be glowing like a Yuletide log. As owner of the Oakland Athletics, Finley gave baseball brightly colored uniforms and white shoes and the designated hitter and even lobbied for an orange baseball. Now his push for a fluorescent-striped football is reaching paydirt.

title: Upheaval in the East: Atrocities; Hatred of Security Forces Growing As Rumanian Atrocities Increase
description: ''It's the Securitate,'' yelled a burly man, leaning out of the open door of the small white car as it careened, horn honking and lights blazing, down a dark and empty boulevard. ''They're shooting again, the bastards.''

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BOTANICAL ART

title: Carolyn TomminsEngaged to Wed
description: Carolyn Patricia Tommins and William Arthur Whalen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Whalen of Bronxville, N.Y., plan to marry in the spring, the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Tommins of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced.

title: Prime Time Returned to the Past
description: AS THE 1980'S AND THE REAGAN era came to a close, much of television's arts and entertainment programming, like the nation, seemed exhausted. The optimism bubble that characterized the decade and its yuppie cheerleaders suddenly burst, exposing a series of long-festering crises: the homeless, AIDS, environmental pollution, political scandals, multibillion-dollar bailouts of financial institutions, mountains of governmental, corporate and private debt. The list appears endless. Little wonder, then, that television in 1989 seemed so curiously eager to return to the past.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Gerard F. Vallone;
Children and Philosophy in the Classroom
description: LEAD: SOCRATES, Plato and Aristotle, among others, asked questions about ethics and life that are still being asked today. But these days sometimes it is children who are doing the asking.

title: Baseball Notebook; Whatever the Sport, Bo Jackson Makes Contact
description: FOOTBALL, which Bo Jackson will play at Giants Stadium today, is a contact sport. So is baseball, which Jackson also plays. While Jackson has shown improvement in avoiding contact in football this year, he has displayed improvement in making contact in baseball.

title: Pope Supports Arab League In Efforts on Lebanon Peace
description: Pope John Paul II told Arab League envoys today that they had his support as they seek to negotiate a peace accord for Lebanon.

title: Tiffany Collection Set For the Benton in Storrs
description: A COLLECTION of 100 Tiffany lamps, windows and vases, from the largest collection of Tiffany art in the world, appears headed to a permanent home at the William Benton Museum of Art in Storrs.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''There is real panic in Detroit. Incentives are going to continue increasing all year.'' - Ronald A. Glantz, analyst, Montgomery Securities, after Ford said it would match Chrysler's $1,000 mini-van rebates.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Old Order; The Collapse Of Stalinism
description: With the collapse of President Nicolae Ceausescu's regime in Rumania, Stalinism, the system of incorporating Communist power in a single, all-powerful leader, has crumbled in every Eastern European Communist country except Albania.

title: Setting High Tech Free
description: Earlier this month U S West Inc. made a successful bid to lay a fiber-optics network in the Soviet Union. Last week, the Commerce Department indicated it would allow the deal to go through. The decision could signal a willingness by the United States to ease restrictions on high-tech exports. These exports are currently limited by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, called Cocom, which includes 17 Western countries. Will Cocom change its rules? Four experts discuss its future. Donald M. Kendall Chairman of the executive committee, Pepsico Inc.

title: Personal Voices Made Plays Worth Watching
description: THERE CAN HARDLY BE ANY doubt that the playwright who mattered most in 1989 was Vaclav Havel. In a year when the world was changing as fast as, if not faster than, at any other time in this century, Mr. Havel was one of the people who changed it - first as a dissident dramatist and now as a political leader shaping the future of Czechoslovakia. But such is the perennial chaos of the New York theater - sometimes a creative chaos, sometimes not - that even Mr. Havel wasn't spared its typically rude shocks in 1989. In April, his play ''Temptation'' received its American premiere in a wildly distorted production that came and went in a quickly forgotten instant Off Broadway even as its author passed in and out of jail in Prague.

title: Sports People; Tarpley's Future
description: THE National Basketball Association says it has no plans to reinstate Roy Tarpley. Tarpley, a Dallas Maverick forward, was suspended without pay by the league after he was arrested on Nov. 16 on charges of driving while intoxicated and resisting arrest.

title: Rachel Somers Marries Barry Siegel
description: Rachel A. Somers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Laurence Somers of Lafayette Hill, Pa., was married last evening to Barry J. Siegel, a son of Howard Siegel of Emerson, N.J., and Phyllis Burstein of Springfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alan D. Fuchs at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: DINING OUT Attractive Atmosphere in a New Hotel
description: LEAD: RESTAURANT owners often complain that reviewers visit their establishments too soon after they have opened. While it is true that restaurants need a certain amount of time to establish a working pattern, sometimes the end result is more mediocre than one might have assumed it would be in the beginning.

title: PRESSURING PERDUE
description: TO THE EDITOR: I am puzzled. What do Henry Spira's cats eat? A survey of the cat-food shelves at my local supermarket shows no cat food, canned or dry, that does not contain animal products. After sharpening their claws on Mr. Spira's politically correct Naugahyde furniture, do his cats hunt, kill and eat mice? Rats? Birds? ROBERT BARRETT San Francisco

title: Maryland Judge Hurt by Bomb Is Improving
description: A Maryland judge injured on Friday when a pipe bomb exploded at his Hagerstown apartment was reported to be in good condition today by a spokeswoman for Washington County Hospital.

title: NEWS SUMMAR
description: International 3-17 Nicolae Ceausescu was captured by insurgent Army troops, which continued to battle against the deposed Rumanian dictator's powerful state security police in several cities. 1 More atrocities by the security forces are being reported by frightened and angry Rumanians. Citizens in Timisoara lined up to view corpses exhumed from mass graves. Many had apparently been tortured. 11 Gunfire and confusion tempers a city's elation 14 The Rumanian Embassy in the U.S. denounced deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, joining a dozen other Rumanian delegations that declared support for the insurgents. 15 Warsaw Pact aid for Rumania was pushed by the Soviet President, Mikhail Gorbachev, but the Kremlin downplayed suggestions that military assistance would be considered. 16 The man who could become Rumania's leader 15 Outlook is uncertain for Rumanian democracy, experts say 16 News analysis: The fall of Stalinism has now reached every Eastern European country except Albania. President Ceausescu of Rumania began his career as a reformer, but ended it as an unflinching Stalinist despot. 1 Baltic separatists were condemned by President Gorbachev, who warned that nationalist movements to secede from the Soviet Union would ''sow discord, bloodshed and death.'' 17 Havel and Dubcek to assume leading Czech posts 17 American forces are restoring order in Panama City, Gen. Maxwell Thurman said, but there was no indication they had made progress toward the capture of Gen. Manuel Noriega. 1 The U.S. drafted plans for invading Panama weeks ago. The Pentagon rehearsed new military plans and secretly moved tanks and helicopters to Panama before the President ordered the invasion. 1 President Bush's decision to invade was inevitable 9 Panama's Army will be disbanded and replaced by a more modest public security force, the newly-installed civilian Government announced in its first major action. 8 The suspect in the Pan Am bombing over Scotland last year, Mohammed Abu Talb, has been identified by investigators after a year of sleuthing, toil and a chain of luck. 1 A remote tribe of Indians in Brazil, considered the last major tribe untouched by modern civilization in the Americas, is struggling for its survival as society reaches into the Amazon. 6 Archbishop Tutu visited Bethlehem on a Christmas pilgrimage as Israeli troops and Palestinian protesters clashed in the Holy Land. He pledged support for a Palestinian state 3 Egypt and Syria appear ready to resume diplomatic relations 3 Two Shiite militias battle in southern Lebanon 4 Reporter's Notebook: Picking up litter in Scott's footsteps 6 National 18-20 President Bush's budget next year will encourage personal saving and include modest spending increases for drug control, education, science, research and the environment. 18 Clean needles and bleach for addicts may not be enough to protect them against AIDS because of other routes of infection, like sharing of paraphernalia and the water used to prepare drugs, experts say. 19 An added danger of crack smoking appears to be a deadly condition with symptoms similar to those of pneumonia. Doctors in inner-city hospitals in Detroit are reporting an average of a case a day of ''crack lung.'' 19 The heavy demand for natural gas has utilities and large industrial consumers scrambling to get enough energy to avoid shortages and plant shutdowns as bitter cold hits the nation. 20 U.S. moves to block potential shortages of fuels for heating 20 Artic air pushes snow into the South, threatening crops 20 Legal notices and freedom of speech have been debated in Federal court in Florida. A judge said a sheriff was wrong to withdraw the notices from a local newspaper after it published a critical article. 18 Seattle span opens accidently; woman is killed 20 A treetop that only wings and hopes can touch 18 Regional 21-24 The harsh cold loosened its grip a bit on New York City. A ''veritable heat wave,'' with temperatures in the mid- to high 20s, is expected today and Christmas Day - but no snow. 21 Racial incidents at SUNY campuses have prompted school officials to take steps to defuse tensions before they get out of hand. 23 Soviet children in public schools in New York City are learning about America and teaching about Russia. In the era of glasnost, sons and daughters of Soviet diplomats are venturing beyond their compound in Riverdale. 21 A would-be patron slashes two doormen at nightclub 21 Neediest Cases 21 Arts/Reviews 36 Campus Life 27 Fashion 30-31 Life Style 28 Obituaries 22 Melvin Dawley, former retail executive Pastimes 37-39 Gardening: Medieval traditions decorate the Cloisters 37 Weddings 34-35

title: Question of the Week; Will East German Athletes Continue to Dominate?
description: rrConsidering their small population, the East Germans have performed an athletic miracle through individual and organized effort, and that is to be lauded without cynicism.
