Yet, the same mind-set in their political system has caused all the discontent that has so rapidly risen to the surface this year. The control that glorifies a few hundred athletes and instills pride in the nation leaves millions more suffering politically, economically, socially, artistically, in short, in every outlet of human expression.

title: Pei, Prince Charles - and Skyscrapers Everywhere
description: IN ARCHITECTURE, THIS WAS SURE-ly the year of I. M. Pei: not a new face, to be sure, but an omnipresent one. In Paris, Mr. Pei's glass pyramid in the court of the Louvre, the object of bitter controversy for years, opened in April to an almost entirely positive reaction. Those who had always thought a crystal pyramid was the right idea for a new entrance and virtual logo for the Louvre rejoiced in self-satisfaction that the 72-year-old Mr. Pei had maneuvered his way through the political thicket so skillfully; the doubters generally came around, moved by the extraordinary beauty of Mr. Pei's exquisitely crafted object and by the extent to which it did allow the older buildings of the Louvre to maintain their integrity. In the end, the quibbles were minor: the way the three little pyramids placed beside the main one trivialized the composition, for example, or the way the staircase was detailed - hardly enough to deny the success of the project as an example of what Mr. Pei does best, which is to create a true civic monumentality in the modernist mode. And that is what the architect did as well in his second major public building to be finished last year, the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center in Dallas. Opened in September, the Meyerson could be called a grand concert hall in the new style: it aspires to the luxury and monumentality of the great classical halls, but the architecture is mainly Mr. Pei's modernist geometries. Its swooping shapes of glass and limestone are a bit too abstract on the outside, but inside, the auditorium, which has somewhat of the air of Viennese modernism to it, is warm and pleasing.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: Certainly dentistry, like any other field of endeavor is a fit subject for humor. This, I know, for I have had several dental humor articles published myself.

title: For the Record
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Diplomats; Rumania Aides in U.S. Switch, But Emigres Aren't Satisfied
description: The Rumanian Ambassador to the United States and the embassy's diplomatic staff today denounced the deposed dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu, joining about a dozen other Rumanian legations in declaring their loyalty to the rebels who toppled the Government this week.

title: On Being Green
description: To the Editor:

title: A Story Of Christmas And War
description: NIXEVILLE-BLER COURT, France, appears on no map, or in any atlas readily available to Americans, but I have a favorite Christmas story -actually a 20-minute interlude during the course of one Christmas day -that took place there. I don't yearn nostalgically for that day of yore, but when I think about it I feel nurtured, as though I am slaking a tremendous thirst.

title: Not a Perfect Holiday, Just a Happy One
description: IT is Christmas Eve. I've shifted into overdrive, madly wrapping last-minute purchases to put under the tree, when I hear, Thump! Thump! Thump! above my head. It's too early for reindeer hooves to be prancing and pawing on the roof, or perhaps too late. I haven't heard that noise for many years - and then it was only a faint echo in my imagination as I drifted off to sleep, visions of sugarplums dancing in my head.

title: Dance to the Music of History
description: DIAGHILEV'S BALLETS RUSSES By Lynn Garafola. Illustrated. 524 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Civilization and Savagery Collide in Metaphor
description: ''JUAN DARIEN,'' THE PUPPET MUSICAL by Julie Taymor and Elliot Goldenthal, is an eloquent expression of the power of theatrical transformation, which in this case approaches transmutation. As the audience watches, objects and images shift and assume radically different, often metaphorical form. A jaguar cub is reborn as a boy (named Juan Darien), and, suffering at the hands of his fellow man, he is driven back to his beastly origins. In this ''carnival Mass,'' civilization and savagery repeatedly collide. The show is the stage equivalent of the magic realism of novelists like Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Isabel Allende. As in their fiction, the apparently mundane suddenly turns into the miraculous.

title: Lisa J. Auslander To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Auslander of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Jayne Auslander to William Samuel Haft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Haft of Old Westbury, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: The No-Parent Child
description: On Nov. 27, Baby Boy W. was born in Brooklyn four weeks early and with test signs of cocaine and syphilis. He is the youngest of three children whose mother is an unemployed crack addict who has dropped out of drug treatment. She has not seen Baby Boy W. since his birth and he is now a candidate for adoption. But who will adopt such a child?

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Israel
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: Most patients do appreciate the comfortable atmosphere and the pain control modalities dental offices provide. Most patients do appreciate that their children have no caries. Most patients do appreciate early diagnosis of periodontal disease and the simple preventive techniques which can help maintain their teeth.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; What the Rich and Famous Did to Be So Noticed
description: Disgrace was a main theme for the famous (Jim Bakker), along with wealth (Donald Trump) and tastelessness (Morton Downey Jr.). Not a few of the big names were big, and appear here, because they did something wrong.

title: For an Amazon Indian Tribe, Civilization Brings Mostly Disease and Death
description: With a palm thatch roof and poles for hammocks, the Indian House health clinic stands at the end of a sandy road, beyond the end of the freshly laid pavement of this Amazonian gold rush town.

title: LIVING WITH STYLE: North versus South; There's no place like away from home on the Holidays
description: There are those who can't make up their minds until the last split second. Should they start the winter solstice basking in the sun or schussing down the slopes? Designer Calvin Klein and his wife, Kelly, are like that. Today will find them either on sunny St. Barts or in frosty Aspen. Wherever, they will not be wanting for fellow celebrants. If it's St. Barts the Kleins choose, they will just be part of the usual celebrity deluge that engulfs the little island at holiday time. But as Marlo Phillips, longtime St. Barts hand and florist extraordinaire, explains, ''If you want to be a recluse, you can be there and no one knows you're there.'' Back in Manhattan, however, on this night before Christmas, magical moments have been planned for the Central Park South ''salon'' of the Conde Nast Traveler magazine's creative director Marie-Paule Pelle. Here, instead of in Paris with her family, Ms. Pelle is indulging in a fantasy fete that she pre-staged for us. Twenty guests have been invited for 9 P.M., to be greeted by their hostess in her Valentino ''white tie.'' The apartment is sparse on furniture, but she has filled it with a family of polar bears found at FAO Schwarz. Guests will sip French wine and dine on scrumptious French cuisine too elaborate to describe. They will exchange presents, and if they are good, perhaps even cuddle a bear. After all, says Ms. Pelle, ''Christmas is the only time of the year to do the things you don't do at any other time.''

title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; If only . . . .
description: If you had $1,000 on Jan. 1, 1980, here's what it would be worth today, depending where you invested it. Because of inflation, a dollar today has only 61 percent of the purchasing power of a 1980 dollar. General Motors common stock . . . 1,740.00 I.B.M. common stock . . . 1,479.61 Philip Morris common stock . . . 8,833.33 The Dow Jones industrial average . . . $3,283.06 Gold . . . 411.90 Passbook savings account* . . . 1,711.86 Under your mattress . . . 1,000.00 Figures as of Dec. 31. (Source: Advest Inc.)

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: Since dentistry has made so much progress in the prevention of tooth and gum disease, it saddened me to read the article. As a psychotherapist and spouse of a dentist, it seems clear that dental phobia is much harder to cure and prevent than cavities.

title: Dr. Pearse to Marry Kurt Eichenwald
description: Dr. Theresa Felicita Pearse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Pearse of New York, London and Lodz, Poland, and Kurt Alexander Eichenwald, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Heinz F. Eichenwald of Dallas, plan to marry in July.

title: Too Much For a Commuter
description: TO the world, Mikhail Gorbachev is the man who has rekindled nearly dead hopes for world peace. He is the man who has thrown open the shutters on the long-sealed window of Soviet history. He is a prince of light emerged from an empire of darkness. He is also the man who keeps me from reaching the second section of the newspaper by the Rahway station.

title: Good Mencken, Bad Mencken
description: LEAD: THE DIARY OF H. L. MENCKEN Edited by Charles A. Fecher. Illustrated. 476 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Two Inspiring Lessons of the 1980's
description: LEAD: At the turn of the 80's, as we look toward the 90's, two themes seem to predominate. One is the growing superiority of human over material resources. The second is a growing superiority of human will over institutions of dominance and violence. Both developments are surprising and unexpected, and suggest a possible plasticity for the future that most attempts at projection do not credit.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE leader of the Broad Street Gang in Newark died a few weeks ago, and this hardhearted city wept.

title: Hints of Strength Come as Surprise
description: Last week's statistics ran counter to the widely held view that the economy is slowing enough to threaten a recession. Durable goods orders surged by 5.1 percent in November, their largest monthly gain of the year. Aircraft orders accounted for nearly half of the increase, but there were gains in many categories. Another positive sign came from consumers. Their spending was up seven-tenths of a percent in November, the steepest rise since March. Personal incomes climbed eight-tenths of a percent, also the best showing since March. And figures from earlier in the year were revised upward. The Government said gross national product grew at an annual rate of 3 percent in the third quarter, up from a 2.7 percent estimate. A negative came from housing starts, which were off 4.7 percent in November. As for inflation, consumer prices rose four-tenths of a percent last month, a bit more than expected.

title: IN SHORT: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: THE GOLD BALL. By Hanne Marie Svendsen. Translated by Jorgen Schiott. (Knopf, $18.95.) In recent years, Scandinavia has produced a number of epic explanations of its century of change from poverty to affluence. Most such accounts are rendered in a Social Realist style, colored with a new concern for Marxism and women's history born in the student revolts of the 1960's and 70's.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: India
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: British Flu Epidemic Claims Lives And Is Forcing Delays in Surgery
description: The worst flu epidemic in 14 years has strong-armed its way through Britain, claiming lives, forcing hospitals to postpone surgery and dominating conversation with worries over who has it, how to avoid it or how to get rid of it.

title: Rights Group Wants Military's Help in Miami
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has asked Gov. Bob Martinez to send in the National Guard here, saying it fears that black communities may be ignored by police officers loyal to a Hispanic officer who was convicted of killing two blacks.

title: Recycling: Creative Challenge
description: I really enjoyed ''Recycling as a Permanent Life Style'' (Dec. 3). In addition to conserving materials and protecting the environment, the author demonstrated prudence and wisdom in approaching packaging from more than one perspective.

title: Dubious Taste
description: To the Editor:

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: NANCY Y. ARNDT;
'Children Need Contact After a Divorce'
description: LEAD: HOLIDAYS are supposed to be happy times, when families gather together to share joyous moments. But for children of divorced parents, the holidays are often filled with shattered expectations and great pain, said Nancy Y. Arndt, a clinical psychologist with a private practice in psychotherapy.

title: Forecast: Bridal Showers
description: Barbara Klaus was most succinct in her comments (''Forecast: Bridal Showers Ahead,'' Nov. 26) with regard to the showers, but neglected to state that before the plans for the shower were made, the bride said to two or more of her friends, ''I would like you to be part of my wedding party. In exchange for this honor I will help you select a bridesmaid's gown in my color scheme, which you will pay for and never wear again! Then you will give me a shower ... but surprise me!'' MRS. HOWARD FENER Hempstead

title: BySabbath Border In Atlantic Beach
description: In the Nov. 26 article on the eruv in Atlantic Beach, the reader gets the false impression from Mr. Woolfe and Mrs. Leistner that the eruv is the cause for people walking ''four and five abreast'' in the streets.

title: 2 SHIITE MILITIAS BATTLE IN LEBANON
description: Fierce fighting broke out today between rival Muslim Shiite militias in southern Lebanon, and the police said that 17 people had been killed and 40 wounded, with thousands of civilians fleeing the battle to safer areas.

title: Schoenberg Festival Is Planned at Juilliard
description: The work of Arnold Schoenberg will be studied in six concerts of orchestral, chamber and solo works at the Juilliard School, from Jan. 26 to Feb. 2. More than 250 students of the music, dance and drama divisions will take part in the series, which is titled 'The World of Arnold Schoenberg' and which will include his own work and that of some of the composers who studied with him.

title: Tatyana Yassukovich to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanislas M. Yassukovich of London and Bibury, Gloucestershire, England, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Tatyana Alexandra Eugenie Yassukovich, to Charles Stewart Dubow, the son of Isabella Breckinridge Dubow of Washington and Arthur M. Dubow of East Hampton, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Thanks From a Survivor Of Hurricane Hugo
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion; To Warm the Urban Alpinist, a Touch of Loden
description: The holly reds and pine greens of the holiday season are mirrored in one of the season's surprise fashion fads: Austrian loden garments and other Tyrolean wear.

title: Fighting in Panama: Panama's Military; New Security Unit Is Named To Replace Noriega's Army
description: In its first major action, Panama's new civilian Government - installed by the United States military - announced this afternoon that it had dissolved the Panamanian Army and would replace the 15,000-member military institution that has ruled this country for more than 20 years with a more modest public security organ under new leadership.

title: Lifestyle: New Year's Eve Dining; Ending 1989 on a Festive but Frugal Note
description: New Year's Eve is a merry bonanza for many restaurants. It is the only night of the year when they get away with giving a couple a bottle of bubbly, an extra appetizer or two, a silly cardboard hat and maybe a lounge trio - and tripling their prices. If your New Year's resolution is to start 1990 with a whopping credit-card tab, Manhattan awaits you with open arms. For the more frugal-minded, many quality restaurants are serving special dinners at regular prices or at a reasonable prix fixe.

title: Collaborators Create an Amateur Sleuth
description: LEAD: FOR about 10 years, or ever since they first met at graduate school at the State University at Stony Brook and agreed that writing was what they wanted to do with their lives, Mary Lou Kallman and Marilyn Oser tried their collective hand at everything.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Brazil
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: Sports of The Times; Christmas With the Eisenreichs
description: It's a ''big old house,'' that white, wooden, four-bedroom house on the quiet street in St. Cloud, Minn., with a Christmas tree inside and other holiday decorations. It is a house that tomorrow, in the warmth against the frost outdoors, will be filled happily for Ann Eisenreich. It will be filled with her family -her husband and five children and three daughters-in-law and three grandchildren -and the aroma of, among other delights, the oatmeal cookies and the angel food cake she baked. ''Oatmeal cookies and angel food cake,'' she said the other day, ''are Jim's favorites.''

title: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches; New Candor in the Coverage in Rumania and East Germany
description: The Rumanian press has begun reporting events with a candor unthinkable before the ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu, Following are excerpts from the Rumanian press agency Agerpres and Rumanian, East German and Hungarian broadcasts as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service. A National Front Rumanian radio domestic service - Ion Iliescu, in a live studio appearance, begins to read a communique from the Council of National Salvation. Iliescu says that the overthrow of the Ceausescu regime is the result of the heroic struggle of all the people, of all nationalities, particularly the youth, and will open a new page in Rumania's political and economic history. He says it was decided to set up a National Salvation Front, supporting the army, to restore democracy and freedom. The Government and the State Council have been dismissed. All state power has been assumed by the National Salvation Front, to which the army will subordinate itself. Local councils of the National Salvation Front, he says, are to be set up in all counties to insure public transportation, public supplies, and a normal development of activities.

title: Law Review Upheld on Free Speech
description: For 20 years, Broward County ran its legal notices in The Broward Review, but after the newspaper published an article last year that was critical of the county sheriff, he canceled the advertising, taking his $35,000 a year in business elsewhere.

title: Computers, Attics and Clues to Mozart and Haydn
description: THE AMERICAN MUSICOLOGIST H. C. Robbins Landon lives in France but commutes to the 18th century. His means of conveyance are many - including the computer, the telephone and the goodwill and vigilance of friends. He was in town the other day noting the uses of the present as a way of getting at the past.

title: Upheaval in the East: Moscow; Gorbachev Says He Will Confer With Allies on Aid to Rumanians
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, apparently not referring to military aid, said today that he would confer with Warsaw Pact members on rendering assistance to the Rumanian people in their ''just cause'' of opposing force fighting to restore Nicolae Ceausescu to power.

title: As Stress Rises for College Students, Counseling Centers Try to Keep Pace
description: LEAD: HELPING psychologically troubled college students is becoming more difficult because the demand for treatment is outpacing the funds available for it, college counselors and administrators say.

title: Hollywood Is Taking Notice of the Diversity of Long Island
description: IN ''Married to the Mob,'' Frank and Angela Demarco live in a modest but gaudily decorated Long Island home. One of the few films to focus on Long Island's middle class, the movie, a hit in 1987, marked a departure of sorts for Hollywood's view of Long Island, which, in films like ''The Great Gatsby,'' ''Sabrina'' and ''The Godfather'' tended to concentrate on the area's wealth.

title: Review/Music; Mendelssohn String Quartet Celebrates 10th Anniversary
description: The players in the Mendelssohn String Quartet look too young to be celebrating their 10th anniversary. But the ensemble was formed in 1979, and has been the resident ensemble at the Hebrew Arts School since 1981. On Tuesday evening, the group played the first of three anniversary programs at Merkin Concert Hall. The other performances are in March and April.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Experts' View; Outlook Is Uncertain for Rumanian Democracy and Economic Improvement
description: Experts on Rumania and international relations agree that the army will continue to play a crucial role as popular unrest propels the country toward change, but they give differing appraisals of the prospects for democracy and improvement in the economy.

title: Christine Frissora to Marry
description: Christine L. Frissora, a student at the Cornell University Medical College, and Dr. Scott A. Rodeo, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, are planning a June wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frissora of Mount Sunapee, N.H., have announced. Miss Frissora graduated from Cornell. Dr. Rodeo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rodeo of San Jose, Calif., graduated from Stanford University and the Cornell Medical College.

title: Shaken Rangers Slip Once More
description: When the game was over, after the Capitals' Dale Hunter had buried the puck in the net, the Rangers stood in disbelief and despair. John Vanbiesbrouck, the goalie, was without a stick; Jeff Bloemberg and Brian Leetch, the two defensmen in the vicinity, were without excuses.

title: ART 'Once Upon a Time' Is a Twice-Told Tale
description: TWO shows with the same title, ''Once Upon a Time,'' have opened and both are fun. The fun in the Scarsdale Historical Society's version is educational; that in the Pelham Art Center's somewhat commercial. But in this opinion, the two taken together make entertainment as good as a trek to the Christmas displays at Rockefeller Center, although Robert Heitmann, the artist featured at Scarsdale, can be seen in Manhattan, too.

title: New Bush Budget Will Stick To Themes From Campaign
description: Sticking to the themes he developed in his election campaign last year, President Bush will emphasize in his budget message to Congress next month new proposals to encourage personal saving and modest spending increases for drug control, education, science, research and the environment, Administration officials said.

title: Upheaval in the East; Pronouncing the Names
description: SILVIU BRUCAN, an opposition leader: SEEL-vyoo broo-KAHN NICOLAE CEAUSESCU, the ousted leader: nee-koh-LAH-yeh chow-SHESH-koo ELENA CEAUSESCU, his wife and second in command: eh-LEH-nah NICU CEAUSESCU, their eldest son and leader in the city of Sibiu: NEE-koo Lieut. Gen. ILIE CEAUSESCU, the leader's brother: ill-EE-yeh Lieut. Gen. NICOLAE ANDRUTA CEAUSESCU, another brother: ahn-DROO-tsah CONSTANTIN DASCALESCU, the Prime Minister: cohn-stahn-TEEN dass-kah-LESS-koo GHEORGHE GHEORGHIU-DEJ, Mr. Ceausescu's predecessor: GYOR-gyeh gyor-GYOO dehzh, with hard g's. ION ILIESCU, an opposition leader: yahn ill-ee-YES-koo CORNELIU MANESCU, a former Foreign Minister: kor-NEHL-yoo mah-NESS-koo VASILE MILEA, the Defense Minister, who reportedly committed suicide: vah-SEE-leh MEEL-lah Col. Gen. NICOLAE MILITARU: nee-koh-LAH-yeh mee-lee-TAH-roo SORIN OPREA, an opposition leader in Timisoara: soh-REEN OHP-prah

title: Don't Give Up on Junk Bonds
description: RECENTLY, I participated on a panel with leaders of the House and Senate to discuss mechanisms for increasing investment in distressed communities. None of the communities or minority businesses we discussed were investment grade. Rather, they were completely unbankable, and most credit analyses by rating agencies would classify them as ''junk'' investments.

title: Lobbying for Nudists' Rights
description: KEVIN KEARNEY began his career as a lobbyist with efforts to preserve open space on Long Island, but lately he has been seeking to expand the range of a more conspicuous breed of nature buff.

title: Miss McMullenPlans to Marry David Hemphill
description: A June wedding is planned by Caroline Lovell McMullen and David Van Scoyoc Hemphill, the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. David Rule Pyott of Alexandria, Va., has announced.

title: The Kind of Gift That's the Best
description: I CAN'T remember a Christmas when we didn't have a tree.

title: Review/Operetta; Gibert-Sullivan Players In 'The Gondoliers'
description: ''I must thank you for the magnificent work you have put into the piece,'' wrote William S. Gilbert to Arthur Sullivan with a somewhat strained modesty on Dec. 8, 1889, the day after the first performance of ''The Gondoliers,'' which the two had interrupted their bickering long enough to write. ''It gives one the chance of shining right through the 20th century with a reflected light.''

title: AIDS Strategy for Addicts Is Faulted
description: Scores of programs that provide clean needles or bleach to drug addicts to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus may fail because they overlook other routes of infection, according to new research and the observations of other experts.

title: IN SHORT: Fiction
description: LEAD: PHANTOM LIFE. By Daniele Sallenave. Translated by Lydia Davis. (Pantheon, $17.95.) It's a ''convenient fiction,'' writes the French novelist Daniele Sallenave, ''that passion is the secret revealer of human natures.'' In her latest novel, her first to appear in English (in an able translation by Lydia Davis), Ms.

title: How to Make Raising Money Cheaper
description: THE acceleration of Japanese purchases of American corporate icons like Rockefeller Center, Columbia Pictures and CBS Records should come as no surprise, given the huge advantage that the Japanese enjoy in capital costs. Recent studies have found that America's capital is between 2 1/2 and 4 times as expensive as Japan's. Inexpensive capital has given the Japanese a booming manufacturing sector and ample cash with which to purchase foreign assets.

title: Style Makers; Zang Toi, Fashion Designer
description: When Zang Toi entered the Parsons School of Design in New York in 1981, he did not even know how to hold a needle. He was a quick study.

title: Future Health: How Much Care?
description: WHAT KIND OF LIFE The Limits of Medical Progress. By Daniel Callahan. 318 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: From Ballet to Poetry At Festival in Stamford
description: STAMFORD will ring in the new year and decade with a New Year's Eve celebration that will be the largest one-day performing arts festival ever held in the state.

title: Pastimes: Gardening; Medieval Traditions Decorate the Cloisters
description: In the Middle Ages, great halls were decked on Christmas Eve and garlands and greens lent their festive color until the Feast of Epiphany on the 12th day, Jan. 6. This tradition is observed at the Cloisters, the medieval branch of New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. Susan Moody, staff horticulturist, steeps herself in the customs of those times to create authentic plant and floral displays for the Romanesque chapels and cloisters.

title: The Christmas Cover Story
description: THIS WEEK'S COVER, A CHRISTMAS card of sorts, was conceived and executed by the photographer Elliott Erwitt and the special effects designer Bran Ferren. ''I thought it would be nice to do something with a little 1990's in it, something high-tech, but not unpleasant,'' says Erwitt, who suggested the collaboration to his Long Island neighbor. ''And Bran said he could make a high-tech tree with flashes and explosions and we could put it in the hands of a kid. Of course, I didn't know what the hell he meant.'' What Ferren meant is illustrated above.

title: Miss Vail Weds David I. Boonin
description: The marriage of Martha Clara Vail and David Isaac Boonin took place last evening at Temple Beth David in Cheshire, Conn. Rabbis Steven Steinberg and Howard Kummer officiated.

title: The Hills Were Alive With the Sound of Tummling
description: A SUMMER WORLD The Attempt to Build a Jewish Eden in the Catskills, From the Days of the Ghetto to the Rise and Decline of the Borscht Belt. By Stefan Kanfer. Illustrated. 333 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: Catherine Ferrante di Ruffano to Marry in April
description: April wedding plans for Catherine Ferrante di Ruffano and Ian Tapsall have been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Georgette D. Ferrante di Ruffano of Kingston, N.J. Miss Ferrante di Ruffano also is a daughter of Giovanni Ferrante di Ruffano of Bridgewater, N.J. Mr. Tapsall is a son of Mrs. Trevor Edwin Tapsall of Windsor, Berkshire, England.

title: Outdoors; Amid Icy Stream, Hunt for Rainbow
description: ALTHOUGH the prolonged bitterly cold weather and two feet of new snow that began falling Wednesday night have plunged the valley of the Salmon River in New York State into the heart of winter, there are those who will continue to fish for the stream's highly prized steelheads, even if they have to don snowshoes to get to the water.

title: Campus Life: Wooster; Welcoming Those Not at Home for the Holidays
description: As at most colleges, not everyone at the College of Wooster goes home for the holidays. Many international students live too far away to make the journey, so they must remain on a nearly empty campus. To make the three-week break less lonely, the college conducts the Host Family Program, in which 75 students are welcomed into the homes of Wooster families.

title: Christmas in Vienna With the First Nine Beethovens
description: THE MOST DEARLY REMEMBERED Christmas present I ever received was given to me by my father when I was 12. It was a complete set of Beethoven's symphonies, the first ever to be recorded in its entirety.

title: Tensions Rise on Hispanic Immigrants
description: MANY communities in Westchester have been dealing with an influx of Hispanic illegal aliens in the last few years. But nowhere has the arrival of these new immigrants caused more tension than in this northern village, where the Mayor and a Hispanic advocate have clashed repeatedly over the Mayor's handling of the situation.

title: Woman Killed as Seattle Span Opens Accidentally
description: A drawspan on the world's longest floating bridge was raised accidentally during a test Friday, sending traffic into a rising wall of steel that killed a woman and injured six other people.

title: Whipping Up Canapes on Short Notice
description: ONE of the treasures of the kitchen is a recipe for hors d'oeuvres that can be whipped up at the last minute with ingredients that are always on hand. Such a failsafe is a godsend when unexpected guests drop in or when nothing beyond a bowl of salted nuts comes to mind to serve before a dinner party.

title: Casting Their Neural Nets
description: THE IMPROBABLE MACHINE What the Upheavals in Artificial Intelligence Research Reveal About How the Mind Really Works. By Jeremy Campbell. 334 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: U.S. Moves to Block Potential Shortages Of Fuels for Heating
description: The Government is moving to help unclog bottlenecks that have created shortages of heating oil and propane in the current spell of extremely cold weather, the Energy Department's top emergency planner said today.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD: CHILDREN'S SHOW

title: Tutu, Visiting Jerusalem, Backs Palestinian Statehood
description: As troops and protesters clashed in Bethlehem, Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa began a Christmas pilgrimage to the Holy Land today, offering support for the creation of a Palestinian state and for Israel's ''independence and territorial integrity.''

title: Families Evolve, Christmas Stays Put
description: IF Christmas is for children, then I am especially glad we are going to my brother's house in Trumbull to celebrate with his family, which includes two little boys. For this is the year of the empty nest, both of our offspring finally in college.

title: Children Help Design a Playground
description: LEAD: PAULA WEISS told the two dozen third graders gathered around her on chairs and the floor that she had a ''little secret'' for them. ''I'm not going to design your playground,'' she said. ''You're going to design it.''

title: The Books He Left Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan Wins Again in Rematch
description: Eight months after he sealed Michigan's national championship victory over Seton Hall with a pair of overtime free throws, Rumeal Robinson was at it again. This time, though, it was just another game.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown. On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass. Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?

title: Fighting in Panama: The President; A Sense of Inevitability In Bush's Decision to Act
description: President Bush offered no high-flown reflections and did no last-minute agonizing as he made the decision to invade Panama last Sunday, officials who were with him at the time say.

title: MORE/On Art
description: The texture of a season is defined as much by the atmosphere around main events as by the events themselves, as much by the huge and ever-changing cast as by current art stars. Here are a few snapshots from a very personal album.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TAPESTRIES

title: TV Watched as History Was Made
description: IT WAS A YEAR OF POLITICAL UPHEAVAL overseas and natural disasters at home. Television brought close the drama of the worldwide impulse for freedom - the exhilarating days of protest in Beijing's Tiananmen Square that ended so painfully and the opening up of the hated Berlin Wall, along with the inspiring upsurges in Poland, Czechoslovakia, even Bulgaria. The camera captured the hope, soon destroyed, in the faces of the young Chinese and newly awakened in the faces of the East Germans who thronged to the West.

title: The Whaling Life, Day by Day
description: LEAD: BACK in the 1840's, when he was crisscrossing oceans in pursuit of whales, Edwin Peter Brown of Orient was just another sea captain making a living far from what he called ''the land So dear to my heart.''

title: Lithuania
description: To the Editor: It has taken me some time to digest an experience that I still do not know whether to consider exhilarating or distrubing. Earlier this year I went for the second time to the Soviet Union to get a flavor of today's climate compared to one I experienced in 1982. I was looking forward particularly to three days in Lithuania.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: TRYING to predict the future by looking back at the last year is very much like driving down a road while using the rear-view mirror to steer, as Allan Kay, a visionary at Apple Computer Inc. (his actual title is fellow), has noted. The task is all the harder in the computer industry, where the technology is always accelerating. Even so, some guideposts stood out this year for executives who are trying to figure out which way to go as the 1990's loom.

title: Kissing Scene a Test for Actress, 12
description: JESSICA PRUNELL of Syosset blushes as she recounts her kissing scene in the film ''Born on the Fourth of July.''

title: On Being Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: Exhibition Football Ivy League Wins in Japan: Despite another lopsided loss, this time to an Ivy League All-Star team, Japanese football is making progress. ''They played really good football,'' said Mark Ligos of Penn, who returned an interception 16 yards for a touchdown in the Ivy stars' 49-17 victory over the Japanese All-Star team in Yokohama yesterday. ''It surprised a lot of us, to tell you the truth.''

title: POSTINGS: East Side Luxury; 238 Rental Units
description: A luxury rental apartment house is under construction on the site of a former A. & P. food market on the southwest corner of 79th Street and First Avenue in Manhattan. The project will have a base of 16 stories and a 28-story tower along the First Avenue side of the building, which will carry the address 350 East 79th Street.

description: The engagement of Ellen Zuckerman to Zachary Ben Mayo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Mayo of Manhasset and East Hampton, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Zuckerman of Englewood, N.J., and East Hampton. A June wedding is planned.

title: Fixing the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: Penny M. Gampel To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Gampel of Fords, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Penny M. Gampel to Steven T. Jaffe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herb Jaffe of Clark, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Bethlehem Township; Residents and Quarry Are at Loggerheads Over Blast Effects
description: WHEN chunks of granite from a nearby quarry tumbled into his backyard last spring, Gus Dobes of Bethlehem Township complained to the state. Months earlier, when he and his neighbors noticed that their houses were shaking more than usual from the quarry's blasts, he signed a petition that was also sent to the state.

title: Christmas Display Spreads Too Much Cheer
description: CHRISTMAS EVE is a night when many families drive around various Connecticut towns to view holiday displays, as they prepare to open presents tomorrow morning. But in Prospect, one family's display has attracted so many visitors and caused such a stir over traffic congestion that the Mayor put up ''no parking'' signs and added police patrols.

title: 'People Who Could Fly'
description: ''The People Who Could Fly,'' a work that combines international dance, theater and storytelling, will be presented this week at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The performances by the Warp and Woof Theater Company are Tuesday through Friday at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M., with an 8 P.M. performance added on Friday. Information: 967-8278.

title: Walton's Longest Season Finally Ends
description: UP on the scoreboard, the final seconds were flashing as the Buffalo Bills held a 37-0 lead. After having defied a wind-chill factor that was 11 degrees below zero at the kickoff, most of the scattered 21,148 customers had deserted Giants Stadium, but a record 55,743 customers had never appeared. Above the tunnel leading to the Jets' locker room, a few vultures in parkas and woolen caps were rehearsing their ''Joe Must Go'' chant. But on the Jets' sideline, in his green cap, green jacket and green pants, Joe Walton was still holding his clipboard. Joe Walton was still coaching.

title: Ferryboats Again Becoming a Familiar Sight Along Hudson
description: FOR three centuries after the first flat-bottomed rowboat glided to Communipaw, now Jersey City, in 1661, ferries traversed the Hudson River daily, shuttling New Jersey residents to more than 20 loading docks that dotted Manhattan's shoreline.

title: Upheaval in the East; 40 Ceausescu Relatives Were in Powerful Jobs
description: The deposed Rumanian Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, included an estimated 40 members of his family in positions of power.

title: Where There's Smoke: Remedies
description: A FIREPLACE that allows smoke to enter a room is less than cheery. The problem can be caused by a variety of conditions, some of which are simple to cure, some less so.

title: IN SHORT: Fiction
description: DEADLINE. By Tom Stacey. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This very brief, sometimes annoying and often compelling adventure novel by a real Fleet Street foreign correspondent, which features a fictional Fleet Street correspondent, raises some essential questions about their profession. Is the foreign correspondent (or the local reporter, for that matter) a keen-eyed, sharp-minded observer of life, the public's representative at rebellions and earthquakes? Or is the reporter a hack, a vulture, living off the carrion of other people's failures and tragedies? What does it mean that Tom Stacey's hero, Gran Jones, has gained in his work ''an extraordinary global eclecticism''? That he was smarter than his informed sources? Or that he was really a jack-of-all-trades, a dilettante? Jones, an aging British newspaperman, lives in virtual retirement in an oil-rich state in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Stacey chooses to leave it nameless, which rankles, but the place sounds like Abu Dhabi or Dubai. ''Deadline'' is only 122 pages long, and the publisher notes that it has already been a television production in Britain, which suggests that the book was an afterthought to the script. We are asked to believe that in his time Jones has interviewed all the makers of midcentury history - including Khrushchev, Churchill and the Shah of Iran. There is no explicit report that he settled any revolutions in Spain, but Hitler did phone him for advice. Soon after ''Deadline'' begins, there is a coup in Jones's adopted homeland and he drags himself after one more scoop, competing with the whippersnappers of the press and television. Flashbacks tell of Jones's history - why he left his wife for a younger woman, why he is now alone, working on a book he seems unlikely to finish. But it's the descriptions of Jones's daily routine, intercut with his memories, that are the strength of the novel; they make us need to know how Jones's personal story comes out, whether he will get his last big exclusive. Still, they aren't quite enough to flesh out this very skimpy thriller. It's too bad Mr. Stacey couldn't have brought Jones's lover, his wife, his children to fuller life, or made his professional past more plausible. For Gran Jones is a familiar character, and essentially a true one, and he deserves better treatment.

title: Panamanians Are Also Dying in Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: Escaping to Ireland for Christmas
description: TO escape the commercial and familial hoopla of the holidays, my husband and I like to take our children to faraway places for a different kind of celebration - one that we create from the bits of experience and tradition we value most. Traveling at Christmas is part of our general inclination to set out against the seasonal tides. We go north in the winter (but not to ski), south in the summer; we stay home to work on weekends and slip out of town on a Tuesday; and when it begins to pour, we don layers of raingear and head for the most mist-enshrouded beaches or for forest trails, glowing with colors the rain unfurls.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: San Francisco Feeling Pinch In Visitor Count

title: Sidney Goldensohn, Physician, Dies at 69
description: Dr. Sidney S. Goldensohn, a psychoanalyst who was the director of mental health services for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, H.I.P., before he retired earlier this year, died of complications from lymphoma on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old. Dr. Goldensohn, a native New Yorker, received his bachelor's and medical degrees from George Washington University and was a graduate of the William Alanson White Institute. He served in the Army Medical Corps in World War II and was chief of neurology at Walter Reed Medical Center.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: I have been in practice for 31 years and am used to the dental profession being the brunt of jokes. Some material is even quite humorous.

title: IN SHORT: Nonfiction
description: THE DIVERTED DREAM: Community Colleges and the Promise of Educational Opportunity in America, 1900-1985. By Steven Brint and Jerome Karabel. (Oxford University, $24.95.) The United States sends more of its young people to college than any other nation in the world. Approximately half of them are enrolled in community colleges, where they are channeled into low- and mid-level technical and vocational programs. It is this paradox between the democratization of higher education and the tracking of students into a highly stratified occupational structure that Steven Brint and Jerome Karabel address in ''The Diverted Dream.'' In the process they attempt to explain both the phenomenal growth and the particular orientation of today's two-year institutions. Small liberal-arts ''junior'' colleges, designed to prepare students for transferring to four-year colleges, were transformed into large-scale ''community'' colleges, intended to provide large segments of the population with vocational programs and terminal degrees. This change required a lengthy and substantial effort, including the use of testing and guidance services, to persuade students and their parents to lower their aspirations. Mr. Brint, who teaches sociology at Yale University, and Mr. Karabel, who teaches sociology at the University of California, Berkeley, reject the notions that the transformation occurred because students-as-consumers chose vocational tracks and that business and industry played a dominant role in shaping this transformation. Instead, they argue, the leaders of the community college movement fashioned a particular mission to secure a niche for themselves in the competitive educational marketplace. The book is well documented and raises important questions about the role of education in our society. For the working class and minority students that predominate in two-year institutions, this book serves as a cruel reminder of the limits of opportunity in a class-structured society. GREGORY MANTSIOS

title: Upheaval in the East; 2 Planes Bring The First Aid
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross sent two relief planes to the Rumanian capital Friday night, carrying four tons of emergency medical supplies, five doctors and nurses and three other Red Cross officials.

title: Theresa M. Carr Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Denys Raymond Carr of Normanton, Yorkshire, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theresa Margaret Carr, to William Van Muran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Van V. Muran of Brookville and Southampton, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsfield, Mass.;

description: LEAD: ONE of this city's most prominent structures, the vacant England's department store building, has been bought by a developer who plans to renovate it for retailing and other uses.

description: A new wind is blowing through America's remote outposts in Antarctica: a not entirely welcome impetus toward healthier bodies and tidier habits.

title: Corrections
description: The editors' identification of Alfred Kazin on Dec. 10, with his review of Abraham Lincoln's writings, referred incorrectly to Mr. Kazin's book ''The Almighty Has His Own Purposes.'' It is in progress, not yet due for publication.

title: Shall We Dance?; As Two Worlds Warm, A Post-Postwar Order Awaits
description: RETROSPECT often makes the most recent moments seem the most vivid. That is usually a trick that our minds play upon us, but surely not in the 1980's. The pictures of Berliners dancing upon, pouring through, chipping hunks out of their hated wall, symbolizing the end of 45 years of cold war, seem incredible now, and surely they and what they epitomize will still seem extraordinary in the next century.

title: Joan Gelb Married to Jacek Jarkowski
description: Joan H. Gelb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Gelb of New York and Washington, was married yesterday to Jacek Jarkowski, the son of Witold Jarkowski of Warsaw and the late Wanda Jarkowska. The Rev. Clarke Oler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's parents.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'

title: Selective Indignation
description: To the Editor:

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: The modern dentist has many challenges in today's changing profession, not the least of which is overcoming patient fears. Deprecating sentiments set forth by unknowing and unappreciative individuals who themselves are beneficiaries of our care, skill and judgment only undermine the progress of the dental profession.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Pearl of New York have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Suzanne L. Pearl and Kenneth S. Bakst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin A. Bakst of Rancho Mirage, Calif., and Lake Tahoe, Nev.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. ELAINE LEVENTHAL;
Focusing on Geriatric Medicine
description: LEAD: ELAINE LEVENTHAL had no intention of giving up when her application for admission to the University of Wisconsin Medical School was turned down. The mother of two children and the wife of a Wisconsin professor, Dr. Leventhal, who already had a doctorate in development embryology and genetics from Yale University, tried again the next year.

title: Yumi Inaba and Dorian Lowell to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sukeyuki Inaba of New York and Tokyo have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Yumi Inaba and Dorian Mark Beaumont Lowell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lowell of Cholesbury, Buckinghamshire, England.

title: Publishers Aid Apartheid
description: LEAD: Well-intentioned Americans are unwittingly aiding the South African Government in its systematic starvation of young black minds. A de facto embargo on the sale and shipment of American books to South Africa is hurting those we want to help most.

title: Fighting in Panama: Role of Religion; Spiritualist Practice Common In Panama and the Caribbean
description: Reliance on religious practices unfamiliar to most Americans is not unique to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. But this is not a major element in Panamanian culture, either, specialists on the region say.

title: DATA UPDATE
New Yorkers, etc.
description: Forget what will or won't be done in the year coming up. Think of the past 12 months and the things that were done that left a happy glow of satisfaction. And give a smaller thought to the things that were not done, and possibly regretted.

title: Tailgating in Europe And New Jersey
description: I disagree with Benedict M. Kohl's letter to the New Jersey editor (Nov. 12) in his comparisons of New Jersey's drivers to those of Europe. Tailgating is an aggressive behavior that is unwarranted under any circumstance, is unsafe at any speed and is illegal for obvious reasons. It occurs in all lanes, not just behind ''slowpokes in the fast lane.''

title: Yachting; I.O.C. Letter Alters Olympic Eligibility
description: International yachting officials in London paved the way last month for professional sailors to compete in the 1992 Olympics. But the road to eligibility has changed in light of a new communique from the International Olympic Committee.

title: New and Original Were the Hallmarks
description: THIS WAS THE YEAR OF MONEY.

title: Sports People; Stallings's Future
description: A month after being dismissed as head coach of the Phoenix Cardinals of the National Football League, Gene Stallings has been interviewed for the head coaching job at Navy, The Phoenix Gazette reported yesterday.

title: Texaco Star Rises Again
description: DURING the past five years, Texaco Inc. has earned some dubious distinctions. It became the victim of the largest damage award in history when a court ordered it to pay the Pennzoil Company $11 billion for illegally elbowing it aside to acquire the Getty Oil Company in 1984. It also became the largest company to file for protection from creditors under the bankruptcy law and the biggest target ever stalked by Carl I. Icahn, the wily corporate raider.

title: Marshall Plan Was in the Spring '47 Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Inching Forward in Cambodia
description: Prince Sihanouk, Cambodia's former chief of state, is a puzzlement. He says nothing wounds him more than the charge that he's an accomplice of Pol Pot, leader of the murderous Khmer Rouge. ''Pol Pot is like Hitler,'' he remarked in an interview with The Times's Steven Erlanger. ''Unless you kill him, you cannot oblige him to stop fighting and killing people.'' And yet the Prince's prime ally in Cambodia's agonizing civil war is none other than Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge.

title: New York's 30 Percent
description: Here's a sad statistic to remember on Christmas Eve: While about 20 percent of the nation's children are growing up in poverty, the figure in New York City is closer to 30 percent. Fifteen thousand of the city's youngsters are ''certified'' as homeless. Thousands still live under hazardous conditions in welfare hotels. Without a stable home or neighborhood, these children may shuttle from school to school. The Children's Aid Society has recently found so much malnutrition among them that its after-school centers in poor neighborhoods now must provide ''mini-meals'' instead of snacks.

title: University's Role In Marrow Program
description: The article ''Marrow Transplants More Available'' (Nov. 5) was an excellent report on important advances in cancer treatment in our state. It is heartening to know that there is new hope for patients with leukemia and lymphoma.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union; Baltic Separatists' Efforts Anger a Frayed Gorbachev
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today lashed out at separatists seeking to secede from the Soviet Union, warning that any such move in the country's current difficult political and economic conditions would ''sow discord, bloodshed and death.''

title: Emilia Battaglia to Marry
description: Emilia Christina Battaglia and Nicholas Sklitsis, 1984 graduates of Fordham University, are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Anthony S. Battaglia of Sunnyside, Queens, have announced. Miss Battaglia, 26 years old, is a senior publicist at St. Martin's Press in New York. Mr. Sklitsis, 26, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine Sklitsis of Brooklyn. He is a production manager with the Macmillan Publishing Company.

title: Frozen Inside Himself
description: THE COMFORTS OF MADNESS By Paul Sayer. 120 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown. On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass. Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bethesda, Md.;
I.B.M. a Partner In an Office Park
description: LEAD: PARK TOWER REALTY of New York and International Business Machines Corporation have formed a partnership here to develop 40 acres at RockSpring Park, a Class A office park with a 250,000-square-foot I.B.M. building.

title: An Enthralling 'Sunday in Park'
description: THERE is something doubly affirming about the Forum Theater Group's staging of Stephen Sondheim's ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' which runs through next Sunday. It compels one to treasure Sondheim and to trust the Forum.

title: Officeholders Need Renewal of Ethics
description: Each day's newspaper brings additional revelations of misconduct or criminal behavior on the part of elected or appointed officials. What is particularly saddening is the fact that the public does not respond in outrage. The attitude seems to be, ''What do you expect of politicians and public servants?'' Well, I expect more and I would like to see every person who betrays the public trust brought to account.

title: Melissa Shaw to Wed Gregory Fleming
description: The engagement of Melissa Danne Shaw to Gregory James Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil S. Fleming of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Dillard Munford of Atlanta and Crawford Shaw of New York and Quogue, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Abortion Viewed as Human Rights Issue
description: In a recent article appearing in the Long Island Weekly, certain facts concerning my successful re-election campaign were incorrectly stated. The article read, ''Mr. Dillon, a Roman Catholic, said during the campaign that his opposition to abortion derives from his religious beliefs.'' I never said that and, to the contrary, I have always said that my position is based on the scientific evidence that human life begins at conception, and the ethical principle that it is always wrong to unjustifiably kill innocent human life. In short, I view abortion as a human rights issue. DENIS DILLON District Attorney Nassau County

title: Miss Isman Weds David A. Appell
description: Amy Sharon Isman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Isman of New City, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to David Aaron Appell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael N. Appell, also of New City. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Abraham P. Bloch, the bridegroom's great-uncle, and Rabbi Jackie Friedman, the bridegroom's cousin, at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: Bitter Cold Giving Way to a 'Veritable Heat Wave'
description: The cold snap that has fastened onto the New York area since Thursday loosened its clutch just a bit yesterday.

title: The Sound of Synthetic Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills Rout Jets and Take Division Title
description: The Jets had nothing at stake today, and it showed.

title: J. L. Harrisingh Wed in Brooklyn To Miss Bertrand
description: Judith Ann Bertrand and John Lawrence Harrisingh, assistant corporation counsels for the city of New York, were married yesterday in the Harriet Packer Chapel at the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald Roberts, a Presbyterian minister.

title: A Calendar Of Holiday Music Events
description: THE following Christmas music events were omitted from an article that ran last week. All are free unless otherwise noted.

title: Portrait of Pan Am Suspect: Affable Exile, Fiery Avenger
description: A year after a four-pound plastic bomb blew Pan American World Airways Flight 103 out of Scotland's skies, a chain of luck, toil and sleuthing has led police officers to this university city, where a three-story apartment hides deep in a suburban cul-de-sac.

title: VAN ALLSBURG'S EXPRESS
description: IN 1984, CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG SAW SOMETHING IN HIS mind's eye. It was a train, standing still in a forest, puffing out steam into a silent, snowy night. Accustomed to being visited by such sights, Van Allsburg, an acclaimed children's book author and illustrator, calmly sat down at his drawing table and tugged at the edge of the image, seeking illumination.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE TWO GERMANYS;
What Follows the Fall of the Wall
description: LEAD: FOR the past 7 months, I have been living in West Berlin watching the birth of a post-Cold War economic order. But even as I witnessed the fall of the Berlin Wall, I felt uneasy at the prospects of what might develop.

title: IN SHORT: Nonfiction
description: HEIRESS: The Story of Christina Onassis. By Nigel Dempster. (Grove Weidenfeld, $17.95.) Pity Christina Onassis: all that money, but it couldn't buy her love. It was not for her lack of trying, however, and Nigel Dempster, a columnist for The London Daily Mail, tells all in ''Heiress.'' He divulges that a nearly 200-pound Onassis paid Luis Sosa Balsuado, an Argentine polo player, $1,000 a day for companionship and sex. The ungrateful Mr. Balsuado called her ''about as sexy as a wallowing hippo.'' A slimmer Christina gave her fourth husband, the Frenchman Thierry Roussell, $10 million as a wedding gift, but he returned to his old flame, Gaby Landhage. If the billionaire's battle against obesity cramped her love life, it did not inhibit her social life. People happily accepted invitations to Skorpios, her family's private Greek island. But she rudely asked them to leave if they did not play by her rule: no going to bed before the hostess. And Onassis, an amphetamine abuser, liked to dance all night. Abusing her body apparently took its toll, and Onassis died in November 1988 of a heart attack at the age of 37. Mr. Dempster softens his unflattering biography by references from friends and relatives that blame Onassis' parents for her behavior. Christina looked to men to provide the love she missed as a child, they say; her Dior-dressed dolls and the best nannies and tutors were no substitute for parental attention. Mr. Dempster's look at Onassis' life is as shallow as the gossip on which it is based, merely echoing the poor-little-rich-girl view of the heiress already provided by the news media.

title: Resorts in Snow-Shy Alps Go Beyond Skiing
description: For the third year in a row, mountain resorts in Europe's Alps are expecting a brown Christmas instead of a white one.

title: No Cutbacks on Office Christmas Parties
description: REPORTS of the death of the office Christmas party have been greatly exaggerated. In county business circles it appears that when it comes to cutbacks in the budget, the Christmas party is the last to go.

title: Lifestyle: Evening Hours; Holiday Whirls, Onstage and Off, For the Young
description: Junior sophisticates and teen-agers celebrated the holidays last Sunday at the 33d annual Gold and Silver Ball. Seven hundred 15-to-18-year-olds, the girls in black off-the-shoulder dresses with short skirts, danced the night away at the benefit party of the Youth Counseling League. There was a lot of long hair being tossed with abandon on the dance floor at the Palladium and a lot of mad money hidden in shoes, which have become an alternative to hand and shoulder bags as places for safekeeping.

title: Miss Glaeberman PlansTo Wed J. C. Hammond
description: June wedding plans have been announced for Joanne Glaeberman and Jonathan Craig Hammond.

title:
FOCUS: Washington, D.C.;
Developers and Churches Making Deals
description: LEAD: WITH increasing frequency, developers here are cutting real estate deals that lead to commercial and residential projects on downtown church sites. Already, agreements have been made to create 490,000 square feet of mixed-use buildings on three church-owned sites.

title: DATA BANK: Dec. 24, 1989
CRIME
description: It seemed appropriate, in keeping with the spirit of the holidays, to root around in current mystery releases for some nice books. Nothing as pointedly seasonal as ''Corpus Christmas'' or 'Mistletoe Mysteries,'' among other titles we've seen of late; merely something of gentle sensibility. A story with a hint of culture, perhaps, or a sleuth with a bit of class. Something, anyway, that we might read by the burning Yule log, without feeling the urge to pitch it into the blaze.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: Dear Ms. Klaus:

title: Meals vs. Money: Spouses Struggle to Redefine Roles
description: FOR the first 12 years of his marriage, Paul Maccio of New Haven worked 15 hours a day as a plumbing and heating mechanic. When he returned home, he expected to find a dinner prepared by his wife, Lisa, on the table, clean socks in his drawer and the evening newspaper next to his favorite chair. But those days are long gone.

title: Campus Life: Duke; Satirical Barbs Lead to Dismissal Of Student Editor
description: The removal this month of a student editor of a Duke University humor magazine has touched off a heated debate about the application of the First Amendment to university publications and about race relations on campus. The action was a response to the magazine's publication of satirical articles construed by some community members as racist.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; For Picadillo, Creativity Can Take Wing
description: There are as many versions of picadillo as there are regions of Mexico. Some call for picadillo, a mixture of ground meat, spices and some kind of fruit, to be made with beef or pork. Most call for raisins as the sweetening agent, but one calls for pineapple, and another is made with eggs. Some are spiced with hot chilies; some are not. Some call for almonds; others have no nuts at all.

title: In Praise of The Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street's Arbitration System: Friend or Foe?
description: ''WHEN Naivete Meets Wall Street'' (Dec. 3) drew many letters from readers. The article examined the way investor complaints have been handled on Wall Street in the aftermath of a United States Supreme Court decision in May 1987 upholding the securities industry's right to compel customers to submit their complaints to an industry-run arbitration forum. The story cited critics' concerns about the fairness of the process. And it told the story of Patricia Chegut, a New Jersey school teacher, who took a dispute with her broker to an arbitration panel and was awarded no compensation for her losses.

title: Southampton Considering New System of Trails
description: LEAD: UNDER a proposal before the Town of Southampton, hikers, horseback riders, cross-country skiers, runners, bird watchers and others pursuing outdoor activities would be able to use a system of trails across public and private land from Sag Harbor to Sagaponack.

title: Landmarks On the Journey to Posterity
description: IN THE ANNUAL MEMORY SEARCH for the dying year's most important musical events, the hunter must be careful not to be lured off into neighboring cultural categories. The electronic information bank is invaluable in enforcing such discipline. In the absence of such help, one is too easily distracted by strange notes found lying about the desk at year's end. To cite a particularly serious case, this critic's overloaded and unassisted memory could have blacked out all of 1989's significant cultural events except the 35th anniversary of the TV dinner and the centennial of the bra.

title: Kathleen Rochester, Minister, to Wed
description: The Rev. Kathleen Gail McCombe Rochester, the pastor of the First United Methodist Church in East Hampton, L.I., and David Paul Turnbole, a service-order writer for Parkview Auto Sales in Watertown, N.Y., plan to be married in June. The prospective bride is a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John H. McCombe of Stuart, Fla. Mr. Turnbole is a son of Mrs. Orlin Rohde of Ellisburg, N.Y., and the late Paul Turnbole.

title: Candied Fruit of Provence: Sweet Tradition
description: ON Christmas Eve throughout the south of France a ritual takes place as it has for centuries. To insure good fortune in the coming year a platter is passed around the dining table. It holds the celebrated treize desserts, 13 of the region's delicacies. Although the selection may vary, it is likely to include walnuts and almonds, apricots and figs, almond-based calisson candies and nut-studded nougats and what some consider the star attraction, colorful candied fruits confits. This baker's dozen of Provencal treats represents the gifts that the three wise men offered to the baby Jesus.

title: Getting to Know Your Synchronized Input Shaft
description: 1990 CHEVROLET S-10 OWNER'S MANUAL Illustrated. Paginated by chapter. Detroit: Helm. Free with vehicle; otherwise, $4. THE 1990 BUICK LeSABRE OWNER'S MANUAL Illustrated. 300 pp. Flint, Mich.: Service Publications. Free with vehicle; otherwise, $6.

title: Animal Rescues: Saving a Goose
description: Joan Baron's account ''Rescue Mission: Saving a Swan'' (Opinion, Dec. 3) reminded me of the time, some years ago, when I foiled the kidnapping of a large goose at the pond located at Nassau Boulevard and Hempstead Avenue in West Hempstead.

title: On Being Green
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Decade Of Catching Up, Prices Soar Anew
description: IN ANTIQUES AS IN ART, THEJU astounding prices paid at auction for certain rarities became the most discussed development of the last year - and the decade. The fallout from recent sales of pieces of furniture and decorative art for the seven-figure prices formerly reserved for Renoirs and Rembrandts is bound to be felt for years to come.

title:
GARDENING;
Holly, a Symbol of the Winter Solstice
description: LEAD: HOLLY has played an important role in midwinter festivals at least as far back as the Druids' celebration of the winter solstice. Once the shortest day of the year had passed, they knew that spring would bring forth rebirth. Plants that retained their green leaves throughout the winter were considered to be sacred; they were thought to be the repositories of the life that would return to plants that had lost their leaves and were considered to be dead.

title: Miss Ceremsak to Marry
description: Katharine Ceremsak, an owner of Voila Designs, a textile design concern in Boston, and Leonard Andres, a doctoral candidate in respiratory biology at Harvard University, are planning a May wedding. Miss Ceremsak, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Ceremsak of Evergreen, Colo. She graduated from the University of Colorado. Her father retired as a pathologist. Mr. Andres, 29, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard P. Andres of New York. His father is an assistant vice president of the Chemical Bank in New York; his mother, Barbara Andres, is an actress.

title: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Egypt
description: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

title: IN SHORT: Fiction
description: LEAD: ME SO FAR. By Donald Jack. (Doubleday, $17.95.) This seventh in the Bandy Papers series is Donald Jack's farewell to his puckish Canadian soldier of fortune, Bartholomew Bandy. Having survived the Great War with just a bit of an alienation and alcohol problem, Bandy in 1925 is to be found aboard a ship called the Viceroy of India, embarrassing his dear friend Prince Khooshie of the independent state of Jhamjarh by offending Field Marshal Lord Blount, who unfortunately happens to be the Viceroy of India.

title: Educating The Handicapped
description: Sheila Kislik, president of the Hewlett-Woodmere Board of Education is quoted (''In 5 Towns District a Teacher Impasse,'' Nov. 26) as saying that 65 percent of every annual budget is set in stone and we have no control over it, such as transportation and help to the handicapped.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Tax Plan Splits Young and Old
description: LEAD: THE Mayor of this city of 380,000 people, Sophie Masloff, has successfully led an effort here to shift part of the tax burden from wage earners to property owners. The proposal, which she described as a tax swap, was approved last Wednesday by the City Council and will become effective on Jan. 1.

title: Ms. Thompson Weds S. W. Surko
description: Elizabeth Barry Thompson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Thompson of New York, was married there yesterday to Lieut. Stephen William Surko, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Surko Jr. of Lexington, Mass. Daniel Eaton Pentlarge, a student minister of the Unitarian Universalist Association, performed the ceremony at the Union Club.

title: TALKING: Neighbors; Dealing With Noise Or Worse
description: IMAGINE, for a moment, that the shouting and arguing from the apartment next door have been getting worse. Drug dealing, or at least drug use, is suspected and there is concern about violence. Or the woman down the hall holds regular psychotherapy sessions. Patients start using the hallway as a waiting room, leaving litter and creating a din, as happened recently in a Manhattan co-op building. The woman insists these are friends just waiting for her to answer the door.

title: IN SHORT: Fiction
description: WALK WITH THE SICKLE MOON. By Helen Norris. (Birch Lane/Carol Publishing, $15.95.) A misty coastal town in the north of France. A lonely but attractive American widow. An attractive but lonely local doctor. A quest. It's autumn in Montreuil, nine years after World War II has ended, and it seems that romance is as inevitable as rain. That's just the trouble with Helen Norris's fourth novel; it's a formula, so almost everything is inevitable. Laura Kendall, in search of the child that her son, once stationed in France, had fathered before he died, finds the answers she needs about lineage and love in a kind of made-for-television manner. We're way ahead of her most of the time. When her car skids off a country road, we know that her rescuer is Someone Special. When she takes tea with another guest at her hotel, she coincidentally meets a ''fair-haired boy, perhaps six or seven,'' who is learning English. The dialogue doesn't help inject much realism; it's frequently stilted because the characters talk across a language barrier, in ''translatable'' phrases. Eventually, all this starts to bother even the author. Near the end of ''Walk With the Sickle Moon,'' the hero jokes that certain events could turn out ''like a bad novel.'' By then it's too late for apologies.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SATELLITES;
For Direct T.V. Broadcast, More Hope Abroad Than Home
description: LEAD: Starting a national television network in this country is an extraordinary challenge. The frequencies that network affiliates use to broadcast television signals to households are nearly used up in major markets. And cable operators and the networks have strong ties with local distributors of programming, making it tough for newcomers to break in.

title: Saving the Sands-Willets House, a Mansion with a Prodigious Past
description: WHEN it was young, the great house commanded a panoramic view of what was once the northern East Meadow (now the Town of North Hempstead) between two arms of the Sound, an area from which farmers' produce was shipped out to 18th-century markets on the Island and in New York and New England.

title: Campus Life: Miami; Fraternity Warned For Sexist Acts At a Viking Party
description: Men wearing barbarian outfits, carrying women over their shoulders, singing songs and drinking alcohol is cause for concern in 1989, and at Miami University something has been done about it.

title: Deborah Jacobs to Wed M. J. Wiskind
description: Cynthia Jacobs of Ardsley, N.Y., and Stephen E. Jacobs of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Deborah Faye Jacobs to Michael James Wiskind, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton I. Wiskind of Akron, Ohio. A May wedding is planned.

title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints
description: LEAD: DRIVERS on Long Island highways who are stopped for sobriety tests this holiday season are more likely than ever to be checked by police officers also trained to tell if the drivers are under the influence of drugs.

title: A New Musical Finds Comedy And Romance in Hard Times
description: WILLIAM FINN thought he'd never get out of the soup kitchen where he'd been slaving for more than seven years on his new musical. Then along came the producer Joseph Papp to offer him not a way out of the kitchen but a new recipe for making soup. What they cooked up was a new version of ''Romance in Hard Times,'' a quirkily comic musical written and composed by Mr. Finn and set in a Depression-era soup kitchen. It opens Thursday at the Public Theater.

title: Egypt-Syria Rift Reported Near End
description: Egypt and Syria appeared ready today to end a 12-year break in diplomatic relations within the next few weeks, senior Egyptian and Syrian officials said here today.

title: Fighting in Panama: United Nations; Security Council Condemnation of Invasion Vetoed
description: The United States, Britain and France used their vetoes as permanent members of the Security Council today to block a resolution criticizing the American invasion of Panama, although a majority of the Council's 15 members voted in favor.

title: Sports People; Homeward Bound
description: HE bypassed the National Basketball Association to play professional basketball in Italy, but a homesick Danny Ferry is heading back to the United States. Not permanently; just to be home for the holidays.

title: Upheaval in the East: A Rising Star; A Man Who Could Become Rumania's Leader
description: Ion Iliescu, who announced the arrest of President Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania today, is regarded by analysts and experts here as a rising leader who one day may become Rumania's head of state.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: The close-at-hand problem is always the one the defender must take care of before anything else, but the solution should include what you are committing yourself to over the long haul.

title: Mission of Hope for the Jewish Faithful in Poland
description: THIS is a Hanukkah full of hope for Jerzy Kichler. Mr. Kichler, a Polish Jew, has struggled for nine years to help rebuild the Jewish community in Poland, which was nearly destroyed by Hitler and further reduced by postwar emigration. As the leader of a small Jewish study group in Wroclaw, a city northwest of Cracow, he has met with the expected resistance of the Communist authorities and the unexpected resistance of the remaining Orthodox Jews.

title: In China, I'd Be Dead
description: I was the deputy commander of the student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. Last April, May and June, Chinese students nonviolently petitioned their Government to discuss human rights and put an end to corruption. Great expectation and hope filled the air. It was our spring. Now it is our winter. Army tanks and guns killed and wounded thousands. Hundreds of thousands were arrested; many were tortured. Amnesty International has documented secret executions, perhaps as many as 10,000, since June 4.

title: Games People Play Extend to Murder
description: THE setting of Tim Kelly's mystery play ''Murder Game,'' now at the Broadhollow Theater in Farmingdale, is an architectural oddity replete with cellar, attic and secret passageways.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Scene; Gunfire and Confusion Temper a City's Elation
description: Armed skirmishes between Government troops and the security police swirled today across this city that had led the revolution against the deposed Rumanian leader, Nicolae Ceausescu.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
