A New Meadowlands Condo Community
description: LEAD: IN the decade since the Meadowlands shed its image as an industrial wasteland and became a business and entertainment center, hotels, office towers, retail strips and sports and manufacturing complexes have come to dot the landscape, providing some 55,000 jobs.

title: Towns Challenge Cable TV Companies
description: LEAD: FACED with rising rates and complaints of inadequate service and limited programming options, more than 90 percent of New Jersey's 567 municipalities will be squaring off with their cable operators over the next five years as their current cable television franchise agreements come up for renewal.

title:
INVESTING;
Nintendo as Nemesis
description: LEAD: EACH year, Nintendo sales in the United States rise. And each year, American toy makers ask themselves how soon the fad will peak.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Mellow Newcomer in Bedford Hills
description: LEAD: Unabashedly lacey half-curtains contradict the mounted polo players on the wallpaper and stern-looking tack draped over wall lamps, but a fireplace, flowers, candlelight and a table of desserts mellow this restaurant's interesting if complex space, which was last occupied by Riches.

title: Lisa S. Brier Wed To Peter D. Cole
description: At the Dix Hills (N.Y.) Jewish Center, Lisa Sharon Brier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin S. Brier of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Peter David Cole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Cole of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Stanley Wernick officiated.

title: How Santa Reined In My Thumb Habit
description: MY thumb was always in my mouth. My parents weren't mean about trying to break me of the habit, but they did use fear tactics.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: What must be considered the most remarkable bridge conspiracy occurred 40 years ago in the Philadelphia area. A special Christmas duplicate game was ruled with an iron fist in a velvet glove by the great Olive Petersen. It was played at the club she ran in her home in St. Davids Mrs. Petersen was one of the grande dames of the game, with a career as player, writer and teacher that spanned the evolution of auction bridge into contract. She had been associated with the legendary Milton Work in various capacities and her many tournament victories included three consecutive National Mixed Team titles. She had a kind heart as the evening was to demonstrate. The sequel is clearly recalled by Judge Burrell Ives Humphreys of Wayne, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
Holly, a Symbol of the Winter Solstice
description: LEAD: HOLLY has played an important role in midwinter festivals at least as far back as the Druids' celebration of the winter solstice. Once the shortest day of the year had passed, they knew that spring would bring forth rebirth. Plants that retained their green leaves throughout the winter were considered to be sacred; they were thought to be the repositories of the life that would return to plants that had lost their leaves and were considered to be dead.

title: Not That Dumb
description: To the Editor:

title: Part of ''Miracle on 34th St.'' May Live On in Greenburgh Display
description: LEAD: THE horses still prance, the Santas still wave, the carolers still seem to be singing. The window display at the Aphrodite Restaurant and Catering establishment on West Hartsdale Avenue in Greenburgh is 42 years old - possibly the oldest of its kind in the county - but the mechanized figures still fascinate onlookers with their movements.

title:
FOCUS;
In Washington, Three Sites To Be Built
description: LEAD: With increasing frequency, developers here are cutting real estate deals that lead to commercial and residential projects on downtown church sites. Already, agreements have been made to create 490,000 square feet of mixed-use buildings on three church-owned sites.

title: Hard-Boiled Detectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; In a Winter Season for Discontent, An Midday Sport for King Penguins
description: For aficionados of racing, winter is a time of discontent, of insignificant races and of memories of exactas that might have been. The Breeders' Cup, the last big event of the fall season, marks the edge of the racing doldrums, which extend until the trumpet sounds in Florida or California in February or March.

title: Office Construction in the Doldrums
description: THE New York region's commercial real estate developers, whose teeming construction sites and vastly profitable office ventures became a symbol of the go-go 80's, are entering the new decade with sharply reduced plans and protracted construction schedules.

title: Shared-Services Offices Making a Mark
description: LEAD: IT didn't take long for John V. Moran to decide on leasing a shared-services office, rather than traditional commercial space, when he shopped for space in the central business district of Morristown, N.J.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: If you're like me, you're probably having visions of mistletoe, eggnog and presents under the tree. It would be nice to think that all's well with the world, too. But there's trouble in Photo Land, I'm afraid.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office Sublets; Soft Manhattan Market Brings Rental Opportunities
description: THE shrinking space requirements of tenants in nearly every office district in Manhattan are pushing increasing amounts of sublet space onto an already soft office market, real estate professionals say.

title: Judging Why Earl Warren Was Hailed as 'Super Chief'
description: THIRTY-SIX YEARS AGO, in one of those wonderful twists of politics, the newly inaugurated President Dwight D. Eisenhower made good on a private pledge that he never dreamed he'd have to keep. During the Republican Convention the summer before, Ike had managed to get the support of a key rival, Gov. Earl Warren of California. A quid for the quo, it seems, was that Warren was promised the first vacancy on the United States Supreme Court.

title: Logistics: A Trendy Management Tool
description: EARLY last year, the distribution system at Alpo Petfoods Inc. was a major disappointment for top management. The company's 14 warehouses were located near its customers, but service nevertheless was wanting. In fact, in a survey of its 400 major customers, the company, based in Allentown, Pa., was rated below several of its rivals in service.

title: Beyond Language
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE/On Pop Records
description: Although the past year produced more than the usual number of fine pop albums, none found the kind of critical and commercial consensus that ''Tracy Chapman,'' Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' and U2's ''Joshua Tree'' won in the three previous years. The following is a personal Top 10 in rough order of preference, plus an alphabetical listing of runners-up.

title: 'Cartoons Come to Paterson'
description: SINCE a fire in its administrative quarters last year, the Paterson Museum has been rather subdued - not that it is ever very active. This ''warehouse'' of local history in the Rogers Building, which was once an assembly plant for locomotives, is the centerpiece of the Great Falls Historic District. Yet it seems to be awaiting the arrival of the cultural renaissance that was announced way back in the 1970's.

title: Glory Days for Big Exhibitions, Continued
description: IN TERMS OF THE BIG-SCALE MUSE-um exhibition, the 1980's went out in glory, both in the United States and in Europe. Our luck held all the way from Kasimir Malevich in Amsterdam at the outset of 1989 to Frans Hals at the National Gallery of Art in Washington and Velazquez at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, 10 or 11 months later.

title: Lifestyle; Boxing Day, A Most Civilized Import
description: Tuesday, while many New Yorkers are returning Christmas gifts, Britons living in the city will still be in a giving mood. They will be observing Boxing Day.

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: ''Smile, Darn You, Smile'' is simply another unfunny attempt to degrade a profession which has unfairly taken more than its share of unthinking comedic criticism.

title: Dr. Kroop Plans to Wed
description: Dr. Ellen Nancy Kroop and Dr. Richard Paul Martin, 1989 graduates of New York Medical College who are both beginning residencies, plan to marry in August. Dr. Kroop, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Kroop of Teaneck, N.J. Dr. Martin, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Martin of Hamden, Conn. The prospective bride, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, is at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C.; her fiance, a Yale University graduate, at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

title: Christine Gleichauf Engaged
description: Christine Noel Gleichauf and Peter Metz, Cornell University graduates, plan to marry in October, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Gleichauf of Rochester, have announced. Mr. Metz, 25 years old, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Metz of Freeport, L.I. Ms. Gleichauf, 25, received a master's degree in nutritional sciences from Cornell. She is a doctoral candidate in biomedical sciences at New York University. Mr. Metz is the manager of analysis at the New York advertising-marketing agency of Barry Blau & Partners.

title: Mirroring Small-Town Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Weapons Are They, Anyway?
description: GUARDIANS OF THE ARSENAL The Politics of Nuclear Strategy. By Janne E. Nolan. 320 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Basic Books. $21.95.

title: Cold Wave Testing Natural Gas System
description: With bitter arctic cold sweeping across much of the nation, dozens of utilities and large industrial customers are scrambling to secure enough energy to avoid shortages and plant shutdowns.

title: As American As The Taj Mahal
description: To the Editor:

title: When Leverage Works
description: SUMNER REDSTONE, the 66-year-old owner of Viacom Inc., has always lectured his children about the perils of dwelling on past mistakes. ''I tell them I don't want to hear any 'woulda, shoulda or coulda,' '' he said.

title: From the 'Music Box' Emerges the Nazi Demon
description: FOR SOME CHILDREN, THE question is as innocent as the birds and the bees: ''What did you do in the war, Daddy?'' But for the American writer Joe Eszterhas, that question was never innocent. It was one of the central terrors of his childhood, of growing up in the shadow of the Holocaust.

title: No Headline
description: AT parties, William A. Taylor Jr. keeps his eyes on the noses. As a professional caricaturist, he finds that parties and other gatherings are good places to work, and that he works best when he concentrates on a subject's nose.

title: Anne Adler to Marry J. W. Tarbell Jr.
description: March wedding plans have been announced for Anne Southall Adler and John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr., the son of Mrs. Tarbell of Needham, Mass., and the late Mr. Tarbell, by the prospective bride's parents, Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler, both of New York.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia; Havel and Dubcek to Take Leading Prague Posts
description: The playwright Vaclav Havel will become President of Czechoslovakia next week and the ousted Communist leader Alexander Dubcek will take over as chairman of Parliament under a political agreement announced today.

title:
The View From: The Connecticut Historical Society;
What Is History? A Myriad of Answers
description: LEAD: VISITORS to the Museum of the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford can see paintings, prints, furniture, books, manuscripts and decorative art - all kinds of objects made in Connecticut or owned by its people - which are displayed for their artistic value and for what they reveal about the state's history.

title: PRESSURING PERDUE
description: TO THE EDITOR: Henry Spira's denouncement of the fur and leather industry is not substantiated by facts (''Pressuring Perdue,'' by Barnaby J. Feder, Nov. 26). One of the biggest problems today is pollution created by man, and one of the major causes of this pollution is the manufacture of synthetics. Fur and leather, in contrast, are an organic, biodegradable resource.

title: IN SHORT: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: DEAR DAD: Letters From an Adult Child. By Louie Anderson. (Viking, $16.95.) Louie Anderson, the obese, sweet-faced comedian, is kicking fat jokes, he reports in ''Dear Dad,'' an engagingly candid memoir written as a series of letters to his dead father. Fat jokes have been Mr. Anderson's bread and butter - his bacon - but they have become painful for him.

title: Question of the Week; Will East German Athletes Continue to Dominate?
description: What is not commonly known in America is that the East German assembly line system, while purporting to make sport available to everyone, was actually breaking many of its best athletes.

title: Style Makers; Mimi Chapia, Found-Object Artist
description: As long as she can remember, Mimi Chapia has kept her eye peeled for great junk.

title: Rock's Own Generation Gap, From Pauls Abdula to the Who
description: POPULAR MUSIC HAD A BUSY decade - dividing and recombining genres, tuning in to the world, championing causes, conquering and adapting to television, facing censorship attempts, mastering and being transformed by digital technology. In 1989, it hoped to act like entertainment, simply selling dance records, filling auditoriums and cashing in on the past. But it could't turn back.

title: Permission to Lie to Yourself
description: LEAD: POSITIVE ILLUSIONS Creative Self-Deception and the Healthy Mind. By Shelley E. Taylor. 301 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: POSTINGS: Project Precertification; Cutting Red Tape
description: A new ''call-up'' procedure takes effect in New York City Wednesday aimed at combatting the red tape that delays action on development proposals. Mandated by the city's revised Charter, the procedure allows a developer whose plans are under preliminary interagency review to appeal for a public review once 180 days have elapsed from the filing date.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Trivial Pursuits And Huge Thoughts
description: Like any other decade, this one got a reputation as trivial in the arts-and-literature department. In films, Americans wanted things kept light. At the same time, they bought books about chaos, the decline of their nation and the closing of their mind. Best Sellers

title: Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to 'Smile, Darn You, Smile'
description: Apparently, Mrs. Klaus decided to adopt a Neil Simon one-liner approach to her innermost feelings about dentistry in general and dentists in particular.

title: Jennifer A. Nelson Marries
description: Jennifer Anne Nelson and Kjell Olof Rojvall were married yesterday at Trinity Lutheran Church in Burlingame, Calif., by the Rev. Dr. John P. Uhlig. Mrs. Rojvall, 26 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford R. Nelson of San Francisco. A graduate of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, she is an assistant editor at McGraw-Hill's nuclear publications. The bridegroom, 35, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Olof I. Rojvall of Falun, Sweden. He has a master's degree in architecture from the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm and an M.B.A. from Columbia and is a controller in North Brunswick, N.J., for Asea Brown Boveri Turbine, an engineering company.

title: Critic's Notebook; Latin Music, Where the Big Bands Live On
description: In the mid-1940's, when the big bands lost their dance legs and began playing music for listening, Latin music took up both their orchestral power and the impulse to entertain with sophistication. The salsa bands of Machito and Tito Puente and, later, Eddie Palmieri and a host of others, brought jazz's harmonic sophistication and horn arrangements to the Afro-Hispanic base of Cuban music.

title: Review/Film; 'Music Box,' on Innocence, Evil and the Holocaust
description: With her hair in no-nonsense curls, her drab businesswoman's clothes and a discreet cross around her neck, Jessica Lange is the picture of a working-class daughter whose accomplishments have far outreached her immigrant father's dreams. As Ann Talbot, a Chicago lawyer who defends her father against charges that he was a notoriously brutal member of the Hungarian secret police in World War II, Ms. Lange gives her best performance since ''Frances.''

title: Upheaval in the East: The Countryside; Snipers in a Steeple: The Carnage Shocks Rumanian Village
description: Blood stains the steps of the church of this border town in the southern Rumanian farmlands.

title: King of the Playroom Hath Fallen
description: As children across America revel in their Christmas gifts, toy manufacturers are tallying up the final rush of sales. For one grand old name of the playroom, it is proving to be anything but a merry Christmas.

title: Wedding Binds Students But Separates Families
description: Mamie Xuemin Zhu and Charles Kecheng Li were wed a few days ago in the recreation room of the Wilcrest Baptist Church. Red and pink streamers draped the doors and pink satin hearts were on the wall.

title: Hong Kong Journal; Colony's Cold Shoulder for Democracy's Goddess
description: When an obscure documentary, ''Mainland China 1989,'' was screened in an art theater here last week, Hong Kong censors cut 17 minutes from the 78-minute film, deleting interviews with a mainland dissident and several pro-democracy student leaders. Officials said that without the cuts, the film could ''seriously damage our relations with other countries.''

title: One Worker Killed and Several Hurt in Blast at Louisiana Refinery
description: A thunderous explosion rocked an Exxon refinery today, setting fire to tanks full of heating oil and lubricants, killing one person and slightly injuring several others, officials said.

title: Board of Estimate Approves Fordham Plan to Sell Site at Lincoln Center
description: A plan for Fordham University to sell part of its Lincoln Center campus to a commercial housing developer has been approved by New York City's Board of Estimate.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: The Overview; Rumanian Army Gains in Capital but Battle Goes On
description: Bursts of gunfire sounded through this exultant but tense capital today and into the night as secret police officers loyal to the ousted dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, held out and harassed the new provisional government claiming power in what had been the most rigorously controlled state in Eastern Europe.

title: Iran-Backed Fighters in Lebanon Make Gains Over Rival Muslims
description: Shiite Muslim fundamentalists backed by Iran made further advances today on the second day of warfare with Syrian-backed Shiite militiamen in southern Lebanon. The fighting threatened to spill into the capital.

title: Steelers Alive for Wild Card
description: Louis Lipps caught two touchdown passes and Rod Woodson set up 10 points with a kickoff return and an interception today as the Pittsburgh Steelers kept their playoff hopes alive with a 31-22 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: Col. VASILE ARONESCU, a Securitate chief: vah-SEE-leh ah-roh-NESS-koo

title: Old Elm in Boston Is Felled
description: A 150-year-old elm has been cut down after the city tree warden deemed the 150-foot elm too sick to save. ''It was too far gone,'' said the tree warden, Brian Gilbert. The Parks and Recreation commissioner, Lawrence A. Dwyer, said the 62-inch thick, 70-foot-tall tree on Boston Common was decayed almost all the way through in some places The removal prompted criticism from some preservationists, who have said city officials wanted to remove the tree to make room for a visitors' center.

title: Upheaval in the East: The New Leaders; Bucharest Government Has Yet to Take Shape
description: Little is known in the United States about the members of the Council of National Salvation, the group trying to organize a government in Rumania following the fall of President Nicolae Ceausescu, State Department analysts said today.

title: Reviewing 1989 With 1990 in Mind
description: Not every story in auto racing ends, neatly and definitively, with the wave of a checkered flag. Some take a little longer to develop, and the past year had its share of these.

title: Double Dates
description: ''Are you free for lunch a week from Thursday?''

title: Upheaval in the East: Timisoara; Two American and Two European Journalists Shot and Wounded
description: Two American and two European journalists were shot and wounded while covering the fighting in Timisoara between insurgents and forces loyal to the deposed President, Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: 2 Deaths in New York Attributed to the Cold
description: Two men, one in Brooklyn and the other in the Bronx, died yesterday, apparently because of the extreme cold.

title: Fighting in Panama; Pentagon Releases List of Servicemen Killed
description: The Pentagon has been releasing the names of servicemen killed in the Panamanian invasion as their next of kin are notified. Here are the names released so far: BARNARD, Staff Sgt. Larry R., an infantryman and ranger, and a native of Hallstead, Pa. BROWN, Pfc. Roy Dennis Jr., an infantryman and a native of Buena Park, Calif. COATES, Pfc. Vance T., an infantryman and a native of Great Falls, Mont. CONNORS, Lt. (j.g.) John Patrick, a member of the Navy's special operations unit known as the SEALS, based at Little Creek, Va., and a native of Arlington, Mass. DAVES, Pfc. Jerry Scott, a member of the 1st Battalion, 504th Parachute Infantry Regiment and a native of Hope Mills, N.C. DEBLOIS, Sgt. Michael A., an infantryman, of Dubach, La. DENSON, Pfc. Martin D., an infantryman and a native of Abilene, Tex. GIBBS, Specialist William D., an infantryman and a native of Marina, Calif. HUNTER, 1st Lt. John Wessel, an aviator with the Headquarters and Support Company from the 160th Aviation Battalion, based in Fort Campbell, Ky., of Victor, Mont. ISAAK, Cpl. Garreth C., a marine and a native of Greenville, S.C. LEAR, Specialist Phillip S., an infantryman based at Fort Lewis, Wash., of Westminster, S.C. MANRIQUELOZNO, Specialist Alejandro I., a native of Lauderhill, Fla. MARKWELL, Pfc. James William, a medic and a native of Cincinnati. McFAUL, Chief Engineman Donald Lewis, a SEAL based at Little Creek, Va., and a native of San Diego. OWENS, Chief Warrant Officer Wilson B., an aviator with the B Company, 160th Aviation Battalion based at Fort Campbell, Ky., from North Myrtle Beach, S.C. PEREZ, Cpl. Ivan D., an Army infantryman based at Fort Polk, La., of Pawtucket, R.I. PORTER, Chief Warrant Officer Andrew P., an aviator with B Company, 1st Battalion, 123rd Aviation Regiment, 7th Infantry Division based at Fort Ord, Calif., from St. Clair, Mich. PRICE, Pfc. John Mark, an infantryman and a native of Conover, Wis. RODRIGUEZ, Torpedoman's mate Second Class Issac George, a SEAL and a native of Missouri City, Tex. ROTH, Pfc. Scott Lee a military policeman stationed at Fort Hood, Texas, of Killeen, Texas. SCOTT, Pvt. 2 Kenneth Douglas, an infantryman and a native of Princeton, W. Va. TABOR, Pvt. James Allen Tabor, a heavy weapons specialist from the Headquarters Company, 4th Battalion, 325th Parachute Infantry Regiment based at Fort Bragg, N.C., from Montrose, Colo. TILGHMAN, Boatswain's Mate 1st Class Christopher Tilghman, a SEAL based at Little Creek, Va., and a native of Kailua, Hawaii.

title: Knicks Winning With Odd Lineups
description: The Knicks did not just win their last two games. Stu Jackson, their rookie coach, made the victories happen by devising odd but effective fourth-quarter lineups and strategies. In the game against the Washington Bullets on Friday night and the one with the Nets on Saturday, several Knick starters found themselves cheering from the bench while substitutes finished in their places.

title: For Wyche, Criticism Is Give-and-Take
description: THE advice a mentor once offered seemed prudent to Sam Wyche.

title: Japanese Invest in 2 Hollywood Productions
description: In another of the myriad ways in which Japan is entering the American movie business, two Japanese companies are spending $30 million to produce a science-fiction film for international release and a related but factual series for Japanese television.

title: A Christmas  [ Carol ]  Bonus
description: The first ghost arrived five minutes late.

title: BUISNESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Heaven On Bedford Avenue
description: LEAD: Habituees of Fifth Avenue who mourn the closing of B. Altman's department store in Manhattan know nothing of suffering. Because when it comes to feeling abandoned and deprived, Brooklynites know the worst. Not because we were deserted by the Dodgers; that was small potatoes. No, I'm talking true desolation.

title: NORIEGA SEEKS ASYLUM AT VATICAN EMBASSY; HIS FUTURE UNCERTAIN; PANAMANIANS CHEER
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader in hiding since American troops invaded last week to overthrow and capture him, took refuge today in the residence of the Vatican's representative here and requested political asylum, the American military commander said.

title: Final Sunday Doesn't Settle Everything
description: Tonight's final game of the 16-week National Football League season is required to complete the Super Bowl XXIV playoff picture, a zany puzzle that shifted dramatically yesterday. Two of the 10 playoff spots are undetermined, one in each conference.

title: Japanoply
description: LEAD: Japan's big apple shopping spree Made the savants prophesy That Christmas tourists soon will see The Rockefeller Center tree As a six inch high bonsai.

title: Brazil's New Chief Raises Doubts on Amazon
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24 - Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's conservative president-elect, has aroused the skepticism of environmentalists and is a mystery on a key issue of world concern: preservation of the Amazon.

title: A Growing Interest in an Ancient Asian Art
description: The Asian Art Museum of San Francisco has lately added another to its list of distinctions: Dr. Kumja Paik Kim, the nation's first curator of Korean art.

title: Why Apologize for El Salvador?
description: The Salvadoran Army remains the prime suspect in the November murder of six Jesuit priests, a cook and her daughter. Warning signs abound that the Bush Administration is more eager to ease pressure on the Salvadoran Government than to bring the killers to justice. This does no favor to President Alfredo Cristiani, and seriously misreads American opinion.

title: FIGHTING IN PANAMA: The Palace; In Noriega's Home, Decor Paints a Picture of Extravagance
description: As maximum leader of Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega lived almost as garishly and as extravagantly as the Colombian drug traffickers who for years are said to have been his business partners.

title: Harry Kraf, Lawmaker From West Bronx, 82
description: Harry Kraf, who as chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation sponsored bills to increase staff members in New York State institutions for the retarded, died of cancer on Friday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 82 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Nekoosa Bid Said to Gain
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said Friday that the Federal Trade Commission had found no antitrust violations in its proposed acquisition of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation and had closed its investigation of the deal.

title: Magazines; As Time Changes Direction, Its Motives Are Questioned
description: ONCE again, Time magazine is marching on. Quietly, but consistently, the nation's largest news magazine has been shifting its editorial approach to adopt a more personal, less institutional tone.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Hostage; TV Producer, Freed, Says Panama Captors Did Not Harm Him Physically
description: Jon Meyersohn, a CBS News employee who was released Saturday in Panama City after being held captive for three days by gunmen loyal to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, says his captors psychologically abused him but did not physically mistreat him as they whisked him and a fellow American hostage from safe house to safe house.

title: Walton Makes Farewell Speech to Jets
description: To the end, Joe Walton kept his feelings hidden from his team.

title: Noriega's Move Meets Approval At White House
description: The White House expressed satisfaction tonight that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was ''under the control of diplomatic authorities.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: From Alaska to Hollywood, a Mixture of Successes and Setbacks; A Retail Emperor Is Losing His Reign
description: Robert Campeau, the Canadian real-estate developer who in 1988 engineered the biggest merger in the history of American retailing, spent most of 1989 watching his good fortunes turn sour.

title: Call Sugar Complaints Just Sour Grapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Stop Raiders Cold to Win East Division Title
description: The Giants keep saying they are not the team they were in 1986, when they went on to win Super Bowl XXI. Maybe not, but this version is not so bad.

title: Top Video Stocking-Stuffers
description: ''Batman'' has been the best-selling movie on videocassette in this holiday season ever since it wient on sale Nov. 15. It displaced ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' which had held the top spot for two weeks.

title: Mack Leads Browns to Title
description: The Cleveland Browns rediscovered Saturday night what they may have known most of the year. Without Kevin Mack, they're an ordinary team. With him, they're the American Conference Central Division champions.

title: 4 Family Members Die in Fire
description: A man tried in vain to save his family from a fire that destroyed their trailer home today, the police said. The man, Robert E. Thomas, 27 years old, had gotten up to go to the bathroom just as the fire started at 7:20 A.M., the police said. He ran outside and survived, but his wife, Heather, 27, and the couple's three sons, Robert Jr., 6; James, 5, and Christopher, 2, died, the state police said. Arson investigators determined a malfunctioning furnace caused the fire, the state police said.

title: Anderson's 'Sweetest' Season
description: DURING the 1987 season, Ottis Anderson, then the Giants' forgotten running back, was sitting on the sideline watching Joe Morris carry the ball again and again. And when Morris didn't carry it, either Lee Rouson or George Adams did.

title: Hiroshima's Story as the Victims Would Tell It
description: Children in blood-stained uniforms are buried in rubble. A woman in a blackened kimono sits amid the ruins, weeping. In the background, overturned buses, bare trees and buildings with gaping holes highlight a charred landscape.

title: More Lying In State
description: My first inkling that untruthfulness had become tolerable in the Bush Administration came when I inquired why no high-level official was being sent by the U.S. to the Sakharov funeral.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Red Cross; International Relief Efforts Begin
description: A small relief convoy crossing the Bulgarian border into Rumania today was the symbol and spearhead of a huge international relief effort being prepared to help the casualties of Rumania's uprising.

title: Storm Kills an Australian
description: A storm with high winds and torrential rains swept through the area of Brisbane today, killing one person, damaging homes, uprooting trees and leaving 45,000 homes without power. Three inches of rain fell in 15 minutes in some suburbs of the Queensland city

title: William J. Cassell, 58, Defense Comptroller
description: William J. Cassell, the comptroller and senior civilian official in the Defense Department's Defense Logistics Agency in Washington, died of heart failure on Saturday at his home in Annandale, Va. He was 58 years old.

title: Cuban Prisoners Still Await Fair Hearings
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA FEARS RAINLESS DECEMBER
description: If rain or snow do not start falling soon, Sierra skiers could be riding on rocks in January and California's central coastal farmers could be rationing water in July.

title: Olympic Hearth
description: AS a special gift for Christmas, 287 athletes will begin occupying a new Olympic Training Center at Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Bank Redlining Still Prevalent, Loan Critics Say
description: Critics of bank mortgage-lending practices have charged at a Congressional hearing that the banks still discriminate against New York City's minority neighborhoods despite Federal laws passed in the 1970's to curb such discrimination.

title: Scoring Drought Frustrates Sandstrom
description: The scene, sadly silly, almost absurd, captured Tomas Sandstrom's predicament perfectly.

title: Colombia Drug Suspect Is Flown Back to U.S.
description: Victor Eduardo Mera Mosquera, a fugitive convicted in New York in absentia of leading a cocaine-smuggling operation, was flown back to the United States today after the Colombian Government turned him over to United States Marshals, the marshals service reported.

title: Qintex Chief Sees Empire Disintegrate
description: LEAD: Christopher C. Skase seemed ready to take on the world as he built Qintex Ltd. from a failed mining company into a multinational television and tourism empire.

title: Outdoors: One of the Richest Evenings of the Year
description: WHOSE woods they were I thought I knew, until I leaned against a huge white pine that had been there a century or more. The ridge I was on was graced with conifers and hardwoods, pine, hemlock, spruce, ash, beech, white and yellow birch, hickory and maple, and there was a cedar swamp below.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: From Alaska to Hollywood, a Mixture of Successes and Setbacks; Head of Chip Venture Fighting for a Dream
description: Sanford L. Kane set out to blaze a new trail in American business this year. To his chagrin, he found almost no one will to come along on the journey.

title: Boy, 11, Killed By Stray Bullet On Visit to Aunt
description: An 11-year-old who a year ago moved with his family out of the East New York section of Brooklyn to escape the crime and violence of the neighborhood, died after being shot there Saturday night by a stray bullet.

title: Japan Raises Interest Rates
description: The Bank of Japan said today that it would raise its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 4.25 percent.

title: New Zealand Bank Plan
description: The Bank of New Zealand, the country's largest commercial bank, said last week that it would close four of its foreign operations, including its agency in Los Angeles. The managing director, Lindsay Pyne, said offices in Chile, Bahrain and South Korea would also close. The bank, 51 percent owned by the New Zealand Government, has been struggling to increase profits since posting a $383 million loss in the year ended last March 31.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: From Alaska to Hollywood, a Mixture of Successes and Setbacks; Failed Airline Deal Puts Pressure on Chief
description: For Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of the UAL Corporation, the year was one in which he came close to putting together an unusual company.

title: A Season Of Unease For Apparel
description: For New York's apparel makers, the holiday season has been an uneasy time. The worry in the garment district reflects the uncertain fate of two of its biggest customers, Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, the American subsidiaries of the financially troubled Campeau Corporation, based in Toronto.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Government Speaks; Text of Communique Issued By New Bucharest Leaders
description: Following is the text of a communique by Rumania's provisional government read today over the Rumanian radio, as translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service:

title: Robert Dixson, 82, Philanthropist And a Johnson & Johnson Chief
description: Robert J. Dixson, a retired president of Johnson & Johnson International and an official of many professional, civic and philanthropic groups in New Jersey and, after his retirement, in Florida, died Saturday at his home in Gulf Stream. He was 82 years old.

title: The Ins and Outs of Strength
description: WALK into a health club to become stronger and you immediately realize it's not as easy as slipping on a pair of sneakers and going for a walk, jog or bike ride.

title: Peace in Bethlehem, Little Good Will
description: For a third successive year, Christmas came without joy to those who live here, the town's shrines ringed by soldiers and the season's supposed good will all but extinguished by conflict between Arab and Jew.

title: Urgent Mission at Miami
description: THERE are good reasons for the sense of urgency that Wesley Carroll brings to his work as a football player, a role that has taken him from the difficult surroundings of his Cleveland childhood, through personal tragedy, to a sudden and important place on a University of Miami team that will play in the Sugar Bowl with a chance for an unofficial championship.

title: Upheaval in the East; Queen to Give Back Orders of Rumania
description: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark has decided to return orders she received from the toppled Rumanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu, Danish press reports said today.

title: Four Family Members Are Slain Near Ithaca
description: Four members of a family were slain in their suburban house near Ithaca on Friday night, the state police said.

title: Melvin E. Dawley Is Dead at 84; Retired Lord & Taylor Executive
description: Melvin Emerson Dawley, who spent 36 years with Lord & Taylor, the last 13 of them as the retail chain's chief executive officer, died Thursday at his home in Mountain Lake, a residential community in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 84 years old and, until a few months ago, also had a home in Bronxville, N.Y., where he was a longtime resident.

title: A Rumanian Freighter Sinks
description: Two seamen were missing after a Rumanian freighter sank off the northwest coast of Spain today, Spanish rescue services said. A spokesman said the vessel, the Tololovem, went down after being smashed by high waves off Cape Finisterre. A helicopter plucked 14 of the ship's 16 Rumanian crewmen from a lifeboat. Among the survivors was the captain of the vessel, which was carrying cargo to Britain from the Rumanian port of Constanta.

title: Investigators Doubting 5 Bombings Are Linked
description: Investigators have concluded that the bomb that injured a Maryland county judge on Friday was not connected to the four recent bombings in the Southeast.

title: China Feels The Cuts in Its Economy
description: Displaying the bravado and ambition that have fired China's economic growth in the last decade, this little village had originally expected to increase its industrial production by 50 percent this year.

title: On the Frigid Great Lakes, Ore Shippers Rush to Beat the Ice
description: Running full speed through the black Lake Michigan night, the Joseph L. Block was 20 miles offshore and inbound for Escanaba when her searchlights picked out the front edge of the ice, a jagged sheet nearly a foot thick, smooth and hard as steel.

title: No Party Privacy
description: The new City Charter that the voters approved last month greatly increases the powers of the New York City Council. It also enlarges the need to scrutinize the Council's performance.

title: TV Perennials Bring Holiday Cheer and Profits
description: They arrive each December as certainly as poinsettias on the window sill and Salvation Army Santas on the corner, those Christmastime television perennials.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Secret Police; Ceausescu's 'Private Army,' a Force of Unabated Cruelty and Fierce Loyalty
description: The Securitate, Rumania's State Security special troops engaged in last-ditch battles against the regular army and hastily formed armed posses in Bucharest and other cities, constitutes the ''private army of Nicolae Ceausescu.''

title: Young Professionals Find Joy in Giving
description: Young professionals, long maligned as materialistic and self-absorbed, are increasingly joining volunteer groups or creating their own to improve the quality of life for others.

title: Eagles Gain Wild-Card Spot
description: Anthony Toney and Randall Cunningham provided the offensive firepower today as the Philadelphia Eagles clinched a wild-card spot in the National Conference playoffs with a 31-14 victory over the Phoenix Cardinals.

title: Upheaval in the East: Paris; FRANCE OFFERS AID TO CEAUSESCU FOES
description: Raising the prospect of direct Western military intervention, the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, today offered to help organize a brigade of volunteers to help the Rumanian people combat the forces loyal to that nation's ousted President, Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Gospel Choir Blends Music and Equality
description: Terrence Kelly is used to the looks of disbelief when he brings his gospel choir into black Baptist churches here - used to being asked at the end of each rollicking performance, ''How'd you teach those white folks to sing?''

title: Coal Strike Talks Off; Mediator Predicting A Settlement Friday
description: The United Mine Workers and The Pittston Company have recessed their talks until Wednesday after failing to reach a settlement before Christmas in a bitter strike of 1,700 coal miners in three states.

title: Higher Pay Urged in Law Enforcement
description: A Federal commission will recommend a higher pay scale for Federal law enforcement officers in an effort to improve their morale and halt defections to higher paying jobs in state and local agencies.

title: Question Box
description: La Russa's Standing

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: From Alaska to Hollywood, a Mixture of Successes and Setbacks; Oil Disaster Leaves A Tarnished Image
description: After the Exxon Valdez tanker ran aground last March in Prince William Sound, Lawrence G. Rawl, found that few of his maneuvers at the helm of the nations's third-largest corporation could soothe those outraged, stunned and dismayed by Exxon's handling of the worst oil spill in the nation's history.

title: Hispanic Population Suffering Along With Massachusetts Economy
description: For the estimated 300,000 Hispanic residents of Massachusetts, many of whom remained mired in poverty in the years when the state's economy flourished, the outlook as the economy stagnates is especially bleak.

title: [ NO HEADLINE ]
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections.

title: Syracuse Plans Thank-You Trip
description: LIKE almost everybody else at Syracuse, Roy Simmons Jr., the lacrosse coach, wishes he had never heard of Lockerbie, the Scottish village whose name was seared into the university consciousness a year ago this Thursday when a terrorist bomb knocked Pan American World Airways Flight 103 out of the sky above Lockerbie. The explosion and crash killed 270 people, including 35 Syracuse students and 11 Lockerbie residents.

title: Article 502289 -- No Title
description: The Ford Motor Company intends to sell $1.6 billion in debt securities to pay for its recent acquisition of the Associates First Capital Corporation, the nation's third-largest independent finance company.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Reporters' Notebook; In Rumania, a Sense That No One's in Charge
description: Across the Rumanian countryside and on the deserted streets of the capital, bands of civilians posted themselves at intersections today, stopping the few cars that passed in a haphazard - at times almost comical - search for weapons.

title: 2 Peaceful Magazines Wage War in Vermont
description: There are, predictably, trees dressed in brilliant displays of fall foliage on the covers of both magazines. Inside, the pages of both are filled with soothing editorial and pictorial tributes to the beauty of Vermont.

title: Supermarket Prices Not Often in Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Coptic Monasteries Flourish in Egypt
description: An oasis spring soaks the desert green at Wadi Natrun, and a cloister bell beckons the faithful to prayer and pilgrims to rest and succor.

title: Payment Lag By Consumers
description: Consumer loan delinquencies at banks rose between July and September after dropping in the first half of 1989, according to the American Bankers Association.

title: Metro Matters; Ubiquitous Koch: Multimedia Man And Diet Maven
description: When Edward I. Koch was seeking re-election in 1981, he conceded that if everyone he had alienated in his first term voted against him, he would be defeated. But, Mr. Koch cautioned, while he would find a better job, those people would not get a better mayor.

title: Steam Rides Again! China Engines, U.S. Rails
description: Years and years ago, steam locomotives built in this area were exported to railroads around the world. And then more efficient diesel locomotives made steam rail travel obsolete, Now, two companies are importing from China 83-ton locomotives, based on a 1918 American design.

title: For the Families Left Behind, A Holiday Comforted by Duty
description: Snow robbed the church of one musician. War robbed it of another. As the two guitarists who remained beckoned Christmas with faltering hymns, the Rev. Phillip Leach spoke of the need for faith to overcome confusion.

title: Upheaval in the East: Moscow; Soviet TV View: Ceausescu  [ Equals ]  Stalin
description: A Soviet television news program tonight celebrated the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania by comparing him to two former Soviet leaders, Stalin as a despotic abuser of his own people and Brezhnev as a nepotistic corrupter of his Government.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Christmas. Banks, government offices and most businesses will also be closed.

title: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches; 'The Third Day of Freedom': Reports From Official Press in the East Bloc
description: Soviet bloc press organizations are reporting vividly and extensively on the upheaval in Rumania. Here are excerpts from their reports today, which with the exception of those from Tass were translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service. The Tass excerpts came from the Soviet press agency's English-language service. Hungarian Press Agency M.T.I. From Bucharest

title: Bridge
description: It was a snowy Christmas Eve in Montreal, reports Simon Klein of Huntington, L.I., and the last deal was being played before the Masquerade Ball began. It may, however, have happened on some more ethereal plane, since it would have been a busy night for one of the players. They were an assortment from history, Shakespeare, legend and nursery rhyme. South (Santa Claus): ''One spade.'' West (Macbeth): ''Three diamonds. If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well it were done quickly.''

title: In Tampa, Aid for Older Homeowners
description: Every weekday at 7:30 A.M., the repair trucks roll out of the garage here on their way to the homes of needy elderly residents with leaky roofs and plumbing or whose porches or floors have deteriorated.

title: Just in Time for New Year, a Fat Guage
description: (Missing)

title: South African Churches Asked to Talks
description: President F. W. de Klerk extended ''an open invitation'' today to the churches in South Africa to join the negotiations he has proposed to determine the nation's future.

title: Republicans Settle Suit Over Guards at Polls
description: The Orange County Republican Party, a Republican legislator and his campaign workers have agreed to settle a lawsuit accusing them of hiring uniformed guards to intimidate Hispanic voters.

title: The Magic Circle
description: All over America, families will soon be sitting down for Christmas dinner. Some of them could have modeled for Norman Rockwell. Others will include family members not of the same blood, the same creed, the same color. Never mind. On this day, they are all related.

title: Holiday Today
description: Today is Christmas. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collection, recycling, or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule; Long Island Railroad and Metro-North Commuter Railroad on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Tansportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-15 General Noriega took refuge in the residence of the Vatican's representative in Panama City and requested political asylum, the American military commander said. Page 1 The White House seemed satisfied that General Noriega was ''under the control of diplomatic authorities,'' even though it was not clear whether he would now be turned over to United States or Panamanian authorities for trial. 1 The community around Fort Bragg, N.C., seems mostly filled by a somber, quiet pride as more than 2,000 of its members have left for the war in Panama. Many teen-agers have gained an appreciation of war's perils. 1 Noriega's home: decor paints a picture of extravagance 8 A list of servicemen killed 7 News analysis: politically-attuned General vital for invasion 9 TV producer, freed, says captors did not harm him physically 9 Gunfire sounded through Bucharest as secret police officers loyal to the ousted dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, held out and harassed the new provisional government claiming power. 1 Reporters' notebook: Rumania has become a confused land of roadblocks as civilians have created checkpoints at intersections across the countryside and on the deserted streets of the capital. There is a general sense that no one is in charge. 1 The U.S. would approve a Soviet move to send troops to Rumania to support the pro-democracy forces, said Secretary Baker in an unparalleled overture. 13 Bucharest Government has yet to take shape 14 Ceausescu's 'Private Army,' a force of cruelty and loyalty 12 Two American and two European journalists shot and wounded 14 France offers aid to Ceausescu foes 13 Soviet TV view: Ceausescu - Stalin 13 Secret Soviet-German protocols at the start of World War II were condemned by the Soviet Congress, which declared that the pact between Stalin and Hitler violated ''the sovereignty and independence'' of other countries. 1 President de Klerk asked churches in South Africa to join the negotiations he has proposed to determine the nation's future. 3 Christian monasteries in Egypt are flourishing, reflecting the tenacity of the Coptic Christians and a revival of faith that has mirrored the spread of Islamic fundamentalism across the region. 4 Iran-backed fighters in Lebanon make gains over Muslims 2 Peace in Bethlehem, little good will 3 Japan plans to give tax credits to companies that greatly increase their imports of foreign-made manufactured goods as part of its effort to ease trade tensions. 37 Brazil's new chief raises doubts on Amazon 5 National 16-28, 32 Ore carriers in the Great Lakes are battling very harsh early winter conditions. An estimated 1.6 million tons of ore and other materials will have to be left on the docks because of ice floes blocking shipping channels. 22 An explosion at an Exxon refinery near Baton Rouge, La., set fire to tanks full of heating oil and lubricants, killing one person and leaving several others injured, officials said. 16 Federal law enforcement officers should receive a higher pay scale to improve their morale and halt defections to higher paying jobs in state and local agencies, according to a draft report by a Federal commission. 16 A state of emergency in Florida was declared because of the record cold wave, which stranded travelers, overloaded power plants and promised parts of the South their first snowy Christmas in more than a century. 23 Massachusetts' Hispanic residents, many of whom remained mired in poverty in the years when the state's economy flourished, are now facing dire financial troubles as the economy stagnates. 18 The Oakland Interfaith Gospel Choir is winning acclaim for its sound and symbolism. The 60-member chorus is three-quarters white, and includes Jews and Buddhists, Roman Catholics, Rastafarians and a dozen born-and-bred Baptists. 28 In Tampa, aid for older homeowners 16 Vermount recycles Christmas trees 19 2 peaceful magazines wage war in Vermont 32 Steam rides again! China engines, U.S. rails 25 California fears rainless December 24 Regional 33-36 A man was mistakenly declared dead on Saturday by a New York City Emergency Medical Services crew, which left him laying unconscious on an icy floor, E.M.S. officials said. He died later that day. 33 Redlining in minority neighborhoods in New York City still occurs, say critics of bank mortgage-lending practices who spoke at a Congressional hearing. 36 Young professionals who volunteer in charity organizations and other types of groups that help the needy are growing in number. 33 Christmas at B. Altman has been filled with much more gloom than cheer as the 124-year-old department store prepares to close. Much of the merchandise has been sold, and Santa was cut from the budget. 35 A season of unease for apparel makers 37 Many Salvadorans on Long Island, having left the violence of their homeland, are facing the difficult struggle of living as undocumented aliens. 33 Boy, 11, killed by stray bullet on visit to Aunt 35 The Board of Estimate allows Fordham to sell campus land 35 Neediest Cases 36 Queens woman's life brightened

title: Review/Television; Earl Warren's Evolution Into a Leader of the Court
description: ''Super Chief: The Life and Legacy of Earl Warren'' records what the narrator calls the ''veritable revolution'' wrought by the Supreme Court in the 1950's and 60's. Although a couple of dissents are registered -notably that of Judge Robert Bork, who says that the Warren Court often legislated instead of interpreted - tonight's 90-minute documentary comes down decisively in favor of Chief Justice Warren and his accomplishments.

title: SmithKline Sells Units
description: The SmithKline Beecham Company, the pharmaceutical concern, said last week that it had agreed to sell its American and Canadian household products businesses to a West Germany company for $107 million.

title: Insider Charge In Saatchi Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a Connecticut man with insider trading, saying he illegally made $78,812 in profits on information that the Saatchi & Saatchi Company was in talks to buy Gartner Group Inc. Robert Troup, 69 years old, of

title: Really Very Few of the Elderly Are Scrooges
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Colonel's Trial Ordered
description: Israel's Supreme Court ordered the military today to court-martial a colonel accused of instructing soldiers to break the limbs of Palestinian prisoners with clubs at the beginning of the Arab uprising in the occupied territories.

title: We Should All Be Driving Electric Cars by Now; Slim-Line Autos
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Plans Tax Credits For Imports
description: Fearing that trade tensions with the United States are worsening, Japanese officials said today that they had agreed on a plan to give large tax credits to companies that greatly increase their imports of foreign-made machinery, computers, autos and other manufactured goods.

title: INSIDE
description: Tokyo Encourages Imports

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.69 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac. That was down from a rate of 9.75 percent last week. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.34 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent the week before.

title: Fresh Fun for Ages 4 to Adult
description: IN 1976, Bill Koch, then 20 years old, won an Olympic silver medal in the 30-kilometer cross-country ski race. In 1982, he won the overall World Cup title in cross-country as well as four individual World Cup events. No other American has come close to these cross-country achievements before or since.

title: Brewers Offer Non-Alcoholic Beers
description: Facing chronically flat sales, the nation's two largest beer companies are brewing up an unlikely antidote: non-alcoholic beers. Anheuser-Busch Inc. is rolling out O'Doul's Non-Alcoholic Brew in certain states and metropolitan areas, and the Miller Brewing Company, a subsidiary of Philip Morris Inc., is beginning to ship its Sharp's brew nationwide.

title: Review/Music; A Take-Charge Conductor In Complete 'Brandenburgs'
description: The New York Chamber Symphony's presentation of Bach's complete ''Brandenburg'' Concertos at the 92d Street Y has become an annual holiday tradition. For the orchestra it also amounts to a birthday celebration. The series began in 1976, when Gerard Schwarz led a pickup band that, on the strength of its success in the ''Brandenburgs,'' was constituted in 1977 as the Y Chamber Symphony (subsequently renamed), with Mr. Schwarz as music director.

title: Fighting in Panama: The Chief of Staff; Vital for the Invasion: Politically Attuned General
description: Had President Bush not chosen a politically attuned Army general as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the United States might not have mounted a full-scale attack against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Fox to Provide Business News
description: Fox Television, in a joint venture with Sky Television, will start an early-morning weekday news program, ''World Business Report,'' on Jan. 15.

title: Oh, No! Still More (Quite a Bit More!) From P.D.Q. Bach.
description: Why mince words? Prof. Peter Schickele, unrepentant, will wring out the old year once again at Carnegie Hall tomorrow, Thursday and Saturday at 8 P.M. with the sounds of P. D. Q. Bach.

title: Illegal Salvadorans Fight Poverty, Winter and Fear on L.I.
description: Living 10 to 12 in a house, working as landscapers, dishwashers and maids, tens of thousands of Salvadorans are struggling to survive on Long Island, having traded the violence of their homeland for the uncertainty of life as undocumented aliens.

title: Fighting in the East: Washington; Baker Gives U.S. Approval If Soviets Act on Rumania
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States would approve if the Soviet Union or other Warsaw Pact nations decided to send troops into Rumania to support the pro-democracy forces trying to assume control in Bucharest.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: From Alaska to Hollywood, a Mixture of Successes and Setbacks; Two Star Producers Strike a Glowing Deal
description: If a screenwriter had handed Jon Peters and Peter Guber a script about two Hollywood producers who waltzed off with millions as the result of a takeover, Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters would have rejected the script, calling it too improbable. They would have been wrong. Nowhere else does the improbable become reality more often than in Hollywood. No other business seems to attract so many and so diverse a group of buyers as the movie industry. The mix includes American real estate developers and soft-drink makers, who like the glamour of the business as well as Japanese manufacturers who want to own the programming and the outlets on which it is played. But any buyer who wants to become a major player needs to own a studio.

title: Southern Sudan City Greets Convoy With Food and Soap
description: Residents of an isolated southern Sudanese city jubilantly welcomed a convoy of barges that brought the first consumer goods in 10 months, the official Sudan News Agency reported today.

title: Upheaval in the East: The United Nations; China Resists Any U.N. Statement On Rumania Turmoil, Envoys Say
description: The United States and other Western nations are trying to convene the Security Council by Tuesday to voice concern over the situation in Rumania, but China is opposing the move, diplomats say.

title: At B. Altman, Christmas but No Santa
description: Santa Claus skipped over the B. Altman and Company department store in midtown Manhattan yesterday. In fact, he did not appear once during the entire Christmas shopping season. He had been cut from the budget.

title: Vehicle Output in Japan
description: Japan's vehicle production fell 1.5 percent in November from a year earlier, to 1,134,520, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Friday. The figure compared with 1,123,416 in October, up five-tenths of a percent from a year earlier. A total of 818,913 cars was manufactured in November, up 9.4 percent from November 1988. There were also 312,755 trucks made, down 21.5 percent, and 2,852 buses, down 43.1 percent. Car sales set a record of 818,913, surpassing the previous high of 748,712, in November 1988.

title: In Place of Gift Boxes, Donations to Neediest
description: Many recipients of Christmas gifts will not find their presents wrapped in paper and ribbons under the tree this morning. Rather the gifts have gone to causes served by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Does Peace Have a Chance?
description: LEAD: Might the hopes for peace on earth be a little less utopian at the end of this year than at its beginning? The sense of renewed hope has been almost tangible as each day brought news of transformations in Eastern Europe and the thawing of East-West relations.

title: New York/New York for the Homeless
description: Last spring, New York State and City mental health officials, tired of bickering over responsibility for the dangerously crowded psychiatric emergency rooms in city hospitals, negotiated a sensible division of duties - the ''New York / New York'' agreement. It appears to be working well. Emergency-room crowding and the problems it created have eased.

title: 12 KILLED IN FIRE AT NURSING HOME
description: A Christmas Eve fire swept through a retirement home, killing at least seven people and sending at least 26 to hospitals with injuries.

title: Arafat and Mubarak Discuss Preparations for Peace Talks
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, held talks here today with Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, on plans for preliminary Middle East peace talks in Washington.

title: Soviet Congress Condemns '39 Pact That Led to Annexation of Baltics
description: The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies declared today that Stalin and Hitler had illegally conspired to divide Eastern Europe into spheres of influence before World War II, saying the secret agreement between the two leaders violated ''the sovereignty and independence'' of other nations.

title: Ohioan on Deck
description: PAM POSTEMA, the veteran Class AAA umpire, is gone. She received her walking papers in November after major league baseball decided her 13-season apprenticeship showed insufficient ground for making her the first female major league umpire.

title: Stricken Man Left for Dead By the E.M.S.
description: A man lay unconscious on the icy floor of a Bronx apartment for more than three hours Saturday after a New York City Emergency Medical Services crew mistakenly pronounced him dead and alerted the police to summon the city's morgue to pick up the body, the police, E.M.S. officials and a witness said yesterday.

title: Robert B. Chamine, Broker, 79
description: Robert B. Chamine, a securities broker with Kidder Peabody & Company Inc. for 40 years and a longtime member of the New York Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in New Milford, N.J. He was 79 years old. Mr. Chamine had also been a member of the exchange's board of arbitration. He was a native of Manhattan and a resident of New Milford for more than 35 years.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: From Alaska to Hollywood, a Mixture of Successes and Setbacks; A Spectacular Coup For Ad Entrepreneur
description: Before he left the Saatchi & Saatchi Company in 1987 to form the WPP Group, a marketing-communications company, Martin Sorrell was known as the ''third Saatchi.'' These days, the brothers Maurice and Charles Saatchi are rapidly becoming known as Mr. Sorrell's former employers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''His reign of terror is over.'' -Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. [ 1:5. ]

title: Oklahoma on Top In the Big Shootout
description: Oklahoma, obviously rusty from a two-week layoff, managed only 136 points. But Loyola-Marymount could do no better, scoring just 121 points. So the Sooners prevailed, 136-121, Saturday night in a free-wheeling exchange of points between the two highest-scoring teams in the country.

title: Tyler Selling Atlas to ICI
description: The British chemical giant, ICI P.L.C., has agreed to buy the Tyler Corporation's Atlas Powder Company unit to strengthen its standing in the commercial explosive and detonator product businesses.

title: Books of The Times; Aaron Copland's Reticence About Himself and His Art
description: Copland: Since 1943 By Aaron Copland and Vivian Perlis Illustrated. St. Martin's Press. 463 pages. $29.95.

title: Ernest Morial, Former Mayor Of New Orleans
description: Ernest N. Dutch Morial, New Orleans' first black Mayor and a civil rights advocate in the 1950's and 1960's, died here last night after collapsing outside the home of a friend. He was 60 years old.

title: A Woman's Pain Eased After Yars of Suffering
description: Fannie R., 85 years old, pads about her sparsely furnished apartment in Astoria, Queens, searching for a photograph. She finds it, and her anxious blue eyes cloud over with melancholy. ''This is a photograph of my son and grandson,'' she says, trying to suppress tears.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER FINDS WOES MOUNT
description: President Carlos Saul Menem's seeming golden touch for curing Argentina's woes has been tarnished by a return to soaring inflation as well as new military restiveness and conflict within his own political party.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 24, 1989: MONDAY None TUESDAY Delmarva Pwr & Lt Co WEDNESDAY Brooklyn Un Gas Co THUSDAY Boston Edison Co FRIDAY Cascade Nat Gas Corp

title: L.I. Man Shot to Death After Minor Collision
description: A minor traffic accident led to the death of a 25-year-old Long Island motorist early yesterday when the other driver involved shot him and and drove off, the police reported.

title: Beyond the Daisywheel: New Laser Printers
description: THE standard in business correspondence used to be the electric typewriter, with its crisp, clear letters. So when the personal computer began to replace the typewriter, the printer of choice was the daisywheel, which is basically an adapted typewriter head.

title: Sea's Bounty, Not the Mammoth, May Have Drawn Nomads to Alaska
description: A PREHISTORIC tableau is etched in the popular mind. On a bleak plain, hunters wrapped in animal skins and carrying spears lean into the frigid wind as they pursue the caribou and woolly mammoth; women and children follow them. These are the first migrants crossing from Asia to North America many thousands of years ago over the connecting bridge of land where the Bering Strait is now.

title: Hereford Journal; What Shall It Profit the Church to Be Rich in Art?
description: The trouble started a year ago, when the authorities of Hereford Cathedral announced that they would auction off the cathedral's 13th-century map of the world to raise money for building repairs and their real mission: ministering to the people of this mostly agricultural community on the border between England and Wales.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots One of 2 Robbers
description: An off-duty New York City police officer fought off two robbers yesterday in an elevator in her Co-op City apartment building and shot one of them, the police said.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for Year to Nov. 30

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Detroit Diesel Officer Named to President Post
description: LEAD: Ludvik F. Koci has been named president and chief operating officer of the Detroit Diesel Corporation, moving up a rung and adding a few new operational responsibilities.

title: Patterns
description: >Visions of Hot Sunshine

title: Outboard Marine Chief Retiring 3 Years Late
description: The Outboard Marine Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Charles D. Strang, is set to retire, three years late, because he wanted to take the company into the boat business to complement its boat engine business.

title: Memories Motivate Givers to Neediest Cases
description: Many of the letters pouring into The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund describe a city of the homeless without hope, of children without food, of the elderly without family or friends.

title: China Backs Trade Zones
description: China said yesterday that despite a shift in power away from regional governments to more central control, it would not alter the privileges given to its special economic zones that allow them to attract foreign investment. The influential newspaper

title: Announcement In Bucharest
description: Following is the text of the announcement of the execution of Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, as broadcast today by the Bucharest radio and translated by The Associated Press:

title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting Continues in the Western City Where the Uprising Against Ceausescu Began
description: Gunfire broke out sporadically in this western city today as security forces loyal to the Ceausescu regime battled army troops supporting Rumania's popular uprising.

title: Asbestos Costs Give Schools Hard Choices
description: Twenty years ago, before the hazards of asbestos became known, the steel beams inside sprawling, brown-brick New Canaan High School were sprayed with it. Though tests have shown that the flame-retardant coating - harmful only if its particles are inhaled - is mostly intact and safe for now, it is to be removed anyway, at a cost of perhaps $10 million.

title: Shooting and Scoring Take a Dip
description: After having shot better than 50 percent from the field every season since 1977-78, the Los Angeles Lakers have slipped to 45.6 percent despite having the best record in the National Basketball Association this season.

title: Native Hawaiians Vote on Sharing a T>rust's Riches
description: The Hawaiians who can trace their families back to the time of the kings and queens who ruled the islands until 1893 are being asked to decide how many of them should share in land, money and programs worth millions of dollars.

title: Chess
description: There is a long tradition in chess of seeing the attacker as noble and the defender as a grub who is just lucky when he wins. The assumption is that the attacker calls the shots and the defender responds willy-nilly. Even then, one might admire the extemporaneous resourcefulness of the defender, but that often seems to be overlooked.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Farm Prices ... Dec. Leading Indicators ... Nov.

title: Soviet Party Leaders Debate The Breakaway by Lithuania
description: Communist Party leaders addressed a Central Committee meeting today devoted to the decision by Communists in the Baltic republic of Lithuania to break with Moscow and form an independent party.

title: Rogers Communication reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $728,700,000, or $43.23 a share, and $83,400,000, or $3.16 a share, for the latest and prior years, respectively. The latest year credit included $721.3 million from the sale of the company's U.S. cable television interests. The company said the latest year results are not readily comparable to the year-ago figures. The operations of Rogers Cantel Inc., Rogers Entertainment and Canadian Home Shopping Network Ltd. were consolidated only in the final quarter of fiscal 1988 versus all of fiscal 1989. The company also said it had long- term debt in the latest fiscal year end of $755.4 million, compared with $899.5 million in fiscal 1988. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: 'How China Works'
description: China has disappeared from the news, but it will be back, soon.

title: Acklands Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Reults Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Maryland 98, Sacramento State 68: Jerrod Mustaf scored 21 points as Maryland (7-3) routed Sacramento State (8-7) Sunday night in the championship game of the Chaminade Christmas Classic in Honolulu.

title: Does the U.S. Have to Try Noriega?
description: Assuring that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, now protected by the Papal Nuncio in Panama, eventually appears in a U.S. courtroom is less important than addressing Panama's urgent needs. For the Bush Administration and the Endara Government today's top priority needs to be the rebuilding of a healthy Panama, independent from Washington and international drug lords.

title: Saraha Resorts reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the improved results were due to the acquisition of the Pioneer Hotel and Gambling Hall in Laughlin, Nev., in December 1988, and the expansion and renovation of the Sahara Hotel & Casino during the previous fiscal year.

title: EPICENTER LURING HUNDREDS TO PARK
description: A trail through Aptos Canyon has become a tourist attraction, drawing hundreds of hikers eager to stand at ground zero of the deadly and devastating October earthquake.

title: Bit More Time To Savor 1989
description: New Year's Eve partygoers around the world will have to wait an extra second before ringing in 1990.

title: New Jersey Towns Try To Limit Stone Quarries
description: As more people settle in western New Jersey, local officials are deciding that the region's stone quarries, which once blasted and crushed in rural isolation, have become a threat to civic peace and residential prosperity.

title: The Ceausescus: 24 Years of Fierce Repression, Isolation and Independence
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, who was reported yesterday to have been executed with his wife, Elena, his Deputy Prime Minister, was a maverick and despotic Rumanian Communist leader who pursued an independent course abroad and demanded slavish subservience at home. He was 71 years old; his wife was 70.

title: Bad Year Seen for Primary Dealers
description: Primary dealers of Government securities are winding up their worst year in a decade, and possibly longer, industry experts say.

title: Chaparral Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Village of Snake Charmers Sees Hard Times
description: ''It was television and the movies that destroyed our business,'' Shyam Lal said. ''Once children have seen this on TV, they aren't interested in seeing the real thing.''

title: Critic's Notebook; Public Enemy, Loud and Angry, Is Far From Its Own Best Friend
description: The rap group Public Enemy has a knack for shooting itself in the foot. Its response to a controversy last summer over anti-Semitic statements by its ''minister of information'' has now appeared in lyrics from its new single, ''Welcome to the Terrordome,'' that also seem to cross the line into anti-Semitism.

title: 'Enough' for Glasnost?: Though He Set Liberalization in Motion, Soviet President Chafes at Hard Criticism
description: As East-bloc Communism relentlessly collapses, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the man whose policies of reconstruction are presumed by many to have inspired the wave of popular rebellions, has been declaiming lately like the last Communist on earth.

title: Texfi Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
Tutu Cool to Pretoria Offer to Join Talks
description: Midway through a visit that has stirred passions and debate here, Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu gave a cool response tonight to the South African Government's newest bid to draw church leaders into negotiations on the future of his country.

title: For Harried Taxpayers, An Expert on a Disk
description: EVEN as the warm glow of the holidays fills the room, the cold-hearted Grinch reminds us that it is time to think about taxes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bancorp New Jersey Inc., Somerville, N.J., a bank holding company, said it would begin repurchasing 500,000 common shares over five years.

title: Security Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included loan-loss charge of $1,180,000. c-Net income

title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald P. Sheahan, Executive, 58
description: Donald P. Sheahan, executive vice president of the American subsidiary of a major Japanese securities-trading house, died of cancer yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Tobacco's Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Globex Trading System Delayed and Disputed
description: Globex, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's much-touted computerized trading system, is six months behind schedule, delayed by technical problems. In addition some brokerages are concerned that they could be held liable if the system fails to execute an order.

title: The Sports Hero At Christmas
description: Yesterday, Christmas Day, between ''A Christmas Carol'' and caroling, there was shown on television a documentary on the life of former Chief Justice Earl Warren. Perhaps it was a coincidence, but it seemed totally appropriate on that day, a day, for millions all over the world, of hope, that symbolizes the lifting of spirits, and a day for dreams of a future joyful and triumphant.

title: Support Grows for National Education Standards
description: While governors, educators, business executives and parents debate the future of public education, there is evidence that the country has already leaped ahead toward answering one big question: should the United States, like the highly literate societies of Japan and Europe, set national standards for its schoolchildren?

title: Maine Faces Budget Cuts as Economy Sags
description: Barely a year ago state taxpayers were cashing preholiday rebate checks worth nearly $42 million. But with the Northeast's economy in a tailspin, Maine officials face spending cuts of half again that much.

title: Catapult and Catalyst; Albelin Energizes the Devils at Both Sides of the Rink
description: Tom Albelin of the Devils rubbed his sandy crew cut the other day as he pondered his team's debacle last season.

title: 'Shock Therapy' for Poland: Jolt Might Be Too Damaging
description: Many economists say the crash plan proposed last week by Poland's Finance Minister is the right economic medicine to revive that nation's crumbling Communist economy. But they worry that the medicine might be too strong to be politically acceptable.

title: Japan Lifts A Key Rate Half a Point
