description: The Bank of Japan moved today to raise its official discount rate by half a point, to 4.25 percent, effective immediately, apparently winning a bitter tug-of-war with the Finance Ministry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Creative Addition
description: Continuing to bolster its creative ranks, Wells, Rich, Greene has lured Len Fink away from Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York. Mr. Fink has been appointed executive vice president and executive creative director of Wells. At Chiat, his award-winning campaigns include the ''Crashing Glasses'' spot for the Advertising Council and commercials for Gravy Train dog food and Veryfine juices.

title: Giants All Say It Wasn't Easy
description: This was five weeks ago, and Bill Parcells, the coach of the Giants, was talking to someone who had followed the team closely.

title: Metcalf & Eddy Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Thanks for Deliverance, but Mindful That All Is Still Not Well
description: On this Christmas of hope and death, Rumanians gave thanks today for their liberation from dictatorship and prayed for swift deliverance from the turmoil that still surrounds them.

title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Listen to the Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan State Beats Hawaii in Aloha Bowl
description: Blake Ezor rushed for an Aloha Bowl record 179 yards and scored three touchdowns as Michigan State took advantage of eight Hawaii turnovers today in a 33-13 victory.

title: Snow Comes Too Late to Save Buffalo Festival
description: After struggling for three years to stage a Winterfest of snow sculpture and ice skating amid balmy January temperatures, the organizers gave up this year. Then the snow began. Buffalo residents awoke today to their first white Christmas since 1985, in a December that is expected to be one of the two coldest on record.

title: Tyrant's Fall Brings Joy to One Family
description: The night that security forces mowed down hundreds of students in University Square, Florin Tanescu ran to a friend's apartment for cover.

title: David V. O'Brien, Federal Judge, 57
description: David V. O'Brien, Chief Judge of the United States District Court in the Virgin Islands, died Friday at Georgetown University Hospital, where he was undergoing treatment for Hodgkin's disease. He was 57 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brooklyn Union Gas named Elwin S. Larson chairman and chief executive and Robert B. Catell president and chief operating officer.

title: Biomagnetic Technologies reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Vincent to Lakers
description: Jay Vincent, a forward, signed with the Los Angeles Lakers Sunday and will be reunited with his former teammate at Michigan State, Magic Johnson.

title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum
description: Citing policies that have traditionally been pursued in the United States, legal experts questioned today whether Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian leader, was entitled to sanctuary or asylum in the Vatican's embassy in Panama City.

title: Poets, Students, Soldiers and a Few Communists Forming a Government
description: The Council of National Salvation, the group organizing a new government in Rumania, is a mix of poets, writers, actors, directors, military officers, student leaders and former Communist Party officials who share the bond of opposition to the Ceausescu regime, experts on the region said today.

title: Wonderful in Black and White
description: Frank Capra's heartwarming ''It's a Wonderful Life'' has been television's favorite Christmas rerun for some time, but never more topical than this year: it is a Christmastime tale of a neighborly savings-and-loan bailout. Critically, it wasn't a great movie in 1946, and still isn't. Worse, it has been ''colorized,'' a sickly tinting process that trashes black and white without beginning to approach true movie color.

title: Spallone Plans Changes In Yonkers's Moyoralty
description: For most of the last two years, with this city bitterly preoccupied by a housing-desegregation struggle, activity in City Hall centered on the fourth floor, in the ornate City Council chamber and the office of Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko behind it.

title: Electroshock Therapy Is Defended
description: Electroshock therapy is safe and effective for a small percentage of mental patients, but it is not a cure and has some serious side effects, the American Psychiatric Association says.

title: Bo Schembechler's Last Run for Roses
description: The Rose Bowl, a post-season college football game often called ''the grand-daddy of 'em all,'' began in 1902 with a Michigan victory over Stanford. Since then, it always has held a special mystique for Midwesterners.

title: In Quake-Prone Valley, An Array of Instruments Waits for the Next One
description: AS a caretaker for the nation's most ambitious earthquake prediction experiment, Andy Records spends each day in the dry hills above this central California village, fiddling with instruments designed to detect subtle signs that the earth is restless.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas. Banks, government offices and most businesses were also closed.

title: Ethnics All
description: To the Editor:

title: California Town Seeks Way to Harass Bears
description: Some residents of this remote gold-mining village are calling for a hunt to thin an aggressive population of hungry black bears that are searching out food at the local dump and in people's trash and freezers.

title: Billy Martin of the Yankees Killed in Crash on Icy Road
description: Billy Martin, the combative baseball manager who was celebrated for his ability to motivate players but was notorious for fighting with them and others, was killed yesterday in a traffic accident near Binghamton, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Harry Kraf, Lawmaker From West Bronx, 82
description: Harry Kraf, who as chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation sponsored bills to increase staff members in New York State institutions for the retarded, died of cancer on Friday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 82 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: American Building Maintenance Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
An Award Candidate
description: Andre Ware, the record-setting Houston quarterback, is among 15 candidates for the ninth annual Davey O'Brien National Quarterback Award.

title: Bush's Obsession: President Says Noriega's Hold on Power Has Left Him 'Extraordinarily Frustrated'
description: President Bush and his advisers had ''become obsessed with'' Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in the last 11 months, according to a longtime friend of the President's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Heller Breene Sold by WCRS
description: The WCRS Group has solved the problem of what to do about Heller Breene Advertising, its Boston ad agency that was sent reeling eight weeks ago when Heller's co-founder left for another agency: it sold the company. The buyer is Cipriani

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Refinery Fire Could Raise Heating-Oil Cost
description: An explosion and fire that damaged parts of a huge Exxon Corporation oil refinery in Louisiana on Sunday could raise heating bills for consumers, at least temporarily, oil industry executives and analysts said yesterday.

title: New Competition in Noodle Soup
description: It happened in automobiles. It happened in computer chips. And once again, after years of ignoring foreign competitors, American companies are waking up to a hot market.

title: Morgan Library Explores the Mind of Browning
description: The centenary this month of the death of Robert Browning is being celebrated with an exhibition at the Pierpont Morgan Library. The 55 items on view in ''Robert Browning (1812-1829): Growth of a Poet's Mind'' are designed to reveal something of the way the poet transformed his thoughts from mind into printed matter.

title: Quiksilver Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cigarettes and Schooling
description: Anti-smoking efforts should be directed at young people with relatively little schooling because the use of cigarettes drops sharply among those with more education, Federal health researchers said last week.

title: INSIDE
description: The Canadian Connection Drug traffickers are flying cocaine from South America to the Caribbean to Canada, for transport into the United States. Page A3. Hate Crimes Rising in U.S. While a recent rash of bomb incidents has evoked memories of past violence in the South, experts who follow hate crimes say they are a nationwide phenomenon. Page A20.

title: Fast-Changing Events Shape Holiday Rituals
description: For Daniel Pomerleau and his daughter, Tasha, their Christmas ritual had outlasted the Cold War.

title: Great Country Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Researchers Devise New Ways to Treat Prostate Problems
description: QUESTIONS about the long-term safety and effectiveness of the standard operation for enlarged prostates have led to intensified efforts to develop new ways to treat the condition, which is common among older men. Among the alternatives are several new drugs, hormones, mechanical devices, new kinds of surgery and even intense heat.

title: MHP Machines Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from utilization of tax loss carryforward of $29,000.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Drossman Lehmann Marino has begun a national print and television campaign about sudden infant death syndrome.

title: 3Com Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Television Has Become a Weapon in Panama and Rumania
description: The revolutionaries of Rumania and the invaders of Panama both made quick use of television last week in an effort to capture the hearts and minds of their countrymen. But the differences were more striking than the similarities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Nicolae Ceausescu was executed, along with his wife, by the army he once commanded, according to the Free Rumanian Television of the new provisional Government. A1

title: In Age of AIDS, Sex and Drugs Are Classroom Topics
description: At Junior High School 45 in East Harlem the other day, ''Mom,'' portrayed by a 13-year-old, had just discovered a clinic card belonging to her teen-age daughter. The daughter, played by a 12-year-old, confessed: she had contracted AIDS after having sex with her boyfriend and had been going to the clinic for treatment.

title: Czar Vs. Intellectuals
description: In denouncing those who favor ''legalization'' of drugs, William Bennett also ripped into ''intellectuals,'' particularly ''liberal intellectuals,'' for criticizing his law-enforcement approach to the so-called ''war on drugs.''

title: Measurex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Faradyne Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Vikings Make Playoffs and Bump Bengals
description: The Minnesota Vikings won the National Football Conference Central title tonight, beating Cincinnati, 29-21, as Rich Karlis kicked five field goals and Chris Doleman led a defense that produced six turnovers.

title: Don't Kill Dogs That Have Vicious Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: Burkina Faso Leaders Foil Revolt
description: The Government of this sub-Saharan nation said today that it had foiled a coup attempt against the two-year-old Government led by Capt. Blaise Compaore. But it denied reports that it had executed seven of those arrested.

title: Coast Guard to Test Tanker Tracking System
description: The Coast Guard says it will test a new system for keeping track of oil tankers in Alaska's Prince William Sound, the site of the nation's worst oil spill.

title: Super Food Services reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 18
description: Earnings per share were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 15, 1989.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 31 Players Still Among Free Agents
description: The Mark Davises, the Mark Langstons and the Rickey Hendersons have theirs, but 31 players out of the record group of 90 free agents remain unsigned as baseball takes its annual holiday hiatus this week. The unsigned roster includes Wally Backman, Lee Mazzilli, Rick Rhoden, Shane Rawley and Rich (Goose) Gossage.

title: In the Battered Capital, People Are Celebrating
description: When United States troops attacked Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's headquarters last week Ramon Perez barely escaped with his life.

title: The Need for Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk; The Feud On Funds To Fight Drug War
description: Richard G. Darman calls William J. Bennett ''czar.'' Mr. Bennett calls Mr. Darman ''Dar.''

title: 2 Are Shot, One Fatally; Co-Worker Is Held
description: One woman died and another was injured today in a confrontation at their home with a fellow employee who was arrested and charged with murder and attempted murder, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * The Promotion Group and BMS Marketing Services, sales promotion agencies, have merged under the name the Promotion Group.

title: Gains Reported in Detecting Toxic Substances
description: A new family of high-speed analytical instruments may soon enable public health authorities to maintain continuous surveillance over air, water and soil exposed to contamination by chemicals or microorganisms.

title: Turmoil in the Earth
description: Seismologists have found that portions of three segments of the earth's crust are being forced together in an area known as a subduction zone at Macquarie Ridge, which runs under the Pacific Ocean from New Zealand to Antarctica.

title: A New Age of Feudalism?
description: During my 12 years as Mayor, New York City became a stronger, more prosperous city.

title: Alvarez Is Interviewed
description: The University of Pittsburgh has interviewed the Notre Dame assistant head coach, Barry Alvarez, as it seeks a replacement for its head coach, Mike Gottfried.

title: DA Stuart Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns; Can Main Street Revive Itself? Merchants Ask
description: rrVonette's Sweet Shop on Main Street looks like a yellowed and faded Norman Rockwell cover from an old Saturday Evening Post. Swan-necked soda fountains crane upward from behind the counter. Little children spin themselves silly on swivel stools.

title: Order Is Shifted on Mobil Oil
description: A Federal judge unsealed confidential corporate documents last week in a lawsuit against the Mobil Oil Corporation, but he withheld the order when lawyers for Mobil said they would appeal.

title: Church Sees an End to the Bloodshed
description: The Vatican said today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega took refuge in its embassy in Panama after expressing ''the will to end the conflict'' and that his decision should halt the bloodshed.

title: VWR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the third quarter loss and the decline in 9-month net income reflected the absence of an operating unit divested in December 1988, severe declines in graphics sales from the loss of certain product lines and increased operating expenses in the VWR Scientific Group. The company said the increased expenses relate to the integration of the recently acquired Sargent-Welch operations with existing scientific business and higher costs attributable to the opening of a new distribution center and implementation of new computer systems.

title: Volcano at South Pole Offers Golden Clues About the Atmosphere
description: MOUNT Erebus, the only active volcano in Antarctica, is spewing microscopic crystals of pure gold over the white continent.

title: John C. Eidt, Manufacturer, 93
description: John Charles Eidt, a retired manufacturer who was active in the American Legion, died yesterday at his home in Long Beach, L.I. He was 93 years old.

title: MacLeod Meets With Kings' Reynolds
description: John MacLeod, who was dismissed as head coach of the Dallas Mavericks on Nov. 29, has met informally with Jerry Reynolds and discussed the Sacramento Kings' head-coaching position. MacLeod has been rumored to be a leading candidate to replace Reynolds, who has been named player personnel director of the Kings, succeeding Bill Russell.

title: Going Home
description: Assistants to the Duke football coach, Steve Spurrier, say the former Heisman Trophy winner at Florida intends to return to his alma mater as head coach, The News and Observer of Raleigh reported yesterday.

title: Panamanian Resistance To U.S. Virtually at End
description: With Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in the Vatican mission and trying to negotiate safe departure from the country, resistance to American forces virtually collapsed today. An American spokesman said the general's move to seek asylum was ''a major victory'' for the United States.

title: Near the Wall, Bernstein Leads an Ode to Freedom
description: Leonard Bernstein transformed a performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony today into an appeal for brotherhood as West and East Berliners mingled freely for the first Christmas in 28 years.

title: Sensormatic Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $968,000 and $3,261,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Marilyn Quayle Questioned on Abortion Pill
description: Marilyn Quayle, the wife of the Vice President, exchanged letters with the head of an anti-abortion group last week over whether she endorsed the use of an abortion-inducing pill for rape victims.

title: Reff Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,572,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $132,000, or 2 cents a share, and $209,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. d-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Dogs Found To Recognize Some Colors In a Study
description: The world is not all black and white for dogs, but they have only limited color vision, researchers have concluded.

title: Israeli Arab Gets Life For a Grenade Attack
description: A court here today sentenced an Israeli Arab to life in prison after he pleaded guilty to commanding a Palestine Liberation Organization group that hurled a hand grenade into a shopping street in Haifa last year, wounding 25 people.

title: ARMY EXECUTES CEAUCESCU AND WIFE FOR 'GENOCIDE' ROLE, BUCHAREST SAYS
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, absolute ruler of Rumania for 24 years, and his wife were executed on Monday by the army that he once commanded, the Free Rumanian Television of the new provisional government said.

title: Madrid Now Expresses Reluctance To Give Noriega Political Asylum
description: Responding to reports that the deposed Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, would like political asylum here, Spain backed away today from earlier expressions of willingness to consider such a move.

title: U.S. Families Send Messages to Lebanon Hostages
description: Families and friends of eight Americans held hostage in Lebanon sent them messages of encouragement, hoping that somehow they will be delivered, but after so many years of captivity, there is no sign as to where the missing men are being detained.

title: Into the 90's With Youthful Wit and Zest
description: Their clothes are inventive, amusing, often riveting, without being bizarre. The new designers, between 20 and 30 years old, come from a variety of cultures and backgrounds. What they have in common is a passionate interest in fashion and usually some training in art. As a result, their sketches often have style and charm.

title: 5 Accused of Helping Dissidents Flee China
description: China said today that it had arrested five men from Hong Kong and Macao and smashed an underground network that helped dissidents flee the country.

title: Gould Investors LP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Latest year loss included gains of $4,183,000, or $3.80 a share from the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments, compared to a gain of $2,027,000, or $1.69 a share in the fiscal 1988. Fiscal 1989 results included the operations of One Liberty Propeties Inc. on a consolidated basis since Sept. 11, when Gould Investors' equity interest in One Liberty's common shares increased to 65.7 percent.

title: Fog Is Blamed for Auto Pileup
description: Fog was blamed for a 14-car pileup early today on State Highway 4 between Pittsburg and Concord, the California Highway Patrol said. The accident occurred shortly before 1 A.M. and closed two of the three westbound lanes about four miles west of here for about 90 minutes, the patrol said. ''It was a chain reaction in the fog,'' a patrol officer said. Only two minor injuries were reported.

title: Westchester HELP Needs Help
description: Westchester County has just demonstrated the best and worst in public response to the tormenting problem of housing homeless families.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This Christmas will be remembered in Rumania's history as not only the day that the Christ child was born, but the day that the Rumanian nation was reborn.'' - Emil Panzaru, an official of St. Dumitru Rumanian Orthodox parish in Manhattan. [ A1:4. ]

title: Market Place; A Rally in Notes Backed by Assets
description: DECEMBER has been a profitable month in the small but growing market for asset-backed securities, where institutional investors trade notes backed by consumer loans. After absorbing a two-month glut of new issues, the market staged a year-end rally that brought yields down and raised note prices.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: ANNA BLANDIANA, a Council of National Salvation leader: AH-na blahn-DYAH-nah SILVIU BRUCAN, an opposition leader: SEEL-vyoo broo-KAHN koo NICOLAE CEAUSESCU, the ousted leader: nee-koh-LAH-yeh chow-SHESS-koo ELENA CEAUSESCU, his wife and second in command: eh-LEH-nah NICU CEAUSESCU, their son and leader in the city of Sibiu: NEE-koo ZOIA CEAUSESCU, their daughter: ZOH-yah GHEORGHE GHEORGHIU-DEJ, Mr. Ceausescu's predecessor: GYOR-gyeh gyor-GYOO dehzh, with hard g's.

title: 26 Are Sickened by Gas Leak
description: A carbon monoxide leak in the furnace of a Harlem apartment building sent 26 people to the hospital yesterday suffering from dizziness and nausea. The leak at 502 West 143d Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, was discovered at 12:30 P.M. A faulty flue in the furnace's gas-powered burner leaked the fumes, the police said. Residents were taken to Harlem Hospital, the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and St. Lukes-Roosevelt Medical Center. The leak was fixed and the building reopened by mid-afternoon, the police said.

title: Rison Caught Speeding
description: The Indianapolis Colts' rookie wide receiver, Andre Rison, was in far too much of a hurry to get home for Christmas, the Indiana State Police said.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Playwright as Critic: Stoppard on Art and Its Practitioners
description: Before Tom Stoppard became a playwright, he worked as a drama critic on daily newspapers in Bristol, England, an occupation for which he felt singularly misfitted, and one from which he may not have fully recovered. Once, in conversation, he described his method of criticism: ''I operated on the assumption that there was an absolute scale of values against which art could be measured. I didn't trust my own subjective responses. And I never had the moral character to pan a friend. I'll rephrase that. I had the moral character never to pan a friend.''

title: Panel Honoring 20 as Heroes Who Risked Lives for Others
description: What started out to be a routine traffic stop for speeding turned into a brush with death for an Arizona policeman, who was saved by a passerby.

title: Share in Colt Is Reconsidered
description: Connecticut officials are reconsidering a possible investment in the buyout of Colt Industries' firearms division because of uncertainty in the gun market, said Francisco L. Borges, the State Treasurer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Pam Ciccone has been named vice president of Metro Magazines-New York.

title: World Bank Seen Shifting China Stance
description: As the Bush Administration gingerly moves to repair economic ties with China, the World Bank seems likely to soon resume lending programs suspended after the crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in June, say officials of the bank, the United States and foreign governments.

title: Inquiry at Boeing Unit
description: The Boeing Company has said its Computer Services division is under investigation for possible overcharges of $25 million to the Government for research work. The company disputed the results of a Pentagon audit that said it had exceeded Government limits on billable research costs, The Seattle Times reported on Sunday.

title: 2 Held in Boy's Killing by a Random Bullet
description: Two Brooklyn men were arrested yesterday in connection with the firing of the stray bullet that killed an 11-year-old boy in the East New York section of Brooklyn Saturday night.

title: Cognos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said cost reduction and management reorganization measures resulted in a restructuring charge of $3.1 million in the latest third quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Loss Of Tri-Star At AC& R
description: THE West Coast office of AC& R Advertising took its third serious blow in nearly two years on Friday, losing the enormous account of Tri-Star Pictures, the Hollywood studio whose marketing operations were taken over in March by Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc.

title: Phnom Penh Faces United Front
description: Cambodian guerrillas backed by the United States said today that they had combined forces with the Communist Khmer Rouge in new attacks on the Phnom Penh Government.

title: Jets Likely To Dismiss Walton Today
description: Joe Walton's charmed life with the Jets - he is the only coach in American Football Conference history to last seven seasons without winning a division title - is expected to end officially this morning.

title: G.E. Gets Korean Job
description: The General Electric Company says it has received a $500 million contract to build fighter plane engines for the Government of South Korea.

title: Peppers Helpful In Studies Of Herpes
description: THE substance that makes chili peppers hot appears to be useful in studying herpes infections, scientists in San Francisco have reported.

title: U.S. to Establish Relations With New Bucharest Leaders
description: The White House said today that it was establishing diplomatic relations with the new government of Rumania, but also said that it regretted the secret manner in which the deposed President, Nicolae Ceausescu, and his wife, Elena, had been executed.

title: For B Company, 'It Was Worse Than Anyone Could Imagine'
description: A few days ago, the men of Bravo Company, Fourth Battalion, Sixth Infantry thought this was a Christmas they might never see.

title: Books of The Times; 'Vineland,' Pynchon's First Novel in 17 Years
description: Vineland By Thomas Pynchon 385 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: Safety a Concern Before Tennessee Fire
description: Polly Stevens remembers seeing her friend Carl Ogburn, a flashlight in his hand, peering in terror from a window on the 8th floor as black smoke billowed around him.

title: Careers; Nurturing Technology Businesses
description: WHETHER the American economy achieves a soft landing in 1990 or tumbles into a full-scale recession, it will be bolstered by thousands of technological entrepreneurs who have started small companies, Robert G. Hawkins says.

title: Trizec Corp reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Per-share figures reflected a 50-percent stock dividend declared in July. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Deaths From Measles Are the Most Since '71
description: More people have died of measles this year than in any year since 1971, Federal health officials said. Most of the deaths were among unvaccinated preschoolers and schoolchildren whose vaccinations were ineffective.

title: Cavaliers Defeated By Hawks
description: Spud Webb scored a career-high 26 points and also had 12 assists, sparking the Atlanta Hawks to a 115-104 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers today.

title: German Question, French Anxiety
description: LEAD: How do the French feel about German reunification? Events in Eastern Europe are proceeding at such a dizzying pace that inconsistent reactions are inevitable.

title: By Design
description: The way things are shaping up for 1990, fashion is going in many directions. Everything from Western to ethnic to modern has been mined for inspiration. It would be easy to lose your way. These suggestions may help you stay on your own course while you contemplate new routes.

title: Tiny Fish Help Solve Cancer Riddle
description: RESEARCHERS at the Brookhaven National Laboratory are employing a novel model to study skin cancer in humans: they are exposing tiny tropical fish to ultraviolet radiation.

title: Syntech International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Troubles at the Whitney, Both at the Top and in the Future
description: The trustees of the Whitney Museum recently set up a committee ''to review the current status and consider future directions of the museum,'' but their mild language blurred the fact that serious problems are plaguing the institution, the country's foremost museum of American art.

title: Death in Gaza Laid to Beating
description: An American pathologist said today that a Palestinian prisoner died last week of numerous blows to the abdomen during interrogation in the Gaza Strip by members of the Israeli civilian secret police earlier this month.

title: Q&A
description: Calcium in Vegetables Q.Is it possible for the child of strict vegetarians to get enough calcium from a diet that does not include eggs, meat, fish or milk products? A.It might be difficult, but it is not impossible. The recommended daily allowance of calcium for children is 600 to 1,000 milligrams, depending on age. Many fruits and vegetables contain significant and sometimes surprisingly large amounts of calcium, according to estimates from the United States Department of Agriculture and nutrition experts who work in the food industry.

title: Talking Business; with Vanous of Planecon; Eastern Europe's Promising Areas
description: The movement toward market economies in Eastern Europe is creating business opportunities for Western companies. Jan Vanous is president of Planecon, a consulting firm that specializes in economic research and investment counseling regarding Eastern bloc nations.

title: Soldier's Gifts Taken While He Is in Panama
description: Christmas presents and two television sets were stolen from the home of a paratrooper with the invasion force in Panama.

title: Rhinestone Streets
description: Holiday lights sparkle from store windows, fire escapes and cornices these days, and drivers on an increasing number of New York streets are likely to find points of light shining up from the pavement as well.

title: 40 Die in Sri Lanka Fighting
description: The police said today that more than 40 people had been killed in fighting in eastern Sri Lanka between rival Tamil guerrilla groups.

title: Intervale Pleads for Reopening of El Station
description: Alone among the 425 stops depicted on the New York City Transit Authority's latest subway map, the Intervale-163d Street station in the South Bronx carries the notation in block letters ''CLOSED.''

title: Iran Releases 50 Iraqi War Prisoners to Red Cross
description: Iran released 50 ailing or disabled Iraqi prisoners of war to Red Cross representatives today as a gesture of good will, the official Teheran radio reported.

title: Judge Wounded by Bomb Leaves Hospital
description: A judge who was wounded by a pipe bomb was released from a hospital today, three days after he lost part of a finger and suffered other injuries in the explosion.

title: 'Mahabharata' Faces Test of Integrity
description: ''The Mahabharata,'' the Indian religious and mythological epic about truth and deceit, love and war, divinity and mortality, has arrived in the land of its birth in an intense five-and-a-half-hour movie version by Peter Brook. For the director, India is the true test of the film's integrity, although it has already received praise around the world.

title: Climbing Tied to Brain Harm
description: OXYGEN deprivation suffered by mountain climbers who reach the tops of Mount Everest or other peaks may cause minor brain damage, like temporary memory loss or motor dysfunction, researchers say.

title: Latin Drug Traffickers Use Canada as New Route
description: In their seemingly endless search for new ways of smuggling cocaine into the United States, the drug traffickers of South America have created a Canadian connection.

title: VATICAN IS URGED TO REJECT NORIEGA
description: Bush Administration officials told the Vatican today that it would be ''totally inappropriate'' for the Holy See to grant Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega temporary refuge in the residence of the Papal Nuncio in Panama City and suggested that the best solution would be simply to ''walk him to the door.''

title: Bridge
description: Once there were six, then five, and now there are six again.

title: Lithuania Need Not Be Rumania
description: The news yesterday of Nicolae Ceausescu's execution shows what can happen to brutal dictators who prefer to go on killing and denying freedom to people in Eastern Europe. Fortunately for the people of the Soviet Union, Mikhail Gorbachev is a leader who prefers to bargain peacefully with those who rightly seek more freedom and autonomy.

title: Protest at St. Patrick's Focused on Cardinal's Dangerous Zeal
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Pedestrians Killed in Accidents
description: Two pedestrians were killed in separate accidents on Sunday, one in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan and one in the Baychester section of the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Bill Auction Set for Today
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title: 2,000 Rally in Taipei for Speedier Changes
description: About 2,000 opposition supporters marched downtown in Taiwan's capital today in a noisy but peaceful Constitution Day demonstration to demand swifter political change.

title: 3 Seek New Trial in 70's Police Killings
description: Fourteen years ago, amid fear that a dangerous band of armed blacks was killing police officers, three men -Herman Bell, Anthony Bottom and Albert Washington - were convicted of murder and sentenced to 25 years to life.

title: Bombings Echo Past, but Experts Hear Different Undertones
description: The recent rash of bomb incidents in the South coincides with a rising national tide of extremist violence and hate crimes, organizations that follow white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups say.

title: Investor Buys Hotel in Rio
description: The Copacabana Palace Hotel, a faded Rio landmark where European royalty and Hollywood movie stars once stayed, has been taken over by the American businessman who reopened the Orient Express railroad in Europe.

title: Computer Mail Gaining a Market
description: Electronic mail, which has taken a secondary position to the facsimile machine through the personal computer boom of the 1980's, is finally coming into its own.

title: Sahara Casino Partners reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 Journalists Killed in Rumanian Combat
description: Two foreign journalists have been killed and five wounded, including two Americans, during fighting between revolutionaries and forces loyal to Nicolae Ceausescu, the deposed president.

title: GTC Transcontinental reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Japan Urged to Lift Living Standards
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today praised Japan's strong economic growth, but called on Tokyo to increase its people's living standards to help the Japanese consume more and reduce that nation's huge trade surplus.

title: Nevada Rejects U.S. Requests On Proposed Nuclear Dump
description: Nevada has rejected Energy Department requests for environmental study permits for the proposed Federal nuclear waste dump at Yucca Mountain, Gov. Bob Miller said today.

title: Lee Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Moses Pendleton, Choreographer and Product of His Time
description: With his trim haircut, scholarly eyeglasses and intent stare, Moses Pendleton looks like one of Chekhov's impoverished young intellectuals. But the choreographer is clearly a product of his time.

title: Market Place; Banks That Shine Amid the Gloom
description: THE last few months have been terrible times for bank stocks, as losses from real estate lending at some New England banks have raised fears of similar problems in other regions.

title: Remodeling Plan for China's Colleges Is Pressed
description: Among the contacts being renewed between China and groups in the United States is a collaborative effort in which American educators are to help China remodel its higher education system.

title: Soviets Lose to Islanders
description: Pat LaFontaine scored two goals and Derek King had three assists as the Islanders beat the Soviet Wings, 5-4, tonight for their first victory ever against a team from the Soviet Union.

title: American Recreation Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter net included a pretax gain of $677,000 from the sale of property. Latest 6-month net included a pretax gain of $326,000 from the sale of assets; year-ago 6-month included the pretax gain of $677,000.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Trial; For an Unrepentant Ceausescu, Summary Justice
description: Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, went to their deaths by firing squad defiantly spurning the right of their military accusers to judge them.

title: Upheaval in the East: Foreign Reaction; New Bucharest Government Supported Despite Criticism
description: Several nations and the human rights group Amnesty International criticized Rumania's new leaders today for executing former President Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, without a public trial, saying a free Rumania should live by the rule of law.

title: Man Is Accused of Killing His Ailing Wife
description: A retired police officer who was facing major heart surgery fatally shot his ailing wife because he was afraid he could not take care of her and did not want her to suffer anymore, the authorities say.

title: Billy Martin Never Beat Injustice
description: This was in the summer of 1961, while Billy Martin was serving what would turn out to be the first of many sentences of exile from New York. He was finishing up as a player with the Minnesota Twins, wearing a gray road uniform in his old ball park, Yankee Stadium.

title: Schembechler's Theory
description: Bo Schembechler, the Michigan football coach and athletic director, said yesterday that some of the presidents of the schools in the Big Ten Conference used a ''buddy system'' to vote Penn State into the conference last week. Speaking publicly on the subject for the first time, the retiring coach lamented the fact that none of the Big Ten athletic directors were consulted.

title: El Paso Gas Settles With TransAmerican
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company, a subsidiary of Burlington Resources Inc., said today that it would pay the TransAmerican Natural Gas Corporation $300 million to settle a five-year dispute over a contract to purchase gas.

title: Landmark Buying Cigna Partnerships
description: Landmark Ventures Inc. said it would acquire 54 venture-capital partnerships from Cigna Venture Capital Inc. for more than $100 million. The partnerships have 1,200 investments in nearly 800 companies. Landmark, previously known as Technology Transitions Inc., manages about $60 million in 25 technology-based growth companies that include computer-based systems, software and support services and advanced electronics.

title: People
description: * Otis K. Henderson 2d has been named advertising director of Instructor magazine, published by Scholastic Inc.

title: Nuclear Industry Needs a Watchdog That Bites
description: To the Editor:

title: Bancroft Convertible Fund reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
United Press International: Sanctuary; Experts Doubt Vatican Will Yield Noriega to U.S.
description: Two close observers of Vatican diplomacy said yesterday that they doubted Roman Catholic officials would turn Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega over to the United States. The deposed Panamanian leader is in refuge in the Papal Nuncio's residence in Panama City. .

title: As Westmark Divests, Its Chairman Resigns
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive of Westmark Systems Inc. and its subsidiary, Tracor Holdings Inc., effective Dec. 31.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-15 An interim President for Rumania was named and a new Government was assembled by the leaders of the revolution. Armed resistance by forces loyal to the late dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, tapered off. Page A1 New Government wins some foreign support despite criticism A11 The burials have begun in Bucharest amid a somber realization that the precise number of Rumanians killed will never be known. A1 The avarice of Nicolae Ceausescu and his family is being laid before the Rumanian people. The military tribunal that ordered their execution accused them of salting away $1 billion in foreign bank accounts. A10 Videotape of trial shows defiant Ceausescus A11 Lithuania's break from the Kremlin was denounced by the Communist Party Central Committee, which rallied behind President Mikhail Gorbachev, who said he would visit the republic to meet with rank-and-file party members. A1 The diplomatic impasse in Panama over the fate of Gen. Manuel Noriega continued as a semblance of normalcy returned to the capital. Businesses and Government offices opened for the first time since the American attack. A1 Experts doubt the Vatican will yield Noriega to U.S. A15 Efforts to denigrate Gen. Noriega were pressed further in an unusual report by the American military command in Panama describing him as a ''truly evil man'' who wore red underwear and associated with prostitutes. A14 Gen. Noriega's drug-related assets, believed to exceed $10 million deposited in several European countries, should be frozen, the Bush Administration said. A15 U.S. hopes Noriega prosecution is stronger A15 Cuba asks council for action on U.S., citing harassment A15 Nicaragua is shocked and frustrated by the weak international outcry against the American attack on Panama, the kind of military action they have long feared in their own country, officials say. A14 Amity with Palestinians, not emnity, is preferable, said Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, as he pledged to push plans for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in spite of opposition. A3 Israel attacked two bases in Lebanon belonging to the Lebanese Communist Party. An air strike near Beirut followed an earlier ground attack by elite troops in southern Lebanon, killing at least four people. A3 Israelis should forgive the Nazis, Archbishop Desmond Tutu said. It was the latest in a series of comments that have irked some Israelis during his Christmas visit to the Holy Land. A5 Africa's spot on the global agenda could slip downward with all the attention placed on Eastern Europe by the world's powers, African officials say. A6 India will not buy Swedish arms made by Bofors, the company reportedly involved in a kickback scheme with the administration of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced. A7 National A16-21 Low doses of the AIDS drug AZT are as effective as the current standard dose and less likely to cause side effects, experts say, but some patients are still suffering the side effects because of Government delays in approving lower dosages. A19 A plan for universal health insurance proposed by the head of a bipartisan Government commission would require employers to provide coverage for all employees or pay a tax to help provide it. A16 Organs of three fire victims help keep others alive A21 Day care for students' babies is being provided in a small but growing number of high schools around the country that are addressing the leading reason why girls drop out of school: motherhood. A20 The frigid weather across the South has left much of Houston without water. Temperatures were back in the 70's, but broken pipes and low water pressure meant no showers or drinking water for residents. A21 Saving the Old South in Savannah, Ga., has become a contentious issue between those who want to preserve the city's historic past and ensure its economic future. A16 Nevada rejects U.S. requests on proposed nuclear dump A18 Klan's anti-drug drive in Florida raises suspicion A16 Hearty doe raises Maine hopes for caribou transplant A20 Retail sales show gains for the season D1 Risks are high in competition for new jet fighter D1 New head for S.E.C. enforcement division D1 Regional B1-5 New York City's solid infrastructure belies the widespread perception that the city is falling apart. Improvements in roads, bridges and other public works systems this decade have begun to reverse a legacy of decay. A1 Edward Koch's year-end interview was restrained in tone as he maintained that the city was ''far better off now'' than when he took office in 1978. B3 Koch vetoes bill to aid the users of video terminals B3 Signs of a new mayor are appearing throughout New York City. Nameplates bearing ''David N. Dinkins'' will soon cover the ''Edward I. Koch'' on 50 signs around the city. B1 Gunmen flexing 'their muscles' kill two in drive-by shootings B1 Saving open space in New York State and preserving wetlands and forests is rapidly becoming more difficult as the money to buy environmentally sensitive lands dwindles. B1 Home for the holidays in New York, college students are recapturing childhood memories and high school friends, savoring the Christmas season and testing new-found self-confidence. B1 The Howard Beach riot convictions of three defendants for their role in the 1986 attack on three black men were overturned by a state appeals court, citing errors by the trial judge. B3 The retirement age for some judges mandated by the New York State Constitution was invalidated by a Federal judge, who cited the Federal law against age discrimination. B3 Agency will charge E.M.S. technicians in negligence case B3 Neediest Cases B5

title: Tisches Add to Holdings Of Bank of Boston Stock
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation, hard hit by losses on real estate lending, has received a vote of confidence from Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS Inc., who has bought a large block of the banking company's stock.

title: Upheaval in the East; Belgrade Party Unit Backs End of Monopoly
description: The Central Committee of the ruling Communist Party recommended today that the party adopt a proposal to end its 45-year monopoly on power in Yugoslavia.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Not Just Anti-Apartheid, but 'No White Settlers'
description: The goals of ending apartheid and ushering in black majority rule sound familiar, but the language heard this month had a harder, brittle edge. When the Pan-Africanist Movement, the newest arrival on the anti-apartheid scene, was born here on Dec. 2, its supporters rocked the hall with their chants of ''One settler - one bullet!''

title: Woman's Body Found in River
description: The body of a 22-year-old from nearby Watertown was found today partly submerged in the icy waters of the Mad River. A group of teen-agers found the body of Julia M. Ashe at the Scovill Dam waterfall with her hands bound and a piece of tape over her mouth. She was dressed in the clothes she wore when she left home on Dec. 16 to go Christmas shopping, the police said. The police speculated that Miss Ashe, a student at the University of Connecticut, had been abducted at a shopping plaza. Her car was on a dirt road nearby.

title: Retail Sales Show Gains For Season
description: With a final sales flurry, the 1989 Christmas season for retailers ended on an upbeat note, as expected.

title: Book Notes
description: In Need of Rewriting

title: One for the Gippers
description: Certain rulers have the ability to drive Presidents right up the White House wall. These are unsavory rulers. Ayatollah Khomeini was an unsavory ruler. So was General Noriega. That's why President Bush sent an army to toss him out.

title: Organs of 3 Fire Victims Help Keep Others Alive
description: When a fire killed their three young sons last month, Dubby and Diana Wilcox were approached about donating the children's organs. At first they said no, but after considering what they thought the boys would have wanted, they changed their minds.

title: NEC's $64 Million Brazilian Contract
description: The NEC Corporation won a $64 million order from Brazil's telecommunications company to set up a public mobile communications system in Rio de Janeiro, a NEC spokesman said. NEC will build about 30 stations from mid-1990 to early 1991, and supply a total of about 10,000 hand-held, portable and car telephones, he said.

title: How to Make 100 Guests Marvel at Your Poise
description: THE stroke of midnight Sunday will signal the start not only of a new year but of an entirely new decade.

title: Lessons
description: Wouldn't it be nice to receive 16 years of education - a high school diploma and a college degree - in 10 minutes for an investment of 5 cents?

title: Unanswered Question Surrounds Martin Death
description: Speculation often surrounded Billy Martin's enigmatic life. Now it surrounds his death.

title: Harvard U. Adds To Usual Titles
description: Harvard University may profess to be striving to fight its image as a citadel of the privileged. Sometimes, however, the Harvard of old peeps through the modern curtain.

title: Neutrogena Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain from a cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting for income taxes of $345,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Baltics; GORBACHEV AGREES TO GO TO LITHUANIA ON SECESSION MOVE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has decided to go to Lithuania soon to consult with rank-and-file Communist Party members about the Lithuanian party's decision to break from Moscow, several people who attended an emergency party meeting here said today. The two-day meeting of the national party leadership ended without agreement on how to address the problem.

title: Eating Well
description: EVEN at this time of year, when everyone is doing it, predicting the future is almost as dangerous as making resolutions: it is almost impossible to be successful at either. Year-end wrap-ups, on the other hand, hold no such uncertainty. They provide a sense of satisfaction for those who do the wrapping, and also for those who have posed the questions.

title: Unifirst Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Bush Signs Pay Rise Bill
description: President Bush signed an executive order today carrying out legislation raising top Government salaries by up to 35 percent next year and giving all Federal workers a 3.6 percent cost-of-living pay increase. House salaries will rise from $89,500 to $96,600 in 1990, while Senate salaries climb from $89,500 to $98,400. Top-level members of the executive service level, who now earn a maximum of $99,500, would earn $107,300.

title: Anonymous Donor Treats Professors
description: An anonymous benefactor is enriching the lives of faculty members at Whitworth College, providing free vacations, expensive food and other gifts.

title: Nuclear Industry Needs a Watchdog That Bites; Other Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Shamir Pledges to Press for Arab Voting
description: In a noticeable shift of tone, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said today that he preferred friendship to enmity with Palestinians and pledged to press ahead with proposals for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip despite opposition both within his own party and from many Palestinians.

title: What's in a Name? 50 Signs and a New Era.
description: Fifty slots on 50 signs on major roads connecting the five boroughs were waiting for official word on an 'N.'

title: Holtz Has a Perfect Excuse to Push Irish Hard
description: There was once a time, when D'Juan Francisco was a young football player at Notre Dame and not so wise, when he would wonder why things had to be done precisely as Lou Holtz demanded. When the players came together to form a huddle, why did the three stripes on the sides of their shoes have to be exactly in line with the next set of feet? Why did the backs have to have their hands behind their backs, while the others placed their hands on their knees? Why did the first step on certain movements have to be taken with this foot, in just that way?

title: Proxy Fight Seen Over Myers Seat
description: A dispute between the chairman of the L. E. Myers Company and a primary shareholder may lead to a proxy fight for control of the electrical construction concern, based in Oak Brook, Ill. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last week, Leonard Chavin, a Chicago real estate investor with 19 percent of Myers's outstanding shares, said he had nominated another representative to the company's board at Myers's 1990 annual meeting. Mr. Chavin already controls three board seats. If his representative is seated, Mr. Chavin will control a majority of the board.

title: After Noriega: U.S. View; Officials Asking Europeans To Freeze Assets of Noriega
description: The Bush Administration said today that it would ask several European countries to freeze more than $10 million in drug-related assets that the ousted Panamanian strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is believed to have deposited in their banks.

title: Money Dwindles for Purchase of New York's Vanishing Open Land
description: Long a national leader in preserving open space, New York State is in danger of falling behind as it rapidly runs out of money to buy environmentally sensitive lands.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Upheaval in the East; Bulgaria Communists Pledge Talks With the Opposition
description: Bulgaria's Communist leaders said today that they would hold talks with the opposition early in 1990.

title: After Noriega: Prosecution; U.S. Hopes Noriega Case Is Stronger
description: Federal prosecutors said today that they hoped that their drug-trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega would be strengthened after the jailing in Miami of a close associate of the deposed Panamanian strongman.

title: Fonteyn and Kolpakova To Coach Ballet Theater
description: Dame Margot Fonteyn and Irina Kolpakova, former prima ballerinas of the Royal Ballet and the Kirov Ballet respectively, will coach members of American Ballet Theater during the company's winter rehearsal in January.

title: Houstonians Without Water After Cold
description: Water was the primary topic of conversation today in Houston, where nearly every section of town had either no water at all or just a demoralizing trickle.

title: Africa Fears Its Needs Will Become Secondary
description: African officials say they are concerned that with attention focused on Eastern Europe, sub-Saharan Africa is likely to be relegated far down on the global agenda.

title: Israeli Court Rules Jews for Jesus Cannot Automatically Be Citizens
description: Messianic Jews are not entitled to automatic Israeli citizenship, Israel's Supreme Court has ruled, concluding that their belief that Jesus was the Messiah makes them Christians instead of Jews.

title: Police Officer and a Guard Wounded in Queens Chase
description: A New York City police officer was shot and slightly wounded last night in a foot chase that started with a report of shots fired at Lefrak City in Elmhurst, where a security guard also was wounded, the police said.

title: Official Thanks
description: The corruption scandal that marred Mayor Edward Koch's third term made it easy to forget that he brought to city government some of the finest public officials ever to serve New York. Those who worked tirelessly for the people of New York far outnumbered the losers. Here are a just a few who have earned the city's gratitude.

title: C.I.A. Founding Faced Strong Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of U.S. Panel Pushes Universal Health Insurance
description: The chairman of a commission appointed by President Ronald Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders has issued a far-reaching proposal for universal health insurance and urged its adoption by Congress and the Bush Administration.

title: Books of The Times; Bettelheim's Beliefs and the Ways They Evolved
description: Freud's Vienna And Other Essays By Bruno Bettelheim 282 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Colt Industries, the New York-based industrial manufacturing company, promoted Paul R. Kuhn to president of its Menasco Aerosystems division.

title: After Noriega: United Nations; CUBA ASKS COUNCIL FOR ACTION ON U.S.
description: Cuba called today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to hear its complaint that American forces in Panama have surrounded the ambassador's residence there and are harassing its diplomats.

title: Donors Offer Special Words For Neediest
description: What I gave, I have; what I spent, I had; what I kept, I lost. John Bunyan He who bestows his goods upon the poor, shall have as much again, and 10 times more. John Bunyan In this world it is not what we take up, but what we give up, that makes us rich. Henry Ward Beecher No man can have society upon his own terms. If he seeks it, he must serve it too. Ralph Waldo Emerson

title: Stocks Are Mixed in Very Slow Trading
description: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday in extremely slow post-Christmas trading. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.13 points, to 2,709.26, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange edged out declines by 712 to 664.

title: School Offers Day Care For Teen-Age Mothers
description: When she was just a child, Joanna Rivas used to look at her parents and think: ''How easy it is to have a child. It must be fun.'' Now she is 17 years old, a 10th grader with a 5-month-old daughter, and she knows better.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Oryx Appoints a Chief For New British Unit
description: LEAD: The Oryx Energy Company, the United States exploration and production group spun off by the Sun Company, has established an independent subsidiary to develop most of the oil and gas properties it has agreed to acquire from the British Petroleum Company for $1.1 billion.

title: U.S. Seeking to Freeze Assets Tied to Noriega
description: The Bush Administration said it would ask several European countries to freeze bank accounts holding more than $10 million in what it says are drug-related assets belonging to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega associate could provide new evidence against the general.

title: Videotron Ltee reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hostages in Colombian Jail Are Freed by Police Assault
description: The police stormed a cell block controlled by drug traffickers holding 18 hostages. Six traffickers were killed and five hostages wounded, officials said today. All hostages were released, and the situation at the La Picota jail in southern Bogota returned to normal, a Justice Department spokesman said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The current party and state leadership will not permit the breakup of the federal state. If we cross this line, we will deliberately be heading toward the disintegration of the Soviet Union.'' -President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:3. ]

title: Chicken Soup For Obscurity
description: JOAN and Lydia Wilen are headed toward the big time. Sales of their books, ''Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies'' (Fawcett, 1984) and ''More Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies'' (Fawcett, 1986), are soaring, and the sisters, who place their ages ''somewhere between Brooke Shields and Joan Collins,'' are the toast of the talk-show circuit.

title: Accounts
description: * Sandals, an operator of resorts in Jamaica, to the William Cook Agency, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 17 about competition for Nobel Prizes referred incorrectly to Oreste Piccioni. As he notes in a recent letter, he was not a student assistant but a scientific associate of Owen Chamberlain and Emilio Segre, who shared the 1959 Nobel Prize in Physics. The article also gave an incomplete description of a dispute between Dr. Piccioni and the Nobel laureates. In 1972 he sued them in Alameda County (Calif.) Superior Court, contending that they had not properly recognized his role in the discovery of the antiproton, for which the prize was awarded. The suit was dismissed on procedural grounds. Dr. Piccioni says he made a suggestion that was essential to the experiment. Dr. Chamberlain acknowledged Dr. Piccione's suggestion in his Nobel speech but says it was not essential.

title: Kabul Is Hit With Rockets
description: Rocket barrages on Kabul by Afghan rebels killed eight people and wounded six today, the official Kabul radio said. Government forces killed 30 rebels in a counterattack, the radio report said. Five rebel bases were destroyed by air and artillery strikes near the capital.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: TWO seaside hours north of traffic-choked Los Angeles, Santa Barbara is a well-heeled retreat of sandy beaches framed by scrubby hills, where Ronald Reagan repaired to his vacation ranch.

title: George J. Becker, 81; Taught at Swarthmore
description: Dr. George J. Becker, an author of books on writers and literary criticism and a retired chairman of the English department at Swarthmore College, died on Friday in a nursing home in Bellingham, Wash., after a long illness. He was 81 years old. Dr. Becker was on Swarthmore's faculty for 25 years, heading its English department from 1953 to 1970, when he transferred to Western Washington University. He retired in 1974.

title: Review/Art; A Show of the Anti-Movement Movement
description: ''We will not lead; we will only detonate'' is one of many slogans that mingle with art and written texts in an exhibition at the Institute of Contemporary Art here.

title: Austral Drops Against Dollar
description: The Government of President Carlos Saul Menem suffered an economic setback today when the Argentine currency lost 27 percent of its value against the dollar in a single day.

title: New Midway Fares
description: Midway Airlines Inc. said it had introduced promotional fares of $19 to $99 one way on flights from Chicago to any city it served in the continental United States. The fares end on March 31, but the tickets must be purchased by Jan. 20. Requirements for minimum stays were waived to all destinations, and restrictions on advance purchases were also waived to all destinations in Florida, except Jacksonville. Tickets to other destinations must be bought 21 days in advance.

title: Arson Discounted in Fatal Fire
description: A fire that killed 16 people in a high-rise retirement center started on the first floor, but investigators have not narrowed the cause, city fire officials said today.

title: Another Suspension For Valenzuela?
description: When Pat Valenzuela returned to racing at Santa Anita yesterday after a 60-day suspension for failing a cocaine test, the jockey rode right into more trouble.

title: Joseph Livingston, 84; Won Pulitzer in 1964
description: Joseph A. Livingston, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter whose column appeared in more than 50 newspapers nationwide, died Monday at the age of 84.

title: I.M.F. Loan to Pakistan
description: The International Monetary Fund said it would lend Pakistan $213 million to support an economic program aimed at reducing the nation's budget deficit, freeing trade and introducing flexible exchange-rate management. The loan is the second installment of a three-year, $497 million I.M.F. credit. The first $142 million was drawn in December 1988. Under Pakistan's economic program for 1990, public spending will be directed toward health, education and irrigation, the I.M.F. said.

title: Israel and Relevance
description: Now starts the 21st century, argues the Israeli philosopher Yirmiyahu Yovel. The 20th century was not only brutish but short. It started in 1914, with the conflict President Woodrow Wilson called ''the war to end wars.'' It ends, Mr. Yovel claims with some intellectual justification, in 1989. This year, the most heavily armed parts of the world learned that force is not strength.

title: Thefts of Cargo Containers Are Up at Los Angeles Ports
description: Thefts of shipping containers are increasing at the Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors and from nearby warehouses, the Los Angeles Police Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation say.

title: Death and Rebirth in Rumania
description: ''The sentence was definitive and was carried out.'' So ended the announcement on Rumanian radio of the Christmas Day execution by firing squad of Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife. It is hard to feel pity for the Communist autocrat responsible for the wanton massacre of his ill-used people. Yet summary justice is a treacherous substitute for rule of law.

title: James J. Manderino, Pennsylvania Speaker, 57
description: James J. Manderino, Speaker of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, died early today, a few hours before he planned to announce his retirement next year, an aide said. He was 57 years old.

title: Nuclear Industry Needs a Watchdog That Bites; Oil Imports Rise Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Tutu Urges Israelis to Pray for and Forgive Nazis
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu of Cape Town, the Anglican Primate of Southern Africa, urged Israelis today to pray for and forgive those responsible for the Nazi genocide.

title: Mesa Air to Buy Aspen Air Routes
description: Aspen Airways Inc. said it had agreed to sell to Mesa Airlines Inc. its aircraft and routes except for those serving the ski resort of Aspen. Terms were not disclosed. Don Ringsby, the president of Aspen Airways, said the transition would begin in mid-February and should be completed by June. Mesa Airlines, based in Farmington, N.M., said it would seek an agreement with United Airlines to operate Aspen Airways' old routes as a United Express carrier.

title: Israel Conducts 2 Attacks in Lebanon
description: Israeli warplanes bombed and apparently destroyed a Lebanese Communist Party base south of Beirut today shortly after a ground attack by an elite paratroop unit on another Communist Party camp in southern Lebanon, the army said.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle yesterday gave an incorrect clue for 10 Down. It should have read, ''Tempe's Bowl.'' (The answer was Fiesta.)

title: Insurers Must Protect Their Policy Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle to Create Phones for the Future
description: In the battle for the residential telephone market, two companies -A.T.&T. and Panasonic - are so far the big winners among scores of equipment makers. They lead the way in technology and innovation, and they have the market share to prove it.

title: National Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,119,000, or 9 cents a share for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Rare Battle for Top Post Erupts at Board of Trade
description: A year marked by scandal has led to a rare contested battle for the chairman's post at the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's oldest and largest futures exchange.

title: Disney Comic Venture Set
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had licensed a joint-venture company to produce nine new comic books featuring Disney characters for publication in Latin America.

title: Winter Break: Skyline Replaces Ivory Towers
description: Amid lights, bells and teeming sidewalks, six graduates of Ward Melville High School in Setauket, L.I. - home from college for the holidays - set out in one afternoon to get a dose of Christmas, Manhattan and one another.

title: Ewing Off As Knicks Roll On
description: Patrick Ewing scored a season low of 11 points tonight as the Knicks ran their winning streak to seven games by defeating the Miami Heat, 100-94. The Knick center also had his poorest shooting night from the field, making only 4 of 18 shots.

title: Lamson Stake Disclosed
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd. said it owned 7.64 percent, or about 998,700 shares, of the common stock of the Lamson & Sessions Company, a maker of truck and railroad equipment based in Cleveland. Industrial Equity, a Hong Kong-based company associated with the New Zealand investor Sir Ron Brierley, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it bought the shares from Oct. 5 to Dec. 22 for $8.13 to $10.19 each. Lamson shares closed today at $10.125, up 12.5 cents each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Judge Voids New York Rule Requiring Judges' Retirement
description: A Federal judge yesterday invalidated a provision of the New York State Constitution that requires certain state judges to step down at the age of 76.

title: After Noriega; Colombia and Bolivia To Go to Drug Summit
description: The Presidents of Colombia and Bolivia plan to attend a summit meeting on drugs with President Bush despite Peru's decision to boycott the gathering unless American troops leave Panama.

title: Despite Perception, New York City Is on the Mend
description: New York City has begun to reverse a legacy of physical decline. Over the last decade, with money to spend and a new emphasis on rebuilding New York rather than adding to it, city officials have made major improvements in the physical environment.

title: Gay and Disappointed
description: To The Living Section:

title: Valvano Tones It Down
description: One of Jim Rehbock's responsibilities as the North Carolina State trainer at basketball games is to use any means necessary, including force, to prevent Jim Valvano from leaving the coach's box to protest officials' calls. Lately, Rehbock has added another policing task to his portfolio of duties, hurrying to tell Valvano when a visitor walks unbidden into Reynolds Coliseum while the team practices.

title: Professional Care reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $48,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $395,000, or 12 cents a share and $600,000, or 18 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Samuel Beckett Is Dead at 83; His 'Godot' Changed Theater
description: Samuel Beckett, a towering figure in drama and fiction who altered the course of contemporary theater, died in Paris on Friday at the age of 83. He died of respiratory problems in a Paris hospital, where he had been moved from a nursing home. He was buried yesterday at the Montparnasse cemetery after a private funeral.

title: Upheaval in the East: Gorbachev; Excerpts From Speech Given by Soviet Leader
description: Following are excerpts, translated by The New York Times, from an official transcript of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech Monday on the Lithuanian Communist Party's decision to break away from the national party:

title: After Noriega: Noriega; MILITARY COMMAND BELITTLES GENERAL
description: The United States military headquarters here, which has portrayed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as an erratic, cocaine-snorting dictator who prays to voodoo gods, announced today that the deposed leader wore red underwear and availed himself of prostitutes.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AFTER-CHRISTMAS REMEMBERED

title: Upheaval in the East: Broadcasts; Excerpts From Press Agency Reports on Rumanian Upheaval
description: Following are excerpts from the French television network Antenne 2, the Soviet press agency Tass and broadcasts from Agerpres and other Rumanian sources, as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service: Execution of Ceausescu

title: Apple Strays From Mass Appeal
description: From the time it decided to sound friendly by naming itself after a fruit, Apple Computer Inc. has proclaimed that its corporate mission is to spread computers to the masses.

title: Launching of Titan Is Delayed a 6th Time
description: Cold weather and high winds today forced the Martin Marietta Corporation to postpone its first commercial rocket launching for a sixth time.

title: Upheaval in the East: Hidden Wealth; Disclosures of the Ceausescus' Riches Appall Many Threadbare Rumanians
description: From drippingly fat bank accounts in Switzerland to meat scales made of gold, the reported plunder and greed of Nicolae Ceausescu and his family is starting to be laid before a shocked and disgusted Rumanian people.

title: To Free Nonmarried Couples From Legal Limbo
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate; Mandating More Glitter On Times Sq.
description: LUTSES are loose in Midtown, doing their colorful, frolicsome, cheerful bit to restore the glitter of the Great White Way.

title: About New York; Beam of Light Warms Sad Story Of 'Grandmother'
description: Bertha Czaczkes is 90 years old and lives alone in an apartment in Washington Heights. Her sister Serafine, the closest person to her in the world, passed away long ago. Yellowing pictures of the two of them are all about.

title: Fetisov Perturbed by a Devils' Acquisition
description: The Devils announced yesterday that they had signed another Soviet defenseman, to the consternation of their more famous Soviet player.

title: Prices Off Sharply in Thin Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities plunged yesterday in thin trading.

title: Joel R. Jacobson Is Dead at 71; New Jersey's First Energy Chief
description: Joel R. Jacobson, New Jersey's first energy commissioner and an outspoken public official, died early today at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He had been admitted Friday with severe chest pains. He was 71 years old and lived in South Orange.

title: Steelers Are Enjoying Their Late Awakening
description: The numbers game has been a gruesome chore for the Pittsburgh Steelers throughout their remarkable season.

title: Sir Lennox Berkeley, Composer, Dies at 86
description: Sir Lennox Berkeley, an eminent British composer perhaps best known for his Stabat Mater choral work, died on Tuesday. He was 86 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East; Pronouncing the Names
description: NICOLAE CEAUSESCU, the executed former leader: nee-koh-LAH-yeh chow-SHESS-koo ELENA CEAUSESCU, his wife and second in command, also executed: eh-LEH-nah NICU CEAUSESCU, their son: NEE-koo ZOIA CEAUSESCU, their daughter: ZOH-yah DOINA CORNEA, a leader in Cluj: DOY-nah KOHR-nah ION ILIESCU, named President of the interim Government: yahn ill-ee-YES-koo CORNELIU MANESCU, a Council of National Salvation leader: kor-NEHL-yoo mah-NESS-koo DUMITRU MAZILU, named Vice President of the interim Government: doo-MEE-troo mah-ZEE-loo NICOLAE MILITARU, named Defense Minister of the interim Government: nee-koh-LAH-yeh mee-lee-TAH-roo AUREL DRAGOSCH MUNTEANU, a Council of National Salvation leader: oh-RELL DRAH-gohsh moon-TYAH-noo PETRE ROMAN, named Prime Minister of the interim Government: PEHT-treh ROH-man Rev. LASZLO TOKES, a leader in Timisoara: LAHSS-loh TOH-kehsh

title: Catherine M. Kelly, Secretary, 66
description: Catherine M. Kelly, an executive secretary at The New York Times from 1953 to 1970, died of a stroke Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 66 years old and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Nippon Motorola Delays Chip Plant
description: Nippon Motorola Ltd., a Japanese unit of Motorola Inc., has postponed building a semiconductor plant in northern Japan for about 10 months because of a weak market for memory chips, a spokesman said. Nippon Motorola had planned to start construction in October.

title: New Jet Fighter: Risks Are High
description: The two teams of military contractors competing for a contract to build a new generation of jet fighters are finding their gamble is even bigger than anticipated.

title: Cold Reduces Orange and Vegetable Crops
description: The recent freezing weather has partly devastated the orange crop in Florida, which will drive up the price of orange juice. But a huge Brazilian orange crop is expected to help keep the increases down.

title: International Capital Equipent reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KEY RATES
Compuflight Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Walton Is Dismissed as the Jets Clean House
description: The Jets' general manager, Dick Steinberg, officially cleaned house today. He dismissed Coach Joe Walton and his 10 assistants, accepted the resignation of Mike Hickey, whose college drafts had provided the bulk of the Jets' players, and reduced the role of Jim Royer, who evaluated and signed pro personnel.

title: INSIDE
description: Avoiding AZT Side Effects Studies have shown low doses of AZT effective against AIDS and less likely to cause side effects. But critics say the Federal Government has been slow to respond. Page A19. Fighting to Build a Fighter The companies competing for a contract to build a new generation of jet fighters are finding their gamble bigger than anticipated. Page D1. Jets Dismiss Walton Dick Steinberg, the Jets' new general manager, dismissed Coach Joe Walton and his aides. Page B9.

title: Rite Aid Corp reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 2
description: b-Included after-tax gains from the sale of the company's 46.8 percent interest in Super Rite Foods Inc. of $18,370,000, or 44 cents a share and $20,165,000, or 49 cents a share for the 13 weeks and 39 weeks, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $710,000, or 2 cents a share for the 13 weeks and $2,072,000, or 5 cents a share for the 39 weeks. The company said the LIFO method of valuing inventory had the effect of reducing net income 4 cents a share for the 13-week period and 12 cents a share for the 39-week period ended Dec. 2, 1989. For the comparable periods last year, the LIFO adjustments were 2 cents a share for the 13 weeks and 8 cents a share for the 39 weeks.

title: Festival Matches 4 Friends
description: While the four teams are from all over, the E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival tournament, which starts tonight at Madison Square Garden, will have a distinctively local flavor.

title: Burlington Journal; The Mayor Still Leads With His Left
description: Peter Clavelle was miffed.
