Halfway through his first term as Mayor of Vermont's largest city, he was being asked once again in an interview the other day to compare himself with his predecessor, Bernard Sanders, the flamboyant Socialist who attracted international attention to this municipality of 40,000 people on the eastern shore of Lake Champlain. And it was once too often.

title: Munitions Plant Explodes
description: A clandestine gunpowder factory exploded today in northeastern Brazil, killing four people, injuring more than 100 and destroying nearby homes. Fire-rescue workers dragged more than 100 people from the wreckage of their homes after the blast in the city of Feira de Santana, more than 900 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro.

title: A Is for Abominable
description: To The Living Section:

title: Hearty Doe Stirs Hopes Of Caribou 'Transplant'
description: Attempts to reintroduce caribou to Maine have been thwarted by disease and bears, but based on the success of a hearty doe named Daisy, officials hope Canada will provide more animals for ''transplant.''

title: Wine Talk
description: WHICH is more important, where a wine comes from, or the grape from which it is made? In California, it's the grape. A wine is a cabernet sauvignon or a zinfandel or a chardonnay. In France, it's the opposite. We know the place - Chateau Latour, for example - and care little about the grapes from which the wine is made. Or so it would seem.

title: Microsemi Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $56,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $514,000, or 7 cents a share for the year, and the quarter and year also included a charge of $8,924,000 for the disposition of five businesses; a charge of $1,386,000 for inventory evaluation; a $1,200,000 reserve for certain notes receivable from an affiliated company; a $1,035,000 writeoff of goodwill related to two previously acquired subsidiaries; and a $450,000 writedown to market value of an investment in a non-affiliated electronics company. c-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $27,000 and $493,000, or 6 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: New Earle Palmer Unit
description: Earle Palmer Brown, a marketing communications agency based in Bethesda, Md., has established a Southeast division comprising its Atlanta, Tampa and Miami offices. The chairman of the division will be Alf Nucifora, formerly president of the Atlanta office. Don Hofmann, president of the Tampa office, was named president of the division.

title: The Pop Life
description: New Voices of 1989

title: Smokers in Scandinavia Unite to Resist Bans
description: Shoved into corners, banned from local flights and excluded from some hotel floors, smokers in Scandinavia say they have had enough and are beginning to fight back.

title: Koch, in Veto, Discounts Risks In Computer Use
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday rejected legislation aimed at protecting New York City municipal employees who use video display terminals.

title: River Oaks Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Follow Your Own Nose
description: To The Living Section:

title: Albert L. Shore, Financier, 81
description: Albert L. Shore, a financier and supermarket developer, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and also had a home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Panel Absolves Guard In Virginia Beach Acts
description: The Virginia Army National Guard performed ''in a highly professional manner'' during Labor Day disturbances in Virginia Beach, according to findings of an independent review announced today by the National Guard Bureau.

title: The New Minister Of Soviet Culture Takes Truth as Task
description: The Soviet Union has appointed one of its most popular actors and film directors as Minister of Culture, and there is general rejoicing in the Moscow arts world.

title: Chief Executive Resigning At Bank of New England
description: Troubled by problem real estate loans and mounting losses, the Bank of New England Corporation announced yesterday that its chief executive would step down and that the bank would continue to seek some kind of reorganization, possibly including the sale of the bank.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ASEA A.B., Sweden, a heavy equpment maker, said it had sold its ABB Electric Inc. unit to Magnetek Inc., Los Angeles, which makes transformers, for $54 million.

title: 3 Convictions Are Dismissed In 2d Howard Beach Trial
description: Citing significant errors by the trial judge, a New York State appeals court has thrown out the riot convictions of three of the defendants in the 1986 racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Federal Delay in Lowering Standard For Doses of AIDS Drug Is Assailed
description: Two large studies have shown that low doses of the AIDS drug AZT are just as effective for many patients as the standard dose and are less likely to cause dangerous side effects. But thousands of people infected with the AIDS virus are suffering the side effects unnecessarily, critics charge, because the Government has delayed considering a lower dose.

title: Benny Binion Is Dead; Casino Owner Was 85
description: Benny Binion, owner of the Horseshoe Casino in Las Vegas whose flamboyant promotional efforts included an annual monthlong ''World Series of Poker'' for high-stakes players, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, where he lived. He was 85 years old.

title: Gay and Pleased
description: To The Living Section:

title: Comparison by Ferry
description: Danny Ferry, the former Duke all-American who said arriverderci to the National Basketball Association after being selected second in the college draft last spring, says he realizes a move from Il Messagero Roma of the Italian pro basketball circuit to the Cleveland Cavaliers would force him to toughen up.

title: India Orders a Ban on Arms Company in Scandal
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh said today that India will bar all purchases from the Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors until the company reveals the names of Indians to whom it apparently paid kickbacks in a 1986 arms contract.

title: Upheaval in the East: Leadership; An Aristocrat Among the Revolutionaries
description: Rumania's new Prime Minister, Petre Roman, rates in the Communist world as something of an aristocrat - his father, Valter Roman, was a prewar member of Rumania's then-tiny Communist Party who fought in the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War.

title: Handing Down Lebanon's Rich Tradition
description: SINCE she does not drive, Malvina Azzi cannot get to George's Bakery as often as she would like. But sometimes Mrs. Azzi, 78 years old, persuades one of her four sons to drive her the 30 miles down the Merrimac River to George's, in the gritty old mill town of Lawrence, Mass. There she buys the ingredients she needs to cook her favorite Lebanese dishes, rich and buttery, meat-filled celebration foods, aromatic with cinnamon, allspice and coriander. She learned to prepare those dishes in Majlouna, a village in the Lebanese mountains where she lived as a young child.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOR children who give ''the fisheye'' to salmon en croute, the Inn at Essex offers a special buffet at Sunday brunch: a small table spread with chicken fingers, pizza, peanut butter cookies and other foods attractive to young palates. And one weekend each month, the young guests are invited to help prepare the brunch in the hotel's bakeshop.

title: Insurance Head Named Continental's President
description: William E. Thiele, senior executive vice president in charge of insurance operations for the Continental Corporation, was named president yesterday, effective Jan. 1.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: MANY people enjoy recalling the tastes of childhood, but few pursue those memories to the extent William Loew has.

title: Executive Leaving NBC
description: Thomas B. Ross is leaving biNBC News, where he is a senior vice president, for Hill & Knowlton Inc., the public relations and public affairs subsidiary of the WPP Group, where he will be a senior vice president and global director of media relations. Mr. Ross began his career as a journalist, and from 1977 to 1981 he was Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs. He is also the co-author, with David Wise, of the books ''The U-2 Affair,'' ''The Invisible Government,'' and ''The Espionage Establishment.''

title: Billy Martin's Two Worlds
description: The sadness of Billy Martin, who died Monday on an icy road near his farm in upstate New York, is the sadness of a badly disconnected life. Inside a baseball stadium he came as close as he ever did to joy and self-control, even when he was railing against umpires and defeat. But outside lay another world that he never seemed to grasp and certainly couldn't control, a world in which his pugnacity, combined with alcohol, produced behavior as pathetic as it was predictable.

title: Food Notes
description: Pine Nuts Grow on Trees

title: Chuck Person Is Out
description: Chuck Person, the Indiana Pacer forward, is recovering from a scratched cornea and is not expected to play for at least two games.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The S.E.C. named William R. McLucas its chief of enforcement and announced the formation of an enforcement unit to protect individual investors against fraud at financial institutions. [ Page D1. ] The recent freezing weather has damaged the orange crop in Florida, which will drive up the price of orange juice. But a huge Brazilian crop is expected to keep the increases down. [ D1. ] The 1989 Christmas season ended with retailers posting gains. But pressure on profit margins has been heavy from steep price-cutting in the weeks before Christmas. [ D1. ] A year marked by scandal has led to a rare contested battle for the chairman's post at the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's oldest and largest futures exchange. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL The O.E.C.D. praised Japan's strong economic growth but called on Tokyo to increase its people's living standards to encourage buying and reduce the nation's huge trade surplus. [ D12. ] Prime Minister Singh of India said his nation would bar all purchases from Bofors, a Swedish arms manufacturer, until the company reveals the names of Indians to whom it had apparently paid kickbacks in a 1986 arms contract. [ A7. ] COMPANIES Bank of New England's chief executive will step down when a replacement is found and the bank, troubled by problem real estate loans and mounting losses, will continue to seek some kind of reorganization, possibly including its sale. [ D1. ] Bank of Boston received a vote of confidence from Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS Inc., who has bought a large block of its holding company's stock. [ D2. ] A former engineer with Hughes Aircraft has filed suit against the giant military contractor, accusing it of selling $3.2 billion of potentially flawed computer chips to the Navy. [ D2. ] El Paso Natural Gas will pay $300 million to TransAmerican Natural Gas to settle a five-year dispute. [ D3. ] MARKETS Stock prices ended narrowly mixed in extremely slow post-Christmas trading. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.13 points, to 2,709.26, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange edged out declines by 712 to 664. [ D6. ] Heating oil futures prices climbed dramatically after an explosion at the nation's second-largest petrochemical refinery. [ D13. ] The dollar declined against most key foreign currencies. [ D13. ] Prices of Treasury securities plunged, in thin post-holiday trading. [ D12. ] Yields were mostly down on C.D.'s and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions. [ D4. ] TECHNOLOGY A.T.&T. and Panasonic are the big winners among scores of equipment makers, and the two are now struggling to outdo each other in designing the telephones of the future. [ D5. ] The British Library has a new weapon in the campaign to save crumbling books: gamma rays. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Discovery Airlines's fight for certification presages far more important battles over the issue of foreign control of American carriers. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The last few months have been terrible for bank stocks, as losses from real estate lending in New England have raised fears of a nationwide problem. Market Place. [ D6. ] Schering-Plough is using cold-war imagery and language on behalf of a cold remedy. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D15. ]

title: Upheaval in the East: Victims; For the Victims in Rumania, Flowers and Places of Honor
description: The bodies came, one by one, to Belu Cemetery today.

title: Upheaval in the East; INTERIM RUMANIAN LEADERS NAMED AS FIGHTING SUBSIDES; HUNDREDS BURIED IN CAPITAL
description: The leaders of Rumania's revolution named an interim president and announced the formation of a new Cabinet today as armed resistance by holdouts loyal to the late dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, tapered off in the streets of the capital.

title: Last-Minute Tie Gives Devils Share of Division Lead
description: The Rangers added some variety last night in raising their streak to eight games without a victory. They allowed their first short-handed goal of the season and another goal with 25 seconds left in the third period and had to settle for a 4-4 deadlock against the Devils at Madison Square Garden.

title: Upheaval in the East;
description: The United States Government is giving the International Red Cross $500,000 to buy medical supplies for victims of the fighting in Rumania and is considering plans to send more aid, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Klan's Anti-Drug Drive in Florida Raises Suspicion
description: Ku Klux Klan groups say they have begun a campaign to rid Lakeland's streets of crack dealers. But the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the police say they are viewing the campaign with suspicion.

title: New Head For S.E.C. Division
description: Richard C. Breeden, the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today named William R. McLucas, who has been with the commission for 12 years, as the agency's chief enforcement officer. Mr. Breeden also announced the formation of an enforcement unit to protect individual investors against fraud at banks and savings institutions.

title: After Noriega: Panama City; Impasse Over Noriega Persists, But Order Returns to the Streets
description: As the diplomatic impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega continued, businesses and government offices opened here today and other normal activities resumed for the first time since an American invasion deposed the military leader a week ago.

title: Ford Recalls 36,000 Aerostars and Rangers
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a voluntary recall of more than 36,000 of Aerostar vans and Ranger trucks today, citing possible brake or throttle defects.

title: Jordan Will Loosen Curbs on Transport From the West Bank
description: The Jordanian Government has agreed to requests from the Palestine Liberation Organization to ease restrictions on the movement of people and goods from the Israeli-occupied West Bank to Jordan, officials said today.

title: Recycling Plan Depends On All New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Pedestrians Killed, 2 Hurt in Freak Crash
description: A 9-year-old boy and a woman were killed and another boy and a woman were critically injured in Brooklyn late yesterday afternoon in a freak automobile accident in which the driver who caused it fled the scene, the police reported last night.

title: Review/Television; Millo and Domingo in the Met Opera 'Aida'
description: Public television's series ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents'' is opening its 1989-90 season tonight -on Channels 13 and 49 at 8 o'clock - with Verdi's ''Aida.'' This year-old Sonja Frisell production, conducted by James Levine, was taped at a Saturday matinee performance on Oct. 7. Once again the distinguished series, which started out as ''Live From the Met,'' meets its obligations quite grandly. Television does remarkably well by this repertory chestnut.

title: After Noriega; Noriega Called Exhausted
description: General Noriega was in no position to command Panamanian forces after United States military forces began their attack last week, and he arrived at the Vatican Embassy on Sunday in a state of exhaustion after barely escaping capture by American troops, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Gunmen Kill 2 Bystanders In 'Power Play'
description: A group of men, apparently trying to show that a drug location was their territory, fired randomly as they drove down a Queens street Monday night, killing a teen-ager and mortally wounding a pregnant woman, the police said.

title: Former Aide Sues Hughes Over Computer Chips
description: A former engineer with the Hughes Aircraft Company has filed suit against the giant military equipment contractor, charging that it sold potentially flawed computer chips to the Navy and then covered up the problem, the engineer's attorney said today.

title: Economic Scene; Foreign Owners For U.S. Airlines?
description: FIRST there were Pan Am and T.W.A. and United and American. And now - Discovery?

title: Toasting a Decade as the Ancients Did
description: BEVERAGES, like foods, have intimate links with the seasons. Icy blends of rum and fruit juice, for example, are ideal for the dog days of summer. The coming of winter provides a long-awaited excuse to make special drinks usually reserved for the holidays: wassail, hot mulled wine and eggnog. The days don't seem quite so cold, or the nights quite so long, with a sustaining mug of holiday cheer.

title: Thomas A. Savage, Executive, 70
description: Thomas A. Savage, a former president of William Iselin & Company, which provides financial services to the garment trade, died of pneumonia on Sunday at the Youville Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Cambridge, Mass. He was 70 years old and lived in Sebago Lake, Me.

title: Using Gamma Rays to Save Old Books
description: The British Library has found a new weapon in the campaign to save crumbling books: gamma rays. Book preservationists around the world now use alkaline baths or sprays to save important old volumes damaged by the acid in paper and inks. But these methods can involve painstaking page-by-page applications and an average cost of up to $480 a book, said Marie Jackson, national preservation officer of the British Library, the largest in Britain. With the gamma ray method, she said, volumes can be treated in bulk at an average cost of only $4.50 to $8 a book, far cheaper even than microfilming (about $48 for a 300-page book).

title: Review/Opera; Prey and Vaness in the Met's 'Fledermaus'
description: When Otto Schenk's bloated production of ''Die Fledermaus'' came thudding onto the Metropolitan Opera stage three years ago, one was sure the director was condescending, keeping the humor consistently coarse and obvious for the benefit of benighted American audiences. It was little consolation to see a year later that, thanks to Mr. Schenk, ''Fledermaus'' was playing much the same way at the Vienna State Opera.

title: Peres Delays a Soviet Visit; Economic Talks Unprepared
description: Finance Minister Shimon Peres has indefinitely postponed a visit to the Soviet Union planned for early next month, his spokesman said today.

title: The I's Have It for Another Decade
description: LEAD: The end of a decade provides an appropriate occasion for reflections on the course of recent events, but social life and culture march -or straggle - to a rhythm of their own, not to the rhythm of the calendar.

title: From Roosevelt, to Wilson, to Bush
description: LEAD: One can at least say this about George Bush's invasion of Panama: It is an act of real originality in post-1945 U.S.-Latin American policy.

title: Bridge
description: The Omar Sharif Individual tournament, to be played in Atlantic City in May at the Showboat Casino Hotel under the auspices of the Goren Organization, seems to have cleared all the hurdles. There will be a total prize fund of $200,000, with a first prize of $40,000 in the expert division, and the American Contract Bridge League has agreed to award master points, a precedent-setting decision.

title: DISSIDENT DEFIES BURMESE LEADERS
description: In the first recent act of open defiance of the Burmese military Government, a dissident leader and former Prime Minister has refused to renounce a rebel government he formed during last year's national uprising, diplomats said today.

title: Vatican Duties, U.S. Rights
description: By opening his door to Panama's fugitive strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Papal Nuncio in Panama served both a church mission and a practical need. But now the Bush Administration, in ''extraordinarily tough terms,'' pressures the Vatican to expel the general and further protests that it was ''totally inappropriate'' to have sheltered him at all. Washington has a legitimate case for seeking custody of a man under criminal indictment in the U.S. But it is wrong to place this issue above all other concerns.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL Suns 121, Trail Blazers 105: Kevin Johnson had 31 points and 13 assists as Phoenix handed Portland its fourth straight road loss. (AP) Celtics 112, Clippers 111: Larry Bird scored 27 points and hit a pair of free throws with two-tenths of a second left, and Reggie Lewis had a season-high 28 off the bench as visiting Boston extended its winning streak over Los Angeles to 11 games.(AP) Bulls 112, Timberwolves 99: Michael Jordan scored 28 and Scottie Pippen added 22 as Chicago gained its 10th victory in a row and handed Minnesota its ninth loss in a row. (AP) Nuggets 114, 76ers 111: Walter Davis scored 24, including a key jump shot with 1:16 to go, to lead Denver, playing at home, to its fourth victory in a row. Philadelphia had a chance to tie the game in the closing seconds but Charles Barkley, who scored 32, missed a 3-point shot. (AP) Jazz 133, Warriors 118: In Salt Lake City, Karl Malone scored 18 of his 39 points in a runaway first quarter and John Stockton had 18 points and 17 assists as Utah stopped Golden State's winning streak at six.(AP) Bucks 103, Rockets 96: Jack Sikma scored 26, including 13 in the fourth quarter, for Milwaukee. The Rockets lost their seventh road game in a row despite 34 points and 12 rebounds by Akeem Olajuwon. (AP) Pacers 98, Magic 90: Reggie Miller scored 22 of his 28 points in the second half to lead Indiana to the home-court victory. Miller scored 12 in the third period and 10 in the fourth. Sam Vincent scored 29 for Orlando.(AP) Spurs 107, Hornets 82: Terry Cummings matched his season-high with 32 points and David Robinson dominated inside as the visiting Spurs won their sixth consecutive game. The Hornets fell to 4-20, the worst record in the league. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 6, Penguins 3: Bob Joyce, Dino Ciccarelli and Michal Pivonka scored third-period goals to give Washington a rallying victory on home ice over Pittsburgh.(AP) Bruins 6, Maple Leafs 4: Craig Janney scored twice and assisted on two goals by Cam Neely, leading Boston to the home-ice victory.(AP) Sabres 6, Red Wings 3: Scott Arniel, Rick Vaive and Benoit Hogue scored late in the third period to give Buffalo the victory over visiting Detroit. Detroit's Gerard Gallant scored at 14:20 of the third to tie the score at 3-3, but Arniel scored two minutes later. (AP) Jets 5, North Stars 3: Winnipeg, playing at home, scored four goals in the third period to rally for the victory. Minnesota suffered its 11th defeat in 13 games.(AP) Blues 8, Blackhawks 3: Brett Hull regained the league scoring lead with two goals as St. Louis, playing at home, ended a three-game losing streak. Hull, who has 31 goals, added an assist and broke a tie for the scoring lead with Luc Robataille of Los Angeles. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Arkansas 117, Delaware State 75: Mario Credit had 20 points last night and Arkansas (8-1) held Delaware State (2-4) to two field goals in the first 8 minutes. (AP) WORLD JUNIOR HOCKEY Canada 3, United States 2: Stephane Fiset stopped 33 shots and Dave Chyzowski scored the winning goal as Canada opened the world junior tournament yesterday with the victory in Turku, Finland. (AP)

title: Harold Ellis Klue, Principal, 84
description: Harold Ellis Klue, a principal at the Riverdale Country School for Boys for 29 years, died on Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Marshal Guthrie, 70; Developed Cold Drug
description: Dr. Marshal Beck Guthrie, a dermatologist and clinical pharmacologist who was with SmithKline & French Laboratories in Philadelphia for 32 years before his retirement in 1986, died Dec. 17 at Sacred Heart Hospital in Norristown, Pa. He was 70 years old and lived in Wayne, Pa.

title: Koch Says City Is 'Far Better Off Now'
description: In a year-end interview in which he seemed at times to be addressing historians as well as reporters, Mayor Edward I. Koch insisted yesterday that New York City was ''far better off now'' than when he took office and was confident that he would be well remembered.

title: Chrysler Sees A Tough 1990
description: The Chrysler Corporation forecast today that 1990 could be an especially tough year for the domestic auto industry and total sales would drop to 14.5 million vehicles from an expected 14.9 million in 1989.

title: Hinson Gets 31 as Nets End 3-Game Slide
description: Roy Hinson's tender right knee has left him with two choices this season: either he must play in pain, or he cannot play at all.

title: S-K-I Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Upheaval in the East; Rumania's 11 Days of Turmoil
description: Dec. 15: Demonstrators ring a church in Timisoara, in western Rumania, to prevent security forces from arresting a clergyman who was active in promoting the rights of ethnic Hungarians. Dec. 16-17: Security forces open fire on thousands of demonstrators in Timisoara, who have expanded their protest to demand freedom and a better life. Hundreds are buried in mass graves. Dec. 18: The United States issues a formal protest over the use of force in Timisoara. Dec. 19: More shooting is reported in Timisoara. Britain, the Polish Parliament and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union condemn the violence. Dec. 20: President Nicolae Ceausescu, returning from a state visit to Iran, declares a state of emergency in westers Rumania and attributes the unrest to ''fascist, reactionary groups.'' Protests spread to at least eight other cities. In Timisoara, tens of thousandds of people take to the streets, chanting ''Give us our dead!'' Dec. 21: The revolt spreads to the capital, and security forces open fire on protesters. Mr. Ceausescu is shouted down while addressing what he had planned as an orchestrated rally. The state television shows his shocked face. Dec. 22: Army units join the rebellion, and a group known as the Council of National Salvation announces that is has overthrown Mr. Ceausescu and will forma a provisional government. It says it will try leaders of his 24-year-old Government and restore democracy. Mr. Ceausescu and his wif, Elene, flee the presidential palace. The United States and European nations applaud his ouster. Dec. 23: The provisional Government says the Ceausescus have been captured in a town north of Bucharest. Fierce street fighting takes place between the army, which backs the new Government and elements of the hated secret police, loyal to Mr. Ceausescu. Dec. 24: Fierce fighting continues in the capital and other cities. Dec. 25: The state radio announces the execution of Mr. Ceausescu and his wife after a secret trial that found them guilty of genocide and plundering more than $1 billion. The United States, the Soviet Union and other countries rcognize the provisional Government. Source: Associated Press

title: Marketing With Images Of Glasnost
description: IN a year when the Berlin wall became as familiar a sight in American television commercials as a suburban kitchen, it was bound to happen that a national marketer would eventually play on the phrase cold war.

title: Doug Harvey, 65; Hockey Defenseman In the Hall of Fame
description: Doug Harvey, who won the Norris Trophy as the National Hockey League's top defenseman seven times from 1955-62, died today in a Montreal hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: General Homes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $1,408,000 for the quarter and a loss of $438,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After income of $317,000 and a loss of $16,718,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. The company said results of operations for fiscal 1989 included a pretax charge-off in March 1989 of $113 million, of which $2.7 million related to discontinued operations. The company said results of operations for fiscal included a pretax charge-off in March 1988 of $91.1 million, of which $17 million related to discontinued operations. Year-ago, full-year net included a credit of $6,048,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: 2 E.M.S. Technicians Face Charges in Death
description: Disciplinary charges will be filed against two New York City Emergency Medical Services technicians who mistakenly presumed a Bronx man dead Saturday as he lay unconscious, E.M.S. officials said yesterday.

title: Counseling, From Careers to Everyday Stresses
description: School guidance counselors, whose original purpose was to assist high school students choose their courses and apply to college, are becoming a much more integral part of students' daily lives, especially at the elementary level.

title: After Noriega: Nicaragua; Sandinistas Are Fearful They Will Be a Target
description: The American attack on Panama has left Nicaraguan leaders shocked and deeply frustrated by what they see as a weak international reaction to the kind of direct military action they have long feared against their own Government, Sandinista officials say.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE in my household has always been a time of great abundance but at the same time utmost simplicity. My memories of New Year's Eve in France focus on the grand roast fillet of beef with winter vegetables.

title: Savannah Torn Over Its Direction: Past or Future?
description: To the north is Charleston, which despite Hurricane Hugo gets as much economic mileage out of Old South charm as anyplace south of Williamsburg.

title: Time Warner Disclosure
description: Time Warner Inc. disclosed today that two class-action lawsuits had been filed in the last month by Warner Communications Inc. shareholders challenging the amount of money that they would receive in the second stage of Warner's $14 billion merger with Time Inc.

title: Review/Theater; In His Apartment, a Puppeteer Wages a War Without End
description: A puppeteer, a survivor of the Holocaust, is living in Germany in 1950 -and is convinced that World War II is still being fought. He believes that if he steps out of his apartment, he will be arrested and returned to the concentration camp from which he escaped. In the privacy of that room, the apparently insane puppeteer acts out plays about his incarceration while his landlady helplessly tries to awaken him to reality.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We knew we had to stay on the air. If television falls, the revolution falls. That's for certain.'' -Eugenia Bogdan, an employee of Free Rumanian Television. [ A1:4. ]

title: Housing Aides Discriminate, Coalition Says
description: Pointing to deep-rooted ethnic and racial antagonisms in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a coalition of housing groups asserted yesterday that city housing officials are illegally using quotas there to favor Hasidic Jews in renting apartments. In legal papers filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the groups said that the New York City Housing Authority has violated a settlement agreed to in 1978 and approved by the court. The settlement was intended to insure that black and Hispanic residents would have equal access to public housing in the neighborhood.

title: Reserve Prisons for the Dangerous Offenders; Mentally Ill Inmates
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Bit of Mexico Brought to Manhattan
description: ''WHEN I moved to New York,'' Leslie Cozart said, ''I realized that few people here knew what Mexican furniture was all about.''

title: Ewing Misses Practice Session To Recover From a Rib Injury
description: As the Knicks went through what Coach Stu Jackson said was a much-needed practice today at the Miami Jewish Center, Patrick Ewing sat off to the side and watched.

title: Battle for Engine Maker Ends With Board Seats
description: A year spent wrangling with lawsuits and proxy battles is ending happily for Laurans A. Mendelson.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo to Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7,529,000, or 7 cents a share, for the latest 12 months and $9,925,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year-ago period. Revenue was from continuing operations.

title: Communists and Foes Agree to Broad-Based Talks
description: The ruling Communists and an opposition coalition agreed today to hold wide-ranging talks on Bulgaria's future, and the Government dismissed the Interior Minister, who had been criticized over police violence against demonstrators in October.

title: PITTSTON RESUMES MINE STRIKE TALKS
description: The Pittston Company resumed negotiations with its coal miners today to end a brutal strike in Appalachia that is now nearly nine months old. The participants are working toward a deadline of this weekend, the Federal mediator said.

title: Halton Reinsurance reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The revenues were not available.

title: How Nuclear Wastes Can Be Recycled
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing $2 Billion - An Accounting Quagmire; The Lapses by Lincoln's Auditors
description: As Federal investigators press their inquiry into the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the biggest failure in the current savings industry crisis, a number of regulators, auditors and other experts say accounting and auditing safeguards also collapsed during the Lincoln fiasco.

title: Market Place; Tax Laws Spur Borrowing Boom
description: IN the era of leverage, its founders do not reside on Wall Street, public perceptions to the contrary. The boom in borrowing can, to a considerable extent, be laid at the doorstep of the Congressional tax law writers.

title: Lebanon to Lodge Complaint At U.N. Against Israeli Raids
description: Lebanon said today that it would make an urgent complaint with the United Nations Security Council about Israel's latest ground and air attacks, which reportedly killed 12 people and wounded 31.

title: The Keeper of 3 Architectural Icons
description: ON a Wednesday morning in London last September, Peter Palumbo, the chairman of the Arts Council in Britain, met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to lobby for more money for the council. Ten Downing Street is only one of the historic stops in Mr. Palumbo's life.

title: Roses: Scents From the Past and Colors From the Present
description: ONE of the newest things in the world of roses is the rediscovery of old roses. Gallicas and Damasks and Centifolias with a European history going back in some cases to Bronze Age Crete are blooming anew. So are Bourbons and Noisettes and other classes of roses hybridized in the 19th century from European species and forms of Rosa chinensis collected in the Orient by plant explorers.

title: Dataproducts Bid Adviser Changed
description: The investment group making a $10-a-share offer for the Dataproducts Corporation said it had changed its financial adviser, replacing the Chase Manhattan Bank with Paine Webber Inc.

title: General Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax-loss carrybacks of $285,000 for the quarter and $675,000 for the 6 months.

title: O'Rourke Won't Vet Budget
description: The Westchester County Executive said today that he would neither sign nor veto the county's 1990 budget, meaning that the budget, which mandates more than 600 layoffs, will take effect on Monday.

title: Pelts From Traps Far Outnumber Farm Pelts
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health
description: As a child I suffered from frequent upper respiratory infections that lingered for weeks, far beyond the usual seven-day duration of a cold. My mother complained about my poor appetite and irritability. And I still shudder with embarrassment at memories of blowing my nose at school all day long to relieve the congestion.

title: Pritzkers Reduce Stake in Beverly
description: An investment group led by the Pritzker family of Chicago has lowered its stake in Beverly Enterprises to 3.8 percent from 5.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Pritzkers gave no reason for the sale of the shares. Beverly, a nursing home chain based in Pasadena, Calif., has been selling some of its operations to reduce debt.

title: Baxter Renews Big Contracts
description: The Baxter Healthcare Corporation announced that it had extended medical-supplies contracts with three companies that run more than 450 hospitals nationwide. The contracts are worth $2.5 billion.

title: Energy and Pragmatism: 3 Who Will Serve; Mark Green; Consumer Affairs
description: Ten years ago, a politically troubled President Jimmy Carter asked Mark Green to become the White House's consumer affairs director. He declined. A decade later, Mr. Green not only accepted the job as New York City's commissioner of consumer affairs, but also actively sought the position. Why the change in attitude?

title: Vatican Balks at Handing Over Noriega
description: The Vatican appeared today to reject President Bush's argument that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was a common criminal who should be handed over to the United States for trial.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Our Foreign Policy Experts
description: >Question: After the convulsions in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, the Philippines and South Korea, what's the main difference between established foreign policy experts and 20-year-old college students? Well, students generally don't know about Prince Souphanouvong of Laos or Patrice Lumumba of the Congo. And they can't argue interminably about why Moscow blinked during the Cuban missile crisis of 1962.

title: Thornburgh to Disband Crime Strike Forces
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced today that he would proceed with plans to disband the Justice Department's organized crime strike forces despite some opposition in Congress.

title: Glasnost for Africa?
description: LEAD: There is one part of the world in which applause for recent developments in Eastern Europe is muted: sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Chapter 11 For Kohlberg, Kravis Unit
description: The Hillsborough Holdings Corporation, the company formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company to acquire the Jim Walter Corporation last year for $2.4 billion, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today after its bondholders rejected a plan to overhaul the company's finances.

title: Metro Matters; A Second Look At Some Stories Of the Last Year
description: Some matters that were subjects of this column in the last year continued to unfold after they were first reported. Here's an update:

title: Connecticut Will Buy Condos To Offer Low-Cost Housing
description: State housing officials said today that they plan to enter Connecticut's glutted condominium market and buy homes at bargain prices to rent or sell to moderate- and low-income families.

title: Debate on 'Dollarization' Is Growing in Argentina
description: The return of runaway inflation and the collapse in value of the national currency have opened a growing public debate over whether Argentina should simply adopt the United States dollar as its money.

title: Michael Still Reigns In Yearly Name Game
description: Michael and Jessica held onto first place, but Brian and Danielle were set back severely.

title: Many Foresee Bankruptcy For Federated and Allied
description: Many people dealing directly with the Campeau Corporation or trading in its securities express a growing conviction that the troubled company's two American retail subsidiaries will find it difficult to avoid filing for bankruptcy.

title: Northeast Shuttles Lift Fares
description: The Trump Shuttle and the Pan Am Shuttle, which dominate air service connecting Boston, New York and Washington, will raise fares 20 percent, starting next Wednesday.

title: Q&A
description: Painting Wrought Iron Q.We have a wrought-iron fence around our patio that has been painted several times with a flat black rust-preventive paint. We scrape off all peeling paint and sand down rusty areas each time before repainting. We used a widely sold brand of rust-preventive paint one time, and another brand that contains epoxy the second time. The latter was so thick it was like applying glue. Both times, after the paint dried it looked streaky and showed the brush strokes in a sort of two-toned black. We would like a nice even flat black appearance. What are we doing to make it so streaky? A.It sounds as if the paint is much too thick, or you are brushing it on in layers that are too heavy. You are also probably brushing back and forth over the same section too many times. Paint should never be so thick it does not brush on easily, and it should flow together slightly as it goes on. Only a minimum of back-and-forth brushing is advisable. Remember that two thin coats are always better than one thick one.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THERE is no single pattern to the closeness of childhood best friends. They may show their affection and alliance through whispered confidences, shared favorite toys or swift punches to the arm. The relationship often reflects each child's stage of social development more than it does the goals, values and beliefs they hold in common.

title: Review/Pop; Stephanie Mills in Song, Dramatically
description: It was almost exactly 15 years ago that the teen-age Stephanie Mills opened at the Majestic Theater on Broadway as Dorothy in ''The Wiz'' and introduced what has since become her signature song, Charlie Smalls' ballad ''Home.'' On Tuesday evening, Miss Mills, now 32 years old, returned to Broadway, this time to the Brooks Atkinson Theater (256 West 47th Street) for six nights in what has been billed as a triumphant coming-home-to-Broadway engagement.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Rumania's most repressive controls on individual freedoms, the legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu, were removed by the new Government. Among laws reversed were a ban on abortion and a law requiring registration of all typewriters. Page A1

title: KEY RATES
Help for Parents
description: To The Home Section:

title: The Lowly Stacking Chair Ascends
description: THE stacking chair is a rather lowly furniture form. But one of the most recent designs, by Donghia Furniture for the American Academy in Rome, is anything but.

title: A Rope of Pearls Needs a Good String
description: PEARLS seem synonymous with classic style, habitually draped around the necks of fashion editors and the current First Lady. But pearl necklaces need to be maintained, so what is the procedure when a strand breaks or needs routine restringing? How does one find a reliable restringer, especially in light of horror stories about jewelers who substitute cheap pearls for fine ones? One way is to ask around and deal with someone who is recommended.

title: 'Vespri Siciliani' to Open Opera Orchestra Season
description: The Opera Orchestra of New York is to open its 20th-anniversary season at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 16 at 8 P.M. with a performance of ''I Vespri Siciliani.'' Susan Dunn (soprano), Robert Brubaker (tenor), Paolo Coni (baritone) and Paul Plishka (bass) are to be the soloists in a concert version of the Verdi work, under the direction of Eve Queler.

title: Stocks Rise, With Dow Gaining 15.14
description: Stocks advanced yesterday and the pace of trading picked up as a result of bargain hunting and the usual year-end ''window dressing,'' in which investment managers seek to embellish their portfolios.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase by 9.3% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 9.3 percent rise in open positions on short sales in actively traded securities in its national market system for the month that ended Dec. 15. The advance was sharply higher than the 2.8 percent increase in the previous period.

title: Craig Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflecting change in accounting year. Year-ago fiscal year consists of 15 months. The company said net earnings for the fiscal year and the prior 15-month period included the earnings of Stater Bros. Holdings Inc. on the equity method of accounting. The reduction in earnings was attributable, in large part, to a one-time reduction in Stater's tax liability for the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1988. The company does not report revenues.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 12 about the Grumman Corporation misstated the nickname of the company's chairman, John O'Brien. He is known as O.B.

title: Rangers' Slide Reaches 9 Games
description: For the Rangers, the streak without a victory is now at nine games, the longest in more than two years. During the slide, their flair for creative self-destruction has been unbounded.

title: Retirement Fund Buys Stake in RPS
description: A pension plan for police and firefighters in Detroit has acquired a 5.8 percent stake in RPS Realty Trust. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Policemen and Firemen Retirement System of the City of Detroit said it might seek control of the New York real estate trust.

title: Critic's Notebook; Networks Look Back at What They Saw
description: Once again, the network news departments are succumbing to the seasonal obligation to remind us of times past, without expending too much time present. On Tuesday evening ABC, abetted by Time magazine, offered ''Images of the 80's,'' Peter Jennings presiding. Last night, Tom Brokaw and Jane Pauley shared the burden of ''The 80's,'' on NBC. And tonight, at 10 P.M. on CBS, Andy Rooney puts his particular spin on 1989.

title: Talking Deals; Drug Companies Leave Cosmetics
description: WHEN the Schering-Plough Corporation put its Maybelline division on the block earlier this month, it became the latest drug company to sour on the cosmetics business.

title: Bridge
description: A first-time expert partnership can suffer a major bidding disaster on occasion, as witness the two men in a world championship who landed in a grand slam missing four aces after a slight Blackwood misunderstanding.

title: George Couri, Executive, 77
description: George J. Couri, the chairman of Couristan Inc., an importer of floor coverings, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in the Dyker Heights section of Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

title: Man Admits Smuggling Tons of Marijuana
description: A man prosecutors called the biggest single broker of Southeast Asian marijuana pleaded guilty on Tuesday in Federal District Court to smuggling nearly 200 tons into the United States over four years.

title: Casters Get Furniture on the Move Again
description: LEAD: Although the caster is thought by many to be a Victorian invention essential for easing the movement of the period's cumbersome, overstuffed chairs, furniture of all sorts was made mobile early in the 18th century.

title: The Credibility Gap on Drugs
description: ''Drug abuse and the crime, violence and human suffering it engenders is the most urgent and intractable problem of our time,'' thundered Mario Cuomo back in January. President Bush and others have similarly raised their voices in a year of public outcry over the crack epidemic.

title: Fixing New York City: Needs Are Awesome
description: While New York City has begun to dig out from decades of neglect, much rebuilding remains to be done.

title: Has Realty Giant Grown Too Large?
description: Until recently, the Chicago-based JMB Realty Corporation could do no wrong in the eyes of institutional and individual investors. But now, some people are wondering if the real estate giant has expanded too aggressively at a time of uncertainty in the national real estate market.

title: Notebook; Black Collegian Seeks Some Pioneer Roles
description: Chris Nelson, a defenseman who plays for the University of Wisconsin Badgers, has three ambitious career goals: to be the first black player on the United States Olympic team, to be the first American-born black player in the National Hockey League and to follow his playing career with one in television.

title: Hilton Sale Hits Snag; Stock Falls
description: The shares of the Hilton Hotels Corporation fell sharply today amid fears that the company might not be sold after more than four months on the block.

title: Florida Growers Rush To Save Frozen Crops
description: When the temperature plummeted into the low 20's over the weekend, making much of Florida colder than Anchorage, Ben Abbitt prayed for warmer weather to save the 7,000 acres of oranges owned by him and 250 other members of the Haines City Citrus Growers' Assocation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Nominations Made For Golden Globes
description: ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' ''Glory'' and ''When Harry Met Sally . . .'' each received five Golden Globe Award nominations, which were announced today by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
The Homeless: Victims of Prejudice
description: LEAD: As interns at the Legal Action Center for the Homeless last summer, we helped staff the legal clinics that it runs at soup kitchens in Manhattan. As we entered a clinic one day with our white co-workers, the volunteer doorkeeper and ticket taker abruptly stopped us and shouted, ''Get to the back of the line!

title: Efforts Abroad to Help the Economy
description: Panama faces the daunting task of rebuilding an economy ravaged not only by bullets and bombs but also by two years of economic war with the United States.

title: Wise Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Georgia Tackle Ousted
description: Hiawatha Berry, a starting defensive tackle for the University of Georgia, was dismissed from the squad by Coach Ray Goff yesterday, three days before the Bulldogs are to meet Syracuse in the Peach Bowl. Goff said without elaboration that Berry, a senior, was dismissed for violating rules.

title: What 'Godot' Hath Wrought
description: In January 1938 a panhandler named Prudent drove a knife into an Irishman living in Paris, narrowly missing his victim's heart. Upon recovering, Samuel Beckett sought out his assailant in jail to ask what had prompted the attack. ''Je ne sais pas,'' replied Prudent. The same cryptic words turned up in ''Waiting for Godot,'' spoken by a character called Boy, who deflects Vladimir's thirst for answers with, ''I don't know, sir.''

title: History of Victorian Ornament on Display
description: AN exhibition of illustrations, including color plates, bookbindings, texts and lithographs illustrating the growth of Victorian style, has opened at the New York Public Library.

title: Between Freedom of Expression and Freedom From Intolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the weekly magazine 7 Days misstated the rate paid by an advertiser, Marimekko, for a full page in color in the Dec. 27 issue. The store paid the full retail rate of $2,870.

title: U.S. Textile Imports Up
description: United States textile imports rose by 13 percent and their value climbed to more than $32 billion in 1989, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said today.

title: Illegal Offer Denied
description: Johnny Rodgers, a previous Heisman Trophy winner, yesterday denied having contacted the 1989 winner, Andre Ware, illegally. But Rodgers, who played at Nebraska, said in Omaha that he did buy Ware's mother a fur coat and other items.

title: Nevada Sues to Block Nuclear Waste Dump
description: Nevada's Attorney General sued the Federal Government today in an attempt to prevent the construction of a nuclear waste dump at Yucca Mountain, 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas.

title: G.M. Cutting Jobs
description: The General Motors Corporation, said it would lay off 2,050 workers indefinitely at two plants that build Corsica and Beretta cars. The G. M. compact-car lines compete with such Japanese models as the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord, Mazda 626 and Subaru Legacy. G. M. will lay off 1,600 employees at a Linden, N.J., plant, and 450 workers at a plant in Wilmington, Del.

title: Ernest A. Weymuller, Surgeon, 82
description: Dr. Ernest A. Weymuller, an otolaryngologist who was surgical director of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary before his retirement in 1981, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Events That Made The News
description: THE 1980's will stand as the decade when the advertising industry broke out of its insular niche on Madison Avenue and on to the front pages.

title: Subway and Bus Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: Lithuanians Backing Communist Party Split
description: Thousands of Lithuanians have rallied behind their Communist Party's decision to split with Moscow, officials in the rebellious Baltic republic said today.

title: Martha Winburn England, Professor, 80
description: Dr. Martha Winburn England, a retired English professor at Queens College and a writer and translator, died on Monday at the Parkway Nursing Center in Little Rock, Ark., where she lived. She was 80 years old.

title: Steinberg Has at Least One Candidate
description: Bruce Coslet, coordinator of the Cincinnati Bengals' high-tech, no-huddle offense, will be interviewed for the Jets' vacant head-coaching job.

title: Conair Buys Cuisinart Line
description: The Conair Corporation, a maker of hair driers, said yesterday that it had bought the assets of Cuisinarts Inc., the maker of food processors, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August. Conair, based in Stamford, Conn., said the purchase price was nearly $27 million. The assets consist of the Cuisinart product line of food processors and cookware, trademarks, patents, inventory and equipment.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Pioneer Savings Bank, Orlando, Fla., said it had received regulatory approval for the sale of 13 central Florida branches to a unit of Southeast Banking Corp., Miami.

title: India Reports 1,000 Deaths in Hindu-Muslim Fighting
description: Weeks after this city and more than 150 villages were devastated by some of India's worst Hindu-Muslim fighting, police officials are still uncovering graves from massacres that they say have left as many as 1,000 dead.

title: RUMANIANS MOVING TO ABOLISH WORST OF REPRESSIVE ERA
description: Seeking to dismantle the legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed dictator, Rumania today lifted some of the controls that have made this country one of the most repressive in Europe.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
First Place Gets Crowded As Capitals Defeat Devils
description: Coach John Cunniff of the Devils expected his team to be highly motivated for a game with plenty at stake, but he conceded later that he had misread the mood of his players.

title: GROWTH HORMONE MAY HELP ADULTS
description: A hormone that promotes growth in children can also help adults lose fat, gain muscle and burn calories faster, a new study has found.

title: Rumanian Revolt, Live and Uncensored
description: ''This is the first revolution on live television,'' said Ion Todan, proud and tired this afternoon amid the chaotic but businesslike clutter at the heart of the videocracy that has replaced the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Yields Fall In Week
description: Yields of taxable and tax-free money market funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report declined in the week ended yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Barbara Litrell has been named group sales director of The New York Times, with responsibility for The New York Times Magazine and its part 2 sections, as well as for advertising in fashion, home furnishings, cosmetics and package goods categories. She had been marketing director of The Times Magazine.

title: Oriental Rugs Explored In New Television Series
description: THE decorative arts, long a popular subject for books, lectures and museum shows, are soon to be explored on television, too.

title: Books of The Times; Klaus Barbie and French Memory
description: An Uncertain Hour The French, the Germans, the Jews, the Klaus Barbie Trial and the City of Lyons, 1940-1945 By Ted Morgan Illustrated. 416 pages. Arbor House/ William Morrow. $21.95.

title: MANAGUA ECONOMY HINGES ON PANAMA
description: By deposing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the United States may end up gaining important new economic leverage over Nicaragua and Cuba, diplomats and business officials say.

title: Ethiopia Base and 2 Towns Said to Fall to Rebels
description: In a significant setback for the Ethiopian Government, Tigrean rebels have captured a major military base and two other towns, the rebels and Western diplomats in Addis Ababa said today.

title: New Ford Rebates
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was offering cash rebates of as much as $750 on 1989 and 1990 F-series trucks through Feb. 5. Last week, Ford announced a sales incentive plan on 28 Ford, Lincoln and Mercury 1989 and 1990 models.

title: New Leaders Move to Reassure Noriega's Backers
description: As Panamanians returned to work and began rebuilding their shattered capital, the country's new civilian Government was taking steps today to reassure the public that there would be no widespread retribution against former supporters of the deposed military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Police, Hard Pressed in Drug War, Are Turning to Preventive Efforts
description: Tactics are changing on the police lines of America's drug war. Frustrated by the overwhelming numbers of drug offenders and an almost infinite supply of illicit drugs, more and more police officers are talking like social workers, arguing that the real solution lies in preventing young people from getting involved with drugs in the first place.

title: Dinkins Picks Six for Posts In Government
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins named six more members to his administration yesterday, including the chief fund-raiser for his mayoral campaign, Elisabeth F. Gotbaum, and Mark Green, a senior campaign adviser and longtime consumer advocate.

title: Noriega's Nemesis: Maxwell Reid Thurman
description: A few months after he was due for retirement, and 14 years after he last commanded troops in the field, Gen. Maxwell Thurman finds himself at the center of the largest United States military operation since the Vietnam War. As head of the United

title: Pretoria Gets a Goading From a Maverick Chief
description: When South Africa created its black homelands and pushed four of them into nominal independence, it did not anticipate that they would hatch a maverick like Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa.

title: Compuflight Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $73,000 for the latest year and $47,000 for 1988. Revenue included service fees and other income (principally interest income). Share earnings equal less than 1 cent a share. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Paris Journal; Homeless, but Not Hungry: The Poor of France
description: The sparkle of the Seine and the glow of its floodlit palaces, tour boats and riverside restaurants do not reach a barge anchored at a dark, quiet quay here. Outside it every night men stand in line, some nodding to a mate, others stone-faced, all clutching a pink card that grants a meal and a bed.

title: Southern Bell Investigation
description: Florida's Attorney General said today that the state was investigating whether the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company had underpaid commissions to governments in several Southeastern states for pay-telephone use. Attorney General Robert

title: All-Pro Team Named
description: Joe Montana and Jerry Rice, the deadliest passing combination in the N.F.L., were overwhelming choices for the All-Pro team of The Associated Press. The choices were announced yesterday in Manhattan.

title: The Canadian Speed Trap Adds a New Snare
description: In the long cat-and-mouse game between drivers who flout speed limits and police officers who enforce them, the Canadian police are gaining the upper hand, for now, with a device invented last summer.

title: Nursing Homes Rethink Tying Aged as Protection
description: Every day more than 500,000 elderly Americans in nursing homes and hospitals, most of them frail and demented, are tied to their beds or wheelchairs. But institutions across the country are re-examining their use of restraints.

title: Outdoors; Ski Area Overcomes A Summer Tornado
description: rrIt's business as usual at Mohawk Mountain, Conn., this ski season. Of course, to people who skied there in the past, the area looks somewhat different. After all, any place that has been visited by a three-funnel super-cell tornado is bound to show some changes.

title: KCS Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,472,000, or $4.71 a share. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,374,000. The company said the shares outstanding are after giving retroactive effect of stock splits on Nov. 3, 1989.

title: Mickey L. Hooten, executive, 54
description: Mickey L. Hooten, a television executive for the Hearst Corporation and a former chairman of the ABC Television Network Affiliates Board of Governors, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

title: California Rule On 'Junk' Sales
description: State regulators, spurred by the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, intend to prohibit the sale of high-risk ''junk bonds'' from the offices of California's state-chartered savings institutions.

title: How Do You Define Status? A New BMW in the Drive. An Old Rock in the Garden
description: The famous Zen rock garden of Ryoanji temple is a model of austere, tranquil beauty. But many of the Japanese who come to view it these days arrive in BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes. The men often wear Armani suits, the women carry Chanel handbags and both may wear Tiffany jewelry. They are of a generation that seeks status rather than tranquillity, and this has transformed the place of the rock garden in Japan; owning one has become an important new status symbol.

title: Denzel Washington Takes a Defiant Break From Clean-Cut Roles
description: ''It was difficult to break myself down and become a primitive man: that was the challenge of this part,'' Denzel Washington was saying about his portrayal of Trip, a runaway slave who takes up arms against the Confederacy in the film ''Glory.'' ''He's a man who says words like onliest. Onliest!'' He shook his head. ''I've played a lot of the clean-cut roles, the intelligent parts. Not that Trip isn't intelligent. He's very cunning, a brilliant survivor. And then, one day, he finds himself in a place where he can make a difference.''

title: A Bronco Sentenced
description: Gerald Perry, a starting tackle for the Denver Broncos, was sentenced yesterday in Aurora, Colo., to 15 days in jail, beginning Feb. 5, and was fined $610 after he was convicted of having solicited a prostitute.

title: Results Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL North Carolina Wins Shootout

title: Jack Smith Dies at 66; Urban Planning Expert
description: Jack C. Smith, a planning specialist who headed the New York City Planning Department's Office of Master Planning from 1960 to 1965, died of cancer on Tuesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Wearing the Buildings That Catch the Eye
description: ''I WALK around the city a lot and see such great buildings, I like to document them,'' David Schofield said. ''I never imagined I'd see my work on T-shirts.''

title: Jetborne International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
United Airlines Lowers Fares
description: United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier, today followed the lead of a smaller crosstown rival, Midway Airlines, and said it would lower some fares up to 30 percent.

title: Lions' Finance Official To Succeed Thomas
description: Chuck Schmidt, who oversaw the books for the Detroit Lions as understudy to the general manager, Russ Thomas, was named yesterday to succeed Thomas as the team's chief operating officer. Occupying a new joint position, he will also be executive vice president. Schmidt was previously vice president of finance.

title: St. John's Beats Howard
description: In a surprisingly close contest, St. John's (10-2) defeated Howard University (2-7) by 77-65 before a standing-room-only crowd of 6,008 at Alumni Hall last night.

title: Moody's Lowers Ratings On Debt of 2 Nynex Units
description: The ratings on $4 billion of debt of the New York Telephone Company and the Nynex Credit Company have been downgraded, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.

title: Existing Home Sales Rise, Spurred by Falling Rates
description: Sales of existing homes, spurred by a big jump in activity in the South, advanced 3.2 percent in November, climbing at their fastest pace in 11 months, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Tokyo Firm Is Punished
description: The Daiwa Securities Company of Tokyo has been punished for compensating a customer for losses in stock transactions, a company official said Tuesday. The official said the company had not violated any laws, but he quoted Masahiro Dozen, Daiwa's president, as apologizing for unfairness to other investors.

title: Different Kind of Pain for Morris
description: At his best, Joe Morris was a Pro Bowl player, a darting cutback runner who made 1,000-yard rushing seasons routine and helped the Giants win Super Bowl XXI. From 1982 through 1988, he became their career rushing leader with 5,296 yards.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday this week about Bo Schembechler's final game as Michigan's football coach misstated the date of his first heart attack. It was 20 years ago this week, on Dec. 31, 1969.

title: Betty Garde, 84, Dies; Actress in 'Oklahoma!'
description: Betty Garde, an actress who played roles in hundreds of radio dramas and portrayed Aunt Eller in the original Broadway production of ''Oklahoma!,'' died on Monday. She was 84 years old.

title: Safecard Services reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included pre-tax gains of $500,000 for the quarter and $2,450,000 for the year from payments made to the company in settlement of litigation.

title: Floods Kill 35 in Brazil and Ravage Colonial Sites
description: Heavy tropical rains have flooded much of northeastern Brazil, killing 35 people, leaving 200,000 homeless and ravaging some of the country's finest colonial-era architectural treasures.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I AM trying to decide when it all went wrong in New York, when it was that one could no longer walk down a street without feeling guilty about having a destination. The people I see every day don't have a destination. ''See you around,'' they say to one another, and sure enough they do. They are like pigeons, rising suddenly to wheel in the air, then settling back on the same old perches. At night many of them nest along the street in back of the bus station, in curious compounds made of mattresses and shopping carts and dilapidated chairs. ''See you around,'' they say when they leave their piles of blankets for a cup of coffee at the Salvation Army van.

title: Autoinfo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Saying 'Cheese' Isn't Enough Now
description: WHEN the actress Ali MacGraw decided to be photographed with her son, Joshua Evans, they both wore white T-shirts, she wore black tights and he wore jeans. They were photographed in an Art Deco bathroom.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Disney Strategist Takes Advisory Role
description: LEAD: Gary L. Wilson, a member of the management team that rebuilt the Walt Disney Company, said yesterday that he had relinquished his post as executive vice president and chief financial officer. He said he would remain with Disney as a consultant.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: CORNELIU BOGDAN, Minister of State at the Foreign Ministry: kor-NEHL-yoo bog-DON NICOLAE CEAUSESCU, the executed former leader: nee-koh-LAH-yeh chow-SHESS-koo ELENA CEAUSESCU, his wife and second in command, also executed: eh-LEH-nah ION ILIESCU, named President of the interim Government: yahn ill-ee-YES-koo CORNELIU MANESCU, a Council of National Salvation leader: kor-NEHL-yoo mah-NESS-koo DUMITRU MAZILU, named Vice President of the interim Government: doo-MEE-troo mah-ZEE-loo NICOLAE MILITARU, named Defense Minister of the interim Government: nee-koh-LAH-yeh mee-lee-TAH-roo Rev. LASZLO TOKES, a leader in Timisoara: LAHSS-loh TOH-kehsh

title: Small Quake in California
description: A small earthquake struck today seven miles northwest of here, but there were no reports of damage or injury. Hall Daily, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology, said the quake measured 3.2 on the Richter scale of ground motion.

title: Apparel America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Both year-ago periods' results were restated.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about programs to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus by drug addicts referred incorrectly to one at the community research branch of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. It provides bleach to clean needles, but does not give out needles.

title: Kodak Unit in Settlement
description: A small film company that makes videocassettes of the nation's top tourist attractions said today that it had settled a breach-of-contract lawsuit against a division of the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Pirates and Wolfpack Advance at Garden
description: The preseason scouting report on Seton Hall was that the Pirates were strong up front but woefully inexperienced in the backcourt with a freshman, Terry Dehere, and a junior-college transfer, Oliver Taylor, running the show.

title: Two Suspected Bombs Found to Be Hoaxes
description: Authorities here and in Charlotte, N.C., destroyed two parcels believed to contain bombs today, but both were discovered to be hoaxes.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Panama News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today as he arrived at the Corpus Christi Naval Air Station in Texas as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company. OPENING STATEMENT

title: Notebook; Czyz and Lalonde Eye Comebacks
description: Jeff Harding, the World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, is widely viewed as a very beatable boxer. And the prospect of fighting him has prompted two retired former champions - Bobby Czyz and Donny Lalonde - to go back into training.

title: York Research Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss York Research attributed its increase in earnings to the completion and successful operation of the company's initial cogeneration facility in New York City.

title: Breast Implant Surgery: More Facts Are Sought In the Battle Over Safety
description: An increasingly emotional battle over the safety of breast implant surgery is being waged within the Food and Drug Administration, in state legislatures and in the courts.

title: 'Anti-Me' on China? No. Pro-Freedom
description: Whatever happened to the uproar over China? It has all but disappeared in the new preoccupation with events in Panama and Rumania. Yet the questions endure, and President Bush's recent remarks show that he still doesn't understand his critics.

title: Review/Television; 'Anything but Love': A New Twist on an Old Gimmick
description: Will they or won't they? The somewhat prurient question, or gimmick, has bolstered the ratings of countless television series. ''Moonlighting'' and ''Beauty and the Beast'' are among the more recent examples, and in each instance the hero and heroine did. Now there is ABC's ''Anything but Love'' (Wednesdays at 9:30), the show that asks: Can carefree Hannah Miller, former schoolteacher and aspiring writer, be just good friends with angst-ridden Marty Gold, award-winning magazine reporter? Or, in time-honored tradition, will they? Any bets?

title: Where Fear of Street Violence Rules Life
description: Joseph Evans, a 33-year-old Queens bricklayer, reached into his coat yesterday afternoon and pulled out an eight-inch hunting knife and a loaded clip for a .38-caliber automatic revolver. He was showing how he protects himself against the violence of South Jamaica.

title: Afghans Get Soviet Weapons, Not Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Yet The Toast Of the Town
description: rrThe game, as they say in the laundry business, was on the line. It was the last quarter of the Knicks' game at Miami Tuesday night, and the Knicks' co-captain and starting point guard, Mark Jackson, observed the proceedings from an uncommon place, the bench. A towel was draped over his shoulders, ready to be flung off the moment the coach called for him to save the night, to be thrust into the thick of it. The call never came.

title: Emboldened Dissidents Are Warning the Rulers
description: The Arab press has greeted the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu with an unusual outpouring of editorial warnings that the fate of Arab dictators may resemble that of the executed Rumanian tyrant.

title: Keith Waggoner, Theater Manager, 42
description: Keith Waggoner, a manager for Jujamcyn Theaters, died on Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 42 years old.

title: Suns Forward Injured
description: Tom Chambers, a Phoenix Suns forward, fractured his left cheekbone slightly and suffered a cut requiring 14 stitches in Tuesday night's victory over Portland at Phoenix, X-rays taken yesterday by the team surgeon, Dr. Richard Emerson, showed. The injury occurred when Chambers dived for a rebound and was elbowed accidentally by the Blazers' Kevin Duckworth.(AP)

title: Notebook; U.S.-Soviet Encounters Prove a Hit Down South
description: The recent success of a squad of American collegiate All-Stars playing an elite Soviet touring team was significant on two counts. The games met with enthusiastic responses in two Southern cities, Orlando, Fla., and Dallas, and the United States skaters were competitive on a world-class level.

title: Corrections
description: The Real Estate column in Business Day yesterday, and its picture caption, about a building under construction in Times Square by Eichner Properties and VMS Realty Partners, misstated the address. It is 1540 Broadway, not 1801 Seventh Avenue.

title: Jews in Rumania Are Reported to Be Safe
description: American Jews concerned about the security of the 20,000 Jews living in Rumania have been reassured in recent days that the Jews were safe and had not been singled out in the revolution that toppled the Government of Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Recalling Charles Eames
description: To The Home Section:

title: U.S. Plans to Stop Paying Fines for Nuclear Arms Plant Operators
description: Within a few months the Energy Department plans to end its decades-old practice of paying all bills, including environmental fines and other penalties, incurred by the companies that run the nation's 17 nuclear weapons plants, department officials say.

title: Ismail Joins Workout
description: Raghib Ismail, the ailing Notre Dame flanker, took part in some contact drills yesterday and might see action in the Orange Bowl game Monday night against Colorado, Coach Lou Holtz said in Miami. ''It was encouraging to see him be able to do some things,'' Holtz said.

title: JMB's Major Acquisitions
description: 1983: Federated Realty Associated, purchased from Federated Department Stores for $112 million. 1984: Urban Investment and Development, from Aetna Life and Casualty for an estimated $1 billion. 1986: Aluminum Company of America's properties in Century City, Calif., for $600 million. 1987: Cadillac Fairview, the large Canadian developer-owner of shopping centers and office buildings, for $4.1 billion. Walt Disney's Arvida unit, which mainly develops planned communities in Florida and Georgia, for $400 million. 1988: Amfac, a diversified services company with operations in food processing, hotels/resorts, retailing, agriculture and property, was merged with a JMB subsidiary, in a deal valued at $920 million. 1989: Randsworth Trust P.L.C., the London-based real estate company, for $800 million, including refinanced debt. Panhandle Easters Corporation's Houston Center, a mixed-use developement, for $400 million. Source: Company reports

title: Consul Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Commuter Airliner Crashes, Killing 6, In Washington State
description: A twin-engine United Express commuter plane crashed and burst into flame while trying to land Tuesday night, killing the six people aboard, the authorities said.

title: Reserve Prisons for the Dangerous Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LARGE damaged areas of wooden strip flooring can sometimes be satisfactorily repaired by an experienced installer. But large repairs are almost always visible, and the results may not be permanent. Often, a more practical solution is to minimize the visibility of the repair by replacing damaged sections of floorboards with small patches, making as close a match as possible. The job requires modest carpentry skills but is within the range of most amateurs.

title: Washington Talk; Some Need Crystal Ball To Peer Into the Present
description: In economics, as in other spheres, it is the simplest questions that are often the hardest to answer.

title: A Cigar May Be a Smoke, But a Carved Indian Is an Antique
description: WEARING feather headdresses and grim expressions, cigar-store Indians were once familiar on the sidewalks of Manhattan. Today, they and the stores they advertised have mostly vanished, but one man is doing his best to be sure that, one way or another, they will endure.

title: Crew Keeps Stadium Flushing
description: A work crew of 23 was assigned to do nothing on Christmas weekend but flush the 503 toilets at the Gator Bowl to prevent a freeze-up at the stadium before the annual New Year's college football game.
