A freeze in 1983 caused about $400,000 damage in broken water pipes, so during last week's record cold, officials hired a brigade of flushers to keep water moving through the plumbing. Each person was responsible for an average of 21.8 toilets each.

title: Judge Thwarts Suffolk's Video-Terminal Law
description: In a victory for Suffolk County employers, a state judge today struck down a county law that regulates the use of video-display terminals in the workplace.

title: Rumania Pleads for World's Aid
description: Rumania's new Government asked the General Assembly today to make an international appeal for emergency aid to the country.

title: Test Shows Martin Driver Was Drunk
description: Results of a blood test showed yesterday that the driver of the pickup truck in which Billy Martin was killed was legally drunk when the truck crashed near Martin's upstate New York home.

title: Town Needed People, So It Offered a Bounty
description: Two years ago, hoping to save its businesses and its school, this Farm Belt community put out an invitation for new residents, offering a free lot and $1,200 cash to anyone who builds a house worth $30,000.

title: INSIDE
description: Auditing Safeguards Failed In Lincoln Savings Collapse When the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association collapsed, so did accounting and auditing safeguards. Government investigators are trying to determine whether the auditors were negligent or were misled. Page D1. Trying to Defy Gravity Japanese scientists said gyroscopes had lost weight when spun at high speeds, but experts expressed skepticism about the finding. Page A18. Shuttle Fares to Rise 20% The Trump and Pan Am shuttles will raise fares by 20 percent next Wednesday on routes linking Boston, New York and Washington. Page D1. Dinkins Names More Aides The Mayor-elect named Elisabeth F. Gotbaum as parks commissioner and Mark Green as consumer affairs commissioner. Page B1.

title: Calendar: Giving Crafts A Try
description: Class Sampler, West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street; 212-787-6557.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Premier Brands, to Delaney Fletcher Slaymaker Delaney Bozell, the London subsidiary of Bozell, for its Cadbury beverages and whiteners division, with a budget of $7 million.

title: Neighborhoods in New York Seeing Red Over Blue Videos
description: In the last four months, at least 10 stores that specialize in selling pornographic videocassettes have opened in Manhattan. Three are in Times Square, where such merchandise is commonplace.

title: Elderly Poor Prompt Gifts For Neediest
description: The chance to help the elderly who are frail and isolated and living with little income or companionship has motivated many people to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paris Is Pressing Aid for Rumanians
description: As the bicentennial year of the French Revolution draws to a close, France is making an all-out effort to send aid to Rumania, an effort aimed in part at showing, once again, France's leadership in the fight for liberty, equality and fraternity.

title: Peru and U.S. Resume Their Anti-Drug Effort
description: Peru has decided to resume anti-drug operations with the United States, a week after it halted the effort to protest the American invasion of Panama, the Justice Department said today.

title: Rumania: Up for Grabs
description: LEAD: Nicolae Ceausescu is gone at last. A ruler who came to power in 1965 with promises of democracy and higher living standards, and who became a national hero in 1968 when he denounced the Warsaw pact invasion of Czechoslovakia, has now been tried and shot by his own people.

title: Interpoint Corp reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Consolidated earnings for both years are restated to reflect the pooling-of-interests merger with Micra Corp. in July 1989 and the current year included a one-time cumulative effect of an accounting change. Micra after-tax losses of about $730,000 are included in the results for 1989 as are acquisition costs of $270,000. The cumulative effect of the accounting change added $170,000 to profit during the year.

title: A Correction
description: In a letter opposed to drug legalization published on Tuesday the writer's name appeared incorrectly. He is Charles H. Silberstein, M.D.

title: Pamela Taft Married To Mark S. Blackwell
description: Pamela Anne Taft Married To Mark S. Blackwell Pamela Anne Taft and Mark Strath Blackwell were married yesterday at the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. Dr. Richard Stanger and the Rev. William J. Hammann, a retired Lutheran minister and the bride's great-uncle, officiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the fatal shooting of a teen-ager and a pregnant woman in Queens misstated the site. It was the west side of 160th Street, between 107th and 108th Avenues.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up Slightly
description: The discount rates on Treasury bills posted moderate gains yesterday, but prices of Government couponed issues were largely unchanged in light trading.

title: Two Men and a Gyroscope May Rewrite Newton's Law
description: Japanese scientists have reported that small gyroscopes lose weight when spun under certain conditions, apparently in defiance of gravity. If proved correct, the finding would mark a stunning scientific advance, but experts said they doubted that it would survive intense scrutiny.

title: Energy and Pragmatism: 3 Who Will Serve; Elisabeth F. Gotbaum; Parks Commissioner
description: Elisabeth F. Gotbaum's resume bears the stamp of someone, who, her friends and former colleagues say, is comfortable in nearly any postition that draws on an ability to bring diverse parties together and to get projects off the ground. One translation: She knows how to raise money.

title: Machine Tool Import Fight
description: The Commerce Department ruled today that mechanical transfer presses from Japan were being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

title: President of Microsoft Plans June Retirement
description: Jon A. Shirley, the president and chief operating officer of the Microsoft Corporation since 1983, will retire in June at the end of the company's fiscal year, Microsoft said yesterday.

title: Giants Tickets Go on Sale
description: About 8,000 tickets for the Giants' playoff game on Sunday, Jan. 7 will go on sale Friday at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena ticket office.

title: Office Pool, 1990
description: The originator of annual prognostication was Jonathan Swift, whose ''Predictions for the Year 1708'' confidently named ''the great actions and events of next year particularly related, as they will come to pass. Written to prevent the people of England from being further impos'd on by vulgar almanack-makers.''

title: EXECUTIVE
description: * Alleghany Corp., a financial services holding company, appointed David B. Cuming senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Energy and Pragmatism: 3 Who Will Serve; Douglas H. White; Personnel
description: Douglas H. White, who was appointed by David N. Dinkins yesterday to head the city's Department of Personnel, is no stranger to the corridors of City Hall or government.

title: Mrs. Reed Weds Oscar de la Renta
description: Annette Reed and Oscar de la Renta, the fashion designer, were married Tuesday at his home in La Romana, the Dominican Republic. A local justice of the peace officiated.

title: Murder of 3 Relatives Draws 20 Years to Life
description: A 23-year-old man was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison yesterday after he admitted that he beat his parents to death with a baseball bat in order to steal money from them to buy crack and that he killed his nephew in the same way after the child woke up.

title: Egypt and Syria Agree to Revive Ties
description: Egypt and Syria have agreed to restore diplomatic relations after a 12-year break caused by Egypt's peace agreement with Israel.

title: Electro Scientific Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Around Los Angeles, Private Foundations Offer Art to the Public
description: Some of the liveliest art impresarios here are not museums or galleries, but private foundations that shun the route of caution and committees to work in offbeat ways.

title: Metaphorical Images of the Garden
description: ''ALTHOUGH my garden is never quite what I want it to be,'' said Bernice Steinbaum, ''I've come to realize that gardens represent man's control over nature.''

title: At Least 3 Die in Earthquake In Southeast Australia Coast
description: An earthquake measuring 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale shattered buildings in the Australian city of Newcastle today, killing at least three people and injuring 87, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Doremus & Company, a financial public relations and advertising agency owned by the Omnicom Group, has formed a financial printing company, Doremus Financial Printing, headed by David H. Wade.

title: Girls Die in Brooklyn Fire; A Window Gate Is Blamed
description: Two young sisters, apparently trapped by a window gate that fire officials say had been illegally altered so it could not be opened, died in a four-alarm blaze in Brooklyn yesterday after they pulled a tool box to the window in a desperate effort to pry their way to a fire escape.

title: Exxon Plant Shut
description: The explosion Sunday at the Exxon Corporation's refinery in Baton Rouge, La., has forced an adjacent Exxon chemical unit to suspend production, company officials said. The chemical plant, though undamaged by the explosion and subsequent fire, uses naphtha from the refinery to produce compounds like propylene and benzene.

title: French Bank to Be Sold
description: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. said today that it had agreed to sell its French retail bank subsidiary, Grindlays Bank S.A., to Monte Dei Paschi di Siena of Italy for an undisclosed price. The company said in a statement that the 14-branch bank, which it bought in 1984, was an efficient retail bank but no longer fit with its strategy in Europe of expanding wholesale cross-border banking. The deal is subject to regulatory approval.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: A Star From Brazil

title: Plane Crash in Pennsylvania Kills President of Company
description: A twin-engine plane crashed into the second floor of a house here today, killing the pilot and his passenger.

title: Brown Seeking Brown
description: Ron Brown, who has been the receivers' coach at the University of Nebraska for three years, has been offered the head coaching job at Brown University, his alma mater. But he said, in a radio interview in Omaha, that he would not decide whether to accept until after the Fiesta Bowl game on Monday. (AP)

title: Eagles Have Healthy Advantage
description: When the Los Angeles Rams play the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday in the National Conference wild-card game, the difference between the teams may be in their health. The Rams have suffered so many recent injuries to their defense that they may be unable to stop Randall Cunningham, the Eagles' elusive quarterback.

title: Upheaval in the East: Ceausescu's Kin; Brother of Deposed Leader Dies In Vienna, Reportedly by Suicide
description: The eldest brother of former President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania was found hanged in the cellar of his Vienna offices today, apparently after committing suicide, police officials said.

title: Book Awards Panels Do Read Them All
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Upholds Verdict In Murder Conspiracy
description: A state appeals court today upheld the conspiracy conviction of a Columbia County man for plotting to kill members of his family in 1986.

title: Kinsman From U.S. Is Taking Greece by Storm
description: Reversing America's low-profile diplomacy in Greece, he insists on braving the threat of terrorism by displaying the American flag wherever he goes. He does not hesitate to step into the crowd to cheer at basketball games, and he jokingly reassures Greeks that he, like most of them, is an islander - from the island of Manhattan.

title: Banks' Bad Real Estate Loans Spur Rising Worry of Failures
description: Federal regulators and banking experts say they are increasingly concerned that mounting losses from troubled real estate loans could lead to a series of bank failures, straining the Federal insurance program that protects depositors' funds.

title: Developer Transforms A Factory in Jersey City
description: Two 150-foot-high smokestacks that tower over the Van Vorst historic district in Jersey City mark the site of the former Joseph Dixon Crucible Company factory at Wayne and Varick Streets, a maze of cavernous buildings where crucibles, pencils, crayons, stove polish, lubricants and other products were once made.

title: Once-Prized Area Struggles To Recoup Quake's Losses
description: When night falls and lights go on in houses throughout the city, whole blocks of the Marina district stand black, the rows of dark windows mute testimony to the damage left behind by the Oct. 17 earthquake.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia; CZECH PARLIAMENT UNANIMOUSLY PICKS DUBCEK AS LEADER
description: Alexander Dubcek, the Communist who led the ill-fated Prague Spring liberalization movement of 1968 only to be ousted by Soviet troops, was unanimously elected chairman of the national Parliament today.

title: Books of The Times; A Biographer's Tale of Women With Spirit
description: The Grown-Ups By Victoria Glendinning 244 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Honda Makes Pledge to Israel
description: The Honda Motor Company of Japan can supply Israel with adequate spare parts for the American-built cars that the company's United States subsidiary plans to sell in Israel, a spokesman said today.

title: Los Angeles Journal; In Relentless Pursuit Of Avocado Rustlers
description: The two government agents are suspicious. While prowling through this city's vast wholesale produce market, a known distribution point for contraband, they notice one cardboard box stacked among many because it appears to have been opened and later resealed.

title: Gorbachev At Bay
description: The revolt of the Lithuanian Communist Party has brought Mikhail Gorbachev face to face with the most threatening consequence of his reform policies. If nothing is done, he told the party Central Committee in Moscow, ''we will deliberately be heading toward the disintegration of the Soviet Union.''

title: China Line: No Thawing
description: Government anxiety over the domestic impact of the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania makes it less likely that the Chinese leadership will respond substantively to President Bush's request for the easing of martial-law restrictions before Congress returns to Washington on Jan. 23, ready to do battle with Mr. Bush over his overtures to Beijing.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Baltics; Latvian Soviet Republic Votes To End Communist Primacy
description: Latvia joined its Baltic neighbor Lithuania today as the second Soviet republic to abolish the Communist Party's constitutionally guaranteed supremacy, local advocates and journalists said.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is New Year's Day. Sunday night, starting at 7 P.M., Times Square will be closed to traffic. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Only main office, at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, will be open. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No pickup, recycling, or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on holiday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks, Schools: Closed. Transportation: Buses and trains on Sunday schedule. Extra trains and buses Sunday evening. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks, Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: Market Place; Cash Is Poured Into Stock Funds
description: The public is pouring cash into stock mutual funds at the heaviest rate since stock prices peaked in the summer of 1987. But the managers who run those mutual funds have turned very cautious and are sitting on much of the cash.

title: Southeastern Lifts Blue Arrow Stake
description: Blue Arrow P.L.C., the world's largest temporary employment company, said Southeastern Asset Management, a United States company, had increased its stake to 8.4 percent from 7.16 percent. Blue Arrow said it had been informed that Southeastern now holds six million American depository shares, which represent 60.2 million of Blue Arrow's outstanding shares.

title: For the Record
description: On Investigating Judges From ''The Good Judge,'' a report of the Twentieth Century Fund Task Force on Judicial Responsibility.

title: Volkswagen Price Rise
description: Volkswagen A.G. said Wednesday that it would raise the German prices of most of its models by an average of 2.9 percent, starting today.

title: Campbell Group Files Plan to Sell
description: Since April, when John T. Dorrance Jr., the head of the family that owns almost 59 percent of the Campbell Soup Company, died, Wall Street has buzzed with speculation that the Dorrances would sell the company. For eight months, the family issued unanimous denials.

title: Barrett Resources Corp reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $230,000, or 4 cents a share, for the latest 12-month period and $442,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest year income reduction was due primarily to a $385,000 one-time gain on the sale of a note recorded in 1988, offset by a $255,000 payment received for termination of a gas sales contract in 1989.

title: Poseidon Pools of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings for the 1988 year was restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split declared on May 18.

title: Taiwan Adds To Stock Tax
description: Legislators debating a stock transaction tax in Taiwan's parliament attacked each other with fists hours after the market ended its final session for the year 88 percent higher than its 1988 finish.

title: Tempers Rise Over Fate of Rare Book Collection at Harvard
description: A frozen hush lies over the Charles River here in the holiday lull, but tempers on both banks remain hot over the future of a rare-book collection established 51 years ago at the Harvard Business School.

title: Exxon and Other Spill Defendants Want Evidence Secret Until Trial
description: The Exxon Corporation and other defendants in more than 150 lawsuits resulting from the Exxon Valdez oil spill are asking that all evidence be kept secret until the cases go to trial.

title: Bank Buys Stake In Emerson Radio
description: Fidenas International Bank Ltd., a Bahamian investment bank, has acquired a 5.06 percent stake in the Emerson Radio Corporation, a North Bergen, N.J., consumer electronics concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Fidenas said that it had acquired the shares as an investment, but that it might ''seek participation in management if conditions warrant.''

title: Our Towns; Someone to Call When Jobs End And Pain Grows
description: rrFifty-seven-year-old George Jagger had worked at the Excel Wood Products Company here for 11 years before he was laid off last April.

title: New Faces: Annabella Sciorra and Ron Eldard; The Actors Who Gave Life To the Couple in 'True Love'
description: There may not be a happy-ever-after ending to ''True Love,'' but the film about the emotional twists and turns leading up to an Italian-American wedding in the Bronx has certainly had a happy outcome for Annabella Sciorra and Ron Eldard. The movie, in which they make their feature-film debuts, has earned both actors favorable reviews for their portrayal of a young couple who must contend with the often ludicrous details of planning a wedding as well as a post-nuptial future for which neither is quite ready.

title: INSIDE
description: Latvia Alters Party Role Latvia became the second Soviet republic to abolish the constitutionally guaranteed leading role of the Communist Party. Page A11. Earthquake in Australia An earthquake killed 11 people, injured more than 120 people and caused heavy damage in Newcastle, Australia. Page A3. Desolation in San Francisco The Marina district in San Francisco, a prized address until October, is now a desolate place. Page A14.

title: Dickens With Music
description: A musical version of Dickens's ''Christmas Carol'' is to be presented by the Argonaut Repertory Theater this weekend at the Mazur Theater, Murphy Center, Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. The production, which closes the season at the theater, features 18th- and 19th-century Christmas carols. Shows are at 8 tonight and at 3 and 8 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $10 ($8 for students and the elderly, $6 for those under 12). Tickets to tomorrow night's show and a gala afterward are $25. Information: 864-1917.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Tripucka Sparks Hornets Kelly Tripucka scored 14 of his season-high 25 points in the fourth quarter last night as the Charlotte Hornets won for only the second time in 14 games, beating the Cleveland Cavaliers, 94-92, in Charlotte, N.C. The loss was the fifth straight for Cleveland. Tripucka, who was benched before the game, was booed continuously. He cried at midcourt after the game and criticized the Hornets' fans. Tripucka, with a .375 shooting percentage this season, hit his first 5 shots in the game and wound up hitting 11 of 17. His jump shot from the corner with 1 minutes 33 seconds left broke an 88-88 tie, and his two free throws with six seconds to play sealed the victory. Tripucka and Tyrone (Muggsy) Bogues started all 23 of the Hornets' previous games but were benched last night by Coach Dick Harter, who was trying to shake up his team. Robert Reid started at point guard, with Rex Chapman at shooting guard and Dell Curry in Tripucka's place at small forward. (AP) Nuggets 132, Heat 107: Alex English scored 20 points and Denver used a 12-0 run early in the game to gain its fifth straight victory. The Nuggets, playing at home,had eight players in double figures, led by English and Blair Rasmussen, who had 18 points and 11 rebounds. Denver trailed by 2-0 before scoring the next 12 points, 4 each by English and Rasmussen. The Nuggets led, 39-27, after one quarter and the Heat got no closer the rest of the game.(AP) Clippers 139, Warriors 119: Ron Harper scored 29 points and Gary Grant sparked a 45-point first quarter with seven of his 20 assists as Los Angeles Clippers routed visiting Golden State. Charles Smith scored 22 points and Benoit Benjamin added 19 off the bench for the Clippers, whose largest previous offensive output this season was 129 points. The Warriors were led by Mitch Richmond with 26 points and Chris Mullin with 25. Don Nelson, the Golden State coach, was ejected by Referee Pete Quinn with 2:39 left in the first half and the Warriors trailing by 62-47.(AP) Jazz 113, Trail Blazers 109: John Stockton scored a career-high 33 points and handed out 15 assists as Utah handed visiting Portland its third consecutive loss.

title: After Noriega: Panama City; Residents Say Force Loyal to Noriega Set Fire to Neighborhood in Reprisal
description: Residents of a neighborhood devastated by fire in the hours after the American invasion began on Dec. 20 said today that the destruction was not a product of fighting between American and Panamanian forces, but had been carried out by forces loyal to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as a reprisal for the residents' rejection of the general.

title: A Bit of Cabaret Glamour For the Final Night of '89
description: During the final hours of the 1980's, the kind of high-style nightclub glamour that used to be abundant in Manhattan on New Year's Eve will be in scarcer supply.

title: Review/Theater; 'Foundation,' A Spaniard's Political Metaphor
description: In the opening scene of Antonio Buero-Vallejo's play ''The Foundation,'' Thomas (Thomas Nahrwold), an aspiring young novelist, paces before the picture window in the lounge of what appears to be a luxurious Alpine spa and exults in the ecstatic music of Rossini wafting through the room he occupies with five other men.

title: Upheaval in the East: Ceausescu's Fall; 2 Rumanians Defend the Leader's Execution and Secret Trial
description: The trial and execution of President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania were defended in interviews yesterday by a Rumanian sociologist who knew him well and by a brother of a prominent figure in the events preceding his downfall.

title: Kurt Baum, Tenor, Is Dead at 81; He Sang at Met in 40's and 50's
description: Kurt Baum, a tenor who regularly performed at the Metropolitan Opera during the 1940's and 50's, died of unspecified causes on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Lou Rawls Telethon
description: The ''Lou Rawls Parade of Stars,'' an annual telethon with the pop singer as host, will be televised tomorrow, beginning at 8 P.M. on Channel 11. The seven-hour telethon, the 10th such broadcast, raises money for the United Negro College Fund. The broadcast, which will originate from locations in Los Angeles and Las Vegas, will feature appearances by Anita Baker, Bill Cosby, Bob Hope, Patti LaBelle, Julio Iglesias, Lola Falana, Charley Pride, Gregory Peck and Frank Sinatra. Information: 326-1100.

title: Restaurants
description: Brandywine

title: Meeting Set for Today in Metro-North Fare Dispute
description: State transportation officials said today that they would meet Friday with representatives of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to try to resolve a dispute over fare increases on the New Haven line of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: FLORIDA GOVERNOR SEEKS DISASTER AID
description: Gov. Bob Martinez sought Federal disaster aid today for Florida farmers whose crops were damaged in the statewide freeze last weekend.

title: The Score Board Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit resulting from utilization of net operating loss carryforward of $10,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $98,000. d-After an extraordinary credit of $23,000 resulting from utilization of net operating loss carryforward. All per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 1-for-100 reverse split effective Feb. 21, 1989.

title: Washington at Work; Man as Symbol: Atwater's First Year as the Republican National Chairman
description: There comes a moment in the careers of all public figures when it becomes clear that their names are no longer their own, but for better and for worse are spoken freely in households large and small across the nation.

title: Japan Details Import Plans
description: Government officials today provided more details of a package of tax incentives, tariff eliminations and other measures intended to reverse trade policies and increases Japan's imports.

title: U.S. Completes Plan for Military To Bar Latin America Drug Flow
description: The Bush Administration has completed plans to use the military to cut drug-supply routes from Latin America that would include using an aircraft carrier battle group off the coast of Colombia to monitor all sea and air traffic, a senior Administration official said today.

title: A Matchup Of Backcourts
description: As friends growing up in the New York area, Jim Valvano and P. J. Carlesimo have followed each other through the college basketball coaching establishment.

title: Economic Scene; Reality's the Thing This Field Needs
description: FOR the thousands of economists attending the annual meetings here of the American Economic Association, and for the millions of people in the world undergoing rapid and often chaotic change, there is a crucial question: How good is the state of economics?

title: Health Care for All Children
description: Finally, the latest Federal budget reconciliation act requires states to expand Medicaid coverage for children. Better still, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York is studying proposals to take the state beyond that - to contemplating universal health coverage for children from the prenatal stage to age 21.

title: SHREVEPORT POSTER ASSAILED AS RACIST
description: A poster that depicts blacks as roaches being sprayed by a white hand and as suspects running away from a white judge bore the logo of the local tourist bureau and was sold to businesses in the Shreveport area this fall.

title: Vandals Raid a Jewish School Near Washington
description: A Jewish secondary school has been ransacked while closed for Hanukkah in a ''hate-violence incident,'' the authorities say.

title: MANILA DESCRIBES EVIDENCE ON PLOT
description: Philippine Government officials said today that they had evidence that a leader of the political opposition to President Corazon C. Aquino was involved in this month's coup attempt against her.

title: Review/Dance; An Evening of Transformations by Momix
description: Picture a Momix performer clad in blue from his shoes to his 1950's shoulder pads, topped by a television monitor for a head. The face on videotape mouths some lyrics while the figure strums a small electric guitar.

title: Dining Out Guide: Winter Dishes
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Arizona 206

title: Brazil Inflation Sets a Record
description: Brazil's monthly inflation rate rose to a record 53.55 percent in December, the Government statistics office, said today.

title: Dresser Ends Smith Pact
description: Dresser Industries said today that it had terminated an agreement to acquire Smith International Inc through a merger. Dresser, a supplier of products and services for the energy industry, said it was exploring possible alternatives with Smith.

title: Stepping Out for the Midnight Countdown
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE festivities may seem like timeless traditions, but throughout most of history, Dec. 31 came and went with none of the hoopla that will envelop New York and elsewhere this weekend. In fact, until 1564 in France and 1752 in England, the new year began -much more logically - on March 25 with the first hopeful signs of spring.

title: OSI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SFE Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included a charge of $7 million to provide for the writedown of excess inventory. c-After an extraordinary credit of $683,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: Utah Power and Light Appoints Top Officer
description: During the Utah Power and Light Company's recent merger with Pacificorp, the largest utility merger in the country, Verl R. Topham, Utah's executive vice president, pushed through compromises that reduced opposition and made the deal possible.

title: Jurors' TV Viewing Is Growing Issue
description: Can a television drama influence a jury's verdict? One lawyer thinks so, and with an eye toward winning a new trial in a medical malpractice case, he wants the jurors questioned to find out.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: Blues at Birdland

title: New Inquiry Rejected In Shooting of 2 Boys
description: The Minnesota Attorney General refused today to reopen an investigation into the fatal shootings of two 13-year-old Laotian boys by a police officer.

title: RJR Nabisco Planning $1.25 Billion Note Sale
description: The RJR Nabisco Holding Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the first phase of its plan to reduce its $25 billion debt and would embark on the next stage - refinancing its remaining debt - by seeking Government clearance to sell $1.25 billion in new senior notes.

title: A Single Yugoslavia, Pluralized
description: Will Yugoslavia be the next Eastern European state to erupt - or can free elections help contain its explosive nationalist rivalries? Communists in Croatia and Slovenia, the most westward-looking of Yugoslavia's six republics, want to hold multiparty elections. In Serbia, largest of the six, the Communist Party objects. The federation's Communist Central Committee has now wisely backed the Croats and Slovenians.

title: In Hispanic Community, Many Ignore AIDS
description: Years after health officials identified a high incidence of AIDS among minorities in the inner city, much of the Hispanic population continues to ignore or deny the threat, say Hispanic leaders in AIDS services.

title: Audrey Christie, 79; Singer and Dancer Became an Actress
description: Audrey Christie, a versatile actress who began her career as a singer and dancer in musical comedies and went on to deft dramatic portrayals, died of emphysema on Dec. 19 at her home in West Hollywood, Calif. She was 79 years old.

title: Review/Art; Small-Scale Works on Paper by Gerhard Richter
description: Of all the West German artists who rode to international prominence more than a decade ago on the wave of Neo-Expressionism, none have been more compelling or less predictable than Gerhard Richter. A painter during the early 1960's of blurred black-and-white images derived from photographs of the most banal sort, Mr. Richter produced monochromatic compositions during the later 60's and early 70's, many of which consisted of little more than meandering gray lines against gray backdrops.

title: 6 Neighbors and Railroad Battle Over Crossing
description: A quarrel over a railroad crossing is threatening the only access six homeowners have to the village and their homes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Curtice-Burns Foods Inc., Rochester, a food processing company, and its affiliate, Pro-Fac Cooperative, said they had purchased Globe Products Co., Clifton, N.J., a maker of fruit and cream fillings for bakery use.

title: Bond to Sell Beer Units
description: Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. said today that it planned to sell its Australian brewing assets to Bell Resources Ltd., a debt-plagued subsidiary, for about $1.6 billion (United States). But Bond said Lion Nathan

title: Letter to TV Threatens More Bombings in South
description: An Atlanta television station today made public a racially charged letter that took responsibility for the two recent fatal bombings in the South and threatened more violence against ''the black leadership'' and Federal judges.

title: Review/Art; Pillars of Periodicals at the Brooklyn Museum
description: The latest installation in the Grand Lobby of the Brooklyn Museum is trendy and spectacular. It is a huge colonnade that seems entirely constructed of magazines like Harper's Bazaar and Esquire. Three of the five columns are new; the other two, sheathed in magazines, are actually part of the building. The Grand Lobby now seems held up by fashionable publications.

title: Break Over, Giants Return To Business
description: The three-day holiday break was wonderful.

title: Auctions
description: An early marble portrait bust attributed to Gianlorenzo Bernini that was thought to be lost for more than a century is to be auctioned at Christie's in New York on Jan. 10.

title: Elderly Farm Couple In Missouri Indicted In Deaths of 5 Men
description: An elderly farm couple accused of killing transients in northwest Missouri were indicted by a grand jury today on five counts of first-degree murder.

title: Kenya's Plan for Tower Annoys Aid Donors
description: Kenya's major financial donors, including the United States and Japan, have expressed their disapproval of plans to build a 60-story, $200 million office tower, which they say the country cannot afford.

title: Young Stowaway Found Dead On Eastern Jetliner in Miami
description: A 17-year-old boy who had apparently stowed away on an Eastern Airlines 727 from Barbados was found dead here Wednesday in the plane's unpressurized rear stairway.

title: Prison Can Be a Dumb Solution
description: Grady Wacaster was a prison warden in Spooky Hollow, N.C.

title: After Noriega: Burial; At Arlington, Peruvian Kin Mourns Casualty of Panama
description: A Peruvian immigrant who joined the United States Army last year in the hope of furthering his education today became the first of the soldiers killed in Panama to be buried with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: KEY RATES
Panel Contradicts Autopsy In Death of Man in Custody
description: A state investigation has found that a Queens man who died in police custody last spring choked to death on vomit while lying face up in a restraining blanket, and not of cocaine intoxication, as concluded by New York City's Medical Examiner in an autopsy.

title: Taurus Footwear reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $3,452,000 for the latest third quarter and $3,154,000 for year- ago period, and interest expense for latest quarter was $5,693,000 and year- ago period totaled $4,015,000. The year-ago periods' results were restated. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago fiscal results have been reclassified.

title: Skymusic Ensemble
description: Carman Moore, the composer, will lead his Skymusic Ensemble in his new dance piece, ''Magical Circles,'' at the South Street Theater, 424 West 42d Street, tonight at 8. The work is to be danced by Angela Verdurmen, a dancer and choreographer from the Netherlands, and includes slides by Caterina Bertolotto. The performance is to be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $10. Information: 279-4200.

title: Why Hong Kong Is Turning Back Boat People
description: To the Editor:

title: Nairobi Factory Gives Women Hope
description: Jacinta Wanjiku, a 30-year-old divorced mother of four children, strides through the tile-making plant on the outskirts of this city, knowledgeably checking on whether deliveries of mortar and sisal have arrived on time for the production schedules. After a recent three-week training course in England she can also check the machines.

title: Family Asks Judge to Find Mafia Boss Mentally Ill
description: In ranking the Mafia hierarchy, law-enforcement authorities put Vincent (the Chin) Gigante near the top - the undisputed boss of the Genovese family. He is now a target of a Federal investigation.

title: Court Rules on Assessment Of Subsidized Units in Jersey
description: A New Jersey appeals court has ruled that subsidized housing should be assessed for tax purposes on its actual purchase price, rather than on its higher market value.

title: Sock Shop Shuts Stores
description: Sock Shop International P.L.C., a British retailer that has been expanding rapidly in the United States, abruptly closed its 17 shops in the New York area on Wednesday.

title: Colorado Coach Was Irish Fan
description: rrThe Notre Dame games did not come through on the radio in the McCartney home back in Riverview, Mich., so the entire family used to sit in the car in the driveway, where reception was better.

title: Eastern Plans Wage Cuts, 600 Layoffs
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it was laying off 600 employees, mostly managers, and cutting wages by 10 percent or 20 percent for about half its work force.

title: American Express to Sell Geneva Bank for $1 Billion
description: The American Express Company has reached an agreement to sell its Geneva-based private banking subsidiary to another Swiss banking institution for about $1 billion, American Express said yesterday.

title: Upheaval in the East: Overview; RUMANIANS FINDING A BOUNTY OF FOOD THEY LONG MISSED
description: Sacks of coffee beans and other long-unseen goods, beef, pork, chocolate bars, even oranges and, reputedly, bananas, appeared in the stores here today, belated Christmas presents from the brief, violent revolution that overthrew Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: In Queens, A Look Back At 2 Visions Of the Future
description: As the penultimate 20th-century decade closes with the weekend, so to does a somewhat strange look back at the future as envisioned in two New York World's Fairs, one 50 years ago and the other 25 years ago. The retrospective of aging prospectives is centered at the Queens Museum, in the New York City Building, itself a relic of the two fairs, in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Armitage Says Her Troupe Is Disbanding Temporarily
description: Karole Armitage has announced the temporary disbanding of the Armitage Ballet. The seven-member company was founded in 1985 to perform Ms. Armitage's dances, including her frequent collaborations with the artist David Salle.

title: Upheaval in the East; Ousted Member of Politburo Is Under Custody in Prague
description: An ousted Czechoslovak Communist Party Politburo member, Miroslav Stepan, has been detained pending an inquiry into his role in security force violence against a democracy protest last month, state television said today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Role With Everything

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY AT ALICE TULLY HALL

title: Foul Shots At End Give Edge To Knicks
description: About three hours before the Knicks played the Nets tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, they learned they would be without Charles Oakley, their power forward and the National Basketball Association's third-best rebounder.

title: On Stage
description: The Best for Last?

title: Early Church Music
description: An early 14th-century English Mass setting, as well as a 13th-century Alleluia and a 16th-century setting of the ''Coventry Carol,'' are to be sung as part of the Festal Eucharist service on Sunday morning at 11 o'clock at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 53d Street. The performers are the Gentlemen of the Choir of St. Thomas, directed by Gerre Hancock. At the Festal Evensong service, at 4 P.M., Mr. Hancock and the choir are to sing works by Thomas Morley, Adrian Batten and Robert Whyte. Admission is free. Information: 757-7013.

title: Metal Detectors Make Schools Like Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Fares Rise Monday, But Subway Tokens Won't Be Changing
description: Ending a small mystery that had been growing around the Transit Authority's decision to raise the price of a subway and bus ride from $1 to $1.15 next Monday, a Transit Authority spokesman indicated last night that passengers will be able to use the same token they have been using until now.

title: Medieval Origins
description: The Ensemble for Early Music is to perform ''Herod and the Innocents,'' a production based on two medieval Nativity plays, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, tonight at 7:30. The two works on which the production is based - ''The Representation of Herod'' and ''The Slaughter of the Innocents'' - come from the Fleury Play Book, a 12th-century French manuscript. The production is to be repeated tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $22. Information: 307-7171.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''WEST SIDE SLEIGH RIDE,'' a program by actors from the Open Eye, New Stagings for Youth, portraying characters in six short stories with holiday themes, for ages 7 and up, 2 P.M. Sunday (last performance), at 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: students and the elderly, $6; others, $8. Information: 769-4143. ''A CHARLES DICKENS CHRISTMAS,'' a musical based on the author's life and the help he receives from his muse to write ''A Christmas Carol,'' presented by Theaterworks/ USA, at 2 P.M. today and 12:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. Tickets: $12 and $15. Reservations: 677-5959. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a show by Bil Baird's Marionettes, 1 and 3:15 P.M. daily through Jan. 1, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section. Tickets: $12. Information: 307-7171 or (718) 636-4100. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' magic and comedy, at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Information: 772-9180. ''CHARLOTTE'S WEB,'' a musical based on E. B. White's story about a spider named Charlotte, performed by On Stage Productions, 3 and 7 P.M. today and tomorrow. At Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: students and the elderly, $8; others, $10. Information: 666-1716. ''ROCKET AND FRIENDS,'' a show by the Puppet Company, 1 and 3 P.M. tomorrow, at 31 Union Square West, Loft 2B. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: 741-1646. ''ALADDIN,'' a play performed by the Royal Buckingham Theater Company, 8 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays, and 3 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, through Jan. 15, at the Nat Horne Theater, 440 West 42d Street. Tickets: children, under 12, $10; others, $15. Information: 279-4200. ''THE DANGEROUS CHRISTMAS OF RED RIDING HOOD,'' with music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Bob Merrill and book by Robert Emmett, 11 A.M., 1:30 and 7:30 P.M. today, and 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Tada Theater, 120 West 28th Street. Admission: children, $5; adults, $7. Information: 627-1732. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE WIZARD,'' a play about a shy dragon who lives in Central Park and a sly wizard, written by Miranda McDermott, with child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. on Saturdays, at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations required: 734-5195. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a show by the Puppetworks, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. today and tomorrow, at the Puppet Playhouse, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' a puppet show by the Papageno Puppet Theater, with Susan Delery Whedon, who sings with recorded music in an abridged version of the Humperdinck opera, 1:30 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, at the West 72d Street Studios, 131 West 72d Street. Admission: $4. Information: 874-3297. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic show with audience participation, with Torkova and Imam, 2 P.M. on Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Information: 924-1472.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-13 Alexander Dubcek was elected to head Czechoslovakia's national Parliament 21 years after he was ousted by Soviet troops during the Prague Spring of 1968. Page A1

title: Review/Theater; From Author of 'Falsettos,' A Musical About the 1930's
description: The real history of the American musical theater in the 1980's began in 1981 with William Finn's ''March of the Falsettos,'' an exuberant show about the love between husbands and wives, parents and children, men and men, and everyone and psychiatrists. Though the story might now have to be revised to accommodate the virus that would later rewrite the lives of its characters, the score and lyrics of ''Falsettos'' remain as invigorating as ever. Certainly no musical since has offered an opening number to match Mr. Finn's at once merry and neurotic fugue of familial kvetching, ''Four Jews in a Room.''

title: Upheaval in the East: Israel; A Nation of Two Minds About Ceausescu's Fall
description: In recent days, Israel has sent six tons of medical supplies to Rumania, lauded democracy's emergence there and condemned the violence by which forces loyal to Bucharest's ousted dictatorship sought to suppress a revolution.

title: Sikh Clash Kills at Least 4
description: Hundreds of police officers surrounded a Sikh temple today in the northern state of Punjab and battled militants inside, the police said. At least four policeman were reported killed. About 500 police officers surrounded the Darbar Sahib temple and exchanged fire with entrenched militants who hd tried to take over. The temple is in the Tarn Taran town, 15 miles north of Amritsar, the location of the holiest Sikh shrine, the Golden Temple.

title: Knee Injury to Idle Liut for 3 Weeks
description: The outstanding goaltender in the National Hockey League this season and the outstanding one in the league two seasons ago will be sitting out games for a while with injuries.

title: Neediest Gain As Partygoers Forgo Singing
description: The office Christmas party may be a staple of corporate life, but in the name of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, some parties acquired new twists this year.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria; Rallies in Sofia Demand Faster Liberalization and Minority Rights
description: Thousands of Bulgarians demonstrated in a park today to demand that the Government move more quickly to bring about democratic change.

title: Ragen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $21,000 for the quarter and $34,000 for the year. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $319,000 for the quarter and $209,000 for the year, and after extraordinary gains on disposal of discontinued operations of $325,000, or 7 cents a share, and $1,380,000, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said included in the 1989 loss is a provision for doubtful notes receivable in the amount of $215,000 entered into by the company in connection with an option to acquire a manufacturer of video switches. The option was not exercised by the company.

title: Intruder Killed by Trap at House
description: A man was killed here this week by a trap set up inside a house whose owner had complained of frequent break-ins.

title: Frank Mankiewicz To Advise Hungarians
description: Frank Mankiewicz, a top adviser to Robert F. Kennedy and George S. McGovern in their Democratic Presidential campaigns, appears to be ready to engage in another dramatic political battle, one on behalf of Hungary's Socialist Party, which until October called itself the Communist Party.

title: Sri Lanka Reports Death of Top Sinhalese Militant
description: The last senior leader of a Sinhalese extremist group has been captured and killed, and the dominant Tamil militants have ambushed and killed members of a rival Tamil organization, Sri Lankan officials said today.

title: Gray Runs for 280 Yards as Texas Tech Swamps Duke
description: James Gray ran for 280 yards and scored four touchdowns tonight to lead Texas Tech to a 49-21 victory over Duke in the All-American Bowl.

title: Prosecutor Joins Inquiry in Fire That Killed 2 Girls
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office has joined a Fire Department investigation into a fire Wednesday in which two young sisters, believed to have been trapped by a window gate, were killed as flames swept through four buildings.

title: Stass Reed Dies at 76; Owned Wine Business
description: Stass Reed, a member of Czarist Russian nobility who became a New York businessman, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Paris and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Midway to Buy Dornier Planes
description: Dornier G.m.b.H., an aircraft company based here, said that Chicago-based Midway Airlines Inc. had signed a contract to buy 33 Dornier-328 airliners worth about $250 million. It said included in the contract was an option to double the order, with delivery to begin in 1993.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
Long Island Residents Try 2 Routes to Property-Tax Relief; Nassau Homeowners Are Seeking Hearings To Cut Assessments
description: Last spring, Violet Ragland and some of her neighbors in the Baldwin Woods area of Roosevelt, a Nassau County community, compared their property-tax bills and saw that while their houses were virtually identical, their assessments were all different.

title: Sundstrom to Utica
description: The Devils reduced their overcrowded roster yesterday by demoting Peter Sundstrom to their minor league affiliate, the Utica Devils, two days after the demotion of the defenseman Sergei Starikov.

title: 3 Children Die In Brooklyn Fire As Rescue Fails
description: An infant and his two young brothers died last night in a fire in their apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, despite the efforts of neighbors to rescue them through a courtyard window, fire and rescue officials said.

title: Rider Suspended Again
description: Two days after returning to the races from a 60-day suspension because of a positive cocaine test, Patrick Valenzuela has been suspended for five days because of interference in the stretch.

title: Reconciliation of Egypt and Syria Leaves Israel With Mixed Feelings
description: Israeli leaders warned today that Syria remains a powerful threat to Israel despite its reconciliation with Egypt this week. But they also said they hoped that Cairo could persuade Damascus to adopt a moderate line toward Israel.

title: Northwest Warns Flight's Ticket Holders of Threat
description: Northwest Airlines took the unusual step yesterday of advising ticket holders that it had received a ''security threat'' against a flight scheduled for tomorrow from Paris to Detroit.

title: Coaching a Big Factor In Oilers-Steelers Game
description: Two distinctive coaches, Chuck Noll of the Steelers and Jerry Glanville of the Oilers, will be the 12th men when their teams meet in the American Conference wild-card game Sunday in Houston.

title: Deregulation Created Our Thrifts Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Are Their Names Now?
description: Where are their names?

title: Applied Spectrum Technoloies Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said that reduced operating losses in fiscal 1989 resulted from Applied Spectrum's continued efforts to reduce expenses to better match revenues. The 1988 net loss included $366,000 of non-operating income from the cancellation of a major OEM shipment.

title: Gehl Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $708,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: Leetch Turns Losing Into Personal Matter
description: The game was only 10 minutes old and it had already been a dreadfully long one for Brian Leetch. The puck had just banked off his leg and into the net of his teammate, John Vanbiesbrouck, and Leetch's face had gone as red as the goal light that glared behind the endboards.

title: Europeans Press Japan On Autos
description: Even as the European Community moves to scrap its internal trade barriers by the end of 1992, it is trying to limit access by Japan's powerful auto makers. It is putting pressure on Tokyo to accept a system of ''voluntary import restraints,'' but with a tough twist. Under proposals disclosed this month, even cars that Japanese auto makers assemble at their new European plants would fall within the quotas on Japanese cars.

title: Lions' Sanders Honored
description: In balloting by 70 sportswriters and broadcasters who cover the N.F.L. for The Associated Press, Barry Sanders, the Detroit Lion running back, was a near-unanimous choice as offensive rookie of the year with 69 of 70 votes. Andre Rison of Indianapolis, a wide receiver, got the other vote.

title: Photo of American soldiers standing guard yesterday outside the residence of the Papal Nuncio in Panama City, Panamanian citizens demonstrated against the mission's harboring of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed leader. (Black Star/Cindy Karp for The NYT) After Noriega: U.S. and Rome; Negotiations Over Noriega Stall, but Bush Still Presses
description: The Bush Administration continued today to insist that the Vatican turn over Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian leader who has taken refuge with the Papal Nuncio in Panama City, but has decided to adopt a very patient approach with the Holy See.

title: For a New Emigre in Israel, A Menorah, and Minor Pains
description: Before Emma Finkelstein, her mother and two daughters left the Soviet Union and immigrated here three months ago, she could not obtain a Hanukkah candelabra in her hometown.

title: Virginia Sends Auburn Into a 3-Game Slump
description: A half-hour after his 13th-ranked women's basketball team had dropped a 61-59 decision tonight to Virginia for an unprecedented third straight loss, Coach Joe Campi of Auburn laughed when someone suggested that the odds may have finally caught up with him.

title: In Panama, We're Rebuilding Frankenstein
description: In 1968, Panama was a fortunate country - free, democratic, with a good measure of social justice and economic equity.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., a manufacturer of automotive and other products, said Haren B. Thakor had resigned as chief financial officer. James K. Baker, chairman and chief executive, will take over the position on an interim basis.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Saturday described a survey on the quality of cable television in Manhattan, which drew an unusually large number of responses.

title: LAW: At the Bar; From the frying pan as Solicitor General to the fire of renewed academic debate.
description: rrDuring his years as Ronald Reagan's Solicitor General, representing the United States before the Supreme Court, Charles Fried usually managed to have somebody mad at him.

title: The Large-Scale Visions Of a Small Opera Company
description: There is great commotion these days on the tiny stage of the Amato Opera Theater at 319 Bowery, near Second Street, as Count Almaviva tries one disguise after another in pursuit of young Rosina.

title: Long Island Residents Try 2 Routes to Property-Tax Relief; Suffolk County Panel Urges School Districts To Merge Operations
description: The number of public-school districts in Suffolk County should be reduced by half through mergers to create a more efficient school system, a county task force said today. Much of the $55 million in annual savings would go to reduce property taxes, the task force said.

title: Upheaval in the East: A Victim; For an Emigre Family, Loss of a Son
description: Alex Bacall of Kew Gardens, Queens, said he watched the grisly scenes of mass graves in Rumania broadcast in recent days with only one thought in his mind: ''I pray my Robert is not among them.''

title: An Emblem Is Renewed For Merrill
description: AMERICA can rest on this last weekend of the 1980's secure in the knowledge that ''Merrill Lynch is bullish on the 90's.''

title: LAW: The Lawyer As Lobbyist; Lobbying Lures Fresh Faces As Lucrative Legal Specialty
description: Ten years ago, when the Washington law firm of Patton, Boggs & Blow tried to recruit bright young lawyers, it played down the fact that a large part of its practice was lobbying. Prospects found it both unsavory and unlawyerly, said Thomas H. Boggs, the firms's most celebrated partner.

title: Slower Growth Is Seen For U.S. Manufacturers
description: American industry should enjoy an eighth straight year of expansion in 1990, but the gains among manufacturers, at 2 percent, will be lower than this year's 2.2 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: An Outburst of Affection From Martin's Fans
description: The celebrities will gather at St. Patrick's Cathedral today for the funeral of Billy Martin, who died Monday at the age of 61 in a traffic accident. Two of his former teammates and closest friends, Whitey Ford and Mickey Mantle, will be among the pallbearers, along with George Steinbrenner and Willie Randolph.

title: 9 Are Killed and 107 Hurt In Earthquake in Australia
description: An earthquake killed at least 11 people and injured more than 120 today in this southeastern industrial city, officials said. The army was called in to help prevent looting.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Philips's Lasco Group Gets New President
description: LEAD: Frank J. Martin has been named president of Philips Industries' Lasco Products Group, taking over at the bathtub and plastic pipe manufacturer during a slump in housing construction that has pinched suppliers of building materials.

title: Correction
description: The main front-page article on Tuesday about Rumania misidentified Ana Ipatescu, for whom a street in Bucharest is named. She was a heroine of the 1848 uprising against the Turks and the Russians, not of the Communist takeover after World War II.

title: Blast at U.S. Offices in Chile
description: A bomb exploded today in the offices of the American-Chilean culture center in Santiago, causing damage but no injuries, the police said. No group asserted responsibility for the blast at the center, which is partially financed by Washington. But Chile's most active left-wing guerrilla group, the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, warned last week that it could strike at American interests in Chile to protest the American invasion of Panama.

title: India's Capital Gets an Air Chief as Administrator
description: A new national government in India means, sooner or later, a new administration for the country's capital city, which like Washington is a federal territory longing for the privileges of statehood.

title: Earnings Dip Seen By XL/Datacomp
description: XL/Datacomp Inc., one of the largest resellers of the International Business Machines Corporation's midrange computers, said that because of changes in I.B.M.'s sales strategy, it would have sharply lower revenues and earnings in the coming year. The company said I.B.M. planned to reduce discounts and to promote its products for narrowly focused uses rather than for generalized applications.

title: Iran, Fearing Loss of Syria Tie, Widens Aid to Lebanon Shiites
description: Fearful that a 10-year alliance with Syria may be coming to an end, Iran is increasing military and financial aid to its Muslim funamentalist surrogates in Lebanon to help them gain supremacy in Muslim areas.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.10 billion, to $366.01 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $208.10 million, to $87.61 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were down by $523.80 million, to $119.98 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds decreased by $371.50 million, to $158.41 billion, the institute said.

title: Title Defense at Hofstra
description: For the first time in 30 years, Madison Square Garden will promote a boxing program on a college campus when Kevin Marston of Jamaica, Queens, defends his New York State junior lightweight title Jan. 12 against Reggie Otero of Brooklyn at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. The last time the Garden promoted a fight on a college campus was Dec. 4, 1959, when Gene Fullmer retained his middleweight title in a 15-round decision over Spider Webb at Utah State University. (AP)

title: China's Inflation Slows
description: China's annual inflation rate slowed to 7.1 percent in November, compared with a 27 percent rate at the beginning of the year, the State Statistical Bureau said today. The official New China News Agency quoted an unidentified bureau official as saying the data meant China's austerity program, begun 15 months ago, was working. The official said fruit prices fell by 11.4 percent and vegetables by 6 percent in November. But prices rose for fuels, building materials, daily necessities, books and meat. He gave no details.

title: Flying After 60
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has said it will take a fresh look at the rule barring pilots age 60 and over from flying commercial airliners. The review may or may not produce new policy; what's crucial is that the F.A.A. base its inquiry on medical science instead of the hunches and suppositions that govern present policy.

title: Pilot Is Missing After F-15 In Training Crashes Into Sea
description: An F-15 jet fighter crashed into the Gulf of Mexico during a mock dogfight this morning, and the pilot was still missing late today.

title: People
description: * Christian Dobles has been named senior vice president of Uniworld Group Inc.

title: Review/Cabaret; Manhattan Rhythm Kings Evoke 30's Singing Groups
description: The Manhattan Rhythm Kings, who started out as a trio of street musicians playing, singing and dancing in the Lincoln Center area in the summer of 1979, have been indoors for a decade. But the core of their repertory is still pop songs of the 20's and 30's and the period singing styles of two landmark trios, the Boswell Sisters and Paul Whiteman's Rhythm Boys (one of whom was Bing Crosby).

title: 4 Killed in Freeway Crash
description: A pickup truck slammed into an overturned tanker carrying 1,100 gallons of fuel Wednesday night, causing a huge explosion and the death of four people. The driver of the tanker was not in the vehicle and thus escaped injury in the crash, which occurred on Interstate 10. All those killed were inside the pickup truck.

title: Man Is Held in Killing Arranged by Victim
description: A man who was fatally injured here last weekend when hit by a car driven by a college student had paid the student to run him down, the police said today.

title: Colorado Runner Recovers in Time
description: The football players in the black jerseys were leaving the field at the end of another University of Colorado practice, one step closer to the end of a time they hope will be remembered as their championship season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I see this as a sort of continuation of the Prague Spring in 1968 and a certain moral vindication for the hundreds of thousands of its active participants.'' -Alexander Dubcek, after his election as chairman of the Czechoslovak Parliament. [ A1:6. ]

title: A Scrappy New Spirit At Young & Rubicam
description: Fighting a racketeering indictment and landing on the short end of two highly publicized lawsuits, Young & Rubicam finds itself suffering from a malady its copywriters invented: a king-sized Excedrin headache.

title: 2 Plays and 2 Musicals To Close on Sunday
description: Producers of four shows - two plays and two musicals - have announced that they will close after Sunday's performances.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M.

title: Treasury Security Prices Advance
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in very light trading yesterday, as dealers took advantage of a recent fairly steep drop to do some buying.

title: Ronaldo de Juan, Painter, 58
description: Ronaldo de Juan, a painter, died of lung cancer on Dec. 21 in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.

title: Cards Interview Coslet
description: The Phoenix general manager, Larry Wilson, still searching for a head coach for the Cardinals, interviewed the Cincinnati Bengals' offensive coordinator, Bruce Coslet, yesterday. Coslet said Wednesday that he was also to be interviewed for the Jets' head coaching job.(AP)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Federal regulators and banking experts are concerned that mounting losses from troubled real estate loans could lead to a wave of bank failures, straining the Federal insurance program that protects depositors' funds. The danger, regulators and analysts say, is that when the country enters an economic downturn, as most economists say it eventually must, the losses at commercial banks may be so large that the Government might have to raise insurance fees on the banking industry or rescue some banks with taxpayers' money. [ Page A1. ] American industry should enjoy an eighth straight year of expansion, but gains among manufacturers, at 2 percent, will be lower than this year's 2.2 percent, the Commerce Department said. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL Even as the European Community moves to scrap its internal trade barriers by the end of 1992, it is trying to limit access by Japan's powerful auto makers. It is putting pressure on Tokyo to accept a system of ''voluntary import restraints,'' but with a tough twist. Under proposals disclosed this month, even cars that Japanese auto makers assemble at their new European plants would fall within the quotas on Japanese cars. [ D1. ] COMPANIES American Express has agreed to sell its private banking subsidiary in Geneva to another Swiss banking institution for about $1 billion. [ D1. ] Three members of the Dorrance family plan to sell their 17.4 percent stake in Campbell Soup, they told the S.E.C. That puts them in opposition to the two sons and one daughter of John T. Dorrance Jr. Mr. Dorrance headed the company until he died in April. The sons and daughter, who own 31 percent of Campbell's stock, last week reaffirmed their intent to keep Campbell independent. [ D1. ] Eastern Air Lines said it was laying off 600 employees, mostly managers, and cutting wages by 10 percent or 20 percent for about half its work force. [ D3. ] RJR Nabisco said it had completed the first phase of its plan to reduce its $25 billion debt and would embark on the next stage -refinancing its remaining debt - by seeking Government clearance to sell $1.25 billion in new senior notes. [ D3. ] L. F. Rothschild Holdings reached agreement with creditors on a bankruptcy court reorganization plan. [ D3. ] MARKETS Orange juice futures prices rose again after Brazil halted exports to assess the damage in Florida from the cold snap and decide whether to raise prices. [ D1. ] Florida's Governor Martinez requested Federal disaster aid for farmers whose crops were damaged during last weekend's statewide freeze. [ A23. ] Stock prices rose across a broad front, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.90 points, to 2,732.30. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in very light trading, as dealers took advantage of a recent, fairly steep drop to do some buying. [ D5. ] The dollar finished sharply higher in domestic trading after a mixed performance overseas. [ D14. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The public is pouring cash into stock mutual funds at the heaviest rate since stock prices peaked in the summer of 1987. But the managers who run those funds are sitting on much of the cash. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ] How good is the state of economics? That is a crucial question. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] ''Merrill Lynch is bullish on the 90's,'' its new advertising campaign announces. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D4. ]

title: North River Plant in Bad Odor Because of Sewer
description: To the Editor:

title: New Tactics in the War on Drugs Tilt Scales of Justice Off Balance
description: New laws and procedures intended to speed the courts' handling of criminal drug cases are now in many instances making matters worse. And both Federal and state judges say the nation's new drug policies are only going to compound the problem.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: The 11th Course

title: Diner's Journal
description: Morocco on 45th Street

title: Lagos Journal; Nigeria Enlists the Nettlesome Man in Short Pants
description: With his usual attire of sneakers, short pants and khaki hunting cap, Tai Solarin looks more like the village eccentric - which he has often been called -than the bank president that he recently became.

title: Upheaval in the East: News Reports; Excerpts From Broadcasts and a Press Dispatch
description: Reports continue today from Soviet bloc nations and elsewhere on the situation in Rumania. Here are excerpts from Libyan, Hungarian and Chinese radio broadcasts and from an Agence France-Presse dispatch, as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service. Contact With Qaddafi

title: After Noriega: United Nations; Two Delegates Vying to Be the Voice of the New Government
description: The legitimacy of the new American-backed Panamanian Government of President Guillermo Endara will be tested at the United Nations on Friday, when Panama seeks to address the General Assembly during its emergency debate on the United States invasion.

title: Ailey and Blind Dancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Flabby Logic on 'No-Shows'
description: Common sense suggests that legislators who use taxpayer funds earmarked for legislative positions to hire full-time campaign workers ought to be prosecuted for stealing. But not according to a New York State appeals court. Last week it dismissed the core payroll padding charges against Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate minority leader. Now it's up to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, to restore elemental accountability.

title: Why Hong Kong Is Turning Back Boat People; Illegal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: String Orchestra
description: Alexander Schneider is to conduct the New York String Orchestra in Beethoven's Grosse Fuge, Haydn's Symphony No. 31, and a Mozart Adagio in E for Violin and Orchestra tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall. The soloist in the Mozart is Eugene Watanabe. Tickets are $7 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

title: A.&P. Decides to Move Its $13 Million Account
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, better known as A.&P. supermarkets, has put its advertising account into review, and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/New York, its agency for more than three years, will not participate in it. The agency said the account's annual billings are around $13 million. In a prepared statement, Peter Rosow, joint managing director of the agency, said, ''The major issue is the proposed staffing requirements and compensation agreement, which would exacerbate a financial problem we've been struggling with since 1986.''

title: 33 in Northern Bangladesh Are Reported Killed by Cold
description: A cold wave in normally tropical northern Bangladesh has killed at least 33 people in the last week, a newspaper reported today.

title: Social Security Chief Seeks to Expand a U.S. Welfare Program
description: The Commissioner of Social Security has begun an effort to enroll many of the one million to two million poor people who are eligible for the Supplemental Security Income program.

title: Dow Rises 7.90 Points, To 2,732.30
description: Stock prices rose across a broad front yesterday, but the advance was tempered by end-of-the-year selling.

title: TV Weekend; 'Uncommon Women,' Then and Now
description: The past has been very much in the present this year on television, from revivals of ''Our Town'' and Mary Martin's ''Peter Pan'' to the new NBC series ''Quantum Leap,'' in which the hero jumps back a couple of decades each week to assume different identities. Anything, it seems, to escape the present. So it should hardly seem surprising that this New Year's Eve at 9 P.M., Channel 13 is reaching back to 1978 for a revival of one of its most successful ''Theater in America'' presentations: Wendy Wasserstein's ''Uncommon Women and Others.''

title: Ames Will Close 15 More Stores
description: Ames Department Stores Inc., still adjusting to its purchase last year of hundreds of stores from the Zayre Corporation, announced it would close 15 stores in February. The retailer said most of the stores are former Zayre stores and 14 of them are in areas where Ames stores will continue to operate. The chain had announced the closing of three other stores on Christmas Eve.

title: Streaking Islanders Take Fifth Straight
description: Pat LaFontaine generates more energy and spends more time on the ice than anyone else on the Islanders.

title: After Noriega: Noriega's Advisor; G.I.'s in Panama Capture Israeli Regarded as Top Noriega Adviser
description: An Israeli widely regarded as Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's closest associate has been seized by United States troops in Panama, a senior American Embassy official said today.

title: Health System Presents Stiff Choices for Dinkins
description: During the mayoral campaign, David N. Dinkins promised improvements in medical care, especially for the poor and people with AIDS.

title: Well, Officer, There Was This Chimney, See, and . . .
description: Anthony Esquilin got stuck in a chimney early yesterday while trying to rob a bodega in the Bronx, the police say.

title: DFSoutheastern Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9-month periods were not available.

title: Quake Conditions in U.S.
description: The geological conditions that produced yesterday's earthquake north of Sydney, Australia, are strikingly similar to those on the East Coast of the United States, according to specialists in earthquake hazards.

title: G.M. Schedules More Job Cuts
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would eliminate 3,200 jobs indefinitely at three plants that build mid-size cars. It was the second announcement of job cuts by the company in as many days.

title: Teams Pay for Fight
description: The Chicago Blackhawks and the Minnesota North Stars engaged in a pregame free-for-all Thursday night that was not free at all. Jane Freer, a spokesman for the National Hockey League, said yesterday that each team would be assessed an automatic $25,000 fine. Player suspensions, she said, could follow next week.

title: Campbell Soup Picks Chief
description: The chairman of the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that the board's first choice to fill the chief executive's job had been accepted but the person's name was not announced.

title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons
description: Drug use inside prisons across the United States has become a major problem with a variety of consequences, including threats to prison order, violence among inmates and corruption of guards and other employees.

title: Abraham Worcel, 51, Biology Professor, Dies
description: Abraham Worcel, a professor of biology at the University of Rochester, died on Wednesday at Genesee Hospital in Rochester. He was 51 years old and lived in Penfield, a suburb of Rochester.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Carlyle Group, Washington D.C., a merchant banking group, completed the previously announced purchase of the Ticketron Sports and Entertainment division from Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, a maker of computer systems. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rescuers in Australia Searching For 8 Trapped in the Earthquake
description: Spotlights illuminated the tangled wreckage of the Workers' Club here tonight as rescue crews continued to search for eight people believed to have been entombed Thursday when the building collapsed during Australia's worst earthquake.

title: Remembering Billy Martin, Battler
description: All around town yesterday, on a cold late December morning, Christmas decorations, still cheery, remained in evidence. Near the corner of Madison and 51st Street, about a block from St. Patrick's Cathedral, the taxi slowed because of a police barricade and heavy traffic.

title: Stallone Sues Broker Over Artworks
description: Sylvester Stallone has sued an art broker for $5 million, saying she led him to pay millions of dollars too much for several artworks.

title: Lodestar Trims Its Stake in ADC
description: The Lodestar Group, a New York-based investment fund that specializes in corporate mergers and acquisitions, has lowered its stake in ADC Telecommunications Inc. to 4.5 percent from 6.4 percent.
