In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lodestar gave no reason for the sale of the ADC shares.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Increase 0.7%
description: The prices received by farmers for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from November to December, leaving the monthly average 2.1 percent above the level of December 1988.

title: Stocks Close Strong Year Witha Gain
description: Stocks rose strongly yesterday in sharply higher trading, capping the Dow Jones industrial average's second best year of the decade in percentage terms.

title: Upheaval in the East: Ceausescu's Hometown; A Community Rushes to Renounce Its Native Son
description: Here in the farming and light-industrial town where Nicolae Ceausescu was born, people want the new Government to change their civic identity. Tomorrow would be none too soon, they say.

title: After Noriega: Catholics; Bishops Are Irked by Criticism on Noriega Refuge
description: Roman Catholic officials in the United States and Panama have reacted sharply over the last several days to criticism of the Vatican for giving Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega refuge in the Vatican mission in Panama.

title: Fan at Rock Concert Killed By the Police, Coroner Rules
description: The death of a college student while in police custody outside a Grateful Dead concert here has been ruled a homicide.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bucharest; As Communist Rule Fades, Rumanian-Soviet Ties Grow
description: After its revolution and the collapse of its Communist Party, Rumania, which was once alone in the Eastern bloc in shunning Moscow's leadership, is now improving its ties to the Soviet Union.

title: Home Thoughts of a Rumanian At a College Haven in the U.S.
description: Last December when Norman Manea was invited to exercise freedom of thought as a writer and a teacher at Bard College, nobody foresaw what would be happening in Eastern Europe.

title: Dinkins Names 3 More Heads Of Departments
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins appointed three more people to his incoming city administration yesterday, naming department heads for aging, employment, and legislative affairs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The index of leading indicators edged up 0.1 percent in November after modestly declining in October, the Commerce Department reported. That was in line with expectations and was seen as a further indication that the nation's sharply slower economic growth is unlikely to deteriorate into a recession. Five of the index's 11 components contributed to the increase, led by a rise in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials. [ 33. ] Farmers received 0.7 percent more for raw products in December than in November, the Agriculture Department said. [ 34. ] The United States is headed for permanent levels of dependence on oil imports higher than those that led to havoc in the 1970's, many experts are saying. [ 33. ] MARKETS Stock prices rose strongly, ending the second-best year of the decade, in percentage terms, for the Dow industrials. The Dow settled at 2,753.20, up 20.90 for the day, 41.81 for the week and 584.63, or 27 percent, for the year. [ 33. ] Treasury note and bond prices were mostly lower, and bill rates were mixed, in the final trading session of a year characterized by gradually rising prices of Treasury and investment-grade corporate debt issues and by declining values of ''junk bonds.'' [ 36. ] Prices of heating-oil futures rebounded to close at a six-year high, and gasoline futures jumped amid signs that moves to produce more heating oil are cutting into gas supplies. [ 41. ] The dollar closed higher in light trading. Gold prices rose, with bullion for current delivery ending at $402.50 an ounce on the Comex. [ 41. ] COMPANIES Antonovich Inc. has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The move by the New York-area fur retailer follows the announcement by a competitor, Fur Vault, that it would sell its unprofitable retail operations. Fur retailers face new competition from foreign companies, like Jindo of Korea, and are under pressure from animal rights groups. [ 33. ] Some airlines are seriously considering raising fares or adding ticket surcharges to offset higher fuel prices, people in the industry say. The moves could come just before the time of year when carriers generally cut their fares. [ 33. ] The City of Chicago plans to terminate its franchise agreement with Commonwealth Edison as of Dec. 31, 1990, the company said. Analysts see the action as a first step in negotiations for a new franchise agreement with the big electric utility. [ 35. ] An Australian court appointed receivers and managers for the Bond Corporation's brewing interests. News reports speculated that the move marks the beginning of the end of Alan Bond's diversified empire, which includes G. Heileman in the U.S. [ 35. ] Campbell's chairman said the first choice to become chief executive had accepted the post. The person's name was not announced. [ 35. ] INTERNATIONAL Many American economists are scrambling to understand how centrally run economies can be transformed into systems dominated by free markets. A lack of expertise on that subject was evident at an annual meeting of economists this week in Atlanta. [ 33. ] Nigeria's oil minister was moved to a new position. Rilwanu Lukman also serves as president of OPEC. [ 34. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Patents for financial instruments are being validated at the Patent and Trademark Office and in court. Established patent law has held that financial products and services, which are ideas rather than inventions, are not eligible for the same patent protection as products. Patents. [ 34. ] Even people who have wills may not have completed an equally important document, a letter of instructions to heirs and executors. Such a letter may list one's assets and liabilities and tell where important papers are kept. Your Money. [ 34. ]

title: Your Money; Heirs Could Use More Than a Will
description: EVEN among the minority of people who have wills, relatively few have completed what can be an equally important document, a letter of instructions to heirs and executors, says Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: AFTER NORIEGA: VATICAN IS BLAMING U.S. FOR IMPASSE ON NORIEGA'S FATE
description: The Vatican blamed the American Government yesterday for the impasse over Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's fate, calling the United States an ''occupying power'' with no right to demand that the ousted dictator be handed over to its forces.

title: Du Pont Selling Blood Test Unit
description: The Chiron Corporation and Ortho Diagnostic Systems Inc., a unit of Johnson & Johnson, said today that they expected to enter an agreement to purchase most of the AIDS and hepatitis blood-screening business of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Chiron said negotiations could be concluded over the weekend.

title: U.S. Indicts 18 in Counterfeit Shoe Scheme
description: A Federal grand jury in Tucson has indicted 18 people to break what the United States Attorney calls a worldwide conspiracy that made and marketed millions of counterfeit name-brand athletic shoes.

title: Tisdale a Part-Owner
description: Wayman Tisdale, a forward with the Sacramento Kings of the National Basketball Association, has bought part of the Oklahoma City Cavalry, a Continental Basketball Association expansion team, the C.B.A. said yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Chevron Unit Fire
description: The Chevron Corporation said its Philadelphia refinery had a fire Thursday that was quickly extinguished by Chevron staff with no injuries. But the refinery's reformer unit has been disabled for six or seven days, the company said. ''The reformer fire will not cut or reduce our ability to make heating oil,'' said Jack Galloway, a Chevron spokesman in Philadelphia. The fire will cut gasoline production by about 25 percent and propane production by about half for the next few days, he said.

title: Conditions for Carriage Horses Improve Some in Holiday Season
description: To the Editor:

title: Rio Journal; Autos Cry for Alcohol; France Will Do Its Part
description: As they set out for summer vacations these days, Brazilian drivers are likely to scan the sea lanes before they scan the highway lanes.

title: Every Day's a Holiday, Almost
description: The end of the year, from Thanksgiving on, is known to Americans as ''the holiday season,'' suggesting that other seasons are not. True, it is definitely super-holiday time. But if the whole truth be known, America is no world-beater in this category. With 11 national holidays, we are merely average. J. P. Morgan & Company's annual World Holiday and Time Guide shows official national observances of something somewhere on all but about 20 days of 1989. Corners of the old British empire took the most time off: Malaysia had 38 holidays; Australia, Sri Lanka and Canada had more than 20.

title: Koch's Last Day at the Office
description: After coping with one last emergency, a fire and a blackout, Edward I. Koch walked out of City Hall for the last time as Mayor yesterday, his tenure virtually at an end. Page 27.

title: N.F.C. Looks Superior On Eve of the Playoffs
description: The last time the Nationals seemed so superior to the Americans, the Baltimore Colts were 18-point favorites to beat the Jets in Super Bowl III. But that was before the rival leagues merged and the Colts switched conferences, and before Joe Namath proved that the American Football League was at least equal to the National Football League.

title: Margaret Grein, a Law Student, Weds
description: Margaret Grein,A Law Student,Becomes a Bride The Cathedral of St. John the Divine was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Margaret Allene Grein, a daughter of Bishop and Mrs. Richard F. Grein of New York, and James Arthur Moore, a son of Mrs. James Thomas Rutherford of Denver and Willow Springs, Mo., and the late Robert Lee Moore. The Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the cathedral, performed the Episcopal ceremony, assisted by Canon Joel Gibson.

title: Giants' Johnson Practicing Again
description: In 1988, Damian Johnson, the Giants' starting right offensive guard, suffered back spasms while warming up for the seventh game of the season. He underwent surgery and was gone for the year.

title: Charles F. Scott, 75, Retired Oil Executive
description: Charles F. Scott, a retired executive of the Mobil Oil Corporation, died Wednesday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Wolfpack Holds Off the Pirates
description: As experts discussed the looming battle between Seton Hall and North Carolina State in the ECAC Holiday Festival championship game this week, nearly all the attention focused on a battle of the back courts. How would Seton Hall stop Chris Corchiani and Rodney Monroe? How would State stop Terry Dehere and Oliver Taylor?

title: Marijuana McCarthyism
description: LEAD: Joseph Hoberman grows orchids for a hobby. On Oct. 25, he was tending them when four cars stopped in front of his home.

title: Worrying Anew Over Oil Imports
description: After a long period of complacency during which American reliance on foreign oil fell sharply and the price dived to under $10 a barrel, the United States is now headed for permanent levels of dependence on imports that are higher than those that led to havoc in the 1970's, many specialists say.

title: Poland's Senate Votes To Overhaul Economy
description: The Polish Senate approved a landmark economic package yesterday that should place Poland far in front of other Eastern bloc nations in moving from Communism to capitalism.

title: Penn St. Holds Off B.Y.U.
description: On an evening filled with offense, the Penn State defense came up with two critical plays at the end as the Nittany Lions held off Brigham Young for a 50-39 victory tonight in the Sea World Holiday Bowl at Jack Murphy Stadium.

title: Koch Takes His Leave From City Hall
description: Edward I. Koch walked out of City Hall for the last time as mayor yesterday, his passionate and sometimes obstreperous tenure as New York City's chief executive virtually at an end.

title: Philosophers Hang Out The Shingle
description: Following the example of psychotherapists, Dutch philosophers are opening private practices and charging clients up to $50 an hour to discuss ideas.

title: 4 Grisly Killings Fuel Terror in a Hamlet
description: Only a few miles away from Ithaca and the Cornell University campus, lies Ellis Hollow, a picturesque rural hamlet that has long attracted academics, professionals and successful executives like Tony Harris, a sales manager for a national electronics distributor.

title: Bridge
description: In the early years of contract bridge, 60 years ago, two-over-one suit responses were not forcing, and there was some argument about one-over-one. In one restricted area the non-forcing two-over-one has recently made a comeback.

title: Bond Brewing Group Put in Receivership
description: The Supreme Court of the state of Victoria today appointed receivers and managers for brewing interests held by the Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia.

title: Arson Fire Damages Clinic
description: A fire that the authorities attributed to arson heavily damaged a Planned Parenthood clinic here early today. There were no injuries. The clinic does not provide abortions. Patty Brous, director of development for Planned Parenthood of Kansas City, said there had been several recent acts of vandalism against the clinic. The clinic offers family planning services, birth control, pregnancy tests and treatment for sexual diseases.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland; Polish Senate Approves Program to Introduce Market Forces to Economy
description: The Polish Senate today approved a package of economic changes that should place Poland far in front of other Eastern European nations in moving from Communism to capitalism.

title: Treasury Note and Bond Prices Dip
description: Treasury note and bond prices were mostly lower and bill rates mixed yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday session that ended a year characterized by gradually rising prices of Treasury and many investment-grade corporate debt issues and by declining values of many high-yielding ''junk bonds.''

title: Corrections
description: The On Stage column in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect starting date for Eric Bogosian's ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll'' at the Orpheum Theater. Performances begin Jan. 30 and continue for 12 weeks; the official opening is Feb. 8.

title: Dr. Milton Grand, 85, Pediatrician, Is Dead
description: Dr. Milton J. Grand, a member of the senior pediatrics staff at Montefiore Medical Center, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack Monday night. He was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Furrier Antonovich in Bankruptcy Filing
description: The memorable ''Ahhh Antonovich'' broadcasting advertisements will continue for now, but Antonovich Inc., one of the largest retailers of furs in the New York metropolitan area, has run into serious financial difficulty and has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Advice for Dinkins: Focus on Drug Crisis
description: Days before David N. Dinkins takes over as mayor, New Yorkers are eager to have his administration overhaul the city's schools and house and heal its poor. But more than anything else, they want him to treat its addicts and make its streets safe.

title: Births of Loved Ones Inspire Gifts to Neediest
description: ''Forty-four years ago today our first child, a son, was born,'' began the letter written last Thursday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund by Elaine and Ernest Alson of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Spencer Brown, Poet And Ex-Principal, 80
description: Spencer Brown, a poet and former principal of the Fieldston School, died of cancer of the kidneys on Tuesday at the Skyview Nursing Home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 80 years old and had lived for many years in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth Howard Weds Mark Stock at West Point
description: Elizabeth Ann Howard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Howard of Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Second Lieut. Mark Lincoln Stock, a son of Maj. and Mrs. Ronald Paul Stock of Baitesville, Ind. The Rev. Robert Drummond performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: J. O. Patterson Sr., 77, A Top Church Official
description: Presiding Bishop J. O. Patterson Sr. of the Church of God in Christ, who retired this year in failing health, died at William F. Bowld Hospital here today. He was 77 years old.

title: New Economic Puzzle: East Bloc
description: The upheaval in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe has many American economists scrambling to understand the biggest issue in economics today: how to transform a centrally run economy into one dominated by free markets.

title: Moyniham Wants Repea; of Tax Rise
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York today called for repeal of a scheduled increase in the Social Security payroll tax, terming it regressive and unfair.

title: Sam Morgenstern, Composer, 83
description: Sam Morgenstern, a composer, conductor and musicologist, died on Dec. 22 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Pittsburgh Appeal Against Menorah
description: The Supreme Court has rejected an emergency request by the City of Pittsburgh for authority to bar a large menorah from the steps of the City-County Building.

title: Phones Become Easier For the Disabled to Use
description: Holidays can be especially frustrating for people who have difficulty using the telephone and therefore cannot enjoy the greetings of distant relatives and other well-wishers. But now there are more high-tech devices and services available to help the disabled and the elderly get the most out of their telephones.

title: Alexander Ellis 2d, President's Brother-in-Law, 67
description: Alexander Ellis 2d, the brother-in-law of President Bush and a prominent businessman here, died Friday of a stroke. He was 67 years old.

title: Pursue Peace, Not Just Elections
description: In January, the U.S. Secretary of State and the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers will meet in Washington to discuss how to form a Palestinian delegation to meet with Israel. If all goes well, these ministers, along with the Palestinians agreed upon in Washington, will all meet in Cairo to discuss procedures for holding West Bank and Gaza elections to choose representatives to negotiate with Israel for interim self-government.

title: Stranded in Darkness, Thousands Had to Wait
description: In some parts of the city, residents lined up to go into grocery stores one at a time beside employees who held flashlights and showed the way. Some paid $2 for a single candle. Others double-locked their doors at home, afraid of going out at all.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Troops Entered Envoy's Residence, Nicaragua Charges
description: Nicaragua's Ambassador to Panama said United States troops searched his residence on Friday, and the Nicaraguan Government responded by ordering 120 American diplomats and embassy workers to leave Nicaragua.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-10 The Vatican blamed Washington for the impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Noriega, calling the United States an ''occupying power'' with no right to demand that he be handed over to its forces. Page 1 U.S. troops searched the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in Panama City for two hours. In retaliation, President Daniel Ortega has ordered 120 U.S. Embassy workers to leave Nicaragua. 1 The body of an American in Panama was exhumed from a common grave. The victim, a long-time resident of Panama, was abducted by armed men the night of the U.S. invasion. 6 Reporter's Notebook: Blasting rock'n'roll at Gen. Noriega 6 Deal reached on Panama's U.N. seat; invasion is condemned 6 The toll of the ''terror'' in Timisoara, the city where the Rumanian revolution began, appears to have been far lower than the thousands claimed at first, but the fear was not. 1 Ties between Rumania and Moscow are now improving after a long chill. Unlike the changes in other Eastern Europe countries, the Rumanian revolution has been missing an anti-Soviet component. 8 In Nicolae Ceausescu's birthplace, residents want to change the city's name from Scornicesti to Liberty to erase its connection to the deposed and executed dictator. 8 Vaclav Havel was elected President of Czechoslovakia by the National Assembly. Mr. Havel insisted he would serve only until free parliamentary elections are held next year. 1 Man in the News: Vaclav Havel, the playwright and human rights campaigner who is Prague's first non-Communist President since 1948, was reviled by the Government as an enemy of socialism just two months ago. 10 Major economic reforms for Poland were approved by the Polish Senate after a heated debate over the pain the program would inflict on the Polish people. The plan ends price controls and privatize many state-owned companies. 9 Economists are scrambling to grasp the biggest issue in economics today: how to transform the centrally run economies of Eastern Europe into free-market systems. 33 Riots in a Vietnamese refugee camp in Hong Kong erupted as police looking for weapons clashed with stone-throwing refugees who feared they would be forcibly returned to Vietnam. 3 Japan's inquiry of a hydrogen bomb that fell overboard from an American aircraft carrier and sank near Okinawa 24 years ago will be dropped, Tokyo and Washington officials said. 3 A suspension of civil rights in Punjab enacted in 1987 by former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has been repealed by the lower house of the Indian Parliament. 3 Elections for a Lebanese parliament to rival the Government of President Elias Hrawi have been postponed by the rebellious Christian commander, Gen. Michel Aoun. 2 Police and protesters clash at women's march in Jerusalem 2 Pretoria courts skilled East German immigrants 4 National 11-12, 26 Drug use inside America's prisons, which for years has been denied or ignored, has begun creating myriad problems, from controlling inmates' behavior to corrupting prison staffs. 1 A New Year's fad of firing guns in the air is adding new dangers to the celebration. The police in several cities are stepping up efforts to halt the skyward spray of bullets ringing in the New Year. 11 Evidence has linked recent bombings in the South to a series of letters claiming responsibility, Federal investigators said. 11 Civil rights legislation will be pushed during the next session of Congress by rights groups aiming to reverse recent Supreme Court decisions narrowing protection against employment discrimination. 11 Supreme Court rejects Pittsburgh appeal against Menorah 11 A student's death in police custody was ruled a homicide by the Los Angeles County coroner. The 19-year-old student died after he was choked while being arrested outside a Grateful Dead concert. 12 Rape victim jailed for failing to go to court 12 An increase in the Social Security tax should be repealed, said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who called the scheduled tax rise regressive and unfair. 12 U.S. scraps rules on conflicts in health research 26 Thornburgh won't pursue disclosure involving Gray 11 Index of leading economic indicators rises 0.1 percent 33 Regional 27-30 A gas main in the Bronx exploded, killing one man and forcing a shutoff of power and subway service in large sections of the Bronx and Manhattan. At least six other people were injured. 1 Stranded in darkness, thousands must wait 29 The macabre slaying of a family in Ellis Hollow, N.Y., has sent a shudder throughout upstate New York. A week after the slaying on Dec. 23, the state police lack a motive and a suspect. 27 Metro-North fares in Connecticut will not rise on Jan. 1 as fares in other Metropolitan Transportation Authority areas, under a compromise that delays improvements. 27 Edward Koch's last day in City Hall as Mayor was spent writing letters, visiting police precincts, taping a television program, hosting an open house at City Hall, and coping with one last emergency: the fire in the Bronx. 27 New Yorkers want David Dinkins to overhaul the city's schools, house its poor, make its streets safe, and most of all, treat its drug addicts. 27 David Dinkins names three more heads of departments 28 An effort to save the income-tax cut scheduled in New York next year is being pressed by business groups around the state, despite appeals from the Cuomo administration. 30 Cuomo grants no clemencies for the first time 30 Furrier Antonovich files for bankruptcy 33 Neediest Cases 30 Business Digest 32 Arts/Entertainment Will Beckett's wishes prevail? 13 Reflections of a Rumanian writer 13 Philosophers take clients 18 Theater: ''The School for Wives'' 17 Music: Carman Moore's ''Magical Circles'' 14 Book: ''Spock on Spock'' 20 Consumer's World 50 All-terrain vehicles remain a safety hazard Telephones are becoming easier for the disabled to use Coping with dry, chapped skin Winterizing your car Guidepost Sports Baseball: Thousands at Martin's funeral 45 Column: Berkow on Martin 45 Football: Fighting words from Holtz 45 Damian Johnson on comeback trail 46 Wild-card games a clue to conference styles 46 Texas Tech seeking respect 47 Peach Bowl coaches enthusiastic 47 Hockey: Devils beat Rangers 45 Sports People 46 Obituaries 31 Abraham Worcel, professor Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 24 Human rights: the hard part Every day's a holiday, almost Bridgeport's hot trash Letters 24 Russell Baker: Thanks to year zero 25 Matei Calinescu, Nicolas Spulber: Charade in Rumania? 25 Abba Eban: Pursue peace, not just elections 25 Barbara Boggs Sigmund: I didn't give myself cancer 25 Peter Gorman: Marijuana McCarthyism 25

title: Fiery Blast Shuts Off Power to Many New Yorkers
description: A natural gas main in the South Bronx exploded in a tower of flames visible across the metropolitan area yesterday, killing two people and forcing a shutoff of power and subway service in large sections of the Bronx and Manhattan throughout the afternoon and early evening.

title: Nigeria Promotes Its Oil Minister
description: Nigeria's oil minister, Rilwanu Lukman, who also serves as OPEC's president, was moved today to a new position within the Nigerian Government in a significant reshuffling of the Cabinet, an official statement said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Suisitna Wins at Aqueduct

title: Thanks To Year Zero
description: For the longest time people didn't know it had been the longest time because they had no sense of time whatever.

title: Dance Troupe to Give Financial Center Show
description: The dance troupe Jamison Project will give a free performance at 6:30 P.M. on Jan. 16 at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, between Vesey and Liberty Streets. The troupe is led by Judith Jamison, who was recently appointed artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Burmese Capture Key Rebel Base
description: Burmese forces backed by more than 800 rounds of mortar fire captured a major base of the Karen rebels on the Thai border today, the Thai police said. Dozens of people were reported killed. The border police said that as many as 3,000 Burmese soldiers fought hundreds of rebels for four days before overrunning the camp at Pa Loo, about 10 miles southwest of the Thai border town of Mae Sot.

title: With Masaryk, Benes Deserves Restoration
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Objects to Ad
description: The White House today expressed disapproval of advertisements for a decongestant featuring President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.

title: Officers Break Up A March In Israel
description: The police fired tear gas, pulled demonstrators by their hair and struck them with night sticks today to break up a peace march in Jerusalem by more than 3,000 Israeli, Palestinian and European women.

title: 2 Ministry Guards Killed in Northern Spain
description: Two civil guards were shot and killed on Thursday in the northern city of Gijon in an attack that the police attribute to a shadowy leftist terrorist group known as the Oct. 1 Anti-Fascist Resistance.

title: HONG KONG POLICE RAID REFUGEE SITE
description: The police raided a Vietnamese refugee camp today and clashed with stone-throwing boat people who reportedly feared that they would be forced to return to their homeland. Officials said 40 people were wounded.

title: Rights Groups Work on Measure To Reverse Court's Bias Rulings
description: Civil rights organizations and their major Congressional allies are putting finishing touches on legislation to reverse recent Supreme Court decisions that have made it harder to show job discrimination and easier to challenge affirmative action programs.

title: Leading Indicators Rise 0.1%
description: The Government index intended to forecast the economy edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in November after a modest October decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An occupying power cannot interfere with the work of a diplomatic mission nor demand that a person seeking asylum in that mission be handed over to it.'' -Joaquin Navarro-Valls, the Vatican spokesman. [ 7:2. ]

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Dec. 9 about a memoir by Zofia S. Kubar, a Holocaust survivor, misstated the title.

title: Allison Weiss Wed to Paul Frentrop
description: Allison C. Weiss, a vice president of international public affairs at American Express in New York, and Paul Marie Louis Frentrop, the senior financial editor of the newspaper NRC Handelsblad in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-el in New York by Rabbi David Posner.

title: Upheaval in the East: The New President - Man in the News; A Master of Irony and Humor, Vaclav Havel
description: ''History has begun to develop very quickly in this country,'' Vaclav Havel said on Nov. 28, the day Czechoslovakia's Communist Government pledged to give up its 41-year monopoly on political power. ''In a country that has had 20 years of timelessness, now we have this fantastic speed.''

title: Rape Victim Jailed for Failing to Go to Court
description: A woman has been jailed here at a prosecutor's request because she failed to appear to testify against the man accused of kidnapping and raping her last June.

title: Mourners Pack Cathedral for Martin's Funeral
description: More than 6,500 people, ranging from former President Richard M. Nixon to a 9-year-old boy wearing a sweatshirt, jacket and cap with Yankee insignia, turned out for Billy Martin's funeral yesterday. More than 3,000 of them jammed St. Patrick's Cathedral for the 70-minute service, and approximately 3,500 stood outside in the cold, jamming the Fifth Avenue sidewalks in front of and across from the church.

title: Hornet Chief Tolerant Of Fans' Booing
description: One day after Kelly Tripucka was brought to tears on the court by constant booing from the home crowd in Charlotte, N.C., Carl Scheer, the Hornets' president and general manager, justified the fans' behavior.

title: Union Pacific Cuts
description: The Union Pacific Railroad, a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation, said 190 management employees had accepted retirement or agreed to leave the company. The move represents a 4.4 percent reduction in the railroad's nonunion personnel, it said. The company's management staff now numbers 4,350, down 27 percent in four years. Since January 1986, the union work force has declined 26 percent, to 25,500 from 34,600.

title: 5 Acquitted in Carrier Protest
description: Five members of Greenpeace, an anti-nuclear group, have been acquitted of mischief by a judge who ruled that the anchoring of a United States Navy vessel, capable of carrying nuclear weapons, off Vancouver was an invitation to protest. The provincial court judge, Wallace Craig, said on Thursday that they were right to protest and that Canadians had been too passive in the past. The five spray-painted peace symbols and the international radiation warning symbol on the aircraft carrier Independence.

title: About New York; Old Acquaintance Will Not Forget Guy Lombardo
description: Another New Year's Eve without Guy Lombardo. It has been 13 years since the ''sweetest music this side of heaven'' rolled from a New York bandstand, then oozed elegantly across a nation's airwaves - an annual serenade to Americans' naive and conflicting notions that each year represents a new beginning, and that nothing changes.

title: In Cradle of Rumanian Revolt, Anger Quickly Overcame Fear
description: On the day after security forces fired the opening shots of Rumania's revolution, Lorin Fortuna, newly tapped as the head of the opposition, met secretly the head of the opposition, met secretly with the Communist Party leader of Timisoara.

title: Gregory R. McNab, 79, Retired G.M. Executive
description: Gregory R. McNab, who retired from General Motors in 1974 as director of distribution outside the United States, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Urban Hazard The police in many cities are stepping up efforts against a New Year's Eve tradition that has turned some neighborhoods into free-fire zones: shooting bullets into the air. Page 11. New Link in Bomb Cases Officials said there was strong evidence that whoever mailed the bombs that killed a judge and a lawyer was responsible for subsequent letters threatening more violence. Page 11. All-Terrain Vehicle Safety Despite court action to protect children, the number killed in accidents on all-terrain vehicles is unchanged.

title: Crew of Freighter Struggles To Keep Ship Afloat in Pacific
description: A Greek freighter's 28 crew members struggled today to keep their 600-foot ship afloat about 800 miles northeast of Hawaii, but the vessel was not in immediate danger of sinking, said the captain of a tanker that came to the rescue.

title: Tokyo Drops Issue of Lost U.S. Bomb
description: Japan has agreed to drop its demand for further information about the circumstances in which a hydrogen bomb fell overboard from an American aircraft carrier 24 years ago off the coast of Okinawa, Japanese and American officials said today.

title: After Noriega;
description: The looting that swept Panama after last week's United States invasion has cost about $10 million in losses at two ports and a free-trade zone, officials say.

title: THORNBURGH ENDS DISCLOSURE INQUIRY
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that he had decided against prosecution or disciplinary action over a news disclosure about a Pennsylavnia Congressman because Justice Department investigators had been unable to find out a great deal about it.

title: With Little to Prove, Syracuse Enjoys Fuss
description: Bobby Dodd, Georgia Tech football coach whose name adorns a football stadium and a street in this city, liked all the fuss and feathers about bowl games. In justifying them, he once said, ''There's never been a bad bowl game.''

title: Washington Activated
description: The Los Angeles Rams activated James Washington, a safety, from injured reserve yesterday for tomorrow's wild-card game against Philadelphia. He has been on injured reserve since hurting a thigh in a game Nov. 5 with Minnesota.(AP)

title: Loans Finance Iraqi Agriculture Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: Beckett's Plays: Can His Fiat Last?
description: Even as his friends and admirers acknowledged the enduring legacy of Samuel Beckett, several wondered if the death of the playwright would lead to the liberation or the distortion of his work. There may be dissension among diverse keepers of the flame.

title: No Cuomo Clemencies, for First Time
description: For the first time in his seven years in office, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has declined to grant clemency to any of the hundreds of state prison inmates who petitioned him for early release.

title: Fernandez Picks House on S.I.
description: He is not yet sure when he will move in or how long it will take him to commute to work, but finally, after months of searching, Joseph A. Fernandez, the incoming Schools Chancellor for New York City, has selected a home.

title: Winterizing Your Car
description: The recent spell of bitterly cold weather has been a challenge to car owners.

title: After Noriega: Reporter's Notebook; For Whoever's in Charge, Captain Holds the Fort
description: When troops of the 82d Airborne Division under the command of Col. Renard Marable stormed up a hill to capture Fort Tinajitas on Dec. 20, the armed resistance to them was led by Capt. German Gonzalez Pitti. Within four days, however, Captain Gonzalez was back in the fort behind his own desk, on which his nameplate sits above a plaque reading, ''Blessed Be He Who Brings Peace.''

title: Robert Rosenthal, Library Curator, 63
description: Robert Rosenthal, a curator at the Joseph Regenstein Library of the University of Chicago, died Wednesday in Scotland after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Rosenthal, 63 years old, lived in Chicago and had been visiting friends and booksellers in Scotland.

title: In Rumania, an Old Stalinist Charade?
description: LEAD: Was the execution of Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, a charade to enable the Rumanian Communist Party to preserve its hold on power? It seems, alas, likely.

title: Volvo Trucks
description: Volvo A.B. will make a preliminary decision at the beginning of next year whether to increase its truck production capacity, Sten Langenius, managing director of Volvo's truck division, said. A final decision will be made later in 1990, when the economic oulook becomes clearer, he told the newspaper Goteborgs-Posten. Mr. Langenius said that any eventual increase would mean at least 10,000 more trucks a year and that they were likely to be produced in southern Europe, in a European Community country.

title: Books of The Times; The Making of a Pediatrician and Seeker of Peace
description: Spock on Spock A Memoir of Growing Up With the Century By Benjamin Spock, M.D., and Mary Morgan Illustrated. 282 pages. Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: Coping with Dry, Chapped Skin
description: Frigid temperatures and icy blasts of wind punish skin outdoors, while indoors, dry, heated air makes things worse. When moisture is stripped away, skin becomes dry and chapped.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is New Year's Day. Tomorrow night, starting at 7, Times Square will be closed to traffic. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Only the main office, at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, will be open. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No pickup, recycling, or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on holiday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks, Schools: Closed. Transportation: Buses and trains on Sunday schedule. Extra trains and buses Sunday evening. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks, Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria; Turks Win Right to Use the Muslim Names They Were Forced to Change
description: Bulgarian Turks will be allowed to adopt the Muslim names that they were forced to change in an often violent campaign of assimilation that began in the early 1980's, a senior official announced today.

title: Chicago Puts Its Utility On Notice
description: The City of Chicago may be moving into the corporate takeover business.

title: Author and Actress Are Knight and Dame
description: A knighthood was bestowed on the author V. S. Naipaul today, and the actress Maggie Smith was made a dame. Another cultural figure on Queen Elizabeth II's semiannual honors list, which is compiled by the Government, was the actor Michael Gambon, who was made a Commander of the British Empire. The Queen carries out the investiture of the honors later.

title: Esiason Bows Out
description: Boomer Esiason, nursing an injured toe, is passing up a chance to play in the Pro Bowl for the second consecutive year. The Cincinnati Bengals' quarterback was also disinclined to play because he believes that quarterbacks are sitting ducks.

title: U.S. Scraps Rules on Conflicts in Health Research
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today scrapped conflict-of-interest guidelines proposed by the National Institutes of Health for recipients of Federal research grants. He said they might impose unnecessary burdens on scientists and jeopardize the United States' pre-eminence in biomedical research.

title: Boater's Body Found in Water
description: The body of a boater swept away in choppy seas on Tuesday while retrieving duck decoys in Raritan Bay was found today 30 feet off the shore of Gunnison Beach here, the state police said. The man was identified as Ronald M. Sikora Jr., 19 years old, of Carteret.

title: Patents; Financial Instruments Protected
description: ONE of the truisms of the financial services industry - that no good idea goes uncopied -may not be true much longer.

title: Magnetic Trains Could Mean Safety Nightmares; Wrong Way to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Fat Substitutes
description: To the Editor:

title: 700 in Montreal At Harvey Burial
description: Doug Harvey, the defensive mainstay of the Montreal Canadiens in the late 1950's and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, was buried today with several of his former teammates in attendance.

title: Virginia Women Top Rutgers in Overtime
description: After the halftime buzzer sounded tonight in the championship game of the Bell Atlantic Holiday tournament, most of the members of the women's basketball teams from Rutgers and Virginia raced across the floor and into their locker rooms at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

title: Review/Music; Sound, Dance and Art Mix To Create 'Magical Circles'
description: Many composers defy categories, but Carman Moore simply treats them with disdain. His sort of all-embracing approach to musical idioms and media used to be called eclectic, he remarked on Thursday evening at the opening performance of his current program with his Skymusic Ensemble at the South Street Theater. ''But this is what we're doing right now,'' he said, ''trying to find a place for all the music in our heads.''

title: Pretoria Encourages Immigration Of Skilled East German Workers
description: The Government is encouraging skilled East Germans to immigrate to South Africa, which has a shortage of skilled labor but has a surplus of unskilled labor.

title: Upheaval in the East Czechoslovakia: Czechoslovakia's Seven Weeks of Drama
description: Nov. 12: Amid the political turmoil sweeping Eastern Europe, Milos Jakes, the Communist Party General Secretary, tells a Communist youth conference that the party will not tolerate street protests or relax control of the country. Nov. 17: In the largest anti-Government rally since 1968, tens of thousands of demonstrators take to the streets of Prague. The protest is crushed by police. Nov. 19: Tens of thousands of Prague protesters denounce police brutality. Opposition groups, including some Communist allies, coalesce into the new Civic Forum and demand the resignation of the Communist leaders responsible for the 1968 invasion. Nov. 20: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Prague demand free elections and the resignations of the hard-line Communist leaders. Protests also break out in other cities. Nov. 24: The Communist leadership, headed by Mr. Jakes, resigns and karel Urbanek, a little-known party official, replaces him as General Secretary. Alexander Dubcek, the party leader during the 1968 Prague Spring, returns triumphantly to the capital and addresses a huge crowd in Wenceslas Square. Nov. 27: Millions of people walk off their jobs and into the streets at midday, bringing Prague and the rest of the country to a standstill. Nov. 28: Responding to opposition demands, a member of the Communist Politburo says free elections could be held within a year. A few hours later, Parliament carries out a Government promise to the opposition to strip the Constitution of language giving the Communist Party the dominant role in society. Dec. 1: The new Politburo of the Communist Party declares that the Soviet-led invasion that ended the Prague Spring of 1968 was wrong. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union acknowledges that the Czechoslovak liberalization movement of 1968 resulted from a yearning for democracy. Dec. 3: A new Cabinet that includes non-Communists for the first time in 21 years is named but is rejected by the opposition. Dec. 7: Ladislav Adamec resigns as Prime Minister and is replaced by his relatively unknown 43-year-old deputy, Marian Calfa. Dec. 10: The first Cabinet in 41 years without a Communist majority is sworn in by President Gustav Husak, the Communist hard-liner, who immediately resigns. Dec. 14: The new Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, a former leading dissident, declares that the agreement under which Soviet troops are stationed in Czechoslovakia is invalid because it was concluded under duress. Dec. 28: Mr. Dubcek is elected chairman of Parliament. Dec. 29: Parliament elects Vaclav Havel, the playwright and opposition leader, President of Czechoslovakia.

title: M.T.A. Yields on Connecticut Fare, but Will Trim Plans for Repairs
description: Connecticut and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad agreed today on a compromise that will keep fares unchanged on the Connecticut portion of the New Haven line with no cuts in train service.

title: Drug Smuggler Seized By Colombian Troops
description: Colombian Army troops today seized a suspected drug smuggler described as the fifth most important man in the Medellin cocaine cartel, the police said.

title: Upheaval in the East Czechoslovakia: Havel, Long Prague's Prisoner, Elected President
description: Vaclav Havel, the Czechoslovak writer whose insistence on speaking the truth about repression in his country repeatedly cost him his freedom over the last 21 years, was elected President by Parliament today in an event celebrated by the throng outside the chamber as the redemption of their freedom.

title: I Didn't Give Myself Cancer
description: LEAD: What ever happened to the tragic sense of life?

title: Airlines May Add Charge To Counter Fuel Cost Jump
description: Some airlines, including Trans World and Continental, are seriously considering raising fares or adding a surcharge to tickets to offset a sharp increase in fuel prices, people in the industry said yesterday.

title: In Cities, One More Hazard On Dec. 31: Falling Bullets
description: To the usual urban New Year's hazards of drunken drivers and hangovers add another: bullets raining from the sky.

title: Businesses Press Cuomo to Keep Income-Tax Cut Set for Next Year
description: Despite appeals from the Cuomo administration, business groups across New York State are preparing for a high-pressure campaign to save the income-tax cut scheduled for next year.

title: Retired Police Officer Killed As Jewelry Store is Robbed
description: A retired police officer, working in a Brooklyn jewelry store, was killed yesterday by a robber, the police said.

title: INDIA HOUSE VOTES TO RESTORE RIGHTS
description: The Indian Parliament voted today to repeal a widely criticized constitutional amendment that allowed the suspension of civil rights in Punjab state.

title: Controversy Stirred By Holtz's Pep Talk
description: The contradictions between the profusely complimentary public posture that Lou Holtz, Notre Dame's football coach, often holds toward opponents and his private observations have become a focal point of the upcoming Orange Bowl meeting with top-ranked Colorado.

title: Turgeon's Tie Breaker Extends Rangers' Fade
description: For the Devils, speed was at the top of their wish list during the off season, so Sylvain Turgeon was not a surprising acquisition. He had speed in his legs and wrists, a combination that can turn games around in a hurry.

title: New Evidence on Bombings in South
description: Federal investigators said today that evidence strongly indicates that the person or group whose bombs killed a Federal judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Georgia is also behind a subsequent series of letters claiming responsibility for the bombings and threatening further violence.

title: Magnetic Trains Could Mean Safety Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Rights: Now the Hard Part
description: The cause of human rights came triumphantly of age in the liberating 1980's. The decade began with the collapse of military rule in much of Latin America and ended with the toppling of one-party absolutism in Eastern Europe. Seemingly impregnable tyrannies were humbled by ordinary people who risked their skins demanding fundamental rights. Their voices could only be stilled by brute force, as in China, and sometimes even force was not enough, as in Rumania.

title: After Noriega: United Nations; Deal Is Reached at U.N. on Panama Seat as Invasion Is Condemned
description: A representative of the Government of President Guillermo Endara of Panama was given only a limited right to speak at the United Nations today as a resolution criticizing the American invasion was approved as expected.

title: Review/Theater; 'School for Wives,' Insurance Against Cuckoldry
description: The word ''chauvinist'' dates only to the Napoleonic era, but the literary prototype, at least for the male porcine variety, certainly goes back to Moliere and his hapless, manipulating would-be husband Arnolphe in ''The School for Wives.''

title: After Noriega: Panama City; U.S. Reported to Find Body Of an Abducted American
description: A body exhumed from a common grave today has been tentatively identified as that of a longtime American resident of Panama who was abducted from his house by armed men the night of the United States invasion, American officials said.

title: Cooper Union to Show Works of Alumni
description: ''The Dream Continues,'' an exhibition of art by black and Hispanic alumni of Cooper Union, will go on view Jan. 16 at the school, 7 East Seventh Street. Paintings, drawings, sculpture and photographs are included in the show.

title: Lebanese General Postpones His Plan for a Rival Parliament
description: The rebellious Christian commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, said today that he was putting off elections for a Parliament to rival that of the Government of President Elias Hrawi.

title: Pact at Pimlico
description: Union workers at the Pimlico and Laurel race tracks voted today to accept the five-year contract they had rejected a week ago, averting a strike Monday. The contract covers about 660 parimutuel clerks, guards, parking-lot workers, admissions personnel, jockeys' room valets and the starting-gate crew.

title: Surgery Idles Langway
description: Rod Langway, defenseman for Washington, will be lost to the Capitals for four to six weeks after surgery Thursday to repair damage to both knees, team officials said yesterday. Langway was injured in the second period of last Saturday's game against the Rangers.(AP)

title: All-Terrain Vechicles: Still a Safety Hazard
description: Nearly two years after the birth of an elaborate plan to reduce deaths involving all-terrain vehicles, the number of youngsters being killed in such accidents is little changed.

title: Letter: On Drug Abuse; Imprison Addicts, for the Children's Sake
description: To the Editor:

title: Protozoa Infections Are America's Secret Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Heck's in Deal With Jordache
description: Unable to turn a profit despite emerging from Federal bankruptcy court protection, Heck's Inc. announced plans to sell its retail operations, consisting of 55 discount stores in six states, to New York-based Jordache Enterprises Inc.Heck's is essentially giving away its retailers to a subsidiary of Jordache, which will assume the chain's debts and long-term obligations, said Maartan Hemsley, Heck's chief operating officer.

title: The Perfect Party Food
description: Shrimp are America's favorite shellfish. And they make wonderful hors d'oeuvres at parties on New Year's Eve or any other time. Caterers say guests consume twice as many shrimp as any other cocktail food. Virtually all shrimp in markets have been frozen and are sold thawed. They are graded according to size or number of pieces per pound. The larger the shrimp, the higher the price. The flavor varies; a strong iodine taste can be caused by the shrimp's diet or a lack of freshness. Shrimp should be cooked very briefly. They are done as soon as the flesh turns opaque, often less than a minute after being placed in boiling water. Cooking them in salty water will give them better flavor. Here is a guide to how much to buy: $ Size Shrimp per pound Price Small 40 to 60 $6 to $8 Medium 31 to 40 $10 Large 21 to 30 $12 Extra Large 15 to 20 $15 Jumbo 10 to 14 $17 to $20 Giant prawn 3 to 9 $20 to $25

title: Herman Short, Ex-Police Chief, 71
description: Herman Short, a former Houston Police Chief, died of a heart attack in Houston on Thursday. He was 71 years old.

title: Bridgeport's Hot Trash
description: How best to reduce the solid waste that is burying the nation? The windy debates have produced two choices: recycling and ''resource recovery,'' or incineration to produce electric power. A relatively new plant in Bridgeport, Conn., makes clear that resource recovery has a strong future.

title: Toasting 1990 With a Sip, But Just a Sip
description: TONIGHT, when guests arrive at the Stamford home of Debbie and Samir Ansary for a black-tie New Year's Eve party, the couple will ask them who the designated driver is. Not that the couple has anything to worry about, said Mrs. Ansary, who expects about 50 people to show up; for the last few years, consumption of alcoholic beverages has decreased dramatically at all their holiday parties.

title: Britain's Closest Call
description: THE BATTLE OF BRITAIN The Greatest Air Battle of World War II. By Richard Hough and Denis Richards. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: Refining Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion; A 1990's Spin on the Neckwear of the 40's
description: Odd new neckties are finding their way into the men's-wear stream. Short and stubby, they look as if Harpo Marx got to them with his scissors.

title: Not Just a Matter of Matzohs, But of Moroccan and Chinese
description: For decades, kosher restaurants have been part of the New York scene, featuring traditional fare like matzoh balls, chopped chicken liver and lox. But within the last few years, kosher pizza and falafel eateries have proliferated, as have upscale restaurants offering kosher cuisines like French, Moroccan and Chinese. While the bulk of them are in New York, Miami and Los Angeles are also well tapped by these newcomers.

title:
GARDENING;
A Regimen for Plants Acquired as Gifts
description: LEAD: ABOUT now you may be wondering how to care for that lovely plant received as a holiday gift. You would like to keep it in good condition, if only to show the person who gave it to you that you really appreciated the gift.

title:
TELEVISION
TV VIEW: The Risks in Going Global
description: LEAD: As entertainment becomes more global - with mergers of publishing, film-production and broadcasting companies into powerful multinational corporations like Time Warner and Sony-Columbia - regional identities, even national identities, are in danger of becoming blurred at the edges, of blending into a homogenized, one-world culture.

title: Splendor in the Grasslands
description: THE ANCIENT CHILD By N. Scott Momaday. 314 pp. New York: Doubleday.

title: Upheaval in the East: Ceausescu's Legacy; In a Dictator's Palace, Lavish Echoes of Power
description: For the last five years, 8,000 workers and 7,000 soldiers toiled each day to build the House of the Republic, a great and solid palace measuring 300 feet from ground to flagpole that was to have been a memorial to a man and his wife - Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu.

title: Eagles Coach Is Eager To Put Rush on Rams
description: If Buddy Ryan is right, the Philadelphia Eagles are a cinch to beat the Los Angeles Rams in the National Football Conference wild-card game on Sunday.

title: ANTIQUES: The 1990's Await What Was New A Century Ago
description: ''Old, not modern'' is how Dr. Johnson defined ''antiques'' in his 18th-century dictionary. In 1930, when United States Customs tackled the question, it came up with the more precise regulation that an antique was a work of art or a handicraft made before 1830, giving rise to the accepted notion that a genuine antique must be 100 years old - at least to pass through Customs duty-free. But old, as this century discovered, is a matter of perspective.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
Financial Planning in a New Year
description: LEAD: Managing your personal finances in the new year requires more thought than simply remembering to write 1990 on your checks instead of 1989. Each year brings another set of complicated changes in taxes and government benefits. Careful planning helps make the most of them.

title: Memorable Meals: A Critic's Choices
description: WHILE 1989 was not a banner year for discovering restaurants rated excellent, there was one clear winner in that league. La Provence (86 Washington Street, South Norwalk, 855-8958) combines a comfortable decor inspired by the south of France, with food to match. The restaurant, operated by two graduates of the Guy Savoy restaurant in Paris, features some of the most original and delicious fare to be found in Connecticut in years. Among especially memorable dishes were a savoy cabbage salad with Roquefort, pecans and bacon; sauteed chicken Moroccan style, and shrimp and sea scallops sauteed with garlic, parsley and petite French green lentils. Desserts were uniformly ambrosial. What makes La Provence all the more remarkable are the moderate prices: a three-course prix-fixe dinner was $17.

title: ART GALLERY VIEW: Egyptian Art Is Alive and Well in the West
description: Contemporary art and Egypt? Contemporary art and African or Oceanic art perhaps. Or Oriental art. Or Latin American art. But Egypt?

title: Helen of Troy Holds Promise
description: LEAD: SALES have climbed sharply at the Helen of Troy Corporation, thanks in part to a generous advertising campaign paid for by the Procter & Gamble Company. No, the consumer products giant has not begun a new kind of charity. Procter & Gamble has simply been spending to promote one of its own product lines, Vidal

title: PattiSue Plumer Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia Sue Plumer, a lawyer who was a member of the United States track team at the 1988 Olympics, was married yesterday to Steven David Levere, a lawyer. The Rev. Frederick Plumer of Irvine, Calif., a minister of the United Church of Christ and the bride's father, and Rabbi Charles Familant performed the ceremony at the Menlo Country Club in Woodside, Calif.

title: Lenore J. Kantor Is a Bride
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., Lenore Jane Kantor and Eric Scott Goldman, 1987 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania, were married last evening. Rabbi Philip Schechter and Cantor Wayne Siet officiated. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. James L. Kantor of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Neil J. Goldman of Englishtown, N.J. The bride, 24 years old, will keep her name. She is the assistant to the directors of administration and human resources at the 92d Street Y. Mr. Goldman, 24, is a law student at New York University.

title: Next Week; How Should N.C.A.A. Football Champions Be Decided?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Guerrillas' Kidnapping Ring Broken, Brazil Says
description: The Brazilian police say they have broken up an international kidnapping ring that was funneling millions of dollars in ransom money to a leftist Chilean guerrilla group.

title: Few chairs at Swearing-In
description: Twelve thousand invitations, each good for two people, have been sent out for the inauguration of David N. Dinkins tomorrow as New York City Mayor on the steps of City Hall, a spokeswoman for the inaugural committee said yesterday.

title: FILM: 'White Palace' Poses a Question About Love
description: LEAD: You caught me on a day when I'm looking particularly bouffanty,'' says the actress Susan Sarandon, fluffing a headful of loose curls with one hand, reaching for a pack of cigarettes with the other. She pulls one from the pack and lights it - her fourth in 25 minutes.

title: Resolution For 1990: Renew Passport Soon
description: NEED a New Year's resolution? Here's one: Renew your passport first thing. If it expires any time in the coming year, this is a must, but even if it has longer to run, the United States Passport Service says that at this time of year you can get your new passport back by mail in two weeks. Things may not run that speedily again until well into the fall.

title: Con Ed Not Sure What Caused Explosion
description: Consolidated Edison investigators yesterday backed away from the company's original explanation that a backhoe operator caused a natural gas main explosion in the South Bronx on Friday. The explosion, which sent flames roaring hundreds of feet into the sky, killed two people and forced a shut-off of power and subway service in large sections of the Bronx and Manhattan for several hours..

title: DANCE: Reflections on the Wellsprings of Balanchine's 'Serenade'
description: LEAD: THE IMPACT THAT GEORGEJU Balanchine's ballets have had in the Soviet Union is only now beginning to be known in the West. Vadim Gayevsky, a Moscow critic who attended the recent Miami Balanchine Conference, a symposium of American and Soviet scholars, has paid special attention to Balanchine in his writings.

title: Elaine Whitney Wed to J. T. Garber 2d
description: Elaine Eva Whitney, a daughter of Louise N. Whitney of Fairfield, Conn., and Edward A. Whitney of San Diego, was married yesterday in Southport, Conn., to John Tennant Garber 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Garber of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Alastair V. Votaw performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Planning to Build A Neighborhood
description: AS a sculptor and foundryman in this seaside town for the last 16 years, Richard Remsen has seen retired people move in and families and businesses move out, creating what he considers an unnatural and empty environment.

title: A Rekindled Interest in 'Sweet Charity'
description: THE night after ''Sweet Charity'' opened at the Darien Dinner Theater, ''City of Angels'' had its Broadway premiere at the Virginia Theater. What, you may wonder, is the connection?

title: Devils Are Sparked By Turgeon's Speed
description: For the Devils, speed was at the top of their wish list during the off season, so Sylvain Turgeon was not a surprising acquisition. He had speed in his legs and wrists, a combination that can turn games around in a hurry.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Chorus of Disapproval 1989. South Gate. $89.95. 1:39. PG.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Our Man Flint 1966. CBS/Fox. $59.98. 1:47. No rating.

title: Review/Dance; Linked by Chairs, in Dove's 'Vespers'
description: Ulysses Dove's ''Vespers'' drew tumultuous cheers in a performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday night at City Center, and it is easy to see why. Like ''Episodes,'' his new work this season, ''Vespers'' is an explosive dance set to driving percussive music. But the older dance, performed to music by Mikel Rouse, is a purer conscious venture into formalism.

title: Lifestyle: Evening Hours; Coming Out: An Elegant Tradition Endures
description: Fifty-six young women wearing long white dresses and gloves and carrying bouquets of pink and white flowers were introduced to society at the 54th Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 22.

title: The Fluid Grace of Skating, the Many Rigors of Training
description: LEAD: FOR Christopher Fullagar and the hundreds of other youngsters in New Jersey like him, whose days are bounded, in a sense, by the frozen expanse of an ice skating rink, the journey from the first forward swizzle to the triple Axel takes at least 12 years and thousands of dollars. During that time, there are lessons, coaching sessions, jubilant moments and discouraging plateaus, with pulled muscles and bruises part of the territory.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
The Decade Is Dead, Long Live the Past
description: LEAD: I'M not one of those people who think things are better just because they happened when I was younger. Perhaps because I've been a sports fan since I was about 3, I tend to judge things based on performance.

title: The S Stands For Super, But Indy's the Name
description: THE ANNOUNCEMENT RESEMBLES MANY ANother for a major movie on video: On Feb. 1 Paramount will release ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' on VHS ($24.95) and Super-VHS cassette ($39.95) and laser disk ($29.95). One difference, though, is the S-VHS option. Studios seldom offer the format, because it requires a specially equipped VCR and the market is narrow. In fact, Paramount has never before released a film on S-VHS in this country. ''We decided to do this movie in all formats so customers can watch it any way they want,'' says Eric Doctorow, a senior vice president of Paramount.

title: After Noriega; Spaniards Protest G.I. Intrusion in Panama
description: The Spanish news agency issued ''an energetic protest'' tonight with the American authorities over what it said was an intrusion into its offices in Panama by American soldiers there today.

title: Adding Insult
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Officials Warn Of Rabies
description: LEAD: AN outbreak of rabies in Warren and Hunterdon Counties is expected to spread throughout New Jersey, officials of the State Department of Health said.

title: Resolution 339 Is Recalled
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: The Commercial Property column on Dec. 17 about foreign investment in the suburbs misstated the size of the addition to the Royal Executive Office Park for which approval is expected from the village of Rye Brook, N.Y. It is 340,000 square feet.

title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs
description: Drug abuse by junior high and high school students in New York State declined between 1983 and 1988, according to a study released by the State Office of Mental Health.

title: Style Makers; Mark Anderson, Designer
description: Mark Anderson Design made its name in graphics: product packaging and annual reports for Apple Computer; trade-show exhibits for Herman Miller and U S Sprint. Now it is branching out into functional art objects - a chair, a lamp, a toaster - that pay somewhat flippant homage to the principles of architecture and design.

title: Airport Buses
description: To the Editor: Every time I fly to Kennedy International Airport from Los Angeles and ride the Carey bus into Manhattan I go through the same experience Simone Galdfarb described. And finding a taxi in the vicinity of Grand Central Terminal is impossible. I usually end up pulling a very heavy suitcase 10 to 11 blocks before I find an available cab.

title: Taiwan Held Liable in Killing of U.S. Journalist
description: The Government of Taiwan is legally responsible for the acts of a military official who ordered the killing of a Taiwanese-American journalist, a Federal appeals court here has ruled.

title: After Noriega: Nicaraguan Furor; Accounts by U.S. Differ On Search of Residence
description: American military and diplomatic officials today offered contradictory explanations of the origins of Friday night's raid on the Nicaraguan Embassy residence here. Both versions were immediately challenged by Nicaraguan diplomats involved in the incident.

title: Neglected King
description: To the Editor:

title: Work, Women and Men
description: A FEW months ago, I mentioned to some associates that I was thinking about writing an article on why I liked working with women. Men invariably responded with flippancy, raised eyebrows, ribald chuckles or lewd innuendo. Women unhesitatingly gave the topic a serious context. Most wanted a full discussion of the subject right then and there.

title: After Noriega: The Federal Case; U.S. Still Trying to Bolster Indictment
description: The Government has not recovered documents from the invasion of Panama that reveal any smoking gun that would bolster its drug-trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega or lead to new charges, Federal officials say.

title: Alice Smith Plans To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Batterman Smith of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alice Van Buren Smith to Jonathan Bruce Clark, the son of William G. Clark of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Augustus B. Fields 3d of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: Tina Lund Is Married To James von Kreuter
description: Tina Anne Lund and James Alan von Kreuter were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Patrick Mooney. Mrs. von Kreuter, 29 years old, attended New York University and is a model with the Ford Agency in New York. She is the daughter of Ingeborg Wolf Lund of Middle Village, Queens, a trust officer at the Bank of New York, and the late Jens Lund, a Danish sea captain.

title: Anita Carr Plans To W>ed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard D. Carr of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anita Celine Carr, to Jeffrey John Hass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron R. Hass of Sweetwater Oaks, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: Mylene Hodgson Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York, Mylene Sheridan Hodgson was married yesterday to John Talbot Curtis 2d by the Rev. Dorsey W. M. McConnell.

title: OFFICIALS AND WHAT THEY REPRESENT
description: In her article ''Power Lines and Battle Lines'' (Opinion Page, Nov. 5), Amy Handlin asks (Rhetorically, I hope), ''Are not public officials elected to represent the emotions and fears, as much as the tangible needs, of their constituents?'' I cant' help but wonder if she would approve of such responsibilities as they were once manifested, namely, in electing officeholders who played upon the public fears of certain minorities and other ''undesirables'' moving in. I guess that in our more enlightened age, only ''politically correct'' emotions and fears, no matter how groundless they may be, are worthy of consideration. HOWARD HIRSCH Trenton

title: Veteran Actor Finds Niche
description: LEAD: IN 17 years in show business, David Carroll has done it all: Broadway musicals and straight plays, feature films, movies, series guest spots and soap operas on television, even grand opera.

title: No Headline
description: For more than 300 years, the family of Rabindra Ghosh has profited from a unique right bestowed by a Mogul emperor: control of about 40 miles of the Ganges River near here.

title: The Rememberance of Memory Past
description: ''I WALKED 10 steps from my desk to the secretary's and couldn't remember what files I came out for.'' ''I spent 15 minutes finding my car at Westfarms.'' ''Even with two of us, we couldn't think of a co-worker's name.''

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Need for Pristine Places

title: Lifestyle; Not Everyone Makes Resolutions
description: For some people the dawn of the century's final decade is not an occasion for cosmic resolutions or personal soul searching.

title: Headliners; Happy New Year x 500,000
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had better start addressing cards now if he intends to return by next New Year's Day the holiday greetings he was to receive this weekend. James Lawlor of Fairfield, Iowa, said his idea was to send the Soviet President a huge card ''and have everybody in America sign it.'' A busy year later he ended up with an 800-foot-long ''card'' signed by a half-million people. ''I felt the man needed encouragement,'' said Mr. Lawlor (at right, in New York with Yuri P. Chizhik of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations). ''I liked the changes he was making.'' Soviet officials were all for it, and agreed to display the card near the Kremlin. The message to Mr. Gorbachev expressed ''gratitude for your great contribution to world peace.'' One of the signers was Yoko Ono, who wrote, ''One world, one people.'' But not everybody was as serious. Said one from San Diego, ''Hey, Gorby, let's do lunch.''

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today mislabels an exchange rate for Brazil's currency of a year ago. A dollar on Dec. 22, 1988, was equal to 935 old cruzados, not new ones; the new cruzado, equal to 1,000 old cruzados, was not introduced until Jan. 14.

title: The Private Lives of Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Time off. Happy New Year. When It's Icy

title: Study Finds No Cracks in First of 3 U.S. Reactors at Savannah River
description: After months of study, the Energy Department has dismissed the possibility of any cracking in one of the three reactors at the Savannah River nuclear weapons complex in South Carolina. Studies of the two other reactors are planned for next year.

title: THE HATED SEASON
description: I deplore the acts described by Steven Lewis, as do all conscientious hunters. He does a disservice by lumping us together with the unethical few who choose to violate laws and ignore the rights of landowners. I count it a great privilege to receive permission to hunt on private land. The landowners become my friends. I share game with them. I offer to help them if help is needed. I am perfectly at ease parking in their driveways or barnyards.

title:
GARDENING;
A Regimen for Plants Acquired as Gifts
description: LEAD: ABOUT now you may be wondering how to care for that lovely plant received as a holiday gift. You would like to keep it in good condition, if only to show the person who gave it to you that you really appreciated the gift.

title: Charlene Fu Marries
description: Charlene Lin Fu, an Associated Press reporter newly posted to Beijing, and Christen Allan Billing, until recently a reporter for The Trentonian, were married yesterday at Browncroft Baptist Church in Rochester by the Rev. William M. Crawford. The bride, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Y. Fu of Jacksonville, Ill. She is a graduate of Northwestern University. The bridegroom, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anders S. Billing of Morristown, N.J. He will report from Beijing for several newspapers, including USA Today. He is a graduate of the Philadelphia College of Bible and received a master's degree in world religions from Harvard University.

title: Q&A
description: Last-Minute Travel Clubs

title: Offensive Language?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Film Producer Discusses His Niche
description: HE HAD BEEN THE white knight of the British film industry, a relentless if self-appointed crusader invited to cross continents and heal Gomorrah. Today, David Puttnam is once again the outsider. The maverick movie maker who tilted at Hollywood and lost is back home making movies from the same Kensington mews house where he first began nearly two decades ago.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: TWO LIVES, ONE RUSSIA, by Nicholas Daniloff. (Avon, $4.95.) After two weeks in a Soviet prison, the journalist Nicholas Daniloff felt closer to his great-great-grandfather, who was imprisoned in Siberia during the Decembrist uprising of 1825. ''This discursive interwoven narrative fits comfortably the sprawling and interconnected way life unfolds in the Soviet Union,'' Colette Shulman said here in 1988, ''encompassing the whole human experience and obligating one always to live with conflicting ideas and realities.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?

title: The Private Lives of Writers
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
My New Year's and How It Grew
description: LEAD: I LEARNED all about New Year's Eve as a child. It was invented around 1940 by a man named Guy Lombardo, who was in charge of everything (including a Canadian band that played once a year, in New York). It seemed to me then that he dropped a ball from The Times Tower and the year changed. (In prehistoric times, cavemen put down their clubs around Dec.

title: Nets Lose to Pistons, 117-106
description: For three quarters tonight, the Nets looked almost as good as the Detroit Pistons. Then reality set in.

title: The World; As Ideology Recedes, The U.S. Rearranges Its Global Struggles
description: Viewing American foreign policy these days can seem a bit like watching a badly dubbed and poorly edited foreign movie. The actors often seem to be speaking the wrong lines and their actions often seem to be all out of order.

title: STAGE VIEW: An Intimate Look at Beckett the Man
description: Samuel Beckett, who died Dec. 22 at the age of 83, was not only the pre-eminent playwright of his time, he was the most influential of artists. Shaping his drama around his perception of the impermanence of life, he greeted existential absurdities with characteristic humor. His signature brand of uproarious pessimism is represented by the statement made by Nell, the mother encased in an ashcan in ''Endgame'': ''Nothing is funnier than unhappiness.''

title: Minnelli's Musicals Without the Extravagance
description: Though filmed in Technicolor and intended as big-screen extravaganzas, classic Hollywood musicals gain certain advantages on video: the chance to replay favorite songs endlessly, and sometimes to fast-forward past pesky narrative filler. Anyone who can't get to ''Directed by Vincente Minnelli,'' the complete retrospective of his 34 musicals and melodramas now at the Museum of Modern Art through Jan. 28, can find all of the director's best musicals on video.

title: Keeping Marble at Its Lustrous Best
description: MARBLE is durable, but susceptible to soiling, staining and becoming dull. Periodic maintenance will keep it looking its best and prompt action will remove most stains.

title: Nothing Her Highness Can't Handle
description: LEAD: SKELETON-IN-WAITING By Peter Dickinson. 154 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.
