title: TELEVISION TV VIEW: TV Is Not a Medium for Adults. Radio, on the Other Hand,...
description: I SAW my first television in 1932 - a BBC production of Pirandello's play ''The Man With a Flower in His Mouth.'' I have seen a lot of television since, in most of the countries of the world, and have spent three years as a television critic. I am convinced that the future of broadcasting rests with radio.

title: BIRDMEN OF HARLEM
description: What a happy story. I'd love to be there: help carry that big bag of bird feed and be invited some cold day to sit in the lookout room and, perhaps, see a red-eyed vireo. CECILIA LEMIEUY Sharon, Conn.

title: Talking: Appraisals; Lenders Becoming Warier
description: IN the last few months a growing number of appraisals being made by lenders are falling short of the price agreed upon by buyer and seller.

title: The Early Bird Catches the Praise, Too
description: THERE is a tacit agreement among morning people that they are superior to lie-a-beds. Because their feet hit the floor first in the morning, they have a jump on the day and assume an advantage over those who sleep later.

title: Diana and The Diver
description: To the Editor:

title: The Private Life of a Nation Builder
description: THE LABYRINTH OF EXILE A Life of Theodor Herzl. By Ernst Pawel. Illustrated. 554 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: P.L.O. Tries to Block Spread of Lebanese Fighting
description: Guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization took up combat positions in southern Lebanon today to prevent eight days of fighting between rival Shiite militiamen from spilling into areas under Palestinian control.

title: Coach Is Arrested
description: THE coach of the Rockford Lightning has struck again. Charley Rosen, coach of the Continental Basketball Association team, was arrested Friday night after storming out of the locker room and punching his Cedar Rapids counterpart, George Whittaker, whose Silver Bullets scored a 119-98 victory over the Lightning.

title: Loren Hecker to Wed Jeffrey Taufield
description: Wilma K. Hecker of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Loren Celia Hecker, to Jeffrey Zane Taufield, the son of Mrs. Robert S. Taufield of Englishtown, N.J., and the late Mr. Taufield. A March wedding is planned.

title: Protesters Reportedly Expel Communists
description: Angry crowds expelled the Communist Party leadership, police officers and other officials from the Soviet Azerbaijani city of Dzhalilabad after the police fired on protesters, killing one and wounding 150, local journalists said today.

title: The Region; Floria Starts With Support, Confidence and Big Problems
description: James J. Florio has vowed to be a much different Governor of New Jersey than Thomas H. Kean, in management style if not in his policies. But the discussions of changes he hopes to make in the structure and substance of government are likely to be overshadowed by the slowing economy and a looming fiscal crisis.

title: San Francisco Journal; A Place To Leave Your Heart On Nob Hill
description: When the sticky champagne glasses are cleared from the tables New Year's morning and the confetti swept up, the Venetian Room at the Fairmont Hotel will be just a memory, perhaps the last of the famed hotel supper clubs to shut its doors.

title: Mencken's Prejudices Didn't Reflect Baltimore; Pervasive Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: State Office Keeps Busy Preparing Legislation
description: WHILE holiday revelers roam from party to party preparing to ring in the new decade, a dedicated group of civil servants in the Office of Legislative Services in Trenton sit hunched over computer consoles working feverishly to keep the government running smoothly into the new year. For them, the happy New Year's Eves are the odd-numbered ones: when they can join the merrymakers, perhaps take a saved-up vacation day and participate in the holiday cheer. But in even-numbered new years, the weary staff of the office's central management unit is faced with a daunting task: cataloguing, editing, logging, proofreading and printing the barrage of bills and resolutions that are pre-filked by the thousands for early introduction in the next legislative session. ''It's very pressured,'' said Glenn E. Moore 3d, director of central staff for the Legislative Services Office, which has over the years become the backbone of the State Legislature. ''We have bills being drafted for the new session at the same time we are pre-filing bills from the old session.'' Legislation Can Expire

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Disney World Adding Hotels And Shows

title: Printing What Cameras Catch
description: YOU see the image in your camera's window and press the button. The film advances - and there is another scene, moving you to press the button. With the device around your neck, you are a director, an auteur - an imagist with the power to preserve your experience.

title: Confessions of a Soap Opera Extra
description: Andy Warhol was wrong. In my case, at least, fame clocked in at only 6:42 minutes, and that was before the final cut.

title: Daisy Fuller Young, Atlanta Mayor's Mother, 87
description: Daisy Fuller Young, mother of Mayor Andrew Young, died Friday night. She was 87 years old.

title: Prospects; How High for Oil?
description: Frigid temperatures across much of the United States this month sent demand for heating oil soaring, providing a final upward jolt to crude oil prices. Some spot crude traded at prices up 40 percent or more from a year ago. Will these prices hold? Five experts on oil offer their views. Phillip Chisholm Executive director, Petroleum Marketers Association of America, Washington.

title: Mencken's Prejudices Didn't Reflect Baltimore
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORDINGS: The Past Raises Its Voice Once More
description: As early as 1902 singers started putting their art on Mr. Edison's fairly recent (1877) invention, only they recorded on flat disks rather than the cylinders favored by the inventor. It is safe to say that every great singer, and thousands of lesser ones, made records. Eventually their original records disappeared, but they were not lost. For when the LP disk came along in 1948 many record companies that specialized in transferring the vocal art to the new medium jumped into the breach. Nor were pianists and conductors neglected, or jazz, or whatever. And so to the compact disk, and the transfer of old records to the new silver wafer.

title: Economic Vitality Persists
description: LEAD: AS economic indicators go, the eerie emptiness in the B. Altman store on Manhasset's Miracle Mile during the holiday shopping season seemed a portentous signal for the new decade.

title: Fasion: On the Street; The Hottest Look Is Simply Warmth
description: When it's cold, really cold, anything goes.

title: Upheaval in the East: Moldavia; Rumanian Rebellion Inspires Proud Soviet Relatives at the Border
description: The rebellion storming eastward through the Communist bloc with the tolerance of Mikhail S. Gorbachev now glitters just beyond this border town in Soviet Moldavia, a vulnerable edge of his own country grown tinder-dry with nationalist grievance.

title: From Friend to Mysterious Alien Force in 40 Years
description: Things from the late 1940's are suddenly quite interesting, not because baby boomers are nostalgic for a moment that was just before their time but because, as eras end, it is natural to look back at their origins and think about some of the roads not taken.

title: Waving Off The Incense?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gita S. Singh Is Married
description: Gita Stiles Singh and Charles Joseph Whalen Jr., both students at the University of Rochester School of Medicine, were married yesterday at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Rochester by the Rev. Robert Belligotti. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sukthankar Shanti Singh of St. Davids, Pa., and Bombay, India, is a magna cum laude graduate of the University of Delaware. The bridegroom, a son of Cecile Williamson and Charles J. Whalen of Charlton, N.Y., graduated magna cum laude from Siena College.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: ANNAPOLIS, MD.;
Builders Target Older Market
description: LEAD: BUILDERS of a midrise condominium development near here hope to cash in on what they believe is a large market of older well-to-do Washington-area people looking for maintenance-free luxury housing within reasonable distance of the water.

title: China Condemns British Decision To Take In Hong Kong Families
description: China today condemned a British decision to grant full residency rights to 50,000 Hong Kong families, calling it ''a gross violation'' of an agreement between the two countries and threatening to take unspecified retaliatory action.

title: FILM FILM VIEW: Oliver Stone Takes Aim At the Viewer's Viscera
description: THE CROWDS LINING UP AT THE Ziegfeld are liable to be a lot less festive than ordinary holiday moviegoers, even those on their way to see a big film whose star is surely Oscar bait. In fact, they're apt to be experiencing serious apprehension. ''Born on the Fourth of July'' is a film with a painful subject, and it's the work of a director extremely adept at inflicting pain. It's clear that Oliver Stone isn't one to regard moviegoing as a passive experience. Part of his method is to make audiences squirm. Mr. Stone, who sends his actors to boot camp as a means of preparing them to play soldiers, clearly believes in the power of experience to hammer home ideas that might otherwise remain abstract. All of his films, even ''Wall Street'' (with the soul-searching comeuppance it affords Charlie Sheen's ambitious young stockbroker) and certainly the jittery, volatile ''Salvador,'' the frighteningly ominous ''Platoon'' and the vituperative ''Talk Radio,'' are harrowing to watch. And the anxiety they generate in audiences is a significant part of what makes these films work. Mr. Stone presents a visceral experience that greatly overshadows his films' rational side and at times even eclipses it completely.

title: Campus Life: Washington State; After Thefts, Fraternity Faces Stiff Sanctions
description: Kappa Sigma is the oldest nationally chartered fraternity at Washington State University. It scheduled a dance for late October, and it needed some way to decorate its house. So a group of students pledging for membership set out to round up a variety of materials around Pullman that included 50 sheets of plywood, a dozen rolls of tarpaper, five bales of hay, two fake geese and a cement statue of the Virgin Mary.

title: Long Island City
description: To the Editor:

title: Legendary Lunch
description: To the Editor: Over the years I've done quite a lot of high-mountain driving - all but one or two of Europe's most formidable passes - and confess to being scared by any grade close to 30 degrees.

title: Battle by Battle, Inch by Inch
description: THE SECOND WORLD WAR By John Keegan. Illustrated. 608 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95; after Jan. 31, $29.95. THE TIMES ATLAS OF THE SECOND WORLD WAR Edited by John Keegan. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $45; after Jan. 1, $50.

title: Muskets at the Ready, Students Bring History Back to Life
description: THE Union and Confederate troops, their muskets stacked, marched to the regimental dinner two by two, opposing armies celebrating a holiday truce and separated on this day only by tables of brownies, cinnamon buns and pies.

title: CAMPAIGN PUSHED FOR SOBER DRIVERS
description: From Harvard to the Hard Rock Cafe to Hollywood, people concerned about highway deaths on New Year's are promoting the designated driver concept, and researchers say it is catching on, but habits do not change easily.

title: Give Me an 'E'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ohio's 3-Pointers Thwart Fordham
description: Dave Jamerson scored 39 points to lift Ohio University to a 79-73 come-from-behind victory over Fordham tonight in the Volunteer Classic.

title: Margaret A. Schiller Is Wed To Scott Bower in Virginia
description: At the Fairfax (Va.) Presbyterian Church, Margaret Ann Schiller, the daughter of Mrs. Herbert Hans Schiller of Fairfax and the late Mr. Schiller, was married yesterday to Scott Frederick Bower, a son of Mrs. Andrew Daly of Holmdel, N.J., and the late Kenneth Bower. The Rev. Gene Kendall officiated.

title: Toasting the New Year With a Sip, but Just a Sip
description: LEAD: PAINTING the town red on New Year's Eve and reaching the next day for a taste of the hair of the dog is ancient history for most people in Westchester. From the liquor industry to county restaurant owners and insurers, the expectation is that most celebrants will practice moderation tonight and wake up clear-headed tomorrow to talk about it.

title:
DINING OUT;
Above-Average Touches in Italian Fare
description: LEAD: OVER the summer, shoppers at the Essex Green Shopping Center in West Orange watched as workmen transformed the old Gate House across the road into an upscale Italian restaurant. It opened in the fall and is now called Giuseppe Marotta after its owner and host.

title: Robert Mickelson Weds Miss Mazur
description: Paula Ruth Mazur and Robert Philip Mickelson, both independent movie producers in Los Angeles, were married there last evening at the Park Plaza Hotel by Rabbi Barry Cohen. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Mazur of New York. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Mickelson of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: The book that took Harry Devlin 20 years to write, ''Portraits of American Architecture: Monuments to a Romantic Mood, 1830-1920,'' recreates an era when a Classical vision of life, so orderly, so rational and carefully conceived, steadily lost its hold over this country's imagination, giving way to the force of Romantic thought.

title: Review/Music; Alexander Schneider and Strings
description: The annual holiday concerts of the New York String Orchestra under Alexander Schneider celebrate youth and experience. This year's orchestra consisted of 63 players (including winds and a percussionist) between the ages of 15 and 22, assembled for the 81-year-old Mr. Schneider's 11-day seminar. The teaching, one suspects, must somewhat contradict what the students learn at modern academies, just as some of the conductor's interpretive choices depart from current notions of correct period practice. But one also suspects that the opportunity for close contact with this embodiment of an ever more tenuous tradition rooted in the first half of the century will prove invaluable for these students.

title: Q And A
description: Tax on Condominiums Question: How are the real estate taxes on condominium apartments calculated? Should similar apartments in the same building pay the same taxes? . . . K. B., Manhattan Answer: According to Jeffrey Schanback, deputy commissioner for the property division in the city's Department of Finance, when tax apportionment assignments are first made for condominiums, the portion to be paid on each unit is also established. These assignments are based on both the units' representational portion of the entire building and their proportionate share of the building's common areas.

title: A Land Where Innocence Is Forbidden
description: MY HOUSE IS ON FIRE By Ariel Dorfman. Translated by George Shivers with the author. 167 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE NEW YORK TELEPHONE COMPANY;
After a Strike, Putting Things in Order
description: LEAD: THE four-month strike is over, and New York Telephone has a backlog of 5,000 service calls in Westchester. But don't worry, company officials say - this is an outfit that is cool and, indeed, thrives under pressure.

title: Kicker Is Giants' Problem
description: Professional football coaches like players who can block and tackle and run and pass and catch the ball. They do not like kickers because kickers do nothing but kick, and they can miss kicks and they can get hurt.

title: Let's Stop Buying Butchery in El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HATED SEASON
description: Those of us who hunt have become used to the usual caricature of the beer-swilling shoot-at-anything-that-moves trespasser out to terrorize animals and people alike during hunting season (About Men: ''The Hated Season,'' Nov. 26). It's no surprise to find the cartoon resurrected once again by Steven Lewis.

title: Headliners; A Courtroom Battle of Wits
description: It appears the New York State Supreme Court will soon settle the question of whether Vincent (the Chin) Gigante (wearing bathrobe, accompanied by his chauffeur) is suffering delusions of persecution, as his relatives contend, or fear of prosecution, as Federal officials insist. Federal investigators say that Mr. Gigante, who is sometimes seen walking the streets of Greenwich Village wearing a robe and muttering to himself, is the undisputed boss of the Genovese crime family and is faking mental illness to discourage possible indictments. Mr. Gigante's brother, the Rev. Louis Gigante, a South Bronx priest, has asked to be appointed to manage his affairs on the ground that Vincent is mentally incompetent. A psychiatrist retained by the Gigantes said that Vincent ''suffers from hallucinations and delusions of persecution.'' If the court agrees and puts Mr. Gigante's property in his relatives' care, it might be difficult to confiscate his holdings as part of a criminal prosecution. ''This could be a legal move to avoid an indictment,'' said a Federal investigator. ''He's crazy like a fox.'' A court ruling is expected soon.

title: New Orleans
description: In America's No. 1 party town, it's party time once again. But then when is it not?

title: Ideas & Trends; A Decade Ends, And the Nouvelles Of New York Are Not Invited
description: There was a moment in December 1980, when then President-elect Ronald Reagan was kneeling on the floor of Brooke Astor's Park Avenue apartment after one of her important black-tie dinners. He was looking for a diamond earring she had dropped and together they were laughing. It was an oddly glamorous moment, the philanthropist, the President and the lost diamond.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Caribbean islands on Dec. 10 omitted some B.W.I.A. flights from Miami. B.W.I.A. flies daily to Aruba and Curacao and twice a week to Martinique.

title: Automate the Futures Exchanges
description: LAST month former Senator Thomas Eagleton resigned from the board of directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, charging that the exchange is too riddled with cronyism to discipline unethical traders. Mr. Eagleton recommended that the Chicago exchange replace traditional open-outcry trading with an electronic system that leaves an audit trail.

title: Banking's High-Tech Retail Chase
description: IN the battle among banks for retail customers, the victors are likely to be those that use high technology best. So banks are now spending more than $10 billion a year on electronic technology to attract more customers, serve them more efficiently and keep staffs free to sell more profitable products.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow is New Year's Day. Tonight, starting at 7, Times Square will be closed to traffic. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Only the main office, at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, will be open. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No pickup, recycling, or street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and subways on holiday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks, Schools: Closed. Transportation: Buses and trains on Sunday schedule. Extra trains and buses Sunday evening. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks, Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule.

title: Crack Mothers, Crack Babies and Hope
description: Since 1971, a program called Mabon (Mothers and Babies Off Narcotics) has been sheltering and treating drug addicts. Once the residents were trying to beat heroin; today they are trying to beat crack. At the moment there are 20 women and 23 children enrolled in the program run by Odyssey House and located on Wards Island.

title: 12-Round Fights Come Up Short
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Nation; For Some, There's No Aid When the Crops Freeze
description: When everything comes together right, when the Florida sun stays warm, Antonio Francisco can pick 90 buckets of tomatoes a day.

title: Streetscapes: The Kingsbridge Car Barn; Vacant, Outmoded and Nearing the End of the Line
description: EARLY mass transit in New York City consisted of occasional horse-drawn coaches competing with other vehicles on the city streets. By putting coaches on rails, the loads that horse teams could carry was increased, and in 1853 the Third Avenue Rail Road Company laid tracks up Third Avenue.

title: In Short: Fiction
description: LEAD: THE SOUND OF MY VOICE. By Ron Butlin. (Canongate/David & Charles, $16.95.) This brief and very fine first novel by the Scottish poet and short-story writer Ron Butlin tells in expressionistic fashion of the malaise of one Morris Magellan, a British biscuit company executive adrift on a sea of sorrow and alcohol.

title: Julia Robertson and Ian Kasman Wed
description: Julia Marie Robertson and Ian M. Kasman were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Robertson of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mort Kasman and Elke Kasman, both of New York.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: The end of the 1980's prompts a review of the top echelon of American bridge. Almost all the veterans who made their reputations in the 1930's have died, like Waldemar Von Zedwitz, Oswald Jacoby, B. Jay Becker and Richard Frey. Others have retired from tournament playlike Charles Goren and Sam Fry Jr. Only Sam Stayman, a slightly younger octogenarian, continues to compete with concentration, enthusiasm and considerable success. S. Garton Churchill, who has contributed much to the theory of the game, is in his 90th year and makes occasional appearances, as does Easley Blackwood, who is now 86.

title: We Have Socialism, Q.E.D.
description: LEAD: Conventional wisdom these days can be summarized in the form of a syllogism.

title: Campus Life: Missouri; Now, Fraternities Must Check Ages Of Party Guests
description: In October, four fraternity-associated sexual assaults prompted the University of Missouri to suspend the 28 ''little sister'' organizations that had paired their members with fraternity members in rush and fund-raising activities. All of the attacks, the university's police said, were alcohol related.

title: State Lags In Treating Cocaine Addicts
description: FOUR years after crack flooded into New Jersey, state support for drug treatment programs remains oriented primarily toward heroin addiction, and the programs can handle only a fraction of the cocaine and heroin addicts, private health and drug experts say.

title: Nautical Flavor for Mixed Use
description: A new mixed-use development with a nautical motif has been completed in what was once an industrial area in South Norwalk, Conn. Named Windsway, the project comprises 12,000 square feet of office space and 39 rental apartments. It is in one of six so-called enterprise zones created by the state to stimulate renovation and development through tax-abatement incentives.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: To speak of the postal history of Alaska, the next-to-newest state after Hawaii, seems anomalous. But Alaska yields inexpensive pleasures of discovery for the hobbyist.

title: Hermann Oberth, 95, German Rocket Expert
description: Hermann Julius Oberth, a pioneer of the space age who worked with Werner von Braun to help develop Germany's V-2 rocket, died on Friday. He was 95 years old. Mr. Oberth died at a hospital in Nuremberg after a short illness, the Hermann Oberth Museum in Feucht said in a statement.

title: Sarah Slusser Engaged to M. B. Arnold
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Slusser of New York and Windsor, Calif., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Ann Slusser and Matthew Baylor Arnold, a son of Dr. Mary B. Arnold of Barrington, R.I., and the late Dr. John H. Arnold.

title: Life on the Couch
description: SLEEPING ARRANGEMENTS By Laura Cunningham. 195 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Carl C. Hoss Is Wed To Marcia Ann Casey
description: Marcia Ann Casey and Carl C. Hoss were married last evening at the Old North Church in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Golledge, assisted by Canon Jonathan F. Young, performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Hoss is the daughter of Mrs. James P. Casey of Bristol, Conn., and the late Mr. Casey, a former Mayor of Bristol.

title: Reducing Infant Mortality
description: CONCERNS over high infant mortality rates among high-risk populations on Long Island have prompted Nassau and Suffolk Counties to begin more aggressive campaigns to investigate and reduce the causes of such deaths.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THREE KINGS DAY

title: Sustaining a New Year's Eve Tradition
description: I NEVER wonder where I will be on New Year's Eve. As long as my friend Beverly has New Year's Eve parties, I'll be there. Her parties are the most luxurious highlights of my social calendar. But this year I will be smarter. I am ready to have a great time without eating myself silly and waking up in the morning without my self-respect.

title: A Neighborhood Chinese Restaurant
description: FARMINGDALE'S Lotus Garden is the neighborhood Chinese restaurant I would most like to have in my neighborhood.

title: U.S. Reversal on Israeli's Arrest
description: An official said his disclosure of the arrest of a man identified as the top Noriega aide appeared to have been based on erroneous data. Page 6.

title: Shifting the Focus at B-Schools
description: FOR the deans of the nation's graduate schools of business, the 1980's presented its share of challenges. Enrollments grew rapidly, bringing on intense competition for professors in fields like accounting and finance. And business schools began rethinking their curriculums amid a growing awareness that American business, once dominant in the world, has tough new competition from overseas.

title: Results Plus
description: Track and Field Coghlan Wins Two Races: Eamonn Coghlan, saying he was running to stay in shape, not for serious competition, won two races yesterday in the Manufacturers Hanover New Year's Classic in the Army field house at West Point, N.Y. Coghlan, the former Irish Olympian who set the world indoor mile record at 3 minutes 49.78 seconds in 1983, took the two-mile run in 8:53.15. A couple of hours later, he returned to the track to win the 1,500-meter run in 3:54.63.

title: Palmy Days At a Hideaway In Morocco
description: THE entrance to the Gazelle d'Or, the old converted hunting lodge of Baron Jean Pellenc in Taroudant, southwestern Morocco, is a long drive lined with whispering eucalyptus trees that bend and touch 30 feet overhead. The road passes through a tall wrought-iron gate, its guard in a white djellaba, a hooded overgarment for both men and women. It then winds among tall bamboo to a flowered, circular area in front of the simple hotel doorsteps. Vivid purple and pink bougainvillea spills over the door and forms a welcoming canopy; unglazed clay pots on the steps hold a variety of cactuses.

title: Dr. Suzanne Conzen, Internist, to Wed
description: Dr. Suzanne Daniela Conzen, a resident internist at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, and Dr. Timothy Watkins James, a resident in surgery at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H., plan to marry in May. The engagement was announced by the prospective bride's parents, Salome B. Conzen of New York and Willibald H. Conzen of Verona, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas H. James of Norwich, Vt.

title: Review/Music; Medieval Pageantry in 'Herod' Tale
description: So ancient are the origins of ''Herod and the Innocents'' - the musical church play done this weekend at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine - that its players have not so much re-created an art form as reinvented one. This is actually two music dramas taken from the 13th-century anthology ''The Fleury Playbook'' and grafted together by Frederick Renz's Ensemble for Early Music.

title: Els M. Neukermans to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Armand P. Neukermans of Palo Alto, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Els Maria Neukermans and Peter Standish Paine 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paine Jr. of New York and Willsboro, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: The year 1989 will go down as the one that David Levy lost to a computer. The Scottish international master and computer programmer was flatly crushed 4-0 in his Dec. 11-14 match with the world's most powerful nonhuman chessplayer, Deep Thought, the creation of a team of scientists at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh.

title: FILM: Again, Sidney Lumet Ponders Justice
description: SIDNEY LUMET IS PLAYING A familiar role. He is at work, directing the latest movie in his long and prolific career. He is on his native soil, or, more accurately, native asphalt - the streets of New York, streets that have spawned so many of his films. He is wearing his customary clothes, a work shirt and jeans, and chewing Juicy Fruit gum in the same frenetic way he shoots takes. And once more, he is back in court.

title: In Short: Fiction
description: From Liverpool, With Hysteria ''So this is America,'' Ringo Starr said 25 years ago when several thousand wailing fans greeted the Beatles at Kennedy International Airport. ''They all seem out of their minds.'' A. J. S. Rayl, who has reported on the entertainment industry for a number of publications, and the freelance photographer Curt Gunther, who was lucky enough to tag along with Brian Epstein and his four charges as they crisscrossed this country, have put together BEATLES '64: A Hard Day's Night in America (Doubleday, $24.95), a tribute to Beatlemania in pictures and words. Ms. Rayl's text, closer in spirit to Iron Butterfly's ''In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida'' than to ''I Want to Hold Your Hand,'' rumbles along endlessly as it follows the concert tour from city to city, concentrating on just how many policemen were on hand to protect John, Paul, George and Ringo and just how many girls turned out to maul them. We also get the usual sentimental hooey about the Beatles' helping people forget the assassination of John F. Kennedy (''A new Camelot was rising from the ashes of the old''), when what they really wanted to forget was the music of Frankie Avalon and the Singing Nun. Still, there are Mr. Gunther's photographs. Many of these 150 previously unpublished black-and-white shots catch the boys at their most puckish, clowning around with Fats Domino in New Orleans and with one another everywhere else; a few of the photos, especially one or two of John Lennon, are truly memorable, even haunting. Notable, too, are the pictures of all those teen-age Beatlemaniacs, most of whom managed to look as straitlaced as any Young Republican. But they didn't act like Young Republicans. At the last stop on the tour, a benefit performance in New York City, the crowd hooted Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme as well as the other opening acts. ''Get off the stage!'' the kids shouted. ''We want the Beatles!''

title: After Noriega; Vatican Statement On Noriega Issue
description: Following is the text of the Vatican statement issued today on the former Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, as translated from the Italian by The Associated Press:

title: Cost of Living, Year One
description: A BABY'S first year is a time of joy, learning, love and money. Lots of it. And as more items are created just for baby, and baby-boom parents want their baby to have it all, even more costs are added.

title: Miss Campbell, Editor, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Campbell Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Cushing Campbell, to John Sanford Bouton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Cole Bouton of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Only a Big Cut in the Pentagon Budget Will Do
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: THERE are any number of reasons why our family found itself cooling off in the pastel blue water of a date palm irrigation reservoir in Ghardaia, Algeria, about to drive across the Sahara - too many Foreign Legion films in my youth, the indelible impression ''Lawrence of Arabia'' made on its original release, even the fact that, when we were children, my best friend had a sandbox while I did not. Whatever the case, the great desert called and my wife and two of our three children had humored me in my nomadic impulse.

title: MUSIC MUSIC VIEW: Another Way To Experience An Opera
description: The word ''stink'' often en-ters into operatic conversation, but those who utter that vulgarism usually don't mean it literally.

title: County Challenges Initial Census Figures
description: BETHLEHEM may have been crowded, but Caesar Augustus produced a more accurate count of the population 1,989 years ago than the Census Bureau is likely to achieve in its 1990 count in Westchester.

title: Recalling The High Notes Of 1989
description: IT has been a year for innovation in the county's music world, from a 136-year-old parish getting its first organ - a stunning Moller - to a double performance of ''Siegfried,'' in what is planned to be an annual Wagner festival. But these are just two of the highlights one recalls when looking back upon 1989.

title: Aiming High Under the Big Top
description: IN Europe, the circus is not just something to take your kids to - grown men and the government fight about it passionately in the popular press. So when the Olympics of circus arts is held in Paris every January, the historic Cirque d'Hiver building becomes the hottest spot in the city on a chilly winter weekend. Here under its gaudy Baroque dome, the best young circus artists in the world test themselves in a weeklong competition that can launch a star across the continents.

title: Gift to Neediest Helps a Church Remember the Why of It All
description: There was no shortage last week of Christmas-related donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Iowa Takes 19-0 Lead and Routs North Carolina
description: Franthea Price had 25 points and Iowa scored the first 19 points of the game tonight on the way to a 106-81 victory over North Carolina. By winning, Iowa finished third in the Super Shootout tournament.

title: Style Makers; Henry Fitzhugh, Subway Art Promoter
description: Promoting travel on the London Underground has become an art form for Henry Fitzhugh, a 45-year-old Texan who has lived and worked in Britain for almost 20 years.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Held in Drive-By Killings in Queens
description: Three teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged in the killings of a pregnant woman and an 18-year-old girl in a Queens housing project. The who were killed as the youths tried unsuccessfully to shoot a man with whom they had argued earlier.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Boerum Hill
description: THE serenity of Boerum Hill, a neighborhood lined with Greek Revival, Italianate and early Victorian brownstones, is quite a contrast to the bustle of downtown Brooklyn, just a five-minute walk away. Many residents think of the area as a hidden treasure.

title: Look for a Soviet Troop Withdrawal From Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware of Mailman: $500 Funeral for Dog
description: A dog that was shot by a mailman this week will be buried in a silk-lined casket at the expense of the Postal Service, and the letter carrier has been charged with felony counts that could send him to prison for more than five years.

title: Upheaval in the East: Voices Revived; Long Silenced, Rumanian Artists Break Free
description: Rumanian intellectuals, writers and artists emerged this week after long decades spent in the darkness of the Ceausescu regime, and found themselves groping for words.

title: Inauguration: Pomp, Circumstance and Paychecks
description: When Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins and members of his administration assume office tomorrow, some will be gaining more than just increased prestige and power. Some, including Mr. Dinkins, will be getting significant salary increases.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-17 American troops made a ''screw-up'' when they searched the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in Panama City, President Bush conceded. The Nicaraguan government ordered 20 U.S. diplomats to leave Nicaragua within 72 hours in protest. 1 U.S. versions of search of embassy residence differ 6 U.S. denies it has top Noriega aide 6 Case against Noriega has not been bolstered by the invasion 8 Military analysis: The U.S. invasion of Panama on such a large a scale increased the number of casualties and possibily forfeited the opportunity to seize General Noriega. 1 Rumania's intelligentsia emerged this week from decades spent in the darkness of Ceausescu's shadow and found itself groping for words. 1 In a dictator's palace, lavish echoes of power 14 The Soviet republic of Moldavia appears on the verge of its own rebellion. Moldavians have been closely watching the revolt by their blood kin in Rumania, just over the border #15 Protesters expel Communist leaders from Azerbaijani city 15 News analysis: Poland's reform plan is leading the way among Eastern European nations in the move from Communism to capitalism. The trail- blazing experiment is being closely watched in the West. 14 The East bloc's espionage in the West has not slackened, despite the democratic revolt that has shaken Eastern Europe. 15 Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong detention camps have made plans to resist the next forcible return of boat people to Vietnam by setting fires, using homemade weapons and taking hostages. 16 China condemns British decision to accept Hong Kong families 16 Policeman is your friend, Chinese are told 17 South Korea's former President, Chun Doo Hwan, is to answer questions today about the abuses of power and corruption that marked his repressive eight-year rule. 3 Segregated education in South Africa is being debated again after the disastrous showing this year of black high school seniors, 58 percent of whom failed their final examinations. 3 Trade dispute over wheat imports splits Nigeria and U.S. 9 On the Ganges River, a last waterlord's last stand 11 P.L.O. tries to block spread of Lebanese fighting 12 Jews and Palestinians hold a rally in Jerusalem 13 National 20-23 President Bush's image has changed in his first year in office. He is more complex than he once seemed, showing flaws that were not apparent before and not showing flaws for which he was once disparaged. 1 The threats to the nation's forests include ozone and other natural factors, as well as acid rain. Although acid rain appears to pose a long-term threat, evidence suggests these factors may be more harmful in the short run, scientists say. 1 A proposed ban on disposable diapers is part of a general recycling effort in Vermont that would push mandatory recycling, extend the bottle-deposit law and force newspapers to use partly recycled newsprint. 22 As giants battle for Maine paper mill, a town waits 21 Study finds no cracks in first of reactors at Savannah River 21 Two bald eagles build nest, and Florida project trembles 22 The nation's homicide rate has risen 5 percent during the year, reaching record levels in several major cities. Law-enforcement officials agree that criminal disregard for life seems to be growing. 20 An airplane threatened by terrorists landed uneventfully in Detroit amid media attention and fortress-like security. Northwest Airlines informed ticket holders Thursday of a ''security threat'' against the flight. 20 San Francisco Journal: A hotel's last New Year's Eve 20 D.E.A. refuses to relax restrictions on marijuana 20 Lelyveld succeeds Gelb at The New York Times 21 Taiwan held liable for killing of U.S. journalist 23 Growls and howls as North unleashes classic performance 22 Regional 24-30, 34-35 H.U.D.'s double subsidies for families in New York City have been uncovered. Eager to fill quotas, H.U.D. has given almost $2 million a year to 600 households already subsidized by the city and the state, records show. 1 Mayor-elect David Dinkins' salary, like that of other members of his administration, will go up significantly tomorrow, but whether the city and state need to pay such high salaries is being debated. 30 12,000 invitations, only 6,000 chairs at Dinkins' swearing-in 30 The cause of the gas main explosion in the South Bronx is still under investigation. The explosion killed two men and cut power and subway service in large parts of the Bronx and Manhattan. 24 Two killed, one injured in shooting at a nightclub 26 Two teen-agers arrested in drive-by killings in Queens. 34 Study finds that fewer teen-agers are using drugs 35 New York's anti-smoking law goes into effect tomorrow. 29 Neediest Cases 26 Arts/Reviews 50 Campus Life 39-40 Fashion 46-47 Life Style 41-42 Obituaries 32 Weddings 48-49

title: Tainted Bait
description: To the Editor:

title: Lynn H. Kennedy To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Lynn Haviland Kennedy to Robert Preston Macrae, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Allan Macrae of Short Hills, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Haviland Kennedy of Nyack, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: In Short: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: PRODUCTIVITY AND AMERICAN LEADERSHIP: The Long View. By William J. Baumol, Sue Anne Batey Blackman and Edward N. Wolff. (MIT, $29.95.) Surely one of the sectors to survive the productivity growth slowdown of the past decade has been the one supplying books and articles publicizing the demise of productivity in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last week depicting reported AIDS cases was incorrectly labeled. The numbers were in thousands.

title: A Downtown Cleveland Mall Adjusts to Setback
description: When the BP America headquarters building was completed here in early 1985 on Public Square, the city's center, there was brave talk that a new era in downtown prosperity was beginning.

title: The World; Rumania's Years of Desperation, Days of Relief
description: To the end, Nicolae Ceausescu was uncompromising. Never mind the tide of reform sweeping other Communist countries, he declared.

title: THEATER: A Young Actress Extends Her Reach To the Stars
description: When Fiona Shaw opened as Rosalind in ''As You Like It'' at London's Old Vic last summer, the theater critic Michael Billington wrote in The Guardian that the Irish-born actress ''has a touch of Celtic fairy about her that makes you believe her when she says, 'I have, since I was 3 years old, conversed with a magician.' '' If Miss Shaw, one of Britain's newer leading stage actresses, has not kept counsel with a sprite, then her rise from drama student to star in four short years has been the result of her own particular magic.

title: JEWS JOIN IN RALLY WITH PALESTINIANS
description: In a mood of friendship and good will, at least 15,000 Jews and Palestinians danced, sang, laughed and talked to one another today as they formed a human chain for peace that snaked two and a half miles around the walls of Jerusalem's Old City.

title: Late Kick Wins for Syracuse
description: John Biskup, who wore a big black No. 1 on his white Syracuse jersey, became No. 1 with his coach, Dick MacPherson, in the last minute of the Peach Bowl game today.

title: The Memphis Belle Takes the Air - and Screen - Again
description: It was, says David Puttnam of his first film since he resigned as chairman of Columbia Pictures two years ago, ''very complicated to choreograph.'' For Michael Caton-Jones, it was ''a bit like trying to make Ben Hur with three horses, one of them rather old and sleepy.'' Neither the producer nor the director was greatly exaggerating. You had only to spend a day on that Lincolnshire airfield, watching the shooting of ''Memphis Belle,'' to feel that it might have been easier to organize the Battle of Britain itself.

title: DATA BANK
Suffolk Pondering Golf Courses' Fate
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the fate of two golf courses on the South Fork is still up in the air, they may be aided by a Suffolk County Planning Department report that recommends protecting existing courses and encouraging new ones.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?

title: Flaws in Panama Attack; Critics Cite Civilian Deaths, Noriega Escape And High Rate of Special-Forces Casualties
description: Pentagon officials insist that the American intervention in Panama successfully demonstrated the armed forces' proficiency at airborne operations. But a closer examination of the Panama attack indicates that its large scale increased the number of civilian casualties and possibly forfeited the opportunity to seize Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Panama operation also stirred concern in the United States military over the surprisingly high casualty rate among special operations forces, small clandestine units designed for commando-type operations.

title: Resistance Stirs Among Boat People
description: With the next forcible return of Vietnamese boat people expected within two weeks, Hong Kong officials disclosed today that refugees inside detention camps here have drawn up resistance plans that include setting fires, arming themselves with homemade weapons and taking hostages.

title: Mixed Messages
description: Consistency is not a keystone of the coming year's styles. Quite contrasting ideas will coexist, satisfying the ever-growing eclecticism of fashion followers.

title: 7 People Die in New Zealand As Two Small Planes Collide
description: Two sightseeing planes collided off southern New Zealand today and one crashed, killing seven people on board, according to news reports.

title: New Kosher Products, From Tacos to Tofu
description: YOU don't have to be Jewish to love kosher food. In fact, less than a third of the 6 million consumers who spent about $1.5 billion for kosher products last year were Jewish.

title: Christmas Just Keeps On Going
description: DON'T think that because tomorrow is New Year's Day, Christmas is finally over. The holiday does not end officially until next Sunday, Jan. 6,- which is Twelfth Night, also known as Epiphany. On this day, all decorations must come down in order not to invite bad luck for the coming year.

title: What a Circus!
description: Aw, come on, everybody, lighten up a little. It wasn't that bad. The decade, I mean. You know which one I'm talking about. The one that's going to end tonight. The (shudder, shudder) 80's.

title: H.U.D. Windfall - Subsidies for the Subsidized; In New York, H.U.D.'s Vouchers Pay for Already Cheap Housing
description: The showpiece of the Reagan Administration's housing program was a voucher system, created to give a cash subsidy to poor people so they could choose their own rental housing.

title: Kathleen Farrell To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. James R. Farrell of Oradell, N.J., have made known the April wedding plans of their daughter, Kathleen Adair Farrell, and Mikael Peter Thygesen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Thygesen of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Sludge Visionary
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Patchwork Political Outlets
description: LEAD: IN 1913, a newspaper cartoon captioned ''The First Cubist'' pictured a grandmother stitching a crazy quilt. The image denigrated the paintings of Duchamp, Cezanne and other modernists then on display at the 69th Regiment Armory in New York, implying that avant-garde works were no better than an unsophisticated handicraft.

title: Free-Floating Into the Future
description: LEAD: DISAPPEARING THROUGH THE SKYLIGHT Culture and Technology in the Twentieth Century. By O. B. Hardison Jr. Illustrated. 389 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: Topics of The Times; 'Me' and New York
description: Michael Moore got a taste of Hollywood when he had to search for a distributor to handle his scorching documentary, ''Roger and Me.'' And now he's had a taste of New York.

title: The Region; The Mayor Leaves Several Million Words And More For The Record
description: In the 4,383 days of a tenure that ends at midnight tonight, Mayor Edward I. Koch issued 5,222 news releases. They will be saved of course, part of the nearly 5,000 boxes of Koch papers already at or soon to be deposited in the municipal archives - Fiorello H. La Guardia's papers filled just 600 boxes - and the Mayor's total does not include what must be miles of videotape from the city-owned television station, which recorded his pronouncements with a faithfulness that would have made a commissar blush.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: JOHN PHILLIP JOHNSTON;
Third World is Key to a New World
description: LEAD: BY the year 2000, 100 million children in the third world are expected to die from malnutrition and diseases for which there are known cures - unless something is done. So warns a report recently issued by Unicef - the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland; Warsaw's Economic Plan: Prosperity as Goal, With Freedom to Fail
description: Just as Poland led the way among Eastern European nations in the move to democracy, it is leading the way in abandoning Communist economics in favor of capitalism.

title:
GARDENING;
A Regimen for Plants Acquired as Gifts
description: LEAD: ABOUT now you may be wondering how to care for that lovely plant received as a holiday gift. You would like to keep it in good condition, if only to show the person who gave it to you that you really appreciated the gift.

title: Nightmare in Vichy
description: AN UNCERTAIN HOUR The French, the Germans, the Jews, the Klaus Barbie Trial, and the City of Lyon, 1940-1945. By Ted Morgan. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Arbor House/ William Morrow. $21.95

title: Decline in Car Sales Cuts Towns' Revenues
description: A SHARP decline in car sales coupled with an apparent increase in ''buying down'' is cutting into municipal tax revenues across Connecticut and could result in larger tax increases than expected next year in some towns, municipal officials say.

title: Compensating for Filling In a Wetland
description: A CENTURY of draining and road building, mosquito eradication and waste dumping has reduced the Hackensack Meadowlands to a featureless reed-choked vista that greets motorists driving the northern reaches of the New Jersey Turnpike. Few birds sing, and about the only thing that nests in the once-fertile mud are discarded tires.

title: Day Catfish Hit Jackpot
description: FIFTEEN years ago tonight, Helen and Jimmy Hunter had dinner plans.

title: >Eggnog With Secret Ingredients
description: THE Kobak recipe for 12-step holiday eggnog:

title: What Needs To Be Done?
description: MIDDLE-CLASS NEW YORK IS SLIDING slowly into decline. A novelist friend who spent his whole life on the West Side is thinking Suffolk because his young son is hounded by drug dealers twice a day as he goes back and forth to school. An elderly woman is knocked to the sidewalk on Park Avenue and brutally beaten with a pipe until she surrenders her pocketbook. Women and children in Harlem and Bed-Stuy are shut-ins behind barred windows and locked doors, afraid of the streets and hallways that neighborhood junkies, dealers, prostitutes and pimps have captured as their own territory.

title: Making an Escape and a Discovery
description: THE captors held my husband and me for six years. Like many hostages, we let them into our home unwittingly. Who would have guessed those wide-eyed faces disguised heinous schemes - plans to ransack our drawers, extort candy in check-out lines, vandalize our furniture with crayons and grape juice, and hijack phone conversations with demonic screams?

title: When Justice Goes Wrong
description: JUSTIFIABLE HOMICIDE: Battered Women, Self-Defense, and the Law. By Cynthia K. Gillespie. (Ohio State University, $24.95.) The idea in our law that it is excusable to kill in self-defense goes back to medieval England. The cases that led to the development of the common law on self-defense fell into two classes: there were the highway-robber cases, where an unknown assailant sets upon someone who, in fighting back, kills his attacker; and then there were the barroom brawls, in which a dispute between two men escalates into a dangerous armed battle. Neither scenario has much to do with the realities of life for battered women who kill their husbands - and, as Cynthia Gillespie's analysis in ''Justifiable Homicide: Battered Women, Self-Defense, and the Law'' reveals, neither does the modern-day law under which such killings are judged. For one thing, the law presumes parties who are of roughly the same size and strength. Then, too, in order to encourage honorable manly behavior - no shooting in the back, no guns pulled on unarmed fighters - the law says that killing in self-defense is generally sanctioned only where the killer was in imminent danger of serious bodily harm, where there was no retreat, and where the killer used only as much force as his victim. But as applied to battered women, these rules can be terribly unfair. If a woman has for years been beaten, raped, tortured and threatened by her husband, and he now has his hands around her throat and is choking her, is she justified in picking up a gun and shooting him? In case after case, the courts have said no, and sent her to prison for doing so. Ms. Gillespie has found more than 200 horrifying cases along these lines, each one more gruesome than the last. In most, the women have suffered years of beating, years of serious injuries and years of neglect by the police and family court authorities. It is often painful reading, but Ms. Gillespie's careful research, and her stirring accounts of justice gone wrong, make a strong case for rethinking the law of self-defense.

title: To Get Fiscal Reform, Voters Must Say No
description: This year on Long Island even the wealthiest school districts were not immune from irate and aroused voters. In Hewlett-Woodmere (''In 5 Towns District, a Teacher Impasse,'' Nov. 26), a bond and two budgets were defeated before a reduced budget was finally approved.

title: Faster, The 1980's:When Information Accelerated
description: No decade stands alone. As Thomas Mann observed, ''it is only we mortals who ring bells and fire off pistols'' when the calendar flips from years numbered 80-something to years numbered 90. The Roaring Twenties arose from the roar of war in the preceding decade and collapsed into a roaring depression in the next. So too, the decade now passing spins out in history's continuum. But which strand from the 1980's is dominant?

title: In Short: Fiction
description: LEAD: KARIN. By Margareta Bergman. Translated by Paul Britten Austin. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) Devastated by the suicides of both her anorexic daughter, who has drowned herself, and her husband, who could not cope with the loss, Karin Berggren Holmes retreats into recollections of the past to try to make sense of the present.

title: Low Fat, Low Salt and Microwave-Ready
description: Kosher manufacturers are offering a more elaborate and updated array of products to cater to young Jewish professionals who don't have time to prepare kosher food at home. These consumers ''want a broader range of products to fit their lifestyles,'' said Menachem Lubinsky, president of Lubicom.

title: The Mummy, the Monster And Miss America
description: Followers of our regular Works in Progress feature are aware that, among other things, the Iraqi Government is rebuilding the ancient city of Babylon; that lifesize replicas of Columbus's three ships are under construction in Spain; that Fidel Castro is restoring Havana's Hotel Nacional to the flamboyance of its heyday in the 1920's; that a stadium in Barcelona is having its floor lowered in preparation for the 1992 summer Olympics, and that a company in California has finished a prototype for a personal aircraft that some of us may own in the next century. To judge by the evidence, it seems true that, bit by bit, the world as we know it is being renovated. The past is being reinvented, even as the present is being improved upon and the future is being imagined.

title: Two Bald Eagles Build Nest, And Florida Project Trembles
description: The fate of a proposed $75 million hazardous waste processing plant near here has been put into question by the discovery of a pair of bald eagles that began building a nest on the site last week.

title: POP VIEW: Private Codes Enliven Jazz
description: The music at The Vil-lage Vanguard a few weeks ago seemed normal, at first. Branford Marsalis, sounding mostly like John Coltrane, but throwing bits of Sonny Stitt and Sonny Rollins, Wayne Shorter and Lester Young into his saxophone improvisations, worked in front of a standard rhythm section of piano, bass and drums. It was obviously mainstream jazz: lightly amplified, the group improvised with preset chord structures, defined solo orders and a whole set of rules for the solos. The bass walked when it was supposed to, the drums played a supporting role for the most part, all the musicians swung; the whole thing took place in a famous jazz club.

title: Fashion; Two New Stores That Cruise Fashion's Fast Lane
description: One shop has a faux French accent and the other a real Spanish one, but they both speak the same fashion language. It's a language understood by young fashion followers on a budget who nonetheless change their clothes as often as the color of their lipstick. Two new boutiques on Lexington Avenue within a block of each other are now vying for these young women constantly seeking out the latest trend.

title: Dr. Bari Brandt Is Engaged to Dr. Lee Gonshor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Brandt of Woodbridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Bari Michele Brandt, to Dr. Lee Gonshor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Gonshor of Dresher, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title:
Campus Life: Wisconsin;
University Ends Brothers' Venture In Condom Sales
description: LEAD: For two years, entrepreneurs in Madison had been selling condoms packaged in an envelope bearing a likeness of the Bucky Badger mascot of the University of Wisconsin. But the product came to the attention of university officials only after two of their students from Waukesha, Wis., bought the ''Get Lucky

title: Polly Cronyn Parrott, Editor, 79
description: Polly Cronyn Parrott, a former editor at The New York Herald Tribune died at her home in Plandome, L.I., on Thursday. She was 79 years old.

title: RECORDINGS: At Home in the Top 40 And Still Full of Kitsch
description: It's taken 10 years for the imes to catch up with the B-52's. With the Top 10 successes of their seventh album, ''Cosmic Thing'' (Reprise 9 25854, all three formats) and its hit single ''Love Shack,'' the group has finally moved beyond cult status. The B-52's were always popular on college radio stations, but from the perspective of the early-80's mainstream, the group was a novelty act, at once studiously retro and unnervingly futuristic.

title: Commodity Prices Spurred by Cold
description: Cold weather drove prices up sharply for several commodities last week. Futures contracts for heating oil reached six-year highs, peaking at $1.02 a gallon before profit taking caused declines at week's end. In November, heating oil futures sold for slightly less than 60 cents a gallon. An explosion that shut down the nation's second-largest refinery, an Exxon complex in Louisiana, added to the upward pressure. The record-breaking cold extended into Florida and south Texas, damaging winter crops of fruit and vegetables. Orange juice futures rose to $1.65 a pound; the previous week they had traded around $1.25. The Brazilian authorities pushed prices up further when they said they were suspending orange juice exports while they assessed the price situation.

title: Mencken's Prejudices Didn't Reflect Baltimore; Monstrous Then Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Growls and Howls As North Narrates 'Peter and the Wolf'
description: Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide convicted of three charges in the Iran-contra affair, made his musical stage debut Friday night as a narrator of ''Peter and the Wolf,'' Prokofiev's classic musical tale for children.

title: Tucker's Shots Lift Knicks to 9 in Row
description: The Knicks have not played especially well in their last five games, but they have found ways to win them all.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: RANDOLPH, MASS.;
New Rental Nearly Filled
description: LEAD: AT Liberty Place, a 107-unit apartment complex in this suburb about a half- hour southwest of Boston, only items like landscaping remain to be finished, and only three units have yet to be rented. Tenants began moving into the $8.7 million project's first phase, two buildings with a total of 18 apartments, last spring.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: PAWCATUCK;
>A 'Family' and Town Battles the Shock of a Plant's Closing
description: LEAD: IN the Pawcatuck section of Stonington, a neighborhood where generation after generation has stayed to work and raise a family, the closing of the Harris Graphics Corporation plant there a few months ago was the end of an era. A longtime major employer was gone, hundreds of jobs were lost and a sense of community identity shaken.

title: The World; The Call of Separatism Rings in Gorbachev's Ear
description: Lenin once condemned czarist Russia as a ''prison house of nations,'' and put part of the blame for the country's social and political problems on the myriad peoples forced together under the czar's hand. The words of the Soviet Union's founder must echo in the mind of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the man now holding the keys to the prison.

title: Czech Couple Keep Eye on Homeland
description: AS history is made in Prague, an American couple with strong ties to Czechoslovakia have watched the events on television in their home here. Milena Jelinek, an assistant professor in the film division of the Columbia University School of the Arts, personally knew many players in the current drama before coming to the United States in 1960.

title: Lipps Helps Steelers Get Back in Business
description: Louis Lipps strolled to work on Friday in a blue suit, a portable phone and a folder of papers in hand.

title: After Noriega: Panama City; U.S. AIDE REVERSES REPORT OF ARREST
description: A senior United States Embassy official said today that his earlier disclosure of the arrest of an Israeli identified as Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's closest associate appeared to have been based on erroneous information from the American military.

title: About Cars; Decade of Growth and Decline
description: I KNOW, I know. You are tired of hearing about the decade. But automobiles are worth thinking about. And looking at.

title: Social Events
description: Downtown Antiques Show

title: Eden in the Heart of the City
description: SOUTHERN COMFORT The Garden District of New Orleans, 1800-1900. By S. Frederick Starr. Photographs by Robert S. Brantley. 308 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $35.

title: Maura Croghan Plans To Wed James Eustace
description: Maura Terese Croghan and James R. Eustace, 1985 graduates of Fairfield University, are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John H. Croghan of Miami, have announced.

title: Highbrow vs. Alternative Venue
description: To the Editor:

title: Grandmothers, Granddaughters
description: THE print hangs on the wall in our living room. ''Teacup and Letter'' was a Christmas present from my daughter, Carol, an artist, a printmaker and painter. It is framed in natural wood, which picks up the browns of the bureau on which the cup and letter rest. The cup is Royal Stafford procelain, with a beautifully curved black and white handle. The fluted edge is outlined in black with a band of purple below it. A nosegay of red roses completes the decoration on the curving white bowl of the cup.

title:
Style Makers;
Giancarlo Gasponi, Postcard Photographer
description: LEAD: Giancarlo Gasponi has three pet peeves: telephone wires, television antennas and parked cars. He is not too fond of passers-by, either. Mr. Gasponi has been the best-selling postcard photographer in Italy for the last five years.

title:
INVESTING;
How 'Dull' Investing Can Pay Off
description: LEAD: INDEX funds are designed to be dull. While most money managers work feverishly to outperform the stock market - and fail - index funds strive to match the averages. Using computerized techniques, the funds try to replicate benchmarks like the Standard & Poor's 500 Index.

title: Lifestyle; Live From the Waldorf-Astoria, The Modern Mr. New Year's Eve
description: An hour or so before dawn on New Year's Day, Jerry Kravat, a tall and rumpled figure in white tie and tails, comes home to his Upper West Side apartment, uncorks a bottle of champagne, presses buttons on his video-cassette recorder and reruns New Year's Eve.

title: Esther McCoy Is Dead; Architecture Critic, 85
description: Esther McCoy, an architectural historian and critic, died of emphysema on Friday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 85 years old.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Airport Buses
description: To the Editor: In Mayer Horn's reply to Simone Goldfarb's letter concerning the Carey Airport Express facility on Park Avenue (Travel, Oct. 15), he writes, ''The Police Department has been diligent in recognizing the vulnerablity of travelers at the Park Avenue stop.''

title: Worker Is Badly Burned in Gas Explosion
description: A gas explosion leveled a house and critically injured a worker investigating reports of a leak in the area, the police and company officials said.

title: After Noriega; U.S. ADMITS ERROR IN SEARCHING HOME OF MANAGUA ENVOY
description: President Bush conceded today that American troops in Panama committed a ''screw-up'' when they searched the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama City on Friday, but questioned why the diplomat had weapons ''up to his eyeballs'' in his house.

title: Sports of The Times; The 80's: An Improbable Decade in Sports
description: WITH the calendar approaching 1990, it's fashionable to assess what has happened since the calendar was turned to 1980, a decade in sports when money got bigger but not necessarily better, when ''drug rehab'' and ''Olympic boycott'' entered our vocabulary. It's also fashionable to assess ''the best'' of the decade. Such as the best athlete. And the obvious nominees are five whose success spanned the decade: Joe Montana, Wayne Gretzky, Earvin (Magic) Johnson, Larry Bird, Martina Navratilova. All winners, all artistes on their personal stages.

title: Louisville Beats Kentucky
description: Cornelius Holden and Keith Williams each scored two baskets in an 11-2 surge midway in the second half, which carried Louisville to an 86-79 victory over Kentucky today.

title: 150 March in Howard Beach
description: About 150 people marched through the streets of Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday to protest a state court's dismissal this month of the riot convictions of three defendants in a racial attack in 1986.

title: In Short: NONFICTION
description: JUST ENOUGH ROPE: An Intimate Memoir. By Joan Braden. (Villard, $19.95.) Joan Braden has taken a lot of heat for this book, which has been criticized as a vapid kiss-and-sell by a Washington society hostess with the capital's most notorious ''open'' marriage. The title, ''Just Enough Rope,'' refers to the amount of freedom the author has received from her husband, the syndicated columnist Tom Braden. Washington insiders, however, sniff that it also alludes to the fact that she has hanged herself with this ''intimate memoir.'' This reviewer does not take such a harsh view. After all, how can a book be all bad that features a shower scene with Nelson Rockefeller, a bedroom scene with Bobby Kennedy, a toe-tingling lunch with Kirk Douglas and an account of Frank Sinatra singing ''High Hopes'' without his toupee? Not to mention the report of a birthday party for Bobby Kennedy with such guests as Kim Novak, Angie Dickinson and Marilyn Monroe, at which Marilyn asked Bobby questions she had written out in advance with red lipstick on a piece of paper. (''What,'' she asked breathily, ''does an attorney general do?'') Ms. Braden offers these ''ancient truths'' and ''tribal instincts'': ''Never ever go to a dinner party when you're ill.'' ''When a man says to me, 'If my wife knew that I was having lunch with you, she'd have a fit,' I put him down as unenlightened and something of a boor and I try not to have lunch with him again.'' ''Only a woman could ever know Nelson Rockefeller.'' ''Hindsight and experience tell me that alone with a man, a woman who decides to take a shower is asking for trouble.'' ''Women journalists, like other working women, have good reason for knowing that the great American workplace is full of attractions to sex, propositions for sex, and adventures in sex. . . . I think they tend to overemphasize sex.'' ''Tom and I don't have to cheat. We trust.'' And she begins a chapter about her ''special friend'' by asking: ''Am I keeping Robert McNamara from getting married?''

title:
DINING OUT;
A Critic's Choice: The Best of 1989
description: LEAD: AS 1989 closes, once again we proffer our yearly judgment on where to find the best dining in the area. Our list includes many familiar names, restaurants whose kitchens have maintained their high standards year after year, as well as some exciting newcomers.
