title: Giants Battle for a Maine Paper Mill
description: A feeling of helplessness and uncertainty has settled over this small town in northern Maine, where the future of the local paper mill is on the line in a battle between two of the nation's largest forest-products companies.

title: Welcome The New Horizon
description: The dizzying conclusion of the decade did mark the end of a historical period, so dramatically that only die-hard dodos could still suggest it may be only a mirage or a trick.

title: 'You Exaggerate Your Symptoms'
description: A WINTER flu or cold will linger longer if you've got the blues, according to Dr. Peter Salovey, a health psychologist and researcher at Yale. Instead of hibernating under a sea of blankets feeling bad for yourself, try to keep active, he advises, and think optimistically.

title: Motherwell Collages 'Paraphrase' Life
description: IN one of his celebrated asides, Oscar Wilde proposed that life imitates art. Tom Wolfe said much the same thing in an essay on the contemporary novel for a recent issue of Harper's Magazine.

title: In Short: Fiction
description: LEAD: WHAT I HAVE TO TELL YOU. By Mary Elsie Robertson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Seattle may not be the first place most people would go to consult an oracle, but that is where Jessie, the protagonist of Mary Elsie Robertson's fifth novel, finds Phoebe, the psychic who helps in Jessie's quest for her missing (and presumably dead) husband, Dwayne.

title: Mary R. Hulick Wed
description: Mary Rebecca Hulick, a vice president and a marketing manager at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, and William James Bendix, a partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Medina & Bendix, were married yesterday at St. Edmund's Episcopal Church in San Marino, Calif., by Bishop Oliver B. Garver Jr. Mrs. Bendix, 31 years old and a graduate of Mount Holyoke College, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Hulick of Pasadena, Calif. The bridegroom, 35 and a graduate of Colgate University and the St. John's University School of Law, is the son of Dr. and Mrs. William Bendix of Kinston, N.C.

title: More Hell From Harry
description: WHERE THE BUCK STOPS The Personal and Private Writings of Harry S. Truman. Edited by Margaret Truman. 388 pp. New York: Warner Books. $22.95.

title: Dr. Steiner Weds Michael J. Halpern
description: Dr. Nancy Jill Steiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Steiner of New York and Llewellyn Park, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Jeffrey Halpern, the son of Edith Halpern of Rye Brook, N.Y., and the late Frank Halpern. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: The Ramans are back - if indeed they exist. In 1973 Arthur C. Clarke published a classic puzzle-story about enigmatic aliens, ''Rendezvous With Rama.'' In that novel (set in the year 2130) an enormous spaceship shaped like a hollow cylinder entered the solar system; all attempts to communicate with it were unsuccessful, yet the spaceship (dubbed Rama) allowed itself to be boarded by a team of human explorers, who discovered many marvels of bioengineering inside but no sign of the Ramans, the advanced beings who presumably built the impressive craft. Attempts to puzzle out the aliens' intentions were abandoned when the spaceship suddenly fired its massive engines and departed, leaving behind a chastened humanity and the distinct threat of a sequel in the novel's last sentence: ''The Ramans do everything in threes.''

title: New York State to Start Restricting Smoking
description: Acceptable behavior in public will change on Monday, when one of the nation's strictest anti-smoking laws will go into effect in New York State.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: HELENA, MONT.;
New Image For Old Jail
description: LEAD: A 98-YEAR-OLD former county jail is undergoing a $1.6 million gut renovation to become a center for media and performing arts, part of a small surge in construction in this state capital.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Money may at first seem an unlikely venue for propaganda. But any coin in any pocket has a message. Whether a bust of George Washington reminding us that we were the first of the great revolutionary governments or a profile of Lincoln reminding us of the Civil War and our experience with slavery. Each coin has some meaning underlying the mundane utility of money.

title: Policeman Is Your Friend, Chinese Are Told
description: There was quite an instructive report on Chinese television this week, showing a ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Tiananmen Square and featuring some of China's new heroes: the People's Armed Police.

title: Remember This: Write What You Don't Know
description: BEFORE the Reagan Administration cut off liberal money to the arts and humanities, I traveled around to a lot of posh little writing-teaching gigs. They'd fly you in, you'd get a pile of manuscripts to look over and a bunch of students. After some seminars and receptions, you'd take your check and fly home.

title: New Life for an Ambitious Remnant of the 80's Boom
description: One of the most ambitious projects started in the development boom of the mid 1980's along the Princeton Corridor -- the stretch of Route 1 between New Brunswick and Trenton, N.J. -- was Princetonpark Corporate Center, a joint venture of the Seltzer Corporation of Fort Washington, Pa., and Olympia & York, the giant Toronto developer.

title: Painter's Home Vies to Be a National Park
description: LEAD: AS Sperry Andrews paints with watercolors and oil in two barn-shaped studios, he continues an artistic tradition that started in 1883 on the same property. Then, the artist J. Alden Weir acquired a farm in Ridgefield and opened his home to other impressionists who joined him in painting the surrounding landscape.

title: FOSTER CHILDREN WHO FIND A HOME
description: I want to say how happy - overjoyed, really - I was upon reading ''Where Foster Children Become Family'' on Nov. 26. Having worked as a psychologist with foster children and their natural and foster parents, I know firsthand the difficulties involved in helping the children find a better way of life. I thank God for people like Barbara Kenyon, who turn their lives around to help others, and for articles like this, which help others to do the same. LISA DILEO FRETZ Jackson.

title: ANOTHER ASPECT OF CHILD SUPPORT
description: In regard to the article ''Helping Women With Child Support'' (New Jersey Q & A, Nov. 19): The efforts of Sandy Feld and Aware are to be applauded. The fact that there are deadbeat dads who don't pay child support is reprehensible. It makes all dads look bad. However, on behalf of the innocent children of divorce everywhere, there might be other factors to consider. A lot of New Jersey fathers are paying several times the national average child support payment. Yet unqualified judges are allowing children to be moved out of the state where living expenses are but a fraction of those here in New Jersey. When this occurs, one can't help but wonder, ''Where is my money going?'' Nonetheless, most of these dads will continue to obey the law - for the sake of the child. Perhaps there should be an accountability law - a court-ordered directive to make certain the child is indeed receiving that support. Maybe then, these ''bum dads'' would be more amenable to the laws of the state. JOE PISCOPO Alpine

title: Pitt Gets Bowl Victory And New Head Coach
description: It wasn't a bad day at all for Paul Hackett.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Tonight, at the crack of midnight, the 12th annual New Year's Eve performance of the Sorvillo Symphony, played on pots, pans, tambourines and an occasional kettle, will be heard in front of Helen and Carmen Sorvillo's home in Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Sorvillo, an art teacher, and Mrs. Sorvillo, who works for Newsday, have been welcoming the new year in this manner since the birth of their eldest son, Paul.

title: Gail Schargel Is Married
description: The marriage of Gail Schargel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schargel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., to William Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Manley Powell of Elkins, W. Va., took place last evening at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck. Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer officiated. Mrs. Powell, a graduate of Lehigh University, is a commercial real-estate appraiser for the Appraisal Group in Charlottesville, Va. Mr. Powell graduated from the University of Richmond and is studying for an M.B.A. at the University of Virginia.

title: Josephus Long Is Dead; Boston Banker Was 45
description: Josephus Long, senior vice president of the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company, died of renal cancer last Sunday at his home in Boston. He was 45 years old.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: BETSY THOMASON;
Guiding Women in Wilderness Training
description: LEAD: WHEN Betsy Thomason attends a party and is asked what she does for a living, she says her response produces raised eyebrows as well as downright guffaws.

title: Pro Postema
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: >Ms. Blakeley Plans to Wed
description: Katherine Marion Blakeley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher P. Blakeley of Ambler, Pa., and Mark Douglas Teich, the son of Helen C. Teich of Floral Park, L.I., and the late David Teich, plan to marry in March, her parents have announced.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They will discover all kinds of poisonings, and speeded-up cancers. We will realize what torture our lives have been.

title: Women in a Jewish Tapestry, in Words and Pictures
description: LEAD: ''PEOPLE stereotype me as a 'Jewish-American Princess' when they find out I live in Hewlett, L. I.,'' says Rebecca Mintz, a college student who was among those interviewed for ''The Invisible Thread,'' a collection of portraits about Jewish-American women.

title: Upheaval in the East: Espionage; It's Still Business as Usual for Spies, Even as the Eastern Bloc Rises Up
description: For years, experts have dubbed Czechoslovakia's spy agency the ''two Czech'' service. Agents of the Office for the Protection of State Secrets got one check from Prague, the pun goes, and another from their real bosses at K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow.

title: The Private Lives of Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors; On Frozen Pond: Ice Fishing
description: ALTHOUGH I have never been an ice-fishing addict, there have been times when a day spent on a snow-covered lake or pond trying to induce a lethargic perch, pickerel or trout to seize my lure or bait brought considerable pleasure.

title: Atlantic Beach Seeks Fire Protection Pact
description: LEAD: IMAGINE a major house fire on a bitter-cold winter night and no firefighters at the scene to fight the blaze.

title: Legendary Lunch
description: To the Editor: In view of all that Ms. Pogrebin consumed at her legendary lunch at La Ruota, am I correct in assuming that you published her article posthumously? ROBERT N. STRAUSS New York, N.Y.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Art to Order

title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA
description: Rejecting a recommendation by its own chief administrative judge, the Drug Enforcement Administration has refused to relax restrictions on marijuana.

title:
MUSIC;
Princeton To Ring In New Year With Gala
description: LEAD: FOUR years ago, looking for a way to bring the year to an entertaining close and to usher in the new year in a way that would foster a lasting feeling of community spirit, the Princeton arts community created ''Curtain Calls,'' an event that has become a tradition.

title: MUSIC: The Forgotten Schubert Is Getting Another Chance
description: FRANZ SCHUBERT WAS NOT THE ignored and misunderstood genius that the romance of historical anecdote has seduced us into believing. And curiously, it is the stage pieces - which subsequent generations have chosen to ignore - that first brought him to the attention of the Viennese music public.

title: The World; It May Prove Difficult to Let Panama Get On With Its Life
description: As American troops sought to secure order here last week after having ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power, the American invasion of Panama turned into an occupation.

title: 'Sweet Charity,' Vintage Cy Coleman
description: THE night after ''Sweet Charity opened at the Darien Dinner Theater, ''City of Angels'' had its Broadway premiere at the Virginia Theater. What, you may wonder, is the connection?

title: 16 Luxury L.I. Homes
description: The C. Oliver Iselin estate in Upper Brookville, L.I., is being developed into 16 luxury homes, each on at least five acres. Iselin, a banker and sportsman who died in 1932, owned three boats that successfully defended the America's Cup.

title: Fan's Recipe For Soccer Boom
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: What Made Us Happy During Trying Times
description: AS the New Year approaches and the 1980's draw to a close, everyone's appraising the last 10 years. Experts try to tell us why things went wrong in the world. We see lists of everything from the 10 biggest movie bombs to the 10 worst restaurants.

title: Wall Street Prepares For a Failure Boom
description: AS the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation prepared its filing for bankruptcy last week, it became the darling of Wall Street. A parade of investment bankers, having sniffed out the fact that the highly leveraged company, formed in 1987 by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, was planning to file for protection from its creditors, came peddling their skills at reorganization.

title: On Language; Word of the Year: Freedom
description: IN HIS RECENT MEETing with President Bush, Mikhail S. Gorbachev was reported to have suggested that the American stop using the phrase Western values, as in ''the triumph of Western values.'' This hint that the West had won the cold war smacked too much of gloating.

title: In Vermont, a Proposal to Ban Disposable Diapers
description: Dotty Schnure, a mother who has a job away from home, always used disposable diapers on her two young daughters. She estimates that she used 90 small diapers a week per child when they were infants, 60 medium-size diapers a week per child for the next three months, and 30 large diapers for the next two years - roughly 4,920 diapers per child.

title: TELEVISION: How Soviet TV Focuses Its Cameras on Eastern Europe
description: LEAD: Television in the Soviet Union has changed radically since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985, and it is proving a powerful tool in the ongoing campaign to change the face of Communism there. As an American whose work involves watching Soviet television, I'm aware of how central the news is to the mission of the medium, and how it, too, is changing in that rapidly evolving political environment.

title: Maria C. Messina, Student, Marries Paul Ronson
description: Maria Claire Messina and Paul Ronson were married yesterday at the Marriott Marquis in New York. The Rev. Ben Bortin, a Unitarian minister, performed the civil ceremony.

title: Looking Back at a Disappointing Decade
description: ALTHOUGH it's much too soon to be nostalgic for the 80's, it's hard to picture them being anyone's good old days. For me the last decade had no memories as sweet as charlotte russes or mello rolls.

title: Miss Tessier Weds W. F. O'Connor 3d
description: Elizabeth Anne Tessier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Tessier of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday in Woodbury, L.I., to William Francis O'Connor 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connor Jr. of Huntington, L.I. Msgr. Anthony J. Savastano performed the ceremony at the Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

title: Reviews/Music; Henry Threadgill, Brassy to Blue
description: The composer and saxophonist Henry Threadgill has spent the last decade or so leading some of the most provocative bands in New York. His new group - a loose septet featuring Curtis Fowlkes on trombone, Brandon Ross and Masujaa on guitars, Marcus Rojas and Edwin Rodriguez on tubas and E. J. Rodriguez on drums - doesn't break any patterns. Freewheeling and risky (Mr. Threadgill turned a scrap of melody into an entire, detailed composition by conducting his group through quickly changing improvisations), the band, which played at Carlos 1 on Friday night, made Mr. Threadgill's reimagined musical Americana jubilant.

title: Debate Renewed on Self-Service Gas
description: LEAD: WHEN lawmakers recently strengthened the state's 40-year-old ban on self-service gasoline stations, it appeared that a longstanding issue had lost momentum. Instead, the legislators may have revived it.

title: INSIDE
description: Sense of Revolt in Moldavia The rebellion storming through the Communist bloc now glitters just beyond a border town in the Soviet republic of Moldavia, a region filled with nationalist fervor. Page 15. U.S. Homicides Soar Again Accounts from several major cities suggest that homicides, which declined early in the decade, are now occurring in record numbers and that drugs are a leading cause. Page 20. All Well on Northwest Flight With intense security on both sides of the Atlantic, a jetliner that had been threatened with terrorism flew from Paris to Detroit without incident and nearly empty. Page 20. Searching for Blast's Cause Consolidated Edison investigators backed away from the company's explanation that a backhoe operator caused a gas main explosion and fire in the South Bronx Friday. Page 24. Next Stop for Koch Aides Many members of the outgoing Koch administration are preparing to leave City Hall, but some may be asked to remain. Page 30. News summary, page 2 Obituaries, page 32

title: Corporations Are Investing in Young Minds
description: LEAD: MORE and more often these days, school systems facing shrinking budgets are turning to their corporate neighbors for material support and financial help. And companies, concerned about the quality of American education and its effect on the country's economic well-being, are responding by becoming more and more involved in the schools.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLER
description: FICTION This Week Title Weeks on list 1 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $5.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 7 2 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 46 3 STOLEN BLESSINGS, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The scandalous life of the Hollywood superstar Marilyn Taylor. 5 4 A THIEF OF TIME, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $4.95.) Tracking down a missing archeologist, missing artifacts and a murderer in the Indian ruins of New Mexico. 2 5 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in ''The Gunslinger.'' 10 6 CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Bantam, $5.95.) A woman's visit to her native Toronto leads her to reflect on the changes time has wrought. 5 7 SAVAGE THUNDER, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) A young English widow finds romance with a Cheyenne in 19th-century Arizona. 5 8 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $5.50.) The exploits of Billy the Kid. 8 9 THORNYHOLD, by Mary Stewart. (Fawcett, $5.95.) Mysteries, witchcraft and romance await a woman who inherits an English cottage. 5 10 A SEASON IN HELL, by Jack Higgins. (Pocket, $5.50.) A young widow's quest for her stepson's killers results in horrendous adventures. 4 11 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once-idyllic California town. 10 12 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $5.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 23 13 A TWIST IN THE TALE, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.95.) Short stories set in a variety of locales and with surprising endings. 2 14 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a funeral. 14 15 THE KOBAYASHI MARU, by Julia Ecklar. (Pocket, $4.50.) How the ''Star Trek'' officers behaved when they were cadets. 3 NONFICTION 1 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 6 2 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $7.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 19 3 THE BLOODING, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Bantam, $5.95.) The murder of two girls in an English village is solved through genetic clues. 6 4 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Grace Catalano. (Bantam, $3.50.) The lives and predilections of the five members of a teen-age singing group. 3 5 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Penguin, $7.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 7 6 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Murder and incest in an Oregon town. 34 7 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. 64 8* THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 323 9 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 14 10 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) A science that sees order in what appears erratic. 37 11* LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 84 ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 THE PREHISTORY OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) The cartoonist's sketches and notes. 13 2 THE CALVIN AND HOBBES LAZY SUNDAY BOOK, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $9.95.) A new collection of cartoons. 13 3 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1990. (World Almanac, $6.95.) The latest edition of a reference work. 4 4 THE OLD FARMER'S ALMANAC 1990. (Yankee Publishing, $2.95.) The 198th annual edition. 8 5 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1990 edition. 5 6 * THE NIGHT OF THE MARY KAY COMMANDOS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 13

title: Small World
description: Brace yourself, the world is getting smaller. Fax machines and the Concorde have brought the ends of the earth together with record speed. Now as we enter a new decade, designers are addressing a universal problem - lack of space. Many have created sophisticated and ingenious objects that address every need from fitness to storage. They are not simply compact and utilitarian, but wonderful to look at too.

title: >Why I Can't Fathom Smokers
description: WHEN I was 4 years old, I didn't understand why I couldn't eat dessert before dinner and why I couldn't smoke cigarettes. Now that I am 17, I've got the answers to those questions, but these days something else is bothering me. It has to do with my grandfather. He was kind and helpful, and most of all, he was like a second father to me, but I don't understand why he smoked. Ever since I can remember, my grandfather smoked cigarettes - two-and-a-half packs a day. Little did he know that it would stop him from doing the many things he loved to do.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: RANDOLPH, MASS.;
New Rental Nearly Filled
description: LEAD: AT Liberty Place, a 107-unit apartment complex in this suburb about a half- hour southwest of Boston, only items like landscaping remain to be finished, and only three units have yet to be rented. Tenants began moving into the $8.7 million project's first phase, two buildings with a total of 18 apartments, last spring.

title: Anne E. Connell, Consultant, Weds
description: Anne Elizabeth Connell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Connell of Wexford, Pa., was married there yesterday at St. Alexis Roman Catholic Church to Timothy Fletcher Henningsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Henningsen Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. James E. Kunkel performed the ceremony.

title: Topics of The Times; Happy New Year, and Duck
description: Too many Americans believe that the best New Year's noisemakers are guns - unaware that a bullet shot into the air returns to earth at nearly the same velocity as when it was fired.

title: Versailles
description: To the Editor: Next time you visit Versailles, take the tour of Madame DuBarry's apartments even though it is only given in French. The guide, who was British, gave the tour in French and was reluctant to offend the French tourists by speaking English. She could not explain why the tour was not offered in English. She claimed she had been asking the same question for 15 years.

title: Working For an Unknown, Arif Nasr
description: WHO is Arif Nasr? reads the sign we created to display at one town fair. The bold words underline a dark silhouette. Choosing a silhouette for illustration was not just a design concept. We don't know what Arif looks like. We don't know what he looks like and yet we continue to work on his behalf.

title: Sports People; Brown Turned Down
description: SHOULD an assistant football coach in the Big Eight accept a job as head coach in the Ivy League? Ron Brown, receivers' coach at the University of Nebraska, thinks not. He has turned down the chance to be the head coach at Brown University.

title: All About New Year's Eve
description: What is it with New Year's Eve, anyway? I don't think I've actually ever met anyone who liked it, and yet we all persist in celebrating. It's a silly holiday, one of forced revelry, a night when - like the senior prom - reality can't possibly fulfill expectations.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Bohemia - $161,800 1591 Feuereisen Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-iun kitche, family room; taxes $3,900. East Islip - $660,000 2 The Keel 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old waterfront colonial; dining room, c/a, 2-car attached garage, 1 acre; taxes $11,000 Oakdale - $193,000 265 Edgewood Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,700 Sayville - $195,000 487 Lincoln Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, 13-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $4,900 St. James - $185,000 221 Sixth Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; dining room, family room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,300 Stony Brook - $160,000 2 Mystic Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, fireplace, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,000 OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. - $237,500 56 Salter Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, sun room; taxes $3,809. Scarsdale, N.Y. - $350,500 174 Ferndale Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 69-year-old Norman Tudor; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, deck, playroom; taxes $5,016. Branford, Conn. - $161,000 30 Pine Orchard Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; h/w floors, attic, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,261.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; When Onions Are Stars of the Show
description: To enjoy the full flavor of cooked onions, it isn't enough to cook them just until they are soft; they must be soft and golden brown. It takes a little longer, but it is worth the time. In this Indian-style lamb recipe, the onions are used as a topping, preserving their texture and their sweetness, which is usually partly lost when they are combined with other ingredients. As an interesting experiment, try a mouthful of the lamb mixture without the onions to see how important they are.

title: BIRDMEN OF HARLEM
description: I only wish my father were alive to read John W. Miller's article ''Birdmen of Harlem,'' (Nov. 19). My Dad raised and raced pigeons, in Brooklyn, for more than 40 years. His obsession started when he was about 9 years old. He even secretly kept some pigeons in his bedroom until my grandmother got wise to him. My father was a longshoreman on the Brooklyn docks. His pigeon flying was an escape (his poetry) from the waterfront scene. He, too, ''experienced the slow, lazy fever of flying pigeons on a rooftop.'' HARRIET LOIR Long Beach, L.I.

title: 'Open Outcry' Works Well and Cheaply
description: FOR a number of very basic reasons, I think the open outcry system of trading futures contracts will be with us for a long time to come. The pit system is cheap, efficient and enormously successful. In contrast, the architects of computerized trading systems have yet to show that they can compete economically with the pit system.

title: Tainted Bait
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus: Cleveland; A Downtown Mall Adjusts to Setback
description: WHEN the BP America headquarters building was completed here in early 1985 on Public Square, the city's center, there was brave talk that a new era in downtown prosperity was beginning.

title: Seoul's Disgraced Military Leader Is to Testify Today
description: During more than a year in self-imposed exile, former President Chun Doo Hwan has declined to answer questions about the abuses of power and corruption that marked his repressive eight-year rule of South Korea - the dark side of the nation's economic miracle of the last decade.

title: GOOD TASTE
description: WARM LENTIL SALAD, ROAST CHICK-en with mashed potatoes, scallops crusted in potato slivers, olive-flecked risotto and tarte Tatin. These may have been the hot restaurant orders in 1989, but ''sauce on the side'' was the most uttered phrase. In 1990, that request will become a mantra.

title: Followers Make Good Leaders Good
description: IT is probably inevitable that a society as star-struck as ours should focus on leaders in analyzing why organizations succeed or fail. As a long-time student and teacher of management, I, too, have tended to look to the men and women at the top for clues on how organizations achieve and maintain institutional health. But the longer I study effective leaders, the more I am persuaded of the under-appreciated importance of effective followers.

title: Research Park Moves Forward
description: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY and the city of Evanston are clearing more land, including a historic landmark, for a new phase in the development of a $400 million, 24-acre research park aimed at speeding technology to the marketplace and putting university and city land on the tax rolls.

title: Buying Abroad
description: To the Editor: A warning for readers regarding duty-free shops in airports. At the airport in Moscow I purchased what I thought was a 14-karat white-and-yellow-gold Omega watch for the equivalent of $670 only to find out from the authorized dealer in New York that not only was it stainless and goldplate but also that had I bought it here it would have been $475. There's really nothing I can do, as I do not plan a return trip for quite some time. Guess the spirit of free enterprise and capitalism has really caught on in the Soviet Union. JUDY KOZUCK New York, N.Y.

title: Can There Be Too Much Power?
description: EACH human brain cell can store the equivalent of 10,000 bits of information, and the brain has about 10 billion brain cells, according to The Body Almanac. The memory capacity of the brain, therefore, is estimated at 100 trillion (100,000,000,000,000) bits, or slightly more than 10 terabytes. Each brain cell can discharge an electrical impulse about 200 times a second. By computer standards, the brain is astonishingly slow.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
Look to the Shrubs for Early Blossom
description: LEAD: The edge of a woodland, whether part of a forest or a buffer of trees can be home to an astounding array of shrubs. Most gardeners are aware that many rhododendrons and azaleas grow best where they receive at least partial shade.

title: In Short: Fiction
description: LEAD: COLLECTED STORIES. By R. V. Cassill. (University of Arkansas, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $14.95.) Just about every story in this collection is a textbook example of what a piece of short fiction ought to be: immediately engaging, swiftly paced, economical. This is hardly surprising, since R. V. Cassill is the editor of ''The Norton Anthology of Short Fiction.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Weekend at Bernie's 1989. International Video Entertainment. $89.95. LD, $39.95. 1:41. PG-13.

title: THE ULTIMATE DECISION
description: My views on the ''right to die'' are substantially different from Andrew H. Malcolm's. But I must say that he is a splendid writer and that I have never seen the case for the ''right to die'' (at least, under certain circumstances) articulated more persuasively than in his article ''The Ultimate Decision'' (Dec. 3).

title: Antiquated Word?
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Ship in Distress Aided By Coast Guard Near Hawaii
description: A Coast Guard vessel reached a Greek freighter taking on water northeast of Hawaii today and evacuated half its crew, the Guard said.

title: Lucy Marshall to Wed G. M. Sandor
description: Mr. and Mrs. David L. Marshall of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lucy Berry Marshall to Gregory Martin Sandor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Sandor of New Canaan, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
Critics' Choices: Memorable Meals
description: LEAD: FOR restaurant reviewers, at least, a new year is a tempting time to reflect on dinners past. In a look back over the scores of New Jersey restaurants we have visited in the last couple of years, many stand out as memorable.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: What kind of year was 1989? Not a bad one, if new films and cameras are your ultimate fantasies. And even if you don't know an ISO speed from a fill-flash button, chances are the quality of your pictures improved during the last 12 months.

title: Coping With the Economic Prospects of 1990
description: SURVIVING the decline in the economy will be the overriding issue for 1990, say leaders of the county's business community. Although the consensus is that Westchester will fare better than many other areas, there is concern that layoffs and a lack of affordable housing will hamper the county's economic recovery.

title: Survival Was What Counted
description: THE LOST CHILDHOOD A Memoir. By Yehuda Nir. 256 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: In Short: Nonfiction
description: MEMOIRS OF A BASTARD ANGEL. By Harold Norse. (Morrow, $22.95.) From an audacious opening (''Call me bastard'') to a coyly symmetrical ending more than 400 pages later (''This is but the draft of a draft, as Melville said of Moby Dick''), Harold Norse's ''Memoirs of a Bastard Angel'' charts a colorful life rich in literary affiliations but lacking in fulfilled ambitions. A poet and ''charter member of the 'Beat Generation','' Mr. Norse retraces a path beginning in New York City in the 1930's, passing through Europe in the 50's and ending up in California in the 60's. He emerges as a peripatetic priapus, apportioning his interests between belletristic concerns and homosexual escapades. With lingering affection for some and noticeable animosity toward others, Mr. Norse recalls his associations with W. H. Auden, James Baldwin, Julian Beck, Paul Bowles, Charles Bukowski, William Burroughs, Allen Ginsberg, Paul Goodman, Christopher Isherwood, James Jones, Anais Nin, Ned Rorem and Tennessee Williams - to breathlessly name but a few. Mr. Norse ultimately betrays his own resentments: ''It seems that many times in my life I have been the bearer of fame and fortune to others by some word or instruction that I have passed on. But I haven't always been that lucky myself.'' The greater irony is that it is the less famous and more nameless figures who come most alive - the shopkeepers, socialites and anonymous ''tricks'' who peopled Mr. Norse's life. Intermittently humorous and didactic, the book is encumbered by a tendency to include too many encomiums: ''In 1951, William Carlos Williams wrote, 'You are the best poet of your generation.' I was discovered - again.'' Mr. Norse is constantly being rediscovered but is still waiting to be found.

title: Army Won't Try Two in Artillery Accident
description: The base commander here has decided against a court-martial for two artillery gunners whose errant round last Sept. 27 killed 3 soldiers and wounded 24.

title: Campus Life: Arizona State; Updating Some '89 Reports: Cross Atop Chapel Still Remains An Issue
description: The cross that stands atop Arizona State University's Danforth Chapel has been the object of student complaints and debates since the building's dedication in 1948. Now, because of protests from the Arizona Civil Liberties Union, the cross is the subject of a lawsuit.

title: Campus Life: Dickinson; No One Charged In a Fatal Fall At a Fraternity
description: No individuals face criminal charges in the death of a Dickinson College freshman who fell from a bedroom window at Alpha Chi Rho on Sept. 29, but the local police have charged the fraternity with ''furnishing alcoholic beverages to a minor.''

title: How'd I Do?
description: Dear David, When you and I recently appeared together before a large crowd out in Brighton Beach, I began by telling the people, ''I want to thank everyone out there who voted for me. I appreciate it.'' Then, I added, ''I also want to thank everyone who didn't - you liberated me.''

title: Winter Wedding For Miss Cuddihy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Murray Cuddihy of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter Harriet DeHaven Cuddihy to David Alan Butz, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert J. Butz of Columbus, Ohio. A February wedding is planned.

title: In Short: Fiction
description: LEAD: THE CHILDREN OF SEGU. By Maryse Conde. Translated by Linda Coverdale. (Viking, $18.95.) Some of the minor problems of ''Segu,'' Barbara Bray's translation of the first installment of Maryse Conde's epic tale about a noble Bambara family in late 18th- and early 19th-century West Africa, are amplified in its sequel, ''The Children of Segu,'' by an unfortunate translation from the French by Linda Coverdale.

title: Tourist Trade Seeks to Sustain Growth
description: LEAD: AFTER two weak years for Long Island tourism, up until 1987 the region's major growth industry, local businesses are rallying to an unprecedented degree to gain a hotel-room tax to finance tourism promotion and the building of a convention center in Suffolk County.

title: Baroque Concert
description: Bach's Magnificat and Vivaldi's Gloria will be the major works in a concert of holiday Baroque music by the Taghkanic Chorale and Orchestra at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, at 9 o'clock tonight. The 120-member choral ensemble, conducted by Dennis Keene, will sing Venetian antiphonal pieces, the Rondeau from Jean Joseph Mouret's Symphony of Fanfares, and Handel's ''Coronation'' Anthem. Tickets are $15. Information: 254-8553.

title: Therapist Cherishes Her Theatrical Past
description: CALL on Carol Ilson expecting to discuss the book she wrote about the producer Harold Prince during summers at her Ocean Beach retreat and it is just as likely she willtalk about her life as a psychotherapist.

title: Musicales and Anniversaries
description: THE concert schedule usually takes awhile to recover fully from the holiday break, and next Sunday at 4, the First Congregational Church of Greenwich will help bring in a return to musical normalcy with a weekly series of hourlong candlelight events. It was the idea of the music director, Richard Vogt, to have an informal setting for these short musicales so tea, hot chocolate and other refreshments will be available, starting at 3:45.

title: In Short: Fiction
description: LEAD: THE BOOK OF MASKS. By Hwang Sun-won. Edited by Martin Holman. (Readers International, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $9.95.) According to Martin Holman, Hwang Sun-won, who is the author of 17 books of poetry and fiction, is ''a household word'' in South Korea. Although he is not well known elsewhere, the stark brilliance of many of the 15 tales in ''The Book of Masks,'' all culled from Mr.

title: 1990: Previews From 36 Creative Artists
description: LEAD: By the time a play, or a dance, or a piece of music reaches the stage, or a movie makes it to the screen, or an artwork is unveiled, it has often been years - sometimes decades - since its creator first conceived of it. On the eve of 1990, The New York Times asked three dozen creative artists about their projects for the coming year.

title: Miss McGrath to WedPeter Joseph O'Rourke
description: The engagement of Brinn Patricia McGrath to Peter Joseph O'Rourke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O'Rourke of Hillsdale, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. McGrath of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: RESEARCHERS FIND ACID RAIN IMPERILS FORESTS OVER TIME
description: Acid rain appears to pose a long-term threat to forests, but ozone and natural causes of stress are also implicated in forest decline and may be more harmful to trees in the short run, scientists in a Federal research program have found.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; Christmas May Be Ove But Trees Still Sparkle
description: One of the most enduring symbols of the holiday season is the Christmas tree, and New York City certainly has no shortage of dazzling ones. And this may be the very best time to see them, after Christmas, when the crowds and traffic have thinned. Most will be up through this week.

title: Commercial Property: Princeton Corridor; New Life for an Ambitious Remnant of the 80's Boom
description: ONE of the most ambitious projects started in the development boom of the mid 1980's along the Princeton Corridor - the stretch of Route 1 between New Brunswick and Trenton, N.J. - was Princetonpark Corporate Center, a joint venture of the Seltzer Organization of Fort Washington, Pa., and Olympia & York, the giant Toronto developer.

title: Annals of - Oops! - Flight
description: CAL RODGERS AND THE VIN FIZ The First Transcontinental Flight. By Eileen F. Lebow. Illustrated. 275 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. $22.95.

title: The Region; Connecticut Makes A Real Estate Deal
description: Connecticut's glutted condominium market, where owners and investors have come and gone with the winds of profit and loss, is about to get an infusion of what state officials call ''forever housing.''

title: More Americans Are Killing Each Other
description: After a hopeful but apparently transitory pause early in the decade, Americans are killing each other at an increasing rate.

title: Foreign Missions Face Maze of Red Tape
description: PROSPECTIVE tenants in New York often have to contend with costly real estate brokers, cranky landlords and choosy co-op boards. But foreign governments at the United Nations in search of new office or living space have an additional complication: the United States Government.

title: Wait Just a Second
description: Poised on the brink of a new decade, the world will pause Sunday night for one second. A ''leap second'' will occur at the very end of Dec. 31, 1989, making it the longest day of the year. The reason is that the extra second is needed to keep the world's clocks in time with the rotation of the planet, according to Government timekeeping officials.

title: Fighting The War Machine
description: Thank you for your article about Kathy Boylan, our Island's most prominent peace activist [ ''About Long Island: Waging Protest Against the Machines of War,'' Oct. 1 ] . It would be interesting to ask why a deeply religious Catholic woman, along with a 67-year-old nun, would risk 14 years in prison, not to mention swimming through highly polluted icy cold water, to protest the Navy's launching of another Trident nuclear submarine.

title: 40 Artists Explore the Meaning of Disguise in Hastings Show
description: BY the title, ''Masks: The Alternate Self,'' the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson implies that the number of maskable selves is unlimited. In the show designated, however, it doesn't work out that way. Nevertheless, the mask form is as old as art itself and most of the 40 artists here rise to the occasion, especially Harold Olejarz, in his ''Cedar Man.''

title: Hunter Addition
description: A $67 million addition to the Hunter College Campus Schools that would eventually make possible an increase in enrollment from the present 1,600 students to 2,200 is under consideration by the city. The proposal would add about 100,000 square feet to the school, enough for 20 new classrooms and a new gymnasium.

title: SOUND: The Advance Was Digital And It's Just a Beginning
description: The last day of the decade is clearly an occasion for retrospect. In audio, the 80's were a watershed - a time of fundamental change. The cardinal event was the birth of digital sound, a truly radical turning point whose ultimate implications are not yet fully realized.

title: Ideas & Trends; In College Sports, The Real Players Collect Millions From The Networks
description: Jim Brock is executive director of the Cotton Bowl football game, which will pay its competing teams about $3 million each to play in Dallas tomorrow afternoon. The five big bowl games - Cotton, Rose, Orange, Sugar and Fiesta -will pay their 10 teams a total of about $36 million, much of the money coming from television. In total, the 18 post-season bowl games will pay their 36 schools about $60 million this year, Mr. Brock said, up from $53 million a year ago.

title: Legendary Lunch
description: To the Editor: About once a month, I am a day-tripper to New York City. I find eating a pizza slice in the Port Authority Bus Terminal has all the cachet Letty Cottin Pogrebin found in the exotic Italian Riviera. One woman's crepes suzettes is another woman's pepperoni pizazz. JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Update
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; The Nuclear Arms Business Is Stalled, Still and Again
description: Yet another mighty artifact of the cold war is crumbling with startling speed: the complex of plants that makes America's nuclear bombs.

title: Black Students Lag in South Africa
description: Fifty-eight percent of black high school seniors failed their final examinations this year, a disastrous showing that has revived the controversy over segregated education in South Africa.

title: In Short: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: A FIRE IN HIS SOUL. Irving M. Bunim, 1901-1980: The Man and His Impact on American Orthodox Jewry. By Amos Bunim. (Feldheim, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $12.95.) When Irving Bunim died in 1980 at the age of 79, he left behind an extraordinary legacy of achievements in the Orthodox Jewish community in the United States.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SNOW SCULPTURE

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Sports Change in The 1990's?
description: Professional sports on free television will be replaced more and more by pay-per-view and cable network broadcasts. Nonprofessional, or college-sports networks, will continue to grow, but with more broadcasts on pay-per-view and cable networks as well.

title: Jennifer Heller To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Heller of Madison, N.J., and Sanibel Island, Fla., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Heller, and Dr. Noah Heftler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Heftler of New York and East Hills, L.I.

title: Headliners; Christmas in Berlin
description: As Leonard Bernstein and an international orchestra churned through Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in a concert in East Berlin Christmas Day, it was evident that the maestro had not played a better house in many a year. The musicians came from East and West Germany, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain, and the performance came on the first Christmas in 28 years that East and West Berliners had mingled freely. After the concert, the high point of three days of performances celebrating the new, freer Europe, the 71-year-old Mr. Bernstein said he was ''experiencing an historical moment incomparable with others in my long, long life.'' To emphasize the point, he did some editing of the chorus, which was inspired by Schiller's 18th-century poem, ''Ode to Joy.'' Mr. Bernstein substituted the word ''freedom'' for ''joy.''

title: WHEAT RIFT SPLITS NIGERIANS AND U.S.
description: A bitter trade dispute with the United States over wheat imports is posing a tough challenge for Nigeria's President, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, and is likely to come up when he visits Washington next month to meet with President Bush.

title: Basking in Power's Glow: Bush's Year as President
description: Here is what the country has learned about George Bush in 1989:

title: In Short: Nonfiction
description: LEAD: PLAIN AND SIMPLE: A Woman's Journey to the Amish. By Sue Bender. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) For Sue Bender, an artist in Berkeley, Calif., Amish life offered the promise of order, simplicity and meaning, all of which she longed for. Spellbound by the quilts made by Amish women and the way their stitching and choice of color encapsulated their values, Ms.

title: Donna Cohen Is Bride Of Dr. Jon Levenson
description: Donna Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Cohen of Penn Valley, Pa., was married there last evening at Har Zion Temple to Dr. Jon Alan Levenson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard L. Levenson of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Gerald Wolpe officiated.

title: Mencken's Prejudices Didn't Reflect Baltimore; A Bigot Is a Bigot
description: To the Editor:

title: Threatened Northwest Flight Lands Safely
description: With fortress-like security thrown up to meet a threatened attack, an almost empty Northwest Airlines jumbo jet from Paris landed here today, uneventfully except for the crush of reporters and television crews assigned to greet the few passengers.

title: Sports People; Grange of Illinois
description: WHEN the University of Illinois plays Virginia in the Citrus Bowl tomorrow, the Galloping Ghost will be there in spirit. He couldn't make it in the flesh.

title: DATA UPDATE
Anna G. O'Keeffe, Student, Is Wed
description: Anna Gould O'Keeffe and William Joseph Fenwick, both sophomores at Fairfield University, were married yesterday at SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., by the Rev. Robert Verrigni and the Rev. Carsten Martensen. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Keeffe of Larchmont. The bridegroom is a son of Theresa A. Fenwick and Glennon Fenwick, both of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: The Final Self-Defense
description: TERRIFYING LOVE Why Battered Women Kill and How Society Responds. By Lenore E. Walker. 342 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 10 about a stock transaction involving Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins of New York City misstated provisions of Federal gift-tax laws. The maximum each taxpayer can give without paying gift taxes is $600,000 in total, not per recipient.

title: Brilliant Silks Woven by Hand In Thailand
description: ''PEEP SHOW,'' a mostly routine 1950 revue produced by Mike Todd, deserves at least a footnote in theatrical history as probably the only Broadway show ever to contain a song by a ruling monarch. The number was ''Blue Night,'' written by Thailand's jazz-loving young King Bhumibol Adulyadej. The show also brought Thai silk to the New York stage for the first time.

title: The Nation; The Entire Senate Is About to Have Ethics Problems
description: In the eerie quiet that envelops the Capitol when Congress is out of session, there is a sense of dread about what comes next. The ethics turmoil that consumed the House of Representatives for much of 1989 is about to reappear in the Senate.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: LEAD: The Winds of War 1983. Paramount. $139.95. 14:43. CC. No rating.

title: VIDEO: The Living Room Is Now the Stage
description: A WAGGISH SCHOLAR once observed that the writing of history might be classified as one of the performing arts because it calls for so much interpretation. Mere facts can be read any number of ways.

title: Canoe Necessity: A Mantra
description: I TOSSED caution to the waves when I took Eddie canoeing on our third date. Long Island Sound was cold, almost wintry, so we wore wet suits.

title: Here's A Solution for the Lack of Affordable Housing
description: IN an effort to tackle the problems of homelessness and the lack of affordable housing in New Jersey, the Amato administration has suggested, and a bipartisan team of Essex County legislators has introduced, model legislation that would pool rental security deposits to create funds at below-market rates for building low-income housing.

title: Cost of Living to Rise on L.I.
description: LEAD: AN average 15 percent increase in the cost of riding the Long Island Rail Road and soaring heating-oil prices will lead the upward climb in the cost of living on Long Island when the New Year begins tomorrow.

title: Robert Pirosh, 79, Veteran Of Combat And Author, Is Dead
description: Robert Pirosh, who won a 1949 Academy Award for his World War II screenplay ''Battleground'' and who helped write the Marx Brothers classic ''A Day at the Races,'' died of heart failure last Monday. He was 79 years old.

title: DANCE DANCE VIEW: Ailey's Troupe Weathers a Season of Sorrow
description: TONIGHT, THE ALVIN AILEY American Dance Theater will close what has been one of its most difficult - and yet most successful - seasons. Ailey died on Dec. 1, five days before the troupe's opening at the City Center. Out of the red-hot crucible of grief and mourning, the Ailey dancers performed as never before.

title: A Touch of Glasnost in Lloyd Harbor
description: LEAD: THE speed of world change was clocked in stately Lloyd Harbor last month, when a group of 30 top-level industrial and agricultural managers from the Soviet Union exchanged words of hope and fidelity with their Long Island hosts during a farewell dinner at the former Marshall Field estate.

title:
GARDENING;
A Regimen for Plants Acquired as Gifts
description: LEAD: ABOUT now you may be wondering how to care for that lovely plant received as a holiday gift. You would like to keep it in good condition, if only to show the person who gave it to you that you really appreciated the gift.

title: Moving From Mainstream to Kosher Offers a Seal of Approval
description: Many mainstream manufacturers are reformulating their products to meet kosher requirements. Wise Potato Chips, a division of Borden Inc., produced kosher potato chips for Passover this year. Slim-Fast, a diet drink, and Boomer's Oogies, a line of chocolate cookies, were also certified recently. And Bisquick and Entenmann's baked goods were too.

title: Gone Fishing On the Bridges of Florida
description: IT'S another easy morning on Little Jim Bridge in Florida's Indian River country, the sun just beginning to warm the backs of the regulars fishing from the catwalks and debating, again, how best to hook the noble snapper.

title: Ellen Friedman And S. D. Bender To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Ellen F. Friedman to Samuel David Bender, a son of Dr. Eileen T. Bender and Dr. Harvey A. Bender of South Bend, Ind., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Friedman of New York and Neponsit, Queens. A May wedding is planned.

title: Faith McGillicuddy to Wed S. J. Benoit
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. McGillicuddy of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Faith Burtis McGillicuddy, to Stephen Joseph Benoit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur N. Benoit of Cos Cob, Conn. A February wedding is planned. Miss McGillicuddy, the owner of McGillicuddy Interior Design in New York, graduated from Holy Cross College and the New York School of Interior Design. Her father is the chairman and chief executive officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York.

title: Alison Baldock To Wed in May
description: May wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Baldock of Springtown, Pa., for their daughter Alison Reams Baldock and Dr. Richard Albert Rockar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Rockar of Cabot, Pa.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: AMERICAN MUSIC SALUTE

title: A Movie in the Making Rains Death on Drug Dealers
description: LEAD: RONALD GORTON SR. is using his hatred of drugs as inspiration for a cinematic morality tale, now being filmed in Connecticut, in which officers of a fictional Federal agency torture drug dealers or kill them with submachine guns.

title: Lelyveld of The Times Is Named Managing Editor as Gelb Retires
description: Arthur Gelb, managing editor of The New York Times since 1986, retires today at age 65 and will be succeeded by Joseph Lelyveld, his deputy since last July.

title: Miami Berated For Its Schedule
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cliffhanger
description: The Shawangunk cliffs tower like gothic ramparts over a sleepy valley west of New Paltz, N.Y. Seen from a distance, they appear as impregnable as a fortress, and one might wonder how anyone could scale them. But then at the base of the cliffs you discover that whenever rock is deposited in such a massive formation, it is never entirely sheer. It is riven by cracks, some the width of your hand, others wide enough to squeeze an arm or leg into. There are ledges you could stand on and protruding rock crystals and horns you could grab hold of. It is possible to conceive of a line that would follow these natural features of the rock all the way up, 300 feet, to the top. Since the 1950's, the Shawangunk escarpment has been perhaps the main rock-climbing center east of the Rockies. Climbers have affectionately nicknamed the cliffs the ''Gunks.''

title: THE ULTIMATE DECISION
description: My mother is in the later stages of Alzheimer's disease. Although she is otherwise in general good health, I know that one day I may face the same situation Andrew Malcolm did. I struggle to remember any snatches of conversation that indicate what my mother's desires would be. But each recollection that suggests yes is counterbalanced by another that suggests no. How does a son or daughter, sharing only one part of a parent's life, select the proper context for those casual utterances? The only sure thing is that there is no guarantee that whatever I decide will, in fact, be right.

title: Susan Crawford Married in West
description: Susan Patricia Crawford and Murdock Hardy Martin, graduates of Yale University, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Santa Monica, Calif., by the Rev. Reginald Schultz-Akerson, assisted by the Rev. Ernest Pipes, a Unitarian minister. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Charlton Crawford of Santa Monica. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Hardy Martin of Moss Point, Miss.

title: Negative Portrayals?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shocks, Aftershocks And Heroics
description: IN 1989, sports was occasionally shocking. Some of the biggest headlines occurred without warning, some without precedent.

title: Ms. Brown to Wed Jonathan R. Hock
description: The engagement of Laura Suzanne Brown to Jonathan Richard Hock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Hock of Great Neck, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Brown of Washington and Vineyard Haven, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Licence to Kill 1989. CBS/Fox. $89.98. Laser disk. $39.98. 2 hours 11 minutes. Close captioned. PG-13.

title:
ART;
The Lively Social Awareness Of Two Veteran Painters
description: LEAD: GEORGE McNEIL'S is the kind of painting a little of which goes a long way. That is the drawback of his expansive show at the Joseloff Gallery on the University of Hartford campus in West Hartford. But if one is willing to indulge him over the course of 13 immense paintings plus 8 lithographs, one will find a painter of singular talent - a talent wedded to an unusual biography.

title: Hunterdon County's Decision on Landfill Unsettles Residents
description: ''I'M between a rock and a hard place,'' said George B. Melick, director of the Hunterdon County Board of Chosen Freeholders. ''Nobody in their right mind wants a landfill in their backyard.''

title: The Virtues Of Liquid Prell
description: To the Editor:

title: West Side Preservation
description: When Frederick Law Olmsted finished laying out his Riverside Park a century ago the beauty and serenity of the area on Manhattan's Upper West Side triggered a real estate boom that led to the building there of scores of four- and five-story brownstones, many with panoramic views of the Hudson River.

title: Priscilla A. Hook, Teacher, to Wed
description: An April wedding is planned by Priscilla Ann Hook and Kevin Holleran, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Hook of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced. Mr. Holleran is a son of Mrs. Richard P. Holleran of Downingtown, Pa., and the late Mr. Holleran.

title: Megan Robinson to MarryJ. R. Pope Jr. in September
description: September wedding plans have been announced for Megan Louise Robinson and Joseph Richard Pope Jr. by the prospective bride's parents, Sarah Bonham Robinson of Westfield, N.J., and Bruce M. Robinson of Pleasanton, Calif. Mr. Pope's parents also live in Westfield.

title: Robert D. Egan Wed in Vermont To Miss Nelson
description: Elizabeth Anne Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Nelson of Middlebury, Vt., was married there yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to Robert Davis Egan, a son of Dorothy D. Egan of Hudson, Ohio. Msgr. Paul M. Bresnehan and the Rev. David Andrews, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Private Lives of Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Computing's Peacemaker
description: IN the computer industry, which is known for flamboyant characters and child prodigies, American Telephone & Telegraph's Robert M. Kavner is emerging as a statesman. A newcomer to the business and an accountant by training, he is orchestrating an extraordinary shift in the fractious industry: Laying the foundation for a single software standard upon which computer equipment and program manufacturers can agree.

title: Dozens Die in Cold Weather in South Asia
description: At least 75 people, many of them homeless, have died of exposure to the cold in northern India and Bangladesh during the last three days, news reports said today.

title: New Growth in a Captive Market
description: WITH prison systems strained by overcrowding and law-enforcement officials burdened by record numbers of drug-related arrests, states and municipalities throughout the United States are using electronic monitoring devices to turn an offender's home into a prison cell.

title: Two Men Killed and One Badly Hurt in Shooting Outside Nightclub
description: Two men, including a paralegal in the Queens District Attorney's office, were killed, and a Yale University sophomore was seriously wounded, when a gunman opened fire on a crowd of people standing outside a Manhattan nightclub near Union Square early yesterday, the police said.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: ''WHY don't you see if you can get a fire going,'' my host suggested. ''I'll find something to start it with. The wood's on the porch,'' he directed, and so it was.

title: Arbitration a Key to Negotiations
description: SALARY arbitration could turn out to be the pivotal issue in the negotiations between the owners and the players for a new collective bargaining agreement. The current agreement expires at midnight tonight (no, there will be no pickets outside ball parks tomorrow; nor will the gates be locked to keep the players out).

title: Campus Life: Rhode Island; Publishers Help A Library Keep Its Newspapers
description: In early November, the University of Rhode Island's library announced that it would have to cancel its subscriptions to 50 local, national and foreign newspapers because of a substantial budget cut.

title: Miss Waterbury Has a Wedding
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, Carol Anne Waterbury, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Waterbury of New York, was married yesterday to Vincent Quinlan, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael Quinlan. The Rev. Brenden Quinlan, the bridegroom's brother, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Damien Myett. Christine Waterbury was the maid of honor for her twin. Dermot Quinlan was his brother's best man.

title: Gorbachev's Agenda for the 90's
description: LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev surprised the Bush Administration on many occasions in 1989. Even greater shocks lie in store for 1990, if the Administration really believes what it is saying about Mr. Gorbachev: that he is presiding over an economy and domestic empire in shambles, and that we can demand concessions in return for our assistance in helping him stabilize his economy and Eastern Europe.

title: Sports People; Capitals' Stevens Out
description: A GOOD part of the defense will be resting for the Washington Capitals over the next few weeks.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch; Spots to Close the 80's, From Low-Key to Noble
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Amsterdam's

title: Sports People; Still Fastest, but. . .
description: HE was stripped of his Olympic gold medal at the 1988 Olympics after failing a drug test, but Ben Johnson will still be recognized as the world's fastest man. At least for a few more weeks.

title: History on the Run
description: SOMEWHERE between Hyde Park Corner and Buckingham Palace, London, around noon, May 27: I am changing clothes in a London taxi, in mixed company, while my companions politely look aside, and the cabby threads his way through crowds around the palace with a look on his face that says, ''How in Heaven's n-a-i-me did I ever get into this?'' I am trying to run a historic mile in each of four cities from Leningrad to Washington in one day, and London is the second stop.

title: THE HATED SEASON
description: We live in the northeast section of Vermont. Once the leaves fall off the trees, you cannot walk anywhere, not even on your own property, until the last weekend of November.
